title: Cocaine and Anxiety
description: The list of hazards associated with cocaine use continues to grow.

title: New Issue in Congress: Gambling and Indians
description: Conflicts between American Indians and the Federal Government are nothing new, but the contest that once raged on Western battlefields has now moved to the bingo parlor and, most recently, to Congress as well.

title: APPROVAL IS CITED IN SHIN BETH CASE
description: The former head of Shin Beth, Israel's domestic intelligence service, confirmed for the first time today that he had approval from his political superiors for his actions in the case of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers who were beaten to death in 1984.

title: Hypertension Drugs Differ Sharply in Side Effects
description: THREE popular drugs for hypertension - all in widespread use and all equally effective in reducing high blood pressure - differ sharply in their effects on sleep, sexual activity, mental performance and feelings of well-being, according to a new study.

title: Homer & Durham Adds Allied-Signal Work
description: Homer & Durham, which won the $4 million Allied-Signal corporate advertising account last month, reported yesterday that the company had also assigned it its Engineered Materials Sector.

title: BLOCKED TO THE GROUND
description: As a free safety, Don Rogers always had blockers coming at him from everywhere. Tall tight ends and swift wide receivers angled at him, sometimes a huge offensive lineman barreled into him. But as a rookie in 1984, he was blocked to the ground only once - the least of any starter on the Cleveland Browns' defensive unit that season. No matter how big or how quick those blockers were, this 6-foot-1-inch, 206-pound free safety could handle them. Maybe because of that, he thought he could handle cocaine. But cocaine blocked Don Rogers to the ground as no opposing blocker ever had.

title: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MAY SALES OF HOMES FELL 11.6%
description: Sales of new homes fell 11.6 percent in May, the biggest decline in more than two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Yugo America Shifts To Fledgling Agency
description: Yugo America of Montvale, N.J., which has been selling a low-priced Yugoslav-built car in this country for the last year, has left Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey and assigned the business to Lambert, Dale & Bernhard, an agency created in April.

title: FROM SIDEWAYS STRUTTING TO SIDEWAYS PRINTING
description: OUR daily mail has grown out of hand. We have it delivered to one of those red-flagged, pole-mounted aluminum Rural Free Delivery boxes you see in the country, where the mailman makes his uninterrupted rounds by Jeep or other vehicle instead of on foot. Our first such mailbox was suitable for monthly bills and fliers advertising poison ivy lotion and weed killers. That box was in due course replaced by a larger one, and eventually by the largest size available. Now I drive to the post office in the village each day to pick up whole cartons of missives.

title: Japan Trade Sets Records
description: Japan posted a record current account surplus of $41.73 billion with the United States last year, and had a record overall surplus of $49.17 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Topics; Albany Opportunities; True Understatement
description: To protect municipal treasuries all over New York, the Legislature last year prohibited a certain maneuver by which some owners of real estate greatly reduced their taxes. The owners learned to seek tax refunds by showing that buildings similar to theirs had been sold for many times their taxable value.

title: Postal Service Delivers Even Unprofitable Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: FISH NECKTIES REEL IN BUYERS
description: After their conversation had rambled for a couple of hours at Saz's, a popular sports bar in Milwaukee, Mark Abramoff and his best friend from high school, Jim Stratte, put it all together. There are 70 million fishermen in the country, they agreed, and as far as they could tell nobody had made a tie that would appeal only to them.

title: People Express Backs Founder
description: People Express Inc. yesterday expressed support for Donald C. Burr, chairman and founder of the six-year-old carrier, after Newsweek magazine reported that its directors had been searching for a new executive to run the financially troubled airline. Citing unidentified sources, Newsweek said in its current issue: ''At the board's behest, two well-known airline executives have been asked if they would be interested in running People; they weren't.''

title: GORBACHEV PRODS U.S. ON ARMS OFFER
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused the United States today of ignoring Soviet peace overtures and of coercing the Western European allies to spurn Soviet arms control proposals.

title: AUTO OF SUSPECT IN POLICE KILLING FOUND IN STREET
description: Police officials said yesterday thatthey had found the getaway car used by the suspect in the fatal shooting of a rookie police officer in Queens. But despite that and other leads, investigators said they had been unable to find the fugitive.

title: 3 New U.S. Landmarks
description: From the heights of culture to the heights of elegance to the heights of height, three Fifth Avenue institutions have just been recognized by the Federal Government for what they are - National Historic Landmarks.

title: Now Hear This
description: The results are in. The International Platform Association has announced that three people have been voted into the group's Orators Hall of Fame, based on voting by more than 300 politicians, journalists and professional speakers.

title: Market Place; Sanders Bid's Spillover
description: MILITARY electronics stocks are back in Wall Street's spotlight following last week's surprise offer by the Loral Corporation to buy Sanders Associates for $44 a share. Yesterday afternoon, Loral said it would begin a tender offer for 10 million Sanders shares, or a controlling interest, at $50 a share in cash.

title: Help in Caring For the Elderly
description: MIXED among the usual concerns with alco-hol and drugs, strained marriages and other stress, employee assistance counselors like James R. O'Hair at Westinghouse Defense Electronics have begun to hear about difficulties of a different sort.

title: ELECTIONEERING IN JAPAN: AMID THE DIN, NO ISSUES
description: This unassuming alcove in northern Japan sits along roads that snake past flooded rice fields and thick woods of red pine.

title: SUN-TIMES BUYOUT SET FOR $145 MILLION
description: Robert E. Page, president and publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, announced today that an investor group he heads had agreed to pay $145 million to buy the newspaper, the nation's 11th largest, from Rupert Murdoch, who controls an array of media properties.

title: Jack Christiansen, Star Back on Lions And N.F.L. Coach
description: Jack Christiansen, a former defensive back with the Detroit Lions and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, died Sunday at Stanford Medical Center after undergoing surgery for cancer. He was 57 years old.

title: Copper Unions Accept Pay Cuts at 2 Companies
description: Employees of two copper companies have approved new contracts that cut their wages 20 percent, and talks continued at two other companies, Kennecott and Inspiration Consolidated Copper.

title: The I.R.S. as a Self-Financing Operation?
description: While supporters of the tax revision bill recently adopted by the Senate sing praises about its benefits for taxpayers, few have widely extolled the benefits for the nation's tax collector, the Internal Revenue Service.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
BANKS PLEDGE JOBS TO GRADUATES OF 5 TROUBLED BROOKLYN SCHOOLS
description: In an unusual partnership of community churches and businesses aimed at improving public schools, graduates of five of New York City's most troubled high schools are to be guaranteed jobs at major banks in the city.

title: TREASURY SECURITY PRICES RISE
description: Prices for long- and short-term Treasury securities rose yesterday as traders continued to wax optimistic about the likelihood of a cut in the discount rate soon.

title: A Queens Man Is Held In Slaying of Two Boys
description: Bail was set at $500,000 cash today for a New York City postal worker charged with killing two teen-age boys and leaving their bodies in a wooded area of the Village of Mizpah.

title: Alabama Democrats Delay Naming Nominee
description: The state Democratic Party refused today to certify a nominee to succeed Gov. George C. Wallace, deciding instead to review the contested results of a runoff between Attorney General Charles Graddick and Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley.

title: MANAGEMENT OF SPACE STATION IS RESTRUCTURED
description: The space agency said today that it would move key management functions for the proposed space station to Washington to insure better management.

title: COURT HEARINGS OPENED TO THE PUBLIC BY JUSTICES
description: The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that the First Amendment gives the public and press a qualified right to attend pretrial criminal hearings over the objection of the defendant.

title: Reagan Draws $700,000
description: President Reagan continues to be a potent draw for senatorial fund-raisers.

title: AUTHOR RECALLS BROOKLYN'S MYTHIC, MAGIC YEARS
description: ''Brooklyn,'' says Elliot Willensky, ''was, when I was a child, the kind of attraction that caused my chin to drop in awe. I would sit with my nose against the window of the IRT, my knees imprinted with the rattan impressions of the seat covers, and I would look out at its world going by.''

title: Congress Must Curb Political-Fund Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Journalist Vanishes
description: Yuri Vereshchagin, a reporter for the Soviet railroad newspaper Gudok, who was on a Mediterranean cruise, has disappeared on a tour of Rome.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $6,750,000 for both the quarter and 6 months resulting from a contract settlement with a customer.

title: Lawyers for Killer of 2 Lose More Court Pleas
description: Lawyers trying to block the execution of Theodore R. Bundy lost more rounds in court today, and the convicted serial killer rebuffed Utah detectives making a last-ditch effort to solve cases there.

title: OJEDA LEADS METS PAST CARDINALS, 7-0
description: The Mets traded Ed Lynch to the Chicago Cubs today for two minor leaguers, shed tears for a departed comrade and then resumed their marauding march without pausing for long regrets.

title: Article 044386 -- No Title
description: Speeding the search for an AIDS cure, the Federal Government said today it will provide $100 million to 14 research centers for intensified drug trials.

title: Still Irresolute on the Deficit
description: Any minute now, the Supreme Court is expected to tell Congress that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law is unconstitutional. That will cause an uproar, but no more than is already warranted. For on the vital issue of deficit cutting, Congress and the Administration are still playing ''let's pretend.''

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: Sales and earnings for both periods include the Food-A-Rama acquisition that was completed on Dec. 31, 1984.

title: CANADIANS SHUFFLE GOVERNMENT AS POLL SHOWS LESS SUPPORT
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada overhauled his Cabinet today amid evidence that his Progressive Conservative Party was declining in popularity.

title: COOPERATE AGAINST DRUGS
description: Consumers of illegal drugs in the United States spend some $110 billion on drugs each year - almost 3 percent of the gross national product and twice the American oil bill. The estimated 30 million marijuana smokers, 30 million cocaine users and half a million heroin addicts who support such spending not only prove that the antidrug policies have failed but they also help finance the spread of corruption into Mexico, disrupting President Miguel de la Madrid's badly needed ''moral renovation'' program.

title: KICKING AROUND IDEAS AND EACH OTHER
description: Think of it as the ''Battle of the Broadcasters.''

title: PNC to Purchase Citizens Fidelity
description: The PNC Financial Corporation of Pittsburgh said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Citizens Fidelity Corporation of Louisville, Ky., for $700 million in stock in the latest example of the consolidation taking place through interstate banking.

title: G.O.P. PLANS TO CITE RULING IN CALIFORNIA
description: Republican Party officials said they would use the Supreme Court's ruling today on partisan gerrymandering to reopen their legal challenge to a Congressional redistricting plan drawn by California Democrats in 1982.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The results for 1985 reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 12, 1986.

title: Southwestern Bell Fills Post
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation has appointed John E. Hayes Jr. as president and chief executive of its subsidiary, the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company.

title: CBS PLANS A RETOOLING OF ITS 'MORNING NEWS'
description: CBS News, again retooling its morning news program after years of ratings failure, will not renew the contracts of Maria Shriver and Forrest Sawyer as co-anchors of the ''CBS Morning News,'' according to network officials.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After net income of $536,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A Ladder Made of Iron
description: When Dale Murphy took the field in Atlanta against the Giants last night, he moved past Richie Ashburn into 11th place on the list of baseball's iron men.

title: C.B.O.E. Appoints A New Chairman
description: Alger B. Chapman, vice chairman of American Express Bank Ltd. of London, was elected chairman and chief executive of the Chicago Board Options Exchange yesterday.

title: Midland Officer to Lead Key Operations in U.S.
description: When Midland Bank P.L.C. completed its $1.08 billion sale of the Crocker National Bank in May, Larry F. Clyde was one of the few senior Crocker executives to stay with Midland.

title: Oakland Barred In Raider Suit
description: The Supreme Court today barred Oakland, Calif., from claiming ownership of the Raiders of the National Football League, who moved to Los Angeles in 1982.

title: PANATECH RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
WALL STREET'S SPENDERS BOLSTER REVIVAL OF SOUTH ST. SEAPORT
description: They come in waves, weekday after weekday; hundreds if not thousands of the city's business-uniformed money movers, descending from their Wall Street towers to pump their purchasing power into a reborn South Street Seaport.

title: BEHIND THE RECORD FINANCINGS
description: An investment banker who had decided to bid $150,000 for a summer home near New York City recently caught himself telling the home's startled owner that he would pay $150 million.

title: GENERAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
From Top Dollar To Bottom Line
description: Some unexpected insights have popped up in the court files of the United States Football League antitrust case against the National Football league, now in its eighth week in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT'S markdown time again, when the city's stores purge their shelves of unsold fashions. Markdowns happen when stores order goods from samples that are better in quality than the merchandise that eventually goes on sale, or when they overbuy or a design simply is unstylish or unpopular.

title: Body of U.S. Airman Reported in Tunisia
description: Libya's press agency said today that the body of an American airman who took part in the United States bombing raids on Libya had washed ashore on a remote beach in Tunisia.

title: Investor Raises Stake in NL
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons has raised his stake in NL Industries from 17.5 percent, to 20.4 percent. Mr. Simmons is now faced with the prospect that NL will initiate a shareholders' rights plan, intended to thwart a hostile takeover by allowing NL shareholders to buy the company's common shares at half price. The rights plan, adopted in

title: ART: BIGGEST BIENNALE, THE 42D, OPENS IN VENICE
description: The Biennale, which opened Sunday in the sweltering heat of Venice, is as ambitious and confused as any in this international art exhibition's long and controversial history. It has a global theme - art and science. With an unprecedented 40 countries represented and with national and theme shows spilling into the city from the Public Gardens, the exhibition's permanent site, it is the largest Biennale so far.

title: Jamaica Municipal Elections
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga has called municipal elections for July 29, but he told a meeting of his Jamaica Labor Party that general elections would not be held in the immediate future. The call for municipal elections Sunday night came at a time when the opposition People's National Party, led by former Prime Minister Michael Manley, is well ahead of the Jamaica Labor Party in opinion polls.

title: COCAINE CAUSED ROGERS DEATH
description: The Sacramento County Coroner's office officially announced today that Don Rogers, the Cleveland Brown defensive back, had died after using cocaine. But Charles R. Simmons, the coroner, said the investigation has not determined when or how the cocaine was ingested.

title: Half of U.S. Jews for Palestinian Homeland
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHING AS SECOND CAREER
description: Where do good teachers come from?

title: Montreal Releases Sikh Accused of Conspiracy
description: One of five Sikhs arrested here last month on explosives-related conspiracy charges was freed today for lack of evidence. A preliminary hearing for the others was set for Wednesday.

title: OPEC ENDS CONFERENCE WITHOUT OUTPUT CURBS
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a languid six-day conference here today unable to agree on crucial production restraints to prop up oil prices.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1986 and 1985 share earnings represent Class A common shares and Class B non-voting shares. The Class B non-voting shareholders are entitled to an additional 5 cents a share per annum, by means of a non-cumulative dividend, over any dividends paid on the Class A common shares. The share earnings for the quarter have been calculated after deducting the extra dividends (1-1/4 cents a share). The second quarter earnings reflect the company's minority interest in the earnings of Ingram and Bell from Jan. 1, 1986, the date of acquisition, to April 30, 1986. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Philadelphia Issue Of Revenue Bonds
description: A $185.6 million issue of Philadelphia water and sewer revenue bonds is tentatively offered to yield a maximum 8.04 percent for a 7 1/4 percent bond due in 2014 at a price of 91.25. The underwriters are led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: DE NIRO ON MARQUEE: A LINE AT BOX OFFICE
description: Gary Cummings, a librarian from Clinton, Conn., was in a line yesterday on 48th Street that began near Eighth Avenue and stretched to Broadway. So were Nancy Wemhoener, a housewife from Manhattan; Bill Sliwa, a firefighter from Staten Island; Mark Grampp, a 21-year-old senior at the State University of New York at Purchase, and Ken Heckle, a tourist from England.

title: Some Liberty Tickets Left
description: Tickets are still available for the Statue of Liberty centennial events this weekend, Liberty Weekend officials said yesterday.

title: VOTE 'FATAL' TO BASE PLAN FOR S.I., D'AMATO FEARS
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that the House of Representatives vote last week against a proposed Staten Island naval base ''may prove to be fatal.''

title: City University Dean Named To Head Community College
description: The dean of academic affairs of the City University of New York, Dr. Augusta Souza Kappner, has been named president of the Borough of Manhattan Community College, effective Sept. 1.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'MANDELA,' DOCUMENTARY
description: ''MANDELA'' is a tribute - out and out, straightforward - to Nelson and Winnie Mandela. It is by the committed and for the committed, and therefore one doesn't judge it any other way. It has one long sequence that is infinitely moving, surrounded by material that is more or less routine. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, falls victim to its own reverence.

title: FILM: MAMET ADAPTATION, 'ABOUT LAST NIGHT...'
description: ''ABOUT LAST NIGHT . . .'' is a movie with a seriously split personality. If it were a friend, you'd suggest it seek help.

title: Careers; Financial Planning's Big Growth
description: THE explosion in financial planning has resulted in a hodgepodge of titles, institutes and warnings. In fact, things have become so complex that there are now planners who plan how to plan -rather than actually offer financial advice, they guide their customers to other specialists.

title: EARL F. LANDGREBE
description: Earl F. Landgrebe, a former United States Representative who was one of President Nixon's supporters throughout the Watergate scandal, died today at his home apparently of a heart attack.

title: TO UNLOCK SCHOOL REFORM, TEACHERS ARE THE KEY
description: WHEN the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy published ''A Nation Prepared: Teachers for the 21st Century'' last month, it made no secret of its intent to transform the schools. Past reform efforts have failed largely because they ignored the crucial role of the teachers.

title: JOURNALIST IN GREECE CLEARED OF CHARGES MADE BY NEWSPAPER
description: Paul Anastasiades, a Greek Cypriot reporter based here, has been cleared of an accusation that he threatened in 1983 to destroy the offices of the largest newspaper in Greece and kill members of its staff, according to court records made public today.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for 13wks to March 29
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,236,000 and a tax credit of $1,889,000 for the quarter, and the year includes income of $59,745,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $8,058,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,027,000 for the quarter, and for the year income from discontinued operations of $992,000. d-Net loss. The 1985 earnings for the year and quarter have been restated to reflect a change to FIFO inventory accounting from the LIFO method for Food Service inventories. This change was made May 14, 1985.

title: Continental Bank
description: An investment group led by First Carolina Investors, which holds about 9 percent of the Continental Illinois Holding Corporation, said it had requested a seat on the board of the Chicago-based bank holding company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, First Carolina said it had asked that H. Thomas Webb 3d, the president of First Carolina, be elected to the board.

title: U.S. Ends Inquiry In Stewart Death
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that there was insufficient evidence to warrant a Federal grand-jury investigation of the death of Michael Stewart.

title: Lorimar Revises TV Acquisition Plan
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation is restructuring the plan under which it recently agreed to acquire seven television stations for $1.85 billion.

title: CASH SCORES UPSET
description: Of all the amazing stories told here over the years, not many will be able to rival the one Pat Cash will spin should he win three more matches this week, culminating with a victory late Sunday afternoon, when the men's singles final will become a page in Wimbledon history. Today, for the first time, Cash appeared to sense that he can indeed win the championship in a year when he almost withdrew for fear of embarrassing himself.

title: It's Festival Time
description: The Supreme Court is in its end-of-term rush, and Congress has already left town for two weeks, joined by many other Washingtonians, in and out of Government.

title: Reitman Group Names Two New Executives
description: Jerry I. Reitman, chairman and chief executive of the two-month-old Reitman Group, a direct response ad agency, has just brought in a president, Steven Stark, who will also be chief operating officer, and Bruce Lee, who will be senior vice president, executive creative director.

title: U.S. EFFORT ON LIBYA OIL SAID TO GAIN
description: Government officials said today that diplomatic efforts by the United States had succeeded in persuading some allies to cut sharply their purchases of Libyan crude oil.

title: FINDS POINT TO A GRANDER EARLY JERUSALEM
description: The recent evaluation of many of the 1,000 objects discovered in a tomb on a hillside west of the Old City of Jerusalem goes a long way toward proving that the physical size of early Jerusalem was as grand as its historical reputation, an issue long in dispute.

title: Lear Siegler Retirement
description: Lear Siegler Inc. said that Robert T. Campion, chairman and chief executive, would retire, effective Aug. 15. Norman A. Barkeley, president, will assume the roles of chairman and chief executive of the diversified company. Mr. Campion, 65 years old, will work as a consultant to the company and will continue to serve as a board member and chairman of the executive committee. Lear Siegler, which was formed in 1962 through the merger of Lear Inc. and the Siegler Corporation, has interests in electronics and electromechanical products, automotive products and industrial products.

title: Syrian President Vows To Help Free Hostages
description: President Hafez al-Assad promised Representative Bob Dornan today that Syria would continue its efforts to free American hostages in Lebanon, Syria's press agency reported.

title: FARMERS' PRICE DROP
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 1.6 percent in the June reporting period from May, and were 6.2 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: VATICAN SEES BAR TO ANGLICAN PACT
description: Pope John Paul II has told the Archbishop of Canterbury that the ordination of women as priests by some Anglican churches presents an ''increasingly serious obstacle'' to eventual Anglican-Roman Catholic reunion, the Vatican said today.

title: Tax-Exempt Offerings Off 14.4% in First Half
description: The volume of tax-exempt securi-ties offered to the public in the first six months of 1986 totaled $49.2 billion, which was 14.4 percent less than a year earlier, the Securities Data Company reported yesterday.

title: FRIEND AND FOE SEE HOMOSEXUAL DEFEAT
description: The United States Supreme Court decision yesterday upholding Georgia's sodomy law was greeted with dismay by homosexual groups across the nation and with jubilation by a variety of religious and political groups opposing them. Both sides agreed the ruling would slow the advancement of homosexual rights.

title: Bail Is Revoked For Crime Figure
description: A Federal judge yesterday revoked the $1 million bail of Angelo Ruggiero, asserting that Mr. Ruggiero ''might be a danger to society'' if he remained free while awaiting trial on heroin-trafficking charges. No date has been set for the trial.

title: TOURNEY PROVES A ROUSING SUCCESS
description: Argentina has won the World Cup and Diego Armando Maradona has been established as the premier player in the world's most popular sport, but there were other winners here, too.

title: Who Gets the Credit?
description: Congress now seems certain to approve before the end of this session - in an election year at that - perhaps the most extensive revision of the income tax code in history. But it's not clear who, if anyone or any party, should be able to claim the political credit.

title: MARYLAND TO STUDY PROBLEMS
description: The University of Maryland will set up two task forces to study the questions about academics among athletes and drug use on campus that were raised by the death of the basketball star Len Bias 11 days ago, university officials said today.

title: BLACK FEDERATION THREATENS STRIKE
description: The South African authorities said today that seven blacks died in violence in Soweto over the weekend in what appeared to be one of the worst episodes of bloodshed in the black township since the Government's declaration of a state of emergency.

title: ITALIAN POLICE REPORT THE CAPTURE OF A CHIEF IN MAFIA HEROIN TRADE
description: A fugitive Sicilian accused of being a key figure in the Mafia's heroin trafficking in the United States was arrested over the weekend, the police announced today.

title: A Costly Beard
description: How much is a beard worth? To Bert Blyleven, the Minnesota Twins' pitcher, $50 a day. The Twins have a rule against beards and have never had a bearded player.

title: CSI TELEMARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax benefit of $104,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Manila Takes Bank Control
description: One of the largest banks in the Philippines was brought under state control today. The Commission on Good Government seized 95 percent of the stock of the United Coconut Planters Bank and elected new directors.

title: One Union Local Rejects Pact at Weyerhaeuser
description: The first group of the 7,500 striking employees of the Weyerhaeuser Company to vote on a new contract offered by the company overwhelmingly rejected the proposal today.

title: Investors Extend Conrail Offer
description: A group of 42 investors, whose $1.4 billion offer for the Government-owned Conrail freight railroad was to expire today, said it was extending its bid and that Congress should act to accept it while market conditions were ripe. Morgan Stanley & Company, the syndicate's organizer, said Conrail's success and the solid stock market performance made this the right time for Congress to finally unload the railroad.

title: Massachusetts Offering Bonds
description: A $526 million refunding by Massachusetts to reduce debt service payments on outstanding general obligation bonds was tentatively priced through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The maximum yield is 7.50 percent for 7 1/4 percent securities maturing in 2005 at a price of 97.4629.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE COURT OPINIONS ON HOMOSEXUAL RELATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in its decision that the Constitution does not protect private homosexual relations between consenting adults. Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Justices Lewis F. Powell Jr., William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor. Chief Justice Burger and Justice Powell wrote concurring opinions. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote a dissenting opinion, joined by Justices William J. Brennan Jr., Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens. Justice Stevens wrote a separate dissenting opinion, joined by Justices Brennan and Marshall.

title: U.S. AGENCY TO DECIDE A CLAIM ON NICARAGUA
description: A United States agency is about to decide whether the Nicaraguan Government improperly took over land owned by the Standard Fruit Company, agency officials said last week.

title: KAUFMAN AND BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,800,000, or 49 cents a share.

title: CLARA ROGERS
description: Clara Rogers, born to former slaves, died of pneumonia Saturday at the Erie County Medical Center.

title: RED SOX WIN FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: Dwight Evans drew a bases-loaded walk off Jim Acker with two out in the 10th inning tonight, enabling the Boston Red Sox to defeat the Toronto Blue Jays, 10-9, for their fifth straight victory.

title: The Shoreham Power Play
description: Acting to capitalize on a guardedly favorable fact-finding report, opponents of the Shoreham nuclear plant seek a quick state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company. They have a plausible case: a respected panel has advised Governor Cuomo that a public authority might save consumers money by shifting some costs to the Federal Government. But a takeover might also compound the economic problem created by Shoreham's $5 billion construction. There is no justification for haste.

title: CELLTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $106,000 for the quarter and $243,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $175,000 for the quarter and $355,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: COURT VOIDS N. CAROLINA PLAN ON LEGISLATIVE REDISTRICTING
description: Rejecting the Reagan Administration's narrow interpretation of the 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act, the Supreme Court today unanimously struck down four North Carolina election districts as discriminatory against blacks.

title: U.S. HONORS BROOKLYN SCHOOL
description: A bilingual public elementary school in Brooklyn is among 270 public and private elementary schools nationwide being honored by the Federal Government for excellence in the 1985-86 school year.

title: COMEDY: BOB GOLDTHWAIT
description: BOB GOLDTHWAIT, who gained a popular following playing Zed, the demented motorcyclist in two ''Police Academy'' movies, is one of the more paradoxical figures in the stand-up comedy world. Mr. Goldthwait, who bears a slight physical resemblance to the heavy metal rock star Ozzy Osbourne, carries casual grossness of language and demeanor close to the limit. His alter ego is a caricature of an overgrown, emotionally damaged child - a fulminating id.

title: A.M.C.-Chrysler Pact
description: In the first contract assembly agreement between two domestic auto makers, the American Motors Corporation signed a tentative agreement to make cars for the Chrysler Corporation at the A.M.C. plant in Kenosha, Wis. A.M.C. had cleared the path for the deal by reaching an agreement on job classifications last week with the United Automobile Workers. The price of the contract was not disclosed. About 3,500 workers would be recalled to assemble Chryler's M-body series, which are full-size, rear-wheel-drive cars.

title:
PLAYERS;
HANNAH TACKLES ANOTHER CAREER
description: BOSTON

title: A QUICKER (AND MORE COSTLY) WAY TO FIRE ISLAND
description: There are those who curse and complain about the clogged highways and crowded trains to and from Long Island's beaches. And then there are those who rise above it all.

title: Jackson: Hit, and Miss
description: Bo Jackson started his professional baseball career on a positive note in Memphis last night, hitting a sharp single up the middle on a 2-1 pitch in his first time at bat. The single drove in a run and sparked a three-run first inning for the Memphis Chicks, but the Chicks still lost, 9-5, to the Astros of Columbus, Ga.

title: Robins Gets Debt Plan Extension
description: A Federal judge gave lawyers for the A. H. Robins Company another 90 days to finish the pharmaceutical company's Chapter 11 reorganization plan, but scolded the lawyers for having taken too long already. Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. also said he would take a more active role in reviewing the progress of the case and would reduce the 90-day extension if enough progress was not made.

title: NEW RESTRICTIONS ON IMMIGRATION GAIN PUBLIC SUPPORT, POLL SHOWS
description: There is strong and growing public support for new restrictions on immigration despite widespread sympathy for both legal and illegal immigrants as individuals.

title: PERUVIAN JUSTICE MINISTER RESIGNS AND PRISON GUARD CHIEF IS OUSTED
description: Peru's Justice Minister, accused of sharing responsibility for the brutal crushing of a prison mutiny earlier this month, resigned from his post today.

title: Nation in South Pacific Establishes Soviet Ties
description: This South Pacific island nation announced today that it had established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Powerful Adhesive
description: The gene for production of the extremely powerful adhesive that enables mussels to form a lifelong attachment to rocks has been isolated, clearing the way for the ultimate production of an adhesive to reattach broken teeth, reconnect broken bones and perform a host of other applications.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT MEXICO;
SUPPORT FAIR ELECTIONS
description: Now that things are not going well for Mexico, economically and otherwise, many Americans who worry about the repercussions for the United States have begun to complain about the way Mexicans run their own affairs. Among other things, such Americans are upset by electoral fraud and corruption and would like to weaken the governing Institutionalized Revolutionary Party, or PRI. This would be a mistake. We should support democratic principles and fair elections in Mexico but should steer clear of efforts to influence the outcome.

title: EPIDEMIC OF ANIMAL RABIES RAGES IN MID-ATLANTIC AREA
description: The worst outbreak of animal rabies in at least 40 years is sweeping the Middle Atlantic States and the Southeast, spreading alarm among residents and public health officials.

title: Cabdrivers Call Strike For Liberty Weekend
description: A coalition of taxi drivers seeking a fare increase called on all drivers yesterday to stay off New York City's streets from 5 A.M. Thursday through 5 A.M. Friday, as the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration is getting under way.

title: PRIVACY LAW AND HISTORY
description: With its decision today that the constitutional right to privacy does not extend to homosexual conduct, the Supreme Court interrupted the expansion of the concept of privacy on which it embarked more than 60 years ago.

title: Bridge: There Are Varieties of Bids That Mark an Expert Player
description: Suppose one wanted to devise a computer program that would assess the ability of players on the basis of their bidding sequences, without any reference to the corresponding hands. What single test should be employed? A good answer, perhaps the best answer, would be to instruct the computer to count the frequency of bids below game in a suit previously bid by an opponent. The beginner never makes such bids, but after becoming more expert finds more and more opportunities for such moves.

title: CREATIVE CONSULTING CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Asbestos Worry Closes Courthouse
description: Fears of asbestos contamination at Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday prompted a virtual shutdown of the 54-year-old building for the day. About 1,000 court proceedings were postponed.

title: METROMEDIA TO SELL MOBILE PHONE OPERATIONS
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation has agreed to buy the paging and mobile telephone businesses of Metromedia Inc. for $1.65 billion in cash.

title: Topics; Albany Opportunities; Twilight Zones
description: Republicans and Democrats in the New York Legislature agree that ''opportunity zones'' to revitalize economically distressed areas are a good idea. Yet they would now scuttle it in partisan squabbling about the number and selection of zones.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 1, 1986
description: Companies

title: Dr. Yedidiah Ghatan Wed to Aviva Sontag
description: Aviva Yocheved Sontag, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Sontag of Oceanside, L.I., and Dr. Yedidiah H. E. Ghatan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zachariah Ghatan of Teheran, Iran, were married yesterday. Rabbi Manfred Fulda performed the ceremony at Congregation Kneseth Israel in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Cardinal Lekai Dies; Primate of Hungary
description: Laszlo Cardinal Lekai, primate of Hungary's Roman Catholic Church, died today of a heart attack, the Hungarian radio said. He was 76 years old.

title: Uniroyal to Liquidate
description: The directors of Uniroyal Inc. have decided to liquidate the company by the end of the year and, after paying its debt, distribute any remaining proceeds to shareholders. Uniroyal has been gradually dismantled since a $950 million leveraged buyout in 1985. It has $840 million in debt.

title: KEAN SIGNS BUDGET OF $9.3 BILLION AFTER REDUCING STATE AID TO CITIES
description: Governor Kean signed a $9.3 billion state budget today, but not before deleting more than $50 million in state aid that will leave the budgets of 80 municipalities unbalanced and force them to cut spending or raise taxes.

title: ROCK: TANGERINE DREAM, AT BEACON
description: WITH a somber demeanor and the latest equipment, Tangerine Dream brought thoroughly elementary music to the Beacon Theater on Saturday night.

title: Article 017886 -- No Title
description: Two secretive multimillionaire Texans have offered to buy the Panhandle Eastern Corporation for $2.2 billion, the big Houston natural gas company said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Court is most vulnerable and comes nearest to illegitimacy when it deals with judge-made constitutional law having little or no cognizable roots in the language or design of the Constitution.'' - Associate Justice Byron R. White. [ A18:2. ]

title: SALVADORAN REFUGEES: PEASANTS WHO GET CAUGHT
description: Within sight of the mountains where they once hid from army sweeps, peasants identified as supporters of the anti-Government guerrillas are slowly filling refugee camps around San Salvador, the final stopping place for the many who have been captured by Government troops.

title: Money Goals
description: John Vanbiesbrouck was in many ways the Rangers' savior last season. He accounted for 31 of their 36 regular-season victories, he was the rock that enabled them to upset the Flyers and the Capitals in the playoffs, and when it was all over he was awarded the Vezina Trophy as the National Hockey League's best goalie.

title: USAir Adds More Jets
description: USAir is ordering seven additional Boeing 737-300 twinjets in a purchase worth more than $175 million, the Boeing Company announced today. Deliveries to the Washington, D.C.-based carrier, which now has ordered 47 of the aircraft, will begin in August 1987.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Gorman, the United States Davis Cup tennis captain, apparently believes that when something works it should be left alone.

title: Braxton's Title Stripped
description: David Braxton has been stripped of his North American Boxing Federation 154-pound crown because cocaine was found in his system following a May 22 title fight in Detroit, an N.A.B.F. executive said yesterday. Duane Ford, a N.A.B.F. vice president, said Braxton was stripped of his title by the organization's executive board during a weekend meeting in San Diego at which the test results were presented. Braxton won the title with a unanimous 12-round decision over Ken Snow of Tyley, Tex.

title: Dukiet Interviewed
description: Marquette University officials said yesterday that Coach Bob Dukiet of St. Peter's College in Jersey City has been interviewed for the vacant head basketball coaching position. The St. Peter's athletic director, Bill Stein, said he was unaware of Dukiet's interest in the Marquette job. Dukiet was registered at a Milwaukee hotel yesterday but could not be reached.

title: DESPITE WIDE AIDS COOPERATION, A FEUD HOLDS CENTER STAGE
description: Although the enormous degree of international collaboration in the scientific battle against AIDS is obvious, tensions resulting from feuds between French and American researchers clearly persist.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banknorth Group, St. Albans, Vt., elected John H. Barry president and chief executive.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
Chess: Ribli, With Precision, Takes The Dortmund International
description: Zoltan Ribli, a 34-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, smoothly won the Dortmund International Tournament in West Germany, 8-3. Ribli was never in trouble and played with an intimidating accuracy.

title: Congress Helps Call Roll On Pretoria's Detentions
description: The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, a national civil rights organization, has taken on a decidedly international issue.

title: Postal Service Delivers Even Unprofitable Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Japan Chip Pact Seen Near
description: United States and Japanese negotiators neared ''substantial'' agreement today in their efforts to resolve a dispute over trade in semiconductors, according to officials from both sides.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The company said year-ago share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effected as a stock dividend in April.

title: LAGERFELD'S DINIM, UNGARO'S PRINTS
description: Karl Lagerfeld lined a short white denim jacket with brightly printed cotton, added a neatly fitted skirt and thereby contributed to the upward mobility of the sturdy fabric usually associated with jeans. He calls the suit and other styles, including a jacket with a fitted midriff and modest peplum flaring over the hips, his ''executive denims.'' While not reaching the formal heights of James Galanos's blue denim coat lined with sable, the suits certainly are decorous enough to be worn to board meetings.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS SAY U.S. DETAINS REFUGEES FROM MANY LANDS
description: A detention policy inaugurated by the Reagan Administration in 1981 to curb the influx of boat people from Haiti has turned into a national program affecting thousands of refugees from around the world, two human rights organizations say.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $574,000 for settlement of litigation. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $102,000.

title: African-Chinese Clash
description: To the Editor:

title: Fruehauf Plans To Sell Assets
description: The Fruehauf Corporation expects to sell $375 million in assets if a leveraged buyout by its management and Merrill Lynch is successful, according to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The buyout group's $48.50-a-share tender offer has been approved by the Fruehauf board despite a $49.50-a-share hostile takeover bid by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman.

title: THE ANSWER? SOLD SEPARATELY
description: PAUL paid thousands of dollars for a computer and word processing system. A few weeks later, when he hit a snag and could not find the answers he needed in the manuals, he called the dealer. The dealer said sure, a company expert could answer the questions easily, but not until Paul forked over several hundred dollars more for a support contract. The contract entitled him to access to a special telephone number and a fixed number of minutes with a technician.

title: WESTERN EUROPE'S AID FOR HIGH TECH GROWS
description: The governments of Western Europe today greatly enlarged the scope of their high-technology research program, called Eureka, by approving 62 new joint projects budgeted at more than $1.9 billion.

title: A THEATER ACTOR AND DIRECTOR
description: Robert Drivas, an award-winning director and actor of stage, screen and television, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ford Bank Group Head Plans a Swift Strategy
description: Gerald J. Ford, chairman of the Ford Bank Group, has been known to study a newly acquired bank's existing management for up to six months before making any changes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INSIDERS When the sidewalks simmer and streets become sticky underfoot in New York's summer heat, the inside parks of Manhattan, the atriums of midtown, can be refreshing oases. Atriums are usually not only cool but also have other attractions, such as exhibitions or, in the case of the comparatively venerable atrium at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street, entertainment.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD PARTISAN LINES IN REDISTRICTING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today for the first time that partisan gerrymandering of election districts violated the Constitution, but only when it was so severe as to ''consistently degrade'' a political group's influence.

title: WORKERS STRIKE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: More than 20,000 municipal and private employees, including the city garbage collectors, went on strike early today as contracts expired.

title: CONSTANTINE POULOS
description: Constantine Poulos, a World War II correspondent for the New York-based Overseas News Agency and former editor and publisher of The Jamestown (N.Y.) Sun, died June 3 at a nursing home in Jamestown, a family member said. He was 70 years old and lived in Jamestown.

title: SEATTLE-VICTORIA: NEW ARTERY TO OPEN
description: Every morning at 8 all summer long, the distinctive bellow of a steam whistle raises thunderous echoes and sends the gulls scattering across Elliott Bay as the tourist ship Princess Marguerite backs out of her pier and swings up Puget Sound to Victoria, British Columbia, to deliver yet another load of money.

title: CHARLES SZLADITS
description: Charles Szladits, adjunct professor emeritus of comparative law at Columbia University, died Saturday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Thompson Released
description: On April 4, the Montreal Expos obtained Jason Thompson from the Pittsburgh Pirates and waited for him to start hitting. After watching him bat .196 in 30 games, with no home runs and four runs batted in, they'd had enough. Yesterday, they released the first baseman and his $1,080,000 salary.

title: STRUGGLING LLOYD TOPS JORDAN
description: From the vantage point of Chris Evert Lloyd and the other quarterfinalists in the bottom half of the draw, there really isn't anyone in the top half who can prevent Martina Navratilova from reaching the Wimbledon final for the fifth consecutive year.

title: PRIVATE-EYE DRAMA, ABC'S 'SPENSER: FOR HIRE'
description: AFTER tumbling to the bottom of the ratings, ABC is hard-pressed to find bright spots on its programming schedule these days but, in a pinch, ''Spenser: For Hire'' would be a moderately promising candidate. The ratings for the detective series in its first season were of the borderline variety but, given the rest of ABC's lineup, the show attracted enough interest and reviewer support to merit renewal. ''Spenser: For Hire'' will be back in the fall. Considering its promise more than its achievement, the show deserves the break.

title: U.S. AND HONG KONG IN TEXTILE PACT
description: The United States and one of its biggest textile suppliers, Hong Kong, initialed a bilateral import pact today that allows for modest growth in imports through 1991.

title: MEDCHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 9 months.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Italian Civil Servants Strike
description: About 260,000 public employees staged a 24-hour strike throughout Italy today to press demands for putting in force a contract approved by Parliament in 1980 but never put into practice, labor unions said. The nationwide strike, which the unions said primarily involved workers in government offices, law courts, customs posts and diplomatic missions abroad, was the latest action in a series.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bomb on Tel Aviv Bus Wounds 5 Passengers
description: A bomb exploded on a city bus today just before the morning rush hour, slightly wounding five passengers, police and hospital officials said.

title: CITES WALDHEIM
description: Gottfried Reinhardt, an American film director whose father founded the Salzburg Festival in Austria, said today that he had declined an Austrian medal of honor because of Kurt Waldheim's purported ties to Nazi war crimes.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PLAY OF THE EYES. By Elias Canetti. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 329 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: ARREST OF TOP LABOR LEADER BY PRETORIA CONFIRMED
description: As an international human rights group confirmed that the leader of South Africa's largest labor federation had been taken into custody, another labor leader expressed fear yesterday that there would be more detentions of union activists.

title: U.S. Agencies Collect 8 Gold Lions in Cannes
description: Not only did an American ad agency win the Grand Prix at the International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France, as reported yesterday, but the United States, for the first time in years, was the overall big winner of gold, silver and bronze Lions, which are what all the money being spent on entrance fees is all about.

title: SPONSOR IN SENATE WITHDRAWS A BILL ON LIBELING DEAD
description: A week after it passed the State Senate unanimously, a bill that would have established a completely new category of libel - based on comments made about a dead person - was withdrawn today by its chief Senate sponsor.

title: Advertising; McCabe Will Leave His Agency
description: YESTERDAY in a memo to the staff, Ed McCabe told his people at Scali, McCabe, Sloves that he would be leaving the 19-year-old agency to look for new challenges.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 1, 1986
description: International

title: PILOT'S HELMET HELPS INTERPRET HIGH-SPEED WORLD
description: THE pilot sits in the cockpit wearing a dark, bulging, bug-faced helmet that makes him look like the sinister Darth Vader in the movie ''Star Wars.'' Projected on his visor is a synthesized panorama of the world he is flying over and into, the terrain below and the skies around. It is like having his head inside a marvelous, action-packed video game.

title: Lawyers of Ex-Officers Say Juror Was Biased
description: The sentencing of three former New York City police officers convicted of receiving bribes was postponed at the last minute yesterday after defense lawyers charged that a juror at the officers trial in Queens had been ''allied with the prosecution.''

title: YANKEES' SLIDE IS ENDED AT 10
description: Unlike the 1913 Yankees, the 1986 version did not get a 3-3 tie after losing 10 consecutive home games. For sure, the 1986 Yankees scored three runs last night, but they altered the pattern by holding the Detroit Tigers to two runs and ended their miserable month of June with a victory.

title: WHILE LIBERTY FETE NEARS, 219 ALIENS IN CITY FACE EXPULSION
description: Roberto Navarro was sitting on a bench outside the immigration court in lower Manhattan, an envelope pressed between his hands. As the two guards started to bring him back to his cell, Mr. Navarro noticed a visitor, a stranger. He passed the envelope to him.

title: SHULTZ RULES OUT MOVES DAMAGING SOUTH AFRICAN ECONOMY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the goal of an announced policy review on South Africa was to find ways of ending apartheid and beginning interracial negotiations without damaging the South African economy.

title: In Honor of a Civic Leader
description: Bird song filled the morning air, offering a brief respite from city cacophony. A white butterfly fluttered onto a leaf. Birds swooshed through the marshy grass of the Central Park Bird Sanctuary, which was dedicated yesterday to George Hervey Hallett Jr., a civic-minded New Yorker and an empassioned bird watcher. Mr. Hallett died last year at the age of 90.

title: LORAL RAISES ITS OFFER TO ACQUIRE SANDERS
description: The Loral Corporation raised the stakes today in its bid for Sanders Associates, announcing that it would begin a tender offer for more than half of Sanders stock at $50 a share.

title: DIVISION IS BITTER
description: A bitterly divided Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Constitution does not protect homosexual relations between consenting adults, even in the privacy of their own homes.

title: Cecile S. Jourdan Wed To Craig Iver Forman
description: Cecile Stephanie Jourdan, a sculptor, and Craig Iver Forman, the news editor of the London bureau of The Wall Street Journal, were married yesterday in London at the Chelsea Town Hall by the registrar, Mrs. Averil Wilkinson.

title: Dow Climbs to a Record 1,892.72
description: Wall Street celebrated the Fourth of July early yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average marched to a record and briefly crossed the 1,900 mark for the first time.

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,377,000. The LIFO method of valuing inventory had the effect of reducing net income 2 cents per share for the 13-week periods ended May 31, 1986, and June 1, 1985.

title: MUSIC: FROM VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, is a breezy, beautiful, cosmopolitan city of some four million people. This listener knows it well, and attended a Saturday night program of music from Venezuela at Alice Tully Hall with a mixture of nostalgia and equatorial yearning.

title: G.M.A.C. Markets $400 Million Debt
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation began offering $400 million of noncallable short-term debt through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: IMAGE OF LIBERTY MAY SEEM UBIQUITOUS THIS WEEKEND
description: The Statue of Liberty resides at the entrance to New York Harbor, but this Independence Day, in its centennial year, it might seem to be everywhere.

title: 2d Titanic Expedition Is Planned by Scientist
description: The scientist who discovered the final resting place of the luxury liner Titanic last year now hopes to see it close up in a special submersible vehicle, a spokesman for the Woods Hole Oceanographic Insitute said today.

title: Continental Airlines
description: The Continental Airlines Corporation, which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since Sept. 24, 1983, said today its reorganization plan had been confirmed by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Houston.

title: Oil Prices Plummet; Farm Products Weak
description: Petroleum futures prices fell sharply today as an OPEC conference ended without the ministers resolving individual production quotas.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: The latest year results included a non-recurring gain of 4 cents a share on the sale of land.

title: Bicyclist Burned In Robbery Dies
description: A Bronx man who had been doused with gasoline, set on fire and burned over 90 percent of his body in a robbery died yesterday, the authorities said.

title: AFTER SUICIDE, SPECULATION FOCUSES ON BROYHILL FOR SENATE SEAT
description: Thad Eure has been Secretary of State here for the last 50 years. ''You know,'' he said today, ''since I've been in office, I have seen seven North Carolina U.S. Senators die in office. That was hard for me to believe until I sat down this morning and made a list.''

title: English Comes First
description: A nation succeeds only if the vast majority of its citizens succeed. It therefore stands to reason that with immigrants accounting for about 40 percent of our population growth, the future economic and social success of the United States is bound up with the success of these new Americans. Demography, in a word, is destiny.

title: Postal Service Delivers Even Unprofitable Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN VESSEL ARRIVES, AS OP SAIL FLEET ASSEMBLES
description: The full-rigged Amerigo Vespucci from Italy glided by the Statue of Liberty yesterday in a preliminary salute to the symbol she will celebrate this weekend.

title: TTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary income of $97,000 for the quarter and $182,000 for the year on early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes extraordinary income on early extinguishment of debt of $122,000 for the quarter and $282,000 for the year.

title: America's Guilt - or Default
description: Predictably, the World Court has found the United States guilty of violating international law by supporting the ''contra'' war against Nicaragua. Just as predictably, the Reagan Administration feels vindicated for not bothering to defend itself; it scorns this frail institution as irredeemably hostile. The Court's judgment was deplorably broad, but America's response is damagingly petulant.

title: Lobbyists in Yellow?
description: Some analysts have said there is a growing anger in the heartland about the influence of lobbyists and political action committees in Washington.

title: FED FINES HOUSEHOLD $600,000
description: The Federal Reserve Board imposed a $600,000 civil penalty today against Household International Inc. - the largest one-time fine it has ever levied - for repeated lending violations at its limited-service bank subsidiary.

title: Don't Put 3-Year-Olds in School, but Strengthen Bonds at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ENVOY TO HONDURAS LEAVING EARLY
description: The United States Ambassador to Honduras has been relieved of his duties after less than a year of service here, according to a United States Embassy spokesman.

title: Ralston Purina Buys Carbide Unit
description: The Ralston Purina Company said it had completed the purchase of the Union Carbide Corporation's battery products division in the United States and some foreign countries.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An Athletic Landmark
description: June is the month of weddings, and there was a notable one a couple of weeks ago when it was announced that Tennessee State University had joined the Ohio Valley Conference. The union was a natural. The O.V.C. is made up of colleges that are close to Tennessee State not only in athletic accomplishment but also in geography (both the school and the league office, in fact, are situated in Nashville), and the Tigers, previously independent, had been searching for a conference affiliation.

title: ARREST IN MAN'S HOME BEGAN TEST OF GEORGIA LAW
description: Michael Hardwick, the homosexual man who unsuccessfully challenged Georgia's sodomy law, has shunned publicity since the day a police officer saw him having sex with another man.

title: Nouveau Bubbles
description: In the cool, dark cellars of Moet & Chandon, where a process known as remuage has put the fizz into many a New Year's Eve champagne bottle, a new method for creating those bubbles could quicken an otherwise long process, increase production without compromising quality, and cost no more to produce, researchers say.

title: FORGETFULNESS IS SEEN CAUSING MORE WORRY THAN IT SHOULD
description: MOMENTS of forgetfulness are among those small blows to self-esteem that can lead people to worry about declining intelligence or impending senility.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Air and Space and Birthday
description: Ten years and 100 million visitors after it opened its doors, the National Air and Space Museum will celebrate its birthday today in a fairly low-tech and traditional fashion.

title: KENNETH L. DIXON
description: Kenneth L. Dixon, a former war correspondent for The Associated Press, syndicated columnist and newspaper editor, died Sunday at Our Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center in Baton Rouge. He was 71 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. said its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional five million shares of its common stock. The company's shares closed at $90 a share yesterday, up $1.125.

title: French Set Foreign Curb
description: Foreign participation in newly privatized French companies will be limited, at least initially, to 15 percent, Economy Minister Edouard Balladur said today.

title: SIMMONS DEFENDS STRATEGY
description: Chet Simmons, the United States Football League's first commissioner, finished his testimony yesterday in the U.S.F.L.'s antitrust case against the National Football League, reiterating the position he had taken last week: that he and league owners conducted their business affairs - including a switch to a fall schedule and discussions of a merger strategy - in a ''survival mode'' because of the N.F.L.

title: COURT'S RULING SPURS PARTY FIGHT FOR LEGISLATURES
description: The Supreme Court's decision Monday on gerrymandering has turned an unaccustomed spotlight on state legislatures, where Democrats and Republicans were already engaged in what both parties agree is an extraordinary struggle.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News poll on attitudes toward immigration misstated one finding. Of those surveyed, 42 percent said immigration should be kept at present levels or increased.

title: Market Place; Stock-Picking Time Again
description: PICKING favorite stocks at midyear has become something of a tradition on Wall Street. This time around, the process is particularly challenging since the equity market is scaling record heights.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A New Test For Schoolboys
description: Slowly but relentlessly, sport's drug epidemic is drawing converts to the belief that mandatory testing is, if not desirable, then at least necessary - and not only on the pro and college levels, but even among the preps.

title: PETER CASE'S NEW ALBUM SIGNALS A RIFT WITH ROCK
description: PETER CASE sings about what happens to rock performers after the lights go out and the cheering fades in ''Steel Strings,'' a song from his new album ''Peter Case'' (Geffen). There'll come a time when ''the manager's doin' time in jail/The pink Cadillac is up for sale,'' he predicts. Then he asks, ''Do you want a man of steel/Or do you want a man that's real?/They're only men of steel when they're on steel strings.''

title: INTERCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Economic Scene; F.T.C.'s Ruling On Soda Deals
description: FOR almost six years now, the Reagan Administration has encourged corporate mergers of almost every size and shape - the $10 billion Texaco-Getty combination, the $6.3 billion G.E.-RCA deal and the $4.8 billion Sperry-Burroughs transaction. Such deals would have been unheard of in the 1970's.

title: EDWARD J. O'DONNELL
description: The Rev. Edward J. O'Donnell, former president of Marquette University, died Monday after a long illness.

title: 'PORTRAIT OF AMERICAN IMPRESSIONISTS'
description: ONE of the prettiest pictures on the screen tonight will surely be the spectacle on Channel 13 at 8:30. The program is ''In Open Air: A Portrait of American Impressionists,'' part of the ''You Gotta Have Art'' series.

title: A Reagan Fiasco In the World Court
description: Suppose you had a lawyer who failed to shield you from an impending lawsuit by neglecting to exercise in a timely manner your right to refuse the court's jurisdiction? And, having missed that opportunity, suppose your lawyer then failed to present the merits of your case to the court, thus helping to assure a judgment against you? That is essentially what our Government has done in the case we lost last week to Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice.

title: Telerate Has Service Delay
description: Trading on some major Chicago commodity exchanges was disrupted throughout the day yesterday following the explosion on Monday afternoon of a Commonwealth Edison electrical transformer.

title: Textron Will Split Bell Aerospace
description: Textron Inc. said it would divide its Bell Aerospace unit, its most lucrative division, into two units. B.F. Dolan, president and chief executive of Textron, said the move was an effort to ''stimulate growth within each of the divisions.''

title: DOZENS OF SHIPS BEGIN ASSEMBLING FOR LIBERTY CELEBRATION
description: In Manhasset Bay, George Werner, chairman of Port Washington Yacht Club's welcoming committee, wore his ''normal nautical garb,'' white pants and a blue blazer, as he rode out in the club launch to greet the 95-foot Belgian ketch Zenobe Gramme.

title: Bond Rally Loses Its Steam
description: The bond market rally that began last Friday lost some of its steam in technical trading yesterday, as dealers consolidated their positions in anticipation of a cut in the discount rate sometime soon.

title: ISRAELI GROUP MEETS U.S. OFFICIALS OVER CHARGES IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: A high-level Israeli delegation has met with Justice Department officials to discuss prospects for criminal charges against an Israeli Air Force colonel who has been linked to a spy ring, sources close to both governments said today.

title: How Reagan Has It Both Ways With Moscow
description: Ronald Reagan is fond of drawing on an anecdote about a theatrical drama on New York's Lower East Side when discussing negotiations with the Russians.

title: NO MORE SOLIDARITIES, GORBACHEV PROMISES
description: While Mikhail S. Gorbachev used his appearance at the congress of the Polish Communist Party to urge the West to take his arms-control offers seriously, he had a message for Eastern Europe as well.

title: MARQUIS SHOWS OFF ITS STAGE
description: Electricians drilled and carpenters hammered frantically yesterday in the race to complete the 1,600-seat Marquis Theater at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, which officially opens on Tuesday.

title: Squid Without Tears
description: In the summertime at the resorts of France and Spain, a favorite snack is deep-fried squid rings with a zippy garlic mayonnaise. Fresh squid properly cooked is one of the most delicious, and inexpensive, forms of seafood available.

title: Violence Mounts in Chile On Eve of a Strike
description: The police said today that eight bombs had exploded in Santiago and three leftist guerrillas had died in a raid on their home.

title: New York Soprano Gets Tchaikovsky 2d Prize
description: Barbara Kilduff, a 27-year-old soprano from New York City, won second prize today in the singing competition at the Tchaikovsky music competition. She sang arias from Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Coq d'Or'' and Thomas's ''Hamlet.''

title: AIRSHIP CRASHES AT BASE IN JERSEY
description: A nine-story-high experimental aircraft that combined four helicopters and a blimp crashed and disintegrated tonight during a test flight at the United States Naval Air Engineering Center here, killing one of five crew members.

title: To Abandon SALT Is to Blind the U.S.
description: So far, most critics of President Reagan's decision to abandon SALT II have focused on the near-term prospect of a renewed arms race. Nearly as troubling is the possibility that our ability to gather intelligence about the Soviet Union's strategic forces will be severely handicapped. This could prove to be as dangerous to national security as the arms race itself.

title: ANDERSON TO CALL SESSION TO AN END IN ALBANY TODAY
description: After months of failure by legislators and Governor Cuomo to come to agreement on several key issues, the majority leader of the State Senate said Tuesday that there was no point in continuing negotiations and that the Senate would end the legislative session today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BLACK sea bass is fine for texture and flavor and, to my palate, is quite special and delicate. I don't think it is contradictory to say that the flesh is notably tender yet firm. When filleted, the bass is extraordinarily easy to cook.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: BERN MARCOWITZ has been a member of the Museum of Modern Art for 36 years and, he assumed, was not only familiar with the museum's ways but also prepared for any surprise it might offer. But on a recent visit to MOMA's handsome ground-floor cafeteria, he was taken aback to discover, alongside the traditional bran muffins and banana muffins, a tray of muffins with a neatly printed sign that read ''Morning Glory.''

title: GIANTS WIN IN 10TH, TAKE FIRST IN WEST
description: Candy Maldonado, who tied the score with a ninth-inning pinch-hit homer, hit a two-run single with two outs and the bases loaded in the 10th inning tonight to lead the San Francisco Giants to a 9-6 victory over the Braves.

title: BISHOP MATTHEWS, A METHODIST, DIES
description: The Rev. Marjorie S. Matthews, the first woman elected a bishop of the United Methodist Church, died yesterday at a nursing home in Grand Rapids, Mich., after a long struggle with cancer. She was 69 years old.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Intense Border Fighting
description: Iran and Iraq reported today that heavy fighting raged around Mehran, an Iranian border town seized by Iraqi forces six weeks ago.

title: Alzheimer Program
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MURROW: His Life and Times. By A. M. Sperber. Illustrated. 795 pages.

title: Convert Label on Israeli ID's Is Mean-Spirited
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 GIVEN PROBATION IN ALIEN SMUGGLING
description: A Federal district judge today declined to impose prison terms on five church workers convicted May 1 as participating in a conspiracy to smuggle aliens into the country illegally and instead suspended their sentences and placed them on probation.

title: New Federal Jury Trials In Civil Cases Under Way
description: New Federal jury trials of civil lawsuits are being convened after a two-week hiatus resulting from budget problems, a court official said today.

title: Power I
description: The Democratic National Committee is feeling bullish about its $1,000-a-plate gala scheduled Sept. 24 at the Washington Hilton.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEEMS TO REFLECT OFFICIAL UNEASE ON WALDHEIM
description: A decision by the United States Ambassador to Austria to skip Kurt Waldheim's inauguration as President next Tuesday has illustrated the tender state of United States-Austrian relations.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes restructuring charges for specialty stores of $3 million for the quarter and $6 million for the 6 months, and for both the quarter and 6 months a $3 million repositioning cost for Kuppenheimer, totaling 29 cents a share and 44 cents a share, respectively. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect the May 1986 3-for-2 stock split. The company said there was no material change in sales of ongoing operations compared to 1985; Chas. A. Stevens, sold as of Jan. 31, accounted for all of the $18.3 million 6-month difference in sales.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Said to Down Plane
description: Western diplomats said today that guerrillas had shot down a military transport plane carrying 100 soldiers in southern Afghanistan.

title: A DREAM NOW REAL, WALKER RESTS
description: Kenny Walker, who had just come a very long way in a very short time, was breathing easily now as he sat in the lobby of a big hotel in a strange city where almost no one knew who he was.

title: Deus ex machina I
description: The development of direct mail solicitation into a major source of political finance and the concurrent rise of feminism occasionally run at cross-purposes, converting former friends of the party into enemies. Fund-raising by mail depends heavily on machines, which, it develops, do not have adjustments for consciousness-raising.

title: HENLEY SET FOR 5 DAYS
description: In the 147-year history of the Henley Royal Regatta, little has changed, which gives the added day of racing to five days this year a certain significance. The last time anything similar occurred was 80 years ago, when racing went from three to four days.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SCREEN: 'RAINY DAY FRIENDS'
description: ANY movie that makes good actors look either incompetent or foolish can't be defended on humanitarian grounds, which would seem to be the only possible excuse for ''Rainy Day Friends.''

title: World Bank Official Moves to Drexel
description: In a move to bolster its international presence, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that Hani K. Findakly, director of the investment department at the World Bank, had joined the firm as senior vice president and director of international fixed-income capital markets.

title: Sikma Sent to Bucks
description: Jack Sikma, the Seattle SuperSonics' center, was traded yesterday to the Milwaukee Bucks for the center Alton Lister. As part of the deal, the Sonics will receive Milwaukee's first-round draft choices in the 1987 and 1989 National Basketball Association draft, and the Bucks will receive Seattle's second-round draft picks in those two years.

title: Democracy Not a Cure For All Latin Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING IN MAY ADVANCED 0.8%
description: Construction spending climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in May as a big rise in government building projects offset weakness in the commercial sector, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MORRISON INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued unconsolidated insurance subsidiary of $255,000. All share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for the 5-percent stock dividend declared on March 31, 1986.

title: NICARAGUAN, IN U.N., REBUKES U.S. OVER CONTRAS
description: The Nicaraguan Foreign Minister told the Security Council today that the vote by the House of Representatives to provide military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels ''constitutes a declaration of war, carries with it dangerous and unforseeable consequences and is one more step in the direction of sending United States troops to Nicaragua.''

title: Day of Sail, Night of Fire
description: First the ships, silent, elegant totems of history. Then the fireworks, clamorous, exuberant celebrations of the present. Those are Friday the Fourth's main events - probably the biggest such displays ever - and they'll survive the tawdry commercialism, accessible to all.

title: PHILADELPHIA SERVICES STRIKE A CHALLENGE FOR THE MAYOR
description: About 13,000 municipal workers went on strike here today for the first time in eight years, confronting Mayor W. Wilson Goode with a key test in his effort to regain political momentum.

title: FORMER OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF ROLE IN LEASING CASE
description: A former senior official with the State Office of General Services was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy, fraud, bribery and perjury in connection with state leases and renovation of a building in lower Manhattan.

title: TO BE A CITIZEN: NEWCOMERS' QUEST
description: In this week of parades, celebrations and spectaculars, there are to be short and simple ceremonies rich with meaning. Across the country today, tomorrow and Friday, some 26,000 immigrants will raise their right hand, renounce their loyalty to the lands of their birth and swear an oath of allegiance to a new country - the United States of America.

title: HUNTING GUINEA HENS AROUND TOWN
