description: WHAT is the trend-setting barbecue chef grilling this year? It may well be a scrappy, bald-headed bird with a squawk like a squeaky windmill called the guinea hen. Favored by ancient Greeks and Romans, coveted by modern-day French and only recently introduced to the northeastern United States on a substantial commercial level, the guinea hen is fast becoming the fowl of choice among adventurous home cooks and restaurant chefs in the metropolitan area.

title: CAPTAIN CRAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Net loss. Latest quarter results include the recognition of $105,000 of previously deferred franchise income.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Pacific Stereo retail chain misstated the financial performance of a competing chain, the Federated Group. Earnings (not sales) were off 57 percent in the latest quarter; sales rose 28 percent.

title: BUYING A GRILL: PLAIN OR FANCY, SAFE DESIGN IS PARAMOUNT
description: BUYING a barbecue grill is something like choosing an automobile - both the stripped-down budget models and the accessory-laden prestige versions will get you where you want to go. It's simply a question of ease and speed.

title: Monarch Capital Deal
description: The Monarch Capital Corporation, an insurance and investment concern, said it would acquire the Narragansett Capital Corporation for $121.8 million, or $56 a share.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In open contrast to the civilization of love, the specter of violence appears with disquieting characteristics that leave its consequences of sorrow and death in so many parts of the world.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes income from operations distributed of $1,295,000, or 23 cents a share.

title: FILM: 'THE GREAT MOUSE DETECTIVE'
description: MANY of the new crop of children's animated movies are so saturated with powdered sugar that one suspects just watching them will produce cavities. What a treat it is to see an animated feature that doesn't moralize or patronize young children, or drown them in bathos. With ''The Great Mouse Detective,'' which opens today at the New Embassy 49th Street and other theaters, the Disney people have gone back to the basics that have delighted children and their parents for half a century.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Deny Opium Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Nuclear Plant Shut After Restarting
description: Faulty instruments in the reactor core forced a shutdown at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant two hours after it resumed operations after a 41-week shutdown, a plant spokesman said today.

title: THE LAND OF THE FREE, THE HOME OF THE BURGER
description: WHILE a handful of backyard cooks will be out grilling larks' tongues and suchlike funny foreign foods this Fourth of July, millions and millions of other Americans will be happily incinerating hamburgers. And they will be right.

title: FILM: ANTHONY PERKINS IN 'PSYCHO III'
description: THE news this morning is not that emotionally unstable Norman Bates is back - he's come back before (in ''Psycho II''). It's that Anthony Perkins, who created the character 25 years ago in the Alfred Hitchcock original, is not only back as Norman Bates (and none the worse for wear), but also making his debut as the new film's very creditable director.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on June 25 of Morris Kirsch, the retired chairman of Kirsch beverages, listed his survivors incompletely. They include his wife, Bertha.

title: Honeywell Link to NEC
description: In a move that seems likely to step up competition in the supercomputer market, the NEC Corporation said yesterday that it would set up a joint-venture company with Honeywell Inc. to market NEC supercomputers in North America.

title: CRACKS IN 747 JETS PROMPT F.A.A. TO CALL FOR STIFFER INSPECTION RULES
description: Reacting to the continuing discovery of cracks in the forward area of some older Boeing 747 jumbo jets, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday proposed an intensified program of inspection and repair.

title: 8 ARE WOUNDED BY BOMB BLAST IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A bomb exploded in a liquor outlet in central Johannesburg today, wounding eight people, in a further attack on civilian targets after two similar explosions in the city center a week ago.

title: BIG BEAR CO reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $605,000, or 9 cents a share, on the sale of land. The share earnings for the latest and previous years have been adjusted for a 10- percent stock dividend declared and issued during the quarter ended March 1.

title: 2 ARE INDICTED IN BRIBERY CASE AT CITY HOSPITAL
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted the former head of Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx yesterday on charges of taking nearly $100,000 in bribes from a company that recruits Filipino nurses for hospitals in the city.

title: Democracy at Risk in Peru
description: Bravado in Peru has now yielded to bravery. President Alan Garcia acknowledges that the failure to control a military assault against armed, rebellious prisoners resulted, after they were crushed, in the massacre of 100 helpless inmates. Recognizing that ''a horrific crime'' has done ''enormous damage to the country,'' he moved boldly to arrest 100 members of the paramilitary Republican Guard and to force the guard commander and Minister of Justice to resign.

title: SALICK HEALTH CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Figures for 1985 have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1985.

title: 2 WALL ST. EXECUTIVES SETTLE IN BIG INSIDER TRADING CASE
description: Two investment bankers were charged yesterday with participating in an insider trading ring with Dennis B. Levine, the Wall Street professional who pleaded guilty last month in what the authorities described as the largest insider trading case ever uncovered.

title: Mother and Baby Die In Fire Set by Arsonist
description: A mother and her 3-month-old baby girl died late last night in their two-story home in St. Albans, Queens, in a fire set by an arsonist, according to the police.

title: COKE TO PURCHASE ITS LARGEST BOTTLER
description: Taking the biggest step yet in expanding its role in the bottling business, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to buy the largest Coke bottler in the country - the JTL Corporation - for about $1.4 billion.

title: SHIFT IN U.S. POLICY IS DENIED
description: The White House stressed today that the Administration's policy review on South Africa was aimed at better implementation of existing policies rather than dramatic departures.

title: MARGALO GILLMORE, AN ACTRESS ON THE STAGE AND ON SCREEN
description: Margalo Gillmore, a stage and motion-picture actress who appeared in many of Broadway's most famous plays, including ''The Barretts of Wimpole Street,'' ''The Women'' and ''Life With Father,'' died Monday at her Manhattan apartment. She was 89 years old.

title: UNIONISTS TO GET LOW-INTEREST CREDIT CARDS
description: The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today announced a new benefits plan that will offer its 13.1 million members free low-interest credit cards and discount legal services.

title: PRIVATE TAKEOVER OF SPACE SHUTTLE FLEET SUGGESTED
description: A member of the Presidential commission that investigated the Challenger disaster has called on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to give up its fleet of space shuttles and turn the program over to a private company.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 exchange of stock effective March 25, 1986.

title: KOCH TO SOFTEN BILL THAT ORDERS SMOKING LIMITS
description: Mayor Koch agreed yesterday to modify an antismoking bill he has proposed by exempting businesses faced with severe financial hardships and eliminating a requirement for ''adequate ventilation'' before a business can set up a designated smoking area.

title: LLOYD ADVANCES TO SEMIFINALS
description: Her toughest matches are often decided during the breaks between games, a time for sipping water, toweling off and contemplation. What the women who have sat in the chair opposite Chris Evert Lloyd think about in those 60 seconds is a matter of conjecture but the record shows they haven't found many right answers peering into the bottom of a paper cup.

title: Social Security Increase
description: More than two million Social Security beneficiaries who worked in 1984 will get monthly benefit increases averaging $14.30 in their July checks, it was announced Monday. Dorcas R. Hardy, the new Commissioner of Social Security, said her agency would also distribute retroactive checks averaging $265 to the same people on Thursday.

title: Rider Sues N.Y.R.A.
description: Don MacBeth, the jockey seriously injured in a racing accident April 5, has filed an $87 million negligence suit in State Supreme Court against the New York Racing Association, contending that he was never told that a veterinarian had declared his mount, a 4-year-old colt named Fleet Halo, unfit to race before that finding was overruled. Before the accident at Aqueduct, in which he suffered a fractured spine, MacBeth had been grossing $600,000 in purse earnings a year.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SO-SO MARK FOR U.S.F.L. PLAY
description: After 24 witnesses over 29 days of testimony in the United States Football League's antitrust-suit trial against the National Football League, somebody finally talked about football. The kind that's played on the field.

title: Faded Glory
description: The dozen Cy Young Award winners who've pitched in the major leagues this season had posted a collective record of 51-63 as of yesterday, with Rick Sut-cliffe (4-10) and Bret Saberhagen (4-9) the biggest disappointments. Both Sutcliffe, now on the disabled list, and Saberhagen are candidates to join this list of Cy Young honorees who lost 18 or more in a single year sometime during their careers:

title: OFFICIAL SAYS NICARAGUA PLANS NO CRACKDOWN
description: A senior Nicaraguan leader said today that steps taken against the opposition last week did not signal the beginning of a crackdown.

title: TV'S BIGGEST NEWS CHALLENGE YET
description: As production work crews added finishing touches to elaborate sets and communications hookups on islands and ships throughout New York Harbor this week, broadcasters said they were getting ready for the most logistically complicated weekend of events they have ever covered.

title: Europe Mobile Phone
description: Ericsson Radio Systems A.G. of Sweden has joined a European consortium developing cellular digital mobile telephones, ANT Nachrichtentechnik G.m.b.H., a co-leader in the consortium, said today.

title: Let Us Now Celebrate the Second
description: Happy Independence Day! Hooray for the Second of July!

title: COOKS MOVE BEYOND HUMBLE HOT DOG
description: OUTDOOR barbecues were once among life's ingenuous summer pleasures, requiring neither forethought nor fashion consciousness. Steaks, burgers, hot dogs or maybe chicken breasts were all that were expected, and indeed they could be sublime. Today, like many once-simple commodities such as television (three networks), sneakers (high or low) and pizzas (thick and chewy or thin and crispy), grilling has become frightfully upscale and potentially confusing.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OPEN HOUSE - As the city girds for the outburst of celebration this weekend, there are quiet corners in which memories of the nation's early days may be contemplated at a less fevered pace. One such enclave is occupied by the Abigail Adams Smith Museum.

title: PICNIC ALTERNATIVES
description: EVERYTHING the latest scientific research tells us about the relationship between diet and diseases like cancer and heart disease points to the importance of increasing fiber, lowering fat and cholesterol and avoiding or restricting the consumption of foods that have been preserved by smoking, pickling and salt-curing.

title: Advertising; Drug-Free Campaign Gears Up
description: DESPITE the fact that he is extremely busy putting together the components in the recently formed Omnicom Group, Allen G. Rosenshine, its chief executive, has nonetheless volunteered to supervise the creative work for the industry's huge anti-drug effort, one of the largest public service advertising campaigns ever undertaken.

title: AS WEEKEND NEARS, HARBOR BRISTLES WITH ACTIVITY
description: Square-rigged ships and naval vessels sailed around New York Harbor, the Parks Department planted 45,000 red, white and blue petunias in Battery Park and hundreds of homeless people gathered in protest in the park as New York yesterday filled with harbingers of the start of the four-day Statue of Liberty Centennial.

title: COLLEGE SEXUAL ASSAULT CASE STIRS MASSACHUSETTS
description: For a college president, Francis J. Pilecki took an unusual interest in his students, often inviting them to parties at his house. At the time, professors and administrators at Westfield State College here saw nothing to be disturbed at, since Mr. Pilecki, a bright, gregarious, energetic man, had helped raise the school's academic reputation.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $740,000.

title: Two Good Men
description: When Boomer Esiason of the Cincinnati Bengals married not long ago, his best man was Frank Reich of the Buffalo Bills, an old college roommate at Maryland.

title: Seaver Proves 'I Can Help'
description: In the Red Sox dugout between innings at Fenway Park on Monday night, Tom Seaver approached John McNamara.

title: NBC News Tops Ratings; CBS Drops to 3d Spot
description: NBC's ''Nightly News'' program, continuing its surge in the tight competition for the network news audience, finished No. 1 in the ratings released yesterday while the ''CBS Evening News'' dropped to third place for the first time in nearly five years.

title: KOCH PRESENTS LIBERTY AWARDS TO 86 IMMIGRANTS
description: The Statue of Liberty centennial celebration made its unofficial debut yesterday, at a good-natured ceremony marked by the rumpled charm of New York relaxed.

title: STATE ASSEMBLY APPROVES PLAN FOR A PUBLIC TAKEOVER OF LILCO
description: The Assembly approved a plan early today to set up a public authority to take over the Long Island Lighting Company and bar the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, despite a shift in position by Governor Cuomo.

title: FERNANDEZ GAINS 10TH VICTORY
description: The Mets, strutting along unchallenged and almost untouched, muzzled the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 2-1, with their pitching tandem of Sid Fernandez and Roger McDowell and ran their latest winning streak to five games.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Mark J. Minkin has joined Altman & Manley, Boston, as executive vice president.

title: ROBUST OR FRUITY WINES DO BEST
description: TO recommend wine for a barbecue, it seemed like a good idea to find out first what the word ''barbecue'' means. Is it a noun or a verb? Is it something edible or an activity?

title: DOW TOPS 1,900 ON 10.82 RISE
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, after trading in the shadow of 1,900 for more than a week, closed above that level yesterday for the first time ever. Along the way it set its second record in two days.

title: Class Suit Against Merrill
description: A Federal judge in New York has granted class representative status to a group of Michigan investors that is suing Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith for purportedly failing to disclose important information about zero coupon Treasury-backed securities.

title: Power II
description: It is some evidence of the growing political influence of the world wildlife movement that more than 80 members of the House have joined in co-sponsoring Representative Robert J. Mrazek's bill to reinstate a ban on importing kangaroo products into the United States.

title: CAVENHAM, USA INC reports earnings for 12wks to March 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,903,000 relating to the utilization of a net operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss. The 1986 results for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks included a pre-tax charge of $7,580,000, reflecting an adjustment to a store closure reserve originally established two years ago for the company's wholly- owned subsidiary, the Grand Union Co.

title: People Express Talks Reported
description: United Airlines is talking with People Express about buying some of the low-cost airline's eight Boeing 747 jumbo aircraft, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday. It could not be learned, however, whether the two sides were close to an agreement.

title: HOLYFIELD USING NOVEL TRAINING FOR STAMINA
description: On July 12 in Atlanta, Evander Holyfield will fight for the World Boxing Association junior-heavyweight title (190-pound limit) against the champion, Dwight Muhammad Qawi, in only the 12th fight of his career.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RENT-A-WRECK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to March 31
PANEL ACCEPTS 3 DISPUTED PSYCHIATRIC CATEGORIES
description: After months of vigorous opposition by feminist groups, the American Psychiatric Association announced today that its trustees had approved the addition of three new psychiatric disorders to its official diagnostic manual, but only in an appendix.

title: CORNISH MINERS NOW, MUSEUM PIECES TOMORROW?
description: After 35 centuries of times as hard and darkly yielding as the rock tunnels of Cornwall, the Cornish tin miner, one of the proudest and most ancient toilers of Britain, is approaching the end of his ways with a sense of absurdity as much as despair.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: I'M not going to be a spoilsport and tell you to stay indoors and eat bean salad and fruit for the Fourth of July. But before you indulge in big bangs and barbecues, there are a few points worth keeping in mind to insure that your celebration will be a safe, not a sorry, event.

title: Sale by Beatrice
description: The new owners of the Beatrice Companies said they had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to help them sell off Beatrice's Playtex group and its other personal products operations. These operations, which include Jhirmack haircare products, Halston fragrances and Max Factor cosmetics and fragrances, have annual revenues exceeding $1 billion.

title: Army Officer Charged
description: An Army officer at Fort McNair was arrested and charged Monday with selling cocaine to an undercover police officer, the District of Columbia police said. Capt. Louis Tortorella, 31 years old, of Greenbelt, Md., was arrested at about noon in a parking lot after an investigation a police spokesman, Shannon Cockett, said. Captain Tortorella, an assistant operations officer with the deputy chief of staff for operations, plans and security at Fort McNair, was charged with conspiracy with intent to distribute cocaine.

title: Giant Is Penalized
description: An Essex County Superior Court judge in Newark has found Byron Hunt guilty of speeding and drunken driving, and ordered the 27-year-old Giant linebacker to give up his driving privileges for a year, pay $250 and spend 12 hours in an alchohol-treatment center. Judge William Harth's decision followed a ruling handed down last February by Judge Carl Stier of the Bloomfield Municipal Court.

title: Geriatric Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: 'COMRADES' EXAMINES SOVIET LIFE
description: THE question arose in Britain:

title: BERRA DRIVE TOPS TIGERS
description: Neither Dave Righetti nor Willie Hernandez sat in front of his locker last night with his head bowed. Neither felt he had anything to apologize for.

title: LIABILITY COSTS DAMPEN SUMMER FUN
description: With Fourth of July celebrations only hours away, some cities and towns around the country are canceling fireworks displays because liability insurance is unaffordable or unavailable.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1986
description: Markets

title: Crude Oil Continuing Drop on World Market
description: Crude oil prices slumped further yesterday on the world oil market, and oil analysts in the United States said that the failure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on production quotas is likely to keep them in this low range for the next several months.

title: IACOCCA SAYS LIBERTY FUND SURPASSED ITS GOAL BY $12 MILLION
description: Lee A. Iacocca announced yesterday that the campaign to raise $265 million for the restoration of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island had surpassed its goal by $12 million.

title: IN SOWETO, PACKED BAGS IN CASE THE POLICE COME
description: At her office in the medical clinic here where she works, and also at her home, the woman said she keeps her bags packed and ready.

title: CABLE CONCERN VOIDS A BRONX CONSULTING CONTRACT
description: The company chosen to provide cable service to the Bronx has canceled its $50,000-a-year consulting contract with one of the borough's top political figures, a spokesman for the company said yesterday. The contract has been one element of a Bronx investigation into the awarding of cable franchises.

title: Deus ex machina II
description: A case in which residents of Bikini Atoll in the Pacific are trying to recover $450 million from the United States for seizure and contamination of their islands will be argued in the Court of Claims today, only one day after the date 40 years ago that the first peacetime nuclear test was conducted over their home.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1986
description: International

title: 'Nickleby' Returning To Broadway Aug. 20
description: ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the Royal Shakespeare Company's adaptation of the Charles Dickens novel, will return to Broadway with a new cast on Aug. 20 at the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street. The eight-and-a-half hour production, directed by Trevor Nunn and John Caird, has been on a limited American tour that began last month at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Bridge: Brain-Teasers Are Offered On Dutch Teletext System
description: The bridge players of the Netherlands, like those in other parts of Western Europe, can use a teletext system.

title: TESTIMONY ON BIAS
description: A grand jury began hearing testimony today about events leading to the death of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball player who died of cocaine intoxication June 19.

title: FORSTMANN IN DEAL FOR MIDLAND-ROSS
description: The Midland-Ross Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Forstmann Little & Company, a private investment firm, for $28 a share in cash, or a total of about $450 million.

title: We Need a National Policy on the Aged Urgently
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Killer Is Given 24-Hour Execution Stay
description: A Federal district judge refused today to grant a new trial to the condemned killer Theodore R. Bundy, but the judge ordered the execution delayed for 24 hours to allow defense lawyers time to appeal to a higher court.

title: LIBERTY CELEBRATION: WHERE TO GO, HOW TO GET THERE AND WHAT TO DO
description: The boats are pulling into the harbor. The cameras are getting into place. And dozens of Government agencies are ready to spring into action. Tomorrow night the celebration begins and New York is about as ready as it ever has been to play host to a party of mammoth proportions.

title: Lyle Is Acquitted
description: Ron Lyle has been acquitted by a Municipal Court judge of assault and interference charges stemming from a quarrel outside the former heavyweight contender's boxing club in Lakewood, Colo. The 44-year-old Lyle was accused of slugging Jon Kraus, whom the police identified as a brother of a woman also involved in a dispute with the former fighter on Feb. 14 at Ron Lyle's Ringside club.

title: Mexico Sees Debt Accord
description: Mexico will reach ''substantial agreement'' on a new financing package by the end of this month, the Mexican Finance Ministry said yesterday.

title: The Price of Liberty
description: The following document is brought to you by E-Z Flow Tomato Ketchup, Achilles Tennis Shoes (''Tending more tenderly to tense, tired tendons''), Rub-a-Dub-Dub Hot Tubs and by Japasone, ''The motorcycle that gets you there in one piece almost every time.'' And now, our sponsors proudly bring you a declaration:

title: Occidental Deal
description: Three oil companies said they had completed their previously announced purchase of certain oil and gas assets of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for $444 million. The Apache Petroleum Company, the Apache Corporation and the Davis Oil Company bought the properties. Davis, a privately held concern, will acquire 50 percent of the assets, while Apache Petroleum will own 45 percent and Apache Corporation will hold 5 percent.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACK ACTIVIST TELLS OF AN AMBUSH
description: Four black activists were killed and two were wounded after South Africans said to be allied with the police lured them into a house with promises of weapons and then raked the house with gunfire, according to an affidavit of a statement by one of the survivors.

title: SEASON'S DRINK: COOLERS
description: IF an American asked for a wine cooler at a picnic on the lawn of an English manor, the hostess, raising an eyebrow, might bring out her wooden wine-service furniture designed by Robert Adam in 1780 for the Duke of Cumberland. Ask for a wine cooler at a backyard barbecue in this country and you get a fizzy drink.

title: Rebuild the Sandy Hook Lab, Watchdog Over Marine Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Sturtevant & Hildt
description: Sturtevant & Hildt Advertising, a recently formed subsidiary of Diener/Hauser/Bates, has got permission from MGM Home Video to announce it as a client. Billings are about $4 million. The new agency people were formerly executives at Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall, which had also handled the MGM Home Video account.

title: AN ASSESSMENT OF 2 POPULAR DIET BOOKS
description: ANYONE can lose weight by taking in fewer calories than are expended. This is not a secret, nor is it magic. But most diet books promise both - a secret that works like magic, producing instant weight loss without pain. It is a promise they cannot keep. And sometimes dieters get more than they bargained for - weight loss at the cost of their health.

title: ISRAELI HIGH COURT CHALLENGES AMNESTY
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today challenged the Government to explain why there was no police investigation of allegations that the head of Israel's domestic intelligence service ordered the killings of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers and that he subsequently covered up his involvement.

title: NEWARK MAYOR VOWS CHANGE
description: Vowing to bring prosperity to all citizens of this troubled community, former City Councilman Sharpe James took the oath of office today as the 37th Mayor of the state's largest city and promptly appointed new leaders for the Police and Fire Departments and other agencies.

title: GOVERNORS ISLAND CREAKS UNDER THE INVASION
description: The center of attention on Governors Island, a sleepy little town of 3,500 people, is expected to switch rather dramatically tomorrow night from the bowling alley to the new made-for-television amphitheater, where President Reagan will relight the Statue of Liberty and touch off the colossal Liberty Weekend.

title: POPE, IN COLOMBIA, ATTACKS ECONOMIC INEQUALITY
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today and condemned the economic power exercised by wealthy nations over poor ones. He also urged this country's political leaders to resist the expansion of the ''tragic and macabre empire'' of terrorism.

title: Advertising; McGraw-Hill Study Promotes Ad Pages
description: As a way of promoting advertising in the pages of its trade magazines, McGraw-Hill every other year estimates how much sales calls are costing those who call on industrial companies. Like everything else, it keeps going up, giving more justification for reaching customers through advertising rather than personal visits.

title: APPEALS COURT HEARS EMERGENCY PLEA IN SPY CASE
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit heard oral argument today on the Government's emergency appeal against a proposed instruction to the jury in the trial of Jerry A. Whitworth for espionage and tax fraud.

title: HIGH COURT, 5-4, SHARPLY LIMITS CONSTITUTIONAL PROTECTION FOR ADS
description: The Supreme Court, sharply limiting First Amendment protection for commercial speech, today ruled 5 to 4 that governments may sometimes ban truthful advertising of products and services that are legal to sell.

title: Sister Marjorie Tuite, Advocate for Women
description: Sister Marjorie Tuite, a social activist who was an advocate of women's rights in the Roman Catholic Church, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Chicago.

title: BALLET: TWO CASTS IN 'ROMEO'
description: OPULENT yet often ponderous, Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' needs fine performers to stir it to life. Fortunately, the casts of two recent performances by American Ballet Theater worked hard to make it exciting.

title: Sanders Holders Told to Hold Stock
description: Sanders Associates Inc.'s chief executive, Jack L. Bowers, today asked shareholders to hold onto their stock until the company's directors evaluate the Loral Corporation's hostile tender offer of $50 a share for 51 percent of the Sanders common shares.

title: Disk Drives Dropped
description: Computer Memories Inc., the company whose disk drives were blamed for the slow market start of the International Business Machines Corporation's PC AT, said today that it had discontinued the production and marketing of disk drives, which constituted 95 percent of its business.

title: TEAMS FORMING TO SEEK LARGE U.S. JET CONTRACT
description: Two teams of aerospace industry giants are forming to seek an Air Force contract for the next generation of fighter aircraft, the companies said today.

title: DROPOUTS ARE WAGNER PRIORITY
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., who was elected president of the New York City Board of Education yesterday, said he would move immediately to reduce the high number of dropouts and begin a major review of decentralization.

title: BANTAM CO-CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER RESIGNS
description: Alberto Vitale, who joined Bantam in 1975 and was named president and co-chief executive officer of the publishing house 15 months ago, is now the company's sole chief executive. Louis Wolfe, who shared the chief executive duties with Mr. Vitale, has resigned.

title: COURT RULES THAT 5TH AMENDMENT DOESN'T APPLY IN PSYCHIATRIC CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination did not apply to a proceeding to commit to a psychiatric prison a man said to be ''sexually dangerous.''

title: DANCE: PLAY BASED ON SANDMAN SIMS
description: THOSE who have followed the tap revival of the last decade and a half know that Howard (Sandman) Sims is a virtuoso among virtuosos - in a class by himself. To say Mr. Sims dances on sand is like saying Philippe Petit is a tightrope walker.

title: Fast-Moving Target Hit In Missile Defense Test
description: An Army missile successfully intercepted a fast-moving target Friday in the latest test of devices that might someday defend the United States against nuclear missiles, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

title: New Forms of Animal Life Reported on Atlantic Floor
description: A previously unknown type of blind shrimp and a six-sided animal that may be from a species long thought extinct have been found near geysers on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Exhaustive Study
description: The scene is now long familiar: An exhausted football player comes staggering off the field, plops down on the sideline and promptly takes a deep swig from a canister of pure oxygen to revive himself.

title: Advertising; 2 Health Aid Accounts Won
description: Both Lowe Marschalk Inc., and Saatchi & Saatchi Compton have got assignments that will fit nicely in their medicine cabinets.

title: 13 (Count 'em) Toasts
description: On the Fourth of July in 1778, The Pennsylvania Packet reported, the ''honorable'' Congress celebrated the anniversary of Independence ''at the City Tavern in this metropolis.''

title: STOCK TALLY: A FAMILIAR LOOK
description: Makers of a wide array of consumer goods - ranging from egg cartons to aspirins to shoes - and a new crop of merchandisers that rely on cable television to sell discounted products sparked the stock markets during the second quarter.

title: International Minerals Sets Deal
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to sell almost all of its industry products group, or about 25 percent of the company, to an investor group. Terms were not disclosed but analysts estimated the deal to be worth between $150 million and $200 million.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for 13wks to June 1
BARBECUES DRESS UP
description: THANKS to new designs in disposable tableware, backyard barbecues no longer have to be casual affairs. Today, they can be as elegant as formal dinner parties. A table can be grandly set with paper plates and plastic wine glasses that mimic the look of fine china and crystal.

title: Crime in the Bedroom
description: A narrow Supreme Court majority, taking a narrow view of the rights at stake, has given states renewed license to regulate sexual conduct they deem deviant. In a 5-to-4 ruling endorsing Georgia's right to declare sodomy a crime, the Court crudely rejects as ''facetious'' the argument that such a law invades privacy and strikes at deeply personal, basic liberties.

title: 'FLEX' BUILDINGS PROVE INCREASINGLY POPULAR IN JERSEY
description: Until recently, when a light industrial tenant needed an office, a corner of the space would be set aside and walls would go up, desks would be moved in and telephones would be installed.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL - YANKEES VS. DETROIT TIGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: HART URGES TOUGHER U.S. ACTION TO CHANGE SOUTH AFRICA'S POLICIES
description: Senator Gary Hart today called for the Reagan Administration to take stronger measures against the South African Government, including demanding the ''unconditional release'' of Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MOSCOW CONTENDS IT PROPOSED WAY TO SUMMIT PARLEY
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry official asserted today in Moscow that the Soviet Union had proposed an approach for rescheduling talks to prepare for the next Soviet-American summit meeting.

title: The U.N. Today: July 2, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Executive Bows Out Of Top US Sprint Post
description: The US Sprint Communications Company began operations yesterday, but with only two executives running its three-man office of the president.

title: 'Democracy in America'
description: Fifty years before the French gave the Statue of Liberty to the American people, Alexis de Toqueville came here from Paris and wrote his famous ''Democracy in America.'' This is a good time to recall his observations.

title: FOODNOTES
description: A Toast to Liberty - Shortly before 11 P.M. tomorrow, President Reagan is scheduled to relight the torch of the restored Statue of Liberty, and simultaneously, if all goes according to plan, diners in restaurants around the country will raise their glasses in a Toast to Liberty. Conceived last December by Karen MacNeil, food editor of USA Today, the Toast to Liberty has subsequently received the endorsement of the National Restaurant Association, a number of state wine associations and the Sommelier Society, among others.

title: E.E.O.C. to Study Harper Dismissal
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will move forward with its investigation into a racial discrimination complaint filed against the Boston Red Sox by the former coach Tommy Harper, the club announced tonight.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.2%
description: The Government index designed to predict the economic future rose a meager two-tenths of 1 percent in May, inspiring new doubts about the chances of a significant business revival in the second half of the year.

title: CITY OPERA: BERNSTIEN'S 'CANDIDE'
description: THE New York City Opera is proud of its production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide,'' and rightly so. When it bowed in 1982, it served to validate this work as a legitimate part of the operatic repertory. It has proved steadily popular since, it has been recorded, and Tuesday night it opened the company's 1986 season at the New York State Theater. It will continue through Sunday, and then return in November at the close of the season for yet another week, during which time it will be telecast live.

title: Changes Seen At U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation is planning a major restructuring to split off its beleaguered steel and iron ore operations into a separate subsidiary and change the parent company's name, sources close to the company said yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I MUST admit that over the course of my lifetime I have not thought of the Statue of Liberty often. Four, maybe five times a year, six tops. Something would come up, a Trivial Pursuit question or a ride on the Circle Line, and I'd think to myself, ''Statue of Liberty. Good idea. Great execution. So-so color.'' My thoughts were fond. About 100 years ago, the French wanted to give the Americans a little something special, and they came up with this statue, which no one can deny makes a strong design statement. The French have a lot of experience in design, nice clothes, jewelry. But a statue, now that's original. And to top it off they put it in the middle of the water. Terrific.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BIG TROUBLE,' WILD STUNTS
description: IF, as is not unlikely, you should lose track of what is going on in ''Big Trouble in Little China'' and think you have wandered into a festival of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' ''Romancing the Stone,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''The Karate Kid,'' ''Flash Gordon'' and a throng of facsimiles, don't be concerned. What matters is the stunts and the spirit, and this latest set of exotic exploits of an indomitable hero (Kurt Russell) and a spunky heroine (Kim Cattrall) gives good value.

title: LENDL TOPS ANGER BUT NEEDS 4 SETS
description: It is more a matter of circumstance than evidence of his popularity that half of Ivan Lendl's four matches have been held over thus far. On the first day of Wimbledon, rain prevented the No. 1 player in the world from finishing until the next day. Then on Monday, darkness was Lendl's ally, interrupting an unexpected struggle against Matt Anger of the United States in the round of 16.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $325,000 from the sale of seven units.

title: FINANCE;
description: The Pacific Lumber Company, a subsidiary of the Maxxam Group Inc., is selling about $680.5 million in notes and debentures rated below investment grade to retire certain acquisition-related indebtedness.

title: ASSOCIATED REJECTS MAY'S BIDS
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation yesterday rejected takeover bids made by the May Department Stores Company as inadequate. Associated said it would seek other ways of maximizing value for its shareholders, including the possible sale of one or more divisions.

title: Don't Touch That Dial III
description: Senate television has already wrought a rather jarring change in Duncanville, Tex., where the Senate replaced the Playboy Channel.

title: Kia Approves Deal With Ford
description: Shareholders of the Kia Industrial Company approved the Ford Motor Company's proposal to buy 10 percent of the South Korean auto maker's stock, Kia officials said.

title: 5 CHERNOBYL MARROW RECIPIENTS LIVE, EXPERT SAYS
description: Five of the thirteen victims of the Chernobyl nuclear accident who received transplants of bone marrow are still alive, according to Dr. Robert P. Gale, the Californian who made a dramatic flight to Moscow to assist Soviet physicians with the delicate operations.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said that new divisions started in the latest fiscal year contributed net sales of $5.8 million for the current 3-month period.

title: ON EVE OF LIBERTY SALUTE, A WHIRL OF FINAL TOUCHES
description: Multitudes of people and hundreds of warships and majestic sailing vessels converged on New York yesterday amid final preparations for a kaleidoscopic Liberty Weekend of ceremony, spectacle and entertainment.

title: FACTORY ORDERS DOWN IN MAY
description: Factory orders dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in May as weakness in civilian demand offset a big increase in the military sector, the Government said today.

title: 2 Are Sentenced In Officer's Death
description: In a tense and disrupted proceeding, two former Black Panthers were sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a police officer in Queens in 1981.

title: Methodist Church Panel Restores 2 Hymns
description: ''Onward Christian Soldiers'' and ''Battle Hymn of the Republic'' will remain in the United Methodist hymnal, the church decided today, after a panel that had found the songs too militaristic voted to reverse its decision to drop them.

title: CITY'S HOMOSEXUALS PROTEST HIGH COURT SODOMY RULING
description: The Supreme Court ruling this week that upheld sodomy laws has generated anger and demonstrations in New York City's homosexual community.

title: MONETARISM FALLS FROM GRACE
description: The erratic and unpredictable growth of the nation's money supply over recent months has proved the last straw for a bedrock theory of conservative economics that has helped guide Government policy for two decades.

title: Inconsistent Policy on South Africa and China
description: To the Editor:

title: A LEGACY OF CAUTION TRIPS UP JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: THE first JVC Jazz Festival left a lot to be desired. The successor to the Kool and Newport festivals, also assembled by George Wein, finished its Manhattan shows Saturday. But nine days of concerts made barely a ripple on the city's active, contentious, polymorphous jazz scene.

title: Access to Hearings Is Sought
description: Two newspapers today asked the Supreme Court to allow them to report on their own efforts to get access to court proceedings in the impending fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Deere Engine
description: Deere & Company, in an effort to diversify its farm implement business, has signed a multimillion-dollar deal to develop a rotary engine for the Marine Corps. A Deere subsidiary signed the three-year, $33.5 million contract for research and development of an engine for use in amphibious assault vehicles. The project involves Deere's 750-horsepower, 5.8-liter twin-rotor engine.

title: Woolworth Bid In Britain Fails
description: Dixons Group conceded defeat today in its hostile bid to acquire Woolworth Holdings, the British variety store chain, for the equivalent of $2.9 billion.

title: CUOMO AND LEGISLATORS ANNOUNCE ACCORD ON TAKEOVER PLAN FOR LILCO
description: Governor Cuomo and the leaders of the Legislature reached agreement Wednesday night on a plan to set up a public authority empowered to take over the Long Island Lighting Company, which is struggling to open the long-delayed $4.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Differences Settled
description: Don King has stepped in to help the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, Livingstone Bramble, settle his differences with his manager, Lou Duva, and his promoter, Dan Duva. ''Bramble absolutely refused to fight for the Duvas,'' said King, who agreed to pay Lou Duva $50,000 and Dan Duva $350,000 from Bramble's future fights, settling a dispute that had gone to court.

title: STERN TIMES FOR ARMS MAKERS
description: Military contractors around the country, after five years of the biggest peacetime arms buildup in American history, now are girding for austerity, bitter competition and more onerous demands from the Pentagon and Capitol Hill.

title: Mother's Real Lesson
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: GUIDELINE ON RULINGS
description: ''Affirmative action'' refers to steps taken by an employer, school or other institution to expand opportunities for women, blacks, Hispanic people or members of other minority groups.

title: TODAY
description: 8 A.M. - The Small Ships: About 200 smaller sailing ships, anchored in Long Island Sound, assemble at the Throgs Neck Bridge and begin parade down East River to Gravesend Bay. 10 A.M. - Liberty Worship: Ecumenical ''liberty mass'' celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Bid Results Tallied By The Economist
description: The Economist Newspaper Ltd. said that it had received commitments to acquire more than 51 percent of the outstanding shares of the Business International Corporation, a closely held publishing, research and consulting firm.

title: U.S. AND CUBA TO MEET FOR TALKS ON REVIVING IMMIGRATION ACCORD
description: The United States and Cuba have agreed to have emissaries meet in Mexico City next week for negotiations on reviving a 1984 immigration agreement, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Paging Units Sold
description: The Mobile Communications Corporation of America said it had agreed to buy some paging operations that McCaw Cellular Inc. was acquiring from the MCI Cellular Telephone Company.

title: NEW TOOL FOR FABRIC DESIGNERS
description: APPLYING a New World tool, the computer, to an Old World craft, textile design, will be the focus of a series of classes at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan, beginning this month.

title: Cunningham Dropped
description: Bennie Cunningham, a former first-round draft choice who played tight end on two Super Bowl championship teams, has been waived by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Fruehauf Suit By Edelman
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, filed suit today against the Fruehauf Corporation, charging its officers broke their trust to stockholders by refusing to consider his $1.1 billion takeover offer.

title: MEESE DENIES POLITICAL MOVE FOR A JUDGESHIP VOTE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today denied reports that the Justice Department had been involved in political horse-trading in its handling of the troubled nomination of Daniel A. Manion to a Federal appeals court in Chicago.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS SALE TALKS REPORTED
description: Donald C. Burr, the president of People Express Inc., has become persuaded that the airline should be sold as a whole and has met with the Texas Air Corporation and United Airlines, a source close to the talks said yesterday.

title: U.S., in U.N., Defends Aid to Anti-Sandinistas
description: Telling the Security Council ''we have the evidence of Sandinista aggression,'' Vernon A. Walters of the United States used multicolored charts, shipping records and photographs today to defend military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: SCOUTING
description: Just before Phil Niekro and Don Sutton hooked up last Saturday night, becoming the first pair of 300-game winners to face each other in this century, the California fans were treated to the eighth game in the Equitable Old-Timers Series, the traveling show of former big-leaguers that is touring all the major league parks this year.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COMNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After pre-tax charges totaling more than $1 million representing balance sheet writedowns, losses in excess of gains on investments in other companies and charges for discontinued programs and facility at Ford Laboratories for the latest year, and the previous year is after $748,000 in tax benefits. c-After a tax benefit of $158,000. The company said the latest quarter results include a settlement with Rand Information Systems involving the payment to Comnet of $106,000 in cash plus $50,000 in two-year interest- bearing notes.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION UPHELD BY HIGH COURT AS A REMEDY FOR PAST JOB DISCRIMINATION
description: The Supreme Court today firmly endorsed the use of affirmative action in the workplace to cure past discrimination against minority groups when other approaches would not work.

title: Accounts
description: * MSG Network to the Grey Entertainment and Media subsidiary of Grey Advertising.

title: Standard Oil Seeks To Sell Four Units
description: The Standard Oil Company, continuing an aggressive reorganization, said yesterday that it would sell four industrial products businesses.

title: Tenneco Notes
description: A $250 million financing by Tenneco Inc., through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company, produced a yield of 9.06 percent. The notes, due Jan. 15, 1997, carry a 9 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 99.60. Noncallable for life, the notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: Philadelphia Strike Threatens Festivities
description: Trash piled up on streets as 14,000 municipal workers struck for a second day today, and one union leader vowed to turn the city's Fourth of July festivities into ''an unpleasant situation.''

title: No Celebrations For Some Immigrants
description: Tomorrow, amid a good deal of hoopla, we will rededicate the Statue of Liberty, one of our most cherished national symbols. Yet even as the fireworks go off in New York Harbor, thousands of refugees seeking asylum in this country will be languishing in detention centers, awaiting consideration of their cases by the Immigration and Nationalization Service.

title: Arco Debt Rating Cut
description: The rating on $6.9 billion of debt issued by the Atlantic Richfield Company has been lowered by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: RECITAL: JOHN WALKER ORGANIST
description: JOHN WALKER inaugurated the annual Riverside Church summer series of organ recitals Tuesday night with a program of French and American music, subtitled - as is the style these days - ''A Musical Salute to the Statue of Liberty.''

title: PANEL SAID TO SUPPORT HARPER
description: A Federal investigation into a racial-discrimination complaint filed against the Boston Red Sox by Tommy Harper has upheld the former player and coach's charges.

title: DECISION MAY HALT ITS EFFORTS TO DISMANTLE EMPLOYMENT PLANS THAT SET RACIAL GOALS
description: The Supreme Court's rulings today on affirmative action amount to a rejection of the policies and arguments that the Reagan Administration has been advancing for six years in the field of civil rights.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map yesterday with a Washington dispatch on politics and state legislatures described the political makeup of the Vermont Legislature incorrectly. Power in its two houses is divided between the Democrats and the Republicans.

title: Networks of Another Sort
description: Long before ''networking'' became an art form in politics and business, school ties counted, and they still do.

title: Clear the Air for Nonsmokers
description: Mayor Koch's Committee on Smoking and Health suggests that he soften some of the rules by which he proposed to isolate cigarette smokers throughout New York City. But it makes all too clear why rules are needed.

title: A GEORGE CARLIN SPECIAL ON HOME BOX OFFICE
description: EVEN George Carlin, always reasonably misanthropic, isn't immune to fashion. His latest comedy special for Home Box Office, which late-night viewers can catch at 2 A.M. tomorrow, opens with one of those elaborate production routines that have become the latest wrinkle in pay-cable's packaging of stand-up comics.

title: Advice, Consent and Education
description: The President and the Senate have no constitutional responsibility greater than that of jointly appointing the Supreme Court Justices. President Reagan has obviously taken great care in selecting his nominees. In discharging the duty to render ''advice and consent,'' each Senator must now satisfy himself not only of the nominees' intellectual power, legal distinction and personal integrity but also of the wisdom of the nominees' constitutional vision.

title: GOODWILL SPONSOR DENIES ISRAEL BAN
description: A charge that Israeli athletes are being barred from the Goodwill Games in the Soviet Union was denied today by an official from the event's sponsor, the Turner Broadcasting System.

title: FIREFIGHTERS V. CLEVELAND
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in the case of Local Number 93, International Association of Firefighters v. City of Cleveland. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. presented the Court's opinion, with which Justice Sandra Day O'Connor concurred. Justice Byron R. White dissented. Another dissent by Justice William H. Rehnquist was joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. FROM THE OPINION

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. DETROIT TIGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 6 P.M. (Television -SportChannel 6 P.M. and 10:15 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: METS WIN, 4-3; TIGERS 8, YANKEES 3
description: The Yankees used a new third baseman - Dave Winfield - last night, and they may soon have a new pitcher because Ron Guidry, who suffered his seventh consecutive loss, very likely will wind up on the disabled list.

title: Fire on Cruise Ship
description: A blaze engulfed the generator room of the cruise ship Daphne in the Inland Strait about 80 miles southwest of Juneau today, but none of the 701 passengers and crew were hurt, the Coast Guard said. The ship was on a 340-mile cruise from Skagway to Ketchikan.

title: WEEKEND NOTEBOOK; SPINOFFS, A PAINT-IN, IMMIGRANTS FOR A DAY
description: They all laughed. That was back in 1984, when Mervin Bendenwald gave up his antique store and furniture stripping concession - and what could be more lucrative in Greenwich Village? - to sell Statue of Liberty souvenirs.

title: Plane Maintenance Company Suspended by the Air Force
description: The Hayes International Corporation, a major aircraft maintenance contractor for the Air Force and Navy, was suspended today from receiving new Government contracts because of what the Air Force alleged were ''serious irregularities'' in its business dealings.

title: DANCE: DANISH SOLOISTS TROUPE HONORS BOURNONVILLE
description: If August Bournonville is now a household name to any self-respecting balletomane, it is largely because of the tours undertaken by the group called the Soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 'GONE WITH THE WIND': ATLANTA'S BIGGER REALITY
description: Here in Atlanta, where Margaret Mitchell wrote ''Gone With the Wind,'' and down around Jonesboro, where her family owned a cotton plantation and slaves before the Civil War, the air is thick with feeling for the book, some of it fond and some of it not.

title: Prices Mixed; Trading Light
description: Prices in the Treasury market were mixed yesterday in light trading that was largely unaffected by either the latest domestic economic news or comments from West German and Japanese officials who again insisted their central banks have no intention of lowering discount rates.

title: Abdominal Gains
description: Bill Morris, a 38-year-old vice president for Shearson Lehman Brothers, plans to do 20,000 sit-ups next Thursday to raise funds for the Make-a-Wish Foundation, which provides gifts to terminally ill children. Morris has been billing his feat, to be undertaken at a spa in Paramus, N.J., as an assault on a world record for performing sit-ups without intermittent rest.

title: STEET METAL WORKERS' PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today upholding a Court-ordered affirmative action plan for a sheet metal workers local in New York City.Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the opinion, joined by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. concurred in part and joined in upholding the lower court's orders. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor concurred in part and dissented in part. Justice Byron R. White dissented. Justice William H. Rehnquist, joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, dissented separately. From the opinion

title: LENDL IS EXTENDED IN BEATING MAYOTTE
description: After 3 hours 28 minutes of trading serves that often appeared to travel faster than the eye could see; after pounding volley upon volley past each other for five sets in tennis's version of a barroom brawl, Tim Mayotte finally issued what amounted to a concession speech this evening. With two match points against him, he reached for a forehand that Ivan Lendl had deftly placed at his feet and tried to hit a drop shot. A white towel would not have been more symbolic.

title: El Paso Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has placed the cross-country and track power Texas-El Paso on probation for three years, meaning that the men's teams in those sports will be banned from N.C.A.A. championship meets in the 1986-87 and 1987-88 academic years.

title: A SAIL TO MANHATTAN FOR JERSEY COMMUTERS
description: In two weeks commuters between the Jersey Shore and lower Manhattan will have a new way to get to work: a 45-minute boat ride that will drop passengers off within a block of Wall Street.

title: THE DANCE: POOH KAYE AT AMERICAN FESTIVAL
description: Pooh Kaye returned Monday night to the American Dance Festival, where she and her Eccentric Motions company have performed for three summers now, in a program of new and recent dances that raised questions in a way that seems to come naturally to that venerable modern dance festival. One watched, it seemed, an active probing of the viability of choreography-by-committee and of the conscious development of style.

title: Don't Touch That Dial I
description: Television lights can be addic-tive to the practicing politician.

title: E.S.M. Case Conviction
description: The former president of the collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. was convicted today of conspiracy and 16 counts of mail fraud. The same Federal court jury acquitted another former E.S.M. executive of all counts.

title: PANEL ON MILITARY GIVES FINAL REPORT
description: With a plea from its chairman for simplicity in Federal regulations and honesty in military contracting, a Presidential commission charged with reforming the Pentagon's management published its final report today after a year of deliberations.

title: A PROFILE OF AMERICANS 85 AND OLDER
description: A private study of Americans age 85 and over has found that 9.3 percent of them live alone despite disabilities lasting for six months or longer. In fact, more people in this age group live alone than in homes for the elderly or other institutions, according to Dr. Charles F. Longino Jr., director of the Center for Social Research in Aging at the University of Miami.

title: BIAS IS CALLED A FACTOR
description: Three Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday and charged with the killing a 20-year-old man who was beaten and stabbed while riding a bicycle in Coney Island in May. The police said racial tensions were a factor in the killing.

title: TESTIMONY CITES PLAYER COSTS
description: The subject of player costs dominated testimony yesterday in the United States Football League's antitrust trial against the National Football League. One witness for the N.F.L. testified that competition from the U.S.F.L. caused a rapid escalation in N.F.L. salaries in 1983 and another testified that a former U.S.F.L. owner spent himself out of the league.

title: Angels Discover Antipunch Cards
description: Unruly, intoxicated, fist-throwing baseball fans have become a not unfamiliar sight at big-league parks, where the only tools of restraint are usually ushers and security personnel. Now Anaheim Stadium has thrown the power of high technology into the mix.

title: A Sinking Fund In Penney Issue
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest non-foods retailer, is selling $200 million of 30-year sinking-fund debentures, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures, due in 2016, carry a 9 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 96, to yield 9.40 percent. Noncallable for 10 years, the debentures are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

title: Iowa Agency Branching Out
description: Young & Rubicam's regional agency, Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zerbel of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, is making the unusual move of opening offices of its public relations division in New York and San Diego.

title: Technology; Fireworks By Computer
description: FOR more than a year, Felix Grucci and his former classmate at C.W. Post College, Scott Raso, revised and edited a computer program, working out scores of ''bugs.'' Tomorrow night, in front of millions of spectators jamming lower Manhattan and the shores of Brooklyn and New Jersey, they plan to see if it works.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Q&A
description: Q.About 11 years ago we added batts of insulation on top of the blown-in insulation that was already in place on the attic floor. We put the insulation down with the vapor barrier facing up, but I have read in some of your columns that the vapor barrier should be facing down. What happens if it is left facing up? A.It's not a question of which way the barrier faces; it's a matter of whether it is on the bottom or top of the insulation. It should always be on the side of the insulation that is warm (heated) in cold weather - which in your case means the bottom of the insulation.

title: Continental Air Plans Payments
description: Continental Airlines will begin making cash payments to 90 law firms, accounting companies and other concerns in the next 60 days, following a bankruptcy judge's award of an estimated $15 million in outstanding fees.

title: Reagan Signs Measure For Catchall Spending
description: President Reagan signed a $1.7 billion catchall spending bill today, saying it provided urgently needed money but complaining that several of its provisions infringed on the powers of the executive branch.

title: Amfac Expects Quarterly Loss
description: Amfac Inc., which has interests in wholesaling, food processing, retailing, hotels, sugar processing and real estate, said it anticipates a loss in its second quarter ended June 30.

title: 2 MULTIPLE KILLERS IN FLORIDA RECEIVE STAYS OF EXECUTION
description: Gerald Eugene Stano came within two hours of the electric chair today before the Florida Supreme Court stayed his execution indefinitely.

title: The Right to Remedy, Affirmed
description: What a civics lesson the Supreme Court has given President Reagan heading into Liberty Weekend: America not only aspires to a color-blind society, it remains committed to achieving it.

title: Colossus, Rekindled
description: Nearly 2,300 years ago the people of Rhodes hailed the lifting of a siege by raising a colossal statue of Helios, the sun god. He stood by the harbor, shielding his eyes with one hand, for only a few decades until toppled by an earthquake. Four centuries later he was broken up for scrap and carted off on camels. Yet the Colossus of Rhodes still stands immortal, not because we know what he looked like, but because he is fodder for even the frailest imagination.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 14
Interests of the Adopted
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Libya Said to Find U.S. Flight Recorder
description: The Libyan press agency said today that the flight recorder of an American fighter bomber shot down during the raid on Libya had washed ashore.

title: OLD AND NEW LALIQUE GLASS
description: IN honor of the publication of ''Lalique Glass,'' by Nicholas M. Dawes (Crown Publishers, $25), Barneys New York is offering antique and modern glass from Lalique, on display through July 9. Rene Lalique (1860-1945) was first a jeweler, but in the 1890's he began to experiment with glass, eventually producing vases, chalices, wall panels and lighting fixtures as well as highly sculptural bottles for Coty perfumes.

title: Strike in Philadelphia Closes Museum of Art
description: A strike by city workers has closed the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where the first major retrospective of Diego Rivera since his death in 1957 has been on view.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE RANCH HOUSE
description: THE ranch house in America was so popular after World War II that, in retrospect, it seems to have been a grass roots development. But architectural historians trace its invention to a single architect - and he is alive, well and living in his own sprawling ranch house in California.

title: FOR THE WHITE FARMERS IN ZIMBABWE, ALL'S WELL
description: Winter's deep blue skies have come here, to the fields just north and east of Harare, where stalks bearing plump ears of corn wait to be harvested. For miles and miles, fields of corn, tobacco seedbeds, winter wheat and barley stretch toward the low hills of Shamva, fields owned by white farmers in a black land.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK; FOR 20,000 SAILORS, CITY OPENS ITS DOORS
description: ''Young man,'' an elderly woman said as she walked through Times Square yesterday and hailed a sailor. ''I love seeing all these snappy-looking uniforms in New York again.''

title: END FIGHT, POPE URGES COLOMBIA REBELS
description: Pope John Paul II, addressing a crowd put at more than half a million, appealed today to this country's guerrillas to lay down their arms and ''put an end to destruction and the deaths of so many innocents.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Lewis, a veteran defenseman, and Rich Preston, a right wing, have both rejected one-year offers from the Devils and become free agents without compensation. The Devils have also announced the signings of Timo Blomqvist, a free-agent defenseman who played out his option with the Washington Capitals, and Anders Carlsson, a center selected in the fourth round of last month's entry draft. . . . The Vancouver Canucks has given its captain, Stan Smyl. a multiyear contract after a season in which he scored 27 goals and had 62 points in 73 games. . . . Andre Harris, who led Indiana in rebounds and blocked shots last season, is academically ineligible to play basketball and has left the school. Harris attended a session of summer school that ended June 20 and was notified he had failed to retain his eligibility, said Jan Brown, a spokesman for the sports information office. . . . Wes Gardner, one of the pitchers the Mets sent to Boston in the offseason trade for Bob Ojeda, has a torn cartilage in his right shoulder and will be lost to the Red Sox for the rest of the season.

title: 5 KILLED IN CHILE ON THE FIRST DAY OF GENERAL STRIKE
description: Three people were reported shot dead in poor neighborhoods here as a nationwide strike got off to a violent start.

title: ERLY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary income of $2.5 million, or 94 cents a share, which reflects benefits from net operating loss carryforwards. c-Net loss Included in the latest year results is a $32,356,000 net gain on the sale of the company's olive business in October 1985. The 1985 results are restated for discontinued operations.

title: Walter Craig, Federal Judge; Named to Bench by Kennedy
description: Federal District Judge Walter Early Craig, who served on the Federal bench for more than 20 years, died of cancer Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 77 years and lived in Phoenix.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes non-cash charges of $5.7 million.

title: C.D.'s Off; Funds Rise
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to drift gently downward for the week ended yesterday, while interest rates on money market mutual funds rose slightly.

title: Of Thee I Sing
description: In a Washington taxi a few months ago I heard the driver talking on his two-way radio in a language unfamiliar to me. I asked what it was.

title: Reagan Signs Revision Of Military's Pensions
description: President Reagan signed legislation Tuesday overhauling the military retirement system, rewarding those who make a life career in the services and reducing pensions for those who leave early.

title: Firm Seized In California
description: California has seized control of an investment firm that it charged with violating securities laws and making fraudulent claims to clients who had invested at least $60 million over the last few years.

title: Market Place; The Battle For Associated
description: THE price climb in the stock of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation since the June 20 takeover bid by May Department Stores is viewed as evidence that the ultimate takeover price will go higher, whether May is successful or not, analysts say.

title: Citicorp Investment Picks Merger Chief
description: The Citicorp Investment Bank, a unit of Citicorp, has named Robert H. Whitby to a newly created position as global head of mergers, acquisitions and divestitures, the bank announced yesterday.

title: CITY OPERA: BERNSTEIN'S 'CANDIDE'
description: THE New York City Opera is proud of its production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide,'' and rightly so. When it bowed in 1982, it served to validate this work as a legitimate part of the operatic repertory. It has proved steadily popular since, it has been recorded, and last night it opened the company's 1986 season at the New York State Theater. It will continue in a run through Sunday, and then return in November at the close of the season for yet another week, during which time it will be telecast live.

title: IMMEDIATE BAN SOUGHT ON USE OF A FARM CHEMICAL
description: New York and Maine joined a leading environmental group today and petitioned the Environmental Protection Agency to immediately prohibit farmers from spraying a potentially hazardous agricultural chemical on apples, peanuts and other food crops.

title: Cohn Asks Appeal Of Disbarment
description: Attorneys for Roy M. Cohn have asked for permission to appeal Mr. Cohn's disbarment, which was ordered by an appellate court in Manhattan last week.

title: REACTION MIXED IN CLEVELAND
description: A lawyer for the city's minority firefighters applauded the Supreme Court's approval today of the Cleveland's affirmative action plan for promotion of blacks and Hispanic firefighters, but the head of the firefighters' union vowed continued opposition.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings are based on 152,983,612 shares for the first 6 months of 1986 and 150,263,478 shares for the first 6 months of 1985. The company said that year-ago quarter and 6 months benefited from a $28 million, or approximately 10 cents a share, fire insurance settlement.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Standard Inc. said it had completed the sale of the Mosler Safe Co. by its Security Products division and expects to record a second-quarter gain of more than $40 million from the sale of discontinued operations, including Mosler.

title: STAGE: SHAKESPEARE'S 'TWELFTH NIGHT' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: GIVEN Wilford Leach's record for brightening so many al fresco evenings with Shakespeare, as well as ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' anticipation about ''Twelfth Night'' was as high as the Belvedere Castle that shadows the hospitable Delacorte Theater. In addition, the show was headlined by that Oscar-winning actor, F. Murray Abraham, turning to Shakespeare and returning to comedy in the choice role of Malvolio.

title: BOATER'S SURVIVAL GUIDE FOR CROWDED WATERWAYS
description: With New York Harbor likely to be more jammed than ever, Coast Guard officials want to be certain that mariners know what they need to know so that every one ties up safely at home port after the celebration.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am inspired by the change currently taking place in our life.

title: It's Rickey, Quickly
description: The number of bases that 27-year-old Rickey Henderson has already stolen suggests that he'll top Lou Brock's major league career standard with ease and then hold first place in the record books for years. Here's how the most prolific base-stealers of the 20th century stacked up by the end of the last full season before they turned 28: Total...At 27; Lou Brock...938...220; Ty Cobb...892...485; Eddie Collins...743...371; Max Carey...738...316; Honus Wagner...722...170; Joe Morgan...689...155; Bert Campaneris...649...292; Rickey Henderson*...620...620; Maury Wills...586...57; Cesar Cedeno...550...397. *Through Tuesday night.

title: Woman, 21, Slain In Marble Hill
description: The body of a 21-year-old woman with her throat slashed was found on a landing leading to the roof of an apartment building in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan yesterday, the police reported.

title: SOVIET PAPER DEPICTS A 'HAPPY' MOLOTOV AT 96
description: Almost 30 years after he was expelled from the Soviet leadership, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, once one of Stalin's aides, has been portrayed in a Moscow newspaper as a sympathetic 96-year-old great-grandfather enthusiastic about the changes taking place in Soviet society.

title: TARDY SHIPS DISAPPOINT TOWNS ALONG THE HARBOR
description: It was not all fair winds and following seas today for the communities on Long Island Sound that had volunteered to be hosts for ships taking part in the Fourth of July celebrations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOWPLACE The Studio Museum in Harlem, handsomely headquartered in its own suavely modern premises at 144 West 125th Street (864-4500), has become one of the standard stops for our city's museum-hoppers. Its exhibitions, designed to put before the public eye art and artifacts of black America and of the African diaspora, attract not only the community it draws from but also busloads of art lovers from city and suburb, who come to look and learn in the large duplex gallery.

title: Strike by Aluminum Workers Ends as Union Accepts Cuts
description: The steelworkers monthlong strike against Alcoa, the nation's largest aluminum producer, was settled late Wednesday when local presidents approved a cut of about 95 cents an hour in benefits, the union said.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL TERMS COURT'S RULING A 'DISAPPOINTMENT' AND 'UNFORTUNATE'
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, said that the Supreme Court's twin rulings on affirmative action today were ''disappointing'' and ''extremely unfortunate.''

title: Bargaining on Arms: A Glimmer of Motion
description: ''There are no breakthroughs,'' an American official said of recent Soviet arms-reduction proposals.

title: CLASSIC EVENINGS BY STAVROPOULOS
description: THE model in the silver and white dress carried a book in her right hand and held a champagne glass aloft in her left. She bore a startling resemblance to the Statue of Liberty and the audience attending George Stavropoulos's fall fashion show at the Regency Hotel laughed appreciatively.

title: Philippine Official Preparing For Communist Truce Talks
description: A Government official met today with members of the Communist Party to prepare for cease-fire talks aimed at ending a 17-year-old insurgency.

title: SCOTT CABLE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $361,000, or 12 cents a share, gain on sale. c-Includes gains on sale of $698,000, or 27 cents a share, and $978,000, or 37 cents a share, on quarter and year, respectively.

title: BONN BALKS AT SPURRING ECONOMY
description: The West German Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, issued an unusually stern rebuttal today to demands that Bonn should do more to stimulate its economy, arguing that increased public borrowing would yield only ''a short-lived economic boom.''

title: Topics; Tastes and Sounds of Summer: Eating Central Park
description: Picture the woolly sheep or the brindled cow moving majestically across a meadow, lowering its head only for an occasional tug at a succulent patch of grass.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $57,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $30,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S.-Taiwan Talks Stalled
description: Trade officials from the United States and Taiwan failed to reach agreement on limiting Taiwan's textile exports at their second round of talks in Washington, and have scheduled another meeting later this month, Taiwan's chief trade delegate said.

title: Rise in World Growth Seen
description: Despite the debt crisis, the world economy is set to grow by a modest 3.5 percent in 1986, and 3.7 percent in 1987, a United Nations survey said today. The growth would come on the heels of disappointingly slow expansion last year and a spurt of growth in 1984.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 3, 1986
description: International

title: HERS
description: THE kid marches into the lobby of the Rodeway Inn just outside of Wichita, Kan., soaking wet and mad as a serpent. Hailstones have wrecked her carefully done hair, great rain splotches have drenched her pink taffeta strapless bridesmaid's dress with the petticoats and full skirt. Her face is swollen with tears, shed and unshed. She half-trots back into the room where they will be holding the wedding reception. ''Don't touch me!'' she sobs rhetorically to her date, but he has no intention of touching her and hangs back prudently, at least 10 steps behind her female rage.

title: Don't Touch That Dial II
description: Orders are brisk for the ''Guide for TV,'' a booklet produced by the Senate Republican Policy Committee to help viewers follow the parliamentary maneuvers of the chamber, which sometimes cry out for an N.F.L.-type diagram.

title: U.S. and Vietnam Pledge To Find the Missing
description: The United States today gave Vietnam its first written commitment to support Hanoi's plan to resolve, within two years, the issue of Americans missing in action since the Indochina war.

title: Denial of Jobless Benefits Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that states may deny unemployment compensation to workers who help finance a strike that causes them to be laid off, even if they are not themselves on strike.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL SHIFTS FOREIGN POLICY EMPHASIS
description: Sidestepping the specific issue of Nicaragua, a Democratic Party policy group has drafted a report that combines low-key criticism of the Reagan Administration's foreign policy with a tough line toward the Soviet Union.
