title: 3-Year-Old Boy Dies After 2 Heart Implants
description: Baby Nicky, a 3-year-old Texas boy who underwent two heart transplants in two days last month, died of lung failure today with his parents and two sisters at his bedside.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 5-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 11.

title: MARY B. MATHEWS
description: Mary Burchell Mathews, a longtime patron of the arts, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Wainscott, L.I.

title: JUDGE RULES OUT DRUG TEST PLAN FOR CITY POLICE
description: A state judge barred the city's Police Department yesterday from conducting random drug tests of police officers, calling the testing an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.

title: MITTERAND VISIT RENEWS FRIENDSHIP
description: French and American officials are portraying President Francois Mitterrand's two-day visit to New York, which begins today, as primarily a ceremonial occasion. They hope the trip will help erase any lingering resentment among Americans over France's refusal to permit United States jets to fly over French territory during the April raid on Libya.

title: NASA SET TO ALTER FAULTY JOINT IN SHUTTLE ROCKET
description: The space agency said today that it planned to modify the flawed rocket joints that caused the loss of the space shuttle Challenger rather than carry out a radical redesign or elimination of the whole joint.

title: American Brands Up $5
description: Shares of American Brands Inc. soared $5 in heavy trading yesterday, to $98.50, amid recurring speculation that the cigarette, liquor and insurance company - already worth $5.4 billion - was once again a takeover target.

title: JAZZ: TRIO BACKS UP STAN GETZ
description: STAN GETZ is such a consistently provocative and polished tenor saxophonist that the musicians who accompany him are apt to become an anonymous background, noticeable only if they are giving Mr. Getz less than the support he deserves. The trio playing with him at the Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street, through Sunday - Kenny Barron, piano, George Mraz, bass and Al Foster, drums - not only gives him superb backing but also manages to make individual statements that challenge Mr. Getz as the focal point of the group.

title: Stephens Enters 2 Stars
description: Two Belmont Stakes winners will run for the price of one tomorrow when the Woody Stephens-trained entry of Creme Fraiche and Danzig Connection heads a field of six in $250,000-added Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Greetings Corp., Cleveland, has appointed William E. Schmitt senior vice president and president of the American Greetings division.

title: What Cocaine Can Do to Your Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN HELD IN LEBANON IS FREED
description: An American missing in Lebanon for 10 months and believed to have been held by drug traffickers has been freed unharmed and handed over to the United States Embassy in a Beirut suburb, according to reports today.

title: IRANIANS RECAPTURE BORDER TOWN, TURNING BACK 6-WEEK IRAQI DRIVE
description: Iran has turned back a six-week-old Iraqi counteroffensive, retaking a strategic border town and driving Iraqi forces back to their own territory, according to reports from both sides reaching here today.

title: A'S NAME LARUSSA MANAGER
description: Tony LaRussa, dismissed as manager of the Chicago White Sox 12 days ago, agreed today to take over as manager of the Oakland A's, who have lost 5 straight games and 23 of their last 28. LaRussa was given a multiyear contract.

title: METS WIN, 4-3; GOODEN GETS ALL-STAR NOD
description: The Mets surged 11 1/2 games in front in the National League's East tonight when they beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, for their sixth straight victory and the Cardinals' sixth straight loss.

title:
DESIGN BOOKSHELF;
INSIDERS' VIEW OF INTERIORS OF THE PAST 4:9>
description: FOR those who like to pry into the ways people live or have lived (and who doesn't?) three recent, lavishly illustrated books open doors and windows and present different views of what might be called ''the good life.''

title: FINAL TOUCHES FOR MISS LIBERTY
description: Fatigued but exultant crews worked through the night applying last touches on the Statue of Liberty: bathing her stone, polishing her metal and grooming the shrubs at her feet.

title: PACT REACHED IN ALBANY ON ENVIRONMENTAL BONDS
description: Governor Cuomo and state lawmakers, rushing to end the 208th session of the Legislature, reached agreement Wednesday night and early this morning on a series of measures, including a $1.45 billion bond issue to pay for cleaning up the environment, stronger laws to combat organized crime and a requirement that new school buses be equipped with seat belts.

title: A Job for Clark Kent
description: To the Editor:

title: Tallying Navy Women, Ship to Shore
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. sees brighter, broader horizons for women if his plan to promote them and to allow more of them to serve at sea is enacted.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SOME recently introduced products can help speed up or simplify home repair and improvement projects. Surface Wiring System

title: Topics; Tastes and Sounds of Summer: That Beats the Band
description: The small Connecticut town of Willimantic (pop. 15,000) had to cancel its Memorial Day parade because no local band could be found to march in it. The possibility that the same silence might ruin the Fourth of July horrified Cathy Clark, a onetime tootler in the West Hartford fife and drum corps who works in the Willimantic housing department.

title: ITT IN $1.8 BILLION SALE OF BUSINESSES TO FRENCH
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell control of its telecommunications and office equipment businesses to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, a state-owned French conglomerate, for $1.8 billion.

title: JERSEY WOMAN CHARGED WITH HOLDING EX-MENTAL PATIENTS AS SLAVES
description: A New Jersey woman was indicted by a state grand jury yesterday on charges that she held three women as slaves and kept two others locked in their rooms for almost eight years at an unlicensed boardinghouse she operated.

title: Justice Dept. Delivers Injustice to AIDS Victims; Positive Means Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: Beatrice Aide May Lead Bid
description: Joel E. Smilow has spent the last 19 months in and out of the top position at Beatrice's consumer products segment.

title: FARM CREDIT SYSTEM SEES $600 MILLION LOSS
description: The Farm Credit System predicted today that it would have losses of at least $600 million in the second quarter of the year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on June 19 about Roy Innis's candidacy for the House of Representatives misstated the position of Abraham Hirschfeld, a developer and can-didate for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor. Mr. Hirschfeld praised Mr. Innis and embraced him at a news conference to announce the House race, but did not endorse him.

title: SEAGOING SYMBOLS OF GRACE AND POWER GATHER FOR HISTORY
description: Sailing is a lonely and dangerous business, one ship out for long months fighting wind and weather on the vast, unsteady surface of the sea. Ships rarely rendezvous, but when they do, when a great number of them are summoned to a particular port for a particular reason, it is like a meeting of a large and far-flung clan and few sights can match it for celebration or spectacle.

title: MARCOS AIDE IN U.S. INQUIRY
description: Benjamin T. Romualdez, a former Philippine Ambassador and brother-in-law of Ferdinand E. Marcos, is scheduled to appear Monday before an Alexandria, Va., grand jury investigating possible fraud in a Pentagon contract.

title: Landlord Given Prison Sentence
description: A former New York City police lieutenant was sentenced yesterday to serve one and a half to four and a half years in prison for harassing tenants in four apartment buildings he owned in Manhattan.

title: More in South Africa Are Said to Be Seized
description: A South African news photographer who worked for Agence France-Presse was arrested in Cape Town yesterday, the agency said.

title: Justice Dept. Delivers Injustice to AIDS Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: 780 DETAINED BY PRETORIA FACE CRIMINAL CHARGES
description: The South African Government announced today that it had prepared criminal charges against 780 of the thousands of people held under the emergency decree imposed June 12.

title: PRIVATE GROUP PREPARES HOUSING FOR HOMELESS
description: New temporary housing will be created for nearly a quarter of the city's 4,100 homeless families under a plan announced yesterday by a private, interfaith group.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about diet books incorrectly quoted Dr. Barbara Levine, an assistant professor of medicine and director of the Nutrition Information Center at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, regarding the Rotation Diet. She referred to the diet as a whole, not just its 600-calorie phase, when she said it is ''a little bit restrictive.'' Dr. Levine believes the 600-calorie phase is ''totally deficient.''

title: SIR IAIN SUTHERLAND
description: Sir Iain Sutherland, a British career diplomat, died Tuesday after collapsing with a heart attack in a London subway station.

title: HAGLER'S SURPRISE PUNCH
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler was late for his announcement at Christo's restaurant, but then he's late for everything. And anyway all the boxing people knew what he was going to announce: That he would defend his undisputed world middleweight title against Sugar Ray Leonard on Nov. 6 if Leonard accepted $5 million to his $10 million and if Leonard agreed that Bob Arum would be the promoter. Or if Leonard didn't agree to those terms, then he would accept Thomas Hearns as a challenger again. And when Hagler finally appeared in a black suit with a red tie over a white-collared black shirt, his shaved head glistening, cameras flashed and Arum stepped to the microphone to introduce the 32-year-old gladiator.

title: Miss L. and Rambo
description: Because it's her 100th birthday, Miss Liberty is called upon more than ever this year to symbolize Independence Day and the nation. A combination of the calendar, French-American politics, commerce and the enduring importance of dreams is transforming the annual celebration into a gigantic spectacle.

title: MEDICAL ASSOCIATION ACTS TO TIGHTEN BARRIERS TO INCOMPETENCE
description: The American Medical Association has begun what it describes as a major new effort to improve procedures for disciplining incompetent doctors.

title: Burroughs-Sperry
description: The integration of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation is proceeding more smoothly than expected and earlier estimates of efficiency savings of $150 million in the first year now appear to be conservative, W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman of Burroughs, said. He told a news conference that since the $4.8 billion merger was completed 35 days ago, management of both units had identified an unexpectedly large number of areas in which competitiveness could be increased.

title: DISMISSED AIR CONTROLLERS DESCRIBE EFFECTS OF STRIKE
description: Most air traffic controllers dismissed by the Federal Government in August 1981 now have jobs with substantially lower wages and status but also less stress, a report to be published next month says.

title: Software Account To Bozell, Jacobs
description: The Boston office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has gotten the account of Cullinet Software of Westwood, Mass., a leading supplier of software for mainframe computers. The company, formed in 1968, has annual sales of $200 million and does business in 35 countries.

title: SCREEN: PRINCE IN 'CHERRY MOON'
description: FOR all those out there who can't get enough of Prince, ''Under the Cherry Moon'' may be just the antidote. In addition to starring in the part of a gigolo-piano player in gilt threads who finds love, the rock celebrity who likes to dress up also directed and collaborated on the music. (His album, ''Parade: Music From 'Under the Cherry Moon' '' was released in March, so the movie, which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, can be thought of as incidental pictures.) It's in black and white - you know, homage to the B films of the 1940's; well, maybe B-minus - and is set on the French Riviera, as conceived by a fan of fan magazines. Everybody in the glitter set seems to love Chris, the gigolo, though not as much as he loves himself. He falls for a poor little rich girl (Kristin Scott-Thomas, who turns in quite an appealing performance under the circumstances), and after some awkward banter, she falls back. He speaks execrable verse to her to prove his sincerity. But her ruthless father is put off by seeing his lovely daughter in the arms of this peculiar young man, as what sane father would not, and in the end Prince is able to direct himself in a death scene.

title: 3 MORE ARE GIVEN PROBATION IN ALIEN SMUGGLING
description: A Federal district judge today suspended the sentences of the remaining three defendants convicted of illegally smuggling Central American aliens into the country.

title: 'MIKADO' ON A&E NETWORK
description: IF we may speak of a golden age of bel canto and a golden age of Romantic pianism, we may also pinpoint a golden age of Gilbert and Sullivan. It comes to life in the grand D'Oyly Carte recordings of the 1920's. The voices captured therein are not always lustrous in themselves and they are rarely operatically trained, but there is a sense of style, teamwork and sheer giddy joy that has never been duplicated.

title: LECONTE TOPS CASH FOR SEMIFINAL BERTH
description: There were no wristbands or headbands tossed to the band of squealing girls that adopted him as their favorite. Pat Cash left Centre Court fully clothed, pausing to bow to the Duke and Duchess of Kent in the Royal Box. The improbable story Cash had been writing at Wimbledon was ended three chapters short of completion by Henri Leconte of France in what was perhaps the most entertaining quarterfinal match of the day.

title: COURT'S QUOTA RULING ENDS A 38-YEAR BATTLE
description: For Herbert Hill, the decision yesterday by the United States Supreme Court to uphold affirmative-action quotas for a New York union local culminated a legal battle that began 38 years ago.

title: Thrift Figure Gets 30 Years
description: Jeffrey A. Levitt, former owner of old Court Savings and Loan, signed over all of his property to the state today and was sentenced to 30 years in prison for stealing $14.7 million from two Maryland thrift institutions.

title: CHERNOBYL CLOUD KEEPS WELSH LAMB OFF TABLE
description: Radioactive rain from the Soviet nuclear disaster at Chernobyl has so befouled the green highlands around here that what the Welsh call the ''oen'' - the lamb - is now under Government protection from slaughter until the last traces of fallout are gone.

title: SHANKER PRESSING FOR SHIFT IN UNION
description: Continuing to press for a shift in emphasis for the American Federation of Teachers, the union's leader, Albert Shanker, said today that he would focus the attention of the convention opening here Thursday on what happens in the classroom rather than on what results from the bargaining table.

title: A 2,000-MICROPHONE MAN
description: It was last November that Laurence H. Estrin was asked to oversee the sound system for Liberty Weekend, and the call caught him working in Oman.

title: FRANK B. JEWETT JR.
description: Frank B. Jewett Jr., founder and president of Technical Audit Associates, a company that provides technological analyses for corporations, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, aboard his boat in Vineyard Haven, Mass. He was 69 years old and lived in Vineyard Haven and New Caanan, Conn.

title:
GARDENING: CITY;
WHAT TO DO IN JULY
description: AT summer's start, city gardens tend to be lush and luxuriant. They will remain so only if gardeners stay vigilant through the season.

title: WASHINGTON SEEKING WAYS TO USE LEVERAGE
description: In beginning a new policy review on South Africa, the Reagan Administration is pursuing two possibly contradictory goals: to block moves in Congress for drastic economic sanctions against Pretoria, and to heighten pressure on the South African Government to begin high-level interracial negotiations for abolishing apartheid.

title: NEW DATA LINKED TO TERROR PLOTS
description: The recent arrest of a Jordanian student in Genoa, Italy, may provide important new information on the terrorist operation that led to the United States bombing of Libyan cities April 15, senior Italian judicial officials said today.

title: Boesky Has 9.9% of Retailer
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, disclosed today that he has purchased 9.9 percent of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

title: ESPLANADE RECALLS OLD NEW YORK
description: PEOPLE at the Battery Park City esplanade tomorrow will watch the Fourth of July parade of ships on the Hudson River from ground that seems surprisingly familiar. Completed three years ago, the long walkway brings to mind the old parks, streets and squares of New York. The new lampposts were cast from originals in Central Park; the lamp heads were adapted from traditional city luminaires; the elegantly hooked street lamp - the bishop's crook - once lined most of Madison Avenue, and the benches are the same as those used in parks throughout the city.

title: BATH AND SHOWER: SOME ACCESSORIES
description: A COMMON way to organize the bath and shower is to slip a white, vinyl-coated steel caddy over the shower head. Kraus Hardware, 1127 Third Avenue, at 66th Street, carries a large shower organizer by Selfix with three shelves that holds shampoo, soap, razors and other things.

title: KEY DESIGNER OF B-17 BOMBER
description: Edward C. Wells, one of the Boeing Company's engineering stars, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Bellevue, Wash. He was 75 years old.

title: APPEALS PANEL DENIES U.S. MOTION IN NAVY ESPIONAGE SUSPECT'S TRIAL
description: A Federal appellate court panel today refused to block a trial judge's jury instruction in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth.

title: WHAT TO DO IN JULY
description: GARDENERS should be on the alert to help their plants survive the dry days of summer, especially in communities that have water restrictions. Mulches - organic covers on the cultivated ground - keep soil moist and cool while preventing the growth of weeds.

title: 2 Friends Recall Bias's Last Hours
description: Terry Long and David Gregg, roommates of Len Bias, said it never occurred to them that someone could die from cocaine use. In an interview off-camera with WRC-TV, Long said: ''It never occurred to me that someone might die.

title: CBS BROADCAST GROUP SAYS IT WILL CUT 700 JOBS
description: CBS, citing dramatically slowed growth in television advertising revenue, will eliminate 700 jobs in the CBS Broadcast Group, executives said yesterday.

title: JERSEY AIRSHIP CRASH SAID TO HAVE ENDED PROJECT
description: The crash of a nine-story-high experimental airship here Tuesday night has ended the project, a Federal official said today.

title: QUESTION IS WHETHER TO ACCEPT LIMITS ON RESEARCH AS PART OF A SOVIET DEAL
description: Recent Soviet initiatives at the Geneva arms talks have stirred a debate within the Reagan Administration over whether it is prepared to accept limits on its antimissile research program in return for cuts in strategic arms. Up to now, the United

title: A SHOW HOUSE WITH SUMMER CACHET
description: Ah, summer in Southampton. The Mercedes-Benzes are here. The hydrangeas are here. And at the fourth annual Rogers Memorial Library Designer Show House, another telltale sign of summer - the work of nearly three dozen decorators - is here.

title: DeBusschere Arrested
description: Dave DeBusschere, the former Knick star and front-office executive, was arrested late Tuesday night on a charge of driving while intoxicated, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The 45-year-old DeBusschere, who lives in Garden City, L.I., was arrested at 11:34 P.M. Tuesday on Mulberry Lane in West Hempstead, L.I. He pleaded not guilty before County Court Judge Herbert Lipp and was released pending a court proceeding July 30.

title: Bridge: Display of Strength Forces A Cautious Opening Lead
description: Most people would admit, if they are honest, that their approach to a stranger may be modified if they are aware that he has great wealth.

title: Advertising; The Fourth Generates Big Plans
description: IF there is an event around at which it is possible to entertain, you can bet you'll find media people with advertising prospects in tow. And since this Fourth of July weekend is turning out to be the granddaddy of such events, it has generated some big thoughts among wine buyers.

title: Turkish Prime Minister Visits Northern Cyprus
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal arrived here today, the first visit by a Turkish head of Government to the breakaway Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

title: Q-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Boeing Order
description: Union de Transports Aeriens has decided to order two of the Boeing Company's 747-400's to cover such long-distance routes as Paris to Singapore, an airline spokesman said. The new version of the 747, which has not yet been built, will require only two crew members in the cockpit instead of the three now needed on most long-distance flights. The planes will cost about $128 million each, and the first one will be delivered in early 1989.

title: FOLK HERO FOR THE 80'S: LEE ANTHONY IACOCCA
description: Two July Fourths ago, Leo-Arthur Kelmenson and a few hundred others were cruising by yacht from Manhattan to Liberty Island to celebrate the start of rehabilitation of the Statue of Liberty when a few people realized that the most celebrated of those celebrating, the man who was organizing the entire statue rehabilitation effort, the fellow whose deep eyes, dominant nose and no-nonsense jaw would have been recognized by everybody, was missing.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Keeper of the Agricultural Keys
description: Draft horses outnumbered tractors and six million farms produced the nation's food in 1937 when Wayne Rasmussen left the high plains of south-central Montana to come to Washington to join the Department of Agriculture and chronicle the Roosevelt Administration's efforts to restore economic health to American farming.

title: School Suspension Is Partway to Dropping Out
description: To the Editor:

title: SAMBITO POSTS SPECIAL SAVE
description: When the game was finally over and the fans in Fenway Park could smile again on their way home, the pitcher went out of his way to retrieve the last ball he had thrown. Joe Sambito had just earned his seventh save in a season that, for him, very nearly did not happen. His save had protected Tom Seaver's first victory with the Boston Red Sox. This was one baseball Sambito had to have.

title: Head of Brazil to Visit U.S.
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil has accepted an invitation from President Reagan to make a state visit Sept. 10, the White House announced today.

title: YACHTS AND NAMES CROWD THE HARBOR
description: Don Johnson's secretary called the Coast Guard the other day to ask if the ''Miami Vice'' star could have a patrol boat shuttle him to several yacht parties over the weekend. The answer was no. Among the galaxy of the rich and famous cruising around the isle of Manhattan this weekend, Mr. Johnson is just another pretty, stubbled face.

title: HIGH COURT SHIELDS U.S. IN RECREATION ACCIDENTS
description: The Supreme Court today shielded the Government from being sued over recreational accidents at Federal dam and flood control sites.

title: CALENDAR: PATRIOTIC EXHIBIT
description: Patriotic Folk Art Exhibit, Susan Parrish Gallery, 269 West Fourth Street, 212-645-5020.

title: Pengo in Accord With Its Lenders
description: Pengo Industries, an oilfield services company based in Fort Worth, said it had reached a permanent agreement with its secured lenders for restructuring $144 million of debt.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NEW SCHOOL: A History of the New School for Social Research. By Peter M. Rutkoff and William B. Scott. Illustrated. 314 pages. Free Press/Macmillan. $22.50.

title: Dead Pair Were Wanted
description: A couple killed Sunday when their pickup truck went off the south rim of the Grand Canyon were wanted in California on sexual abuse charges and committed suicide, the authorities said. The couple, Richard McMillan, 50 years old, and Laura Lynn Allen, 30, Lancaster, Calif., were accused of molesting Ms. Allen's 9-year-old daughter and 8-year-old son.

title: First Chicago Names Officer
description: The First National Bank of Chicago has hired as its new head of credit policy a former executive vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank who was dismissed by that bank after it acquired more than $200 million in loans from the failed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma. First Chicago has nominated

title: EXPLOSIONS OF TWO ROCKETS VIEWED AS RANDOM FAILURES
description: The explosion of an Air Force Titan rocket in April and the loss of a NASA Delta rocket in May were apparently caused by random failures, not major design flaws, officials said today. But they said the incidents pointed up a need for increased quality control and backup systems.

title: ALL OVER TOWN, ALORS, IT'S VIVE L' AMITIE
description: IN some parts of New York City this week, it almost seems as though French is being spoken more than any other language, while the red, white and blue of the French tricolor ripples alongside that of the Stars and Stripes. With exceptional enthusiasm, the French have joined in the Liberty Weekend celebrations: balls, receptions, lunches and dinners, artistic presentations and professional discussions, harbor cruises and open-air concerts are all on the festive agenda as New York Francophiles and the city's French community join with guests from Alsace, Paris and other parts of France to salute the 100th anniversary of You Know Who.

title: DOWNTOWN IS AWAITING THE HORDE
description: Whether a heartless invasion or a heartfelt embrace awaits the people of lower Manhattan, they are planning as best they can to meet their imponderable weekend fate.

title: European Students See Us as a Threat to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Record for the Dow: 1,909.03
description: Stock prices reached record levels for the third day in a row, but the advance lacked the conviction that Wall Street might have liked.

title: Match, Dad?
description: Osvaldo Sabatini, nervous-wreck father of Gabriela Sabatini, right after her quarterfinal Wimbledon victory over Catarina Lindqvist: ''I smoked half a pack of cigarettes, and ate the rest.''

title: 2 U.S. CREWS LOSE <
description: Racing began on a Wednesday for the first time in the 147-year history of the Henley Royal Regatta today.

title: BINGHAM CASE: TRIAL YIELDS NO ANSWERS
description: How did a 9-millimeter pistol get into San Quentin Prison on Aug. 21, 1971, and start a 30-minute outburst of violence that left six people dead?

title: LIBRARY GROUP CONFERS ON VEXING ISSUES
description: The 105th annual conference of the American Library Association ends this afternoon in New York, after wrestling for six days with questions of pressures from ''sanctimonious citizens,'' intellectual freedom and the future of library financing. The theme was ''Saluting the Past -Charting the Future,'' and it seemed certain to the librarians that the future would include some of the same problems that have vexed them for decades.

title: Congress; Of Rocking the Cradle And the Legislative Boat
description: A long and painful labor appears to be in store for the effort in Congress to develop a national policy on leaves for parents with newborn or newly adopted babies.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 3, 1986
description: The Economy

title: EUROPEANS, U.S. EASE TRADE RIFT
description: The United States and Europe declared a six-month truce today in their most serious trade dispute in decades and said that a permanent settlement looked promising.

title: Promotions For Two Executives
description: From Dallas comes word that C. Anthony Wainwright, 53 years old and already president of the Bloom Companies of Dallas, has additionally been named chief operating officer with expanded duties that will see him in New York more often.

title: The U.N. Today; July 3, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on complaint by Nicaragua against the United States at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: WORLD BANK HOPES TO TAP JAPAN FUNDS
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., the new president of the World Bank, said today that the institution was exploring ways to recycle Japan's global trade surpluses, projected this year at nearly $60 billion, to provide more growth capital for debtor countries.

title: BLUE JAYS STOP CLEMENS AT 14
description: Roger Clemens's 14-game winning streak ended tonight when George Bell's tiebreaking, bases-loaded single off the reliever Bob Stanley highlighted a three-run eighth inning that gave the Toronto Blue Jays a 4-2 victory over the Red Sox.

title: Parting Shot
description: Pat Williams, who recently resigned as general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers, on his relationship with Harold Katz, the team's owner: ''I wanted to give him something to symbolize our association, but I couldn't get an ulcer framed.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Science Watch column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly described the drug captopril. To treat high blood pressure, the drug inhibits production of hormones that cause constriction of blood vessels and direct the kidney to retain salt and water.

title: Westchester
description: Following is a selection of events taking place in the metropolitan region during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: A CULTURAL SAMPLER OF LIBERTY FESTIVITIES
description: The following is a sampling of some of the cultural events related to the Liberty Weekend festivities. Unless otherwise noted, all events are free.

title: BUSH, AT N.A.A.C.P., ATTACKS PRETORIA
description: Vice President Bush today called on the South African Government to begin negotiations with the black leadership toward the establishment of a ''multiracial and truly democratic society - the sooner the better.''

title: Sledgehammer Infractions at Dartmouth
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Europe Assails Trade Pattern
description: RICOCHET effects in trade are intensifying global protectionist pressures, adding a fresh note of urgency to the need for Japan to open its market to more imports from the rest of the world.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
On Succeeding Reagan
description: As the Heritage Foundation has appeared to be playing an increasingly influential role in the Reagan Administration, politically minded Washingtonians have been examining its quarterly journal, Policy Review, more closely for portents. The summer issue carries a ''symposium'' of seven prominent conservatives on the question: ''Who Should Succeed Reagan?'' And the results provide new insight into current rightwing preferences for 1988.

title: Marketing of Statue Affects Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: CAFFERTY EXHIBITION AT HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: NOW that 19th-century academism is back in fashion, its devotees no longer have to cloak their admiration in irony. All the same, justifying the scholarship that such art needs in order to hold the ground gained calls for some critical adjustments. Proposed by ''Domestic Bliss,'' a survey of American genre painting at the Hudson River Museum, the most ingenious of these is that, though it was aimed straight at the public appetite for sentimentality, anecdotal art often shows signs of social and psychological awareness.

title: Going to Court
description: Fifty-one weekends out of the year, Lowell, Mich., 15 miles east of Grand Rapids, is a quiet little place of 3,500 people. Then the hoop-crazed hordes come to town.

title: Janus Films at 30
description: A celebration marking the 30th anniversary of Janus Films continues this weekend with screenings of foreign films at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. Today and tomorrow there will be two films by Federico Fellini - ''Amarcord'' and ''The Clowns.''

title: DANCE: 'NEW CHOREOGRAPHERS'
description: NINE new works were presented Wednesday night on the program called ''New Choreographers '86,'' one of the events in Clark Center's ''Summer Dance '86'' festival at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. The dances had interesting moments. But those moments did not always add up to form satisfying wholes.

title: Diner's Journal
description: PATRIOTIC fervor from the Fourth of July weekend will glow all month at Cafe Chardonnay, the handsome little wine bar on East 73d Street between First and York Avenues, where an engaging American Wine Festival is under way. The first week of the festival, starting tomorrow, features selected American wines from top vineyards; they include the 1980 Edna Valley Chardonnay ($3.25 for a 2 1/2-ounce taste, $6.50 for a 5-ounce glass) and the 1971 Mayacamas cabernet sauvignon ($6 for a 2 1/2-ounce taste, $12 for a 5-ounce glass).

title: 'Hardesty House,' New Lawyer Series
description: There is no discernible law and heaps of visible disorder in the new lawyer series ''Hardesty House,'' a drama that appears tomorrow at 10 P.M. on ABC.

title: MANDLIKOVA BEATS LLOYD, 7-6, 7-5
description: For two weeks, Chris Evert Lloyd tottered on the baseline at Wimbledon, very close to stepping off on the wrong side of the score. Blame it on the draw, Mrs. Lloyd said, which read like the work of a prankster. But there were other factors involved, too, including a reputation to live up to, a misbehaving serve and groundstrokes that constantly strayed. Her tennis was a series of great escapes worthy of Houdini.

title: Nicaragua Says Foes Kill 32 With a Mine
description: A land mine destroyed a truck carrying passengers in northern Nicaragua, killing 32 people, including 12 children, the official Voice of Nicaragua radio reported today.

title: SPRINGSTEEN WITH A BRITISH ACCENT
description: As darkness fell on lower Manhattan and streets were closed to traffic, streams of tourists poured out of subway stops and into the narrow streets of the financial center, where they could be part of a special night.

title: Dow Off 8.16, to 1,900.87, In a Quiet Trading Day
description: Stock prices ended lower yesterday in slow pre-holiday trading as futures-related activity eroded the value of many stocks.

title: CLEVELAND DIVIDED AFTER COURT'S RULING
description: A day after the United States Supreme Court upheld an affirmative action plan that for three years has pitted blacks against whites in the Cleveland Fire Department, the divisions are as stark as ever.

title: 51 WINNERS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY
description: Several weeks ago, Mary Ellen Ruppert stood before her fourth graders and made an announcement as big as any ever heard at St. Maria Goretti School in Madison, Wis.: 10-year-old Jason Verhelst had won the state's Statue of Liberty essay contest.

title: THE NOT-SO-OPEN ROAD AS VACATION TIME STARTS
description: America's holiday highway season, a war to some, a joy to others, has begun.

title:
LET THE TORCH CAST TRUE LIGHT ON OUR IMMIGRANT STORY;
Held at Bay By the Beauty Of the Bay
description: I will certainly be in good company this Liberty Weekend, what with all those swells who paid $5,000 a throw to sit in the specially built grandstands aboard the battleship Iowa, along with President Reagan and his entourage, as the ship rides at anchor from a good vantage in New York Harbor. Other thousands - perhaps more than a million people - will be along the shores of New York and New Jersey.

title: Boschwitz's 'Nifty Idea'
description: In some offices on Capitol Hill, some constituents are more equal than others. Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Minnesota Republican, has developed a priority system for classifying his mail to make sure important communications - well, communications from important people - are not lost in the shuffle.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AT&T Technologies Inc., Berkeley Heights, N.J., is being awarded a $55.3 million Army contract for classified electronics, the Defense Department said.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA PRESS FINDS JOB PRECARIOUS
description: Roberto Sanchez is among several hundred people who are losing their jobs after the closing of La Prensa, the opposition newspaper.

title: THE DANCE: MCKERROW AS JULIET
description: AMANDA MCKERROW is a surprising performer. One expects a poetic lyricism to color the characters she plays in story ballets. But there was also a chilling power to her portrayal of the jealous Gamzatti in a performance of ''La Bayadere'' presented by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House this season. And Miss McKerrow's Juliet offered a similar revelation when the company presented Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan.

title: Don't Stop Tourism To South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson River Photos
description: Fifty-eight photographs by Robert Ketchum are on display in an exhibition called ''The Hudson River and the Highlands'' at the Bear Mountain Inn Gallery in upstate New York. It will be on view daily through July 27 from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Admission is free, but there is a $2.50 fee for parking up to 5 P.M. To get there, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to the Palisades Interstate Parkway north to its end and Route 9W south a short distance. Information: (914) 786-2701.

title: 800 CAR DEALERS SALUTE LIBERTY AND IACOCCA
description: The scene in Upper New York Bay yesterday seemed one of almost biblical proportion.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12wks to May 20
Books: Blue and Gray
description: WHY THE SOUTH LOST THE CIVIL WAR. By Richard E. Beringer, Herman Hattaway, Archer Jones and William N. Still Jr. Illustrated. 582 pages.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE are some neighbors who carry neighborliness just a centimeter further than most - but what a centimeter!

title: French Agree To Trade Pact
description: France agreed today to go along with the trade agreement announced Wednesday between the European Community and the United States, according to diplomats here, who said the French position made it almost certain that the accord would get the formal backing of the community's ministers next week.

title: MITTERRAND URGES SPACE COOPERATION
description: President Francois Mitterrand, in New York for Liberty Weekend ceremonies, called yesterday for cooperation between France and the United States to resolve problems with space launchers and on other joint projects in space.

title: Lenehan Wins 2
description: Rain forced postponement of all jumper classes at the 10th annual ''I Love New York'' Horse Show today, but in a limited schedule of hunter competition, Brian Lenehan of Westport, Conn., won two blue ribbons.

title: HOROWITZ CHARMS TOKYO CRITICS
description: As Japanese music critics see it, Vladimir Horowitz has transformed himself from ''a cracked antique'' into ''an incomparable magician.''

title: DISCOVERY OF FARTHERMOST QUASAR HINTS AT MORE ON COSMOS'S FRINGE
description: Discovery of the most distant object yet observed in the universe, a quasar 73 billion trillion miles from Earth, might indicate more exist at the fringes of the cosmos and force a change in scientific thinking, researchers say.

title: Hudson Valley
description: Following is a selection of events taking place in the metropolitan region during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: LIBERTY AT 100: SYMBOLISM IS EVER FRESH
description: Nearly a century ago, and continents away, a young Armenian prepared to leave for America. The craftsmen of his village, too old to join the journey, sent a gift with him. It was a traditional silk rug, bearing the image of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Citrus Canker Found In Florida Grove
description: State agriculture officials said today that canker, a disease that damages trees and fruit, had been found in a mature, producing Florida citrus grove for the first time in nearly 60 years.

title: LIGHT FROM LASERS
description: With the eyes of America on its most cherished symbol of freedom, the city and the nation rededicated the Statue of Liberty in a blaze of light last night, marking its centennial as a beacon of hope in New York Harbor.

title: S I HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
REPORT SHOWS U.S. WAS OUTVOTED IN THE U.N. THROUGH MOST OF 1985
description: The United States Mission issued a report today that it said showed that most of the world voted against the United States most of the time during the 1985 United Nations General Assembly session.

title: CAPE TOWN BLAST INJURES 2 WHITE POLICEMEN
description: Two white police officers were slightly wounded today when a bomb exploded at a Cape Town police station, the South African Government said.

title: ARISTEK COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Southwestern Bell Computer Plans
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said that it was seeking Federal approval of plans to provide businesses a less expensive way to transmit computer data by interweaving it with regular telephone calls or other customers' transmissions. By using telephone company computers to translate data from one computer language to another and send it in small bursts along regular telephone lines, customers can save the costs of having specialized equipment and private lines to each point to which they send data.

title: Ranger Sale Accord
description: Eddie Chiles has agreed to sell his controlling interest in the Texas Rangers to Gaylord Broadcasting Company of Dallas, the team announced yesterday. Gaylord acquired one-third of the stock in the Rangers as well as broadcasting rights in February 1985.

title: RAPT CROWDS VIEW STATUE'S RELIGHTING
description: Huddling against a stiff wind, thousands of people packed the Battery Park promenade last night to watch as the rededicated Statue of Liberty was gradually bathed in a brilliant white light.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available due to July fourth holiday * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MEXICAN PARTY RUNS SCARED IN JUAREZ
description: Jaime Bermudez, the candidate for mayor of Ciudad Juarez, across the Rio Grande from El Paso, spent this afternoon working the crowds outside the factories in the Bermudez Industrial Park here during the shift changes.

title: Why the Times Square We All Love and Hate Has Got to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Thoughts for the Fourth of July; His Last Request
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption yesterday under a drawing of Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, with articles about the Supreme Court, described the scene incorrectly. She was discussing a securities law case, not an affirmative action case.

title: 'WE DARE TO HOPE FOR OUR CHILDREN'
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Reagan's remarks prepared for delivery last night on Governors Island before the relighting of the Statue of Liberty, as issued by the White House:

title: PROGRESS CITED BY U.S. IN JAPAN CHIP DISPUTE
description: The Reagan Administration today provisionally suspended a major anti-dumping case against the Japanese semiconductor industry, reflecting what it called ''mutual concurrence on a large number of provisions'' of a semiconductor pact between the two countries.

title: Ringing In the Fourth
description: Washingtonians awaiting the national fireworks display over the Mall tonight can sample a variety of Independence Day observances. The National Archives will enliven Constitution Avenue at 10 A.M. with music by the Third U.S. Infantry Fife and Drum Corps, a cannon and musket fire demonstration by three reconstituted Revolutionary War regiments in uni-form and a dramatic reading of the Declaration of Independence by Rob Coles, a great-great-great-great-great-grandson of Thomas Jefferson.

title: How to View the Statue
description: The Statue of Liberty, 305 feet of stone and steel and copper, is the most monumental of monuments. Yet what she symbolizes best is movement. Liberty shimmers under the overlay of one symbol after another. She was nominally intended, a century ago, to bespeak French-American friendship. But what the sponsors really had in mind was a colossal political statement, to shore up fragile republican sentiments in France.

title: TOM OFFENBURGER
description: Tom Offenburger, an aide to Mayor Andrew Young and a former spokesman for the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, died Wednesday at Emory University Hospital, where he had undergone surgery Monday to replace two valves in his heart.

title: DIVI HOTELS NV reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A GEMUTLICH VIENNESE CAFE
description: Cafe society, by its very nature, is ephemeral, but in the case of one breezy new open-air cafe in New York, it is ephemeral by design.

title: BIG BOARD ENDS EQUAL VOTE RULE
description: The directors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to abandon a decades-old rule that gave all of a public corporation's shareholders equal voting rights. Instead, companies traded on the exchange will have the right to issue classes of common stock with unequal voting rights.

title: U.S. Crews Gain In 2 Close Races
description: Two of the heralded American entries were almost beaten by teams with lesser credentials in second-round elimination races of the Ladies' Challenge Plate today at the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Union Halts Some Talks On Pact With U.S. Steel
description: Local union presidents today began a two-week break from talks with the United States Steel Corporation, dashing company hopes of a new contract by Friday.

title: The Most Unfortunate Immigrants
description: It's an appropriate coincidence that at a time when the nation is celebrating its immigrant heritage the Supreme Court should have issued its important decisions upholding race-conscious remedies in certain cases of employment discrimination against minority groups.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAYS TOP RED SOX; BARFIELD CLOUTS 21ST
description: Jesse Barfield and Rance Mulliniks each hit two homers tonight in lifting the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Pope on Videotape
description: The religious roots of liberty were celebrated yesterday at a mass of thanksgiving at St. Patrick's Cathedral that included a videotape greeting from Pope John Paul II.

title: NL Industries
description: The NL Acquisition Corporation said it had commenced its previously announced offer to purchase ''any and all shares'' of NL Industries for $15.125 a share. NL Acquisition was created by the Dallas investor Harold Simmons to acquire the outstanding stock of the New York chemical and oilfield services company. Mr. Simmons, through three concerns he controls, already owns 20.4 percent of the company. The tender offer, which is being contested by NL Industries, will end at midnight, New York time, on July 31.

title: INVESTIGATION IS SOUGHT
description: Two human rights organizations called yesterday for an investigation of reports that a military patrol in Santiago had set fire to two teen-agers, one of whom is a permanent resident in the United States.

title: Uprooting Bias at Agriculture
description: When the Reagan Administration, not exactly a tiger in civil rights enforcement, finds violations in its own ranks, a pretty bad state of affairs can be presumed. Conditions in the Agriculture Department must be awful.

title: China Public Relations
description: China's first public relations firm began operating today, promising to promote economic activities among China's regions and to act as a bridge with foreign businessmen.

title: JUDGE SETS ASIDE THE CONVICTION OF A MAN IMPRISONED FOR 6 YEARS
description: A judge yesterday set aside the murder and robbery convictions of a 26-year-old Brooklyn man who has spent the last six years in state prisons steadfastly maintaining his innocence.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''I'M frequently offered a lot of money to kill people on screen - to pump up in a gym and blow people away, and I eagerly look for scripts that offer me an alternative.''

title: 'AT THE PRICE OF YOUR OWN BLOOD'
description: Following are excerpts from an unofficial translation of President Mitterrand's remarks last night on Governors Island:

title: RULE OF ADVERSE DRUG REACTIONS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today issued a requirement that adverse reactions to prescription drugs in use before 1938 be reported to it.

title: PORNOGRAPHY PANEL BARRED FROM PUBLICIZING RETAILERS
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Attorney General's commission on pornography not to publish a list of retailers identified as distributors of pornography, saying the list was a potentially unconstitutional ''threat'' to stores selling adult magazines.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell by $315.3 million, to $223.54 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Arch of Probability
description: To the Editor:

title: STEERING COURSE TOWARD A RENDEZVOUS IN THE HARBOR: GETTING TO KNOW AMERICA
description: Shortly after the Sagres 2 from Portugal dropped anchor here Wednesday, a handsome cabin cruiser called Miss Jennifer ambled by to take a look at the white-hulled visitor.

title: NEW STUDY BACKS LINK OF OBESITY AND GENES
description: A study of thousands of male twins offers new evidence for the theory that genes can determine who gets fat and who does not.

title: REPUBLICAN HOPEFUL NAMED TO FILL TERM OF CAROLINA SENATOR
description: Gov. James G. Martin, a Republican, named Representative James T. Broyhill today to complete the term of United States Senator John P. East, who committed suicide Sunday.

title: FOR JAPAN, THE TREND IS DYNASTIC
description: At midday, dozens of the candidate's supporters came to the makeshift campaign headquarters, kicked off their shoes and sat on the straw-mat floors for a session of gossip and green tea.

title: France Begins Trial Of Lebanese Gunman
description: The trial of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, a Lebanese suspected of being an international terrorist, began in Lyons today.

title: TOURS FOR PEDALING OR RAFTING
description: The Pocono Whitewater Adventure Center in Jim Thorpe, Pa., which is only 110 miles from the George Washington Bridge, has expanded its schedule to include one-and two-day bicycle tours of the Lehigh River Gorge. These excursions are made on so-called all-terrain or mountain bikes - provided by the center - because most of the pedaling is on rural roads, trails and abandoned canal routes.

title: Edward G. Christianson Dies; Executive of Oil Corporations
description: Edward George Christianson, a petroleum engineer and executive of the Shell Oil Company, the Amarada-Hess and Petro-Lewis corporations, died of heart disease Saturday at Georgetown Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Washington, D.C.

title: RECORD FIELD SET FOR TOUR DE FRANCE
description: Silvano Contini seemed ecstatic when he checked in today for the Tour de France, completing the paperwork and undergoing a medical test before the world's longest, biggest and richest bicycle race begins Friday. A record number of riders - 210, or 30 more than ever before - will take part.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE FALLS TO 7.3%
description: New York City's unemployment rate fell to 7.3 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: AUCTIONS
description: COLLECTORS and dealers seeking to know which way the wind is blowing in the American folk-art field will be watching the bidding on an 18th-century rooster weathervane when it is auctioned next Thursday in Portland, Me. The gilded pine carving, described a decade ago by Dr. Robert Bishop, director of the Museum of American Folk Art, as the oldest American wood weathervane still in use, is expected to establish an auction record. The vane will be sold by F. O. Bailey in a dispersal of works from the folk-art collection of David Morse, a Portland stockbroker.

title: New Jersey
description: Following is a selection of events taking place in the metropolitan region during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: JAM AT FERRY, BUT CITY TRAFFIC IS LIGHT
description: The relighting of Miss Liberty's torch did not attract the expected traffic jams last night as thousands of spectators crowded subways and shuttle buses to reach viewing points.

title: TODAY
description: 9 A.M. - Opening Salvo President Reagan, aboard battleship Iowa, steams down the Hudson past a flotilla of warships, receiving 21-gun salutes.

title: BULLWINKLE AND PALS AT MUSEUM
description: In 1949, a pioneering cartoon serial produced expressly for television made its debut. It was called ''Crusader Rabbit,'' and the man who brought it to the screen was Jay Ward. Since then, almost all television cartoons have utilized the techniques Mr. Ward devised, and his original pieces are widely respected as masterpieces of the genre.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WINDOWS ON THE WORLD, perched a quarter of a mile above the ground atop the World Trade Center, poses a troublesome challenge to one of my long-held maxims concerning restaurants: that food quality varies in inverse proportion to a dining room's altitude (airplanes being the extreme example). Now nearly 10 years old, Windows on the World, the highest and grandest dining room of them all, has proved that being a serious restaurant and a sky-high tourist attraction are not mutually exclusive. The restaurant's performance is even more impressive considering that its expansive glass-enclosed dining rooms, seating 300, would probably be packed even if the kitchen served sauteed Spam and frozen pot pies.

title: TWO LOS ANGELES CLUBS FOR THE 'NEW ELITE'
description: The stampede to the newest restaurant can be so great here at times that one cannot make a reservation without giving the secret password. To get into a hot new ribs place in Beverly Hills a few years ago, otherwise sensible people were calling and saying, ''I'm a farkleberry.'' Something of the same frenzy now surrounds two new and exclusive nightspots - Helena's and Vertigo. Both serve food, but food is not why anyone goes.

title: Thoughts for the Fourth of July; Liberty Come to Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Confusion Still Accompanies Theory of Restricted Choice
description: The theory of restricted choice is a confusing subject for many, and merits a confusing quotation. ''A little learning is a dangerous thing,'' pontificated Alexander Pope.

title: ALICE AUSTEN'S VIEWS OF THE HARBOR
description: From the sloping lawn of her grandfather's home on the northeast coast of Staten Island, 20-year-old Alice Austen had a panoramic view of New York Harbor and the construction and unveiling 100 years ago of what was to become the nation's most renowned symbol.

title: CYNTHIA HARVEY TO SPEND A YEAR WITH ROYAL BALLET
description: A strange calm hangs over the backstage lobby of the Metropolitan Opera House, where a sign advises dancers to pack up their theater cases for storage until the winter season. American Ballet Theater's year draws to a close this weekend with three performances of ''Giselle,'' and plans are being made and goodbyes beginning to be exchanged.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NO lady has ever had quite so many parties thrown in her honor, quite so many Champagne glasses raised in toast, or so many pounds of caviar or tons of hot dogs consumed in her name as has the Statue of Liberty.

title: F.S.L.I.C.'s Reserves Fall
description: The reserves of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation fell by $1.06 billion in 1985, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Korean Accord Nearer
description: The International Olympic Committee asked North Korea today to spell out further demands for being co-hosts of the 1988 Summer Games after getting its conditional agreement to an offer by the designated host, South Korea.

title: Bonds Rise in Light Trading
description: Bond prices rose by half a point or more in light pre-holiday trading yesterday, an advance caused by additional evidence that the nation's economy growth is slowing dramatically.

title: REAGAN SAYS AQUINO WILL VISIT U.S.
description: The White House announced yesterday that President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines would visit President Reagan in September.

title: S.I. MEMBER OF PLANNING UNIT QUITS AMID INQUIRIES
description: The Staten Island member of the City Planning Commission has resigned amid investigations into possible conflicts between his official duties and his private law practice.

title: LAWYERS DELIVER DIFFERING VIEW OF EX-CITY AIDE
description: Prosecution and defense lawyers painted widely varying portraits yesterday of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, in opening arguments in the first trial related to the city's corruption scandal.

title: KUWAIT DISSOLVES ITS PARLIAMENT
description: The Emir of Kuwait, under pressure from the Persian Gulf war and falling oil prices, dissolved Parliament tonight and suspended several articles of the Constitution.

title: Brophy to Coach Leafs
description: John Brophy opened last season as an assistant coach with the Toronto Maple Leafs. He'll open the next one as head coach.

title: BID FOR HOMOSEXUAL-LAW REFERENDUM IS DROPPED
description: City Councilman Noach Dear dropped his campaign for a referendum on New York's new homosexual-rights law yesterday, saying that the United States Supreme Court decision Monday upholding a Georgia sodomy law had led him to shift strategy.

title: Rorer Plans Cuts
description: Rorer Group Inc. said it is considering the divestiture of its Armour Pharmaceutical Company subsidiary, which it recently acquired from Revlon Inc. Armour had sales of about $160 million in 1985. Rorer said it is seeking to obtain prescription or consumer pharmaceutical lines, possibly in an exchange, and might not sell Armour at all if it could not get an ''acceptable product stream'' or combination of products and cash for Armour, which markets strictly to hospitals. Rorer's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $41.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: FROM THE HARBOR TO THE END ZONE
description: To Americans who spent a portion of their youth playing football on corner lots, a quick reference to the Statue of Liberty brings memories not only of a torch-bearing lady in New York Harbor, but also of a deceptive play used by a wily football team in need of a long gain or even a quick touchdown.

title: Giants Sign Carlton
description: Steve Carlton, the four-time Cy Young Award winner released by the Philadelphia Phillies on June 26, has signed a contract with the San Francisco Giants for the remainder of the 1986 season, General Manager Al Rosen of the Giants announced last night. The 42-year-old left-hander, second on the career strikeout list with 3,982, was immediately named by Manager Roger Craig to pitch Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: JERSEY HAILS THE TALL SHIPS
description: A flotilla of yachts and power boats welcomed the tall ships today as they rode at anchor in Sandy Hook Bay, their bowsprits pointing toward Manhattan.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LYRICAL LEFT: Randolph Bourne, Alfred Stieglitz and the Origins of Cultural Radicalism in America. By Edward Abrahams. Illustrated. 265 pages. University Press of Virginia. $20. THE Greenwich Village writer

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $256,134 for the latest quarter, $239,626 for the 6 months, and $35,342 for the year-ago quarter. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $28,000. d-Includes income of $62,976.

title: DETENTION BEFORE TRIAL IS BARRED IN SOME CASES
description: A divided Federal appeals court, ruling in the case of the reputed Mafia boss Anthony Salerno, declared yesterday that it was unconstitutional to hold a defendant in jail before trial ''simply on the ground that he is likely to commit a crime.''

title: Steven Crist on Horse Racing; AT LONG LAST, CORDERO IS BACK ON TRACK
description: It wasn't much of a race: only two horses, one a 2-year-old from Puerto Rico with a 43-year-old rider recovering from injuries, the other a maiden 2-year-old with a rider who retired last year. But for the fans at Belmont Park yesterday, it was cause to cheer.

title: Longer Hours at U.S. Library
description: The Library of Congress, where budget cuts forced earlier closing hours in March, touching off protests and arrests, will return to its longer hours July 10, a spokesman said today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAID TO DETAIN 200
description: South African security forces detained more than 200 men and boys yesterday and evicted scores of women and children in a morning raid on two schools in a Cape Town suburb where people left homeless by recent violence had sought shelter, according to reports reaching the United States.

title: THE MAN AT THE HEAD OF THE SHIPS' PARADE
description: Some people might be anxious about leading the Salute to Liberty Parade of Sail today, Capt. Harrison McKay of the New York City Fire Department's Marine Company 1 conceded. But firefighters are not the nervous type, he said. If they were, they would probably not be so likely to rush into burning buildings.

title: Closest Shaves
description: If it's true that good teams win the close ones, then St. Louis and Los Angeles, last year's National League division champions, have become very bad teams indeed. Here's how all the clubs stood as of yesterday in games decided by one run: NATIONAL LEAGUE...W...L...Pct.; Mets...15...6....714; Montreal...18...9....667; Philadelphia...15...9....625; San Diego...17...14....548; San Francisco...13...12....520; Atlanta...12...12....500; Chicago...15...15....500; Houston...15...15....500; Cincinnati...12...16....429; St. Louis...12...20....375; Pittsburgh...8...14....364; Los Angeles...13...23....361; AMERICAN LEAGUE...W...L...Pct.; Boston...13...6....684; California...15...7....682; Baltimore...11...7....611; Cleveland...9...7....563; Texas...15...13....536; Yankees...14...13....519; Chicago...14...14....500; Toronto...13...13....500; Seattle...9...10....474; Detroit...9...11....450; Kansas City...11...14....440; Milwaukee...11...15....423; Minnesota...10...14....417; Oakland...8...18....308.

title: MERCHANTSBANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,546,000, or 64 cents per share, for the quarter and $1,976,000, or $1 per share, for the year due to the reduction of Federal tax expense through utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $264,000, or 14 cents per share, for the quarter and $631,000, or 39 cents per share, for the year due to the reduction of Federal tax expense through utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. The company said the 1985 results include an extraordinary credit consisting of a special preferred stock dividend received from Federal Home Loan Bank of Boston of $120,000, or 7 cents per share.

title: CURB VOTED ON GIFTS TO ESTIMATE BOARD
description: The State Legislature ended its 208th session today after a marathon nightlong meeting, passing an anticorruption measure aimed at New York City but failing to reach agreement on a plan to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly.

title: The Worm and the Apple; The Driver's License Breakdown
description: When a state licenses drivers, it obligates itself to make the licenses readily available. For its signal failure to meet that obligation in New York City, the New York Department of Motor Vehicles deserves an unusually large, unusually furry worm.

title: JULY 4 PROMPTS FILIPINOS TO PONDER U.S. INFLUENCES
description: In the Philippines, the Fourth of July is a holiday, too.

title: ART: 'VIENNA 1900: ART, ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN'
description: THE first thing to be said about ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture and Design'' at the Museum of Modern Art - and I mean it as a compliment - is that in its presentation it is not at all Viennese. Order, logic, clarity and proportion abound. The catalogue contains no gaseous rhetoric, no misconceived allusions to New York in the late 1980's, no claims of any sort that cannot be sustained. The role of faction, ever present in Vienna, has been abolished. Of acts of revenge, likewise a Viennese staple, there is never a trace. Ambitions are precise and well directed. Quality wins out over quantity, and history has no loose ends.

title: Hispanic Bid For 5 TV Units
description: A group of Hispanic investors joined the bidding for the Spanish International Communications Corporation, offering more than $250 million for the five television stations.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100-percent stock dividend, paid June 3, 1986.

title: TRANSFORMING LOWER MANHATTAN INTO 'LIBERTY LAND'
description: The million hot dogs?

title: Pact for Robertson
description: Alvin Robertson, the San Antonio Spurs all-star guard, has signed a six-year $3.6 million contract after a month of negotiations between Tom Sekalovich, Robertson's agent, and the Spurs' president, Angelo Drossos. ''Extending his contract solidifies our team and solidifies our backcourt from where it all starts,'' said Rob Bass, the general manager.

title: A GUIDE TO MUSIC IN CLUBS AROUND TOWN
description: Stan Getz Quartet, Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). Before Stan Getz was 20 years old, he had played his tenor saxophone in the bands of Jack Teagarden, Stan Kenton, Jimmy Dorsey and Benny Goodman, among several others. At 20, he was one of the founding brothers of the Four Brothers, the Woody Herman saxophone section of 1947, and since then has been consistently on top of the jazz world through be-bop, bossa nova and benign success. He will be at New York's newest jazz club - and one of its most pleasant -tonight through Sunday with a premier New York rhythm section: Kenny Barron, piano; George Mraz, bass, and Al Foster, drums. They play shows at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. each night for a $20 admission and two-drink minimum. Meanwhile, the great New Orleans pianist Ellis Marsalis, father of two outstanding young jazz musicians, the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis and the saxophonist Branford Marsalis, plays upstairs in the restaurant Joanna from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. tonight through Sunday for no charge except food or drinks.

title: Long Island
description: Following is a selection of events taking place in the metropolitan region during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: At Sanders, Engineer Is at Helm
description: While Mr. Schwartz of Loral got into the military business as an investor, his counterpart at Sanders, Jack L. Bowers, has spent his whole career in it.

title: ACROSS U.S., A CEREMONY FOR HISTORY
description: Under starlit skies, in view of a newly resplendent Statue of Liberty, Ron Ranvindran, Sadye Lee Vassil, Riva Sagalova, Thanh Tran, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Arman Amazallag, Samson Arshansky and Pirkko Antonopoulos became Americans last night.

title: JAZZ: WALTER NORRIS, PIANIST
description: WALTER NORRIS is a stunning jazz pianist whose visits to New York - and to the United States - are so fleeting that relatively few people are aware of him. He has lived for the past nine years in West Berlin, where he is a guest professor at the Conservatory for the Arts.

title: 5.3% Mattel Stake
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., has purchased 5.3 percent of Mattel Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Columbia said that it had acquired the shares for investment purposes and might seek to buy more shares or to sell its stake, depending upon market conditions.

title: PULIDO GETS HELP IN HIS FIRST VICTORY
description: The Yankees played to the crowd at Yankee Stadium last night and were an even bigger success than the rock 'n' roll show and the fireworks.

title: SHIPS OF ALL SIZES JOIN AD HOC ARMADA
description: Three great fleets moved on the city yesterday - sailing ships from the east, warships from the south and pleasure boats from every direction. Together, the Coast Guard said, they formed an ad hoc armada, about 25,000 vessels - from dark green kayaks bobbing in the East River to long gray aircraft carriers anchored in New York Bay.

title: PEANUTS LOWREY
description: Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey, who spent 30 years in the major leagues as a player and a coach, died Wednesday of congestive heart failure. He was 67 years old and had been hospitalized for the last seven weeks.

title: BUYER FOR SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN
description: Scientific American Inc., the publisher of the venerable monthly scientific magazine, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a West German publishing company for $52.6 million.

title: Harden to Stand Trial
description: The Denver Broncos safety Michael Harden was ordered yesterday to stand trial in Oakland County Circuit Court on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon in his car.

title: Steel Bankruptcy Effort
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has granted the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation 120 more days to submit a plan for reorganizing its business. Judge Warren Bentz also added six weeks - July 15 to Aug. 26 - in which creditors may file claims.

title: HAL ROACH STUDIOS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said that increase in revenues was primarily attributable to its videocassette division, which began operations in May 1985 and generated revenues of more than $2.5 million during the year, and to increased deliveries of Kids Inc. television series episodes which contributed over $1 million additional revenue.

title: BLUE CROSS TAX STATUS IS CHALLENGED
description: The differences between Blue Cross-Blue Shield health insurance plans and commercial health insurers may not be great enough to justify Blue Cross-Blue Shield's tax-exempt status, the General Accounting Office has concluded.

title: MINORITY HIRING RULING PUTS CONCERNS ON NOTICE
description: The Supreme Court decisions Wednesday endorsing the use of affirmative action in the workplace will not change the way most companies go about hiring minorities, but they do send a warning to companies that have been lax, according to experts and executives interviewed yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Santiago, Chile, in some editions yesterday about a nationwide strike misstated the number of reported deaths. Five people were reported killed - four in Santiago and one in Valparaiso.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;
description: Armed men held up a branch office of the Bank of France today, escaping after they forced employees to turn over an estimated $12.5 million in cash, authorities said.

title: CHILE AUTHORITIES ACT TO PROSECUTE LEADERS OF STRIKE
description: The Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, reacting to a general strike called by opposition groups demanding a return to democracy, brought charges of inciting disorder against the protest leaders and two magazine editors today.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: All United States stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Independence Day. Government offices, banks and most businesses will be closed. Four New York commodity exchanges - Mercantile, Commodity, Cotton and Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa - were also closed yesterday because of the Statue of Liberty celebration.

title: 'FASHION FROM VIENNA' SHOW
description: A very small show at the Austrian Institute might be seen as a complement to the ''Vienna 1900'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Called ''Wiener Charme, Fashion From Vienna 1914-1915'' - and consisting mainly of color plates by 25 artists associated with the designer collective Wiener Werkstatte - the institute's display runs through Aug. 29.

title: LLOYD ESPNSCHIED, ONE OF THE INVENTORS OF THE COAXIAL CABLE
description: Lloyd Espenschied, co-inventor of the coaxial cable, which paved the way for television transmission, died June 21 at a nursing home in Holmdel, N.J. He was 97 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: A Liberty Quiz
description: Questions 1. What is Miss Liberty's full name? 2. Describe what she is holding. 3. Which part of her was shown at the 1876 American Centennial Exhibition in Philadelphia? 4. Explain the role Charlotte Bartholdi played in her appearance. 5. Name the young engineer and bridge-builder who designed her inner structure, creating, in effect, the first skyscraper. 6. What is written on the book she holds in her left hand? 7. How did the architect Richard Morris Hunt, the first American graduate of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, provide her with a sure footing? 8. Who paid for her? 9. On which island in New York harbor was she placed? 10. In her honor, Emma Lazarus wrote a sonnet, which is engraved on a bronze plaque in the museum within the pedestal, titled ''The New Colossus.'' Why ''new''? 11. Where in Paris might you see her smaller twin sisters? 12. Name the short story that O. Henry wrote about her. 13. Seven spikes emanate from her diadem. What do they represent? 14. In which Alfred Hitchcock film is her right arm the setting for a gripping climax, in more ways than one? 15. Who takes care of her? 16. How did Irving Berlin, Robert E. Sherwood, Moss Hart and Jerome Robbins pay tribute to her in 1949? 17. Why might she have been named ''Progress Bringing the Light to Asia''?

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed the right-handed pitcher Scott Scudder, a first-round draft pick, and assigned him to Billings of the Pioneer League.

title: G.M. Scrapping Plans for Factory
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was scrapping plans for a $60 million plant to make plastic mini-van parts, a venture that was expected to create 1,000 jobs in Framingham by 1989.

title: Connecticut
description: Following is a selection of events taking place in the metropolitan region during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Dining Out Guide; Out of Town
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: First Bank System
description: The Treasury Department said First Bank System, a bank holding company based in Minneapolis, had agreed to pay a civil penalty of $248,160 to resolve allegations of currency transaction reporting violations. The Treasury said, however, that there was no evidence the bank had engaged in any criminal activity in failing to report 1,148 cash transactions of more than $10,000.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Thoughts for the Fourth of July
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPTURING THE FIREWORKS AND THE HOOPLA ON FILM
description: On land, on sea and in the air, Liberty Weekend offers a wealth of picture-taking possibilities, and to take advantage of them, you do not need a press pass or professional equipment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Tobacco Products Inc., San Antonio, announced the resignation of Edward C. Gardere and Edmund G. Vimond Jr. from the board of directors.

title: MEESE URGES CURB ON MEXICO CRITICS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, answering questions from Mexican journalists, said today that the time had come for American officials to stop ''pointing fingers across the border'' at Mexico.

title: FROM BASE TO TORCH, MISS LIBERTY GLOWS
description: At precisely 9:39 last night, in front of millions of television viewers and 4,000 invited guests who paid $5,000 a seat to be on Governors Island, President Reagan, choking back tears, pressed a button to relight the Statue of Liberty.

title: Publisher Began With Book Club
description: West Germany's Holtzbrinck group is the country's second-largest publishing group after Bertelsmann, the giant concern that owns Bantam Books and Parents magazine in the United States.

title: CABARET: MORGANA KING
description: WHERE most jazz voices can be likened to trumpets, saxophones or clarinets, Morgana King has cultivated a vocal sound that most closely resembles a jazz violin. Her refined, vaporous tone is so meticulously manufactured that at times it almost seems to be emanating from a source beyond the body.

title: JUNE 21-30 AUTO SALES ROSE 21.2%
description: Sales of new American-made cars rose 21.2 percent in late June from the comparable period of last year, a time when sales were soft. Light-truck sales were also up, the makers said today, by 10.5 percent.

title: EX-REP. JONATHAN BINGHAM, 72, DIES
description: Former Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, the veteran liberal Democrat from the Bronx, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: REPERCUSSIONS SEEN IN AFFIRMATIVE ACTION CASES
description: At least a dozen court cases around the country may be affected by the new Supreme Court decisions upholding the use of affirmative action as a remedy for discrimination in employment, according to Justice Department officials and civil rights lawyers.

title: At Loral, Investor Revived Company
description: Bernard L. Schwartz took over a faltering Loral Corporation 14 years ago, and built it into a successful military electronics manufacturer. Now he is attempting to expand Loral - by buying Sanders Associates Inc., a Nashua, N.H., company in the same business as Loral.

title: LADY LIBERTY AT THE BAT
description: Few melting pots bubble like the National Pastime, A social circle that's often been committed to rhyme.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, JULY 4, 1986
description: Liberty Weekend America rededicated the Statue of Liberty in a blaze of light, marking its centennial as a beacon of hope in New York Harbor. President Reagan ''unveiled'' the monument by triggering a 1.4-million-watt series of laser beams that shot a mile across the harbor and bathed the statue in successive stages of red, blue and white light. Then, after a program of music and dance, speeches and swearing-in ceremonies for new citizens, the statue's torch flamed into golden brilliance. [ Page A1, Columns 5-6. ] Three great fleets advanced on New York City - sailing ships from the east, warships from the south and pleasure boats from everywhere.
