The Coast Guard said they formed an armada of 25,000 vessels. [ B4:4-6. ] The scene in Upper New York Bay was dizzying as aircraft crowded the skies and vessels covered the waters from shore to shore. Into this swirl steamed the Queen Elizabeth 2, flying a 100-foot-wide American flag and carrying 800 Chrysler Corporation dealers. [ A1:6. ] Traffic was light in Manhattan but the lure of crossing New York Harbor for only 25 cents proved so great that the police had to board Staten Island ferries and order people to disembark. A throng of 20,000 had formed to await ferries at Manhattan's Battery Park when police officers started ordering passengers off and officials closed the ferries to cars. [ B6:4-6. ] The concept of the Statue of Liberty has always exceeded its physical presence. The icon is a global symbol of hope, freedom and opportunity for newcomers.

title: Judge Gesell Has It His Way, Without TV
description: In the solemnity of the Ceremonial Courtroom of the United States District Court, and without the ballyhoo of television, 98 foreign nationals from 41 countries took the oath of United States citizenship here this afternoon from Judge Gerhard A. Gesell.

title: THOMAS NELSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that approximately $3 million of the loss in the latest year was due to a tax assessment by the Internal Revenue Service relating to the company's operations in fiscal 1982.

title: Shamir Denies Role In Reported Cover-Up
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir has broken his silence on the security scandal, specifically denying that he was involved in a cover-up of the 1984 killings of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers.

title: Teddy Pendergrass Critically Hurt in Crash
description: The soul singer Teddy Pendergrass, who has been paralyzed from the waist down since a 1982 auto crash, was critically injured today when the van he was driving slammed into a telephone pole, a hospital spokesman said.

title: U.S. AND CAYMANS SIGN CRIME PACT
description: The United States and the Cayman Islands signed a mutual legal assistance treaty today in which they agreed to aid each other's law enforcement efforts in narcotics trafficking, money laundering, tax fraud, insider trading and securities fraud.

title: Moslems and Christians Join Strike in Lebanon
description: Moslems and Christians united in a general strike today, bringing most of the country to a standstill to show their concern over the continuing conflict in Lebanon and the country's worsening economic plight.

title: Alpha Setback
description: Alpha Industries said the Raytheon Company had canceled contracts for microwave components because the contracts were reportedly behind schedule and would attempt to recover costs and possibly damages. Alpha said the potential impact could exceed amounts it had already provided for the completion of the contracts, and as a result could cause auditors to qualify their opinion for the 1986 financial year. Alpha's stock slipped 87.5 cents, to $9.50 a share, in American Stock Exchange trading today.

title: TV FAVORED ON CENTENNIAL
description: Three-fourths of the American people say they plan to watch the Statue of Liberty centennial celebrations on television, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are the keepers of the flame of liberty; we hold it high tonight for the world to see.'' - President Reagan. [ B3:6. ]

title: LANE TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $85,000 for the quarter and $145,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 4, 1986
description: Markets

title: Musical Chekhov
description: A musical adaptation of Chekhov's ''Marriage Proposal,'' set to a Latin beat, will highlight a free, outdoor presentation this weekend at the Boat Basin Rotunda, 79th Street and the Hudson River.

title: Terrorism Forever?
description: Even if conflicts in the Middle East should be resolved, Americans should not expect the incidence of terrorism to decline, according to the Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies. Its new report, ''Combating Terrorism: A Matter of Leverage,'' cautions that terrorism will remain a serious international problem because ''it has become too useful a tool to be discarded easily by ethnic groups, nihilists or nation-states seeking political leverage.''

title: B.A.T. Sells More Stores
description: B.A.T. Industries of Britain said yesterday that it had sold the Frederick & Nelson department store chain in Seattle and three Crescent stores in Spokane, Wash., to G. Arthur Henkens, a former Frederick & Nelson chief executive, and two other investors. Batus Inc. of Louisville, Ky., the American subsidiary of B.A.T., did not disclose the price.

title: HOUSING SET FOR NEWARK NEWS BUILDING
description: In 1966, The Newark Evening News, which had long been New Jersey's most prestigious newspaper, installed 36 high-speed presses and added a wing to its 10-story headquarters. Altogether, the newspaper spent $12 million to upgrade its facilities.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DOWN IN JUNE, RETURNING TO 7%
description: The nation's jobless rate fell two-tenths of a point, to 7 percent, in June as the economy generated 25 percent more new jobs than new job seekers, the Labor Department reported today.

title: GORBACHEV PRAISED BY MITTERRAND
description: President Francois Mitterrand yesterday called Mikhail S. Gorbachev a ''modern man,'' the first the Soviet Union has had at the helm, a man with whom it was possible to negotiate an arms control agreement.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. WHITE SOX, at Chicago, 7 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 7 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Gorbachev's Brezhnev Doctrine
description: Whatever changes may be afoot in Soviet foreign policy, the notorious ''Brezhnev Doctrine'' has just been reaffirmed. Appropriately enough, Mikhail Gorbachev chose Poland as the site and the Communists who crushed the Solidarity rebellion as the audience for reiterating the Soviet declaration of Eastern Europe's non-independence.

title: 'ACCOUNTS,' SCOTTISH DRAMA
description: TELEVISION isn't all fireworks and Sousa marches this Independence Day weekend. Among the more quietly rewarding alternatives is a television movie entitled ''Accounts,'' being shown tonight at 11 on Channel 13. The presentation is part of a summer package showcasing productions from Britain's Channel 4.

title: FOR IACOCCA, A DAY OF ACCOLADES AROUND THE CITY
description: From the sidewalks of New York to the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, tourists, friends, millionaire contributors to the statue-rebuilding effort, and dozens of people who are themselves celebrities, seemed to come to the same conclusion yesterday, as did John Cardinal O'Connor in a special mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: 3 Held in Plot to Free Inmate by Helicopter
description: Three members of the Puerto Rican terrorist group Armed Forces of National Liberation were arrested here today on charges of plotting to free their leader from the Federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan., with a helicopter, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: RUDY VALLEE, 30'S SINGING IDOL AND 'VAGABOND LOVER,' DEAD
description: Rudy Vallee, whose twangy crooning style, aided by a handheld megaphone, made him a singing idol of the 1930's and 40's, died last night at his home in North Hollywood, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Chevron to Sell Its Stake in UNC
description: The Chevron Corporation has agreed to sell its entire 38.8 percent stake in UNC Inc. back to the nuclear component and shipbuilding concern, which is based in Annapolis, Md. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chevron said, as part of an April 30 agreement with UNC, Chevron has asked its two representatives on the UNC board to resign.

title: Reliance Capital Gets Blair Control
description: The Reliance Capital Group said yesterday that it had acquired a majority of shares of John Blair & Company, apparently ending a bidding war for the broadcast and mail marketing concern.

title: THE OUT-OF-TOWNERS TAKE MANHATTAN
description: The birthday party guests are arriving, singly and in battalions.

title: ULSTER PIANIST, 26, WINS COMPETITION IN MOSCOW
description: Barry Douglas, a 26-year-old from Belfast, Northern Ireland, delighted Soviet audiences with his strength and artistry at the piano and took the top prize today in the eighth Tchaikovsky competition. Russian music fans who had packed the great hall of the Moscow Conservatory to await the results burst into cheers when Andrei Eshpai, the Soviet chairman of the jury, announced the winner of the grueling three-week contest after the jury had deliberated for nearly three hours.

title: METS WIN ON 2 HOMERS IN 10TH
description: Ray Knight had struck out the first four times he went to bat last night at Shea Stadium, and Darryl Strawberry had not hit a home run all season against a left-handed pitcher.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DATAPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decrease in 1986 revenue resulted from the continuing decline in the personal computer market. In fiscal 1986, provision for excess inventory was $1,020,000. This reserve is primarily attributable to inventories associated with purchase orders which were cancelled by several major customers during fiscal 1986 accounting for the latest quarter loss.

title: A Lady Liberty Quiz
description: 1. What do the seven spikes in the crown represent?

title: Marine Band, on Tape, In Liberty's Limelight
description: When the United States Marine Band plays for the televised Liberty Weekend extravaganza in New York Friday and Saturday, much of what the audience in millions of homes hears of it will be taped.

title: STEERING COURSE TOWARD A RENDEZVOUS IN THE HARBOR: WARSHIPS RE-ENACT A TRADITION
description: A procession of fighting ships from 14 navies steamed slowly into New York Harbor yesterday, dropped their anchors, drifted slowly backward on the southerly current until their cables went taut and broke out on their mastheads the black ball signifying a ship at anchor.

title: PROGRESS ON VACCINE IS SEEN
description: Scientists have reported the discovery of a new group of cells attacked by the AIDS virus that may be among the virus's first targets in destroying the body's immune system and may also cause brain infections.

title: WE FORMED A NEW NATIONALITY JOHN CORRY
description: The immigrants are us, an unimpeachable thought, offered frequently in ritualized invocations. Yes, we are a nation of immigrants, and yes, it was wonderfully appropriate when Warren E. Burger, the Chief Justice of the United States, swore in more than 200 immigrants last night in the ceremonies on Ellis Island. The country was enriched, and across the harbor, people in Battery Park cheered.

title: Capitol Police Ask to Bolster Their Canine Bomb Squad
description: Rex, a large black German shepherd, sniffed a battered pickup truck parked in a vacant field, then pounced on the front end of the vehicle, barking and pawing at the plastic explosives hidden inside the bumper.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'CANDIDE' AT CITY OPERA While Lady Liberty is the star of New York Harbor, it's ''Candide'' weekend at the New York State Theater. ''Candide'' is one of the many events being presented in New York City this weekend that are separate from the Statue of Liberty festivities. These range from theater productions to art exhibitions to free music in the city's parks. The New York City Opera is presenting ''Candide'' five times this weekend. One of City Opera's biggest critical and popular successes in recent years, Leonard Bernstein's latter-day send-up of Voltaire, in all its swinging, sophisticated glory, will be presented tonight at 8, with repeat performances tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M., and Sunday at 1 and 7. Some consider ''Candide'' Mr. Bernstein's most perfect theatrical creation, and the City Opera production is appropriately witty and fast-moving. Tickets are $7 to $40. Information: 870-5570.

title: Prostitution Charges Dropped
description: Prostitution charges were dropped today against a second Brown University student in return for her cooperation in bringing four more indictments against an insurance agent who is accused of running the prostitution ring.

title:
LET THE TORCH CAST TRUE LIGHT ON OUR IMMIGRANT STORY;
History Doesn't Need A False Glow
description: This Liberty Weekend, by honoring America's immigrants, America honors itself. But sentimentality - manufactured and hyped in ads and corporate promos - casts a false glow over the event and its larger meaning, to its detriment.

title: RECLUSE'S WILL CREATES PUZZLE FOR RHODE ISLAND
description: When Ethel Turner died last April, her neighbors were stunned to discover that the reclusive woman's will provided that her 100-year-old Victorian house in an affluent oceanfront enclave be razed.

title: NETWORKS AND THE STATUE'S LIGHTING
description: SOME of it looked terrific, and some of it looked bad, and some of it looked downright pointless. The big party on Governors Island last night, to which ABC had exlusive rights, never quite fit, and one wasn't sure whether it was meant for Oberammergau or Las Vegas. On the other hand, as Peter Jennings said earlier, ''In many respects, you viewers at home may have the best seats in the house.''

title: GEORGE ARCENEAUX
description: George Arceneaux, a pioneer in the development of new varieties of sugar cane, died died Tuesday at the Terrebonne Medical Center.

title: THE SAILING SHIPS: HOW TO TELL THEM APART
description: Sloop - Single mast. Generally carries two sails: a mainsail, attached to the mast and a boom, and a headsail, which flies forward of the mainsail.

title: A DIOR SCENT'S GLITTERY DEBUT
description: At the Galeries Lafayette in Paris, a huge facsimile of a perfume bottle was lit by lasers and hung from the ceiling. At Harrods in London, that bottle was the centerpiece of the store's Christmas catalogue. At C.K. Tang in Singapore, the fragrance was everywhere - in boutiques on each floor, in every show window, on floor-to-ceiling banners, on the wrists of most customers.

title: PENTAGON BARS 12 FROM BOXING TEAM
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today barred 12 Defense Department employees from joining an American amateur boxing team at the Goodwill Games that begin in Moscow on Saturday, according to the United States Amateur Boxing Federation.

title: SPY MET AN ISRAELI THROUGH INVESTOR
description: An officer at a New York investment concern introduced the convicted spy Jonathan J. Pollard to the man who became his first Israeli contact, according to sources familiar with the case.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 15
description: b-After a pre-tax provision of $975,000 for loss on closing of three Zackly's Restaurants in Florida. c-Net income.

title: MUSIC BARGE LEADS PARADE ON EAST RIVER
description: Moments before she began to lead the parade of sailing ships down the East River yesterday morning, this extraordinary-looking silver barge opened her hydraulic doors and the American Wind Symphony Orchestra burst into a fanfare for trumpet and percussion.

title: Leutwiler Cites A Role Mix-Up
description: Fritz Leutwiler, former chairman of the Swiss National Bank, said there was a misunderstanding about reports yesterday that he had resigned as mediator between South Africa and its creditor banks because of the state of emergency declared in that country. The resignation had been announced by Erich Heini, who said he was acting as a spokesman for Mr. Leutwiler.

title: OPERA: NEW 'CANDIDE' CAST
description: JUDGING from the happy reports coming out of the New York City Opera's opening night Tuesday, then Wednesday's equally happy performance, the company's weeklong performances of ''Candide'' are featuring casts of equivalent quality.

title: 'KEEPERS OF THE FLAME OF LIBERTY'
description: Following are excerpts from the text of remarks by President Reagan last night on Governors Island at the relighting of the torch of the Statue of Liberty, as issued by the White House:

title: Liberty Week For Sports, Too
description: In a week when Americans are celebrating both their legacy of freedom and the custom of welcoming foreigners to share in the nation's promise and bounty, sport has provided a couple of fitting but little-noted occurrences.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch from the United Nations on June 14, about a draft agreement for the reunification of Cyprus, said, ''Greeks make up 70 percent of the population.''

title: AUTODIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
JARUZELSKI ADDS GENERALS TO LEADERSHIP
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski was renamed First Secretary of the Polish Communist Party today, and three other generals were appointed to a new ruling Politburo.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI TAX IDEA FAVORED BY PACKWOOD
description: In a major step toward compromise on the shape of a final tax revision package, Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has declared his willingness to accept the general terms of a House offer under which the Senate's lower tax rates would be adopted.

title: A KETCH MARKS OWN AND STATUE'S CENTURY
description: When the 86-foot ketch Little Jenny sailed out of Huntington Bay, L.I., at 4 A.M. yesterday, she was virtually alone on the placid waters.

title: HOMOSEXUALS, UPSET BY RULING, PLAN DRIVE TO ABOLISH ANTI-SODOMY LAWS
description: Leaders of homosexual groups angered over a Supreme Court decision upholding the right of states to ban sodomy say they are considering economic boycotts, lawsuits, mass protests and a lobbying campaign to legalize homosexual acts between adults in the 24 states that ban sodomy.

title: Why Pick on New York's Regents?
description: Why is Governor Cuomo of New York assailing the State Board of Regents? He has called it an ''elitist group'' that exercises ''irresponsible leadership'' in education. Those are propositions that need more evidence and, if true, more specific remedies than the Governor has yet provided.

title: MANILA POLICE DISPERSE 5,000 IN PROTESTS AT U.S. EMBASSY
description: Antiriot forces, using truncheons, tear gas and guns, dispersed 5,000 anti-American demonstrators today who had gathered in front of the United States Embassy here.

title: A CHEERFUL PROFUSION OF PEOPLE AND MUSIC
description: The southern tip of Manhattan blossomed into a vast street fair yesterday as endless crowds streamed into the canyons of the financial district, filling 50 blocks bedecked with balloon arches and echoing folk music.

title: FIGNON TESTING FORM IN RETURN TO TOUR
description: For a two-time winner, Laurent Fignon was feeling uncertain when he started the Tour de France here today.

title:
Patents;
Data Hunt Automated By Agency
description: THIS week the Patent and Trademark Office began operating an automated search system that is expected to revolutionize the patent examination process.

title: WINDFALL IS ELUDING MERCHANTS
description: Edward Koch, the Mayor, and Sandy Rosner, a songwriter from Chocowinity, N.C., take a similar view of commerce, Liberty Weekend, and the several million Americans who have descended on New York City.

title: FAMILY SAILS AMID HISTORY FOR A MOMENT
description: Seven-year-old Josh Curtis wondered aloud yesterday what in the world the Statue of Liberty would say if she could speak. His question was lost in the roar of thousands of boat engines and the blare of their horns.

title: How About Pay and a Degree for College Athletes?; Upgrading at Buffalo
description: To the Editor:

title: AMID SALUTES, REAGAN REVIEWS ARMADA
description: With President Reagan aboard, the battleship Iowa sailed past 31 other fighting ships arrayed in the Hudson and the Upper Bay yesterday, receiving a series of gun salutes - and doffed caps from some of the crews of 21 foreign warships lining the route.

title: How About Pay and a Degree for College Athletes?
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE BY MINERS HITS SOUTH AFRICA
description: Nearly 2,000 black mineworkers have gone on strike at four diamond mines to demand the release of detained labor leaders, their employer said today.

title: SUBWAYS TAKE ON PARTY ATMOSPHERE
description: On the way in, merrymakers heeded the warnings of traffic experts, and New York's subways and commuter trains became yesterday - for one day at least - rolling parties on the way to the big party. The city's streets seemed swathed in a strange sort of silence.

title: ROO ART IS WINNER IN THE SUBURBAN
description: Roo Art set a slow pace while staying off a tiring rail and then had plenty left to outrun Proud Truth in the final furlong and win the $284,500 Suburban Handicap by two lengths yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Permission for Howe
description: John Lence, the agent for Steve Howe, says that the 1980 National League rookie of the year with the Los Angeles Dodgers has been given permission by Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, to negotiate a contract with a major-league team beginning July 14. Howe, a left-handed relief specialist, has had a career plagued by missed games and suspensions relating to the use of cocaine.

title: FARMERS PLAN A NATIONAL MEETING TO OPPOSE NEW REAGAN POLICIES
description: Representatives of several leading farm organizations said today that they had received a $250,000 grant from Farm Aid Inc., organizers of last year's farm benefit concert, to finance a national farm policy convention in September in St. Louis.

title: JOURNALISTS REPORTING TO WORLD
description: Last night, an Italian television network devoted more than two hours of prime time to coverage of Liberty Weekend. In Japan, it was much the same.

title: Former Argentine Aide Extradited From U.S.
description: A former Cabinet official under Juan D. Peron came home from the United States in handcuffs today to stand trial on charges ranging from fraud to leading a rightist death squad.

title: TODAY
description: 9 A.M. - Harbor Festival Second day of three-day festival of food, crafts and entertainment continues until 11 P.M. at the World Trade Center Plaza and the streets east of Broadway and south of Fulton. Ethnic dancing, noon to midnight, at stages on Water Street. 48th National Folk Festival at Wall and South Streets, noon to 11. Giant puppet shows at 1, 3, 5 and 7 P.M. at the Custom House facing Bowling Green. Stage at Whitehall and Water Streets features immigrant cultures by day, Brazilian music at night. Continuous musical entertainment in Battery Park. Food and souvenir stands on most streets. 9 A.M. - Freedom's Future rrxhLegal, political and academic experts open ''Liberty - the Next 100 Years,'' a two-day conference at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, off Times Square. 10 A.M. - First Lady rrxhNancy Reagan formally reopens the statue and Liberty Island to visitors. Walter Cronkite will be master of ceremonies and speakers include Lee A. Iacocca, who led restoration effort, and Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. Noon - First Visitors rrxhLed by a group of elementary schoolchildren, visitors return to the statue and the island, closed since June 23, 1985. Ferry service from lower Manhattan to statue resumes (adults $3.25 round-trip, children $1.50). Noon - Other Visitors rrxhMany of the 22 tall ships and 33 warships open to the public. Antique cars, which finished cross-country race, assemble at World Trade Center for a parade. Music and dance at Liberty State Park in New Jersey. 8 P.M. - Music in the Park rrxhThe New York Philharmonic, under Zubin Mehta, gives a free concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: 2 HARVARD CREWS ADVANCE
description: Harvard supporters had the most to cheer about at the Henley Royal Regatta today as both the junior varsity and freshmen crews advanced to Saturday's semifinal round of the Ladies' Challenge Plate, where they will race each other.

title: Soviet Jazz in Town
description: The Smithsonian will bring the capital a taste of Soviet jazz this weekend, with a concert tomorrow by the Ganelin Trio.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. WHITE SOX, at Chicago, 2:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 2:15 P.M.) METS VS.

title: FRIEDMAN'S ASSETS RE-FROZEN
description: The bank accounts and other assets of Stanley M. Friedman, frozen after his indictment in March and later ordered released by a state appeals court, have been frozen again, said a spokesman for Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: METS TOP ASTROS, 2-1, FOR 8 IN ROW
description: If the Mets' first four starting pitchers were football players, they would be known as the Fearsome Foursome or the Purple People Eaters or the Steel Curtain. They are mere baseball players, though, so they are known simply as outstanding.

title: WANTED: GUARD DOGS, COURAGE A MUST
description: The Air Force, which recruits and trains working dogs for the military services and Federal agencies, is having a hard time keeping up with a rapidly growing demand.

title: ELLISVILLE, ILL. ON PARADE: A SMALL-TOWN HOLIDAY
description: Without the distraction of a big band - or even a small one, for that matter - 46 people, one float, six bicycles decorated with colored crepe paper, three wheelbarrows, a baby buggy, two wagons, a real fire truck, two sheep, two cats and a couple of dogs (part of the time) marched in the bright morning sunshine all the way up Main Street from the school today.

title: PROF. AARON LEVENSTEIN
description: Prof. Aaron Levenstein, professor emeritus at Baruch College, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Mohegan Lake, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title:
PATENTS;
An 1879 Design Patent For Statue of Liberty
description: A design patent for the Statue of Liberty was granted in February 1879 to Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, the French sculptor.

title: A Teen-Ager Is Killed In Brooklyn Shooting
description: A 14-year-old boy who was a bystander at a dispute was fatally shot Thursday night in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Judge Sirica Plans to Retire
description: Federal District Judge John J. Sirica, whose subpoena of the Watergate tapes helped force President Nixon to resign, plans to retire from the bench, saying that at the age of 82, ''I've paid my dues.'' Judge Sirica, in a telephone interview Thursday, said he would retire Oct. 1. He has been in semiretirement since 1977, but working several hours on most days.

title: Mixed Signals From Moscow
description: Soviet leaders sent congratulations to President Reagan for the Fourth of July, but the media here dismissed the festivities celebrating the 100th birthday of the State of Liberty as a commercialized ''propaganda show.''

title: CHILE BACK TO NORMAL ACTIVITY AFTER 2-DAY STRIKE
description: Shops reopened, students went back to school, shoppers returned to the sidewalks, and buses and taxis were back on the street today after a 48-hour general strike.

title: MITCHELL SWIMMING ON RECORD COURSE
description: Betsy Mitchell does not like the 200-meter backstroke. When she is swimming it at race speed, her stomach hurts and her legs hurt. She gets dizzy. She gets discouraged.

title: Toxic-Water Suit Is Settled
description: Residents of a South San Jose neighborhood who sued over injuries from chemical contamination of drinking water have reached a multimillion-dollar settlement with the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, an attorney for the plaintiffs has reported.

title: DO CONTACT LENSES POSE RISK?
description: SCIENTISTS at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta issued a report last week alerting doctors to a ''striking increase'' recently in the number of reported cases of a particularly dangerous eye infection, one to which contact lens wearers seem to be prone.

title: TAX SHELTERS MAY AID FRENCH FILMS
description: A new system of tax shelters for movie investments in France has begun to pump money and optimism into the depressed French film industry.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS PRESSED INTO ECONOMIC ISOLATION
description: A confusing series of threats, statements and denials by South Africa's officials and advisers in recent days underline the nation's growing economic isolation.

title: TO YOUNG SAILORS, NEW YORK SHINES
description: Seen from the water, New York is some other city. Seen through the eyes of a young sailor on his first trip here, it is a fantasy beyond anything imagined.

title: Staying Put I
description: Saying that ''the people who need me and want me the most'' had been the most influential factor in his decision, Coach Mike Newell of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock announced yesterday that he had turned down a lucrative offer to become the basketball coach at Marquette University. At a news conference, Newell said that Marquette had met all his contract demands - ''and then some'' - but that ''I will continue to lead U.A.L.R. and central Arkansas toward that dream of a national championship.''

title: TURKISH CYPRIOT CLOSES CROSSINGS
description: Rauf Denktash, leader of the internationally boycotted Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, ordered the indefinite closing of all crossing points on this divided island today.

title: EVANS HOME PACES RED SOX
description: Dwight Evans hit a three-run homer in the fourth inning and Rich Gedman added a bases-empty homer one out later, powering the Boston Red Sox to a 6-5 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight.

title: COMPUTERS CITED AS PRIVACY THREAT
description: A report by the Office of Technology Assessment warns that advances in Government computerized record systems have eroded some of the individual protections established by the Privacy Act of 1974.

title: Pilots in Town
description: The Vietnam Helicopter Pilots Association was holding a four-day reunion in Washington this weekend, and, like many veterans' groups, its members spent some time at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. At an 8 A.M. service yesterday, the pilots placed a wreath at the long, dark wall, and watched a flyover by two helicopters piloted by members of their group. The gathering is a true reunion, said Jay Elliott, adding that he had already run into a man he had not seen in nearly 20 years.

title: LENDL TO FACE BECKER IN FINAL
description: Ivan Lendl had seen this act before, only too recently as far as he was concerned. On Wednesday, the top-ranked player in the world and top-seeded player here was taken to an excruciating fifth set before he outlasted Tim Mayotte in the fading light on Court 1. And today, on Centre Court, with darkness again only a few games away, Lendl was forced to the limit once more, this time in the semifinals by Boris Becker's sparring partner.

title: Indians' Game Draws 73,303
description: The Indians defeated the Kansas City Royals, 10-3, tonight before the major leagues' largest crowd in more than 13 years.

title: NICARAGUA INDIANS FAIL TO HEAL SPLIT
description: Nicaraguan Miskito Indian leaders, long divided by internal disputes, appear to have failed in a new effort to seek unity, according to several Nicaraguan rebel officials here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It doesn't get better than this.'' -Annette Shea, with friends on West 72d Street during Operation Sail. [ 28:4. ]

title: Bridge: Alert Player Will Find Move That Is Not Merely Routine
description: One of the most valuable qualities for any bridge player is alertness, especially in defense. It is easy to make a routine play, failing to make the effort needed to recognize that a slightly unusual move is called for.

title: MEDIATOR NAMED TO UNTANGLE ITALY'S CABINET CRISIS
description: President Francesco Cossiga, acknowledging that efforts to name a new government were deadlocked, appointed a mediator today to untangle deepening political disputes over who should succeed Bettino Craxi as Prime Minister.

title: NEO-NAZIS' DREAM OF A RACIST TERRITORY IN PACIFIC NORTHWEST REFUSES TO DIE
description: All 24 known members of the violent neo-Nazi group called the Order are dead or imprisoned, but their dream of a racist state in the Pacific Northwest refuses to die.

title: Books of The Times; Cycles of Destruction
description: THE NEMESIS AFFAIR. A Story of the Death of Dinosaurs and the Ways of Science. By David M. Raup. Illustrated. 220 pages. W. W. Norton. $14.95.

title: FIREWORKS FILL SKY
description: A procession of tall ships joined an armada of mighty warships in New York Harbor yesterday, and an enormous fireworks show turned the night sky to blazing color in a salute to the Fourth of July and the centennial of a rekindled Statue of Liberty.

title: Dollar Up In Europe
description: The dollar edged up today against most major currencies in European trading that was subdued because of the Fourth of July holiday weekend in the United States. Gold prices were little changed.

title: BRUSH SHAVERS, A NOSTALGIC BREED APART
description: The brushes sit innocently in D. F. Sanders, among ''design objects'' like Tizio lamps. But these are no fly-by-night Milanese fad items.

title: STARBURSTS OF FLOWERS AND GEMS
description: As the earth shook, the skies exploded last night in a brilliant and furious dance amid the stars and skyscrapers - showering streamers of almost every hue upon the celebration.

title: Moscow Replaces Chief Of Chernobyl Inquiry
description: The director of the Government commission investigating the Chernobyl nuclear accident has been replaced, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Carlton Breaks Silence Streak
description: Steve Carlton put on a San Francisco Giants uniform for the first time today and broke his eight-year ban on interviews by saying he thinks he can pitch until he is 50 years old. ''I would've walked away from the game,'' the 41-year-old left-hander said at a news conference, ''if I were having mechanical problems or had a sore arm.''

title: FOR CITY'S CHIEF CLEANER, A BIG CHALLENGE
description: To Thomas Gallagher, ''Every person who walks the streets of New York is a potential litterer.''

title: POPE, BACKING INDIANS, WINS COLOMBIA CHEERS
description: An Indian introducing Pope John Paul II was interrupted here today when he called attention to the killing of an activist priest. But the Pope, winning cheers from the crowd, asked the Indian to resume his talk and said he would pay close attention to his words.

title: HIGH COURT'S AMBIVALENCE ON HIRING GOALS IS EXPECTED TO FOSTER SUCH ANTIBIAS PLANS
description: While the Supreme Court this week firmly rejected the Reagan Admimistration's broad attack on plans that allow racial preferences in the hiring and promotion of members of minority groups, its decisions also illustrated the Court's deep ambivalence on the issue.

title: Seeking Help
description: The attorney who defended a small-time drug dealer in the baseball cocaine scandal in Pittsburgh last summer has asked a Federal judge to delay his own sentencing for bribery and obstruction of justice so that he can enter a drug rehabilitation center for treatment of a 16-year addiction to cocaine. Adam O. Renfroe Jr., 37, who was convicted on June 12 of offering a prospective witness $20,000 to change her testimony against a man Renfroe was representing in Delaware, asked for a two-week postponement of his July 28 sentencing so that he can enter a 29-day treatment program and ''prevent a castastrophe with respect to psychological and emotional welfare.''

title: BATTLING BOATLOCK IN HARBOR
description: ''Motor vessel 'Big Mouth,' '' Ens. Andy Blomme boomed through a bullhorn from the bridge of the Coast Guard cutter Gallatin. ''Do not move any farther north.''

title: Alcoa Offer Accepted By Aluminum Workers
description: Leaders of the Aluminum, Brick and Glass Workers International Union voted today to accept a contract with the Aluminum Company of America, ending a 34-day walkout against the nation's largest aluminum manufacturer.

title: MERCHANT AND IVORY STRIKE GOLD
description: Ismail Merchant's expectations for ''A Room With a View'' were modest.

title: Strip Licenses From Bad-Egg Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK RELAXES AS IT SAVORS A CELEBRATION
description: People moved about more lazily. Faces were less taut and many wore radiant smiles. Even the sky was flawless - blue, then a starry black. .

title: They Keep The Pot Stirred
description: Here's to every immigrant and immigrant offspring who didn't measure up:

title: FOR VIETNAMESE REFUGEE, A HEARTFELT CELEBRATION OF LIBERTY
description: For a decade, Lee Truong dreamed of escaping from Vietnam. After he made it to a refugee camp in Hong Kong in 1980, he spent two more years waiting for a sponsor in America. And for the last seven months, living and studying in Boston, he saved his money to visit New York and pay homage to the Statue of Liberty.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After singling in his first professional time at bat, Bo Jackson has gone hitless in his last 15 trips to the plate for the Memphis Chicks, giving him an .067 batting average after Thursday night's game. . . . Shawn O'Sullivan, a Canadian silver medalist in boxing in the 1984 Olympics, will be sidelined for several months due to surgery on his right hand, which he injured in his first professional defeat, a knockout by Simon Brown on June 8.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42. 1. This is a detail from John Trumbull's painting ''Declaration of Independence,'' which is popularly but erroneously thought to depict the signing of the document on July 4, 1776. According to historians, the date of the actual signing was (July 12/July 24/Aug. 2/Aug. 14), when copies were received from the calligraphers. 2. In Wales, the word ''cwmwl,'' (pronounced COOM-ool), which means cloud, now means despair. Explain. 3. Recent headlines from Lakehurst, N.J., recalled headlines almost five decades old. Explain. 4. On Wall Street, Feb. 6, Feb. 27 and March 20, 1986 were joined by July 1. Explain. 5. At a gathering that had been depicted by a foreign Government as a prayer meeting for peace, most people arrived armed with spears, axes, clubs and other such weapons. What meeting was it? 6. The Supreme Court held that a Georgia law that makes it a crime for anyone to engage in oral or anal sex could be used to prosecute homosexuals, but did not rule on whether the Constitution protected heterosexuals from prosecution under the same law. True or false? 7. The score was Mayor Koch, 86, Liberty Weekend officials, 12. Explain. 8. ''This is the first time in a long time that I've looked out on the field and wanted to be pitching,'' said a 41-year-old athlete who has started a new chapter in his career.

title: SIX DIRIGIBLES HOVER OVER HARBOR
description: A stately, plump buckmulligan of blimps has hovered over the Liberty Weekend festival.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll on plans to watch the Liberty centennial celebrations omitted the answer to a question. When people were asked if they planned to do anything special to mark the holiday, they described family gatherings, trips and local fireworks observances more often than television watching of the Liberty centennial events.

title: Doctors Shift Tactics In Ontario Strike
description: Leaders of a doctors' strike in Canada's most populous province voted today to end a three-week general walkout but will continue to halt medical service on a rotating basis to fight a law limiting their fees.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON'S RECOVERY
description: In February a cyanide-laced Tylenol capsule killed a woman in Yonkers, leading Johnson & Johnson to remove all capsule forms of the product from the market. Despite the incident, Tylenol retained its position as the nation's best-selling analgesic and five months later is selling 96 percent of what it sold before the tampering, the company says.

title: Of the 'Liberty of Statue'
description: Amid the hoopla for the centennial celebration of the Statue of Liberty, there were small moments, quiet moments, when the lady herself emerged.

title: Carter Leads Walkout At Party in Zimbabwe
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, angered by Zimbabwean criticism of United States policy toward South Africa, led a walkout today from an Independence Day reception here.

title: U.S. Chip Talks Stir Japan Fears
description: As semiconductor talks continue, concern is mounting here that Japan may be giving up too much in the continuing negotiations.

title: Police Unhampered By Miranda Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: RUDY VALLEE, SINGING IDOL, DIES AT 84
description: Rudy Vallee, whose twangy crooning style, aided by a handheld megaphone, made him a singing idol of the 1930's and 40's, died Thursday night at his home in North Hollywood, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: 55 MARK SETS RECORD LOW
description: Temperatures yesterday hit a record low for July 4 of 55 degrees, two degrees lower than the previous record of 57 degrees in 1938.

title:
PATENTS;
Storing and Releasing Energy From Walking
description: Dr. Boris Schwartz of Hawthorne, N.J., who practices surgery, also practices hiking.

title: Costa Rica Cuts Pretoria Tie
description: Costa Rica has decided to sever all diplomatic ties with South Africa immediately to protest apartheid, President Oscar Arias Sanchez announced today. An official statement referred to ''the indifference of the Government of Prime Minister P. W. Botha in satisfying the expectations of the international community.'' Among other restrictions, the move will bar South Africans from taking part in international sports events here.

title: Sri Lanka Painfully Works Out Its Tamil-Sinhalese Conflicts
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokens From the Boss
description: ''We're looking to change habits,'' says Stephen Berger, Executive Director of the Port Authority. The habit in question is that of driving to work in Manhattan.

title: THE POWDER KEG
description: On the eve of the Fourth of July - a pyrotechnical celebration made even brighter and noisier by this centennial of the Statue of Liberty - Donald Lavert Rogers was buried in a quiet service in Sacramento, Calif.

title: FEW HEALTH PROBLEMS FOUND ABOARD CRUISE SHIPS
description: Three months after the Federal Government ended spot checks of sanitary conditions on cruise ships, the more than 80 ships that carry passengers on pleasure trips out of United States ports appear to have few health problems, according to Federal officials.

title: A Rib for Manatt
description: The Democrats will roast their former national chairman, Charles Manatt, at a $1,000-a-plate dinner in Los Angeles on Wednesday. The event is already being described as a chuck roast.

title: Runaway Fireworks Injure 30 in Newark
description: At least 30 people were injured tonight by rockets that went astray during a fireworks display and landed in the stands at Ironbound Stadium here, authorities said.

title: SIMPSON LEADS BY 2 IN HARTFORD EVENT
description: Tim Simpson, the first-round leader, shot a steady 66 today for a 12-under-par 130 and a two-stroke lead over Tom Watson after two rounds of the $700,000 Greater Hartford Open.

title: TESTS SUGGEST EARLIER DRUG USE BY BIAS
description: Detailed tests done on Len Bias's heart show that the University of Maryland basketball All-American probably had used cocaine before his fatal dose on June 19, according to Dr. John Smialek, the state's medical examiner.

title: Miss Reagan Heard From
description: At the recent meeting of the Republican National Committee in St. Louis, there was much speculation that Maureen Reagan would seek the position of party co-chairman when Betty Heitman's term expires next winter.

title: Kin Ordered Jailed On Captivity Charge
description: A woman and her two teen-aged children were each sentenced to 12 months in jail for holding the woman's husband captive in the basement of their home for two months.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. Aug. 2. 2. The economy is suffering because the Government has banned the slaughter of an estimated 3 million lambs until there are no more traces of fallout from clouds caused by the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. 3. An experimental airship made up of a blimp and four helicopters crashed near the site where the dirigible Hindenburg exploded in flames more than 49 years ago. 4. They are the respective dates when the Dow Jones industrial average closed for the first time above 1,600, 1,700, 1,800, and now 1,900. 5. In a departure from the ban on virtually all outdoor meetings by blacks, the South African Government permitted a rally of thousands of Zulus in a sports stadium. 6. True. 7. Mr. Koch, critical of Liberty Weekend official organizers who selected only a dozen prominent naturalized Americans to be honored, presented New York City Liberty Awards to 86 immigrants. 8. Tom Seaver was obtained by the Boston Red Sox from the Chicago White Sox. 9. Ambassador Lauder will not be in Austria for the inauguration of Kurt Waldheim as President. 10. Despite a rabies epidemic among animals, there has not been a confirmed case of human rabies for more than a year because of a surefire vaccine for humans who have been bitten by or exposed to rabid animals. 11. It is the largest bottler of Coca-Cola in the nation. 12. Mr. Donahue was freed by Lebanese captors 10 months after he was abducted. 13. Modify. 14.

title: BANK BILLS BOG DOWN IN CONGRESS
description: The off-again, on-again world of banking legislation seems to be off again.

title: WILLARD AMES HOLBROOK
description: Brig. Gen. Willard Ames Holbrook of the Army, retired, who took the Nazi surrender of Linz, Austria, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 88 years old.

title: TV: HOW DAN RATHER MAKES US FEEL GOOD
description: Where would we be without Dan Rather? Scoff at this if you must, but he's terrific at big parties - tummler, cheerleader and genial host. We know he's having a good time because he tells us so. ''Fourth of Julys don't get a lot better than this,'' he said yesterday, and, for at least that moment, we had to agree. If we didn't, it would have been like sassing our dad or big brother.

title: YANKEES BEATEN BY 2-1
description: Perhaps, in the end, it did not really matter whether the fan leaned over the railing and touched the ball. The way John Cangelosi was running, the way he had seemed to shift gears as he rounded second base, it was likely going to be a triple anyway. And it was going to hurt the Yankees.

title: THE IDEAL VS. RAZZMATAZZ
description: To return to New York is almost always, I find, to be struck by its strength and by its extravagance, by sharp images and carnival colors. (I should perhaps add that I am not an American: Until I came to work here, I had spent most of my life in London, the city where I was born.) To return this week was to have both impressions reinforced as never before - a greater show of strength, a bigger splash of color, and all in the name of Liberty.

title: TALL SHIP PARTIES THE RULE IN A JERSEY HIGH-RISE
description: At 6:30 this morning, Margie Kane rang the bell at Frank McNerney's place on the 14th floor of Winston Towers overlooking the Hudson River. The party had begun.

title: COLUMBIA STUDIO CHOICE OF CHIEF SEEN AS GAMBLE
description: As the producer of such highly acclaimed films as ''Chariots of Fire'' and ''The Killing Fields,'' David Puttnam has one of the best reputations in Hollywood.

title:
PATENTS;
How Nicotine Users Can Avoid Lung Peril
description: Administration of nicotine through the skin is proposed by a psychology professor as a means of satisfying smokers while eliminating the side effects of tobacco on the lungs. Frank T. Etscorn, with the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, in Socorro, was granted patent 4,597,961 this week for his method of transcutaneous application.

title: Richmond Wins Firecracker 400
description: With his Chevrolet covering the 400 miles in 3 hours 1 minute 56 seconds, Tim Richmond won the slowest ever Firecracker 400 today at the Daytona International Speedway.

title: SHAMIR SPEAKS OUT IN ISRAELI SCANDAL
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir has begun to publicly deny accusations by officials of Shin Beth, the domestic security agency, that he was involved in Israel's intelligence scandal.

title: Hoang Van Thai, 71; A Vietnamese General
description: Gen. Hoang Van Thai, a Vietnamese revolutionary who fought against French and American forces, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Hanoi, the official Vietnamese press agency reported today. He was 71 years old.

title: CHIRAC FACES CHALLENGES ON 3 FRONTS
description: After a hundred days in power, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's new conservative Government is approaching its most important test so far in its bid to liberalize the French economy.

title: Freedom, in Song and Literature; Letters Of the Republic
description: This weekend, as we herald the principles on which this country was founded, we might recall the nation's fragile early years. A sampling from the correspondence of John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, two prominent signers of the Declaration of Independence, sheds light on their spirited efforts to forge a new Republic despite a bitter estrangement that kept them at odds for years.

title: LaRouche Groups Face $17 Million in Fines
description: Four organizations linked to the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. could be fined up to $17 million under a decision upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: INDIANS IN WEST TURNING TO VOTING RIGHTS TOOL THAT AIDED BLACKS IN SOUTH
description: A Federal voting rights law written to open Southern politics to black candidates has emerged as the most powerful tool Western Indians have in their effort to gain representation in local politics.

title: Let's Junk The National Anthem
description: That ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' has failed as our national anthem, that it is an embarrassing symbol, a musical laughingstock, is all too clear. Nor is there any doubt that this nation - having survived 210 years -deserves better. The solution is obvious.

title: From Sea to Shining Sea, by Road
description: Recently, I drove from coast to coast for the first time. I wonder if tourists who plan to forsake the risks of terrorism abroad this summer will share my discovery that this country can put anyone at the mercy of its enormity and caprice.

title: Your Money; Owning Jointly To Save Taxes
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN planning technique for families that want to pass assets to a younger generation in a way that avoids the possibility of estate or gift taxes involves the joint ownership of property.

title: ALL-AMERICAN CONCERT, FROM POP TO PATRIOTISM
description: In Liberty State Park, on the banks of New York Harbor, more than 200,000 people celebrated the Fourth of July with a gigantic picnic that began before dawn and culminated after sunset in a rousing concert of American music topped by spectacular fireworks.

title: A BRIEF BUT SPECTACULAR RETURN TO THE AGE OF SAIL
description: Sleek and sheer, sails set full or neatly furled, the world's tall ships sailed into New York Harbor yesterday - from near, from far, from out of the past.

title: Her Birthday, and Ours
description: The day had everything you'd ever want in a birthday, and less. It began with the quiet majesty of the Parade of Sail. It ended with an ear-splitting panorama of pyrotechnics. And it all happened under the gaze of the refurbished Lady of the Harbor, unveiled the night before amid the glitter of presidents and personages and the flash of laser lights.

title: To Teach, Perchance to Learn
description: ''To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me,'' Shakespeare says in ''Love's Labor's Lost.'' But those who run the Folger Shakespeare Library's summer program for English teachers take their guidance instead from views the bard expounded in ''Othello'': ''Those that do teach young babes do it with gentle means and easy tasks.''

title: TOURISTS FOR A DAY, NEW YORKERS REVEL
description: They brought their binoculars, their cameras, their periscopes, their radioes, their blankets and their lunch. They drank champagne in penthouses on Riverside Drive, on yachts and in the board rooms of Wall Street.

title: Strip Licenses From Bad-Egg Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Raises Prices by 2.9%
description: The Ford Motor Company raised its car prices by an average of 2.9 percent today, but also announced new buyer incentives that include loans at 6.9 to 9.9 percent interest, or cash bonuses of up to $600.

title: FOR RONALD REAGAN, THE CEREMONIES STIR PRIDE AND PATRIOTISM
description: President Reagan blended politics and patriotism yesterday in what aides described as one of the most exuberant days of his Presidency.

title: BECKER DISPLAYS DOMINANCE AGAIN
description: In a country that bows to royalty, Boris Becker has already become the prince of Centre Court here. What his opponents, the fans and those who chronicle these matches find remarkable is how much at home he is here in a setting that would unnerve most 18-year-olds. What is a constant source of fascination is how his game is so perfectly suited for the grass that many players wish was part of the past.

title: A BASEBALL CAP FIT FOR A CHIEF
description: When President Reagan stepped off the battleship Iowa yesterday morning, he was wearing a traditional memento of a dignitary's visit -a blue baseball cap with a gold emblem reading ''BB61 Iowa'' on the front and ''Cmdr in Chief'' across the back.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING BACK Should the lady in the harbor feel that too much is being made of age on the occasion of her 100th birthday, she might find solace as she looks eastward from her high perch toward Brooklyn, where the Brooklyn Museum houses statues and other relics of an antiquity that makes a century appear as a fleeting fragment of time.

title: THOUGHTS ON STRAWBERRY SHORTCAKE
description: Given the intense scrutiny old-fashioned American food has been accorded of late, it's no wonder that people are arguing about the authentic versions of just about everything from mashed potatoes to strawberry shortcake.

title: Barry Harris, Pianist
description: The pianist Barry Harris is appearing at the Jazz Cultural Theater this weekend.

title: JAMES C. DOUGLASS
description: James Campbell Douglass, a former New York advertising executive, died June 24 at a nursing home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived in Warren, Conn.

title: Auto Workers Reach Pact With Caterpillar
description: Negotiators for Caterpillar Inc. and the United Automobile Workers today reached a tentative contract settlement on a new contract for 17,000 workers, ending 30 hours of bargaining.

title: FRENCH SEE BETTER TIES FROM VISIT
description: French officials said today that President Francois Mitterrand was extremely pleased by his two-day visit to New York, by the warmth of his reception here and by the important role afforded France at the celebration of the Statue of Liberty's centennial.

title: POLICE HALT RIGHTS MARCHERS AT WALL ST.
description: Hundreds of homosexual-rights activists, marching to protest a Supreme Court ruling on sodomy, confonted a police barricade yesterday in crowded lower Manhattan. After 15 tense minutes, in which some demonstrators urged a charge against the police lines, the march broke up without incident or arrests.

title: REAGAN OPTIMISM ON ARMS PACT SEEN
description: President Reagan told President Francois Mitterrand yesterday that he was persuaded that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was the first Soviet leader who wanted to negotiate an arms control agreement with the United States, a representative of the French President said.

title: Street Basketball: Melting Pot, Melting Pavement
description: While walking in New York City's Central Park, I ran into a basketball pal. He told me that ''our'' court had been torn apart. It seemed a tragedy. It was a great court, a hidden, rare full-sized court situated where the Portuguese blocks of Soho meet the edge of Little Italy.

title: Progress Seen in Talks On Copper Contracts
description: Workers at the Kennecott Copper Corporation were to vote Monday on a contract offer that would recall laid-off workers but slash wages and benefits. Meanwhile, about 1,650 copper workers at ASARCO Inc. agreed to 20 percent wage cuts over three years.

title: Four Dance Stars Win '86 Astaire Awards
description: Four noted individuals in dance have been named winners of this year's Astaire Awards, given by the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation.

title:
PATENTS;
Using Plastic Slides With Lab Specimens
description: A method of applying medical specimens, such as blood and other smears, to plastic slides was patented this week by a medical technologist at San Francisco State University. William D. Delameter, who received patent 4,597,982, says it will enable laboratories to process flexible slides that have less than one-tenth the thickness and weight of standard glass slides.

title: Nicaragua Announces Expulsion of a Bishop
description: Nicaragua expelled a Roman Catholic bishop today, accusing him of supporting the anti-Sandinista rebels.

title: No Charges
description: E. Michael McCann, the district attorney of Milwaukee County, said that no criminal charges had been filed against Reggie Jackson of the California Angels, who was involved in an altercation with a fan in a Milwaukee bar on May 3. McCann, however, said the case has been referred to the city attorney office for review. ''All the evidence indicates that neither man struck the other with his fist, kicked the other or used a weapon of any kind,'' McCann said.

title: 15 Killed in 24 Hours Of Violence in Punjab
description: Gunfire killed 15 people in Punjab state in less than 24 hours in the worst outbreak of Sikh terrorism in weeks, the police said today.

title: THE MARCHES OF ULSTER: A NEW SUMMER OF RAGE?
description: A century ago, a British Government led by William Gladstone fell because it tried to establish a political arrangement in Ireland over the protests of Protestants in the island's northern counties. Now, for the first time since then, the Protestants in Northern Ireland confront a political arrangement that seems invulnerable to their fury.

title: Reagan to Meet de la Madrid In August to Repair Strains
description: In an attempt to smooth over badly strained relations between Mexico and the United States, President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid plan to meet Aug. 13 in Washington, Mexican Government sources said today.

title: At the Holocaust Museum
description: Arthur Rosenblatt, who served 19 years with New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, took over Tuesday as the first director of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, to be constructed near the Mall in the shadow of the Washington Monument.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JULY 5, 1986
description: Liberty Weekend A procession of tall ships joined an armada of mighty warships in New York Harbor and an enormous fireworks show turned the night sky to blazing color in a salute to the Fourth of July and the centennial of a rekindled Statue of Liberty. As darkness fell on a day of stately nautical maneuvers, the biggest fireworks display in American history - a booming 28-minute barrage of skyrockets - burst like supernovas over the harbor. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] President Reagan mixed politics and patriotism on the Fourth of July in what aides described as one of the most exuberant days of his Presidency. From the battleship U.S.S. Iowa, Mr. Reagan reviewed an international flotilla of warships and then went to a luncheon meeting on Governors Island with President Francois Mitterrand of France. at which the two Presidents discussed arms control and relations with the Soviet Union, which Mr. Mitterrand will visit next week. [ 1:6. ] On a day of flawless weather, New Yorkers and visitors were in a mood appropriate not only to the Fourth of July, but a singular Fourth of July, one that celebrated their roots and their unabashed pride in their country. The cornucopia of festivities in New York seemed to make other Fourth of July celebrations around the nation pale by comparison. Being at the center of the national celebration seemed to add an extra lilt to the delight of New Yorkers. [ 1:5. ] A gigantic street fair occupied the southern tip of Manhattan.

title: Staying Put II
description: Dick Versace, the basketball coach at Bradley, also was being considered for the opening at Marquette, but he intends to stay put, too, although for a different reason.

title: Robert S. Olnick, 74, Real-Estate Developer
description: Robert S. Olnick, a New York real estate developer, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: CABARET: HORACE SILVER AND QUINTET
description: The pianist Horace Silver's latest quintet, which is appearing through tomorrow at the Blue Note, (131 West Third Street), doesn't live up to many of its illustrious predecessors.

title: TEACHERS' UNION BACKS NATIONAL STANDARD SYSTEM
description: After two days of vigorous debate, the nation's largest teachers' union today endorsed a recent recommendation by the Carnegie Corporation to establish a national board of standards to certify elementary and high school teachers.

title: REAGAN BACKS PENTAGON BAN
description: President Reagan crushed any hopes that the United States would lift its ban on military personnel competing in the Goodwill Games today as the competition began with the Soviet swimmer Vladimir Salnikov smashing his world record in the 800-meter freestyle and the American Angel Myers winning two gold medals in swimming.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JULY 5, 1986
description: The Economy

title: TEXAS ARCHITECTS HURT BY OIL
description: When the economy was booming in Houston in 1981, Morris/Aubry Architects was booming with it, finding more than enough work to keep its 300 employees busy.

title: City Is to Get Special Boulder
description: A large wooden crate on the main deck of the tall ship Sorlandet doubled as a buffet during the Norwegian square-rigger's cruise of New York waterways yesterday. It was covered with a white tablecloth and piled high with bread and cheese.

title: Light Fires at the World Bank
description: The World Bank is in sorry shape. Clients on three continents are desperate, but in the last 12 months this great institution, the world's leading provider of aid, has barely disbursed as much credit as it has collected in interest and repayments. Enter Barber Conable, the former Congressman who has just taken over as its president. He cannot perform miracles, but he can light fires. America and Japan are best positioned to help.

title: A 'GREASE' SLICK AND ENERGETIC
description: ''GREASE,'' that mocking musical tribute to the pomaded, slicked-back hairstyles worn by the ''cool'' teen-agers of the 1950's, has been revived by Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: AN ENCHANTED EVENING CAMPING IN NEW YORK
description: Campers rose from their sleeping bags early yesterday at the intersection of the Long Island Expressway and the Grand Central Parkway, awakened by planes roaring out of La Guardia Airport.

title: FEMALE LAWYERS SEEK OWN FORUMS
description: IN 1975, 10 women who had recently graduated from the University of Connecticut Law School decided to meet at monthly luncheons just to keep in touch. Thus was born the Hartford Organization of Women Attorneys.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PARKING
description: In July 1935, the Reverend C. H. North of Oklahoma City became the first person ever issued a summons for a parking meter violation. He beat the ticket by saying he was inside a store getting change - an excuse tried many times thereafter.

title: TESTS OF A NEW CHEMICAL WEAPON SET PROPONENTS AND CRITICS AT ODDS
description: Congressional critics of chemical weapons and Pentagon officials pressing for their production are quarreling over how to interpret the latest test data on a new chemical bomb.

title: Oversized Problems With Undersized Lots
description: AMONG the thousands of new housing units under construction in Suffolk County are many rising on individual lots, some as small as 4,000 square feet, that do not meet zoning requirements. Generally, those regulations require at least 10,000 square feet.

title: SHAPING A 'DREAM' FAR MORE BITTER THAN PUCKISH
description: The Guthrie Theater production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' that opens at the Pepsico Summerfare in Purchase this Saturday offers New Yorkers a rare opportunity to see the work of one of the world's most important contemporary theater directors. Liviu Ciulei is well known for his stage productions and operas in Minneapolis, Chicago and Washington, as well as most of the European capitals. He made his local debut in 1978 directing a class of Juilliard School students in ''Spring Awakening,'' Frank Wedekind's graphic essay on adolescent sexuality, and since then he has directed Gogol's ''The Inspector General'' at Circle in the Square and a private workshop of Brecht's ''Jungle of Cities'' starring Al Pacino. After an absence from New York of more than five years, Mr. Ciulei this year has mounted two productions here -''Hamlet'' starring Kevin Kline at the Public Theater, as well as ''Dream'' - featuring the provocative and intellectually stimulating approach to the classics for which he is internationally renowned.

title: RUMBLINGS FROM THE HOURS FOLLOWING PRIME TIME
description: Television's prime-time evening hours, studded with stars and heavily publicized programming, may monopolize most of the medium's glitter, but it's no secret that the industry's bread-and-butter profits are produced by other segments of the schedule - those daytime soap operas and game shows, those late-night old movies and grab-bag series. The audiences may be smaller, but the production costs are cheaper and the commercial breaks longer. In prime time, for instance, a 50-minute production will be offered with about 10 additional minutes of commercials and announcements. Later in the evening, as I was recently reminded while watching CBS's ''Night Heat'' series, a program of similar length can be saddled with 20 minutes of unrelated material, stuffed into breaks that run as long as five minutes.

title: U.S., CUBA TO TALK OVER IMMIGRATION
description: Relations between the United States and Cuba have been strained in recent years, but last week Washington and Havana agreed to discuss the revival of a 1984 immigration pact.

title: YANKEES WIN, 8-0, BEHIND RASMUSSEN
description: When the questions persisted, Dennis Rasmussen allowed himself to finally think about the All-Star Game, about going to Houston over the three-day break this month and perhaps pitching in the sport's midseason showcase. And he grinned.

title: LIE DOWN WITH HACKS, RISE UP WITH LIONS
description: HOT PROPERTIES By Rafael Yglesias. 408 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: O'Neil, Wichell Win
description: Chris O'Neil and John Wichell won their events today as United States swimmers captured nine more medals, including a third for Angel Myers, at the Goodwill Games.

title: Some Kind Words for the Military
description: The Presidential Commission on Defense Management said in its final report last week that the Department of Defense and its civilian suppliers had been, to some extent, unfairly saddled with a sorry image.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN'S RANK: CITIZEN IN HER OWN LAND
description: Lydia Maletsatse rose as usual in Soweto on Friday morning and clad herself for the day. Unusually, she headed not for Sandton, the elegant Johannesburg suburb where she works serving tea, but instead for the city center, where she sought a new status: citizen in her own land.

title: MARINERS DEFEAT RED SOX, 9-5
description: Danny Tartabull and Ken Phelps hit homers, and Dave Henderson broke a 3-3 tie with a two-run double in the seventh inning today as the Seattle Mariners beat the Boston Red Sox for the first time this season, 9-5.

title: Madlock Hurts Ankle On Stadium Sprinkler
description: Bill Madlock, the Los Angeles third baseman, already on the disabled list with a pulled left groin, sprained his right ankle tonight when he tripped over a sprinkler head before the game against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: THE AMERICAN IDEA
description: When he died seven weeks ago, Theodore H. White, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and journalist, was working on an article for this magazine to commemorate the Fourth of July. Below is an excerpt from the unfinished piece.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A WORLD QUITE ROUND. By Gordon Weaver. (Louisiana State University, Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $9.95.) Like many superior fiction collections, Gordon Weaver's two stories and novella explore a single, large theme - the symbiosis of art and experience.

title: CITY TAXES FOUND HIGHEST IN U.S. AND RISING STILL
description: As many New Yorkers had surely come to suspect without a report from a commission, their taxes are the highest in the country. Moreover, according to a study of city tax policy released last week, the increase in their taxes is outstripping the increase in their incomes.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The greed pressures have built up so in this industry, the younger people want instant gratification.''

title: RAIL, BUS FARE RISES NOT AS BIG AS FEARED
description: PASSENGERS on NJ Transit buses and trains will be paying higher fares soon, but the increase is smaller than anticipated a few months ago.

title: Jennifer A. Coyle To Wed Aug. 23
description: An Aug. 23 wedding is planned by Jennifer Alison Coyle and William Noyes Moseley, 1985 graduates of Lake Forest College. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Coyle of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Selling to the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: PROVISIONAL PROGRAM FOR TEACHERS IS DEFENDED
description: An article in the New Jersey Weekly of June 8 focused on a few aspects of a single unfortunate incident related to New Jersey's Provisional Teacher Program ('' 'Alternate' Teaching Assailed Over Error of $400''). Rather than have your readers judge the program on the basis of that one incident, I would like to provide them with more-comprehensive information.

title: Dina A. Sheridan To Marry in Fall
description: An October wedding is planned by Dina Anne Sheridan and Stephen Barrett Grant, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Sheridan Jr. of New York and Windham, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Grant is a son of Col. Thomas J. Grant, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Grant of Alexandria, Va.

title: Ann C. Doyle Wed to Charles Thurlow
description: Ann Cornelia Doyle, a daughter of Mrs. Albert Cornelius Doyle and the late Mr. Doyle of Brockton and West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Charles Bradbury Thurlow, a son of Bradbury K. Thurlow of Rumson, N.J., and New York and the late Fearn Cutler Thurlow. Maj. Gen. Henry J. Meade, U.S.A.F., Chaplain Corps, retired, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Ice Cream Bars Recalled After Reports of Illness
description: Hundreds of people in four states, including four pregnant women, complained of illnesses after eating Polar B'ar ice cream bars contaminated with a deadly bacterium, doctors said yesterday. Kraft Inc. has recalled the bars.

title: MONTCLAIR THEATER OFF TO A ROUSING START
description: THE summer theater at Montclair State College has a new name (SummerFest), a new producing director (David G. Watson), a newly accorded professional status (an Actors' Equity contract) and a smashing debut show (''The Rink'').

title: LENDL VS. BECKER: A STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: It seems appropriate that after two weeks of sorting out the seeded players and following the exploits of untouted players such as Pat Cash and Slobodan Zivojinovic, the Wimbledon men's singles championship will be decided between Boris Becker, the defending champion, and Ivan Lendl, the No. 1-ranked player in the world.

title: Watson and Knox Overtake Simpson
description: Tom Watson, seeking his first tournament victory in two years, and Ken Knox both overtook Tim Simpson today for a share of the lead in the $700,000 Canon-Sammy Davis Jr.-Greater Hartford Open.

title: THE CASE AGAINST HOMO ECONOMICUS
description: THE BATTLE FOR HUMAN NATURE Science, Morality and Modern Life. By Barry Schwartz. 348 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: WHERE TO FIND AND GIVE TEACHER THAT APPLE
description: TO EVERY teacher who has ever taught Reading, Riting and Rithmetic, there has always been a fourth ''R'' on their minds: Retirement. And living in the Planned Retirement Communities of Central New Jersey these days - a P.R.C., as they are known - are enough retired teachers to staff any good-sized school system.

title: GARDEN OF AMAZING DELIGHTS
description: UNATTAINABLE EARTH By Czeslaw Milosz. Translated by Czeslaw Milosz and Robert Hass. 141 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $17.95.

title: 4 Killed in Taiwan Crash
description: Four soldiers were killed today and two were seriously injured when a military truck skidded off a bridge and tumbled onto a road in central Taiwan, the police said.

title: Miss Ritter Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Ritter of Kennebunk Beach, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Hartley Ritter, to Thomas Merrill Ewing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Ewing of Canandaigua, N.Y.

title: Finding a Lesson In Len Bias's Death
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: Once Upon a Time . . . And the Earth Was Created. Written and directed by Albert Barille, designed by Jean Barbaud; animation by Philippe Landrot and Pepe Borg, 1978; Sony Video Software; 77 minutes.

title: GROUPS WORK TO RECLAIM OLMSTED'S HERITAGE
description: EFFORTS are now under way in Hartford, New Haven, Bridgeport and New Britain to restore parks designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, the Hartford native who led the 19th-century movement to establish green spaces in the country's rapidly growing cities.

title: G.I. Goat Power
description: FACED with the need to mow a rugged 20-acre tract at a sewage-treatment plant, Fort Dix, N.J., called in a special platoon: 29 goats.

title: A LITTLE DEMENTIA IN THE NAME OF PROGRESS
description: THE CIRCLE OF REASON By Amitav Ghosh. 423 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: REMEMBER LIBERTY'S SCAFFOLD?
description: THE nation's most publicized rehabilitation project, the Statue of Liberty, came in on time and within budget. The restoration, requiring the services of numerous architects, engineers, construction managers, contractors and laborers, conferred celebrity status on the work of one area construction company, Universal Builders Supply Inc. of Mount Vernon. The $2 million contract for the aluminum scaffolding that encased the statue for two years - making the rehabilitation work possible -was won by Universal.

title: Judge Rules Out POLICE DRUG TESTS
description: The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits ''unreasonable searches and seizures,'' and last week a New York State Supreme Court judge applied it to urine tests on New York City Police officers.

title: VILLAGES SEEKING FORMER CITY LAND
description: NASSAU County last month acquired 310 acres of property once used for a backup water supply system by New York City. Now, villages in which much of the property is situated want to buy the land from the county to keep the 143 parcels from development.

title: Fargis Wins Jump-Off At Lake Placid Show
description: Joe Fargis of Petersburg, Va., the only American to win two Olympic show-jumping gold medals, won the featured event today at the I Love New York Horse Show.

title: HOW COCAINE TOOK CONTROL OF MY LIFE
description: I was fortunate. Facing the barrel of a coke dealer's .357 Magnum revolver brought me to my senses and helped me realize that I needed help, that cocaine had taken control of my life. Len Bias and Don Rogers were not as lucky. They didn't get that kind of warning.

title: THE BIG CLEANUP: 'SEND IN THE PLOWS'
description: By the early morning hours of the Day After the Fourth, only the diehards were left at the tip of lower Manhattan, toasting the Statue of Liberty amid a sea of paper wrappings, cans, bottles and, of course, a warehouseful of discarded centennial souvenirs.

title: WORLD OF THE BLACK BOURGEOISIE
description: THE HORNES An American Family. By Gail Lumet Buckley. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: WESTERNERS REACH SOVIET TO CHECK ATOM SITE
description: A team of Western scientists has entered the Soviet Union and is to be allowed to monitor its main underground nuclear test site for the first time since the dawn of the nuclear era.

title: GETTING TOUGH TOO LATE
description: MORALITY, REASON, AND POWER American Diplomacy in the Carter Years. By Gaddis Smith. 296 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $18.95.

title: LOUISIANA'S WETLANDS ARE STEADILY GOING OUT ON THE TIDE
description: FOR decades, vast reaches of the wetlands that lie at the mouth of the Mississippi River have been sinking, swallowed by the advancing waters of Gulf of Mexico. Even now, it is estimated that Louisiana is losing almost 40 square miles of marsh every year, a rate of about one acre every 16 minutes.

title: Soviet-American Crossroads
description: President Reagan has said the Administration is making a careful study of the recent series of proposals put forward by Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: Handel's 'Julius Caesar'. An English National Opera production, featuring Janet Baker, Valerie Masterson, Sarah Walker, Della Jones, James Bowman, John Tomlinson; with Charles Mackerras conducting.

title: LEGISLATORS FORCED TO FORGO SUMMER RECESS
description: WHEN Governor Kean signed the state's $9.3 billion budget for the coming year last Monday, he eliminated $54 million in state aid to municipalities and forced the Legislature to postpone its plans for a summer recess.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 21 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 21 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: THE NEW MOLOTOV
description: Even in Moscow, there is no disgrace a politican can't live down if he lives long enough. Vyacheslav M. Molotov, who was expelled from the Soviet leadership nearly 30 years ago for attempting to oust Nikita S. Khrushchev from office, was set on the road to ressurrection in 1984, when his party membership was reinstated.

title: THE NEW VOGUE IN LIFE INSURANCE
description: MOST people never consider life insurance as a potential tax shelter. Some types of policies, however, are such appealing shelters that cash-rich investors pump their money into them instead of municipals or mutual funds. What's more, this protection is not endangered by provisions in the tax bills under consideration by Congress.
