title: MEETING AT STEVENS TO EXPLORE ANCIENT CRAFT OF CALLIGRAPHY
description: THE construction of alphabets, rather than engineering projects, will soon be the focus at Stevens Institute of Technology here.

title: DIFFERENT APPROACHES ILLUMINATE BEETHOVEN'S CELLO SONATAS
description: Violoncello: What an odd word! The ''ello'' suffix tells us it is a diminutive form, meaning ''little violone.'' (Violone, in turn, is an augmentative word, meaning ''big violin'' - or viol, depending on whom you ask.) Notwithstanding that implication of smallness, the cello is the largest member of the present-day violin family, the double bass being more closely related to the earlier viols. Many would say that it is the most beautiful as well, capable of a range of sonorities unmatched by any other orchestral instrument.

title: Michigan Mulls Prepaid Tuition
description: In Michigan, parents may be able to start buying some protection from tuition worries. Under a proposal by Gov. James J. Blanchard, the state is preparing to handle the financial planning and, given an investment by parents, to guarantee a child's tuition at one of Michigan's 13 public colleges and universities.

title: CHALLENGE TO DOCTOR'S ETHICS EMERGES
description: THE medical ethic has traditionally dictated that individual physicians formulate their opinions and recommend referrals and therapy on the basis of honest evaluations of data, without regard to personal financial gain. While it is impossible to remove all financial pressures from the decision-making process, there are some practices, such as fee splitting, that are unethical because they so strongly influence practice patterns solely on the basis of financial considerations. Whether overt or covert, fee splitting offers personal financial gain in order to influence decisions made by the physician who controls the patient's care, and it is that aspect of the practice that makes it unethical.

title: CHANGING SIDES WITH MUSICAL
description: SWITCHING from one side of the footlights to the other has characterized the chameleon-like career of James Brochu, who has written and is directing ''Startime,'' a musical that opens Friday at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor. The last time out at Coachlight, Mr. Brochu played the romantic leading man in Cole Porter's ''Can-Can.''

title: Senna in Pole Position For French Grand Prix
description: Ayrton Senna of Brazil, who leads the world driver standing, held the pole position for the French Grand Prix in his Lotus-Renault through final qualifying today. It is his fifth pole spot in eight races.

title: Don't Leave the Union Hall Without It
description: Not only union members but also non-members in a new ''associate'' category will benefit from low-cost legal services and a low-interest credit card announced by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last week. The federation said its ''Union Privilege Legal Services'' and ''Union Privilege Mastercard,'' to be issued by the Bank of New York either free or at a bargain price to the credit-worthy, would be made available to about 5 million of the 13.1 million members of A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions this year, to all members next year and then to former members and certain non-members. Labor leaders consider the new services a step toward providing union members with benefits beyond collective bargaining - and as an organizing tactic, that will reach out to new kinds of workers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SIX KEY CUT. By Max Crawford. (Atheneum, $14.95.) This novel of drug dealing, murder, betrayal and madness opens with the cryptic epigram: ''There is no real Miami.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE New Jersey Highway Authority is starting an experimental program to catch toll cheaters along the Garden State Parkway, but officials would not say last week when the program would begin or if every tollbooth would be a target.

title: REVERSAL ON JUDICIAL NOMINEE BRINGS TROUBLE TO SENATOR GORTON
description: Senator Slade Gorton has run into political trouble after his last-minute switch on the confirmation of a controversial nominee for a Federal judgeship. Some of the trouble is linked with animosities arising from a 23-year-old libel suit.

title: DANCE
description: The rafters may rise when Jawole Willa Jo Zollar and the Urban Bush Women move into the Douglas Fairbanks Theater for a week, starting Tuesday, under the aegis of Clark Center's Summer Dance Festival '86. The vibrant company of six black women will perform a full-evening dance called ''Anarchy, Wild Women and Dinah,'' which Ms. Zollar describes as ''a raucous and rousing dance/theater work of songs and movements that resonates with the feeling and rhythms of the blues, African-American folktales and gut-bucket dancing.''

title: BLACK FEMALE VOCALISTS BANISH FORMULA POP
description: Pop music history was made recently when the weekly trade magazine Billboard reported that for the first time in its charting of records, America's three best-selling pop albums were by black female singers.

title: OGYGIAN, 2-5, WINS DWYER AT BELMONT
description: Ogygian, who missed the Triple Crown but could be the nation's best 3-year-old, passed the longest and stiffest test of his career by scoring a 2 1/4-length victory in the $180,300 Dwyer Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Contra Aid Prolongs the Torment of a Desperately Poor Country
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS WARN ON GETTING TOO MUCH SUN
description: AS LONG Islanders flock to the beaches in search of the perfect tan, doctors are warning about the growing incidence of skin cancer caused by the ultraviolet rays of the sun.

title: FOR OPERA ON THE MALL, A TASTE OF SOME RARITIES
description: ''WAGNER said it best, I think,''

title: The Litigator
description: Reading of David Boies's ''brilliant'' argument before the appellate court, thus described by his colleague who told him what the case was ''all about'' as they journeyed downtown by taxi, one is reminded of the anecdote of an English jurist in the early years of this century. Mr. Justice Darling is said to have remarked of the noted English barrister F. E. Smith (later Britain's Lord Chancellor), that ''I would rather hear F. E. Smith open a complicated case before me than any counsel at the bar.'' Asked why, he responded: ''It is so interesting to discover which of two fresh minds will grasp the facts first.'' The court of appeals must often have the same experience with Mr. Boies. JOHN W. MCCULLOUGH Chicago

title: Pamela J. Fekett Is Bride Of A. T. Bauman, Lawyer
description: Pamela J. Fekett and Andrew T. Bauman were married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony at the chapel of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University in Greenvale, L.I. The Rev. Scott Matheny, the Presbyterian chaplain of Columbia University, officiated.

title: Eating Off Books Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER COUP FOR THE FIGHTING GALLOS
description: BY now, almost everyone who watches television is familiar with Frank Bartles and Ed Jaymes, the lovable pair of geezers who hawk Bartles & Jaymes wine cooler from their porch. ''Ed took out a second [ mortgage ] on his house, wrote to Harvard for an M.B.A., and now we're preparing to enter the wine-cooler business,'' intoned Frank in the first of a series of more than 30 commercials that always end with him humbly thanking the viewers for their support.

title: PARK ON EX-ASPHALT SITE DEDICATES PLAYING FIELD
description: Asphalt Green, the neighborhood recreation complex built around the odd, half-barrel shaped municipal asphalt plant on the Upper East Side, has dedicated its new $1.5 million Astroturf playing field and announced plans to build an Olympic-size swimming pool.

title: IN A FIGHT FOR COMIC SUPREMACY, YANKS LOSE
description: The hallowed Oxford Union debating hall rang the other night with the contentious proposition that Englishmen are funnier than Americans, but the issue advanced little beyond the Catskills.

title: Miss Hart Is Engaged To Wed David Buron
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth N. Hart of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Wakefield, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lindsey A. Hart to David M. Buron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Buron of Bridgewater, Mass. The wedding is planned for Oct. 11.

title: RUSSIAN BECOMING AMERICANS IN FAIR LAWN
description: When Catherine Sharfstein began searching for a suburb, she knew nothing. How could a Russian immigrant living in the Bronx know the difference between a Nutley and a Lodi? So she set out to investigate suburbia in her usual methodical manner.

title: MUSIC: RAVINIA'S 'NEW' TCHAIKOVSKY
description: The Ravinia Festival, the summer home of the Chicago Symphony, is some 30 miles north of the downtown Loop and a mile or two west of Lake Michigan. An Easterner might describe Ravinia as a Midwestern Tanglewood without hills. There are an open-sided concert shed and a compact chamber music hall, both heavily used during July and August. For those who cannot find indoor tickets (and many of the summer's most popular concerts are already sold out), there are acres of lawn, shaded and meticulously kept, on which to picnic in clement weather. As it happened, the day was one of serene, wind-swept beauty with some excessive humidity offset by the summer breeze. In keeping with the commemorative importance of the date, American music was scheduled, but rather than the usual Gershwin and Sousa, Ravinia offered a chamber concert of works by the composer Joseph Fennimore, followed by an all Tchaikovsky program featuring the world premiere of Mr. Fennimore's new adaptation of Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 2.

title: VIEW CAMERAS MAKE A COMEBACK
description: OFTEN the first place where one can spot a trend is in a photography store. When buying habits change, it is generally a sign that something new is happening.

title: SPICY STAPLE OF INDONESIA
description: Nasi goreng: Two words of Indonesian will help the visitor stave off hunger anywhere in this vast and varied nation of islands scattered over several seas. From Islamic Banda Aceh, at the northern tip of Sumatra, through the ancient civilizations of Java and Bali to the edge of the wilderness of Irian Jaya on New Guinea, there are many Indone-sian cuisines but few national dishes. Nasi goreng is the best of them.In Indonesia's national language, which helps hold all this diversity together, nasi goreng means fried rice. But that's just a translation of convenience. A good nasi goreng is no ordinary plate of staple food. It is a complete meal of flavors and spices, garnishes and accompaniments.

title: The Litigator
description: The United States Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings in the late 1970's regarding conglomerate mergers and acquisitions receive very little attention in Cary Reich's fascinating account of the life and times of David Boies. Mr. Boies's presence there, as chief counsel, was not an insignificant event.

title: Milan Station
description: To the Editor: I hasten to add our experience to that of Joe Rapoport (Letters to the Editor, Travel, May 18).

title: Wendy Weil Is the Bride Of Engineer
description: Wendy Hollings Weil, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Weil 3d of Denver, was married yesterday to Richard Stockton Rush 3d, a son of Ellen Davies Rush of San Francisco and Mr. Rush Jr. of Westminster, Vt. The Rev. George B. Edgar, the bride's great-uncle, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Vail (Colo.) Chapel.

title: Sacco's Pistol
description: To the Editor:

title: Eight Strikers Arrested In Philadelphia
description: The police arrested eight striking city workers today for blocking the entrance to a water plant, but reported no other incidents as the strike by about 15,000 municipal employees entered its fifth day.

title: CLASSIC GARDEN TAMES A FIERCE WELSH CRAG
description: The serene beauty of the storybook castles that, like Powis Castle, rise above rolling green hills on the English-Welsh border, seems to belie the bellicosity of their past. The Marches, as the borderlands were known, once were a perennial battleground for marauding exploits between Welsh princes and Anglo-Norman knights.

title: August Ceremony Set For Mindy Silverman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Silverman of Syosset, L.I., and Lauderhill, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mindy Roberta Silverman to William Paul Connelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Connelly of Indian River Shores, Fla.

title: Miss Podlubny Is a Bride
description: Sara-Jane Victoria Podlubny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Podlubny of Knighton, Leicestershire, England, was married there yesterday to John Berry Millard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Millard of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert Smith performed the ceremony at St. Mary Magdalen Anglican Church. The bride is a computer programmer for Barclays Bank in London. Mr. Millard attends the Diploma School of the Architectural Association of London.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: La Bayadere. A Kirov Ballet production, with choreography by Vakhtang Chabukiani and Vladimir Ponomarev after Marius Petipa, 1977; Kultur; 126 minutes.

title: Make the Players Get Their Diplomas
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WASHINGTON ASKS FOR FEEDBACK FROM THE FARM
description: COMBINES were lumbering across the high plains last week but the talk around many communities was most likely not about the harvest.

title: POP: DAVID ALLYN SINGS
description: DAVID ALLYN is a singer who couples clear, precise enunciation with an easy but expressive interpretation of a song's lyrics. It is a delivery that is ideal for a small, intimate room such as Gregory's (First Avenue at 63d Street), where he will be singing Wednesdays through Saturdays throughout July.

title: John Herzan Wed To Lauren Brown
description: Lauren Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Brown of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to John Herzan, a son of Dr. Helen M. Herzan of Arlington, Mass., and the late Dr. Francis A. Herzan. Justice of the Peace Emay Twining Buck of Old Lyme, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Brown home.

title: Nancy Pfeffer to Wed A. Van Ripps on Aug. 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Pfeffer of White Plains have announced that their daughter Nancy Lee Pfeffer and A. Van Ripps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Ripps of Bayonne, N.J., are to be married Aug. 9.

title: Caroline Mitchell Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Lindsay Mitchell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Thorn Mitchell to James Roy Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Clark of Cary, Ill. A September wedding is planned.

title: ONE IS KILLED AND 27 ARE HURT IN PLANT ACCIDENT
description: A worker who apparently fell into a tank of chemicals was killed last night and two of three other workers who went to find him were seriously injured at a metal products factory in Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Phyllis Anne Benjamin Is Wed to Michael Shia
description: Phyllis Anne Benjamin, a candidate for a doctorate in musicology at Harvard University, and Michael Almaza Shia, a postdoctoral fellow at the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research, were married yesterday at the Endicott Estate in Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Larry M. Hill, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Boston Teachers Count the Minutes
description: WHAT difference does five minutes make? To the Boston School Department it will mean a difference of $60,000, the amount it must pay teachers at the Boston Latin School who, their union claims, worked five minutes extra a day for the last two years.

title: NAVRATILOVA CAPTURES HER 7TH WIMBLEDON CROWN
description: This is an era when an air of inevitability hangs over Centre Court the day the women's singles final is played at Wimbledon. Fans cannot help but think the match itself is just part of some elaborate ceremony ending with Martina Navratilova's raising the treasured challenge trophy above her head. There have now been seven such moments in Miss Navratilova's career - five in succession -an impressive montage to hang on her wall.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOT REJECTS U.N. PLEA TO END BLOCKADE
description: Rauf Denktash, leader of the secessionist Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, today turned down a United Nations request for an urgent meeting to lift a blockade on traffic between the zones of this divided island.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GREAT WORKS OF JEWISH FANTASY AND OCCULT. Compiled and translated by Joachim Neugroschel. (Overlook, $27.95.) Although written for Yiddish-speaking, Eastern European Jews of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the fables, ghost stories and humorous tales in this anthology are as universal as childhood.

title: REUNITED
description: When he isn't bogged down in matters of church and state, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, foreign minister of Nicaragua, is just like any other guy attending his class reunuion. Mingling with other members of the class of 1961 at the Marynoll seminary last week, Father d'Escoto, who was born in Los Angeles, fondly recalled his experience there, saying he ''loved every minute of it.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LAST OF THE BREED. By Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) Backward are many of the sentences in this large, robust novel, but who's worrying? Certainly not the multitudes who make up Louis L'Amour's readership.

title: Kari McCabe Has Wedding
description: Kari Birgitta McCabe and Nate McBride were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Osborn Elliott, stepfather and mother of the bride, in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Beth Ide, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: Can you suggest companies that conduct serious historical-literary tours of Ireland and Northern Ireland? - C. M., New York Answer:Officials of tour companies that specialize in Ireland and Northern Ireland say there is no regularly scheduled program of historical or literary package tours. However, tour companies arrange such trips for clubs, societies and other groups that approach them, provided there are at least 15 travelers. The tour firms will also organize historical and literary tours for individuals or parties of fewer than 15 people, who are driven by a chauffeur-guide or drive themselves. (Many hotels give special rates to groups of least 15 people, which is also the number generally required to hire a tour bus.) Among tour organizations that tailor special-interest tours in Ireland for groups or individuals is C.I.E. Tours (122 East 42d Street, New York, N.Y. 10168; 212-972-5600 or 800-243-8687). Like other companies, C.I.E., which is Ireland's national transportation authority, can also include a visit to Northern Ireland.

title: MONTAUK LIGHTHOUSE TO BE A MUSEUM
description: AFTER months of negotiations, the Montauk Historical Society has reached agreement with the Coast Guard to convert the Montauk Point Lighthouse into a museum.

title: IN THE 'ME' AGE, FEWER NUNS
description: WHEN he was a child in Roman Catholic grade school in Woodhaven, Msgr. John A. Alesandro recently recalled, there was a nun teaching ''in every single grade.''

title: CAN THE FUN OF A NEW CAREER (AT 65) STAVE OFF MEDICARE?
description: MY HUSBAND graduated from college last month. Since it also happened to be his 65th birthday, it was the day he went on Medicare, too.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WHO ever would have thought that just looking at the mail would be so depressing? It is, alas, and getting more so every day. At first glance, the sheer bulk looks reassuring and impressive, an indication that we've made a mark in the world, we're in demand, people know we're here. It's only after a second look, and bitter experience, that we come to the conclustion that maybe it would be better to be anonymous -that almost all the envelopes addressed to us can safely be thrown into the wastebasket without being opened, and that we would miss absolutely nothing. This deep-six filing applies particularly to envelopes addressed by computer, affixed with pretyped labels or, indignity of all indignities, sent to ''Resident.''

title: JARUZELSKI TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: Poland, as Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski sees it, is now so thoroughly ''normal'' that some of the more than 300 people locked up for political crimes can be amnestied. But the Polish leader's offer last week was limited to ''perpetrators of certain categories of offenses.''

title:
INVESTING;
WHAT THE EXPERTS DO WITH THEIR MONEY
description: IT has been said that doctors make the worst patients. So it should be no surprise that many Wall Street strategists, analysts and money managers do not always follow their own advice.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Dempsey
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Dempsey Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Allison Dempsey, to Stephen B. Gruppo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno Gruppo of Cos Cob, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: SOVIET WRITERS SEEK PEACEFUL CO-EXISTENCE WITH THE STATE
description: ''BY THE will of fate, it may be that we are almost the last country in the world that reads,'' the poet Andrei Voznesensky told the Union of Writers two weeks ago. The claim had a touch of literary hyperbole, but what Mr. Voznesensky had in mind is that despite television, urbanization and the spread of pop culture the written word retains an almost mystical force among Russians.

title: Carl Schurtz Married To LuAnne Edwards
description: LuAnne Edwards, a vice president of Government Finance Associates, a financial advisory firm in Princeton, N.J., and New York, was married yesterday to Carl F. Schurtz, a composer of music for documentary films and television and a music teacher at St. Bernard's School in New York. The Rev. Willard Curtis performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Richland, Mich.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SAMUEL GOMPERS PAPERS: Volume One: The Making of a Union Leader, 1850-56. Edited by Stuart B. Kaufman. (University of Illinois, $39.95.)

title: CHALLENGE BY FRENCH YACHT
description: As the birthday celebration for the Statue of Liberty comes to a close in New York today, a spinoff of its sailing festivities has landed in Newport, R.I., in the form of a race challenge from a leading French yachtsman.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MADONNA OF 115th STREET: Faith and Community in Italian Harlem, 1880-1950. By Robert Anthony Orsi. 287 pp. (Yale University, $29.95.)

title:
GARDENING;
TAWNY DAYLILIES: BEAUTIFUL SURVIVORS
description: THE tenacity and beauty of the roadside tawny day lilies makes them the objects of admiration. Patches of these summer-flowering perennials may be found along country roads competing with weeds, grass and almost anything other than dense shade. They grow in shallow as well as deep places, in wet as well as dry areas and in poor as well as fertile soils. In periods of drought, they may wilt and even turn somewhat brown, but they survive and even flower.

title:
THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE;
ITALY TO EASTCHESTER
description: CRESCENZO DeLUCIA was remembering the day more than 70 years ago when he arrived by boat at Ellis Island from Italy with his mother and a younger brother.

title: A DISPUTE IN ANTI-LILCO RANKS
description: THE informal alliance between many Suffolk Democrats and civic groups that oppose the Shoreham nuclear power plant may be coming apart.

title: 'GONE WITH THE WIND' AUTHOR IS HONORED
description: Last Monday in Atlanta, Ga., the United States Postal Service issued a one-cent Great American stamp to honor Margaret Mitchell. Mrs. Mitchell was the author of the novel, ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: DID YOU HEAR ABOUT THE NAKED SKIER?
description: THE MEXICAN PET More ''New'' Urban Legends and Some Old Favorites. By Jan Harold Brunvand. Illustrated. 221 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $13.95.

title: Robyn Shapiro Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Shapiro of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robyn Lynn Shapiro, to Dr. Norm Turkowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Turkowitz of Bellmore, L.I. Miss Shapiro, a graduate of George Washington University, will attend the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School of Yeshiva University in September. Dr. Turkowitz graduated from Hofstra University and the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine.

title: Topics; Lasting Values; Oozenoz
description: It's a wish as futile as entreating mosquitoes to disappear, but mosquitoes are worth swatting and it's a wish worth making: that observers of American celebrations give up the expression ''Oohs and aahs.''

title: MIDDLE-AGE DATING
description: I'M DIALING A PHONE NUMBER, AND when I've touched five digits, I suddenly hang up. For two or three minutes I sit on my bed, my lips moving occasionally, as if I were an actor going over a part. Then I pick up the phone, hesitate, start to put it down again. Instead, I quickly touch seven tones. A woman answers.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID SEEK OUT AND KILL 5 BLACK OFFICIALS
description: Anti-Government gunmen armed with Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles shot and killed five black municipal officials early today, the authorities said.

title: Jane Appleyard To Wed Sept. 6
description: Announcement has been made by Bishop and Mrs. Robert B. Appleyard of Weekapaug, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Sharp Appleyard, to Raymond Allen Roel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. Roel of Woodbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for Sept. 6.

title: DOCTOR'S LINEUP OF DODGERS BETTER THAN LASORDA'S
description: TEAMS use buses to transport their players between hotels and ball parks and between ball parks and airports. The Los Angeles Dodgers could have used a bus the other day to take eight of their players to Centinela Medical Center. The eight injured Dodgers visited Dr. Frank Jobe, the team's orthopedist, when the Dodgers returned home from a road trip last Thursday. The timing of the group visit was significant because the Dodgers had fallen into last place the previous night.

title: Japan Should Eat More, Not Sell More
description: Sometimes, not even diligence and frugality are enough to assure prosperity. For the first time since 1974, Japan's economy has skidded into recession.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Seattle on June 22, on the growth of ultrafundamentalist Christian sects, misidentified a Chicago organization that monitors religious cults in this country. It is the Citizens Freedom Foundation.

title: PROPER EQUIPMENT MAKES GARDENING LESS OF A CHORE
description: There is no getting around the fact that gardening is work.

title: MAKING HIGH GARAGE RATES PALATABLE
description: WITH soaring downtown real estate rates forcing garage prices ever higher, many garage owners have found that to keep customers, they must provide more than just the parking space. Some are offering ambiance; others are offering safety.

title: PRESERVING HISTORIC MUSICALS
description: ''Many people throughout the world believe that the American musical is one of our nation's most important contributions to culture,'' Robert Kimball, a leading authority on musical theater, said recently. ''And yet if you want to locate the scores of major works by Jerome Kern, George Gershwin or Rodgers and Hart, you face enormous obstacles. Original material has been lost - songs, orchestrations, scripts and so on. You also find that a lot of works exist only in updated or revised versions - a 20's comedy updated for the 40's, say, with jokes about Harold Stassen and Harry Truman added to the original.''

title: NICARAGUAN MOVE ASSAILED BY POPE
description: Pope John Paul II issued a stinging attack on the Nicaraguan Government today for expelling a Roman Catholic bishop, describing the move as an act of the ''dark ages.''

title: Liberty, for All
description: A hunger seized New York this Liberty Weekend, an eagerness to play a tangible part, a zeal to Be There. ''Oh my God,'' said Nicholas Scott, a young security guard Friday at Battery Park City. ''I can't believe I'm actually a part of this.'' The millions were not disappointed. There truly were once-in-a-lifetime moments, as when the Statue blossomed in pure light or when soaring fountains of fire filled the sky.

title: NEW AGENCY TO PUSH THE USE OF MASS TRANSIT
description: TRANSIT agencies in the metropolitan region, armed with a new Federal grant, have launched plans to further encourage the use of mass transit by Manhattan-bound commuters.

title: France
description: To the Editor: Referring to the excellent article by Lucinda Franks (''In France, the Meal as a Metaphor'') in the Travel section of April 20, I wish to say a few words.

title: A PASTEL PLEASURE IN THE HAMPTONS
description: THERE have been changes, including the chef, at the Inn at Quogue, a colonial hostelry in the village of Quogue. The difference in the food is fairly subtle.

title: FARM TOUR '86: BLUEBERRIES TO BOVINES
description: SANDI ROSE was out in the fields this week, planting marigolds, dahlias and towering snapdragons around the red-and-white signs that direct visitors around her farm's blueberry bushes. Later, she telephoned friends and relatives in an effort to corral them into coming out to the farm to work next weekend.

title: THE GROUP, 12 YEARS LATER
description: ALL FIVE women in Norma Goldstein's living room on the Upper West Side of Manhattan feel as if they've come home. Norma, a 54-year-old pianist, settles into a corner of the couch. Alice Campagna, a 44-year-old restaurant owner, scours the room for an ashtray. Andrea Sedlak, a 39-year-old senior research scientist, pours herself a glass of wine. Brenda Boozer, 38, an opera singer, and Carol Morra, 45, an actress, catch up on news of each other as they fill their plates with chicken.

title: Houston Official Refuses To Accept Pay Cut
description: The City Controller has refused to accept a 3 percent salary decrease imposed on other municipal workers, instead promising to set aside that portion of his income to help employees hurt by the pay cuts.

title: JUST KEEPING AN EYE ON THE TEEN-AGER DOWN THE BLOCK
description: MY friend has gone to Nantucket again for her annual three-week stay. I used to watch her house and water her plants. This year her 17-year-old son stayed home. He's watching the house and watering the plants. I am watching her son. I much prefer the plants. My friend has a wonderful way with plants and flowers. They bloom, they thrive, they are gorgeous under her tutelage. The first year she went away, she asked me to care for her plants inside and out. Her attitude was casual. In fact, all she really said was, if you think of it, check up on my plants.

title: What It Means to Be Stateless
description: I remember: spring 1944, in Hungary. Shabbat unlike any other. The courtyard of the principal synagogue was crowded with the city's last Jews. We stood in an endless line waiting to enter the building, not to pray but to rest and collect our thoughts. The process of our deportation had begun several hours ago, as gendarmes had driven us out of our homes. The bureaucratic machinery was functioning efficiently, but we did not know for what purpose.

title: AN EASY INTRODUCTION TO THE PC
description: WHEN one looks at the cost of a personal computer in an office environment, the most obvious expense is the hardware. It is the easiest factor to quantify, after all. One needs the computer, a monitor, a printer and perhaps a modem.

title: RURAL, SUBURBAN AND KINKY
description: BINDWEED By Christianne Balk. 54 pp. New York: Collier Books/Macmillan Publishing Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95. THE FIRE MUSIC By Liz Rosenberg. 58 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $6.95. LOCAL TIME By Stephen Dunn. 110 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95. CHRISTIANNE BALK'S ''Bindweed,'' winner of the 1985 Walt Whitman Award of the Academy of American Poets as the best first book of poems by an American, shows some of the awkwardness and tentativeness characteristic of younger poets, but it also introduces an artist resonant with talent. Ms. Balk writes poems that stay close to nature, tapping the rhythms of the changing seasons for metaphors of the human life cycle and rounding out nature's powerful processes with the human qualities of joy, loss and grief. In ''The Young Widow Talks to Herself'' the husband's absence is felt to be ''a gouge in the snow / Scooped between the spruce trees,'' and just as we feel the cold concentration of the widow's sorrow, we can also project the time when spring flowers will occupy the exact same place.

title: Hundreds Are Detained By Troops in Chile
description: Soldiers and the police rounded up hundreds of men in a Santiago neighborhood today as Chile's military Government responded to two days of opposition protests in which six people were killed, witnesses said.

title: FLIP-TAX MEASURE GAINS IN ALBANY
description: THE uncertain status of the flip tax - the fee paid to cooperative apartment corporations by shareholders when they sell their apartments - would be clarified by a measure passed by the State Legislature and now awaiting Governor Cuomo's signature.

title: DISSATISFACTION WITH STABILZATION'S COST INDEX GROWS
description: WHENEVER New York City's Rent Guidelines Board meets in public, the two tenant representatives sit together facing the audience at one end of a 30-foot-long table and the two landlord representatives sit as far away as possible on the other end. Between them sit the four public members and the chairman.

title: A.M.A. TAKES ON INEPT DOCTORS
description: The American Medical Association, the nation's most influential organization of physicians, has launched a new effort to identify and discipline incompetent doctors.

title: GRILLING AS ART
description: JULY IS BARBECUE SEA-son across America. To me, it has a special appeal in New York's Hamptons, on the south shore of Long Island. There are few pleasures in life that can equal the aroma of freshly grilled fish or beef mingling with the clear saltiness of a sea breeze.

title: The Litigator
description: On June 1, you featured articles about the lawyer David Boies Jr., 45 years old, and the surgeon William Cahan, 71 (''In His Father's Footsteps,'' by Samuel G. Freedman), two men who have reached pinnacles in their professions.

title: THOUSANDS JOIN IN PROTESTS IN PAKISTAN
description: Tens of thousands of anti-Government demonstrators rallied here and in other major cities of Pakistan today as Benazir Bhutto, the opposition leader, resumed her campaign to press for elections to oust President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq.

title: Vermont Asks: Are Cows Art?
description: SOME residents of Stowe, Vt., said the plywood Holsteins grazing in a field next to a local motel were art. Others said they were advertising. William R. (Woody) Jackson said they were a copyright infringement.

title: A TIRELESS ADVOCATE FOR TEAM HANDBALL
description: IF soccer is the world's most popular sport, what's the second most popular?

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ANOTHER LIFE TO LIVE
description: IT wasn't easy. In fact, it was downright scary. But Rosemarie, 47 years old, was going to do it. She was going to get a college degree.

title: Harness Driver Posts 6 Victories on Program
description: John Campbell drove six horses to victory on the 11-race harness card today at the Meadowlands.

title: NEW JETTY MAY EASE THE DANGERS BOATMEN FACE IN BARNEGAT INLET
description: ''JUST 15 minutes in that cold water and they'd have been gone,'' said William R. Hammarstrom, captain of the 85-foot Carolyn Ann III, a party fishing boat, recalling the plight of the eight people he rescued on May 10.

title: Verbatim; Time of Troubles
description: 'An alarming proportion of America's teen-agers drop out of school, commit crimes, become pregnant, abuse drugs or alcohol, commit suicide or die from injuries and become disabled, mentally and physically. Yet our knowledge of how to prevent the serious and widespread casualties of adolescence is limited and fragmented.'

title: METROMEDIA ADDS TO ITS PILE OF CASH
description: Metromedia's $1.65 billion sale of paging and mobile phone businesses should make its billionaire founder even richer. John W. Kluge struck the deal with Southwestern Bell, which will use the new units to become the largest force in cellular telephones. Mr. Kluge took Metromedia private in 1984 in what was regarded as the first step toward expanding his empire. However, he has since sold off virtually the entire company; the phone businesses were the last remaining large holdings. Now Wall Street is wondering what will be done with that mound of cash.

title: Punting at Oxford
description: To the Editor: In ''Reflections on Five Rivers'' (Travel, June 15), it seems your caption writer confused the Thames with the Cherwell, calling the Cherwell the Isis, whereas in Oxford it is the Thames that is known as the Isis. As I recall, it was possible to punt on the Isis although the water was uncomfortably deep for the pole, but we much preferred the more romantic Cherwell with its leaf-shaded banks and gentle flow. Perhaps the most peaceful and contented hours of my life were spent punting on the Cherwell, a picnic hamper up front, a jug of wine trailing from the side.

title: PRODUCTIVITY, FROM A TO ZZZZZZZZZ...
description: SLEEPING on the job.

title: Karen DaCosta Engaged
description: Mrs. Conrad DaCosta of Brick Township, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Karen Frances DaCosta to Jeffrey Perzan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Perzan of Tucson, Ariz. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Mr. DaCosta, is an associate in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. Mr. Perzan is a lawyer for the International Business Machines Corporation in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: C. C. Hauge To Be Bride
description: Caroline Clark Hauge, an account executive for the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, and William Bradford Crenshaw, a member of the class of '87 at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, plan to be married Aug. 31.

title: KING VIDOR, PRIVATE EYE
description: A CAST OF KILLERS By Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. Illustrated. 301 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95. IN his introduction to ''A Cast of Killers,'' Sidney D. Kirkpatrick tells us he did not set out to write this book. An authorized biography of the late film director King Vidor was the author's objective. Mr. Kirkpatrick says that after his subject's death in 1982, he opened a locked strongbox Vidor had long ago hidden behind a garage water heater. Only then did he discover the almost incredible tale that unfolds here.

title: HEIRS OF STATUE'S PROMISE LINE UP TO PAY A VISIT
description: Some had stood through the night. Others joined the line at dawn. And hours later, when the call came to board, their voices lifted in unison, softly at first, singing ''God Bless America.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TOOLS have a way with me.

title: FISH STUDY BY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS H ELPS PROTECT A BROOK
description: FISH, environmentalists know, can be the protectors of lakes and rivers. Whether it is a small fish in big waters, as in the case of the snail darter in the Little Tennessee River, or big fish in big waters, as in the case of striped bass in the Hudson River, or even small fish in small waters, as in the case of brook trout in Indian Brook in Lewisboro, proving that fish are present may help protect a body of water from the effects of development.

title: A CHEERFUL CELEBRATION OF THE GOOD-HEARTED AMERICAN IDYLL
description: Amid the joyous jumble that was lower Manhattan this weekend, an Indian immigrant named Shailesh Patel was frantically unpacking boxes of Statue of Liberty T-shirts. He did not have a free second to look up from his newsstand and admire the statue itself, not so far away in the harbor.

title: Lucille Pendleton To Wed Nov. 29
description: The engagement of Lucille Culbertson Pendleton to Hugh Van Seaton, has been announced by Josephine C. Pendleton and Edmund E. Pendleton of Washington, parents of the future bride. Mr. Seaton is a son of Mrs. Walter Seaton of Eureka, Mo., and the late Mr. Seaton. A Nov. 29 wedding is planned.

title: LOS ANGELES MINORITIES SPLIT OVER COUNCIL PLAN
description: A bitter, name-calling battle over a plan to redraw City Council districts erupted this week between the sole Hispanic member of the Council and the sole Asian-American member, in effect pitting the two fastest-growing minority groups in Los Angeles against each other.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A LITTLE IGNORANCE. By Penelope Scambly Schott. (Clarkson N. Potter, $16.95.) This nostalgic first novel is set in the 1940's and narrated by Alison Walters as she matures from a child of 8 to a knowing, sexual 15-year-old.

title: AMID POMP, GAMES BEGIN
description: The Goodwill Games, the first large-scale confrontation of American and Soviet athletes since the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, opened here tonight with a two-hour extravaganza of dance, athletics and elaborate pageantry.

title: A 2d PROJECT FOR FORMER WAREHOUSES
description: In 1982, the Key Land Development Corporation purchased a former Fire Island ferry and began offering free shuttle trips to Manhattan from its 150-unit Bay Street Landing I development on Staten Island.

title: Working Profile: Ben C. Rusche; Semantics and the Art of Burying Nuclear Waste
description: Ben C. Rusche was trained as an engineer and now holds what just might be the most thankless political job in Washington. But his biggest problem, he says, is probably the English language.

title: MIXED REVIEW FOR $33 MILLION IN PER CAPITA GRANTS
description: MUNICIPAL officials are happy with the General Assembly's decision to return $33 million of an estimated $312 million state surplus to the municipalities, but few seem content with the way the money will be distributed.

title: 4 in Newark Hospitals After Fireworks Blast
description: At least four people remained hospitalized yesterday after a fireworks explosion injured about 30 people who were watching a Fourth of July celebration at Ironbound Stadium in Newark, hospital officials said.

title: TORONADO A SPIFFY COMPACT
description: IT is handy to refer to rear-wheel drive as ''conventional,'' but the new convention really has it the other way round. Most of today's cars are pulled rather than pushed, with transversely mounted engines driving the same wheels that steer.

title: Contra Aid Prolongs the Torment of a Desperately Poor Country
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC
description: Summer is here and New York musical life has moved outdoors. The sound may not always rival that of the best auditoriums, but listening to some favorite works outdoors has an undeniable esthetic pleasure of its own. (I vividly remember a perfomrnace of Beethoven's ''Creatures of Prometheus'' overture, surrounded by the chirp and chatter of genuine creatures.) Tonight at 8, for example, Ainslee Cox will conduct the Goldman Memorial Band in songs by Irving Berlin, Stephen Foster, George M. Cohan and others at Damrosch Park, within the Lincoln Center complex, near the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 62d Street. One highlight will be the world premiere of the concert band version of Beatrice Laufer's ''And Thomas Jefferson Said . . . .''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FOUR months ago, it appeared that the perennial legislative impasse over how to pay for shore protection might be broken soon. Of late, however, normalcy has returned.

title: LIFE BETWEEN THE CITY AND THE DEEP BLUE SEA
description: I'VE had a longtime love affair with Fire Island. It was more than 30 years ago that my feet first touched that 31-mile-long beach, and the sand has clung ever since.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: SHAREHOLDERS of Midlantic Banks Inc., a bank holding company based in Edison, and Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia have approved a previously announced merger.

title: THE WAY OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN: CREATING 'LIVING HISTORIES'
description: THE busy sounds from the 20th century seem to hush and fade into murmurs within the dome-shaped wigwam. A faint light streams into the dwelling from the cracks between the sheets of bark shingles. The bent-cedar saplings tied with cordage make up the framework. The cool, packed earth is the floor.

title: PHILHARMONIC CATCHES TEMPO OF LIBERTY WEEKEND
description: As the sun was setting over the Statue of Liberty, Central Park came to life last night in her honor, in an international classical concert that was as spirited and lively as the enormous crowd that watched and listened.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Knocked About by Words - A connoisseur of the darker emotions, Ingmar Bergman sees humiliation as a peculiarly modern feeling, a toxic waste product perhaps of our political and emotional life. This is from ''Bergman on Bergman'' (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster), interviews with Stig Bjorkman, Torsten Manns and Jonas Sima.

title: A. T. Foster Wed To Miss Norton
description: Michele Elizabeth Norton, the daughter of Virginia Norton of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Elmer Norton of Bristol, Conn., was married yesterday to Alexander Tolstoi Foster, a son of Anne Tolstoi Wallach and Ronald Martin Foster Jr., both of New York. The Rev. Mark Anschutz, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Carlyle House in Alexandria, Va.

title: NEW INITIATIVES AT CITY COLLEGE FOR HARLEM
description: Last Tuesday at 10 A.M., Vincent Thomas sat atop the highest hill on Manhattan Island and addressed Harlem.

title: UNRAVELING A RING OF INSIDERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission last week named more names in the Dennis B. Levine insider-trading network, which is beginning to look like an industry of its own. Like Mr. Levine, who pleaded guilty last month, the two former investment bankers charged last week are expected to implicate others.

title: ACHILLE LAURO CASE STIRS NEW DISPUTE
description: As the jury in the Achille Lauro hijacking trial prepares to consider a verdict, a top Italian intelligence official has questioned the assertion by the prosecution that it uncovered the true authors of the terrorist action.

title: Martha Hamilton-Phillips to Marry in September
description: Martha Hamilton-Phillips, an assistant professor of art history at Hunter College, and Dr. Robert Purks Maccubbin, a professor of English at the College of William and Mary, plan to be married Sept. 20. The couple's parents are Dr. Howard L. Hamilton of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Alison Phillips Hamilton and Mary Anna Maccubbin of Gaithersburg, Md., and the late Walter Aubrey Maccubbin.

title: INVENTING OUR PROBABLE PAST
description: ONCE upon a time historians took historical novels seriously enough to review them in the American Historical Review and discuss the genre earnestly in essays. William Francis Allen, the mentor of the historian of the American frontier Frederick Jackson Turner (1861-1932), wrote in 1890: ''If historical fiction has a real and important place in literature, its task, nevertheless, is an extremely difficult one.'' Allen went on to exhort the historical novelist to combine ''the accurate scholarship of the historian'' with ''the highest exercise of the historical imagination.''

title: DODGING THE BULLETS AT THE CITY'S WELFARE AGENCY
description: New York City's Administrator of Human Resources presides over a staff of 25,000, a budget of nearly $5 billion and the miseries of more than a million needy New Yorkers. In winter, when the homeless are most at risk, even the weather is against him; welfare as an issue is a target for critics all year round. When George Gross left his job in Washington as chief lobbyist for the National League of Cities to take over at the Human Resources Administration in 1984, several city officials had turned the job down. His predecessor had resigned while H.R.A. was under attack for its handling of foster care, child abuse and the homeless, and for trying to silence whistle-blowers. Last week Mr. Gross left the agency to become executive director of the State Financial Control Board. Alan Finder, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, asked him to talk about his two years in the post. Excerpts follow. Question. You have called this the most difficult job of your career. What makes it so hard to run the H.R.A.?

title: A LAKE SWIMMER MEETS THE OCEAN
description: I'VE always loved the water. One of the earliest pictures my parents have of me is as a grinning baby, crawling on all fours in an inch of Lake Michigan, looking shoreward totally without fear.

title: Crew Is Rescued After 2 Weeks Adrift
description: Six crew members who spent two weeks adrift in life rafts after their fish-processing boat sank were rescued 300 miles east of here today by a Navy intelligence ship, the Coast Guard said.

title: MAHWAH
description: SIX years ago, Mahwah was the focus of national attention when the gates to the sprawling Ford assembly plant were shut for the last time, leaving 3,700 people without jobs in one of the country's largest industrial layoffs.

title: IN STAMFORD, 'YESTERDAY'S TOMORROWS'
description: PLATO seems to have been the first to write about paradise on earth. Sir Thomas More the first to call it Utopia. And both conceived of it in political terms. On the other hand, to the Shakers, who in their prime were the largest and most successful of the Utopian groups, earthly paradise was a matter of applying ''hands to work and hearts to God.''

title: PLAN OFFERED TO AID INDIGENT ILL
description: LEGISLATION that would fundamentally change the way New Jersey hospitals are repaid for treating the poor is scheduled for consideration Wednesday by the State Senate Institutions, Health and Welfare Committee.

title: Gauntlet Is Thrown
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE
description: FROM the Portuguese community in Tarrytown to the Arab neighborhood in Yonkers, Westchester County is today as much of a destination for immigrants as it was in the early part of the century when boatloads of Italians and Irish settled in the county's cities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RICH LIKE US. By Nayantara Sahgal. (Norton, $14.95.) India in the mid-1970's, at the time of Indira Gandhi's assumption of emergency powers, is the setting for this fervent, ambitious novel.

title: Benjamin Evett, Antonia Prescott Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Prescott of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Antonia Courthope Prescott, to Benjamin Robert Murray Evett, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David Evett of Cleveland, Heights, Ohio.

title: Plane Slams Into Tree In California, Killing 4
description: A single-engine plane slammed into a tree after takeoff Friday from South Lake Tahoe Airport, killing all four people aboard, the authorities said.

title: ALWAYS ON THE SIDE OF THE HERETICS
description: MURROW His Life and Times. By A. M. Sperber. Illustrated. 795 pp. New York: Freundlich Books. $22.95.

title: MEMORIES TUMBLE IN WITH THE SURF IN A WALK ON RYE BEACH
description: ''I MUST go down to the sea again . . .'' I cannot live too far from the sea. When I am inland, I yearn to walk on the sand. Spring, summer, fall or winter, I love to walk at the edge of the water, letting the ripples of waves wash lightly at my feet. I love to pick up a shell, a pebble, a piece of driftwood. I draw strength and peace from nature's merged forces - the earth, the sky, the water. It is always the sea, but for me, most of all, it is Rye Beach.

title:
DINING OUT;
COLONIAL SETTING OFF THE TACONIC
description: IF mealtime finds summer travelers near the Taconic Parkway and Route 84 and a fancy dinner is in order, diners might consider stopping at Le Chambord, a scant minute and a half away from this intersection. The restaurant and inn occupies a splendid 1863 Georgian Colonial building. Although events within are less promising than the facade and the formal service would suggest, the food has its moments.

title: Peggy Davison to Wed David Stephens in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Henry Davison of Bluff Point, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Rae Davison to David Brockman Stephens, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Wade C. Stephens of Lawrenceville, N.J. A Sept. 27 wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PRIVATE LIVES: Men and Women of the Fifties. By Benita Eisler. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) The picture on the dust jacket is pure 1950's camp: Mom, Dad and the kids are barbecuing hot dogs on the beach.

title: PLAN TO REALLOCATE PART OF RADIO BAND DISPUTED
description: Objections from public safety organizations have delayed action on a proposal for commercial development of a sizable part of the best radio spectrum available for land-based, two-way radio communications.

title: TEACHERS MAKE HOUSE CALLS TO THE ILL
description: Terry Lachman, his satchel stuffed with the instruments of his profession, makes daily rounds calling on sick children in their apartments around the South Bronx.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OUT OF BONDAGE. By Linda Lovelace With Mike McGrady (Lyle Stuart, $14.95.) In her 1980 book ''Ordeal,'' Linda Lovelace, star of the pornographic movie ''Deep Throat,'' described her life as a porn star as a nightmare of physical and psychological abuse.

title: THE EGYPTIAN ECONOMY HAS NO PLACE TO TURN
description: LIVING is far from easy for most people in this filthy, crowded city. Extended families jam into one or two tiny rooms and squatters build shanties on rooftops, against ancient city walls and along the banks of the Nile. About one million people live amid the stench of raw sewage in the sprawling cemetery known as the City of the Dead, the lucky ones in crumbling old mausoleums.

title: Marcos Reports 3 Offers Of Asylum in Africa
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos was quoted today as saying that three African countries - Ivory Coast, Gabon and Ghana - had offered to give him asylum if he would help them build their economies.

title: Q AND A
description: Replacing Loft Fixtures . . .

title: IMPROVEMENT IN TEACHERS SEEN AS THREATENED
description: The expected departure from the classroom of about half the nation's teachers over the next six years will leave a shortage of qualified instructors that threatens the impetus for improvement in the profession, Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, has warned.

title: NOTHING FORGOTTEN, NOTHING LEARNED
description: THE ARMY AND VIETNAM By Andrew F. Krepinevich Jr. Illustrated. 318 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $26.50.

title: Today
description: 7 A.M. - On Your Mark . . . rrxhContestants in Liberty triathlon begin with 1.5-mile swim from Liberty Island, followed by 100-mile bicycle race and 10-kilometer foot race that ends at Liberty Bell in Philadelphia. 10 A.M. - Food, Music and Puppets rrxhLast day of festival of food, crafts and entertainment.

title: SINGLE - AND SEARCHING
description: ROUND in our circle we sit - the over-35 singles - discussing in various settings all over Long Island issues of concern. ''How to Combat Loneliness,'' ''Better the Second Time Around,'' ''Effective Communication for Successful Relationships.'' The variations are endless.

title: HOW MOSTLY MOZART MADE IT TO 20
description: Twenty years ago, no one was sure if the Mostly Mozart Festival would make it to its second birthday. It was all quite experimental, one possible response to a problem: New York City had a brand-new cultural center, but its constituents vacationed during the summer. What to do?

title: THE OTHER JEFFERSON HOUSE
description: All the world knows Jefferson's Monticello, the grand mansion he built for himself near Charlottesville, Va. But few people know his hardly less beautiful rural retreat at Poplar Forest, near Lynchburg and some 90 miles from Monticello. Though much smaller, it is no less original, and from a strictly architectural point of view even more perfect. It is a masterpiece of compact design, an octagon imposed upon a square, and it was the darling of the later half of Jefferson's career, after his retirement from the Presidency, when he could give himself up to looking after his two estates and the country pursuits he loved best.

title: FIRST FRESH AIR CHILDREN LEAVE FOR VISITS
description: Norell Black, an exuberant 8-year-old from Brooklyn, thinks the best parts of going away on summer vacation are ''swimming, biking and eating barbecued hamburgers on picnics.'' And for the next two weeks, she will do just that.

title:
GARDENING;
TAWNY DAY LILIES: BEAUTIFUL SURVIVORS
description: THE tenacity and beauty of the roadside tawny day lilies makes them the objects of admiration. Patches of these summer-flowering perennials may be found along country roads competing with weeds, grass and almost anything other than dense shade. They grow in shallow as well as deep places, in wet as well as dry areas and in poor as well as fertile soils. In periods of drought, they may wilt and even turn somewhat brown, but they survive and even flower.

title: Church of England Bars Services Led by Women
description: The Church of England's policy-making synod today rejected a motion to allow women ordained in the Anglican Church abroad to conduct services in England.

title: Elizabeth Aldrich Betrothed
description: Elizabeth Wolcott Aldrich and John Nance Atcheson, who received M.B.A. degrees in June from Stanford University, plan to be married Aug. 23.

title: A SUICIDE IN THE SENATE
description: Senator John P. East had been confined to a wheelchair since contracting polio when he was 24. Last year, after he was hospitalized for hypothyroidism, a disorder that he said frequently left him tired and depressed, he announced that he would not seek a second term.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
The Allure Of Rail Land
description: DONALD TRUMP would have a field day here. Huge tracts of abandoned railroad switching yards, similar to the Penn Central land that the New Yorker is attempting to develop along the Hudson River in Manhattan, are scattered throughout downtown, legacies of a time when Chicago was the nation's railroad nexus.

title: LIBERTY CONFEREES DEBATE JUDGES' ROLE
description: The spirit of concord that had settled over New York in tribute to the Statue of Liberty was disrupted yesterday, in tribute to the practice of liberty.

title: MEDITATION WHILE CLEANING A GARAGE
description: I LOVE mindless tasks around the house. The tasks aren't really mindless; they just require so little conscious thought that my mind is allowed to roam freely until I make some connections to who I am and where I've been. Give me a chance to rake leaves, paint a fence, or pull weeds, and I am in my own form of meditation.

title: REAGAN AND GORBACHEV SEEM CLOSER TO SETTING A DATE
description: SOVIET and American leaders are indicating by their public statements that there will probably be a summit meeting in this country late this year or early next year between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: SEASON FOR CHERRIES BEGINS, BUT SELECT CAREFULLY
description: THE cherry season has begun.

title: 364 ROOMS
description: Several years ago, Mayor Thomas P. Ryan of Rochester, in what was no doubt unusual language coming from a chief executive, was quoted as saying, ''Frankly, there really isn't a great deal of excitment here.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Ducks and Culture IT's not only art lovers who give high ratings to the Heckscher Museum in Huntington. For a few hundred ducks, the fine arts museum is also the best restaurant in town.

title: THE SLOW MOTION WAR IN AFGHANISTAN
description: AS a new Communist leadership in Kabul tries to rebuild the army and gain popular support, the divided Afghan guerrilla movement still seems unable to pull itself together.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: FREEDOM'S HOLY LIGHT by Richard H. Schneider. Thomas Nelson Publishers. 128 pages. $14.95.

title: STATELY BRUTES OF ENGLAND
description: The British enjoy a reputation of caring for dogs, cats and parakeets more than they do for human beings, but they have not always been such zoophiles. Readers of BEASTLY BUILDINGS: The National Trust Book of Architecture for Animals (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95) may, in fact, think the title's adjective misapplied.

title: Elderly and Blind Are Tax Reform's Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: PSYCHIATRISTS VERSUS FEMINISTS
description: The American Psychiatric Association arrived at a compromise last week, medically and politically. The group's trustees recommended the addition of three disorders to its official diagnostic manual, a move opposed by feminist groups, but agreed to list them only in an appendix.

title: The Litigator
description: As an economist with the United States Justice Department's Antitrust Division, I have dealt with David Boies on a number of matters.

title: DREADED TOURISTS PRETTY WELL LIKED IN VERMONT, POLL SHOWS
description: Tourists in Vermont are wealthy, witty, law-abiding citizens who are pleasant to deal with and who blend in well with the local people, according to most of the residents surveyed by the University of Vermont and the state Department of Forest, Parks and Recreation.

title: The Night They Ate Out
description: Missing from Ellis Weiner's article, but not from Peter de Seve's illustration, was the worst aspect of dining in many Manhattan restaurants: second-hand smoke. It can, even at a distance of a few tables, overwhelm the aroma that makes up about half of what we call ''taste.'' STANLEY A. KURZBAN Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: NAKASONE'S FATE RESTS ON VOTE TODAY
description: Cruising campaign sound trucks ended their relentless blare tonight as Japan prepared for unusual simultaneous elections on Sunday for both houses of Parliament.

title: DANCE: 'CON/TEXT' BY SOLOMONS COMPANY
description: GUS SOLOMONS JR. emphasized theatrical subjectivity in ''CON/ Text,'' which the Solomons Company Dance offered Thursday night at Just Above Midtown. Indeed, half of the audience saw something different from what the other half saw, for Mr. Solomons presented the parts of the 30-minute work simultaneously in adjacent spaces, Studio A and Studio B. Each contained a large screen, and while dancers in the two rooms performed in front of their screen, the audience beheld video images of events in the next room, thanks to Michael Schwartz and Mark Robison, the zealous videographers, and Philip Guerrard, the video director.

title: Sunday Observer; Oh, To Be Nimble And Quick
description: THERE'S THIS WEIRD place called Nurseryburg,'' a man who scouted for photo opportunities was saying. ''And they've got this guy Jack, you'll never guess what he does. I mean, can you believe jumping over a candlestick?''

title: SANCTUARY TRIAL LEAVES A POLITICAL AFTERTASTE
description: THE timing was striking. As the nation prepared to celebrate Liberty Weekend and the country's historic status as a haven for immigrants and refugees, a Federal judge here suspended sentences and imposed probation on eight church workers convicted May 1 of participating in an conspiracy to smuggle Central American aliens into the United States.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What if they hadn't come? Where would we be? What kind of a life would we have?'' - Marie Simeone, at the Statue of Liberty, speaking of her grandparents. [ 16:5. ]

title: Sports of The Times; The Captain in Moscow
description: NAPOLEON got here but it cost him dearly. The German army could not penetrate the city during World War II. But Ted Turner yesterday stood proudly in the center of Moscow and surveyed what his millions had wrought: a peaceful sports spectacle.

title: LYME ACADEMY OF THE ARTS THRIVING IN ITS 10TH YEAR
description: THE history of the Lyme Academy of the Arts is a short but successful one, thanks to Old Lyme's love of art and the school's belief that aspiring artists must begin with the basics.

title: FOR CO-OPS, ONE BLOCK, ONE MANAGING AGENT
description: LIKE most good ideas, this one seems like a fairly obvious solution to the management problems experienced by many cooperatives. Rather than using different management companies and dealing with a string of part-time building managers, several co-ops on West 67th Street and Central Park West have decided to hire one company that will provide one full-time manager for the block.

title: Nuclear Waste Dumping at Sea
description: Charles D. Hollister and G. Ross Heath argue for continued funding of the subseabed-emplacement program as the safest nuclear-waste-disposal alternative (Letters, June 15, in response to ''The Story of a Town,'' by Joyce Maynard, May 11).

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: The Song of Bernadette. Starring Jennifer Jones, Charles Bickford, Anne Revere, Roman Bohnen, Vincent Price, Gladys Cooper; directed by Henry King, 1943; Key Video; 156 minutes.

title: A PRESS MOGUL REACHES FOR MORE POWER
description: IT has not always been easy for France's leading newspaper mogul.

title: Keeping The Stores Downtown
description: TEN years ago, this city of 40,000, home of the University of Virginia and principal urban center of prosperous Albemarle County, joined the nationwide movement to bolster downtowns against the challenge of suburban shopping centers. After long public debate, the city began rebuilding East Main Street, its seven-block main commercial artery, as a pedestrian mall.

title: WHERE THE PARCELS ARE
description: A TOTAL of 4,833 acres would be acquired in 28 separate parcels in nine Suffolk County towns. The land would be purchased in three phases over the next three years at an estimated cost of $60 million.

title: IN-HOUSE TEAM HEADS CUOMO CAMPAIGN
description: Governor Cuomo, who began his career as a political outsider and lost his first three primary and election contests, is now presiding over a re-election campaign organization that demonstrates what money and incumbency can buy.

title: HOW INDIFFERENCE TO FORTUNE LEFT A LEGACY FOR EXPLOITATION
description: Since Diego Giacometti died last July in Paris at the age of 82, a lot has happened. Some of it is welcome. Exhibitions and publications have established his reputation as one of the outstanding artist-craftsmen of the postwar era. Other developments, however, are troubling. They have to do largely with commerce and self-interest, and they suggest the dangers for an artist who refuses to respond to the art-world machinery his work has set in motion.

title:
ART;
SQUIBB: LITHE, ATHLETIC SCULPTURE
description: THE 17 sculptures currently on view at the Squibb Gallery here seem to be less than formally installed. This resounding sense of informality comes from the fact that the sculptor is William King.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Oberlin, Ohio; College Enters Realty Trade
description: LIKE many other colleges around the country, Oberlin College has long accepted gifts of homes or property from alumni and faculty. But last year the small, liberal-arts college expanded its realty dealings and began buying and selling houses under a program that college officials say offers benefits to sellers, buyers and the college's endowment fund.

title: Rehnquist and History
description: What is past may well be prologue, but American politics has a way of rewriting scripts and shuffling the cast of characters.

title: Jennifer Beal Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Beal Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., and Squam Lake, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Drew Beal to Clyde Cebron Tuggle, a son of Mrs. Arthur C. Tuggle of Atlanta and the late Mr. Tuggle.

title: GETTING TO KNOW LADY LIBERTY ANEW
description: Almost everyone was taller than I in Battery Park, where I had gone to see the relighted Statue of Liberty. At first I thought that all I would get to see was somebody's back.

title: Travel Advisory; TOURS AFLOAT IN JAPAN, NORDIC FEST IN THE MIDWEST
description: VIEWING TOKYO, OLD AND NEW, FROM THE DECK - New York has its Circle Line tours of the waters around Manhattan Island. Paris has its famous bateaux mouches, plying the waters of the Seine. Venice has its gondolas, and other cities have well-known tours of their waterways. But little is heard about their counterparts in Tokyo operated by the Tokyo Cruise Ship Company.

title: Susan D. Sturges To Wed Sept. 28
description: A Sept. 28 wedding is planned by Susan Diane Sturges, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sturges of Bridgewater, N.J., and David Campion Acheson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Acheson of Washington.

title: Cape Study Shows Water Danger
description: RESIDENTS of Upper Cape Cod last week received support for their contention that their drinking water is being contaminated by industrial waste from Otis Air National Guard Base and Camp Edwards.

title: Unresolved
description: The United States Boxing Association lightweight title was vacant on Friday morning, and after a 12-round title fight Friday night in Atlantic City between Frankie Randall of Morristown, Tenn., and Fred Pendleton of Philadelphia, it's still unfilled. The contenders fought to a draw in which one judge, Phil Newman, scored 116-114 for Pendleton, Rich Strange favored Randall, 115-113, and Lynne Carter scored it a draw, 114-114.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, JULY 6, 1986
description: Liberty Weekend A refurbished Statue of Liberty was reopened to the public as the Liberty Weekend party, hardly pausing after the Fourth of July festivities, continued with boat and air races, open houses aboard berthed ships and a huge festival in lower Manhattan. Nancy Reagan, surrounded by American and French school children, cut a red, white and blue ribbon to officially reopen the monument. [ Page 1, Column 2. The first ordinary Americans to visit the Statue of Liberty since she was closed for restoration last year stood through the night waiting for the reopening. Some had joined the line at dawn. They included the Millers, the Mamarils, the Brownsteins and the of Vasquezes, the Smiths and the Sabhawals. When the call came to make ready for the visit, they began singing ''God Bless America.'' About 4,000 tourists and New Yorkers were in a queue that snaked through Battery Park. [ 1:3. ] International Gunmen in South Africa shot dead five black municipal officials, the authorities said. The Bureau for Information, sole source of authorized news under the emergency decree, said the attackers had driven around two segregated black townships south of Johannesburg opening fire on Government vehicles. Two of the assailants were said to have been killed by the police. The attacks seemed to be one of the most audacious assaults on black supporters of Government authority since the current period of unrest began in September 1984. [ 1:6. ] Signs that fighting for Nicaragua will soon intensify, now that more American aid for the anti-Sandinistas appears to be assured, are all around the Honduran border bases of Nicaraguan guerrillas.

title: Imports as Saviors
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST END ART WORLD: PAINT IT COMPETITIVE
description: ELAINE BENSON sadly contemplates ''the baby sitter'' - her red, white and blue swing that lies propped against the tree. For the first time in 22 years, because the tree is damaged, the swing was not hanging in front of her Bridgehampton art gallery when she opened for the season in May.

title: WATERFORD FESTIVAL OPENS 3D YEAR WITH ALL-MOZART CONCERT
description: WHEN Peter Sacco and Cynde Iverson decided to start a festival at Harkness Park in Waterford a couple of summers ago, the two faculty artists at Connecticut College had high hopes but grave doubts: Would audiences support yet another outdoor concert series? As it turned out, they did not have to worry.

title: THE GREAT COCAINE CAPER
description: THE FRUIT PALACE By Charles Nicholl. 307 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. PETER FLEMING went in search of Colonel Fawcett, A. F. Tschiffely rode the length of the Andes, Paul Theroux traveled the trains of Patagonia, and Dervla Murphy walked Pizarro's route across Peru. Such were the themes of some of South America's greatest travel writers. They seem conventional beside the Grail that inspired Charles Nicholl's journeys in Colombia - he was sent by his trendy publisher to write the Great Cocaine Story.

title: Kathryn Mazzini Wed To William D. Kerr 3d
description: Kathryn M. Mazzini, the relocation administrator at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, and William D. Kerr 3d, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco. The Rev. Richard P. Fowler officiated.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CORRIGAN, by Caroline Blackwood. (Penguin, $5.95.) Devina Blunt, a reclusive widow in the English village of Coombe Abbot, is captivated by a flirtatious invalid in this novel by the Irish writer Caroline Blackwood. In The Book Review last year, Carolyn Gaiser called the book ''a charming tour de force'' and a ''delightfully ingenious variation on a familiar story - the aging widow preyed upon by a charming confidence man.'' AGATHA CHRISTIE, by Janet Morgan. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) This biography of the celebrated mystery writer ''is a vigorous, lucid and highly readable book that will tell Christie fans what they have long wanted to know,'' Antonia Fraser wrote in these pages in 1985. Ungar has issued THE NEW BEDSIDE, BATHTUB & ARMCHAIR COMPANION TO AGATHA CHRISTIE (Paper, $12.95; Cloth, $25), an expanded and updated edition of its Baedeker of Christieana, with essays on Christie's work as well as synopses of the novels, plays and short-story collections. In 1979 our reviewer called it ''a grand memory book.'' STANLEY ELKIN'S THE MAGIC KINGDOM, by Stanley Elkin. (Obelisk/Dutton, $8.95.) Eddy Bale, mourning the loss of his 12-year-old son, leads a group of terminally ill children on a trip from England to Disney World. The novel's comic vision ''is both hysterical and profound,'' Max Apple said here last year. ''Part sick joke, part lyrical meditation on the nature of disease, the journey to this magic kingdom earns its place among the dark voyages that fiction must take.''

title: Contra Aid Prolongs the Torment of a Desperately Poor Country
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
PLAYING IT COOL ON A HOT SUNDAY
description: ON AN unseasonably hot Sunday in May, thousands of Maplewood and South Orange residents gave the lie to recent reports of an upsurge in racism throughout the country.

title: MUSIC MAY COME FIRST, BUT WORDS ARE IMPORTANT, TOO
description: Two Southern California professors, Lorraine Prinski and Jill Rosenbaum, have completed a study entitled ''Sex, Violence and Rock 'n' Roll:

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Catalogue Companies In Good-Will Exchange Lillian Vernon and FBS, both nationally known catalogue houses with retail outlets in New Rochelle, are exchanging good will with a Catalogue Connection Sale: customers at one outlet will receive gift certificates good for a 10 percent reduction at the other for one month, beginning Friday and continuing through Aug. 2.

title: RACE DAY: BOAT, ROADSTER AND BLIMP
description: Four blimps lumbered across the sky over the Hudson River yesterday afternoon, capping a day of unusual races in New York.

title: Data Bank July 6, 1986
TICK ILLNESSES RISE IN SUFFOLK
description: IT is tick season on Long Island, and this year the incidence of Lyme disease, a potentially serious illness caused by the bite of a deer tick, has significantly increased in Suffolk County.

title: FEDERAL DEADLINE FAILS TO SOLVE AGE OLD HOPI-NAVAJO DISPUTE
description: A deadline that is more symbolic than real in the long land dispute between the Navajo and Hopi Indians passes at midnight Sunday with the problem still far from resolved.

title: COMPUTERS FOR CATCHING SCOFFLAWS
description: IN the 1966 movie, ''Cool Hand Luke,'' the character played by Paul Newman gets arrested for cutting meters off their posts with a pipe cutter. Within one week of the movie's opening, Baltimore lost 40 meters in the exact same manner. And in the years following, roving gangs of meter vandals plagued countless American cities.

title: NEW CHIEF JUSTICE FOR R.I.
description: The new Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, whose predecessor resigned to end an impeachment inquiry, has pledged himself to the highest standards of conduct and ethics.

title: NEW WORLD VINE
description: FOR WINE-LOVING IMMIGRANTS WHO docked at Ellis Island, America filled the glass. Even if New York's hard streets were not paved with gold, hillsides upstate were lush with native grapes - and farmers, not czars or kings, were born to the purple.

title: Imports as Saviors
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS LIBERTY REOPENS AMID GAIETY IN THE HARBOR
description: A refurbished Statue of Liberty was reopened to the public yesterday as the Liberty Weekend party, hardly pausing on the morning after, rolled ahead with boat and air races, open houses aboard berthed ships and a huge festival in lower Manhattan.

title: FINDING YOUR WAY IN A CROWD
description: THE exceptional volume of buying, selling and refinancing triggered by the decline of interest rates is now creating havoc for those who are trying to schedule a closing date.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday with an article about the New York City Opera misidentified a makeup artist with the company. He is Harvey Livingston.

title: GROUP TO STUDY L.I. GROWTH PROBLEMS
description: A group of Long Island business, government, labor and academic leaders is undertaking a study to suggest solutions to the problems faced by the crowded region, which is predicted to gain hundreds of thousands of jobs by the year 2000.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: King Makossa. Featuring Manu Dibango; V.I.E.W. Video; 55 minutes. $39.95.

title: BUSINESS CAN SPEAK OUT IN OTHER WAYS
description: LATE last month, in the most important challenge to tobacco industry advertising in 25 years, the Federal Trade Commission sued the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for violating the Federal prohibition against false and deceptive advertising in an ad entitled ''Of Cigarettes and Science.'' The commission properly charged that the ad, which disputes the scientific evidence linking cigarette smoking to heart disease, was nothing more than a blatant attempt by R. J. Reynolds to increase overall cigarette sales by deceptively downplaying the relationship between cigarette smoking and cardiovascular disease.

title: 12CITIES WIEGH ENCOURAGING LATINS TO BE CITIZENS OF U.S.
description: Twelve cities with high concentrations of Hispanic residents have been considering resolutions aimed at encouraging Hispanic aliens who are legally in this country to become naturalized citizens.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: NORTHERN PITCHER PLANT Sarracenia purpurea Size: One to two feet tall.

title: Mayor Goode's Latest Headache
description: Philadelphia's Mayor W.
