Wilson Goode, labeled ''grossly negligent'' by his own investigatory panel for allowing a dispute over the radical group Move to mushroom into a fire that destroyed more than 60 homes last year, faced more trouble last week. More than 13,000 nonuniformed municipal workers went on strike Tuesday for the first time in eight years, and city services immediately began to break down.

title: ILLUMINATING THE PATIO: HIDE THOSE LIGHTS FOR THE BEST EFFECT
description: ADDING lighting to a patio can greatly extend its usefulness after dark. And since patios or terraces usually adjoin the back door or side door of the house, such lighting can also increase safety and security.

title: Braves Get Alexander
description: The Atlanta Braves, seeking to improve their pitching for a run at the National League West title, yesterday acquired Doyle Alexander from the Toronto Blue Jays for Duane Ward.

title: Tempted by Outlaws
description: Tony Casillas of Oklahoma, who last year won the Lombardi Award as the nation's top defensive college lineman, says he is ''90 percent certain'' he will sign a contract with the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football League, especially since the pot has been sweetened by the Outlaws. Casillas, who was the No. 2 overall pick in the National Football League draft by the Atlanta Falcons, has been offered a four-year deal by the Outlaws, up from two years, that is ''worth a lot more than $2 million,'' according to his agent, James Maloney. Casillas said he hoped to sign soon because his wife, Lisa, is ready to begin her third year of medical school and needs to learn if she will be entering Emory University in Atlanta or continuing at the University of Oklahoma.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
UNCIRCULATED U.S. BICENTENNIAL COINS
description: The United States has issued three new coins to honor the Statue of Liberty centennial. A decade ago three special coins were also issued to mark the nation's 200th birthday. Unlike this year's numismatic tributes, the Bicentennial coins never created much excitement - neither within the hobby nor among the general public. Millions of Bicentennial coins in a special silver version are still gathering dust in federal vaults. What's more, many collectors are unaware that the coins can still be purchased from the Government.

title: FILTERING OUT THE SLUGS AND PESOS
description: EXCEPT for its digital time indicator, and the fact that elapsed time cannot be seen from the street, the Duncan electronic meter looks exactly like its mechanical predecessors. In fact, its battery-powered microcomputer can be installed inside any meter's iron frame.

title: 5 MORE FESTIVALS READYING IN COUNTY
description: FIVE major summer cycles are ready to join the county's long-running Lyndhurst and Caramoor Festivals.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: WAY OUT EAST In addition to supporting the local economy, summer folks also help keep the South Fork's community institutions going. For example, today, the brand new Fine Arts Council at Southampton College benefits when Coty Award-winning fashion designer Mary McFadden inaugurates a new series of lectures. Miss McFadden will discuss, with the help of slides, ''Fashion Design: An Odyssey of Symbols and Their Sources'' at 5:30 P.M. at the college's Fine Arts Theater. The $15 donation will help pay for cultural programming on campus.

title: AT DANBURY CENTER, BLUES TO CLASSICAL
description: THIS summer will be the first full-subscription season for the Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury, and it is offering a series of concerts to appeal to the symphonic, popular and theatrical tastes.

title: ARREST OF UNION LEADER REPORTED
description: South African security forces have arrested a black trade union leader, James Mndaweni, president of the Council of Unions of South Africa, according to labor monitoring groups. Mr. Mndaweni is being held on charges of attending an illegal gathering May 1, the groups said.

title: Ann E. Fleming Wed To Thomas L. Temple
description: Ann Elizabeth Fleming, a daughter of Mrs. James A. Hardison Jr. of Wadesboro, N.C., and J. Carlton Fleming of Charlotte, N.C., was married in Charlotte yesterday to Thomas Leofric Temple, a son of Carolyn C. Temple and Frederick H. Temple, both of Charlotte. The Rev. Thomas B. Stockton performed the ceremony at Myers Park United Methodist Church.

title: THE ECONOMY IS BARELY INCHING FORWARD
description: Last week's meager increase in the Government index designed to predict the economic future was only the latest in a series of uninspiring reports involving growth and trade. But the two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the index of leading indicators registered for May, along with a downward revision of reports on March and April, discouraged even those analysts who had not expected a strong gain.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In his second year on the Professional Golfers' Association senior tour, Ken Still of Tacoma, Wash., has won more than $42,000, good enough to place him 22d in money winnings. But the 51-year-old golfer went shopping in Tacoma Thursday during a break in the tour and tripped over a wire at a shopping center, breaking his left kneecap in two places.

title: The Reunion: What We're Seeking
description: There are some articles that really ''hit home.'' This is why I was so aware of ''You Can Go Home Again,'' by Maud de Luna [ Opinion Page, June 8 ] .

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Schlosser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Schlosser of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rachel Schlosser, to Albert Birkbeck Vanderhoof 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderhoof Jr. of Red Bank, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: THE PITFALLS OF AN ARTIFICIAL DOUBLE
description: Many partnership agreements have minuses as well as pluses: If a bid is given an artificial meaning, the natural one is not available. An example is the modern trend to ''support doubles.'' This calls for the opener to double following a response and an overcall when he has three-card support for his partner. A raise promises four-card support, and helps the responder judge the prospects. For example:

title: Dershowitz v. Ephron
description: To the Editor:

title: WRITERS OF GRAFFITI, IN TURNABOUT, VOW A CLEANER PATERSON
description: JOSEPH (SCAT) STROBINO stole his first can of spray paint and went out ''bombing'' when he was in the fifth grade.

title: DOING THE TURNPIKE CRAWL
description: IT'S time for the big summer push for tourism, and the experts say favorable gasoline prices and fear of terrorism abroad will make our already crowded highways more crowded.

title: Plan to Phase Out Lead Shot
description: GETTING the lead out of shotgun shells used for waterfowling in this country has been a tedious endeavor, but it is nearing consummation.

title: PAYING THE PRICE FOR LOW FARES
description: In recent weeks, the nation's major airlines have severely restricted the ability of travelers to get seats at the lowest fares and on the flights most convenient for them. The airlines have done this by pressuring fliers to make up their minds far in advance of departure and by imposing stiff penalties if they change them later.

title: HARTFORD VOLUNTEERS OFFER PRENATAL HELP
description: STARTING this month, a group of 20 women will spend three hours a week going door-to-door in their Hartford neighborhoods, trying to locate women who are pregnant. The volunteers, who have completed a six-week training course, are part of Babywatch, a program that will teach the women about prenatal care, infant mortality and the problems that sometimes occur in pregnancy.

title: ARTIST'S 'URBAN VISIONS' INSPIRE A LOOK AT LABOR
description: Lazara Rosa and Jaime Mourao painted the strike by New Bedford fishermen. Eric Casimiro painted construction workers. Jenny Valente painted the old seaport buildings of downtown New Bedford.

title: Anita Clifford to Marry Michael J. Rich in August
description: Anita Bradshaw Clifford, a doctoral candidate in comparative literature at Columbia University, and Michael Jerome Rich, a vice president of sales at McGavern Guild Radio, a broadcast time sales company in New York, plan to be married Aug. 2.

title: REBELS, VICTIMS AND APOLOGISTS
description: CRESCENT MOON AND OTHER STORIES By Lao She. 324 pp. San Francisco: Panda/China Books and Periodicals. Paper, $7.95. MISS SOPHIE'S DIARY AND OTHER STORIES By Ding Ling. Translated by W. J. F. Jenner. 271 pp. San Francisco: Panda/China Books and Periodicals. Paper, $5.95. LILIES AND OTHER STORIES By Ru Zhijuan. 205 pp. San Francisco: Panda/China Books and Periodicals. Paper, $4.95. MIMOSA AND OTHER STORIES By Zhang Xianliang. 270 pp. San Francisco: Panda/China Books and Periodicals. Paper, $5.95. PAGODA RIDGE AND OTHER STORIES By Gu Hua. Translated by Gladys Yang. 260 pp. San Francisco: Panda/China Books and Periodicals. Paper, $4.95.

title: NEWARK MAYOR VOWS PROSPERITY
description: The new Mayor of Newark, Sharpe James, was sworn in last week and began at once to make changes in the operation of the troubled city. The 50-year-old former City Councilman, who defeated 16-year-incumbent Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson in May, appointed new heads of the Police and Fire Departments, and other city agencies.

title: ISRAEL'S HIGHEST LAW IS STILL NATIONAL SECURITY
description: ON the surface, there seems to be little similarity between the two notorious affairs involving the Israeli security-intelligence establishment - the Shin Beth case here and the Pollard case in Washington. But in fact both affairs reflect some very basic Israeli attitudes toward decision-making, the conflict between maintaining security and the law and how the establishment takes care of its own.

title: A N by Any Name is Still a N
description: The Privacy Journal is a monthly Washington newsletter that usually deals with such serious issues as computer abuse, polygraph legislation and confidentiality of records. But its editor, Robert Ellis Smith, occasionally ranges into less momentous matters.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE county's first hospital alliance may provide a cancer-treatment program in one location, a drug- and alcohol-abuse treatment center in another, and a comprehensive rehabilitation program at still a third site. These are among the preliminary recommendations in the first report, issued last week, by APM, the New York City consulting firm, one of two there hired by WestCare, a joint corporation set up by three Westchester hospitals to enhance patient care by sharing resources and reducing costs.

title: GARDENING BECOMES A BIG NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS
description: The ornamental plant, the exotic herb, the rose and the common petunia are changing the economics of agriculture in New England.

title: 747'S START TO SHOW THEIR AGE
description: ''As with any mechanical item,'' the Boeing Corporation said in a news release, ''as airplanes get older the inspections get more thorough.''

title: Labonte Earns Pole For Georgia Auto Race
description: Terry Labonte, fresh from a 19th-place finish in the Firecracker 400 on the high-banked oval at Daytona Beach, Fla., turned to a road course today to win the pole position for the $104,000 Food Giant Big Apple 300 Nascar Bush Grand National Series race.

title: Schoolteachers In Private Practice
description: SUPPORTERS praised it as an idea long overdue: a group teaching practice, somewhat like a group medical practice.

title: BRIDES DRESS WITH EDWARDIAN FLARE
description: THE wedding gown is not known for making a fashion statement. There are endless variations in fabric and decoration, but the underlying styles sound familiar themes.

title: NOTEBOOK: REAGAN AMID 'ALL THE HOOPLA'
description: Nancy Reagan trembled with cold as a stiff wind seized Governors Island Thursday night. Her husband sat stiffly beside her, biting his lip. Nearby, Francois Mitterrand and his wife, Daniele, shifted in their seats. White House officials quietly groaned.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MONTCLAIR: THE STORY BEHIND BOOKPLATES
description: LIKE monograms on linen and crests on silver, bookplates originated as both a practical device and personal conceit.

title: NANTUCKET
description: This is a summer of celebration on Nantucket. The Unitarian Church, built in 1809 and listed in the National Register of Historic Places, is reopening after a three-year restoration project. The Theater Workshop of Nantucket, started by Joseph M. (Mac) Dixon in 1956, is celebrating its 30th anniversary. And Nantucket's Oldest House, a national historic landmark, is 300 years old this year. Built by Jethro Coffin and his bride, Mary Gardner, in 1686, the house will be the site of lectures and an exhibition of memorabilia.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: AUTO RACING FRENCH GRAND PRIX, at Le Castellet, France (Television - ESPN, 10 A.M.) CLEVELAND GRAND PRIX, at Cleveland (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.) BASEBALL YANKEES VS. WHITE SOX, at Chicago, 2:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 2:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Amy Fine Marries Bradley Collins Jr., A Fellow Teacher and Art Historian
description: Amy Fine, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold J. Fine of Knoxville, Tenn., was married there yesterday to Bradley Collins Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Collins of New York. The Rev. Robert Swain, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at Club Le Conte.

title: ON AN AUSTERE ITALIAN ISLAND
description: Climbing a steep hill, we looked down upon a Mediterranean landscape both ancient and eerily modern.

title:
GARDENING;
TAWNY DAY LILIES: BEAUTIFUL SURVIVORS
description: THE tenacity and beauty of the roadside tawny day lilies makes them the objects of admiration. Patches of these summer-flowering perennials may be found along country roads competing with weeds, grass and almost anything other than dense shade. They grow in shallow as well as deep places, in wet as well as dry areas and in poor as well as fertile soils. In periods of drought, they may wilt and even turn somewhat brown, but they survive and even flower.

title: Barrington J. Fludgate Marries Monika Klein
description: Monika Klein, a daughter of Mary T. Klein of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Charles R. Klein, and Barrington James Fludgate, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Fludgate of Worthing, Sussex, England, were married yesterday at the Belmont Country Club in Warwick, Bermuda. Archdeacon Thomas Dyson performed the Anglican service.

title: CLASSICS GO NATIONAL ON RADIO
description: A unique broadcasting service takes to the air this month. Called the Beethoven Satellite Network -BSN for short - it is the first nationwide radio link devoted exclusively to classical music.

title: Now Hear This
description: In the computer-controlled subway trains of Washington's sparkling Metro system, few operators try to inject any originality into the station announcements. Most merely drone the name of the stop and the side of the train on which the doors will open.

title: VANCOUVER ALSO EXHIBITS NEW HOTELS
description: For many Expo 86 visitors, particularly those making their first visit to Vancouver, the city itself will provide an agreeable surprise - it is one of this continent's most spectacularly beautiful cities. Travelers who haven't been there for a while will get a surprise, too: the bevy of luxury hotels that have sprouted there in the last two years.

title: SWEDISH SEARCH FOR METHANE TESTS RADICAL THEORY OF FUELS
description: After eight years of battling by Thomas Gold of Cornell University for serious consideration of his theory that almost unlimited reserves of methane lie deep within the earth, Swedish engineers have begun drilling a 15,000-foot hole in search of such gas.

title: Contra Aid Prolongs the Torment of a Desperately Poor Country
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ
description: A most unusual double bill will open on Tuesday at Michael's Pub. Simply having a double bill at Michael's Pub, which is traditionally satisfied to feature one performer or group at a time, is unusual. But in this case the attraction for the following three weeks will be two of the most popular jazz and pop singers of the past 40 years - Anita O'Day and Chris Connor.

title: Timothy P. Pettee Weds Sheila Peck
description: Sheila Peck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rankin Philip Peck Jr. of Grosse Point Shores, Mich., and Timothy Platt Pettee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Ottaway Pettee Sr. of Westport, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Paul's Church in Grosse Pointe Farms. Msgr. Francis X. Canfield officiated at the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: TODAY'S FORECAST: TIDAL WAVE
description: My friend Willis and I had just spent the afternoon swimming in a cool jade pool at the bottom of Wailua Falls on Kauai.

title: BUYING HIS WAY HOME
description: Steven John Donahue was a dealer in drugs, according to his wife, until he ran afoul of some Lebanese who deal in drug dealers. Mr. Donahue reportedly was nabbed trying to slip some Lebanese hashish past sharp-eyed American agents at Newark airport in 1982. In a plea-bargain deal, his wife said, Mr. Donahue agreed to help the American authorities by working undercover back in Lebanon.

title: THREE COMEDIES LIGHT UP SUMMER WITH LAUGHTER
description: Good, high-grade comedy is rare. It's also unlike good, high-grade anything else. When you finally do come across something that makes you laugh out loud, spontaneously, it can have the effect of a narcotic that alters your perceptions without your being aware of the exact extent. You walk out of the theater experiencing a high that leaves no hangovers, no chemical traces of any sort, but which does curious things to the nerve-ends of remembrance.

title:
THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE;
CUBA TO WHITE PLAINS
description: WHEN Judith Aucar started her first day as a student at Sleepy Hollow High School in Tarrytown in 1968, her English vocabulary consisted of two words -tomatoes, which she pronounced toe-mah-toe-ES, and coffee.

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager, Leaping Roof to Roof, Is Killed in Fall
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager who had been hopping from rooftop to rooftop during the fireworks display in New York Harbor Friday night fell to the ground and was killed, the police said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Paul Williams, catcher, the second-round draft pick.

title: CASHING IN ON HIGHER CAUSE
description: SOMETIME in the summer of 1983, Jerry C. Welsh, a man of Bible Belt fervor who is in charge of marketing for American Express's Travel Related Services Company, went in search of a cause that would enthuse his bosses.

title: THE MUSIC MAN PULLS OUT ALL THE STOPS
description: Perched on top of the bleachers, peering out from under a Liberty Weekend baseball cap, Art Bartner was getting the country into shape.

title: ILLUMINATING THE PATIO: HIDE THOSE LIGHTS FOR BEST EFFECT
description: ADDING lighting to a patio can greatly extend its usefulness after dark. And since patios or terraces usually adjoin the back door or side door of the house, such lighting can also increase safety and security.

title: APPOMATTOX, WHERE A PEACE IS ENSHRINED
description: Even today, 121 years after the end of the Civil War, there is a stillness at Appomattox. The restored village in the rolling green hills of southern Virginia where Gen. Robert E. Lee met with Lieut. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant is simple and dignified, a cluster of brick houses and taverns, a country store, the courthouse and the private residence where the two generals met to agree to terms.

title: Despina Koules Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven A. Koules of Fitchburg, Mass., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter Despina Louise Koules to Arthur Charles Anton Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton of Chelmsford, Mass. A fall wedding is planned. The future bride, a graduate of the Lawrence Academy and Middlebury College, received a master's degree from the Harvard University Graduate School of Education. Mr. Anton graduated from the Groton School and Harvard College.

title: SUCCESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: CROSS-TOWN MERGER ENDS 30-YEAR RIVALRY OF HIGH SCHOOLS
description: FAIRFIELD TOWN plans to cross Eagles with Tigers and get Mustangs. The hybrid will not be the latest in cross-breeding technology, but rather the product of declining school enrollment.

title: SAVORING TURN-OF-THE-CENTURY VIENNESE DESIGN
description: The ferment that characterized art and design in Vienna at the turn of the century resulted in a disciplined reshaping of objects and a seductive expressiveness in their decoration. Both qualities are abundantly documented in ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture & Design,'' at the Museum of Modern Art through Oct. 21.

title: Bo Jackson Struggling
description: The rave reviews that Bo Jackson got used to as college football's Heisman Trophy winner have turned into stiff criticisms in his first week of professional baseball. According to the two pitchers on the staff of the Columbus (Ga.)

title:
DINING OUT;
EAST HANOVER: ITALIAN FARE REIGNS
description: A SOPHISTICATED new restaurant has appeared in an unlikely spot on bustling Route 10 in East Hanover. What was the former premises of an eatery named Chili Willy's is now called Prima Donna, and the the setting has been transformed into a formal and elegant version of what used to be described as a Continental dining salon.

title: R. N. DICKSON TO WED JANE ROTHSCHILD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Rothschild Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Houghton Rothschild to Robert Nigel Dickson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dickson of Adelaide, Australia. The wedding is planned for September.

title:
POSTINGS;
12 FOR 65% LESS
description: By 1988, when its 96-unit project in Lawrenceville, N.J., is finished, HOWCO Residential Development of Livingston will certainly have sold at least 12 apartments - at 35 percent of their market value.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LITCHFIELD HOUSES Volumes of books have been written about the charm and beauty of Litchfield houses, including a comment by the author Samuel Chamberlain who characterized the town as a ''citadel of fine domestic architecture with few equals in this country.''

title: New York Banks Invest in Students
description: Students at five East Brooklyn high schools have a new incentive to stay in school: a shot at a job at one of New York City's biggest banks. Chase Manhattan, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company have agreed to hire a total of 250 graduates a year from the schools - where dropout rates are well over 50 percent - and to offer college scholarships to the most promising students.

title: HERITAGE OF BLACK DANCE GETS A BOOST IN DURHAM
description: Oddly enough, some of the most enduring influences upon American dance stem from the relatively brief summer sessions that occur yearly under the name of dance festivals. The American Dance Festival springs immediately to mind in this regard. Where would modern dance be today without the summer dance school and performances that originated in 1934 under Martha Hill's leadership at Bennington College in Vermont? It was here that the big four - Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Hanya Holm and Charles Weidman - hammered out the multi-faceted form of American modern dance, benefiting from residencies that culminated in major premieres and basic principles now familiar to all.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption of a picture last week with an article about the McIlhenny Company, the maker of Tabasco sauce, misstated the first name of one McIlhenny cousin. The name is Edmund McIlhenny Jr.

title: TOPICS
description: WARM weather brings with it many welcome things, but some unwelcome ones as well. I am speaking of the plethora of joggers, runners, bikers, stray pets, children playing hockey and baseball in the street, scooters and motorcycles. As a result, driving becomes particularly hazardous, and the burden of safety is put squarely on the car operator.

title: Cornford, Poet and Militant
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE;
MINSK TO YONKERS
description: IT has been five years since Elena and Gregory Khess and their two daughters left the Soviet Union on a night train bound for Austria, with no money and no possessions.

title: MOSCOW OUTLINES COLLEGE OVERHAUL
description: The Soviet leadership has indicted the nation's system of higher education and announced a sweeping program to make it more responsive to the needs of a modern industrial economy.

title: FRENCH TROUPE PAYS A LONG-AWAITED VISIT
description: When the Paris Opera Ballet opens its American tour at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday, it will be the first time in more than 38 years that the company has appeared in the United States. Put in other terms, when the Paris company was last in New York in 1948, two of the ballets it is bringing on this tour were recent creations - ''Palais de Cristal,'' by George Balanchine and ''Les Mirages,'' by Serge Lifar.

title: WHERE THERE'S SMOKE, THERE'S A FIERY ACTRESS NAMED DEBRA WINGER
description: ''Reviews don't change my opinion of a film,'' Debra Winger says of her new movie, ''Legal Eagles.''

title: TV SERIES SHOWS PROBLEMS OF AGED
description: A GROUP of elderly people who are angry about such issues as housing shortages and rising utility bills will be going on the air to try to find some solutions to the problems of older people.

title:
ART;
GETTING A VIEW OF PROVINCETOWN
description: LOOKING beyond ourselves and gathering information are both basic humanistic desires. In this spirit, the idea of bringing selections from the Provincetown (Mass.) Art Association and Museum to East Hampton's Guild Hall Museum - in an exchange program called ''Crosscurrents'' - is certainly worthwhile. There is an opportunity to be introduced to another regionally specialized collection and to be reminded of an aspect of American cultural history that dates to the 19th century.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SALUTE TO THE STATUE The New Jersey Symphony is presenting a series of outdoor pops concert this month in honor of the 100th birthday of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Rowing; U.S. Crews Dominate Henley
description: American crews will be finalists in 5 of the 11 cup events for which they are eligible when the championships of this 147th Henley Royal Regatta are decided Sunday.

title: FROM SLAVERY TO SLAVE WAGES
description: OLD SOUTH, NEW SOUTH Revolutions in the Southern Economy Since the Civil War. By Gavin Wright. 321 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: FINANCIAL TOWER
description: ''We're not robbing from New York City,'' said John Cali, the principal of Cali Associates, one of the most active developers of office space in New Jersey.

title: OTB's Impact On Horse Racing
description: The article ''Horse Racing: 'Hidden Giant' of the Island's Economy'' on June 1 was quite thorough and, for the most part, accurate.

title: DAILY LIFE AMONG THE CHILDREN
description: MOLLIE IS THREE Growing Up in School. By Vivian Gussin Paley. 144 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $12.50.

title: Robert Wagner's Wish List for City Schools
description: The election of Robert F. Wagner Jr. to the presidency of the New York City Board of Education last week signaled a new era in the nation's largest school system. Or so the 42-year-old former Deputy Mayor hopes.

title: Topics; Lasting Values; Contemporary Chic
description: Josef Hoffmann was the co-founder in 1903 of the Wiener Werkstatte, a consortium of artists and craftsmen dedicated to creating ''good simple articles of household use.'' If he were alive today he'd be the hottest name in decorating.

title: Man Sues Former Wife Over Use of His Sperm
description: The father of an infant girl has sued his former wife, contending that she used his sperm without permission to conceive a child and asking that he be freed from supporting their daughter.

title: SCHOOL AHOY! ON CHAMPLAIN SCHOONER
description: Some people would call a week of cruising the lake on a 76-foot schooner a charming introduction to summer. Others find it a romantic step into the past, a century after such vessels disappeared from the lake.

title:
INVESTING;
HOPE GLIMMERS FOR FARM BELT BANKS
description: Some early-bird investors are betting that the worst of the drought in agricultural and land prices is over: the stocks of some farm belt banks have been creeping upward.

title: GARDENS' BOUNTY FEEDING THE NEEDY
description: LAST summer, William Liddell of Hamden had enough home-canned green beans to feed his family through 1987. In his garden, 12 rows of beans ripened in the sun.

title: HEALTH AGENCY PROPOSES DOUBLING REAGAN BUDGET REQUEST ON AIDS
description: The Public Health Service has proposed more than doubling the Federal budget for all activities related to AIDS, including investigation and treatment of the deadly disease.

title: SINGING OUT STRONG FOR HALF A CENTURY
description: IT'S no coincidence that Long Island's two oldest choral groups had their beginnings in rural areas. Fifty years ago when the Choral Society of the Moriches and the North Fork Chorale were founded, it was to fill voids in their isolated farming communities.

title: THAT OLD BUGATTI IS NO TIN LIZZIE
description: WHEN William Serri Jr. drives a Bugatti racing car, he does so the way some people might drive a new sports car: for the fun of it.

title: Inviting a Conductor to Shake His Fist at Austria
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUPREME COURT WORKS AT ITS MANDATE
description: HANDING down major decisions last week on homosexual relations, gerrymandering and affirmative action, among others, the Supreme Court also had important things to say about its role in governing the nation.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GRUMBLING GRYPHONS The Hudson River Museum has assembled a series of productions for children, based on favorite stories. They will be performed at 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. on the next four Wednesdays. The Grumbling Gryphons perform ''The Myth of Persephone'' this week, followed in succeeding weeks by ''The Magical Tales of Hans Christian Andersen by Pegasus Productions; Folk Tales From Around the World'' by the Big Apple Puppet Theater; and Pegasus Productions' ''Jungle Book.'' Tickets are $3, adults $4.

title: FOR LIBERTY'S 100TH YEAR, THE BIGGEST PARTY EVER
description: America celebrated itself this weekend in a style which, whether deemed appropriately grand or embarassingly excessive, was undeniably stunning. With President Reagan leading the cheers, millions of spectators ringed New York harbor on the Fourth of July for the 100th birthday of the Statue of Liberty.

title: GARY KASPAROV LETS THE PUBLIC IN ON HIS TRADE SECRETS
description: Before anything as important as the world championship match, you can expect the players - if they practice in public at all - to keep hidden the nuances they have spent months preparing. But that's not the style of the current titleholder, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union.

title: FULFILLMENT FOR ASTROS' DAVIS
description: He was never much of a baseball fan when he was growing up. Before Glenn Davis was drafted by the Houston Astros in January 1981, he had attended one spring training game. ''The next game I seen is the one I played in,'' he said. ''The only thing I remember when I was a kid was the Cincinnati Reds. I had a couple of guys I liked on that team, and I also liked Mike Schmidt.''

title: SEAFOOD WITH A SPECIAL TOUCH
description: NOT so many years ago, dining in a hotel represented the last resort, something you would do only when time or imagination failed or a city's culinary geography was unknown to you.

title: Expeditions
description: To the Editor: Gary Goshgarian's article, ''Taking an Expedition Vacation'' (Travel, April 20), clearly expressed many feelings I have about my own Earthwatch experience.

title: THE AX FALLS HARD AT CBS
description: Everyone at CBS knew that layoffs were coming, but few expected the cuts to be so deep. The company said last week that it would trim 700 jobs in the CBS Broadcast Group, out of a work force of 8,000.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Rates on a Roller Coaster Last week, the stock market soared on hopes that the discount rate would soon be cut to spur a sluggish second half. But a rate cut would not mean that interest rates will fall steadily, says Arnold X. Moskowitz, senior vice president at Dean Witter.

title: DO TODAY'S PIANISTS HAVE THE ROMANTIC TOUCH?
description: For the last few years, I have served as a juror in piano competitions around the world - the Van Cliburn in Fort Worth, the International in Sydney, and so on. It has been in one respect a stimulating experience, this chance to hear some of the best young talent. In another it has been a depressing experience. All this talent, all this preparation and dedication - and so little to say in one major segment of the repertory! That segment is Romantic music. In the early 1960's I wrote a piece for these pages bewailing the prevalent literalism and uniformity of international music-making, especially among pianists. Most of the younger ones sounded alike and were hard to tell apart. Every age makes music its own way, and the 1960's was a period in which the printed note all but strangled the artist. So intent was everybody on textual fidelity, on strict rhythms, on the ideal of ''musicianship,'' that the concept of the artist was all but abandoned. It has remained abandoned. But this is all wrong, even historically wrong. Until recent times an interpreter was supposed to bring his own mind, heart, sensitivity and knowledge to the music, refracting the composer's message through his own personality. Composers historically were quite willing to go along when they had confidence in the artist. But in the 1960's -and, alas, today -the artist has abdicated his role. He is content to be a reproducer rather than a co-creator.

title: CITY ISSUES A LIST OF SAFE PUBLIC BEACHES
description: The City Department of Health has released a list of public swimming areas in the five boroughs that have been approved as safe for the summer season.

title: AT STRATFORD; SHAKESPEARE AND THOSE IN HIS SHADOW
description: Two events heighten the season at Stratford-Upon-Avon: the celebratory opening of the new Swan Theater - a third stage primarily devoted to the presentation of plays by Shakespeare's contemporaries - and the return of Michael Bogdanov with an invigorating contemporary approach to Shakespeare, in this case, ''Romeo and Juliet,'' playing at the Royal Shakespeare Theater. The Swan, a theater built within the former premises of the original Memorial Theater, will, of course, have the more long-range effect, allowing the Royal Shakespeare Company to expand its repertory and its perspective. As Trevor Nunn, joint artistic director of the company, said, this will be ''a theater for the performance of 16th-, 17th- and 18th-century plays which can be seen as broadly contextual to our house dramatist, William Shakespeare.'' In the past, a limited number of those plays have been presented at the Other Place, Stratford's small theater, which presumably will now concentrate on new works and more tangential classics.

title: IN JULY, JUST SIT ON A LOG AND OBSERVE
description: THE sun is up now, behind me, its long golden rays reaching over the housetop, touching the tips of the young maple with light. Some of its leaves are turned over, suggesting imminent rain. But it's only a trick - chiaroscuro the artists call it. That particular sapling settles directly in line with a broad V formed by a pair behind it. No artist would countenance such precision in a composition, but nature tosses her head and laughs at our determined subtleties.

title: RESORT PONDERS AIRPORT'S FUTURE
description: CITY officials here are studying plans to improve safety at historic Bader Field. If adopted, they say, the airport could be kept open despite public pressure to close it and a recent crash that took two lives.

title: Worker Rights And 435 Bosses
description: DO workers in restaurants run by the House of Representatives in Washington want to join a union?

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a visit to Italy and a one-week cruise out of Venice, I'm able to report three delightful surprises.

title: Contra Aid Prolongs the Torment of a Desperately Poor Country
description: To the Editor:

title: 'PLEASE, GOD, IF IT'S HIT TO ME, DON'T LET ME SCREW UP'
description: ''THAT young man will probably remember this moment for the rest of his life,'' Curt Gowdy said a few years back, as a player approached the foul line for a crucial foul shot during an NCAA basketball championship game. But I wondered. Would the moment come back to him years later, more clearly and with greater emotion because he made the foul shot or because he missed it, won the game or lost it.

title: Skip the Retraction
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSITY CHANGE URGED IN JORDON
description: King Hussein blamed political groups today for instigating student riots at Jordan's second largest university last May, and called for changes in the country's system of higher education.

title: HISTORY WITH COMPASSION AND CONTEMPT
description: HENRY ADAMS History of the United States of America During the Administrations of Thomas Jefferson. Edited by Earl N. Harbert. Maps. 1,308 pp. New York: The Library of America. $27.50. HENRY ADAMS History of the United States of America During the Administrations of James Madison. Edited by Earl N. Harbert. Maps. 1,436 pp. New York: The Library of America. $27.50.

title: Mexico's Finances
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting for the Ruling
description: The air of tense distraction descends each weekday at 10 A.M. and lasts about 15 minutes as the Supreme Court hands down its opinions for the day and, over on Capitol Hill, Congressional aides quiver by the phone.

title: CAN DON BURR GO BACK TO THE FUTURE?
description: PEOPLE EXPRESS INC., which became the nation's fifth-largest carrier by charging unthinkably low fares, is fighting for its life. With its financial health deteriorating and its stock price plunging, the airline announced on June 23 that it might have no choice but to sell all or part of itself.

title: PRECAUTIONS URGE ON LYME DISEASE
description: SUMMER is in full swing -and so is the Lyme disease season. The illness, caused by a microorganism transmitted through the bite of the deer tick, is named for the Connecticut town where it was discovered in 1975. But since then, it has been a growing health threat in Westchester, and this season is no exception.

title: Sullivan Wins the Pole For Race in Cleveland
description: Danny Sullivan led a drive today on the qualifying records for the Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix Sunday, winning the pole position for the Indy-car race with a lap averaging 135.144 miles per hour.

title: WEST MEETS EAST AT THE GOODWILL GAMES
description: It is both a kind of summitry through sports and a promotional gambit of global proportions.

title: L.I. PROGRAM TO PRESERVE FARMLAND NEARING END
description: A $21 million program to preserve farmland on eastern Long Island is nearing an end in Suffolk County, where officials and farmers say it has bolstered local agriculture during a period of general decline and retrenchment.

title: TEACHERS AND THE CRITICISM OF THEIR VACATION
description: TEACHERS, as a group, are a paranoid bunch. Their feeling, and I speak from experience, is that whenever anything goes wrong with children, or, in fact, with society as a whole, they ultimately will be asked to take the blame. Not that teachers deny that they probably play an important role in a child's or a future adult's development - they do, and they bear, in truth, an awesome responsibility.

title: Minor Leagues '86; Turner Gill; Summer a Time for Starting Over
description: SOON after Turner Gill arrived at Municipal Stadium to begin work on a rare transformation from professional football to baseball, he was presented with a reminder of his previous athletic life.

title: MUSIC VIDEOS HIT A SOUR NOTE
description: SCARCELY two years ago, Cyndi Lauper was a relative unknown. Then ''Girls Just Wanna Have Fun,'' her hit single, soared to the top of Billboard's pop charts, and suddenly she was up there in the pop-music stratosphere with the likes of Madonna and Bruce Springsteen.

title: Maude H. Wood Engaged to Wed Thomas Kent Jr.
description: Maude Hunnewell Wood and Thomas D. Kent Jr., teachers at the Episcopal Academy in Merion, Pa., plan to be married Aug. 23. The future bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. William P. Wood of West Grove, Pa., have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent of Murray Hill, N.J., and Seabrook Island, S.C.

title: N.Y. STATE LEGISLATURE ENDS 208TH SESSION
description: AFTER all the fuss about the New York City corruption scandal - the headlines, the politicians' speeches, the news conferences, the commission findings, the lobbying by ''good government'' groups - New York State's Legislature ended its 208th session last week with little to show for itself in anticorruption measures.

title: Marquette Picks Dukiet
description: After a nationwide search, Marquette University named Bob Dukiet of St. Peter's College in Jersey City as its basketball coach yesterday.

title: METS STOPPED BY ASTROS, 2-1
description: The largest crowd of the season at Shea Stadium was conducting wave races. Bob Knepper of the Houston Astros allowed a home run, a double and four line-drive outs in the first three innings, and the Mets had every reason to expect more.

title: SUFFOLK PLAN TO BUY LAND FACES SNAGS
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature is set to vote Tuesday on the most extensive land acquisition program ever proposed by the county.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: SUMMER CONCERT SERIES A series of nine open-air summer concerts begins today in the Wildflower Theater in the peaceful Dorflinger-Suydam Wildlife Sanctuary at White Mills, Pa.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY SLOWS TRAVELERS
description: The nation's major airports are entering the peak summer travel season with a range of stepped-up security measures designed to thwart terrorist attacks.

title:
R.J. REYNOLDS VS. THE GOVERNMENT;
A CHILLING EFFECT ON CORPORATE SPEECH
description: IF ONE thing is common to all First Amendment cases it is this:

title: FOR CONTRAS, PROSPECT OF AID STIRS PREPARATION FOR COMBAT
description: Among Nicaraguan guerrillas, in their border bases and hidden bunkers, there is a prickly sense of preparing for war. With American aid coming, the battles that lie ahead seem to be approaching with a rush.

title: 3 HOME RUNS LIFT EXPOS OVER BRAVES
description: Tim Wallach hit two home runs and the pitcher Bryn Smith helped himself with a three-run homer, leading the Montreal Expos to a 12-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

title: THEY SPIN THE TALES FOR SOAP OPERAS
description: ''It's hard to surprise a daytime audience today,'' says Douglas Marland, head writer of the CBS soap opera ''As the World Turns.'' ''They know all the formulas and are usually six feet ahead of you, but if the surprise is well thought out and justified, they love it.''

title: LILCO STUDIES: SUPPORT FOR ALL SIDES
description: THREE separate studies in recent weeks have examined the possible results if a public power authority were to replace the Long Island Lighting Company. The studies - one prepared for Suffolk County, one for Nassau County and one for New York State - all agreed that such a takeover is feasible and would save energy consumers some money.

title: Now the Silly Season
description: July marks the beginning of the official silly season here and in Moscow, and this year's promises to be a dandy. Consider, for example, the opening remarks of President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev.

title: BAKERSFIELD RUNS ON A LEANER MIX
description: IN a rash moment in 1980, California Business magazine wrote that Bakersfield ''boasts of a big-time, recession-proof economy based on agriculture and oil.'' Such optimism has faded along with potato and petroleum profits. Today, Bakersfield is in a slump based on agriculture and oil.

title: Chernobyl Evacuees Annoyed By Bureaucrats, Pravda Says
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda charged today that some efforts to help people evacuated because of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster had become snagged by bureaucracy.

title: Canadian Holds Brief Lead
description: Like the event itself, the North American team had its ups and downs today in the Tour de France.

title: Fragrance And Nostalgia
description: I enjoyed Marian McEvoy's article ''The Fashion for Fragrance'' (May 18). On my first trip to Europe, as a very young girl, Paris meant Caron, Guerlain, Gres, Molyneux.

title: A REGION TURNS ON A POWERFUL NEIGHBOR
description: DEFYING threats of retaliation against their economic self-interest, South Africa's black-ruled neighbors have increased their calls for sanctions since the internal emergency was proclaimed by Pretoria on June 12.

title: BOARD VOTE URGES TALKS ON BUYING RAIL PROPERTY
description: THE County Legislature last week approved a $2.4 million purchase of the Putnam Railroad right of way, a 16-mile-long unused roadbed that stretches from Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to the Eastview section of Mount Pleasant.

title: Constance Humphrey To Wed in September
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Humphrey of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter Constance Field Humphrey to James Murray Egan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Egan, also of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for September.

title: Carolyn Ranzetta a Bride
description: Carolyn Marie Ranzetta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley H. Ranzetta of Demarest, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Allen Christy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Christy of Hatfield, Pa. The Rev. Hilary Milton performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride and bridegroom graduated from West Chester (Pa.) University.

title: Topics; Lasting Values; Liberal Champion
description: Jonathan Bingham, patrician lawyer and public servant who died last week at the age of 72, won his first election when he was 50. He toppled the Bronx Democratic Party boss, Charles Buckley, from the Congressional seat that he had held for three decades.

title: HOW STATE POLICE PREPARED FOR THE CENTENNIAL'S CELEBRANTS
description: ON a shoulder of the Sprain Brook Parkway, Lawrence D. King watched the numbers flash across the digital screen on his dashboard - and waited, but not for long. The screen that measured the speed of individual passing cars read: 49. 55. 54. 61. Then there was 81.

title: OPPONENTS OF SANDINISTAS STRUGGLE TO HAVE THEIR SAY
description: FOR opposition leaders here, last week might have seemed a good time to remain quiet. The Government had just shut the country's only anti-Sandinista newspaper, La Prensa. Then, for the first time, it issued an order stripping a native Nicaraguan priest of the right to return home from abroad. The priest, the Rev. Bismarck Carballo, had been spokesman for the Roman Catholic Primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, and was apparently being punished for political opinions.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $122,500 10 Kester Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split-level; *2*hardwood floors, family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,992. Farmingdale $195,000 254 Cranberry Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old ranch; dining room with fireplace, *2*hardwood floors, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,000. Freehold $127,000 34 Koening Lane *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old bilevel; *2*fenced yard, fireplace, patio; taxes $1,536. Livingston $170,000 32 Irving Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old colonial; deck, living room with *2*fireplace, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,408. Mine Hill $119,900 19 South First Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; remodeled kitchen, *2*family room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,040. Paramus $179,900 316 South Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; family room with *2*fireplace, patio, den, dining room; taxes $1,939. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. $370,000 11 Crescent Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 63-year-old frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, deck; taxes $3,684. Killingworth, Conn. $250,000 293 Route 148 *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1772 Cape Cod; *2*3 fireplaces, screened porch, 4 acres; taxes $1,941. Woodmere, L.I. $250,000 859 Talbot Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old high ranch; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,200.

title: CHIPPING AWAY AT THE MOON'S REMAINING SECRETS
description: Eight hundred forty-three pounds of rocks make up the material legacy of the Apollo program. The heirs are a handful of die-hard moon researchers, squeezing out the last ounces of knowledge and nursing hopes of a new era of moon exploration or even - some dare say it - colonization.

title: WILL THE LOSSES SHOCK US INTO STRONG ACTION?
description: THE recent deaths of Len Bias and Don Rogers not only underscore the seriousness of drug use among professional athletes but also bring into bold relief the drug crisis sweeping the nation. The use of psycho-active drugs has spread rapidly into an epidemic of extraordinary scope.

title: CABLE TV
description: Some big-gun premieres dominated the film fare on cable during Liberty Week, but the new week's vintage movie crop is estimable. Could anything be more summery than ''Summertime''? For home viewers bypassing Venice this year - and for hopeful first-timers - this dazzling photographic dip into the Canal City and its seasonal romantic story, with Katharine Hepburn and Rossano Brazzi, are the next best thing to a trip across. David Lean's direction was cited by the New York Film Critics. The 1955 picture checks in Wednesday at noon on Cinemax.

title: POLISH DIRECTOR FINDS HAUNTING RELEVANCE IN DOSTOYEVSKY
description: The thing that most impressed Andrzej Wajda as he adapted ''Crime and Punishment,'' for the stage was how accurately prophetic Dostoyevsky's great novel had been in projecting what the Polish director terms our contemporary era of theoretical crimes.

title: Zapata Keeps His Title In Featherweight Bout
description: Hilario Zapata of Panama scored a unanimous 15-round decision over Dodie Boy Penalosa of the Philippines tonight to retain his World Boxing Association flyweight title.

title: The Night They Ate Out
description: I enjoyed Ellis Weiner's article ''The Night They Ate Out'' (June 8). Not only was it funny, it was right on the mark. I am all for eclectic menus, fresh ingredients and light preparation, but why cannot it all be put together in a simple and straightforward way? CHRISTOPHER FLORES Red Bank, N.J.

title: Syrian Troops Return To Patrol in West Beirut
description: Syrian troops, back in Beirut for the first time in four years, were on patrol today in an expansion of their 10-year-old military role in Lebanon.

title: COUNTERCULTIVATORS
description: FRIDAY NIGHT AT SILVER STAR By Patricia Henley. 127 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. Paper, $7.50.

title: SIX KILLED IN GENERAL STRIKE IN CHILE
description: A coalition of 18 Chilean professional, labor, student and other groups had tried for two months to launch a dialogue about democracy with the 13-year-old Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Their letters went unanswered, so last week the coalition, know as the Assembly of Civility, called a two-day general strike.

title: Amy Benenson to Marry in September
description: Edward H. Benenson of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and East Hampton, L.I., and Mrs. Richard Lewisohn of New York and Holmes, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy R. Benenson to Clifford H. Aronson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Aronson of Marina Del Rey, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title: Nancy Thornton Plans to Be Married
description: The engagement of Nancy McCullough Thornton to George Colville Reycraft has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John V. Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., and Wainscott, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of George D. Reycraft of New York and Key Largo, Fla., and Pamela Colville Reycraft of New York.

title: ADAM SMITH MEETS NIETZSCHE
description: THE PASSION OF AYN RAND By Barbara Branden. Illustrated. 442 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title: Miss Mitchell Exchanges Vows With S. A. Shaver
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., yesterday Suzanne Mitchell and Steven A. Shaver, both May graduates of Middlebury College, were married by the Rev. Ellen M. Shaver, mother of the bridegroom.

title: PATERSON BOARD PRAISED FOR TEACHER DRESS CODE
description: As a longtime public school teacher, let me commend the Paterson Board of Education for resisting all efforts to release the teacher dress code imposed by Jerome Gibson, principal of School 13 (New Jersey Weekly, May 18).

title: On Language; Redundadundadundant
description: IN ''THE PATIENT HAS the Floor,'' the new book of sparkling essays by Alistair Cooke, this one-man English-speaking Union bravely draws a conclusion: ''When all is said and done . . . much British writing about America, and American cogitations on the nature of England, spring still from the deep desire not to be unduly impressed by each other . . . .''

title: For Democrats, Me-Too Reaganism Will Spell Disaster
description: Last month, President Reagan won a considerable and rather surprising victory. Contrary to general expectation, he persuaded the House of Representatives, a body presumably controlled by his Democratic opposition, to vote $100 million in military and logistical aid to the contra forces organized by the Central Intelligence Agency to overthrow the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua. He humiliated the Democratic leadership, which passionately resisted the proposal, and induced 51 Democrats - one-fifth of the party in the House - to desert their party and reject its policy.

title: BYZANTIUM'S GLORY STILL SHINES IN ITS SILVER
description: An event of primordial importance in its field is the exhibition of ''Silver From Early Byzantium,'' which can be seen at the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore through Aug. 17. If you think that it sounds like a show for specialists, you are absolutely right. It was planned to overlap with next month's 17th International Byzantine Congress in Washington and its primary appeal is to international scholarship at its highest, most stringent, and sometimes most contentious level.

title: RACCOON RABIES HEADED TOWARD STATE
description: STATE officials are warning Connecticut residents traveling this summer not to take raccoons home as souvenirs. It is not only against state law, but also it could be fatal.

title: VAULTING TO NEW HEIGHTS
description: ON A SUN-HAZED SATURDAY IN Dallas, Billy Olson is standing beside the Southern Methodist University stadium's pole-vault pit.

title:
GARDENING;
TAWNY DAY LILIES: BEAUTIFUL SURVIVORS
description: THE tenacity and beauty of the roadside tawny day lilies makes them the objects of admiration. Patches of these summer-flowering perennials may be found along country roads competing with weeds, grass and almost anything other than dense shade. They grow in shallow as well as deep places, in wet as well as dry areas and in poor as well as fertile soils. In periods of drought, they may wilt and even turn somewhat brown, but they survive and even flower.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Katherine Powers to Wed Timothy Shryock Brackett
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Powers of Grandview, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Powers to Timothy Shryock Brackett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner Wyndom Brackett of Wyckoff, N.J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 29.

title: Correction
description: A map accompanying an article on Bologna last Sunday mislocated the University of Bologna. A corrective map appears below.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LETTERS OF GERTRUDE STEIN AND CARL VAN VECHTEN. Volume One: 1913-1935. Volume Two: 1935-1946. Edited by Edward Burns (Columbia University, $75.)

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston; A Chinatown On the Prairie
description: OUT in a flat, grassy field 14 miles southwest of downtown's shiny glass towers are the beginnings of what is being touted as Houston's ''new Chinatown,'' an ambitious commercial meeting of the Far East and the Southwest. Long-range plans are to attract a diversity of Asian businesses to Tang City, a master-planned community of homes, parks, office complexes and even a medical center.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE GREAT DAN: A Biography of Daniel O'Connell. By Charles Chenevix Trench. (Jonathan Cape/Merrimack Publishers' Circle, $18.95.) Daniel O'Connell (1775-1846) dominated Irish politics during the first half of the 19th century.

title: Sports of The Times; The Second-Strongest Arm
description: The strongest arm in the world is 100 years old and counting. Without a rubdown or a relief pitcher, the Statue of Liberty's right arm has begun its second century of holding that torch high in New York Harbor. But the world's second-strongest arm is also on display here.

title: The Litigator
description: I don't begrudge David Boies his individual success or his moments of courtroom brilliance (''The Litigator,'' by Cary Reich, June 1).

title: SNOW CHIEF POOR 3D AS FILLY IS WINNER
description: Snow Chief, the Preakness winner and strong pre-race favorite, finished a badly beaten third today as a brilliant gray filly named Melair won the $400,000 Silver Screen Handicap by 6 1/2 lengths.

title: Why Young People Are Leaving L.I.
description: It was interesting to read ''Where Have All the People Gone?'' by Arlene Zaleski [ Opinion Page ] and ''The Memories Live On in the Houses We Leave,'' by George Vecsey, both on June 1.

title: CRIME
description: Lovejoy is back in his 10th adventure - THE TARTAN SELL by Jonathan Gash (St. Martin's, $14.95). He has not changed. He never will change. He may be perpetually broke, his private life is always in a mess, he is a liar and pretends to be a coward, his business dealings are unethical, no woman is safe from him, but he responds to antiques the way Mozart responded to the key of D minor. Antiques set up a vibration in him, and all of a sudden this dubious character becomes an artist.

title: TRANSIT OFFICER SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: An off-duty transit police officer was shot and killed early yesterday in St. Albans, Queens, by two assailants who walked up to the passenger side of the parked car he was sitting in and opened fire with a 9-millimeter handgun, the police said.

title: DIRECTORS AND AGENTS DIFFER ON FEES AND SERVICES
description: IF there is a single problem that condominiums and cooperatives seem to share, it is the one summed up by the word ''management.''

title: KRISTIANSEN BREAKS RECORD
description: Ingrid Kristiansen lowered her world 10,000-meter record today by 46 seconds with a time of 30 minutes 13.74 seconds, but Steve Cram and Said Aouita failed in other attempts to rewrite the record book.

title: NEW CASSETTES: BILLY WILDER FARCE, AFRICAN RHYTHMS
description: One, Two, Three. Starring James Cagney, Pamela Tiffin, Arlene Francis, Horst Buchholz, Hans Lothar; directed by Billy Wilder, 1961; MGM/UA Home Video; 110 minutes.

title: THOUSANDS ARE SAILORS FOR A DAY
description: Thousands of people lined up at the South Street Seaport and along the Brooklyn and Hudson River piers yesterday to board the tall ships whose graceful masts and spars presided over the waterfront during Liberty Weekend.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: Having just recently returned from Venice, I can perhaps shed some additional light on ''What's Doing in Venice'' (Travel, June 8), especially for the budget-conscious tourist.

title: 'TERMINATION' SPECIALIST PROSPERS IN HARD TIMES
description: Often one of the best ways to gauge the severity of tough times is to look at the people who are prospering from them.

title: Irene Zahorjan Is Wed in Providence
description: rene Zahorjan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Zahorjan of Orchard Park, N.Y., was married in Providence, R.I., yesterday to Robert Keith McNamara, a son of Keith McNamara of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Adelaide S. McNamara. The Rev. Charles A. Baldwin performed a Protestant ceremony at the Manning Chapel at Brown University.

title: A FILM ABOUT CHILDREN, FROM HARLEM TO JAPAN
description: Children are children everywhere. They can become friends and overcome environmental and physical handicaps through the arts.

title: A CHANGE FOR THE BETTER
description: Don Aase's emergence as the best relief pitcher in the American League is, in virtually every way, sudden and somewhat unexpected. He spent his first six seasons in the minor leagues, then his first four in the majors as a so-so starting pitcher.

title: MARCOS BACKERS TAKE OVER HOTEL, BUT FAIL TO WIN MILITARY SUPPORT
description: Demonstrators and armed soldiers loyal to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos took over the Manila Hotel Sunday night after his running mate in the election in February, Arturo M. Tolentino, declared himself acting president on Mr. Marcos's behalf.

title: Israeli Spy Case Confirmed
description: The Israeli Police Minister, Haim Bar-Lev, confirmed today that an Israeli officer was on trial for spying for Syria, but gave no further details.

title: SUMMER JOB MARKET: CHANGES IN THE HUNT
description: Steven Wall's search for his first summer job began last April when he visited his school counselor at Grover Cleveland High School in Queens. From there it went ahead in fits and starts.

title: CIVIL RULE FAILS TO END BRAZIL'S CHURCH-STATE RIFT
description: When Brazil's military regime stepped down last year, the president of the National Bishops' Conference, Jose Ivo Lorscheiter, remarked that Roman Catholic priests, who had long been at loggerheads with the dictatorship, could also return to their ''barracks.''

title: Vigilantes in Arizona Capture 15 Illegal Aliens
description: An Alabama-based paramilitary group caught 15 undocumented aliens in Arizona near the Mexican border and held them at gunpoint for an hour and a half until Border Patrol agents arrived, an immigration official said today.

title: Miss Silberstein Becomes a Bride
description: Margery Beth Silberstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Ronald Silberstein of Chestnut Hill and South Dennis, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Leonard Stuart Bloom, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Bloom of Bethesda, Md. Rabbis Samuel Chiel and Laurence Silberstein, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Boston Hotel.

title: Guard Taken Hostage For 5 Hours in Michigan
description: A convicted murderer apparently upset over his impending transfer handcuffed a guard and held her hostage in his cell for nearly five hours today before surrendering, a prison official said.

title: POPE PRAYS FOR VICTIMS OF VOLCANIC CATASTROPHE
description: Pope John Paul II knelt today before a bare cement cross planted in the desolate sea of dried mud that was once the town of Armero and prayed that ''through the solidarity, work and willpower of the people of this land, there should arise, as if out of the ashes, a new city.''

title: The Inkster Team Is Honing Skills
description: JULI INKSTER had just bogeyed the 16th hole in the final round of the 1984 Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament when NBC, which was broadcasting the event, asked for and got a delay in play. The women were moving right along, but the pace was too fast for network officials, who wanted competition to end at the conclusion of their time slot.

title: HAUGHTON IN COMA AFTER SPILL
description: Billy Haughton, the harness racing driver, was unconscious and in critical condition yesterday with head injuries he suffered in a spill at Yonkers Raceway Saturday night.

title: TWO MEN KILLED AT BROOKLYN SITE BY A CHEMICAL
description: Two workers suffocated late Saturday night after they were overcome by fumes from a toxic chemical at a Brooklyn metal painting factory, the authorities said. A third worker was hospitalized yesterday in critical condition.

title: Nancy Fisher Is Bride Of Anthony P. Allison
description: Nancy Fisher, a doctoral candidate in urban, social and medical geography at the University of Washington, and Anthony P. Allison, director of the Moscow office of the Marine Resources Company International, a joint business and trading venture of the United States and the Soviet Union, were married yesterday. Probate Court Judge D. Paul Shapero officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd C. Fisher, in Stamford, Conn.

title: Advertising; Tucker Wayne Named To Handle Wax Paper
description: The Reynolds Metals Company's consumer products division has awarded Tucker Wayne & Company, Atlanta, already its agency, the advertising for Cut-Rite brand wax paper, recently acquired from the Scott Paper Company.

title: A Family Involved With Cellophane
description: For Robert L. Richards Jr., the decision of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to leave the cellophane business in the United States marked the end of a family involvement with cellophane.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS LEGALITY OF FED'S POLICY BODY
description: The Justice Department, resolving an evident dilemma, has sided with the Federal Reserve in a dispute over the constitutional legitimacy of the central bank's principal body for making monetary policy.

title: Norsk Hydro Reserves
description: Norsk Hydro, a Norwegian oil company, said Friday that the recoverable reserves of its North Sea Oseberg oilfield were far higher than previously believed and that 100,000 barrels of crude a day could be added to the field's production. A company spokesman said Norsk Hydro was upgrading the estimated recoverable reserves on the field to 1.28 billion barrels of crude, from 962 million.

title: Sullivan Wins Again
description: Danny Sullivan overcame oppressive heat and humidity and a penalty for a pit-stop infraction today to win the Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix Indy-car race, his second straight victory.

title: Mohawk Data Board Upheld
description: A Federal District Court judge in San Francisco has rejected an appeal from two former directors of the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation to block the company's appointment of two new board members, including the chairman, Asher B. Edelman. The former directors, Thomas K. Christo and Francis P. Lucier, disputed whether the oral resignations they gave at a board meeting on June 3 were binding.

title: THE CHAMP: 15 1/2 HOT DOGS IN 10 MINUTES (WITH BUNS)
description: In a weekend of indulgence, 27-year-old Mark Heller of Manhattan -depending on one's perspective -might rightfully lay claim to the prize for the most indulgent act.

title: JOBLESS YOUTHS OF SUMMER
description: GEORGE PAPAILIAS, a 16-year-old New Yorker, didn't get a job this summer. ''I was disappointed because I like the independence that comes from earning my own spending money,'' he said. ''All my friends are working so I don't know what I will do with my free time.''

title: TENSIONS OF FILIPINO POLITICS IMPEDE REBUILDING BY AQUINO
description: The Philippine economy has not rebounded as many hoped it would after President Ferdinand E. Marcos departed in February. Investment has been slow to materialize, and the stock market, after a burst of buoying goodwill, has settled into stagnation, if not paralysis.

title: Scientific American's Bidder
description: Robert Maxwell, the chairman of Pergamon Press Ltd. in Britain, confirmed yesterday that it was his company that made a last-minute $61 million offer for Scientific American Inc. He characterized the bid as ''perfectly proper and above board.''

title: What About Those Tax-Bill 'Special Exceptions'?
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHITECTURE: THE MODERN OFFERS 'VIENNA 1900'
description: THE art of turn-of-the-century Vienna seems to hold something for everyone - crisp geometric forms for the modernist, lavish decoration for the traditionalist. No wonder it has become so popular now, in the age of ambivalence in which we live. For a time that cannot make up its mind whether it wants to go forward or backward, Vienna has a special allure. It seems to be telling us that we can have it all - that a culture can be revolutionary and can wallow in romantic glory at the same time.

title: FRAUD CHARGED AS MEXICANS VOTE IN KEY STATE ELECTION
description: Amid accusations of electoral irregularities, residents of Chihuahua voted today to elect a governor and city and town governments in one of Mexico's most important state elections.

title: POLICE BLANKET OF BLUE FOSTERS A SAFE FESTIVAL
description: As 800,000 people, the largest crowd ever for a concert in Central Park, filed quietly off the Great Lawn Saturday night after the New York Philharmonic's salute to the Statue of Liberty, a spectator called to a police officer standing on the fringes: ''Hey, you guys got all the bases covered. Good work!'' Indeed, the thousands of officers on duty during the celebration - 22,000 on July 4 alone - formed a virtual blanket of blue around the city for the four-day festival, and crowds from Battery Park to the George Washington Bridge seemd both awed and reassured by their presence.

title: HOW TO GET OFF THE PHONE
description: Basic telephone rates for homes and small businesses are on the rise -they went up $1 a month on June 1, the second installment of a $2-a-month local charge ordered by the Federal Communications Commission. Clearly, most of us will have to find new ways to cut our telephone bills.

title: MUSIC: WATERLOO FESTIVAL BEGINS SUMMER SEASON
description: The Waterloo Festival, which began its summer season this weekend, is about an hour's drive from New York on the grounds of this restored Colonial village near Stanhope, N.J. This year the festival has a new artistic director, the pianist and critic Samuel Lipman, while the ubiquitous Gerard Schwarz is wearing one of his myriad hats as the festival's principal conductor.

title: CRICKET ('WELL PLAYED, PERCY') ON RISE IN AMERICA
description: Matt Mitchell was there by 11:30 A.M., punching boundary stakes into the turf on the green in front of the Haverford College president's house. Aside from the sharp smacks, only a background buzz of summer and the occasional honk of Canada geese on a nearby pond punctuated the weekend tranquillity. Already the temperature approached 90 degrees. ''Going to be horrible out there,'' Mr. Mitchell said.

title: Pengo's Chief Struggles Against Oil's Decline
description: Richard L. Frank, the president, chief executive officer and chief financial officer of Pengo Industries, said that keeping his company afloat had been quite a challenge.

title: REAGAN PICKS 12 TO GET NATIONAL MEDAL OF ARTS
description: President Reagan has selected nine American cultural figures, including three who are foreign-born, to receive the National Medal of Arts for their contributions to the nation. Three patrons of the arts have also been chosen to receive medals.

title: CONGRESS PREPARES ITS COURTROOM FOR JAILED JUDGE
description: Congress is moving rapidly toward its first impeachment trial in half a century, a process that could tie up an already overburdened Senate for weeks.

title: YANKS ARE HELD TO 4 HITS, LOSE TO WHITE SOX, 5-2
description: He had not quite finished filling in the lineup card. Lou Piniella studied it, almost interminably, then looked up from his desk. ''I just need some right-handed hitting,'' he finally said.

title: SUNDAY ALONG THE RIVER
description: A sultry Sunday morning in Moscow. The lines are long outside Lenin's tomb but beyond the Kremlin, the sidewalks are silent. Apartment windows are closed because most Muscovites who could possibly arrange it are in the white birch forests, enjoying the short but vital Russian summer.

title: Venezuela Plan On Debt Voted
description: The Venezuelan Congress has approved a new repayment plan for $6.9 billion of private-sector foreign debt.

title: NEW MEXICO ENERGY PROJECT MINES EARTH'S INTERIOR HEAT
description: A technology designed to mine heat from the earth's interior has succeeded for the first time in producing energy on a potentially commercial scale, according to scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory and the Department of Energy.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: The Mets have played nearly half a season without being shut out. Has a team ever gone an entire season with such a distinction?

title: Coaches Named For All-Star Game
description: John McNamara of the Boston Red Sox and Davey Johnson of the Mets, whose teams boast the best records in the American and the National Leagues, have been named coaches for the All-Star Game on July 15.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE CHILDREN: COPING WITH RE-ENTRY
description: When Theresa J. Lauderdale moved to the United States at the age of 16, she had lived in five countries and spoke four languages. Yet her high-school peers had little interest in the outside world, she says, and she found it difficult to make friends.

title: Robins Plan For Claims
description: The A. H. Robins Company would put $100 million into a Dalkon Shield trust, followed by payments over 10 years of an undetermined amount, and would have no role in how the money would be spent, according to a draft of its plan of reorganization being circulated to lawyers involved in its bankruptcy case.

title: A Greenwich Village Quest
description: Scene at Sheridan Square:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 7, 1986:

title: Ancient Lizard's Fossil Is Discovered in Texas
description: The skeleton of a seagoing lizard that lived 80 million years ago has been uncovered in a creek bed in northern Texas, paleontologists report.

title: Policeman Wounded; His Assailant Is Slain
description: A Jersey City policeman was wounded and his assailant was killed in an exchange of gunfire tonight, authorities said.

title: 'FRANCE SALUTES NEW YORK' FESTIVAL
description: New York will hardly have time to draw breath after the gigantic Statue of Liberty birthday party before the ''France Salutes New York'' festival begins, tonight at Lincoln Center.

title: AMID BOWLER HATS, A BUILDING FIT FOR RISK-TAKERS
description: Pausing in a circumambulation of the newly opened Lloyd's Building - with little doubt, London's most daring postwar building - Richard Rogers advanced an intellectually subtle argument for its appropriateness among the classical porticoes, stone facades and Wren steeples that define its crowded urban context.

title: The Court Meets the Gerrymander
description: A quarter of a century ago the Supreme Court brushed aside warnings of a ''political thicket'' and opened the process of reapportioning legislatures to review by the courts. The predicted judicial calamity has not occurred. Instead, rotten-borough politics lost and democracy won. Today, city voters elect the same number of legislators as their suburban or country cousins.

title: Oil Concerns Deny Charges
description: Major oil companies charged with price violations by state officials last week said the allegations were groundless. The companies - Exxon, Mobil, Sun and Texaco - have been accused of violating antitrust laws by charging retail and wholesale customers different prices for gasoline.

title: 'SISTER SUZIE CINEMA,' A 'DOO-WOP OPERA'
description: MOVIES, doo-wop singing, free-associative imagery and yearning, unabashed romance are the makings of ''Sister Suzie Cinema.'' Tonight's program in the nominally avant-garde ''Alive From Off Center'' series at 10 on Channel 31, simulcast in stereo on WNYC-FM (93.9), ''Sister Suzie Cinema'' is a fantasy about fantasies - about the way movies, music and other cultural artifacts shape what we feel.

title: BECKER DOMINATES LENDL, RETAINS WIMBLEDON TITLE
description: The doubts disappeared two weeks ago when Boris Becker walked onto Centre Court for the first time in a year and felt as if he had never been away. Goose bumps spread over his body, he said, and the grass was a magic carpet under his feet. Others doubted whether the boy who dared to win Wimbledon could do it again, but Becker was no longer one of them. All that remained was for the chair umpire to say ''play.''

title: Temperature of 98 degrees Ties Record for Day
description: The temperature reached 98 degrees in Central Park yesterday afternoon, tying a record for July 6 set in 1911, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Mission to Nowhere
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, flies off this week on a diplomatic mission that may set a modern record for pointlessness. He is going to see whether the South African Government will eat its recent words, undo its actions and negotiate the country's future with leaders of the black majority.

title: Birthday for Nancy Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan celebrated her 65th birthday quietly at the White House today, with the day marked by the gift of a custom-made saddle from President Reagan. Elaine Crispen, the First Lady's press secretary, said President Reagan had told Mrs. Reagan the saddle would be awaiting her at their ranch in California when they arrived in mid-August for vacation.

title: Kent State Trustees Reject Design for Protest Memorial
description: Kent State University trustees have rejected a design they had earlier accepted for a memorial to the four students killed and nine others wounded by National Guardsmen in a Vietnam war protest in 1970.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bridge: California Expert Is Making Rare East Coast Appearance
description: One of the world's great players, one who rarely appears on the East Coast, will give a four-evening series of seminars in Westchester this week.

title: LAW SCHOOLS TURN TO COMPETING TO WIN STUDENTS
description: After two decades of steady growth and prosperity, American law schools find themselves struggling with declining applications, sagging enrollment and increasingly aggressive competition for students.

title: Dollar Again Falls to New Low Against Yen
description: The dollar opened today at a record Tokyo low of 159.70 yen and continued to fall - at one point reaching 158.90 - despite the Bank of Japan's intervention in support of the dollar, dealers said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are tough and unapologetic about what we are doing.'' - Musa Hitam, Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister, on the execution of two Australians for drug offenses. [ A5:2. ]

title: TRADING IN FUTURES INCREASES BY 28%
description: Spurred by the rising popularity of interest-rate futures, the trading volume in futures and options on futures contracts rose by more than 28 percent in the first half of the year at the nation's major commodity exchanges.

title: THE DANCE: NUREYEV IN BALLET THEATER'S 'GISELLE'
description: RUDOLF NUREYEV and Cynthia Harvey were the season's new faces in American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle,'' albeit not during the same performance, in the company's final weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: WEAPONS DEAL ALIVE FOR LORAL
description: The Loral Corporation's takeover bid for Sanders Associates Inc., if it succeeds, would put Loral back in the competition for a huge military contract just after it was eliminated from the field of bidders.
