title: FOR THE GRAND FINALE, CAST OF THOUSANDS
description: Rockets' red glare and bombs bursting in air ending Liberty Weekend gave proof through the night that, yes, those in the audience actually saw what they thought they saw, a mass conglobation of about 6,000 Jazzercise ladies, tap dancers, fiddlers, Elvis imitators, square dancers, marching bands, banjo players, drill teams and the Four Tops standing on the field at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: Catching Up
description: * Kathy Ormsby, the North Carolina State distance runner who suffered paralysis of her legs in a leap from a bridge in Indianapolis early last month, remains in stable condition at Duke Medical Center in Durham, N.C. The 21-year-old Miss Ormsby underwent surgery June 19 to realign and stabilize her spine, and she's now able to sit up in bed. Among the family members and close friends who have visited her is her coach, Rollie Geiger, who describes her as now being ''in good spirits'' and looking forward to leaving the hospital in ''four to six weeks.''

title: HORNER TIES MARK WITH 4 HOME RUNS
description: Bob Horner of Atlanta became the 11th player in major-league history to hit a record four home runs in one game, but the Braves fell to the Montreal Expos, 11-8, yesterday.

title: OUTDOORS: ST. LAWRENCE FISHING
description: UNLESS one is extraordinarily disciplined, the first hour of fishing from an unfamiliar craft in unfamiliar waters is something like driving a rental car in a strange city.

title: The Fanatic's Lexicon
description: To the Editor:

title: FERNANDEZ WINS, 5-3 FOR 11TH
description: For those who may have glanced at the National League West standing and wondered if the weekend's events at Shea Stadium might be a preview of the league's championship series, here are the thoughts of Hal Lanier, manager of the Houston Astros.

title: The Mayor's Sweet School Victory
description: The election of Robert F. Wagner Jr. as president of the New York City Board of Education testifies to his considerable ability and partially realizes Mayor Koch's dream for the board. The Mayor deserves credit for pursuing that goal even as distracted by municipal scandal and worries about his ability to govern. Having now improved the board, he and Mr. Wagner now face the challenge of improving the schools.

title: U.S. WINS 2 TITLES AT HENLEY REGATTA
description: American crews rowed in five championship races today at the Henley Royal Regatta and won two of them.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Come Hither
description: Several weeks ago, Martin Peretz, editor in chief of The New Republic, invited Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for lunch with the magazine's editorial staff, as Government officials and politicians do periodically. But no response was forthcoming.

title: HASIDIC ENCLAVE: A STEP BACK TO OLDER VALUES
description: Every Friday, 15 minutes before the start of the Jewish Sabbath, a siren wails atop a Hasidic school in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Some last-minute hustle and bustle is obvious on the streets and then, as the day of rest arrives with the sinking sun, the siren goes off. Suddenly all is quiet. The men are in the synagogue, the women are in the home and the Sabbath begins.

title: WHO IS BASEBALL'S BEST? PLAYERS SAY MATTINGLY
description: HE has been a batting champion, his league's most valuable player, and now his contemporaries have affirmed what all the numbers and awards say about Don Mattingly. To the major league baseball players, Mattingly is the best in the game.

title: American Fashions for American Shops
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 7, 1986
description: International

title: Advertising; Pinpointing Corporate Managers
description: KAREN ZEHRING, who says she has wanted to be a publisher since before she knew what the word meant, has attained that exalted state and is coming out with a controlled-circulation magazine in November.

title: Spain Begins Its Celebration As the Bulls Prepare to Run
description: A skyrocket fired from the balcony of the city hall today marked the start of festivities surrounding the running of the bulls.

title: Federation of Teachers Adopts Carnegie Report
description: The American Federation of Teachers convention today overwhelmingly adopted the Carnegie Report on Education, which calls for the professionalization of teaching by establishing a national board of certification.

title: CITY OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'CANDIDE'
description: IT is the lighter works of Rossini that most music lovers now take most seriously; the same paradox applies to the music of Leonard Bernstein. I'll gladly forgo the Mass and the three big symphonies anytime for the brash, witty, four-minute amalgamation of Richard Strauss, Aaron Copland and Broadway glitter that is the ''Candide'' overture.

title: Devaluation By Peking
description: China devalued its currency by an average 15.8 percent against major foreign currencies, the State Commission for Foreign Exchange Control said Saturday.

title: Protests in Pakistan Are Called a Success
description: Benazir Bhutto, the opposition leader, said today that nationwide anti-Government protests had been a success and that she would soon announce new plans to oust Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq as president.

title: BANC ONE STRETCHES BORDERS
description: When the Banc One Corporation decided recently to repaint its corporate jet, the joke around the company's headquarters here was that the aircraft would receive a new name: ''Devour.''

title: American Express Bank
description: The American Express Bank Ltd. has bought a 40 percent share in the International Corporate Bank, or Interbank, which was previously owned by the Phillipines' state-run National Development Company. Interbank said in a statement on Thursday that the 40 percent share was equivalent to $16 million, an amount that represents a portion of the American Express Bank's exposure in the central bank that was converted into equity. Interbank is the seventh-largest domestic commercial bank in the country in terms of net worth.

title: FINAL WORDS ON CELEBRATION
description: David L. Wolper, Liberty Weekend ''Everything worked out like I planned it. It went off with taste, dignity and importance. People had a good time, felt good about themselves and felt good about their country.''

title: Chocolate Riches
description: The good news is that David Osborne, head of a Washington concern called Truffles and Flourishes, is already gearing up for a third season of production this fall. When you make truffles the way he does, lacing the super-rich chocolate bonbons with so much cream that their shelf-life is measured in hours, the climate in the capital does not permit candymaking before October or after Easter.

title: A MARCH BY PROTESTANTS OPENS A SEASON OF TENSION IN ULSTER
description: The unwelcome bagpipers of the Orangemen broke into ''Abide With Me'' at six minutes to noon and strutted directly into the gray, grim enclave of Roman Catholic nationalists that is known as the Tunnel.

title: Truth Keeps Marching
description: The members of the United Methodist Church's hymnal committee are surely not bomb-throwers. But their decision in May to delete ''Onward Christian Soldiers'' and ''The Battle Hymn of the Republic'' from the Methodist hymnal was the liturgical equivalent of changing the formula for Coke.

title: EXPERTS SEE VALUE IN OCEANS AS SITES FOR WASTES
description: In years to come, the world's oceans will be increasing in importance as a dump site but other uses, such as mineral mining and aquaculture, will be slow to catch on, marine experts say.

title: ART AND BATHROOM TALES ON CHANNEL 13 FESTIVAL
description: CHANNEL 13's ''Four on Thirteen'' festival, featuring programming from Britain's Channel 4, is offering a double feature tonight: ''Every Picture Tells a Story'' at 10, and ''Twenty-Six Bathrooms'' at 11:30. The odd combination reflects a measure of the admirable variety for which Channel 4 has become famous or, if you will, notorious.

title: Advertising; 2 New Grey Accounts: Seasoning and Stores
description: Grey Advertising began its long weekend with two new accounts.

title: NEW STATE, OLD MINES, TORN CLUB
description: When New Mexicans talk about the land south of their border, they often refer to the country as ''Old Mexico.'' But if they are trying to make sure that the rest of America understands the distinction, there is ample evidence that many people in the other 49 states have yet to get the message.

title: If Warsaw Wants Normal Relations
description: Last week, in a four-hour speech to Poland's Communist Party congress, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski offered partial amnesty to ''certain categories'' of political prisoners and promised tolerance for those with dissenting views. General Jaruzelski has tried this ploy before, hoping to persuade the West that all was normal in Poland - and thus to encourage us to resume normal economic relations. As before, the United States should welcome the gesture, but it should also do what it can to press the Polish leader to make good on his promises.

title: Advertising; Welch/Currier Buying Boston's Blouin & Co.
description: Up Boston way, Welch/Currier, founded in 1980, has begun acquiring the equity in the five-year-old Blouin & Company, from its founder-owner, Richard R. Blouin.

title: Coffee Quotas May Return
description: Coffee exporting and importing countries belonging to the International Coffee Organization, which regulates the world market, are preparing for a possible reintroduction of export quotas, according to I.C.O. delegates.

title: Argentine Inflation
description: Argentina's cost of living index rose 4 percent in June after a 4 percent increase in May, and compared with a 30.5 percent rise in June 1985, the National Statistics Institute reported Saturday. Inflation in the year ended June was 50.1 percent, against 87.4 percent in the 12 months ended in April.

title: MORE U.S. TRAVELERS LOOKING ACROSS THE PACIFIC
description: Air travel between the mainland and Hawaii is booming this summer, adding to a surge of traffic over the Pacific Ocean that has begun to rival the volume of passenger traffic over the North Atlantic.

title: LITTLE HELP SEEN FROM A RATE CUT
description: Although anticipation of a cut in the discount rate has continued to fuel rallies in the credit markets, several economists are beginning to question whether the cut, which most now see as inevitable, will do much to stimulate the nation's sluggish economy.

title: Nancy Perlman Married in Greenwich
description: Nancy Deborah Perlman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Perlman of Tucson, Ariz., was married in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Thomas Davis Klingenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Klingenstein of Greenwich. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Group Says Population Hits Five Billion Today
description: Sometime, somewhere on Monday, the world will reach a milestone: the birth of a child will bring Earth's population to five billion people, the World Population Institute said today.

title: WHAT ABOUT THOSE TAX-BILL 'SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coney I. Boy, 10, Suffocates In Old Refrigerator at Aunt's
description: The body of a 10-year-old Brooklyn boy, who apparently suffocated, was found in an old refrigerator in the basement of his aunt's Brighton Beach apartment late Saturday night by his father following a six-hour search, the police said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Afco Credit Corporation, named Michael M. Nisbet president of the company and of its Canadian affiliate, Cafo Inc.

title: PINOCHET'S OPPONENTS: POLARIZED BY VIOLENCE AND LACKING A STRONG LEADER
description: The two-day general strike in Chile last week pointed out two major difficulties confronting Chileans who want Gen. Augusto Pinochet to give up power in favor of a democratically elected government.

title: LIBERTY PANEL PONDERS WHEREFORES OF FREEDOM
description: A simple-sounding question kept intruding into the weekend's conference on ''Liberty - the Next 100 Years'': as one panelist put it, ''Free for what purpose?''

title: Rozelle to Present Drug Plan Today
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, will announce a new drug program for the league at a news conference today.

title: Peggy Is His 'Thing' And the Chimp's, Too
description: Mario Buatta took a chimpanzee to hear Peggy Lee sing the other night.

title: Hyundai Exports Triple
description: The Hyundai Motor Company's car exports tripled to 138,436 vehicles in the first six months of 1986, from 46,000 in the comparable 1985 period, Hyundai officials said Saturday.

title: NAKASONE'S PARTY APPEARS TO REGAIN A CLEAR MAJORITY
description: Japan's long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party registered stunning gains today in parliamentary elections, capturing the powerful House of Representatives in a landslide victory of historic dimensions.

title: 2,000 Posters 2 Months In Advance of Primary
description: Two thousand ''Lundine Lieutenant Governor'' posters have sprouted on light poles in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, considerably in advance of the Sept. 9 primary and the Nov. 4 general election.

title: 'KATHERINE ANNE PORTER' ON 13'S 'MASTERS' SERIES
description: TELEVISION might be expected to have special problems when it attempts to probe the mind of the writer, whose thoughts are meant to be read. Yet tonight's installment of the ''American Masters'' series on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock conveys an impression that is worth thousands of written words in its study of Katherine Anne Porter.

title: Washington Watch; The Deadlock Over Conrail
description: The Heritage Foundation, hoping to succeed where others have failed, will soon try to break the stalemate on the sale of Conrail. The issue is caught between Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole and John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which controls the sale legislation in the House.

title: Jennifer S. Weissman Marries Jeffrey Lavine
description: At Beth-El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday Jennifer Sari Weissman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Weissman of New York, was married to Jeffrey Neal Lavine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Lavine of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Aaron Pomerantz performed the ceremony.

title: OVERSEEING OF C.I.A. BY CONGRESS HAS PRODUCED DECADE OF SUPPORT
description: Despite some highly public skirmishes over the last decade, Congressional committees that oversee the Central Intelligence Agency have provided almost unbroken support for the agency and other intelligence activities, according to past and present committee members and Reagan Administration officials.

title: Philadelphia Considers Taking In Trash
description: If negotiations resuming Monday between the city and unions representing 14,000 striking employees do not progress fast enough, the city will arrange to take in trash, Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today.

title: Nynex Hires Leader For Computer Retailing
description: In a move to secure an experienced leader for its expanding retail computer operations, the Nynex Corporation has hired James N. Turner, 55, a former top retail executive for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: MATTINGLY A HIT AMONG PEERS
description: THE BAT moved in a powerful and perfect arc - once, then twice, then three times. Don Mattingly watched his hands intently as he swung, ignoring the pregame commotion in the clubhouse and focusing fully on the rhythm he had created. And he swung the bat again, slowly.

title: Advertising; M.E.D. to Do Plax Ads
description: A week ago, it was announced that Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising would be doing the consumer advertising for Plax, a product from Oral Research Laboratories that is designed to remove plaque. On Thursday M.E.D. Communications of Woodbridge, N.J., reported that it would be doing the professional advertising and that it and Ally had teamed up to successfully solicit the account.

title: Laurie Bender, Illustrator, Marries Roy Philip Weber
description: Laurie Ellen Bender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bender of Elmsford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roy Philip Weber, a son of Mrs. Emanuel Shapiro of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Harry Weber. Rabbi Paul Siegel officiated at Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: Behind the Computer Magic, Young Brains
description: The displays included a computer game and a computer program that teaches differential calculus, and the whizzes that proudly stood before these exhibits included two fifth graders from Wellesley, Mass., and a recent high school graduate from St. Paul.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 7, 1986
description: The Economy

title: O'GRADY WINS IN PLAYOFF
description: Mac O'Grady shot a course-record 62 today, then got his first PGA Tour victory in a one-hole playoff with Roger Maltbie.

title: Liberty's Encore
description: Any Washingtonians who still have not had their fill of the inspiring image of the Statue of Liberty after the holiday weekend festivities need not despair. Next week the Smithsonian Resident Associate Program will present a slide-lecture by Peter B. Kaplan, featuring the best two dozen of some 75,000 color pictures he has taken of the statue since he was officially appointed its ''preferred photographer'' by the Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island Foundation in 1983. The program will be held on July 15 in the Hirshhorn Museum auditorium.

title: Market Place; How the Funds Did in Quarter
description: THE nation's two top-performing mutual funds in the second quarter had one thing in common: They rode to stardom chiefly on the soaring price of Home Shopping Network Inc., the ''hottest'' new issue of this year. Home Shopping, a cable television retailer, went public on May 13 at $18 a share and closed on June 30 at $95.375 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: INDIANS TOP ROYALS FOR 7TH STRAIGHT
description: Tom Candiotti pitched a four-hitter today as the Indians defeated the Kansas City Royals, 5-0, for their seventh consecutive victory.

title: Peter Mack, 69, Dies; 'Flying Congressman'
description: Former Representative Peter Francis Mack Jr., Democrat of Illinois, died Friday at the Shady Grove Adventist Hospital, a hospital spokesman said Saturday. Mr. Mack was 69 years old.

title: If You Don't Watch It, Tort Reform'll Get You
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Phone Proposal Stirs the Hill
description: BOB DOLE, the Kansas Republican who is Senate majority leader, may have stirred the troops with his ''Free-the-Bell-Seven'' legislation, filed just before the July 4 recess. But the troops are hardly united.

title: A NEW WAY TO FINANCE PUBLIC TV
description: The fall in oil prices drops another shoe on the already bent heads of programmers at the Public Broadcasting System.

title: FOR URBAN GARDENERS, A SOURCE OF GUIDANCE
description: When insects began eating his backyard garden, Herbert Magenheim did what farmers have been doing for years: he called a Cornell University Cooperative Extension agent for advice.

title: Humor Off the Field
description: The house was packed, and Tim Wrightman, tight end of the Super Bowl champion Chicago Bears, had his game face on. He went out there, a little tardy, and milked the silence. Finally he said: ''I'm sorry I'm late. You all know Coach Ditka had his driver's license suspended. Well, it's my week to drive him around.'' Chuckles filled the banquet room. ''On the subject of offense,'' he continued, ''the Bears have a good one. But the defense is tougher. They're so tough that when they finish sacking the quarterback, they go after his family in the stands.''

title: Carlos M. Arrom Wed To Paula Whitehorn
description: Paula Barri Whitehorn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Whitehorn of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Carlos M. Arrom, a son of Dr. Raquel Alvarez of Skokie, Ill., and Dr. Orlando Arrom of Miami. Rabbi Barry Greene performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Jeshurun.

title: A STUDY ASSESSES TRAITS OF WOMEN WHO KILL
description: A new research study of women who kill, a group that has been given relatively little attention by social scientists, dispels some common myths about these women. They are neither more emotional nor less predictable than men who kill, the study has found. And most do not conform to the stereotype of the ''Arsenic and Old Lace'' killer, or to the pattern of figures like Bonnie Parker.

title: Letter: On Caring for the Elderly; Don't Cut Off Old People
description: To the Editor:

title: ON DAY OF RECORD HEAT, LIBERTY WEEKEND ENDS
description: After four extravagant days of ships, fireworks, ceremonies and festivals, Liberty Weekend drew to a close on the hottest day of the year yesterday with capacity crowds at the Statue of Liberty and a spectacular glamour-and-glitz production-show finale.

title: A MEMORY OF MCAULIFFE
description: It was a moment so laden with emotion that it choked the voice of Mary Hatwood Futrell, president of the National Education Association, and had many of the more than 7,500 people present dabbing their eyes with handkerchiefs or quietly crying.

title: PURCHASERS REPORT JUNE SLOWDOWN
description: Economic activity slowed in June and could stagger for months to come, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest survey released today.

title: HAITI'S SMALL INDUSTRIES FACE A STRUGGLE WITH UNCERTAINTY
description: It was early afternoon, and the rows of sewing machines in the lingerie factory were silent.

title: DEVELOPER PUTS MARK ON TOKYO
description: Taikichiro Mori has left his mark all over downtown Tokyo - literally. On most of the real estate developer's buildings, which seem to sprout like bamboo throughout the Toranomon business district, Mr. Mori has affixed a sign bearing his name and the building's number. He started in 1957 with Mori Building One, and he is up to 45.

title: The U.N. Today: July 7, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 3 P.M.

title: A Death Knell For Tax Shelters?
description: Some two years ago, when Roscoe L. Roger Jr., then Commissioner of Internal Revenue, was asked what he would do if he could make one change in the tax code, he replied: ''Oh, boy! I would go back and look at the whole question of the ability to offset losses from one type of business activity against income that is totally unrelated.'' Which is to say, tax shelters. At the heart of every tax shelter -almond groves, master recordings, office buildings, feed lots, what you will - is the deduction of purely passive losses, paper losses as they are most often described, from real dollar income. The passive losses offset the investor's positive income, and to that extent he pays no tax.

title: Iraq Asks Amnesty International to Prove Abduction of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Bangladesh Elephants Kill 5
description: Two wild elephants smashed a mud-and-straw hut in a village in the Chittagong Hills, crushing to death a woman and her four sons while they were sleeping, a Government-owed newspaper said today. The elephants emerged from a forest on June 26 and attacked the hut in Buichara village, 220 miles southeast of Dhaka.

title: Court Delays Economist Bid
description: A temporary restraining order, issued Thursday, bars the Business International Corporation and Economist Newspaper Ltd. from consummating a sale of the former to the latter.

title: CUOMO GAINS SUCCESSES THROUGH G.O.P. SENATORS
description: After three years of being criticized as lacking leadership in his dealings with the Legislature, Governor Cuomo concluded a legislative session last week that enacted several new programs and resolved a half-dozen key issues that had been in dispute for years.

title: Irish Filly Takes American Oaks
description: Valley Victory, an Irish filly making only her second career start on the dirt, scored an overpowering 11-length victory over favored Life at the Top in the $232,800 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: FRENCH PRESIDENT'S VISITS ABROAD MAY BURNISH HIS IMAGE AT HOME
description: When President Francois Mitterrand leaves Monday on a four-day state visit to the Soviet Union, it will be his second trip abroad in less than a week.

title: APARTHEID'S MAP CAN BE MISLEADING
description: An Afrikaner business official was telling a story the other day about the affluent suburb where he lives, Sandton, which is supposed to be for whites only.

title: JAGJIVAN RAM, CHAMPION OF INDIA'S UNTOUCHABLES, DIES AT 78
description: Jagjivan Ram, a former Deputy Prime Minister of India and a spokesman for more than 100 million untouchables, died in New Delhi today. He was 78 years old and had been hospitalized since May with severe respiratory problems.

title: American Wins 3d Stage of Tour
description: Davis Phinney won the third stage of the Tour de France cycling race today, but Thierry Marie of France retained the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Dwindling Era
description: They may yet slug it out for the division title, as they were expected to, but for now the Reds and the Dodgers are merely bottom-enders in the unpretentious National League West. In Cincinnati, the disappointments of the summer have brought far-reaching sentiment that it's time to slam the door shut on the final vestiges of the Big Red Machine era.

title: MALAYSIANS HANG TWO AUSTRALIANS
description: Two Australians convicted by Malaysia of trafficking in heroin were hanged this morning.

title: CONTINUING PROBLEMS FOR COPPER
description: Although tentative labor agreements at some copper companies last week eased fears of a strike this summer, the nation's troubled copper companies continue to face a number of problems that analysts and experts say will keep the industry in the doldrums for some time.

title: A DIFFERENT EMPHASIS AT YALE
description: To the holders of the 70,000 master's degrees in business awarded nationwide this year, Burton Malkiel, the dean of the Yale School of Organization and Management, offers a gentle reproach.

title: MAN BURNED IN CHILE STRIKE DIES
description: A 19-year-old Chilean-born photographer from Washington who was reportedly set on fire by soldiers in demonstrations last week against the Government died today of his burns, according to relatives and doctors at Santiago's emergency hospital.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IF WALLS COULD SPEAK The walls of the high-ceilinged lobby at 1 Penn Plaza, the big office building at 231 West 33d Street, opposite Madison Square Garden, form a natural art gallery in a way that has not escaped the attention of the management.

title: Lloyds Sees Bid Approval
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said Friday that it expects United States regulatory authorities to clear its proposed acquisition of the Union Bank, a California subsidiary of Standard Chartered P.L.C., clearing the way for the Lloyds bid for Standard to proceed.

title: Defining Women's Rights Will Aid Abortion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: 100-METER DASH FOR ASHFORD
description: Evelyn Ashford and Jackie Joyner excelled in track and field, as did Leslie Daland in swimming and Cheryl Miller in basketball to lead the United States today in the Goodwill Games.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CINCINNATI REDS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: 11 States Considering Big Combined Lottery
description: Eleven states and the District of Columbia are considering a weekly lottery with jackpots that could reach $100 million, a participant in talks said today.

title: 'STAR' WARS: DUELING K'S
description: FOR fastball aficionados, it's almost too good to be true. If baseball fans could vote for the starting pitchers in the All-Star Game, they would surely choose Dwight Gooden of the Mets and Roger Clemens of the Red Sox. And barring a muscle twinge, baseball's two most compelling pitchers will be firing dueling fastballs, if not dueling K's, through the first three innings at the Houston Astrodome next Tuesday night. Strangely enough, the two right-handers will be seeing each other really pitch for the first time.

title: WHAT ABOUT THOSE TAX-BILL 'SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS'?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Stress on Home Violence
description: A new Justice Department study, financed by the National Institute of Justice, today called on police departments nationwide to treat spouse-beating cases as violent crimes and to set up specific programs to deal with such cases.

title: Syrians in Lebanon Patrol Moslem Areas
description: Syrian forces patrolled Moslem areas in the capital today and dominated a vital highway intersection outside the city.

title: Washington Watch; The Oil Reserve Outlook
description: It looks increasingly likely that the Administration will decide to suspend its plan to halt additions to the strategic petroleum reserve. The President's Domestic Policy Council takes up the issue this week and the betting is that it will decide to look elsewhere for savings, so that the buildup of the reserve can continue beyond this month.

title: Advertising; New Magazine Planned For Hospital Patients
description: Albert Lewis, in publishing for 13 years and president and publisher of Professional Stained Glass magazine, has teamed up with Andrea Troy, a rehabilitation counselor, and Brian Weeks, a psychiatric social worker and a psychotherapist, to form Patient Publications at 270 Lafayette Street in New York.

title: SOFTBALL IN BRONX WITH A POLITICAL PITCH
description: While most New Yorkers spent the weekend figuring out how to get downtown for a look at the harbor, a group of Nicaraguan expatriates were making their way uptown to Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to play softball on one of the park's many shadeless diamonds. The occasion was an annual get-together of Nicaraguan softball league teams.

title: Relatives Seek Inquiry In Palestinian Killings
description: The families of two Arabs from occupied Gaza, killed after their capture in a 1984 bus hijacking, asked Israel's Supreme Court today to order an investigation into the deaths, legal sources said. The families are also seeking the cancellation of immunity from prosecution that was granted to officials of Shin Beth, the domestic security agency.

title: U.S. to Sell $9.5 Billion in 1-Year Bills
description: Issues of Government securities this week will include the regular weekly Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills today and $9.5 billion of one-year Treasury bills on Tuesday.

title: Risks of Being on Uncle Sam's Crew
description: In 1984, 6,688 Federal employees were bitten by dogs. An additional 2,642 employees were injured by bites of other animals and insects.

title: Constitution's Turn
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has always been a little schizophrenic about his relations with Congress. On the one hand, as chief administrative officer of the Federal courts, he found it necessary and proper to press for legislation affecting the judges and courts for which he was responsible.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MOON PINNACE. By Thomas Williams. 352 pages. Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Sprinting Advantage
description: Colts have won 110 of the 112 Kentucky Derbies, and no one has ever suggested giving the fillies a headstart or allowing them a less-distant finish line. But just look at what happens when it's the females that have the upper hand.

title: Insurers Sue In Florida
description: The insurance industry has filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of a new Florida law that orders decreases in commercial liability insurance premiums.

title: Publishing Unit at I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had created a new business unit to enter the electronic publishing market -small computer systems that create typeset-quality text and pictures camera-ready for printing.

title: CONCERT: 'MS. LIBERTY'
description: ALTHOUGH the evening was called ''Ms. Liberty: An American Folk Performance Celebrating Extraordinary Women in U.S. History,'' and was cited as a ''piece for collaboration,'' the ties that bound the three ''acts'' together were tenuous at best. Lenny Pickett, the spokesman for one of the performing groups, the Borneo Horns, admitted as much. ''Any connection between the music we play and the projected slides is purely coincidental,'' he said with a grin.

title: JORDANIANS CLOSE ARAFAT'S OFFICES
description: In a growing struggle with Yasir Arafat, Jordan today closed all 25 offices of Al Fatah, the Palestinian leader's mainstream group in the divided Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: WILLIAM T. DODD
description: William T. Dodd, former secretary-treasurer of the United Association of Plumbers, Pipefitters and Steamfitters, died Wednesday at Boca Raton (Fla.)

title: An Opposition Leader Flees Arrest in Liberia
description: A Liberian opposition politician, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, fled arrest after staging an illegal weekend rally, the Star newspaper said today.

title: Analyst's Forecast Spurs Stock Action
description: Every market day there are several reasons offered as to why stocks go up or down. Yesterday, John A. Mendelson was one of them.

title: Raymond L. Wise, 91, Dies; Former Director of A.C.L.U.
description: Raymond L. Wise, a lawyer and former member of the board of the American Civil Liberties Union, died of heart failure Sunday at the Miami Heart Institute in Florida. He was 91 years old and lived in North Miami.

title: Foster Care Is Start of a Lifetime in Institutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Court to Umpire Wheelchair Case
description: On May 30, Robert Loewenstein, manager and third-base coach of the Sanitary Plumbing women's softball team of Grand Island, Neb., was kicked off the field by the umpires and told not to return for the rest of the season. Loewenstein is no Earl Weaver or Billy Martin.

title: Arms Aide Is Nominated
description: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating Lynn Marvin Hansen to be assistant director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Hansen has been an alternate delegate at the East-West talks on security in Stockholm.

title: 'Yogic Flying'
description: At a press briefing tomorrow, several hundred adepts will demonstrate the technique of ''yogic flying'' at the Washington Convention Center.

title: Robert Bosch
description: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. does not rule out participation in a planned joint telecommunications venture between the ITT Corporation and France's Compagnie Generale d'Electricite. Robert Bosch's chief executive, Marcus Bierich, said at a news conference, ''We are fairly certain that we will be asked to consider that topic.'' He added that cooperation could make sense.

title: FEES AND DELAYS IN ESTATE CASES ARE CHALLENGED
description: New York State officials, exercising closer scrutiny over public administrators of wills and estates, have begun challenging thousands of dollars in legal, accounting and other fees and expenses claimed from the estates of deceased Queens residents.

title: Crude Oil Off Sharply In Reaction to OPEC
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products fell sharply on the world oil market yesterday in what oil analysts said was a continuing reaction to last week's inconclusive conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Bendectin Case Ruling Given
description: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for trial in Ohio state courts of suits by a woman from Scotland and a woman from Canada against the maker of Bendectin, an anti-nausea drug that purportedly caused birth defects in some children whose mothers had taken it during pregnancy.

title: TURF FIGHT IN THE TOWNSHIPS: BLACK BATTLES BLACK
description: They moved between the shanties, heads swathed in white bandannas and armed with clubs fashioned from metal pipe. Across a kind of no-man's land, along an empty street, their adversaries had formed a line on a ridge.

title: Waterhouse Fills Key Post
description: Price Waterhouse, a worldwide accounting and tax consulting firm, has named Thomas L. Raleigh Jr. co-chairman of operations and deputy senior partner. Mr. Raleigh, 59 years old, succeeds John W. Zick, who has retired.

title: Mexican State Election In Chihuahua Challenged
description: The opposition National Action Party, accusing Mexico's governing party of electoral fraud, said today that it would probably seek the annulment of the gubernatorial and municipal elections Sunday in Chihuahua.

title: HONEST, ANOTHER GALA PLANNED FOR 'THE LADY'
description: It is a dizzying thought.

title: Market Place; The Big Money Turns Cautious
description: INSTITUTIONAL investors, the driving force behind the bull market that began nearly four years ago, are now turning cautious. In fact, trading volume yesterday during the largest one-day point plunge in the history of the Dow Jones industrial average would have been even higher, money managers suggested, except for a lack of buyers willing to accommodate sizable sell orders.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SHOPPERS who don't really know SoHo concentrate on the main thoroughfares - West Broadway, Spring and Prince Streets. But the cognoscenti don't leave the area without checking out the side streets where they may find special little boutiques that have slipped quietly onto the scene.

title: PLAN FOR ELLIS ISLAND DEVELOPMENT STILL IN QUESTION
description: Even amid the euphoria of Liberty Weekend, officials continued debating one unanswered question of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island restoration effort: what to do with the former hospital buildings and wards on the 17 acres of Ellis Island nearest Liberty Island.

title: Mail-In Lotto Winners
description: ''I've got enough tickets to wallpaper a room,'' Dennis McCaffery said about his six-year collection of nonwinning Lotto forms.

title: CHRISTOPHER C. McGRATH DIES; FORMER BRONX CONGRESSMAN
description: Christopher C. McGrath, a former judge, United States Representative and surrogate of the Bronx, died of heart disease yesterday at New York University Hospital Center. He was 84 years old and lived on the Upper East Side, having moved there from the Bronx upon his retirement from office in 1972.

title: BRIEF HISTORY OF LAW TO BALANCE THE BUDGET
description: The Supreme Court's decision today that invalidated a mechanism for automatic Federal spending cuts marked the end of that novel provision of the budget-balancing law.

title: 49ers' Wright Out
description: The San Francisco 49ers learned yesterday that one of their starting cornerbacks, Eric Wright, will be out from two to four months because of a slow-healing groin injury. Wright, who was injured last season, likely would not be back until midway into the 1986 season, a spokesman said.

title: A Guiding Spirit Keeps His Eye on Op Sail
description: One of the people most intimately involved in Liberty Weekend had to watch the festivities from a distant sideline.

title: Topics: Fudge Factors; Fare Share
description: One of President Reagan's favorite arguments for cutting back on Federal programs concerns regional cross-subsidies. Californians, for example, shouldn't have to pay taxes to build subways in New York City.

title: West German Banker Jailed
description: A Frankfurt court today convicted Ferdinand von Galen, former head of the prestigious West German bank Schroder-Munchmeyer-Hengst, of breach of trust.

title: GOLD LURES GEOLOGISTS TO CONNECTICUT
description: When 12 geologists and students from the University of Connecticut set out to survey an abandoned cobalt mine in a state forest last summer, they did not expect to strike one of the richest concentrations of gold in North America.

title: Navajos Tear Down a Fence At Border With Hopis' Land
description: About 200 Navajos tore down a barbed-wire fence yesterday separating their land from an area that Congress has designated for the exclusive use of the rival Hopi tribe.

title: Of Smoking and Women
description: College women are more likely than college men to smoke cigarettes, according to a Federal study released today. The study showed the women's daily smoking rate was 18 percent last year, as against 10 percent for men.

title: DEFICIT-PARING SETBACK IS EXPECTED TO BE SLIGHT
description: The Supreme Court's rejection of a central feature of the balanced-budget law could slow efforts to reduce Federal budget deficits, members of Congress and the financial world said today.

title: STUDY CITES THE HIGH COST OF FARM PROTECTIONISM
description: If the United States, Western Europe and Japan stopped protecting agriculture, their taxpayers and consumers would save $100 billion a year and developing countries could earn up to $18.3 billion more to help pay their debts, a study by the World Bank indicated today.

title: Sallie Mae Offer
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Jan. 8, 1987, through various securities dealers.

title: Rockwell Joins Two Divisions
description: The Rockwell International Corporation today announced that it would consolidate its commercial electronics and military electronics divisions into a single unit to be called the electronics operation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIGHT AND LIVELY There are those who say New York is becoming an early-to-bed town compared with what it was a few decades ago. There is much evidence to the contrary, but for those who don't mind getting their night life in before sunset, there is the early show at Panache, the restaurant at 149 East 57th Street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 8, 1986
description: Markets

title: Manhattan Garage, Lacking Braces, Falls
description: A garage behind a house in lower Manhattan collapsed yesterday morning, and investigators said construction workers excavating a site next door had caused the collapse by failing to use support braces required under the city building code.

title: Spalding Gray at Newhouse
description: The monologuist Spalding Gray will begin a four-week engagement tonight at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Mr. Gray will present two monologues - ''Terrors of Pleasure'' and ''Swimming to Cambodia'' - on alternating days.

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHYSICS MAY BE UP AGAINST THE WALL THIS TIME
description: THERE is a nagging suspicion abroad that the science of physics may be on its death bed.

title: 2 FRENCH AGENTS IN SHIP'S BOMBING WILL BE RELEASED
description: New Zealand will release the two French secret agents imprisoned for their role in the sinking of an environmentalists' ship last July provided they spend the next three years on a remote French Pacific island, the French Government announced today.

title: Gannett Will Sell Knoxville Journal
description: The Gannett Company agreed yesterday to sell The Knoxville Journal to Ronald D. McMahan, the newspaper's editor, and to William C. McKinney, publisher of the Gannett paper in Lansdale, Pa.

title: GENITAL HERPES IS MORE COMMON BUT THE ALARM IS DIMINISHING
description: USING new detection methods, scientists have discovered that one-fourth or more of the adult population in the United States has genital herpes. New research has also shown that the virus is spreading more insidiously than previously thought, often from people with no evident symptoms.

title: Talking Business With McKinneY of Manville; More Tests For Company
description: In 1982, John A. McKinney, chairman and chief executive of the Manville Corporation, decided to file for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws to deal with mounting claims filed by victims of asbestos-related disease.

title: STUDENT COCAINE USE REMAINS UP AS USE OF OTHER DRUGS DROPS
description: Cocaine use has remained high among high school and college students while the illicit use of marijuana, the most prevalent drug used, dropped from 1980 to 1984 and leveled off in 1985, according to a survey made public today.

title: Mack Trucks Sale
description: Henley Group Inc. took another step in restructuring its assets by selling its 10 percent interest in Mack Trucks Inc. to Sterling, Grace & Company and other institutional investors for $37 million. Henley contains about 35 businesses spun off from Allied-Signal Inc. in November, ranging from real estate to health-care and energy service companies. A spokesman said Henley sold the interest because it had a small investment and was offered a favorable price.

title: THE SUMMER BREAK
description: THIS is vacation season, so let's store the spreadsheets, dump the data bases and take a break with some innovative computer games.

title: The Patent Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FANTOMAS. By Marcel Allain and Pierre Souvestre. 324 pages. William Morrow. $17.95. MARCEL ALLAIN and

title: HUGE CLEANUP IS ADDED TO LIST OF SUPERLATIVES
description: In New York City's biggest cleanup operation since the World War II victory celebrations, a giant force of Sanitation and Parks Department workers swept through the city yesterday.

title: U.S. Program Proposed For Controlling Radon
description: The General Accounting Office today proposed reorganizing and expanding Federal efforts to curb radon, a naturally occurring radioactive gas that may be infiltrating the homes and increasing the cancer risk of millions of Americans.

title: Bridge: Long Trip May Coincide With Success in Tourney
description: There is probably a correlation between success in a tournament and distance traveled to reach it. Those who must make an effort to compete are rather more likely to be serious contestants than those who live on the doorstep.

title: SCIENTISTS HOPE TO FORECAST LIGHTNING STRIKES
description: WIRES trailed by rockets to trigger lightning flashes, cables between mountains to create ''upside-down'' thunderheads, computer-linked networks of observatories and other devices are helping scientists learn what energizes lightning and controls where it hits and how much damage it does.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Fairchild, Hitachi
description: The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., said that Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo had agreed to become the first alternate-source supplier of a new line of Fairchild digital logic circuits. Fairchild, based in Cupertino, Calif., said Hitachi's semiconductor and integrated circuit division would make Fairchild advanced complementary metal oxide semiconductor devices, a type of circuit used where low-power consumption is required. Kirk Pond, executive vice president of Fairchild's digital unit, said that the alliance with Hitachi is expected to give Fairchild an edge in Japan, the largest market for CMOS devices.

title: BRITONS ARE CATCHING FOOTBALL FEVER, AN AMERICAN IMPORT
description: The cheerleaders waved their pompons and screamed ''DEE-fense.'' Smoke from the charcoal grill where the cheeseburgers sizzled wafted over the gridiron. And the marching band played the Marine Corps Hymn. It was all as American as the Fourth of July, only it was July 6 and it was England as the hometown team - the B-52's -struggled to keep its hopes alive for a playoff berth in the Budweiser League.

title: The Fiscal Fig Leaf, Removed
description: The Supreme Court's ruling on the balanced-budget law peels away the pretense that immense budget deficits can be reduced by invoking the solemn Gramm-Rudman-Hollings formula. The budget law is a gimmick, a substitute for tough decisions. The immediate temptation will be to tinker with it to make it legal. The responsible course now, even more than before, is to forget the fig leaf and reduce the Federal deficit.

title: Trial Is Set for F.B.I. Agent
description: A Federal district judge today set a Dec. 2 trial date for an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation indicted on five counts of making false statements to the Justice Department concerning Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union. Robert S. Friedrick, leader of the F.B.I.'s organized-crime squad in Cleveland since 1981, has pleaded not guilty.

title: MACHINES TO SELL L.I.R.R. TICKETS BY CREDIT CARD
description: Kevin Fehn slipped his Visa card through a machine at Pennsylvania Station yesterday. Thirty seconds later, the machine's computer punched out a monthly commutation ticket for Mineola.

title: Prices on Bonds Close Mixed
description: Prices for Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday as jitters in the stock market spilled over into the credit markets and dampened what had been a promising bond rally in the early morning.

title: FED CLEARS MUTUAL FUND SALES BY BANKS' PARENTS
description: The Federal Reserve Board for the first time has sanctioned the sale of mutual funds by bank holding companies, but set a variety of conditions.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Janet Anderson, the 1982 United States Women's Open golf champion, withdrew from this year's tournament because of a lower back problem. She will be replaced by Diane Dickman, a 22-year-old amateur from Modesto, Calif., the United States Golf Association announced. . . . John McEnroe, who has been on a leave of absence from tennis, said yesterday he would return to Canada for the 10th consecutive year and seek his third straight Player's International Championship. The Toronto event begins Aug. 9. . . . Richard Sander, the Memphis State assistant athletic director, has been named athletic director at Virginia Commonwealth. . . . William Alston, a University of Rhode Island basketball star from Paterson, N.J., was released on $50,000 personal recognizance yesterday after his arraignment in South Kingston, R.I., on a felony charge of first-degree sexual assault involving a female student.

title: Stop Mexico's Inflation and Eliminate the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: NO FAREWELL ON THE CHIEF'S LAST DAY
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's announcement today of his majority opinion striking down a key provision of the budget-balancing act was apparently the last time he will hand down a decision of the Supreme Court.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Swatch Gets New Head For Its U.S. Operations
description: Swatch A. G., the Swiss company that makes the Swatch watch, has named Felice A. Schillaci president of its United States operations.

title: And Thanks to the Holiday Shepherds
description: The berserk man who killed and stabbed at random aboard a ferry in New York Harbor yesterday broke the spell. But he must not be allowed to erase the memory. For four extraordinary days, New York enjoyed a serene kind of tumult, thanks not only to the good behavior of the holiday crowds but also to the impressive labor of the thousands of public servants who drew the weekend duty.

title: Djerejian's Next Stop
description: Edward P. Djerejian, who leaves his post next month as White House deputy press secretary for foreign affairs, is expected to become the chief Soviet affairs specialist on the National Security Council.

title: Earthquake in Tibet
description: A strong earthquake rocked Rutog County in western Tibet today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The quake, measuring 6.3 on the Richter scale, was recorded here by the State Seismological Bureau.

title: 2 CITY LANDLORDS CONVICTED OF FORCING TENANTS TO LEAVE
description: Two landlords have been convicted of conspiring to force tenants out of their Manhattan apartments. The jury verdict, reached Saturday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, ended one of the most extensive and lengthiest housing investigations undertaken in New York.

title: OAKRIDGE ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company said the increased loss in fiscal 1986 is partially attributable to oil and gas depreciation, depletion and amortization expense of about $417,000. The company said that it bore, for financial statement purposes, 100 percent, rather than 66 2/3 percent, of the losses of its 66-2/3 percent owned Pueblo Coal Inc. subsidiary.

title: NUREYEV DISCUSSES HIS ART, PAST AND PRESENT
description: The directness with which Rudolf Nureyev addresses any issue does not contradict the complexity behind the man and artist. He knows his worth and he justifies every statement. There is no modesty, false or otherwise.

title: Los Angeles Gunman Says He'll Plead Guilty
description: The man arrested after a daylong siege at a Beverly Hills jewelry store, in which three hostages died, wants to plead guilty against his attorney's advice and be executed, it was reported today.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A's Beat Clemens in LaRussa's Debut
description: Jose Canseco and Dave Kingman shelled Boston's Roger Clemens with consecutive home runs in the sixth inning tonight as the Oakland A's marked Manager Tony LaRussa's debut with a 6-4 victory over the Red Sox.

title: Topics: Fudge Factors; Fate and Fat
description: Some people claim they gain weight just by looking at a piece of fudge. One's heart goes out to them.

title: HUNGARIANS CLIP COUPONS AND CALL IT COMMUNISM
description: Zsigmond Jarai trades bonds in Hungary, which, in theory anyway, is something like being a wine merchant in Saudi Arabia.

title: Waldheim Document Issued by Jewish Group
description: Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, made public at a news conference today a document indicating that Kurt Waldheim's wartime intelligence unit ordered the deportation of Greek Jews.

title: Ogden Exploring Sale of Food Unit
description: The Ogden Corporation, a diversified service concern, said that it was exploring the sale of its food products unit, which markets Progresso Italian foods, Hain health foods, Las Palmas Mexican food and Hollywood natural foods.

title: GORBACHEV URGES EUROPE TO PURSUE OWN INTERESTS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told President Francois Mitterrand today that Western Europe should not let itself be treated as a ''theater of operations'' and should set an example of peaceful coexistence.

title: Literature and Television
description: Critics of the American obsession with television maintain, among other things, that the 30 hours and 38 minutes the average American spends in front of the TV set every week is creating a society of viewers rather than readers - or, as some put it, not literates but vidiots.

title: SALT II Has No Effect on Soviet Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: MET PICHERS FALTER IN LOSS
description: It was 93 degrees in Shea Stadium last evening, the ball was carrying and the pitchers were serving up some fat ones. And, in the batting bee that followed, the Mets had one of their better hitting nights of the season but one of their worst pitching nights, and they were finally outhit and outscored by the Cincinnati Reds, 7-6.

title: IN CAREER AS OFFICER, HERO HAD NEVER USED HIS GUN
description: During the 24 years that he was a police officer, Edward del Pino, a brawny fireplug of a man, never fired his gun in the line of duty.

title: Court Action On Asbestos
description: The Supreme Court refused today to limit the amounts of money won against asbestos makers by people who said their health had been injured by exposure to the substance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 8, 1986
description: International

title: Cadbury Purchase
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said that its proposed $230 million purchase of RJR Nabisco Inc.'s beverage business had been cleared by American antitrust authorities.

title: MCENROE ABSENCE CONFOUNDS RESULT
description: His name surfaced again Sunday, after Boris Becker, who is only 18 years of age and getting better all the time, won his second Wimbledon men's singles championship, reaffirming his standing as the top grass-court player in the world. Who can stop Becker from making this an annual occurrence? The answer was John McEnroe. McEnroe has won three singles titles at Wimbledon and was the doubles champion four times. He is also the ''X factor'' on the men's tour, a player who is acknowledged as the most talented in the game. His motivation is in question, however, pending his performance when he returns in August after a six-month sabbatical.

title: SOME ART OF UNION'S MISSING
description: Of 34 works by leading contemporary American artists given to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in the late 1950's, 21 are missing. Some of the remaining 13 have been restored, but others still hang -unrecorded and without curatorial attention - in the union's offices.

title: ONE WORKER KILLED AND 3 HURT IN EAST SIDE SCAFFOLD COLLAPSE
description: A workman was killed and three others were injured yesterday morning when part of a scaffold fell to the ground from the 13th floor of a construction site at 95th Street and Third Avenue.

title: A Jet Doctor Resigns
description: Dr. Calvin Nicholas, whose career with the New York Jets spanned 24 seasons and included a Super Bowl championship, announced his resignation yesterday as the club's chief internist. With the resignation, Dr. Nicholas ended an association that began in 1962 when the team was called the Titans.

title: NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION PARTIES ISSUE CALL FOR NEW ELECTIONS
description: Leading opposition parties called on the Sandinista Government today to hold new national elections and asserted they would win with 80 percent of the vote if such elections were held.

title: Secure-Phone Contracts Let
description: The National Security Agency has awarded initial production contracts to three companies for a new generation of scrambler telephones.

title: SOLDIERS BID A FAREWELL TO SMOKING
description: The ashtrays have been consigned to a closet at the headquarters building here, and Sgt. Maj. Donald G. Merritt's office door is emblazoned with a brilliant yellow ''No Smoking'' sign.

title: Air Bags Supplement Auto Seat Belts
description: To the Editor:

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Working Profile: John Barianos; A Repairer of Historic Catastrophes
description: It is a rare historic edifice in the nation's capital that has undergone restoration in recent years and not benefited from the fine hand and ministrations of John Barianos.

title: Site of Friedman Trial Changed to New Haven
description: The Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman has been moved a second time, this time from Hartford to New Haven, and is to begin on Sept. 8, court officials said yesterday.

title: BROAD CHANGE IS CENTRAL ISSUE
description: In American education circles this year there has been much talk of reform, the more sweeping the better. The notion of broad changes in classrooms around the country has become the dominant topic of discussion among educators, particularly since the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy recommended in mid-May that the nation's education system be ''rebuilt.''

title: Congress; Already, the Tax Conference Has Turned Sticky
description: Before House and Senate tax-writers sit down next week to work out their differences on a sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax laws, some sticky issues must be settled - such as who gets the distinction of being chairman of the proceedings and where to hold the conference.

title: Is Reagan Ready?
description: Even President Reagan, whose Administration has compiled the most anti-arms control record of any in the nuclear era, now seems to concede the possibility of reaching an agreement with the Soviet Union. But don't bet the rent money that it's going to happen.

title: SEARCH NARROWS AT NBC
description: General Electric Company's search for a replacement for Grant Tinker as chairman of NBC is narrowing, with three of the leading candidates from within the network eliminated from consideration, according to network officials.

title: SATURN'S RINGS MAY NOT LAST
description: THE rings of Saturn, Jupiter and Uranus may be more ephemeral than astronomers have suspected. Scientists interpreting data from the Voyager 2 spacecraft's flight past Uranus now suggest that the rings cannot have existed in their present form for much more than 100 million years.

title: Pool Time for Adults
description: On the seventh hour of the seventh day of the seventh month, seven Parks and Recreation Department officials led 77 swimmers on a seven-lap course at the 77th Street public pool.

title: Rochester Golfer Leads State Open
description: John Calabria, a former PGA Tour player who is now head professional at the Brook Lee Country Club in Rochester, shot a four-under-par 67 today to lead the first round of the ninth annual Michelob New York State Open.

title: MICROFRAME INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said that since it only completed its initial public offering in January 1985 it doesn't consider comparison with fiscal 1985 to be meaningful.

title: PROPER MEDICAL CARE REPORTEDLY DENIED MAN BURNED IN CHILE
description: A Chilean novelist, Ariel Dorfman, said today that a Washington-based photographer who died of burns in Santiago on Sunday had not been given proper medical care.

title: IBM Credit Notes To Yield 7.162%
description: The IBM Credit Corporation is offering $300 million of 7 1/8 percent notes due 1989 at a price of 99.90, to yield 7.162 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: HEIRESS SAYS EX-HOSPITALS AIDE INSISTED SHE SIGN BLANK PAPER
description: Ann L. Maytag, the washing machine company heiress, testified yesterday that John J. McLaughlin insisted in 1981 that she sign blank pieces of paper relating to her trust that, according to prosecutors, he later filled in to enrich himself.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * The Bank of New York elected Thomas A. Price senior vice president.

title: 24 BLACKS ARE REPORTED SLAIN
description: The South African authorities today formally lifted longstanding restrictions on Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed nationalist leader Nelson Mandela.

title: AMNESTY IS PROMISED TO SOLDIERS
description: Hundreds of rebel soldiers and civilian supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos left the Manila Hotel early today, ending a two-day occupation. The troops were promised amnesty. Arturo M. Tolentino, who declared himself acting president on Sunday on behalf of Mr. Marcos and led the takeover, left the hotel Monday, saying that an agreement had been reached to end the occupation and that people would begin leaving at dawn today.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART SEASON OPENS
description: WHAT do we expect of our friends in brain-frying weather such as this?

title: PLAYERS FACE RISK OF SUSPENSION
description: The National Football League commissioner announced a new anti-drug program yesterday that calls for increased mandatory testing for all players as well as possible lifetime suspensions for those who repeatedly use illegal drugs.

title: Auditor's Settlement On E.S.M.
description: A Federal District Court judge today cleared the way for a $50 million settlement paid by the auditor of the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. to 17 municipalities that lost money when the securities firm collapsed.

title: CONCERN OVER SCHOOLING OF MILITARY RECRUITS
description: ONE of the nation's top naval officers has warned that large numbers of young people are unfit for military service because of educational and physical deficiencies.

title: Rohm & Haas
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, a plastic and chemical products manufacturer, is offering $50 million of 8 1/8 percent 10-year notes through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Noncallable for seven years, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and are offered at a price of 99.628, to yield 8.18 percent, or about 9/10 of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: Acknowledging that ''it now seems difficult to separate big bucks from political victory,'' the Washington newsletter Campaigns and Elections is holding a seminar on how to raise bundles of money.

title: WILLOWY PRINCESS DRESS RETURNS TO CENTER STAGE
description: Marc Jacobs does it in taffeta and it has turned into one of the best sellers in his fall collection. Oscar de la Renta prefers it in velvet lace, embellished with jewels. Other designers show it in wool crepe or jersey, both for day and for night.

title: Muffled Blasts
description: Bob Horner actually tied two major league records with his four home runs Sunday. When the Braves wound up beaten by Montreal, Horner became the second player in history -and the first since Ed Delahanty, whose Phillies fell to the Cubs by 9-8 on July 13, 1896 - to hit four homers in a losing cause.

title: West German Paper Predicts Sakharov-Mandela Exchange
description: The West German newspaper Bild said today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished Soviet physicist, and Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned South African black leader, would be freed as part of an East-West prisoner exchange.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES TO LOWS IN TOKYO
description: The dollar plummeted to post-war lows against the yen in Tokyo yesterday after Japan's ruling party won a resounding victory in national elections.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.S. Issues Final Rules For Arsenic Emissions
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced final air pollution standards today for arsenic emissions by copper smelters, glass factories and some arsenic plants.

title: A WARNING IS ISSUED BY NADINE GORDIMER OVER LITERARY CURBS
description: Nadine Gordimer, the South African novelist, warned of a ''second crisis of censorship'' in her country in a statement made public yesterday in New York by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: BRITISH DIPLOMAT POSTPONES VISIT TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, acknowledged today that he was postponing a visit he had hoped to make to South Africa this week because he had been told that President P. W. Botha would be unavailable to meet him.

title: Advertising; Trinova: The Birth Of a Name
description: ANSPACH GROSSMAN PORTUGAL, the graphics design firm, has done a rare and wonderful thing. It has gone against an apparent trend and created a corporate name with meaning.

title: TOUR SETS O'GRADY BAN
description: One day after he gained his first victory on the PGA Tour, Mac O'Grady was notified yesterday that he must begin serving a six-event suspension from the tour next Monday. He was also directed to pay a $5,000 fine that was part of the penalty imposed by PGA Tour Commissioner Deane Beman two months ago ''for actions unbecoming a professional golfer.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM HIGH COURT'S DECISION ON DEFICIT-CUTTING ACT
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinion today striking down the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act calling for a balanced Federal budget.

title: City Finds Aide Broke Law in Demoting Man
description: An official who forced the demotion of a subordinate who had complained about possible corruption in the construction of the city's new water tunnel violated a city law protecting ''whistle blowers'' from retaliation, the Department of Investigation said yesterday.

title: AS BACKERS VOW TO FIX LAW, OTHERS SAY JOB IS CONGRESS'S
description: Senate Republican leaders, responding to the Supreme Court decision striking down a key part of the budget-balancing law, said today that they would move to amend the law so that its automatic spending cuts would be constitutional.

title: Senator Leahy Opens Race
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy today formally opened his bid for re-election, promising supporters he would run a positive campaign stressing the importance of preserving Vermont's rural character. Mr. Leahy, a Democrat, was first elected to the Senate in 1974.

title: Chess: Karpov, Seeking Challenges, Keeps Winning Decisively
description: Anatoly Karpov has not been world champion since the last game of his unsuccessful title defense against Gary Kasparov in Moscow last Nov. 9, yet the 35-year-old Russian still wins tournaments as though he were king of the hill.

title: Four Accounts Switch To Doner of Baltimore
description: The gang at W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore, had good reason to celebrate over the weekend - during the four days before they had packed in four new accounts with aggregate billings of around $10 million.

title: The U.N. Today: July 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Court Was 'Superficial' In the Homosexuality Case
description: Last week, the Supreme Court decided one of the major open issues in American constitutional law, concluding that the Government has the power to criminalize private consensual homosexual acts.

title: Careers; New Action at Banks
description: AS is well known, the record flow of underwritings, new financial products and corporate mergers has whetted the appetite of top graduates with Master of Business Administration degrees for jobs at investment banking firms. With such jobs they anticipate high salaries, exciting action and quick promotions.

title: Spaniard Wins 4th Tour Stage
description: Pello Ruiz-Cabestany of Spain finished just ahead of a charging pack today to win the 152-mile fourth stage of the Tour de France.

title: MATH ADVANCE PENETRATES SECRETS OF KNOTS
description: A SERIES of surprising discoveries is helping the practitioners of one of the purest forms of mathematics, the theory of knots, to attack a fundamental problem of their discipline: how to distinguish one knot from another.

title: COURT UPHOLDS RIGHT TO CLOSE BOOKSTORE USING NUISANCE LAW
description: A Supreme Court decision today that could have nationwide application is expected to decide the fate of Village Books and News, a bookstore in a residential suburb of Buffalo that sells sexually explicit material.

title: COURT BACKS SCHOOL ON STUDENT'S 'VULGAR' SPEECH
description: Taking a broad view of school officials' disciplinary authority, the Supreme Court today upheld by 7 to 2 a school's two-day suspension of a 17-year-old student who made what it called a ''lewd and indecent'' speech to a high school assembly.

title: MARKET RECORDS BIGGEST LOSS EVER
description: Just days after climbing to record levels, stock prices plunged yesterday amid newfound concern about the nation's economy and warnings from a brokerage firm and a market newsletter that prices had risen too high.

title: THE DAILY NEW'S LATEST BIND
description: James Hoge, the publisher of The Daily News, describes his newspaper's predicament in stark tabloid style. ''Survival is at stake,'' he declared in a letter to employees last month, ''and there is no time to lose.''

title: BOGOSIAN PRESENTS A SAMPLER
description: FROM Ruth Draper to Whoopi Goldberg, from Joyce Grenfell to Spalding Gray, the solo stage act has proved an enduring vehicle. Miss Draper's matron taking Italian lessons might wince a bit at the inelegant language of some of Ms. Goldberg's street people, but each actor would find the other's theatrical territory and style familiar, except for the name. The old ''one-man show'' has given way to the ''performance artist.''

title: TEACHERS ACT TO INCREASE DECISION-MAKING POWER
description: Within the next year, about 100 school districts will begin to carry out recommendations of the Carnegie Report calling for reorganizing public schools to give teachers more power, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, Albert Shanker, said today.

title: Westpac of Australia Set to Acquire Wepco
description: The Westpac Banking Corporation of Sydney, Australia, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire William E. Pollock Government Securities Inc., one of 35 primary dealers in United States Government securities.

title: BRITONS STIRRED BY NEW 'PORGY' AT GLYNDEBOURNE
description: The denizens of George Gershwin's Catfish Row took possession Saturday night of the English stately home renowned for its productions of classic operas, and what might have been seen as a gesture of musical condescension became instead the triumph of the operatic season.

title: NAKASONE CALLS PARTY'S VICTORY THE 'VOICE OF HEAVEN'
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, welcoming his ruling party's spectacular election victory on Sunday as the ''voice of heaven,'' pledged today to use the success to pursue anew his diplomatic and economic policies.

title: Norwest Bank Official Will Become Its Chief
description: James R. Campbell, president of Norwest Bank Minneapolis, the lead bank of the Norwest Corporation, a holding company, will assume the additional title of chief executive.

title: GERMAN SHIPBUILDER IS SEEKING COURT PROTECTION
description: Harmstorf A.G., one of West Germany's leading shipbuilding groups, said today that it was placing its three northern West German yards in receivership.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CINCINNATI REDS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: 98 degrees Record for Date; Power Use at Peak
description: The temperature reached 98 degrees in Central Park at 2:53 P.M. yesterday, breaking the record for the date of 97 degrees, set in 1934.

title: NCNB Move Into Virginia
description: The NCNB Corporation, the largest bank holding company in the Southeast, announced plans to expand northward yesterday, saying that it had agreed to acquire First America Savings and Loan Association of Virginia in a stock swap valued at $92.5 million.

title: Talks Are Resumed In Philadelphia Strike
description: Negotiations resumed today for the first time in a seven-day strike by 14,000 municipal workers, leading Mayor W. Wilson Goode to cancel announcement of an emergency plan to take in tons of uncollected trash.

title: Hotel With a History, MacArthur to Marcos
description: The Manila Hotel, opened in 1912 and extensively remodeled in the 1970's, is a Philippine landmark, home to high society and to political intrigue, and often a scene of historic events.

title: ABC'S FOURTH OF JULY COVERAGE A HIT
description: ABC's Liberty Weekend extravaganza, assailed by some critics as an exercise in excess, was nonetheless a hit with viewers. The four-day, 17-hour television marathon, parts of which were criticized by rival networks as a commercialization of the news, scored impressive audience ratings, according to preliminary data.

title: 'MEXICAN TAPES,' ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: AS part of its monthlong tribute to immigrants - a birthday present to Lady Liberty -Channel 13 will broadcast ''El Gringo'' at 10 o'clock tonight. It is the start of a four-part series called ''The Mexican Tapes: A Chronicle of Life Outside the Law.'' The first episode, about illegal Mexican immigrants living in a southern California neighborhood they call La Colonia, shows good intentions but, unfortunately, has little else to recommend it.

title: HANGINGS PROMPT BITTER REACTIONS
description: Early this morning, a prison truck took away the bodies of two young Australians who local newspapers are calling ''the first non-Asian drug pushers'' to be executed under this country's harsh narcotics laws. They had been hanged side by side at dawn, a prison official said.

title: ANGRY WINFIELD KNOCKS IN 4 RUNS
description: Together, they were a study in contrasting emotions. Scott Nielsen played the part of a nervous rookie on the verge of his big-league debut; Dave Winfield was an angry, unsettled veteran. But late tonight, separated by a few empty locker stalls in the visiting clubhouse at Arlington Stadium, they found a large measure of satisfaction.

title: FERMENTA FOUNDER SET TO SELL TO MONTEDISON
description: The embattled founder of Sweden's Fermenta A. B., Refaat el-Sayed, announced today that he planned to sell his company to Montedison, the giant Italian chemical producer, in a deal worth an estimated $290 million.

title: Rave Hair Care Line To Waring & LaRosa
description: Waring & LaRosa, already an agency of Chesebrough-Pond's, has been given an additional assignment, the Rave hair care line, which will probably bill $4 million.

title: OFFERS DUE FOR PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: The sale of People Express gained momentum as Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banker for the low-cost carrier, asked interested companies to make bids by today, sources close to the negotiations said.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. CLEARS CONSUMER SAFETY OFFICIAL
description: A Justice Department investigation has cleared Terrence M. Scanlon, a member of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, of charges that he had misused his office. As a result, the Senate has scheduled a vote on his confirmation as chairman of the commission for next Tuesday.

title: SEPARATION OF POWERS IN HISTORY
description: When the Constitution was framed, the doctrine of separation of powers was accepted without question. Yet it was not written into the Constitution.

title: FAUCET IDEA BUILDS AN EMPIRE
description: The company has a full lineup of models, from low-priced, functional ones to those whose appearance and performance have been carefully styled to project luxury. It even has some imported models, to satisfy customers with a taste for things European.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: * Bernard Flanagan, vice president/ marketing of The Wall Street Journal, has been elected 1986-87 national chairman of the American Advertising Federation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Cairo on Friday about the dissolution of Parliament in Kuwait misstated the Emir of Kuwait's position on the Iran-Iraq war. The Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, has supported Iraq.

title: 'BUTTON' DEVELOPED TO AID DIALYSIS PATIENTS
description: Doctors at the New England Medical Center are to implant a ''skin button'' in a dialysis patient Wednesday to provide a painless, infection-free way to install tubing or electrical wires that could improve treatment for millions of patients with conditions ranging from diabetes to cancer to chronic pain.

title: Louisiana Land Option Signed
description: The Dallas investor Harold Simmons disclosed that he had an option to buy 800,000 shares, or 2.9 percent of the outstanding stock, of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company. An agreement on the option was signed June 26 between the Amalgamated Sugar Company, a concern controlled by Mr. Simmons, and Jefferies & Company, a Los Angeles securities dealer, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Helicopter Grounded By Police 'Air Force'
description: The bogy hovering 800 feet above the Great Lawn in Central Park Saturday night during the Liberty Weekend concert of classical music was a helicopter towing a Burger King advertising banner, to the annoyance of many in the audience.

title: An Open Letter to Botha
