description: Mr. State President, You have now succeeded in establishing a deadly silence surrounding yourself and your Government. Now no one can report on what you are planning or doing, no one can expose your lies and evils, no one can speak up for those oppressed, hounded, turned out of their burning homes, tortured or killed by the latest incarnations of the Gestapo. Not even the number of those who are disappearing around us daily may be divulged.

title: JOYNER SETS MARK TO WIN HEPTATHLON
description: In English as well as in Russian, the track announcer was exclaiming ''super'' and ''outstanding'' and ''fabulous'' as Jackie Joyner of Long Beach, Calif., set a world record in the heptathlon tonight at the Goodwill Games.

title: WQXR CELEBRATES WITH ITS HISTORY
description: Boxes of tapes, cassettes, the extra-large acetate disks once used by broadcasters and other assorted paraphernalia clutter Robert Sherman's office at WQXR these days. The reason: He is in charge of activities celebrating the radio station's 50th anniversary, and much of that has to do with culling its archives for historical moments worth rebroadcasting.

title: Green Seeks 6th House Term
description: Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he would seek a sixth term in Congress from the 15th District saying the city needed him to represent it on the House Appropriations Committee. Mr. Green, who is 55 years old, noted that the death of Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, had left the city with only one lawmaker on the committee.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
C. K. Streit, Advocate Of Democracies Union
description: Clarence K. Streit, a journalist who advocated a federal union of democracies, died of kidney failure Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 90 years old.

title: American Is Acquitted Of Espionage in Britain
description: A former United States Navy commander and member of the Central Intelligence Agency who was arrested on an espionage charge was acquitted today after the prosecution said he had duped the Russians with useless information.

title: MAN WITH SWORD KILLS 2 AND WOUNDS 9 ON S.I. FERRY
description: A homeless Cuban refugee, chanting and apparently deranged, went on a rampage with a sword aboard a Staten Island ferryboat yesterday and killed two people and wounded nine others before being subdued by a retired police officer at gunpoint.

title: CITY'S POETRY CAPTURED IN DUSTY VIEWS
description: A picture is a piece of time, a small part of the cloudy past discovered in the clear air of the present. When there are a great number of photographs and the tiny pieces of time are put together, it is possible to see the image of an era - or, in this case, a city.

title: ONE DEAD AND 4 INJURED IN CRASH
description: A pedestrian was killed and four motorists were injured yesterday when a truck struck five vehicles on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: FROM BASEBALL CARDS TO 'MUTANT NINJA TURTLES'
description: Sunday afternoon, when everyone else was babbling about the record heat and the crowds at the beach, James Devlin climbed on his 10-speed and biked several miles to the Coliseum Motor Inn for the baseball card and comic book show. It is held in the motel's basement the first Sunday of every month, and James never misses it.

title: FROM FRANCE, THE CREAM OF FALL FASHION
description: In a rare cooperative effort, two disparate segments of the French fashion industry banded together last night for a showing of the best current Paris designs to mark the opening of ''France Salutes New York,'' a 10-day arts festival.

title: AMBACH ANNOUNCES PLAN TO RESIGN AS STATE'S EDUCATION CHIEF
description: Gordon M. Ambach, the New York State Commissioner of Education since 1977, announced yesterday that he would step down from one of the country's most powerful and visible education posts at the end of the coming academic year.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SCHRAMM REBUTS CHARGES BY U.S.F.L.
description: Tex Schramm, the general manager and part owner of the Dallas Cowboys, testified yesterday in the United States Football League's antitrust trial against the National Football League that the N.F.L. enacted no policies specifically designed to harm or destroy the U.S.F.L.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
Who Should Make Medication Decisions?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1985 share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1986.

title: PRINTERS TO VOTE ON UNION MERGER
description: Leaders of the country's oldest union, the International Typographical Union, announced today that they had reached a tentative agreement to merge with the Communications Workers of America.

title: FAILURES REPORTED IN AIDS BLOOD TESTS
description: Screening tests for AIDS have made the nation's blood supply much safer but more than a year of experience with the tests has shown several critical problems, medical experts told a scientific conference today.

title: No Illnesses Are Linked To Tainted Ice Cream
description: Although more than 170 people have complained of illness after eating tainted ice cream bars, nobody has tested positive for listeriosis, a potentially fatal disease, officials said today.

title: You Don't Have to Pay Anyone to Get a Cab
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAYS IT WARNED MARCOS ABOUT INSTIGATING TROUBLE IN MANILA
description: The Reagan Administration said today that former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines had been warned that his efforts to undermine the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino were ''inconsistent with his status as a guest in the United States.''

title: COURT BACKS NEW YORK ON TWO POLITICAL ISSUES
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday let stand separate lower court rulings that upheld New York in two political cases - legislative reapportionment and the New York City primary runoff.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS MAJOR STEP IN LAW THAT CUTS DEFICIT
description: The Supreme Court today struck down the central provision of the most sweeping measure Congress has devised to curb soaring Federal deficits.

title: The Art of Bowerbirds
description: To attract the attention of females, male bowerbirds of New Guinea and Australia build elaborate bowers -towers, huts or piled pathways made of sticks that they decorate with objects such as fruits, flowers, butterfly wings, shells and stones.

title: GEOMETRY ON A DISK: A FAR CRY FROM SCHOOL
description: One of my favorite high-school subjects was geometry.

title: HIPOTRONICS, INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
I.B.M. WINS PATENT SETTLEMENT
description: Settling a major Silicon Valley patent infringement suit, five former employees of the International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday to stop marketing a disk drive system based on key I.B.M. technology.

title: A Selective Approach At Kurnit's New Shop
description: Shep Kurnit is now running the recently formed Kurnit Communications, which seeks to do advertising for the public good.

title: The Tax Bill Score, Please?
description: When the House adopted tax revision legislation on a voice vote last year, some listeners found it hard to distinguish between the volume of the yeas compared to the nays. Politics being what it is, a few cynics suggested the lawmakers avoided a roll-call inasmuch as a vote either way could be fraught with political peril.

title: Europeans Approve Pact
description: The European Community formally approved a tentative accord today aimed at averting a farm trade war with the United States.

title: DECISION ON DEFICIT-CUTTING BILL: A CLOUD OVER THE COMPTROLLER'S FUNCTIONS
description: In striking down a key provision of the new budget-balancing law, the Supreme Court today implicitly cast a cloud over some of the most basic powers exercised by the Comptroller General of the United States, who monitors the propriety of Government spending.

title: Chile, Before the Deluge
description: President Pinochet of Chile, who once likened himself to Caesar, now seems determined to follow the path of Louis XV of France: let the revolutionary deluge come, provided it comes after his rule.

title: Airline Proposal
description: The Justice Department's Antitrust Division said it still opposes the proposed merger of NWA Inc.'s Northwest Airlines Inc. and Republic Airlines Inc. It said a Transportation Department administrative law judge was wrong in ruling on June 27 that the deal would not substantially reduce competition in any market.

title: New Aircraft For President
description: The Air Force awarded a $249.8 million contract to the Boeing Company today for two 747 airliners to be used to fly the President. They will replace the two Boeing 707's now used by the White House.

title: Giants Option Clark
description: Will Clark, the rookie first baseman who started off strong for the San Francisco Giants this season, yesterday was sent to Phoenix of the Triple-A level Pacific Coast League to work on his hitting while his injured elbow heals. Clark, 22 years old, was placed on the disabled list June 4 after suffering a hyper-extended left elbow in a collision with Andres Galarraga of the Expos in Montreal on June 3.

title: A CARIBBEAN STOP ENDS POPE'S TRIP
description: Pope John Paul II, on his way back to Rome from Colombia tonight, paid a seven-hour visit to this Caribbean nation and told its 126,000 people, most of them Roman Catholic, ''to work for the dignity and equality of every human being.''

title: George Hamlin, 65, an Actor And Ex-Director at Harvard
description: George Hamlin, an actor and the former producing director at Harvard University's Loeb Drama Center, died Saturday at a nursing home in Riverdale section of the Bronx, after suffering a stroke. He was 65 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Chicken a la King
description: If it wasn't quite ''Carrie'' or ''The Dead Zone,'' still it had the dreamlike trappings of Bob Haskell's worst nightmare. He was in a park in Bangor, Me., dressed only in skivvies (approximately), and a couple of hundred people were looking at him.

title: Williams's Last Stop
description: Over the years, the managerial career of Dick Williams has taken a lot of bounces. Seattle, he said yesterday, is the last bounce.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are going to continue education and counseling. But there has to be a bottom line.

title: JUDGE, CITING OVERCROWDING, BARS ADMISSIONS AT BRONX PSYCHIATRIC CENTER
description: A Federal judge, saying overcrowding at the Bronx Psychiatric Center was depriving patients of their constitutional right to adequate care, has barred new admissions there.

title: DNA in Cancer Cells
description: The amount of genetic material, or DNA, in tumor cells may be a strong indicator of a patient's chances of survival, according to a study performed at the City of Hope National Medical Center in Duarte, Calif.

title: RANDOM HOUSE TO PUBLISH NANCY REAGAN'S MEMOIRS
description: Nancy Reagan, who has kept day-by-day diaries of her White House years, has signed a contract to write her memoirs for Random House.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Birmingham Steel Corp., Birmingham, Ala., agreed to acquire Intercoastal Steel Corp., a privately held steel mini-mill operation in Chesapeake, Va. Terms were not disclosed.

title: T.W.A. IN DEAL WITH NORTHWEST
description: Trans World Airlines and Northwest Airlines announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle under which Northwest would purchase a 50 percent interest in T.W.A.'s Pars reservation system.

title:
PLAYERS;
Fernandez Works On 'Longevity'
description: Sid Fernandez has come within sight of a place few athletes reach, that place where performance at last meets promise. In the two and a half years since the Los Angeles Dodgers made a trade they must now regret, Fernandez has lost weight and gained self-assurance. There is always room for some more. Fernandez has led many of the customers at Shea Stadium to believe that the first no-hitter in the history of the Met franchise will come from him. It is too easy to watch a 6-foot-1-inch, 205-pound pitcher and forget that he is 23 years old.

title: Bausch & Lomb Plans Acquisition
description: Bausch & Lomb, the Rochester-based eye-care company, said that it would acquire Dr. Mann Pharma of West Germany for $97 million. Dr. Mann Pharma markets prescription and over-the-counter drugs used to treat visual disorders. A Bausch & Lomb spokesman said the acquisition strongly enhances the company's chances to establish a worldwide ophthalmic pharmaceuticals enterprise.

title: BL Name Change
description: BL P.L.C., the former British Leyland, will change its name to Rover Group P.L.C. The board of the auto maker voted to make the change at an annual meeting in London. BL, an amalgamation of such famous British marks as Austin Rover, Triumph and Land Rover, was saved from financial collapse by the Government in 1975.

title: French-U.S. Ballet Celebrated in Pastillage
description: While most of New York was sluggishly recovering from its hangover the morning after the big weekend, Guy Pascal was building two opera houses.

title: Sports of The Times; New Dimention in Drug Issue
description: Until now, drug programs in sports have focused on the users and abusers, the self-victims. But in presenting the National Football League's new drug program that includes two unscheduled drug tests during the season for every player, Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, recognized another dimension of the drug problem in sports: the innocent victims who might be injured during a game by the drug users and abusers.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, ''A Death Knell For Tax Shelters?'', misidentified the former Commissioner of Internal Revenue. He is Roscoe L. Egger Jr.

title: PARAMILITARY GROUP THAT CAUGHT 15 ALIENS PLANS MORE PATROLS
description: Members of a paramilitary group who helped capture 15 illegal aliens near the Arizona-Mexico border Saturday night said they planned to continue and perhaps increase their patrols, despite sharp criticism from a Government official.

title: NEW ECONOMIC LEEWAY FOR NAKASONE EMERGES
description: The ruling party's landslide victory in Sunday's national elections, while not portending a basic shift in Japan's economic course, could mean greater progress in resolving trade issues and in restructuring Japan's economy, diplomats and economists said today.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TURKISH CYPRIOT REBUFFS U.N.
description: Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, today rejected a United Nations request to reopen the crossing points on the dividing line between the Greek and Turkish ethnic parts of Cyprus.

title: FIRST ALBANY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
High-Flying Pilots
description: The emergence of the Mets has allowed Dave Johnson to post a percentage that's second-best in major league history among all managers who won at least 200 games. The top 10:

title: Victim of Boat Crash Is Still in the Hospital
description: A woman who was injured in a boat collision during the Parade of Sail on Friday was listed in fair condition yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Junk Bonds' Shift by S.& P.
description: Responding to the rapid growth in the corporate bond market of speculative industrial subordinated debt, the Standard & Poor's Corporation has introduced new rating policies on ''junk bonds,'' to state the degree of risk more precisely.

title: U.S. Rejects Plea To Limit Arthritis Drug
description: The Government refused today to take emergency action against a widely prescribed arthritis drug suspected of causing deaths among the elderly, saying studies did not support allegations of unreasonable risk.

title: JUDAIC COLLEGE GETTING NEW MANDATE
description: Dropsie College, a pioneering leader in Judaic and Near Eastern studies that has lately fallen on lean times, is being reborn in a more ambitious form, with a broader intellectual mandate and a new name.

title: The Reagans Slip Out For a Birthday Dinner
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, kept top aides and the press in the dark as the couple slipped away from the White House in an unmarked motorcade Sunday night for a private celebration of Mrs. Reagan's 65th birthday.

title: Roy Poole, a Featured Actor In Plays, Film and Television
description: Roy Poole, an actor on the stage, in films and on television, died last Tuesday in Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

title: Cocoa Talks Resume
description: Cocoa producers and consuming nations, seeking to replace a price-stabilizing accord that expires in less than three months, have reopened talks on setting a new price structure. The latest round, which began today, is the fifth since talks sponsored by the United Nations began in 1984. The session also marks the return to the talks of the Ivory Coast, the world's biggest producer.

title: U.S. Steel Is Seen Disclosing Plans
description: The United States Steel Corporation has scheduled a news conference today in which it is expected to announce a major restructuring that will split off its troubled steel and iron ore operations into a separate subsidiary and change the parent company's name.

title: Uh-Oh, Bo
description: Bo Jackson was 0 for 4 Monday night at Greenville, S.C., the sixth time in eight games with the Memphis Chicks that he'd gone hitless.

title: TEXAS LEFT-HANDER STOPS YANKEES, 6-1
description: They have become familiar scenes this season. In the afternoon, George Steinbrenner turned up the heat in his feud with Dave Winfield. In the evening, the Yankees, wilting in oppressive 94-degree weather, faltered once more against left-handed pitching.

title: Jordanians Turning To Moscow for Arms
description: Jordan has bought surface-to-air missiles from the Soviet Union because an arms deal with the United States collapsed under Congressional pressure, Jane's Defence Weekly said today.

title: Mead-Zellerbach
description: The Mead Corporation said it had agreed in principle to buy the Zellerbach Distribution Group from James River's Crown Zellerbach subsidiary for $250 million. Mead, with 35 distribution centers, primarily in the Middle West, would add about 2,100 new employees and 42 additional distribution operations mostly in the South and West, making it the largest producer and distributor of paper products in the country. The Zellerbach Group, a paper, industrial and packaging operation, includes the Zellerbach Paper Company, the Virginia Paper Company and the Southern Paper Company.

title: U.S. Housing Agency Told to End Segregation
description: A Federal district judge, in a ruling released Monday, ordered the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to end segregation in publicly financed housing in 36 east Texas counties.

title: Van der Velde Takes Tour Lead
description: Johan Van der Velde of the Netherlands sprinted ahead in the fifth leg of the Tour de France today to win the day's race and also capture the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

title: Real Estate; New Office Towers on Madison
description: A SHORTAGE of sites for office construction on the East Side avenues of midtown has forced development heavyweights to move west or to make do with midblock locations. But two newcomers to the Manhattan development scene, the Louis Dreyfus Property Group and Hartz Associates, a division of Hartz Mountain Industries, are building office towers on corner sites on Madison Avenue.

title: MAYTAG HEIRESS TESTIFIES ON ROLE IN A STOCK DEAL
description: Ann L. Maytag testified yesterday that the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, John J. McLaughlin, pressured her in 1983 to buy discounted stock in a California health-care company that according to the prosecution was actually a bribe to Mr. McLaughlin.

title: FOR MANY VISITORS, FIRST VIEW OF U.S. IS A LINE
description: Foreign visitors arriving at Kennedy International Airport are being forced onto huge lines for as long as four hours to reach Immigration inspectors, according to immigration officials and airline representatives.

title: U.S. ISSUES BAN ON SULFITES' USE IN CERTAIN FOODS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today banned the use of sulfite preservatives in fresh vegetables and fruits. Sulfites have been linked to 13 deaths and many illnesses, mainly among asthmatics.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review on Saturday of Liberty Weekend programming misidentified a performing group that appeared. It was the Garfield (N.J.) Cadets, a drum and bugle corps not affiliated with any school.

title: Not Guilty Plea Entered In Los Angeles Killings
description: A man who said over the weekend that he wanted to be executed for three murders stemming from a hostage siege at a fashionable jewelry store asked a judge today for speedy justice as his lawyer entered pleas of not guilty.

title: Executive Changes At Villard and Grove
description: Random House announced yesterday that Marc Jaffe, editorial director of Villard Books, would leave the company this month. In another development, Aaron Asher, executive editor of Harper & Row, has been named publisher of Grove Press.

title: HUSSEIN FACES DOMESTIC PROBLEMS AS HE ORDERS ARAFAT OFFICES SHUT
description: Military policemen, heavily armed and backed by pickup trucks bristling with .50-caliber machine guns, went about the business of shutting Palestinian guerrilla offices here today, sealing the doors with red wax.

title: COMPARING YOGURTS
description: YOGURT is generally held to be one of the most healthful of snack foods. Like milk, it is an excellent source of calcium, and even people who are lactose-intolerant - unable to digest milk sugar - can usually eat yogurt. It is also a good source of protein.

title: Tandon Introduces 2 Computer Series
description: The Tandon Corporation, as expected, has introduced its own brand of I.B.M.-compatible microcomputers in the domestic market.

title: Concern Wins on Name
description: A Utah company specializing in paging services and mobile telephones can use the name General Telephone because the GTE Corporation, known as the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation until the early 1970's, was not operating in the state when the local business was begun, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains on partial settlement of an insurance claim of $800,000 for the quarter and $3.9 million for the year. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,284,000 from the replacement of a pension plan. d-Includes a gain of $500,000 on the sale of non-operating assets. The share earnings and shares outstanding for both periods reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 28, 1986.

title: Economic Scene; Modern Views On Population
description: THE five billionth person on Earth was born Monday, according to estimates of the Population Institute in Washington.

title: Officials Say State Dept. Aide May Be Given Honduras Post
description: President Reagan is expected to name William Walker, a career diplomat, as Ambassador to Honduras, officials said today.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
description: The company reported that on June 30, 1986, a letter of agreement was signed by the company and Unitog Canada Ltd. whereby Unifirst will purchase all the outstanding stock of Unitog Canada Ltd.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Bottle for the Beach Going to the beach? Travel light with this new Beach in a Bottle. The brightly colored plastic spray bottle twists apart: The top holds 24 ounces of water, for a cooling beachside spray, or your favorite beverage.

title: UPSTATE, BARGAINS ARE AT BORDER
description: Steve Drown, a Plattsburgh undertaker, journeyed just across the Canadian border here recently to buy a car. With the American dollar now worth close to $1.40 Canadian, he saved more than $1,000 on a new Chevrolet Nova.

title: Landslide, Not Earthquake, in Japan
description: Sunday's election in Japan surely constitutes a personal triumph for Prime Minister Nakasone and a mandate for needed economic reform. But in a society so dependent on consensus politics, it is dangerous to expect too much too soon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 9, 1986
description: The Economy

title: GTE Unit Sets New Cable Coding
description: GTE Laboratories Inc., the research arm of the GTE Corporation, said that it had developed a new technology that substantially increases the number of telephone conversations that can be carried by standard cable or radio communication systems, while maintaining high quality.

title: HEAT MAY HELP ALCOTT IN OPEN
description: When Amy Alcott won the Mazda Hall of Fame Championship last Sunday in Houston, she completed another of her successful four-day battles against other fine golfers and 100-degree heat.

title: Namath Baffled
description: Joe Namath, breaking a three-month silence on the subject, said he was surprised and baffled by ABC-TV's decision to take him out of the broadcasting booth for Monday Night Football.

title: Advertising; B.B.D.O. Arrival
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, long a Lever Brothers agency, has hired Arthur C. Unger, a former top Lever executive, as executive vice president and director of new product development. At 42, Mr. Unger has 19 years of package goods experience, having joined Lever as an assistant product manager and working up through marketing director of the household products division, with the rank of vice president. From there he was made president of the personal products division, where he was replaced last February.

title: Parental Nagging as an All-Weather Sport
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR COMMUNIQUES INDICATE A BIG BATTLE ON IRAN-IRAQ BORDER
description: Iran said today that its forces, backed by fierce artillery barrages and air strikes, had killed 2,000 Iraqi soldiers while advancing into eastern Iraq. But Iraq said its soldiers repulsed the Iranian attack while inflicting thousands of casualties.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $12 million and extraordinary losses of $11.7 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $22.3 million and $32 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-Includes an unusual pre-tax credit of $8.1 million which includes principally the gain on the sale of KMOX-TV. The company said that because of the tax treatment of the $8.1 million credit in the latest quarter, it benefited from a substantially lower tax rate of 35 percent in the latest quarter compared to 47 percent in the year- ago period, and that for the latest 6 months the tax rate was 34 percent compared to 46 percent for the year- ago period.

title: The Uses of Sailing
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE two women are sitting at a corner table in the restaurant, their shopping bags wedged between their chairs and the wall: Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale's, something from Ann Taylor for the younger one. She is wearing a bright silk shirt, some good gold jewelry; her hair is on the long side, her makeup faint. Across the table the older woman is wearing a suit, a string of pearls, a diamond solitaire and a narrow band. They lean across the table. I imagine the conversation: Will the new blazer go with the old skirt? Is the dress really right for an afternoon wedding? How is Daddy? How is his ulcer? Won't he slow down, just a little bit?

title: The Questions Count As Well as the Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CROSSING BRIDGES - Lou Singer's Brooklyn tours have become, over the last decade, an established institution for those out-of-borough folk who otherwise would rarely cross the water to the historic borough on the Atlantic Ocean. Now Mr. Singer has instituted a round-trip service that will bring tourists for a day-long outing from Manhattan, across the Brooklyn Bridge, to visit the Brooklyn Museum and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden or, if they wish, the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

title: WALDHEIM CAN BE KEPT OUT OF THE U.S.
description: Kurt Waldheim, who was inaugurated yesterday as President of Austria, can and should be excluded from the United States.

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mortgage Rates Higher
description: Mortgage rates rose between early May and early June, the first increase since September, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday. The rise reflected generally higher interest rates in the period.

title: DANCE: FRANCE-AMERICAN BENEFIT GALA AT THE MET
description: LIBERTY, Equality and Fraternity, with an accute accent on the latter, were scattered all over the Metropolitan Opera House stage last night as the Paris Opera Ballet and the American Ballet Theater joined forces for one of the most surprisingly successful gala benefits the dance world has seen in years.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASTROS' RALLY BEATS EXPOS, 4-1
description: Denny Walling hit a two-run homer off Jeff Reardon in the eighth inning to cap a four-run Houston comeback tonight and give the Astros a 4-1 victory over the Expos. Nolan Ryan (5-6) pitched seven innings of five-hit ball before Charlie Kerfeld came in for his third save.

title: NEW ESTIMATES SEEN AS EASING PRESSURE ON CONGRESS TO CUT BUDGET
description: Preliminary estimates by the House and Senate Budget Committees show that Congress and the Reagan Administration could avoid the backup procedure for spending cuts under the budget-balancing law if they carry out all the savings promised in the 1987 budget.

title: All the Presidents, Almost, On Stamps
description: For stamp collectors, depictions of former Presidents have always been prized items.

title: COMPRESSION LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $508,000 for the quarter and $768,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES POSSIBLE PLOT TO SEND BOMB TECHNOLOGY TO ISRAEL
description: The Federal authorities are investigating whether American companies and representatives of Israel's weapon industry plotted to illegally export technology used for making cluster bombs, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. REPORT DECLARES CIVIL DEFENSE IN POOR SHAPE AND GETTING WORSE
description: The United States is losing any ability to protect the population and operate the Government in the aftermath of a nuclear war, a Federal agency said today.

title: New Warnings On Subway Door Openings
description: D.O.E.

title: CREATOR OF JAZZ FESTIVAL CHARTING NEW DIRECTION
description: BEFORE George Wein's annual jazz festival began its 10-day run on June 20 under its new name, the JVC Jazz Festival, he viewed this as a year of transition for the annual gala, which he started in Newport, R.I., in 1954. It had a new and possibly confusing name. Carnegie Hall, one of the festival's two primary venues along with Avery Fisher Hall, was closed for renovation. And the changing nature of current jazz led Mr. Wein to believe he might have to rethink his approach to a jazz festival.

title: 'GROWING UP WITH ROCKETS,' CAPE CANAVERAL FAMILY LIFE
description: ''GROWING UP WITH ROCKETS,'' to be seen on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock, was organized, produced, directed, narrated and largely written by Nancy Yasecko, a young woman who grew up as the daughter of a NASA engineer in Cocoa Beach, Fla., during the early years of the space era.

title: What Is Gorbachev Saying?
description: First it was Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain and now it is President Mitterrand of France who is trying to convince President Reagan that he should take Mikhail Gorbachev's ''peace offers'' more seriously.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago 6-month results cover restatement for the cumulative effect, to Dec. 31, 1984, of a change in accounting for cost of timber harvested.

title: SAFEWAY GETS BID FROM DART
description: The Dart Group Corporation, which operates a group of discount auto supply and book stores, announced a $3.6 billion offer for all the shares in Safeway Stores Inc., the nation's biggest supermarket chain.

title: Robert S. Lopez Dies; Yale History Professor
description: Robert S. Lopez, Sterling Professor Emeritus of History at Yale University, died of complications arising from cancer Sunday at his home in New Haven. He was 75 years old.

title: GOLDMAN AIDE TIED TO INSIDERS
description: David S. Brown, a 31-year-old lawyer and investment banker, resigned from Goldman, Sachs & Company last Thursday because of links to the investigation of insider trading on Wall Street, Goldman, Sachs said yesterday in a memorandum to employees.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $16,000 and $38,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Detectable Comestibles
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Advertising; Shaw and Landey Set Goals
description: SHAW & PLATT, billing some $21 million, and Martin Landey Associates, doing about $15 million, have merged to form Shaw & Landey, and the two owners are committed to finishing the year at $50 million and hitting $100 million in three years.

title: BUBKA BETTERS MARK AT 19-8 3/4
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his world record in the pole vault tonight with a flight of 19 feet 8 3/4 inches at the Goodwill Games.

title: CLOSING SUMMARIES START IN SPY CASE
description: Closing arguments began today in the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth, with prosecutors struggling to overcome problems created by the wording of the Government's 13-count indictment.

title: United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation plans to establish a pretax provision of $155 million to cover expected losses of its Norden Systems subsidiary, cutting its second-quarter net by 75 cents a share.

title: PARENTAL NAGGING AS AN ALL-WEATHER SPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Two P.&G. Groups Get New Leaders
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that Gerald V. Dirvin, a group vice president, had assumed responsibility for the company's paper products division and for its patient care products. Mr. Dirvin, 49 years old, succeeds Sanford G. Weiner, who died June 27 at the age of 46.

title: Hello, This Is Not Helsinki
description: With Congress still enjoying its Fourth of July recess, people who telephoned the Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs of the House Foreign Affairs Committee this week often got a recorded announcement inviting them to leave their name, number and message. Both before and after the Supreme Court's invalidation of a key part of the Federal budget-balancing law on Monday, the recording concluded: ''Unfortunately, due to Gramm-Rudman, if you are calling long distance, we will not be able to return your call.''

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CINCINNATI REDS, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: 'Sills' Moves to Village
description: ''Sills & Company,'' the improvisational comedy revue directed by Paul Sills, has moved to the Actor's Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South, between Grove and Bleecker Streets.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an unusual investment gain of $4,344,000.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FORD: The Men and the Machine. By Robert Lacey. Illustrated. 778 pages. Little, Brown. $24.95. ''FORD'' is a workmanlike assemblage by an English writer of a great American family saga. Robert Lacey carries us briskly through almost a century of corporate fortunes (Model A, Model T, Mustang) and misfortunes (Edsel, Pinto). He makes admirably clear the technical and marketing considerations that have gone into each new or revised model and provides plenty of opportunity along the way to view the changing social landscape. The episodes that particularly excite Mr. Lacey, whose specialty until now has been books about British royals and aristocrats, are the personal ones, especially the tortured relations between Henry Ford and his son, Edsel, the power struggle between Henry Ford II and Lee Iacocca, and the second Henry's occasional trading in of one wife for another.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF THE CAROLIAS F A reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
REDS RALLY TO WIN IN 10TH AS METS' BULLPEN FALTERS
description: Every now and then in this season of storybook success, some reality of life comes back to sober the Mets. That's what happened to them last night in Shea Stadium when their two best relief pitchers blew a game to the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Space Agency Names Pilot as Safety Director
description: The space agency reached outside its own ranks today for a safety director to prevent another disaster like the one that destroyed the space shuttle Challenger.

title: CHURCH OFFICE IS REPORTED RAIDED
description: The South African police removed extensive files from the offices of the South African Council of Churches yesterday in what appeared to be a move to step up pressure on the organization for its stand against apartheid, the council's general secretary said in a telephone interview from Johannesburg.

title: BRITONS FANCY CHANCES OF THEIR HEAVYWEIGHT
description: ''It was a hook what put me down,'' says the large boxer, sounding more wise than angry now that he is an upright contender once again.

title: POLICE ASSIGN TEAMS TO ALL FERRIES FOLLOWING SWORD SLAYING OF TWO
description: Teams of police officers will be assigned to all Staten Island ferryboats temporarily to deter anyone from repeating the rampage of a sword-wielding Cuban refugee charged with killing two people and wounding nine others Monday, police officials said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The economy is not as robust as we would like it to be.

title: From the Beach To the Bank
description: The thing about Southern California, transplanted Easterners are always moaning, is that you miss the change in seasons. But beachboys who excel at two-man volleyball have less of a problem. For them, sprouts of green - as in dollars - confirm the arrival of summer, when their rapidly expanding pastime opens its pro season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 9, 1986
description: International Cuba is said to be no longer insisting that Washington close down the operations of Radio Marti to Cuba as part of a possible agreement on reinstating immigration with the United States, Reagan Administration officials said. Instead, the Cubans indicated in advance of new negotiations that they are now seeking an agreement from the United States recognizing their right to broadcast over an AM frequency in the United States to match the Voice of America's Radio Marti transmissions to Cuba, the officials said. [ Page A1, Column 2. ]

title: LEE GOLDMAN
description: Lee Goldman, former president of Community School Board 26 in Queens, died Sunday at Long Island Hospital in New Hyde Park. Mrs. Goldman, who had been injured in a car accident in March, was 61 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Mitterrand Trades Views With Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Francois Mitterrand met today and concluded that prospects for a Soviet-American summit meeting were favorable despite continued differences over nuclear weapons, a Soviet official said.

title: CUBA, IN IMMIGRATION CONCESSION, SAID TO DROP BAN ON A U.S. RADIO
description: As part of a possible agreement on reinstating an immigration accord with the United States, Cuba is reported to have dropped its insistence that Washington cease operations of Radio Marti, which broadcasts to Cuba, Administration officials said today.

title: WILLIAM M. MEEHAN
description: William M. Meehan, senior partner of the stock brokerage of M. J. Meehan & Company and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CBS Profits Rise 55%
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 55 percent, mainly because of gains from the sale of its television station in St. Louis and a lower tax rate.

title: The Heat Forces Cut In Some Lilco Service
description: In the fourth day of a heat wave, the heavy use of air-conditiioners yesterday forced the Long Island Lighting Company to reduce power to 17 large commercial customers to keep full service to the rest of its users.

title: Angry Words and, Now, Silence on Mexico
description: William von Raab had been Commissioner of the United States Customs Service only a few months when, on an official visit to Mexico City, he was invited by the Chief of Police to his country home for the weekend.

title: LEMONADE: OF SIPS AND SWEET MEMORIES
description: BOTH puckery and sweet, lemonade is a sprightly thirst-quencher on a hot summer afternoon, served on its own or as part of a picnic spread. While it is thought to be as American as apple pie, it was invented in Paris in 1630. At that time, according to James Trager's ''Food Book'' (Avon, 1970), there was a sudden drop in the price of sugar so people started experimenting with the suddenly inexpensive sweetener. Apparently, some bright soul thought to combine sugar with water with lemon juice.

title: BROADWAY OPENING SET FOR 'STARLIGHT EXPRESS'
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Starlight Express,'' which has been playing to capacity audiences in London since March 1984, is scheduled to open at the Gershwin Theater on Feb. 26.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $38.4 million on the sale of Alliance Mortgage Co.

title: Consumer Debt Rises
description: Americans buying cars and other big ticket items took on $5.4 billion more in installment debt than they repaid in May for the second-highest increase in debt this year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MILK is a controversial food. While valued for its nutrient content, especially its high-quality protein and easily absorbed calcium, it is also condemned as a food that people were never meant to consume beyond the first two to four years of life. Not until the advent of agriculture some 10,000 years ago did milk and milk products become frequent constituents of the adult human diet. Indeed, in some cultures, such as the Japanese, the diet still has few dairy products, if any, in it.

title: Du Pont Seeks Baxter Division
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it had agreed to acquire the American Critical Care unit of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. for $425 million in cash and payments based on future sales.

title: NEIGHBORS NOTED TRAITS OF VIOLENCE IN SUSPECT
description: During nine years in the United States, Juan J. Gonzalez showed increasing signs of violence and paranoia, those who knew him say, until those traits finally erupted Monday, when, the police say, the Cuban refugee killed two people and wounded nine others in a sword attack on the Staten Island ferry.

title: One Peru Gunman Slain In Soviet Embassy Raid
description: An armed group attacked the Soviet Embassy with submachine guns and explosives today, and one guerrilla was killed when a bomb exploded in his hands inside the compound, the Government said.

title: Choosing a Sunscreen
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Lost: One 10-Foot Lady
description: Charles Ferguson, executive director of Washington's National Independence Day Parade, admits that he may have encouraged unwanted attention when he advertised last week that the miniature Statue of Liberty to be featured in Friday's march down Constitution Avenue would be auctioned later for a price in the range of $35,000.

title: Dollar Shifts Narrowly While Gold Advances
description: The dollar seesawed within a narrow range yesterday, as market participants waited for fresh signs about where the economy and interest rates were going.

title: Market Place; Measuring Market's Mood
description: VARIOUS measures of market sentiment indicate that just before Monday's 61-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, many individual investors had become complacent about prospects for continued gains in stock prices.

title: McGinnis Leads In State Open
description: Tom McGinnis, the assistant pro at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, posted a 68 today to take a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the New York State Open. His score was three under par for the Big G course at the Grossinger Resort and it gave him a total of 138, four under par, for 36 holes.

title: THE CHANGING FORMULA OF NBC'S 'ST. ELSEWHERE'
description: THE history of ''St. Elsewhere'' is an oddity, even for television. Now preparing for its fifth season, the NBC series, which can be seen on Wednesdays at 10 P.M., began life as a doctor-and-nurse version of ''Hill Street Blues.'' Like the police show, ''St. Elsewhere'' is partial to hand-held cameras and the simultaneous juggling of several plots, many of which are stretched out over several episodes. Both series are the products of MTM Enterprises, founded by Grant Tinker, who is currently chairman of NBC.

title: EX-DEFENSIVE BACK WAS STAR FOR GIANTS
description: Carl (Spider) Lockhart, who was a defensive star for the New York Giants for 11 years, died of cancer yesterday at Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 43 years old.

title: BLAME DEBATED AS TRIAL WEIGHS BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: Three years after the bridge over the Mianus River collapsed, the state of Connecticut and the bridge designers traded accusations of blame in Superior Court here today for the accident, which sent four vehicles plunging to the water from Interstate 95, killing three people and seriously injuring three others.

title: PART-TIME WORK NEW LABOR TREND
description: A fundamental change is occurring in the American workplace as more and more employers rely on temporary and part-time workers.

title: SHARP EXCHANGE AT U.S.F.L. TRIAL
description: Tex Schramm, the president and general manager of the Dallas Cowboys, spent a contentious day on the witnesss stand yesterday, most of the time trying to explain again how the suggestions of a professor from the Harvard Business School did not serve as the National Football League's blueprint ''to conquer'' the United States Football League.

title: SECOND TUTU-BOTHA MEETING DUE
description: President P. W. Botha and Bishop Desmond M. Tutu are scheduled to hold their second private meeting since a nationwide state of emergency was declared last month, a spokesman for Bishop Tutu said today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S URBANE SOLDIER IN A WAR OF IMAGES
description: At the start of South Africa's newest state of emergency, David Steward emerged as something new in the nation's imagery - a South African, speaking for the nation, clad not in army or police fatigues but in navy blue pin stripes and Ralph Lauren shirts.

title: Republic Sets Write-Off
description: The Republic New York Corporation, parent of the Republic National Bank of New York, the nation's 30th-largest bank, said yesterday that it would take a $12.9 million charge against second-quarter earnings because of debt refinancing.

title: BIDS SEEN FOR PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: The directors of People Express yesterday considered bids from Texas Air and United Airlines to buy all or part of the airline, sources involved in the negotiations said.

title: Tunisian Premier Dismissed
description: President Habib Bourguiba dismissed Mohammed Mzali as Prime Minister and secretary general of the ruling party today, naming Finance Minister Rachid Sfar as a replacement. The announcement ended weeks of speculation about the political fate of Mr. Mzali and marked the start of a new episode in the struggle to succeed the ailing 83-year-old President.

title: Mailings From Bush
description: Like other potential Presidential contenders in both parties, Vice President Bush periodically mails to journalists a fat packet of photocopies of clippings, most of them favorable news articles of Mr. Bush's political visits to communities around the country and the world.

title: STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results include gains on the sale of marketable securities of $1.23 a share in the latest quarter and 37 cents in the year-ago period.

title: White Sox To Weigh Offers
description: The owners of the Chicago White Sox said today that they would entertain offers from other cities to move the team while they also pursue locating the club in suburban Addison, Ill.

title: Ravioli at Their Choicest
description: ONE of the most fashionable (and delicious) restaurant dishes is ravioli - not the standard cheese-filled squares smothered with tomato sauce, but rather ultrathin ravioli holding everything from truffles and foie gras to scallops, shrimp, duck, lobster and more. Anyone who has ever rolled out ravioli dough by hand knows how difficult it is to make it extra thin and uniform all over.

title: O'Grady's Option
description: Mac O'Grady, who is embroiled in a feud with Deane Beman, the PGA Commissioner, may go to Federal Court later this week in an attempt to block a six-event suspension and a $5,000 fine, the golfer's lawyer said yesterday. The penalties were imposed by Beman for ''conduct unbecoming a professional golfer'' and upheld by an appeals committee.

title: The Spy and the American Jew
description: Espionage is to diplomacy what infidelity is to marriage: it is the apparently loving relationship between the couple - in this case, the United States and Israel -rather than the deed itself that makes the case of Jonathan Jay Pollard so shocking.

title: Westpac U.S. Manager Has Freedom to Expand
description: Anthony J. Walton left the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1983 to take a job with Australia's Westpac Banking Corporation. Mr. Walton stayed put in New York, however, for the job was to expand the bank's business in the Americas.

title: 12 Seized in Poland While Holding a Protest
description: Twelve people were arrested today after they staged a demonstration outside a prison in the southwest city of Wroclaw for the release of political prisoners.

title: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS CALIFORNIA RESORT AREA
description: Preceded by the howling of coyotes, a strong earthquake shook Palm Springs and other communities on the western rim of California's Mojave Desert this morning.

title: ACTIVITY ALONG FAULT IN EARTH
description: The moderately severe earthquake yesterday near Palm Springs was ''no surprise,'' according to scientists at the United States Geological Survey, because it occurred on an active fault in the earth.

title: S.E.C. AND ASHLAND SETTLE BRIBERY CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Ashland Oil Inc. and a former chairman of making $29 million in illegal foreign payoffs between 1980 and 1982 to win crude oil contracts in Oman.

title: CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
CLERK IS KILLED IN TOKEN BOOTH AT IRT STATION
description: A subway-token clerk in Brooklyn was stabbed to death in his booth during an apparent robbery early yesterday, and the police said they had been unable to learn how the assailant had got in.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Helmet to Be Studied
description: Officials at the State Racing and Wagering Board are looking at the helmet worn by Billy Haughton to determine if it had sufficient strength to withstand the impact sustained by the harness driver in a weekend accident. Meanwhile, the 62-year-old Haughton, who has won 4,983 races, remained in critical conditions with head injuries at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla.

title: Picket Line at Regine's
description: Men in dinner jackets squeezed past men in sandwich boards picketing Regine's, a jet-set watering hole on Park Avenue.

title: Marcos Denies Urging Coup in the Philippines
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos denied today that he had encouraged his supporters to rebel and said he was aware that events in the Philippines could jeopardize his status as a guest in the United States.

title: REPORT HAILS SEX EDUCATION
description: Teen-age girls who participated in a special sex education program in Baltimore refrained from sexual relations longer than girls who were not in the program, according to a study by Johns Hopkins University released yesterday.

title: U.S. ACCUSED OF SEAT BELT LAPSE
description: An automobile safety group accused the Department of Transportation today of undermining its efforts to promote seat belts when it failed to persuade Honda and Toyota to recall belts from a million cars.

title: FIRST OF 4 CAMPAIGN DINNERS RAISES $500,000 FOR LUNDINE
description: Representative Stan Lundine, Governor Cuomo's choice for lieutenant governor, raised at least $500,000 last night at a $1,000-a-plate event at the Sheraton Centre. It was the first of four such events, marking the start of an unusual Democratic contest for lieutenant governor.

title: Advertising; Promoters of Catfish Are Hunting an Agency
description: If you are looking for an assignment you can really sink your teeth into, call Templeton Inc., in Farmington, Conn., a marketing consultant that also does agency searches when the client needs them.

title: Medal Lost and Found
description: Paul Bocuse, father of nouvelle cuisine, flew in from Lyons to present on behalf of President Francois Mitterrand the medal of the Ordre National du Merite to Pierre Franey, chef, author and a food writer for The New York Times. But the medal got lost.

title: THE WEST BANK: ARENA IN HUSSEIN-P.L.O. CONTEST
description: The same power struggle that has been going on in Jordan between Yasir Arafat and King Hussein has been playing itself out on the West Bank for the last few weeks.

title: PLASTI-LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
A NEW PLAN TO SPEED BUSES ON FIRST AVE.
description: With work on the Second Avenue subway line abandoned for lack of money, the city's Transportation Department has proposed the creation of two express bus lanes on First Avenue to speed commuters up and down Manhattan's East Side.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: PHOOEY to being born with a silver spoon in your mouth. Today's youngsters, a great many of them at any rate, seem to be born with micro chips in their hands. That's probably even more prestigious and, ultimately, more lucrative. While they go about acquiring technological skills with apparent ease, however, the more mature among us, who still think of the ball point pen as a modern miracle, watch them in amazement.

title: Richardson's Problems
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the former guard of the Nets who has been banned from the National Basketball Association because of drug use, was arrested twice within 24 hours. The charges were driving with a revoked license, threatening his wife, from whom he is separated, and leaving a detoxification center without authorization, according to the police in Allendale, N.J. On Sunday, Richardson was arrested on charges of driving while on the revoked list after the police found him asleep in his wife's car with the motor running.

title: Reagan and Drug Abuse
description: President Reagan is considering starting a major White House offensive on drug abuse this summer, adding his personal prestige and influence to the campaign that his wife, Nancy, has been developing for several years. Mr. Reagan is said to believe that the cocaine-related deaths of two star athletes, Len Bias of the University of Maryland and Don Rogers of the Cleveland Browns, have focused public attention on the problem as never before, presenting an opportunity for aggressive national leadership to achieve some progress. Senior White House aides are preparing suggestions for Mr. Reagan that include a major Presidential speech on the subject.

title: 'Creaming' by New York High Schools
description: Do New York City's public high schools unfairly discriminate against minority students? Do they prepare students for a changing, technological society?

title: Seafirst Settles Suit Against 5
description: The Seafirst Corporation yesterday announced an out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit that the Seattle-based bank filed against five former officers in the wake of huge losses related to the 1982 collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

title: Magazine Rebuffs Pergamon Offer
description: Scientific American Inc. has rejected a $61 million offer from Robert Maxwell, the chairman of Pergamon Press Ltd. in Britain, saying that Mr. Maxwell did not abide by the terms of the initial bidding. Scientific American, publisher of the scholarly monthly magazine, last week accepted a $52.6 million offer from a German publishing concern, Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck of Stuttgart.

title: Simmons Plan Is Outlined
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said today that his goal ''right now'' was to acquire up to 15 percent of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, but that additional investments would depend on various market conditions.

title: Their Best Shot
description: David Courtney, public relations man for the Los Angeles Kings, who won only 23 of 80 games and finished in the basement of the Smythe Division last season: ''The Kings don't have a highlights film. What we have is a highlights slide.''

title: If African Nationalists Speak, Are Irish Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Church of England Delays Vote on Women
description: The Church of England, faced with a report warning that the 450-year-old church could be split if women are ordained as priests, decided today to postpone action on the issue for at least six months.

title: AGAIN, RIVER HOLDS KEY TO REVIVAL OF MEMPHIS
description: The 21-story tower is the first new office building on the downtown skyline in 12 years, an angular, glass-walled structure that looms over the city's riverfront and its blocks of aging brick buildings.

title: FILM: IMAMURA'S 'PIGS AND BATTLESHIPS'
description: THE time is 1960. The Allied occupation of Japan, in its 16th year, has been a smashing success. Democracy is, to all outward appearances, thriving, as is industry, which was initially regarded as something of a joke but would later challenge traditional trade relations to such an extent that American businesses today continue to reel from the competition.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SQUALL IN MANILA: AQUINO RIDES IT OUT
description: The two-day occupation of the Manila Hotel by military and civilian supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos appears to have left President Corazon C. Aquino, with her overwhelming popular support, and Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, with his military power base, as the major political figures in the Philippines today.

title: Oh, THAT Alexandria
description: Casual spectators at last weekend's matches between the Potomac Polo Club and the Alexandria Sporting Club may have assumed that the latter outfit had ventured across the river from the Virginia suburbs. In fact, the six-man Alexandria team had come all the way from the original and ancient city of that name in Egypt.

title: RICKOVER, FATHER OF NUCLEAR NAVY, DIES AT 86
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the crusty and outspoken naval officer who became the father of the nuclear Navy, died this morning at at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86 years old.

title: STUDY CITES GASOLINE AS THE TOP HAZARD AMONG SHIPMENTS
description: Although nuclear material and hazardous waste get the attention, gasoline is the most dangerous cargo in the nation's transportation system, Congressional researchers said today.

title: One Hot Bird
description: Damaso Garcia had a 17-game hitting streak, one of the best in the majors this year, as the Blue Jays took on Seattle last night.

title: BNH BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVES
description: * Del Monte U.S.A., San Francisco, named Gerald Spielvogel chief financial officer and vice president of finance.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATE COURT OF APPEALS RULING IN GOETZ CASE
description: Following are excerpts from the State Court of Appeals decision to reinstate attempted murder, assault and other charges against Bernhard H. Goetz in connection with the shooting of four youths aboard an IRT subway train in Manhattan on Dec. 22, 1984. Chief Justice Sol Wachtler wrote the opinion, which was unanimous.

title: PATRIOTS' PROBLEMS 'CATALYST'
description: The announcement on Monday by Commissioner Pete Rozelle of increased mandatory testing and stronger punishment for National Football League players who use illegal drugs followed months of unsuccessful negotiations between owner and player representatives on the subject and continuing reports of drug use by football players and other athletes, league officials said yesterday.

title: 60-Second Debate; Should Congress pass legislation to require warning labels on alcoholic beverages?
description: SEN. STROM THURMOND, Republican of South Carolina.

title: HOPE FOR GRASSHOPPER'S DEFEAT STILL IN LABORATORY
description: Wayne Bateman walked along a dusty section road on his farm watching the grasshoppers trying to buck a stiff southerly wind to cross the road and attack his ripening alfalfa on the south side.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Women and Food - The results of a nationwide survey conducted for the Conde Nast publishing company yield findings that are sometimes surprising, often obvious and occasionally contradictory. Focusing on eating, shopping and cooking patterns, the recently released results of the 1985 ''Women and Food'' survey analyzed responses to a written questionnaire completed by 2,077 women, ages 18 to 65. Eighty-eight percent of the respondents lived in ''family households'' of two or more people.

title: THE AMERICAN FROM MOSCOW
description: The love of music and motion began with lessons at the Bolshoi School in the heart of this city when Alla Svirsky was 6 years old. It took her to the title of Master of Sport, the highest athletic honor in the Soviet Union, but then her life took another turn, to the San Fernando Valley of California.

title: Chief of News Agency Quits As New Owner Takes Over
description: Luis G. Nogales, who guided United Press International through Federal Bankruptcy Court proceedings that ended in June, announced his resignation today as chairman of the news agency.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE WHOLE-WHEAT STORY: FROM THE OUTER CRUST TO THE INNER CRUMB
description: IF San Francisco is the sourdough capital of the world, New York might be considered the whole-wheat capital of the universe. The city's choices include everything from baguettes to buns.

title: BOND PRICES TUMBLE IN SLOW SESSION
description: Bond prices tumbled and rates on short-term Treasury bills rose sharply yesterday in thin trading by professionals. The credit markets appeared to be moving in sympathy with the selloff in stocks.

title: Minstar Stake in Enron
description: Minstar Inc., controlled by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, raised its stake in Enron Inc. to 11.4 percent from 10.2 percent. Separately, the Leucadia National Corporation said it had lowered its stake in Minstar to 1.8 percent, from 11 percent.

title: The Rickover Record
description: Nuclear submarines that patrol the deep oceans are the strong point of America's defense. Their missiles deter attack, and unlike land-based missiles they're undetectable and invulnerable. Adm. Hyman Rickover, now dead at the age of 86, was a principal architect of the nuclear navy.

title: DETECTABLE COMESTIBLES
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Bias Inquiry Proceeds
description: The Prince George's County state's attorney has reserved two weeks of grand jury time for the investigation of the cocaine-related death of Len Bias. The State's Attorney, Arthur Marshall, said he had issued 61 subpoenas and prepared another 10.

title: 31 ARE KILLED IN CLASH BETWEEN RIVAL ZULU VILLAGES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Thirty-one people were killed in a battle between Zulu factions from two rival villages, the police said today.

title: U.S. STEEL: NEW NAME ENDS AN ERA
description: In a move that ratifies the fall from dominance of the American steel industry, the United States Steel Corporation said today that it was changing its name as part of a broad restructuring of operations.

title: SCIENTISTS READY TO RETURN TO TITANIC
description: Scientists are to sail from here Wednesday aboard the research vessel Atlantis II to make the first direct examination of the sunken luxury liner Titanic, Dr. Robert D. Ballard of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution said today.

title: REAGAN FAVORS TALKS WITH BLACKS
description: President Reagan said in an interview Tuesday that his Administration saw ''a great need for communications with responsible black leaders'' in South Africa, The Daily News reported today.

title: Supreme Court Stays Execution in Georgia
description: The Supreme Court today granted a stay of execution to a convicted killer, James E. Messer Jr., who had been scheduled to die in Georgia Wednesday morning for killing his niece.

title: What the Justice Dept. Really Said About AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Crude Prices Are Mixed In a Slow Trading Day
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products were mixed in light trading yesterday.

title: REAL CONSTRUCTIVE ENGAGEMENT
description: The Reagan Administration's re-examination of its policy toward South Africa is encouraging, but it should stop clinging to the concept of ''constructive engagement.'' Clearly, that policy has not worked. If anything can be done to prevent a bloodbath in that unhappy nation, the United States must now become both more constructive and more deeply engaged.

title: WINE TALK
description: SEE how you do on these multiple-choice questions: 1.

title: Bill Signed to Advance Start of Daylight Time
description: President Reagan signed legislation today that moves up the start of daylight time to the first Sunday in April.

title: WEALTH OF COOL SUMMER SALADS FROM THE SEA
description: AT one time a fish salad could only have meant tuna fish -canned tuna fish combined with mayonnaise and celery. No more: consumers are eating as much canned tuna today as in 1978 (3.3 pounds a year each, on average), but their fish-salad menus have expanded.

title: Unfortunately, New York State Doesn't Ban Use of Polygraphs
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE'S TOP COURT RESTORES CHARGES IN GOETZ SHOOTING
description: New York's highest court yesterday unanimously reinstated charges of attempted murder and assault against Bernhard H. Goetz, who shot four youths on a Manhattan subway train in December 1984 because, he said, he feared they would rob him.

title: CARL (SPIDER) LOCKHART DIES
description: The defensive back, who spent his entire National Football League career with the Giants, succumbed to lymph cancer at the age of 43. Page A20

title: PALESTINIAN AIDE UPROOTED AGAIN
description: Three years ago, Abu Marwan turned over the Damascus offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization to Syria.

title: Friday Is the Last Day For Voters to Register
description: Friday is the last day for New Yorkers to enroll in a political party and register to vote in the Sept. 9 primaries.

title: Crying On the Outside
description: As this is written the outside temperature is 99 degrees. That's in the shade. I stepped out there to read the thermometer. The humidity was perhaps 135 percent. I was glad to come back into the air-conditioning.

title: EXCLUSIONARY TENDER OFFERS BANNED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to prohibit tender offers that exclude certain classes of shareholders, such as a large holder of a company's stock who might be seeking to take over the concern.

title: If You Were Bernhard Goetz . . .
description: What would you have done, assuming you are a reasonable person, if you were Bernhard Goetz in that subway car when accosted by four teen-agers? The answer may be difficult but the question is that simple. Lower courts in New York confused the issue beyond recognition as they dismissed the indictment charging him with murderous assault. Now a unanimous Court of Appeals has reinstated the indictment and made the issue clear.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT has always struck me as odd that peppercorns have not played a more prominent role in Western European and American cooking. In the traditional kitchen, pepper is taken for granted. There are, of course, exceptions, among them steak au poivre, in which the raw meat is coated liberally with coarse, freshly ground pepper, and sauce poivrade, a rich brown sauce flavored with pepper.

title: BIG PROFIT FOR POSTAL SERVICE MAKES RATE INCREASE UNLIKELY
description: A substantial profit for the Postal Service means the price for mailing cards, letters and packages is unlikely to rise for at least a year and a half, postal officials said today.

title: CHOOSING A SUNSCREEN
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers have scheduled a news conference today to announce a new head basketball coach amid reports they have been negotiating with Lenny Wilkens. There have been reports that Wilkens, who is the former head coach of the Seattle SuperSonics and is currently the team's general manager, is viewed as a compromise choice over two other candidates who are current National Basketball Association assistant coaches - Atlanta's Willis Reed and John Wetzel of Phoenix. . . . The New Jersey Generals announced four signings: Russell Erxleben, a punter and a place-kicker; Tony Massagli, another place-kicker; Elvis Butler, a defensive tackle, and Vince Courville, a wide receiver.

title: STATE BACKS TRADE CENTER FOR HARLEM
description: A nine-year-old plan to build an international trade center on 125th Street - a key element of economic-development efforts in Harlem -received a major boost yesterday when the state said it would contribute one-third of the $165 million cost of the center.

title: The U.N. Today: July 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DOW DROPS 18.27 MORE, TO 1,820.73
description: Wall Street did not do half as bad yesterday as it did during the record-breaking 61.87-point drop on Monday, but stock prices still fell sharply as smaller investors, mimicking their bigger counterparts, sold equities furiously.

title: IN MISTS OF MEMORY, SUN ALWAYS SHINES ON FAMIY CAMPING
description: SOME people mark the coming of summer when they smell honeysuckle or see a bright-red geranium on a neighbor's porch. Others start grilling hamburgers outside or go on picnics.

title: BARYSHNIKOV JOINS NUREYEV IN NIGHT OF GLITTERING FIRSTS
description: TWO of the world's most acclaimed ballet dancers and the companies they direct shared the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last night in a rare performance on the second evening of Lincoln Center's 10-day ''France Salutes New York'' festival.

title: WHITMAN MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 'FESTIVAL LATINO' ADDS SHOWS AT THE DELACORTE
description: The Delacorte Theater, which has traditionally been a showcase for ''Shakespeare in the Park,'' will take on a Latin flavor this summer for the 1986 ''Festival Latino in New York,'' Joseph Papp said yesterday. The festival, which is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year, is a zarzuela of plays, films, dance and musical events from Latin America, the Caribbean, Spain and Italy. It will run from Aug. 6 to 31 at both the Public Theater downtown and, for the first time, much of the month of August at the Delacorte. Events at the Delacorte will be free.

title: 'Golden Land' to Close
description: ''The Golden Land,'' a musical created by Moishe Rosenfeld and Zalmen Mlotek, will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Second Avenue Theater. Directed by Jacques Levy, the musical will have run for 277 regular performances and 18 previews.

title: PRESIDENT READY FOR COMPROMISES ON TAX, AIDE SAYS
description: With the effort to overhaul the tax system approaching its critical weeks, President Reagan is willing to compromise on several key issues provided the Senate's proposed low tax rates are retained, his chief of staff said today.

title: PROTESTS ARE FEW
description: Kurt Waldheim was inaugurated today for a six-year term as Austria's President in a solemn session in Parliament, while artists and intellectuals staged mocking street protests against his elevation to the largely ceremonial post.

title: Boy George's Brother Arrested in Drug Raid
description: Narcotics officers arrested a brother of the pop singer Boy George and three other people today on charges of conspiracy to sell heroin, the police said.

title: Armco Will Take Charges in Quarter
description: Armco Inc., the steelmaker in Middletown, Ohio, has said that it would take special charges of $150 million in the second quarter because of the consolidation and divestment of several businesses.

title: Dillon (Curly) Russell, A Be-Bop Bass Player
description: The jazz bassist Dillon (Curly) Russell, a leading be-bop musician, died of emphysema last Thursday at Queens General Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Queens.

title: ROCHESTER'S WATER IS CONTAMINATED
description: City residents began boiling water, buying it in bottles or carrying it from the suburbs late Monday after health officials issued a warning of low-level bacterial contamination of the entire city water system.

title: HAMMERSTEIN MUSICALS FORM A LIVING LEGACY
description: Long after their long runs on Broadway, the musicals of Oscar Hammerstein 2d are still bustin' out all over - across the country and even in Europe - and the Hammerstein family is very much involved in keeping alive the lyricist's extremely popular legacy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Kuala Lumpur on Monday about hangings of two Australians in Malaysia for drug trafficking described the status of some narcotics trafficking cases incorrectly. While several citizens of Hong Kong have been sentenced to death by Malaysian courts, those sentences have not yet been carried out.

title: DUPONT, IN CAPITAL, PRESSES PRESIDENTIAL BID
description: Former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware, a Republican Presidential hopeful who was known as a moderate in his two terms, argued today that he was best qualified to extend and fulfill the conservative agenda begun by President Reagan.

title: Bridge: Strange Bid May Succeed By Confusing Opponents
description: Weird bidding sometimes permits weird play to succeed. The opponents are working with misleading information and are quite likely to go astray.

title: UNION IN GRIEVANCE AGAINST DRUG PLAN
description: The National Football League players union filed a grievance against the league's Management Council today, saying it would not allow Commissioner Pete Rozelle's new drug plan to be ''shoved down our throats.''

title: CHILE BURN CASE: ANGUISH AND ANGER
description: Leading opponents of the Pinochet Government and human rights activists stood vigil today around the closed coffin of a young man who met a fiery death when he came home to rediscover the land where he was born.

title: Threat Clears Texas Shelves
description: Stores here began removing about 100,000 containers of Accent brand flavor enhancer today after officials received an anonymous threat that six 4.5-ounce units had been poisoned with cyanide, the authorities said. No illnesses were reported and no cyanide was immediately found.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE BURGER ON CBS NEWS SPECIAL
description: WARREN E. BURGER, Chief Justice of the United States, can be seen tonight with Bill Moyers. Never before, apparently, has a Chief Justice been interviewed at such length, and never before, certainly, has a Chief Justice been interviewed in the Supreme Court in front of a television camera. That, however, is only a footnote; the question is, what does Chief Justice Burger say? In fact, he doesn't say much, and this, in a way, is reassuring.

title: KOCH SIGNS MEASURE REQUIRING LANDLORDS TO FILE INCOME DATA
description: Mayor Koch yesterday signed into law a bill requiring owners of commercial and residential property to file annual statements with the city of their property's income and expenses.

title: FILM: 'GIRL IN THE PICTURE'
description: ONE feels positively churlish in writing an unkind word about as good-natured and unassuming a work as ''The Girl in the Picture'' - but the word is boring. The movie, which opens today at Lincoln Plaza 3, is like a puppy whose only trick is to roll his eyes, turn over and wait to be scratched.

title: HESS TESTIFIES ON JETS' MOVE
description: Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, gave a detailed account in Federal District Court yesterday of why he did not return the Jets to New York City after he took them to Giants Stadium in New Jersey following the 1983 National Football League season.

title: SCHOOL PROJECT CUTS PREGNANCY RATES
description: CAN school programs that offer teen-agers comprehensive sex education, counseling and referrals for contraceptives stem the tide of adolescent pregnancies? Or do such programs only provoke greater sexual activity among the young?

title: TRAVELERS REALTY INCOME INESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There are no comparable 1985 6-month data because the trust commenced operations on March 28, 1985.

title: SALES SOFT, I.B.M. CUTS PC PRICES
description: A rapid erosion of the International Business Machines Corporation's lead in the personal computer market has forced company officials to take a series of urgent actions in recent weeks to restore I.B.M.'s position, computer retailers and industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Sanctions Can Work
description: The argument for tightening sanctions on South Africa is becoming irresistible, though little room is left for logic.

title: JOHN FORSYTHE, IN ABOUT-FACE, PLAYS HELPLESS MAN
description: ''This is my first acting job away from 'Dynasty' in six years,'' said John Forsythe of his new television movie, ''Fired,'' which is being filmed on his summer hiatus away from ''Dynasty'' and is scheduled to be broadcast on ABC in the fall.
