The film is a striking change of pace from his role as Blake Carrington, the urbane billionaire who engages in amorous and corporate intrigue every week on ABC's long-running soap opera.

title: Peat Marwick Settles Suit Brought by F.D.I.C.
description: Peat Marwick, Mitchell & Co., the Big Eight accounting firm, said yesterday that it had settled a $90 million lawsuit brought against it by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the collapse of the Penn Square Bank.

title: LAMBERT POHNER, A NATURALIST DEVOTED TO CENTRAL PARK BIRDS
description: Lambert Pohner, a naturalist who watched over the birds and butterflies of Central Park for more than 40 years, through every season, undaunted by snowstorms and heat waves, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results for all periods reported include Bank of Manchester, Manchester, Ga., and Bank of Coweta, Newnan, Ga., which were both acquired on June 30, 1986, and accounted for as poolings of interests.

title: SAFEWAY'S STOCK UP AFTER BID
description: Safeway Stores' stock soared $4.625 a share yesterday, to $58.25, in exceptionally heavy trading in reaction to the Dart Group Corporation's offer to buy the nation's No. 1 supermarket chain for $58 a share, or close to $3.6 billion in cash.

title: 2 Seized in Swedish Swindle
description: Police announced today the arrest of two Swedes suspected in the largest computer swindle in Swedish history - an attempt to bilk $7.4 million from SSP, an insurance company. The two denied the charges.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 10, 1986
description: Companies

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AWAY FROM FAST-FOOD JOINTS, SOME FIND A SPECIAL GETTYSBURG
description: A huffy, thick-set man with a hiking staff led a half-dozen youngsters across a field here, following the path that Maj. Gen. George E. Pickett took 123 years ago today in the famous, failed charge of 15,000 Confederate soldiers against the Union position on Cemetery Ridge.

title: A Woman's Home
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Bond Sale to Help Hospitals in Texas
description: From Houston, the Harris County Hospital District is tentatively offering about $195 million of revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 8.62 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS PLUS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that there are no comparative 1985 data because it did not commence operations until July 9, 1985, the date of its initial public offering.

title: Stop the Child Torture In South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress; The Elusive Quest for Clarity on the Contras
description: The Nicaraguan rebels, who won approval of their $100 million in aid by the House of Representatives last month, are not entirely off the hook with Congress. Legislators who oppose financing the rebels still have some options left for continuing the fight as the issue moves to the Senate.

title: KASHMIR SHAWLS ON DISPLAY IN CAPITAL
description: For more than 50 years, a rare collection of more than 100 woolen textiles from Kashmir was tucked away in a repository of priceless works at the Textile Museum here. The exquisitely designed shawls and other pieces had never been exhibited.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LEGACY OF LADYSMITH. By John Kenny Crane. 398 pages. Linden/ Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: MUSIC: TOM WAITS STARS IN 'FRANK'S WILD YEARS'
description: For well over a decade Tom Waits, now 37 years old, has been turning out rock albums that have won critical plaudits and a cult following but haven't sold in the millions. Yet he keeps getting them made, and in the meantime he's blossoming as a film actor and playwright.

title: THE PARIS OPERA BALLET SHOWS OFF A RISING STAR
description: The Paris Opera Ballet has returned to New York on a wave of excitement, with local critics describing the French dancers as ''sensational'' and ''simply amazing.'' But all the world loves a young rising star, and perhaps the greatest excitement has been reserved for Sylvie Guillem. At age 21, she is one of the Paris Opera's most talked-about etoiles, or leading dancers, and promises to be a highlight of this visit by the French company, which performs at the Metropolitan through July 19.

title: SANDINISTA FORCES ARE SAID TO TRIPLE STOCK OF COPTER
description: The Nicaraguan Air Force has tripled its stock of Soviet-made transport helicopters over the last two months, according to diplomats and military specialists here.

title: AT A CITY PROJECT, PRICE OF SURVIVAL IS VIGILANCE
description: Charlie was standing at the door, one hand on the knob, about to leave Apt. 6H at 178 Avenue D, one hand holding on to his younger brother, Geraldo.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sears Planning Public Offering
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it planned to make a public offering of 10 million common shares of its stock. The Chicago-based retailing and financial services company said the proceeds of the offering would be added to its general funds and would provide capital to expand its businesses, especially its financial services activities.

title: COURTS LIFTING HOPES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A South African court's decision to release a detained television soundman is being cited by some legal experts here as showing a growing readiness by some judges to challenge the Government's actions under the state of emergency.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Officer Resigns At Diamond Shamrock
description: J.L. Jackson, president, chief operating officer and a director of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, resigned yesterday in what appears to be further fallout from the company's restructuring.

title: Italian Cyclist Takes Tour Leg
description: Guido Bontempi of Italy won a sprint to the finish line today to capture the sixth leg of the Tour de France in 4 hours 47 minutes 1 second. Johan Van der Velde of the Netherlands, however, retained the overall lead.

title: Wang to Cut 1,600 Workers
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said today that it planned to cut its worldwide work force by 1,600 through early retirement and forced and voluntary layoffs. Wang said after the reductions it would employ about 30,000 workers worldwide.

title: 27 REPORTED HELD BY INDIAN CONTRAS
description: American-backed Indian guerrillas have kidnapped at least 27 people in refugee camps near here in the last six weeks, according to several witnesses who have lost relatives and friends.

title: SEAT BELT ALONE MAY POSE HAZARD
description: Back-seat passengers may be safer in some automobile accidents when they are not wearing a lap safety belt, a report by the staff of the National Transportation Safety board asserts.

title: ALABAMA DEMOCRATS STILL IN TURMOIL OVER PRIMARY RESULTS
description: Two weeks after the last vote was cast in a disputed runoff, Democrats are still looking for a nominee to succeed Gov. George C. Wallace and a way to end a feud that could put Republicans on Alabama's political map permanently.

title: UNIONIST HELD AFTER U.S. TOUR
description: A black South African labor leader was detained when he returned to Johannesburg yesterday after a tour of the United States in which he pressed the case against apartheid, according to reports reaching New York, London and Washington.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary yesterday of Adm. Hyman G. Rickover described his tenure in the Navy incorrectly. He had 63 years 6 months of service: 59 years 6 months as an officer and 4 years as a midshipman.

title: Philadelphia Seeking Court Order in Strike
description: The City of Philadelphia asked a court today to order some health and medical employees back to work as some talks resumed in the nine-day-old strike by 14,000 municipal workers.

title: CHILE POLICE SCATTER MOURNERS
description: Riot policemen firing tear gas and water cannon disrupted a funeral procession of 2,000 people today as they mourned a youth believed to have been burned to death by soldiers.

title: Briton Talks of Pretoria During Visit to Africa
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, arrived here today from Zambia on a mission on behalf of the European Community to try to set up talks on the unrest in South Africa.

title: 7 YEARS AFTER EMBASSY SEIZURE, IRAN STILL PRINTS U.S SECRETS
description: Seven years after Iranian student militants took over the United States Embassy in Teheran, the classified documents that the students found there continue to have implications for both sides.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Associated Electric and Gas Insurance Services Ltd., Jersey City, elected John A. Schoneman president and director, and Franklin D. Sanders president of Aegis Insurance Services Inc., its managing agent.

title: AID TO ZIMBABWE SUSPENDED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration has suspended disbursement of economic aid to Zimbabwe in response to sharp criticism leveled by a high Zimbabwean official at the United States Embassy's July 4 reception, State Department officials said today.

title: Key Officer Leaves Coke
description: Coca-Cola USA said today that its senior vice president for marketing, Sergio Zyman, who was involved in the highly successful ''Coke Is It'' campaign and the controversial introduction of new Coke, had resigned.

title: Europe Steel Accord Seen
description: European Community ministers reached a compromise today to resolve an internal dispute that had threatened a deal allowing higher community steel exports to the United States, diplomatic sources said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 2 about two investment bankers accused of insider trading incorrectly described the departure of one, Robert M. Wilkis, from E. F. Hutton. He resigned; he was not dismissed.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisitions of First Connecticut Bancorp and Merrill Bankshares Co. on a pooling of interests basis.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINAL REPORT OF ATTORNEY GENERAL'S PANEL ON PORNOGRAPHY
description: Following are excerpts from the final report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography: The Question of Harm Sexually Violent Material The category of material on which most of the evidence has focused is the category of material featuring actual or unmistakably simulated or unmistakably threatened violence presented in sexually explicit fashion with a predominant focus on the sexually explicit fashion with a predominant focus on the sexually explicit violence. Increasingly, the most prevalent forms of pornography, as well as an increasingly prevalent body of less sexually explicit material, fit this description.

title: Joyner Voted Star Starter
description: Wally Joyner of the California Angels was named yesterday the starting first baseman for the American League in the 57th All-Star Game, becoming the first rookie ever selected by the fans to start the game. Joyner, with 917,972 votes, edged Don Mattingly of the Yankees, who compiled 783,846.

title: South Korea's Failure Starts at the Top
description: To the Editor:

title: HAROLD R. ISAACS, 75, AUTHOR AND M.I.T. PROFESSOR EMERITUS
description: Harold R. Isaacs, an author and professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died in Boston yesterday from complications resulting from heart surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A CANDLE, AT 50, FOR ACCOMPLISHMENT
description: IT seems extremely odd to be 50. Somehow, I did not expect it. The idea of being 50 years old was linked in my imagination with such implausible events as disappearing on the way to the grocery store - things that never happen to me. Fifty seemed to be some place at the end of the earth, like Ceylon. But when I got to Ceylon, it felt like ''here.'' And now, 50 is ''here.'' Two-thirds along the way. A time - still time - to cast a cold eye ahead. This third of my life is for me. These are my final options.

title: Interstate Banking Bill Hits a Snag in California
description: A heralded agreement reached in February that would permit New York banks to enter California's vast consumer market is in serious danger of unraveling, according to bankers and state officials.

title: Wilkens to Cavaliers
description: Lenny Wilkens, who spent two seasons playing for the Cleveland Cavaliers in the 1970's, will be coaching the team next season. The 48-year-old Wilkens, who had been general manager of the Seattle SuperSonics, received a contract expected to pay him $750,000 over three years.

title: People
description: * Donald P. Martin has been appointed senior vice president, secretary/treasurer and chief financial officer of William Esty Company.

title: Ad Revenues Climb
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has released the estimates for April newspaper advertising revenue volume. The good news is that they were up 10.8 percent over April 1985, to $2.26 billion. Retail increased 11.8 percent, to $1.17 billion, national advertising was up 9.1 percent, to $294 million, and classified was up 10 percent, to $793 million.

title: GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1985 quarter and 6 months results included a nonrecurring pretax gain from the sale of contract servicing rights of $35,470,000, or 95 cents a share after tax.

title: Korey, Kay & Partners Wins Members Only
description: Korey, Kay & Partners has become agency for Members Only, whose men's and women's outerwear and sportswear were formerly advertised by Epstein, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit. Billings could exceed $3 million.

title: At Least 20 Are Killed In Philippine Typhoon
description: A typhoon battered densely populated Luzon Island today, causing floods in four northern provinces and landslides that killed at least 20 people, including two children, the authorities said.

title: SUMMARY OF THE MAJOR ACTIONS TAKEN BY THE NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN 1986
description: The 209th session of the Legislature ended its main session of 1986 at 6:30 P.M. on July 3, with many of the most important bills of the year not passed until the final 24 hours in a nightlong meeting.

title: Farewell to Ban on Work at Home?
description: There arefew more enduring images in Americana than that of a homemaker working at her knitting machine in a quiet room.

title: American Brands' Rise
description: Takeover speculation revived yesterday around American Brands Inc., causing the company's stock to rise sharply on heavy trading.

title: CORRECTION
description: The introduction to a chart in The Living Section yesterday, rating the makers of whole-wheat bread, incorrectly described products carried by the Briermere Farm shop. It sells only its own brand of bread.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about problems afflicting copper producers misstated the number of profitable ones. There were three; the Cyprus Minerals Company had a profitable first quarter and is expected to have a profitable year.

title: RE-INVENTING ORDINARY ACCESSORIES
description: DAVID WIENER, 28 years old, has skied professionally and raced Porsches.

title: At Orchard Beach, Updated Fare
description: Age has not been kind to Orchard Beach, once called ''the Riviera of the Bronx,'' which will be 50 years old this month.

title: Ah, Texas and Journalism
description: Journalists and political operatives alike in Washington and Dallas are convinced that Bob Mann, a devout Texan who is Senator Edward M. Kennedy's press secretary, will soon be appointed editor of The Dallas Times Herald. Mr. Mann is a close and longtime friend of William Dean Singleton, the 34-year-old fellow Texan who recently purchased The Times Herald from the Times-Mirror Company of Los Angeles.

title: Dow Jones Lifts Profit
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 10.2 percent, to $42 million, or 43 cents a share, from $38.1 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: JOB FOR AUSTRIA: HOW TO BURY WALDHEIM ISSUE
description: Acknowledging that long-term damage has been done to the country's image abroad, Austria's main political actors have signaled a willingness to bury the controversy over President Kurt Waldheim's war record and moral character. At his inauguration

title: CANADIAN, IN 9.95, TAKES 100 METERS
description: Ben Johnson of Canada ran the second-fastest 100-meter dash in history tonight, a time of 9.95 seconds, and Edwin Moses extended his 400-meter hurdle victory streak to 96 finals with a time of 47.94 as the track and field portion of the Goodwill Games came to an end.

title: IRONWARE, BY HAND
description: HAND-FORGED iron hardware, typical rustic handwork of the 17th, 18th and early 19th centuries, is being made today by blacksmiths around the country. Reproductions of period hinges, latches, bolts and shutter hardware are particularly popular with people restoring or building Colonial-style homes.

title: THE RIGHT STYLE WAS IN THE MIX
description: FROM the outside, the house is an unremarkable series of low wood-and-glass boxes nestled against the tall trees at the edge of a majestic sweep of lawn. Sleek and modern, it might easily reveal a minimalist spareness. Inside, however, the mood is eclectic and fanciful, and one is transported to another time and place - one that never really existed, but that uses as its referent the turn of the century, a wealthy and eccentric family, and the accretions of several generations in a most unusual household.

title: 2 POWERS AGREE TO DISCUSS WAYS TO VERIFY A-TESTS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle to discuss problems of verifying the underground testing of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a first-quarter after-tax gain of $31,358,000, or 32 cents a share, from the sale of 2 million shares of Continental Cablevision Inc. common stock; excluding the gain, earnings for the period were $72,408,000, or 75 cents a share. Earnings per share have been restated to reflect the issuance of a 50- percent dividend in the form of Class B common stock; the new shares were distributed June 30 to stockholders of record June 9.

title: Royal Optimist
description: Frank White of the Royals, after a 13-inning loss to Baltimore ran their losing streak to 11 games: ''Things are starting to look a little brighter. We held them to a tie for the first nine innings.''

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
19 INJURED IN MELEE AT PRISON
description: Guards and inmates of the state prison at Dannemora clashed on Tuesday, leaving 11 guards and 8 prisoners injured.

title: Key Grade of U.S. Oil Falls Below $11 a Barrel
description: With bearish sentiment continuing to dominate the world oil market, the price of West Texas Intermediate crude, the principal American grade, fell below the $11-a-barrel level yesterday for the first time in two months.

title: South Carolina Agency In $345 Million Offering
description: The Piedmont Municipal Power Agency of South Carolina, in a $345 million refunding, is offering electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.04 percent for an issue due in 2023, through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: U.S. COURT DISMISSES FRENCH SUIT OVER THE DISCOVERY OF AIDS VIRUS
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a suit filed by the Pasteur Institute in Paris against the United States Government in which it sought recognition as the discoverer of the virus that causes AIDS.

title: THE DIPPER TURNS FIFTY
description: The two lengthy gentlemen met for the first time yesterday morning. Patrick Ewing in white T-shirt, blue shorts and basketball shoes, Wilt Chamberlain in white T-shirt, black stretch pants and beach clogs, shook hands.

title: Market Place; Railway Issues Divide Experts
description: FOLLOWING a stellar performance in 1985, railroad stocks have trailed the general equity market so far this year. And Wall Street analysts, peering down the line, are divided on prospects for individual carriers.

title: North Carolina Sets Refunding
description: North Carolina, which had not issued any general obligation debt securities since April 1983, is offering $460 million of public improvement and highway refunding bonds, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: 'COMRADES' SHOWS LIFE IN SIBERIA
description: THE Soviet East is the American West with huskies instead of horses, sables instead of cattle. A peek at the Soviet East, vanishing, like the American West, under the demands of modern times, is afforded American viewers tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: McLAUGHLIN'S LAWYERS QUESTION MAYTAG HEIRESS
description: Lawyers for John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, sought to demonstrate yesterday that, far from stealing from a washing-machine company heiress, Mr. McLaughlin saved her a lot of money and provided many legal services without compensation.

title: BOMB IN PARIS RIPS OFFICES OF POLICE
description: A powerful bomb ripped through an annex of Paris police headquarters here today, killing a police inspector and wounding at least 22 people, 3 seriously.

title: ATHENS TO CUT LIBYAN MISSION
description: The Greek Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, after several months of pro-Libyan statements, says the number of Libyan diplomats here is being significantly reduced.

title: Squibb to Spin Off Medical Systems
description: The Squibb Corporation, a major producer of pharmaceuticals, said it would spin off its medical systems business to shareholders. Squibb's medical systems business had 1985 sales of $200 million.

title: WHAT THE POLICE SAY ABOUT LOCKS
description: AT a time when security consultants talk about infrared motion-detection systems, microwave transmitters and peephole video cameras, police and locksmiths say the best protection against burglars is often just a strong door and dead-bolt locks.

title: White House Water Cut Off Temporarily
description: The water supply to the residential rooms of the White House was cut off today after an alarm indicated the water had no chlorine in it, but President Reagan got his morning coffee anyway, using bottled water.

title: Bridge: Player's Mental Metronome Should Be Shut Off at Times
description: One of the oddities of bridge ethics is the need for a part-time mental metronome.

title: AMID PRAISE, A COMPLAINT
description: Mayor Koch is unhappy about the credit he got, or did not get, during Liberty Weekend, he said yesterday.

title: Murphy Streak Ends
description: For the first time since Sept. 25, 1981, Dale Murphy of the Atlanta Braves watched a ball game yesterday and ended the longest consecutive-game playing streak among active players at 740. Manager Chuck Tanner said he and Murphy met Tuesday and decided the mental pressure of maintaining the streak was hurting the player.

title: Suicide, Pregnancy and Spending for Public Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: MANAGEMENT SHIFTS ARE BEGUN AT USX
description: The newly named USX Corporation, formerly United States Steel, has a new management lineup with the division of the company this week into four operating units - two in energy, one in steel and one in diversified products.

title: Amstar Is Placed On Auction Block
description: The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, is up for sale.

title: ROYALS TOP ORIOLES, ENDING SLIDE AT 11
description: The Kansas City Royals snapped a club-record 11-game losing streak tonight, blanking the Baltimore Orioles, 3-0, as Danny Jackson teamed with Bud Black on a three-hitter.

title: Heroic Officer
description: In two weeks last year, Detective Paul Ragonese risked his life three times to protect others.

title: JAZZ: O'DAY AND CONNOR
description: THE unprecedented joint appearance of Anita O'Day and Chris Connor at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where they will be singing through July 26, is more than just a nostalgic recall of the big band era in which they both played prominent roles. Their lives have run somewhat parallel courses. Each of them sang with Stan Kenton's orchestra and went on to solo careers during which they developed large and loyal followings despite personal problems and illnesses.

title: Communicom Plan
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved the reorganization plan of Communicom, clearing the way for a proposed $70 million sale of the cable system. The plan would turn over control of Communicom, which has franchises in southern California, to two banks owed $110 million. The banks then would get the proceeds of the proposed sale to the American Cablesystems Corporation.

title: Mine Roof Collapse Kills 3 in Illinois
description: A roof collapsed deep within a southern Illinois coal mine today, killing three men, including a father and son, officials said. It was the second fatal accident at the mine in three weeks.

title: G.E. Rail Car Makes Purchase
description: The General Electric Rail Car Services Corporation, one of the nation's largest rail car leasing companies, said it had completed the purchase of the rail car and the repair facility assets of the North American Car Corporation for about $420 million in cash. G.E. Rail Car, a subsidiary of the General Electric Credit Corporation, said the assets include about 35,000 rail cars and 14 repair facilities in the United States and Canada.

title: FINANCIAL TIMES PLANNING MOVE TO MODERN PLANT
description: The Financial Times today announced an $84 million plan to adopt modern printing technology and move to a new plant east of London. Britain's leading business daily, with a circulation of 250,000, thus joins the migration of major newspapers away from Fleet Street, London's historic newspaper district, to cut costs.

title: ROCK: THE CURE AT PIER 84
description: THE CURE is one of rock's most singleminded bands, dedicated to nightmare surrealism and unremitting despair. It played a sold-out concert Tuesday at Pier 84, bringing bleak, private emotions into a public arena.

title: OPEN TO McGINNIS
description: Tom McGinnis, a former PGA Tour player who is now the assistant pro at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, shot a five-under-par 66 today to win the New York State Open by five strokes.

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HIGH COURT'S 1985-86 TERM: MIXED RESULTS FOR PRESIDENT
description: In the Supreme Court term that ended Monday, President Reagan won a significant reaffirmation of Presidential primacy in executing the laws, but he suffered a series of major defeats on issues at the heart of his social agenda.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I was married, my husband used to tell me I had ''natural good looks,'' which, I see now, might have meant (a) I didn't use enough eye shadow, or (b) he wasn't prepared to spend much of his money on how I looked. Indeed, in my youth, no one would have tagged me as a natty dresser. In academic life you need Brooks Brothers shirts and tweed skirts; the rest is vanity.

title: 9-DAY OUTING TESTS STAMINA ON WHEELS
description: If you have a yen to test your stamina on an extended bicycling excursion, you may want to enter a 630-mile trip July 26-Aug. 3 through a portion of New York State.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEASTLY TIMES - With the temporary closing of the Central Park Zoo - not counting the Children's Zoo - there are few creatures, other than dogs, cats and people, that have Fifth Avenue addresses. There is, however, a very special group of fauna that has taken up summer residence on the second floor of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street (369-4880).

title: FUND, C.D. YIELDS FALL
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were lower for the week ended yesterday.

title: RETARDED ADULTS TEST AUTONOMY
description: ALAN COHEN, 34 years old, had a hard time moving away from home after he graduated from high school. ''I was worried that my parents would worry about me all the time,'' he said, ''They knew they had a mentally retarded son. They thought I might get hurt.''

title: Mother Teresa Cuba Mission
description: Mother Teresa, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has persuaded Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, to allow the Missionary Sisters of Charity, her order of nuns, to establish a mission. She announced the news at a packed church in the suburb of Regla on Tuesday night. She had made an unscheduled meeting with Mr. Castro, who is trying to improve his Government's relations with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: CONSENSUS ON KEY PARTS OF TAX BILL
description: Even before House and Senate tax writers sit down next week to negotiate a sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax system, a consensus on major elements of the final bill has already emerged among Congressional leaders and the White House.

title: MUSIC: LEE ERWIN SCORE FOR SILENT 'HUNCHBACK'
description: THE renowned theater organist Lee Erwin, who enjoyed a 30-year career on radio and television, has devoted himself for the last 19 years to composing, performing and recording organ music to accompany silent-film classics. Mr. Erwin has written brand-new scores for some 70 silent movies, including all the films of Buster Keaton, Charlie Chaplin and D. W. Griffith, among others. Six years ago he toured the United States with the ''Silent Clowns'' festival. And on Tuesday evening, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, he performed his score for the 1923 silent-film version of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' on the cathedral's booming pipe organ, as the movie was shown.

title: WASHINGTON BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAEL DENIES SMUGGLING CLUSTER BOMB TECHNOLOGY
description: Israel's Ministry of Defense today denied accusations that Israel had smuggled in secret American technology to manufacture cluster bombs.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net income from discontinued operations of $10,598,000 and $11,822,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Treasury Bonds in Rebound
description: The credit markets did an about-face yesterday, with prices of Treasury securities rising enough to more than offset Tuesday's declines.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gord Lane, the former Islander defenseman, has agreed to come out of retirement and accept a position as player-assistant coach of the Springfield Indians, an Islander affiliate in the American Hockey League. Lane, 33 years old, retired after the 1984-85 season and was head coach of the Brandon Wheat Kings in the Western Hockey League last season. . . . St. Peter's College in Jersey City is expected to announce today that its new head basketball coach will be Teddy Fiore, an assistant coach for the last five seasons.

title: On Arab 'McCarthyism'
description: In general, Arab-American organizations in the United States have tended to to keep a relatively low political profile, working through lobbyists and representatives rather than seeking direct confrontation. One reason, says James J. Zogby, director of the Washington-based Arab American Institute, is what he terms a ''new McCarthyism'' aimed at Arab-American political activity.

title: 22 People Are Killed In Sri Lanka Violence
description: Attacks by Tamil separatists on three trucks carrying passengers, and a retaliatory attack against a Tamil family, killed 22 people today, according to the police and residents of Trincomalee district.

title: British Steel Reports Profit
description: A streamlined British Steel Corporation, the state-owned operation that had losses measured in the billions of pounds earlier in the decade, has reported its first annual profit in 11 years.

title: The Sandinista Road to Stalinism
description: The Sandinistas ask us to believe that Congress's full support for the Nicaraguan ''contras'' is forcing them to crack down further on free thought and speech. We don't believe it. The depredations of that C.I.A.-sponsored army neither justify nor explain the totalitarian trend in Managua.

title: 2 British Soldiers Killed By Booby Trap in Ulster
description: A booby-trapped truck exploded tonight near the border with the Irish Republic while four British soldiers were inspecting it, killing two and seriously wounding the others.

title: Report on Bias
description: The assistant Maryland state medical examiner said yesterday that Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball player, died after apparently smoking a pure form of cocaine free-base, rather than from inhaling the drug in powder form, as originally stated. Redness in the lining of Bias's windpipe, caused by the inhalation of heat, and unusual congestion in the throat, indicated Bias had smoked the drug, Dr. Dennis F. Smyth, the assistant medical examiner, said.

title: A FAMILY GATHERS TO CELEBRATE ITS ORIGINS
description: More than 300 people were atop the windy hill beside the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church here Sunday, gathered to celebrate the centennial of the congregation organized by Audubon's Norwegian settlers in 1886, the year the Statue of Liberty was dedicated in New York harbor.

title: Advertising; A Judge's Reflections On Cannes
description: STEPHEN O. FRANKFURT is completely captivated by the John Hancock Insurance commercials that recently won the Grand Prix at the Cannes International Advertising Awards Film Festival for Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY POLICY STANDS ON CLUSTER WEAPON EXPORTS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had a standing policy against allowing the export of any equipment, plans or techniques to Israel that could be used for cluster weapons.

title: Hundreds Lived to Tell of Custer's Defeat
description: To the Editor:

title: New at Vista
description: Volunteers in Service to America, the Federal program better known as Vista, has a new director.

title: Copper Workers Vote To Accept Concessions
description: Workers in five states have voted 3 to 1 to accept a contract offer from the Kennecott Copper Corporation that cuts wages and benefits by 23 percent, it was announced today.

title: No Japanese Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL STREET MINIMIZES 'WITCHING HOUR' PERIL
description: For all the uproar over the ''triple witching hour,'' a group of financial leaders today expressed little interest in doing away with the phenomenon.

title: Ex-Des Moines Editor Joins Editorial Board of The Times
description: Geneva Overholser, most recently the deputy editorial page editor of The Des Moines Register, has been appointed to the editorial board of The New York Times. Her appointment was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IP TIMBERLANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that it commenced operations on March 14, 1985; therefore, comparative figures for the first half of 1985 do not exist.

title: J.P. Martin Job
description: J.P. Martin, a black-owned agency, has been named by Golden Ribbon Playthings for the national introduction of the Huggy Bean, a line of dolls that it says is the first line of black ''character'' dolls to be marketed nationally. There was no previous agency.

title: The Glimmer in Moscow's Arms Proposals
description: There have of late been a number of intriguing shifts in the Soviet Union's position on arms control. Some of these changes were incorporated in the letter Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent to Ronald Reagan last month. Others were presented by the Soviet delegation at the bargaining table in Geneva during the round of talks that concluded some two weeks ago. Washington ought to consider the new proposals with a mix of open-mindedness and caution. Its response could have a profound impact on the future not only of arms control but of superpower relations in general.

title: BOMB THREAT SHUTS BUS TERMINAL FOR 4 HOURS
description: More than 25,000 rush-hour commuters were stranded for up to four hours at the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue yesterday evening as the police waited for the bomb squad to arrive and investigate a black attache case feared to contain a bomb.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The United Nations Development Corporation, responsible for developing hotel, office and residential facilities to be used by the United Nation and affiliated organizations, is tentatively offering about $128 million of senior and junior lien refunding bonds, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Argo Petroleum Corp., Santa Monica, Calif., said a reorganization was essential to the company's survival. The company also said that its secured lender, Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Co., had accelerated all of Argo's $38.8 million of outstanding debt.

title: CORDERO TO RETURN WITH A NEW MOUNT
description: Angel Cordero Jr., sidelined since suffering multiple injuries in a spill March 8, had been scheduled to make his return Sunday aboard Sunny Leader in the Tremont Stakes for 2-year-olds at Belmont Park. Cordero is coming along fine, but Sunny Leader has suffered a setback. Cordero will return as scheduled, but aboard a different colt in the same race.

title: Technology; Doing Business By Computer
description: IT would be almost unthinkable nowadays for a business not to have a telephone to communicate with customers and suppliers. In the future, it may be almost as unthinkable for a business not to have a computer for the same purposes.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ATLANTA BRAVES, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: TWO MAJOR TOWER PROJECTS ADVANCE
description: The city's Planning Commission yesterday approved two major projects -a twin-towered addition to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and a 43-story Citicorp building that would be the largest office building in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: ISLAND OF COEXISTENCE ENDURES ON DIVIDED CYPRUS
description: On Cyprus, Pyla is a reminder of how things used to be.

title: PANEL CALLS ON CITIZENS TO WAGE NATIONAL ASSAULT ON PORNOGRAPHY
description: A Federal advisory commission delivered a report today calling for a national assault on the pornography industry through a combination of more vigorous law enforcement and increased vigilance by citizens' groups.

title: McRae Update
description: Last March 13, for a spring-camp game against Philadelphia, Manager Dick Howser penciled Brian McRae's name into the Kansas City Royals' starting lineup, making 18-year-old Brian and 39-year-old Hal the first father-son combination in major league history to play with the same team. So how's the youngster doing? After 19 games at second base and in the leadoff spot for Eugene, Ore., of the Class A Northwest League, he's hitting .259, with 23 runs scored and 10 driven in.

title: WHO DID STUDY
description: These are the members of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography: Henry E. Hudson, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, chairman. Judith V. Becker, associate professor of clinical psychology in psychiatry at Columbia University's College of Physicans and Surgeons.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in September 1985.

title: MUSIC: CITY OPERA PERFORMS 'KISMET'
description: ON Tuesday night, ''Kismet'' took over the stage of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center for the week, and exotic is the word for it. Indeed, there's so much color and swirling design per square inch in this New York City Opera production that one would need several pairs of eyes to absorb it all completely.

title: BRUSQUE AND POWERFUL, FINK IS SOON TO LEAVE AN ALBANY HE HELPED CHANGE
description: It has been less than a week since Stanley Fink gaveled to a close the main part of this year's legislative session, his last as Assembly Speaker. But already the talk here is of ''the Fink legacy'' and of how much he changed the way state government operates.

title: THE ROYAL COURT REDUX
description: The English call it a ''promenade'' production, far too genteel a term to describe Jim Cartwright's first play, ''Road'' (at the Royal Court Theater). In America, we would use the word ''environmental,'' but this is not a series of performance art tableaux. It is an active experience in which theatergoers join actors in exploring a microcosmic stretch of Margaret Thatcher's Britain, in this case, a small Lancashire town facing hard times in the 1980's, a period, says one character, when ''every single thing's a disappointment.'' For all the despair, Mr. Cartwright's play is vibrant with the sounds, slang and humor of today. Imagine a cross between ''Under Milk Wood'' and ''Balm in Gilead,'' and you will have an idea of the flavor of this compelling play.

title: OFFICIAL DEMOTED FOR ACTIONS AGAINST CITY 'WHISTLE BLOWER'
description: A deputy commissioner in the city's Department of Environmental Protection was demoted yesterday and given an $11,000-a-year pay cut for retaliating against a subordinate who reported allegations of corruption in the construction of the city's new water tunnel.

title: Times Mirror To Sell Stations
description: The Times Mirror Company, which has agreed to acquire the company that publishes The Sun and The Evening Sun of Baltimore for $600 million, said it would sell WMAR-TV in Baltimore and WRLH-TV in Richmond to the Gillette Group Inc. for more than $200 million.

title: Woman, 24, Slain On Subway Stairs
description: A woman who worked as a stenographer in the Manhattan District Attorney's office was shot and killed yesterday morning as she was entering a Bronx subway station on her way to work, the police said.

title: Birth Trauma Is Found Minor Factor in Palsy
description: Researchers reported today that trauma occurring in labor and birth did not appear to be a major cause of cerebral palsy. These findings could protect obstetricians from some malpractice charges.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 10, 1986
description: International

title: Chiat/Day Plans Aid For Italian Car Maker
description: Less than a month ago Grace & Rothschild announced that it would be the agency for the United States introduction of BL's Land-Rover and Range-Rover, a vehicle that would fill the niche of a four-wheel-drive vehicle for the affluent.

title: FEDERAL PANEL CALLS FOR IMPROVED AIDS TEST
description: A panel of experts convened by Federal health agencies said today that it was essential to develop more sensitive and accurate screening tests to protect the nation's blood supply from AIDS.

title: Two Motives Are Cited In the Slaying of Officer
description: Investigators are checking if an off-duty transit police officer was shot to death in Queens last Saturday because he had recently intervened on a friend's behalf in a dispute with a drug dealer, a law-enforcement source said yesterday.

title: OXIE REICHLER
description: Oxie Reichler, editor emeritus of The Yonkers Herald Statesman, died Monday at Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Port Jefferson Station.

title: Chromalloy Bid From Sun
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation yesterday offered to acquire the 56 percent of the Chromalloy American Corporation that it does not already own in a stock swap valued at about $267 million.

title: Pharmacia Deal
description: Pharmacia A.B., one of Sweden's largest pharmaceutical companies, has acquired A.B. Leo, another Swedish pharmaceutical concern that specializes in cancer care products, for $430 million in cash and stock.

title: HERMAN MILLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Fiscal 1986 share earnings reflect the adoption of SFAS 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions, effective June 2, 1985.

title: Star Wars' Bastard Brother
description: Star Wars, President Reagan's idiosyncratic missile defense program, has some oddly matched fans and foes. The leading believers, after Mr. Reagan, seem to be the Russians.

title: BOB FELLER TAKES A STAND
description: Fortunately for Bob Feller, his career as a pitcher for the Cleveland Indians did not last long enough for him to have to look down the barrel of the 1961 Yankee lineup. Unfortunately, he did not remain in the major leagues long enough to have the opportunity to meet the 1962 Mets. His Hall-of-Fame career does not coincide with the themes of the old-timers' games that will take place in Flushing this Saturday and the Bronx a week from then.

title: HIGH-TECH RESEARCH DIRECTOR AND DRIVER SLAIN BY BOMB IN BAVARIA
description: Terrorists using a remote-control bomb killed the research director of West Germany's largest electronics company and his driver today.

title: THE ECONOMIST RACES AHEAD
description: More than a century ago The Economist gained a reputation under its famed editor, Walter Bagehot, for presenting a weekly overview of business and international affairs with a mixture of analysis, opinion and irreverence that was unabashedly elitist. Its editorial formula has scarcely changed.

title: REDS SWEEP METS BY ROUTING GOODEN
description: The Mets took an 11-1 beating from the Cincinnati Reds yesterday in Shea Stadium and were swept in a three-game series for the first time in a year. And later everybody walked through the debris now littering storybook season and asked why.

title: ABC PLANS A LIBERTY VIDEO CASSETTE
description: ABC, which paid $10 million for exclusive rights to televise the four-day Liberty Weekend festivities, said yesterday that it is planning to market a video cassette containing highlights of the celebration. The cassette will be available in video stores in about three weeks.

title: For Austria, Waldheim Election Wasn't a Referendum on Nazism
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE TEXT IS UNDER FIRE ONCE AGAIN
description: A Japanese history textbook that emphasizes the country's Imperial tradition and gives scant attention to its wartime aggression has ruffled Japan's relations with its Asian neighbors, especially China.

title: Medicus Intercon
description: Medicus Intercon, the health-care advertising subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, has got some more business from its client Miles Laboratories of West Haven, Conn. They are for a new product, ciprofloxacin, which is an oral antibacterial agent, and also for the Hollister-Stier division, formerly served by Carrafiello Diehl & Associates.

title: RESTAURANTEUR SERVED FRENCH ELITE
description: Marie-Louise Point, owner of La Pyramide, the oldest three-star restaurant in France, died Saturday at her home in Vienne. She was 87 years old.

title: PRETORIA TO DROP BAN ON UNION MEETINGS
description: The South African Government said today that an order barring indoor meetings in the Johannesburg area was incorrectly formulated and and would be amended to exclude labor unions.

title: IRVING LEVINSON
description: Irving Levinson, president of SBS Graphics, a printing company in Manhattan, died Tuesday at his home in White Plains. He was 74 years old.

title: JERSEY STILL HAS NO PLACE TO DUMP RADON-TAINTED DIRT DUG IN ESSEX
description: Nevada and Washington State don't want it. Orange County and Rockland County don't want it. Neither do West Orange or Vernon, N.J. And so, with a judge throwing another legal block in their way, New Jersey officials are still stuck with enough dirt - contaminated by radon from an old clock factory - to cover a football field to a height of 5 feet, 5 inches.

title: USA Cinemas to Grow
description: USA Cinemas, the nation's 15th-largest theater operator, said today that it planned to expand after its acquisition by Boston Ventures Limited Partnership was completed in the fall.

title: Ad Pages on Rise
description: The Publishers Information Bureau reports that in May its member publications (most of the country's important magazines) collectively carried 13,681 pages of advertising, a 1.2 percent increase from May 1985, while ad revenues for the period were up 6.9 percent, to $470.7 million.

title: HOSPITAL OUTLINES CARE OF SLASHING SUSPECT
description: A sword-wielding Cuban refugee who is accused of killing two people and wounding nine others on a Staten Island ferryboat Monday had been ''thoroughly evaluated and actively treated'' before being released two days earlier from Presbyterian Hospital, an official there said yesterday.

title: 3 STORMS AND 6 DAYS LATE
description: The party was already over. The multitudes had gone home. Maybe there were a few foam rubber diadems left in town, but that was about it.

title: BRADLEY PURSUING GRAND SLAM
description: Pat Bradley, the only golfer to have a victory in each of the four women's major tournaments, will continue her quest for a triumph in all four of the majors in a single year when she and 152 other women tee off Thursday in the 41st annual United States Women's Open championship at the NCR Country Club.

title: FIRST UNITED BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wells Fargo Wins Appeal
description: Wells Fargo Bank said today that a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit would allow the bank to continue offering mutual funds to Individual Retirement Account customers.

title: A Rage To Judge
description: It is midnight in a posh Atlanta suburb. Joan and Tom Doe are in bed.

title: TRAVELERS REAL ESTATE INESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEIGHBORS WATCH FOR CRIMINAL ACTIVITY
description: ABOUT a year ago, Donald and Dale Sack decided they wanted to do something about the drug dealers who were selling marijuana near their East 68th Street apartment.

title: DANCE: FRENCH-AMERICAN GALA AT MET
description: LIBERTY, Equality and Fraternity, with an acute accent on the latter, were scattered all over the Metropolitan Opera House stage Tuesday night as the Paris Opera Ballet and the American Ballet Theater joined forces for one of the most surprisingly successful gala benefits the dance world has seen in years.

title: PATIENTS' LAWYER STABBED ON CREEDMOOR GROUNDS
description: A Legal Services lawyer for mental patients was stabbed in the chest and stomach yesterday after he gave a man a ride in his car on the grounds of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village, the police said.

title: U.S. Seeks More From Texas Air
description: The Department of Transportation today requested further concessions from the Texas Air Corporation as a condition of approving its proposed acquisition of Eastern Air Lines Inc.

title: Panhandle Rejects $2.2 Billion Bid
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, one of the nation's leading natural gas companies, rejected a $2.2 billion takeover bid, but traders nevertheless bid up the price of Panhandle stock by $1.25 yesterday, to $48.50 a share, in heavy trading.

title: WHITSON TRADED FOR STODDARD
description: Ed Whitson's brief and stormy career with the Yankees - a career marked by poor pitching performances, constant jeering by fans in the Bronx and reported threats to his life - finally ended today when he was traded to the San Diego Padres for Tim Stoddard, a relief pitcher.

title: USE OF LIBERTY FUNDS SPURS DISPUTE
description: Although the final cost of Liberty Weekend may not be known for several weeks, a disagreement has arisen between Secretary of the Interior Donald P. Hodel and Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, over who would pay for a deficit if there is one.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect that on May 28, 1986, the company declared a 2-for-1 stock split to be effected in the form of a 100-percent stock dividend payable July 15, 1986, to shareholders of record as of June 30, 1986.

title: Answer:
description: The men pictured on the front page are Benjamin F. Baer, chairman of the Federal Parole Commission; the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WEEDS RAMPANT: THE BATTLE IS JOINED
description: THE Gardener's Eye will not tolerate weeds. The fact defines both person and plant: a gardener is one who is bothered by weeds; a weed is a plant that bothers gardeners.

title: YEARS OF NO-STRINGS CREATIVITY ENDING FOR FIRST 'GENIUS' GROUP
description: For each of the past 60 months, a $4,000 check arrived regularly for Derek Walcott, a poet-playwright chosen in 1981 to be one of the first recipients of a MacArthur Foundation five-year fellowship.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
UNION SEEKS DRUG-PLAN DELAY
description: Representatives of National Football League owners and players took actions yesterday in the dispute over Commissioner Pete Rozelle's new anti-drug program.

title: U.S. EXPECTED TO ACT TO BAR BOOK PROFITS FOR SPIES
description: Justice Department officials say the department will ask Congress to include espionage in an existing Federal law that bars people convicted of Federal crimes from profiting from the sale of their stories.

title: Tichenor Acquisition
description: Tichenor Media System, seeking to expand its presence in the Spanish radio market, said today that it had agreed in principle to a $20 million acquisition of New York radio station WADO from Command Broadcast Associates Inc.

title: SANCTIONS HURT BLACKS WORST, THATCHER SAYS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she thought it would be ''immoral'' and ''utterly repugnant'' for well-off Western nations to impose sanctions on South Africa that would throw poor Africans out of work.

title: JACK TOAL
description: Jack Toal, former president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade and chairman of the Health and Welfare Fund of the Taxicab Industry Benefit Funds, was killed last Friday in an automobile accident on the Hutchinson River Parkway. He was 48 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Damage at $4.5 Million In California Quake
description: Aftershocks subsided today from an earthquake that left at least $4.5 million in damage in southern California, officials said.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for 12wks to June 20
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for 5-for- 1 stock split paid June 20.

title: Specialist on Buyouts Is Hired by Shearson
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers announced yesterday that it had hired Daniel J. Good, a well-known investment banker, who has been head of mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts at E.F. Hutton.

title: SECURING THE HOME
description: RAY JOHNSON started breaking into houses when he was 11 or 12 years old - he is not certain of the year - and decided to quit after spending 25 years in prison on burglary and robbery convictions.

title: REPORT DRAWS STRONG PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: Reaction to the final report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography today, linking pornography to criminal behavior, ranged from condemnation to commendation.

title: WOODS ENLIVEN 'ROOM' IN EAST HAMPTON
description: It is rare that a craftsman is given the chance to design an entire room for an exhibition. But for ''The Room'' at the Pritam & Eames Gallery in East Hampton, David Ebner, a Bellport, L. I., furniture maker, was asked to design and produce chairs, tables and accessories, even the door and the mantel.

title: Cruise Control
description: What, the Mets worry? If they should play just .500 ball the rest of the way, here's what each of the other clubs in the division would have to do to catch them*:

title: LAURELS, AND NOSTALGIA, FOR A GERMAN SOCIALIST
description: It has been three years since Herbert Wehner laid down his mandate as a member of the Bundestag, where he had served since its inception in 1949. Since then, it has grown quiet around the grand old man of the West German Parliament, who had been termed an oratorical ''volcano'' and ''a boulder in the desert of German politics.''

title: FORMER NAVY RADIOMAN SOLD SECRETS, HIS LAWYER ADMITS
description: The lawyer for Jerry A. Whitworth admitted today that the former Navy radioman had sold communications secrets to John A. Walker Jr. but said Mr. Whitworth was unaware that Mr. Walker was working for the Soviet Union.

title: CALENDAR: A DESIGN FOR COLISEUM SITE
description: Coliseum Panel Discussion, Donnell Library Auditorium, 20 West 53d Street; 212-753-1722.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What is moral about deliberately and willfully depriving many black people - and whites and coloreds and Indians - of the living they are honestly gaining when most of the moderates are not asking for that and hoping to goodness it will not come about?'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, opposing imposition of

title: LOCKHEED SET TO BUY SANDERS
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Sanders Associates Inc., a military electronics company, for $60 a share in cash, or a total of $1.2 billion.

title: Swan Song For Sobriquets
description: When the San Francisco Giants signed Steve Carlton last week, they prolonged not only the career of a great pitcher but a dying baseball tradition as well. Carlton is the last of more than 150 major-leaguers who have played under the nickname Lefty.

title: Cahners Publishing Buying American Baby
description: The Cahners Publishing Company, the British-owned, Newton, Mass., publisher of trade publications, is planning to move out of that confine with the acquisition of the privately held American Baby Inc., whose best-known property is a monthly magazine of that name with a circulation of one million.

title: Scientific American
description: Robert Maxwell, chairman of Pergamon Press Ltd., said yesterday in London that he had abandoned his attempt to acquire Scientific American Inc., publisher of the scholarly monthly magazine. Scientific American rejected Pergamon's $61 million offer on Monday and reaffirmed its intent to accept a $52.6 million offer from a West German publishing concern, Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck of Stuttgart. Mr. Maxwell said his bid was opposed because he planned to oust management, while the West German company planned to retain management.

title: THOUSANDS FLEE FUMES A 2d TIME
description: A derailed railroad tank car that had been spewing toxic fumes since Tuesday exploded tonight, forcing new evacuations and causing more injuries in the path of the fumes, the authorities said.

title: Dow, Halting Slide, Rises by 5.34
description: After two days of heavy losses for Wall Street, stock prices inched higher yesterday even though volume tailed off and investors seemed most interested in speculative issues.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have dark wood paneling that I would like to make lighter, but I don't want to use a wallpaper over it. Is there any kind of paint that I can apply? A. You can apply almost any kind of paint, providing you properly prepare the surface. First, remove all wax or polish on the finish, either by washing with a strong detergent or by wiping down with a solvent such as paint thinner (this is highly flammable, so be careful).

title: AMERICAN FIBER OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Declares Mistrial In Florida Crime Case
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today in the racketeering case of a reputed Florida crime leader, Santo Trafficante Jr., ruling that the prosecution had introduced prejudicial hearsay evidence.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 16.

title: Suitors Seek French Deal
description: A tentative agreement for a French takeover of the ITT Corporation's telecommunications operations has produced a scramble among North American and European concerns seeking to acquire the second-largest French telephone switch manufacturer.

title: The U.N. Today: July 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 p.m.

title: MUSIC: STOLTZMAN AND DOUGLAS
description: THE clarinetist Richard Stoltzman lent his creamy tone and songful phrasing to largely undeserving material in a concert Tuesday at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. Accompanied by the pianist Bill Douglas, Mr. Stoltzman plugged his new album of tidbits and mood music, ''Begin Sweet World.''

title: WINFIELD BENCHED BEFORE YANKS WIN
description: Dave Winfield sat for seven innings tonight, but he kept his unhappiness to himself. In the eighth, he rose from the bench and delivered a run-scoring double that the Yankees needed, and they went on score a 5-4 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: How to Keep Low Fares Flying High
description: Who killed People Express? In a few years, this upstart airline that was given life by deregulation created air travel affordable to all. Yet suddenly it lies on the auction block, raising questions about the workability of airline competition.

title: Samaranch Optimistic
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday that he thinks North Korea will accept an I.O.C. proposal under which some events in the 1988 Summer Games, scheduled for South Korea, will be held in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang.

title: Iran Reports Success In Strikes on Iraq
description: Iran's official press agency reported today that predawn air strikes by Iranian warplanes wiped out four Iraqi brigades, killing or wounding 2,300 soldiers.

title: Bridgemarket Approved by Panel
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has unanimously approved a modified plan to build a combination market, open plaza and restaurant beneath the Manhattan side of the Queensboro Bridge.

title: AQUINO OFFERS CLEMENCY TO TOLENTINO FACTION
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she would offer clemency to the men who declared a rebel government Sunday and took over the Manila Hotel, but that she would require them to give a pledge of loyalty to her Government.

title: A NEW TEST FOR DREW LEWIS
description: It is a far cry from the corridors of power in Washington to the rail yards in this Middle Western grain capital, but Drew Lewis, former Secretary of Transportation, is making a new career here as a troubleshooter at the Union Pacific Railroad.

title: Jackson and Nicaragua
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a once and future Democratic Presidential hopeful noted for periodic incursions into foreign policy, made another effort this week. He reports he met Monday in Washington with the Nicaraguan Ambassador to urge the repeal of the Sandinista Government's new restrictions on the church and the press.

title: WIDE FRAUD CHARGED IN MEXICO STATE ELECTION
description: Jose Quesada Escarcega, a 45-year-old railroad telegrapher and member of the opposition National Action party, volunteered to be a poll watcher in state elections Sunday at a voting booth in the city's northwestern section, where he lives.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ONE of the first lines of defense against burglary in any home or apartment should be a dependable perimeter alarm system. These have sensors attached to doors and windows that activate a loud alarm when anyone tries to open one of them while the system is ''armed'' (turned on). There are also space or intruder alarms that will sense an intruder's presence and sound a warning, but only after the intruder is already inside the house and is passing through the protected area.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income

title: Reagan Unit Cleared Of Campaign Charge
description: Overruling its staff, the Federal Election Commission said today that President Reagan's 1984 campaign committee had not misspent $2.1 million in prenomination expenses.

title: Toyota and the Tax Bill
description: When Senate and House conferees begin work on the tax bill next week, all of them recognize they will be subjected to a barrage of pressures from special interests. But in some instances campaigns are being organized to lobby the conference on issues that don't strictly involve taxes at all.

title: AS GLORIA MONTY'S WORLD TURNS
description: Join us now for another episode of ''General Hospital.'' You'll recall that this was one sickly soap opera eight years ago when a new executive producer, Gloria Monty, appeared to perform theatrical triage - splashy sets, younger faces, sexier scenes, lots of technological flash and dash. A year later G.H., as they call it in the industry, was the country's top-rated daytime soap and ABC-TV's biggest moneymaker.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $108,600,000 for the quarter and $188,300,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter income from continuing operations includes a charge of $34.6 million related to an asset-redeployment program. The company said the fiscal 1985 earnings from continuing operations include a charge of $44 million and a gain of $28.5 million.

title: Advertising; 4 Young Executives On Move at Newsweek
description: Obviously Mark Edmiston, president of Newsweek, is familiar with the expression ''Youth must be served.'' He has also hearkened to it.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Accounts
description: * Abraham Hirschfeld, candidate for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor of New York, to the Bloom Agency.

title: The U.N. Today: July 11, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Goetz in Confrontation With a Photographer
description: Bernhard H. Goetz was involved in a confrontation yesterday with a photographer who tried to take a photograph over the objection of Mr. Goetz's companion.

title: Traffic II
description: It says something about the level of observance of traffic regulations in Washington that an official District of Columbia car was sighted on Capitol Hill carrying a bumper sticker warning: ''I Stop for Red Lights.''

title: TALL TOWER IS PARADED IN FESTIVAL
description: ''Giglio'' in Italian means lily, but in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn this Sunday and next, it means a 65-foot-high, 8,000-pound tower that more than 100 men will lift and parade in the 99th Annual Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel and St. Paulinus.

title: Australian Debt Studied
description: Australia's triple-A rated long-term debt is under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 362 money market mutual funds rose $1.73 billion, to $225.30 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the first week all three categories have increased since May 21, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: GENICOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Crew Member Is Killed In Nebraska Train Crash
description: A slow-moving coal train rammed the rear of a stopped 87-car freight train in heavy fog early today, killing one crew member and injuring three others, one critically, a railroad spokesman said.

title: Israeli Ruling Delayed
description: Israel's Supreme Court has delayed for 10 days a judgment on the legality of presidential grants of immunity from prosecution to four members of Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence agency, who reportedly were involved in the killing of two captured Palestinians accused of hijacking a bus in 1984, or in efforts to hide the facts in the case. The court had been expected to rule today whether the Government and the Shin Beth men went about the process of requesting immunity legally.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MITTERRAND FINDS SUMMIT PROSPECT HAZY
description: President Francois Mitterrand, ending talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said here today that the prospects for a meeting between President Reagan and the Soviet leader this year remained uncertain.

title: Supremely Unsettled
description: To the Editor:

title: Offer for Associated Is Increased by May
description: The May Department Stores Company said last night that it had increased its offer to acquire the Associated Dry Goods Corporation to $67.68 a share in stock from an earlier offer of $66 a share.

title: BRITISH CONCERN TO BUY RALSTON FEED BUSINESS
description: In yet another restructuring move, the Ralston Purina Company announced today that it had agreed to sell Purina Mills, the nation's largest animal feed business, to BP Nutrition Ltd.

title: Oslo May Cut Oil Royalties
description: The Norwegian Government said yesterday that it would propose eliminating some of the royalties required of North Sea oil companies in an effort to give the companies an incentive to maintain operations there despite the sharply lower oil prices. A Government spokesman also suggested that oil companies might no longer have to pay the same share as the state in developing new production fields.

title: Pat Martino Trio
description: The guitarist Pat Martino will lead a trio Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: DOLE STUDIES PLAN TO SEAT MANION
description: Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, is considering a parliamentary maneuver that would put Daniel A. Manion on a Federal appeals court without another Senate vote, a spokesman said today.

title: U.S. SAYS COCAINE-RELATED DEATHS ARE RISING
description: The National Institute on Drug Abuse, saying that the public needs to know more about cocaine, said today that there had been dramatic increases in cocaine-related injuries and deaths in recent years.

title: NU HORIZONS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chinese Goods Ordered
description: Chinese beer and toys are most in demand by American buyers attending this week's China trade exposition here. ''Quite a number of deals have been made,'' said the show's director, Pasteur Lai of Lein Tai Hong Ltd., based in Hong Kong.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
United Settles Sex-Bias Case
description: United Airlines will pay nearly $33 million in back wages and reinstate flight attendants who were forced to quit because of a no-marriage rule, since declared illegal, under a proposed settlement filed in Federal court today.

title: 26 Aliens Found Locked In Railroad Car in Texas
description: Officials unlocked the door of a boxcar Wednesday afternoon and found 26 illegal aliens locked inside by smugglers, with one man dead, another dying and a 16-year-old girl suffering from shock and dehydration.

title: NICARAGUA AND BISHOPS AT ODDS AGAIN
description: An explosion last week that killed 32 people as they rode in a truck through a remote part of northern Nicaragua has become a new source of conflict between the Government and Roman Catholic bishops.

title: WAGNER'S SCHOOL POST SEEN AS A KOCH VICTORY
description: Three years ago, Mayor Koch suffered one of the more embarrassing, even stunning defeats of his City Hall career - the rejection of his handpicked choice for city schools Chancellor, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Now the Mayor may have succeeded in accomplishing indirectly what he failed to do directly, in the estimation of many educators, union leaders and elected officials. Instead of becoming Chancellor, Mr. Wagner has just been elected president of the seven-member Board of Education, thanks to maneuvering at City Hall.

title: CATERPILLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MT BAKER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: BHUTTO, IN INTERVIEW, BACKS U.S. ARMS AID IN PAKISTAN
description: Pakistan's leading opposition figure said today that while military spending in this country was ''far too high,'' she would nevertheless continue the United States military aid program here if she succeeded in toppling the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: Nina Morgana, Singer; Toured With Caruso
description: Nina Morgana, who sang soprano roles at the Metropolitan Opera from 1920 through 1935, and was believed to be the last surviving person to have sung in recital with Enrico Caruso, died Tuesday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 94 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: DANIEL LEADS ON A 70
description: Beth Daniel, who came within one shot of the United States Women's Open championship in 1981 when Pat Bradley won, took a one-shot lead in the first round of the 41st United States Women's Open championship today at the NCR Country Club.

title: OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Figures are converted from Dutch florins at the rate of 2.6145 to the dollar.

title: DANCE: BUSH WOMEN
description: THERE are theatrical experiences, very occasionally, that seem to have as much to do with the experiencing of daily life as any theater. Urban Bush Women's ''Anarchy, Wild Women and Dinah'' is such an event. This theater-dance piece, which will be performed through Sunday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street, is not the tidiest of creations. It is certainly not the prettiest. It is anarchic, and it is wild, with some moments of great tenderness expressed with devastating simplicity. But then, its subject - living as a black woman - is all those things.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Best Products Co., Richmond, which manufactures plastic products, has dismissed Bernard A. Cohen, executive vice president. He will not be replaced.

title: LERNER PRAISED AT TRIBUTE AS A 'GENTLEMAN GENIUS'
description: Leonard Bernstein saluted him as a ''gentleman genius,'' Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. said, ''few men in our melancholy age gave so much pleasure to so many people,'' and Julie Andrews vividly described how Alan Jay Lerner and his collaborators on ''My Fair Lady'' forever changed her life.

title: Ex-Im Bank Cuts Rates
description: The Export-Import Bank, after agreement among 22 countries, will cut minimum interest rates on its foreign loans.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 11, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Anti-lobbying Zeal Has Gone Too Far
description: The spectacle of Michael K. Deaver promoting his White House access has stirred understandable anger across the nation, but on Capitol Hill the reaction has taken the form of a legislative temper tantrum that is itself cause for concern. Rather than improve Government service, the proposed legislation could seriously damage it.

title: ITALIAN JURY GIVES CRUISE-SHIP KILLER 30-YEAR SENTENCE
description: A Palestinian who confessed to the murder of Leon Klinghoffer, an American tourist aboard the liner Achille Lauro, was convicted and sentenced today to 30 years in prison for his actions during the ship's hijacking in October.

title: BOTNICK IS CRITICAL IN FAREWELL
description: Victor E. Botnick, presiding at his last board meeting as chairman of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, accused reporters and ''certain elected officials'' yesterday of intentionally undermining the public's confidence in the city hospital system.

title: Deadline for Casillas
description: The United States Football League's Arizona Outlaws have given a rookie defensive tackle, Tony Casillas, until Tuesday to accept a contract offer, according to Bill Tatham Jr., a club co-owner.

title: LABORATORY MORELS 'BLOOM'
description: For generations, fanciers of morel mushrooms have had only two ways of satisfying their taste for the gnarled fungi with the nutty taste. They could spend hours tramping through the woods looking for outcroppings at the base of dying elms or old fruit trees. Or they could pay $20 to $40 a pound at specialty food stores.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $36 million from RCA Corp. before estimated acquisition costs, and sales included $803 million from RCA. These were the operating results for RCA since June 1. After acquisition costs, the company said latest quarter net was reduced by about one cent a share.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE title of last night's concert at Alice Tully Hall, ''France Salutes New York,'' might have led you to expect a stageful of Gallic musicians engaged in playing, say, Gershwin or Copland. Instead, what did we have but the resident artists of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, plus half a dozen guests, saluting French composers: Ravel, Poulenc, Debussy, Messiaen and Faure. No complaints as to the musical results, but let's begin by getting the direction of the salute straight.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: IRVING PLACE has sprouted a rustic little breakfast and sandwich shop that looks as if it belongs in an upstate hamlet rather that in the belly of Manhattan. In fact, the young couple who created Friend of a Farmer, 77 Irving Place (between Park and Third Avenues at 19th Street), hail from upstate - and so do most of their provisions. Terry and Carrie Morabito have been an instant hit since they opened their restaurant and carryout three months ago in this tranquil neighborhood and started selling their earthy homemade whole-wheat bread, moist zucchini bread, lacy apple pie, brown-egg omelets, buckwheat pancakes, wholesome sandwiches, homemade preserves and more. Beverages include cappuccino, sparkling cider, iced tea and the like. Sandwiches and breakfast entrees are in the $5-to-$6 range.

title: FORD PLANS SHOULDER HARNESSES FOR REAR SEAT BELTS
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to introduce seat belts with shoulder harnesses for the rear seats of its passenger cars in the ''next few years.'' The company declined to be more specific.

title: Key NASA Official Takes Industry Post
description: Richard G. Smith, one of the officials who approved the launching of the ill-fated space shuttle Challenger, will leave as the director of the Kennedy Space Center for private industry as the shake-up continues in the National Aeronautics and Space Adminstration.

title: PRISON SET AFIRE NEAR WASHINGTON
