description: Hundreds of inmates at the District of Columbia's sprawling prison complex in nearby Lorton, Va., set fire to a dozen crowded dormitories early today, forcing the temporary evacuation of more than 800 prisoners to more crowded, higher-security cellblocks.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airship International Ltd. said that McDonald's Corp. had granted it the right to make and sell 16-inch reproductions of the McDonald's blimp, which will be called McBlimp Inflatables. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ELECTRICAL CONCERN'S PROFITS UP
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported higher second-quarter earnings yesterday despite a large charge for a restructuring, a write-down of assets and other unusual items.

title: A Debut in Queens
description: With a ceremonial tossing of dead fish by Queens Borough President Claire Shulman and Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern, a pair of black bear cubs made their debut yesterday at the Flushing Meadow-Corona Park Zoo.

title: N.A.M. Study on Trade
description: A spokesman for 13,500 American manufacturers said today that ''it's taking longer than we expected'' for the declining dollar to narrow the trade deficit, but improvements should ''begin to be visible by the end of this year.''

title: Pizza Inn Buyout Offer
description: Pizza Inn Inc., one of the largest pizza restaurant chains in the country, said today that it had received a proposal to take the company private from an investor group headed by F. J. Spillman, its chairman and president, and Waylon E. McMullen, a director.

title: U.S. PUTS PRESSURE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The senior American official responsible for African affairs said today that the United States had to end the siege mentality of South Africa's leaders and ''see what we can do to rekindle prospects for negotiation and dialogue'' between blacks and whites.

title: YOUNG BRITISH SAILORS SEEN IN 'REMEMBRANCE'
description: A GROUP of sailors is out for a night on the town. A young stranger, drunk or heavily drugged, staggers into the local bar-disco and creates a disturbance. The bouncer drags him outside and viciously beats him. The stranger is taken, just barely conscious and carrying no identification, to a hospital.

title: The Gorbachev Doctrine: Mailed Fist
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a dire signal to Eastern Europe when he spoke last month at the Polish Communist Party congress in Warsaw. Call it the Gorbachev Doctrine, and make no mistake: it could be far tougher than even the Brezhnev Doctrine.

title: Big Band Stomp
description: The pianist Jaki Byard will lead his Apollo Stompers big band tonight and tomorrow at 10 and midnight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

title: METS BEAT BRAVES BEHIND OJEDA
description: The widely rumored decline and fall of the Mets came to an end - or at least a pause - last night in Shea Stadium, when New York snapped a three-game losing streak and almost casually defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-1.

title: Hunt Oil Units Restructured
description: Ray L. Hunt, a half brother of the financially troubled Hunt brothers in Dallas, has formed a holding company to oversee his growing interests. He is the youngest son of

title: Dow Rises by 5.76 After Late Flurry
description: With a debate raging over whether the Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates, the stock market was sharply lower for most of yesterday's session before a flurry of buy orders in the last hour resulted in a modest advance.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After penalties of $13,832,000 on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances for both latest quarter and 6 months. c-After similar penalties of $1,261,000. d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $545,00.

title: EVACUEES RETURN TO HOMES IN OHIO
description: With officials saying that a poisonous chemical cloud was dissipating, life returned to normal today for most of the residents in this city of 20,000 people, which was evacuated Wednesday evening after a railroad tank car exploded.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA DURING THE ADMINISTRATIONS OF JAMES MADISON. By Henry Adams. 1,436 pages. The Library of America. $27.50. IN his later years Henry Adams enjoyed thinking of himself as a failure. Now his ghost will have to learn to live - quizzically, no doubt - with the burden of incontestable success. After being out of print for several decades, Adams's monumental history of the Jefferson and Madison Administrations has been reissued, as the latest publication of the Library of America - the surest sign the present age has to offer that it is a certified classic.

title: Two Streaks End
description: Danny Jackson, whose 3-0 victory over Baltimore ended the Royals' losing streak at 11 games only hours after his wife, hospitalized five times with false labor pains, finally gave birth to a healthy son: ''I'd have to say she was more overdue than the team.''

title: DOCTORS HAD TRIED TO HOSPITALIZE SUSPECT IN SLASHING ON FERRYBOAT
description: Emergency room doctors at Presbyterian Hospital believed that the man later accused of killing two people on a Staten Island ferryboat was so mentally disturbed that they sought to have him hospitalized last Friday, a senior physician at the hospital said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on June 27 about William Dean Singleton, a new owner of The Dallas Times Herald, misstated his educational background. Mr. Singleton attended the University of Texas at Arlington but did not graduate.

title: U.S. SAFETY OFFICIALS CITE DECLINE IN RAIL ACCIDENTS
description: The incidence and severity of accidents involving trains carrying hazardous materials have steadily declined in recent years, according to Federal railroad safety officials and investigators.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSOCIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from the sale of land, after provision for income taxes, of $37,500 for the quarter and $324,303 for the year.

title: Topics; Democracy Served; The Alfonsin Example
description: When berated for its dictatorial ways, Argentina's former military regime used to argue that a real assault on chronic hyperinflation required suspending democratic freedoms. In its first year, the dictatorship did reduce inflation substantially, from about 300 percent in late 1975 to barely 100 percent a year later.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rickover's Son Says His Father Was Exploited
description: To most Americans, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover was a man who rose from humble origins to the highest levels of government to make great contributions to the nation. But to his son, he was also a man who, senile toward the end of his life, was exploited by people around him.

title: Cheaper Milk for Staten Island Is Just a Feint in a Price War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Worrisome Ban on Truthful Ads
description: For the first time since it gave commercial advertising some constitutional protection a decade ago, the Supreme Court has upheld a ban on ads that speak the truth about a legal product. It ruled 5-to-4 that Puerto Rico could forbid the casinos it licensed from soliciting gamblers on the island.

title: Mexico Bashes Itself
description: One of the charges that badly stung Mexicans last spring was the claim of some Americans, like Senator Jesse Helms, that its ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) lacked legitimacy. Along with officials of the Reagan Administration and others, we implored the critics to stop bashing Mexico and show some sympathy for its problems.

title: Gray Drug Fair Put on the Block
description: The Sherwin-Williams Company said that it planned to sell its 450-store Gray Drug Fair chain, and had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to find a buyer.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Some Shoulders You Can Lean On
description: Who are the most consistently effective starting pitchers in the majors? Part of the answer is provided by the so-called ''quality start,'' which requires the hurler to last at least six innings and yield no more than three earned runs. Among all pitchers who have had at least 10 such outings this season, these boast the highest ratio of quality starts to total starts*:

title: SCHEDULE OF FESTIVAL PERFORMANCES
description: The Pepsico ''Summerfare'' begins tonight at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase. Performances will be held in Theaters A through E, the Choral and Recital Halls and the Neuberger Museum. To reach the center from Manhattan, take the West Side Highway to the Henry Hudson Parkway. Then take the Cross County Parkway to the Hutchinson River Parkway and continue to Exit 28 (Purchase); turn left and take Lincoln Avenue to Anderson Road; the university is on Anderson Road.

title: Posner Testifies in Tax Case
description: Victor Posner, the reclusive Miami Beach financier, testifying in his own defense today, denied charges that he evaded $1.2 million in income taxes when he donated land to a Miami Bible college in the 1970s.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After special items reduced net income by a net $4.9 million, or 29 cents per share.

title: RICHARD J. BLUM
description: Richard J. Blum, a former vice president of Saks & Company and former president of the now-closed Saks-34th Street, died yesterday, from complications after a series of strokes, at a nursing home in Briarcliff, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Deputy Taken in Escape From Texas Jail Is Found
description: A sheriff's deputy taken hostage by an armed prisoner in a jail escape was found unharmed tonight, and hundreds of searchers were reported closing in on the convict.

title: BOAT PEOPLE'S QUANDARY: 'WHAT ELSE CAN WE DO?'
description: They were sweeping the floor the other day and getting the plain wooden sleeping platforms ready again at this refugee center on Palawan Island.

title: BOMB EXPLODES AT JOHANNESBURG STOCK EXCHANGE
description: A bomb exploded at the stock exchange here today, but there were no injuries and little damage, according to the Government's Bureau for Information - the sole source of authorized news.

title: Third-Class Oil Keeps the Mail Flowing
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. TOWN BOARD CHALLENGES TRANSFER OF RCA TO G.E.
description: The General Electric Company's acquisition of the RCA Corporation and its subsidiary NBC, which received Federal approval last month, has been challenged by the East Hampton (L.I.) Town Board, which contends that G.E. is unfit as a broadcaster because of past corporate misconduct.

title: Cable Comes to S.I.
description: Dominick DeSantis was thinking of sitting home last night to watch a little cable TV.

title: France Rules Out Manufacturing A Neutron Bomb in Near Future
description: France's new conservative Government has changed its position, deciding not to manufacture a neutron bomb in the immediate future. according to French defense officials.

title: SCREEN: 'CLUB PARADISE,' A COMEDY
description: ''CLUB PARADISE,'' Harold Ramis's latest ramshackle comedy, is about a retired Chicago fireman (Robin Williams), who invests his disability pension as well as himself in the promotion of a nascent Club Med-style resort, set on the fictitious Caribbean island of St. Nicholas.

title: PRESIDENT'S FINAL TAX PUSH OPENS
description: President Reagan, beginning his personal effort to help forge the final compromise needed for tax overhaul, made it clear to a cheering crowd here today that his key priority would be the lowest possible individual tax rate.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $11,091,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: CORDERO'S RETURN EAGERLY AWAITED
description: When Angel Cordero finished riding in a workout between races at Belmont Park last Thursday, his first public appearance since March 8, he seemed almost surprised by the applause from fans who had lined the rail to see him.

title: Top Collegian
description: In a poll of major-league scouting directors, Jeff King, the standout third baseman from Arkansas selected first in the June baseball draft by the Pittsburgh Pirates, was named college player of the year by The Sporting News.

title: Polynice Asked to Go
description: A judge in Charlottesville, Va., gave Olden Polynice a 30-day suspended sentence and ordered him to stay away from the store from which he shoplifted a $17 pair of headphones April 30. Terry Holland, head coach of the Virginia basketball team, for which Polynice was the center and leading scorer last season, said in a statement released by the school that he is recommending that Polynice give up his athletic scholarship and leave the team.

title: Organ-Guitar Jazz
description: The organist Jimmy Smith will lead his trio, plus the guest guitarist Kenny Burrell, tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS OF YESTERDAY, TODAY AND TOMORROW
description: IT used to be that as summer sizzled, the stream of photography shows slowed to a trickle. But no more: the number of photo exhibitions at galleries and museums this summer approximate a torrent. And while the first hot breath of July was once a cue to trot out the tried-and-true from storage drawers, these days curators and dealers are taking risks. Some have brought us retrospective shows of overlooked 20th-century masters. Others have focused on the newest of the new, trying to make sense of today's image-making activity and to chart the course of the medium's future.

title: SPINKS CHALLENGER CALLED SLOW-FOOTED
description: When it was reported last week that Steffen Tangstad, the European heavyweight champion, would be Michael Spinks's opponent on Sept. 6 at Las Vegas in HBO's heavyweight unification series, the reaction was generally one of disapproval.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Phineas Newborn Jr., Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, below West Fourth Street (242-1785). Born into a musical Memphis family and a pianist with his father's big band and on early B. B. King recordings while still in his teens, Phineas Newborn Jr. was in every sense a prodigy. By the time he made his classic Atlantic, RCA and Contemporary jazz albums, in the 1950's and early 60's, that prodigious abundance of technique was getting him compared with the virtuosic Art Tatum, and dismissed by some as all fingers, no heart. That was never true, and certainly isn't now. In his maturity, Mr. Newborn is one of the masters of jazz piano, with an immediately identifiable tone and touch, great harmonic originality, and, as a kind of signature, octave runs that seem to fairly whip along the keyboard. Shows are around 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. through Sunday, with a $10 music charge and $6 minimum.

title: MILITARY ELECTRONICS STOCKS SURGE
description: Leading a general rise in military electronics stocks, Sanders Associates' shares soared $5.125 yesterday, to $61.875, exceeding the $60-a-share takeover agreement announced Wednesday with the Lockheed Corporation.

title: SIX MEN SHOT FROM PASSING CAR ON A STREET CORNER IN LAURELTON
description: Six young men standing on a street corner in Laurelton, Queens, were shot last night from a passing car occupied by two men, the police said.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that an implementation of a new pension accounting standard on Jan. 1 increased the latest quarter earnings by about $3 million, or 1 cent a share, and the 6-month earnings by $7.4 million, or 3 cents a share. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Chrysler Cuts Loan Rates
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced 5.5 percent financing on selected cars and trucks.

title: Bridge: Top New York Stars to Play In Big Apple Regional Event
description: Most of New York's top-ranked stars will compete in the Big Apple Regional Championships beginning today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 34th Street and 11th Avenue.

title: Copper Smelting Halted At Plant Near Border
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation stopped operating its copper smelter at Douglas, Ariz., today to comply with state air quality standards, but the company says it hopes to win the right to restart the plant.

title: CYCLONE AT CONEY ISLAND ROLLS AGAIN AT LAST
description: Mayor Koch threw a switch at Astroland in Coney Island yesterday, sending riders along 3,000 feet of swoops and swerves as the Cyclone Roller Coaster, its insurance problems solved, got off to a late seasonal start.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANK OF JAPAN SILENT
description: The Bank of Japan remained silent today on whether it would follow the Federal Reserve's lead and cut its own basic interest rate, but economists and traders think the bank may do so in a few days.

title: Dining Out Guide; New and Notable
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, #206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 15, 1985) A sparkling array of California and Southwestern-style food is offered at this exuberant spot. Virtually all the recipes are intelligently conceived and demonstrate just how appealing this style of cooking can be in skilled hands. Appetizers include roasted quail salad with jicama and basil; carpaccio of salmon with basil and tequila, and Southwestern cured beef tenderloin with pickled onions. Entree choices are chilled roast veal with asparagus and potato salad; grilled salmon with sorrel dressing, and free-range chicken with corn chilies and mustard greens. Dinner entrees $17 to $21. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to 1 A.M.; closed Sundays. AURORA, #60 East 49th Street (692-9292) -***(Jan. 31, 1986) Joseph Baum's new creation has a winsomely plush dining room that combines a corporate ambiance of burnished wood wainscoting and cushy leather chairs with a playful bubble theme - on plates, windows and waiters' jackets. For the most part, the kitchen stresses flavor over flair. Appetizer options are duck confit and lobster salad and puff pastry filled with ragout of sweetbreads and wild mushrooms. Main courses include smoked sea bass on watercress salad; grilled duck with fresh figs, and roasted pigeon with sweet garlic sauce.

title: Union Carbide Files Appeal
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday appealed one condition of the decision to send the lawsuits from the Bhopal disaster to Indian courts.

title: US TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 11, 1986
description: International Two Israeli soldiers died and nine were wounded in a battle with four Palestinian guerrillas, who also died in the fighting, on the coast just north of the Lebanese border. Hours later, Israeli aircraft attacked what were described as Palestinian bases in Lebanon. [ Page Al, Column 5. ]

title: Midwest Pepsi Bottler Recalls 2 Slice Products
description: Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers is recalling bottled Regular Mandarin Orange Slice and Regular Apple Slice in parts of Missouri and Kansas because of possible fermentation, which can cause bottles to explode.

title: TALKS WITH HAVANA COLLAPSE OVER ITS RADIO RIGHTS IN U.S.
description: The State Department said today that efforts to revive an immigration agreement with Cuba had collapsed.

title: A CYCLIST'S SEARCH FOR HIMSELF
description: The 209 other riders in the Tour de France set off on a bicycle race, but Alexi Grewal says he is traveling on a journey into himself.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SLIVIA SYLVA WEINTRAUB of Transylvania was in a crinkly white Mary McFadden dinner dress - and in a tizzy, too. Carmen de Albornoz, the wife of the guest of honor at Mrs. Weintraub's black-tie dinner party on Wednesday night, had come down with food poisoning, a situation that set the hostess in motion, busily making 51 last-minute place-card switches.

title: WOMEN IN MIDWEST INHERIT A LEGACY OF LEADERSHIP
description: Jan Meyers, a Republican Congresswoman from suburban Johnson County, Kan., acknowledges she has a lot in common with Bobbie Hammond, who rides the lonely, blue-green ranges of Kansas's Flint Hills, down near Emporia.

title: ATTORNEY FOR WHITWORTH LINKS HIM TO SPY LETTERS
description: A defense attorney today told the jury in the trial of Jerry A. Whitworth that Mr. Whitworth had written a series of anonymous letters admitting involvement in espionage for the Soviet Union.

title: DANCES OLD AND NEW HERALD SUMMER SEASON
description: Familiar dance with a new face and new dance with some familiar faces will be performed in programs this weekend that signal the start of the summer dance season.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $109,000 from a tax loss. c-Net income

title: 11 Strike Leaders Arrested in Chile
description: Policemen ringing a courthouse arrested 11 of 15 leaders of last week's two-day general strike who were trying to make voluntary court appearances, and tear-gassed their supporters outside a court.

title: N.F.L. Facing Delay of Game
description: The National Football League's training camps, as usual scheduled to open early for rookies during the next week or so, may be rather quiet places until the veterans arrive. As of yesterday, the 28 teams had signed a total of only 47 draft choices, and one club - the Cincinnati Bengals, who've signed just their eighth- and 10th-round picks - has decided not to open early at all unless there's a flurry of contractual completions before the rookies' original reporting date, July 20.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RED SOX WIN, 8-7, ON ANGEL BALK IN 12
description: Todd Fisher's balk with two out in the bottom of the 12th inning tonight scored Dwight Evans to cap a four-run rally and give the Boston Red Sox an 8-7 triumph over the California Angels.

title: U.S. and Spain Discuss Cut in Military Presence
description: The United States and Spain began talks today on reducing the United States military presence, with Madrid reportedly pressing for the dismantling of two of four bases.

title: CASINOS TRANSFORM ATLANTIC CITY'S SUBURBS
description: In their first eight years, casinos have failed to revitalize blighted Atlantic City. But for the surrounding communities, where casino workers live, the gaming establishments have meant substantial jobs, growth and income.

title: STUDY QUESTIONS DIAGNOSES MADE IN INFANT DEATHS
description: Many of the cases of sudden infant death syndrome reported at a Brooklyn hospital are actually the result of suffocation, letting the babies get too hot or other accidents stemming from parental misjudgment, according to an article published yesterday in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: FIRST PEOPLES BANK OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $750,000 and $1,450,000 for latest quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: LE DUAN, VIETNAMESE COMMUNIST CHIEF, DIES AT 78
description: Le Duan, the head of the Vietnamese Communist Party and one of the architects of victory in the Vietnam War, died today in Hanoi. He was 78 years old.

title: ART: 'LIBERTY' ECHOES 1883 SHOW
description: ''IN SUPPORT OF LIBERTY,'' at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I., is in a quiet, understated way one of the most ambitious of the exhibitions that have sprouted all over to mark the rehabilitation of the Statue of Liberty. It is also one of the few in which the statue itself does not appear.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from sale of stock in Merabank, a savings bank in Phoenix, Ariz. The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid April 11, 1986.

title: Berry Urged to Report
description: Walter Berry, the St. John's star who was Portland's first draft choice and 14th over all, is being urged by the Trail Blazers' management to report to rookie camp on Monday, even though he has not signed a contract.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HESS REBUTS DAVIS
description: In a long day on the witness stand yesterday, Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, disputed the testimony of two previous witnesses in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League.

title: OKLAHOMA WOMAN, FEARING FARM LOSS, TAKES HER OWN LIFE
description: A farm wife despondent over her family's mounting financial woes committed suicide Wednesday by climbing atop a barrel of burning garbage and asphyxiating herself.

title: ART: A MEDICI MENAGERIE AT ACADEMY OF DESIGN
description: AS bankers, the Medici counted among their clients Edward IV, the English King who moonlighted as a wool merchant, and several Popes. (The family itself produced three.) As bankers, politicians and patrons of art, they controlled Florence for most of the 15th century, making it the cultural capital of the Renaissance. They were dislodged by the French in 1494 but, having made their mark in Rome, they came back strong in 1530 and, ennobled, they remained in power for another 200 years.

title: Friend Is Charged in Slaying Of Woman on Subway Stairs
description: The boyfriend of a woman who worked as a stenographer in the Manhattan District Attorney's office was arrested yesterday on charges of shooting her to death during an argument on the steps of a Bronx subway station, the police said.

title: New Tack on Cases Against Israel?
description: There was once a time when allegations that the Israeli Government had violated American law were handled with an eye to preserving the close relationship between the United States and Israel.

title: Sanctions Won't Bend South Africa
description: In their search for ways to promote peaceful reform in South Africa, Western governments have turned, grudgingly at first, but with increasing conviction, to economic sanctions. The vote last month by the House of Representatives brings comprehensive economic sanctions squarely into the mainstream of political debate in the Western democracies. When Congress returns next week, both the Senate and Administration will be pressed to put some teeth into the largely symbolic sanctions package approved by the President last year.

title: Beaten by Odds
description: One good thing about working for Donald Trump is that if you're not content with one career, you can always set out on another. Or you can at least try, which is what Steve Mooney did a couple of months ago when he took time off from his 9-to-5 existence as a mailroom employee at Trump's Castle Casino in Atlantic City to send a letter to his boss, the antitrust quarterback who owns the Generals.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include the merger of Hawley Bank under the purchase method of accounting.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per shares results have been restated to reflect the 100-percent stock split that occurred in June 1985.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Walter W. Woodward is returning to Griswold Inc., Cleveland, as executive vice president and creative director.

title: A New Post
description: The hard-pressed American Enterprise Institute has taken a step toward greater economic stability by creating the new post of vice president for finance and administration and filling it with James Hicks, an executive of the Dow Chemical Company. Paul F. Oreffice, chairman of the research group's finance committee, is also chief executive officer of Dow.

title: A Hidden Masterpiece Comes to the Met
description: Rare and delightful in its tenderness, a 13th-century ivory carving of the Virgin and Child has emerged from a storeroom at Broadway and 155th Street to go on display this morning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''I'VE always liked talking to people who were interested in making movies,'' said John G. Avildsen, the Academy Award-winning director of ''Rocky,'' whose latest film is the financially successful ''Karate Kid Part II.''

title: BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Traffic I
description: Among the many newsletters being sent these days to offices of Washington lawmakers is one called Monday A.M., which carries a Tipp City, Ohio, address and identifies itself as ''the newsletter of the radar detector industry.'' The current issue emphasizes the peril of electronic speed traps by noting that two members of a prominent political family - Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy - both were recently unable to avoid police traps and thus paid speeding fines.

title: BALLET: NUREYEV'S 'SWAN LAKE'
description: IN Rudolf Nureyev's version of ''Swan Lake'' for the Paris Opera Ballet, Odette - the Swan Queen - literally comes out of the woodwork.

title: Patrick's Status in Doubt
description: A few weeks ago, the Rangers were said to be considering the dismissal of Craig Patrick as general manager. Patrick's contract expired July 1, and since then, Ranger management has refused comment and the mystery has grown.

title: A REALTY GAMBLER'S BIG COUP
description: If he had not joined his father in the family real estate business more than 30 years ago, Larry A. Silverstein might well have become a trapeze artist.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from sales of investments of $6.2 million and $10.2 million for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $81.7 million and $163 million for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $83.9 million for both the quarter and 6 months from reduction in tax liability resulting from Litton Industries distribution.

title: ADDITION OF SCALIA'S VOTE UNLIKELY TO ALTER RULINGS
description: The Supreme Court's voting patterns in the term that ended Monday suggest that none of the major cases would have been decided differently if President Reagan's nominee to the court, Judge Antonin Scalia, had been voting instead of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who is retiring.

title: ANDREOTTI IS ASKED TO FORM A GOVERNMENT IN ITALY
description: A Christian Democrat who has led five previous governments was asked today to try to form a new cabinet to replace that of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Record in the Legislature
description: The hot issue in the closing scramble of the New York Legislature was Shoreham, Long Island Lighting's costly but inoperative nuclear plant. By joining with nine Republican senators from Long Island to keep the plant from being charged to voters' electric bills, Governor Cuomo appeared to gain the Republicans' cooperation on other major matters. But a cool reckoning suggests they gave him the appearance of victory more often than its substance.

title: Lesson Against Drugs
description: ''I want to say to any kids who still look up to me for my past accomplishments: Do not become involved in drugs in any way.''

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSOCIATION (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Boy George Said to Be Treated for Addiction
description: Boy George is under treatment for heroin addiction, his record company said today, confirming reports that the flamboyant British rock star had a drug problem.

title: F.C.C. Won't Renew Ohio Station's License
description: The Federal Communications Commission's review board, in a rare action, has refused to renew the license of an Ohio radio station on charges the station's owners lied to the commission.

title: PARIS BOMB STIRS LAW-AND-ORDER CRY
description: The bombing of an annex of the police headquarters here has intensified a fierce nationwide debate over the Government's program to combat crime and political violence, according to French political commentators.

title: Advertising; New York Campaign For Crush
description: CRUSH, the 70-year-old orange soft drink, is finally making it to the New York market, but with little left to identify it with the soda pop formulated by Neil Ward in his Chicago pharmacy in 1916. Except perhaps the name.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOUISIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $13,985,000 representing an increase in the bank's reserve for credit losses; the bank's reserves totaled $51,752,000.

title: Cyanide Threat Hits Jello
description: An anonymous caller claimed yesterday to have poisoned boxes of sugar-free Jell-O in Chicago and Detroit, prompting two Middle Western grocery chains, Kroger and Jewel, to pull the product from their shelves. The threat came two days after an anonymous letter said Ac'cent flavor enhancer had been poisoned with cyanide in the Houston area. In neither case was there any evidence that either product had been poisoned or even tampered with, and no extortion demands or motives were known.

title: LOTUS'S INFLUENTIAL HEAD DECIDES TO CALL IT QUITS
description: Mitchell D. Kapor, the freewheeling software entrepreneur whose Lotus 1-2-3 program transformed him into a cult figure in the computer industry, resigned yesterday as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, saying that he wanted to ''explore other endeavors.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on July 3 incorrectly described Palmer Turnheim's departure as senior vice president at the Chase Manhattan Bank. After 48 years at the bank, he is retiring, not resigning.

title: BRAZIL CHIEF MEETS POPE ON CHURCH-STATE STRAINS
description: The President of Brazil, upset over strong criticism of his Government's land redistribution program by elements of the Brazilian Roman Catholic hierarchy, met with Pope John Paul II today in an effort to win his help in calming church-state relations.

title: Shearson Officer Hired To Aid Hutton Overseas
description: Peregrine Moncreiffe, who has been executive director of Shearson Lehman Brothers International Inc., is moving to E. F. Hutton & Company to take responsibility for developing Hutton's international investment banking operations.

title: TRIBOROUGH, AT 50, STIRS MEMORIES OF NEW DEAL
description: On a blazing summer afternoon exactly 50 years ago, a 22-year-old Manhattan bank teller drove up in his new black Chevrolet, paid his 25 cents and became the first customer to drive across the Triborough Bridge.

title: 'SUMMERFARE' OFFERS A GARDEN OF GLOBAL DELIGHTS
description: AT the dawn of this decade, the notion of a global arts community and the terms ''world theater'' and ''world music'' seemed more like utopian concepts than actualities in America's cultural life. But thanks to events like the Pepsico ''Summerfare'' festival of the arts, which starts tonight, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival each fall, all that has begun to change. Now entering its seventh season, Pepsico's 24-day ''Summerfare'' festival at the State University of New York in Purchase is an irresistible magnet for culturati not only from the New York area, but all over the nation as well. In the last three years, as its focus has grown increasingly global, ''Summerfare'' has established itself as one of the foremost international showcases for the performing arts in this country.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO 6% FROM 6 1/2%
description: Citing a ''relatively slow'' economy and low inflation, the Federal Reserve Board today cut its benchmark lending rate to 6 percent from 6 1/2 percent.

title: Songwriting Duo
description: The songwriters Michael Hurley and Steve Weber will perform Sunday at 8:30 and 10:30 P.M. at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Admission is $6, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Museum's Move Called 'Ripe for Adjudication'
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday denied a motion by Attorney General Robert Abrams to dismiss the Museum of the American Indian's petition to move to Texas.

title: Democrats on Panel Cite Regional Disparities
description: Economic growth during the last five years has been confined largely to a group of 15 East Coast states plus California, whose annual expansion nearly tripled that of the rest of the country, according to a Congressional analysis published today.

title: BURLINGTON WRITES OFF $1.9 BILLION
description: Burlington Northern Inc., one of the nation's largest railroads, said today that it would take a $1.9 billion pretax charge against earnings because of accounting changes and weakness in its railroad and oil and natural gas businesses.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 14
description: The company said adoption of FASB statement 87, which requires recognition in financial statements of overfunding in company-sponsored retirement plans, is also reflected in 1986 results. Primarily due to this overfunding, the accounting change increased net income by $8.2 million in the latest quarter and $12.9 million in the year-to-date.

title: Market Place; Diverse Views From Advisers
description: IT may seem confusing to the average investor, but a brokerage firm can speak with different voices when it comes to offering advice on the stock market.

title: AUCTIONS
description: IN 1949, Tadeus Altounyan, a British oil company executive, was traveling in Aden (now Yemen) when he heard of an Arab tribesman who had a ''very old thing - a created person'' in his possession. The bedouin was not eager to sell what proved to be a 7-inch-tall bronze statuette of an ancient Spartan warrior, Mr. Altounyan recalled recently by telephone from his home in Hythe, Kent. But he persuaded the man to exchange it for its weight in silver - then worth about $60 or $70.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Announced that Fred Tolliver will miss the rest of the season with a sprain fracture of his pitching arm.

title: 1927 'CASANOVA' SMOLDERS AGAIN
description: Georges Delerue gets a little nervous before the ballroom scene in ''Casanova,'' which will be shown tonight at Alice Tully Hall with Mr. Delerue conducting his own score. In the newly restored 1927 French film, not only are dancers twirling across the floor, but the dance orchestra is shown on screen as well - and the movie conductor's final flourish had better be met with absolute silence from the 15-piece orchestra in the pit. ''I have bad dreams about it,'' Mr. Delerue said the other day.

title: Reaction to Fed Cut Is Muted
description: After weeks of anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board would cut its discount rate, the credit markets responded to the actual announcement late yesterday with more of a whimper than a bang.

title: Our Feel-Good Society
description: To the Editor:

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS TO SELL SUBSIDIARY TO UNITED IN A $146 MILLION DEAL
description: People Express Inc., in a move to win valuable time to solve its financial problems, has agreed to sell its Frontier Airlines subsidiary to United Airlines, the carriers announced yesterday.

title: Republic Sued by Pilots
description: Pilots at Republic Airlines filed a lawsuit today against the company, saying it withheld $600,000 owed the pilots after their old pension plan was terminated.

title: Aquino Says U.S. Visit Is Scheduled for Sept. 17
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she planned to meet with President Reagan in the United States on Sept. 17.

title: Topics; Democracy Served; Outreach in Seoul
description: America honored its traditions last week in Seoul as well as New York, with a belated gesture to Kim Dae Jung, a key South Korean opposition leader.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that in June it completed the sale of its Cable Television business, realizing a pre-tax gain of $651 million for the latest quarter and $651.2 million for the 6 months. The company said that also in the latest quarter and 6 months, a provision totalling $790 million was recorded to cover the costs and expenses of the company's major restructuring program, the writedown of assets to net realizable value, and certain other unusual items. The company said that this transaction had no effect on net income because of the different income tax rates applicable to them.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Budweiser Superfest, Madison Square Garden. Patti LaBelle, who is headlining the annual marathon of mainstream pop-soul musical entertainment this evening, is the Judy Garland of pop-soul. A singer who knows how to get down and wail (she takes ''Over the Rainbow'' beyond the limit), Miss LaBelle is also the high priestess of good vibrations whose concerts are communal outpourings of affection. In her latest single, ''Oh, People,'' her raw conviction turns humanistic slogans into emotionally touching statements. Sharing the bill are the Whispers, who represent post-doo-wop harmonizing at its most refined;, the ruggedly propulsive pop-soul ensemble Frankie Beverly and Maze, and Atlantic Starr. Tonight's show is at 7:30. Remaining tickets are $22.50 and are available at the box office (564-4400) and through Teletron (947-5850).

title: SURVIVOR OF MT. HOOD ENDS STAY IN HOSPITAL
description: A teen-ager who lost part of both legs in Oregon's worst mountain-climbing accident flashed a big smile from his wheelchair as he left a hospital and headed home Wednesday.

title: COUNCIL APPROVES RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR NEW YORKERS
description: Most new non-uniformed municipal employees will be required to live in the city, under a bill approved yesterday by the City Council.

title: Prepayment Rates Dip on Mortgages
description: Prepayment rates may be leveling off for the pools of mortgages that are packaged into high-coupon Ginnie Mae securities, data released this week by the Government National Mortgage Association suggest.

title: A Familiar Spiral
description: The Soviet Union has apparently supplied Nicaragua's Sandinista Government with 15 more M-17 helicopters, bringing its force of these crucial weapons to 22 or 23. Nothing could suggest more dramatically the futility and dangers of President Reagan's course in Central America.

title: Meese and the 'Spirit'
description: In response to numerous inquiries to Washington news offices, let it be noted that the figure standing behind Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in photographs in Thursday newspapers is a 12-foot, 6-inch aluminum statue titled ''The Spirit of Justice.''

title: Hasbro Deal Set
description: Hasbro Inc. said that it had agreed to make and market products of Axlon Inc., a maker of computerized toy animals.

title: Pacific Realty's U.S. Home Stake
description: The Pacific Realty Corporation, a closely held national real estate developer based in Dallas, said it had increased its stake in the U.S. Home Corporation and might later attempt an acquisition. It said that it was also ''considering various other options regarding this investment'' but that no decision had yet been made.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on July 2 about big gainers and losers in the stock market described the performance of the Pharmacontrol Company incorrectly. Its stock price, not its sales, rose 182.4 percent in the second quarter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We never said that pressures -some call them sanctions - are ipso facto to be ruled out. The question is what is the target, what are you trying to accomplish, what are the consequences of your action?'' -Chester A. Crocker, an Assistant Secretary of State, discussing United States policy on South Africa. [ A4:1. ]

title: Time and King Hassan
description: When King Hassan II of Morocco pays a state visit to Washington in two weeks, Time magazine will give him a reception at the Madison Hotel. Some Time editors reportedly resisted attending the affair until the Moroccan Embassy assured them that the Moslem monarch would have no objection to cocktails and highballs being served, because it was, after all, a Western party. It is also a party in celebration of a 20-page advertising supplement on Morocco that is to be published in the magazine a few days afteward.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said all share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September 1985. The 1986 results include a non- recurring gain of $2.2 million, or 6 cents a share, for the previously announced sale of its Canadian automotive products business.

title: RASMUSSEN GETS 10TH IN ROMP
description: Shunned by those who selected the American League pitchers for the All-Star Game next week, Dennis Rasmussen focused his attention on his starting assignment tonight, saying, ''I still want to win tonight very badly and get us going.''

title: Economic Scene; The Worries In Stock Slide
description: THIS week's sharp break in the stock market has aroused anxieties that the economy is weakening. With so much money riding on stocks, economists are fearful that a market plunge might stifle the spending plans of businesses and individuals because of the ''negative wealth effect'' - that is, the drag created by the drop in value of stock holdings.

title: BIAS PANEL SUBPOENAS OFFICER
description: A Washington police officer has been subpoenaed to testify before a Maryland grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias because the officer was seen removing items from Bias's dormitory and car soon after the star basketball player died of cocaine intoxication, Maryland law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: ANTI-COMMUNISM CALLED THE THREAD BINDING GROUP THAT CAPTURED ALIENS
description: A little more than three years ago, four members of the Alabama National Guard, frustrated by their perception of the Communist menace, unsatisfied by individual experience with the Ku Klux Klan and the John Birch Society, and unable to find any other organization that they felt would allow them to combat Communism, formed their own group to supply and assist anti-Communist forces in Central America.

title: HOW TO FILL OUT THE DAY OF A 'SUMMERFARE' NIGHT
description: For visitors to ''Summerfare'' seeking a day of activities to complement their evening at the festival, museums, historic sites and restaurants abound in the Purchase vicinity.

title: French News Agency Stages 24-Hour Strike
description: The staff of Agence France-Presse staged a 24-hour strike today to protest reorganization plans involving 300 job cuts by the end of 1988.

title: Storage, Creditors Reach Agreement
description: Storage Technology Corporation said it reached an agreement in principal with its creditors on a reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

title: BCI to Sell Unit
description: The BCI Holdings Corporation, which acquired the Beatrice Companies in April, said that it had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. and the First Boston Corporation to help it dispose of a unit, BCI Webcraft Technologies Inc. BCI said Webcraft had sales of about $200 million in the fiscal year 1986 and has grown at an average rate of 20 percent over the last five years.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.E. INCOME ROSE 5.3% IN 2D QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 5.3 percent on a 14.7 percent increase in sales.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13wks to May 30
SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ATLANTA BRAVES, at Shea Stadium, 8:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8:15 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $156,000 for the quarter and $312,000 for the 6 months.

title: Safeway Net Falls by 8.6%
description: Stung by depressed economies in key market areas and strong competition, Safeway Stores Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings slumped 8.6 percent, to $45.6 million, or 75 cents a share, from $49.9 million, or 83 cents a share, a year ago. The 1986 earnings figure also includes $8.2 million recouped from overfunded pension plans.

title: Only a National Strategy Can Cut Off Illicit Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: MARK WAINSTOCK
description: Mark Wainstock, research and program director for the American Association of Exporters and Importers, died last Friday at Staten Island Hospital, where he had undergone treatment for Hodgkin's disease. He was 41 years old and lived in Stapleton, S.I.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DERBY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said per share earnings for the 1985 period would not present a meaningful comparison because the bank's conversion to stock form was completed in December 1985.

title: Required Reading; 'No Drugs on Campus'
description: Excerpt from a speech by William J. Bennett, Secretary of Education, to the Heritage Foundation in Washington, July 8:

title: Dr. Ben Wood, Leader In Educational Testing
description: Dr. Ben D. Wood, professor emeritus of collegiate educational research at Columbia University and a leader in the use of technology and testing in education, died Tuesday at his home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., after suffering a stroke.

title: Solo Piano
description: The pianist Ellis Marsalis is performing tonight through Sunday at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street (675-7900). Sets are at 9:30 and 11:15 P.M. and 1:00 A.M.; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: YOU sweep past a beaming doorman into the marmoreal opulence of the Plaza Athenee hotel, then down a few steps to a clubby paneled anteroom where a comely maitre d'hotel greets you with diplomatic aplomb. The dining room, all crisp turquoise with white trim, is plush, formal and as unmistakably French as the Champs-Elysees: velvet banquettes, leather armchairs, ornate mirrors, well-separated tables. The overall effect is Old World but not old-fashioned, and as comfortable as a cashmere sweater.

title: FOR DONOVAN, REVENGE IS GOLDEN
description: Late in the game - an old-fashioned 83-60 stomping of the Soviet team on its own court - Anne Donovan found herself looking at the Soviet players, to see how they were taking it.

title: 12-STORY COMPLEX ON S.I. CLIMBS THE SIDE OF A HILL
description: Motorists who regularly travel the Staten Island Expressway are witnesses to the surge in residential development in northern Staten Island. Much of the growth is in attached, low-rise patio homes in the Graniteville section close to the western edge of the expressway, near the Goethals Bridge to New Jersey.

title: A Misguided Approach To Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: THE only thing that's definite - well, almost definite - is that it's going to be done: a musical version of that famous Gloria Swanson-William Holden film, ''Sunset Boulevard.'' Richard Barr and David Bixler, who will co-produce, now have a verbal go-ahead from Paramount Pictures and, if negotiations continue and things progress without a hitch, the hope is that it will be on Broadway by next spring. According to Mr. Barr, the script and score are 85 percent completed, with Calvin Remsberg doing the book and lyrics, and Roger Ames the music.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PLAYING IN FRENCH The Goldman Memorial Band will be celebrating French musical influences as part of the Liberty centennial season with a series of French-inspired concerts this weekend. Tonight, the band will present music written for France by composers from other countries - including Gluck, Chopin, Stravinsky, Verdi, Meyerbeer and Rossini - at Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park. Tomorrow evening, the scene moves to Brooklyn's Seaside Park (at Ocean Parkway and Sea Breeze Avenue) for a concert of works for the American musical theater based on French literary sources. The program includes works by composers ranging from Victor Herbert, Leonard Bernstein and Frederick Loewe to Jerry Herman. Tomorrow's concert will be repeated Sunday night at Damrosch Park. All concerts are from 8 to 10 P.M. and are free. Information: 867-8290.

title: SIR MOSES I. FINLEY, A SCHOLAR IN THE CLASSICS
description: Sir Moses I. Finley, a noted classics scholar at Cambridge University in England who wrote works that were accessible to the general public, is dead.

title: NATIONAL ENTERPRISE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from purchase of the company's 4 3/4 PC convertible subordinated debentures of $373,000 for both the latest quarter and 6 months, and $446,000 for both the year-ago quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $560,000 from closed plants. d-Net loss

title: U.S. WOMEN WIN BASKETBALL CROWN
description: Soviet and other Eastern-bloc athletes dominated the competition today at the Goodwill Games. But in basketball, the United States women won the championship by defeating the Soviet team, 83-60. It was only the third defeat for the Soviet Union in 155 international games dating back to 1957.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
6 DEAD IN FIGHT
description: Two Israeli soldiers were killed and nine wounded today in a three-hour battle with four Palestinian guerrillas on the coast just north of Israel's border with Lebanon. All four guerrillas died in the fighting. Hours later, Israeli aircraft attacked what were described as Palestinian bases in Lebanon.

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The results for the current fiscal- year periods include the company's equity in earnings of joint ventures and unconsolidated subsidiaries of $261,000 and $471,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said it had no equity in earnings in unconsolidated affiliates to report in the year-ago periods.

title: U.S. Team Is 5-0
description: The United States defeated Italy, 86-64, today to finish with a 5-0 record in Group C after the first round of the world basketball championships.

title: MORGENTHAU CALLS U.S. BID TO FIGHT COCAINE 'MINIMAL'
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan accused the Federal Government yesterday of making only ''a minimal effort'' to fight cocaine in the New York area at a time when the region is being overwhelmed by what he called a cocaine epidemic.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDERED FOR MAN CONVICTED IN OFFICER'S DEATH
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that a man convicted of killing a New York City police officer 12 years ago should not have been denied his right to defend himself, even though his legal strategy was to ''remain mute'' throughout the trial.

title: IN 2 LOCAL CLUBS, 18 BANDS FROM THE ROCK UNDERGROUNG
description: EIGHTEEN bands, standard-bearers for a rock underground that stretches from New York to California and Australia to Britain, are performing this weekend at two local clubs -CBGB in Manhattan and Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J. Most of the bands have international reputations; none of them record for Warner Brothers, CBS or any of the other entertainment conglomerates. Instead, they are the pride and joy of small record labels, run by fans or musicians.

title: Bangladesh Parliament Opens With Violence
description: Heavily armed policemen fought with demonstrators in battles that left at least 200 people injured on the opening day of Parliament.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A FAMILY FLOURISHES IN BITTERSWEET BARRIO
description: Angel Luis Rios was young, single and working as a waiter at a San Juan, P.R., cafe in 1962 when he was struck with wanderlust.

title: CITY STRIKE PARTLY SETTLED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The smaller of two striking municipal unions reached a tentative contract agreement with the city today, but a settlement with the larger and more dominant union continued to elude negotiators.

title: Keep Speed Limit and Road Deaths Down
description: To the Editor:

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said for purposes of calculating income per common share for the 3 months ended May 31, 1986 and 1985, net income has been reduced by dividends on the company's preferred stock of $1,926. The company's outstanding warrants, options and other convertible securities are excluded from the 1986 and 1985 computations since their effect would be anti-dilutive.

title: Fed, in May, Decided To Stick With Policy
description: Federal Reserve Board policy makers voted, 11 to 1, at their meeting in May to leave basic monetary policy unchanged, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Bid on Walker Still in Doubt
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C. cleared a major hurdle in its bid to acquire the Hiram Walker liquor group today, when the Canadian Government approved the deal. But the sale remains in doubt because the new owners of the liquor group's parent company, Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. of Toronto, are in court trying to block the sale to Allied-Lyons, a diversified British concern.

title: C.I.A. IS ASSIGNED ROLE OF RUNNING CONTRA ACTIVITIES
description: The Reagan Administration has given the Central Intelligence Agency day-to-day responsibility for managing rebels' military operations against the Nicaraguan Government, Administration officials said today.

title: Revealed! The True Secret of Reagan's Popularity!
description: I think I've stumbled on the real reason behind President Reagan's immense popularity. I used to think he is popular because he has restored traditional family values or has made it possible for Americans around the world again to hold their heads high - or simply because he is such an appealing sort of fellow.

title: Natalie Kubera Is Wed To E. Howard H. Roth
description: Natalie M. Kubera and E. Howard H. Roth, one of the original partners of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Beane, were married yesterday at the Jesuit's Chapel of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo by the Rev. Thomas D. McMahon, assisted by the Rev. James J. Redmond.

title: Edward Hopper Sites
description: Photographs of locations that served as subjects of paintings by Edward Hopper will be on view through July 27 at the Hopper House Art Center, 82 North Broadway in Nyack, N.Y. The photographs, by Gail Levin, are from her book ''Hopper's Places.''

title: Victory in Sight?
description: Last week Ozzie Virgil, the backup catcher for the Atlanta Braves, was tested for drugs under a clause in his new contract, a guaranteed contract.

title: Aid Resumed To Nigeria
description: The Federal Government's Export-Import Bank said today that it would once again insure banks making short-term loans for United States sales to Nigeria, after a suspension of more than two months because Nigeria fell behind in its repayments.

title: MAJOR REBUILDING AT 13 SCHOOLS SET BY CITY UNIVERSITY
description: Ten years after courting bankruptcy, the City University of New York is embarking on an ambitious financial plan to expand and rehabilitate many of its inadequate and rundown campuses, university officials said yesterday.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This man is not wearing his usual working clothes. Who is he and what is he doing? 2. ''We are tough and unapologetic about what we are doing,'' said Musa Hitam, Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister. To what was he referring? 3. The Supreme Court struck down the central provision of the new law designed to curb Federal budget deficits. What cardinal constitutional provision did it say was violated, and how? 4. According to a New York Times poll of major league baseball players, who is the best player in the game? 5. The United States Steel Corporation is changing its name, a move acknowledging that steel plays a reduced role at the company. What is the new name and what percent of the company's sales does steel now account for? 6. Magid al-Molqi was sentenced to 30 years in prison. Who is he? 7. After a monthlong trial run, project Hot Dry Rock succeeded in producing energy on a potentially commercial scale. What is hot dry rock technology? 8. Experts say a weakening of ties between employees and employers is developing, reversing a 50-year trend of job stability and protection. Why? 9. New Zealand will release two French secret agents imprisoned for their role in the sinking of an environmentalist group's ship, provided they spend the next three years on a remote Pacific island.

title: METS WIN ON FERNANDEZ'S 2-HITTER
description: The Mets brutalized the Atlanta Braves last night in Shea Stadium by 11-0, and a pair of virtuoso performances even stole the show from a brief brawl between the teams:

title: DEFENSE HINTS HEIRESS PROMPTED THEFT INQUIRY
description: The defense in the bribery and theft trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, suggested yesterday that the case had been instigated by a wealthy heiress in the hope of making it easier to collect money she said was owed her by Mr. McLaughlin.

title: DOLE WEIGHS PLAN ON BENCH NOMINEE
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, is considering a parliamentary maneuver that would put Daniel A. Manion on a Federal appeals court without another Senate vote, a spokesman said Thursday.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brazil, Lenders Near Debt Pact
description: The Brazilian Government and its foreign creditors plan to sign a debt rescheduling agreement covering $31 billion in loans later this month in New York, according to Willard C. Butcher, chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SEAMAN FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WILLIAM D. NUNN Jr.
description: William D. Nunn Jr., a biochemist and professor of molecular biology and biochemistry at the University of California at Irvine, died of a heart attack July 1 at his home in Irvine. He was 43 years old.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the latest quarter and 6 months were favorably impacted by approximately 11 cents a share and 21 cents a share, respectively, as a result of adopting FASB 87 pension accounting guidelines.

title: NIXON TO PAY A 'PRIVATE' VISIT TO SOVIET, KREMLIN AIDE SAYS
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to arrive in Moscow on Saturday on a private visit to the Soviet Union, an official of the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What Haiti Needs Is Aid and Understanding
description: To the Editor:

title: Music at Caramoor
description: At Caramoor tonight at 8:30, the pianist and conductor Tamas Vasary will lead the Orchestra of St. Luke's in music by Rossini, Marcello and Haydn and appear as soloist in the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 18 in B flat (K. 456).

title: PRODUCER PRICES FELL IN FIRST HALF AT THE STEEPEST RATE SINCE 1949
description: With oil prices tumbling in the first half of the year, an important measure of inflation fell at the steepest rate since 1949, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A.M.C. Price Rise
description: The American Motors Corporation has raised the suggested retail prices of its American-made Renault Alliance and Encore subcompact cars by 2.9 percent, or about $235 each on average-equipped models.

title: PENTAGON STUDY FAULTS PLANNING ON GRENADA
description: A classified Defense Department assessment of the invasion of Grenada by American forces in 1983 found that the mission was fraught with confusion brought on mainly by hasty planning, newly published documents show.

title: TRANSFERS OF 500 TO EASE CRISIS AT CAPITAL PRISON
description: The Justice Department and penal systems in three states agreed today to take custody of more than 500 of the 800 prisoners driven from their burned-out dormitories at Lorton, the city's reformatory complex in suburban Fairfax County, Va.

title: Some Respect for the Yellow Brigade, Please
description: There has been a lot of attention focused lately on the taxi business in New York City - corruption in the Taxi and Limousine Commission, the appointment of a new chairman, the July 4 strike. Taxi driving is hard and grimy - romantic to some - but a service that we take for granted and perhaps cannot do without.

title: MORTGAGE AND REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $900,000, or 11 cents a share, of additional interest income resulting from the payoff of one participating loan. c-Includes $3,933,000, or 29 cents a share, of additional interest income resulting from the payoff of six participating loans.

title: A.T.&T. Cuts Cost
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has reduced the cost of some phone calls by a penny by cutting rates for calls that go 56 to 124 miles, and for calls that travel 1,911 to 3,000 miles. The savings, which will total $9 million a year, were generated by reductions in the charges local companies pass on to long-distance companies for connecting their calls to the local network of phone lines. A.T.&.T. reduced its rates by $2 billion on June 1.

title: On Traveling to Nicaragua 4 48.8,2.9>
description: As Nicaragua has become an increasingly contentious point of foreign policy debate in recent years, more and more United States policy makers have taken it upon themselves to visit the country.

title: UAL'S BOARD APPROVES ACQUISITION OF FRONTIER
description: The board of UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, today approved, as expected, the acquisition of the Frontier Airlines subsidiary of People Express Inc. for $146 million in cash.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page on Wednesday about the Commissioner of the United States Customs Service incorrectly described the legal status of Arturo Durazo, former police chief of Mexico City. He is on trial in Mexico City on charges of extortion and illegal possesion of firearms.

title: Soviet Team Beats U.S. in Volleyball
description: The Soviet Union, behind the big serves of Yuliya Salcevich, defeated the United States, 15-12, 11-15, 15-4, 15-4, tonight to advance to the championship match of women's volleyball at the Goodwill Games.

title: Powell to Remain on Court
description: Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, given a clean bill of health, said Thursday that he had no intention of retiring.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ken Forsch, the 40-year-old right-hander who was sidelined all of last year with an elbow injury and released May 25 by the California Angels, has been signed by the Seattle Mariners and assigned to Calgary in the Pacific Coast League. . . . Another right-hander, Fred Toliver of the Philadelphia Phillies, will be lost for the rest of the season because of an injury involving bones and ligaments in his right elbow. . . . Also out for the rest of the season is Joe Hesketh, a Montreal Expos left-hander, with a shoulder injury. . . . The shortstop, Dave Concepcion of the Cincinnati Reds will miss more than three weeks because of a broken left hand suffered in a collision at first base with a Montreal infielder, Vance Law. . . . Steve Howe, the onetime Los Angeles Dodgers bullpen ace who has battled cocaine addiction and has been pitching in the minor leagues, has been talking, through his agent, with the Toronto Blue Jays, the club has confirmed. . . . Angel Cordero Jr., who will ride at Belmont Park Sunday for the first time since suffering multiple injuries in a spill March 8, has been named on three horses on the card, including heavily favored Gulch, in the Tremont Stakes for 2-year-olds.

title: EuroDisneyland
description: The regional council for the Paris region has approved plans for a Disneyland amusement park east of the capital city. The park, dubbed EuroDisneyland, will be built in Marne-la-Valee, 20 miles outside of Paris, and will cost 10.6 billion francs, or about $1.5 billion. The council for the Ile de France region voted, 112 to 20, to sign a contract with Walt Disney Productions, which had been negotiating with the French Government since December. Prime Minister Ja

title: PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 12, 1986
description: International

title: 13 Dead in Japan Landslides
description: Landslides caused by torrential rains have killed 13 people in Kagoshima on the southern island of Kyushu, the police said. National Police officials said five more people were missing and more than 800 Self Defense Force personnel, firefighters and local rescue workers were digging through the muddy debris on the city's hilly outskirts.

title: BOMED MEDICAL MANUFACTURNG LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: 2 Alcoa Union Locals Continuing Strike
description: Two locals of the Aluminum, Brick and Glass Workers rejected a contract and continued their strike today against the Aluminum Company of America, a union official said.

title: PINOCHET SAYS HE PLANS TO RULE CHILE UNTIL 1997
description: Rebuffing those who want him to give up power, Gen. Augusto Pinochet said today that he expects to remain President of Chile until 1997.

title: Loans by World Bank
description: The World Bank has announced a $100 million loan to the Government of Hungary and an $81 million loan to Nigeria. The loan to Hungary is intended to accumulate more foreign exchange by producing more farm goods for export and replacing some imports, the World Bank said. The Nigeria loan is to help to improve livestock production.

title: Woman Appeals for Return Of Her 2-Day-Old Daughter
description: A 23-year-old woman appealed today for the return of her 2-day-old daughter, who was taken from her by a woman posing as a nurse at a suburban hospital.

title: How to Get Attention
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, believes in moral persuasion. But, like most Washington veterans, he also believes in the power of the purse.

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sounds of Soul
description: The singer Millie Jackson and the vocal trio Ray, Goodman and Brown will play a double bill tonight at the Red Parrot, 617 West 57th Street (247-1530). Tickets are $15 for the 8:30 P.M. show and $20 for the 11:30 show.

title: AMERICAN LIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A.M.A. ASSAILS DECISION OF JUSTICE DEPT. ON AIDS
description: The American Medical Association charged today that a Justice Department decision permitting certain types of job discrimination against people with AIDS was legally incorrect and unjustified.

title: SWATCH'S BOLD NEW LOOK
description: Swatch, a Swiss company, has an unusual approach to clothing the young American. It is starting with the wrist and going on from there.

title: Margot Einstein, 86, Is Dead; Stepdaughter of Physicist
description: Margot Einstein, a sculptor who was the stepdaughter of Albert Einstein, the physicist who formulated the theory of relativity, died Tuesday at the home in Princeton, N.J., that she had long shared with her stepfather. She was 86 years old.

title: HOTELS FIND FREE FRILLS COST A LOT
description: THE first in-room amenity in a hotel was probably a miniature bar of soap, and that was the standard until shampoo, shower caps, shoe mitts and sewing kits began appearing regularly. In the 1980's, these basics were followed by lotions, bath gels, mouthwashes, shaving cream, razors, chocolates, shoe horns, shoe polish, suntan lotions and even pre-pasted toothbrushes and vitamin pills.

title: Contract for McCallum
description: Napoleon McCallum is probably one of the richest ensigns in the Navy at this moment.

title: STATE TAX OFFICIALS MUST RELEASE 400 RETURNS
description: A Federal judge, accusing New York State tax officials of ''obstructive conduct,'' has ordered them to give 400 income-tax returns to a grand jury that is investigating charges that state auditors extorted bribes from taxpayers.

title: JACKSON HITS 2 TO BEAT SEAVER
description: Reggie Jackson hit two homers, his first since May 14, off Tom Seaver and the California Angels defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5-0, tonight behind the pitching of Kirk McCaskill.

title: BUSH, LOOKING TO 1988, SETS UP A NEW FUND
description: Vice President Bush, saying that he was taking a ''prudent first step'' concerning a possible Presidential bid in 1988, today announced the formation of a new political fund to aid in the election of Republican delegates in precinct contests under way in Michigan.

title: Collaborating to Portray An Unusual Life
description: Michael Anderson is 3 feet, 6 inches tall, the victim of a congenital bone disease. Norris J. Chumley makes documentary films.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 12, 1986
description: The Economy The Producer Price Index, an important measure of inflation, fell at a 6.5 percent annual rate in the first six months of the year, the steepest pace of decline since 1949, the Labor Department said. Collapsing oil prices were the force behind the drop. Producer prices were unchanged in June, and experts predicted that they would be flat or lower for July. Since energy, financing and other costs are also dropping, industrial output and employment could get a much-needed lift. Experts said that the Fed, in cutting its discount rate, had little reason to fear higher inflation. [ Page 1. ] Many U.S. banks lowered their prime lending rates by half a percentage point, to 8 percent, the lowest level since January 1978. Moving one day after the Fed cut its discount rate, the banks said their own cost of funds had fallen in recent weeks. Experts said that small and medium-sized companies, as well as less-developed countries, would benefit the most from the reduction. [ 33. ] Tax conferees must set the limits of ''middle income.'' The decision will have sweeping ramifications for many issues, including the top individual rate, and it will determine whether the plan is viewed as fair, which could have an impact on the national elections in the fall. [ 33. ] The Fed's policy-making committee, by 11 to 1, voted not to change monetary policy at a May meeting, minutes of the session show. The decision to cut the discount rate was apparently made at the Open Market Committee's meeting this week.

title: U.S., KEEPING PRESSURE ON CHILE, SENDS OFFICIAL TO URGE TRANSITION
description: The Reagan Administration continued to press the Chilean Government today for what it called an honest investigation into the death of a young Washington resident who was reportedly set on fire by Chilean soldiers.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings for 1985 periods have been restated to include four banks acquired in pooling-of-interests transactions since mid-year 1985.

title: VAC-TEC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DICKINSON, KING LEAD AT OPEN
description: Judy Dickinson was praying for more rain after she gained a tie with Betsy King today for the second-round lead of the 41st United States Women's Open.

title: WALL STREET WOOS ITS SUMMER INTERNS
description: One balmy evening last month, Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment bankers, held two parties for M.B.A. students spending their summers in New York.

title: Pro Football vs. Drugs: No Contest
description: Are employers justified in testing employees for drug use? The question masks a spectrum of issues ranging from performance to privacy; it may be hard to answer, depending on which employers and which employees. In the case of Pete Rozelle's new drug-testing program for National Football League players, the answer is an easy yes.

title: Tyson 24-0 on Knockout
description: Undefeated Mike Tyson broke Lorenzo Boyd's nose in the first round tonight and then scored a knockout at 1:43 of the second round in a heavyweight bout at the Stevensville Country Club.

title: A Public Relations War
description: Fenton Communications Inc., a Washington-based public relations company with impeccable liberal credentials, has signed on as American spokesman for the Marxist-led Government of Angola, a client that the conservative firm of Gray & Company apparently found too hot to handle.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Kansas City, Mo., yesterday on leadership roles of women in the West misstated the political affiliation of Norma Paulus of Oregon. She is the Republican nominee for Governor, not a Democrat.

title: MENTOR ENFORCES TEAMWORK
description: The man who is winning the Tour de France sped into Nantes in his native Brittany today, riding in a car. His name is Cyrille Guimard, he manages the Systeme U team and he wears an oversize grin these days.

title: Oscar Zariski, 86, Professor In Mathematics at Harvard
description: Oscar Zariski, one of the nation's leading algebraic geometrists who was the Dwight Parker Robinson Professor of Mathematics Emeritus at Harvard University, died July 4 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: British Inflation Drops
description: The annual rate of inflation in Britain fell in June to 2.5 percent, its lowest level in nearly two decades, from 2.8 percent in May, the Government said today. The last time the consumer price index was lower was in November 1967, when the rate was 2 percent.

title: TRIBE'S LATEST ENTERPRISE: BINGO
description: Fifteen years ago, when only a handful of Mashantucket Pequot Indians remained on the reservation here, an elderly woman implored her grandson: ''Hold on to the land.''

title: FRENCH TERROR GROUP SAYS IT PLANTED PARIS BOMB
