description: The authorities said today that a letter purporting to be from Direct Action, a left-wing French terrorist organization, said the group was taking responsibility for a bombing attack this week on the annex of a police headquarters here.

title: WHATEVER YOU DO, PLEASE DO NOT TIP
description: ''Do Not Tip,'' says the guest check at the Casual Quilted Giraffe, the sleek, stainless steel and black Art Deco restaurant opened last week by the owners of the more expensive Quilted Giraffe. And in case a customer misses the admonition, the tip line on the credit card form is crossed out.

title: Short on Supplies
description: Bill Kratzert was forced to withdraw from the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic yesterday when he ran out of golf balls.

title: JUDGE HALTS CONDO SALE AT EAST SIDE BUILDING
description: A state judge has halted the sale of condominium apartments in an Upper East Side building partly owned by the real estate company of the family of Evangeline Gouletas Carey, the wife of former Gov. Hugh Carey.

title: CABARET: BASSEY OPENS THE MARQUIS
description: The Welsh-born singer Shirley Bassey enjoyed the distinction of inaugurating the Marquis - in the Marriott Marquis Hotel at Broadway and 46th Street - the first new musical theater to be built on Broadway in 13 years.

title: BANKS CUT PRIME RATE BY 1/2 POINT
description: Banks across America lowered their prime lending rate yesterday to 8 percent from 8 1/2 percent, the lowest level since January 1978.

title: CUBAN-AMERICAN LEADER BUILDS A FOUNDATION OF POWER BEYOND MIAMI
description: In a cramped upstairs office in a warehouse zone 25 miles southwest of Miami, Jorge Mas Canosa's square face breaks into a smile when he hears himself described as possibly the most powerful Cuban-American in the United States.

title: THOMAS C. BARGER
description: Thomas C. Barger, former president and chief executive officer of the Arabian American Oil Company, died of Parkinson's disease June 30 in San Diego.

title: Peres Looks to Syria To Control Its Allies
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres indicated today in a radio interview that Israel expected Syria to restrain pro-Syrian armed groups in southern Lebanon.

title: THE BALLET: PARIS OPERA 'SWAN LAKE'
description: Rudolf Nureyev's production of ''Swan Lake'' for the Paris Opera Ballet may suggest that the ballet is more about its hero than its heroine. And yet the triumph of Isabelle Guerin as Odette-Odile on Thursday night was proof again that the original focus of every 19th-century classic was its ballerina.

title: A Page Reunion
description: A group of about 40 former Congressional pages, about a third of the class of '81, were to attend a reunion in the capital this weekend, and they expected to have much to talk about.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $2,857,000.

title: CHAMPION SETS HER OWN PACE
description: Some of the other competitors in Los Angeles celebrated the most recent coming of the Olympic ideal by hiring agents who prepared marketing strategies and conducted a careful count of unhatched chickens. Tracie Ruiz prepared by pulling her hair back skull-tight, covering it with unflavored gelatin, getting to work and leaving someday to the future.

title: U.S. Envoy on Latin Tour
description: President Reagan's special envoy for Central America, Philip C. Habib, arrived in El Salvador today for talks with President Jose Napoleon Duarte and other officials, Government and United States Embassy spokesmen said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A WEEKEND IN HAITI CAN INCLUDE A DIVORCE
description: Tom Bagley and Patty Johnson arrived in Haiti from Walpole, Mass., on a Thursday. On Friday morning, Mr. Bagley recalls, a Haitian lawyer took him to a small, bare office in a downtown court building to be divorced from the woman he had been married to for seven years. A clerk asked Mr. Bagley to identify himself and state why he wanted a divorce.

title: THOMAS MICHALAK
description: Thomas Michalak, a conductor and violinist, died of heart failure Thursday at the St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark. He was 45 years old.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNAIONAL INC (o) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $493,000 for the quarter and $1,314,000 for the 6 months.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2.6 million on the repurchase of notes for both the quarter and 6 months. Per share results are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 13.

title: MANDELA PLEA TO CURB CONFLICT REPORTED
description: The imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela recently made an impassioned appeal to a South African Cabinet minister for direct talks to prevent a worsening conflict, a diplomat said today.

title: Chip Makers' Ratio Slips
description: The semiconductor industry's key indicator dropped for the second consecutive month, suggesting that the sales recovery for the beleaguered chip makers may have slowed.

title: CENTERRE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-Includes tax credits of $600,000 for the quarter and $1,065,000 for the 6 months.

title: TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings have been restated for the 33 l/3 percent common distribution made in December 1985. The company said that highlights of the latest quarter included the adoption of the corporate name change from Toledo Trustcorp Inc. to Trustcorp Inc. approved by shareholders at the annual meeting on April 10.

title: BRETT TO MISS ALL-STAR GAME
description: Reserve players for the All-Star Game Tuesday at the Houston Astrodome were named yesterday, although there remained considerable doubt about one of the American League backups and one American League starter was scratched.

title: 10 BLACK REBELS REPORTED KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South African security forces said today that they had shot dead 10 black guerrillas in the last two days.

title: Andrews Set to Return
description: For the first time in two years, William Andrews, the Atlanta Falcons' running back, will get hit on a football field next week.

title: Mexican Soldiers Seize Juarez Police Offices
description: Mexican soldiers wielding bayonets have taken over the police department here, but the Government has denied an assertion by the National Action Party, an opposition party, that the city is under martial law.

title: Friendship in Chains
description: DESSA ROSE. By Sherley Anne Williams. 236 pages. Morrow. $15.95. As Sherley Anne Williams explains in an introductory note to ''Dessa Rose,'' her first novel, the story is based on two historical incidents. In one, she writes: ''A pregnant black woman helped to lead an uprising on a coffle (a group of slaves chained together and herded, usually to market) in 1829 in Kentucky. Caught and convicted, she was sentenced to death; her hanging, however, was delayed until after the birth of her baby.''

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 4 COMPANIES CUT PRICE PAID FOR OIL
description: The nation's four largest oil companies yesterday sharply cut the price they pay suppliers for the major American grade of crude oil. The reductions were as much as $1 a barrel.

title: Hanoi's Leader, From Victory to Defeat
description: Le Duan, the Vietnamese Communist leader who died Thursday at the age of 78, did not enjoy the renown of his predecessor, Ho Chi Minh, and never assumed his title of party chairman. But he was a major figure in our history. Le Duan played a principal role in organizing the victory over the forces of South Vietnam and the United States and then presided over the brutal reunification of North and South. In 17 years at the helm, he also waged an armed conflict with China and sent Vietnam's army to conquer and occupy Cambodia.

title: REAGAN AIDES REPORTED TO WEIGH PLAN FOR A SPECIAL PANEL ON DRUGS
description: President Reagan's advisers are considering whether to recommend that a high-level commission be established to find ways to curb drug abuse, White House officials said today.

title: LEGISLATOR PLANS TO VETO 2D TERM FOR JERSEY JUSTICE
description: A New Jersey State Senator said yesterday that he would seek to block the reappointment of the state's Chief Justice because of what he called ''unseeming indiscretions on his part which tend to reflect poorly upon the dignity of the Supreme Court.''

title: What Haiti Needs Is Aid and Understanding
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eastern Odyssesy of a Famous Unknown American
description: Dean Reed, an American-born singer who spent the last 15 years of his life behind the Iron Curtain, died last month in East Germany. He was one of the Kremlin's favorite performers, and Pravda praised him as ''a true friend and comrade.'' Yet his passing drew scant attention in the West, and obituaries in major newspapers failed to capture the tragedy of his life and possible intrigue shrouding his death. In the end, the Soviet system he strived so tirelessly to promote might very well have seen to his death.

title: A PRECOCIOUS LIFE IMITATES STAR'S ART
description: As the star of Israel Horovitz's ''Today, I Am a Fountain Pen,'' 9-year-old Danny Gerard is masquerading as a 10-year-old.

title: Envoy to Lebanon Shifted
description: Reginald Bartholomew, the United States Ambassador to Lebanon since 1983, will be nominated by President Reagan to be Ambassador to Spain, it was announced today. In Madrid, Mr. Bartholomew would succeed Thomas O. Enders, who is leaving government to join Salomon Brothers, the New York investment firm.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grant to Help Produce 3 Lanford Wilson Plays
description: The Theater Development Fund has announced that its 1986 Clinton Wilder-T.D.F. Production Grant has been awarded to Rod Kaats, a producer, to help mount a production of three one-act plays by Lanford Wilson.

title: Mixed Results From Rate Cut
description: Bond prices were mixed in light trading yesterday, as traders chose to hang on to short-term issues and take profits on more speculative longer-term securities.

title: N.F.L. Postpones Its New Drug Plan
description: The National Football League agreed today to postpone increased mandatory testing of all players for the use of drugs until an arbitrator decides whether it has the right to act unilaterally on the matter.

title: THEODORE F. HATCH
description: Theodore Frederick Hatch, a specialist in health protection for workers, died last Saturday in Concord, N.H. He was 85 years old.

title: Snow Chief Idled For Rest of Year
description: Snow Chief, the nation's richest and most accomplished 3-year-old, has chipped a bone in his right knee and will not race again his year.

title: Water Leak in Arlington, Va.
description: The primary water main supplying this suburb of Washington ruptured early today beneath the Potomac River, leaving 60,000 residents without water and forcing officials to declare a water emergency. Isolated parts of the District of Columbia were also without water. Arlington County returned to about 85 percent of its normal water pressure by afternoon, but Larry Brown, the county manager, banned most outdoor water use.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: TV: CAMPUS SITCOM WITH ALAN KING
description: Now, why would anyone want to saddle a great stand-up comic, a fine humorist such as Alan King, with a family and a job as a college professor? Someone has done this, by way of a sitcom, and a glimpse of the pilot film at 8 o'clock tonight on CBS immediately explains why it is not on the fall schedule as a series, at least as of now.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D. INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Time for a Public Health Raise for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite Leaves Museum to Fly
description: The Air Force has dusted off a Navy satellite that has been hanging in the National Air and Space Museum for 15 years and plans to put it into orbit this fall for communications experiments, officials said today. In return, the museum received an earlier version of the Transit 5-A.

title: G.E. Awarded Engine Contracts
description: The General Electric Company's Aircraft Engine Business Group said it had received a $161 million United States Air Force contract and a $200 million contract with Greece's Hellenic Air Force.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Many Doubt That He Ever Wanted the Power He Gained Over the Utility
description: Beginning next year, a public authority controlled by the Governor of New York will have the power to make a multibillion-dollar takeover bid on Wall Street for the Long Island Lighting Company, a private corporation.

title: Tokyo Seeks Lower Prices
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has asked his ministers to help insure that lower import prices brought on by a stronger yen are passed on to the consumer, a Government official said.

title: Red Sox Discover Weird Way to Win
description: The Boston Red Sox have not built their substantial lead in the American League East merely with superb pitching and opportunistic hitting. A little luck, a never-say-die attitude and taking advantage of opponents' mistakes have also had a lot to do with Boston's firm grip on first place.

title: Patricia A. McDermott Weds Robert S. Narus
description: Patricia Ann McDermott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McDermott of Belle Mead, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert S. Narus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley T. Narus of Convent Station, N.J. The Rev. J. Francis Feenan performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Convent Station.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $363,000 and $433,000, reflecting reduction of income taxes arising from utilization of net operating loss carryforward for latest quarter and year- ago period, respectively.

title: RCA Quits Chip Venture
description: The RCA Corporation, citing overcapacity in the industry, said it had withdrawn from a $230 million electronics factory it was building jointly with the Sharp Electronics Corporation of Japan.

title: LOS ANGELES, IN A SHIFT, CONSIDERS GROWTH CURB
description: For the first time in Los Angeles, a city historically devoted to perpetual growth, a major movement to curb development is growing among residents.

title: Navistar Financial
description: The Navistar International Corporation of Canada said it had agreed to sell its finance subsidiary, the Navistar Financial Corporation Canada, to Genelcan Ltd., a Canadian affiliate of the General Electric Credit Corporation.

title: JUST MESSING AROUNG
description: It squirts six feet into the air, then plummets into a curly mass of fluorescent green or pink or orange. Whether called Silly String, Spaghetti Confetti or Crazy Ribbon, it is fast becoming the fad of the summer for the 5-to-13-year-old set.

title: TO ETHIOPIANS WHO FLEE, SOMALIS OFFER SQUALOR
description: As evening fell, the wind whipped the dust into a surrealistic fog and rain poured down on silhouetted refugees huddled under thornbush branches.

title: TOXIC WASTES REPORTED HIGH IN AFFLUENT AREAS
description: Neighborhoods of higher income often contain more toxic waste and have higher cancer rates than some poorer areas, according to a new study.

title: BROOKLYN WELFARE HOTEL FIRE KILLS FAMILY'S FOUR CHILDREN
description: A family's four children were killed after a fire broke out in their welfare hotel in Brooklyn yesterday, Red Cross and police officials said.

description: Sixteen weeks after the trial began, the jury today began deliberating the charges of espionage and tax fraud against Jerry A. Whitworth.

description: A Federal district judge ordered Guilford Transportation Industries today to rehire with back pay more than 1,700 railroad workers whose jobs were abolished after a strike against the Maine Central Railroad.

PATENTS;
Garment Protects Cat From Impregnation
description: A protective garment patent this week is described as shielding a cat from impregnation. Patent No. 4,598,666, awarded to Dr. Jacob E. Spanko, a Pittsburgh dentist, describes a neck band that prevents a male cat from getting the usual grip with its teeth on the female's neck.

title: TOP-SECRET PLANE IS SAID TO CRASH
description: An Air Force plane crashed in California early today, and experts in military technology identified it as one of the military's most secret weapons, a Stealth fighter designed to elude radar and other sensors.

title: Exchanging Life Insurance
description: SWITCHING life insurance policies from one company to another is not for everyone. Insurance customers who switch are often faced with a new physical examination, new restrictive clauses and other requirements that could be onerous.

title: Florida Democrat Challenges Aspin for Leadership of Panel
description: Representative Charles E. Bennett said today that he would challenge Representative Les Aspin next year for the chairmanship of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: Inquiry Under Way On Burning Tank Car
description: Federal officials investigating the derailment and explosions of a railroad tank car here said today that a weld might have given way when it derailed, exposing the toxic contents.

title: COUNTRYWIDE MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no comparable data for 1985 period because the company had not begun operations in the second quarter of 1985.

title: BancTexas To Sell 4 Banks
description: The BancTexas Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its four Houston-area banks to United Bankers Inc., moving closer to the sale of the entire bank holding company. BancTexas had agreed three weeks ago to sell its seven north Texas banks to Gerald J. Ford, a Dallas banker.

title: JULY 4 CLEANUP MAKE HISTORY
description: Liberty Weekend's revelers generated so much trash that the four-day event has entered the Garbage Hall of Fame.

PATENTS;

description: A Brooklyn chemist is patenting a metal rod that is already being used to strengthen teeth by passage through the root canal.

title: Canada's Joblessness
description: Canada's unemployment rate declined one-tenth of 1 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted level of 9.5 percent, the Government said today. Statistics Canada, which compiles jobless figures, estimated that almost 11.7 million were employed last month, up 49,000 from May, when unemployment stood at 9.6 percent. The Government agency said most of the increase in employment resulted from hiring to carry out the 1986 census.

title: Stocks Mostly Off; Loss in Week 79.44
description: Despite a reduction in the interest rates set by the Government and banks, stock prices were mostly lower yesterday as one of the worst weeks in Wall Street's history came to an end.

title: The Dirty Days Are Near
description: A long time ago I had a friend more candid than most. ''I like my sex dirty,'' he used to say.

title: EDDIE SHU
description: Eddie Shu, a versatile jazz musician who played in Gene Krupa's orchestra in the 1950's and with Louis Armstrong's All Stars in the 1960's, died on July 4 in St. Petersburg, Fla. Mr. Shu, who had had cancer for several years, lived in Tampa, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: FROM MADISON SQ. PARK TO SHEA, BASEBALL'S ROOTS RUN DEEP IN CITY
description: This has long been a city of box scores and fly balls, lazy bleacher afternoons and legends. By some accounts, baseball was born in New York, some of the game's greats played here and for every new star who signs a contract to play the summer game, the city offers an echo from the sport's past.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of directors of People Express in Business Day yesterday misidentified one, David F. Thomas. He is vice president at Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd., not president.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL DIVIDED OVER HIGH COURT RULING
description: A divided Civil Rights Commission, in the face of a Congressional threat to cut off its money, today rejected a resolution that asked the Justice Department to stop opposing affirmative action plans.

title: SHORE RESIDENTS FIGHT MOSQUITOES AND THE CITY
description: Like many of the grand homes along the shoreline of Douglaston, Queens, the Mattone house has a panoramic view of sailboats bobbing on Little Neck Bay. There are two secluded brick patios for enjoying the outdoors and a large deck off the second-story kitchen.

title: DR. RALPH WALDO LLOYD
description: Dr. Ralph Waldo Lloyd, president emeritus of Maryville College in Maryville, Tenn., died Monday at his home in Bradenton, Fla.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Going Out Guide on Wednesday misstated the days for tours from Manhattan to Brooklyn museums offered by Lou Singer, and provided incomplete telephone information. The tours are given Wednesdays through Sundays. The telephone - (718) 852-0384 - is answered from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M.

title: FERRY SLASHING REPORT ASSAILS HOSPITAL FOR FREEING SUSPECT
description: A city investigation concluded yesterday that Presbyterian Hospital was wrong to release a mental patient who two days later was charged with killing two passengers and wounding nine others with a sword on a Staten Island ferryboat.

title: BLOOD BANKS ACT TO COUNTER DANGEROUS HEPATITIS STRAIN
description: Evidence that blood transfusions are giving some recipients a dangerous form of hepatitis has become so compelling that the nation's blood banks have decided to screen donations for it even though they lack a precise test.

title: BOARD MOVES ON APPROVAL OF HIGH SCHOOLS HEAD
description: In a lengthy session, its first meeting under its new president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., the city's Board of Education yesterday approved in principle the controversial appointment of a new executive director of the city's 111 high schools.

title: CITY OPERA: 'KISMET' CHANGES
description: As used to be said of ''Blossom Time,'' ''Kismet'' is one of those musicals where the audience walks into the theater humming the tunes, and purists assert that the best way to experience it is to listen to the Borodin String Quartet No. 2, from whence most of the memorable melodies spring. Still, those willing to put reality on hold and immerse themselves in a preposterous but unusually likable fantasy world may find the New York City Opera's current production a beguiling couple of hours.

description: A 63-year-old man was found stabbed to death last night in a pet-food store on the Lower East Side, the police said.

ON LONG ISLAND;
The Buyer Pays for Construction Delays
description: WHEN a development of 28 single-family houses called Pond Estates opened for sales in Setauket last summer, the developer lacked building permits for two of the lots, so those houses had to be kept off the market. The rest of the project sold out in six months.

description: The terms of 31 patents owned by the General Foods Corporation, which has its headquarters in White Plains, have been extended for five years, 10 months and 17 days.

description: Governor Cuomo and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato paid a higher percentage of their incomes in taxes than Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for Governor, according to income tax returns for the last four years.

description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that it had earned $52.4 million, or $1.42 a share, in the second quarter, up 7.2 percent from $48.9 million, or $1.34 a share, a year ago.

title: All Hail the Marine Band
description: By definition, there is nothing more loyal than a present or former member of the Marine Corps, and a number of them seem to think the extensive telecasts of Liberty Weekend in New York did not sufficiently credit the United States Marine Band as a star performer. The director, Col. John R. Bourgeois, has received a number of calls to that effect, including one from a crusty general who inquired, ''What was that masked band?''

title: Turkish Cypriots to Open Greek Crossing Points
description: The Turkish Cypriot administration announced today that it would reopen crossing points between the Greek and Turkish Cypriot sectors on Saturday.

description: Officials of the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York ordered a recall of approximately 66,000 bottles of Lemon Lime Slice in the metropolitan area yesterday, after an anonymous caller told the police that he had contaminated a ''bottle or bottles'' of ''Pepsi'' with cyanide.

description: The Yankees took another step forward behind their Kiddie Corps tonight as Doug Drabek became their third pitcher in the last nine games to gain his first major league victory.

description: Liberal arts graduates are back in demand in corporate suites, and it's a trend that is sure to bring rewards to companies that realize the practical value of a liberal education.

Copeland is part of the Cope-Pam Holding Company, an affiliate of the Hillman Company, a closely held company based in Pittsburgh. Emerson declined to disclose the sale price.

description: A Maryknoll priest was robbed and knifed on a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday morning, the police said.

title: OPERA: HOIBY'S 'TEMPEST,' IN IOWA
description: ''The Tempest,'' Shakespeare's last major play, has constantly tempted composers, but no one has yet succeeded on the same level as Verdi with ''Otello'' and ''Falstaff'' or even Gounod with ''Romeo et Juliette.'' Mozart, Mendelssohn and Britten contemplated the task and then abandoned it. All manner of lesser composers have plunged forward, including in our own time Frank Martin of Switzerland and the American John Eaton, whose version was first heard last summer at the Santa Fe Opera.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, said it had agreed in principle to acquire H-C Industries, a maker of plastic closures, steel crowns and packaging machinery for bottlers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Manson Follower Again Denied Parole
description: Leslie Van Houten, the youngest of Charles Manson's followers, was denied parole today. The parole board cited the ''henious, atrocious'' nature of the the 1969 Sharon Tate-LaBianca killings in which she was convicted.

title: ADVANCED MICRO, INTEL CITE LOSSES
description: Citing weak demand from the computer industry, two of the largest semiconductor manufacturers today reported continuing losses for the quarter ended in June. They were Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Intel Corporation.

title: Poland Gives Medal To New York Restorer
description: Gustav Berger, an art conservator from New York City, yesterday received the Special Medal of Merit for Polish Culture from the Polish Government for his part in restoring ''The Panorama of Raclawice,'' a 400-foot-long historical painting on exhibit in Wroclaw, Poland.

title: HIJACKING VERDICTS APPEALED
description: The public prosecutor's office filed an appeal today of the verdicts and sentences in the Achille Lauro hijacking case, arguing that some of the jail terms ordered by a jury here should be more severe.

This weekend, it is inserting into its repertory a new show that does not require a certificate of competence in Castilian in order to be savored.

title: KEY TAX BILL QUESTION: WHAT'S MIDDLE CLASS?
description: When the House and Senate conferees start carving a compromise tax plan next week, they have to come to grips with the elusive question of what constitutes the middle class.

title: What a City Council Might Do Well
description: For the first time in a generation, members of New York's City Council have had to learn what it's like to adopt a budget without the tutelage of strong-willed leaders. What they learned is that it's not very different. The discipline once ascribed to Thomas Cuite, the majority leader, and finance chairman Edward Sadowsky turns out to inhere also in something called fiscal reality.

title: Mexican Debt Talks
description: Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepulveda Amor of Mexico said today that his country was close to reaching an agreement with international financial institutions on a restructuring of Mexico's foreign debt. He told a news conference at the end of a three-day visit to Portugal that negotiations on Mexico's $98 billion debt were going on with different institutions, principally the International Monetary Fund. An agreement would make Mexico eligible for $1.5 billion from the I.M.F. and open the door for new loans from other lenders.

title: Navy Salutes Rickover
description: The Navy will pay its final respects to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover in a memorial service at the National Cathedral Monday at 1 P.M. The service, open to the public, will be led by Adm.

title: WHY ARE ALL THOSE SWANS DRESSED IN BALCK?
description: Audiences may love it or loathe it, but it's impossible to shrug off the New York City Ballet's ''Swan Lake,'' as redesigned by Alain Vaes. Indeed, it may be one of the two most instructive reinterpretations of a work from the standard repertory to be seen in recent years - the other being Dance Theater of Harlem's ''Giselle.'' Both clearly distinguish between choreography and stage production - a distinction that is sometimes ignored in mountings of familiar works - and, in their own ways, both exemplify how scenery and costumes can enhance or obscure choreographic meanings.

title: CHILEAN OPPOSITION TO PROTEST PINOCHET PLAN
description: Opposition parties vowed today to begin a new round of protests after President Augusto Pinochet indicated he would seek to stay in power until 1997.

title: MARRIAGE AND OTHER STEADY HABITS
description: I FEEL like the dodo bird. As a member of genus Marriedlongtimus, I seem to be in a group quickly becoming extinct.

title: ROCK: VAN MORRISON AND GROUP
description: THE career of Van Morrison, one of rock music's most defiantly idiosyncratic singer-songwriters, has been marked by a gradual movement away from hard-edged soul-inflected music toward the quieter realm of mystical rumination. Mr. Morrison's latest album, ''No Guru, No Method, No Teacher,'' is a prolonged reverie whose most vivid image is of a luminous garden wet with rain. Its songs pointedly compare erotic love with paradise, the holy trinity and divine salvation.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ANIMAL HEALTH CARE
description: THE floundering farm economy is taking its toll on the drug, chemical and biotechnology companies that last year sold nearly $2 billion worth of products to treat, immunize or fatten American farm animals and pets. During the past five years, sales of drugs, vaccines, and feed additives have grown at the anemic rate of 1 percent a year, compared with average annual growth of 13 percent between 1975 and 1980, according to the Animal Health Institute, a trade group for companies in animal health care.

title: BORGES ON LIFE AND DEATH
description: I MET Jorge Luis Borges in 1981, when I returned to Buenos Aires from a job at the BBC in London and began working for La Prensa. He received me very kindly, remembering that during the 1920's, when he was not well known, La Prensa had been the first newspaper to publish him. Later I returned to see him frequently. Sometimes he would dictate a poem that he had been composing during a long night of insomnia. After typing it, I would put it in his desk near his collection of Icelandic sagas, a precious gift from his father.

title: JANUARY INTRUDER AT FERRARO OFFICE CALLED 'JUST A SNEAK THIEF'
description: The intruder wore sunglasses and carried an instant camera. When he was found on a quiet Saturday afternoon in the Queens office suite of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, he conjured up images of political espionage and intrigue.

title: Kelly Shafer Engaged
description: The engagement of Kelly Doreen Shafer and Todd Mitchell Felsen has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Shafer of Ludington, Mich., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Morry Krantz of Randolph, N.J., and Miami Beach, and Neil A. Felsen of Secaucus, N.J.

title: Children of Poverty
description: I read Andrew Stein's article, and I wondered, why not start a program, similar to Save the Children, dedicated to ''saving'' homeless children in New York City or, at least, to improving the quality of their lives. Those of us who are not affluent enough to adopt or sponsor a child might participate in a program which would enable us to help a child with the purchase of a school bag, a new pair of jeans or a doll for a monthly contribution of, perhaps, $10.

title: Cocaine Draws New Attention
description: Cocaine was news last week: Government reports attested to its popularity, politicians went to upper Manhattan to buy it and Pete Rozelle announced a plan to curb its use in the National Football League.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ROMAN. By Douglas C. Jones. (Henry Holt, $16.95.) In a previous novel, ''Elkhorn Tavern,'' Douglas C. Jones described the early years of Roman Hasford, a boy living in the Arkansas hill country during the Civil War.

title: CARTOON ART TO CHEER PATIENTS
description: MORE than 50 original cartoons and comic strips by noted cartoonists from around the country will add a touch of cheer to the treatment rooms of the Yale Comprehensive Cancer Center when it opens its Collection of Cartoon Art next Sunday.

title: Arafat Proposes U.N. Take Over West Bank
description: Yasir Arafat has proposed in a magazine interview that the West Bank be put under United Nations administration as a step toward resolving the Middle East conflict.

title: BMW Readies A New Home
description: Eleven years ago, when BMW AG, the West German manufacturer of automobiles and motorcycles, started its United States subsidiary, it placed its headquarters in Montvale, N.J., largely as a matter of convenience.

title: In Wake of Offices, Morris Affordables
description: In the last several years, as Morris County, N.J., has become a focal point for Fortune 500 corporate offices, developers have struggled to keep pace with the growing demand for affordable housing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 13, 1986
description: International

title: 2 IN ULSTER POLICE REMOVED FROM DUTY
description: Two senior police officers in the Royal Ulster Constabulary have been removed from operational duty as part of a continuing investigation into charges that police pursued a ''shoot to kill'' policy against unarmed Roman Catholics.

title: Manila Takes Stakes on Turf
description: Manila rallied relentlessly in deep stretch to wear down Glow and win the Lexington Stakes by a nose on the turf at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: CASINOS FEARFUL OF CHAOS
description: THE chairman of the Atlantic City Casino Association has warned that, because of lack of concern by government, the industry faces chaos before the end of the decade.

title: INSIDE THE EXPLOSION
description: THE BIG DANCE The Untold Story of Kathy Boudin and the Terrorist Family That Committed the Brink's Robbery Murders. By John Castellucci. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; The Rebirth of A Seedy Strip
description: MORE than ten years ago, the Hollywood production team for the movie ''Cinderella Liberty'' was seeking a street that would evoke the feel of a sleazy sailor haunt. The team settled on First Avenue, a string of strip joints, tattoo parlors and taverns with early-morning happy hours.

title: Jordan Expels Arafat Again
description: For Yasir Arafat, expulsion from Jordan is nothing new. In 1970 and 1971, when Mr. Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization seemed to be getting strong enough to threaten King Hussein, the army killed thousands of P.L.O. guerrillas and chased the rest out of the kingdom.

title: Thanks to Everybody For Liberty Weekend
description: To the Editor:

title: A SHORT-CUT TO THE BEST SOLUTION
description: ''WHAT if?'' was the question that launched a million micros. Personal computing in the business world came of age with the spreadsheet, first VisiCalc legitimizing the Apple II, then Lotus 1-2-3 driving the I.B.M. PC to stellar success.

title:
INVESTING;
AFTER WALL STREET'S LATEST JOLT
description: DESPITE a torrid East Coast heat wave early last week, a sudden, scary chill hit Wall Street. After watching the market set record highs the previous week, traders knocked almost 62 points off the Dow Jones industrial average last Monday. The slide continued on Tuesday, as the Dow lost another 18 points.

title: EX-POLICE CHIEF OFFERS AN APOLOGY FOR SCANDAL
description: When Arthur G. Hess took over the 250-member police force of South Carolina in 1978, city officials hoped he would lift morale and repair the department's tarnished image.

title: HINAULT WINS TRAIL TO TAKE 3d
description: Bernard Hinault dispelled all the doubts and rumors about his health today by winning the first major test in the Tour de France bicycle race, a 61.5-kilometer (38-mile) time trial, and moving into third place in the overall standings.

title: CENTER AIDS THE POOR AND MIDDLE CLASS
description: The high quality of the reporting was clearly evident in the article ''Helping Couples Cope With Children'' on June 15, describing the program of the Open Door Parent-Child Caring Center. There are, however, two errors that we would like to correct: 1.

title: TOPICS
description: I HAVE developed a romantic attachment to the Northern State Parkway. For 30 minutes every weekday morning I enjoy my trip to work in Centereach. I daresay that the reason for my enjoyment stems from the fact that I drive against rush-hour traffic.

title: TAKEOVER PROPOSAL CALLED REASONABLE, BUT INADEQUATE
description: An article in the New Jersey Weekly of June 22 by Anthony S. Cicatiello, the head of a public-relations concern that represents major corporations, advocates passage of legislation that would protect New Jersey companies from being stripped of their assets by hostile takeovers financed by junk bonds.

title: Evelyn Haber Marries Philip Averill Berman
description: The marriage of Evelyn Ruth Haber and Philip Averill Berman took place last night at Temple Israel in Manhattan. Rabbi Martin Zion officiated.

title: Catherine Reilly, A Teacher, Weds
description: Catherine Maureen Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Reilly of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Wyatt Uhlein 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Uhlein Jr. of Litchfield, Conn., and Cape Vincent, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: PRINCE'S 'CHERRY MOON' LACKS A GLOW
description: ''Once upon a time,'' says the narrator at the beginning of ''Under the Cherry Moon,'' ''there lived a bad boy named Christopher Tracy . . .''

title: PARENTS ARRESTED IN DEATHS OF 4 CHILDREN IN HOTEL FIRE
description: The parents of four small children who were killed in a fire at a Brooklyn welfare hotel were arrested yesterday and charged with endangering them by leaving them alone in their room, authorities said.

title: BEYOND STOCKHOLM, AN ISLAND ODYSSEY
description: The 24,000 islands of the Stockholm archipelago float in a gray-blue sea like so many pieces of broken china scattered across the floor in every conceivable shape and size, from tiny shards to the odd half-plate with a jag-ged edge.

title: CANTON TO HOST AMATEUR GAMES
description: FOR years, many of the state's major sports attractions have been held in relatively small cities and towns. The Greater Hartford Open professional golf tournament is held in Cromwell, some of the nation's biggest stock car races are run in Lime Rock and perhaps the state's premier long-distance running event, the Litchfield Hills Road Race, is staged in Litchfield.

title: YANKS WIN, 8-0; AGUILERA EXCELS; 4 HITS BY DYKSTRA
description: The Mets staged a 25-year reunion of old-timers yesterday to salute their adventurous past, then got back to the business of their rosy future and wiped out the Atlanta Braves for the third straight game.

title: ITALIAN IS FAVORITE IN WOMEN'S TOUR
description: The other Tour de France, the women's version for 86 riders from 12 countries, is off and rolling cautiously.

title: BEST SELLERS: JULY 13, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Measuring Ineptitude
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MT. VERNON GROUP IS IN QUEST TO BREED 'PERFECT' VEGETABLES
description: CARROTS - crunchier, juicier and sweeter - that are beyond the aspirations of most gifted gardeners are making their debut this month as a snack food in 100 test-marketing areas nationwide. The carrots, the offspring of a union between a plant biotechnology company and a giant food producer, will be entering the $6.7 billion snack market under the name VegiSnax as a product of the Kraft Food Company. What is unusual is that the carrots were bred with the crunchiness and sweetness built in to Kraft's specifications by DNA Plant Technologies Corporation, headquartered in Mount Kisco and familiarly known as DNAP.

title: The Death of A Son
description: I relate to the feelings of Albert F. Knight, as I, too, lost my only son in August 1965 (''The Death of a Son,'' About Men, June 22). David drowned while on a Y.M.C.A camping trip in Maine.

title: I'M SUCCESSFUL AND YOU'RE NOT
description: SLAVES OF NEW YORK By Tama Janowitz. 278 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title:
ART;
OLD SUMMER FUN IN YALE DISPLAY
description: THE emphasis is on the adjective ''old'' with the current offering at the Yale Art Gallery, ''The Good Old Summertime.'' This show of prints and drawings is an engrossing survey of American mores from 1850 to 1910. We are again reminded that our country was founded on Puritanism and that we learned slowly to have fun.

title: SOME LEGENDARY PLAYING FROM BARERE
description: Simon Barere is pretty much forgotten today except by a small group of piano buffs who put him on the level of Hofmann, Friedman, Lhevinne and the other Romantic masters. One thing cannot be disputed. The Russian-born Barere (1896-1951) had one of the fabulous mechanisms of all time, an assertion that can be backed up by a two-disk album of all his HMV recordings, made between 1934 and 1936 (Archives APR 7001). The set is available through the German News Company and by mail order to Archive Piano Recordings, P.O. Box 57, Horsham, West Sussex RH1 37Y, England.

title: SQUASH AFICIONADOS UNITE TO BUY THREATENED SOUTHPORT CLUB
description: IN the grand scheme of things, the announced demise of the Southport Racquet Club could hardly be construed as an earth-shaking event. Still, it was the sort of news that comes so suddenly, so out of the blue, that people tend to remember where they were when they heard it.

title: SUBWAY MUSICIAN CHALLENGES THE LAW
description: The lilting melody of ''Spanish Romance,'' a 13th-century Spanish folk tune, floated across the gray platform of the subway station at 53d Street and Lexington Avenue. While passers-by listened, Lloyd Carew-Reid bent over his acoustic guitar, earning his living and breaking the law.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ANNUAL SIDEWALK SALE - New Canaan's annual sidewalk sale will be from 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Saturday. The local Chamber of Commerce has prohibited participants from importing special merchandise for the sale ''because we don't want this to degenerate into a sleazy operation,'' said Beth Toner-Alonzo, executive director of the chamber.

title: The Cotswolds
description: To the Editor: Many thanks for John Chancellor's article ''The Cotswolds, an Inn at a Time'' (Travel, May 11). It captures perfectly the spirit and serenity of the English countryside, whose beauty and intricacies can indeed be perceived better on foot than any other way.

title: BUSTLING PORT ELIZABETH LIVING UP TO ITS ROLE AS CONTAINER SHIP HUB
description: THE huge steel boxes being hoisted off ships here on a recent afternoon were a familiar sight to Bernard J. Sloan, manager of New Jersey marine terminals for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: No Smoking On or Off the Job
description: UNDER a new labor contract, the Police Department of Holden, Mass., banned smoking last September, both on and off the job, by any of its newly hired full-time officers.

title:
GARDENING;
NEW IDEAS ON VISIT TO ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: ON a typical business day, Rockefeller Center may seem to be a madhouse of elbow-to-elbow pedestrians and throbbing traffic. Yet, it is not uncommon amid this mass of activity to see someone stopped to admire a planter filled with live trees, shrubs and flowers, or even a small park.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection will hold a public hearing Tuesday on a cleanup plan for Price's Pit, one of the most serious and controversial Superfund sites in New Jersey.

title: FROM COLT .45s TO THE METS '86
description: WHEN you look back on 23 years in the big leagues, what you're really looking back on is 23 years of performing in public and relating to people. So, most of my private memories of my life in baseball involve public reactions and relationships. Even the nickname ''Le Grand Orange.''

title: STRETCHING THE S.E.C.'S REACH
description: JOHN S. R. SHAD took his wife and family to the Orient last summer for vacation. After traveling through India, Nepal, Singapore and China, they arrived in Kyoto, Japan, a city Mr. Shad had last seen at the end of World War II.

title: CONSUMER RATES

GARDENING;
NEW IDEAS ON VISIT TO ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: ON a typical business day, Rockefeller Center may seem to be a madhouse of elbow-to-elbow pedestrians and throbbing traffic. Yet, it is not uncommon amid this mass of activity to see someone stopped to admire a planter filled with live trees, shrubs and flowers, or even a small park.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No psychological test has any proven validity, not even the crudest accuracy, in forecasting violence.'' -Dr. John Monahan, forensic psychologist at the University of Virginia School of Law and author of ''Predicting Violent Behavior.'' [ 18:2. ]

title: Highland Falls
description: To the Editor:

title: The Zeckendorf Flag Flying High Again
description: A SILVER-BLUE limousine with license number 9593TBN is heading north on Park Avenue, weaving in and out of traffic on rain-slickened streets. In the right front seat, working the phone and oblivious to the confusion on the street, is William Zeckendorf Jr. He is in a hurry.

title: FRIENDS, IT SEEMS, ARE NOT PERFECT
description: EVERYONE seems to know about long and apparently good marriages that came to an end with an ''incident'' such as the children leaving home. As with less-formal relationships, something essential had evidently been missing in our case.

title: DANCE: A FRENCH-AMERICAN BILL AT BATTERY PARK
description: THE setting was spectacular, with an uninterrupted view of New York harbor and the Statue of Liberty, and ships, blimps and birds hovering or nosing over at times to get a glimpse of ''Liberty Dances.'' It was an ambitious evening of new French and American modern dance that Elise Bernhardt and Dancing in the Streets presented on Friday. And two of the dances fully lived up to the promise of the program, which will be presented again through tomorrow. Liz Lerman's ''Still Crossing'' brought new meaning to this month's celebrations of the Statue of Liberty centennial. And Josette Baiz's ''Water, the Matter'' was a provocative, sleek little bit of madness that wittily appraised a disturbing facet of modern life.

title: Helen T. Rollins Plans To Marry W. A. Lord
description: Helen Tremaine Rollins, an analyst for CSA Inc., a computing leasing concern in Boston, and William Aborn Lord, a vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, plan to be married Aug. 23.

title: THEATER FOCUSING ON ENGLISH PLAYS
description: HAVING started the season with a sentimental, all-out, all-American splash - and the timeliest of all possible musicals (Irving Berlin's ''Miss Liberty'') - Summerfun Theatre Inc. has now apparently switched allegiance.

title: TWILIGHT BRINGS OUT FUN FOR FRESH AIR CAMPERS
description: Children have sung songs around fires as long as they have been camping. But what 31 boys from Camp Hayden-Marks of the Fresh Air Fund joined in during a recent twilight sing-along was a far cry from ''Tenting Tonight'' or ''Good Night Ladies.''

title: The Monsters in My Head
description: I WAS SURE HE WAS COMING to get me. First a hard step on the gravel and then a foot dragging behind. Step-drag, step-drag. I lay frozen in my bed. The long alleyway between our family house and the neighbor's was hardly three feet wide; dark, covered with black dirt, gravel and tufts of weeds and grass just barely able to survive the sunless space. The two windows of my room faced the clapboard wall of our neighbor's house, and Venetian blinds remained permanently closed against the nonview.

title: Spero T. Lappas Wed To Julie M. Sourbeer
description: Julie Marie Sourbeer and Spero Thomas Lappas were married yesterday at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Camp Hill, Pa., by the Rev. George Daskalakis.

title: TOPICS
description: HAVING contemplated the unbelievable current divorce rate of older married couples, I've decided to keep my husband.

title: Actuary Engaged To Miss Garrity
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Garrity of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Anne Garrity to Edward R. Heilbron, the son of Josephine K. Heilbron of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Robert S. Heilbron. A September wedding is planned.

title: THE ILLEGITIMATE THEATER
description: THE TRIUMPH OF PIERROT The Commedia dell'Arte and the Modern Imagination. By Martin Green and John Swan. Illustrated. 297 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: ACTING: THE METHOD AND MYSTIQUE OF JACK NICHOLSON
description: JACK NICHOLSON IS SINGING ''Three Blind Mice'' for his visitor. Actually, singing might be the wrong word for the eerie droning intonations he's producing; it sounds more like ritual chanting.

title: HANDS-ON HISTORY FOR GREENWICH YOUTHS
description: LOYALISTS to the King of England were dressed in shorts and short-sleeve shirts as they huddled on one part of the battlefield. Patriots of the American Revolution, in similar attire, conferred on another.

title: INTRIGUE AND TYRANNY IN MOTOR CITY
description: FORD The Men and the Machine. By Robert Lacey. Illustrated. 778 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: THEATER: 3 PLAYS BY AGATHA CHRISTIE
description: EVERY summer the Apple Corps Theater presents a mystery festival, with plays by Agatha Christie and her rivals, designed to chill theatergoers. That the theater itself is comfortably air-cooled adds to one's customary enjoyment of this lightweight seasonal entertainment. However, the company's current production, three one-act Agatha Christie plays grouped under the title ''Rule of Three,'' is the thinnest of contrivances. Each play, in fact, lacks rudimentary mystery ingredients. The only mystery is how Dame Agatha could have regarded them as the real thing.

title: CONJURER IN EXILE
description: LESS THAN ONE Selected Essays. By Joseph Brodsky. 501 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: MR. WOLFE AND MR. BEATON
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: ACCOMPANIMENT TO NEWPORT'S SPLENDOR
description: Most people in the music business are convinced that the who and the what of a concert performance often take second place to the where. The ambiance of a listening space, that is to say, can exert a strong pull on listeners with only vague notions of what they are about to hear.

title: Mary Patricia Kurtz Weds John Stone 3d
description: The marriage of Mary Patricia Kurtz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Kurtz of Stamford, Conn., to John McWilliams Stone 3d, a son of Mr. Stone Jr. of Wayne, Ill., and Hays Clemens Stone of Geneva, Ill., took place yesterday. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Witness in Wife-Killing Case Is Sentenced in Plea Bargain
description: A Louisiana man whose testimony helped send a former New Jersey insurance broker to death row for the murder of his wife has been sentenced to five years in prison as part of a plea bargain in the case.

title: TAX CURB HOLDS BACK A GROWING CITY
description: The faster this city grows, the farther behind it falls financially because of a state law that limits tax increases.

title: KEEPING BALANCHINE'S BALLETS AUTHENTIC BUT ALSO VITAL
description: George Balanchine's ballets are among the dance world's priceless treasures, a seemingly inexhaustible repository of inspiration and renewal for dancers, choreographers and audiences - indeed, for anyone interested in 20th-century art.

title: Sailboat Made for Disabled
description: Tom Banks had just come in from an afternoon of sailing. His wire-rimmed sunglasses were glazed with dried saltwater spots; his dark, curly hair was tousled from 30-knot winds, and his complexion had the ruddy tones that come from sunshine reflected on water.

title: FED GIVES A KICK TO A DULL ECONOMY
description: The Fed again moved to stimulate the stubbornly sluggish economy, cutting the discount rate by half a point, to 6 percent, and analysts said another cut is possible. The third reduction this year put the discount rate at its lowest in more than eight years, and immediately began showing up in lower prime rates - down to 8 percent at major banks. But West Germany and Japan did not immediately follow suit, despite pressure from the United States. Japan said its economy was stimulated enough, thank you, citing the rapid fall of the yen against the dollar.

title: TRYING TO COOL TEMPERS IN EAST HAMPTON
description: A woman walked into the village police station here one recent summer's day and asked the desk officer, Bruce Backlund, if it would be legal to carry a concealed hammer in her purse. She said she wanted to bash in cars that do not yield to pedestrians in crosswalks.

title: 'DULL, DULLER, DULLES'
description: THE JOHN FOSTER DULLES BOOK OF HUMOR By Louis Jefferson. 224 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95. THE title suggests a riddle: where do you place ''The John Foster Dulles Book of Humor'' in a bookstore? Between ''Dean Rusk's Favorite Recipes'' and ''George Shultz's Ten Best Party Tricks''? Those who never knew, or hardly remember, the austere Presbyterian Dulles, President Eisenhower's Secretary of State and the man for whom the homburg hat must have been invented, might initially suspect that ''The John Foster Dulles Book of Humor'' is a deliberate oxymoron. The image problem was once addressed by Dulles himself: ''Anyway, I know that in some ways I am a cold fish, and that I'm afraid is that.'' Also, it was Prime Minister Anthony Eden of Britain who used to joke about ''dull, duller, Dulles.''

title: BACTERIAL COLONIES LIKE US
description: MICROCOSMOS Four Billion Years of Evolution From Our Microbial Ancestors. By Lynn Margulis and Dorion Sagan. Foreword by Lewis Thomas. Illustrated. 301 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: P. R. Sprayregen And Miss Netter Are Wed on L.I.
description: Laurie Netter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Netter of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married last evening to Philip R. Sprayregen, a son of Mrs. Lee V. Eastman of New York and East Hampton and the late Richard H. Sprayregen. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Netter home in East Hampton.

title: SINGING THE BLUES
description: THEY ARE AS plain and serviceable as a rail fence, and it is rare to find a man who hasn't owned a pair. But now, for the first time since the late 1970's, rugged denim blue jeans are returning as a badge of casual style.

title: Saving Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY JUNCTURE FOR GOVERNOR'S RACE IN HARTFORD
description: Next Saturday afternoon, if the schedule holds, the Democratic state convention here will decide whether the gubernatorial contest between Gov. William A. O'Neill and Toby Moffett ends, or begins a new phase.

title: BALLET: PARISIANS OFFER LOCAL PREMIERE OF 'LULLI'
description: AS Alice in Wonderland might say, the Paris Opera Ballet season is becoming curiouser and curiouser. Presenting its second program for the first time Friday night, this unpredictable company came up with quite a few surprises.

title: THE DANCE: FILM USED FOR 'MOVING IMAGES'
description: Three choreographers combined dance with films in ''Moving Images,'' the program offered Wednesday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The items on it were fascinating not only because they were three effective dances, but also because they exemplified three ways of uniting cinematic and choreographic imagery.

title: THE CHERNOBYL DOCTOR
description: HEADING FOR THE LOS ANGELES International Airport on a warm, sunny afternoon in late May, Dr. Robert Peter Gale stopped at a bookstore to get a copy of Tolstoy's ''The Death of Ivan Ilyich.''

title: OLD-FASHIONED GAZEBOS CAN INSPIRE GARDEN DESIGN
description: Jay Litton Pennock Jr. doesn't deny the romance of gazebos.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: OUT OF THE PAST - Back in 1907, when Gustav Buek and his wife bought Home Sweet Home, the 1660 cottage in East Hampton that was the ancestral home of the poet-diplomat John Howard Payne, they were determined to make it as authentic as possible. So these summer folks spent the next 20 years filling the unpretentious saltbox with American furniture and English ceramics from Payne's era, 1791 through 1852.

title: LEGISLATURE AWAITING REPORT ON THE FUTURE OF OLD LANDFILLS
description: LATER this summer, the state's Department of Environmental Protection will present the Legislature with a new report on one of New Jersey's least-publicized environmental problems:

title: THE PLOT TO START A RACE WAR
description: THE LANDING By Haynes Johnson and Howard Simons. 319 pp. New York: Villard Books. $17.95.

title: RETURNING WITH A PEACE ANTHEM
description: JAMES PAPOULIS is not so far removed from Cold Spring Harbor High School and his suburban Huntington roots - a mere decade, in fact - that he is not ''incredibly excited'' about returning home Tuesday in a kind of local-boy-makes-good appearance at Heckscher Park.

title: INTERRUPTIONS TEND TO CAUSE CONFUSION
description: Some very odd things happen at bridge tournaments, both at the table and away from it. One in each category came together late at night during the 1986 Spring Nationals in Portland, Ore.

title: Dance
description: Dance lovers may well feel festive, for summertime is festival time. Some of the festivities will take place Sunday and Monday on the esplanade in Battery Park, where Dancing in the Streets, Inc., is presenting ''Liberty Dances.''

title: HIGH-TECH, WIRED, ENTANGLED RUNNING
description: HESITANTLY, quietly, I now admit to being a Walkman runner. The confession is not made with pride or arrogance. It's made sheepishly and a little shamefully.

title: Bonnie Hancock Is Married to Dr. David H. Miller
description: Patricia Clay Hancock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Price Williamson Hancock of South Londonderry, Vt., was married yesterday to Dr. David Hopkins Miller, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward Oehler Miller of Castine, Me. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father and the bridegroom's brother the Rev. Miller Jr. at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt.

title: A TREE NOT ONLY GROWS IN BROOKLYN, BUT IN JERSEY CITY
description: WHEN you ponder all the trees that have provided shelter, escape and refreshment to humanity, you see before you the greatness of an eternal plan, one that is global and spatial, making everything in the universe an integral part of time and place.

title: THE TOP TWO IN TOP FUEL
description: The final elimination rounds of the National Hot Rod Association's Winston Summernational drag races take place today at Raceway Park in Old Bridge, N.J. Winners will be determined in more than a dozen amateur categories and the three professional classes.

title: NEW YORK AS A HOMETOWN AS WELL AS A WORKPLACE
description: SHOULD people employed by New York City also be required to live here? Mayor Koch has long thought so, and last week the City Council agreed.

title: ABOARD THE COAST STARLIGHT
description: Rail travel appears to have lost a great deal of its appeal to the American imagination. Railroads are neither the ''irresistible bazaars'' that Paul Theroux experienced even in the 1970's, nor do they carry any of the profound social importance attributed to them in the 19th century, when, according to a book written in 1910, they were ''the largest single contributing factor to the welfare and happiness of the people,'' second only to the Christian religion and the public school.

title: Deirdre Pennoyer Is Married
description: The marriage of Deirdre Elizabeth Pennoyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., to Christopher Morgan Nadai, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert T. Nadai of San Francisco, took place yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley. The Rev. Calvin C. Adams of St. John's and the Rev. Stephen Babos, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: AN AMAZIN' DISCOVERY
description: ON the sidewalk outside Shea Stadium, the envelope was blowing in the wind. It was addressed to ''My Amazin' Mets 25th Anniversary Celebration.'' But it had no stamp, no postmark.

title: NEUROLOGIST INSISTS THAT MUSIC, AS WELL AS LIFE, CAN BEGIN WHEN ONE IS 40
description: EIGHT years ago, Frank R. Wilson, a California neurologist, was asked by his daughter's piano teacher to give a talk on how the brain explained musicianship.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A NATURAL HISTORY OF SEX: The Ecology and Evolution of Sexual Behavior. By Adrian Forsyth. (Scribners, $16.95.) The copulation of bedbugs, sex change among coral reef fish and cuckoldry by humans and bluebirds - all are under lively scrutiny in this thoroughly engaging chronicle about why males and females do what they do.

title: A CRUEL STEP BACKWARDS IN AIDS POLICY
description: THE Justice Department's recent opinion on AIDS in the workplace is at odds with all pertinent decisional law, the Labor Department's own long-standing regulations, most legal scholarship and virtually all medical thinking, including that of the Government's own Centers for Disease Control. The Reagan Administration should be ashamed for allowing such a flawed, offensive and destructive opinion to be issued, and it should promptly recall the opinion for further study and major revision.

title: CORRECTION
description: An interview with Peter Sellars in the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies a revival of a Broadway musical he was engaged to direct. The production was ''My One and Only,'' not ''On Your Toes.''

title: WHEN A FOG CREEPS OVER LIFE
description: MY mother is spending the day as she spends all her days - drifting in and out of the fog that has taken over her life. Her home for the last two years has been one of the better health-related facilities, but most of the time she has little awareness of her surroundings.

title: MR. WOLFE AND MR. BEATON
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, an article about baseball on the Westchester Opinion page last Sunday did not appear as the author had written it. The second and third columns of type were transposed.

title: Burlington in Accord With Pothole Bandit
description: The Pothole Bandit and the City of Burlington have reached a truce in the bandit's war on potholes.

title: On Language; Arrogance of Power
description: THE POWER CRAZE began when they started calling the baseball slugger a power hitter. Then, in 1956, the sociologist C. Wright Mills labeled the movers and shakers of society the power elite; in the 1960's, the journalist-historian Theodore H. White coined power broker. Campus slanguists soon picked up on the use of power as an attributive noun (lending its meaning to an adjacent noun) with power tool, meaning ''one who studies fiercely,'' and power boot, ''unusually forceful regurgitation.'' Vogue magazine last month referred to the hairdressing of celebrities as power cuts.

title: A Broker Is Wed To Miss Moseley
description: Elizabeth Howland Moseley, a trader in restricted securities at the First Boston Corporation, and Jonathan Patterson Edwards, a broker for Billiton Commodities, both in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Bryan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Moseley Chapel, named for the bride's family, at the Governor Dummer Academy in Newbury, Mass.

title: ROCK: STARSHIP, AT RADIO CITY
description: THE rock band that calls itself Starship is almost diametricallly opposite both in spirit and musical taste to its immediate forerunners, Jefferson Airplane and Jefferson Starship. Instead of continuing to perpetuate the utopian optimism of San Francisco's hippie culture, the band, which appeared at Radio City Music Hall on Friday evening, has become an 80's hard-rock ensemble modeled after Foreigner, Journey and other groups with one-word brand names.

title: The Story of X
description: In matters of the flesh, we've come a long way, baby. A generation ago, Harvard kept all its dirty books in a special cage in Widener Library; the X Collection, it was called. There's still a vault, but now it's to protect books, not young minds. The X has long since escaped the cage.

title: COUNTY WARNS OF POSSIBLE TAX INCREASE
description: THE good news for Westchester taxpayers is that the county ended last year with a surplus of $22.8 million, but the bad news is that officials are fearful that it isn't enough to prevent a good-sized property tax increase next year.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE MILITARY MIND
description: THE STRAW GIANT Triumph and Failure: America's Armed Forces. A Report From the Field. By Arthur T. Hadley. 314 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: THE PRE-ELECTION AGENDA IS LOADED WITH LOOSE ENDS
description: THE JUDICIARY. The Senate will begin this month its consideration of President Reagan's nominations of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice and of Federal Judge Antonin Scalia as an Associate Justice. It could take up again this week the controversial nomination to a Federal appeals court of Donald A. Manion, an Indiana lawyer whose qualifications have been questioned. Mr. Manion won a narrow vote last month, but Senate Democrats forced a reconsideration. Last week, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, was weighing an adroit tactic of his own that would delay action until the end of the session, when adjournment would allow the original vote to stand, assuring confirmation.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: JIM NAGOURNEY and Gene McHale describe themselves as the closest the Yankees and Mets have come to striking a major league deal. Or, they might say, a merger.

title: BAPTISITS' MISSION: TO BUILD A CHURCH IN TOLLAND
description: VOLUNTEERS from all over the country are helping to build the new, 11,000-square-foot First Baptist Church of Tolland, and they are paying for the privilege besides.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in The Week in Review on June 29 about discipline of lawyers cited the charges that led on June 23 to the disbarment of Roy M. Cohn in New York.

title: AS U.S. TRAVEL ABROAD DROPS, EUROPE GRIEVES
description: From the Eiffel Tower to the Coliseum to the Parthenon, a familiar figure is missing from the European landscape - the American tourist.

title: An Old Part of an Old City Is Invaded by Style
description: It was a hot July morning on the narrow street in the North End. Above the Ischia Grocery two elderly women were leaning out their windows, chatting in Italian.

title: CURBS ON MEDICAID BEING CONSIDERED
description: The Reagan Administration is working on proposals that would delay or deny Medicaid benefits for many people with high medical costs, including disabled children and elderly people needing long-term care.

title: White-Supremacy Delegates Meeting to Plan a Homeland
description: Leaders of a white-supremacy group met today in an armed compound, as sheriff's deputies patrolled outside, to plan for a ''whites only'' homeland in the Northwest.

title: PAINTING OVER DIRT: A BRUSH WITH DISASTER
description: WHEN outside paint starts to blister, peel or flake off within a couple years of being applied, in nine cases out of 10 the real problem is not the paint.

title: MODERN JAPAN, LAND OF SUPERSTITION
description: It all looks easy for Japan's governing party now that it has won a smashing victory at the polls. But when party leaders scheduled national elections for last Sunday they were testing the fates as well as the political waters.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KILLING FOR COMPANY: The Case of Dennis Nilsen. By Brian Masters. (Stein & Day, $18.95.) In British criminal history, Dennis Nilsen holds a double distinction.

title: CLEANING KEEPS A VCR FEELING FIT
description: Like any other performer, a VCR occasionally has an off night. But luckily, the most common kind of indisposition can be prevented, or quickly cured, by a bit of elementary maintenance.

title: Dr. Barry E. DiBernardo Marries Heidi Muschick
description: Haidrun Anni Muschick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willi Muschick of Marion, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Edward DiBernardo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph DiBernardo of Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Edward E. Steinkirchner performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Newark, N.Y.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LOSS OF MOLLUSKS PERTURBS NATURALISTS
description: THE sign above the seashell exhibition at Cattus Island Park here tells half the story:

title: AMERICAN BOXERS ADVANCE
description: Terrance Southerland and Ernesto Chavez, two last-minute substitutes on the United States boxing team, made their international debuts with victories today as five Americans won first-round matches at the Goodwill Games.

title: PILOT OF SECRET JET IS IDENTIFIED
description: The Air Force today identified the pilot killed in what experts said was the crash of an experimental radar-eluding fighter jet.

title: A BOVINE DRUG THAT HELPS PEOPLE SEE
description: DR. JOHN M. BOWEN, director of the Veterinary Medical Experiment Station for the University of Georgia's College of Veterinary Medicine, calls it a ''wonder drug.'' David K. Crossen, a drug analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, says it is ''the best anti-parasitic ever developed.'' And now another superlative is on the way: It may join the tiny number of animal drugs adapted to human use.

title: 'WEST SIDE STORY' IN NEW FAIRFIELD
description: BY the time the Sharks got to ''America,'' more than midway through the first act of ''West Side Story,'' everything was clicking at the Candlewood Playhouse on opening night.

title: Miss Van De Water Weds
description: Susan Barclay Van De Water, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van De Water of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James N. Reeks Jr., a son of Mr. Reeks of Oneonta, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Reeks. The Rev. Herman Harmelink 3d performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church. The bride will be known as Mrs. Van De Water-Reeks.

title: MAKERS OF CORDLESS PHONES SHOULD PROVIDE SCRAMBLERS
description: By all means, prosecute anyone who makes use of private telephone conversations, as in the case of Plainsboro Committeeman George Spanos (New Jersey Weekly, June 15). But for Attorney General W. Cary Edwards to seek to have New Jersey's wiretap statute amended to prevent the private conversations of cordless-phone users from being monitored is far from any real solution.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RITES: A Guatemalan Boyhood. By Victor Perera. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Take a young Portnoy, clean up his act a bit and plop him down in Guatemala.

title: BOMBING IN PARIS DESCRIBED AS BOLD
description: The devastating attack on a police headquarters in the heart of Paris on Wednesday was a bold and apparently sophisticated operation for a far-leftist French terrorist group that had suffered some serious reverses in recent months, experts on terrorism here believe.

title: Books to Offices
description: In the late 1920's and early 30's, the New York Public Library started experiencing severe space problems. One director warned that by the end of 1933, ''thousands of volumes must be moved out of the central library or be stowed away in boxes.''

title: MAISONS NEEDED
description: HIS city's athletic club, the French mayor said, is ''particulierement dynamique,'' and after winning numerous local and regional titles, it plans to come to the ''Marathon de New York.'' Could these 30 runners from La Rochelle, France, be fed and housed in their sister city of New Rochelle, the Mayor Michel Crepeau asked his colleague, Mayor Leonard C. Paduano.

title: The Mailman Posts a Profit
description: Words like ''higher-than-anticipated operating expenses'' have in recent years come to be associated with the Postal Service almost as freely as ''sleet,'' ''the gloom of night'' and ''appointed rounds.''

title: F.D.A. Restricts Sulfites in Salads
description: The Food and Drug Administration's announcement last week that it would restrict the use of sulfites in food had been expected for some time. After all, the agency acknowledged last year that the preservatives had been linked to 13 deaths and many severe illnesses, mainly among asthmatics.

title: 16 STATES WEIGH STARTING A JOINT LOTTERY DRAWING
description: Sixteen of the 22 states with lotteries and the District of Columbia are talking about banding together to offer a regular multistate lottery drawing that officials say would increase state revenues and produce jackpots of more than $50 million.

title: EXPERTS CRITICIZE REAGAN PROPOSAL FOR WEAPONS CUTS
description: Some nuclear arms experts say the Administration's proposal for deep reductions in strategic arms could increase the vulnerability of American nuclear forces to Soviet attack.

title: TOUGH CALL FOR PSYCHIATRISTS: DECIDING WHO IS DANGEROUS
description: The sign on the wall outside the psychiatric emergency unit at Bellevue Hospital instructs police officers to unload their guns before entering. The reasons are obvious.

title: FOR SYLVAN BYWAYS, ALL-TERRAIN BIKES
description: THE owner of a Westport bicycle shop said he was not surprised when his customers came in and bought all-terrain bicycles and, in their enthusiasm, rode them out the store and down the stairs.

title: MUSIC: THE TOKYO STRING QUARTET
description: Every summer, the Berkshire Mountains area becomes a thriving center for musical endeavor. There is Tanglewood, of course, and also Music Mountain in Falls Village. And then there is the Norfolk Chamber Msuic Festival, which houses the Yale Summer School of Music and Art and presents concerts on the Ellen Battell Stoeckel estate in a capacious redwood shed.

title: Barbara B. Boeger Weds John Mason
description: Barbara Benton Boeger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Boeger Jr. of Tequesta, Fla., and John Homans Mason, a son of Mrs. Henry L. Mason of Boston and the late Mr. Mason, were married yesterday. The Rev. Douglas Brayton, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at Edson Hill Manor, an inn in Stowe, Vt.

title: Children of Darkness, and Light; More Light
description: Daylight saving time means that those who work till 6 o'clock don't step from their offices into sunless streets. It means their ride home is a lot more interesting because they can see out the window.

title:
GARDENING;
NEW IDEAS ON VISIT TO ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: ON a typical business day, Rockefeller Center may seem to be a madhouse of elbow-to-elbow pedestrians and throbbing traffic. Yet, it is not uncommon amid this mass of activity to see someone stopped to admire a planter filled with live trees, shrubs and flowers, or even a small park.

title:
GARDENING;
NEW IDEAS ON VISIT TO ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: ON a typical business day, Rockefeller Center may seem to be a madhouse of elbow-to-elbow pedestrians and throbbing traffic. Yet, it is not uncommon amid this mass of activity to see someone stopped to admire a planter filled with live trees, shrubs and flowers, or even a small park.

title: REDS DEFEAT EXPOS BEHIND DENNY, 2-0
description: John Denny combined with Ron Robinson on a two-hitter, and Buddy Bell batted in one run and scored another tonight as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Montreal Expos, 2-0.

title: BUDGET CRISIS IN TEXAS POSING PAINFUL CHOICES FOR LEGISLATORS
description: Texas shook in February when State Comptroller Bob Bullock, saying that plunging oil prices had brought on a financial crisis, told legislators the state was facing a $1.3 billion shortage in its two-year budget.

title: HARLEM HAS BLUEPRINTS FOR ITS FUTURE
description: WHAT do the Caribbean Basin Initiative, textile quotas and preferential tariffs have in common with Harlem's 125th Street? A lot, according to the planners of a $165 million Third World Trade Center proposed for Harlem's main commercial thoroughfare.

title: SALVADOR REBELS OFFER PEACE PLAN
description: Leftist Salvadoran rebels have offered a peace proposal that includes a cease-fire and an offer to take part in elections after a transitional government is formed.

title: Suzanne H. Walentek Is Wed to Michael B. Travis
description: Suzanne Helena Walentek, a daughter of Blanche Walentek of Forest Hills, Queens, and Karl J. Walentek of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Michael Bruce Travis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Travis of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Daryl Baker performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Birmingham, Mich.

title: Making Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: HOPE AMID DECAY IN BOSTON PROJECT
description: After 20 years of neglect, 1,100 of the 1,500 apartments at the Columbia Point housing project have been boarded up, despite a waiting list of 12,500 people for apartments in the public housing system.

title: Salem Drive, $13.20, Takes Oceanport Race
description: Salem Drive took the lead in the closing strides and posted a half-length victory over favored Exclusive Partner today in the $57,750 Oceanport Handicap for 3-year-olds at Monmouth Park.

title: HOMELESS 'BASH'
description: By bringing together a disco and the Department of Social Services, County Legislator Paul J. Feiner and his corps of youthful volunteers have given a Westchester homeless family something to celebrate.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
JAPANESE VOLUNTEERS
description: A new program, Japanese Women Community Volunteers, ''will be a great opportunity for Japanese women to be involved in the community and for other people in Westchester to get to know the Japanese,'' said Keoko Myers of Hartsdale, one of three members on the program's advisory council.
