Fumiko Takeda Feingold of Chappaqua, another member of the advisory council, said, ''I meet many Japanese women who come here expecting to meet Americans, but they found American women working and they had very few oppportunities to meet them. This program will provide those opportunities.''

title: THE AVERAGE GUY TAKES IT ON THE CHIN
description: FOR millions of breadwinners, the American dream is becoming the impossible dream.

title: DETROIT BETS ON MORE MODELS FOR SMALLER MARKETS
description: BACK in the mid-1970's, executives at a small importer of Japanese cars, Subaru, thought they spotted a hole in the American automobile market: There were no small, four-wheel-drive cars for sale. So they started equipping their small sedans and station wagons with four-wheel drive and sales started soaring, particularly in areas with heavy snowfall.

title: THE COST OF FREE CAR RENTALS
description: What the auto-rental business calls ''free'' is often not free at all.

title: DON'T BLAME CITY FOR ISLAND'S CRIME
description: Re: ''Crime on L.I.: City Role Is Key'' [ June 22 ] : Have you noticed the rapists, drug dealers and car thieves lining the grass of the parkways, looking for rides to Long Island? As a Queens resident for 42 years, I can feel safer knowing mayhem is departing the city for greener pastures.

title: DOWN THE CRAZY RIVER
description: LA SALLE By John Vernon. 240 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: CHINA FROM ENGLAND'S POTTERIES
description: Drive 150 miles north of London to a cluster of tiny towns in the top corner of Staffordshire county in the Midlands and you will find the center of Britain's ceramics industry. Tunstall, Burslem, Hanley, Stoke, Fenton and Longton spill over the hillsides and valleys that make up the coal- and clay-rich district known as the Potteries. In 1910 the six municipalities were united to form the city of Stoke-on-Trent (population 252,509), a manufacturing center of rather ordinary architecture that is chiefly of interest to the visitor for its central industry: potting.

title: Final Report On Pornography Prompts Debate
description: As the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography finally unveiled its finished report last week, the debate over its conclusions seemed likely to continue for months.

title: Woman Is First to Gain World Jumping Final
description: Gail Greenough of Canada, riding Amadia, completed a flawless third leg today to become the first woman to gain a berth in the final of the World Show Jumping Championships.

title: MR. WOLFE AND MR. BEATON
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A MOTHER'S FEAR NEARLY COMES TRUE
description: TODAY was one of those days working mothers dread - with one difference. This one was nearly fatal.

title: Russell S. Reynolds 3d Marries Lynda C. Low
description: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Lynda Carolyn Low, the daughter of Joan G. Low of Burlington, Vt., and Dr. Paul R. Low of Greenwich, was married to Russell S. Reynolds 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds Jr., also of Greenwich. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony Penny W. Oudheusden was the matron of honor.

title: Hawaii Congressman Quits
description: Representative Cecil Heftel resigned his House seat Friday to begin his official campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor. No date was immediately set for a special election to fill the rest of the term. State law bars a candidate from retaining one office while seeking another.

title: Philadelphia Pact Voted; Other Talks to Resume
description: Members of one union of city workers approved a new contract today but vowed to stay off the job while the city remained deadlocked in its negotiations with a second union involved in a 12-day municipal strike.

title: RUNNING AFOUL OF THE LAW ABROAD
description: LAST July, John Jay Bonstingl, a high school teacher from Columbia, Md., set sail from Piraeus for a five-day cruise of the Greek islands. At Santorini he disembarked and bought two gold chains for about $300, charging the purchase to his Visa card. The shopkeeper did not telephone for a charge authorization until sometime later.

title: JOHN D. SEYMOUR
description: John Davenport Seymour, who began an acting career in 1918 that spanned radio, television, film and the theater, died of heart failure Thursday at Doctors Hospital.

title: IN VENICE, THE BIENNALE SINKS INTO A SEA OF AMBIGUITY
description: The Venice Biennale is as much of a morass as ever. Although in a large international exhibition of this stature there are invariably pockets of great interest, the current show is so equivocal that it discourages a straightforward response to the art. What is particularly frustrating is that just about every attempt to bring credibility and fresh blood to the 42d Biennale has ended in compromise, irresolution or self-interest.

title: Statue Off the Starboard Bow!
description: Captain Jan Piaseki and the seven-member crew of the Polish sloop Stomil had the worst seats in the house for the fireworks and folderol of Liberty Weekend. Failed by man and nature, the Stomil sat becalmed for two weeks 500 miles off the coast of New York.

title: AQUINO HAS THE ARMED FORCES ON HER SIDE, AT LEAST FOR NOW
description: ''THEY are triplets, whether they like it or not:

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SPAIN'S SUBTLE AND DRY SHERRY
description: Never, perhaps, have a wine and a town been so closely linked as manzanilla sherry and Sanlucar de Barrameda in southwestern Andalusia. It is not only that the salty tang of this ultradry sherry can instantly bring to mind Sanlucar's sea breezes and fine beaches, but more important, that Sanlucar is the only town in Spain, and, indeed, the world, where manzanilla can be made.

title: Boyd Suspended
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox won't be on the American League All-Star squad on Tuesday night in Houston because he wasn't selected by Manager Dick Howser.

title: DRAGONFLIES AND HEGEL'S COWS
description: CATS OF THE TEMPLE By Brad Leithauser. 70 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: A PLEASING CHINESE PIECEMEAL
description: ON Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton, H.S.F. has proved to be a reliable addition to the year-round dining scene in the Hamptons. In an area notable for its seasonal fluctuations, it is remarkable that H.S.F. has managed to be such a perennial.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $122,500 10 Kester Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split level; hardwood floors, *2*family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,992. Farmingdale $195,000 254 Cranberry Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old ranch; dining room with *2*fireplace, hardwood floors, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,000. Freehold $127,000 34 Koening Lane *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old bilevel; *2*fenced yard, fireplace, patio; taxes $1,536. Livingston $170,000 32 Irving Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old colonial; deck, living room *2*with fireplace, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,408. Mine Hill $119,900 19 South First Avenue *2*3 bedroom, 1 bath, 40-year-old ranch; remodeled kitchen, *2*family room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,040. Paramus $179,900 316 South Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; family room with *2*fireplace, patio, den, dining room; taxes $1,939. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. $370,000 11 Crescent Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 63-year-old frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, deck; taxes $3,684. Killingworth, Conn. $250,000 293 Route 148 *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 1772 Cape Cod; *2*3 fireplaces, screened porch, 4 acres; taxes $1,941. Woodmere, L.I. $250,000 859 Talbot Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old high ranch; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,200.

title: JOSEPH VLASIC
description: Joseph Vlasic, founder of the pickle-producing company that bears his name, died in a hospital here Thursday.

title: Photo of the exterior of the Rodin Museum in Paris. (Randolph Harrison) Rodin Museum
description: To the Editor: Charles Lockwood recommends a stroll in the ''tranquil gardens'' of the Musee Rodin.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Can a leopard change its spots? I don't know. Until that happens it will be a rough road.'' - Robert Joedicke, Shearson Lehman analyst, on People Express's full-service strategy.

title: Toward Pakistani Democracy
description: Now that democracy has been restored in the Philippines, the United States needs to consider how best to promote political pluralism in Pakistan if we are going to protect our strategic interests on the subcontinent as effectively as we protected them in southeast Asia.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THOMAS HOBBES: Radical in the Service of Reaction. By Arnold A. Rogow. (Norton, $19.95.) Numerous books about Thomas Hobbes have sought to associate his views about human nature and the origins and obligations of governments with the political and social upheavals of 17th-century England.

title: DUBIOUS FACADE, DELIGHTFUL FOOD
description: ''DON'T judge a restaurant by its facade.''

title: Photo of the exterior of the Rodin Museum in Paris (Randolph Harrison) Rodin Museum
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see Charles Lockwood's piece on the Hotel Biron Rodin Museum (Travel, May 18). How Rodin happened to come to the place and how it consequently became a Rodin Museum makes an interesting little story in its own right.

title: UNTYING THE KNOT OF NUCLEAR TEST VERIFICATION
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union have been engaged for five years in two monologues on the verification of underground testing of nuclear weapons.

title: SON TO CONDUCT HIS FATHER'S SYMPHONY
description: FOR Maxim Shostakovich, the Soviet emigre who will conduct the Waterloo Festival Orchestra at Waterloo Village here Saturday night, one important musical mission is conducting the works of his father, the composer Dmitri Shostakovich, who died in 1975.

title: Miss Stanton Is Affianced
description: Judge Louis L. Stanton of New York and Phoebe R. Stanton of New York and South Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Helen Stanton to Rodman Wesley Benedict, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Benedict of Cranbury, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DESIGNS ANNOUNCED FOR BULLION COINS
description: The United States Treasury has received design approval for its new gold and silver bullion coins. However, that approval was given grudgingly by the Commission of Fine Arts, the Federal review body that examines designs of all new U.S. coins and national medals.

title:
DINING OUT;
'NEW AMERICAN' IN WHITE PLAINS
description: QUARROPAS is one of a handful of recently opened restaurants offering personal revisions and reinterpretations of classic cuisines. Its name, literally White Swamp, is what the American Indians called what is now known as White Plains. The kitchen works with fresh and, when available, local ingredients, preparing and presenting them carefully and imaginatively in a self-styled way popularly known as New American. The reason for the growing enthusiasm about this cooking becomes clear at Quarropas. At their best, dishes can be sensational. For the most part, viands are roasted, sauteed, grilled or baked expertly, their integral flavors celebrated and enhanced with pureed vegetables, fresh herbs and spices, not masked under sugary or starchy sauces.

title: TESTING LIVE HOGS TO GET SAFE PORK
description: TRICHINOSIS is no longer a major health problem. Laws mandating sanitary farm and slaughterhouse conditions, and preventing the feeding of raw garbage to hogs, have sharply reduced the number of cases. So have education campaigns recommending that pork be cooked or frozen at temperatures that kill the trichina parasite. The result, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control, is that for the most part fewer than 150 cases of the disease have been reported each year for the past two decades.

title: FOCUS: Washington; Subway Shaping A Skyline
description: LIKE an irrigation ditch gurgling money along its 70-mile right of way, Washington's expensively glamorous subway system, the Metro, is watering a multibillion-dollar crop of development. Above the ditch, clusters of 18-story office towers rise unexpectedly, like grain elevators on the vast one-story suburban prairie.

title: Space Plans to Be Reviewed
description: Top Reagan Administration officials are to meet early next week to review the direction being taken by the troubled space program, but a decision on replacing the space shuttle Challenger has again been delayed, the White House says.

title: 1,000 SOWETO MOURNERS DEFY DECREE
description: About 1,000 mourners, some clenching their fists in defiance of emergency decrees, marched, sang banned songs and chanted outlawed slogans at a funeral today in Soweto.

title: FOR ALLAIRE, A COUNTRY-STYLE FAIR
description: A COUNTRY-STYLE, family-scaled fair that has grown in stature during its seven-year history will make its annual appearance Saturday at Allaire State Park in Monmouth County.

title: Mr. Wolfe and Mr. Beaton
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennis Honors
description: Some former players - John Newcombe and Tony Roche of Australia, Chuck McKinley of the United States, Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy and the late Dorothy Round Little of Britain - and Ted Tinling, the British designer of women's tennis apparel, were inducted into the Tennis Hall of Fame yesterday in Newport, R.I.

title: Guitar Duets
description: The guitarists John Renbourn and Stefan Grossman will play duets at 8 and 11 tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Tickets are $8.50.

title: REAGAN ADAMANT ON NOT CURBING 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan today reaffirmed his opposition to curtailing research on a defense system against nuclear missiles, saying such a shield was not a ''bargaining chip'' in arms control talks with the Soviet Union.

title: WHAT WILL PUBLIC POWER REALLY MEAN?
description: JUST a few months ago, the idea of a public power authority was only a distant dream for opponents of the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham Nuclear Power Station. Now legislation creating such a public authority has been passed in Albany.

title: AMERICANS IN ITALY FEW BUT HAPPY
description: A pastel-striped American Express tour bus pulled into a parking space in the Piazza di Spagna at noon Friday to let off a group of people who had just finished a tour of the Sistine Chapel and the Vatican Museum.

title: NAKASONE'S VICTORY MAY INCREASE HIS LONGEVITY
description: JAPAN'S Liberal Democrats have governed for 31 years, so long that half the population has no memory of a different political life. In that sense, the party's victory in parliamentary elections last week had a ring of inevitability. But this time the Liberal Democrats devastated the ineffectual opposition so thoroughly that post-election analysis acquired apocalyptic tones, with some commentators talking of an ''epic change'' and a ''momentous turning point.'' Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone rode the same tide, calling the results nothing less than the ''voice of heaven.''

title: Executive Might Head Boards of Javits Center
description: The leading candidate to head the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is John H. Krumpe, president and chief executive officer of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, according to sources close to the center.

title: CONGRESS HAS ITS HANDS FULL AND ITS EYES ON THE CLOCK
description: CONGRESS returns tomorrow from its two-week Independence Day recess, to distressing signals from the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole. The Kansas Republican is talking of keeping the legislators at work past Aug. 15, the scheduled date for the next recess.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A NEW ROLE FOR A SCHOONER OF OLD
description: A MIDWEEK sail into the sunset on a tall-masted schooner, a sip or two of champagne to enjoy in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, hors d'oevres and dinner aboard and a late night return up the Hudson to the Englewood Boat Basin suggests nothing less than a mini-vacation condensed into a memorable five-hour getaway that is accessible after work or, with varied and expanded itinerary, overnight or weekends.

title: U.S. PREDICTS MORE TERRORISM IN EUROPE
description: Despite the recent reduction in terrorist activities by Middle East groups, United States intelligence analysts say they anticipate new efforts by these organizations to carry out ''indiscriminate'' attacks in Western European capitals.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch last Sunday about a radio spectrum for land-based two-way communication carried an outdated description of Mark S. Fowler's tenure as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. He has been appointed to a new term, which began July 1.

title: BORED? TAKE OFF WITH A STRANGER
description: I AM HAVING AN ADVENTURE By Perri Klass. 253 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: 'FREUD IN SNEAKERS': DARING EXPERIMENT
description: THE Victory Repertory Theater in Great Neck regularly presents plays designed to challenge the imagination. Much of its work, such as the current ''Freud in Sneakers,'' is written or adapted by the theater's artistic director, Peter Josyph, who also acts in and directs the shows he writes.

title: YANKS WIN, 8-0; NIELSEN, A ROOKIE, DEFEATS TWINS
description: Earlier in the day, Roger Clemens picked up his 15th victory of the season for the Boston Red Sox. Tonight, Scott Nielsen gained his 15th victory of the season as the Yankees breezed past the Minnesota Twins, 8-0.

title: MANY EVENTS ARE WITHIN A TWO-HOUR DRIVE OF THE COUNTY
description: SUMMERTIME is here, and the driving is easy, so let's note some attractive events within a couple of hours from most Westchester locations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GILBERT GREEN: The Real Right Way to Dress for Spring. By Frederick Ted Castle. (McPherson, $16.95.) If you were in New York in the late 1960's and spent your time rubbing shoulders with Andy Warhol at Max's Kansas City, rushing off in cabs to catch the latest Charles Ludlam play or participating in endless improvisational 16-millimeter epics, then Frederick Ted Castle's ''Gilbert Green'' - written in 1968 but only now unveiled - will probably set you reeling with the shock of recollection.

title: The Death of A Son
description: Since the inception of the About Men page, I have been stirred by many of the subjects and the sensitivity of the writers. Albert Knight's article was particularly moving. Mr. Knight captured the emotions, reactions and accommodations that all of us who have experienced grief for a loved one have felt.

title: ENCLAVE ASKS PARK
description: HOMEOWNERS in Meadowmere Park have asked the Town of Hempstead to buy a pie-shaped parcel that was used as a park but was sold 18 months ago over community objections.

title: Helen Gurley Brown, Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Where can I get information about tours to Antarctica? -J. W. M., Syracuse Answer:Tours to Antarctica fall into four basic groups: the relatively low-cost camping trip for outdoor people; a more adventurous expedition for travelers who have already been there once; the conventional tour - with no camping, and a voyage aboard a cruise ship.

title: Data Bank: July 13, 1986
THE RISKS OF PROVIDING AID AND COMFORT
description: SINCE June 1984, Alejandro Gomez and his family have been living in sanctuary as refugees at the Downtown Presbyterian Church in Rochester. On May 23, Mr. Gomez , a trade union activist from El Salvador, was arrested by agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service as he walked with his wife, Leticia, on Main Street and was taken to jail in Buffalo. Released on $50,000 bail, Mr. Gomez returned to the church to await an immigration hearing next month that may end in his being deported to his war-torn homeland.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SEEING DOUBLE, AND MORE - Even the government officials who ordered the road restriped admit that the new markings were a bit confusing. ''You've caught us in a transition stage,'' Suffolk County's Director of Traffic Safety, Richard Strang, said. ''We couldn't take up the old yellow double center lines until the new stripes were set down.''

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '86; TONY TORCHIA;
Love for Baseball Is Undimmed
description: SOMETIME this summer, Tony Torchia, the manager of the Boston Red Sox Eastern League affiliate in New Britain, will quietly record his 700th victory as a minor league manager - the most in the league and in the Red Sox minor league system.

title: FAST FORWARD AND REVERSE
description: AS baseball reaches the All-Star Game break, last season's division winners - Toronto, Kansas City, St. Louis and Los Angeles - are not in first place. That development comes as no surprise, considering recent history. In the last 10 seasons, only 5 of 40 division winners were in first place at the All-Star break the following season; in the last 5 seasons, only 2 of 20 winners were back on top at this time the season after.

title: Murders on West 54th
description: When Ruth Potdevin went to her fifth floor room at the Dorset Hotel at 30 West 54th Street shortly before noon on May 30, 1985, her husband, Robert, thought she would be gone just long enough to change her clothes for lunch.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
'BABY ON BOARD': A NOTE TO THOSE WHO CARE
description: IT never occurred to me when we fastened the yellow, diamond-shaped sign in the back window of our car - the one reading ''Baby on Board'' - that anyone would find the message offensive. We had only just returned home with our first child and placed the sign behind Elizabeth's car seat as much in declaration of our good fortune as in recognition of a new reality. From that moment, the automobile had ceased to be merely a mode of transportation in our eyes, becoming increasingly a lethal weapon, the single greatest cause of accidental death in America. We did not care to add our names to the lengthening list of victims.

title: Big Greenhouse Heat Wave Not in Sight
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Stamford, Vt.;
Keeping Land Undeveloped
description: THE 216 acres of rolling land sold recently near the resort town of Ossipee in New Hampshire invite ambitious development plans. But they will never materialize because a conservation easement protects almost half of it from commercial harvesting or timber cutting.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Scrofula of Literature - While W. B. Yeats was considered cranky in his old age, his letters show that he had developed this poetic faculty by the age of 21. Writing to a friend, he attacks the novelist George Eliot. This is from ''The Collected Letters of W. B. Yeats: Volume One 1865-1895'' (Oxford University), edited by John Kelly and Eric Domville.

title: Malaysia Hangs Two Australians
description: Like other countries in the region, Malaysia has declared war on ''dadah,'' as mind-altering drugs are called, executing 38 people for narcotics offenses since 1975.

title: Amy R. Gelfand, a Nurse, Is Married to Robert Kula
description: The marriage of Amy R. Gelfand, a daughter of Deputy Inspector and Mrs. Elson Gelfand of Merrick, L.I., to Robert Kula, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kula of Hallendale, Fla., took place last evening at the Sands in Lido Beach, L.I. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony.

title: VILLAGE LIFE IN THE VAUCLUSE
description: The buntings had been going up in every town, no matter how small, for days in advance, and the larger villages had pasted up posters in the smaller villages saying what the events of their July 14 would be. Our village, Roussillon, was to have a petanque tournament (petanque is like bowling without the lanes or pool without the pockets), which some of us wanted to see, and a bal populaire (outdoor dance), which we all wanted to go to, and there was even a rumor of fireworks.

title: TWO SUMMER HAVENS ON WHOSE SAND ART WAS WRIT LARGE
description: To the layman, there is something both touching and enviable about the 19th-century notion of an artists' colony. The auguries could hardly have been better. It was high summer. Whether in Provence or Tuscany, Brittany or Bavaria, the South Fork or the Cape, the location was all that could be wished. The company was way above the average in imagination, appetite for life and conviviality. Stuffiness was out, by definition. So were formal clothes, fixed hours and the need to conform. Artists were boisterous, outgoing, easy to please. Good-looking people of both sexes prized their company. How could it not be blissful?

title: Hirohito's War
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO'S RULING PARTY LOOKS OVER ITS SHOULDER
description: IN philosophical moments, President Miguel de la Madrid and other officials often say that Mexico must move toward a genuinely pluralistic political system from one in which a single party has ruled without interruption since 1929. They do not mention relinquishing any of the massive power accumulated by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as PRI, but they sometimes hint that they might consider sharing some of it.

title: Grace S. Chapin To Wed Oct. 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Chapin of Arlington, Va., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Grace Selden Chapin, to Thomas Charles Ruska, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Ruska of Peachtree City, Ga. The wedding is planned for Oct. 11.

title: IACOCCA'S BANDWAGON ROLLS WITHOUT HIM
description: AS Lee A. Iacocca made his way around New York City during Liberty Weekend, it sometimes seemed as if it was his birthday that was being celebrated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE INNOCENTS. By Carolyn Slaughter. (Scribners, $16.95.) As long as the atrocities taking place in South Africa continue, the devastation of racial separation there cannot be overdone by writers.

title: Data Update
description: Source: HSH Associates *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: When Is an Onion A Vidalia Onion?
description: VIDALIA onions are sweet and so popular in the market that consumers pay extra for them. But the question before Superior Court in Statesboro, Ga., was: What constitutes a Vidalia onion?

title: Vezelay
description: To the Editor: I would like to share a very special find in Vezelay, the Residence Hotel le Pontot. It comprises two houses from the 17th and 18th centuries, joined to span the hill leading down from the basilica.

title: HOMELESS STRAIN PRIVATE SHELTERS IN UPSTATE TOWN
description: Terry Orzechowski runs a shelter for homeless women in this city in the mid-Hudson Valley, relying entirely on donations from individuals.

title: Children of Darkness, and Light; A Treasured Guide
description: It is people like Lambert Pohner who give quality to the life of New York, or any city. Mr. Pohner, who died last week at the age of 59, was simply ''Lambert'' to the flocks he often led through Central Park, introducing the birds and butterflies.

title: 'Never Again'
description: 'The ''never again'' that Austrians swore as they emerged from the rubble of the Second World War was valid then and is valid also today, not only because of the horror of the Holocaust but also because of that terrible mental attitude that gave rise to it: anti-Semitism.

title: Amelia Bormann, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Amelia Elizabeth Bormann and John F. Smitka Jr., lawyers in Boston, were married yesterday at the Dwight Memorial Chapel of Yale University in New Haven. The Rev. Gerald P. Cohen, associate Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale, performed the ceremony.

title: MARINE POLICE TAKING TO AIR
description: SPURRED by a dramatic increase in overall boating traffic and the threat of water- borne drug runners, the State Police have begun using a single-engine plane to patrol New Jersey's coast.

title: NO, BUT I SAW THE STILLS
description: Cocky, baby-faced Warren Beatty jabs a bossy finger at Robert Rossen, the aging, infirm director of ''Lilith''; Dustin Hoffman hisses an eloquent obscenity at Robert Redford, who has just flubbed a line during the filming of ''All The President's Men''; the most macho of maestros huddles with a permed-blond transvestite on the set of ''Fellini-Roma.'' These historic yet private off-camera moments have been captured on film by a sly, omnipresent still-photographer named Louis Goldman, as you will joyfully discover while leafing through LIGHTS, CAMERA, ACTION! Behind the Scenes, Making Movies (Abrams, $35). Mr. Goldman has not been content, however, to stuff the 216 pages of this tome with gloriously printed black-and-white remembrances of his colorful past.

title: Emilie B. Murphy To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Murphy of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Emilie B. Murphy to A. Bryon Nimocks 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Nimocks Jr. of Forrest City, Ark.

title: MONARCHS OF THE MEDIEVAL AGE, SPLANDORS OF A SPANISH TRAIN
description: TOUR TO EXPLORE EARLY FRANCE AND ENGLAND - The powers and personalities of the medieval era will be the focus of the 16-day Plantagenet Tour to Medieval England and France, scheduled to begin in August.

title: A Warning About Wild Mushrooms
description: Colette Rossant's article ''Summer's Soft Prize'' (Food, June 8) gives the impression that mushrooms purchased ''at gourmet stores, and even supermarkets'' are safe to eat. However, there are, to my knowledge, no regulations about which mushrooms can be sold in this country, nor is there any means by which a seller can easily verify the identity of a fungus.

title: Maine Changes Deer Law
description: MAINE, New England's leading deer hunting state, has gone to an ''any-deer'' permit system for the first time in its history.

title: Talking Tax Reform; Decisions Before Law Is Changed
description: MANY owners of small residential investment properties are taking a close look at the best way to proceed in the face of expected changes in the Federal income-tax law.

title: OFFICER WOUNDED IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A New York City police officer was shot and critically wounded in Central Park yesterday as he and a sergeant stopped three youths that the officers thought were acting suspiciously, the police said.

title: Children of Darkness, and Light; Minister of Death
description: Rarely has any public official anywhere so personified evil as Jose Lopez Rega. Known to many Argentines as ''el Brujo,'' the male witch, he has now been extradited by the United States to Argentina.

title: Photography
description: Light Gallery, the venerable and lately intermittent showplace for contemporary photography, has gathered together 52 intriguing pictures having to do with sports of all sorts, under the rubric of ''Competition.'' There are glimpses of boxers, wrestlers, runners, bikers, halfbacks and, of course, plenty of baseball players - enough, surely, to satiate even the biggest armchair sports fan.

title: PARTY CONVENTIONS START NEXT WEEKEND
description: AFTER months of trying - overtly and covertly - to line up support, the seekers of elective office in Connecticut next fall face major tests over the next two weeks, as party conventions meet to endorse candidates.

title: FOUR-DIGIT DIALERS, THE NUMBER IS UP
description: THE telephone company hails it as ''the latest in telephone technology'' but to many residents in three northern Westchester towns the new switching, or routing, system spells the end of an era.

title: PASSIVE DEFENSE HAS ITS PERILS
description: Probably the chief drawback to passive defense is that it creates a quiet position in which it is easy to delude oneself into thinking the opponent isn't doing anything.

title: TEAM LOOKS TO THE FUTURE, DAILY
description: HOLLISTER, N.C., the town where he grew up, is so small, Delaney Rudd said, that there isn't a single stoplight. ''We didn't need one,'' he added. ''Not enough cars.'' As a boy he hoped one day to see the world beyond Hollister. To that end he pursued the dream that still animates the soft-spoken 23-year-old: a career as a professional basketball player. ''As kids we would always watch the N.B.A. games on TV,'' he said. ''I knew then that I wanted to make it into the pros.''

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: ELDERLY New Jersey residents who cannot afford medical treatment for eye problems can now obtain care through the National Eye Care Project.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NOBODY LIVES FOREVER. By John Gardner. (Putnam, $13.95.) Bond, James Bond, has got trouble up to his roguish eyebrows in the fifth John Gardner adventure to borrow Ian Fleming's master spy creation.

title: Handbook for Interns
description: The 2,000 summer interns who work for members of Congress customarily arrive in Washington full of ambition and vitality and a wholesome belief that Government is manageable. To channel the former and husband the latter, the Congressional Management Foundation is distributing the third edition of ''A Congressional Intern Handbook,'' a light-hearted but professional guide to the preservation of sanity among members of this migrant political subculture.

title: STATES DEVELOP LUCRATIVE FOREIGN POLICIES
description: SOUTH CAROLINA, state tourist officials freely acknowledge, is probably not the first place most foreigners would choose to visit on a United States vacation. But thanks to a carefully researched promotion campaign centered on West Germany and Britain, the state expects to attract more than 30,000 tourists from Western Europe this year.

title: A High-Coverage Project in Queens
description: THREE years ago, to protect the character of brownstone streets and neighborhoods of low-rise apartment buildings throughout New York City, the Planning Commission established new zoning districts that allow builders to put up bulkier but lower buildings.

title: Reagan Praises Aquino For Conduct in Uprising
description: President Reagan has sent a laudatory letter to President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines, saying her ability to quell a recent rebellion ''has shown the world the mettle of your Government,'' the White House said today.

title: Article 864486 -- No Title
description: A middle-aged San Francisco schoolteacher won a record $3 million slot machine jackpot at Harrah's Tahoe, the casino said today.

title: WAHT'S INEFFICIENT, UNFAIR AND UNSIMPLE?
description: AFTER the Senate passed its tax-revision bill last month, the McNeil-Lehrer Report featured a bipartisan love-in involving leading Republicans and Democrats. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, Senator Bob Dole, Senator Bill Bradley and Representative Dan Rostenkowski fell over each other praising the bill and themselves. ''We are really doing something for the taxpayer,'' each boasted.

title: JUST RIGHT FOR TAR BEACH: BAGGIES
description: THE only kind of surf most Manhattanites know is the kind that goes with turf. But that hasn't stopped the hang-10 set from exercising a rather distinctive influence on the city's streets these days.

title: THE POLITICAL PAST GLORY OF HARTFORD'S BUSHNELL
description: IT'S farewell to Bushnell Memorial Hall this year, as the Democrats join the Republicans in moving their state convention from that traditional site in Hartford to the roomier Civic Center three blocks away.

title: THROUGH SECULAR WORK, NUNS SUPPORT THEIR RELIGIOUS ORDER
description: WHEN prospective clients first meet the director of Franciscan Graphics, a graphic-design studio in Meriden, they sometimes do a double take.

title: PETE SEEGER OBSERVED IN CLEANUP OPERATION
description: Pete Seeger is too modest [ ''Reflections on a Boat Reviving the Hudson,'' June 22 ] . Those of us in our mid-30's who are answering his environmentalist call after too many years of dormancy thank him for keeping the flame.

title: Questions About Back-Seat Belts
description: As the Federal Centers for Disease Control were reporting last week that more American automobile passengers and drivers are wearing seat belts, a study making the rounds at a Federal safety agency suggested that in some instances back-seat riders might be better off if without lap belts.

title: Small Quake in Ohio Felt in 4 Other States
description: A moderate earthquake occurred today in Ohio and parts of Kentucky, Indiana, Michigan and West Virginia, but no injuries and little damage were reported.

title: The Third Branch, Upheld
description: Warren Burger's last opinion as Chief Justice was momentous, yet the country reacted calmly. In nullifying one of Congress's most important recent pieces of legislation, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law, Justice Burger showed how far he'd traveled - and how near the public consensus the Court still stands.

title: TURN UP THAT AIR-CONDITIONER AND READ THIS
description: Washingtonians who recall that the suicide in 1870 of Napoleon III's minister to Washington, Prevost Paradahl, was attributed by some to the city's oppressive heat were not surprised by this week's torrid run-up of suffocating tropical weather. It is a long-standing given: The place is hot.

title: KING KEEPS OPEN LEAD BY 1
description: As if golf isn't difficult enough with its water hazards, bunkers, trees, rough and other challenges that test each player's composure, the 41st United States Women's Open championship has been on the verge of disaster all week.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RUSSIAN JAZZ: New Identity. Edited by Leo Feigin. (Quartet Books, $17.95.) The publication of S. Frederick Starr's ''Red and Hot'' in 1983 introduced Western readers to the long and turbulent history of jazz in the Soviet Union.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: The Pointer Sisters: So Excited! MusicVision, 29 minutes. $19.95.

title: Miss Stevenson to Wed D. B. Scott Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by John R. Stevenson of New York of the engagement of his daughter, Patience Fullerton Stevenson, to Donald Bruce Scott Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of Baltimore and Delray Beach, Fla. Miss Stevenson is the daughter also of the late Patience F. Stevenson.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MALADY OF DEATH. By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. (Grove, $9.95.) The success last year of ''The Lover'' enhanced critical celebration of Marguerite Duras.

title: CY COLEMAN, COMPOSER WITH A KNACK FOR JUGGLING
description: As a young man just starting to write musicals for the Broadway stage, Cy Coleman was asked to write the score for what one day would become the 1967 smash Broadway musical hit ''Hello, Dolly.'' He turned the assignment down.

title: Ellen L. Fox to Wed Dr. Jeffrey Spiro
description: Ellen Leslie Fox, a member of the class of '87 at the New York University School of Law, and Dr. Jeffrey David Spiro, a resident in otolaryngology at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, plan to be married Aug. 31.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Liberty Weekend festivities at Liberty State Park in Jersey City have ended and the crowds have gone home. But their refuse - about 50 tons of it - lingered on for several days, park officials said.

title: TED TURNER: RUSSIAN SOUL
description: HALFWAY through the best Goodwill Games we've ever had, the dominant figure is not Bubka, not Salnikov, not Joyner, not Johnson, but rather the visionary who created these games with a flip of his lip.

title: A SPECIAL SHOW FROM ARETHA FRANKLIN
description: With 24 gold records, 14 Grammys and the popular title of ''the queen of soul'' among her laurels, it would seem that Aretha Franklin had few new worlds to conquer. But Showtime thought otherwise, and the result, ''Aretha!'' - the singer's first television special - has its debut Friday night at 10.

title: A MIDWEST CITY GOES AGAINST THE GRAIN
description: ''GOODBYE, Columbus, goodbye,'' the phonograph sings in Philip Roth's 1959 novella. But these days, more and more people are saying hello to this state capital. Columbus recently surpassed Cleveland as Ohio's largest city, and Chase Econometrics, an economic forecasting service, has predicted that Columbus will grow faster than any other municipality east of the Mississippi River and north of the Mason-Dixon line.

title: A PHILANTHROPIST SHIFTS STYLE IN APPEAL FOR CANCER CENTER
description: Before taking off for a holiday in Scotland, the industrialist Derald H. Ruttenberg gave $7 million to the Mount Sinai Medical Center for cancer research and promised there would be more soon.

title: Hugo Mahabir Plans To Wed Mary Cleary
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malachy F. Cleary of New York City and New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Loretta Cleary to Hugo Mulchan Mahabir, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Mahabir of Port of Spain, Trinidad. An Aug. 9 wedding is planned.

title: C.I.A. Regaining Role With Contras
description: When Congress refused to extend military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels in 1984, it underlined the point by ordering the Central Intelligence Agency to stay out of the remaining assistance operations, which were described as humanitarian.

title: Kenya to Boycott Games
description: Kenya today became the fourth nation to join a boycott of the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh, in protest of Britain's policy against South African sanctions. Nigeria, Ghana and Uganda have already pulled out for the same reason.

title: INTERNATIONAL STAMP SHOW SETS MANY RECORDS
description: Ameripex, the international stamp show held May 22 to June 1 in Chicago, is being hailed by collectors and professionals as an event that could stimulate the hobby for years to come. On practically every score by which these shows are judged, it has been rated as the best such event ever held in this country -and perhaps anywhere - in the history of the hobby.

title: GETTING AWAY FROM IT ALL RIGHT AT HOME
description: SOME people think a real vacation requires a passport and a plane ticket. Their longing for a respite from routine plus the seductive promises of glossy brochures creates a hunger for travel to faraway places.

title: LASERS SLOW ATOMS FOR SCRUTINY
description: Using seven beams of laser light, a team of scientists at AT&T Bell Laboratories has succeeded in slowing free atoms to a frozen crawl and trapping them in a space smaller than the period that ends this sentence.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS FEEL CUOMO PULLS HIS PUNCHES
description: IN an assessment of his record as Governor, Mario Cuomo last January listed among his accomplishments in environmental protection new water quality standards, stricter enforcement of water pollution laws and an increased budget for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: PROCEDURES FOR TREATING THOSE PRONE TO VIOLENCE
description: Following are the standard hospital procedures in New York City for handling potentially violent patients:

title: Gina Maisano, a Designer, Is Wed to Paul S. Flaxman
description: Gina Maisano, a daughter of Genette Maisano of La Jolla, Calif., and John F. Maisano of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Sanford Flaxman, the son of Cecilia Flaxman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Murray Flaxman. Justice George Roberts of the Supreme Court of the State of New York performed the ceremony at the deSeversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: UNCOMPLETED SPAN A LIABILITY
description: OFFICIALS of the state's Department of Transportation said last week that, once again, the problem-plagued bridge that has been under construction along Route 88 for some three years would not be opened as planned, this time because of a safety malfunction.

title: A Way to Tackle AIDS Education
description: We need to think of educating the public about AIDS in a wholly new way - more like the way a corporation markets a new product.

title: IN A BRANFORD THEATER, THE FIERCE WORLD OF SICILIAN PUPPETS
description: THE puppets hang along the walls of the theater auditorium in ghostly shadow until James Weil steps backstage and flicks on the lights. Now, under the light, their satin costumes glimmer in violet, emerald and scarlet, the steel of their swords glints in the light.

title: HARTFORD EXHBIT CELEBRATES RISK
description: PEOPLE who live or work in Hartford probably think the concept of insurance originated in that city, long known as the insurance capital of the world because of the number and reputation of the insurance companies there, and a place where insurance company headquarters have dominated the skyline for years.

title: THE SUCCESS OF THE 'PRESIDENT'S MEN'
description: JOHN D. EHRLICHMAN'S bushy eyebrows are at rest. Those familiar tufts, which 13 years ago soared and plunged dramatically as Mr. Ehrlichman sparred with the Senate Watergate Committee, still exercise during conversations. But they have mellowed.

title: Anne Van Munching To Wed P. B. Ardery
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching r. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Van Munching, to Peter Brown Ardery, the son of the late Grace Brown Ardery and the late Edmund F. Ardery. The wedding is planned for Sept. 27.

title: THE ADMINISTRATION'S IMPECCABLE LOGIC
description: THE Justice Department's conclusion that Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 does not prohibit discrimination based on actual or perceived capacity to transmit AIDS to others has been assailed as legally or medically flawed, mean-spirited, and antagonistic toward the gay community. The criticisms are misplaced. The Department's sober examination of the Rehabilitation Act reveals a commendable dedication to the rule of law and the belief that Congress, not bureaucrats, should be the foremost architect of national public policy.

title: Landlords Guilty Of Harassment
description: To a certain kind of Manhattan landlord, the service seemed worth the fee. Starting in 1979, for as much as $100,000 a building, a gang of professional ''vacators'' would force unwilling tenants out of apartments the landlords wanted to ''turn over'' for higher rents or convert to cooperative or condominium units.

title: TRICKS OF THE TRADE
description: MY DEAR, I MUST HAVE THE WRONG PALAZZO,'' said one of the first guests to visit this Manhattan apartment. The remark is one that the residence's decorator, Keith Irvine, repeats with delight, as well as with a tinge of smugness.

title: Jennifer C. Lenox To Become Bride Of Thomas Craig
description: Mr. and Mrs. George S. Lenox of Akron, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Christine Lenox to Thomas Craig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Tucker Criag of Washington. An Oct. 18 wedding is planned.

title: SIMCOE HANOVER CAPTURES SHEPPARD
description: Simcoe Hanover, the favorite, captured the $433,000 Sheppard Pace for 2-year-old colts and geldings tonight at the fast track of Yonkers Raceway.

title: Michael Houston Marries Miss Gibbons in Hyannis
description: Maude Ann Gibbons, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. John J. Gibbons of Short Hills, N.J., and Hyannis, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Houston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Houston of Auburn, Mass.

title: CHILD-CARE CENTERS CAN FULFILL MISSION
description: THE other day I walked downtown to see my lawyer and found myself passing a day-care center that was situated, like a lot of centers in this country, in the basement of a church. It looked pretty decent. The room was brightly lighted, though not by sunlight, and it seemed well equipped, if cluttered along the walls with exposed pipes and heating ducts. The teachers had obviously done a lot with what were basically pretty dreary surroundings, and the kids seemed to be getting along O.K.

title: EDBERG GAINS FINAL IN SWISS TENNIS
description: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden and unseeded Roland Stadler of Switzerland advanced today to the final of the $231,000 Swiss Open.

title: Writers and Warriors
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EYES OF SUMMER
description: THE EYE IS pleasure to the beholder, ally of the vamp and communicator par excellence. It is also a most vulnerable asset and, especially in the active days of summer should be carefully guarded with protective gear. Racquet sports, baseball, volleyball - all can pose dangers. Mowing the lawn, checking under the hood of an overheated car, even sunbathing demand caution.

title: CORRECTION
description: An interview with Cy Coleman on the theater page of the Arts and Leisure section today misstates the opening year for the original production of ''Hello, Dolly'' on Broadway. It was 1964.

title: Tug-of-War
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
SURPRISES IN A CORPORATE COLLECTION
description: THE art collection of the Chase Manhattan Bank, begun in 1959 by David Rockefeller, then the bank's chairman, has grown to a size and scope that many contemporary museums would envy. Assembled under the guidance of a distinguished committee - three of whose original members were on the staff of the Museum of Modern Art - the collection now has more than 11,000 works, many of which are displayed in the bank's corporate headquarters in Manhattan and offices worldwide.

title: JERSEY ZOO IS GETTING NEW LOOK
description: The Turtle Back Zoo in Essex County will undergo a $15 million renovation designed to reflect the state's wildlife and geology, with animals roaming in open areas.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JULY 13, 1986
description: Fiction

title: SCARSDALE CHURCH CITES OFFERS OF AID
description: THE Hitchcock Presbyterian Church has discovered who its friends are. Since the suspicious fire that destroyed the 73-year-old Scarsdale sanctuary during the early morning of June 5, the offers of help have kept coming. The Rev. Robert MacLennan, the senior minister, said that spontaneous contributions ''from $5 to $5,000'' arrive daily at the manse on Walworth Avenue that now houses the church office. One check came from a pastors' fund in Minneapolis. Another from the confirmation class of a Scarsdale synagogue.

title: Children of Poverty
description: Mr. Stein perpetuates the destructive myth that many people become foster parents ''simply because they get extra income.'' The truth is that foster-parent stipends, which pay the cost of caring for a child 24 hours a day, range from $242 to $314 per month, depending on the child's age.

title: Migs Feind Wed To Brian Landry
description: Marguerite Katharine Feind, promotion art director for Architectural Digest magazine in New York, and Brian Francis Landry, a vice president of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Giles Hayes and the Rev. William Conlon, the bride's uncle, officiated.

title: THE CLASS OF '61 OFFERS SOME DISSERTATIONS ON ITSELF
description: BIOGRAPHY and autobiography dominate the best-seller lists, attesting to an insatiable curiosity about people's lives. But one of the great repositories of American autobiography is virtually unknown: the annual reports published by the 25th reunion classes of Harvard and Radcliffe. These reports, which date back more than a century, have become a tradition and often prompt graduates to provide candid glimpses into their histories.

title: Sales of Tax-Foreclosed Buildings to Tenants to Rise
description: IT is a safe bet that when Mary Price's family rented an apartment at 303 West 122d Street in Harlem 42 years ago, it never occurred to her that one day she would own it.

title: On Reagan's Desk
description: President Reagan has been offered a new sign for his White House desk in the fashion of Harry S. Truman's ''The Buck Stops Here.'' The National Taxpayers Union sent Mr. Reagan a sign that shows, on one side, a taxpayer clad in a barrel with the inscription ''The Buck Starts Here'' and, on the other side, the motto ''When OUTGO exceeds INCOME, UPKEEP insures DOWNFALL.''

title: Enough Is Enough
description: A lot of toddlers have become college graduates during the nearly two decades Gordon M. Ambach has spent in the State Education Department. Last week he announced his resignation as the New York State Commissioner of Education, declaring ''20 years in the department is enough.''

title: DISPUTE PERSISTS OVER LOSS OF GRANT TO JERSEY CITY
description: THE sudden withdrawal of a promised $9 million Federal Urban Development Action Grant to this waterfront city has renewed talk of economic rivalry between New York and New Jersey and touched off defensive strategies to keep northern and central New Jersey from being permanently locked out of the UDAG market.

title: OPERA: 'LA JUIVE,' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: LOW-BUDGET efforts on behalf of rarely heard works traditionally win gratitude from the operatically curious, but the performance of about four-tenths of Halevy's ''Juive'' Thursday night by the New York Grand Opera in Central Park seemed almost calculated to test that sentiment steeply.

title: ANALOG RICHES ENLIVEN CD'S
description: Some people collect music on records; others just collect records.

title: Author of 'Sin'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LOOKING BACK: The American Dream Through Immigrant Eyes. By Marie Jastrow. (Norton, $15.95.) Although the author makes no claim to anything more than a personal documentary of that crucial period of immigration when so many different people came to these shores, ''Looking Back'' reads like engrossing fiction.

title: No Trade, No Mistake
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHINESE-AMERICANS TOLD TO BE MORE POLITICAL
description: The Lieutenant Governor of Delaware, Shien Biau Woo, in the keynote address at a national convention of Chinese-Americans this weekend, urged his fellow Chinese-Americans, ''who do so well in business and science,'' to become more involved in politics.

title: South Africa's Black Trade Unions
description: In his article ''The Struggle - Power and Politics in South Africa's Black Trade Unions'' (June 15), Alan Cowell asks rhetorically, ''What, ultimately, does organized labor want beyond the economic betterment of those it represents?'' It is true that labor unions in the United States may seek reform only in limited areas of health and economic issues (partly because labor law restrains as much as it encourages union activity), but to frame an analysis of the South African black trade unions in such a way misses the mark.

title: COMPLAINTS GROW AS MORE TENANTS TELL OF SEXUAL HARASSMENT BY LANDLORDS
description: The harassment began last August, Betty Staffier said, the day she applied for an apartment in the Naugatuck Valley in Connecticut and the landlord told her very straightforwardly that he would rent one to her if she agreed to sleep with him.

title: Tough Talk Instead of Smart Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
FAMILY TIES
description: WHEN Nina Berkey's father died a year and a half ago, she felt a sudden urge to learn about his family history. Knowledge of those who had gone before, she felt, would create for her some sense of continuity.

title: SHOULD THE RULES BE BENT IN AN EPIDEMIC?
description: Thousands of AIDS patients, though they know that the procedures are unproven and possibly dangerous, and that they stand a fifty-fifty chance of receiving only a cornstarch or salt water placebo, are enrolling in highly uncertain experiments with drugs. They consider themselves lucky.

title: Damage to Tombstones Of Adams Ancestors
description: Tombstones marking the graves of two ancestors of Presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams were overturned by vandals who had been drinking, the police said Thursday.

title: PRISONERS RENOVATING COMMUNITY FACIITIES
description: ALTHOUGH sirloin steaks and ice-cream sundaes are normally the stuff of which dreams are made at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, for a few inmates they have become a lunchtime reality.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Verdi's 'Falstaff.' Featuring Renato Bruson, Katia Ricciarelli, Leo Nucci, Barbara Hendricks; with the orchestra and chorus of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, conducted by Carlo Maria Giulini.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Four of six umpires named to the crew for Tuesday night's All-Star Game at the Houston Astrodome will be working the contest for the first time. Bruce Froemming of the National League, who will be behind the plate, and Paul Runge, who will be at second base, have each served once before in All-Star Game competition.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: FLYING AS IT USED TO BE - Airplane buffs should find the New England Air Museum in Windsor Locks, Conn., just the thing for a summer weekend. Its 130 craft include an early Bleriot XI Monoplane (1909), a Marcoux-Bromberg racer, the plane used in the 1938 film ''Test Pilot,'' starring Clark Gable, a Republic Thunderbolt fighter from World War II, and a Thunderchief fighter from the Vietnam War.

title: SLICE SODA RECALL IS COMPLETE
description: The removal of about 66,000 bottles of Slice soda from metropolitan-area stores was completed yesterday in response to a threat of cyanide poisoning.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a producer's change of plan, a theater listing for comedians today in The Guide (section 2A) gives outdated information about the series ''Jewish Humor, in Person'' at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue. The performer for Tuesday, July 15, is Richard Belzer, not David Steinberg.

title: WILLIAM S. WOODSIDE ON THE CORPORATE ROLE
description: The CHAIRMAN of the American Can Company, William S. Woodside, is among a growing number of executives who believe that private corporations should become advocates for public education. His company has financed programs at Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan, and he heads the education committee of the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit organization of business and civic leaders. At the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers last week, Mr. Woodside announced that American Can would help underwrite teacher training in seven cities.

title: A TEACHER PROBLEM: POOR SELF-PERCEPTION
description: The issues addressed by Shelley Lotenberg [ ''Who Will Educate Tomorrow's Youth?,'' Opinion Page, June 15 ] deserve consideration from teachers as well as the community at large.

title: The Cotswolds
description: To the Editor: In John Chancellor's excellent article, he mentions that books on the area are hard to find.

title: Children of Poverty
description: The infant mortality rate of babies born to teen-age mothers in the city is an alarming 16.1 deaths per thousand births. As Mr. Stein points out, teen-agers are ''far less likely than other expectant mothers to receive prenatal care, thus increasing their risk of bearing low birth-weight babies. . . .'' The Greater New York March of Dimes believes that the Goodhue-Tallon bill, currently in the State Legislature, offers a cost-effective way of addressing this problem. By providing comprehensive prenatal care and education for women who are ineligible for Medicaid but cannot afford private insurance, the bill will help to reduce the incidence of low birth-weight. JENNIFER L. HOWSE Executive Director March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation New York City

title: Maureen O'Brien Marries
description: Maureen Anne O'Brien and George Albert Garcia were married yesterday at St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church in Dorchester, Mass., by the Rev. Michael Parise, assisted by a cousin of the bride, the Rev. Michael Cody. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Hugh O'Brien of Dorchester, is studying for a Ph.D. in psychology at Temple University. Mr. Garcia, a student at the University of Minnesota Medical School, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix J. Garcia of Mendham, N.J. The bride and bridegroom were 1983 graduates of Brown University.

title: Award of $20,000 Is Given For Research in Psychology
description: The Rita G. Rudel Foundation has made its first $20,000 award to Dr. Ruth Nass, which will support her research in hormonal effects on left- and right-handedness and learning disabilities.

title: ALL ALONG THE HUDSON: A FLEET OF VESSELS FOR CHARTER
description: WHERE once there was only the Dayliner, a small armada of cruise boats now plies its trade along the Hudson River, offering sunset and moonlight cruises, sails to West Point football games, trips to lighthouses, floating classrooms, gourmet dining and lectures on architecture or ecology. Sailboats and cruise vessels are chartered for business and pleasure, for reunions and corporate outings and for bar mitzvah receptions and wedding ceremonies.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TALES AND TELLERS - Jean Watson has retired after 16 years as children's librarian at the Greenburgh Public Library, but she is kept busy filling requests for appearances as a storyteller. Her repertoire will be of Italian origin at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday in the Children's Room of the New Rochelle Public Library, where a weekly series of ''Stories From Around the World'' is in progress. The July 22 program will be African, July 29 is devoted to the Irish, Aug. 5 will be Spanish and Aug. 12, Jewish.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Alexis Lichine's Guide to the Wines and Vineyards of France Third edition, revised. 544 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $25; paper, $14.95. Like the complex red wines of his region, Bordeaux, Alexis Lichine's prose gains charm as it ages. The 1986 vintage of his celebrated guide, which first appeared in 1951, shows anew that as a wine writer he is himself a premier grand cru - a first great growth.

title: GLENDALE
description: SOMEONE looking for a pleasant, peaceful neighborhood to put down roots would do well to consider Glendale in central Queens - if he can find a house for sale there or, indeed, find the area at all.

title: High Court Does Harm in Ruling on Sexual Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: FISHING PIER FOR DISABLED
description: THE South Central Connecticut Regional Water Authority has opened a pier for disabled fishermen. The pier is on Lake Saltonstall, a reservoir, in Branford.

title: Follower of LaRouche Loses Recount of Vote in California
description: The only follower of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. who had appeared to win a Congressional primary in California became a loser Friday after a recount.

title: MEDIUM-FORMAT CAMERAS MAY STAGE COMEBACK
description: WILL the medium-format camera stage a comeback? For a time after World War II, this camera -smaller and more flexible than the 4x5 and bigger but slower in operation than the 35-millimeter - was the center of photographic attention. Small enough for use by fast-moving journalists, it produced a quality image that held up well against 4-by-5 film.

title: Cable TV
description: A new film entry on cable this week, ''A Flash of Green,'' should make rewarding home viewing over Cinemax on Monday afternoon at 1. Adapted from a John D. MacDonald novel set on the west coast of Florida, this off-beat drama draws a web of intrigue around a journalist who accepts a bribe. Vincent Canby of The Times praised the 1984 film's overall impact, its ambiance, Victor Nunez's direction and the performances of Ed Harris, Blair Brown and especially Richard Jordan.

title: A GROWING WAVE OF DEVELOPMENT STIRS DEBATE AND FEARS ON THE NORTH FORK
description: IN a shoreline enclave along Peconic Bay in the Town of Riverhead, where once only cattails grew, mounds of sand fill and a new road herald the coming of houses.

title: OPINION NARROWS OVER HIGH COURT
description: The American public is now about evenly split on whether the Supreme Court is too liberal or too conservative in its decisions, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: AN ATTORNEY WHO TEACHES HOW TO PUT HOUSES IN ORDER
description: BEFORE a rapt audience, the man on stage inflates a balloon and runs a long steel needle through it - without breaking the balloon.

title: HONKY-TONK NOURISHES NEW COUNTRY MUSIC
description: Much recent talk about country music pits traditionalism against everything else. On a couple of promising new records made in Nashville, Steve Earle from Texas and Randy Travis from North Carolina suggest that no conflict is necessary. The tightly constructed and well-observed songs about country life on Steve Earle's ''Guitar Town'' (MCA 5713, also available on cassette) rely upon the Dukes, a five-piece studio band whose quick tempos and attacks throughout the album might persuade a listener to call it rock and roll. Mr. Earle, who made one neo-rockabilly mini-LP for CBS Records before the release of ''Guitar Town,'' doesn't hear it that way. ''It's country 'cause I talk like this,'' he told his record company, ''And it's country because I write lyrics, and I tell stories, and I record in Nashville.''

title: T.V.A. IS FINED $150,000 FOR HARASSING ITS CRITICS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has fined the Tennessee Valley Authority $150,000 for harassing and intimidating three engineers who criticized the quality of construction in T.V.A. nuclear power plants.

title: By Hook or by Hand
description: Tony Faulk of Flint, Tex., is not a defensive lineman, but the 21-year-old fisherman was penalized last week for illegal use of his hands. After pleading guilty to a misdemeanor, Faulk was fined $100 only five hours after catching a 122-pound, 5-foot catfish in Lake Tyler on Wednesday.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S their third or fourth date and they're en route to one of those big benefit parties. They're both feeling festive - she in long dress and he in black tie. They arrive at the gala, join their hosts and eventually, go into dinner. Say it's not so! They're seated yards away from each other, across a large round table. That's if they're lucky. If the fates are really against them, they're at different tables.

title: Sunday Observer; Life Can Be Hard
description: HARD-LINERS ARE hard-nosed and play hardball. Inevitably, they lead hard lives because they spend so much time between a rock and a hard place.

title: Italy Sentences 11 in Hijacking Of Achille Lauro
description: An Italian jury could have decided on a life sentence for Magid al-Molqi, the Palestinian who, in a signed confession he later disavowed, had admitted murdering Leon Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old American tourist, during the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking in October.

title: Texas Murder Suspect Recaptured After 2 Days
description: A murder suspect and rapist was recaptured two days after he escaped from jail and a day after the deputy he had taken as a hostage escaped from him.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK CONCERTS -Billy Taylor is not only a renowned jazz pianist, but also an eloquent spokesman for jazz who considers it the classical music of the United States.

title: RHODE ISLAND CHARTER CHANGE WOULD BAR ABORTION SUPPORT
description: Voters in this heavily Catholic state will decide in November whether the Rhode Island Constitution should include an amendment prohibiting state financing of abortion.

title: Remember the Daisy
description: After more than 20 years, the image is still chilling, disconcerting, frightening.

title: BLACK RUNNING MATE LIFTS A MARYLAND CANDIDACY
description: Mayor William D. Schaefer was widely recognized as the closest thing in politics to a sure bet, a candidate who towered over his opponents for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Miss Bredin Wed To M. M. Massie
description: Antonia du Pont Bredin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bruce Bredin of Greenville, Del., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Miller Massie, a son of Wade Hampton Massie 3d of Washington, Va., and the late Grace Wallihan Massie. The Rev. Douglas G. Tompkins Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket.

title: U.S. Accused by Libya Of Provocative Moves
description: Libya's official press agency, JANA, accused the United States today of ''aggressive'' moves in the Mediterranean.

title: Authorized by Karajan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenny Netzer Plans to Wed
description: Jenny Netzer, deputy budget director of the Commonwealth of Massaschusetts in Boston, and Ellis M. Seidman, assistant to the director of the Office of Employee Relations of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, plan to be married Aug. 23.

title: MONROE CLUB ISSUES RECYCLING GUIDE
description: WHEN Kristin Zimet moved to Monroe from Texas three years ago and took her garbage to the town dump, she was ''appalled at the mountains of really valuable things that people were constantly discarding,'' she recalled.

title: WARREN COUNTY FARM YIELDS REWARDS FOR HERB DEVOTEES
description: MORE than 40 years ago, Cyrus Hyde, then a teen-ager, started collecting herbs in Totowa, the Passaic County town where his mother's family had lived in the same house for 200 years.

title: Boy George Is Arrested
description: The pop singer Boy George was arrested today and charged with heroin possession, the police said. He was later released by Scotland Yard and ordered to appear before a London magistrate on July 29. The 25-year-old singer was said to be undergoing treatment for heroin addiction.

title: TO BE OR NOT TO BE COMMITTED: 'LAST NIGHT' TACKLES LOVE IN THE 80'S
description: Debbie and Danny meet at a singles bar - he says he couldn't help but notice she had noticed him; she claims she was just looking at the clock above his head - and end up spending the night together.

title: MITTERRAND'S TRAVELS ARE WELL RECEIVED BACK HOME
description: N the last 10 days, President Francois Mitterrand has shuttled by Concorde across the world stage, from a working lunch with President Reagan in New York to 15 hours of meetings with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow. Mr. Mitterrand said he had made ''modest progress'' in his talks with the Soviet leader and had had a ''frank and cordial'' exchange with Mr. Reagan.

title: Cricket
description: To the Editor: In the April 6 article on cricket, Paul West identified the current West Indies captain, Viv Richards, as having hit six sixes in an over.

title: ZOKOL, WITH 67-205 HAS 2-STROKE LEAD
description: Richard Zokol, taking advantage of faltering play by the leaders, shot a four-under-par 67 today for a two-stroke advantage after three rounds of the $500,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: Children of Poverty
description: Andrew Stein's article ''Children of Poverty -Crisis in New York'' (June 8) brings into focus the plight of our city's children. The public must become aware of the facts that demonstrate that our children are suffering from ''a poverty even crueler in some ways than that of the Great Depression.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Helping Companies to Cross the Hudson
description: LOOKING for value and space, many Manhattan-based corporations have relocated to suburban communities in New Jersey in the last decade.

title: High Court Does Harm in Ruling on Sexual Conduct; Punish and Educate
description: To the Editor:

title: FAIRFIELD PORTER WATERCOLORS IN SHOW AT KATONAH GALLERY
description: THE Fairfield Porter retrospective that appeared at the Whitney Museum in 1984 was about half the size of the original, which had opened the year before at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts. Among the works jettisoned were the artist's watercolors. The Katonah Gallery has in effect compensated for the loss by inviting Prescott Schutz to put together a selection of the artist's efforts in this medium. And it is a task for which he is well suited, being a member of Hirschl & Adler, the gallery that handles the Porter estate, and having been both assistant to the retrospective's curator, Kenworth Moffett, and friend to the artist, who died in 1975 at the age of 68.

title: VOLLEYBALL LEGACY INSPIRES U.S. TEAM
description: The legacy of the 1984 women's volleyball team and the late Flo Hyman is so great that no American team may be able to match it for years to come. But the current American team is going to have to try if it wants to excel in what many believe is the ultimate team sport for women.

title: ISLAMIC INFLUENCE GROWS RAPIDLY IN MALAYSIA
description: The political influence of Islamic conservatives is growing in this Southeast Asian nation almost as fast as the popularity of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is falling, according to scholars and diplomats here.

title: COMPOSERS ONCE SCORNED ARE NOW ENJOYING A REVIVAL
description: An entire lost generation of composers is in the process of being rediscovered.

title: BACH'S FUGUES AND CELLO SUTIES TEST THEIR INTERPRETERS
description: If scholarship and musicianship are the head and the heart of musical performance, three new recordings of J. S. Bach's ''Art of the Fugue'' and two new recordings of his cello suites show how the head can inform the heart and heighten a listener's pleasure in music. In the case of ''Art of the Fugue,'' a performance by the harpsichordist-scholar Davitt Moroney supplies the dimension that performances by the pianist Zoltan Kocsis and the Portland String Quartet, in different ways, lack.

title: Miss Corsi to Wed John W. Watkins
description: Kathleen Corsi and John Winslow Watkins, candidates for M.B.A. degrees at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, plan to be married Aug. 23.

title: Miss Mueller Marries Scott Parker Biedron
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J., yesterday Tracey Anne Mueller and Scott Parker Biedron were married by the Rev. John T. Morrow. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Mueller of Far Hills, N.J., and the bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stan Biedron of Watchung and Mantoloking, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: GROUP OFFERS HELP TO SINGLE PARENTS
description: WHEN a New Haven pediatrician noticed a common complaint among the single-parent families he treated, he decided to take action to alleviate their problem - loneliness.

title: Lisa Joan Chazen Becomes Fiancee Of David Levine
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eric Martin Chazen of Nashville have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Joan Chazen to David John Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norvel Levine of St. Louis. The wedding is planned for Aug. 31.

title: WAITING FOR MADAME
description: THE CONTRACT By J. W. Rhoads. 108 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $12.95. MONSIEUR BAUDOIN buys an apartment. What else is new? He buys it in Paris. And?

title: KEEPING INTELLIGENCE SMART
description: THE AGENCY The Rise and Decline of the CIA. By John Ranelagh. Illustrated. 847 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95. IT looked like the spectacular finale to a Fourth of July fireworks extravaganza. Several hundred feet above the Pacific coast, near Vandenberg Air Force Base, a huge Titan rocket carrying a spy satellite exploded in a brilliant starburst. The loss last April of the Titan and its cargo, coupled with the earlier loss of the space shuttle and the later loss of a Delta rocket, has thrown the United States intelligence community, grown precariously dependent on space and high technology, into one of the most severe crises in its history.

title: AUDITS REPORT WIDE ABUSES AT BUSINESS TRAINING SCHOOLS
description: Government audits of New York State's 90 private profit-making business schools show a pattern of improper practices, misuse of student financial aid and ''pervasive violations of state laws and regulations,'' the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said last week.

title: A MATTER OF VALUE AND CONVENIENCE
description: I was shocked that on the Sunday before Liberty Weekend you would publish an article by Helene Verhaegen of Scarsdale [ ''A Customs Decision: Time to Be American,'' Westchester Opinion, June 29 ] in which she proudly proclaims that the only reason she is applying for United States citizenship is to get through immigration officials at Kennedy Airport more rapidly. Emma Lazarus did not write ''Give me your tired . . . yearning to be free of long lines.''THOMAS DEUTSCH Scarsdale

title: HOLYFIELD CAPTURES TITLE FROM QAWI
description: The simple sentence on the T-shirt that Evander Holyfield wore Friday read: ''I'm going to win!''

title: The Cost of Tyranny
description: The overthrow of several dictatorial and military regimes in recent years brings sharper focus on those remaining. There are always arguments about the danger of destroying order without delivering law and liberty when forces are gathering to topple tyrants.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL - METS VS. ATLANTA BRAVES, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Ceremonies to honor Rusty Staub begin at 1 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. WTBS, 6 P.M., tape.

title: Be Kind to Snakes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: High Court Does Harm in Ruling on Sexual Conduct; A Reactionary Omen
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Mennin Plans to Wed
description: A September wedding is planned by Felicia Anne Mennin and C. Mark Barnard 3d, the future bride's mother, Mrs. Peter Mennin of New York, has announced. Mr. Barnard is the son of Betty Lou Barnard of Burlington, N.J., and the late Mr. Barnard Jr. Miss Mennin, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, graduated from the Chapin School and magna cum laude from Princeton University.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Thatcher Rejects As 'Repugnant' Curbs on Pretoria
description: Politics continued to produce violence in South Africa last week, and while the authorities moved to calm the unrest, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain emphatically reiterated that she opposed economic sanctions as a way of forcing South Africa to abandon apartheid.

title: STATE REGULATORS ACT TO PROTECT SEEKERS OF MORTGAGES
description: STATE regulators, deluged with complaints about long processing times for home mortgages, have taken steps to guarantee that consumers get the loan rates they are promised, or their application fees back.

title: RARE FEAT IS POSSIBLE FOR MET PITCHERS
description: With the Mets holding a seemingly insurmountable division lead, they will have to find something to hold everyone's interest in the second half of the season. Dwight Gooden, Sid Fernandez, Ron Darling and Bob Ojeda have that very thing within their grasp. They could make the Mets only the third team in history to have four 20-game winners in the same season. To do it, though, they will have to pitch even better than they have in the first half.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas;
What to Do With 'The Hole'
description: IT has become so well-known that people refer to it merely as ''The Hole'' when giving directions, and invariably laugh. With the 15 feet of standing water it collects, it has earned the nickname ''Lake Lassiter,'' after the man who borrowed the $22 million to dig the hole, and the ''Oak Lawn Swimming Pool,'' for the neighborhood it graces.

title: College as Part Of Prison Term?
description: IT was an unusual issue before the New Hampshire Supreme Court: Must the state, as ordered by a lower court, pay for the college education of a prisoner serving 18 years to life for second-degree murder?

title: PURPOSE PITCHES, AND HOW A PITCHER CAN USE THEM
description: SPORTSWRITERS used to say that I had five pitches, one of them the brushback. But like every major league pitcher who wants to win, I also had two others: a knockdown pitch and a hit-batter pitch. Note that I didn't say ''beanball'' pitch.
