Nobody in his right mind throws a rock 90-plus miles an hour at a guy's head.

title: MUSIC: 2 GUESTS AT 'MOSTLY MOZART'
description: FRIDAY'S Mostly Mozart program at Avery Fisher Hall put two Mozart concertos at its center and surrounded them with sympathetic friends. Thus, this evening with the festival's orchestra - conducted by Gerard Schwarz - began with some private and relatively unfamiliar Mendelssohn and ended with Schubert at his most entertaining.

title: METS' OLD-TIMERS HAVE A SOGGY DAY
description: It was not the sort of afternoon to make an old-timer miss baseball.

title: PARADE ON LABOR DAY IS CANCELED BY NEW UNION COUNCIL PRESIDENT
description: The new head of the city's chief coalition of labor unions, in his first major actions, has canceled the organization's annual Labor Day parade as well as its executive board meetings for July and August.

title: Report Points to Errors in Grenada
description: For many, the United States invasion of Grenada in 1983 became a symbol of renewed national strength and confidence. But some in Washington have argued that the mission demonstrated some disturbing American weaknesses.

title: HOLLYWOOD AND LITERATURE: AN UNEASY ROMANCE
description: Here's a quick movie quiz: Which of the following novels have been made into movies? 1. ''Herzog'' by Saul Bellow. 2. ''Couples'' by John Updike. 3. ''Cat's Cradle'' by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. 4. ''The Confessions of Nat Turner'' by William Styron. 5. ''Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant'' by Anne Tyler. 6. ''The Adventures of Augie March'' by Mr. Bellow. 7. ''The Coup'' by Mr. Updike. 8. ''A Garden of Earthly Delights'' by Joyce Carol Oates. 9. ''Something Happened'' by Joseph Heller. 10. ''Sirens of Titan'' by Mr. Vonnegut. 11. ''Set This House on Fire'' by Mr. Styron. 12. ''Lie Down in Darkness'' by Mr. Styron. 13. ''The Centaur'' by Mr. Updike. 14. ''Henderson the Rain King'' by Mr. Bellow. The answer: None of them. They, as well as many, many other novels by such major modern writers as Philip Roth, Iris Murdoch, Shirley Hazzard, Muriel Spark, J. D. Salinger, John Cheever, Isaac Bashevis Singer -the list can go on and on - have never been made into movies.

title: Q AND A
description: Tax on a Co-op Buyout - Question: I live in a building that is about to be converted to a cooperative. The sponsor is offering to buy out tenants who are willing to give up their leases and leave. Will this money be taxed as regular income or as a capital gain? If I were to reinvest the money in another residence would the same tax rules apply? Are the elderly exempt from this tax? . . . M. R., Brooklyn Answer: The Internal Revenue Service will tax the income you receive in a buyout as a capital gain in accordance with the Internal Revenue Service Code, Section 1241.

title: NOTES OF AN INVESTIGATIVE SON
description: FAMILY SECRETS A Writer's Search for His Parents and His Past. By David Leitch. 242 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

title: Counting On Reagan
description: In their campaign to retain control of the U.S. Senate in November, the Republicans are relying not on President Reagan's policies but mainly on his personal popularity.

title: U.S. Halts Aid For Zimbabwe
description: The Reagan Administration decided last week to reduce aid to Zimbabwe after a high Zimbabwean official interrupted a Fourth of July celebration at the United States Embassy in Harare, the capital, to deliver a 25-minute anti-American tirade.

title: Navy Shoots 461 Goats On Island Off California
description: After three years of delays, the Navy says it has begun shooting the remaining wild goats roaming the military installation on San Clemente Island.

title: MANY SOURCES, MANY POINTS OF VIEW
description: Once upon a time, a couple of decades ago, independent producers were looking to public television as a showcase for their film and video documentaries.

title: ENROLLMENT CITED AS GAIN FOR YONKERS SCHOOL PLAN
description: THE Yonkers school integration plan appeared to city education officials last week to have been endorsed by the parents of city schoolchildren, even as the Superintendent, Dr. Joan M. Raymond, began preparations to take up a post as head of Houston's schools.

title: RARE GLIMPSE OF THE FURNITURE OF A MODERN DUTCH MASTER
description: The innovative furniture designs of Gerrit Thomas Rietveld appear infrequently on the market. And when they do, the works of the Dutch architect - along with Piet Mondrian he developed the De Stijl movement's advanced ideas of abstraction in design and art - attract an enthusiastic audience of European and American collectors, dealers and museum curators.

title: BERLINERS LENDING A HAND IN EL BARRIO
description: Near the corner of 107th Street and Lexington Avenue, just beyond a vacant lot strewn with garbage and a burnt-out apartment building, comes the sound of German voices in El Barrio.

title: MAKING USE OF SUPERMARKETS' FRESH INGREDIENTS
description: THE change in supermarkets outside the city is more pronounced than ever this summer. Even the dullest stores in my neighborhood (an hour and a half from the city, up the Hudson) now have special fresh-fish sections, where only a few months ago they offered nothing but frozen fillets and the occasional bit of cod. The choice of meat and poultry, once virtually limited to steak, hamburger and chicken parts, has improved to include lamb, veal, offal and fresh Cornish hens. Fresh herbs are available at a fraction of Manhattan prices, and special sections have been set up for exotic fruits and vegetables and Oriental seasonings. I no longer need to stock up at the expensive food emporiums in New York City before I leave for the country.

title: Arrest in Chelsea Killing
description: His body was found wrapped in a canvas dropcloth in a parking lot in Chelsea, tied at the feet, abdomen and head with a string. His gold jewelry and $220 in cash had not been taken.

title: A HIGH-TECH CURE FOR SICKLY CALFS
description: MONOCLONAL antibodies -laboratory-produced substances that bind to specific organisms without damaging body cells - have made it to the market. They are used to diagnose pregnancy and herpes. And on June 19, Johnson & Johnson's Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation announced that it had F.D.A. approval for a monoclonal antibody that reverses kidney transplant rejections.

title: Miss McDonnell Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Ann's Episcopal Chapel in Kennebunkport, Me., yesterday Michela McDonnell, a daughter of Mrs. Barrington Boardman of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Sean McDonnell, was married to Jay Wheeler Stewart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart of Concord, N.H. The Rev. Laman Bruner performed the ceremony.

title: FROM CONCEPT TO ALBUM IN THE HIGH-STAKES WORLD OF POP RECORDING
description: During a private party at Tavern on the Green, the singer Philip Bailey and the producer Nile Rodgers smile toward popping flashbulbs. Mr. Bailey's new album, ''Inside Out,'' is being played through disco-size speakers for CBS Records executives, record-store personnel and journalists. For most guests, it's a first hearing; for Mr. Rodgers and Mr. Bailey, it may be the 10,000th.

title: LASERS TURN LIGHT AGAINST ILLNESS
description: LOOKING through an endoscope, a flexible fiberoptic tube inserted into a patient's esophagus, Dr. Richard Bronzo found a tumor and instantly vaporized it with a laser fitted into a channel of the scope.

title: IMMORTALS OF THE CAFFE GRECO
description: The summer before last was so hot in Rome I spent a good deal of it in the coolness of the Caffe Greco, sipping iced tea, reading, writing letters, using it as a sort of study. It's a charming old place, right on the Via Condotti, a block from the Piazza di Spagna and Keats's house, and even nearer to the building where Leopardi stayed in the 1820's. Elizabeth Browning also lived in the neighborhood, on Via Mario de' Fiori, and Shelley a five-minute walk away, on the Corso.

title: NEW BOOM FOR FLORIDA CREATES NEW CONCERNS
description: With 1,000 new residents arriving each day, Florida's modern land rush is elating those who welcome enhanced political power and economic diversity in a state almost dismissed in the past as a vacation playground and retirement retreat.

title: EARPHONES RESPOND TO THE CD CHALLENGE
description: Earphones, these days, are associated chiefly with peripatetic listeners roaming the streets with a Walkman dangling from their belts.

title: MAN VS. MOLE: FIRST, GET SOME BUBBLE GUM...
description: AS regularly as the swallows that return to Capistrano, the underground marauders have reappeared at my country house, and the perennial battle to preserve my lawn has been joined.

title: Charges Against Goetz Reinstated
description: For nearly 19 months after Bernhard Goetz shot four youths he thought intended to rob him on a Manhattan subway train, the criminal justice system wrestled not with the question of his guilt or innocence, but with the question of whether he should stand trial at all.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: BOSTON COMMON GETS A CURFEW -Muggers, drug peddlers and three-card monte dealers were not a problem in 1634 when Gov. John Winthrop and his neighbors raised $150 to purchase land for the Boston Common. But there have been plenty of complaints about such people lately, prompting Mayor Raymond L. Flynn to impose a 10 P.M.-to-dawn curfew on both the common and the adjacent Public Garden.

title: SUFFOLK ROAD PLAN IS DISPUTED
description: A PLAN by Suffolk County to widen and straighten a road in Commack is raising concern among residents who fear that their property will be confiscated.

title: CLEMENS BEATS ANGELS FOR 15TH
description: After losing two games in a row, Roger Clemens figured he had better win again for the Boston Red Sox fans ''before they really panic.''

title: A HAMPTONS HORN OF PLENTY
description: I AM an unreconstructed nongardener. I do not relish soiling my hands, gathering dirt beneath my nails, stooping, bending, spading, weeding and otherwise doing to God's good earth all those chores that produce the greenest, most pungent of herbs, the lushest of red, ripe tomatoes, the sweetest corn, the hottest of chilies, the sourest of sorrel for that greatest of soups called creme Germiny.

title: YIDDISH GROUPS HELPING TO KEEP A LANGUAGE ALIVE
description: SOME experts say that Yiddish, the traditional language of Eastern European Jews, is a dying tongue. But one would not know that on Long Island, where interest in preserving Yiddish is burgeoning.

title: Marjorie Bahlke Becomes a Bride
description: The Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Marjorie Ellen Bahlke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Bahlke of Lighthouse Point, Fla., to David Robert Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Harrison of Manchester, N.H. The Rev. Anthony Kill, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: GOING AFTER THE PRIZE (OR PUTTING ON THE DOG)
description: Competition is fierce out there, make no bones about it. There's that constant pressure to have the waggiest tail, the wettest nose, the saddest eyes.

title: THE NAVY WORRIES IT MAY HAVE TOO MANY OPENINGS
description: DEMOGRAPHIC tides and budgetary winds are driving the United States Navy toward a dangerous shoal: a potentially crippling shortage of manpower in the coming decade.

title: DOWN-HOME DRAMA THRIVES IN ATLANTA
description: For many Atlantans, including some 100 backers who flew up to attend this spring's Off Broadway opening of Sandra Deer's ''So Long on Lonely Street,'' the mainly negative reviews the play received were hard to swallow. What was at stake was far more than a financial investment. ''So Long On Lonely Street'' was the first home-grown play to grace the main stage of Atlanta's 18-year-old Alliance Theater, where Ms. Deer is literary manager. There, it became a smash hit, breaking all box-office records and filling people throughout the city with great communal pride. The possibility of a New York production fueled the excitement. It was as if ''So Long on Lonely Street'' symbolized a cultural coming of age for Atlanta.

title: 14 Are Killed in Fighting In Western India
description: The army was placed on alert today after 14 people were killed and 50 hurt in violence arising from religious rivalries in the western state of Gujarat, the United News of India reported.

title: Labyrinth of Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: SARAWAK: A KINGDOM IN THE JUNGLE
description: In 1841 James Brooke, an English adventurer and sometime trader, fulfilled every Victorian schoolboy's dream:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FLANNERY ROW By Karen Ackerman. Illustrated by Karen Ann Weinhaus. Unpaged. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 8) TELEVISION'S ''Sesame Street'' has made the old alphabet book all but obsolete. Yet nothing can discourage the children's book publishing industry from producing some unusual, ambitious examples from time to time. No recent work has superseded C. B. Falls's classic ''ABC Book'' (1957) in so effectively teaching a child his letters, but the latest is worthy of sharing a shelf with ''Ashanti to Zulu'' (1977) by Leo and Diane Dillon and ''On Market Street'' by Anita and Arnold Lobel (1981). ''Flannery Row'' is not just another alphabet book; in it Karen Ackerman has invented a charming memory game.

title: City Aides Assail Release of Patient In Ferry Attack
description: Juan J. Gonzalez boarded a Staten Island ferry Monday morning armed with a two-foot sword and the belief that God wanted him to use it. Before he was taken ashore in police custody, he allegedly slashed and stabbed 11 passengers, killing two of them.

title: Music
description: This is the 20th season of Mostly Mozart at Avery Fisher Hall, and what began as a bold experiment has now become an established fact of New York musical life. And this week, the festival promises some exciting concerts.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Bantam, $4.95.) John Irving's novel explores abortion and the relationship between a spiritual father and son -Dr. Wilbur Larch, a Maine physician who performs abortions and directs an orphanage, and the orphaned Homer Wells. Benjamin DeMott wrote in The Book Review last year that ''at its best, this novel is an example, now rare, of the courage of imaginative ardor.'' THE HUNGRY SELF: Women, Eating, and Identity, by Kim Chernin. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) Why are so many otherwise ''normal'' women obsessed with food, dieting, fat and exercise instead of wholeness and autonomy, Kim Chernin asks. Her answer is that such women are fleeing self-development and that female identity is in crisis. In 1985 our reviewer, Phyllis Chesler, found this work ''an inspired psychoanalytical meditation on contemporary female identity and eating disorders.'' But she said the author ''leans too heavily on feminist or psychoanalytic insight as a way to control self-destructive behavior.'' CARPENTER'S GOTHIC, by William Gaddis. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $6.95.) At the center of William Gaddis's third novel is the stormy marriage of the Booths - Elizabeth, an heiress, and Paul, a media consultant - who live in a Victorian house on the Hudson River, north of New York City. But ''plot is what Mr. Gaddis travesties and teases and two-times and swindles,'' our reviewer, Cynthia Ozick, wrote last year. ''It is an unholy landmark of a novel - an extra turret added on to the ample, ingenious, audacious Gothic mansion William Gaddis has slowly been building in American letters.''

title: Thanks to Everybody For Liberty Weekend
description: To the Editor:

title: DON'T LOOK NOW, BUT YOUR CHICKEN CAME HOME TO ROOST
description: REGARDLESS of what Thomas Wolfe thought, you can go home again, and young adults today are doing it in droves.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE CATALOGUE OF THE UNIVERSE By Margaret Mahy. 185 pp. New York: A Margaret K. McElderry Book/ Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 14 and up) IN a literature for young adults overpopulated with innocuously pretty girls, Margaret Mahy, a prize-winning author from New Zealand, presents us with a heroine, deceptively named Angela May, who is unsettlingly beautiful. Her mother, Dido, unable to convince her Aeneas to stay (''he's too fond of his first family to run any risks'') has taken their daughter to live in a rundown cottage atop Dry Creek Road, above the city.

title: WHERE UNCERTAINTY IS KING AND PARADOX SHARES THRONE
description: When atoms float as slowly as balloons and light beams grip them like tweezers, scientists know they are entering a world where ordinary rules do not apply.

title: 2 MAJOR PLANS FOR MT. VERNON GARAGE SITE
description: A KEY block in the heart of Mount Vernon between the City Hall and the Mount Vernon Hospital - a spot where a condemned city parking garage has been crumbling into ruin for the last two years - is now the target of two rival developers.

title: High Court Does Harm in Ruling on Sexual Conduct; Heterosexuals Also
description: To the Editor:

title: Mantle Says Baseball Solving Drug Problem
description: Mickey Mantle says he thinks fears concerning a drug problem in baseball are overblown.

title: ST. CROIX
description: The first tourist to come to St. Croix for the start of a winter season was Christopher Columbus, who arrived Nov. 14, 1493 on his second voyage to the New World. Ever since, most of the tourist activity on this 84-square-mile island, largest and most easterly of the United States Virgin Islands, has been in the winter season.

title: Suffolk Votes to Buy Land for Preservation
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has voted to spend $60 million to acquire 4,833 acres of privately owned land for preservation as undeveloped open space.

title: HERSELF EXPLAINED
description: FOR SYLVIA An Honest Account. By Valentine Ackland. Foreword by Bea Howe. 135 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $13.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
WHEN THE LOCATION IS AN ASSET
description: CONSIDERING how many Chinese restaurants there are in New Jersey, it's amazing how difficult it is to find one that can be truly recommended. Often, there are one or two good dishes hidden among several truly awful ones. Or, all of the dishes are mediocre.

title: ZULUS, TORN TWO WAYS, SEEK MIDDLE GROUND
description: Felix Nzama relaxed on the covered porch of his home above the curls of the Tugela River and mused a little on the nation's miseries and confrontations.

title: Jeffrey Scott Koeze, Law Clerk, Wed To Katharine Hencken Reid in Maine
description: Katharine Hencken Reid, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Seabury Reid of York Harbor, Me., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Koeze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Scott Koeze of Grand Rapids, Mich. Bishop Charles Hall, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Many Bargains, Plus 'Ultimate Bargains' - The Central Avenue Filene's Basement opened just below Ardsley Road in November with 20 to 50 percent off suggested retail prices on women's and men's clothing and footwear, lingerie, accessories and men's furnishings. It is clearing spring and summer merchandise now.

title: RETHINKING THE REVOLUTION
description: THE VIETNAMESE GULAG By Doan Van Toai and David Chanoff. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
INVESTING;
BEARS BEWARE, BULLS LURKING
description: Worried stock investors could have found solace last week - however faint - from analysts at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Even before the rout in equity prices, mutual funds were sitting on loads of cash, according to Melissa Brown, a senior analyst with the firm. The money, which flowed in at record levels from I.R.A. contributors in April, accounted for 10.2 percent of total assets in equity funds at the end of May, Ms. Brown said.

title: Nixon Arrives in Soviet; Dobrynin Meeting Set
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon began what a spokesman called a private fact-finding trip to Moscow today.

title: JAZZ: GEORGE COLEMAN QUARTET
description: THE quartet that the tenor saxophonist George Coleman is leading at the Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South near 11th Street, through today is a rugged, swaggering group that explodes in a boisterous, happy manner rather than with any sense of menace.

title: John Breck O'Connor Plans to Marry Carolyn Kennedy Brush in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Brush of Norfolk and Danbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Kennedy Brush to John Breck O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. O'Connor of Loundonville, N.Y., and Watch Hill, A September wedding is planned.

title: THE SPLIT MILITARY PSYCHE
description: SINCE 1947, THE YEAR Congress created the Department of Defense and the Joint Chiefs of Staff, there have been repeated efforts to restructure both organizations. However, as each Congressional session adjourns, the reform legislation, like an old soldier, simply fades away.

title: SWEDEN'S CAPTIAL SAVORS ITS SUMMER
description: A remarkable transformation takes place each spring and summer in the Swedish capital. As snow and ice melt away and twilight days yield to 18 hours of clear Nordic light, 700-year-old Stockholm emerges at its fairest, with an abundance of blue waters surrounding its 14 city islands and parkland covering a third of its area.

title: The Gipper and I
description: First Lady Nancy Reagan is emerging as First Author as well. Random House announced last week that it had secured, for an undisclosed sum, the right to publish Mrs. Reagan's memoirs.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: The Lady Vanishes. With Margaret Lockwood, Michael Redgrave, Paul Lukas, Dame May Whitty, Cecil Parker; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1938. Criterion Collection, 97 minutes.

title: Ethnic Bankers
description: To the Editor:

title: A TASTE OF FREEDOM
description: COME JULY, FIREWORKS, street dancing, endless toasts and patriotic fervor can only mean one thing: Bastille Day, of course!

title: 2 SENATORS JOIN FIGHT ON RULING BY PIERCE
description: NEW JERSEY'S two Senators have joined forces to block a ruling by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., that would cut off Urban Development Action Grants to New Jersey and other states accused of pirating jobs away from neighboring areas.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN A LONG PRESENCE IN HONDURAS BASES
description: After three and a half years of intense military buildup, the United States is prepared to maintain a military presence in Honduras for years to come, according to several military officials and diplomats in Honduras.

title: Mason's Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chinatown
description: Beyond its restaurants and garment factories, Chinatown is a land of real-estate speculation, a neighborhood of Manhattan area where tenement buildings often sell for more than $1 million. Vacant land in the crowded area is scare, and new construction is therefore infrequent.

title: Jersey Ruling Upheld On Jockey Drug Tests
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a decision permitting New Jersey to administer random drug tests to jockeys, saying that the tests do not represent an invasion of privacy.

title: ROLE FOR BLACKS IS DEBATED IN LINCOLN'S HOMETOWN
description: A political battle over black representation on the City Council of Abraham Lincoln's hometown is about to move into Federal court here. And both private and city officials are warning that it threatens to further polarize racial feelings in the capital city of the nation's fifth most populous state.

title: IRVING SCHLEIN
description: Irving Schlein, a pianist, composer and conductor, died Friday at New York Hospital.

title: ALGAE BLOOM: MYSTERY AND THREAT
description: AS a marine scientist, William C. Dennison has seen a lot of eelgrass, especially in the shallow coastal waters of Alaska, Australia and the Caribbean. But when he came to Long Island in 1984, he saw something special.

title: BANKS, NOT SURROGATE, SHOULD HANDLE MINORS' FUNDS
description: AS A County Surrogate, I have found that there is a lack of adequate standards in the withdrawal of minors' funds, which I must manage and oversee, resulting in unequal treatment.

title: 12 NOVELISTS AND SHAKESPEARE'S BED
description: IN April, The Book Review ran an article by Alfred Bendixen about ''The Whole Family,'' a novel written by 12 authors - one for each character - including Henry James and William Dean Howells. The writing and editing of the book is a story of infighting and backbiting, everyone accusing everyone else of confusion and sentimentality. James, whose chapter was twice as long as most, thought he had ''saved'' the novel, an opinion not shared by the other 11.

title: SHE'S ATTUNING THE CITY'S TV AND RADIO STATIONS TO SUCCESS
description: For a little more than a year now, a relative upstart among public-television stations has been offering New Yorkers alternative, imaginative and sometimes avant-garde programming that has caused a growing number of viewers to sit up, take notice and tune in. The upstart is the city-owned WNYC/Channel 31, which, just a few short years ago, was generally considered little less than a poorer sister to WNET/Channel 13.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Domestic Travel Doldrums - Last week's decision by People Express to sell its Frontier Airlines was in part caused by People's inability to attract enough summer travelers. And People is not alone - many airlines are experiencing this somewhat surprising problem.

title: MODERN TWISTS SPICE A MOZART OPERA
description: The approach to Pepsico Summerfare by car is not inviting - the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase looms up prisonlike, a clump of massive windowless boxes in dull brick. But within its three theaters sprites cavort and notions both challenging and frivolous are given play.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GOLDEN MILE. By John Sherlock. (Viking, $17.95.) John Sherlock's new novel keeps the reader in suspense mainly by jolting him from one dramatic setting to the next - Hitler-dominated Europe, New York's art scene, strife-torn Malaysia, Los Angeles's luxury high-rises.

title: KANJI LOVES JULIE
description: EAST AND WEST By Gerald Green. 476 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $18.95.

title: 3 YOUTHS HELD IN SHOOTING OF OFFICER, NOW PARALYZED
description: Three teen-agers were charged yesterday in the shooting in Central Park of a plainclothes police officer, who is now in Bellevue Hospital and likely to remain paralyzed for life from the neck down, the police reported.

title: McCRORY EASY VICTOR
description: Milton McCrory of Detroit, the former World Boxing Council welterweight champion, established himself as a middleweight contender today with a unanimous decision over Doug DeWitt of Yonkers in a 10-round bout.

title: LITTLE, GEDDES FACING PLAYOFF
description: Sally Little, whose poor health has prevented her from winning over the last four years, and Jane Geddes, looking for her first victory in four years as a pro golfer, came from behind to tie for the 41st United States Women's Open championship today at the NCR Country Club.

title: China Seeking GATT Membership
description: China has applied for membership in GATT, the world's dominant free-trade group and will join in the major trade negotiations due to begin later this year, David Woods, a GATT spokesman said today.

title: The Feeble Fight Against AIDS
description: By last January, the AIDS virus had killed 9,000 Americans. In this year alone, another 9,000 will die. If the epidemic continues to rage, the toll by 1991 will be 180,000. Is everything possible being done to curb the spread of so vicious a disease? The strange answer is that very little is being done. The possible social remedies to prevent AIDS offend law, custom or morality.

title: Diplomacy on the Move
description: Gibson Lanpher, the State Department official who with former President Jimmy Carter walked out of Fourth of July celebration in the United States Embassy in Zimbabwe, is returning to Washington for a new assignment. Mr. Lanpher, the acting ambassador, and Mr. Carter were among those who left to protest a speech critical of the United States that was being given by a Zimbabwean official.

title: HONDURAS BUILDUP: VARIETY OF MEANS
description: The Defense Department has used a variety of methods to establish a small American military presence in Honduras without obtaining explicit approval from Congress, according to Congressional sources and the General Accounting Office.

title: Guns Not Main Cause Of U.S. Fatal Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen R. Soley Married To Dr. E. S. Adkins 3d
description: Ellen Rose Soley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas James Soley of Seaford, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. E. Stanton Adkins 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adkins 2d of Salisbury, Md. The Rev. Dr. Jack Cooper, a professor emeritus of theology at Princeton University, performed the Presbyterian ceremony in the chapel at Princeton, of which the bridegroom is an alumnus.

title: 3 Hurt in Soapbox Derby
description: Three children were injured, one seriously, when a soap box derby racer traveling about 30 miles an hour on his gravity-powered coaster struck a hay bale at the finish line and veered into the crowd. Benjamin Carr, 3 years old, his brother Zachary, 6, and their cousin, Shea Bergman, 7, were hurt Saturday when the coaster of Barry Myhr, 9, went out of control. Barry was not hurt.

title: Power and Triviality
description: Conservatives of the Reagan-Meese school love to denounce ''judicial activism.'' So what did they do when the Supreme Court struck down the Gramm-Rudman budget law? They cheered. The Wall Street Journal said exultantly that the Court had told Congress it could not ''waive the Constitution.''

title: MORGENTHAU-GIULIANI CLASH REFLECTS WIDE CONCERN OVER WHO IS TO BLAME
description: As New York is flooded by cocaine, the city's most prominent prosecutors have become locked in an acerbic battle over where the blame lies and what should be done. Both men - the Manhattan District

title: The Editorial Notebook; Little Men
description: Remembering the wardrobe that got me through a women's college in the 1950's I see Brooks Brothers shirts, khaki pants and a six-foot scarf. I see peacoats from an Army/ Navy store, fly-front drawstring pajamas, letter sweaters worn inside out and a baggy white jacket whose provenance, I think, was Princeton. Like most of my classmates I was doing my damndest to look like a boy; and doing my damndest, Pall Malls (pronounced Pell Mells in my circle) forever at hand, to smoke like a man.

title: Lightning Kills 2 Austrians
description: A bolt of lightning killed two Austrians as they climbed a mountain in this northern Italian region, the ANSA news agency reported today. Franz Plainer, 22 years old, and his fiancee, Irene Scharattecker, 19, were struck by lightning Saturday during a storm while scaling the mountain, the report said. Six other Austrians climbing with the couple were not injured.

title: BAKER WARY ON SIZE OF TAX CUTS FOR MIDDLE CLASS
description: As House and Senate tax writers prepared to begin work this week on a compromise plan to overhaul the Federal income tax laws, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d cautioned them against trying to give middle-income Americans a much larger tax cut at the expense of corporations, saying it could hurt the nation's economic health.

title: Advertising; Trade Deal Tactics Cut Ad Budgets
description: MANUFACTURERS of packaged goods who have cut advertising spending in favor of trade deals (in seeking a short-term profit solution) are behind many of the economic woes of the ad agency and media industries.

title: NICARAGUAN REPRESSION CITED
description: The repression of human rights in Nicaragua is systematic and widespread, a human rights group asserted in a report made public yesterday.

title: Sharon Sabba Is Married To Dr. Mark A. Fierstein
description: The marriage of Sharon Sabba, a daughter of Mrs. Louis Sabba of Manhasset Hills, L.I., and the late Mr. Sabba, to Dr. Mark Alan Fierstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Fierstein of Roslyn, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated at the Renaissance Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Lions Clubs Oppose Women as Members
description: Lions Clubs International, which says it is the world's largest service organization, with more than 1.3 million members, voted Saturday against letting women join.

title: OPERA: 'DIE WALKURE,' 2D IN ARTPARK 'RING' CYCLE
description: Artpark, the performing arts center downstream from Niagara Falls here, has joined the list of smaller companies attempting what would once have been unthinkable for any but a major theater: a complete cycle of Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelungs.'' The project began last year with ''Rheingold'' on borrowed sets; Saturday night, the second installment - ''Die Walkure,'' this time wholly produced by Artpark - was unveiled.

title: A VISION CREATES SANCTUARY FOR CITY'S HOMELESS MOTHERS
description: ''My husband hit me, and he threatened to slit my throat with a screwdriver,'' the young woman said, cradling her 7-month-old daughter in her arms and watching her 3-year-old son play with a tricycle. ''My family didn't want me to be with him in the first place, and they won't talk to me. I had no place to stay, so I came here.''

title: COST OF JUSTICE SYSTEM IS PUT AT $39.7 BILLION IN U.S. STUDY
description: Combined Federal, state and local spending on civil and criminal justice accounted for 3 percent of all government spending in the fiscal year 1983, the Department of Justice said today.

title: YEARS OF TROUBLE: FAMILY TELLS SUSPECT'S LIFE STORY
description: Shavoda (Buddah) Jones, the 15-year-old charged with shooting a police officer in Central Park on Saturday, had the varied interests and dreams of most children, his family and friends said yesterday. He liked mathematics and wood carving, played the violin and talked often of becoming a police officer.

title: SCIENCE HALL IS TO REOPEN AFTER 5 YEARS
description: After five years and $9 million of work, the city is preparing to reopen what officials hope will become a world-class center for public displays of science and technology.

title: Of Airline Mergers and Labor
description: The Department of Transportation may have tipped its hand with respect to protecting labor in airline mergers.

title: A Cymbal-Minded Defense Strategy
description: The billion- and trillion-dollar figures nimbly tossed about in the defense budget debate tend to numb those of us who worry about avoiding the $7 charge on checking account overdrafts. But now and then, the Administration proposes an outlay that jolts us. I just ran across one.

title: THE 'NEW MAN' VS. THE OLD
description: The ''new man,'' said Anthony Astrachan, is not only capable of sensitivity, intimacy and commitment, but he is also, among other things, ''one who has abandoned or transcended most traditional male sex roles and the male attempt to monopolize power -and he supports women's quests for independence and equality with more than lip service.''

title: AFTER A MONTH UNDER EMERGENCY DECREE, CALM IN SOUTH AFRICA IS EVER MORE ELUSIVE
description: In the month since South Africa's newest emergency decree was proclaimed, it has brought the nation a new kind of ferment and protest instead of the quiet that seemed to be its goal.

title: BRITISH OPEN BACK AT SITE OF '77 DUEL
description: It had been so unusually hot for days along Scotland's southwest coast that clouds of dust instead of the normal rain and ocean spray blew over Turnberry's Ailsa Course in July 1977. It just didn't seem the proper setting for a British Open, which is expected to bring out the best in the world's top golfers because of the strength of the elements over a superb links course.

title: A Pro-Marcos Rally Is Thwarted in Manila
description: Riot policemen chased supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos around a downtown Manila park today and prevented them from holding a rally.

title: CONCERN OVER TREASURY FINANCINGS
description: Although Government issues this week are confined to the regular Treasury offering of three-month and six-month bills, the auction may draw more attention than usual, as market participants weigh the possibilities of a disruption in Treasury financing.

title: 3 McDonald's Assignments
description: Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, one of the Mickelberry companies, has picked up three more McDonald's Owner/ Operators Associations, whose approximately $6 million in advertising spending should bring the McDonald's advertising through the agency to $40 million, a whopper.

title: DIFFUSE GOALS SET BY NADERS OF JAPAN
description: Naokazu Takeuchi is a dedicated consumer activist. For 17 years, he has argued for stricter antitrust laws to prevent what he believes are cartels that keep prices high. As president of the Consumers Union of Japan, he has battled the Government and big business, fighting for stricter regulations on food additives and environmental hazards.

title: ALL-STAR GAME MATCHES OLD AND NEW
description: Baseball's annual midseason pause - the grand and glamorous All-Star Game - comes again tomorrow night under another infernal big top. If past form holds, the evening will unfold as just another dull summer rerun.

title: U.S. Is Upset In Basketball
description: Argentina shocked the United States, 74-70, today in the semifinal round of the world basketball championships. It was the Americans' first loss in the 15-day round-robin tournament.

title: 'Full Glory Reflected'
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Denied Tenure Is Awarded $278,000
description: A Federal jury has ordered three University of Cincinnati officials to pay $278,000 to a former professor who asserted that she had been denied tenure because of sex discrimination.

title: U.S.-Bermuda Treaty
description: The United States and Bermuda signed a tax treaty Friday intended to help American law enforcement officials obtain financial information in civil and criminal tax cases and granting Bermuda certain business tax concessions.

title: Boyd Apologizes to Team
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd apologized to his Boston Red Sox teammates today for throwing a tantrum and walking out on the club three days ago.

title: Ralph Steiner Is Dead; Was Still Photographer
description: Ralph Steiner, a still photographer and cinematographer whose documentary films included the 1930's classic ''The Plow That Broke the Plains,'' died yesterday of cancer in Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 87 years old and lived in Thetford Hills, Vt.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VENERATION There is a touch of Chicano Texas one flight up, at Intar Gallery, the art auxiliary of the Hispanic American theater group at 420 West 42d Street, on Theater Row (695-6134).

title: PRETORIA MOVING TO FORCE A HALT TO SCHOOL PROTEST
description: The South African Government announced new measures today to oppose classroom protest, saying students who do not enroll for the beginning of a new school term Monday will be barred from classes for the rest of the year.

title: HUSSEIN-ARAFAT SPLIT: NEITHER WINS
description: In the split between King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, there appear to be two major political losers: the King and Mr. Arafat.

title: HELMS, IN CHILE, DENOUNCES U.S. ENVOY
description: Senator Jesse Helms, ending a weeklong visit to Chile, has strongly criticized the United States Ambassador for attending the funeral of a young man who was fatally burned during anti-Government protests.

title: End Nuclear Wastes By Shutting Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: Hannah A. Achtenberg Wed to Dr. Mark Kinn
description: Hannah Alexandra Achtenberg, an artist and executive director of the League Center, a nonprofit agency in Brooklyn involved in providing diagnostic, educational and treatment programs for autistic, emotionally disturbed and mentally handicapped children and adults, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Henry Kinn, an internist in New York and an attending physician at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: SPANIARD WINS STAGE
description: Angel-Jose Sarrapio of Spain won today's 10th stage of the Tour de France, with Jorgen Pedersen of Denmark retaining the overall lead.

title: Refugee From Bronx Shot in Florida Holdup
description: A 31-year-old convenience store clerk who said he left the Bronx because he was tired of crime was shot by a holdup man Friday, one month after moving here.

title: Polynice Dropped
description: Olden Polynice, the University of Virginia's leading scorer last season, has lost his athletic scholarship and been dropped from the school's basketball team following his plea of no contest to a shoplifting charge.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 14, 1986
description: The Economy

title: DYKSTRA SPARKS SWEEP BY METS
description: The Mets wiped out the Atlanta Braves for the fourth straight time yesterday and made a rousing exit for the All-Star break with a 2-0 victory, a .702 record of success and a 13-game lead.

title: Unsettling Boulder Rumors
description: As long as the Upper Upper West Side keeps its development potential and its eclectic mix of residents, local rumors will spread quickly and have an offbeat ring to them.

title: Naomi Davis Is the Bride Of Joshua Ephraim Caplan
description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday Naomi Davis and Joshua Ephraim Caplan were married by Rabbi Manfred Fulda. The couple's parents are Rabbi and Mrs. Isaac A. Davis of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Caplan of Ocean, N.J.

title: A New Forest for Pooh?
description: Chapter III - In Which Pooh Finds a Home With a Man Who Wants to Be a Senator, and We Learn What May Happen Next.

title: ANGELS TOP RED SOX, 12-3, WITH 17 HITS
description: Dick Schofield drove in three runs, Brian Downing hit a two-run homer and John Candelaria and Doug Corbett held Boston to six hits as the California Angels defeated the Red Sox by 12-3 today.

title: ON STAGE IN SENATE, WHERE TV SEES ALL
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader and possible Republican Presidential contender, is considered an early winner. So far, his image on Senate television has been one of skillful leadership, many political experts say.

title: Allen L. Weingarten Weds Jo-Ann Fox
description: Jo-Ann Weil Fox, a daughter of Mrs. William Fox Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Fox, was married yesterday to Allen L. Weingarten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Weingarten of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: WAGNER SAYS MERIT PAY PLAN WILL HELP KEEP BEST TEACHERS
description: The new president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday that a merit pay policy for teachers should be introduced in the city's schools to help keep the best teachers from leaving the system.

title: JANUARY TAKES SENIORS
description: Don January tapped in a 1-foot par putt on the first playoff hole today to defeat Jim Ferree and capture the Greenbrier-American Express senior tournament for the second straight year.

title: Fires Blacken Stretches Of Alaska Wilderness
description: Fires have blackened 431,751 acres of forest and grassland in Alaska by Saturday, including 346,500 acres of Federally managed land, despite the efforts of 1,125 firefighters.

title: BREAKING LANGUAGE BARRIERS
description: SANDRA HENG, 2 years old, was at Beth Israel Medical Center for a checkup. Ang Boui Khov, in her 31st week of pregnancy, was getting prenatal attention. Chep Rang had just delivered her ninth child.

title: Arizona Car Crash Kills 7
description: Seven people died early today when the car they were in ran off a highway near here and burst into flame, officials said.

title: EDBERG BEATS STADLER IN SWISS FINAL
description: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden defeated Roland Stadler of Switzerland today, 7-5, 4-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-2 in a 3-hour-25-minute final of the Swiss Open tennis tournament In what was far from a lopsided encounter, the 20-year-old Swede, ranked sixth in the world, was hard-pressed to solve the unorthodox style of Stadler, an unseeded left-hander.

title: MANSELL IS WINNTER, LEADS IN TITLE RACE
description: Nigel Mansell won the British Grand Prix today and took over the lead in the world drivers' championship standing.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOT DEFENDS OBSTRUCTION OF CROSSINGS
description: The weeklong closing of crossing points into the Turkish Cypriot state was intended as ''a slap in the face of the Greek Cypriot leadership,'' said Rauf Denktash, President of the internationally unrecognized republic.

title: SIX INJURED ON L.I., ONE CRITICALLY, AS LIGHTNING HITS CROWD IN PARK
description: Six people were injured, one critically, when they were struck by lightning in a Long Island park during a brief thunderstorm last night while waiting for a fireworks display to celebrate the 93d birthday of the Village of Rockville Centre, the Nassau County Police reported.

title: Pulling the Plug
description: How do you know when high school football in your area has gone truly big time? Why, when the state athletic association starts imposing TV blackout rules.

title: Shoreham Shuffle, Same Old Game
description: New York's politically acute Governor and Legislature have now combined to create a state agency that could buy the Long Island Lighting Company and block the opening of its Shoreham nuclear plant. Governor Cuomo and legislators of both parties can claim to have a strategy for saving Long Island from the risks of nuclear power without further burdening consumers' utility bills.

title: Canadian First In Jumping Event
description: Gail Greenough has become the first woman and the first Canadian to win the world show jumping championship.

title: BIG OIL PUSHES GAS, GROCERIES
description: The nation's major oil companies are finally taking the plunge: opening high-volume convenience stores that sell foodstuffs and paper products along with gasoline.

title: Palmer to Pass Up The British Open
description: Arnold Palmer, a two-time British Open champion, said today he will not play in the British Open this week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hear all kinds of comments about tax reform, but it all boils down to the question of 'how this is going to affect me.'

title: LONG ISLAND COULD HAVE 2 NEW COUNTY LEADERS
description: By early next year, Long Island could have two new county executives.

title: INVESTORS BLOCK LLOYDS IN ITS BID FOR STANDARD
description: The Lloyds Bank P.L.C.'s bid to become Britain's largest bank, with a $1.95 billion takeover of Standard Chartered P.L.C., failed Saturday, after last-minute share purchases were made by East Asian and Australian investors.

title: DESPITE PROGRAM, STATE PRODUCES MORE MILK
description: Despite a new Federal program intended to cut dairy surpluses, New York farms produced more milk in May than in any month since record keeping started in 1930, according to a report this week from the State Crop Reporting Service here.

title: While We're Feeling Good About Immigrants ...
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press article on Friday about a mountain climbing program sponsored by an Oregon school misstated plans for the future of the program. Officials of the Oregon Episcopal School say they will defer decisions on the annual outing on Mount Hood until they get the findings of an independent committee that is investigating the deaths of seven students and two faculty members on an expedition in May.

title: Earlier Vesting for Public-Employee Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: While We're Feeling Good About Immigrants ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; For the Wary, Utility Stocks
description: ELECTRIC utility stocks are gaining favor with investors, underscoring a mood of caution in the equity market. The Dow Jones utility average finished Friday at a record 204.05. It climbed 3.29 points in a week that saw other market barometers tumbling, as blue chips and speculative issues alike encountered selling pressure.

title: Ricky Helen Hopfer Weds Robert Gerald Greenly
description: The marriage of Ricky Helen Hopfer, a registered occupational therapist of the Harvard Community Health Plan in Boston, to Robert Gerald Greenly, a senior associate of McBer & Company, a human resource management consulting company in Boston, took place yesterday in Norwich, Conn. Rabbi Carl Astor performed the ceremony at the Norwich Inn.

title: DIOXIN OF '76 ITALIAN ACCIDENT REPORTED DESTROYED
description: Ten years after a chemical plant accident sent a white cloud of dioxin-contaminated steam and gas into the atmosphere over Seveso, Italy, public health officials in Switzerland say they have finally completed disposing of the last of the contaminated wastes.

title: COMPUTERS' IMPACT GROWING IN INDIA
description: Slowly but perceptibly, computers are insinuating themselves into Indian life as a result of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's 19-month-old policies encouraging their use and production. The effects could be far-reaching and profound.

title: A PAINTING CREATED TO BE EXPERIENCED AS ARCHITECTURE
description: The mural on the huge gray wall of 22 Reade Street is not the first one that Francois Morellet, the 60-year-old French conceptual artist, has painted on the side of a building. It may, however, be the most economical.

title: ITT AND FRENCH TIE ASSESSED
description: The sale by the ITT Corporation of a major interest in its telecommunications operations to the French state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite would prompt a major reshuffling of the European telecommunications industry, and would pose possible problems for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's ambitious plans to crack that market.

title: CONGRESS FACING CHOICES ON BUDGET ON RETURN TODAY
description: Congress returns from recess on Monday to Capitol Hill to confront politically difficult choices over budget priorities.

title: PARENTS OF DEAD CHILDREN FREED AFTER ARRAIGNMENT
description: The parents of four children killed Friday in a fire at a Brooklyn welfare hotel were released on their own recognizance last night after arraignment on criminal charges of endangering the children by leaving them alone in a room.

title: MUSIC: HAYDN RE-CREATED
description: The Pepsico ''Summerfare'' 's monthlong survey of Haydn seems as much a defense as a celebration. Haydn, let it be quickly said, has few enemies, but all of us today wrestle with the curious puzzle surrounding him - why a titanic reputation among his contemporaries seems now downgraded to mere lovability.

title: THE SHEARSON CASE OPENS NEW GROUND
description: The indictment of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. recently on charges of laundering at least $1.2 million raises legal questions with ominous implications for the financial industry, some attorneys say.

title: Banker Pleads Guilty
description: The former managing director of the Overseas Trust Bank pleaded guilty Friday to charges of conspiring to defraud the bank of $66 million, court officials said. They said that Patrick Chang Chen-tsong, 35 years old, who will be sentenced Monday, had agreed to become a witness for the prosecution against four former colleagues, including the bank's one-time chairman, Huang Tiong Chan, who is in custody in the United States.

title: Hoes in Hand, People to the Rescue
description: When Pierre L'Enfant laid out Washington, crisscrossing a grid pattern with diagonal thoroughfares and dotting it with circles, he made a city of little parks, more than 600 of them at the various intersections.

title: BUDD IS BANNED IN WAKE OF PROTEST
description: Faced with the prospect of a boycott by five or more African countries protesting the British Government's stand on South Africa, the organizers of the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh announced today that they were barring two South African-born athletes who were to have competed for Britain.

title: SEASON TO FISH OR RUN FOR GOVERNOR
description: There are two activities in which large numbers of Alaskans are engaging this summer: fishing for salmon and running for Governor.

title: MEXICANS COUNT VOTES AMID ACCUSATIONS OF FRAUD IN STATE ELECTION
description: As tensions rose in the streets here tonight, the Chihuahua State Election Commission met to announce the results of voting a week ago in hotly disputed statewide elections.

title: ANOTHER STRONG QUAKE JOLTS CALIFORNIA
description: Michele Maldonado, a hair stylist in Oceanside, was soundly sleeping in her water bed this morning when an earthquake centered less than 30 miles off the coast shook the town. It was enough, she said, to curl your hair.

title: WHITE SUPREMACISTS MEET IN QUEST FOR HOMELAND
description: A gathering of Nazi sympathizers, white separatists, anti-Semites and Ku Klux Klan members convened the Aryan Nations World Congress here this weekend. They called for a white, male-dominated homeland in the Northwest.

title: O'Hara, Christie Win
description: J. P. O'Hara and Neil Christie of Winged Foot Golf Club, which was host of the event, defeated Randy Sonnier and Bob McKenna of Houston, 2 and 1, this morning in the 18-hole final to win the 50th annual Anderson Memorial Tournament. It was their third victory in the Anderson over the last 12 years. O'Hara and Christie last won the title in 1984.

title: BLYLEVEN OF TWINS STYMIES YANKEES ON 3-HITTER, 5-0
description: A shutout? How could anyone expect Bert Blyleven to pitch a shutout against the Yankees today?

title: GIANTS ROUT PIRATES TO GAIN FIRST PLACE
description: Harry Spilman, a reserve first baseman, drove in four runs with a double and a three-run homer and Mike LaCoss allowed five hits in seven innings today, leading the San Francisco Giants to an 11-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: ROCK: THE ART OF NOISE
description: DIGITAL sampling - the computer technology that allows musicians to store, recall and manipulate virtually any sound - pervades the output of the Art of Noise, a British band that performed Friday night at the Ritz.

title: I.M.C. Buyout Leader Familiar With Trouble
description: Charles P. Gallagher, the former chief executive and president of the Susquehanna Corporation, is no stranger to situations in need of a turnaround.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS AND ITS UNIONS
description: Labor unions at People Express Inc. played a significant role in influencing the low-cost carrier to take the offer of United Airlines over that of Texas Air, advisers close to the negotiations said.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS PANELS ARE FAULTED IN SURVEY
description: State human rights commissions, the first line of enforcement against discrimination in many states, have large backlogs and lack the staff or the skill to do their jobs properly, according to a survey of the agencies in New York and six other states.

title: ROCHESTER COPES WITH THE GREAT WATER ALERT
description: To boil, to buy or to bottle?

title: EAST SIDE RAPES TIED TO ONE MAN
description: The police said yesterday that they believed one man was responsible for a series of rapes and burglaries that occurred on the Upper East Side of Manhattan in the last six weeks.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOME: A Short History of an Idea. By Witold Rybczynski. Illustrated. 256 pages. Viking. $16.95. IN the opening chapter, ''Nostalgia,'' of this delightful, intelligent book about the idea of the home in Western culture, Witold Rybczynski dilates on the subject of Ralph Lauren as a ''total fashion designer'' and ''an orchestrator of images.'' By and by he arrives at an amusing description of the four exhibition rooms at Bloomingdale's Ralph Lauren Home Furnishings boutique, which were designated ''Log Cabin,'' ''Thoroughbred,'' ''New England'' and ''Jamaica.'' His point, almost incidentally, is that these rooms are completely innocent of clock radios, electric hair dryers or video games. ''The mechanical paraphernalia of contemporary living has been put away, and replaced by brass-cornered gun boxes, silver bedside water carafes, and leather-bound books.''

title: SYRIAN PATROLS GIVE SENSE OF CALM TO WEST BEIRUT
description: Just over a week after Syrian soldiers were deployed in Moslem West Beirut, the capital has been enjoying a measure of law and order absent in the last two and a half years.

title: Westinghouse Credit Goes to Rumrill-Hoyt
description: The Westinghouse Credit Corporation is taking its corporate advertising account to Rumrill-Hoyt/New York, one of the Saatchi & Saatchi agencies.

title: ISRAEL'S ATTORNEY GENERAL PRESSES CABINET TO INVESTIGATE '84 KILLINGS
description: Israel's Attorney General, Yosef Harish, urged the Cabinet today to establish a special commission of inquiry to investigate the Shin Beth domestic security scandal before the Israeli Supreme Court orders a formal police investigation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 14, 1986
description: International South Africa took new measures against classroom protest, saying students who do not enroll for classes at the beginning of a new school term Monday will be barred from classes for the rest of the year. The measures were announced as the authorities prepared for possible mass protest from black labor unions on Monday, when the nation's biggest labor federation has called for strikes to protest the Government's emergency decree. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: 3-PART CHAPLIN SERIES ON 'AMERICAN MASTERS'
description: THE three-part ''Unknown Chaplin'' was produced by Kevin Brownlow and David Gill for Britain's Thames Television in 1982. It was originally scheduled to be shown here on public television a year ago but programming logistics interfered. The series, at last, will begin this evening at 9 on Channel 13 as part of the station's ''American Masters'' series. Patience will indeed be rewarded.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 14, 1986:

title: ZOELLER FIRES 64 TO WIN BY 2
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, who began the day five shots off the pace, shot a seven-under-par 64 today to leap past a pack of early leaders and win the $500,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic by two strokes.

title: Outdoors; Rituals of Grilling
description: THE reasons for the blossoming of outdoor cookery in summer have little to do with the quality of the food so prepared. With few exceptions, a better job could be done indoors.

title: Holyfield Spends Night in Hospital
description: Evander Holyfield, who outpunched Dwight Muhammad Qawi to win the World Boxing Association junior-heavyweight championship Saturday, spent Saturday night in a hospital bed.

title: Resuscitation Must Be a Medical Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Manhattan Teams Clashing In Big Apple Knockout Final
description: Teams headed by Bob Blanchard and John Rengstorff, both of Manhattan, clashed in the final of the Big Apple Regional Knockout Team Championship yesterday afternoon.

title: FLORIDA BURDEN: THE AGING RETIRED
description: Gertrude Schmidt has no complaints. ''Life has been good to me,'' she says.

title: Working Profile: Barber B. Conable Jr.; Confidence on Top of the World Bank
description: When Barber B. Conable Jr. first took over as president of the World Bank and saw its presidential office, he was aghast. Its confines, it seemed, could hold the Oval Office and, indeed, the entire West Wing of the White House - with enough room to spare for a Redskins scrimmage.

title:
WASHINGTON WATCH;
Fannie Mae Fights the I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service and the Federal National Mortgage Association are locked in a struggle over taxes. The dispute, one of the biggest tax cases the I.R.S. has pursued, stems from the mortgage finance agency's treatment of losses.

title: Group Says the Police Beat Detained Youths
description: The South African security police have beaten young people who have been detained under the Government's emergency decree, according to officials of the human rights group Amnesty International.

title: Walter W. Hitesman, Reader's Digest Chief
description: Walter W. Hitesman, former president of Reader's Digest, died Saturday at his home in Edgartown, Mass. He was 67 years old. Mr. Hitesman was appointed president and chief operating officer of the magazine in 1973.

title: Oil and Baseball Don't Always Mix
description: Harrell Edmonds Chiles, the 76-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Western Company of North America, has decided that baseball and oil no longer mix.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Wasn't there an All-Star Game in the 1950's in which the winning pitcher never made a pitch?

title: Breaking The Ice
description: THE thing about the Goodwill Games is that they got the weather backward. They ran the men's marathon last Sunday when the temperature was in the 80's, and they held the water polo finale outdoors last night when the temperature was in the 50's.

title:
Washington Watch;
Intelsat Proves A Tough Foe
description: REAGAN Administration officials involved in selling other countries on the virtues of competition are trying to figure out why they are losing in their efforts to promote competition with Intelsat, the nonprofit consortium of 110 nations that operates the only worldwide satellite communications network.

title: 'Boat People' Flow To Hong Kong Surges
description: More than four times the number of so-called boat people arrived in Hong Kong in June than in the corresponding month last year, according to refugee officials in the British colony.

title: MAN STABBED AFTER L.I. CRASH
description: A Freeport man was stabbed to death here early today after he and three companions got into an argument with two men over a traffic accident, the Nassau County police said. They said a suspect has been arrested.

title: Jersey Seeks More AIDS Data
description: New Jersey health officials are seeking an AIDS reporting system that would allow them to collect detailed information about victims, including names, addresses and telephone numbers, a spokesman said today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Monday None Tuesday Industrial ProductionJune Retail SalesJune Wednesday Inventory-Sales RatioMay Capacity UtilizationJune Thursday Housing StartsJune Friday None

title: MOST N.F.L. CAMPS OPEN THIS WEEK
description: More than 93 rookies and free agents are expected in Pleasantville, N.Y., Wednesday when the Giants open their training camp at Pace University. The veterans are scheduled to report July 21.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
A LIVELY DEBATE
description: The debate as to whether baseballs are livelier this year will continue as long as home runs keep flying out of major league parks, which, through the first half of the season, they were doing in greater number than ever before. At the current pace, more than 3,800 homers will be hit in 1986, easily breaking the record of 3,644, set in 1977. Home runs are up 15.4 percent in just one year, and, in number per game, there have been more this season (0.91 per team) than in any other since 1962 (0.93).

title: CULTURAL FOUNDATION IS MONEY MANAGER FOR ART
description: When Twyla Tharp first applied for a dance grant in the 1960's, she was neither accustomed to the business of raising money nor enthusiastic about it. As the story goes, her application said: ''I write dance, not grants. Please send money.'' Miss Tharp got her grant.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Tuesday about the slaying of two people aboard a Staten Island ferryboat misstated the circumstances under which the man accused of the slayings, Juan J. Gonzalez, emigrated from Cuba to the United States in 1977. He was not part of the boatlift of refugees from Mariel, Cuba, which took place in 1980.

title: CONFIDENT METS WEAR THEIR OWN STYLE OF WINNING
description: EVERY afternoon when the Mets are at home, Roger McDowell appears on the Long Island Rail Road platform at Port Washington and takes the 2:36 train to work.

title: People
description: * Stephen E. Moynahan has been named a senior vice president of McCann-Erickson, New York.

title: A ROCK MANAGER'S DAY: STUDY OF LIFE ON THE RUN
description: For Danny Goldberg, the day starts at a run and accelerates.

title: MEXICO'S DEBT LINE MAY FIRM
description: A month after Mexico's powerful finance minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, was replaced, unity has returned to the inner circle of Government economic policy makers and there seems to be little possibility that Mexico will pursue an aggressive, unilateral course involving suspension of payments on its foreign debt.

title: FOREIGN ECONOMIES CURB U.S.
description: In cutting its discount rate last week, the Federal Reserve Board attempted to reawaken an economy that has proven markedly weaker than the Fed, the Reagan Administration and most economists assumed, just a few months ago, that it would be.

title: Kampelman in Review
description: Max M. Kampelman, the chief American arms control negotiator in Geneva, has had a long and prominent career as a lawyer, teacher, politician and Government official, but many Washingtonians still remember him best as as early moderator of the long-running public television program, ''Washington Week in Review.''

title: PAKISTANI VISITS U.S. THIS WEEK AMID REPORTS OF SURGE IN OPIUM
description: A sharp increase in the illegal crop of opium poppies in Pakistan this year will be a major topic of discussion during Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo's visit with President Reagan and other officials in Washington this week, according to Pakistani officials.

title: 40 LEGISLATURES ACT TO READJUST LIABILITY RULES
description: To reduce widespread difficulties in the liability insurance market, legislatures in more than 40 states passed a variety of new laws before adjourning for the summer.

title: HISTORIC ROOSEVELT I. BUILDING FACES DEMOLITION AS A HAZARD
description: Lying in ruins - a fire-scarred, gray granite ghost of itself on Roosevelt Island - is the first of two monumental works by the architect James Renwick Jr. that were begun in the summer of 1858. The second was St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: FOOD SHORTAGES IN NICARAGUA TAKE A SERIOUS TURN
description: Arnoldo Rivera, 60 years old, is on an enforced diet of avocados, tomatoes and soup with rice, and he doesn't like it.

title: U.S. GROUP CHECKS SOVIET ATOM SITE
description: In this remote region of Central Asia, usually off limits to foreigners, a team of Western scientists has set up an array of sensitive instruments to monitor the main underground site where the Soviet Union explodes its nuclear weapons.

title: WALL ST. LOOKS OVER SHOULDER
description: Executives at Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, feared that the worst had been confirmed: An electronics expert doing a sweep of Bear, Stearns's offices found what looked like an eavesdropping device in the corporate finance department.

title: CITY STORES' JUNE GAINS BEST OF YEAR
description: New York City retail sales in June registered their best gain of 1986, rising 6.8 percent over the year before, a monthly spot-check found. The June sales performance exceeded the 6.6 percent increase in March, which had been the year's best rise.

title: The U.N. Today: July 14, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: TI Group Chief Comes From Wilkinson Sword
description: Christopher Lewinton, former director and executive vice president of Allegheny International, has joined TI Group P.L.C. in the newly created post of chief executive and deputy chairman.

title: LOWER MANHATTAN GETS A MURAL FROM FRANCE
description: Three stark slashes across a downtown wall constitute the latest gift from the Republic of France to the people of New York.

title: DOLLAR STRONG AFTER RATE CUT
description: Although it is likely to be months before economists and the financial markets can gauge the real impact of last week's cut in the discount rate, the initial effects appear to be rather less than the advocates of monetary ease had hoped and somewhat better than the naysayers had feared.

title: A Guatemalan Dies, And What It Means
description: On Thursday evening, June 26, at about 6:30 P.M., on a visit to Guatemala, I witnessed a crime: two men in civilian clothes approached a young man on the street and fired five bullets into him. Nothing was stolen and the murderers left the scene quickly, but calmly. This crime took place in the main business district of the capital, Guatemala City.

title: Sharon Grossman Wed To Dr. Keith D. Meyer
description: Sharon Sue Grossman, a registered nurse, and Dr. Keith Douglas Meyer, a physician, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Paul Steinberg, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: CANADA IS PREPARED TO ADOPT SANCTIONS ALONE, LEADER SAYS
description: Canada is ready to act alone in imposing economic sanctions on South Africa if other members of the Commonwealth fail to reach agreement, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today after talking with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.

title: Behind the Mask
description: As he lay on the ground near home plate that warm afternoon at Fenway Park two months ago, the last thing on Don Slaught's mind was that he might become a pioneer in the continued evolution of the batting helmet. But since returning to the Texas Rangers' lineup on July 4, Slaught has taken on a resemblance to a hockey goalie whenever he goes up to bat, wearing a helmet with an attached Plexiglas shield covering the bottom part of his face. It's important protection, really, since his left cheekbone was virtually crushed when he was hit by a pitch thrown by Oil Can Boyd on May 17.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page last Monday misstated the date for a slide-lecture on the Statue of Liberty by the photographer Peter B. Kaplan. It will be Wednesday at the Hirshhorn Museum.

title: Article 927786 -- No Title
description: A Franciscan friar who took a vow of poverty died leaving $870,000 in worldly goods, including a cash-stocked oceanfront home in Palm Beach, court records show.

title: Linden Nadler, Freelance Writer, Wed
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York yesterday Linden Nadler, a freelance writer, was married to Gene Stromberg, an assistant professor of education at the Azrieli Institute of Yeshiva University. Rabbi Moshe Morduchowitz performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET UNION SWEEPS FOUR GOLD MEDALS
description: Sergei Gurylev of the Soviet Union edged Dan Watson of the United States for the gold medal in platform diving and the Soviet water polo team beat the United States for the championship today at the Goodwill Games.

title: Ever More Lawyers
description: The law business, which seems to prosper in Washington whether the Government is expanding or contracting, stepped up its steady growth pattern last year. According to the annual survey by Legal Times, a tabloid monthly covering the profession, the capital's 25 largest law firms increased in size by 9.9 percent in 1985, up from 7 percent the year before and the largest increase since President Reagan took office in 1981.

title: CORDERO RETURNS WITH 2 VICTORIES
description: Angel Cordero Jr., riding for the first time since March 8, won with both of his mounts at Belmont Park yesterday, including Gulch in the Tremont Stakes for 2-year-olds.

title: Postal Union Group Votes to Censure Chief
description: Representatives of postal workers in the Northeast have voted to censure their union's national president for his support of the teamsters' president Jackie Presser, who is under indictment, union officials said.

title: Women in the Statehouse
description: More women will be elected to state office and state legislatures in November than ever before, according to the best current information, but there is some doubt whether this trend will extend to the Senate and House. With the 1986 primary elections about half through, the National Women's Political Caucus reports that 10 women seeking re-election as Governors and other statewide offices and 42 women seeking such posts are assured of being on the ballot this fall, more than ever before at this stage of the game.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, a financial services company, has elected Gayle D. Morris senior vice president.

title: N.F.L. PLANS TO CALL FINAL WITNESSES
description: After two months of testimony, the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League is approaching the final stages. The trial resumes in Federal District Court today for what could be the final week of testimony.

title: FORMED POLISH RIGHTS GROUP
description: Edward Lipinski, an economist who quit the Communist Party in 1975 and helped found a workers' rights committee, died today at a Government hospital, friends said. He was 97 years old.

title: Grace & Rothschild Gets Whittle Account
description: Grace & Rothschild, a baby agency begotten by Roy Grace and Diane Rothschild out of Doyle Dane Bernbach, has another new account: Whittle Communications, formerly the 13-30 Corporation, for which the agency will do a corporate ad campaign.

title: Negotiations Break Off In Philadelphia Strike
description: Contract talks recessed indefinitely tonight between the city and the union for its 12,885 striking blue-collar workers.

title: Sports Today
description: GOLF U.S. WOMEN'S OPEN, NCR Golf Club, Kettering, Ohio, (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M.) GOODWILL GAMES Wrestling, cycling, men's gymnastics, men's volleyball, team handball, yachting and tennis at Moscow.

title: POLITICS IN ULSTER TURN A SPOTLIGHT ON THE POLICE
description: In the heat of still another night of sporadic confrontation and violence, the police force of Northern Ireland quietly indicated Saturday at midnight just how beleagured it has become in the treacherous politics of a divided Ireland.

title: 'FLAMENCE AT 5:15' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''FLAMENCO AT 5:15,'' being broadcast on Channel 13 tonight at 11:30, is ostensibly about learning a craft or profession. At 5:15 on winter afternoons, young students from the National Ballet School of Canada assemble in a high-ceilinged salon of a studio to learn flamenco dancing. The students are there to learn about the heel and hand work of flamenco, an ancient dance form that originated with gypsies in southern Spain.

title: ALEC McCOWEN STARS AS RUDYARD KIPLING
description: FOR those who recall - or, more likely, dimly recall -the poetry and stories of Rudyard Kipling, his name has come to suggest more an attitude than a man. His work represented, in a way, the last literary outpost of the British Empire. Thanks to Alec McCowen, who portrays the writer in ''Kipling'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, one may actually cloak the literary figure in the flesh and bones of a person.

title: BALLET: PARISIANS OFFER DEBUTS IN A MIXED BILL
description: SO far so good. That may be the understatement of the dance season as far as the Paris Opera Ballet is concerned. A company unknown to New York has suddenly turned out to be the sensation of the year.

title: Roots and Jewish Humor
description: Alan King has been provoking laughter for 45 years. But he won over his audience at the Jewish Museum last week with thoughtful remarks as well as comic ones.

title: Tanker Is Reported Hit By Iraqi Jets
description: Iraqi jet fighters crippled a tanker and an Iranian tugboat in the northeastern Persian Gulf in an effort to tighten a blockade on Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal, gulf-based marine salvage executives said today.

title: Why I Don't Like The Senate Tax Bill
description: There was applause on the Senate floor when the tax bill passed, 97-3. So what, you may wonder, could possibly be wrong with it?

title: L. T., Ditka And Jockeys
description: THE GIANTS open their training camp Wednesday; the Jets open next week. And not a moment too soon.

title: 18 Hurt in Turbulence On Miami-Bound Jet
description: An Eastern Airlines jet bound for Miami from New York struck a pocket of violent turbulence today, injuring at least 18 people, two seriously, as they were tossed about the cabin, officials said.

title: N.C.A.A. PENALIZES BRADLEY BASKETBALL
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today banned Bradley University's basketball team from post-season play and barred its coaches from off-campus recruiting next season, citing improper recruiting and unethical conduct by Dick Versace, the head coach.

title: WASHINGTON BACKS U.S. ENVOY ON CHILE FUNERAL
description: The White House and State Department defended the American Ambassador to Chile today against charges by Senator Jesse Helms that he acted improperly in attending the funeral of the young man who was fatally burned during anti-Government demonstrations last week.

title: 'Tar-Free' Cigarettes
description: Ultralow-yield cigarettes, marketed by the manufacturers as essentially ''tar-free'', with less than on milligram of tar and one-tenth of a milligarm of nicotine per cigarette, will significantly reduce a smoker's exposure to the toxic chemicals in tobacco smoke, while low-yield cigarettes, with 5 milligarms of tar and up to seven-tenths of a milligram of nicotine per cigarette, will not, according to reseachers at the San Francisco General Hospital Medical Center. The ultralow-yield cigarettes, though, are far from tar-free, according to the authors.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: Upon the recent death of Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, the Queens Democrat, Representative Bill Chappell Jr. succeeded to the chairmanship of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense. That chairmanship historically has acted as a magnet for political funds donated by military contractors, and it appears that Mr. Chappell, a Florida Democrat, will continue that custom.

title: Advertising; Author Offers Details Of McDonald's Switch
description: There was great lamentation in adland when McDonald's deserted Needham, Harper & Steers in the late 1970's and took its huge national advertising account to the Leo Burnett Company.

title: 3 Are Indicted In Man's Torture
description: Three people were indicted yesterday on assault and sex abuse charges, accused of forcing a man to strip naked, hitting him with a whip and sexually torturing him with a hair curling iron while demanding payment of a $35 debt, the authorities said.

title: The Coach's Wife Battles Playboy
description: When her husband was chosen several years ago as the coach of Playboy's annual all-America basketball team, Linnea Smith, by her own recollection, ''gave it very little thought.''
