Now, owing to what she describes as her increased awareness of the magazine's content and the effects of both recreational drug-taking and distorted sexual values, Dr. Smith, wife of North Carolina's Dean Smith, is campaigning for an end of all sports associations with Playboy, to include all interviews as well as the regular picture-taking of top college basketball and football stars. Already, she's had some modest success.

title: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. AGREES TO DISCUSS ARMS POLICY SHIFT
description: The United States has agreed to a Soviet proposal that the two sides meet in Geneva July 22 to discuss President Reagan's decision to repudiate the strategic arms treaty of 1979, Administration officials said today.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed in June.

title: Stump Is Jumping
description: Stump Mitchell, whose contract talks with the St. Louis Cardinals were stalled, says he is jumping to the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football League. ''I hate to leave St. Louis,'' said the running back, adding that he was expecting to fly to Phoenix yesterday to sign a $1.5 million, three-year contract with the Outlaws.

title: SMITH, A O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4,748,000 and $7,628,000 for quarter and 6 months.

title: Timber Talks Resume; 30 People Are Arrested
description: Thirty-one people were arrested today on charges they tried to block the entrance to a Weyerhaeuser Company plant to keep management personnel from going to work.

title: DOW PLUMMETS 27.98, TO BELOW 1,800 LEVEL
description: With declining corporate profits and the weak economy remaining foremost on Wall Street's list of concerns, stock prices dropped sharply yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted through the 1,800 level to its lowest close since late May.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 28, 1986.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $438,000 and $490,000 for latest quarter and year, respectively; and for the year-ago quarter and year, $277,000 and $584,000, respectively. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $250,000 and a gain of $296,000 on pension termination, both for the quarter and year.

title: Market Place; Futures Index Tells Future
description: YESTERDAY'S drop of 27.98 points in the Dow Jones industrial average, to 1,793.45, came as no surprise to many analysts. The reason: Last Friday's close of the September Standard & Poor's 500-index futures had signaled there would be a sharp selloff in the market Monday morning.

title: 'THE SEVESO HERITAGE,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: ''THE SEVESO HERITAGE,'' airing tonight at 11 on Channel 13 as part of WNET's ''Intercom'' series, is the kind of polemical documentary that makes telling points in spite of itself. Written, directed and reported by the Danish reporter Jorgen Flindt Pedersen, the program presents an unabashedly one-sided view of the aftermath of the explosion 10 years ago at a chemical factory in Seveso, Italy, that sprayed the chemical dioxin over the landscape. It tells a tale of human anguish, purported corporate perfidy and political incompetence and betrayal. The absence of alternative viewpoints is so glaring that a viewer can accept the program for what it is, then ponder the messages it presents overtly and others that poke through between the scenes.

title: Business Schools Should Screen Applicants for Moral Fitness
description: To the Editor; Russell E. Palmer's ''Let's Be Bullish on Ethics'' (Op-Ed, June 20) is one of recent articles calling business schools to task for failing to inculcate a sense of ethics in the Masters of Business Administration they send off to lucrative positions in the corporate world. Clearly, the business world is peopled by a frightening number of individuals who, although they possess formidable analytical skills, are unable to distinguish between right and wrong. But should it be up to the business schools to shape the ethical behavior of their graduates, as Mr. Palmer suggests?

title: 25 Are Hurt in Bus Crash
description: A Trailways bus carrying 27 people overturned today when it struck a tractor-trailer that the police said was illegally crossing an interstate median.

title: MORGAN, J P & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net investment securities gains of $66.1 million for the quarter and $124.2 million for the 6 months. c-Includes net investment securities gains of $24.5 million for the quarter and $31.6 million for the 6 months. The latest results included foreign exchange trading income of $60.7 million for the quarter and $133.3 million for the 6 months, compared with the year-earlier periods of $45.6 million for the quarter and $68.6 million for the 6 months.

title: DUPOND ON DUPOND: A 'BEAST OF THE STAGE'
description: Early in his career, Patrick Dupond told an interviewer his goals were to become an etoile, or principal dancer, at the Paris Opera Ballet, to dance all the princes, to perform throughout the world and to dance the works of Balanchine. Now 27 years old, he is a leading if controversial dancer in the French company, has performed ''everywhere but Australia and India'' in roles that include all the famous ballet princes, and has danced his share of ballets by Balanchine. At 17, he was the first French dancer to win a gold medal at the International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
EXECUTIVES
description: * Bercor Inc., La Mirada, Calif., appointed Stuart R. Schaefer senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Randall Gate, who resigned as vice president, finance and treasurer.

title: Singer Spinoff
description: The Singer Company's board has approved the spinoff of its 135-year-old sewing business and its furniture operations.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SUPPORTS DISCRIMINATION BASED ON FEAR OF CONTAGION
description: The Justice Department today made public a legal brief urging the Supreme Court to rule that Federal law does not bar ''discrimination based on concern about contagiousness'' against victims of AIDS, tuberculosis and other diseases.

title: An Anti-Jewish Book Linked to Syrian Aide
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has instructed the United States Embassy in Syria to look into the authorship of a virulently anti-Jewish book that is said to have been written by the Syrian Defense Minister.

title: Lion Kills 2-Year-Old in Brazil
description: A 2-year-old girl has been killed by a lion who escaped from the warehouse of a construction company where it was kept as a guard, the police said today. The accident occurred Sunday in Goiania, in central Brazil, as the girl played in front of her apartment building, according to the police.

title: Tricks, Merits and Mr. Manion
description: Returning senators find Daniel Manion's judgeship nomination where they left it, in limbo. It didn't go away during the recess despite the hopes of senators like Alfonse D'Amato of New York. He wishes President Reagan would find a better candidate. He'll vote for confirmation, but ''with a heavy heart.''

title: MITTERRAND CHALLENGES KEY CHIRAC PLAN
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that he planned to try to block one of the conservative Cabinet's major programs, under which 65 state-owned businesses and banks would be sold to private buyers.

title: 'SLOW BURN,' ON CABLE
description: ON pay cable's Showtime service tonight at 11, ''Slow Burn'' does an interminable fizzle. The production is billed as ''A Matthew Chapman Film.'' Mr. Chapman, whose previous credits include an independent feature entitled ''Stranger's Kiss,'' is the writer and director. Joel Schumacher, director of last year's ''St. Elmo's Fire,'' is the executive producer.

title: JUDGE GRANTS MEDICAID TO STATE'S ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that illegal aliens living in New York State cannot be denied Medicaid assistance.

title: For Stroke Patients, The Freedom of Swimming
description: For those who are battling the aftereffects of a stroke, a swimming pool means far more than summer refreshment, more than wet hair and swan dives.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT SOUTH AFRICA;
AVOID IMPOSING SANCTIONS
description: Faced with the tragedies of racial polarization and spiraling violence in South Africa, Americans ache to do the right thing. Our overwhelming impulse is to help cleanse that troubled land of apartheid. Sanctions will not only frustrate that ambition but, in fact, will boomerang.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: G.M. REINS IN SOME CAPITAL PROJECTS
description: The General Motors Corporation, in recent decisions to shrink or suspend some future product programs, is pulling back from some forms of advanced technology and at the same time is preparing for an even more intensely competitive market at the end of the decade, industry analysts and officials said today.

title: Box-Office Knockout
description: Tim Witherspoon's defense of his World Boxing Association heavyweight crown against Frank Bruno of Britain, set for Saturday in London, is doing big business at the box office. The advance sale at Wembley Stadium reached 40,000 yesterday, surpassing the previous attendance record for a fight - 39,000 - between Muhammad Ali and Henry Cooper at Highbury, another London soccer stadium, in 1966.

title: ALL-STARS COMPARE NOTES ON LINEUPS
description: They stood on the dais and in the clubhouse and on the field, and each time they offered guarded compliments. The players who will face Dwight Gooden and Roger Clemens in the All-Star Game Tuesday evening in the Astrodome are simply trying to avoid feeling awed or inhibited. So they speak softly.

title: SENATE FIGHT ON JUDGE HEATS UP
description: The Senate battle over confirming Daniel A. Manion as a judge for the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago heated up today when Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said he might prevent another vote, which would allow Mr. Manion to be seated.

title: Scanlon Wins Newport Final
description: Unseeded Bill Scanlon, fighting his way back from nagging knee injuries, won his first tournament in four years today by upsetting second seeded Tim Wilkison, 7-5, 6-4, in the $100,000 Hall of Fame Championship.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $96.9 million for the quarter and $130.6 million for the 6 months.

title: Players of the Decade
description: These are the leading all-star vote-getters of the 1980's:

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings include 21 cents a share from the sale of real estate in 1985.

title: CAPITAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Police in India Fire on Rioters
description: The police opened fire today on mobs who were setting fire to shops on the sixth day of Hindu-Moslem rioting.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MINORITIES SEEK CABLE TV HEARING
description: Minority broadcasters, saying they fear economic disaster if their shows are not carried on cable television, have asked the Federal Communications Commission to call a special hearing before deciding which stations cable companies must carry.

title: Purina Mills President Sees a Bright Future
description: Little will change on the surface when BP Nutrition, a unit of the British Petroleum Company, takes over Purina Mills, America's largest feed business. The well-known checkerboard design will be retained, headquarters will remain in St. Louis, and William (Dub) Jones will be staying on as president.

title: Jackson's Options
description: Bo Jackson has already picked professional baseball, but he is negotiating an endorsement contract with Nike that could give him incentive to leave the summer sport for professional football, according to Advertising Age magazine.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Strike Vote Requested In Steel Talks
description: Facing a deadline for negotiations with the USX Corporation in two weeks, the United Steel Workers of America is asking members to take a strike authorization vote, a union spokesman said today.

title: No Room, No View
description: To the Editor:

title: American Savings' Mortgage Accord
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and the American Savings and Loan Association yesterday announced a $3 billion transaction under the Freddie Mac swap program, the largest deal ever negotiated by the mortgage corporation.

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Is Sentenced In Plot on Wife
description: A former air traffic controller who offered a man $5,000 to kill his estranged wife was sentenced today to 2 to 6 years in prison.

title: Absolutely Great Party
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
ISRAEL ATTACKS PRO-SYRIAN GROUPS WITH AIR STRIKE DEEP IN LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force planes attacked pro-Syrian Palestinian positions 15 miles from the capital today. Four people were reported killed and five wounded.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS DEFICIT IS RISING BEYOND ESTIMATES
description: Deficit projections for 1987 are rising beyond the ceiling set in the budget-balancing law, President Reagan's budget director, James C. Miller 3d, said today. He urged Congress to repair the law by giving him the power to make automatic spending cuts.

title: WTC INTERNATIONAL N V reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said the effects of the Teamsters strike, which was settled last month, contributed to the first quarter loss.

title: Calypso Is Preparing To Resume Voyage
description: After extensive refurbishing, the yacht Calypso is preparing to re-embark on her five-year around-the-world excursion to study the relationships between the world's water systems and its people.

title: U.S. WRESTLERS, SOVIET GYNMASTS EXCEL
description: American wrestlers won three gold medals at the Goodwill Games today, while Soviet gymnasts swept the medals in all-round competition, again shutting out a disappointing American team.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Up
description: Prices in the Treasury securities market rose modestly yesterday, largely as a result of technical trading by dealers who appear to have misgauged the response retail investors would have to last week's discount rate cut.

title: 'YELLOW RAIN' ASSERTIONS CONTESTED
description: EVIDENCE collected by British and Canadian scientists has largely refuted charges by the United States State Department that the Soviet Union and its ally Vietnam used chemical warfare agents in Southeast Asia, according to a report in the journal Science.

title: AIDS RECALLS EARLIER TIME
description: Sir Samuel Luke Fildes's painting ''The Doctor,'' which shows a devoted physician on a house call at the bed of a gravely ill child, has come to symbolize the compassion of the physician more than any other work of art.

title: A 'TEACHER' RECALLED AT RICKOVER RITE
description: As the solemn strains of taps flowed through the vaulted National Cathedral this afternoon. the Navy paid its final respects to Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the founder of the nuclear navy.

title: GEDDES TOPS LITTLE BY 2 IN OPEN PLAYOFF
description: Jane Geddes came from three shots back after seven holes to beat Sally Little by two shots in their 18-hole playoff today for the 41st United States Women's Open championship.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Statue of Liberty Stands Also as a Powerful Feminist Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Dykstra's Week
description: Lenny Dykstra, who tripled, hit a home run and threw out a runner at the plate in Sunday's 2-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves, was named the National League player of the week yesterday. Dykstra was 13 for 21, had five runs batted in and hit .619 for the week.

title: OVER THERE IN ST.-TROPEZ, THE LOOK'S FROM OVER HERE By MICHAEL GROSS
description: Taut and tanned half-naked bodies on the beaches are hardly the only fashion in this tiny French fishing village.

title: RAYMOND LOEWY, STREAMLINER OF CARS, PLANES AND PENS, DIES
description: Raymond Loewy, the ''father of streamlining'' who more than half a century ago founded the industrial design movement that radically changed the look of American life, died yesterday at his home in Monte Carlo. He was 92 years old and had been in failing health for several months.

title: A Class Act
description: To the Editor:

title: ALFRED E. SMITH
description: The Rev. Alfred E. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest and a grandson of Alfred E. Smith, the former New York Governor, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in the rectory of St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church, the Bronx. He was 54 years old.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $470,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Investment securities gains for the latest periods totaled $5,476,000 for the quarter and $6,301,000 for the 6 months, compared to the year-earlier periods of $216,000 for the quarter and $196,000 for the 6 months.

title: Telling Gestures in Chile
description: The blunderbuss assaults on American diplomats by Senator Jesse Helms are already legend. But the North Carolina Republican has outdone himself on his new foray into Chile. Unmoved by the fate of a young man apparently burned to death by Chilean soldiers during an anti-Government demonstration, Mr. Helms rages instead at the American Ambassador's gesture of compassion.

title: Wall St.'s Sharp Corrections
description: No less a market observer than Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, pronounced last week's stock market plunge nothing to worry about. It was ''just a correction'' in a bull market that has yet to see its top, Mr. Regan, the former head of Merrill Lynch, told reporters.

title: GOING BEYOND THE BASICS
description: VIRTUALLY everyone who has a personal computer is familiar with some form or another of the Beginner's All-Purpose Symbolic Instruction Code, better known by its acronym, Basic. Basic is the most popular programming language for microcomputers, and millions of people own one of its many versions.

title: Empire Acquisitions
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday it had approved acquisitions of two small, troubled California thrift units by Empire of America. The Buffalo-based mutual savings bank acquired Atlas Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, with assets of $76 million, and Golden Pacific Savings and Loan of Windsor, with assets of $42.8 million.

title: MEXICO'S RULING PARTY WINS BY 2-1 IN DISPUTED STATE VOTE
description: Mexico's ruling party won Chihuahua state elections by a margin of almost 2 to 1 over its conservative challenger, according to the official vote count completed today by the State Election Commission.

title: On Casey's Phones
description: What are those special phones on officials' desks connected to? Where, especially, does the red phone ring?

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 21
description: The company said the net income for the second quarter of 1986 and 1985 was reduced by approximately 7 cents a share and 8 cents a share, respectively, because Roadway Package Systems Inc., the company's small shipment carrier, commenced operations March 1985.

title: WOMAN, 67, AND BLIND WOMAN ARE RAPE VICTIMS
description: An 18-year-old delivery boy was arrested yesterday and charged with beating, raping and robbing a 67-year-old Brooklyn woman in her Borough Park apartment where he also attempted to drown her by pushing her face into a toilet, the police said.

title: 1 Billion of City Notes Offered to Yield 4.35%
description: New York City yesterday offered a total of $1 billion in tax revenue anticipation notes and revenue anticipation notes preliminarily priced at 100.573, to yield 4.35 percent.

title: TOWN WAITS FOR ITS CARRIER TO COME IN
description: Officials and civic leaders in this Navy town are confused but resolute as they await the arrival in mid-1987 of the carrier Nimitz. Until recently the plan was to berth her at the Bremerton Navy Shipyard until a permanent base could be prepared at Everett, Wash., across Puget Sound.

title: KLLM TRANSPORT reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
South Korea Is Urged To Release 2 Prisoners
description: Three human rights organizations asked the South Korean Government yesterday to release two opposition political leaders whom the groups call ''prisoners of conscience'' whose rights to due process have been denied.

title: Associated's Merger Terms
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, saying that the only impediment to a merger with the May Department Stores Company was the price of May stock in an exchange, said yesterday that its board had recommended an exchange ratio of 0.882 share of May for each share of Associated common. That would mean that Associated shareholders would get $69.35 a share in May stock, based on yesterday's New York Stock Exchange closing price for May of $78.625.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
I.B.M. NET DROPS 7.7% IN QUARTER
description: Deeply mired in the computer slump, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a sharp 7.7 percent drop in its second-quarter profits. It said that without an upturn in the nation's capital spending, ''it will be difficult to show earnings growth in 1986.''

title: Winnings of Casinos Set 6-Month Record
description: Atlantic City's casinos ''won'' more than $1 billion from their customers in the first half of 1986, for the highest six-month level since gambling was legalized eight years ago, the State Casino Control Commission reported today.

title: ESPOSITO IS REPLACING PATRICK AS GENERAL MANAGER
description: The Rangers ended months of speculation yesterday by announcing that Phil Esposito, the former Ranger player who was inducted into the Hall of Fame three years after his retirement in 1981, will replace Craig Patrick as general manager.

title: Noose Report
description: Chuck Tanner of the Atlanta Braves is regarded as one of the most pleasant managers who ever pulled on a sock, but it's his boot that troubles Robin Monsky. Specifically, Tanner has kicked Ms. Monsky off the field of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium for the rest of the season and told her that she's also no longer welcome on the team's road trips. This is affecting her work, and well it might. Robin Monsky is the Braves' media information director and, as such, is supposed to be the club's primary link with the press.

title: DIVERS SAW FLIGHT SUIT IN SHUTTLE WRECK
description: An astronaut flight suit, caught in wreckage 87 feet below the ocean's surface, was the marker that told two divers from Cocoa Beach that they had found the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin, the divers say.

title: HOSPITAL STAFFING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $84,000 for the 6 months.

title: THE STING OF JELLYFISH FELT EARLY
description: The season of the jellyfish is at hand - early and in force.

title: Pentagon Auditor Is Cleared
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned the dismissal of Charles O. Starrett Jr., the Pentagon's chief civilian auditor, who had been accused of retaliating against a subordinate who questioned his agency's practices.

title: DANCE: MARK MORRIS'S 'MORT SUBITE'
description: THESE days it seems as if everyone wants a new dance by Mark Morris. The Boston Ballet has one. And it presented it on Sunday afternoon, in what turned out to be the highlight of its program at the Pepsico ''Summerfare'' festival at the State University of New York at Purchase. ''Mort Subite,'' the name of the dance, is said also to be the name of a cherry-flavored Belgian beer. Mr. Morris, a noted modern dance choreographer, has given much evidence of a wild and wicked sense of humor. And the nearly cherry-colored lighting of the backdrop suggested that inspiration. But ''Mort Subite'' is as dark, driving and elegiac as its score, Poulenc's Concerto in G minor for Organ, Strings and Timpani. It is a dance that summons up images of loss and a continuum.

title: U.S. WEIGHS NAMING BLACK ENVOY; A SIGNAL TO PRETORIA
description: White House officials said today that a black North Carolina businessman was the leading candidate to replace Herman W. Nickel, the United States Ambassador to South Africa.

title: Economist Deal Cleared
description: A New York Supreme Court judge yesterday denied Macmillan Inc.'s request that it prevent the sale of the Business International Corporation to a subsidiary of Economist Newspaper Ltd. of Britain. The judge removed a temporary restraining order entered on July 3. In the wake of the ruling by Judge Harold Baer Jr., the Economist Newspaper unit said that by late afternoon it had purchased added shares in Business International, to bring its holding to 87 percent.

title: Fed Official to Head Treasuries Broker
description: Edward J. Geng, who is in charge of market surveillance at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been named president of Fundamental Brokers Inc., the largest broker of Treasury securities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A person who deliberately, for their own personal gain, betrays their country should not walk the streets a free man.'' - Federal District Judge David Z. Kenyon. [ A1:2. ]

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 15, 1986
description: Companies

title: ONE YOUTH WHO ELUDED THE SYSTEM'S GRASP
description: Over the last four years, 15-year-old Shavod Jones had repeated encounters with the city's criminal justice and social service systems, becoming an increasingly troubled youth who nonetheless remained outside the control of the authorities.

title: HEARINGS ON DISPUTED PRIMARY OPEN IN ALABAMA
description: A special panel set up by the Alabama Democratic Party opened hearings today into the disputed results of the gubernatorial primary election, an issue that has divided Democrats and thrown state politics into turmoil.

title: TAX CONFEREES: 9 FOR SENATE, 8 OR 11 FOR THE HOUSE
description: The House-Senate conference committee on tax revision legislation will begin meeting Thursday with nine senators and either eight or 11 representatives serving as conferees, staff members said today.

title: Victory at the Library
description: A supplemental money bill adopted by Congress includes an additional $867,000 for the Library of Congress that will allow it to restore some of the hours it had to eliminate from its schedule in the recent budget crunch, generating great protest. This story ought to end there, but for a few loose ends.

title: Opposition Party Spurns Sri Lanka Peace Plan
description: Sri Lanka's main opposition party rejected a Government-proposed plan today to end the island's ethnic conflict.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a $1,600,000 pre-tax provision for a loss on the anticipated sale of a subsidiary for both the quarter and 6 months, and a tax benefit of $83,000 for the 6 months. c-After a $6,600,000 pre-tax provision for the loss on the closing of production facilities.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Wickes to Sell Woman's World
description: The Wickes Companies said that it had agreed to sell its Woman's World Shops, a chain of retail stores specializing in clothing for large women, to the Amcena Corporation. Terms were not released.

title: COKE PICKS LEADER FOR NEW UNIT
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Brian G. Dyson, the head of its domestic soft drink operations, had been named president and chief executive of a new Coca-Cola bottling company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALL OF US HERE. By Irving Feldman. 81 pages. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. Cloth, $17.95; paper, $8.95. IRVING FELDMAN made his name 25 years ago with his first collection of poems, ''Works and Days.'' Since then he has advanced steadily from volume to volume, establishing himself as one of the most gifted and intelligent American poets of his generation; but nowhere before has he broken new ground quite as boldly as he does in his new collection, ''All of Us Here'' - or rather in the title poem that makes up a good half of the book.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest 6 months includes $118 million in writedowns of oil and gas properties in the first quarter.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Equity securities gains totaled $43.1 million for the latest quarter, compared with $32.8 million for the year- earlier period. The latest quarter results included realized foreign exchange trading profits of $23.5 million, compared with $14.5 million for the year-ago period.

title: The National Pastime
description: A breathless nation will pause tonight to watch the long-awaited midseason extravaganza, as underdog Democrats take on favored Republicans in the talent-studded annual All-Star game. To the victors belong the spoils.

title: DANIEL B. STAMPLER
description: Daniel Bartel Stampler, who founded one of the most popular steak houses in Greenwich Village and ran it for almost 25 years, died Thursday at North Miami Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and had lived in Miami since he sold his business here in 1970.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 22
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March 1986.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Federal Audit Accuses Dairy Dealer in Jersey
description: A Brooklyn Representative in Congress said last week that a New Jersey dairy company that wants to expand its milk sales in New York City had misused $481,000 worth of Federal surplus food intended for school nutrition programs in five states.

title: Lightning Leaves L.I. Boy, 6, Critical
description: A 6-year-old boy struck by lightning while attending a fireworks display Sunday night was in critical condition today at Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park.

title: A Tug of War Erupts on Missile Treaty Data
description: In recent months, key senators and Reagan Administration officials have been engaged in a simmering dispute over the Administration's new interpretation of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty.

title: FUNDAMENTALIST PARENTS PUT TEXTBOOKS ON TRIAL
description: Almost three years ago, Vicki Frost says, she sat down to read through a story called ''A Visit to Mars'' in one of her daughter's sixth-grade textbooks. The story so offended her that she and a few other Christian parents began a campaign against the books used to teach reading in the Hawkins County public schools.

title: Careers; Corporate Search for Creativity
description: WHILE ''creativity'' has become a popular catchword at corporations, experts say top managers sometimes fail to master the difficulties of identifying, recruiting and nurturing creative people.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART DECO IN MIAMI BEACH GETS CITY PROTECTION RULE
description: The long struggle to preserve this aging resort's buildings of the Mediterranean and Art Deco styles has been bolstered by the City Commission's creating of two historic districts encompassing the heaviest concentrations of such structures.

title: MAGICIAN MAKES THE LIST OF 25 'GENIUS' WINNERS
description: The MacArthur Foundation named 25 ''outstandingly talented'' people yesterday to receive awards ranging from $164,000 to $300,000, one of them a 57-year-old magician who has used his skills to debunk self-styled psychics, seers and promoters of miracle cures.

title: Rock Benefit Concert
description: A benefit concert featuring the rock groups General Public, Books of Love and Let's Active and the performers Suzanne Vega and Phranc, will be held tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Felt Forum, Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 32d Street.

title: FORMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
From the Bunker
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, who eventually won the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic over the weekend, on his disappointing even-par third round: ''I hit the ball sideways. It was like Army golf -left, right, left, right.''

title: The U.N. Today: July 15, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SUMO STYLE IS TOO TOUGH
description: Gone from the top of John Ten-ta's head was the fancy knot that told the world he was a sumo wrestler.

title: VIETNAM NAMES A NEW PARTY LEADER
description: A 79-year-old official with a reputation as an ideological hard-liner was chosen today to succeed Le Duan as Vietnam's Communist Party leader, the official Hanoi radio announced, The post is the most important political office in Vietnam.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sales of investment securities of $36.5 million for the latest quarter, compared with $69.6 million for the year-ago period.

title: Turbulence Hurts 18 on Jet
description: Eighteen passengers on an Eastern Airlines jet were injured Sunday when the plane, from Kennedy International Airport at New York, ran into violent turbulence over Palm Beach on its approach to Miami. A few of the total of 215 passengers do not speak English and did not heed the warning to buckle their seat belts. Two passengers, Rose Selago and Josephine Schwebel, both 73 years old, were reported in good condition today at Jackson Memorial Hospital here.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RIGHTS UNIT CHIEF URGING PARTIES TO SCRAP CAUCUSES FOR MINORITIES
description: Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, says the Republican and Democratic National Committees should abolish their special caucuses and auxiliaries for blacks, Hispanic people and other minority groups.

title: SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS WITH THATCHER
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, discussed East-West issues with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for a little more than two hours today at her Downing Street residence.

title: 2 VICTIMS SAID TO HAVE EXPLOSIVES
description: Five bombs exploded today in three Portuguese cities, with one killing the son of an army colonel and another young man in the officer's Lisbon apartment. The police said they believed the two victims were handling explosives.

title: AGENCY DELAYS SHUTTLE FLIGHTS UNTIL EARLY '88 NASA'S SHUTTLE MILESTONES March 1986: Review of items deemed critical to shuttle safety begun.   July: George A. Rodney appointed new associate administrator for safety, reliability and quality assurance.   Late July: NASA to propose new configuration for solid-fuel booster rocket for four full-scale tests.   Aug. 15: Recommendations on shuttle program management to be completed.   August: Recommendations on rate of flights to be submitted. The National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, to announce independent panel to audit the adequacy of NASA's review of items critical to shuttle safety.   Sept. 1: Shuttle safety panel to be established.   September: Changes in management of shuttle program to be decided. Preliminary review of design of solid-fuel booster rocket to be finished.   November: Proposal for changes in cargo scheduling policy to be submitted to NASA headquarters.   December: Final decisions on crew escape system to be reached.   Dec. 31: Review of every aspect of NASA management by Gen. Samuel C. Phillips, U.S.A.F., retired, to be completed.   March 1987: Review of design of solid-fuel booster rocket and review of requirements for maintenance tests and checkouts to be completed.   May: Review of NASA headquarters organization and hazard analysis to be completed.   June: NASA to submit one-year report to the President.   August: New brakes for shuttle orbiter to be delivered.   December: Review to certify design of solid-fuel rocket booster to be completed.   January to March 1988: Earliest date for launching.
description: The space agency said today that the earliest date the space shuttle could resume flying would be in early 1988, a substantial delay from the previous goal of July 1987.

title: DON'T WORRY! THERE IS A WAY
description: The Worry Group has been worrying for the last five years about -what else? - worry.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from securities of $1,725,000, $17,136,000, and $1,915,000 for latest quarter, and latest and year-ago 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a securities loss of $119,000.

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WOLVERINE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock distribution in June.

title: FRANCE DISPLAYS ITS MILITARY MIGHT
description: France marked the 197th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille today with its largest military parade since World War II.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HENRY YOUNG Jr.
description: Henry Young Jr., a former New Jersey Assemblyman and Essex County Sheriff, died Saturday at the Greenfield Convalescent Home in Bridgewater, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Stockton, N.J.

title: Attack on Panamanian Is Anonymous and Unproved
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKERS FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: POTENTIAL ENVOY: BIPARTISAN RESPECT
description: Friends and acquaintances of Robert J. Brown, a North Carolina public relations executive being discussed as a possible Ambassador to South Africa, described him today as a businessman respected by those at both ends of the political spectrum.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $44 million provision for credit losses to allocate additional reserves against the Mexican credit portfolio and a gain of $58,681,000 on the sale of a mortgage banking subsidiary.

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the 9-month ended June 30, 1985, include pretax income of $997,000 realized from proceeds of a property sale.

title: Amnesty International Chief
description: Amnesty International announced the appointment today of Ian Martin, a Briton who heads Asian research in the human rights organization's international division, as its next secretary general. Mr. Martin, 39 years old, will succeed Thomas Hammarberg, a Swedish journalist who will leave the chief executive's post in September after six years. Amnesty International campaigns to free prisoners of conscience, safeguard the rights of political prisoners and end torture.

title: U.S. Is Winner
description: The United States defeated Canada, 77-65, at the World Basketball Championships tonight, and the Soviet Union, Brazil and Yugoslavia claimed semifinal spots. Argentina (5-2) and the United States (6-1) are vying for the last semifinal berth.

title: SKATING THROUGH BARRIERS IN AMERICA
description: Poor kids? ''You get very few here,'' said Debbie Milne, a coach at the Sport-o-rama figure-skating camp. ''I'll get a talented 6-year-old skater, and when the parents realize the cost, they drop out. It's sad, because a lot of the talented are not from the rich families.''

title: Louisville Shift To Gannett
description: The Gannett Company completed the purchase of the family-owned Louisville newspapers today for $306.9 million, retaining their president, George N. Gill, with the new title of president and publisher. Michael G. Gartner, Gannett general news executive, was named editor of The Louisville Times and The Courier-Journal papers, which have been owned for nearly 70 years by the Bingham family.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
MANNED SUB DESCENDS TO VIEW THE TITANIC
description: RIDING in the submersible craft Alvin, Dr. Robert D. Ballard and two pilots descended through almost 13,000 feet of water yesterday and landed on the bow and bridge of the Titanic, which was the world's largest and most luxurious ocean liner when she struck an iceberg and sank 74 years ago.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: Share earnings reflect a 15-percent stock dividend declared in May.

title: BID BY TELE-COMMUNICATIONS
description: Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver, the nation's largest cable television operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 51 percent of United Artists Communications Inc. from two controlling stockholders and would buy the rest of the company from the public in a deal totaling $766 million in cash and notes.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $9 million after taxes from the sale of the remaining portion of the company's minority interest in a leasing company in Japan. Results for the year-ago 6 months include a gain of $15 million after taxes resulting from the sale of a portion of the company's minority interest in the leasing company in Japan.

title: NL TURNS DOWN OFFER BY SIMMONS
description: NL Industries said yesterday that its board had rejected the latest offer from Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, to acquire the New York chemical and oilfield services company. The company also said that its board had voted to spin off NL's profitable chemical unit to shareholders.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EVER since the actress Brigitte Bardot settled there, St.-Tropez has been a magnet for what was once called the jet set. In recent years, however, regulars have been moaning that their elitist resort on the French Riviera had fallen out of fashion, suffering from a bad case of jet-set lag.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue figures represent gross income.

title: 4 BIG BANKS POST PROFIT GAINS IN QUARTER
description: Despite a weak economy and continued turmoil in the oil and agriculture industries, four of the nation's major banks yesterday reported higher second-quarter income. But earnings were down at Chemical Bank, which increased its provision for loan losses.

title: SENATOR REQUESTS HEARING ON C.I.A.
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California, the Democratic whip, called today for a Congressional investigation into reports that the Central Intelligence Agency is planning to take control of the insurgent campaign against the Nicaraguan Government.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes securities gains of $4,017,000 for the quarter and $4,186,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes securities gains of $5,247,000 for the quarter and $7,927,000 for the 6 months.

title: Chaining the Press
description: The White House has long complained that reporters hound visitors for news as they emerge from West Wing meetings with Administration officials and even the President.

title: FLORIDA, BATTLING HISTORY, TRIES TO REIN IN GROWTH
description: Florida keeps falling away, piece by piece, mile by mile.

title: Facing Hearing, Alien Leaves U.S.
description: A Salvadoran facing a deportation hearing has apparently slipped out of the United States along with his wife and children, according to members of a movement to give sanctuary here to aliens.

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLAN FOR COLISEUM SITE: AN ISSUE OF SHEER SIZE
description: Columbus Circle, anchor of the southwest corner of Central Park and gateway to the Upper West Side, has some of the least successful architecture in the city: the New York Coliseum on one side, the former Huntington Hartford Gallery of Modern Art on another, and the Gulf and Western Building on a third.

title: INQUIRY ORDERED IN ISRAELI SCANDAL
description: Israel's Attorney General announced today that he was ordering a police investigation of a scandal involving the domestic security agency.

title: Strange Contradiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security Cards
description: The Social Security Administration is gearing up to issue about twice as many new cards in 1987 as it did this year, on the assumption that a provision in the Senate version of the tax code revision bill will become law.

title: OIL PRICES AT LOWEST IN YEARS
description: Prices of some crude oil and petroleum products fell yesterday to their lowest levels in years on the world oil market. Brent North Sea crude oil, a benchmark of international prices, traded at $8.85 a barrel, the lowest price since this grade was introduced in 1976.

title: Perfume for Aging Spiders
description: A scientist has discovered some curious twists in the battle of the sexes among Sierra dome spiders, a species common in the mountains of western North America. The females build dome-shaped webs, which they use to catch bugs.

title: WIDER DEVELOPMENT OF CLUSTER MUNITIONS AFTER U.S. CUTOFF SHOWS INEVITABLE GROWTH
description: The complex story of Israel's cluster munitions illustrates how hard it is to control the spread of advanced weapons, the uses to which they are put and the technologies that help to build them. Last week, United

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL ALL STAR GAME, at Houston, 8:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.) GOODWILL GAMES Boxing, figure skating, yachting, men's gymnastics, men's volleyball, men's tennis, at Moscow.

title: PARALYZED SHOOTING VICTIM PART OF PROUD 'COP' FAMILY
description: Over three generations, at least seven members of Steven McDonald's family have compiled 175 years of service as police officers - from his great-aunt, who became a New York City policewoman in 1925, to his father, who retired as a sergeant 10 years ago.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Relatives of Marcos Request A Delay in Contempt Charge
description: The youngest daughter and a son-in-law of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos asked the Supreme Court today to stay a lower court decision finding them in contempt.

title: REAGAN MUST SPEAK OUT
description: President Reagan should speak out on South Africa. Sanctions, or at least the threat of sanctions, are necessary, but the seriousness of the South African problem also demands a determined American response enunciated by our head of state.

title: Loral Withdraws Offer for Sanders
description: The Loral Corporation has withdrawn its offer for Sanders Associates Inc., the New Hampshire military electronics concern. The withdrawal sharply improves the prospects that the Lockheed Corporation can acquire Sanders without engaging in a bidding war.

title: U.S. WEIGHS NAMING BLACK ENVOY; NEW RULES PROTESTED
description: Thousands of black students stayed away from classes at the start of a new semester today in apparent protest of new Government orders aimed at preventing classroom dissent.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the Alaska Journal yesterday, from Anchorage, misidentified an Indian tribe. It is the Auk, not Awk.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
FEARING INSTABILITY, WEST SEEKS TO REPLACE MINERALS FROM AFRICA
description: AS international pressures against South Africa's racial policies mount, minerals experts are looking for ways to replace the South African metals on which the economies of industrial nations depend.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BUOYANT MUSIC Bargemusic merits its name because it is a concert hall on a barge. The barge has for eight years been a cultural fixture on the gentrified Brooklyn waterfront almost beneath the Brooklyn Bridge and Brooklyn Heights, where it is tethered to a pier at Fulton Street Landing.

title: SOVIET WARNS PAKISTAN ON BOMB
description: The Soviet Union recently warned Pakistan not to develop a nuclear bomb, touching off a sharp reaction from the United States, Administration officials said tonight.

title: STAGE: 'OUT!,' ON '19 BASEBALL SCANDAL
description: IN a time of multi-million-dollar contracts, high-powered agents and revelations of drug abuse among baseball players and other athletes, there is something decidedly old-fashioned - but still shocking - about returning to the subject of the Black Sox scandal, in which eight players on the Chicago White Sox were banned from baseball after being accused of throwing the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds. As detailed in Lawrence Kelly's intriguing new play, ''Out!,'' the issues behind the scandal were relatively simple. Players, including such stars as Shoeless Joe Jackson, were woefully underpaid. Baseball was a national institution in which the primary parties were treated as children, incapable of handling their own destinies and unworthy of receiving adequate compensation. The story of ''Out!'' is largely one of greed mixed with pride.

title: Long-Distance Plane Nears End of Test
description: The long-distance aircraft Voyager approached the 10,000-mile mark as it headed south from San Francisco today on the second half of a test flight scheduled to end Tuesday.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,208,000 for the quarter and $686,000 for the 6 months.

title: Korean Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States in the first half was a record $3.26 billion, up 75.9 percent from a year ago, the Government said today. Exports were $6.42 billion, up 27.6 percent; imports were $3.16 billion, down six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: 3 FACE S.E.C. CHARGES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a former senior officer of a Chicago investment advisory firm and two former brokers at Shearson Lehman Brothers with taking part in a scheme to defraud an International Brotherhood of Teamsters union pension fund and to pay kickbacks to union officials.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 15, 1986
description: International

title: Business and the Law; Hunt Brothers Vs. Creditors
description: LAST month the wealthy Hunt brothers charged 23 lenders with trying to destroy Hunt businesses in order to recover overdue payments on $1.5 billion of loans. Many lawyers say the case is likely to become the most watched yet of a borrower turning to the courts to limit the powers of creditors.

title: THE CERTAIN APPROACH OF DESKTOP PUBLISHING
description: AFTER attending Comdex, the computer dealers' exposition, last fall I noted, as some readers may recall, that the most manifest trend to emerge in 1986 would be the popularity of desktop publishing. So convinced was I of the strength of this trend, in fact, that I initiated negotiations to purchase a startup magazine called Desktop Publishing. Unfortunately, I lost out to the microcomputing publishing giant CW Communications. That corporation dropped the magazine's original title and chose instead the rather insipid, if punctuationally commanding moniker Publish!

title: PILOT IN JET CRASH MISLED HIS FAMILY
description: The Air Force pilot of a secret plane that crashed Friday apparently sought to conceal the clandestine nature of his work by telling friends that his job was flying mock combat missions against other American pilots.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT IS SENTENCED TO LIFE TERMS FOR ESPIONAGE
description: Declaring that espionage must not be taken lightly, a Federal judge today sentenced Richard W. Miller, the first F.B.I. agent ever charged with the crime, to two concurrent life sentences for spying for the Soviet Union.

title: Compiled and Interpreted
description: Language programming tools are divided into two categories, interpreters and compilers. QuickBasic 2.0 is a compiler.

title: SURVIVING A SETBACK, DENG IS FREE TO PLAY HIS HAND
description: When the World Bridge Federation organized an 82-country contest last month, one of the 100,000 entrants playing the computer-chosen hands was Deng Xiaoping, the 81-year-old architect of China's ambitious program of change.

title: Tribune to Buy Virginia Papers
description: The Tribune Company said today that it had agreed to acquire The Daily Press Inc., a publisher of two Viginia newspapers and operator of two cable television systems, for $200 million. The two newspapers, The Daily Press and The Times-Herald in Newport News, have a combined daily circulation of 104,000.

title: 'THE METS' LOSS, NOT MINE
description: It's the oldest story in sports, and in life. What if. What would the Mets be like now if they had both Dwight Gooden and Roger Clemens.

title: Maurice Blinken, 86; Early Backer of Israel
description: Maurice H. Blinken, a New York lawyer who founded the American Palestine Institute after World War II, died Sunday at the Good Samaritan Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: Youth Dies in Fall On Subway Track
description: A Queens teen-ager was killed when he fell between two subway cars at the 30th Avenue station in Astoria, the transit police said yesterday.

title: 'Thank You, Big Apple'
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCURY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are based on shares outstanding of 5,227,281 and 5,204,820 for 1986 and 1985, respectively, giving effect to stock dividends.

title: PROGRESS FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share figures reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: Reagan Economic Aide
description: President Reagan said today that he would formally nominate Michael Mussa, professor of international business at the University of Chicago, to be a member of his Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Mussa, 44 years old, would succeed William Poole 7th on the three-member council. His nomination had been expected for some time.

POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30

title: 'La Marseillaise' Salutes Bastille Day in Central Park
description: Bernadette Chirac, wife of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France, called Emmanuel de Margerie, the French Ambassador to the United States, who called Martin E. Segal, chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center and head of the France Salutes New York Festival, who then called Albert K. Webster, managing director of the New York Philharmonic.

title: NBC OFFICIAL DENIES PRESSURE
description: Arthur Watson, the president of NBC Sports, yesterday became the third head of a network sports division to testify in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League that the N.F.L. did not exert pressure on his network to deny the U.S.F.L. a contract for the fall.

title: Jet Engine Maker Net Up
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased 18.4 percent on a 5.5 percent revenue rise.

title: LIMITS EASED ON COMMITTING THE MENTALLY ILL
description: After almost two decades of restrictions intended to protect the civil rights of mentally ill people, psychiatric experts report a national trend toward making it easier to commit mentally disturbed patients for involuntary hospitalization.

title: PEPSICO BUYS SEVEN-UP'S INTERNATIONAL DIVISION
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the Seven-Up Company's international soft drink business from the Philip Morris Companies for $246 million.

title: MUSIC: PARK PROGRAM SALUTES TWO COUNTRIES
description: THE weather has been friendly to outdoor concertgoers this summer, and so it was last night to the crowd that gathered on Central Park's Great Lawn for another New York Philharmonic outing there. Just the right amount of breeze soothed an estimated 125,000 brows without chilling.

title: Receiver Fees Set In Volume Case
description: A Federal district court judge overseeing the liquidation of Volume Investors, a commodities firm that collapsed last year, has settled a dispute over fees by granting Volume's receiver significantly more money than he had requested. In a bitter dispute, the Comex Clearing Association, which is owed about $9 million by Volume, had argued earlier that the receiver, John F. X. Peloso, and his lawyers and accountants were not entitled to the more than $800,000 in fees and expenses requested for their year of work.

title: GARMENT CENTER DESIGNS ITSELF ANEW
description: For as long as most residents can remember, there have been two indisputable truths in New York's garment district.

title: Chess: 2 Junior Masters Tie for First In High School Tournament
description: Two of the top United States junior masters, 15-year-old Vivek Rao of Monroeville, Pa., and Danny Edelman, 17, of New Rochelle, N.Y., tied for first place in the National High School Championship.

title: MICRO BIO-MEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HONEYWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Congress; Whither the Immigration Bill?
description: Just before Congress left town last month, the House Judiciary Committee approved a major bill to curb the influx of illegal aliens. The Senate approved a separate bill with a similar purpose last September.

title: Protestants and Police Battle in Ulster Town
description: Protestants and riot police officers fought running battles here today when marchers tried to tear down a fence separating them from the town's Roman Catholics.

title: HOME PLANNED FOR MENTALLY ILL LIVING IN STREETS
description: A private, nonprofit group that aids the homeless has announced plans to open a 50-bed home in Manhattan for mentally ill men and women now living in the streets.

title: Don't Water Down The Antiracket Law
description: In 1970, Congress responded to the threat of organized crime by enacting the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act - known as RICO - which carried tough criminal sanctions and novel civil remedies. Although the criminal provisions have met with widespread acceptance, the civil remedies today are under severe attack. Congress should reject this campaign by special interests to gut the law.

title: Scoop
description: Want the real reason why Bo Jackson chose the Royals? From The Associated Press's sports report last Saturday: ''Heisman Trophy winner Bo Jackson, who gave up a career in the United States Football League for baseball. . . .''

title: Home Savings' New Feature
description: Home Savings of America, the largest savings and loan association in the country, announced yesterday that it plans to introduce a new feature to the mortgage securities market later this week when it offers $410.6 million of mortgage pass-through certificates through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: METROBANC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,384,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,050,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. d-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,023,000 on the sale of land and a building.

title: Topics; Setting an Example; Speech in School
description: The Supreme Court has given school authorities broad discretion to discipline students for ill-mannered speech. No school can function without such authority, though all should use it sparingly.

description: b-Includes after-tax gains on the sale of investment securities of $9.8 million, or 25 cents per share, for the quarter and after-tax securities gains of $17.5 million, or 45 cents per share, for the 6 months. c-Includes after-tax securities gains of $1.5 million, or 4 cents per share, for the quarter and $3.2 million, or 9 cents per share, for the 6 months.

title: FRANCO BASKS AS ALL-STAR
description: Not so long ago, when the baseball career of John Franco was in its formative stages, he would sit before a television at home in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, examine the All-Stars in the annual summertime game, and go out the next day to assume the identity of one of them.

title: Cyanide Leak Injures 4 Upstate
description: A deadly gas, hydrogen cyanide, escaped in a University of Rochester laboratory, injuring a researcher and sending three other people to the hospital, the authorities said today.

title: BOTNICK CANCELS DECISION TO STAY AS AIDE TO KOCH
description: Victor E. Botnick, who announced his resignation amid criticism of his conduct in office, disclosed yesterday that he was delaying his resignation two weeks, but a few hours later, after questions from reporters, reversed himself, and said he would leave, after all.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE SCIENCE: NEW RESEARCH IN DECODING DNA IS LEADING TO DRUGS AND TREATMENTS
description: A TORRENT of advances in diagnosis and an increasingly deep understanding of disease and the nature of life itself are emerging today from studies of DNA, the master chemical of heredity.

title: Hess Returns to Spandau
description: Rudolf Hess, the 92-year-old former deputy to Hitler, was returned to Spandau prison in satisfactory condition today from a hospital in which he had spent nearly a week, a spokesman for the British military forces said. The four World War II allies - the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union - made the decision to return Mr. Hess to prison, the spokesman said. Mr. Hess, who has been the only inmate at the prison since 1966, was sentenced at the Nuremberg war crimes trials in 1946 to life in prison.

title: OKLAHOMA BANK DECLARED INSOLVENT
description: The First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, one of the largest banks in a state plagued by depressions in agriculture and energy, was declared insolvent today by Federal officials and was sold, officials said.

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and the quarter includes an extraordinary credit of $13,435.

title: Advertising; Ex-Revlon Associates' Venture
description: SANFORD BUCHSBAUM, a leading citizen of adland, and Martin Stevens, his longtime associate at Revlon and a frequently lauded creative man, will be doing something they have been talking about for some time now, opening an agency of their own.

title: Bridge: Big Apple Regional Events Are Warm-Up for Nationals
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association's Big Apple Regional Championships, which ended Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, gave many New York experts a chance to warm up for the Summer Nationals scheduled to begin Friday in Toronto.

title: Court Decisions Avert Execution of 2 in Florida
description: Two Federal judges today averted a double execution by the state of Florida, granting indefinite stays to two convicted killers, Raymond Stone and Robert Parker.

title: Quake's Aftershocks Hit Southern California
description: Flurries of aftershocks rattled 150 miles of Southern California coastline today, as residents cleaned up after Sunday's earthquake.

title: MICROPOLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Ms. Freed Wed On Long Island
description: Susan Esther Freed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Herzl Freed of Long Island City, Queens,, was married yesterday to Martin Brandwein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Brandwein of Falls Church, Va. Rabbi Jerome Fishman performed the ceremony at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City.

title: THE DEBATE: WOULD ACCELERATED PROJECT DISTROY USUAL MEHTODS OF BIOLOGY?
description: A proposal to map and define the entire human genetic structure is stirring intense interest and anxiety among the nation's top scientists.

title: Verdict Is Upheld In Stun-Gun Case
description: A Queens judge has refused to throw out the conviction of two former police officers on charges that they tortured a prisoner with an electric stun gun, according to a ruling disclosed yesterday.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $7,435,000 for the latest quarter, $2,405,000 and 3,862,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Ideal Basic Gets Debt Agreement
description: In a move to avoid bankruptcy, Ideal Basic Industries has struck a preliminary agreement with its creditors that would allow the company to convert $300 million of its debt into equity. The company has been in default on the debt since Nov. 29, 1985.

title: 4 FIRE VICTIMS' PARENTS SIGNED UP FOR DAY CARE BUT FAILED TO USE IT
description: The parents of four small chidren who were killed in a fire after being left alone in a welfare hotel had registered the children in a day-care program but never sent them to it, the center's director said yesterday.

title: Statue of Gandhi Nearing Reality for Union Square
description: On the second of October in 1869, Mohandas K. Gandhi was born. On the second of October in 1986, an eight-foot bronze likeness of the Mahatma is scheduled to be unveiled in Union Square.

title: Topics; Setting an Example; All Stars
description: It's never over till it's over, and you gotta play 'em one game at a time and we don't want to get overconfident or anything. But it's still very much in order to propose a midseason toast to New York's Mets.

title: Attack Crack, Not Each Other
description: Crack magnifies the poison of cocaine into a powerfully addictive substance accessible to all. The highly purified crystal destroys lives and turns whole neighborhoods fearful. It demands a sustained, coordinated law enforcement response. What New York has got instead is a shouting match between United States Attorney Rudolph Giuliani and Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau.

title: POLITICAL SHIFT ON 'VULGAR' SPEECH
description: MATTHEW N. FRASER was hit by the swing of the political pendulum. The Supreme Court agreed that his school was within its rights when it disciplined him for using what it considered disruptive, lewd and indecent words in a school assembly; only 15 years ago, those words would not likely have raised any judicial eyebrows. The case, Bethel School District No. 403 v. Fraser, may reflect more significantly on the administration of the public schools than on freedom of speech.

title: 12 RECEIVE NATIONAL MEDAL OF ARTS
description: President Reagan today presented the National Medal of Arts to nine artists and three patrons, saying their contributions were of the kind that in the nation's brief history had helped American culture move away from a time when it ''looked not to the New World but the Old.''

title: The Friendly Gourmet
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MANAGEMENT CITED AT 16 'PROBLEM' NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Of the 16 power plants ranked by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in May as the nation's worst ''problem plants,'' nearly all have management difficulties stretching back for several years, according to a detailed analysis provided by the commission.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $500,000. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and $1.7 million for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter loss is after writedowns of energy- related assets totaling $49.1 million after taxes. The company said an after tax writedown of $29.6 million related to its U.S. oil and gas exploration and production assets was made under the SEC full-cost accounting rules, because of price declines since the end of the second quarter. The remaining writeoffs of $19.5 million related to oil well servicing assets, including $11.4 million in goodwill, whose value was also affected by lower U.S. oil and gas prices.

title: INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Well Armed
description: If Caryn Heise were a factory employee, what she has just been through would make easy work for labor organizers. As it is, she's a 16-year-old junior at West High School in Waterloo, whose girls' softball team played last Saturday in the Iowa state tournament at Independence.

title: GAF Profits Up 8.8%
description: The GAF Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1986 rose 8.8 percent on a 5.4 percent increase in sales.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WE met when we were both 15. She went to the beach with my family that summer, and when she stepped out of the bedroom we shared, wearing a two-piece bathing suit, I watched my father and one of his friends almost pale beneath their ruddy tans. As I lay on the beach in my own suit, its top boned into the facsimile of a bust, I could lift my head and in the gap between my sternum and the fabric I could see a sliver of gray-green water. For the first time in my life I was aware of sex, not the act, nor the mechanics, but the essence of it. And a gulf began to open between my friend and me.

title: Briton Says Iraq Plans More Chemical Weapons
description: Britain charged today that Iraq's use of mustard gas and other chemical agents in its war with Iran was responsible for about 10,000 casualties and said Iraq appeared to be increasing its capacity to produce chemical weapons.

title: Reactor Problems At Texas Utility
description: The Texas Utilities Electric Company, a unit of the Dallas-based Texas Utilities Company, said today that additional problems had recently been discovered ''in several areas of the design'' of its delayed Comanche Peak nuclear power plant, 85 miles southwest of Dallas. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Texas Utilities said that the necessary corrective actions include ''updating of existing design calculations, reinspection and, in some cases, physical rework'' that would further delay the opening of Unit 1 plant.

title: PROFIT AT CITICORP, HANOVER OFF
description: Citicorp and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported lower second-quarter earnings yesterday and Wall Street analysts said the profits were well below expectations.

title: LOOK INSIDE TITANIC COMES THROUGH 'SWIMMING EYEBALL'
description: Imagine a fat slide projector with foam for floatation, thrusters for maneuvering and cameras for seeing, and that is Jason Jr. This underwater device was the finger probing the Titanic yesterday in the viscous darkness two and a half miles below the surface of the North Atlantic. Its technology makes it highly maneuverable at depths that would crush most submarines - and therefore highly interesting to the Navy, which has contributed most of the millions of dollars spent on its development.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,795,000, or 3 cents a share. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,549,000.

title: CLEMENS IS PERFECT AS AMERICAN LEAGUE WINS, 3-2
description: The pregame buildup had been about pitching, about Dwight Gooden and Roger Clemens and their memorable achievements as the two dominant pitchers in baseball. But Gooden was merely a footnote tonight, his work reduced to three innings and a home run that he permitted in the second inning. Clemens became the leading character in a game that came down to pitching and helped the American League to a 3-2 victory over the Nationals in the 57th All-Star Game.

title: OLD-TIME FRAME, CLOCK LIKE A GAME
description: 1. Vintage Frames - Vintage picture frames can make an interesting addition to a desk or bookshelf. Henri Bendel has a collection of brass, turn-of-the-century English frames in a variety of styles, ranging from simple to ornate.

title: COURT IN BONN BARS TAX BREAK ON GIFTS TO POLITICAL PARTIES
description: The highest West German court has declared unconstitutional a law making corporate donations to political parties tax deductible.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1985 results were restated for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 7.

title: BALLET: PARISIANS IN 'MIRAGES'
description: ''LES MIRAGES,'' performed by the Paris Opera Ballet on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, is an atmospheric fairy tale that is very much of its time. First presented in 1947, the ballet has choreography by Serge Lifar that sends the ballet's characters through Cassandre's vast, deserted palace hall in magic bursts of flight and disappearance, to mood-stirring music by Henri Sauguet.

title: CANADIAN NORTH: RABBIT FOR SUPPER, BEARS IN YARD
description: When Gus Kraus was 18 years old, he left home in Chicago and headed north with half a loaf of rye bread, a garlic sausage and a necktie.

title: Stuyvesant High School May Move to New Site
description: Stuyvesant High School, which has been on East 15th Street for 80 years, will likely move to a high-rise building on the northern edge of Battery Park City, the president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: More Woes for Howe
description: Steve Howe has tested ''99.9 percent'' positive for cocaine use in a urinalysis given by the San Jose Bees and has been asked to leave the Class A California League team and re-enter a rehabilitation program.

title: HINAULT GAINS CYCLING LEAD
description: Bernard Hinault blew open the Tour de France today by going on a two-man breakaway in the Pyrenees that ended with his slipping into the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

title: TRAVELERS BUYING DILLON, READ
description: Dillon, Read & Company, an old and prestigious name on Wall Street, will be sold to the Travelers Corporation for $157.5 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: DEBT ACCORD WITH MEXICO FORMING
description: The Reagan Administration, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have settled on the general terms of an agreement to give Mexico about $6 billion in new loans, officials involved in the talks said today.

description: b-Includes a $50 million gain resulting from partial settlement of a contractual dispute, and a $34 million gain from insurance proceeds.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PEOPLE often ask if I have ever had a disaster in the kitchen. The answer is yes, but rarely. Three incidents come to mind, two past and one recent.

title: A Changing Capital
description: The Congress has returned from its July Fourth recess to a Capital that is changing in subtle ways.

title: Bridge: 3 Champions in U.S. Group For Tournament in Peking
description: The longest bridge journeys so far in 1986 were made last month to the longest tournament. It was the Beijing Friendship Cup Invitational International Tournament, a biennial event, and it lasted two weeks.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF HELP IN CHILD-REARING
description: THERE is help for the seemingly insurmountable problems of parenthood. Whether it is a 3-year-old who sees monsters in the closet and won't sleep, a 9-year-old who suddenly won't stay with a sitter or an adolescent who locks his door all day, there is a course or support group somewhere offering solutions and solace.
