Pakistan's Premier in U.S.
description: Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo of Pakistan arrived today on three-day visit to Washington. He will meet with President Reagan at the White House on Wednesday and will hold talks with senior officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about Federal and local efforts against cocaine misstated the indictment rate for people arrested on felony drug charges in New York City. Two out of three people arrested on such charges last year were not indicted, according to the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: Democracy and Digestion
description: The 2,000 Congressional interns spending the summer on Capitol Hill have a varied political bill-of-fare available today, one that, at the least, should underscore for them the diversity of democracy as practiced in Washington.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months results include gains from the sale of a mill in Canada of 32 cents a share for the quarter and 45 cents a share for the 6 months. The company said effective Jan. 1, it adopted new pension accounting requirements, reducing pension expenses for the latest quarter and 6 months by about $2.8 million and $5.7 million pre-tax, respectively, or 6 cents a share and 11 cents a share after tax.

title: Rail Emergency Board Set Up
description: President Reagan established a three-member emergency board today to recommend solutions to a labor dispute that could lead to a strike against most of the nation's major railroads.

title: THEATER: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM'
description: In his production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Liviu Ciulei has set out to explore the dark underside of Shakespeare's comedy, the tragical aspect of the mirth. Mr. Ciulei's version (at the Pepsico ''Summerfare'') is, in many respects, more overtly serious than one often encounters. As fairies collide with mortals and as lovers quarrel, there are threats of violence; in no sense could the production be regarded as lighthearted. At the same time, the director's natural theatricality repeatedly asserts itself and, in several important instances, actors add their own inspired comic touches.

title: Falcons Sign Casillas
description: Tony Casillas, the nose tackle from Oklahoma who was the first-round selection of the Atlanta Falcons in the National Football League and whom the Arizona Outlaws made the top pick in the United States Football League draft, has signed with the Falcons. Although he would not disclose the amount, Casillas confirmed that the agreement with the Falcons was for four years. The Atlanta Journal reported that the deal was valued at $2.35 million, including a $1.43 million signing bonus, a $1 million loan and annual salaries of $175,000, $200,000, $250,000 and $300,000.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net for the year-ago periods included a $1,103,000 gain on the sale of a plant.

title: BERT BLOCK
description: Bert Block, a manager in the entertainment industry, died of emphysema last Wednesday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in South Salem, N.Y.

title: TITONE CLEARED OF ACCUSATIONS INVOLVING BRIBES
description: Judge Vito J. Titone of the State Court of Appeals in New York has been cleared of allegations that he had accepted bribes by defendants in two separate cases.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 16, 1986
description: Companies

title: PHILIPPINE ACCORD REPORTED ON RELEASING A MISSIONARY
description: Armed men who kidnapped an American missionary in the southern Philippines have agreed to free their hostage without a ransom payment in the next two days, military authorities said today.

title: Syria Gives Assurance To Greece on Hostages
description: Margaret Papandreou, the Greek Prime Minister's wife, said today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had promised to work with Greece for the release of hostages in Lebanon.

title: Some Veterans Deserve a Day in Court
description: A veteran who feels shortchanged by the Veterans Administration as it distributes $15 billion in benefits each year cannot normally take the agency to court. Many veterans accept the denial of judicial review in the belief that the Veterans Administration's internal review process is fair enough. But Vietnam veterans call it unfair. Congress should heed their complaint.

description: Debt

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Standard Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent for the sale of its Modernfold division to a new corporation to be formed by Wesray Capital Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Zimbabwe: Ugly Words, Good Deeds
description: A Zimbabwe official's 25 minutes of calculated rudeness to former President Carter and the United States now jeopardize one of America's more important assistance programs. That sounds petty, but the greater pettiness, or something worse, lies in Zimbabwe's refusal to render a proper apology.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $5,126,000 from the purchase of annunity contracts by the corporation's pension trust.

title: A Misread Treatise On Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AT last a celebrity has proposed a weight-loss program that is sensibly slow, nutritionally sound, appropriately flexible and readily adaptable for a lifetime. But will diet-hopping Americans stop with this one? Probably not, even though the celebrity is Jane Fonda, who has already captivated millions with her workouts. Her eating plan may not be gimmicky enough to woo desperate dieters from the likes of the pineapples and papayas, rice and fruit and rigid 600-calorie menus they currently embrace.

title: PLANE ENDS A RECORD NONSTOP FLIGHT
description: In a grueling test of advanced technology and personal determination, a feather-light experimental aircraft today ended a four-and-a-half-day flight that broke world records for distance and endurance.

title: SENATORS SAY ADMINISTRATION DEEPENS CRISIS IN AGRICULTURE
description: Farm-state senators from both parties said today that the Reagan Administration was sending American agriculture into a deeper economic depression by failing to activate provisions in the new farm law designed to increase agricultural exports.

title: UNDERSEA ROBOT GETS A LOOK INSIDE STILL-LUXURIOUS TITANIC
description: An undersea robot entered the sunken luxury liner Titanic today through a skylight, worked its way down the grand stairway and descended four levels for the first view of the great wreck's deep interior.

title: 'VIENNA 1900' AS SEEN IN SHOW AT THE MODERN
description: IN yet another display of repackaging ploys, Channel 13 is offering tonight at 8:30 a 28-minute documentary called ''Vienna 1900.'' The presentation is part of a series called ''You Gotta Have Art,'' which, despite the silly title, features serious films about art, artists and museums. Actually, as in this evening's case, the films sometimes border on being little more than commercials for traveling exhibitions.

description: A city official who was accused of retaliating against a subordinate who complained of corruption resigned yesterday, less than a week after he was demoted and given an $11,000 reduction in pay.

title: U.S. in Final Four In Basketball Event
description: David Robinson of Navy had 21 points and 17 rebounds tonight to lead the United States to a 69-60 victory over Yugoslavia in the world basketball championships. Earlier today, Italy beat Argentina, 78-70, assuring the United States of the last spot among the final four teams.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LAWYER IS FIFTH PERSON LINKED TO INSIDER CASE
description: A 31-year-old lawyer at one of the nation's most powerful law firms has became the fifth person implicated in the big Wall Street scandal centering on charges that Dennis B. Levine, the former mergers executive, and others made millions in illicit profits by buying stock on inside information.

title: MILITARY-POLICE SPLIT IS SEEN TO BE ERODED
description: The plan, made public today, for United States Army personnel to help Bolivian anti-drug forces appears to advance the erosion of laws and traditions separating the military from law enforcement.

title: Northrop's Net Down 74.9%
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it earned $23.1 million, or 49 cents a share, in the second quarter, down 74.9 percent from $91.9 million, or $1.99 a share, for the period last year. Sales totaled $1.4 billion, up 14.7 percent from $1.22 billion.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS WEST FAILS TO REPLY ON ARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a new expression of unhappiness over Washington's positions on arms control, says that a further extension of Moscow's moratorium on nuclear testing will depend on the American response.

title: OILS THAT ADD TINT, TASTE AND BOUQUET
description: LIKE fine wines, specialty oils offer a tempting spectrum -from a honey-tinted hazelnut oil with its roasted-coffee notes to an auburn-hued almond oil with a toasty sweetness - while challenging a cook. Yet the consumer who splurges on an almond, hazelnut or other nut or seed oil does not always get a product as distinctive as its label. The oil might be as nondescript an essence as ordinary cooking oil. A little knowledge about oil processing can help avoid such disappointments.

title: DRUG FLOW THROUGH TURKEY IS REPORTED TO DEFY CONTROL
description: American and Turkish specialists report that political upheavals in opium-producing countries and a large increase in heroin addiction in Europe have produced a flow of narcotics from South Asia and the Middle East through Turkey that is increasingly difficult to police.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect change in pension cost accounting.

description: The USX Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer up to $1.5 billion of debt securities and warrants to purchase debt securities.

title: CBS'S STAFFING PLANS UPSET BY ELLERBEE MOVE
description: A decision by the newscaster Linda Ellerbee not to accept a co-anchor post on a new version of CBS's morning news program has thrown plans for the program into doubt, presenting a staffing dilemma that may also affect the prime-time CBS News program ''West 57th.''

title: 7 MORE STATES FACE LOSS OF SOME FUNDS OVER DRINKING AGE
description: The Department of Transportation said today that it had notified seven states that they face a loss of 5 percent of their Federal highway funds by Oct. 1 if they do not enact laws raising their minumum drinking age to 21.

title: 4 Arrested in Plot to Free Imprisoned Crime Figure
description: Four men were arrested today and charged with plotting to fly a reputed organized crime figure out of prison in a helicopter with state police markings, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Sale of Their Company Puts Naifys in Spotlight
description: United Artists Communications Inc., one of the nation's largest operators of movie theaters and major cable television systems, had been called one of San Francisco's best-kept corporate secrets. That was because the Naify brothers, Marshall and Robert, had kept their company out of the spotlight.

title: Suit Filed on Biotechnology Rules
description: An opponent of genetic engineering research and development filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court here today asserting that the Reagan Administration's new program to regulate the biotechnology industry does not provide adequate safeguards for protecting the public health and the environment.

title: President Resigns Post at Fannie Mae
description: Mark J. Riedy has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Federal National Mortgage Association, so for the fifth time in five years the corporation, which is the nation's largest single supplier of mortgage funds, is looking for a president.

title: BRITAIN SETTLES ON CZAR'S BONDS
description: Britain and the Soviet Union signed a historic agreement today that settles the account on the Czar's bonds, in default since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917.

title: SENATORS SAY BILL TO PROD PRETORIA HAS WIDE SUPPORT
description: Congressional leaders said today that a strong majority of the Senate was prepared to vote for tough economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S MUSIC DEVELOPS IN PRIME TIME
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S music doesn't follow anyone's game plan, and neither does the frequency of his record releases. Before this year, his most recent album was ''Of Human Feelings'' (Antilles), recorded in 1979, released in 1982 and still very much in the forefront of musical developments. This year has now brought two new albums from Mr. Coleman, first his collaboration with the guitarist Pat Metheny, ''Song X'' (Geffen), and now ''Opening the Caravan of Dreams,'' the first release from the Caravan of Dreams label. (The album can be ordered by mail from Caravan of Dreams Records, P.O. Box 886, Fort Worth, Tex. 76101.) Beginning with Ornette Coleman's earliest recordings, which ushered in ''free jazz'' at the end of the 1950's, his music has articulated a process of constant evolutionary change. But two continuing factors have lent the sometimes vertiginous departures a sense of stability overall. One is Mr. Coleman's personal approach to the alto saxophone, which is firmly rooted in the blues and has changed surprisingly little since his apprenticeship in rhythm-and-blues groups during the 1950's. The other is his continuing efforts to mold attentive, responsive bands and keep them together, with minimal personnel changes, as long as possible.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JUST FOLKS - Folklore, in some respects the entertainment that people who couldn't tune in to anything else for diversion created for themselves and handed down to succeeding generations, has long been the subject of serious scholarly research. The brothers Grimm, for instance, found their tales in their study of language history. But there is no rule that says you can't learn about folklore for the sheer pleasure of it.

title: F. Stanton Deland Jr. Is Dead; Lawyer and Harvard Overseer
description: F. Stanton Deland Jr., a Boston lawyer and former president of Harvard's Board of Overseers, the university's governing body, died of cancer Monday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: The Deficit Gimmick Rides Again
description: The dreamers who imagine that the Federal deficit can be restrained with bureaucratic gimmicks are dreaming again. Though the Supreme Court has struck down a key feature of last year's balanced-budget law and the law, in its short life, already caused all kinds of fiscal contortions, its sponsors in Congress and the White House offer more schemes to fix it. How much better if they spent even half the energy on the deficit itself.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on June 30 about the police record of Frank Morales, a 24-year-old inmate at the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., who has been arrested many times on drug charges, incorrectly described his release on June 15, 1983. It was the court - not the Probation Department - that freed Mr. Morales and placed him on interim supervision. The Probation Department, which is required to conduct such supervision of defendants who have been convicted but not yet sentenced, has filed suit to halt the practice.

title: The Dimensions of Yakasone's Triumph
description: The victory of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's Liberal Democratic Party in parliamentary elections last week was a turning point in the history of modern Japan - and potentially a turning point in the history of American-Japanese relations.

title: ARAB-AMERICANS IN ISRAEL: NEW ISSUE
description: The United States Embassy in Israel has complained to the Foreign Ministry here that American citizens of Palestinian origin are being harassed when they arrive at Ben-Gurion International Airport, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: C.I.A., IN GAUGING SOVIET THREAT, DISTANCES ITSELF FROM THE PENTAGON
description: When Representative John Edward Porter was contesting the Pentagon's case for developing new chemical weapons last year, he adopted an unusual tactic.

title: CUOMO 20 TIMES AHEAD OF O'ROURKE IN FUNDS
description: Governor Cuomo, who a few months ago said Republicans were planning to spend $20 million this year in a bid to unseat him, has raised about 20 times as much money as his Republican opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, according to campaign reports filed yesterday.

title: Tragically, Safety Isn't First
description: If New York racing authorities ever impose a minimum standard for the so-called ''safety'' helmets worn by harness drivers, it may well be known as the Haughton rule - in memory of Billy Haughton, whose death yesterday, of head injuries suffered in a spill at Yonkers Raceway on July 5, has focused new attention on helmet design. But it could just as well be known as the Dunckley rule, for David Dunckley, who died May 23 after suffering a head injury at Roosevelt.

title: I.B.M. Account Shift Comes as No Surprise
description: After so many correct rumors and reports, the announcement yesterday by International Business Machines that almost all of its domestic advertising would be handled by two agencies in the JWT Group was anticlimactic even though it involves something like $200 million in billings.

title: Esposito Relishes Top Post
description: On Monday, after a weekend spent trying to keep mum about his new job as general manager of the Rangers, Phil Esposito positioned himself in front of the spotlights assembled in his honor and formally accepted the assignment he had wanted since his retirement from playing five years ago.

title: Praise for the Court's Unpredictability
description: Once again, the Burger Court has confounded its critics. The most recent batch of cases, the last to be decided during the tenure of the retiring Chief Justice, defies ideological classification. On issues ranging from capital punishment to sodomy, press reporting of judicial proceedings to tasteless speech at high school assemblies, racial preferences in employment to the separation of Government powers in the task of budget control, the Court has produced a mosaic of decisions that no one could have predicted. Perhaps that is as it should be, a fitting valedictory for an era in which the Supreme Court managed to please neither the left nor the right, neither the politicians nor the academy.

In the past, some of those works have been fumbling efforts. However, those offered Monday night at Reynolds Industries Theater on the campus of Duke University were stimulating and suggested that this year's project, directed by Linda Tarnay and Carman Moore, was a real success.

title: Steven Olah of Justice Dept.; Led Inquiry Into Teamsters
description: Steven R. Olah, a Justice Department official who led the Cleveland investigation of Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters union, died Sunday. He was 41 years old.

title: Cardinals Keep Mitchell
description: Stump Mitchell, the running back who said on Monday that he was on the verge of jumping to the Arizona Outlaws, decided to stay in St. Louis. According to Mitchell, he signed a new contract with the Cardinals at Lambert-St. Louis Airport early yesterday morning after flying back from Phoenix with his agent, Harold Lewis, who had called the Cardinals just before Mitchell was about to sign with the Outlaws.

title: 5 PEOPLE INJURED, ONE CRITICALLY, IN COLLAPSE OF CEILING AT THEATER
description: Five people were injured last night, one critically, when part of the ceiling collapsed at the Murray Hill Theater in midtown Manhattan during the final scenes of the film, ''Psycho III,'' the police said.

title: Auto Sales Rise 8.9%
description: Sales of new American made automobiles increased 8.9 percent in the first 10 days of July compared with the corresponding period in 1985, the seven major manufacturers reported today. Analysts attributed the gain to the new round of low-interest sales incentives offered by many of the domestic car makers.

title: Rehnquist at the Wheel
description: Speaking of the High Court, when Justice William H. Rehnquist comes up for confirmation hearings as Chief Justice of the United States next week, the Senate Judiciary Committee should be aware that he has been on the wrong side of the law at least once. In August 1977, Justice Rehnquist was given a speeding ticket by a state trooper in Richmond, Vt., after his vehicle had been clocked at 66 m.p.h. on Interstate 89.

title: RESTAURATEUR'S PARTY RECALLS HIS FLIGHT TO FREEDOM IN 1946
description: MORE than a dozen of New York's finest chefs and restaurateurs pooled their talents in an unusual tribute last night to one of their own.

title: PRODUCTION DOWN 0.5% LAST MONTH
description: Production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the fourth decline in the last five months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Backer Gets Campbell
description: It is understood that the management of Backer & Spielvogel notified its staff yesterday that it had been named to handle Campbell Soup's dry soups in addition to the wet ones it already makes ads for.

title: HOSPITAL OCCUPANCY DROPS TO 20-YEAR LOW IN CITY
description: Hospitals in New York City have hit a 20-year low in occupancy, in large part because of a sharp decline in hospitalization that promises to continue, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Deliberations Continue In Texas Drifter's Death
description: Jurors deliberated for a second day today in the case of three men accused of conspiring to kidnap and kill a drifter. who prosecutors say was enslaved and tortured to death with a cattle prod on an isolated ranch.

title: BUSH MAY VISIT SYRIA TO SPUR PEACE TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration may send Vice President Bush to Syria to make a new overture to improve relations in the hope of reviving the Middle East peace process, White House officials said today.

title: Soccer Account

title: COHN'S ACTIONS ARE FOCUS OF TRIAL IN MANHATTAN
description: Lawyers for Lillian Goldman, the wife of the multimillionaire developer Sol Goldman, asserted yesterday that she had been ''swindled'' out of her fair share of Mr. Goldman's fortune in 1984 because her lawyer at the time, Roy M. Cohn, ''conspired'' to protect her husband's money.

title: U.S. SAYS PRETORIA WAS TOLD OF A BLACK NOMINEE

title: BALLET EDDY TOUSSAINT
description: THIS is a rare evening for dance on television, what with ''Wolf Trap Presents the Kirov: 'Swan Lake' '' being broadcast on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock and a look at the Ballet Eddy Toussaint at 10 o'clock on the Bravo cable network. Unlike the world-renowned Kirov, the Toussaint company is new to most American dance fans. That is too bad, for the Montreal-based dance company is an engaging one, with attractive and well-trained young dancers and a repertory of fresh and inventive dances by Mr. Toussaint. Now there is a chance to see the company and its work in an hourlong program called ''Ballet Eddy Toussaint.'' Filmed in 1985 for the Canadian Broadcasting Company, the program offers a representative look at the company in an enjoyable hour of dance that ought to be of interest to both aficionados and those who like their dance uncomplicated and pretty.

title: EX-EMPLOYEES AT L.I. DUMP INDICTED IN BRIBE PLOT

title: DIET GAME, WHERE CHANCES OF WINNING ARE SLIM

According to a report in the July 4 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, some people gain weight more easily than others - and have more trouble taking it off.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,678,000 for the latest quarter,$8,395,000 for the year-ago quarter and $14,790,000 for the year-ago 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $89,474,000 which included a net gain of $78.9 million resulting from the exchange of 3.5 million common shares of Union Carbide Corp. under Carbide's January exchange offer and a tax loss carryforward of $10.6 million. Share earnings for all periods are on a fully diluted basis and reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 8.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ECONOMIST CALLS N.F.L. NOT LIABLE
description: An economist called as an expert witness by the National Football League testified in Federal District Court yesterday that the United States Football League is entitled to ''negative damages'' - which is to say, no damages - in its antitrust case against the N.F.L.

title: Shamrock Trims Stake In Foote, Cone
description: There must have been a loud sigh of relief at Foote, Cone & Belding Communications' corporate headquarters in Chicago as word came from Washington that Shamrock Holdings, from which they felt a takeover threat, had indeed cut its holdings in the company to 7.2 percent, from 9.9 percent.

title: NICARAGUAN POLITICIAN SEEKS ASYLUM IN EMBASSY
description: A member of the National Assembly sought asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy today, diplomats reported.

title: LORIMAR TO BUY 2 TV STATIONS
description: Lorimar-Telepictures has agreed to acquire two independent television stations, WPGH-TV in Pittsburgh and WTTV-TV in Indianapolis.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share figures are fully diluted. The results reflect Midlantic's acquisition of Heritage Bancorp on May 1, 1985.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Banned Bass Stand-Ins - The ban on striped bass in New York - which began May 6 because of PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, in the Hudson River spawning grounds, as well as for conservation purposes - has created a problem for cooks. Cookbooks are filled with excellent recipes for this meaty, white-fleshed fish. Are there any acceptable substitutes? That question was recently posed to a number of chefs and cookbook authors.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Abrams Suing to Stop Beer Franchise System
description: The New York Attorney General charged yesterday that four of the nation's largest brewing companies and four of their franchised distributors are participants in a territorially restrictive distribution system that violates Federal and state antitrust laws.

title: Which Offshore Oil Is Off-Limits?
description: There may be enough oil off the coast of California to supply a tenth of America's needs for the rest of the century. Is drilling for it worth the risk?

title: Eurobond Data System
description: Dealers in the Eurobond market are moving to adopt a centralized information system to provide traders with immediate data on prices and trades of outstanding bonds.

title: U.S. CHOICE OF ENVOY PART OF REAGAN TACTIC
description: Reagan Administration officials acknowledged today that a tentative decision to name a black businessman as the next Ambassador to South Africa was part of an effort to buy time in the face of increasing Congressional pressure to impose severe economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: IN PARIS, HEAPING HELPINGS OF AMERICANA
description: Late one recent afternoon on the Left Bank of Paris, a soignee young Frenchwoman raced past crowded charcuteries and patisseries, where her neighbors were shopping for dinner, and darted into one of the newest food shops in the Seventh Arrondissement, the General Store. Her mission? Fixings for tacos to feed 24.

title: TRACTORS BACK DEUTZ SECURITIES
description: The Deutz-Allis Credit Corporation earlier this week announced the sale of $117.7 million of asset-backed securities with a coupon of 7.8 percent.

title: The Friendly Gourmet
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 'HUBBELLITO' MATCHES HUBBELL
description: As a Mexican left-hander with a screwball, Fernando Valenzuela is also known as ''Carl Hubbellito,'' a reference to the New York Giants' left-hander who popularized the screwball half a century ago. And last night the Los Angeles Dodgers' ace matched the most revered record in All-Star Game history - King Carl's five consecutive strikeouts in the 1934 game at the Polo Grounds.

title: LONDON TRIAL SET IN PLOT ON EL AL
description: A Jordanian who the prosecution says was working for Syria was ordered today to stand trial on charges of trying to blow up an Israeli airliner.

title: WITNESS ASSERTS CO-TRUSTEE USED MAYTAG'S FUNDS
description: John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, used investment partnership funds of Ann L. Maytag to attend two out-of-state seminars on handgun use, a witness testified yesterday at Mr. McLaughlin's bribery and theft trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: LITTON UNIT TO PAY $15 MILLION TO U.S.
description: The military contracting arm of Litton Industries agreed to plead guilty today to 325 counts of fraud for overbilling the Defense Department by $6.3 million, the largest case of false billing against a military contractor.

title: 3 Railroads Rehire 1,700 Under a Court Order
description: About 1,700 employees at three railroads owned by Guilford Transportation Industries Inc. returned to work today, nearly two months after their jobs were abolished after a bitter strike.

title: PUBLISHING: SALES PUSH FALLS SHORT
description: Despite Victor Kiam's attempt to make his book ''Going for It!'' a best seller by spending about $1 million of his own money on promotion, three months after its publication the book has failed to make it onto the best-seller list.

title: GTE Up 8.4% In Quarter
description: The GTE Corporation, citing growth in nearly all its businesses, yesterday reported an 8.4 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter, to $309 million, or $1.38 a share, from $285 million, or $1.33 a share.

title: Sealing In the Flavors
description: DINNER guests at my home are often served fish cooked en papillote because the ingredients can be prepared beforehand and kept cool until it's time to pop the packages into the oven. This method of preparing seafood, chicken, vegetables and the like in bakers' parchment yields a light and attractive dish.

title: The U.N. Today; July 16, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 3 P.M.

title: DETROIT HIT BY STRIKE OF 7,000 CITY EMPLOYEES
description: Eighteen union locals representing 7,000 city workers went on strike just after midnight today after negotiators for the union and the nation's sixth-largest city failed to reach a contract agreement.

title: Market Place; I.B.M.'s Stock Losing Luster
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation, once considered the darling of institutional investors, has lost some more of its luster. The latest shock for shareholders was Monday's announcement of a 7.7 percent drop in second-quarter profits by the computer and data processing giant.

title: July 4 Accounts To Take Months
description: A spokesman for the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation said yesterday that it might ''take several months'' before the final accounts for Liberty Weekend were tallied.

title: South Yemen-Kuwait Talks
description: President Haider Abubaker al-Attas of Southern Yemen left for home today after a visit to Kuwait. The trip was seen by diplomats as crucial to his country's efforts to revive good relations with countries in the Persian Gulf region.

title: REFEREE STOPS BOUT, AND U.S. PROTESTS
description: The United States boxing team formally protested the disqualification of Harvey Richards, a light heavyweight, by a Soviet referee at the Goodwill Games today. In other action, the Soviet Union swept the gold medals in the men's individual gymnastics events.

title: U.S. INQUIRY ON DALLAS AIR CRASH BRINGS PROPOSALS ON PILOT TRAINING
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today cited the crew, inadequate training and a lack of promptly radioed wind-shift warnings as the ''probable causes'' of the crash of a Delta Airlines jumbo jet in Dallas last August.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ACCUSED, A 2D REPUBLICAN LEAVES MASSACHUSETTS RACE
description: Gregory S. Hyatt, a Republican candidate for Governor, announced today that he would drop out of the race, following charges that he had accepted money from a reputed organized crime figure.

title: A Token Amnesty
description: About those all-brass tokens that lost all value on June 15 and now gather dust on top of your bureau or collect lint in the pockets of the suit you haven't cleaned lately.

title: Free 'Taming of Shrew' Set for Riverside Park
description: Free outdoor performances of Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew'' will be presented by the Watery Star Theater beginning July 30 at 8 P.M. at the Rotunda Pavilion in Riverside Park, West 79th Street and the Hudson River.

title: Linebacker's Demands
description: Unless he can get a $175,000 raise or be traded to the Los Angeles Rams, Chip Banks, a Cleveland Browns linebacker, says he will sit out the 1986 season. In an interview published in a Browns newsletter, Banks said that besides wanting a $500,000 salary or the trade he would also like a guarantee against being replaced in third-down situations.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $41 million pre-tax charge, or $21.2 million after tax, from the cost of reducing operations and implementing productivity improvement programs at the Great Northern paper division in Maine. c-Net income The company said in the latest quarter, Great Northern Nekoosa adopted FASB 87 effective Jan. 1, increasing the year 1986's pre-tax income by $17.9 million, of which $4.5 million is included in the second quarter after tax. The company said the change to FASB 87 effective Jan. 1, which was adopted in the latest second quarter, increased pre-tax income for the latest 6 months by $9 million, or 18 cents a share, after taxes.

title: Sidelined by Studies
description: Because he scored 600 on his Scholastic Aptitude Test in May, 100 points below the new National Collegiate Athletic Association guidelines, Earl Duncan will not be able to play for Syracuse as a freshman. The 6-foot-3-inch Duncan averaged 26.4 points as a senior at Santa Monica (Calif.) Catholic High School.

title: Hotel Fire in Taiwan Kills 7
description: A fire started in a basement restaurant today and spread through the first three floors of the Hotel Royal in the southern city of Kaohsiung, killing seven people and injuring eight, a fire official reported. Thirty-eight guests were rescued from the blaze, which lasted an hour, according to the official. All of the injured were tourists from Hong Kong.

title: ASTRONAUT'S FAMILY SEEKS $15 MILLION FROM NASA
description: The family of Michael J. Smith, the Navy commander who piloted the shuttle Challenger on its catastrophic final mission, has filed a $15 million negligence claim against the space agency and a key employee.

title: 'UNPAID' KOCH ADVISOR GETTING $5,000 A MONTH
description: A close friend of Mayor Koch who has been an unpaid adviser since Mr. Koch took office in 1978 is receiving $5,000 a month from the Koch re-election campaign organization, according to the Mayor's campaign statements.

title: HOUSE CHOICES DELAYED
description: Eleven senators, most of them solid advocates of tax revision legislation, were designated today to sit on the conference with the House of Representatives on the tax bill.

title: Mad for Gooseberries
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CROPS AND WEED SHRIVEL IN FIELDS
description: Crops and weeds alike shriveled and died in the heat-struck South yesterday, and the worst Southern drought on record led at least one city, Chapel Hill, N.C., to order its residents to curtail their showers.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY'S ACTUARY FOR 5 PENSIONS QUITS ABRUPTLY
description: One of the most highly regarded civil servants in the city, the chief actuary of all five municipal pension funds, resigned yesterday with the admission that he had given ''untruthful testimony'' in a court deposition.

title: Ex-Drug Addict Warns Panel of Cocaine Peril
description: A man who helped prepare and sell a cheap but lethal form of cocaine told a Senate subcommittee today of his own $400-a-day habit and urged the Government to take strict measures to curb drug dealers.

title: Sarney at the Willard
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil is coming to Washington for a state visit in early September, and he has already reserved a suite at the Willard Inter-Continental Hotel, which won't even be officially open when he arrives. President Sarney is scheduled to check in Sept. 7, and the restored hostelry on Pennsylvania Avenue will not formally open until Sept. 22. The manager, J. T. Kuhlman, reports, however, that there will be a ''soft opening'' without special observance in mid-August, when the hotel will begin accepting guests, serving meals and drinks and renewing the tradition of Washington lodging houses that have occupied the same site since 1816.

title: Judge Rejects Moffett's Suit To Annul Waterbury Primary
description: With the Democratic State Convention just three days away, a State Superior Court judge today dismissed Toby Moffett's lawsuit to overturn a disputed local primary election here.

title: REV. ROBERT K. RUDOLPH
description: The Rev. Robert Knight Rudolph, professor emeritus of systematic theology and christian ethics at the Theological Seminary of the Reformed Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, died of cancer Monday at the Quarryville (Pa.) Presbyterian Home, where he lived.

title: Economic Scene; Need to Mesh World Policies
description: EVERY sharp break in the stock market following a long boom causes a host of investors to ask, ''Can it happen again?'' Nobody has to be told that the ''it'' refers to the Crash of 1929 and the Great Depression of the 1930's.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
F.T.C. Challenges Coke
description: The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today challenging Coca-Cola's proposed takeover of the Dr Pepper Company, saying the acquisition would reduce competition in soft drinks in the United States. The F.T.C. voted, 4 to 1, with one absence.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $6.4 million. c-Includes a tax credit of $24.8 million and a loss of $2.5 million from discontinued operations for quarter, and a tax credit of $42.3 million and a loss of $3.3 million from discontinued operations for 6 months.

title: Missing Buses, Pointing Fingers
description: The bus stops here, the shelters stop there and the buck does not seem to be stopping anywhere at all.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oil Drop Gives Dekalb a Loss
description: The Dekalb Corporation today reported a loss of $51.2 million in the fiscal third quarter, ended May 31, in contrast to a profit of $5.5 million, or 45 cents a share, a year earlier. The oil and gas exploration and farm seed company, based in De Kalb, Ill., said the loss reflected a $49.1 million write-down of its energy-related assets.

title: PARENTS TURN TO COURSES ON PARENTHOOD
description: ''THE job of parent is one of the few things we expect people to be good at without having any training,'' said Hannah Nuba-Scheffler, watching as 10 parents and 14 children gathered recently at the Early Childhood Resource and Information Center in Manhattan. ''It has become more and more acceptable for parents to admit that they don't always know what to do, or how to do it. And they feel they can come here and seek help.''

title: A Dilemma Fashioned for James Levine
description: To the Editor:

title: McGraw-Hill, Time Gain
description: Two of the nation's largest publishing companies - Time Inc. and McGraw-Hill Inc. -reported improved earnings today for the second quarter.

title: Dept. of Reversals
description: In June and July, when the Supreme Court is producing new legal interpretations every few days, lawyers at the Department of Justice have to be fast on their feet. Sometimes they find themselves gracefully executing abrupt reversals of position that would make the most agile politician envious.

title: Oil Contracts Rebound From Monday's Lows
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products rebounded yesterday from Monday's fall to the lowest levels in years. Crude oil contracts regained up to $1 a barrel on the futures and open markets, and petroleum products gained about 2 cents a gallon.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ROBERT C. RANSOM
description: Robert C. Ransom, a member of the corporate legal staff of the International Business Machines Corporation, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Williston, Vt. He was 66 years old.

title: Advertising; Designing Publications
description: YEARS of television watching have made people more visually oriented, according to Walter Bernard.

title: FEDERAL PANEL URGES U.S. ORGAN NETWORK AND TRANSPLANT AID
description: A Federal advisory committtee today prodded the Reagan Administration to set up a national network to arrange for the transplanting of human organs, and said all people who need such transplants should receive them ''regardless of their ability to pay.''

title: Beacon Theater To Be Nightclub
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted 6-0 yesterday to allow conversion of the Beacon Theater into a nightclub.

title: Push Is Coming To Shove for Iacocca
description: The 1988 Presidential sweepstakes began in 1985, so it should not be surprising that in the summer of 1986 the search for a fresh face is already under way.

title: MUSIC: JEAN-PIERRE RAMPAL
description: EVEN if the playing had been first class, which it was not, Monday night's slice of ''Mostly Mozart'' at Avery Fisher Hall would have had a lot going against it.

title: Amity Chef, 5-2, Is Co-favorite
description: Amity Chef and Sherman Almahurst, the early favorites at 5-2, drew the fifth and seventh post positions, respectively, for the $1,025,000 Meadowlands Pace Friday.

title: 'Functional Immunity'
description: What does it mean to have ''functional immunity'' rather than full diplomatic immunity in Washington?

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect the 5-for- 3 stock split approved by the shareholders on April 15, effective April 25.

title: UNREAL ACE DEALS IN REALITY
description: The count was no balls and two strikes, and Dwight Gooden was not trying for a strikeout.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANK SALE HOLDS RISK FOR F.D.I.C.
description: The travails of one of Oklahoma's biggest banks, which collapsed Monday and reopened today under new ownership, could cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Ernst de Flines, David Welch and Richard Johnson have been elected board members at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, New York.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in May.

title: A SIX-YEAR STRUGGLE FOR BANK
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's announcement yesterday of a stunning $640 million second-quarter loss was another blow to Samuel H. Armacost, who has fought an uphill battle during the six years he has been president and chief executive of the company.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LITTON BARRED FROM MILITARY BIDDING
description: The Defense Department suspended Litton Industries today from bidding for Government contracts, following a subsidiary's indictment Tuesday on 325 counts of criminal fraud.

title: Judge Faces Action by House
description: The House of Representatives is expected to begin impeachment proceedings next week against Judge Harry E. Claiborne, the first Federal judge to face impeachment in a half century, a key Democrat said today.

title: HIGH HOPES FOR GLOBAL BALLOON FLIGHT
description: Aviation enthusiasts crowded into the New York Explorers Club yesterday to witness the christening of the balloon Endeavor, whose British pilot hopes to make the first nonstop, round-the-world balloon flight next year.

title: MODEL RAILROADING, ROMANTICS' HOBBY
description: THE model railroader is many things: engineer, electrician, artist and stage designer, historian and, by and large, a bit of a romantic.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represents total income.

title: FIRST MICHIGAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $663,000, or 44 cents per share, for the quarter and $999,000, or 78 cents per share, for the 6 months from deferred income tax benefits.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Net Doubles At Grace
description: W. R. Grace & Company, benefitting from a one-time gain of $83 million from the sale of its interest in the Herman's sporting goods stores, and several home center and hardware stores, reported yesterday that net income had more than doubled.

title: Advertising; DFS Dorland Names A Top Creative Director
description: DFS Dorland/New York has named Clifford Freeman, 43 years old, as its new executive creative director, replacing John M. Keil, 63, who becomes director of creative development. Mr. Keil, however, will continue to take bites out of crime as the voice of Officer McGruff in the public service campaign. Stanley Becker and Eric Weber continue on as the other two executive creative directors.

title: Nehemiah an Amateur
description: On the basis of a written statement that he would ''forgo further pecuniary reward or compensation in the sport of football,'' Renaldo Nehemiah, the world-record holder at 12.93 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles, was reinstated as an amateur by the International Amateur Athletic Federation yesterday. Several previous attempts to regain his amateur status had been turned down by the federation.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect acquisition of State National Bank of Maryland.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Furniture Co., Martinsville, Va., said its board had unanimously approved in principle an offer by Ladd Furniture Inc. to buy all of American's 2.5 million outstanding common shares for $16 each.

title: Reliance Capital
description: The Federal Communications Commission rejected a request from the Reliance Capital Group to establish a voting trust to simplify its acquisition of John Blair & Company, a diversified media concern based in New York. If the trust had been approved, Reliance would have been able to operate Blair while the F.C.C. formally reviewed the transfer of Blair's broadcasting licenses. The F.C.C. also ruled that Reliance did not violate any commission statutes by accepting about 10.5 million Blair common shares.

title: The Golden Goose
description: Boston is one of the country's great urban success stories.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain on disposal of $251,000 for the quarter and a loss on disposal of $1,839,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month period also includes a loss of $1,095,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes losses of $89,000 and $975,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net income

title: WEATHER VANES: 'MONEY ON THE ROOF'
description: The police in New England are searching for the Yellow Station Wagon Ring and other thieves who have been scaling the roofs of homes and barns to steal antique weather vanes that command high prices as folk art.

title: President Is Chosen By Marine Midland
description: The Marine Midland Banks Inc. announced yesterday that it had named Geoffrey A. Thompson president and chief operating officer, effective at the end of the year.

title: House to Vote Today On '86 Spending Cuts
description: The House of Representlatives today cleared the way for a vote Thursday on legislation to reaffirm the $11.7 billion in 1986 spending cuts made in March under the budget-balancing law.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $18,237,000 and $53,492,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $75,139,000 and an extraordinary net of $11 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss The company said preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter.

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Excludes a $553,000 loss from discontinuing a plant.

title: 700 MIGHT HAVE GOT AIDS VIRUS IN TRANSFUSIONS, BLOOD BANK SAYS
description: The blood bank that serves the New York metropolitan area said yesterday that it was working to identify about 700 people who received transfusions since 1977 that may have been contaminated with the AIDS virus.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $39,000,000 for the quarter and $54,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $32,000,000 and $44,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FICTIONS AND FACTS ON KENNEDY WEDDING
description: THE invitation reads: ''Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis requests the honor of your presence at the marriage of her daughter, Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, to Edwin Arthur Schlossberg on July 19, 1986, at 3 P.M., the Church of Our Lady of Victory, Centerville, Massachusetts.''

title: Net Increases At Rockwell
description: The Rockwell International Corporation today reported earnings of $163.3 million, or $1.10 a share, for the fiscal third quarter, ended June 30.

title: CHILEAN JUNTA MEMBER CALLS FOR 'FULL DEMOCRACY' IN '89
description: A member of the ruling military junta today repeated his announced intention to retire in three years, further eroding support for Gen. Augusto Pinochet to continue ruling past 1989.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEMOND CUTS HINAULT'S LEAD
description: Greg LeMond easily won a demanding climb through the Pyrenees today and moved to 40 seconds of Bernard Hinault, the overall leader who had tried to make the Tour de France race a rout.

title: YOUTH CHARGED IN PARK ATTACK TAKEN TO LINEUP
description: The youth charged with shooting a police officer in Central Park last Saturday appeared in a police lineup yesterday and was in court for a brief hearing held to announce the appointment of a defense lawyer.

title: FINANCIAL NEWS NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $804,036 for both the latest quarter and 9 months, and $47,747 for the year-ago 9-month period.

title: NATIONAL COMMERCE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Killed in Light Plane
description: A twin-engine Cessna 441 plane carrying six people crashed today near Lake Michigan, killing three aboard, the authorities said. The three others were injured seriously and taken to hospitals, according to a dispatcher for Pro-Med Ambulance in Muskegon.

title: ELECTROMAGNETIC SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 23.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Venereal Disease Germ Is Tied to Pneumonia
description: Chlamydia germs, the nation's leading source of venereal disease, are also one of the most common causes of pneumonia and other respiratory infections, scientists say.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a pretax loss provision of $40,339,000 for consolidation of certain operations for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: FLOCK RETURNS ANEW TO EAST HARLEM MADONNA
description: Outside the Roman Catholic church on East 116th Street, so much has changed. Gone are Ferraro's Bakery and Rosie's Candy Store. Gone are Dr. Miraglia the optometrist and Dr. Spinelli the urologist. Gone, in other words, is all but the shrunken shell of the Italian-American community that once flourished in East Harlem.

title: Yen Shift Lifts Japan's Wages
description: The strong yen has pushed Japanese wages to the top of the world table, wiping out the competitive advantage of low wages, industry analysts said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because photographs were transposed, a caption in the Advertising Column in some copies yesterday misidentified the two partners in the design firm W.B.M.G. Inc. Milton Glaser was pictured on the right and Walter Bernard on the left.

title: GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $82,965,000 for the latest quarter and $7,648,000 for year-ago period. c-Includes net from discontinued retail operations and a gain from their disposal of $82,965,000 for the latest 6 months and $37,174,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy's Burger War Spoof
description: NEW York TV viewers are blessed with the opportunity of being onlookers at one of the great conflicts of our time, the war involving the big three hamburger chains.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,492,000 for the quarter and $4,031,000 for the 6 months.

title: LUCILLE WALL
description: Lucille Wall, who brought the trials and tribulations of Portia Blake to millions of radio soap-opera fans, died last Friday at a convalescent home here. She was 87 years old.

title: F.B.I. MOVING ON BLASTS LAID TO JEWISH EXTREMISTS
description: Defending the Federal Bureau of Investigation's handling of a series of unsolved bombings attributed to Jewish extremists, a senior bureau official said today that Federal agents had identified specific suspects.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH I.B.M.?
description: Not that long ago, the computer experts were warning that if anything was going to slow the growth of I.B.M., it would be the aggressive electronics giants of Japan. Robert Sobel, a business historian, even entitled his latest book ''I.B.M. vs. Japan: The Struggle for the Future.'' Indeed, the International Business Machines Corporation has its hands full these days. But its problems have precious little to do with the Japanese - who are still floundering in their efforts to enter the American computer market - and a lot to do with problems at home that few predicted.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Lucky Stores Inc., Dublin, Calif., named Edgar H. Grubb senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: People in the Streets Who Should Be in Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Terror in Many Stripes
description: Terrorist attacks have broken out again in Europe. As Washington notes with a hint of smugness, there hasn't been evidence of Middle East-inspired terrorism since the April 15 American raid on Libya, but the idea of terror as a political weapon has proven itself alive with a series of new deaths.

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses of $5.9 million and $7.9 million from discontinued operations for the latest and year-ago 6 months periods, respectively. c-Includes net income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1.

title: D.H. Blair Weighs Offering Shares
description: D. H. Blair & Company, a privately owned investment banking firm, said yesterday that it was considering selling shares to the public to raise capital for expansion. Blair added that it already had more than $100 million in capital, mostly in cash. J. Morton Davis, chairman and owner of the 82-year-old firm, said that he was thinking of selling about 20 percent of the firm's stock for about $40 million. Mr. Davis, who is 57 years old, forecast that Blair would earn $25 million this year.

title: Justice Dept. Official Named

Mr. Trott, who has been an Assistant Attorney General since 1983 and was United States Attorney in Los Angeles from 1981 to 1983, is a former singer with the folk group ''The Highwaymen.'' The White House, in announcing the nomination, said, ''The folk group was known for their Gold Record hits 'Michael Row the Boat Ashore' and 'Cotton Fields.' '' He was a member of the folk group before he entered Harvard Law School.

title: HERS
description: I'VE been thinking a little about women, or one woman, me, and women's alleged propensity to do for others things they can't, won't or don't do for themselves.

title: A Former Premier Going on Trial in Turkey
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit will go on trial Thursday on charges of violating a law barring him from political activity, Turkish news agencies reported today.

title: The World Bank's Dramatic Year
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: 'CRIME AND PUNISHMENT'
description: Andrzej Wajda's version of ''The Possessed,'' presented in 1974 (in English) at the Yale Repertory Theater, was an excavation to the heart of the Dostoyevsky novel. His dramatization of ''Crime and Punishment'' (performed in Polish) at the Pepsico Summerfare excavates to the heart of the author's argument. This is not a complete view of ''Crime and Punishment.'' It is, rather, a point of view, focusing close up on the three most crucial characters, Raskolnikov, who murders a pawnbroker and her sister; Porfiry, the investigator, and Sonia, the prostitute who acts as Raskolnikov's late-rising conscience. The center of the play is a cat-and-mouse cross-examination.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 17, 1986
description: International The U.S. is weighing a new arms plan that calls for simultaneously reducing both the number of underground nuclear tests by the United States and the Soviet Union and the number of strategic weapons on each side. The idea of the linkage is contained in a draft of a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that the State Department has asked President Reagan to sign. [ Page A1, Col. 6. ]

title: Comings and Goings
description: ''This doesn't mean that we don't want World,'' said General Manager Wayne Embry after the Cleveland Cavaliers failed to sign World B. Free to the option year of his contract by midnight Tuesday, making the veteran guard one of six Cavalier free agents. ''We still have an open mind toward him and the lines of communication are very much open.''

title: Browns Sign Ray
description: The Cleveland Browns have signed Darrol Ray, a five-year starter at safety for the Jets before injuring his shoulder during the exhibition season last year and being released last Oct. 23.

title: U.S. TO TEST FOR TIE BETWEEN AIDS AND SWINE FEVER
description: Federal medical researchers said today that they were preparing to test the blood of AIDS patients for the presence of African swine fever in an effort to prove or disprove a disputed theory that the lethal disease in humans is somehow related to the swine virus.

description: Saudi Arabia, the biggest oil producer in the Middle East, is raising the ante in its high-risk strategy to force coordinated production cuts on other major petroleum exporters, oil analysts said today.

description: Two Texas ranchers and one of their workers were convicted today of criminal conspiracy to commit aggravated kidnapping in the torture and death of a worker on their ranch.

description: Brooklyn lost the National League years ago but gained the Ivy League yesterday - if just for a few hours and only for Japanese television viewers.

description: Brian K. Sherwood, executive vice president and director of marketing for the New York advertising agency Geer, DuBois, died of a heart attack Tuesday evening while running in a race in Central Park. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan and Yulan, N.Y.

CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a state prosecutor's announcement that Judge Vito J. Titone of the State Court of Appeals had been cleared of bribery allegations incorrectly described, because of an omitted word, a transaction between the judge and the lawyer who made the accusations. A paragraph giving Judge Titone's account should have said that the lawyer had helped the judge obtain some kitchen appliances at wholesale costs, that the judge paid either the lawyer or the distributor for them and that there was no connection between the transaction and the judge's decision in a case pending before him.

description: Herbert and Charles Allen Jr., brothers who are among the most successful financiers in New York, have given Presbyterian Hospital $15 million that will assure completion of a 300-bed hospital at the northern tip of Manhattan.

description: The Natal Province Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a militant labor union to have South Africa's newest emergency decree overturned as unlawful, but softened some of the restrictions so that detainees may now have access to lawyers.

title: Teed-Off Golfers
description: Golf is, of course, a gentleman's game, but gentlemen will sometimes be boys.

title: FURTIVE LOOK AT SOVIET ROCK PIANIST
description: SERGEI KURYOKHIN, an underground Soviet pianist and composer, displays his impish grin, his philosophical bent and a little of his music in the ''Frontline'' program ''Comrades: All That Jazz,'' tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13. The program has an extra underground connection; it was made for the BBC with a home video camera, without Soviet permission. In tonight's version, the American reporter Judy Woodruff talks with experts on Soviet jazz and rock after the BBC program.

title: Daisy Systems Officer Quits Executive Panel
description: Last year the Daisy Systems Corporation announced a three-member executive committee to ''navigate Daisy through its next phase of growth.'' But yesterday, with the resignation of one of the company's founders as executive vice president, the committee was down to two members.

description: Edward del Pino, the retired police officer who captured Juan J. Gonzalez, the man accused of killing two Staten Island ferryboat passengers and wounding nine others July 7, will receive a $1,000 award from the Kansas Bankers Association. The award is to be presented tomorrow at Bayley Seaton Hospital on Staten Island by the president of the bankers' group, Richard Nichols, who was one of those wounded in the attack. He is recovering at the hospital.

description: The pressure to cut the Federal deficit, some legislative leaders said today, is pushing Congress toward delegating even more power to the President than the original budget-balancing law did.

description: On March 7 President Reagan asked Philip C. Habib, the veteran diplomatic troubleshooter, to become his special envoy for Central America, to demonstrate in Mr. Reagan's words, ''that there can be a diplomatic solution'' for that region.

title: SOME TOP POP SINGERS IN SPECIALS

Gladys Knight, Patti LaBelle and Dionne Warwick are in Home Box Office's ''Sisters in the Name of Love,'' which had its debut earlier this week and can next be seen tomorrow afternoon at 5. And Aretha Franklin gets a Showtime special all to herself, not counting a 24-piece orchestra, a 65-member church choir and a brief appearance by Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist. ''Aretha!'' has its premiere tomorrow evening at 10.

O'Neill for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, today named Richard Sontag, a retired Stamford banker, as his running mate for lieutenant governor. The State Democratic Convention will convene Friday night to endorse candidates for statewide office. Mr. O'Neill is backing the renomination of the incumbent Lieutenant Governor, Joseph J. Fauliso.

description: b-Includes capitalization of $105,000 of software development costs in accordance with FAS 86.

title: DO COSTS COME FIRST - OR DO PATIENTS?
description: In Britain, France, Italy and Greece, Europeans are now accustomed to the idea that doctors will go out on strike when faced with intolerable conditions. Now we in North America are beginning to learn the lesson that patients, too, suffer when doctors are driven to desperation by misguided efforts at economy that interfere with health care.

title: FRENCH VOTE DUE ON SALE BY STATE
description: France's conservative Government moved today to defuse an impending crisis with the country's Socialist President over its plan to sell 65 state-owned companies and banks to private investors.

title: 2 TV CHIEFS RECALL NO N.F.L. PRESSURES
description: On the 40th day of the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League, two more television executives testified that the N.F.L. did not exert any pressure on them to influence their relationship with the U.S.F.L.

title: BOYD IS INVOLVED IN A NEW INCIDENT
description: The Boston Red Sox announced today that they were continuing indefinitely their suspension of Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd after the pitcher reportedly threatened two policemen by saying he had a gun and was going to shoot them.

title: Iraq Tightens Budget To Meet War Needs
description: Public and private spending will be slashed to concentrate resources on winning the economically ruinous war with Iran that has dragged on for six and one half years, President Saddam Hussein said today.

title: G.A.O. SAYS 2 MISSILE DEFENSE PROJECTS WERE CUT TO MEET DEADLINE
description: The cost of a major experiment in the program to seek a defense against nuclear missiles was underestimated by 20 percent, the General Accounting Office said today. As a result, an important element of the experiment had to be eliminated.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FESTA - The generally low-roofed Greenwich Village landscape is punctuated majestically at Carmine and Bleecker Streets, near Avenue of the Americas, by the tower-topped Church of Our Lady of Pompeii, built in 1926 when the congregation's nearby church was torn down to make way for the IND subway on Sixth Avenue. From today through July 27, the church will be even more of a cynosure than usual by virtue of its 14th Festa Italiana that will occupy Carmine Street all the way to Seventh Avenue South.

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALL-STAR GAME A SPECIAL OCCASION
description: The game has seldom been more than an exhibition and an interruption, a pause between pennant races and baseball's grueling dog days of summer. But Tuesday night's All-Star Game at the Astrodome seemed to inject life into a tired and predictable series, making it the special occasion is was meant to be.

title: Robertshaw Seeks Buyer for Company
description: The Robertshaw Controls Company, which makes residential and commercial thermostats and other electrical products for the home and car, said yesterday that it would seek a buyer for the company, reportedly at the insistence of its largest shareholder, the Reynolds Metals Company.

description: Mark Green, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate from New York, yesterday charged that his opponent owned several million dollars in stock in companies doing business with South Africa and called for him to immediately dispose of the holdings.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,135,938, or 52 cents a share, from the sale of an investment in a multifamily project in Dallas.

description: Having swiped 16 bases (in 22 attempts) already this year, Dave Lopes seems certain to become the most successful geriatric base-stealer in modern major league history.

description: The Army today lifted an order that has kept more than 350 OH-6 helicopters grounded for more than a month.

Each piece is steam bent, kiln dried, hand sanded and finished with a light stain and a low-gloss lacquer. Each comes with heavy brass hardware.

Their game against the Chicago White Sox is the first of 28 games in their next 38 that they play at Yankee Stadium.

title: BIAS BARRED IN PICKING JERSEY JURIES
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that a prosecutor's use of challenges to exclude blacks from a jury violated a defendant's constitutional right to an impartial trial.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LES PECHEURS DE PERLES'
description: THE libretto of Bizet's ''Pecheurs de Perles'' cannot confidently be called the worst in opera history - the competition for that honor is stiff -but it does rank right down there with the most appallingly inept of its kind. The central characters are a virgin priestess and two Ceylonese males who love her but are such close friends that they swear never to let a mere priestess come between them. Bizet's librettists treated this romantic triangle absent-mindedly, and to such hilarious effect that that at times the strongest resemblance is to one of those Marx Brothers movies in which the characters appear to be making it all up as they go along.

title: PRETORIA'S FORCES SAID TO CONDUCT DRIVE IN SOWETO TO END RENT STRIKE
description: South African security forces were reported yesterday to have made a sweep through the black township of Soweto in an attempt to get striking residents to pay their rents.

title: FOR MENTALLY RETARDED ADULTS, CHALLENGES OF DAY-TO-DAY LIFE
description: A 25-YEAR-OLD woman, Tanya Baptiste, sits in a classroom that closely imitates scenes from daily life - a supermarket aisle with plastic fruit and empty cereal boxes, a cash register drawer filled with play money, a rotary-dial telephone - and talks of the day she will master this environment and move on. Voicing the desires of many people in their 20's, Miss Baptiste says: ''I want a job, really, I want a job. I want to clean my own house and cook my own meals.''

title: BOARD MAY CHANGE COMPANY BRINGING CABLE TV TO BRONX
description: The city's Board of Estimate is leaning toward replacing the company selected three years ago to bring cable television to the Bronx and parts of Brooklyn. That could mean a two-year delay before people in those areas can watch cable stations on their sets.

description: Lawrence B. Mulloy, who directed the space shuttle's solid rocket booster program at the time of the Challenger disaster, announced today that he would retire from the space agency at the end of the week.

title: TITANIC RECEIVES A FULL INSPECTION
description: In a wide-roaming day of exploration, an underwater robot today examined the sunken luxury liner Titanic from her crow's-nest to her gymnasium.

title: THE LOCAL PLAYGROUND
description: In the suburban town of Roosevelt, L.I., just to the east of New York City, there are park attendants who can point with pride at the basketball court where Julius Erving once played as a boy. In Brooklyn, there are recreation directors who can point out the diamond where Willie Randolph learned to play baseball.

title: Conflict at DePaul
description: Joey Meyer's request for a one-year extension to his contract, which expires in 1988, has been rejected by DePaul, according to a report published by The Chicago Sun-Times.

title: RARE CANCER, WHICH IS INHERITED, SAID TO BE PREDICTABLE BEFORE BIRTH
description: Scientists can now predict before birth whether a child will develop a rare inherited form of cancer, according to a researcher at a conference on genetics.

title: Bangladesh Attack Reported
description: An opposition member of Parliament was badly wounded today by five men who attacked him with bamboo sticks and axes, the authorities said.

title: Market Place; The Weakened Royalty Trusts
description: ROYALTY trusts, which enjoyed popularity in the heyday of strong energy prices, have been weakening steadily in value on the New York Stock Exchange as a result of slumping prices for oil and natural gas. These trusts were created to transfer interests in a company's energy properties to its stockholders, who became unit holders in the trust.

title: New York City Must Rid Itself of 'Separate and Unequal' Schools

Hyundai Deal
description: The Hyundai Electronics Industries Company has signed a $180 million contract to supply 240,000 sixteen-bit personal computers to Blue Chip Electronics Inc., Hyundai officials said. Delivery will begin in August and continue until the end of 1987.

title: Toxic Fumes Kill 3 Workers
description: Toxic fumes from a cleaning solvent overcame workers in an unventilated section of a pumping station on Lake Rabon today, killing three of them, the authorities said. Another worker was in critical condition and 10 emergency medical workers called to the scene were taken to the Laurens District Hospital for observation after being exposed to the fumes. Zack Seymour, the Laurens County coroner, said the workers apparently were at the bottom of the pump station cleaning up paint when they were overcome.

title: Hilton Profits Up 10.5%
description: Bouncing back from a sluggish first quarter, the Hilton Hotels Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $30.5 million, or $1.22 a share, up 10.5 percent from $27.6 million, or $1.11 a share, for the comparable period last year. Revenues were $192 million, up 3.4 percent from $185.7 million in the second quarter of 1985.

title: FILM VERSION OF 'AS IS,' AIDS DRAMA, TO BE ON TV
description: Television has already addressed the subject of AIDS, and several television dramas have focused on homosexuality, but perhaps none have done so as explicitly as ''As Is,'' the filmed version of William M. Hoffman's acclaimed play about a homosexual couple struggling with the lethal disease.

description: The Giants opened training camp today with half of their 14 draft choices missing.

title: WEAKNESSES IN NUCLEAR REGULATORY PROGRAM CITED
description: A nuclear reactor operator can meet all the rules established by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and still have a plant with potential safety problems, witnesses told a House subcommittee today.

title: Economic Study Cites Sports Role
description: Professional baseball, tennis, hockey and basketball directly contributed $175.5 million to the city's economy last year, with the Mets and the Yankees providing 60 percent of the total, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin reported yesterday.

title: A Bankruptcy in China
description: The official newspaper Workers Daily today reported the first factory bankruptcy since the Chinese Communists came to power in 1949. Diplomats called it a victory for reformists over party hard-liners. An instrument plant in the city of Shenyang succumbed to huge debts.

description: There was no mass celebrated at the cavernous Roman Catholic church here this morning. Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega, who normally leads the celebrants, was expelled from the country July 4, and no one has been named to take his place.

description: A House appropriations subcommittee voted today to reinstate a ban on drilling for oil and gas off central and northern California for the next fiscal year.

description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products continued their upward trek yesterday from the lows they reached Monday, even as conditions afflicting the oil market seemed to worsen.

description: A local judge ordered this city's striking garbage collectors back to work today, responding to official fears of strike-induced violence and other potential dangers to public safety.

U.S. TO AVOID CLASHES IN BOLIVIA RAID
description: The White House said today that American military forces assisting authorities in Bolivia in a series of drug raids would make every effort to avoid becoming involved in armed conflicts with narcotics traffickers.

title: THE STATUE OF LIBERTY: TRANSCENDING THE TRIVIAL
description: IF there was anything off-putting about the wild and extravagant praise for the Statue of Liberty over the Fourth of July weekend, it was the ubiquitousness of the image of the statue. That face, that long, flowing gown of copper, and most particularly that seven-pointed crown, seemed to be everywhere. There were pictures of the statue from every angle, taken at every time of day and night, on television, in newspapers and magazines. There were logotypes made from the statue's face on all kinds of commercial products, and a stage designed to echo its crown as a backdrop for the televised celebratory events. There were posters of the statue in store windows. And as the hysteria reached its peak, there were those souvenir green foam-rubber hats that allowed each and every tourist to turn his head into liberty's crown.

title: The Score
description: Some time ago, it was recorded in this space that the Heritage Foundation had suffered a sporting, if not ideological, defeat at the hands of the softball team from the Brookings Institution by a 4-to-3 score. Now the Heritage Foundation wishes it to be known that it captured the season series, winning the last two games by 7-2 and 7-4. Noted.

title: A KOCH ADVISER WHO PLAYS A KEY CITY HALL ROLE
description: For more than eight years, Daniel Wolf, a soft-spoken, silver-haired man who was one of the founders of The Village Voice, has had a desk in City Hall in a room with five other people. title: INVENTORIES DOWN 0.3% IN MAY
description: In a further sign of economic stagnation, the Commerce Department reported today that inventories held by manufacturers and distributors fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in May and that total business sales fell by the biggest amount in 11 years.

title: Criminal in the Cracks
description: How could someone as disturbed and dangerous as Shavod Jones go untreated and unconfined in New York until his arrest for shooting a police officer? The 15-year-old had bounced for years between the courts and treatment programs without being helped, punished or kept off the street. The case has to shake court and mental health officials - and ignite an obvious reform.

title: WATER IS NOW PLENTIFUL, BUT CITY ISN'T RELAXING
description: A year ago last week, Mayor Koch flew up to the Catskill Mountains and, standing on the dry, caked bottom of the Ashoken Reservoir, announced that he was imposing stringent restrictions on water use in New York City. Water in the reservoir system was at 54.9 percent of capacity; the normal level for that day was 94 percent.

description: State officials today are scheduled to begin ''intensive'' surveys of the conditions in all 55 welfare hotels in which the city houses homeless families. The surveys are to determine whether further regulations are needed to improve the hotels, the officials said.

description: The BankAmerica Corporation today reported a quarterly loss of $640 million, the second-largest ever for an American bank.
