description: Eugene Michaud, who remodels homes in central Connecticut, has advertised in several states that he will pay $900 a week to skilled carpenters. So far, he said, ''the results have been pathetic.''

Analysts said it was one of the largest orders of its kind, though it would be spread over several years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 17, 1986
description: Companies BankAmerica lost $640 million in the second quarter, hurt by plummeting oil prices. The nation's second-largest bank increased reserves to cover greater-than-expected losses on loans to energy and real estate companies. The loss is the second largest ever for a U.S. bank, after the $1.16 billion deficit at Continental Illinois in the second quarter of 1984. Bank officials and analysts do not see any imminent danger of BankAmerica's failure. [ Page A1. ] The Pentagon suspended Litton Industries from bidding for military contracts a day after a subsidiary agreed to plead guilty to 325 counts of fraud involving $6.3 million in overbilling. Litton is the military's 19th-largest contractor. [ D1. ] Rates for TV advertising time are being cut, or else raised just moderately, by ABC, CBS and NBC as demand weakens. In the past, the networks were able to command double-digit price increases, so the turnaround comes as a relief to advertisers. [ D1. ] May will acquire Associated Dry Goods in a stock exchange valued near $2.7 billion. The new company, with 303 department stores, is expected to have sales of about $9.4 billion. [ D1. ] Apple's revenues rose for the first time in five quarters, helped by sales of its Macintosh personal computer, and the company reported a profit. At Burroughs, profits increased 41 percent. [ D1. ] Savings executives are attacking rules proposed by the Financial Accounting Standards Board for the accounting for upfront loan charges, including application and origination fees. [ D2. ] First Oklahoma is uncertain about its net worth, after being stripped of the First National Bank and Trust.

title: BIGGS RECOLLECTS BOUT WITH DRUGS
description: The recent cocaine-related deaths of Len Bias and Don Rogers have had a strong effect on Tyrell Biggs, the heavyweight contender. The news accounts, he said, made him sad, and made him identify with the victims. ''It just as well could have been me,'' said Biggs.

description: President Reagan has discovered, as have other Presidents, some hard truths about blue-ribbon commissions. These temporary advisory panels, intended as obedient hunting dogs, often turn out to bite the hand that appoints them.

title: Senate Holds a Debate On Extradition Treaty
description: The Senate debated a treaty today that would make it easier for Britain to extradite suspected terrorists who have sought sanctuary in the United States. A vote on the measure, which is expected to pass overwhelmingly, has been set for Thursday afternoon.

title: Officials Call Foul On Prep Camps
description: Schoolboys who follow the bouncing ball to summer basketball camps are frequently familiar with intense pressure, since many of them, even underclassmen, are among the nation's most highly recruited prep stars. Now they're getting it from a different source, the athletic governing bodies of the various states, which in increasing number are looking askance at any free benefits a player may get there. In some cases, a youth can even find that it's he who's being bounced - right off his high school team.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT

But the amateur should not be reluctant to fix a leak in such faucets, because the one or two differences are actually minor.

title: Apple Juice Cyanide Threat
description: Indian Summer Inc. advised stores throughout New York State to pull its apple juice and cider from their shelves today after it had received an anonymous telephone threat of cyanide contamination. The threat was phoned Tuesday to the company's plant here in Ulster County, and local police and Federal Drug Administration officials are investigating, company officials said. Internal investigations have produced no evidence of contamination or tampering, the company said.

title: Bridge: A Team Marked by Veterans Is Expected to Defend Title

Along with Pete Rose, Jack Nicklaus and Ray Floyd must be counted the bridge team that won the 1985 Spingold Knockout Team championship in Las Vegas and is expected to defend the title next week in Toronto.

description: Decreased interest costs helped lift Chesebrough-Pond's Inc.'s second-quarter profit by a record 98.3 percent, to $48 million, or $1.13 a share, compared with $24.2 million, or 69 cents a share in the 1985 period, the company said today. Sales were $800.5 million, up 3.1 percent, from the $776.7 million in the 1985 period.

Warner-Lambert Gain
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 80.3 percent, to $120.6 million, or $1.61 a share, from $66.9 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales dropped 6.1 percent, to $761.2 million, from $810.9 million. The company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., said that earnings in the latest quarter included a non-recurring gain of $48 million, or 64 cents a share, primarily reflecting the sale of three health technologies businesses and other measures intended to improve productivity.

title: AMR Profits Decline 26.3%
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter plunged 26.3 percent on a 10.1 percent drop in revenues. The company attributed the declines to continued intense competition, which was only partly offset by an increase in passenger volume.

title: DANCE: JANE COMFORT AND HER COMPANY
description: JANE COMFORT is a choreographer who works as much with words as with movement. The program Miss Comfort presented on Tuesday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on West 42d Street, where she and her company will perform through Sunday afternoon as part of Clark Center's Summer Dance '86, made typically reasoned use of both kinds of material. It was a program that drew cheers from the audience at the end. But for this dancegoer, the evening was a puzzling, sometimes irritating excursion into gimmickry.

title: Technology; Personalizing Software
description: PEOPLE having computer systems designed often find they are not very good at specifying what they want the system to do or how they want it to work.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONFEREES SET TO STUDY HIGHER TAXES ON BUSINESS
description: As they prepared to begin the crucial conference on tax revision legislation Thursday morning, Senator Bob Packwood and Representative Dan Rostenkowski tonight agreed that conferees should focus on higher taxes on business in order to give more tax relief to middle-income individuals.

title: Dinner for Pakistan's Prime Minister
description: Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo of Pakistan is in the United States for a weeklong visit, including four days of talks and ceremony in Washington. Tonight he was the guest of honor at a state dinner at the White House.

title: Brazil Rejects Extradition
description: Brazil will not agree to Haiti's request that it extradite a former police chief, Albert Pierre, if he could face the death penalty, a Government spokesman said today. Brazil will not extradite a suspect to face a sentence, such as the death penalty, that is not in its penal code, the spokesman said.

title: COMMERCE UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY SERVICES IN DETROIT SNARLED BY STRIKE
description: Struggling through the first full day of a walkout by 7,000 city workers, Detroit's 1.2 million residents made do today without buses, garbage pickups, health clinics, libraries or summer park programs.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROTHSCHILD, L F, UNTERBERG TOWAN-HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for 1985 are on a pro-forma basis because the company was a partnership at that time and went public on March 13, 1986.

title: PONCE FEDERAL BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 18, 1986, and 8 percent stock dividend paid in January 1986.

Robert Thirkield, 49, An Actor and Director
description: Robert Leeming Thirkield, an actor and director and a founder of the Circle Repertory Company, died July 9. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Shady, N.Y.

title: Federal Tax Reform: Let a Loss Be a Loss

description: The latest quarter net includes the purchase-basis acquisition of Provident Institution for Savings on April 1.

title: Pennzoil Lays Off 181
description: The Pennzoil Company laid off 181 workers today, with about 420 more jobs to be eliminated by the end of 1986. It blamed falling oil and gas prices.

title: A DEFECTION CASE ANGERS BOTH THE GERMANYS
description: What appears to be an old-fashioned cloak-and-dagger story is threatening to create serious political strains in relations between the two Germanys.

title: NORWESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest results include securities gains of $260,802 for the quarter and $1,104,332 for the 6 months, compared to $150,794 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months.

title: MUSIC: BOB DYLAN AND TOM PETTY
description: BOB DYLAN and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers gave an oddly paced, willful concert Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. The joint tour, in which Mr. Petty and his band accompany Mr. Dylan and play two 20-minute segments on their own, opened its three-night stand in New York with a set that ran nearly three hours without an intermission. The show never gathered momentum, but along the way there were some magnificent rockers, some uninspired stretches and a few unexpected cover versions by Mr. Dylan, from Ricky Nelson's ''Lonesome Town'' to Ray Charles's ''Unchain My Heart.'' As always, Mr. Dylan left listeners wondering what was forced, what was heartfelt.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Some years ago we repainted one room with a flat latex paint. This room has been painted with latex many times before, but recently we have noticed a lot of surface cracks that seem to be in the paint, not in the plaster. We have been told that this is a condition called ''alligatoring.'' What caused this and what we can do to avoid it in the future? A. If the condition is actually what is known as alligatoring, the usual cause is that the paint was applied in too thick a layer. Either the paint needed thinning when applied, or you simply applied it too thick with your brush or roller.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $5.3 million from the sale of the domestic business forms operations.

title: EVEN THE FISH DIE IN STREAMS AS THE DUST-DRY SOUTH BAKES
description: For a week and a half, it has been so hot across the South that chickens in their sheds, fish in their ponds, cattle in their fields, ancient oaks in their woods and people in their homes have died of heat.

title: ORACLE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Pretoria Brief Is What Counts
description: With South Africa seething under virtual martial law, President Reagan proposes to send as his next ambassador a North Carolina businessman, Robert Brown, who happens to be black. And why not? Why not remind Pretoria that the United States is a multiracial society directly affronted by its racist doctrines? Mr. Brown has no diplomatic experience, but his political acumen is admired ecumenically across the spectrum, from Senator Jesse Helms to Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta.

title: U.S. PRESSES PLAN FOR BLACK ENVOY
description: The Reagan Administration pressed ahead urgently today with plans to name Robert J. Brown, a black businessman, as the next Ambassador to South Africa.

title: AFTER COLLAPSE, CEILING CHECKS SOUGHT BY CITY
description: The collapse of a ceiling at the Murray Hill Theater that sent three patrons to the hospital late Tuesday night prompted the City Buildings Commissioner yesterday to call for an inspection of ceilings in all movie houses built before 1938.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sri Lankan President Stands Firm on Elections
description: President J. R. Jayewardene today rejected new demands by the main opposition party for early general elections to test popular opinion on a Government plan to end Sri Lanka's ethnic conflict.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boyd Enters Hospital
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd admitted himself to a hospital yesterday for what the Red Sox said was a comprehensive evaluation, including drug testing. The Red Sox said Boyd went to the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, Mass., one day after the team indefinitely extended his three-day suspension, for leaving the team without permission after expressing his anger at not being named to the all-star team.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A DISPLAY OF 12 SPANISH PROJECTS
description: LIKE many other countries in Europe, Spain over the last decade has been invigorated by foreign architectural influences arriving month after month in magazine after magazine. During the last several years, moreover, the Socialist Government has supported change with an increased number of culturally motivated commissions -an effort encouraged by a strong economy. For Spain, the combined presence of architectural ferment, affluence and indulgent patronage has resulted in an architectural moment charged with vitality and a sense of experiment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. elected John D. Zeglis senior vice president and general counsel and Harold W. Burlingame senior vice president, public relations.

title: CITYFED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said the latest quarter results include June operations of recently acquired Kissel Co.

title: Haft May Lift Safeway Offer
description: Herbert H. Haft, the 65-year-old Washington investor, hinted broadly yesterday that he was prepared to sweeten his $3.6 billion offer to buy the nation's biggest supermarket chain, Safeway Stores. He also indicated that he would not take ''greenmail,'' selling his Safeway stock back to Safeway at a profit.

title: NEW CENTURY ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $21,000. c-Net loss The company recently changed its name from New Century Productions Ltd.

CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

When Judicial Merit Is Sacrificed to Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Kills Girl, 3
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed and three family members were injured early yesterday when overcome by smoke from a fire in their home in St. Albans, Queens, fire officials said.

title: Blood Supply Is Seen as Safer Than Ever, But AIDS Is Still Increasing Public's Fear
description: Although there is concern that transfused blood may have infected some people with AIDS and public anxiety about transfusions has mounted, the health authorities contend that today's blood supply is perhaps safer than it has ever been, in part because of dramatic changes in the nation's blood banks.

title: ROZELLE CONTRADICTS TRUMP
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, testified in Federal District Court yesterday that in March 1984 Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, told him he wanted an N.F.L. expansion team in New York, and that if he got one, he would arrange for a new stadium to be built in the city and ''would get some stiff'' to buy the Generals.

title: FIRST BOSTON'S INCOME FELL 51.7% IN 2d QUARTER
description: First Boston Inc., a major investment banking house, reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter fell 51.7 percent from a year earlier as a result of major losses from fixed-income trading. Net income fell to $21.6 million, or 64 cents a share, from $44.8 million, or $1.56 a share, in the second quarter of last year, First Boston said.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO'
description: IF there could be such a thing as a man-made miracle, ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' is it. One might argue further that a perfect performance of Mozart's opera would take the listener as close to heaven as anyone should need to come while still on this earth. The ''Figaro'' put on last night by the New York City Opera, the first the season, fell somewhat short of perfect, to be sure, but it proved to be a delight on the whole. And in a work that depends so much on a meshing ensemble and close rapport among the performers, it is the whole that counts most, not the parts.

title: MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $58,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $359,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Todd Ships Fills Key Post
description: Todd Shipyards, the nation's largest independent shipbuilding company, said that Hans K. Schaefer, president and chief operating officer, had been named chairman and chief executive. Mr. Schaefer, 50 years old, succeeds John T. Gilbride, 70, who has retired after 49 years with the company.

title: On Sin and Dissent
description: Five years ago, People for the American Way was established by Norman Lear, the television producer, to fight religious bigotry in politics and preserve the separation between church and state. Now, objecting to what they say is harassment of their candidates, conservatives are starting a counterorganization.

title: 'Washington Advantage'
description: Washington is one of eight cities that will be trying at a meeting of the Democratic site selection committee in the capital this weekend to line up the party's 1988 national convention. Local officials believe they have a major selling point, which they call ''the $9 million Washington advantage,'' based on what convention delegates and ob-servers would save because so many of them already live in the area and would not have to travel to a distant city and rent rooms there.

title: TIME'S CABLE HEAD NAMED PRESIDENT
description: Despite its long history in the magazine business, Time Inc. yesterday named as its new president an executive whose management expertise lies elsewhere. He is Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., an executive vice president responsible for Time's expanding cable television operations.

title: Chipping In for Security
description: To insure domestic tranquillity and provide for the common defense, the General Services Administration has told other Government tenants at the Jacob K. Javits Federal Center in lower Manhattan that if they want metal-detecting devices, they will have to help pay for them.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said that total contract backlog at the end of the latest quarter was $168 million compared with $131 million for the year-ago period.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $4.8 million related to the consolidation of facilities and inventory adjustments.

title: HUBBELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Classical Guitar
description: MaryAnn and James Larusso will play music for classical guitar at Sunnyside, Washington Irving's former estate, 150 White Plains Road, Tarrytown, N.Y., on Sunday night at 7:15.

title: Advertising; Magazine Lures New Categories
description: A 48-PAGE ''advertorial'' section in the September Field & Stream magazine titled ''The Guide to Huntingwear'' will be part of an effort to lure new advertising categories to the publication.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that in the latest quarter it issued 487,325 shares of common stock in a business combination with Product Coatings Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests. The figures previously reported have been restated to include the results of the acquired company.

title: Labor Relations Flattery
description: President Reagan is expected to nominate Mary Cracraft, a Kansas City labor lawyer, for a Democratic vacancy on the five-member National Labor Relations Board, industry officials say.

description: To the Editor:

description: Martin E. Segal, chairman of the France Salutes New York festival, missed the whole thing.

description: * Altos Computer, San Jose, Calif., said it had acquired Communications Solutions Inc., a manufacturer of I.B.M. compatible data communication software, from Control Data Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

Dust on Fabulous Goods
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: CITY OPERA OFFERS 'LES PECHEURS DE PERLES'
description: THE libretto of Bizet's ''Pecheurs de Perles'' cannot confidently be called the worst in opera history - the competition for that honor is stiff -but it does rank right down there with the most appallingly inept of its kind. The central characters are a virgin priestess and two Ceylonese males who love her but are such close friends that they swear never to let a mere priestess come between them. Bizet's librettists treated this romantic triangle absent-mindedly, and to such hilarious effect that at times the strongest resemblance is to one of those Marx Brothers movies in which the characters appear to be making it all up as they go along.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Run-D.M.C., Whodini and L. L. Cool J., Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue at 33d Street (564-4400). Rap music - syncopated rhymes atop electronic funk - has become a long-running rock style, in no small part due to the popularity of Joey Simmons and Daryl McDaniels, better known as Run-D.M.C. Shouting in unison or filling in each other's lines over the funk drumbeats and hard-rock guitar chords supplied by the disk jockey Jam Master Jay, Run-D.M.C. boast about their exploits and put down others' follies. Some of their rhymes were once supplied by James Todd Smith, alias L. L. Cool J. (which stands for Ladies Love Cool James), now becoming a rap star in his own right - a cocky word-slinger who is fond of polysyllables and unexpected pauses. Whodini is on the pop end of the rap spectrum; its songs often have rap verses and melodic hooks for choruses. While recent rap concerts at Madison Square Garden have been marred by incidents, the security force inside and outside the arena will be, a Garden spokesman said, ''beefed up a lot'' for the concert. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $17.50.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $6.6 million from the sale of the majority of the company's interest in General Computer Corp.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ART: OBJECTS ARE SUBJECT OF 'DAMAGED GOODS'
description: MARCEL DUCHAMP was probably the first to discover that there is nothing, not even anti-art, that a true lover of art won't eventually accept as art. Artists used to enjoy challenging this acceptance but of late there have been signs that they - at least those who would be in the avant-garde if there were one - are getting bored with the situation. Either that, or they are now less interested in acceptance than in probing the psychology behind it.

title: MISSIONARY WARNS AGAINST PHILIPPINE RESCUE BID
description: An American missionary kidnapped by an armed band of Moslems in the southern Philippines warned in a letter made public today that he might be killed if the military tried to rescue him.

title: THE CASE FOR DR. K
description: So, just what is wrong with Dwight Gooden? Not much, if you believe in the significance of tender years and early numbers. In fact, Gooden's projected final statistics for his third season cut a fine figure when stacked up against the third-year records of 10 of the greatest pitchers in history.

title: 'FERGIE FEVER,' AS ROYAL WEDDING NEARS
description: She likes horses, swimming, tennis, champagne, spinach souffles, Trivial Pursuit, the Rolling Stones, Duran Duran, the high-grade pulp novels of Jilly Cooper, and Philip Morris cigarettes, which she is trying to give up in deference to the British royal family's aversion to smoking. Along with the T-shirts, medallions, coat hangers, wristwatches and other tsatskes bearing the likeness of Sarah Ferguson, some original entrepreneur has just come out with a ''Fergie'' perfume.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $104,000 for the quarter and $242,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the quarter and $76,000 for the 6 months.

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Longer Pact for Marshall
description: Leonard Marshall, the Giants' all-pro defensive end, signed a three-year contract extension today that will raise his football income to close to $400,000 a year for the next four seasons. The 24-year-old Marshall walked out of a minicamp for one day last May because of a dispute over his contract, which called for a 1986 salary of $150,000 and would have made him the Giants' lowest-paid defensive lineman.

title: A.M.C. Reports Losses
description: The American Motors Corporation today reported a $52 million loss, or 50 cents a share, for the second quarter. A.M.C. lost $70.4 million in the same quarter a year ago. The company said sales fell 17 percent, to $801 million, from $961 million a year earlier. A.M.C. said cutbacks in its operations allowed it to reduce its losses. The company also announced that it would sell publicly eight million shares of convertible preferred stock to raise $187 million.

title: Lohr Leads on 63
description: Bob Lohr shot a 7-under-par 63 today, one stroke off the tournament record, to lead the opening round of the $400,000 Hardee's Golf Classic. Lohr, 25 years old, of Loveland, Ohio, is seeking his first victory on the PGA Tour. He opened with a three consecutive birdies at Oakwood Country Club and had eight for the round.

title: Brooklyn's Role In the City's Defense
description: Brooklyn's role as a strategic site in the defense of New York City from the 1700's to the early 1900's will be discussed Sunday on a tour of Fort Hamilton in the Bay Ridge section.

title: IMMUNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTRAWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
I.B.M. Upgrading
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had added memory enhancements to the I.B.M. system/88 fault-tolerant computer that would quadruple the main memory and improve the performance for customers. The company also said it had introduced two controllers for the system's direct access storage devices.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for 12wks to June 15
description: The company said a change in accounting methods increased net in the latest quarter and 6 months periods by $500,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1.2 million, or 3 cents a share, respectively.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about organizations that help mentally retarded people listed an incorrect telephone number for the Young Adult Institute. Its number is (212) 563-7474.

DISNEY, WALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REGAN PRETORIA REMARK EVOKES FURIOUS OUTCRY
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, asserted in an interview Wednesday that economic sanctions against South Africa would result in American women's having ''to give up all their jewelry.'' Today the remark drew a barrage of angry responses.

title: COMMERCIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Reliance Stake Sale Reported
description: Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings is considering selling between 25 percent and 30 percent of the privately held concern in a public offering, Wall Street sources said.

title: Prosecutor Defends Singling Out Zaccaro
description: The Addison County State's Attorney, John Quinn, who is prosecuting John Zaccaro Jr. on drug charges, contended today that it was not unconstitutional to prosecute famous people to attract publicity.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BOLIVIA SAYS ITS DRIVE ON COCAINE WILL GO ON UNTIL TRADE IS ENDED
description: The Bolivian Interior Minister announced today that drug raids about to begin here with assistance from the United States military would continue until the drug trade was wiped out in Bolivia.

title: Railroad Sees Write-Offs
description: The Santa Fe-Southern Pacific Corporation said that, because of the sharp decline in oil prices, it expected to have write-offs of about $130 million this year from its oil and gas properties. Santa Fe- Southern also said it expected a ''significant charge against income'' because of accounting changes from its proposed merger of its Santa Fe and Southern Pacific units.

title: U.S. TO SEND PILOTS TO AID MEXICAN FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: Six United States airplanes with civilian pilots under contract to the State Department will participate this fall in a 45-day Mexican effort to eradicate opium fields, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: LOS ANGELES HOMELESS ADAPT LIVES FOR THEATER
description: Every big city in the United States has outposts of charity that offer the homeless a taste of the bread. Los Angeles, for the last few months, has had a place that gives a whiff of the roses, too.

title: 6 REGIONAL BELL UNITS LIFT PROFITS
description: Six regional Bell companies yesterday reported improved second-quater profits, with four of them recording double-digit gains.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN BROOKLYN RAPES AND BURGLARIES
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn man with a record of seven convictions for burglary and other crimes since 1976 was charged yesterday with a series of burglaries and knifepoint sexual attacks in the Crown Heights section of the borough.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $5 million from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Scene of Heroism, Scene of Romance
description: Battalion Chief Robert A. Stehl of the 41st Battalion, at 2900 Snyder Avenue in Brooklyn, and Edward T. McCloskey, his aide, were on the way yesterday morning to supervise the repair work on a ruptured fuel pipe. While driving there, they were notified of a fire at 185 East 31st Street in Flatbush.

title: Claire Motte, 48, Dies; Paris Opera Ballet Aide
description: Claire Motte, ballet mistress of the Paris Opera Ballet and formerly one of the French company's leading ballerinas, died Wednesday in Paris after a long illness. She was 48 years old.

title: Disney Profits Increase 51.5%
description: The Walt Disney Company, citing gains at its theme parks, said today that it earned $79.7 million, or 58 cents a share, in its third quarter, a 51.5 percent increase from $52.6 million, or 39 cents a share, a year ago.

title: GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the 1985 results are pro-forma. The company went public March 4, 1986.

title: WESTPORT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN PLANNING APARTHEID SPEECH
description: President Reagan has tentatively decided to make a major speech on South Africa policy in which he will announce the appointment of a black North Carolina businessman as the American Ambassador to Pretoria, White House officials said today.

title: U.S. ENVOY URGES COMPROMISE IN CHILE
description: An American envoy who arrived here earlier this week pressed Government officials for assurances that there would be a democratic transition in 1989, according to sources familiar with the discussions, which ended today.

title: HOSTAGES REPORTED KEPT IN BEIRUT
description: The First Vice President of Syria asserted today that the American and French hostages in Lebanon were being held by ''militias'' in the Beirut area, not in the Bekaa region or in other Syrian-controlled areas, as some Western officials believe.

title: MAJOR TIMBER UNION REACHES ACCORD
description: A tentative agreement between the Weyerhaeuser Company and one of two unions that struck its 22 plants in the Pacific Northwest a month ago was announced in Portland, Ore., tonight by Norman Lee of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: DANCE: PARIS OPERA BALLET
description: AWARE that that some of America's best-known fortunes stem from the ''robber barons'' of yore or more recent forays into the oilfields, Rudolf Nureyev creates a vision of America in his ballet ''Washington Square'' that is anything but genteel.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The figures include the results of Hoover Universal Inc., since May 1985, and Ferro Manufacturing Corp., since July 1985.

title: OJEDA GETS 11TH VICTORY
description: For six innings, the game hung tenuously on an unearned run. Nolan Ryan, 39 years old and near the end of a glorious career, had risen to become The Express again. He was firing fastballs past the Mets tonight, and he was beating them.

title: PAKISTANI SAYS SOVIET OFFERED A 4-YEAR AFGHAN WITHDRAWAL
description: The Prime Minister of Pakistan said today that the Soviet Union had formally offered to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan over a four-year period, but that Pakistan believed a withdrawal could take place in four months or less.

title: Win One, Lose One
description: It was a busy day for Harvey Richards. He watched the changing of the guard outside Lenin's Tomb at noon, learned he had won a protest decision by three Russian jurors at 2 P.M., and was knocked out by a Russian at 9 P.M.

title: A STEEL STRATEGY BACKFIRES
description: The LTV Corporation became the nation's second-largest steel producer almost by default, doubling its ante as it lost its bets. A conglomerate better known for aerospace, LTV became a union of the beleaguered in the steel industry, the last vestige of such ancient and luckless names as Jones & Laughlin, Youngstown and Republic.

title: A Play for Children
description: ''A Bag of Dreams,'' a three-character play for children, will be presented tomorrow at the B. P. Theater, 195 East 76th Street.

title: MANHATTAN'S SOUTHERN TIP TO GET 60-STORY TOWER
description: A $384 million development project - including a 60-story office tower with a glass dome that would change the face of Manhattan's historic southern tip - has been chosen by the city for the South Ferry area.

title: AUCTIONS
description: DECOY collectors and dealers who assembled on July 5 at Richard W. Oliver Auction Gallery in Kennebunk, Me., saw prices for carved wood ducks, geese and shore birds soar to higher levels than ever before. However, Russell Aitken, the man who bagged the biggest prize - a preening pintail drake carved about 1915 by A. E. Crowell - was not present. He bid over the telephone and won the carving for $319,000, a record at auction for a decoy and for any folk-art work other than a painting.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates

title: Bishop Robert Rusack Dies; Los Angeles Episcopal Chief
description: Bishop Robert C. Rusack, leader of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles since 1974, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Pacific Palisades. He was 60 years old.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lazarus Lindsay
description: John V. Lindsay rose from the dead last night.

title: BANKAMERICA'S UNHAPPY SURPRISES
description: The stunning loss reported by the BankAmerica Corporation on Wednesday shows two sides of the bank's management, industry analysts said today. The first is a glaring lack of oversight over its own operations, and the second is a calculated risk by new managers to get problems behind them.

title: EQUITABLE, IN PROMOTION, NAMES OPERATING CHIEF
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States said yesterday that it had promoted Leo M. Walsh Jr. from chief investment officer to the new position of chief operating officer and had named Richard H. Jenrette to succeed Mr. Walsh.

title: U.S. OFFERS $2.85 BILLION TO LOAN AID TO 3d WORLD
description: The Reagan Administration today pledged $2.85 billion over three years to the International Development Association, removing the last major obstacle to replenishing the capital of the World Bank affiliate that makes interest-free loans to countries most in need.

description: To the Editor:

description: The share earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 9, 1986.
