description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. CHICAGO WHITE SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Jarmusch Film to Open New York Festival
description: ''Down by Law,'' a new film written and directed by Jim Jarmusch, will open the 24th New York Film Festival on Sept. 19 at Lincoln Center. Mr. Jarmusch directed ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' which had its premiere at the 1984 festival.

title: A War Worth Waging, Carefully
description: Even allowing for exaggeration, the estimated scale of Bolivia's drug sales is mind-blowing. The cocaine traffic is said to yield $600 million annually, more than the total 1987 national budget of that impoverished country of six million. To the United States, these exports represent a massive police problem. To the Bolivian Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro they also represent an urgent political threat. Small wonder he welcomes America's military help to turn the tide against drug barons standing poised to capture a nation.

title: UNITED BANKS OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $8.6 million for the quarter and $18.1 million for the 6 months. The company said the 1985 figures are restated to reflect the results of Mallinckrodt as a discontinued operation. Financial results of the Mediplex Group are included in the year-to-date and quarter since April 1. The 1985 share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: AMERICAN CAN TO SELL ITS PACKAGING BUSINESS
description: The American Can Company said yesterday that it was going out of the can business and would change its name.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEILEMAN, G BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the sales figures exclude excise taxes.

title: NAFCO FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lockheed Up; TRW Falls
description: Two diversified electronics and aerospace companies, the Lockheed Corporation and TRW Inc., reported mixed results for the second quarter.

title: St. Bart's Project Suffers Setback
description: An appeals court in Manhattan yesterday dealt another setback to the long-delayed St. Bartholomew's office tower project, ruling that the church's leaders had violated church bylaws by not submitting the plans for the project to a full vote of the parish.

title: DOW ADVANCES 7.60
description: For the second consecutive day, stock prices rose moderately as investors, still shaken after a sharp correction in the last two weeks, cautiously re-entered the market looking for bargains.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone Merging 2 Health Care Agencies
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications is merging its two health care agencies into Vicom/FCB, which will have a San Francisco headquarters and offices in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Time for Schools to Pick Up the Beat
description: To the Editor:

title: POLL STUDIES HISPANIC PARTY LOYALTIES
description: United States citizens of Hispanic descent are much more likely to think of themselves as Republicans than black Americans are, and they like President Reagan much more than blacks do, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Canada Penalizes Six
description: Six Canadian athletes - three weight lifters and three from track and field - have been banned for life from receiving Government financial support for training and competition because they used anabolic steroids, hormonal drugs that enhance muscle growth. Rob Gray, a discus thrower, and Mike Spiritoso and Peter Dajia, shot-putters, plus three weight lifters, Jacques Demers, Mario Parente and Glenn Dodds, are the subjects of the ban, according to Otto Jelinek, the Canadian Sports Minister.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months' results include Norwood Marking & Equipment Co., acquired on a pooling-of-interest.

title: Police Cashier Target Of Theft Investigation
description: A cashier in the Police Department's audit and accounts section is being investigated in connection with the theft of about $79,000 since January, police officials said yesterday.

title: SEARCH NATURAL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $176,751 from settlement of a suit. c-Net loss

title: FOR JET-AGE POPE: ANGELS, DEVIL AND INDULGENCES
description: Pope John Paul II, with his mastery of television and his penchant for world travel, is perceived as the most modern of Popes. So it may have come as a surprise to some that he has lately been talking at considerable length about angels and devils and the Holy Spirit.

title: Deficit Hysteria Again
description: Happily for the economy, the Supreme Court has invalidated the central gimmick of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings boondoggle. But the Court could not eliminate the danger that Congress, in its lemming-like urge to ''do something about the deficit,'' will do exactly the wrong thing - cut expenditures further, raise taxes, or both.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Period Instruments
description: Aston Magna continues its series of 17th- and 18th-century music played on period instruments tonight at 8 in the Chapel of the Holy Innocents at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, with a preconcert lecture and demonstration at 7:30.

title: A Steel Price Rise
description: The USS Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer and an operating unit of the USX Corporation, said it planned to raise the price of its wide flange structural steel by $15 a ton. The increase follows the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's announcement on Monday that it was raising the price of its structural steel by $15 a ton. Both companies said the price increases will become effective Aug. 31.

title: DEBT IS $4 BILLION
description: In the largest bankruptcy filing in United States history, the LTV Corporation, parent company of the nation's second-largest steel manufacturer, today asked for court protection from more than 20,000 creditors.

title: Write-off at Southland
description: The Southland Corporation, operator of the convenience store chain, said yesterday that it expected second-quarter profits to fall short of its record $88.7 million in the same period of 1985 because its Citgo Petroleum Corporation unit will take a noncash inventory charge of about $50 million pretax.

title: JUNE STARTS OF HOUSING DOWN 0.8%
description: Housing construction edged down eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today, and analysts attributed the setback to a slight rise in mortgage rates.

title: Jobs to Hold the Dropouts
description: Two important, related questions for New York: What policies can sharply reduce the 36 percent dropout rate from the public schools? What policies will reverse the drift toward two societies, leaving tens of thousands of youths unqualified for the white-collar service jobs that are likely to be available in the next decade?

title: Mutual Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $4.08 billion, to $229.48 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the second consecutive weekly increase for all three categories, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At the Blue Note
description: The vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson will lead his quartet, and the pianist Monty Alexander will lead his trio, in double bills tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). There are sets beginning at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 2 A.M. show today and tomorrow; there is a $12 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: AFTER too many fireworks, parties, lights, speeches and crowds, and too much music and champagne, New Yorkers mustered the steam for one more salute to freedom. Thousands filled Central Park on Bastille Day as the New York Philharmonic gave equal time to French and American composers. Afterward, at a reception in the Delacorte Theater, chefs took the same cue, pairing mud pie and pear tart.

title: SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net income of $185,000 for quarter and a loss of $530,000 for year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,397,000. d-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $530,000.

title: The U.N. Today; July 18, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Preliminary analysis of the tape shows the crew was unaware of the events associated with the tragedy and the internal communications were being maintained as would be expected during a normal ascent.'' -Statement by NASA on the Challenger. [ A1:2. ]

title: Morning Coat, Striped Pants
description: The Solicitor General of the United States takes the lectern in the Supreme Court's stately chamber with advantages enjoyed by no other lawyer.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nevada Desert Shaken By Nuclear Test
description: A powerful nuclear weapon was detonated deep beneath the Nevada desert today, the 14th announced nuclear test since the Soviet Union began a unilateral test ban last August.

title: Chilean Exiles Hurt and Angry
description: The recent death by fire of a 19-year-old Chilean photographer in Santiago has left an angry wound in the Chilean community of Washington, where the victim, Rodrigo Rojas de Negri, had lived since the age of 10 as the son of a political exile.

title: Philadelphia Trash Still Uncollected
description: Striking garbage collectors defied a court order to return to work today and refused to begin picking up the trash that a judge said Wednesday was threatening public health and safety.

title: CENTRAL FIDELITY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dining Out Guide: Out of Doors
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: ''THE idea comes from this,'' said the sculptor David Hammons, nudging a tuft of tall grass with his foot. ''I wanted the work to be like wisps of grass coming out of the ground. I like a lot of air between things, like musical notes or scales.''

title: MUSICAL ON THE ELDERLY 'TAKING MY TURN,' ON 13
description: INSISTING that most older people are irrepressibly young at heart, the musical ''Taking My Turn'' returns to Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock. If you missed the ''Great Performances'' presentation the first time around, as I did, sit back, relax and enjoy a show that makes one telling point after another with a spirit that is remarkably sweet and gentle.

title: YOUMANS, EXPOS TOP BRAVES
description: Floyd Youmans pitched a four-hitter and struck out nine over seven innings tonight as the Montreal Expos handed the Atlanta Braves their fifth straight defeat, 4-2.

title: Inland Steel Shows a Profit
description: Inland Steel Industries, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, today reported second-quarter net income of $15.7 million, or 48 cents a share, the company's first profitable quarter in more than two years. In the quarter a year earlier, Inland lost $29.6 million.

title: RJR NABISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TWO TIMES EXECUTIVES ARE GIVEN NEW POSTS
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had given John D. Pomfret, a senior vice president, the new corporate responsibility of overseeing the business activities of all the company's 33 newspapers, including The New York Times, its flagship newspaper.

title: Trailways Bus Safety Questioned in California
description: Assistant Chief Glenn Sewell of the California Highway Patrol has recommended that Continental Trailways be forbidden to operate in California because its buses are plagued by safety hazards. The Patrol Commissioner, James Smith, will decide whether to ask the Public Utilities Commission not to renew the bus line's license.

title: Alaska Governor Orders Big State Budget Cuts
description: Governor Bill Sheffield of Alaska has ordered reductions of $550 million in the state's $2.5 billion budget in the face of worldwide oil price cuts.

title: COCA-COLA POSTS 15% ADVANCE
description: Four consumer-products companies yesterday reported healthy gains in second-quarter earnings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: JULY 18, 1986
description: International

title: Intermountain Offers Novel 'Crossover' Issue
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, in a novel financing that has attracted much attention in the tax-exempt bond market because it is a cheaper way to refund outstanding bonds, is offering $405 million of ''crossover'' bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: THE SCREEN: TOM CONTI STARS IN 'SAVING GRACE'
description: THERE'S no more engaging actor around than Tom Conti, but not even he, with the assistance of such notables of international moviedom as Giancarlo Giannini, Erland Josephson and Fernando Rey, can lift ''Saving Grace'' out of its slough of sentiment.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Arsenal for the Federal War on Drugs
description: What can be done to counter the burgeoning drug abuse that America faces? Certainly, state and local governments must continue to use their full resources against drug conditions. But drugs are a national problem, and narcotics control must be primarily a Federal responsibility.

title: Concert by the Band
description: The Band, featuring three original members of the group - Rick Danko, Levon Helm and Garth Hudson - will give a free concert tomorrow at 9 P.M. at Pier 16-17 of the South Street Seaport Museum (669-9400), at Front Street and the East River.

title: The Turner-Gorbachev Olympics
description: Give Ted Turner a score of 8.5 for his Moscow Goodwill Games. That Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, used him and the games for his own propaganda purposes was no surprise and no calamity. The contests, which end Sunday, have been less than Olympian, but then so were the last three boycotted Olympics. The Goodwill Games at least match Soviet and American athletes in Olympic-style competition for the first time in 10 years.

title: BROADWAY
description: WHEN it was originally presented at the Sheridan Square Playhouse in Greenwich Village almost two decades ago, it was described by a prestigious critic as ''without question the most moving theatrical experience in New York.'' It's returning, or at least a new version of it is returning, because, unfortunately, it's even more timely today. ''The Concept'' is about drug addiction, and none of it is fiction or theoretical. It mirrors the experiences of the eight performers - all former addicts - both during their addiction and later, during their stay at Daytop Village, a therapeutic treatment community. It should be in an Off Broadway theater by mid-September.

title: Private View
description: Joe DiMaggio, on why he had attended the Gerry Cooney-Eddie Gregg fight, which attracted only 1,537 fans in San Francisco: ''Because I enjoy my privacy.''

title: ITT Profits Rise by 35.3%
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter climbed 35.3 percent on a 22.9 percent increase in revenues.

title: Swiss Is First in 14th Stage
description: Niki Ruttiman of Switzerland finished eight minutes ahead of the pack today to win the 96-mile 14th stage of the Tour de France, but Bernard Hinault kept the overall lead.

title: BOTNICK'S USE OF CITY CARS IS QUESTIONED
description: The Police Department called for an investigation earlier this year into the possible misuse of city-owned cars by Victor E. Botnick, who recently resigned as the mayor's top health aide amid questions about his conduct in office.

title: Mexican Publisher And Editor Are Killed
description: A newspaper publisher and an editor who had written articles critical of organized crime and corruption were shot to death Thursday as they prepared to go to work, authorities said.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Former Oyster Bay Employee Indicted Wednesday Is Dead
description: A former Town of Oyster Bay employee, indicted Wednesday on charges of defrauding the town of millions of dollars in an illegal waste-disposal scheme, died today at Massapequa General Hospital in Seaford.

title: Rep. George M. O'Brien Dies At 69 in U.S. Cancer Institute
description: Representative George M. O'Brien, Republican of Illinois, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: Detroit's Mayor Appeals to 2 Courts
description: With five million pounds of trash on the streets and municipal workers in the second day of a strike, Detroit officials took the union to court today to force what they said were essential city employees back to their jobs.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 18, 1986
description: Companies

title: Somber Clouds Are Gathering
description: SUDDENLY, amid falling prices in Wall Street, the economy is looking a lot grimmer. It is as though the lightning flashes over the stock market have transfigured the entire economic landscape, at home and abroad.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE refurbished plaza of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street has sprouted more than trees - it also has a pair of quality outdoor cafes. The library has set up two green kiosks on both sides of the plaza that are operated by Neuman & Bogdonoff, the gourmet shop and caterer at Third Avenue and 79th Street. About 50 umbrella-shaded tables and 200 chairs accommodate alfresco diners for breakfast, lunch and early evening snacks.

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Local Hero
description: In John Witchel's opinion, he has ''choked'' - that's his word - in some of the biggest races of his life, failing to swim as well in competition as he can during workouts in his native Manhattan. The 18-year-old from Stuyvesant High School picked a good spot to break the habit: the Goodwill Games in Moscow, where he won two gold medals. Witchel took the 200-meter freestyle in 1 minute 50.1 seconds early on in Moscow and later posted a 1:49.0 200-meter segment with the Americans' winning relay team, times that were good enough to give him hopes of qualifying for the Olympics two years hence.

title: PANEL HEARS OPPOSING VIEWS ON REVISIONS IN PESTICIDE BILL
description: State leaders and health commissioners clashed with rural lawmakers and food company representatives today over a proposal that would bar states from enacting more stringent restrictions on pesticides than those maintained by the Federal Government.

title: 2 TAGS AT PLATE SAVE YANKEES
description: Dave Winfield did not get a hit last night and Dave Righetti did not pitch particularly well. But the two Yankees who have been the most frequent targets of George Steinbrenner's criticism this season impressively showed how they help the team with other elements of their play.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONGRESS RATIFIES SPENDING CUTS
description: Congress today overwhelmingly ratified $11.7 billion in spending cuts made earlier under the budget-balancing law.

title: COMMERICAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
10 IN A FAMILY ARE ARRESTED IN 5 DRUG RAIDS
description: Four men and six women, who the police said were heavy suppliers of cocaine in Washington Heights, were arrested yesterday in a series of raids in upper Manhattan and in Queens.

title: PACT WITH BRITAIN ON EXTRADITIONS BACKED BY SENATE
description: The Senate approved today a landmark treaty with Britain that may make it easier to extradite suspects accused of terrorist crimes from the United States.

title: Bryant Loses Case
description: Kelvin Bryant, the Baltimore Stars' running back who tried to get out of his contract by contending that the United States Football League team had failed to maintain an active franchise, has lost his arbitration case with the team. Bryant has been the Stars' starting halfback in the club's three years of existence.

title: Kafkaesque Handling of Cubans
description: Last week's talks with Cuba about the possible resumption of an immigration agreement have broken down, so for the immediate future we shall have to make immigration policy by ourselves. This is just as well, for at least one element in our policy never should have been subject to negotiation, and should be changed at once: the refusal to grant visas to two groups of Cuban political prisoners and their relatives whom Fidel Castro has granted permission to leave the island.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gain on the sale of the company's remaining shares in Abbey Life in the U.K. c-Includes net gains from discontinued operations and other dispositions. Both year-earlier revenue figures have been restated.

title: FILM: SIGOURNEY WEAVER IN 'ALIENS'
description: THE special-effects specialists are featured prominently in the credits that precede ''Aliens,'' and so they should be. Under the direction of James (''The Terminator'') Cameron, they have put together a flaming, flashing, crashing, crackling blow-'em-up show that keeps you popping from your seat despite your better instincts and the basically conventional scare tactics.

title: EXPLORATION OF TITANIC STERN HAMPERED BY STRONG CURRENT
description: Researchers exploring the sunken liner Titanic today examined the area where the stern half of the ship tore loose, but they were hampered by a current so strong they could not operate the robot vehicle Jason Jr. Earlier this week they sent the robot into the liner's interior.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $19 million from the sale of a portion of the timberlands under an agreement the company had with an unrelated third party. The company said effective Jan. 1, 1986 they adopted SFAS 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions. The effect of this change was to increase net income by approximately $5 million, or 5 cents a share, for the latest 6-month period of which $3 million, or 3 cents a share, related to the latest quarter.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $15,100,000 from the sale of Helme Tobacco. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $940,000 for the quarter and $1,174,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter results included a non-recurring plant closing charge and consolidation of $5 million, before tax benefit, and an $800,000 interest income from investment of funds segregated for the special dividend distribution relating to the sale of Helme Tobacco. The company said the latest 6 months results included a pre-tax costs of plant shutdown and consolidation of $5 million, a pre-tax gain of about $2.6 million from the sales of buildings and land by the Connecticut real estate development subsidiary and $900,000 of interest income. The company said the 1985 6-month period includes a $1.8 million gain from the sale of excess processing facilities.

title: LAXALT SAYS C.I.A. CHIEF SUGGESTED MARCOS CALL EARLY VOTE
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, originally proposed to Ferdinand E. Marcos that he call the early presidential election that ultimately led to Mr. Marco's exile, according to an article by Senator Paul Laxalt.

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 25-percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: New Aftershocks Felt In California Desert
description: Two earthquakes hit this desert area today, with seismologists saying they were more aftershocks of the July 8 temblor that caused damage estimated at $6 million.

title: British Joblessness Up
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose by 15,000 last month, to a record high of 3,220,400, or 13.1 percent of the work force, the Government said today.

title: Turkish Ex-Premier Defends Himself at Trial
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit went on trial here today on charges of involvement in political activity.

title: Life Sentences an Option In Texas Slavery Case
description: The presiding judge said today that he would allow the jury the option of life sentences for three men found guilty of organized criminal activity in a case of torture on a Texas ranch.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 14, 1986.

title: No Loans for Chile
description: In the wake of the violent response by the military to strikes in Chile and the killing of a teen-ager purportedly set afire by Government troops, the United States needs to take a harder look at what it can do to help bring a return to democracy. One important step would be to stop approving loans that support the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Ameritrust said the figures have been restated to reflect the merger of First Indiana Bancorp into Ameritrust during the second quarter of 1986 in a pooling of interests transaction.

title: A Bit of History On a Village Walk
description: A question for fans of Washington Square Park: What body of water once wound its way through the park and still flows somewhere in Greenwich Village? The answer is the Minetta Brook, which, with the help of a pump, now spurts from a fountain in the lobby of 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: FLOURISH AT FINISH AS BEMAN POSTS 75
description: The general has joined the troops because he likes competition.

title: Advertising; Sperry Account
description: The Shimer vonCantz agency in Philadelphia has been assigned to handle the communications needs of the Sperry Corporation's Personal Computer products that were formerly handled by Lewis, Gilman & Kynett. The budget will be about $1 million, some $875,000 for media advertising and the rest for direct mail and production costs.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA CO reports earnings for 13wks to June 24
2 MEN REPORT BEING SUBPOENAED ON DETAINING OF ALIENS AT BORDER
description: At least two of the people who detained 16 aliens who illegally crossed the Mexico-Arizona border on July 5 say they have been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury in Tucson..

title: CONIFER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months' earnings reflect the acquisitions of Patriot Bancorp and Hampshire National Bank on a pooling-of-interests basis. The latest periods' nets include charges of $2.9 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 6 months, both relating to the acquistions.

title: WASHINGTON WATER POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said 1985 figures include results of the desiccant and industrial business unit, which was sold in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: Coach Is Sidelined
description: Like many other beaming fathers, Vince Dooley was expecting to sit in the stands and watch his son, Derek, play football in the Georgia High School All-Star Game tonight in Atlanta. But because of a National Collegiate Athletic Association rule that prohibits college head coaches from attending such games not held on their campuses, Dooley, head coach at the University of Georgia, will watch on television from a hotel room while his wife and the rest of the family sit in the stands and cheer on Derek, a tight end who plans to be a nonscholarship player at Virginia.

title: DAVID ROSE
description: David Rose, a New York builder and philanthropist, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS ACT TO REMOVE BAR TO JERSEY JUDGE
description: The Democratic majority of the State Senate today stripped a Republican Senator of the right to prevent the reappointment of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Robert N. Wilentz.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OPERA: MOZART'S 'COSI FAN TUTTE'
description: Well, Peter Sellars is at it again, with a semi-new production of ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' part of a Mozart cycle he's embarked on at the really quite wonderfully vital Pepsico Summerfare on the State University of New York campus here.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $29,440,000 from an accounting change. The company said about $2.4 million, or 7 cents a share, of the latest second quarter net resulted from the net effect of two unusual items, a gain on the sale of a sawmill in northern California and a reserve for loss on a venture capital investment.

title: Analysts' View Of Bank Stocks
description: WALL STREET analysts are selective in picking their favorites among New York City banks and other money center banks in the wake of the $640 million quarterly loss reported Wednesday by the BankAmerica Corporation. Although the magnitude of this loss - the second largest for an American bank - came as a surprise, analysts were quick to note that it represented a long-identified problem.

title: Prices Mixed, Volume Light
description: Prices in the credit markets were mixed in light trading yesterday as the focus continued to be more on technical factors than on economic fundamentals.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $427,000 for the quarter and $457,000 for the 6 months on investments. c-After losses on investments of $226,000 for the quarter and $430,000 for the 6 months.

title: ROSS, A J LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Scores Are High At Blustery Open
description: Chilly northwest winds churned up whitecaps in the Firth of Clyde before slamming into Turnberry's Aisla course today and making a shambles of many players' efforts in the first round of the 115th British Open.

title: TIMES REPORTER BEING HELD IN PEKING
description: John F. Burns, chief of the Peking bureau of The New York Times, was taken into custody yesterday by Chinese security officials as he and his family were about to leave China for a three-week vacation in Hong Kong.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: Share earnings do not include the 2-for-1 stock split effective July 11, 1986, and therefore, are stated on a pre-split basis.

title: U.S. Steel Is Sued Over New Name
description: The USX Telecenters Corporation, a telephone systems distributor in Sunnyvale, Calif., has filed suit this week against the United States Steel Corporation, contending that the Pittsburgh-based company's name change to the USX Corporation infringed on its trademark.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $1,280,655 charge for early repayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: Top Tummler's Helper
description: To the Editor:

title: A WEEKEND TRIO OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: All in the same year, Lori Herbison was born in Paris, Tenn., Jonathan Rosenberg was born in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, and Monty Karp was born in Pittsburgh, Pa. Now the three are 26 years old, and they have come together as promising directors to present a weekend of one-act plays at the StageArts Theater.

title: McLAUGHLIN JURY HEARS TAPE OF TALKS
description: The jury in the bribery and theft trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, listened yesterday to a secretly recorded tape in which Mr. McLaughlin said that he might owe a wealthy heiress $200,000 but that he had not ''looted'' her in any criminal sense.

title: UNITED CAROLINA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PENNBANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (AT&T)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said a previously reported change in accounting for pension expenses improved the latest quarter's earnings by about $112 million, or 11 cents a share, and by $212 million, or 20 cents a share, for the latest 6 months.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in May.

title: Pacific Realty Offers To Buy U.S. Home
description: The Pacific Realty Corporation, a privately held construction company, offered yesterday to acquire the U.S. Home Corporation, one of the nation's largest builders of single-family homes, for about $320 million.

title: Salley Signs
description: John Salley, a graduate of Canarsie High School in Brooklyn who played at Georgia Tech, has agreed to a reported $1.6 million, five-year deal with the Detroit Pistons. The first four years of the 7-footer's pact are guaranteed.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
How to Slow the Reckless Bicycle Courier
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: New York Team Pressed In Grand National Event
description: Faced with an unlucky draw, the New York City representatives had to fight hard here Wednesday to survive qualifying play in the Grand National Team Championship here. At the end of the day Kathie Wei, Mike Kopera, Judi and Mike Radin and Gail and Jack Greenberg, all of Manhattan, struggled into the third and last qualifying place in their group of six teams.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Woods Hole, Mass., on Wednesday about the exploration of the wreck of the liner Titanic misidentified a former leader of the Titanic Historical Society. He was William H. Tantum 4th, who was president of the society at his death in 1980.

title: KEMP OPPONENET FILES CAMPAIGN COMPLAINT
description: James P. Keane, a Democratic candidate for the House seat held by Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, filed a complaint today with the Federal Election Commission against Mr. Kemp and a Michigan political group.

title: Salaries for Cabinet Hit $90,000 in Jersey
description: Governor Kean has granted $20,000 pay raises to his Cabinet members, giving them higher salaries than his own, a spokesman said today.

title: GTE and Siemens In Joint Venture
description: The GTE Corporation and Siemens A.G. of West Germany said they would form a joint venture to make telecommunications equipment for the United States and other countries.

title: IACOCCA DISAVOWS EFFORT TO DRAFT HIM AS A PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the automobile maker, has moved to halt an effort to draft him as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: AT LEAST 70 PEOPLE ARE DISMISSED AT CBS NEWS
description: After weeks of tense anticipation, CBS News yesterday dismissed at least 70 employees, ranging from veteran on-air correspondents to program executives to secretaries, in the latest round of job eliminations at the network. Further dismissals are possible in coming weeks.

title: French Economic Gains
description: The French Government today announced small declines in both the trade deficit and unemployment in June. The trade deficit fell to $180 million, from $300 million in May. Unemployment figures dropped three-tenths of 1 percent, to 2.44 million, or just over 10 percent of the work force, from 2.45 million in May.

title: PHILIP MORRIS COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 common stock split distributed on April 10, 1986, to stockholders of record on March 14, 1986. In 1986, the company changed its method of determining pension expense to conform to requirements of FAS 87. The change increased this year's second quarter and first half net by $10 million, or 4 cents a share, and $20 million, or 8 cents a share, respectively. Figures for 1986 include results of General Foods Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary since Nov. 1, 1985.

title: Livestock and Grain Off As Heat Relief Is Seen
description: Forecasts of some relief from the scorching temperatures parching a broad section of the United States set off a selling binge in the livestock and grain futures markets today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jimmy Gourley, Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Jimmy Gourley, a guitarist, has been one of the leading spirits in the American expatriate jazz colony in Paris for the past 30 years. A native of St. Louis, he first went to Paris in 1951, when he was 25 years old, and stayed for four years studying and playing. Before going to Paris, he had played in Chicago for six years with Anita O'Day, Gene Ammons, Sonny Stitt, Jackie Cain and Roy Kral. During his four years in Paris, Mr. Gourley led his own quartet and recorded with a stream of visiting Americans that included Zoot Sims, Clifford Brown, Lee Konitz, Bob Brookmeyer and Roy Haynes. He returned to Chicago in 1955 but was back in Paris within two years and has made it his base ever since, playing primarily in Kenny Clarke's trio and occasionally leading his own groups. He came back to this country for the first time in 1975 when he played a solo engagement at Sweet Basil in Manhattan. He is back again tonight and tomorrow evening at Bradley's with Steve Laspina on bass. He starts at 9:45 P.M. and goes on to the early hours of the morning. There is a $5 minimum and a $5 cover.

title: BRONX MAN, 32, GUILTY OF RAPES IN OFFICE TOWERS
description: A Bronx man who the authorities said was responsible for a string of sexual assaults and robberies in midtown office buildings last year was convicted yesterday of rape, robbery and sexual assualt.

title: PRETORIA EXPELS LUTHERAN PASTOR
description: A Lutheran minister, ordered expelled by the South African Government, left Johannesburg yesterday after being detained at the airport by the police, who apparently wanted to insure that he got on his plane to New York, sources in South Africa said.

title: EX-MAFIA CHIEF FOCUS OF TAPES AT 'PIZZA' TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors, beginning the final phase of their case in the ''pizza connection'' trial, presented secretly taped conversations yesterday seeking to show that a former Mafia chief was a major drug supplier.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS NET IS MORE THAN DOUBLED
description: The American Express Company, the giant financial services organization, announced yesterday that its consolidated net income in the second quarter was a record $358.9 million, more than two and a half times its profits of $140.2 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: WEST SIDE MARKETING TWIST: '$1 DOWN'
description: ''Apartments for sale - $1 down.''

title: FOR $150 AN HOUR, WHAT TO WEAR TO WATCH POLO
description: In a day when single women are forever searching for ways to meet eligible men, Patricia Irwin and Alice Stanoszek have purchased tickets to a polo match at Bethpage State Park on Long Island later this month. They know nothing about polo, but somewhere between the first and the last chukker, they hope to encounter eligible men who will explain things.

title: BILL TO AID F.S.L.I.C. IS PASSED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: A House subcommittee today approved an Administration-backed plan to provide as much as $15 billion to support the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the financially pressed insurer of deposits at thrift institutions.

title: BELLSOUTH CORPORATION BELLWETHER EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CAVE GIVES CLUES TO CANNIBALISM
description: A Stone Age cave dwelling in southeastern France has yielded what some anthropologists describe as the strongest evidence ever assembled of the practice of cannibalism by humans.

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Signed Ray Phillips, linebacker; Rich Karlis, place-kicker; Tony Colorito, nose tackle; and Orson Mobley, tight end.

title: 'Mostly Mozart'
description: The pianist David Bar-Illan will play Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 18 in B flat and the violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg will play the composer's Violin Concerto No. 3 in G, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 as part of the ''Mostly Mozart'' festival at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,239,000 for early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: LIMITED AMNESTY IS GRANTED TO SOME PRISONERS IN POLAND
description: The Government approved a limited amnesty today for some political prisoners and criminals, but top leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union will not be eligible.

title: TOBACCO HEIR'S TRIAL TO FOCUS ON CHARGES OF GREED AND DRUGS
description: In opening arguments today at the murder trial of Steven Benson, a 34-year-old Naples man accused of killing his tobacco heiress mother, lawyers for the defense and the prosecution laid the groundwork for a case that has fascinated residents of Florida's Gulf Coast with its steamy tale of matricide, drugs and greed.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
US WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in May.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $88 million, after taxes, from the sale of 9 million shares of Fireman's Fund Corp. stock held by American Express.

title: Shamrock Plans To Cut Dividend
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, an ailing energy and chemical company based in Dallas, said that its board had voted to cut the quarterly common stock dividend to 10 cents, from 25 cents. The company also said it would eliminate the distribution of units of its limited partnership as part of the dividend payment.

title: FILM: ISABELLE HUPPERT IN 'SINCERELY CHARLOTTE'
description: WHEN Isabelle Huppert first appears on screen in ''Sincerely Charlotte'' she seems under the influence of Madonna - singing in a Paris disco, orange streaks in her spiky blond hair, her style is gaudy jewelry and fingerless black lace gloves. But after her boyfriend is murdered and Charlotte runs to an old lover for help, the movie and its star are transformed. The lurid nightclub scenes give way to the sunny French suburbs, where Mathieu now lives placidly with his fiancee, Christine, and her young son; Charlotte's makeup wears off and she becomes so wholesome looking she eventually passes herself off as a nurse.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HENRY FLAGLER: The Astonishing Life and Times of the Visionary Robber Baron Who Founded Florida. By David Leon Chandler. Illustrated. 324 pages. Macmillan. $22.50. HOW many people - at least outside Florida, the state he did so much to develop - could readily identify Henry Flagler today? Yet he was one of the more remarkable of the major carnivores who stalked the American economy in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He merits a biography, and David Leon Chandler's is only the second to be published in the 73 years since his death.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results have been restated to include American Bancorp Inc. acquired Dec. 31, 1985, and First Kentucky Bancshares Inc., acquired March 31. The acquisitions have been accounted for as poolings-of-interests.

title: No Charges
description: A city prosecutor in Milwaukee said Thursday that Reggie Jackson of the California Angels would not be prosecuted for battery as a result of a scuffle in a local tavern May 3. The prosecutor, John Carter, said another charge, disorderly conduct, could still be filed, but only if both Jackson and the other man involved in the incident, Donald Weimer, 26, of Racine, were charged.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JEFFERIES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Apartheid Trial
description: The scene of protests against race laws in South Africa will shift today from Congress and the streets of Washington to District of Columbia Superior Court, where four protest leaders will be tried for trespass in connection with a May demonstration at the local offices of the Shell Oil Company. One of the defendants, Randall Robinson, said they ''intend to use this courtroom to put Shell Oil, American companies and the United States Government on trial for their complicity in propping up apartheid in South Africa.'' Among witnesses scheduled to testify for the defendants are Coretta Scott King and Senators Gary Hart of Colorado, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Carl Levin of Michigan, Paul Simon of Illinois and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut.

title: SEALRIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESEARCHER REPORTS SUCCESS IN TESTS TO DETECT HEMOPHILIA IN FETUS
description: A high degree of success in diagnosing hemophilia before birth by analyzing DNA was reported here today at a genetics meeting.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective in May 1986.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: U.S. TO PLAY SOVIET IN BASKETBALL FINAL
description: David Robinson of Navy scored 17 points and led six American players in double figures tonight as the United States built a 26-point lead then survived a second-half threat to defeat Brazil, 96-80, and reach the gold-medal game of the World Basketball Championships.

title: TOWER AT FERRY TERMINAL: LIVELY, BUT LARGE, DESIGN
description: Eight skyscraper designs were submitted in the competition for the right to build atop the Staten Island Ferry Terminal at the tip of lower Manhattan, and of them, the most romantic is surely the winning scheme by Fox & Fowle.

title: PPG Profit Is Up 2.7%
description: PPG Industries today reported second-quarter earnings of $91.8 million, or $1.54 a share, up 2.7 percent from $89.4 million, or $1.28 a share, a year ago. Sales rose 9.1 percent, to $1.2 billion, from $1.1 billion. The gains were attributed to improvements in the company's glass and coatings business, increased productivity and a weaker dollar.

title: CONTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1985 figures have been restated to include companies subsequently acquired on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Slaying Dragons in Tennessee
description: Something like 1,000 years separate Vicki Frost, of Church Hills, Tenn., from a medieval cartographer. Nonetheless their view of the world is very much the same. Wander into the Western Seas, both warn, and you risk running into dragons. Mrs. Frost's Western Seas are whatever lies outside her Bible-centered universe, and the dragons one meets there are anti-God.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,508,000 for the quarter and $8,987,000 for the year. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: IRISH-AMERICANS DEPLORE VOTE
description: Irish figures in New York City were unanimous yesterday in their condemnation of a Senate vote approving a treaty with Britain to make it easier to extradite accused terrorists.

title: TOP TRADER LEAVES CITICORP FOR HUTTON
description: Mark F. Kessenich Jr., one of the top officers at the Citicorp Investment Bank, is joining the E. F. Hutton Group as an executive vice president and head of its fixed-income trading operations, according to sources at both companies. They also said he would join Hutton's management committee as a top officer.

title: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EX-OFFICERS GET 2 TO 6 YEARS IN QUEENS STUN GUN TORTURE
description: Two former police officers were sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison for torturing a teen-age drug suspect with an electric stun gun at a Queens station house last year.

title: BELL ATLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 periods are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1986.

title: Chicago Bank Suing Hunts
description: A Chicago bank has filed a $446 million counterclaim against several members and interests of the Hunt family, contending that they used fraud and misrepresentation in their dealings with the bank. The First National Bank of

title: Queen Reported Concerned As 3 Countries Join Boycott
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher refused today to comment on widespread press reports that Queen Elizabeth II fears the Government's opposition to sanctions against South Africa will break up the Commonwealth.

title: A Bad Round for the Tax Man
description: Foreign professional athletes who have been forced to limit the time they spend in the United States to keep Uncle Sam from taking a tax bite out of all their income, including that earned abroad, may be able to extend their American tours if an obscure provision of the Senate tax-reform bill becomes law.

title: BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split paid in March.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
House Passes C.F.T.C. Bill
description: The House of Representatives has overwhelmingly passed a reauthorization bill for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Corporations' Tax Escape
description: Forty-two profitable big corporations legally used deductions and credits to eliminate their Federal income-tax liability and claim a tax refund in each of the last four years, a Washington study group said today.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Wednesday about Lee A. Iacocca described his party affiliation incorrectly. Mr. Iacocca lives in Michigan, where voters are not required to register by political party. He says that he has never enrolled in either party, and that he has voted for candidates of both parties in the past.

title: BLUES INNOVATOR ENTERS THE SPOTLIGHT
description: THE annals of popular music are full of brilliant unknowns - innovators whose tastes, personalities or luck have kept them out of the spotlight, known to fellow musicians and dedicated fans rather than the general public. The quiet, bespectacled, 55-year-old guitarist Hubert Sumlin, who returns this weekend to the Abilene Cafe, is one of those musicians. During the golden age of Chicago blues, he worked with everyone from Muddy Waters to Chuck Berry to Bo Diddley, and for 22 years he supplied razor-edged solos for Howlin' Wolf, the basso profundo of Chicago blues, who died in 1975.

title: Inquiry Said to Widen
description: The grand jury investigating the cocaine-related death of Len Bias, the Maryland basketball star, will look into reports that urine samples of players were switched to avoid drug detection, and accusations that some coaches may have known of player drug use, according to a report in The Washington Post.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CYPRIOT CEREMONIES The re-enactment of a traditional Cypriot wedding is an event worth witnessing. Among other things, the ceremony includes the presenting of the bride's trousseau, rolling a boy in the couple's mattress to insure that their first child is a son, watching the groom shave and the bride primp before the vows, and guests pinning Cypriot money to the couple's vestments - all done, it should be noted, to constant dancing and singing. The nuptial celebration is one of many Greek and Cypriot traditions that will come alive this weekend in the National Heritage Folkloric Festival in Astoria, Queens. Also featured will be folk dances, singing, art exhibitions, crafts, ethnic foods, wine tastings and games. The festival, presented by the Cypriot Emigrants Cultural Organization of America, will run tonight from 7 to 11 o'clock and tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 11 P.M. The wedding ceremony will start at 10:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. All activities will take place in Bohemian Hall, at 29-19 24th Avenue, which can be reached by taking the R train on the BMT subway line to the Hoyt Avenue (25th Avenue) stop. Admission is free. Information: (718) 626-7896.

title: School Chief Resigns
description: The Yonkers Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Joan M. Raymond, has formally given her resignation to the Board of Education, effective Aug. 31, so she can take a similar job in Houston.

title: El Salvador Expels A Roman Catholic Group
description: A Roman Catholic group from California was expelled from El Salvador today after being seized in a war zone, a United States Embassy official said.

title: SHUTTLE'S TAPES SHOW CREW HAD NO HINT OF FATE
description: A preliminary analysis of tape recordings from the space shuttle Challenger indicated that in the final seconds before the explosion the crew was unaware of the impending disaster, the space agency said yesterday.

title: THE SCREEN: 'MALCOLM,' AN AUSTRALIAN COMEDY
description: MALCOLM is likable, albeit a touch slow, and the same can be said of the new Australian comedy that bears his name. ''Malcolm,'' which opens today at Cinema 2, is about a young man who, as someone remarks, is not 100 percent there, but is a genius when it comes to trolley cars and anything else that moves. He does his daily chores, buying milk, taking in the mail, feeding his pet bird, by remote control, which is just as well, since dealing with people is not one of Malcolm's talents.

title: WESTAMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IN NEW YORK'S CAPITAL, IT'S LEGISLATURE'S OFF-SEASON AND THE LIVING IS EASY
description: It is a noontime bright as sterling silver, and hundreds of state bureaucrats, shoes off, ties undone, linger over impromptu picnic lunches on the Capitol grounds, just watching the world go by.

title: In South Africa, a Gathering Storm
description: No matter how awful you think the situation in South Africa is, it seems worse and more complicated when you get there.

title: A BOUNTIFUL SEASON IN OUTDOOR SCULPTURE REVEALS GLIMMERS OF A NEW SENSIBILITY
description: AT a moment of so much promise for sculpture, the first question to be asked about the outdoor sculpture season is whether the vitality is evident here, too. The answer is an emphatic yes.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE Broadway theater district is not exactly a shining chorus line of quality res taurants. Theatergoers face depressing odds when trying to choose a dining spot at random - it's sort of like trying to pick a play solely by looking at marquees. One place that I often recommend with confidence is Orso, the sunny and casual Italian restaurant on West 46th Street specializing in moderately priced pastas, individual pizzas and grilled entrees.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Keeneland Sales May Decline
description: The annual Keeneland select yearling sales, at which unraced thoroughbreds fetched an average of more than $500,000 last year and one horse went for $13.1 million, begin Monday amid the usual expectations of fabulous prices at the top of the market. There is also, however, a growing feeling that this year's sales are like the last days of a declining Roman Empire.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, pictures with the Advertising Column in some copies of Business Day on Wednesday, showing the two partners in the design firm of W.B.M.G. Inc., were reversed. In all copies that carried the pictures, Milton Glaser was shown at right and Walter Bernard at left.

title: Claire Watson, 62, Soprano With Major Roles in Europe
description: Claire Watson, an American-born soprano who sang major roles in European opera houses for a quarter-century, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at her home here, according to her husband, David Thaw, a singer in the Bavarian State Opera in Munich. She was 62 years old.

title: Tasting the Salty Air of Politics and Criticism
description: The Solicitor General's Office, an elite corps of lawyers who represent the Government in the Supreme Court, has usually been viewed as a place where law takes precedence over politics. But in the Reagan Administration, it has become a focus of intense political debate.

title: Taxi Panel Aide Helping Inquiry
description: An employee of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission is cooperating in a bribery investigation that resulted yesterday in the indictment of a taxi fleet owner from Queens, law-enforcement officials said.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 4-percent stock dividend paid in May 1986.

title: DETOURS ON THE PATH TO REBUILDING A ROAD
description: Engineers underestimated the amount of steel to be replaced. Transit Authority officials took nine months to approve a minor design change. A subcontractor failed to deliver dirt for a detour road before winter came.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net income of $2,477,000 for the quarter and $3,772,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding for the latest quarter are adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split effective June 16, 1986.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the net income for 1986 reflects new pension accounting methods resulting in a credit to pension expense of $3,482,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,977,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 6 months. It also includes a non-recurring gain, principally from the sale of a business, of $17,724,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. The company said the net income for 1985 includes a net non-recurring gain of $8,139,000 from the sale of certain businesses for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: JAPAN SET TO JOIN 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: Japan has decided in principle to join the Reagan Administration's space-based defense research, a senior Government official said today.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $7.1 million for the quarter and $15.1 million for the 6 months.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''IT'S not absolutely essential that the audience who come to see 'Malcolm' walk away with a message,'' said Nadia Tass, the director of the Australian comedy, which opens today. ''I believe the movie operates on many different levels, and if, on the surface, they are entertained - which is the very first level - then I believe we have succeeded.''

title: CULLEN/FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company realized in the latest quarter a gain of $5,702,000 on the sale of receivables of its bank-card operations.

title: Transamerica Widens Profit
description: The Transamerica Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $67.1 million, or 89 cents a share, up 45 percent from $46.3 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 5 percent, to $1.52 billion, from $1.45 billion.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $2,575,000 for estimated cost of hazardous waste removal. c-Includes a gain of $515,000 from the sale of a plant.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share net figures are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed June 5.

title: DOW AND MERCK RISE
description: The Dow Chemical Company, citing improved operating profit margins, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter soared 43.2 percent.

title: 22 TAX CONFEREES BEGIN THEIR TASK
description: In a room overflowing with lobbyists from every imaginable commercial interest, 11 senators and 11 representatives began meeting in conference today to write a final version of legislation restructuring the Federal income tax system.

title: JERROLD R. ZACHARIAS, ATOMIC PHYSICIST, DIES
description: Dr. Jerrold R. Zacharias, an atomic physicist whose educational reforms transformed the teaching of physics to American high school students, died Wednesday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 81 years old.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. A historic agreement has settled a 60 year-old dispute over the item pictured above. What was the dispute? 2. ''We don't want to be here forever, but it could just turn out that - like South Korea - when all this is over we remain here,'' said a United States military official. To what country was he referring? 3. Municipal workers were on strike in two major cities. What are the cities? 4. A sharp decline in hospitalization has brought overall occupancy at New York City hospitals to 77.7 percent, the lowest point in 20 years. Why are the hospitals concerned? 5. The New York Rangers have a new general manager. Who is it? 6. New tests on DNA samples taken from amniotic fluid or tissue before birth will allow doctors to diagnose a disease that affects one in every 10,000 boys born in this country. What is the disease? 7. Of the 16 nuclear power reactors ranked by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in May as the nation's worst ''problem plants,'' how many are operating now? 8. In the largest bankruptcy filing in the United States, the LTV Corporation asked court protection from more than 20,000 creditors. What is the amount of the company's debt? 9. Irish-Americans condemned a recent Senate vote on a pact with Britain. Why? 10. On a number of major issues the Central Intelligence Agency has presented a picture of Soviet military programs that is (more/less) grim than that of the Pentagon. 11.

title: ENVOY CHOICE DETAILS ROLE IN NIGERIA
description: Robert J. Brown, the black businessman tentatively selected as the new Ambassador to South Africa, had close connections with a prominent Nigerian Government official who was later accused of absconding with millions of dollars from that country.

title: Action Considered Against City Aide
description: Mayor Koch has asked a panel of his top aides to recommend whether the city should take action against an assistant commissioner and general counsel at the Department of Transportation who has refused to waive his immunity before testifying before a Bronx grand jury.

title: Soviet Captures Six Gold Medals
description: The Soviet Union continued its domination of the inaugural Goodwill Games today, winning six of a possible seven gold medals and widening its lead over the United States in the medal race.

title: BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY STRENGTHENS LAW ON WINDOW GUARDS IN APARTMENTS
description: The Board of Health voted yesterday to strengthen a law that requires landlords to install window guards in apartments with tenants under 10 years old.

title: Kean Announces Plan to Give $5.5 Million to Troubled Cities
description: Governor Kean announced a plan today to distribute $5.5 million to the state's most distressed cities in an effort to avoid cuts in essential services and the layoffs of police officers, firefighters and other municipal employees.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
US SPRINT UP
description: US Sprint, that last of the three major long-distance companies to dut prices in the latest round of rate reductions, said it planned to reduce rates an overall average of 9 percent on Aug. 1. MCI lowered its rates on July 1.

title: Brooklyn? Yeah, Brooklyn
description: Three cars ran a red light in Washington the other day, which, unfortunately, is all too common. What was different this time, however, was that a police officer collared all three drivers.

title: Cheaper New York Medicaid
description: Even as Congress considers the Reagan Administration's proposals to reduce the nation's Medicaid costs, there is much that can be done at the state level, particularly in New York. The Medicaid program is one of the largest and fastest-growing expenses in the state budget.

title: U.S. SAYS HOPES FADE FOR SESSION ON SUMMIT MEETING WITH SOVIET
description: State Department officials said today that hopes for a high-level Soviet-American meeting this summer, at which details for a summit meeting later this year would be arranged, appeared to have faded.

title: BROKER AND AUTHOR OF WORKS OF FICTION
description: Martin Abzug, a stockbroker and the husband of former Representative Bella Abzug, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at their home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: OF RACE HORSES AND FOREIGN MUSHROOMS
description: Most horseplayers in the New York area probably have not thought twice about the plight of American mushroom growers. But for race track managers, the recent onslaught of mushrooms from the Far East and the demise of the domestic market is posing an environmental and financial headache.

title: Free Meals for Children
description: For thousands of the city's children, school is more than food for thought. It is two meals a day for youngsters who otherwise might not eat.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings presented here do not reflect that the company announced on July 9, 1986, a 2-for-1 common stock split with a 20-percent increase in its annual cash dividend which will be effected by means of a 100-percent stock dividend to shareholders of record on Aug. 11, l986. The company purchased American Express's 50-percent interest in Warner AMEX in February 1986, and the 1986 results reflect the consolidation of the cable operations. The 1986 and 1985 results include an after-tax gain of approximately $26.3 million and $8.2 million, respectively, on the sale of 1.2 million shares in each year of Hasbro Inc. common stock, and effective June 1, 1986, Warner will no longer account for its investment in Hasbro on the equity method because its holdings in the company fell below 20 percernt.

title: AIMS ON TRADE TALKS OUTLINED

title: SMALL TOWN SUMMER
description: Now, in that slow, sweet time between the Fourth of July and Labor Day, summer makes its deepest, most profound impression upon the human psyche with an old-fashioned cadence and a rhythm. To those who live in cities, it may be nothing more than a succession of oppressive days of baked brick and steaming asphalt, hot nights when violence seethes below the surface, when the humid blanket dampens the spirit and the heat is an awesome, almost malevolent force. And yet summer in small-town America remains a magic, treasured time.

Trident class submarines so far have been built only by the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation in New London, Conn.

title: Arms and the Bar
description: Erwin N. Griswold, former dean of Harvard Law School and former Solicitor General, and seven past presidents of the American Bar Association have signed a letter urging President Reagan not to scrap the treaty with Moscow limiting strategic arms. On Monday Mr. Griswold and other signers plan to join in a Capitol Hill news conference to draw attention to it. Under the banner of the Lawyers Alliance for Nuclear Arms Control, the letter signers write, ''As lawyers, we have never found that breaking an old bargain is a good way to make a new one.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in some copies yesterday about Congressional action on the Federal budget misstated House votes on the United States contribution to the United Nations. The House voted to cut $17.5 million from the United Nations budget, including $2.5 million of the $7.5 million for the United Nations Department of Public Information.

title: URBAN LEAGUE SET FOR 74th MEETING
description: The status and future of the black family, an issue that has drawn intense debate inside and outside the black community, will be a major topic at the National Urban League's annual conference, which begins here Sunday.

title: EXPEDITION FINDS SAFES IN WRECKAGE OF TITANIC
description: Researchers exploring the Titanic in the submersible craft Alvin said today they had found several ship's safes and had tried unsuccessfully to pull one open with a remote-controlled claw.

title: JUDGE WON'T HALT STRIKE IN DETROIT

title: Star Witness Testifies In Tobacco Heir's Trial
description: The state's star witness in the murder trial of the tobacco heir Steven Benson testified today that the defendant did nothing to help his mother, brother and sister when their car exploded.

title: MANY COUNTRY CLUBS STILL MALE BASTIONS
description: Geneva Ernest had been a member of the Robin Dale Golf and Country Club in Brandywine, Md., for 20 years before she decided one hot summer Sunday to file a complaint against the club for sex discrimination. She had just paid the fee for a golf cart and hoisted her clubs into it when a group of men appropriated it.

title: ARTIST AS OUTSIDER
description: OSKAR KOKOSCHKA: A Life. By Frank Whitford. Illustrated. 221 pages. Atheneum. $21.95. Oskar Kokoschka was born a hundred years ago this year in a small town in Austria called Pochlarn. Shortly after his birth a fire broke out, threatening to engulf the entire town, and he was carried to safety in a hay cart. Or so his mother told him, and so he always believed - though Frank Whitford assures us in his new biography of the artist that the fire almost certainly never took place. No matter; the important thing is that the story meant so much to Kokoschka that it reinforced him in his belief in portents and in his sense of being reserved for an exceptional destiny.

title: Witnesses Listed

title: British Laborites Win Vote
description: The Labor Party has narrowly retained its parliamentary seat in this manufacturing town. Labor received 16,819 votes in a by-election Thursday; the centrist Liberal-Social Democratic Alliance won 16,020, and the Conservatives, 7,863, according to results announced today. A poll in The Guardian said nationally 38 percent of the people questioned supported Labor, compared with 31 percent for the Conservatives and 28 percent for the Alliance.

Ms. Rivers, who was a cashier in the audits and accounts section, has not been charged with a crime. Before her suspension, she had been transferred to a post that did not involve handling money.

CITY OPERA: 'LE NOZZE DI FIGARO'
description: If there could be such a thing as a man-made miracle, ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' is it. One might argue further that a perfect performance of Mozart's opera would take the listener as close to heaven as anyone should need to come while still on this earth. The ''Figaro'' put on Thursday night by the New York City Opera, the first the season, fell somewhat short of perfect, to be sure, but it proved to be a delight on the whole. And in a work that depends so much on a meshing ensemble and close rapport among the performers, it is the whole that counts most, not the parts.

title: Soybean Decline Seen
description: The world's output of soybeans is expected to decline slightly in 1986-87 to about 95.6 million metric tons from the record of almost 96.2 million tons in 1985-86, according to Agriculture Department projections. But global demand is expected to remain about the same, meaning that American soybean farmers will probably see scant improvement in market prices for this year's crop.

title: Charges Filed in Killing Of Peru Prison Inmates
description: A district attorney has filed murder charges against the army general and the forces he commanded in quelling a prison riot last month. More than 100 inmates were purportedly slain after they had surrendered.

title: CONNECTICUT DEMOCRATS OPEN STATE CONVENTION
description: Connecticut Democrats tonight opened their state convention, which will determine whether Toby Moffett can challenge Gov. William A. O'Neill for the gubernatorial nomination in a statewide primary Sept. 9.

title: SHCHARANSKY ACCUSES SOVIET ON KIN
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the human rights activist, accused the Soviet Union today of failing to observe a written agreement, which he said was signed as part of an East-West prisoner exchange last February, to allow his family to join him in Israel.

title: TV: FROM LONDON, 'MAGGIE,' A LIGHT MYSTERY COMEDY
description: If Americans are not going to London, London is coming to Americans, at least in brief glimpses, in ''Maggie,'' a lightweight and intermittently amusing mystery comedy tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channel 2.

title: PENTAGON PLANS UNIT TO BUILD UP SPECIAL FORCES
description: The Defense Department plans to establish a new command to direct a buildup in special operations forces, the military units that can be used to intervene in small conflicts, using unconventional tactics and equipment.

title: Crash Delays Amtrak Train
description: An Amtrak train heading toward Chicago with 367 passengers aboard plowed into a disabled car stuck on a crossing early today, causing no injuries but delaying the trip at least 5 hours, the officials said. Carol Frieday, 23 years old, of Byron, driver of the car, told deputies that her car ended up straddling the rails at about 3:30 A.M. Her attempts to push the car off the crossing ended when she saw the headlight of the train, the Lake Shore Limited, heading westbound at 65 miles an hour, and moved away from the vehicle.

title: ANTI-MARCOS LAWSUITS ENDED
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former Philippine President, won dismissal today of three lawsuits accusing him of involvement in mass torture and the deaths of thousands of Filipinos.

title: THREE ARE SENTENCED IN TEXAS TORTURE CASE
description: Three men convicted in a scheme to kidnap drifters for slave labor that left one man dead after being tortured were sentenced tonight to prison terms ranging from four months to 15 years.

title: MAN SHOOTS WIFE AND HIMSELF TO DEATH, POLICE SAY
description: A man described as a law-enforcement officer for the Federal Government shot to death his estranged wife - a housing police officer - in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday afternoon and then shot himself to death, the police reported.

title: Prices Rise Moderately In Heavy Fuel Trading
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products posted moderate gains in heavy trading yesterday, capping a week of sharp price swings.

There's slipping and sliding and colliding, stabbings, bludgeonings and tumbles from the mast. Nothing is left underdone except the hilarity, the one good excuse for such low-jinks on the high seas.

title: La Prensa Must Be Revived
description: In the wake of the House vote approving $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan freedom-fighters, the Sandinistas shut down La Prensa, the last vestige of a free press in Nicaragua. The Interior Ministry said the paper had ''never lived up to its social, ethical or professional responsibility and has not reflected the common goals of the Nicaraguan people.'' It was wrong. The paper should be revived. It is not too late for Americans in general and our media in particular to express indignation over this plunge down the totalitarian path - as they did in 1951 when the Argentine dictator Juan Peron expropriated the great Buenos Aires daily also known as La Prensa.

STAGE: 'DIE RAUBER,' BY SCHILLER
description: Every detail of the Bochum Schauspielhaus performance of ''Die Rauber'' (''The Robbers'') by Friedrich Schiller is shaped by superb dramatic intelligence; the company's realization of the play at the Pepsico Summerfare, while it might startle some purists, is a tribute to Schiller. Few plays have had as much effect on literature, and none as great an impact on politics, as ''Die Rauber,'' written in 1780 when Schiller was 20 years old. What Thomas Carlyle called its ''volcanic fury'' has ensured its popularity with audiences ever since; but it is its power of mind and language that have made it a favorite with actors and directors, and those are the forces the West German ensemble celebrates.

title: To Stop Children From Having Children
description: As Esther B. Fein recently reported in The Times from the Jacob Riis Houses: ''Despite the threat of pregnancy and the prospect of child rearing at so young an age, teen-agers in the project said they usually did not practice birth control. They are not ignorant of birth control methods, they said. They just don't want to use them.'' Neither did most of the 3,400 students at four inner-city Baltimore schools described in a new study for the Alan Guttmacher Institute. Like the kids at Jacob Riis, they are poor, live in projects and take early sex for granted. Of the girls in the seventh and eighth grades, 47 percent were sexually active. So were 92 percent of the boys in ninth grade. Eventually, however, the study found, the pregnancy rate at one pair of schools dropped by 30 percent while at the other pair it increased 58 percent. What explained the difference? The students among whom pregnancy declined participated in an intensive prevention program designed and staffed by the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. At the other schools, used as a control group, students got only the sex education courses required by the state of Maryland. The special program ran for nearly three years. It brought a social worker and nurse into each school to provide individual and group counseling. It also provided medical and contraceptive services at two clinics nearby. By the end of the program, the junior high boys were visiting the clinics as much as the girls; the median age for a girl's first intercourse had risen from 15 1/2 to more than 16 years, showing again that access to contraceptives need not encourage early sex.

title: Close the Loopholes, Take Down the Billboards

For years, billboard owners have been taking advantage of loopholes in the Highway Beautification Act of 1965, which instead of curbing the growth of unattractive roadside signs has caused their numbers to multiply. Before more scenic stretches of highway are ruined, we should revise the sections of the law that allow billboard owners to circumvent Congress's original intent.

description: The Economy

title: DPL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POSTINGS: In Brick Township; Town Houses on 20 Acres
description: In the last 15 years, Brick Township in Ocean County, N.J., has evolved from a comfortable summer resort of 35,000 permanent residents to a bedroom and retirement community of 60,000 people.

title: MEMORIAL TO HONOR SLAIN OFFICERS
