description: WORK began recently in Meriden on a memorial to Connecticut police officers which will be inscribed with the names of all of the officers who have died in the line of duty in the state.

title: TAPES SURPASS BRAILLE IN POPULARITY FOR BLIND
description: In 1934, the Library of Congress made its first recording for the blind, ''The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,'' produced on a wax disk. More than 50 years later, the cassette tape, a descendant of that effort to harness sound for the education of the blind, has grown so popular that it has surpassed the use of Braille in the library, home and classroom, according to academic experts.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TURTLE TRACKING - THE two rare guests at the Long Island Lighting Company's Shoreham Nuclear Power Station appear oblivious to their unusual surroundings. Meals of green crabs, mussels and oysters, and a little more room to swim, are more the priorities of the rare Kemp Ridley turtles than the tight security at their temporary new home.

title: Zeckendorf's Latest Blueprints
description: Manhattan Island, marked near its northern tip by a little red lighthouse, will have a big pink one of sorts at its southern tip if a development proposal announced by city officials last week goes as planned.

title: Nancy Dickstein Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Dickstein of Bethesda, Md., and Snowmass Village, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Joy Dickstein to Murray Charles Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lee Stern of Rockville, Md.

title: Jane Allison Charnley Weds Stephen Swain
description: Jane Allison Charnley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Charnley of Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, was married yesterday to Stephen James Swain, a son of Col. Oren Swain, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Swain of El Paso, Tex. The Rev. Robert Geehan performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., of which the bridegroom is an alumnus.

title: Black Women Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hidden Nuclear Quarrel
description: Two sets of talks with the Russians on special arms control issues are coming soon, and they deserve close attention because they will provide a political barometer.

title: SALZBURG
description: The number of young visitors to Mozart's birthplace seems to have notably increased lately. An Amadeus effect? Milos Forman's fortunate film - although set mainly in Vienna - has apparently whetted the appetite of young people everywhere for the city where the much-exploited Wunderkind was born. Whatever the case, older music lovers and the beautiful people will again flock to Salzburg this week for its festival, which opens Saturday.

title: Byrum Shoots 64-198 To Lead by 2 Strokes
description: Curt Byrum, fighting to regain his PGA Tour status, shot a six-under-par 64 today for a two-stroke lead at 12-under after three rounds of the Hardee's Golf Classic.

title: HOMES FOR THE RETARDED: OTHER VIEWPOINTS
description: Ivan Canuteson, the director at the Long Island Developmental Center, tells in the article ''Homes Eyed for Retarded'' about some 20-year-old buildings that require ''major renovation.'' Most Long Islanders have homes that are far older than 20 years old, and would never consider tearing them down because the heating system had malfunctioned for two days during the past winter.

title: Indian Point Sirens Tested
description: Sirens in the area around the Indian Point nuclear power plants here were tested for three minutes today, and all but one of the 77 worked properly, according to a Consolidated Edison Company official.

title:
ANTIQUES;
VINTAGE CLOTHING GAINS IN POPULARITY
description: MANY of those who once rebelled at wearing hand-me-downs and anything outdated are now flocking to shops that specialize in vintage clothing.

title:
DINING OUT;
A STRIKING CONTRAST IN CAPE MAY
description: IN A SEASIDE resort like Cape May, where the clock seemed to stop at the turn of the century and the gingerbread trim on the houses speaks more of 1886 than today, the contrast is striking.

title: NEWARK: ARTISTRY AND USES OF 'PRIMITIVE' ARCHITECTURE
description: ''SPECTACULAR VERNACULAR,'' an exhibition at the Newark Museum through Sept. 14, is a typical production by the Smithsonian Institution Exhibitions Service: a slickly presented selection of photographs and diagrams, but not enough explanatory text.

title: New Gloss On an Old Sales Tool
description: It is 8:30 on a Sunday morning and David C. Rutgers is sitting in the grand dining room of the Hotel Enquinox here, praising public auctions as a method of selling real estate. ''They are a much more efficient way of buying property,'' he siad enthusiastically. ''They force the seller to make an instant decision. And buyers respond to the potential for a bargain. They respond to greed.''

title:
ART;
STILL LIFES WITH LIVES OF THEIR OWN
description: IDEALLY, an artist's newest direction should come across as a personal step forward. This is certainly the case with the charcoal-on-canvas drawings that Mercedes Matter began some five years ago, and that are on view at the East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art.

title: City Teachers And Merit Pay
description: Teachers in Westchester and Nassau Counties earn as much as $50,000 - about $10,000 more than the top salaries in New York City - and more are expected to be hired soon. Perhaps with that in mind, the new president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said last week that the city should be able to offer its best teachers merit pay.

title: A Week's Worth Of Terrorism
description: If nations kept a police blotter on international terrorism, here is what would have been on it last week:

title: Death Sentence For Duvalier Aide
description: Wild cheers and cries of ''Murderer!'' and ''Assassin!'' erupted from a jury box in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti, last week as a former chief of security for Francois Duvalier was convicted of murder and torture and sentenced to death.

title: Jodie Wisniewski To Marry Aug. 30
description: An Aug. 30 wedding is planned by Jodie Louise Wisniewski and Robert Emmett King Jr., lawyers in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Chester Wisniewski of Birmingham, Mich., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. King of Plandome, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SLAVE. By William Malliol. (Norton, $16.95.) A comic novel about slavery? One has to admire the author's audacity, even if he doesn't pull it off.

title: POTATO SALAD, ONE OF SUMMER'S STARS, HAS MANY FACES
description: SUMMER is the time for some new potato salads, a statement open to interpretation.

title: Joanna McNeil Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Joanna Phelps McNeil to Andrew Lindsay Lewis 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Jr. of Schwenksville, Pa., and Omaha, Neb. An October wedding is planned.

title: A FLIGHT OF FANCY
description: Each year the American Contract Bridge League stages three major tournaments, which for several years have been designated the ''North American Championships.'' The players continue to call them, slightly inaccurately, the Spring Nationals, the Summer Nationals and the Fall Nationals, and they are about as likely to change their ways as New Yorkers are to refer to Sixth Avenue as the ''Avenue of the Americas.''

title: 4 METS ARRESTED IN FIGHT
description: Four Met players were arrested today after an early morning altercation with two Houston policemen at a local bar, but the attorney hired by the players said they felt they were ''unduly assaulted.'' The attorney said one, Tim Teufel, contended he was ''severely beaten'' in the incident.

title: KREMLIN REPORTS UNAPPROVED TESTS RIPPED CHERNOBYL
description: The explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear power station was caused by unauthorized and poorly controlled experiments during scheduled repairs, the Politburo said today.

title: City to Ask Judge to Reduce $65 Million Award by a Jury
description: City officials said yesterday that they would ask a judge to reduce a $65 million jury award to a Brooklyn woman in a malpractice suit against a city-run hospital.

title: LTV'S CHAPTER 11 IS A BLOW TO STEEL
description: LTV filed for Chapter 11, saying it has been overwhelmed by its more than $4 billion in debts. A big chunk of that debt was taken on in 1984 when LTV, figuring bigger could be more competitive, bought Republic Steel to become the nation's second-largest steelmaker. But it did not work -LTV was up against unrelenting pressure from imports and plants that it could not update fast enough. The result is the largest Chapter 11 filing in American industrial history, a step that the chairman, Raymond A. Hay, described as painful but necessary. Analysts say the filing signals a radical change in the American steel industry, and other steelmakers could follow LTV's lead.

title: RANCHERS IN ARIZONA RESENT CITIZEN GROUP'S BORDER PATROL
description: For ranchers in this remote border region, the border crossings of the illegal aliens known as mojados, Spanish for wets, are part of the fabric of everyday social and economic life.

title: NO JOKE, ROBERT KLEIN HAS A QUIET COLLABORATOR
description: One of the difficulties about being Robert Klein is that you have to be Robert Klein so often. Over the last several years, the popular comedian has appeared on HBO many times and in many contexts, including four feature-length stand-up performances that the premium service presented as part of its ''On Location'' series. The latest of these solo outings, ''Robert Klein on Broadway,'' arrives Saturday night at 10, and lasts for 60 minutes. All told, that's a lot of Robert Klein.

title: Boston Police Recruits Face Remedial Schooling
description: Faced with a high number of recruits flunking from the police academy, city officials are planning a program to help them learn to read and write.

title: TRIBE'S BINGO LURES EAGER CROWDS
description: THE biggest bingo jackpot in New England history is expected to draw 1,700 people Saturday to an Indian tribe's new 33,000-square-foot, $4.5 million betting parlor in Ledyard.

title: CAPE MAY-BASED FISH FACTORY IS ONLY ONE IN THE STATE
description: THE Atlantic Prince, a 150-foot-long, state-of-the-art fishing vessel, intrigues dock watchers here as she weighs anchor and heads for the continental shelf 100 miles off the coast, her crew of 30 prepared to make the craft their home for as long as a week as they net, process, freeze and package her catch so that it is market-ready.

title: ENVOYS ASK TO SEE DETAINED REPORTER
description: The Peking bureau chief of The New York Times remained in Government detention here today for a third day as American and British officials pressed efforts to visit him.

title: 19 Nations in Boycott of Games
description: The Commonwealth Games boycott grew today, with 19 nations having deserted the event to protest Britain's policies on South Africa.

title: LET'S TREAT THE EARTH LIKE HOME
description: OUR planet, earth, is treated like dirt.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TRAP. By Dan Billany. (Faber & Faber, Paper, $10.95.) First published in England soon after World War II, ''The Trap'' offers a detailed, often enthralling first-person account of British military campaigns in the Libyan desert.

title: SAVORING SUMMER EN PLEIN AIR
description: Summer comes grudgingly, and late, to Montreal. But finally, cross-country ski trails along the St. Lawrence River give way to bicycles, and horse-drawn carriages atop Mount Royal exchange their steel runners for big, wooden-spoked wheels. Potted maples arrive by truck at downtown sidewalks, cafe umbrellas blossom like garden perennials in this Paris-in-the-Americas of 2.9 million and the temperature heads for the 90's in July.

title: HOMES FOR THE RETARDED: OTHER VIEWPOINTS
description: The recent article ''Homes Eyed for Retarded'' makes it very clear that the plan of the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities to house clients in small residential units (S.R.U.'s) built on the grounds of the Long Island Developmental Center, and to develop additional adjacent property to be sold as private homes, has met with a broad spectrum of reaction, ranging from strong support to intense criticism, from varying interest groups.

title: CRENSHAW SURVIVES A STORMY ROUND
description: The round that Ben Crenshaw played today in the British Open showed how hard it is to score well on one of the most difficult links courses in Britain. Under today's conditions of wind, rain and cold, a 5-over-par 75 was a creditable score, but it probably cost Crenshaw a chance to improve his position significantly.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DETENTIONS WORRY CHARITIES IN U.S.
description: For many years, groups of South African blacks have received substantial assistance from American philanthropies led by the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations and the Carnegie Corporation.

title: CHANCELLOR AT U. OF MAINE, IN JOB FOR 2 WEEKS, QUITS
description: Jack E. Freeman, chancellor of the seven campuses of the University of Maine, resigned Wednesday after only two weeks on the job.

title: Semites and Anti-Semites
description: To the Editor:

title: ALASKA
description: To the Editor: Regarding the inquiry about seeing Alaska (Q & A, Travel, May 18): we asked a similar question a year ago, and found what for us was the perfect answer.

title: WHY LADY CHATTERLEY MET THE GARDNER
description: Now that I have been a dedicated gardener for more than 12 years, I understand exactly why Lady Chatterley fell in love with her gardener, Mellors.

title: SOCIETY WOMEN, DELICATELY SLASHED
description: FANTOMAS By Marcel Allain and Pierre Souvestre. With an introduction by John Ashbery. 324 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. IN 1911 a French publisher covered the walls of Paris with posters depicting ''Fantomas, Master of Dread, Torturer, Emperor of Crime,'' and created a minor myth even before readers had purchased the first volume of his adventures. Within weeks Fantomas had become a popular hero, a fashionable hero, a Dadaist hero, the hero of the intellectual elite.

title: Miss Saltzman to Wed Louis Michael Phillips
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Saltzman of Sayreville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Saltzman, to Louis Michael Phillips, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Phillips of New York and Los Angeles. A September wedding is planned.

title: Ferree Leads Seniors By a Shot in 2d Round
description: Bruce Crampton and Gene Littler made charges, but Jim Ferree took the lead in the second round of the $251,000 PGA Senior Tour's Greater Grand Rapids Open today.

title: RUNNERS TRADE IN THEIR SHOES FOR ROWING SCULLS
description: Until recently, whenever she felt like exercising, Maria Maisano donned her running shoes and headed for the quarter-mile track at Central Catholic High School in Norwalk.

title: TESTS OF PROPELLER-AIDED JET ENGINE MAY SHOW IT CUTS FUEL USE BY 30%
description: Late this summer, a Boeing 727 airliner, its right jet replaced by an engine with a propeller-like look and some ingenious new twists, will undergo test flights over the California desert.

title: TV Evangelist Forms Panel To Explore Presidential Bid
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, has formed an exploratory committee to ''test the waters'' for a possible bid for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, according to a spokesman.

title: DATA BANK: July 20, 1986

ON LONG ISLAND;
Towns Move to Limit Investor Activity
description: THE rental shortage on the Island has encouraged so many investors to buy and rent out units in new condominium developments and homeowners' associations that some towns have begun taking preventive measures.

title: U.S. REPORT STIRS NEW SHOREHAM DISPUTE
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY and the Long Island Lighting Company are at odds once again, this time over a Federal report that notes deficiencies in the company's management n of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station during a period that included low-power testing.

title: 'Paper Pollution'
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVENTUROUS ANTHOLOGIES REVISIT THE BIG BANDS
description: When Time-Life Music inaugurated a series of big band reissues a few years ago - boxed packages of two disks, each devoted to a single band - it started with the customary names: Glenn Miller, Tommy Dorsey, Benny Goodman, Harry James, Duke Ellington. It went on to some less frequently reissued bands - Artie Shaw, Woody Herman, Jimmy Dorsey, Les Brown - before it started going back to the old dependables with second volumes of Miller, Goodman, Dorsey and Ellington.

title: HAMDEN
description: FROM almost anywhere in Hamden, Conn., an enormous figure can be seen lying on its back atop a 600-foot mountain in Sleeping Giant State Park. Formed by volcanic eruptions millions of years ago, the profile of its head and body can be seen for miles, snoozing in everlasting comfort above what has come to be called The Land of The Sleeping Giant.

title: SPAIN'S NEW FACE
description: Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, may attribute his success to his ability to mix his socialism with ''realism,'' but his realism can also be equated with what most of us call ''social democracy'' (''Spain's New Face,'' by Edward Schumacher, June 22). Any government can claim to be ''realistic,'' but only democratic governments move ahead with the consent of the majority of people, as expressed in free elections.

title: A MENTOR'S PRESENCE
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS ago, for the first and last time, I made the mistake of referring to Richebourg Gaillard McWilliams as ''Doctor.'' He did not complain, but there was disappointment in his glance, or so I imagined in my eagerness to please him. A precise man in all things, he insisted that freshmen learn that some professors were properly addressed as ''Mister.''

title: KENTUCKY TREE HOUSE LOSES TO ZONING, 3 TO 2
description: To some, this small city's efforts to protect the attractiveness of its residential areas threatens something even more pleasant: child's play.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'SHIP OF FOOLS' TO STING
description: Bill Cosby in Aesop's Fables; Karl-Lorimar Home Video. 30 minutes. $19.95.

title: Labor Factor Confounds Cost-Cutters
description: ON major construction sites in New York City, union rules prevail. Only electricians can turn on the lights, only plumbers can operate the water lines and two workers must operate each elevator that moves materials and workers.

title: Niekro Wins 307th
description: Tony Bernazard led off the game with a home run tonight and Mel Hall keyed a five-run third inning with a two-run single, helping the Cleveland Indians to a 6-4 victory over the Kansas City Royals. It was Phil Niekro's 307th career victory.

title: Play Budget! Play Ball!
description: After the Supreme Court ruled that Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, could not be given the authority to order spending cuts under the budget-balancing law, he was offered jurisdiction in another area.

title: THESE DAYS, CALIFORNIA HAS AMPLE REASON TO FEEL SHAKY
description: IN California, there is no such thing as ''just another earthquake.'' Even small tremors may be studied for clues to a larger seismic pattern or as possible harbingers of a big quake, which many experts say is probable in the next 30 years. So the two moderate jolts in Southern California in the last two weeks have prompted a flurry of public speculation and scientific activity. Some seismologists rushed to the desert epicenter of the July 8 quake north of Palm Springs, which, at 5.9 on the Richter scale, was the strongest California has felt in seven years. Although a 5.3-magnitude quake off the coast of Oceanside last week was the largest recorded offshore in the San Diego area since seismic records were started in 1932, it caused much less interest, partly because little can be done to study underwater faults. What did they mean? Last week, Katherine Roberts, an editor of The Week in Review, asked several experts for their assessments of the recent seismic activity and the state of earthquake prediction. Following are excerpts from their remarks. THE TIME IS NIGH The segment of the San Andreas Fault that runs west from Bakersfield in the Central Valley down through the north and east of Los Angeles last ''broke'' in 1857, with a magnitude of 8 and a quarter. We now have a prehistoric record of that area and have been able to show that great earthquakes happen on it about every 145 years, plus or minus several decades.

title: Little Missouri, 17-1, Takes the Brooklyn
description: Little Missouri, the longest shot in the race at 17-1, won a bizarrely run Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park after Roo Art, the 4-5 favorite, squandered a 14-length lead.

title: French Literature
description: The French Embassy has added a science and technology bulletin to its stable of publications offered free to Americans. The bulletin, French Advances in Science and Technology, has taken its place beside a digest of the French press and a glossy journal that has the look and feel of Life magazine.

title: 3 Injured in Fire at Hotel
description: Three people were hurt Friday night in a fire on the third floor of a residential hotel, the Belleclaire, at 77th Street and Broadway, fire officials said yesterday. They said the cause of the fire, which started at 10:25 P.M., had not been determined. Two residents were treated at Roosevelt Hospital for smoke inhalation, officials said, and the third was treated at the scene.

title: On the Books
description: After years of dispensing free political advice to his friend Mayor Koch, Daniel Wolf quietly turned pro in 1985, according to financial disclosure forms filed by Mr. Koch last week. Mr. Wolf, a longtime friend of the Mayor who has also been known as an important but unpaid City Hall adviser since 1978, has received $5,000 a month from Koch campaign funds since December, according to the documents. Explaining the payments, Mayor Koch said Mr. Wolf first went on the payroll last summer.

title: JAZZ: ANNIE ROSS
description: ANNIE ROSS - who gained renown 30 years ago as the highest voice, with the clearest articulation of the complex lyrics of Jon Hendricks, in the jazz vocalizing trio of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross - has spent the 25 years since she left that threesome primarily as an actress and cabaret singer in England, other parts of Europe and in the Far East.

title: Black Women Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: A BOY'S BOOK FOR ADULTS
description: MABEL PARKER; OR, THE HIDDEN TREASURE A Tale of the Frontier Settlements. By Horatio Alger Jr. Preface by Gary Scharnhorst. 131 pp. Hamden, Conn.: Archon Books. $17.50.

title: 32 Sri Lankans Killed In Ethnic Violence
description: Thirty-two people were killed in three ethnic clashes on Thursday, according to Government and rebel sources.

title: Let's Keep On So Proudly Hailing That Banner; Sole Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT OF MEXICO ORDERS INVESTIGATION IN DISPUTED ELECTION
description: President Miguel de la Madrid has ordered a top-level review of charges of widespread vote fraud in elections July 6 that were won by his political party in the state of Chihuahua, the Government said today.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ONCE again, the hurricane season is here, the time of year when emergency-management officials in Trenton and coastal counties keep their fingers crossed that New Jersey's luck will hold out. The state has not been hit by a full-blown hurricane since the 1940's and, statistically, it has been overdue for a big one since 1980.

title: SANDINISTAS HAVE AN EDGE IN SIZE, SPEED AND STRENGTH
description: STANDING before a large map of northern Nicaragua last week, Capt. Ricardo Wheelock repeated the Government's assertion, made regularly for more than a year, that rebels backed by the United States have been ''strategically defeated.'' He said Government forces fully control the north and had inflicted more than 4,000 casualties on the rebels during the first six months of the year, a statistic viewed with some skepticism among neutral analysts in Managua.

title: CRISIS RECEDES AS COUNTY ACTS ON GARBAGE ISSUES
description: THE threatened garbage crisis in the county appeared last week to have been contained, with communities beginning to suspend collections of newspapers, metals and other dry trash and private carters getting increased allocations to dump commercial waste at the county resource-recovery center in Peekskill.

title: IN MASSACHUSETTS, ARTISTS IN A QUEST FOR WORKING SPACE
description: Escalating real-estate costs make life precarious for one key element of the Massachusetts art world - the artist. But with the help of a consultant hired by the state, artists are banding together to buy and build places where they can live and work without fear of eviction Anthony J. Radich, director of art projects for the National Conference of State Legislatures, said he believed the program in Massachusetts, which is home to about 17,000 artists, was the only statewide effort in the country aimed at helping artists acquire permanent, affordable space.

title: Curfew in Boston Is Lifted
description: A curfew on the Boston Common and adjacent Public Garden that was criticized by advocates for the homeless was dropped without fanfare after four days over which officials said public safety had improved. The curfew in the garden and the common, from 10 P.M. to dawn, was ordered by Mayor Raymond L. Flynn to combat what officials called a serious problem with gambling, robberies, murder and drug dealing and drug use.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE HIROSHIMA MAIDENS: A Story of Courage, Compassion, and Survival, by Rodney Barker. (Penguin, $6.95.) In 1955, 10 years after the bombing of Hiroshima, 25 young Japanese women disfigured in the blast came to the United States for reconstructive surgery. Rodney Barker's account of their suffering, their journey to America and their later lives is ''a beguiling, unpretentious book that is neither political tract nor historical analysis,'' Taylor Branch wrote here last year. A SWELL-LOOKING BABE, by Jim Thompson. (Black Lizard/Creative Arts, $3.95.) A hotel bellboy is drawn into a robbery scheme that ends in murder in this crime thriller by Jim Thompson. In 1954 our reviewer, Anthony Boucher, called the book one of the best of Jim Thompson's ''sharp and markedly individual studies in crime and punishment. . . . On the surface he's content to tell a rattling good story. . . . Beneath that surface there's a subtle study of the interplay of conscious and subconscious motivations.'' The same publisher has reissued two more Thompson novels, AFTER DARK, MY SWEET and WILD TOWN ($3.95 each). The latter, set in a West Texas oil town, is about an ex-convict who has been lured into a job as a hotel detective in a plot to kill the proprietor. In 1958, Mr. Boucher said it ''explodes at the end into a surprising series of whodunit twists.'' THE NOVEL OF THE FUTURE, by Anais Nin. (Swallow Press/Ohio University, $10.95.) The novelist, diarist and critic offers her thoughts on the process of literary creation in a collection of essays.

title: NEW YORK COURT ADDS TO RULES FOR MANDATING MENTAL DRUGS
description: A decision by New York State's highest court has added New York to a growing number of states that require psychiatrists to go to court when they want to override a mental patient's refusal to take antipsychotic drugs.

title: RETURN TO OLD HOUSE IN THE BRONX KINDLES SIBLING MEMORIES
description: WHENEVER I hear the music from the Ginger Rogers-Fred Astaire films, a light-hearted happiness comes over me. I see myself as a little girl with my brother Martin. He is playing the banjo and singing. Our family and friends watch him, a slim, fair-haired boy, as he sings my two favorite songs, ''The Continental'' and ''Cheek to Cheek.'' Singing the words, ''I'm in heaven,'' I see him put his banjo down and pick me up, almost carrying me as we dance around the room. I am in heaven, and he knows it.

title: SPECTER OF AWARD FOLLOWS SABERHAGEN
description: Maybe Cy Young was never afflicted because he never won it, but Bret Saberhagen clearly is the latest victim of the curse of the Cy Young Award. Although the curse doesn't always strike, it can be devastating when it does. If Saberhagen is skeptical, he can seek the views of Rick Sutcliffe, John Denny, LaMarr Hoyt, Pete Vuckovich, Steve Stone and Randy Jones, among others.

title: SANDINISTAS HOLD BIG RALLY TO MARK 7 YEARS IN POWER
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today defended recent actions by his Government against the opposition and denied that the measures represented a radicalization of Sandinista rule.

title: ACTORS AND AUDIENCES BREW FUN FROM IMPROVISATION
description: Asking Severn Darden to play Bozo the Clown or a Senate page, as happened one recent evening at the audience participation improvisational show, ''Sills & Company,'' is like asking Placido Domingo to sing ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.'' In both cases, the suggestion is mere child's play and beneath the artist's talent. After all, Mr. Darden is a legendary master of improvisational theater, the creator of Valter von der Vogelweide, the hilarious Professor of Interdiscipline, as well as other nitpicking experts of esoterica. The burly, bearded Mr. Darden, who has recently made his career as a character actor in the movies and on television, is a man who delights not only his audience but his acting colleagues.

title: LABOR GROUP SEEKS MEETING WITH 8 DETAINED BY PRETORIA
description: Visiting international labor union leaders appealed to South Africa today for an urgent answer to their request for a meeting with unionists held under the state of emergency.

title: TWO CHILDREN PUT SPECIAL NOTE INTO NIGHT AT CONCERT
description: SUMMER concerts at the 67-acre Lyndhurst estate, a National Historic Landmark in Tarrytown, are pleasant events. This particular evening is one of the perfect ones - a balmy twilight with thousands of picnickers dotting the hillside overlooking the Hudson River's Tappan Zee. The sun is setting over the Palisades on the opposite shore, allowing the night sounds to rise.

title: MEXICO VOTE: NEW VOICES JOIN PROTEST
description: In the 17th-century cathedral here, the priests recently erected two large, hand-lettered signs quoting a pastoral letter issued in March by a group of Roman Catholic bishops in the state of Chihuahua.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING WAYWARD PLANTS IN CHECK
description: A NUMBER of widely planted ornamentals, though attractive and useful in the landscape, have a tendency to become invasive and weedy - any plant that is out of place is a weed.

title: Ford Workers on Strike At Factory Near Atlanta
description: Three thousand Ford Motor Company employees went on strike today, saying the company had accelerated the assembly line at its new plant here without hiring more workers.

title: SHE WAS ABOVE SELF-REPROACH
description: MARGARET BOURKE-WHITE By Vicki Goldberg. Illustrated. 426 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.95.

title: Unwanted Drama At a City Theater
description: New York City's older theaters are often prized for their period architecture, but some may be reaching a dangerous age. Last week the ceiling of the 94-year-old Murray Hill Theater collapsed, injuring three people and prompting an order for precautionary inspections of all city theaters built before 1938.

title: THE STREAK ENDED, AND DiMAGGIO WASN'T HAPPY
description: ''N O, no, you got it wrong,'' Joe DiMaggio was saying. ''I couldn't have said, 'I'm glad it's over.' I would have loved to hit all year.''

title: EXPERTS' ADVICE AWAITS GARDENERS AT RUTGERS CLINIC
description: HORTICULTURAL experts from throughout the state will participate in a one-day clinic Saturday at the display gardens and vegetable research farm of Rutgers University's Cook College.

title: CHILDREN OF POVERTY
description: In his article ''Children of Poverty - Crisis in New York'' (June 8), Andrew Stein describes the enormous challenges facing New York City and the nation in meeting the needs of poor families. But he understates what the city is doing to cope with the problems.

title: VARANASI
description: To the Editor: I read with appreciation, and some fond memories, Charlotte Green's account of the ''Flute Seller of Varanasi.'' I think I may know, however, an explanation for that ''Hindu chant'' with a Verdi melody that she encountered.

title: NEW YORK CITY CITES 28 ESTABLISHMENTS IN HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 28 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A SAMPLING OF EUROPE'S SPA TOWNS
description: Following is a selection of the more celebrated spa towns in various countries in Western Europe. It offers a glimpse of the character of each town, some of the leisure activities and choice places to stay and dine.

title: EDDY RUNNING ON RECORD -- DODD'S
description: AFTER waiting in the wings for weeks while the Democratic and Republican fights for governor held center stage, the contest to elect a United States Senator from Connecticut this fall is finally attracting some billing.

title: Robin J. Roy Wed to Dr. Michael Katz
description: Robin Jennifer Roy, coordinator of editorial and marketing communications services for the Presbyterian Hospital in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Katz, who is the Reuben S. Carpentier Professor and chairman of the department of pediatrics and professor of public health at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Judge Philip G. Wolff of the Town of North Elba, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Land's End, a lodge in Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: THE C.I.A. ON CAMPUS
description: The pervasive secrecy of the C.I.A. can also have its humorous aspects.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Under the Umbrella of Art - The artist Christo wrapped a rocky Australian coastline and Paris's Pont-Neuf in sheets of plastic. In ''Christo'' (Pantheon), by Dominique G. Laporte, Christo outlines ''The Umbrellas, Project for Japan and Western U.S.A.''

title: MALICE AND REUNIONS
description: During the 1950's, Edmund Wilson (1895-1972) wrote for The New Yorker; put together five collections of his earlier work, including ''The Shores of Light'' (1952); published two other books (''A Piece of My Mind: Reflections at Sixty'' in 1956, and in 1958 ''The Scrolls From the Dead Sea,'' the research for which took him to Israel); and, at his family's house in Talcottville in New York's Adirondacks, worked on ''Patriotic Gore'' and ''Apologies to the Iroquois.'' He also traveled to Europe twice. All the while he suffered from gout and high blood pressure.

title: THE NEW RUSH TO SKAGWAY
description: Tucked away at the head of the Lynn Canal, the final arm of the Inside Passage, that vast inland waterway that knits together the hilly islands of southeast Alaska, is Skagway, a miniature port (population: 760) with a Brigadoon quality.

title: LATIN DEAD? VENI, VIDI, VICI
description: DON'T TALK ABOUT dead languages with the Rev. Reginald Foster. He will have none of it. And he will tell you so in Latin. Father Foster, who hails from Milwaukee, is one of the Vatican's top Latin specialists, and his dedication to the language is total.

title: THE HEAD-TURNING SUNBIRD
description: WHEN General Motors launched its little J-cars in May '81, the company was making its first giant push against the invaders from Japan. The idea was to market a front-wheel-drive subcompact that was inexpensive, nicely put together and that could really squeeze a gallon of gas.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PRODIGY. By Amy Wallace. (Dutton, $18.95.) At the age of 3 William James Sidis learned Latin as a gift to his father; at 11 he was admitted to Harvard College and gave a lecture to the mathematics club.

title: CORRECTION
description: An interview with Mary Perot Nichols on the Television page of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misidentified the syndicator of the children's radio series ''Kids America.'' The programs are nationally distributed over the American Public Radio network.

title: Karen Krupnik Becomes a Bride
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Karen Marie Krupnik and Gregory Zaharoff, who received M.B.A. degrees in 1982 from Harvard University, were married by the Rev. John Bishop.

title: House Arrest Instead of Prison
description: CONVICTED in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of insurance fraud, a 35-year-old legal secretary could have received up to 50 years in prison and a $56,000 fine. The judge sentenced her instead to house arrest for two years.

title: Paris Journalists End Strike; Agency to Modify Staff Cuts
description: Employees of Agence France-Presse ended a four-day strike today after the news agency's management agreed to modify a reorganization program, journalists said.

title: A FAMILY CELEBRATES ITS PLACE IN HISTORY
description: THOUGH they are scattered all over North America ''like buckshot,'' according to one member, nearly 100 Olmsteds gathered at the University of Hartford last weekend for a family reunion.

title: TEARS AND PRAYERS FOR HOWSER
description: Gloom, hope and resolve mingled in this baseball city this weekend, stretching from the fans to the players to the clubhouse and even to the opposing manager. The pall arose after Friday's announcement that Dick Howser, the popular manager of the World Series champion Kansas City Royals, would undergo surgery for a brain tumor next week and miss the rest of the season.

title: 'The Fifties'
description: During the 1950's, Edmund Wilson (1895-1972) wrote for The New Yorker; put together five collections of his earlier work, including ''The Shores of Light'' (1952); published two other books (''A Piece of My Mind: Reflections at Sixty'' in 1956, and in 1958 ''The Scrolls From the Dead Sea,'' the research for which took him to Israel); and, at his family's house in Talcottville in New York's Adirondacks, worked on ''Patriotic Gore'' and ''Apologies to the Iroquois.'' He also traveled to Europe twice. All the while he suffered from gout and high blood pressure.

title: Entitled to Better: Turkey's Trial
description: Despite recent progress, Turkey's democracy is stunted by a regime that will not grant rudimentary rights to its critics. A month ago, former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit said aloud that under its present Constitution, fashioned by the armed forces, Turkey is not fully democratic.

title: VARANASI
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest Charlotte Green's article ''The Flute Seller of Varanasi'' (Travel, May 25).

title: TILE FLOORS: SWEEP, SLOSH AND SCRUB
description: In recent years floors paved with slate or quarry tile have become increasingly popular for use in entrance halls, kitchens and other rooms. Both of these ''outdoor'' flooring materials have the natural look that many homeowners prefer, and they create a luxurious-looking floor that blends in nicely with almost any type of decorative scheme.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 20, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We would have liked assistance of a different nature, entirely run by Bolivians.

title:
INVESTING;
DODGING THE BIOTECH SLUMP
description: As biotechnology fever has cooled, the stocks of many biotech companies have fallen sharply in recent weeks. To be sure, some popular stocks, such as Cetus and Genentech, still retain astronomical market valuations - more than $2.5 billion for Genentech.

title: NEWEST INVERT DISCOVERY IS SOLD AT AUCTION
description: If one of 100 known United States airmail inverts sells for more than $50,000, how much should one of 85 known $1 Americana inverts be worth? That was the question collectors, investors and speculators were asking themselves when word hit the market that a partial sheet of the current $1 Americana stamp had been discovered with an inverted candle.

title: COMMUTING TOKYO-STYLE: SAMURAI STRAPHANGER
description: EVER since coming to Tokyo, I now make a conscious effort to set aside time in the morning for scrambling eggs and brewing coffee. A decent breakfast serves a number of purposes for a foreigner in Japan; fortifying the brain at this early hour allows for better kanji comprehension when reading signs on the streets, as well as better coordination when dodging bicycles whose riders demand right of way. But, most important, a morning meal provides that extra kick which can lead to peak performance during subway rush hour.

title: CAN A MAN'S BASIC BOX BECOME HIS CASTLE?
description: I DID not go looking for architecture when I bought a house last year. I did not think I could afford it.

title: BACKSTAGE AT SUMMERFARE IS A BUSY CAST OF WORKERS
description: BEFORE the curtain rises, extensive planning and intricate logistics are required to put even a single performance on stage. When there are 80 performances of dance, drama, music and film, as is the case at this year's Pepsico Summerfare in Purchase, the effort can seem monumental even when all goes smoothly. Given the snags and surprises that inevitably occur, the people who work behind the scenes at the four-week festival find it no small miracle that the pieces fall into place.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BASEBALL AND THE AMERICAN DREAM. By Joseph Durso. (The Sporting News, $16.95.) Joseph Durso's celebration of baseball shows that not much has changed in America's pastime.

title: A GENTILE IN SPITE OF HIMSELF
description: THE MYTHMAKER Paul and the Invention of Christianity. By Hyam Maccoby. 237 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95. THE line of Hyam Maccoby's argument in ''The

title: BIRTHDAY FOR ALBANY
description: New York State's capital, Albany, will celebrate its 300th birthday on Tuesday.

title: AT SEA ON AN ISLAND IN MAINE
description: Two notices - one in the single store on the island, the other on a slab of rock overlooking the harbor - tell some of the story of Matinicus, a small dot in the Atlantic 22 miles off the coast of Maine.

title: HOW COOKS CREATE
description: PROFESSIONAL COOKS OFTEN FACE the problem of developing fresh, creative and original recipes. Even the most flamboyantly inventive chef will occasionally admit that there is nothing new, culinarily speaking, under the sun.

title: Semites and Anti-Semites
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Consider the Cook: Gadgets and Giftware - Consider the Cook is in Cross River's Yellow Monkey Village and its summer sale ends July 31 - a minimum of 10 percent off everything, including just-delivered goods, and a tableful of gadgets and giftwares at half price until gone. During the sale a charge of $1.50 is applied for gift boxes, but gift-wrapping is free at other times.

title: WHO'S GETTING POLLED ANYWAY?
description: OPINION polls seem to be everywhere these days, asking such questions as is the press credible?

title: Kyle L. MacAusland Weds Evan S. Berlin
description: Kyle Lake MacAusland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald MacAusland of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Evan Scott Berlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Berlin of Exeter, N.H. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Edward S. Sulesky at the Josiah Smith Tavern in Weston, Mass.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: Is it possible to travel to Cuba from the United States, and, if so, what documents are needed? If I flew to Cuba from Mexico City, what documents would I need? - J. J. M., Massapequa, N.Y. Answer:An American contemplating a visit to Cuba must consider the legal issues. An official of the United States State Department says that while the Government has not banned travel to Cuba, United States citizens and residents are forbidden to spend American money there. However, the financial restriction is waived for certain visitors, including government officials, journalists and professional researchers, who want to go to Cuba in connection with their work, and people with close family ties there. They have what a spokesman for the Treasury Department called a general license to visit.

title: A PRACTICE IN SECOND OPINIONS
description: DR. ADRIENNE MATYAS KRAUSZ never forgot what her mother told her about the shoemaker who tried, without much success, to undertake new endeavors.

title: 'CAESER' AT DREW
description: FOR CULTURAL consciousness, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival rates cheers.

title: BOLIVIA REPORTS WERE WITHHELD
description: Several American news organizations say they knew about a week and a half ago of plans for United States participation in Bolivian drug raids but decided not to report the plans, largely out of fear of undermining the operation.

title: PESTICIDE USE ON FARMS DOWN
description: FOR the first time since 1979, the amount of restricted pesticides used on Connecticut farmland decreased last year, by more than 25 percent, a state report shows.

title: AFTER 36 YEARS, A CLASS SAYS THANKS
description: From the time she was a little girl, Lillian H. Rosenberg wanted to be a teacher. When she was 18, her dream came true at Public School 99, an elementary school in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: JAY DAY
description: FOR months, even years, the threat to the Peter Jay House has been there. The Greek Revival structure, built in 1838 by the son of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States, sits on a fine piece of property -a developer's dream - adjacent to the county's scenic 137-acre Marshlands Conservancy in Rye.

title: FEWER WHALES SIGHTED AS TINY FISH DISAPPEAR
description: The multimillion-dollar whale-watching industry off Massachusetts is being threatened by an exodus of whales that scientists suspect has been caused by a depletion of a tiny, pencil-shaped fish that the whales eat by the ton.

title: Another Look at An Israeli Scandal
description: Israel's Attorney General, Yosef Harish, last week ordered a police investigation of the scandal involving the domestic security agency, Shin Beth. He acted within hours after the Cabinet voted, 14 to 11, against establishing its own commission of inquiry into the killing of two Palestinians who had helped hijack a bus in April 1984.

title: Cabaret
description: When Helen Schneider opened at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, a month-and-a-half ago, it had been nine years since she had sung in a New York cabaret. She had spent the intervening time in Europe, where she performed both as an actress and as a singer.

title: Miss Acker Weds James A. Rice 2d
description: Amanda Mathilde Acker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Brewster Acker of Ogdensburg, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Alfred Rice 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Davison Rice of Flint, Mich. The Rev. Dr. David L. Moyer performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Top Brazilian Official On Environment Resigns
description: The head of Brazil's Environmental Protection Agency has resigned after 12 years in his post, citing what he called attempts to curtail the agency's independence.

title: Q and A
description: Fixed-Rate Co-op Loans - Question: Why are banks reluctant to offer fixed-rate mortgages for New York City cooperatives? Where can such mortgages be found? . . . F. W., Manhattan Answer: Lenders are generally less willing to give fixed-rate mortgages for co-ops than for condominiums or for single-family homes. Primary lenders usually sell fixed-rate mortgages in the secondary market. But the secondary market - mainly the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association (Freddie Mac) - has not been willing to buy fixed-rate loans on cooperatives.

title: DOING THE LINDO WITH MICROS
description: ONE of the most arcane procedures in management is the algebraic nightmare that goes under the name of linear programming. Most managers would not relish the task of facing this alphanumeric hydra without the aid of a computer, and until recently it lay largely within the universe of multimillion-dollar mainframes, where it was often associated with a heavyweight program called LINDO. Now, however, LINDO has been distilled to a version that can be utilized by micros.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS RESISTING NEW TEACHER-SALARY AID
description: PUBLIC school officials in Westchester are considering the unthinkable - turning down state aid already approved for their districts.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE COMPLEAT VIOLINIST: Thoughts, Exercises, Reflections of an Itinerant Violinist. By Yehudi Menuhin. (Summit, $15.95.) In this little book, intended for the violin student and yet frequently relevant to all musical activity, the master violinist alternates panegyrics to the musical life with practical, yogalike exercises for shaping the musician's body.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'SHIP OF FOOLS' TO STING
description: Mabel Mercer: A Singer's Singer; V.I.E.W. Video, 42 minutes. $39.95.

title: Miami's Newman Quits
description: Ed Newman, the Dolphin guard whose 13-year-career was marred by illness and injury, reluctantly announced his retirement after he and Miami failed to reach terms on a new contract. At the same time, Charles Bowser, a Dolphins linebacker, returned to the Miami training camp less than a day after walking off and indicating he wanted to be traded.

title: SATELLITE DISHES: L.I. LAWS BLUR THE PICTURE
description: HARVEY MINARS has been waging a four-year battle with the Town of Hempstead to gain approval for installation of a satellite dish antenna at his home in Woodmere.

title: BRASSERIE ORIGINALITY IN BRIDGEPORT
description: IF one were giving out report cards, Paris Bistro, a new brasserie-type restaurant in Bridgeport, would earn an A for creativity.

title: TAMING THE SWINGS OF THE YEN AND DOLLAR
description: A HALF-CENTURY ago the rising sun meant Japanese militarism. For the last two decades, it has signified Tokyo's relentless conquest of foreign markets. Today, it could be the soaring yen, a serious threat to global economic stability.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE WAR OF THE TWO EMPERORS: The Duel Between Napoleon and Alexander. Russia, 1812. By Curtis Cate. (Random House, $24.95.) In 1812 Russia stood alone in Europe against Napoleon, victor of Austerlitz, Wagram, Jena and all those other battlefields whose names are known to anyone who has trudged the tourist's Paris.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING WAYWARD PLANTS IN CHECK
description: A NUMBER of widely planted ornamentals, though attractive and useful in the landscape, have a tendency to become invasive and weedy - any plant that is out of place is a weed.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FARMING NATURALLY - For the second year, Alton and Marge Eliason are opening up their 28-acre organically run homestead in Northford to visitors. At noon today, Mr. Eliason, who will be 70 years old this month, will conduct a tour to see the vegetable gardens, the Appaloosa horses, the 100-by-115-foot spring-fed pool, fruit trees, berry bushes and grape arbors.

title: THE SEARCH FOR GORBACHEV
description: GORBACHEV By Zhores A. Medvedev. 272 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: On L.I., the Graying of a Bikers' Rite
description: If it's Tuesday night, Steve Mufson gets on his Harley-Davidson Low Rider in Freeport and heads west. Rich Alexander climbs aboard his Honda Gold Wing in Franklin Square and rides east. Jack Maddonia and Gaspare Spano ride like the wind from Brooklyn.

title: Anne Case Plans October Wedding
description: Anne Catherine Case, a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in economics at Princeton University, and Edward Rhodes, a Paul-Henri Spaak and a Ford Program postdoctoral fellow at the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University, plan to be married in October.

title: STEERING STUDENTS FROM THE RUSSIAN IVY LEAGUE
description: WHEN the Soviet Union announced two years ago that it would revamp its schools, it was a victory for the economic planners who argued that the needs of the labor market should dictate educational practices. After an unusually lively public debate, it was decided that, among other things, more students would be channeled into vocational schools and children would start school at 6 instead of 7 years of age.

title: REMEMBERING ROGER MARIS
description: IT'S known as ''having a year.'' And no other baseball player ever had a year like Roger Maris did in 1961 in hitting a record 61 home runs. Most of the players on the 1961 World Series champion Yankees returned to the Stadium yesterday for their silver anniversary old-timers' reunion. And as they were squeezing into pin-striped uniforms again, Whitey Ford glanced across the Yankee clubhouse filled with people carrying notebooks and microphones.

title: LIBERAL PARTY, DESPITE SMALL SIZE, CLINGS TO ITS ROLE
description: THEY do not have the influence of the Conservatives, or the strict ideology of the Right to Life Party, but the county's other ''minor'' political party, the Liberal Party, is hoping its message will get heard by at least some voters this year.

title: Strikers Return In Philadelphia
description: After initially defying a judge's back-to-work order, 2,500 Philadelphia sanitation workers reported for work yesterday morning and began collecting some of the 45,000 tons of garbage that have piled up since the start of a municipal employees' strike two-and-a-half weeks ago.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING WAYWARD PLANTS IN CHECK
description: A NUMBER of widely planted ornamentals, though attractive and useful in the landscape, have a tendency to become invasive and weedy - any plant that is out of place is a weed.

title: GETTING TO THE ROOT OF THE STARTLING RISE IN TEEN SUICIDE
description: IT HAS been said that we get what we deserve, that we are the authors of our own acts. If some tragedy should befall us - a war, perhaps - then somehow we earned it.

title: SOVIET EDGES U.S. FOR VOLLEYBALL TITLE
description: The Goodwill Games saved one of the best for last, a gripping five-set victory by the Soviet Union over the United States early today for the men's volleyball championship.

title: DENHOLM ELLIOT GOES RIGHT ON STEALING THE SCENE
description: Amid the suffocating atmosphere of repressed Victorian libidos in the dining room of a Florentine pensione sits Mr. Emerson, a breath of fresh air. He cheerily waves his knife at the delectable Lucy Honeychurch and her desiccated chaperone. He offers them his room with a view, saying that the view does not matter to him. Poking his fork against his heart, Mr. Emerson declaims, ''Here is where the birds sing, here is where the sky is blue!''

title: MUSIC: SCIMONE LEADS AN ALL-VIVALDI PROGRAM
description: VIVALDI is occasionally accused of having written the same concerto 700 times. Unfair and oversimplified, to be sure, but listening to an entire evening of his music at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night, it was hard to escape the conclusion that in his vast output the number of works does seem to exceed the number of ideas.

title: THE BUSINESS OF CONFERENCE CENTERS
description: OUTWARDLY they may look the same, but hotels and conference centers are as different as wedding receptions are from sales meetings. The true conference center, designed specifically for business meetings, derives almost all of its revenues from the huge meetings market.

title: CORRIDOR 'CHAOS' IS FEARED
description: WITH New Jersey's economic fortunes going the way of the suburbs, a general lack of regionalized planning is said to be threatening to breed chaos along the highways that have become the state's ''boom'' corridors.

title: FARM VS. NEW HOMES IN SAG HARBOR
description: A PLAN to develop the last remaining farm in Sag Harbor into homes has generated protests from village residents who are urging that the property, the 10-acre Cilli Farm, be preserved.

title: BALLET: CAST CHANGES IN 2 PARIS OPERA WORKS
description: THE choreography ranged from the effervescent to the ponderous. But the dancing was consistently praiseworthy when the Paris Opera Ballet offered a new cast in two works on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: 3 Drown in Alabama Quarry
description: Two sisters and a third girl wading hand in hand in a pond in a rock quarry stepped into deep water and drowned despite efforts of a nearby resident to save them, officials said today.

title: FAME AND FAMILY IN A SMALL TOWN
description: I TAKE great pride in being a native New Yorker, but to tell the truth, the New York where I feel I really belong has been Scarsdale for the last 29 years. For a real city-born girl, who grew up on concrete, so to speak, and who happens to have begun her career quite near Times Square at the wonderful old Metropolitan Opera House, Scarsdale is the country, and was as mysterious, quiet and beautiful to me when I moved there as the forest primeval must have seemed to Evangeline.

title: POSTINGS: Ferry Choice the First; P.D.C.'s Agenda
description: With its designation Thursday of a team led by William Zeckendorf as the developer for an office building at the South Ferry terminal in Lower Manhattan, the Public Development Corporation has embarked on an ambitious long-term program for waterfront development.

title: Lightweight Defenses
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho and Livingstone Bramble will defend their world lightweight titles in a boxing doubleheader Sept. 26 in the Orange Bowl.

title: 2 Abducted by Gunmen In the Philippines
description: A Swiss tourist and a Filipino woman were kidnapped today by men who dragged them into a boat at gunpoint on an island near this southern Philippine city, the police said.

title: THE NEED OF THE NATION'S HOMELESS IS BECOMING THEIR RIGHT
description: IN the face of what a New York court recently described as ''the dire and increasing shortage of available, decent low-income housing'' in many cities, homeless people have turned increasingly to the courts for assistance. Slowly and cautiously, judges around the country have begun to define the rights of the homeless.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL - YANKEES VS. CHICAGO WHITE SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 1:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: BOLIVIANS DENY THEY ASKED U.S. TO SEND TROOPS TO HELP IN RAIDS
description: Bolivian officials say they were surprised and distressed when the Reagan Administration offered last month to send Army helicopters and troops here to help carry out the raids against cocaine traffickers that are under way now.

title: 'Love Is a Durable Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUPE OFFERS CATHARSIS TO NEW YORK'S HOMELESS
description: Down the dimly lighted halls of the men's shelter at Bellevue Hospital Center, past the police officers, the metal detectors and the barricades, then up three flights of stairs, was a small conference room, transformed into an English drawing room.

title: AS PROFITS DWINDLE, TRAVEL AGENTS IMPOSE RESTRICTIONS
description: A perennial question when preparing for a trip is whether to use a travel agent or try to make all the arrangements yourself. It is not an easy question to answer. In theory, an agent should be able to help you today more than ever before.

title: DISTURBED, VIOLENT YOUTHS: WHERE TO TREAT THEM?
description: Two months ago, when social-service workers were deciding where to place Shavod Jones, a 15-year-old East Harlem youth who had pleaded guilty to armed robbery in April, they considered the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School, a treatment center on 200 acres of rolling countryside in Westchester County.

title: ROCK: JOE JACKSON
description: IN the seven years since he made his name as one of the brightest angry young men of English post-punk rock, Joe Jackson has methodically enriched his musical vocabulary by connecting his lean, astringent brand of pop with an encyclopedic array of musical styles, from swing to salsa. On his latest album, ''Big World,'' the palette of musical styles has widened to include songs with Oriental motifs (''Shanghai Sky''), references to Sergio Leone movies (''Wild West''), and tango music (''Tango Atlantico,'' an examination of the Falkland crisis).

title: COMING HOME TO PERFORM, NEIL DIAMOND TAKES STOCK OF LIFE AT THE TOP
description: Olympian aspiration, raw aggression and agonizing self-doubt. Neil Diamond possesses an abundance of all three qualities. This contradictory blend forms the chemistry of the special kind of pop stardom that the 45-year-old Brooklyn-born singer-songwriter has sustained for two decades.

title: 'CASANOVA': CHARMING BUT STILL FAITHLESS
description: Whatever you may think of Giacomo Casanova, he was no dummy. The 18th-century Venetian knew that the man who writes his memoirs is making a pre-emptive strike on history. That Casanova is remembered today as a rake, rogue and cad, that he is remembered at all, is entirely his own doing. He laid some claim to honor, religion and intellectual accomplishment, but his commitments in those lines were never as fervent as his commitment to bedding other men's wives and living on other people's money.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: 'HEROES' HELPING THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: A NEW program for children with learning disabilities has completed its first year at the Washington School here.

title: PROBLEMS BESET CHILD-CARE UNIT CHIEF
description: Everywhere he turns, the head of the city's Office of Special Services for Children is confronted with problems.

title: U.S. Defeats Australia In Lacrosse Tourney
description: Ronnie Marino's four goals helped the United States gain an 18-12 victory over Australia Friday at the World Lacrosse Championships.

title: WHITE SOX BATTER NIELSEN AND YANKS
description: The Yankees' Kiddie Korps did not have a good day yesterday. Bob Tewksbury developed a stiff shoulder and Scott Nielsen developed a pitch that the Chicago White Sox hit early and often.

title:
MUSIC;
WATERLOO TO PRESENT MISS HORNE IN A GALA
description: THE mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne will be the soloist with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra at Waterloo Village here Saturday night.

title: Some Misleading Abortion Ads
description: The clinic ads ask, ''Are you thinking of an abortion?'' If you are, it turns out, the clinic will not give you one.

title: Miss MacKinnon Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Royce MacKinnon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Charles MacKinnon of Clarks Green, Pa., was married yesterday to Bruce John Legan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Legan of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Herbert Keller performed the ceremony at St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church in Clarks Green.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALONE IN AMERICA: The Search for Companionship. By Louise Bernikow. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Louise Bernikow chronicles the way problems and social changes leave Americans stranded.

title: CAROLINE KENNEDY WED IN CAPE COD CHURCH
description: In a small weathered church decorated with the flowers of Cape Cod, Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, the daughter of the late President, married Edwin A. Schlossberg today.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CAMPUS CONCERT - A jug of wine, a cold bird, a few friends and a benevolent weatherman will aid in the enjoyment of the New York Philharmonic during an al fresco performance at 8 P.M. Friday. Picnicking begins at 6 o'clock. For a sixth year, the orchestra is coming to Westchester to perform at Barrett Field on the campus of Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Admission and parking are free.

title: EFFORTS TO CONSERVE WATERFOWL
description: THE creators of the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, recently announced by this country and Canada, believe that some of the traditional procedures for maintaining healthy continental populations of migratory ducks and geese must be significantly altered.

title: POSTINGS: A Pair in Pawling; Designer-Developers
description: James W. Evanson and Lisa Kapp Evanson, architects and designers in their 30's, often find New York's design world inhibiting.

title: Let's Keep On So Proudly Hailing That Banner; A Minor Miracle
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's dreadful; it's a disaster.'' - Lawrence W. Cohn, Merrill Lynch analyst, on BankAmerica's loss.

title: PHILADELPHIA GARBAGE COLLECTORS RETURN
description: Garbage trucks rolled here today for the first time in nearly three weeks as striking sanitation workers, threatened with the loss of their jobs, obeyed a three-day-old court order and returned to work.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN INDUSTRIAL FILMS
description: CORPORATIONS are going Hollywood.

title: EIGHT MILLION TRENDS IN THE NAKED CITY
description: SOCIAL DISEASE By Paul Rudnick. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: Officers Cleared in Death
description: Dino Scarsella was very big and very strong, and that apparently cost him his life. Mr. Scarsella, who weighed 300 pounds, died of suffocation when Snohomish County deputies, aided by re-enforcements, subdued, manacled and forced him to lie face down in the back of a patrol car. His massive body apparently could not inhale enough oxygen to keep him alive in that position, a coroner's jury ruled Friday. The jury decided that law officers were not responsible for Mr. Scarsella's ''unnatural'' death.

title: INTO EACH LIFE (AT THE SHORE) A LITTLE DAMPNESS MUST FALL
description: WHEREVER you look - at newspaper advertisements, billboards or racks of postcards - it's the same image: Behind the sweep of sail off Cape May, the bikini-clad blonde in Wildwood or the rolling sand dunes of Harvey Cedars, there is sunshine. Always, the Jersey Shore is wedded to the sun.

title: TEXAS IN A TAILSPIN
description: IT WAS A FINE SPRING morning in Houston, and the uniformed attendants were scurrying to park the sleek Mercedes and Jaguar sedans gliding up the grand curved driveway that leads to the River Oaks Country Club. Behind the columned yellow-brick facade, all was quiet elegance, green floor vases, damask curtains - the opulence of oil money. Under a huge crystal chandelier in the main dining room, several hundred members of the Houston Realty Breakfast Club gathered. The men looked the part, with chunky gold Rolex watches and black lizard cowboy boots showing under well-cut dark pin-stripe suits. After a breakfast of huevos rancheros, grits and melon, and a hearty pledge of allegiance to the flag, they heard a pep talk about Houston's future.

title: SHIMMERING REMEMBRANCES OF WORLD'S FAIRS PAST
description: Some of the grandest and the most trivial glass designs produced in Europe and the United States over the past century were seen first in world's fairs. This great variety of glass works, from masterpieces to souvenirs, is realistically documented in ''Glass From World's Fairs - 1851-1904,'' an exhibition of 170 European and American works from 40 museums and collectors, on view through Oct. 19, at the Corning Museum of Glass, Corning, N. Y. ''Manufacturers showed off their innovations at these fairs,'' explained Jane Shadel Spillman, the museum's curator of American glass, who coordinated the exhibition. ''And these fairs furthered the cross-fertilization of ideas.''

title: Entitled to Better: Allied to Zemex
description: Companies are changing their names with a rush, and there's no mystery why. Their central business changes, or they diversify far beyond their original bounds.

title: Robert M. Cover Dies; Legal Scholar at Yale
description: Robert M. Cover, a professor at Yale University Law School, died of a heart attack Friday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 42 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: THE OPPOSITION IN CHILE HAS TROUBLE CLOSING ITS RANKS
description: EVERY day at 10 A.M., 30 members of the Carabineros, Chile's militarized national police, march from the Moneda Presidential Palace into the spotless Plaza of the Constitution for the changing of the guard. As the Carabineros band leads the replacement unit, resplendent in brown uniforms, leather boots and white gloves, passers-by stop to admire the spectacle. The morning ceremony - which often follows a night of blackouts caused by guerrilla bombs, or anti-Government protests put down by tear gas -conveys a sense of order and continuity.

title: THE GIVE-AND-TAKE ON SEAT BELT RULES
description: TWENTY years ago, the Federal Government's brand new National Highway Traffic Safety Administration was busy issuing proposed regulations aimed at improving the odds that people riding in cars could live through an accident. One proposed rule would have required the installation of seat belts and shoulder harnesses in all passenger cars sold in the United States. The auto industry fought the proposal, arguing that harnessses, then separate from lap belts, were uncomfortable and that motorists would not wear them.

title: AIR SHUTTLES PLAN IMPROVED SERVICES
description: Spurred by increased competition, the air shuttles that link New York with Washington and Boston are introducing amenities and services that are likely to change what has long been a speedy but Spartan way of life for millions of commuters.

title: Let's Keep On So Proudly Hailing That Banner
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ESSEX, GAME, SET, MATCH
description: BORIS BECKER will not be there, but Tim Mayotte, Brad Gilbert, Paul Annacone, Scott Davis and other world-class players will provide a Wimbledon flavor to the $125,000 Volvo Tennis-New Jersey Championships.

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '86: ROBERTO HERNANDEZ;
THE LATEST STOP ON HOPEFUL TRIP
description: THIS is where it all starts, the road that players hope so desperately will take them to the heights of major league baseball.

title: Averting Potential For Abuses
description: SHOULD anyone who owns a co-op or condominium be allowed to serve on the board of directors? Or should some residents be ineligible because professional or business affiliations place them in a position where they could use their power for private gain? If so, what can the organization do to keep them from running for office? Or are there more diplomatic ways of lessening the temptation for abuse?

title: RACES FOR OPEN SENATE SEATS HELD CRUCIAL BY BOTH PARTIES
description: As the fall election campaign approaches, both political parties are paying increasing attention to the seven Senate seats vacated by incumbent lawmakers who decided to retire.

title: Art
description: Though portraits are not considered the height of artistic endeavor, it's a very rare draftsman who's resisted the urge to do at least one. The face, after all, offers limitless potential for expressive line and color, and the latter half of the 20th century has suspended the requirement that a portrait must actually resemble its subject, giving contemporary artists much greater liberty than their forebears. This freedom is graphically demonstrated in ''The Changing Likeness: 20th-Century Portrait Drawings,'' currently at the Whitney Museum of Ameran Art at Philip Morris, 42nd Street at Park Avenue.

title: STATE PONDERS A PROPOSAL MAKING AIDS REPORTABLE
description: AFTER concerns about confidentiality were raised at a public hearing last week, state health officials are reassessing a proposed regulation that would make AIDS a reportable disease in New Jersey.

title: ARCHITECTURAL DRAWINGS IN AN UNUSUAL SETTING
description: STUBBS BOOKS & PRINTS INC., at 28 East 18th Street, is mostly a book and prints shop, partly an antiques store, sometimes a gallery, always the residence of its owners Jane and John Stubbs, and, through late September, a very unexpected way of seeing 93 architectural drawings. The three centuries of drawings in the summer show at Stubbs are displayed amid Oriental rugs, pre-Columbian figurines, other archeological artifacts, some antiques and many volumes on architecture, landscape and decorative arts. The drawings are not hanging on the white walls of an empty room.

title: A 'REWARDING EXPERIENCE' FOR A BAYVILLE HOSTESS
description: RUTH CALLAM is about as far removed from the stereotypical all-American family as one can get. The 54-year-old resident of this Ocean County community is single, childless, lives alone and likes it.

title: 2 OFFICERS IN QUEENS FATALLY SHOOT A MAN WIELDING A SHOTGUN
description: Two police officers in Queens shot and killed a man yesterday who had aimed a loaded shotgun at one of them, officials said.

title: Former F.B.I. Man Gets 2 Life Terms
description: A jury in Los Angeles rejected last month the claim by Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be charged with espionage, that he had been attempting, however ineptly, to infiltrate the K.G.B., not knowingly betraying his country. Last week, Federal Judge David Z. Kenyon ignored his lawyers' pleas for leniency and sentenced Mr. Miller to two concurrent life sentences.

title: WASHINGTON SQUARE MUSIC FESTIVAL IN 29th SEASON OF ALFRESCO CONCERTS
description: ''I WAS brought up to believe that one should contribute to the community somehow,'' Peggy Campbell said, ''and the Washington Square Music Festival is my baby.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This week: Keep after weeds which take up valuable soil moisture and nutrients; add them to the compost pile. . . . Caution on overfertilizing such plants as geraniums, eggplants and peppers which delays flowers and fruit. . . . Control lawn chinch bugs and keep mowers set to cut high. Forget-Me-Not

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK A SAY ON JUDGESHIPS
description: GENERALLY, judicial nominations sail through Congress with little or no dissent. But this summer, President Reagan's choices have emerged as a leading issue, and the outcome of the debate could determine the fate of an Administration effort to reshape the Federal judiciary.

title: PLAYHOUSE INTERPRETS SHOWS FOR DEAF AUDIENCE
description: MARY SILVESTRI has seen ''West Side Story'' many times. But last week she ''heard'' the show - the plaintive love songs, the taunting of the warring street gangs - for the first time at a Candlewood Playhouse production that was interpreted for the deaf.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with the About Westchester column on June 29 misidentified the location of Stephanie Schur's home. Ms. Schur, who works as a space organizer, lives in White Plains.

title: COLONIAL PARLOR GOING TO THE ATHENEUM
description: HIDDEN by a dense grove of trees, a handsome colonial house in Middletown has undergone an unusual procedure in the last few weeks.

title: 4 KILLED IN ATTACK ON BUS IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Gunmen killed four Lebanese Christians associated with the American University of Beirut today, including a doctor at the American University Hospital. Three others were wounded in the attack, on a bus operated by the university and traveling from Moslem West Beirut to the Christian east side.

title: AN ELUSIVE TASK
description: The biggest favor for the Benko Gambit in recent years has been Lev Alburt's demonstration that, after 5 P-K3, Black gets excellent play by 5...PxP!; 6 BxP, Q-R4ch; 7 N-B3, B-N2; 8 B-Q2, Q-N3; 9 Q-N3, P-K3; 10 P-K4, NxKP!; 11 NxN, BxP; 12 Q-Q3, P-B4; 13 N-N3, BxP.

title: Life Sentence for Teen-Ager
description: An 18-year-old who pleaded guilty to killing his grandparents with a shotgun as they watched television has been sentenced to two consecutive life terms. Richard Mazeffa pleaded guilty earlier this week to two counts of first-degree murder in the Feb. 28 deaths of George and Veronica Mazeffa. He said he killed them because he was tired of people ordering him around.

title: ENERGY AND POLISH TYPIFY THE DANCERS FROM PARIS
description: Different times, different ways - ''autres temps, autres moeurs'' - as the French might say. The Paris Opera Ballet's New York debut in 1948 went down in history as a disaster. The current American visit by the Paris Opera Ballet under Rudolf Nureyev's directorship has turned into a triumph.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: KING MATT THE FIRST By Janusz Korczak. Translated by Richard Lourie. Introduction by Bruno Bettelheim. 332 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95. (Ages 10 and up).

title: HUDSON RIVER CASTLE FOR SALE: HANDYMAN'S SPECIAL WITH VIEW
description: It's a far cry from Versailles, and not nearly so big as Buckingham Palace. Yet for anyone who thinks his home is not really a castle but ought to be, a $3 million mansion for sale here might do the trick.

title: HOME RUN IN NINTH SPOILS METS' RALLY
description: Craig Reynolds hit a two-out home run in the bottom of the ninth off Roger McDowell tonight, giving the Houston Astros a 5-4 victory and ruining a spirited comeback in which the Mets scored four times in the top of the ninth.

title: Aging Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Nell M. Willis, Architect, Wed To A. C. Twining
description: At the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn., yesterday Nell Morris Willis, a daughter of Dr. Hugh Hiter Willis Jr. of Chatham, Va., and the late Mary Eleanor Gassaway Willis, was married to Alexander Catlin Twining, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kinsley Twining of Old Lyme. The Rev. Philip N. Libby performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Dover $132,900 66 West Munson Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Tudor; *2*porch, hardwood floors; taxes $1,818. Middletown $296,000 1 McDowell Court *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, deck off kitchen, *2*sprinkler system, pool; taxes $3,568. Millburn $185,000 70 Mountain View Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Dutch colonial; *2*family room, den, living room with fireplace, *2*detached garage; taxes $2,795. Plainsboro $184,500 38 Krebs Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; paneled family room, *2*dining room, brick patio, Japanese garden; taxes $2,451. Springfield $120,000 85 Meisel Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old Cape Cod; den, living room *2*with woodburning stove, dining room, patio; taxes $1,872. Verona $172,000 5 Howard Street *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old English colonial; *2*living room with fireplace, oak floors, paneled den; taxes $3,027. OTHER AREAS Clinton, Conn. $154,500 14 Thrush Cross Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath new colonial; fireplace *2*in family room, eat-in kitchen, 3/4 acre; taxes not *2*yet available. Hartsdale, N.Y. $237,000 5 Holland Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 59-year-old brick Tudor/Norman; *2*breakfast room, screened porch, walk to village; taxes $3,118. Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $111,500 1 Manus Street *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; eat-in kitchen, *2*den with fireplace, partial basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800.

title: A SLAPSTICK WAY TO TRAIN THE TROOPS
description: A 21-ROOM mansion is destroyed by an explosion just as a happy couple and a real estate broker are shaking hands on its sale. What follows is a serious discussion, aimed at salesmen, of all the pitfalls that can scuttle a sale, and how to avoid them.

title: SOMALIA BRACES FOR TRANSITION POLITICS
description: SOOTHING Indian Ocean breezes swirl around this crumbling capital, a mix of Arab and Italian architecture, as everyday life goes on. Women in bright traditional dresses sell their wares at the crowded market, and men offer copies of the Koran. Just after midday, a somnolence sets in as Somalis take a three-hour rest.
