When dusk settles, the streets fill with people selling items from rusting wheelbarrows and men crowd into coffee houses.

title: SCALIA NEED NOT SQUEEZE THE PRESS
description: As the Reagan revolution encroaches even onto the staid regions of the judiciary, conservatives are joyous. Yet what is a conservative to make of the Administration's most recent Supreme Court nominee, Judge Antonin Scalia? It is said that he is a witty, literate intellectual but so hostile to the press that he is itching to make it easier to sue for libel. This would be a grave mistake.

title: NEW CASSETTES FROM 'SHIP OF FOOLS' TO STING
description: Ship of Fools; Starring Vivien Leigh, Simone Signoret, Jose Ferrer, Lee Marvin, Oskar Werner, Elizabeth Ashley, George Segal, Michael Dunn; directed by Stanley Kramer, 1965. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video, 149 minutes.

title: Governor's Races Steeped in Rancor
description: ''It does bother me as a Republican,'' said Joyce Hampers, the party's candidate for treasurer of Massachusetts, who until last year was a Democrat. ''When we cowboys draw the wagons in a circle, we are supposed to shoot out, not in.''

title: COINCIDENCE PLAYED A PART IN CHOREOGRAPHING 'ALICE'
description: From the start, Glen Tetley's latest ballet had the makings of a Lewis Carroll adventure.

title: PORT CHESTER SEEKING A NEW DOWNTOWN
description: AFTER almost a year of private negotiations, the village of Port Chester and the Robert Martin Company, Westchester's largest developer, have revealed details of an ambitious downtown redevelopment plan that would ultimately cost $250 million and affect 100 acres.

title: TURNING KEY EXECUTIVES INTO STARS
description: EXECUTIVES are casting themselves in their videos these days. ''The more we are working with corporate videos, the more we are working with executives,'' said Dennis H. Paget, manager of creative services at Jack Morton Productions, a $25 million company whose corporate video production has doubled in the past two years.

title: THE DAY OF THE GOOSEBERRY
description: The geese outside the pub in Egton Bridge, a village tucked away in a North Yorkshire valley, paraded up and down in more animated fashion than usual. It was Aug. 6, 1985, and they must have been infected by the excitement over the Egton Bridge Old Gooseberry Show. No doubt they will be infected again this year, on Aug. 5 (the first Tuesday of the month), for the competition is an annual event that has reputedly been going since 1800 and shows no sign of dying out. Indeed, last summer's contest saw the establishment of a new Egton Bridge record: a gooseberry weighing nearly two ounces.

title: RUNNING IN THE SHADOW OF THE GOVERNOR
description: EVERYONE knows that Andrew P. O'Rourke is running against the odds in his bid to unseat Mario M. Cuomo as Governor of New York. Even Mr. O'Rourke joked about it at a political roast here in May, telling his audience, ''I'm not the captain of the Titanic, you know.''

title: MUMMY'S EROTIC DAYDREAMS
description: THE IRISH SIGNORINA Divertimento. By Julia O'Faolain. 187 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $15.95.A YOUNG woman, Anne, travels to

title: WHY THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM MUST BET ON A DARING MASTER PLAN
description: Until quite recently, it was very hard to think big about the Brooklyn Museum, a great art institution bogged down in what had long been perceived as a declining borough. But times had already changed for the better by 1983, when Robert T. Buck, an evangelistic outlander who for a decade had headed the respected Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, took over as the museum's director. And, partly inspired by the success of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a once-ailing institution whose remarkable turnaround over the last two decades has today made the borough a mecca for the performing arts, he set out immediately to help the Brooklyn Museum fulfill what he sees as its ''spectacular'' potential.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 20, 1986
description: Fiction

title: DECLINE AND FALL OF A SLAVEOCRAT
description: TOMBEE Portrait of a Cotton Planter. By Theodore Rosengarten. With the Journal of Thomas B. Chaplin (1822-1890). Edited by Theodore Rosengarten and Susan W. Walker. Maps. 750 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95. THE Southern slaveholders proudly presided over the greatest enormity of the age. As deeply believing Christians, they fearlessly said Amen! to Paul's celebrated warning to the Galatians - ''Whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap'' - and pronounced slavery ordained of God. Theodore Rosengarten reminds us that we know much more about the slaveholders than about their slaves, for they left vast quantities of diaries, journals, account books, family letters and other public and private papers. Those sources reveal the people who presided over that enormity as, more often than not, admirable men and women who struggled heroically to build a Christian civilization.

title: Steel Man's Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about hospital procedures for handling potentially violent patients misidentified the agency that transfers such patients from one hospital to another. The agency is the Psychiatry Emergency Transfer Service, not the Mental Health Information Service.

title: Self-Management
description: To the Editor:

title: MR. BLANDINGS CAN SEEK STATE AID SHOULD HIS BUILDER ERR
description: NEW JERSEY is the only state in the country that insures that builders guarantee workmanship and materials in new homes, providing this service largely through the state-sponsored New Home Warranty Security Plan.

title: NOVELIST IN A MIRROR
description: STILLNESS and SHADOWS By John Gardner. Edited, and with an introduction, by Nicholas Delbanco. 422 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: DEMOCRATS KEEP 6 OF 8 CITIES AS POSSIBLE SITES OF 1988 CONVENTION
description: Reluctant to offend anyone in an election year, the Democrats today kept six cities in the running as the potential site of their 1988 national convention, with New Orleans and Houston emerging as the most serious contenders.

title: Ian James Wilkinson And Miss Taylor Wed
description: The marriage of Stephanie Marstrand Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Taylor of Cortland, N.Y., to Ian James Wilkinson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey B. Wilkinson of Huddersfield, England, took place yesterday in Springfield, Vt. The Rev. Gordon W. Stearns performed the Congregational ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton G. Martin Jr., uncle and aunt of the bride.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Miami;
Time Shares: The Tax Fight
description: WHETHER a time-share unit - the right to use a condominium unit one week a year - is real property has become a hotly debated issue in the resort industry here.

title: HOMES FOR THE RETARDED: OTHER VIEWPOINTS
description: The state misleads us in its planning for small residential units (S.R.U.'s) on the grounds of the Long Island Developmental Center in Melville.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 20, 1986
description: International

title: 12,500 Feet Deep And 74 Years Back in Time
description: For the first time in 74 years, the Titanic was on view last week, like a museum diorama on the ocean floor. Three researchers and their robot camera descended 12,500 feet to the ship, shorn off at the stern but sitting upright in the icy silt several hundred miles south of Newfoundland.

title: Post-Mortem on An Airline Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board apportioned blame last week for the crash of a Delta Airlines jet near Dallas in August, and it did not spare Federal regulatory and support agencies. The same day the report was issued, the board's former chairman, who has made enemies in the airline industry and the Federal Aviation Administration, was nominated to resume his post.

title: LACROSSE LEAGUE
description: Doctors, lawyers, accountants and stockbrokers are playing the game invented by American Indian chiefs more than 300 years ago - lacrosse. The 300 business and professional men who play in the Sound Shore Lacrosse League ''love the action-packed game and enjoy the camaraderie of playing on a team,'' said Paul Seroka.

title: Navratilova Returns
description: Making her first visit to her home-land of Czechoslovakia since her defection in 1975, Martina Navratilova received hugs and flowers from relatives yesterday as she stepped off a plane from West Germany at the airport in Prague.

title: IN MEXICO, WALNUTS MAKE THE SAUCE
description: With walnut season approaching in central Mexico, people start thinking about the dish called chiles en nogada. Nearly everyone is susceptible to the lure of piquant poblano chilies filled with a chopped meat and raisin stuffing, and topped with a sauce made of cheese and ground walnuts. (Fresh walnuts are available only from early August to mid-October.) As legend has it, chiles en nogada was invented in 1821 in the colonial town of Puebla, 70 miles southeast of Mexico City. The plate is said to have made its debut at a banquet held Aug. 28 to honor the saint's day of Don Augustin de Iturbide, leader of the last uprising against the Spaniards. The green chilies, white walnut sauce and garnish of red pomegranate seeds and parsley represent the colors of Mexico's flag, and the short season of this favorite comes in time to commemorate Mexico's independence, celebrated Sept. 15.

title: PRETORIA DETAINED OUSTED CLERIC
description: An American Lutheran minister who was to have left South Africa on Thursday night but instead spent the night in jail was allowed to leave Friday, the State Department said yesterday.

title: BEWARE, THE BEASTS OF THE BEACHES ARE BACK
description: ALONG the ocean beaches of Long Island and New Jersey, swimmers are on the lookout for a marine predator that rolls in with the tide on hot, still summer days, adding a sting to the water. The predator is the lion's mane, or Cyanea capillata, a jellyfish that locally ranges in size from the size of a soup bowl to that of a large salad bowl and owes its nickname to the hundreds of tentacles dangling from its reddish-brown, gelatinous bell.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THOSE CHAMPIONSHIP SEASONS
description: LOWELL WINTHROP got married a few weeks ago. The wedding took place on a Saturday afternoon, but Mr. Winthrop and the new Mrs. Winthrop did not leave for their honeymoon until Sunday evening. The groom, you see, had an important softball game that morning.

title: CITY OPERA: 'DIE FLEDERMAUS' BACK IN REPERTORY
description: ONE danger with a well-known comedy like ''Die Fledermaus'' is that some actors assume it will play itself, and it won't. The cast has to participate in the situations, remember what makes them funny, get tickled about them and get the audience tickled in turn; otherwise there's no comedy. That was one of the problems with the New York City Opera revival of the Johann Strauss favorite Friday night: the plot perambulated idly by while the cast occupied itself with a halfhearted overlay of broad jokes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GHOST DANCE. By Carole Maso. (North Point, $16.95.) In Carole Maso's exquisitely written and ambitious first novel, a college student descends into a snow-white hell in search of her family.

title: Wendy Gliedman Engaged to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Monroe M. Gliedman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Lynn Gliedman, to Mordechai Marcus Beizer, a son of Ruth Bohrer of Yerucham, Israel, and Samuel Beizer of New York. The wedding is planned for September.

title: SIPPING AND STROLLING AT MONTECATINI
description: Situated in Tuscany's Val di Nievole, Montecatini is an experience in reverse time - a Henry James novel with a Fellini-esque edge. The town and its spas combine intrigue and activity; here the cure lies not only in the thermal waters, but in the environment as well. Ubiquitous music, endless boutiques, rainbow gelato stands, garish night auctions, crowded street markets and menus that feature 21 pastas and 25 desserts help to persuade that here is a potential slice of heaven on earth - a melange of Tuscan cuisine and culture; a legendary spa, with a lingering air of Dolce Vita.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ON THE ERIE LIMITED - Engine No. 765, a Berkshire-class steam locomotive built in 1944 for high-speed runs on the Nickel Plate Railroad, served with distinction until it was retired in 1958. It was the end of a railroad era - steam giving way to diesel - and the end of No. 765. Not quite. Railroad buffs have restored old No. 765 to like-new condition, and on Aug. 2 and Aug. 3 the locomotive will pull passenger cars on 200-mile excursions from Hoboken to Port Jervis, N.Y., and return.

title: HOST FAMILIES ARE SOUGHT FOR FOREIGN EXCHANGE STUDENTS
description: AT THE same time that thousands of New Jersey teen-agers are on vacation, many of them away from home, scores of European high school students are preparing to come to the state - not as vacationists in the true sense of the term, but on international exchange programs.

title: VYING FOR THE BUSINESS WORLD'S OSCAR
description: EVERY spring, industrial-film producers vie for their industry's version of the Oscar or the Emmy: the blue ribbon designating a first prize at the annual American Film and Video Festival in New York. ''I'd say we have at least 300 to 400 entries a year,'' said Sandy Mandelberger, the festival's director.

title: TOWNS PROGRAM BENEFITS CHILDREN AND THE HOSTS
description: Amid the singing, yelling and laughing of a busload of children, Peter Lanausse, 9 years old, and Dante Johnson, 10, were looking forward to doing some work.

title: Capital Gains Tax Hike Hurts Not Just the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON A HIGH NOTE - The great outdoors may not exactly be the proper setting for grand-scale opera, but this week two companies are going to give it a try on the free park concert circuit. Tonight, Rath Park in Franklin Square will be transformed into a Parisian garret as Opera Northeast recreates Puccini's ''La Boheme.'' The fully staged production - costumes, orchestra, tears and all - is at 8:15 P.M. On Saturday, at Eisenhower Park's Chapin Lakeside Theater in East Meadow, the National Grand Opera tackles tragic jealousy on an even more intense level when it offers Verdi's ''Othello.'' The curtain is at 8 P.M.ALL TOGETHER NOW

title: TENNIS AND THE BATTLE OF AGE
description: VARICOSITIES aside, I love tennis.

title: CHINATOWN PLAN IS KEY TO DISPUTE
description: A proposed housing project for the elderly in Chinatown has become the flash point for an intense political rivalry, pitting leaders of traditional tongs against newer professional groups competing for influence in the community.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FROST'S FAVORITE STORE - Woodstock, Vt., is gearing up for the 100th birthday celebration of a country store that Robert Frost once called his favorite: F. H. Gillingham and Sons, where the goods range from fishing gear to caviar. It will be the center of a festive weekend starting Friday night at 7 with the Vermont Symphony Orchestra performing on the Historical Society Lawn (adults, $8; senior citizens and children under 12, $6).

title: ON THE TRACK OF 007
description: SHOOTDOWN Flight 007 and the American Connection. By R. W. Johnson. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95. FROM his first page to his last, R. W. Johnson tries to convince his readers that he is not a die-hard conspiracy theorist, but rather merely a dispassionate analyst reviewing the facts surrounding the tragic fate of Korean Air Lines Flight 007. In that, at least, he fails. All 269 passengers and crew members died when a Soviet fighter shot the airliner down after it had strayed well into Russian territory on Sept. 1, 1983, on its way from Anchorage to South Korea. In the nearly three years since, a variety of people, including Mr. Johnson, a fellow in politics at Oxford University, have theorized that the plane may not have been in Soviet airspace by accident, as the official American investigations suggested, but was instead on a secret surveillance mission for the United States. Although Mr. Johnson says, ''I became acutely dissatisfied with the 'official' explanations of the event offered by the Reagan Administration,'' he repeatedly acknowledges that ''readers will have to decide for themselves what to believe.''

title: When Leaders From Abroad Come to Call
description: It was a day in the Johnson Administration and the limousine carrying Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain and James W. Symington, the State Department's chief of protocol, was slowly and ceremoniously making its way around the circular driveway of the White House for an official arrival ceremony replete with military music, colorful troops and a plethora of Union Jacks.

title: Wedding Planned By Audrey Tung
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Tung of Hong Kong of the engagement of their daughter, Audrey L. Y. Tung, to Eric McLean Slighton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Slighton of Princeton, N.J.

title: ONE TRAVELER'S PACKING LIST OF PROVISIONS
description: Traveling in China is not like traveling anywhere else in the world. Prepared for a third world experience, you may well be surprised at the level of amenities. (One that always pleases foreigners is the Chinese custom of providing a large thermos of boiling hot water in every hotel room, even the most humble.) On the other hand, if you expect luxury services outside large, Western-style hotels in major cities, you are in for a rude awakening. (Next to that thermos of hot water, you may find a tea mug containing the remains of the last guest's cup of tea.) Accommodations are often Spartan and toilet facilities, in particular, can be - well, crude at best.

title: BERGEN TESTING CIVIL-CASE SPEEDUP
description: LAWYERS in Bergen County are taking part in a potentially far-reaching State Supreme Court effort to speed the handling of civil cases in the courts.

title: Ms. Clausi Is Married
description: Jennifer Elisabeth Clausi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph S. Clausi of Cos Cob, Conn., and Purling, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Arthur Benoit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Benoit, also of Cos Cob. The Rev. Dale Greene performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: SUCCESS AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: Ivan Reitman embodies all the qualities of today's commercial film maker (''From Slapstick to Yuppie Fantasy,'' by Joy Horowitz, June 15). His movies are dictated by current trends and sure-fire formulas.

title: CONSUMER RATES
LeMond Narrows Hinault's Lead in Tour
description: Jean-Francois Bernard of France finished alone today to win the 153-mile 16th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race by more than three minutes.

title: HBO'S NEW 'SHOWCASE' DISPLAYS PROMISE
description: Home Box Office is huffing and puffing again.

title: Menacing Pitch That Has No Place
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Matt Blair, a 12-year linebacker, has been told not to report to the Minnesota Viking training camp because the club is planning a new defensive system built around younger players. . . . Marty Schottenheimer, the Cleveland Browns' coach, will be given a one-year extension on his contract, extending it through 1987. . . Scooter McCray, a free-agent forward, was released by the Seattle SuperSonics and has been invited to try out with the Cleveland Cavaliers. . . . Orval Tessier. the former head coach of the Chicago Black Hawks, has been named coach of the Cornwall Royals of the Ontario Hockey League.

title:
INVESTING;
SILVER: A NOT-SO-PRECIOUS METAL
description: IF one had to pick an investment that has done absolutely nothing in the past four years - except, perhaps, break investors' hearts - it would be silver.

title: U.S. COMPLETES DRAFT OF ANSWER ON ARMS PLAN
description: The Administration has tentatively decided on a formal response to recent Soviet arms control proposals in the Geneva talks and is sending two envoys to consult with American allies about the plan, Administration officials said today.

title: FINNISH OPERA AT SANTA FE
description: The Finnish National Opera's visit to New York in 1983 came as a surprise to many American music-lovers. The two operas the troupe performed - ''The Last Temptations'' by Joonas Kokkonen and ''The Red Line'' by Aulis Sallinen - all but unknown outside Scandinavia, proved intellectually challenging and worthy both musically and theatrically. On Saturday, the Santa Fe Opera will present the American premiere of Mr. Sallinen's third opera, ''The King Goes Forth to France,'' and the composer has made the trip to New Mexico to see it. He talked about the work shortly after he arrived in this country.

title:
ART;
A PHOTOGRAPHER TURNS TO PAINT
description: EVE SONNEMAN is a renowned photographer who has lately begun to embrace painting as well. This new enthusiasm doesn't water down her commitment to photography, but expands it, adding a new dimension to her professional life.

title: E. Elizabeth Emerson Weds Robert K. Moir
description: At St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., yesterday E. Elizabeth Emerson, a daughter of Mrs. Robert J. Sommer of Ridgewood, N.J., and Representative Bill Emerson of Cape Girardeau, Mo., and McLean, Va., was married to Robert Kirk Moir, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph John Moir of Yarmouthport, Mass. The Rev. Whitney Burr performed the ceremony.

title: THE C.I.A. ON CAMPUS
description: On March 12 of this year, student activists at Hunter College expelled a C.I.A. recruiting officer, stressing their opposition to the United States Government's policies and the use of the C.I.A. in Central America. Mr. Wise indicates that such protests took place mainly in the 1970's, but this type of activity has taken place at many schools recently. In fact, campus protests have increased in the last five years. Although these protests have occurred primarily at the larger and more radical schools, there have been protests at smaller schools, like Antioch, also. EVAN CAMP News Editor The Hunter Envoy Hunter College New York City

title: Ms. Michaud Engaged To Dr. Hans Lehneis
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ellery Michaud of Johnstown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Marie Michaud, to Dr. Hans Richard Lehneis, a son of Hans Richard Lehneis of Frankfurt and the late Mrs. Lehneis.

title: Farmers in Southeast Apply for Midwest Hay
description: Farmers plagued by a drought in the Southeast that has left them with little or no hay to feed their livestock lined up yesterday to apply for free hay being sent from the Middle West.

title: A TRAGEDY IN SOUTH GEORGIA
description: THE disintegration of the space shuttle Challenger last Jan. 28 was not the first catastrophic accident for Morton Thiokol Inc. On a cold, damp morning 15 years earlier, another disaster, this one caused by negligence on the part of both Thiokol and the United States Government, left 29 people dead and more than 50 injured in this isolated corner of southeastern Georgia.

title: POSTINGS: 146 on the Sound; New Rochelle Condos
description: For years now, the most ambitious development proposal by far in New Rochelle has been the plan for a 3,000-acre parcel in Long Island Sound.

title: PROSPECTS
description: What $10 a Barrel Brings -If last week's $5 oil-price drop sticks, the new $10-a-barrel rate will hurt the economy in 1986 but help in 1987, says Burton Zwick, senior economist for Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Discount College For Top Students
description: IN a move to recruit top public high school seniors, Bard College, a small, private liberal-arts school in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., offered them a bargain in January: it said it would slash their costs at Bard to exactly what they would pay at a public college in their home state.

title: JASON GLASS UNDER THE LOCH
description: THE LEGACY OF LADYSMITH By John Kenny Crane. 398 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: CABARET: JEAN CARNE
description: JEAN CARNE gave a performance at her opening on Thursday evening at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue near 17th Street, that might have been all right in the casual atmosphere of her living room but was a little too self-indulgent for a professional appearance.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WHEN PRICE DECIDES WHO LIVES WHERE
description: THE ''American Dream'' of owning a home is in trouble in Fairfield County. First, corporate mobility moved people around. But today, price has become the ultimate determinant of who lives where. Thus, it is very unlikely that our children will be able to live where they grew up.

title: And for His Next Trick
description: When the ''Amazing Randi'' peers into the future these days, he sees tax-free dollars coming his way. James Randi, as he is known when he is not amazing, became last week the first professional magician to win a MacArthur Fellowship, a cash stipend given by the MacArthur Foundation each year to a score or more of the nation's most ''outstandingly talented'' people, usually scholars, artists and the like.

title: Dance
description: ''Dancing Feet,'' which opens on Tuesday for a week at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street, is a celebration of those durable little commodities that are the soul of dance. The program, part of Clark Center's Summer Dance Festival '86, features Charles ''Cookie'' Cook and James ''Buster'' Brown, star tappers and bon vivants, Pat Cannon's Foot and Fiddle Dance Company (a quartet of Appalachian cloggers dancing to fiddle and guitar music) and six flamenco dancers from the Ballet Hispanico.

title: A SUIT OVER MORATORIUMS
description: THE owner of the Hauppauge Country Club and a group seeking to buy it have filed suit against the Town of Smithtown and the State Department of Environmental Conservation, charging that they have been denied the right to develop the site.

title: Let's Keep On So Proudly Hailing That Banner; Whistler's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Leads Davis Play
description: Robert Seguso and Ken Flach teamed up to defeat Jorge Lozano and Fernando Perez Pascal of Mexico, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 today to give the United States a 2-1 lead in a Davis Cup quarterfinal series.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I GUESS it was all those mornings that were really evenings for the likes of Sherman Phillips and Jimmy Judge and Jimmy Breslin and me and the other Long Island newspapermen and newspaperwomen of the early 1950's. The whelps of this profession on Long Island worked at night, all night, and played from before sunrise until collapse. For us, television, also very new at the time, was little more than the face on the barroom wall.

title: THE DIAGNOSIS FROM THE SIDELINES
description: IT started in 1962, when I was sitting on the visitors' bench at the Polo Grounds during a Titans home game. My brother was the head team physician for the Titans, and he asked me to work the visiting team's sideline. ''Don't worry,'' he said, ''just wave if you need me and I'll take care of everything for you.''

title: Fittipaldi Edges Rahal To Get Pole in Toronto
description: Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, setting a course record, outsped Bobby Rahal today to grab the pole position in the final qualifying session for Sunday's inaugural Molson Toronto-Indy race.

title: THE NEW TUMULT IN BANKING
description: THE American banking system, the heart of the nation's economy, is undergoing more wrenching changes than at any time since the Great Depression. Some of the most venerable names in banking - Continental Illinois, Seafirst and Girard Bank - have been taken over either by Government or by stronger institutions. Other grand names - like BankAmerica, Interfirst of Dallas and other Texas banks - are in deep trouble. And lesser-known players are clamoring for the top spots.

title: Volcano Resumes Eruption
description: The volcano Kilauea resumed its three-year-old eruption Friday, sending out a five-mile-long river of molten rock that forced officials to close a road inside Hawaii Volcanoes National Park.

title: Dr. Nancy Quayle Petersmeyer to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C. Wrede Petersmeyer of Vero Beach, Fla., and Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Dr. Nancy Quayle Petersmeyer, to Dr. Christopher John Damm, a son of Gerard M. Damm of Brookhaven, L.I., and the late Carol Dutto Cook.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEAFOOD MENU IN MOUNT KISCO
description: AFTER months of promise, the Grouper Cafe has opened its inviting doors, playing nightly to a packed house. The restaurant is a beauty; not a shred of its tacky past remains. A soothing color scheme in the cool palette enhances the elegant minimalism in the reconstruction. The canted, soaring ceilings and the unobstructed light from the new windows belie the room's Victorian origins.

title: James Newman Weds Sarah Slaughter in Boston
description: Sarah Slaughter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Havron Slaughter of Larchmont, N.Y., and James L. Newman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Newman of Jamestown, R.I., were married yesterday at the Women's City Club of Boston. Justice of the Peace Rosaria Salerno performed the ceremony.

title: THREE GIVEN TERMS OF UP TO 15 YEARS IN TEXAS TORTURINGS
description: Three men convicted in a scheme to kidnap drifters for slave labor that left one man dead after being tortured were sentenced Friday to prison terms ranging from four months to 15 years.

title: Wisconsin
description: To the Editor: Having recently discovered Door County, I was pleased to read Mark C. Hansen's piece ''Door County's Summer Pleasures'' on this unexpected Wisconsin ''seacoast.'' A couple of additional points are worth making.

title: Michael Marston Weds Ms. Sulcer
description: Ginna Mary Sulcer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Durham Sulcer of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Evan Marston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marston of New York and Otis, Mass. The Rev. Elice Higgenbotham, a United Church of Christ minister, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at Douglas Watts, a caterer at 300 West 26th Street.

title: NORTHERN IRELAND'S VOICE OF OPTIMISM
description: NONPARTICIPANTS who dwell vicariously on Northern Irish politics might bear in mind that some of the most revolutionary changes have been wrought by a quiet, undramatic Government program. This was the 1947 act that finally guaranteed the Catholic minority the same right to free education enjoyed by the Protestant majority, spawning a generation of civil rights leaders, community professionals and some fresh cadre for the Irish Republican Army.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'SHIP OF FOOLS' TO STING
description: To the Lighthouse; Starring Rosemary Harris, Michael Gough; directed by Colin Gregg, 1983.Epic Pictures,115 minutes. $69.95.

title: Miss Hotung Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Mary Hotung, who graduated in May from the Fordham University School of Law, and Donald Charles Walkovik, a partner in the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mary McGinley Hotung of Burlington, Vt., and Joseph E. Hotung of Hong Kong. A September wedding is planned.

title: Newspaper Says Queen Is Upset by Thatcher
description: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain is dismayed by many of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policies, and royal advisers have taken the unusual step of briefing a newspaper about the monarch's political views, The Sunday Times said today.

title: CRIME
description: Lawrence Block's WHEN THE SACRED GINMILL CLOSES (Arbor House, $15.95) is an exercise in nostalgia. It also is a sad book about lonely people with few inner resources. It takes Matthew Scudder, Mr. Block's private eye, back to 1975, a time when Scudder was slowly drinking himself to death in various midtown New York gin mills.

title: Landlords Win a Round on 'Nail and Mail'
description: LANDLORDS who oppose the city's so-called ''nail-and-mail'' system of serving Sanitation Code violations have won the latest round in their six-year legal fight with municipal authorities. But the case appears far from resolved and may be headed for the United States Supreme Court.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT DECRIES AN ERA OF 'HIT FLOPS'
description: I write as a playwright, not the most or least successful among those now writing. But how much longer will I write plays?

title: IRELAND
description: To the Editor: Last July I played two of the golf courses mentioned by Gordon S. White Jr. in the article ''A Bit of the Greens'' (Travel, April 13).

title: Miss Sneath Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath of Riverside, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Bernice Sneath, to John Spencer Jones Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Yarmouth, Me.

title: GIANTS START TO FEEL THE PRESSURE TO WIN
description: The Giants' veterans will report to training camp this week to prepare for a football season many people expect to end in glory.

title: DRUG CHARGES SEEN IN DEATH OF BIAS
description: With testimony before a Maryland grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias scheduled to resume tomorrow, the prosecutor in the case says he will try to bring narcotics charges against one of Bias's friends for supplying the cocaine that killed the star basketball player.

title: Widow Gets $605,000 In Delta Crash Lawsuit
description: In the first lawsuit to be brought in connection with the Delta Air Lines crash in Dallas last August, a jury has awarded $605,000 to the widow of one of the victims.

title: High-Speed Maryland Chase
description: A woman who commandeered a police cruiser was arrested after leading officers on a 30-mile chase at speeds of up to 100 miles per hour, the police said. A police spokesman said the chase, in which three squad cars were wrecked, began Friday after officers spotted the 23-year-old Washington woman directing traffic with a curling iron.

title: THE PLEASURES (YES) OF IRONING
description: I RECENTLY found my satisfaction in retirement by doing housework. Not the common everyday activities of beds, dishes and dust, but the romantic housework that gives such pleasure to one who has the time and energy to do it: ironing.

title: CORRECTION
description: Picture captions last Sunday with an article about Maryland politics misstated the standing of two Democratic candidates, Attorney General Stephen H. Sachs, who is running for Governor, and Representative Barbara S. Mikulski, who is running for Senator. Neither has yet won the nomination; the primary is Sept. 9.

title: France Expels Basque To Spanish Authorities
description: France expelled to Spain a man suspected of being a Basque militant under a rarely used emergency procedure in a continuing crackdown on guerrillas, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Buddy Baer, Ex-Boxer, Dies; Lost Two Fights to Joe Louis
description: Jacob (Buddy) Baer, who twice lost title bouts to Joe Louis during his boxing career and played in 17 films during a movie career, died at Veterans Hospital here Friday.

title: Looking The Part
description: MY DAUGHTER, who loves me, wanted me to dress like an actor named Don Johnson who plays a policeman in the television show ''Miami Vice,'' which I saw once. There was a great deal of gunplay. It reminded me of a Randolph Scott movie I saw in 1938 in which maybe 30 armed horsemen trapped Scott in a narrow canyon and emptied dozens of pistols and rifles in his direction without effect until their leader said, ''No use wasting any more lead on him, boys,'' and everybody galloped off leaving Scott unshot.

title: Irradiated Food
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE STILL PURSUING LEADS IN PALME SLAYING
description: Nearly five months after Prime Minister Olof Palme was assassinated on a Stockholm street, the police have not yet made a breakthrough enabling them to arrest a single prime suspect.

title: 'ORPHAN' DRUGS: CAUGHT IN LIMBO
description: KATHARINE SNYDER can't run.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING WAYWARD PLANTS IN CHECK
description: A NUMBER of widely planted ornamentals, though attractive and useful in the landscape, have a tendency to become invasive and weedy - any plant that is out of place is a weed.

title: THE CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING DINER
description: YOU always knew what you were getting yourself into when you entered a diner. It was a place where you were assured a tasteless meal at a somewhat tasteful price. A diner was the only place you could order a coffee and sit for hours without feeling guilty for taking up the booth.

title: Italian Ambassador to Iran Seeks Details in Spying Case
description: Italy's ambassador to Teheran has asked Iran for details about a man with an Italian passport said to have been arrested there Friday on charges of spying for the United States, Foreign Ministry officials said today.

title: OPERATION DOG TAG CATCHES 400 TRUANTS
description: ''OPERATION DOG TAG'' has snared 400 truant canines, according tothe chief canine-control officer for the state, Frank Intino.

title: THE POWER OF VICTIMS
description: STEALING THE LANGUAGE The Emergence of Women's Poetry in America. By Alicia Suskin Ostriker. 315 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $19.95. THE subtitle is misleading. The first chapter of ''Stealing the Language: The Emergence of Women's Poetry in America'' simply gallops through women's poetry from 1650 to 1960 - 44 pages for more than 300 years. The remaining chapters focus on women's poetry from 1960 to the present, with only occasional reference to women poets as ''historical'' as H.D. In that accelerated first chapter, some extraordinarily interesting poets are given short shrift, among them Edna St. Vincent Millay, Amy Lowell and Emma Lazarus. (Lazarus is mentioned in one sentence acknowledging late 19th-century poets who ''wrote on humanitarian issues.'') This is all the more unfortunate in light of Alicia Suskin Ostriker's wonderful analysis of Emily Dickinson's poetry. Mrs. Ostriker is brilliant at close reading, but she rarely puts her talent for it to work in this book. I would have been interested to read her at length about other long-lost poets, like Frances Osgood, who is tantalizingly quoted but given only brief attention here. ''The Emergence of Women's Poetry in America'' would indeed be a book worth writing, but it is not the book Mrs. Ostriker has produced.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: Damages. By Helena Harlow Worthen. (Arbor House, $15.95.) Helena Harlow Worthen is a natural storyteller and her second novel provides a convincing blend of imagination and gritty realism.

title: Litton Promises To Make It Up To the Pentagon
description: After a subsidiary of Litton Industries Inc. admitted last week that it had cheated the Defense Department out of $6.3 million, the Pentagon suspended the company from bidding on new military contracts. But it remained to be seen to what extent the suspension would cost the corporation opportunities to bid on major projects.

title: Trying to Fix The Budget Law
description: As expected, Congress overwhelmingly affirmed last week the $11.7 billion worth of reductions in hundreds of Federal programs made through the automatic mechanism of the balanced-budget law the Supreme Court struck down two weeks ago. There was widespread self-congratulation. There was also Senator Pete V. Domenici's advance evaluation of the vote as a barometer of Congressional mettle. ''It will be, at least, a minor test,'' said the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committe, adding: ''I stress minor test.''

title: SUMMER BOOTS: CHIC, BUT NOT COOL
description: FASHION and logic may not be totally unknown to each other, but they don't exactly keep fast company, either. Take the increasing numbers of boots showing up on city feet these sultry midsummer days.

title: Miss Sutherland Engaged to Wed A Fellow Lawyer
description: The engagement of Susan Jane Sutherland, an associate with the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, to Robert Booth Opatrny, who is an associate with the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Austin Sutherland of Waynesburg, Ohio, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Donald C. Opatrny of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and the late Mr. Opatrny.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Ridgefield Park Gets Its 'Saving Grace'
description: FOR nearly 15 years, Ridgefield Park officials have harbored dreams that the isolated stretch of land tucked away in the eastern corner of their village would one day be transformed from a wasteland to a thriving commercial center.

title: THROUGH CHINA'S NEWLY OPENED DOORS
description: We were high up on the Pamir plateau, somewhere beyond 14,000 feet, when my wife spotted what at first seemed like a mirage: a quarter of a mile beyond the Chinese work camp we were visiting on the Karakoram Highway, a lone figure on a bicycle was pedaling along, barely able to make headway through loose stones and sand. A few more minutes and Mark Skinner was upon us, a prime example of the new possibilities of travel within China.

title: THE ETERNAL LURE OF THE HEALING SPRING
description: In moments of insomnia I say over to myself an alphabet of European place names. As a lullaby, it would not exactly shame Schubert, beginning as it does with Abano, Bath, Carlsbad, Droitwich, Evian and Fussing. But Gastein and Homberg are stylish disyllables. Ischia is a name that sings. Marienbad not long ago made it into the movies. Quiberon has naval overtones that I for one find stirring. Vichy has survived - but only just - its association during World War II with the puppet government of occupied France. And the alphabet comes to a full, hissing close with that most final of place names, Zug.

title: NORMAN HOLDS ONE-SHOT LEAD
description: During another stormy day at the 115th British Open, Greg Norman of Australia staggered home on Turnberry's Ailsa Course with six bogeys on the last 10 holes today and just barely maintained his lead, finishing one shot ahead of Tommy Nakajima of Japan.

title: PONDERING THE LINK BETWEEN MUSIC AND MADNESS
description: The other day, in looking through a psychiatrist's report on the supposed connection between manic-depressive mood swings and musical creativity, I was brought up short. These words about Robert Schumann's lifelong history of depression leaped out at me: ''Starting in adolescence he was troubled by repeated attacks of melancholy which can be traced in his and his wife's letters as well as in their joint diary, later kept by Clara alone. For example, in May, 1831, it takes him three weeks to finish a letter . . .''

title: O'NEILL IS RENOMINATED IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill won renomination today for a second full term as his challenger, Toby Moffett, failed to muster enough votes at the Democratic State Convention to force a statewide primary.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston;
A Partnership of Affordability
description: JOSEFINA RAMERIZ and her two children live in a three-bedroom apartment in Roxbury with new walls, floors, doors, windows, appliances and wiring. It takes luck to rent such space in this city, which has some of the nation's oldest housing, a 4 percent vacancy rate and outlying neighborhoods that have deteriorated as a decade-long boom built up the downtown.

title: THE HARVARD FACTOR
description: WADE INTO THE NAMES OF Harvard's former students and you soon feel not just the tickling undertow of 350 years but also the force, the actual weight and sound, of Harvard's influence on the world outside the Yard.

title: THE SYSTEM FOR TROUBLED YOUTHS IS MORE OF A TANGLE
description: THERE had been many warnings during Shavod Jones's first 15 years: juvenile reports, adult arrests, stays in psychiatric facilities, efforts by his grandmother to gain court assistance in managing him. But only after he was accused of shooting Steven McDonald, a 29-year-old police officer, in Central Park last weekend, were the city's fragmented criminal justice, social service and mental health systems able to piece together a picture of his life and assess their role in it.

title: No First Use
description: President Reagan has now made it clear once again that he will accept no bargain that puts limits on his dream of what he likes to call a ''strategic space shield.'' As long as he sticks to this position, new strategic arms control agreements are beyond reach while he is President. In this situation, it makes sense to look again at an opportunty for change. It is time to think about getting what most Americans think we already have: a policy that we will not be the first to fire nuclear weapons.

title: Through the Smoke to Arms Control
description: So far, the Reagan Administration's main achievement in nuclear diplomacy has been to replace hope with confusion. A nation that once cheered every glimmer of agreement with the Russians has been so bewildered about what restraints are still possible and who's to blame for their absence that it retreats into uncertainty. Politicians still fear to oppose arms control, but some high Administration officials do oppose it, and come very close to doing so in public.

title: A SKIRMISH OVER ISRAEL'S NEW JET
description: ISRAEL and the United States are locked in what could be the biggest air battle ever in the Middle East. Armed with calculators and cost estimates, the Pentagon is quietly trying to shoot down the 300 Lavi advanced fighter jets that Israel is proposing to build.

title: A SHOW IN PARIS ASKS WHAT MAKES MODERN SCULPTURE DISTINCT
description: It is likely to be a good while before we see another sculpture show as ambitious and revealing as ''Qu'est-ce que la Sculpture Moderne?'' at the Centre Georges Pompidou through Oct. 13. It is large, it spans the first 70 years of the century, and it brings together a remarkable number of seminal works by Constantin Brancusi, Pablo Picasso, Julio Gonzalez, Alberto Giacometti, David Smith, Joseph Beuys and others.

title: DEVEOPING L.I. RIVERS WITHOUT DESTROYING THEM
description: STATE officials are wading through a backlog of more than 130 applications to construct projects ranging from multimillion-dollar subdivisions to sun decks along Long Island rivers protected under the State Wild, Scenic and Recreational Rivers Act.

title: ANASTOS PROGRAM IS A FAMILY PROJECT
description: WHEN Ernie Anastos, an anchorman on WABC-TV's Channel 7 Eyewitness News, decided to put together a television show that accented life's positive side, he needed to look no farther than his own backyard for inspiration. Mr. Anastos, 41 years old, lives in a Tudor-style house in Westchester with his wife, Kelly, 15-year-old daughter Nina and 13-year-old son Phillip. The newscaster began by considering his own close-knit clan, and wound up embarking on a project that would focus on both the particular and universal aspects of family life.

title: NEW YORK'S CENTER REPORTS SUCCESS
description: More than three months after its heralded and belated opening, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center has some lingering problems but seems to be thriving, according to exhibitors and center officials.

title: Poodle Named Best
description: A standard poodle, Ch. Alekai Airy, owned by Tatiana Nagro of Mendham, N.J., today was named best of 1,259 dogs at the 33d show of the Putnam Kennel Club on the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation.

title: ISRAELIS SAY SYRIA MIGHT SEEK A WAR
description: Senior Israeli defense officials and military officers say that in the last year Syria has acquired a new military option that seriously complicates Israeli military planning.

title: ILLINOIS AND TEXAS START FINALS AFTER 9 MONTHS OF BRIDGE PLAY
description: Teams from Illinois and Texas began the finals of the Grand National team championship today, concluding nine months of contract bridge play that started at the grass-roots level.

title: AIDS INFECTION IN BLACKS STUDIED
description: The virus for AIDS continues to infect blacks in the United States at a far higher rate than whites, according to data discussed at a medical conference here.

title: ECONOMISTS ARE WONDERING WHAT HAPPENED TO PROSPERITY
description: Right about now, most analysts had figured, the nation's economy would be beginning the surge so confidently expected for the second half of 1986.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'SHIP OF FOOLS' TO STING
description: Sting: Bring on the Night; Directed by Michael Apted, Karl-Lorimar Home Video, 97 minutes. $79.95.

title: BATTLING THE 8-FOOT DISH NEXT DOOR
description: WHEN Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real-estate developer and magazine publisher, decided to install a satellite dish antenna atop a dune at his East Hampton home last spring, he sparked a small war with his neighbors on Drew Lane. They say the dish is an eyesore.

title: The Budget Bird
description: ''How about the appropriation?'' the budget director was asked.

title: ATTACKS ON U.S. ARABS: THE MIDDLE EASTERN LINK
description: A Congressional hearing dealing with violence against Arab-Americans has reflected a growing perception that such violence rises in waves originating in the conflicts of the Middle East.

title: ANGELINA, APTLY NAMED
description: DEAR DIEGO By Elena Poniatowska. Translated by Katherine Silver. 87 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.95.WHEN Diego Rivera left Paris for his native

title: Miss Blackfield the Bride Of David Smith in Darien
description: Tracey Christine Blackfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy G. Blackfield Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to David Edward Smith, a son of Elizabeth Smith of Naugatuck, Conn., and the late Raymond R. Smith.

title: Paula Ann Fusek Is Bride Of Dr. Thomas Van Aken
description: Paula Ann Fusek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Fusek of Valhalla, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas Van Aken, a son of Ruth Van Aken of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late William Van Aken. The Rev. Jack Traugott performed the ceremony at Emanuel Lutheran Church in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: U.S. SAID TO DROP BLACK AS CHOICE FOR PRETORIA POST
description: The White House has decided not to name a black businessman from North Carolina as the next United States Ambassador to South Africa because of problems raised by background checks, a senior Administration official said today.

title: TENNIS BETWEEN YOUTH AND AGE
description: FIRST they were called junior veterans, but that didn't sound right since they were hardly juniors in age. Then someone suggested just veterans, but that made them seem like an over-the-hill gang. Finally they came to be known as 35ers, a name that stuck.

title: Deborah Watkis Wed To Thomas L. Brown
description: At the Concord Baptist Church of Christ in Brooklyn yesterday Deborah Jean Watkis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clinton J. Watkis of Brooklyn, was married to Thomas L. Brown, a son of Julia Hudgins Brown of Richmond and the late Charles Bernard Brown. The Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: Data Update
description: Source: HSH Associates * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: DR. DAVID BROWN MARRIES DR. ADEL
description: Dr. Lori Adel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Adel of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. David Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brown of Key Biscayne, Fla. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner performed the ceremony at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: WHERE THE PASTA IS IN ITS PRIME
description: THE welcome at La Trattoria Italiana in Roslyn Heights is enhanced by a glimpse of the appetizers and desserts displayed on a table near the bar.

title: HOW BRITAIN'S ROYAL FAMILY SHAPES ITS TV IMAGE
description: Amid the predictable and numbing avalanche of British press coverage leading up to this week's royal wedding, The London Standard managed an old-fashioned scoop the other day. Its coup was a picture of the bride-to-be, Sarah Ferguson, looking at a television camera that was pointing away from her. A rare moment indeed, lately, as Miss Ferguson prepares for her official entry, through marriage, as the newest star in one of the world's great television attractions: the British royal family.

title: At 4 A.M., Onlooker Got Ready in the Fog
description: The first Kennedy-watcher planted a folding chair in the predawn fog today within 50 yards of the church where Caroline Bouvier Kennedy married Edwin A. Schlossberg.

title: WALKING SHORT
description: WALKING SHORTS HAVE HAD THEIR UPS AND downs. In the l950's, when their glamour peaked, they were the informal uniform at smart resorts from Bermuda to Palm Beach. Pleated and generously tailored, their legs were curtailed at the knee. ''Anything else,'' says the men's-wear designer Alan Flusser, ''would have been more function than form.'' In time, these abbreviated trousers lost their cachet, supplanted by their shabbier cousins, cut-off blue jeans. Now, however, a new generation has rediscovered their comfort and elegance, qualities that retailers say have made them one of this summer's liveliest sellers.

title: Brenda Sanchez Weds Stephen Golden
description: Brenda L. Sanchez and Stephen A. O. Golden were married yesterday at the bride's home in Quogue, L.I., by Judge John Copertino of the Suffolk County Court in Riverhead, L.I.

title: CABLE TV
description: Good films stuck with forgettable titles all too often slide past discriminating home-viewers on cable. A perfect example this week is ''Once in Paris'' (1978), a romantic comedy about a Hollywood scenarist (played by Wayne Rogers) and his first encounter with the Paris movie world - and a Paris love (Gayle Hunnicutt). Written, directed and produced by Frank D. Gilroy (who won a Pulitzer for his play ''The Subject Was Roses'') the movie is entirely disarming. It looks as Gallic as the Eiffel Tower. And it's stolen, ever so deftly, by Jack Lenoir, as a very wise chauffeur. Catch it Tuesday afternoon at 4 on Lifetime. Dipping way back, we have ''The Joy of Living'' (1938). There are far worse ways to start the day - Friday morning at 5 on USA - than a romantic comedy with the personable likes of Irene Dunne and Douglas Fairbanks Jr., a nice batch of Jerome Kern songs and a script with Dorothy Parker gleams (about a harried Broadway star with sponging relatives, and a sailor determined to spirit her away). The film is rarely revived. The best song is a real beauty: ''Just Let Me Look at You.'' Try it.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston;
Turning Gifts Into Parks
description: TWO years ago, Dr. Sidney Schnur gave this city a 39-acre undeveloped tract he owned in a low-income neighborhood for use as parkland. Children now romp on playground equipment in the park, which is named after its donor, and there are plans for ball fields and tennis courts.

title: THE HEMINGWAY LETTERS
description: In ''The Hemingway Letters'' ( About Men, June 29), Barnaby Conrad, wanting a letter from the great man, had to be content with a Christmas card by Ernest Hemingway to his boyhood friend, William B. Smith. The card was signed, ''Wemedge,'' Hemingway's nickname among his World War I friends.

title: THE BRILLIANCE OF MAYAN CULTURE IS SEEN IN A DARK NEW LIGHT
description: The last 25 years have seen spectacular advances in the field of Mayan studies, but most of them have only been known to specialists. The question was, which museum would put together the scholars, the funding and the loans to bring this new information to the rest of us. Now we know the answer. ''The Blood of Kings, Dynasty and Ritual in Maya Art,'' at the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth, is the most ambitious loan show in the history of the Texas museum, and that is saying a lot.

title: THE HOUSE REPUBLICANS JUST WANT TO STAY EVEN
description: REPRESENTATIVE Tony Coelho of California, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, predicts that the results of the 1986 elections will write an end to one chapter of the Reagan Revolution. ''The battle of the 80's is over in the House,'' he says. ''After we gain 10 to 15 seats this fall, we will have virtually erased Ronald Reagan's impact on the House.''

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
HISTORICAL SPONGE MOVEMENT
description: New York Dada's importance for the history of art turns on the association of Man Ray with the immigrants Marcel Duchamp and Francis Picabia, beginning in 1915. It remained a one-Man show, which expired when Ray followed Duchamp to Paris in 1921.

title: A COUPLE COPES WITH A GARDEN ON A SMALLER SCALE
description: Space is very limited, so we look for unusual plants,'' Inge Clark said of the garden she and her husband, Richard, are creating at their Heritage Hills condominium located in Somers, N. Y. ''It is also a garden with a new point of view,'' said Dick Clark, ''because it was laid out so we could enjoy it from our living room window as well as outside.'' Young trees anchor the outer points of this bed, notably a slow-growing umbrella pine, native to Japan, and a handsome dawn redwood (Metasequoia glyptostroboides).

title: PROF. TURNER SUMS UP
description: WITH an ornate green and red gift samovar in his hands, and a gaping $15 million hole in his pocket, Ted Turner conducted his last economics seminar for the best inquiring minds from world journalism yesterday.

title: Arms and Priority
description: Leaders of the House Armed Services Committee are organizing a campaign to give arms control proposals priority over financing new weapons systems when the defense bill reaches the House floor early next month.

title: QUINN BACK AS ZORBA, WITH ZEST
description: IF producers ever needed a clear-cut justification for hiring stars at sky-high salaries, they could easily point to what Anthony Quinn does for ''Zorba.'' From the moment Mr. Quinn strides onto the Westbury Music Fair's circular stage this otherwise flat, overly sentimental musical begins to sparkle with that indefinable something called star quality.

title: France Will Go Ahead On New Paris Opera House
description: The French Government has said that it will press ahead with a controversial plan started by the previous Socialist administration for a giant opera and music complex in Paris designed by the Canadian architect Carlos Ott.

title: Miss Payer Plans Sept. 13 Wedding To David Thayer
description: Heather MacLeod Payer and David Thayer, both graduates of Bennington College, plan to be married Sept. 13, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Payer of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced.

title: JAZZ SINGER MEETS JAZZ SINGER
description: THE title of the act tells it all:

title: Opera in Australia, All Aboard for Ohio Fair
description: DELUXE CRUISES OF THE PAST AND PRESENT -As an ocean liner of the 1980's sails the Atlantic this summer on a 13-day round-trip cruise between New York and ports in New England and Canada, the ambiance of the great liners of the past - the Empress of Britain, the Normandie, the Queen Mary and the United States - will be evoked through illustrated lectures.

title: Moses and Ashford Winners in England
description: Edwin Moses of the United States posted his 112th consecutive victory in the 400-meter hurdles when he finished first today at the Pearl Assurance international invitational track meet.

title: UNDERWATERGATE
description: SINK THE RAINBOW! An Enquiry Into the ''Greenpeace Affair.'' By John Dyson with Joseph Fitchett. Illustrated. 192 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Victor Gollancz/David & Charles. $19.95.

title: TAPE TELLS THE STORY IN CANON'S NEW SYSTEM
description: THE Canon RC-701 Still Video System, announced a few weeks ago, opens the door on a new kind of photography for everyone, one in which tape replaces film as the operative component. Instead of using a roll of film, the photographer places a tiny tape disk into the back of what looks like a slightly larger-than-normal 35-millimeter camera. Pictures can be shot in sunlight, available light and with flash, using the same techniques and controls found on a standard single-lens-reflex still camera.

title: STOCKPILED TIRES AT MAHOPAC SITE STIR CONCERN
description: A RECENT fire in Putnam County at an automobile junkyard believed to contain several million tires has focused concern over whether the stockpiling of tires poses a serious fire and health hazard.

title: IN SHORT:FICTION
description: ACT OF WILL. By Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) This book's title raises a question: Is the ''act of will'' Audra Crowther's struggle to give her daughter Christina a charmed life? Is it Christina's struggle to build a fashion empire to repay her mother for all she has done? Or is the most remarkable act of will exerted by the reader who gets to the last page of this book? Barbara Taylor Bradford, the phenomenally best-selling author of ''A Woman of Substance'' and ''Hold the Dream,'' gives us Audra Kenton, orphaned from a once-wealthy family, who works as a Yorkshire nurse until she is swept off her feet by Vincent Crowther.

title: THE NEW MATH OF I.R.A. DISTRIBUTIONS
description: Following are answers to some questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q. I will turn 70 1/2 next month, and must soon begin tapping into my Individual Retirement Account. How do I calculate my withdrawal? A. The Internal Revenue Service requires I.R.A. withdrawals - technically known as distributions - to start no later than the end of the year in which you turn 70 1/2. But for the year in which you begin taking distributions only, the I.R.S. allows a three-month grace period - until April 1 of the following year. So while you have until April 1987 to take your distribution for 1986, you must also take your 1987 distribution by Dec. 31, 1987.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HARD-BOILED DAMES: Stories Featuring Women Detectives, Reporters, Adventurers, and Criminals From the Pulp Fiction Magazines of the 1930's. Edited by Bernard Drew. (St. Martin's, $16.95.)

title: Kenneth Lawhorn Jr. Weds Robin Fellows
description: Robin Fellows, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Fellows of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Lawhorn Jr., a son of Marguerite Lawhorn and the late Mr. Lawhorn of Simsbury, Conn. Justice of the Peace Donald Tedesco performed the ceremony at the Inn at Longshore.

title: Illegal Aliens Are Eligible For Medicaid
description: In a seven-year-old case challenging Federal restrictions on Medicaid assistance, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled last week that illegal aliens have the law on their side.

title: SUIT STUDIES THE WAGES OF JOURNALISM
description: A question of wages and hours that journalists and newspaper publishers consider fundamental has been put to the Federal District Court here:

title: CREATE JOBS THAT PAY AS WELL AS CRIME
description: THE United States has an enviable record for increasing employment in the past 15 years for most groups of workers, but not for young black men.

title: JERRY HADLEY -- A THOUGHTFUL TENOR
description: One thing that makes the tragedy of Werther so heart-rending,'' explains Jerry Hadley, the tenor who will sing the title role in Massenet's work when the New York City Opera unveils its new production this Wednesday, ''is the fact that when the opera begins, Werther is enamored of everything in life. It seems, for that instant, that he's found all those things we all crave: He's one with nature, he's found the perfect partner, he's at peace inside, and he's bursting with enthusiasm. Then Charlotte tells him that she has made a vow to her dying mother that she would marry Albert. Werther respects her need to honor that vow, but because they must therefore deny their love for one another, we are watching Werther's decline - and in a sense, Charlotte's, too - for the rest of the opera.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: IT'S got nothing to do with love, being in love, or staying in love. But there are moments in every marriage or relationship that stretch understanding, patience, and even indulgence, to their utmost. These moments can be when one partner sees a toothpaste tube being squeezed from the top, or the corner of a book page being turned down, or if one of the pair is foolish enough to insist on arriving at cocktail parties at the invited hour. But none of these little irritants are universal - in some marriages, both partners squeeze toothpaste tubes in exactly the same manner, neither would dream of turning down the corner of a book page (or both do it), and the two are of one mind about cocktail arrival time, which is usually at least 20 to 30 minutes later than the hour stated on the invitation.

title: KEEPING NEW COKE ALIVE
description: IN April, just a year after the introduction of new Coke, McDonald's notified The Coca-Cola Company that it was converting its 7,000 American restaurants back to original Coke. ''Our customers tell us what they want,'' said Lana Ehrsom, a McDonald's spokesman. They preferred Coke Classic.''

title: The Last Seconds Of the Challenger
description: Since the Challenger exploded Jan. 28, two important questions have gone unanswered. Did the seven-member crew have any hint of danger, and did they die instantly? After a preliminary analysis of tape recordings, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said last week that the astronauts had no forewarning, but the tape stopped too early to tell when they died.

title: Inmate Killed by Guard After Taking a Hostage
description: A prison inmate armed with a handgun took a prison guard hostage today and shot and wounded a second guard before being killed in a shootout with the injured officer, the police said.

title: STRANGE THING OUT THERE ON ROUTE 51
description: For all but 900 people in the world, this sleepy southern Illinois community is little more than a 40-mile-an-hour speed zone on the way to somewhere else.

title:
RECORDINGS;
CASSETTE REISSUES IMPROVE ON THE RICHES THEY MINE
description: Compact disks may hog center stage nowadays, but recorded tapes flourish as never before. It's the long-dominant LP disk format that's becoming an endangered species, while its onetime poor relation, cassettes, prosperously flaunt technological and promotional innovations.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LEAVING THE CITY BEHIND
description: I AM involved in a serious relationship.

title: FROM NEAR AND FAR, GUESTS ADD SPARKLE
description: VISITING artists from nearby states and foreign countries are helping make this week especially fruitful for music lovers. Today, you can hear the Via Nova String Quartet of Paris close out a two-week residency at Music Mountain in Falls Village, with 4 P.M. performances of Mozart, Schubert and Debussy. It is a good time to be at the mountain, too, because the annual exhibition of outdoor sculptures is on display. For reservations, call 496-1222 or 824-7126.

title: Pamela Hilgen Dickson Marries Mark J. Salisbury
description: At the First Congregational Church of Nantucket, Mass., yesterday Pamela Hilgen Dickson, a daughter of Lois E. Dickson of New York and Richard B. Dickson of Old Lyme, Conn., was married to Mark Jessup Salisbury, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Salisbury of Convent Station, N.J., and Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Thomas M. Richard performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Walsh Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Marshall Walsh to Joseph Sears Lovering 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lovering Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Walsh of New York and Edgartown, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: A Full Comeback For U.S. Alligator
description: POACHING and overharvesting had so depleted American alligators by 1967 that they were deemed on the brink of extinction. That year the Federal Government put them under special protection as an endangered species in 10 Southeastern states.

title: FRETTING, CHAFING, SIGHING, WEEPING -- A TOAST TO THE MELANCHOLIC WRITER
description: ''I WRITE of melancholy, by being busy to avoid melancholy,'' explained Robert Burton, author of that rollicking compendium ''The Anatomy of Melancholy.'' Upon completing the first folio in 1621, Burton was confident that his readers would take the subject as seriously as he did himself. I have no such confidence today. In the intervening years, melancholy has been condemned, distorted and dismissed. And yet for those of us whose interest in it is more than academic, who hold that life entitles them to a fair share of sadness, melancholy remains a reasonable - indeed, natural - condition.

title: BHUTTO PRESSING DRIVE IN PAKISTAN
description: Three months after returning to Pakistan, Benazir Bhutto is said to be stepping up her drive to oust President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq from office by organizing supporters to engage in immense disruptions in the streets later this year.

title: ANTI-LABOR ACTS LAID TO BROWN, WHO DENIES THEM
description: Robert J. Brown, the black businessman who had been under consideration for the post of Ambassador to South Africa, grew up here, as a poor boy raised by his grandmother and grandfather, a millworker, in a house on a dirt road.

title: Travelers' Raid
description: More foreigners enter the United States through New York's Kennedy International than any other airport, and lately they've had to stand in line for as long as four hours. The lines have gotten so bad that the Immigration Service has finally agreed to provide more inspectors. That's obviously welcome but the proposal for paying for them is not. The idea is to charge the travelers, through a $2.50 head tax on each entrant.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in the Travel section today, about a trip in China along the Karakoram Highway, discusses ''the new possibilities of travel within China'' for foreigners, an aspect of the nation's relaxation under Deng Xiaoping. The article is by John F. Burns, Peking bureau chief of The Times.

title: Miss Wood Wed To Thomas Ellis
description: Martha A. Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Wood of Hanover, N.H., was married there yesterday to Thomas M. Ellis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Ellis of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. James P. Breeden, dean of Dartmouth College's William Jewett Tucker Foundation, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Dean Eaker Married To Nancy Abondolo
description: Nancy Elaine Abondolo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dante Abondolo of Southbury, Conn., was married last night to Dean Ross Eaker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Eaker of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Eugene J. Lipsey performed the ceremony aboard the yacht Riveranda in New York Harbor.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: HEARINGS began last week on two very different Assembly bills that would establish a state program to regulate development in wetlands areas.

title: Hanging In There
description: What goes up sometimes stays there for a while. Last week, Richard Rutan and Jeana Yeager managed to stay up long enough in a feather-light experimental aircraft to set new world records for distance and endurance.

title: A DOCTOR ON TRIAL
description: There's a gentleman in the waiting room with a summons for you.'' My nurse brought the news as if offering me a dead fish.

title: Miss Purcell-Gilpin Weds
description: The marriage of Henrietta Haultain Purcell-Gilpin, a freelance journalist, to Peter Francis Sherwin, the owner of the Hanover Square Gallery in New York, took place yesterday at the Anglican Church of St. John the Baptist in Pilton, Somerset, England. The Rev. Gordon Mellier performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Coombe-Tenant, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. E. Purcell-Gilpin of Shepton Mallet, Somerset, England, and the bridegroom a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sherwin of Rye, N.Y.

title: FAMILY RETURNS TO REBUILT BLOCK
description: For the first time since the siege in which rowhouses on two streets here were turned to rubble 14 months ago, one Osage Avenue family has returned.

title: JETS SEEKING TO REBUILD OFFENSIVE LINE
description: They are a team that posted an 11-5 record, made the playoffs, and still had a major hole.

title: Gretchen Alexander, Medical Student, Weds Peter Murnane in Pennsylvania
description: Gretchen Barlow Alexander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Alexander of Alton, Me., and George Murnane 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murnane Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph W. Hess Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Samaritan in Paoli, Pa., assisted by the Rev. Stephen Babos, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: AT BADEN-BADEN, TIME OUT FOR ROULETTE
description: The sweep of the central basin at Friedrichsbad, under a Beaux Arts dome that would do justice to Brunelleschi, is of flawless white Carrara marble, and the main pool at the Caracalla baths, the other major watering place in Baden-Baden, is of little tiny tiles shaped into submerged armchairs. You lounge there while jets of water massage your back and the nape of your neck.

title: Albany's Wetlands Plan Arouses Staten Islanders
description: LAFOLLETTE BECKER, a 62-year-old Manhattan resident, is one of New York's smaller landowners. But because of nearby development, her 4,000-square-foot plot of land on Bertram Avenue in Staten Island this year drew a purchase offer of $60,000, money she says she plans to use for her retirement.

title: PONY RIDE VICTIM OF SOARING INSURANCE
description: THE joyous shouts of children are no longer heard along the western end of Van Saun County Park here, a victim of spiraling liability-insurance costs that in recent months have claimed the park's traditional and much-loved pony ride.

title: NICARAGUA, AT VATICAN, DEFENDS BISHOP'S EXPULSION
description: The Nicaraguan Embassy to the Holy See issued a sharply worded statement today defending the Sandinista Government against Vatican charges that it is violating religious freedom. ''The problem is not God,'' the embassy said.

title: A 'CATALYST' HELPS BIG BUSINESS SPREAD CULTURE TO THE WORLD
description: IN THE living room of Susan Bloom's home in East Hampton hangs a photograph by Henri Cartier-Bresson of a man vaulting across a puddle in the Gare St. Lazare in Paris. The picture is inscribed by the renowned photographer with the words: ''To Susan - Thank you for bringing my pictures to people all over the world.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NORTON I: Emperor of the United States. By William Drury. (Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) On a rainy January evening in 1880, Joshua A. Norton, a k a Norton I, Emperor of the United States, died in the street near San Francisco's Nob Hill.

title: HOUSE CALLS
description: House calls are in again, Dr. Connie Vance said last week, but there is a difference: nurses, not doctors, are making the calls.

title: Suzanne B. Seiden Is Wed To Kevin L. Thurm on L.I.
description: Suzanne Beth Seiden, a second-year law student at Fordham Law School, and Kevin Lee Thurm, who is to enter Harvard Law School in September, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Jeffrey Summit performed the ceremony.

title: NEWARK: ARTISTRY AND USES OF 'PRIMITIVE' ARCHITECTURE
description: BELYING its title, ''Hidden Heritage: Afro-American Art, 1800-1950,'' is becoming widely visible. The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is the fourth stop on a nationwide tour for this valuable and sometimes stirring survey. It will be in Hartford through August.

title: Equal Opportunity Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Women Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Margot Rubinstein Plans to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Joan Gilbert of New York and South Salem, N.Y., and Dr. Norman Rubinstein of Spring Valley, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Margot Susan Rubinstein, to Dr. Andrew Steven Gutterman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gutterman of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I. A September wedding is planned. The future bride, a resident in psychiatry at the Westchester County division in White Plains of New York Hospital, graduated from Barnard College and New York Medical College.

title: Parched
description: 'What we've found is that a large number of our farmers are without water.

title: Condo Wiring
description: To the Editor:

title: The C.I.A. On Campus
description: David Wise's article ''Campus Recruiting and the C.I.A.''(June 8) was lucid and instructive. The C.I.A.'s clearance process is, as it should be, the most rigorous of any Government agency.

title: BOBBING AND WEAVING ON ARMS CONTROL
description: AMERICAN scientists install sensitive seismic monitors in the remote steppes of Kazakhstan. . . Richard M. Nixon slips quietly into Moscow for secretive meetings with Soviet officials. . . The Reagan Administration agrees to meet the Russians in Geneva to debate arms control violations, but in Washington the Secretaries of State and Defense are locked in a bitter struggle over how to answer Soviet disarmament proposals.

title: PANEL TO AID QUEENS COLLEGE CHANGES
description: Queens College has formed a College Advisory Board made up of business leaders and professors to recommend sweeping changes in the college's curriculum.

title: ANGELS WIN, 9-3; JONES HITS 2
description: Ruppert Jones hit two homers and drove in four runs, and John Candelaria pitched five and one-third innings for his third straight victory since coming off the disabled list for the Angels.

title: Shift at Soviet Youth Group
description: Viktor I. Mironenko, head of the Young Communist League in the Ukraine, was appointed today to lead the national Communist Party youth organization, the official press agency Tass reported. Mr. Mironenko replaces Viktor M. Mishin, who was transferred to the secretariat of the Council of Trade Unions.

title: Mary Ann Allen Weds
description: Mary Ann Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton R. Allen of Springvale, Me., was married there yesterday to Donald John Wink, a son of Gerard J. Wink of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Mary Keely Wink. The Rev. John E. MacInnis performed the ceremony at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Wink until recently was a computer programmer for John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. Dr. Wink is an assistant professor of chemistry at New York University.

title: GOLD RUSH AMBLES TO AN UNEASY START
description: ISADORE WEINSTEIN, a retired businessman from Kingston, N.Y., was having a friendly sort of tiff with his wife, Ida. They were driving along Gadpouch Road, a heavily wooded dirt lane in Cobalt, a community near Middletown, looking for a stream where they might prospect for gold.

title: IN THE RING: GLADIATORS FROM THE ELBOW UP
description: Today the normally phlegmatic flow of weekend shoppers here at the Sunrise Mall gave way to the raw exercise of power - a sometimes thrilling, always grunting, usually perspiring, display of brute force.

title: POOLING RESOURCES
description: TRADITIONALLY, SWIMMING pools have been relegated to the farthest reaches of a backyard. Rectangular- or amoeba-shaped bodies of bright blue water, they were commonly considered recreational adjuncts only, and therefore placed as discreetly as possible in order not to interfere with the natural beauty of lawns and gardens.
