title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: IN MASSACHUSETTS, HUE HUE AND CRY -It is, in many ways, an all-American conflict.

title: BRAVES BEAT EXPOS: END 6-GAME SLIDE
description: Andres Thomas hit a three-run homer, and Ted Simmons had four hits and scored two runs as the Atlanta Braves snapped a six-game losing streak tonight with a 7-2 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: WITHERSPOON STOPS BRUNO, KEEPS TITLE
description: Tim Witherspoon, looking fat and out of shape, knocked down Frank Bruno with four crashing rights to the head and stopped the British challenger in the 11th round early this morning to retain the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship.

title: CD'S CAN PRODUCE SOFT MUSIC, TOO
description: Not all topics warrant lengthy discussion - so it's short takes today.

title: Czech to North Stars
description: As one Czechoslovak defector was returning for a visit, another was arriving in the United States to begin a campaign to fulfill a boyhood dream - to win the Stanley Cup.

title: Worthy Heirs of the Democratic Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Miracle at Philadelphia'
description: From George Washington's military headquarters at Liberty Pole, New Jersey (now Englewood), Alexander Hamilton, the general's aide-de-camp, wrote a remarkable 17-page letter in September of 1780 insisting that the 13 sovereign states were not fit to govern the country in war or peace.

title: CONGRESS, THE WHITE HOUSE AND PRETORIA
description: AS Washington prepared for a major debate on South Africa policy this week, there was growing recognition that United States influence there may be only marginal. Returning from a visit to observe South Africa's crackdown on dissent, Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, reported that whites and blacks alike seem to have lost hope for peaceful reconciliation. ''The time has run out,'' he said.

title: Few New Clues on Cause
description: The Soviet Politburo's explanation of the April 26 disaster at Cheronobyl assigned blame to everyone on duty at the plant that day, but offered little more than hints of how plant workers caused the accident.

title: FUTURISTIC 'MIKADO' AT THE CANDLEWOOD
description: THEATERGOERS looking for something new, or for a new slant on something old, have a variety of choices this week, and all are state premieres.

title: U.S. Troops Join Bolivian Drive On Drug Traffic
description: Narco-terrorists, as the White House called them last week, have been winning big in Bolivia, a world-class producer of coca leaf. With hundreds of millions of dollars in cash flow, the drug dealers have outgunned and outmaneuvered Bolivia's American-supported drug-law enforcers.

title: MEDICAL ETHICISTS ARE A NEW SOURCE OF SECOND OPINIONS
description: THE CASE: an 84-year-old woman, a stroke victim three months ago, still in a semi-coma.

title: Preparing for Owners' Income Data
description: AMID the possibility of legal challenge, the City Finance Department has begun to implement a law that requires owners of income-producing property to submit annual income and expense data to city assessors.

title: ROCK'S ROLE
description: ROCK HUDSON His Story. By Rock Hudson and Sara Davidson. Illustrated. 311 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Martha McNamara Plans To Wed J. R. Bordewick Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. McNamara Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. McNamara's daughter Martha Jeanne McNamara to James Richard Bordewick Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bordewick of Edina, Minn.

title: Carol Ann Phethean Plans to Wed Sept. 27
description: Carol Ann Phethean and Peter Samuel Yawitz, both cum laude graduates of Princeton University, plan to marry Sept. 27. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. D. Glenn Phethean of Somers, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Burton L. Yawitz of New York and Lords Valley, Pa.

title: Tax Shifts Trouble Aged in Connecticut
description: FOR the 74-year old Mario Daprile and his wife, Christine, 75, of Fairfield, Conn., real-estate taxes were never something to fret about.

title: OVERTURNED MURDER CONVICTION TO BE INVESTIGATED
description: An independent investigation is to be conducted into allegations of prosecutorial misconduct in the conviction of a man recently freed after spending more than six years behind bars for a felony murder.

title: TROUBLED TIME FOR A TALENTED PITCHER
description: IN the visiting clubhouse at the Kingdome here, the familiar numbers and names of the current guests, the Red Sox, were taped to the top of the black steel lockers: 25 Baylor, 26 Boggs, 21 Clemens, 14 Rice. This was last Thursday, the first day of the second half of the season, a season in which the Red Sox, the leaders in the American League East, are looking to capture their first pennant since 1975.

title: Tracking Down Tainted Blood
description: The odds against receiving a blood transfusion contaminated with the AIDS virus are not too different from the chance of winning a lottery. But reassurances issued by health officials in New York and New Jersey last week did not completely calm a public alarmed by the news that blood banks were searching for people who might have received tainted transfusions between 1977, when AIDS is believed to have begun its lethal spread in the region, and April 1985, when a test for AIDS virus antibodies, a sign of exposure to the disease, was initiated.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Avondale Mills, Sylacauga, Ala., elected John G. Hudson president and chief operating officer.

title: IMPORTANCE OF SUBTLETY
description: Making jokes about his age, 75, has become a recognized part of President Reagan's act, so he can now work toward more subtlety in punch lines.

title: Bronx Man Slain Aiding Teen-Ager
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man was fatally shot yesterday morning while coming to the aid of a teen-ager who was being held up at gunpoint in the borough's East Tremont section, the police said.

title: For Robertshaw Head, A Sale and Retirement
description: As word that the Robertshaw Controls Company had decided to seek a buyer was released last week, Ralph S. Thomas, the president and chief executive officer, started calling major stockholders, suppliers, customers and executives. By 6:30 P.M., he had made 46 calls. He had dinner with friends, was in bed by 10:30 P.M. and up by 4 A.M. to fly to Canada to visit a potential acquisition.

title: SURGE IN U.S. SALES OF OUTDOOR GOODS
description: In the wake of terrorist attacks overseas last spring, Robert and Sandy Pittman canceled their trip to Europe and went trout fishing in Pennsylvania instead.

title: DEBATES GROWING ON USE OF ENGLISH
description: Despite opposition from civil rights groups and ethnic organizations, efforts to declare English the official language appear to be gaining strength in parts of the country.

title: Will Mr. Reagan Denounce Pretoria?
description: With the South African Government resorting to increasingly brutal repression and widespread censorship to conceal its actions from the outside world, the White House has announced a ''review'' of American policy to deal with the ''new situation,'' and the Administration may unveil new initiatives this week.

title: HEAD OF URBAN LEAGUE ASSAILS COURT NOMINEES
description: The president of the National Urban League said today that the Senate should reject the nominations of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court as Chief Justice of the United States and Judge Antonin Scalia as an Associate Justice because ''both have been insensitive to minority rights.''

title: FARM EXPERTS SEE SIGNS OF HOPE AS DECLINE IN LAND VALUES EASES
description: Although experts are not predicting an imminent upturn for agriculture, many are seeing some glimmers of hope through the gloom of the continuing farm depression.

title: O'Connor Assails Pornography Rise
description: Calling for an educational campaign to counter pornography, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, said yesterday that Jewish and Christian leaders would meet in the city this month to evaluate the report by the United States Attorney General's Commission on Pornography.

title: Gonzales Retains Flyweight Title
description: Paul Gonzales survived a third-round knockdown to take a convincing 12-round decision over Orlando Canizales to retain the North American Boxing Federation flyweight championship title today.

title: ON L.I., A LOOK AT YEAR-ROUND SCHOOL
description: SAG HARBOR, L.I.-This is thetime of year when most of the nation's teachers and students have put their textbooks back on the shelves and settled in for a long and lazy summer.

title: WEAK G.N.P. DATA EXPECTED
description: Figures on the gross national product for the second quarter, due to be released tomorrow, will provide economists with their first real clues about the shape of the economy in the current quarter and give the credit markets new reasons for hope or despair about prospects that the Federal Reserve Board will cut the discount rate again this year.

title: UNFAMILIAR REALM FOR QUEEN: DID SHE INTRUDE INTO POLITICS?
description: ''God Save the Queen From Damaging the Crown.''

title: William G. Lord, 85, An Ex-Textile Official
description: William Galey Lord, a textile executive and former executive vice president of Burlington Industries, died Friday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 85 years old. After graduating from Yale in 1922, Mr. Lord joined Galey & Lord, a manufacturer of woven materials for interior designers and decorators.

title: Phyllis Edelman Marries
description: The marriage of Phyllis Rachel Edelman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Edelman of New York, to Howard David Schoenholtz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schoenholtz, also of New York, took place yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Rabbi Henry Glazer officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is director of the annual New York City School Science Fair and is enrolled in the doctoral program at Teachers College of Columbia University. Mr. Schoenholtz is a national assignment manager for ABC News.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BIG PICTURE One of the largest screens in town hangs above the ground floor of the American Museum of Natural History's Naturemax Theater, 77th Street and Central Park West. It is 66 feet wide, 4 stories high, and comes with a six-channel sound system that can be heard through nine speakers and obviously cries for films that are big enough for the job.

title: Drug-Crazed Potential Killers in Our Streets: A Case in Point
description: To the Editor:

title: A GLOBAL LINKING OF FARM POLICIES
description: A last-minute temporary compromise has now postponed a disastrous escalation in the incipent agricultural trade war between the United States and Europe. This is all to the good, but it does nothing to mitigate the crisis afflicting farmers around the world. It is a crisis of our own making that will not be resolved until we remove the excessive government controls burdening our farmers.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically reviews the status of such questions, with today's group concentrating on missing people.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 21, 1986:

title: UNREST OVER THE BORDER FAILS TO RUFFLE EL PASO
description: La Primera, which sells new and used clothing by the pound, is the first shop on the Texas side of the bridge here that links the United States with Ciudad Juarez, Mexico. Its signs are in Spanish, most sales are in pesos and 95 percent of its customers are Mexicans.

title: Dina Micklin Silver Weds S. D. Persky
description: Dina Micklin Silver, a daughter of Raphael and Joan Micklin Silver of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven David Persky, a son of Marilyn Schuster of Great Neck, L.I., and Robert Persky of New York. Rabbi Daniel Jeremy Silver, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at her parents' home in East Hampton.

title: Jeffrey Kaufman Wed To Miss Eisenmenger
description: The marriage of Katherine Carol Eisenmenger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Waltz Eisenmenger of Natick, Mass., to Dr. Jeffrey Lawrence Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Aaron Kaufman of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at the Friends Meeting in Cambridge, Mass.

title: FINAL STAGE NEAR IN U.S.F.L. TRIAL
description: When the United States Football League filed its antitrust suit against the National Football League in October 1984, N.F.L. executives responded by calling the charges ''baseless'' and ''without merit.''

title: Japan-U.S. Talks Set
description: Negotiations between Japan and the United States on a new comprehensive air traffic pact will probably begin in Tokyo around the end of September, a United States official said Friday. The two countries have agreed on new cargo rules that, for the first time, will allow companies to combine freight of several shippers aboard a single charter cargo flight, said Gary Devight of the State Department office of aviation affairs.

title: Chief Rejuvenated Dillon, Read in 70's
description: In the mid-1970's Nicholas F. Brady gained notice as the young head of Dillon, Read & Company who revived the venerable investment banking house after it had lost ground in the competitive Wall Street environment of the 1960's.

title: Sandinista Actions Prompted by Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: The Desperate Women Who Turn to Homicide
description: To the Editor:

title: ITZHAK PERLMAN SINGS
description: Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, made an unannounced appearance here Saturday night as an operatic soloist.

title: 1,700 COUPLES MEET TO IMPROVE MARRIAGES
description: Diana Seixas's blue T-shirt reads ''LO.'' Her husband, Mike's, T-shirt reads ''VE.'' Standing together the two spell ''LOVE'' ''only when we get things right,'' said Mr. Seixas, one of 3,400 spouses who were gathered here today trying to get things right with their mates.

title: FINLAND'S ECONOMY MAKES ADJUSTMENTS
description: Finland is sometimes called the ''Japan of Scandinavia'' because of its penchant for consensus, its racial homogeneity and most of all its economic track record.

title: Pilots Dedicate Memorial To 10 Lost Astronauts
description: A tree surrounded by 10 stones bearing the names of the 10 astronauts who have died in the line of duty was dedicated Saturday by an organization of women who are pilots.

title: Chase Credit Card Job To McCaffrey & McCall
description: McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing has won the advertising account of the Credit Card division of Chase Manhattan Bank after a search that had included 16 agencies.

title: 'PUSS' BALLET IS DANCED ON CABLE
description: ROLAND PETIT'S ''Puss in Boots'' gets off to a rather slow start with some prosaic dancing for the villagers in this Perrault fairy tale. Be patient. Mr. Petit is a master showman. And soon the ballet, broadcast tonight at 10 o'clock over the Bravo cable network, comes alive with Mr. Petit's gift for unaffected spectacle and for probing the human heart.

title: Atlantic Salmon Reaches Central Vermont River
description: For the first time in nearly 200 years, an Atlantic salmon has swum from Long Island Sound to the White River in central Vermont, aided by cleaner water and new fish ladders over dams, wildlife officials said today.

title: WORLD ECONOMY SHOWS WEAKNESS
description: The world economy is suddenly displaying unexpected signs of weakness just when falling oil prices and low inflation appear set to strengthen recovery.

title: POPE CURBS MEXICO VOTE PROTEST
description: Pope John Paul II blocked plans by the local Roman Catholic archdiocese to cancel masses today as a protest of purported election fraud, and ordered the churches in the state of Chihuahua to hold services as usual.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: At the All-Star break, the St. Louis Cardinals had hit only 28 home runs in 86 games. At that rate, are they approaching any recent low for home runs hit by a team in a season? What's the major league record for fewest homers?

title: A MAN BATTLES TO SAVE CHERISHED SYNAGOGUE
description: Morris Weiser tapped his cane on the vaulted ceiling of the old synagogue, above the benches where the women sit. Plaster floated down in a white powder to the floor.

title: NAVRATILOVA GETS DISCREET WELCOME
description: Czechoslovakia's most famous defector, Martina Navratilova, returned here today to a discreet but warm welcome.

title: Permit to Practice
description: Its effects are only now beginning to be felt, but already a number of college coaches are clamoring for a key change in the rule that bars freshmen with low admissions scores from participating in Division I athletics. The coaches want it amended to allow affected freshmen to practice with their teams; otherwise, they say, the recruits will lose their athletic edge and, with spare time on their hands, could even fall easy prey to drugs.

title: The U.N. Today: July 21, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CURATOR EXPLAINS THE MAKING OF 'VIENNA 1900'
description: Kirk Varnedoe, the Museum of Modern Art curator who organized the museum's current exhibition of turn-of-the-century Viennese art and design, speaks of a great painting as if it declaims like a poet, rings out like a symphony, sings like an opera star.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 21, 1986
description: Companies

title: TOWNS MOVING TO CUT COSTS WITH SELF-INSURANCE POOLS
description: Towns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are forming their own insurance systems in an effort to avoid staggering rate increases for liability insurance.

title: ALFRED L. LUONGO
description: Alfred L. Luongo, chief judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, died Saturday at the home.

title: Pamela Rae Silton Marries David M. Singer, Publisher
description: Pamela Rae Silton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irvin Silton of Bayside, Queens, was married at the Huntington (L.I.) Town House yesterday to David M. Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Singer of Brooklyn. Rabbi Irwin Isaacson officiated.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MEXICAN PET: More ''New''

title: Staging the Strongest
description: It may seem a strange kind of competition for an outfit that's been left wheezing, gasping and relying on a jury's verdict for resuscitation, but the United States Football League is helping to stage the U.S.F.L. Strongest Man Contest at the Alabama State Fairgrounds in Birmingham next Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I told him to sit down and listen to the word of God.

title: METS FALL BY 9-8 IN 15TH
description: The Mets had not played a game like this since last summer, not since that 19-inning marathon with the Atlanta Braves that began on July 4 and ended at 3:55 A.M. on July 5. That game, which the Mets won, was full of strange and unpredictable twists, and so was this one today, which the Mets lost. But when it finally came to an end - 15 innings and 5 hours 29 minutes after it began - they talked about coming back.

title: THE RESURGENT SHULTZ: HOW A COMEBACK IS MADE
description: In May, Secretary of State George P. Shultz suffered what many of his aides felt was his worst policy defeat. Against Mr. Shultz's strong advice, President Reagan went ahead on the 27th of that month and announced that the United States would no longer be bound by the signed but unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: NEW PHOTOGRAPHS OF TITANIC SHOW SURPRISINGLY INTACT STERN SECTION
description: Despite earlier assumptions that most of the stern section of the Titanic disintegrated when the ship sank 74 years ago, examination of photographs taken Saturday by the unmanned sled Angus have shown that most of the stern section lies on the ocean floor relatively intact.

title: COLT OFFERS $1.6 BILLION STOCK PLAN
description: Colt Industries, a leading supplier of aerospace, automotive and industrial products, said yesterday that its board had approved a $1.6 billion recapitalization plan aimed at increasing shareholder return and employee ownership.

title: THE DANCE: PARIS BALLET DEPARTS IN 'SWAN LAKE'
description: EXIT the Paris Opera Ballet smiling. As Rudolf Nureyev, who had just danced the role of Siegfried in ''Swan Lake,'' stepped forward for his first bow on the company's closing night Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House, the full corps of swan maidens behind him remained onstage, eyes cast down demurely, wrists crossed.

title: Bloom & Gelb Leaving Jordan, Case Umbrella
description: Bloom & Gelb, the direct marketing agency acquired two years ago by Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath, is going to revert back to independent status because things have not worked out as expected.

title: Flood Watch in Effect In Western New York
description: Flood watches remained in effect in Chautauqua and Cattaraugus counties today as heavy thunderstorms pounded southwestern New York for the third consecutive day, slowing down the cleanup from earlier flooding.

title: IN JAPAN, CONCERNS GROW OVER YEN
description: As the yen inches closer toward the 150-to-the-dollar level, economists and business leaders are being forced to contemplate the effects of an exchange rate that only months ago was all but unthinkable here.

title: Andre the Seal Dies in Maine; Delighted Tourists for Years
description: Andre the seal, who swam here each spring from southern New England and was the subject of at least two children's books, was found dead Saturday at the age of 25, his trainer said.

title: FOR MARVIS FRAZIER, DOES FATHER KNOW BEST?
description: FROM the nearby railroad bridge, it must look to the passing Amtrak commuter like just another old, creaking building in this rundown North Philadelphia neighborhood. The upper floors of the three-story building at 2917 North Broad Street have gray-white stucco patches where windows used to be, and the rest is brown brickface.

title: Patricia Hoffman Wed To Samuel Friedman
description: Patricia Anne Hoffman, executive vice president and design director of ICF Inc., a New York company that manufactures furniture for architects, was married yesterday to Samuel N. Friedman, ICF's founder and president. Judge Edward Weinfeld of the United States District Court in New York performed the ceremony at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Ruff.

title: AS PEOPLE MOVE TO FORESTS, THREAT FROM FIRES IS RISING
description: A forest fire last year in Burke County, western North Carolina, swept over 16 square miles of forest in four hours. It raced up the steep wooded slopes of the South Mountains and leaped half a mile at a time from one ridge to the next.

title: NARROW FAIRWAYS PROTESTED
description: Tom Watson, a five-time winner of the British Open, and Seve Ballesteros, who has won twice, led a chorus of protests today about the extremely narrow fairways in the Open this year.

title: WHAT THEY SAY ABOUT MARSEILLES: IT'S CRIMINAL!
description: The chamber of commerce in this bruised and maligned city put some foreign journalists in an Alouette 2 helicopter the other day and flew them over oil refineries, factory sheds, sparkling beaches, chemical pipelines, chalk cliffs and busy wharves.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S AFFAIR WITH THE PHONE
description: Life in Hollywood is lived on the telephone. Actors are forever calling their agents, who are calling studio executives, who are schmoozing with producers, who are wooing half a dozen directors in consecutive calls, hoping one will agree to direct the producer's next movie.

title: RAIL FANS, LACKING INSURANCE, FIND NOSTALGIC TRIPS DERAILED
description: Scenic rides on refurbished old railroad trains, hardly the most daring of transport modes, have become the newest unlikely victims of the liability insurance crisis.

title: In a 'Patchwork' Career, Time for a New Endeavor
description: Five years ago, Martha Ritter wrote about what had happened to the Harvard class of 1970, to which she belongs:

title: OPERA: DIFFERENT VISION OF 'CARMEN'
description: OUR understanding of Bizet's ''Carmen'' has changed over the years. In the early 20th century, it was generally viewed as the chronicle of a good boy gone bad, seduced into a life of crime by the irresistibly alluring gypsy girl who lends the work her name. Today, we are more inclined to make Carmen the heroine - a flawed heroine, to be sure, but one characterized by courage, forthrightness and a certain existential honesty - while one commentator recently referred to Don Jose as a ''maternally dominated psychopath.'' The director Frank Corsaro has taken this denigration one step further in his current production of ''Carmen'' at the New York City Opera. The opera is now set in Seville, 1936, during the Spanish Civil War; Don Jose is a member of the Fascist army, with Carmen a Loyalist spy.

title: FOR NEW YORK'S WEST, OIL SLUMP BRINGS WOES
description: When Brad Gill joined the Berea Oil and Gas Corporation in Buffalo in 1981, he was confident about his new job exploring for oil and gas in western New York.

title: The Editorial Notebook; When Reason Blocks Out the Divine
description: A man recently arrested for randomly stabbing people on a New York ferry was quoted by the police as insisting ''God told him to do it.'' The police's meaning, and most readers' understanding, was that the suspect therefore had no ''rational motive.''

title: Day Care Worker, 32, Guilty of Molestation
description: After deliberating 65 hours, a jury on Saturday convicted a former Malden day care worker, Gerald Amirault, of sexually molesting nine children.

title: Outdoors; Paddlers of All Ages Embark on Kayaks
description: AMERICA'S love affair with the canoe will never end, but many paddlers are learning that the kayak, although less commodious, is a more versatile craft.

title: Finding New Places For Felons' Gallery
description: The Police Department's warrant division would like to see the faces of fugitive felons all over town.

title: TWO OFFICERS HURT CHASING A SUSPECT THROUGH BROOKLYN
description: Two police officers in a high-speed chase were injured, one of them seriously, early yesterday morning in Brooklyn when their patrol car went out of control and slammed broadside into a light post. The impact cut the vehicle, in half, the police said.

title: Bad Weather Prevents New Raids in Bolivia
description: Dense clouds and light rain swept over the tropical Beni region of Bolivia today, preventing further helicopter raids by a Bolivian police unit and American support troops against cocaine-processing centers.

title: Wrongheaded Tax Proposal to Aid Public TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp Unit Names Official
description: The Citicorp Investment Bank on Friday named Alan S. MacDonald head of its North American operations. Mr. MacDonald, 43 years old, the head of the Citicorp Information Business Group, will replace Mark F. Kessenich Jr., who has joined the E. F. Hutton Group as a senior official.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 21, 1986
description: International

title: OF MORALS, EXPANSION AND DRINK
description: When Warner Brothers picked Little Compton, R.I., as the location for a movie about witches set in the fictional town of ''Eastwick,'' the project offended some New England sensibilities. The minister at the Congregational Church, which would have been central to the film, called it anti-woman and anti-Christian.

title: GROOVY IMPRESSIVE IN STAKES VICTORY
description: Groovy, the speedy 3-year-old who became a laughingstock after finishing dead last in the Kentucky Derby and next-to-last in the Preakness, hung a startling 6 1/4-length defeat on the previously unbeaten Phone Trick in the Tom Fool Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: CIRCLING THE WAGONS: SOUTH AFRICA AND SANCTIONS
description: Speaking to rural whites earlier this month, the South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, very nearly dared the West to impose sweeping economic sanctions on his country.

title: Judges and Freedom
description: The long-established role of American courts in protecting individual liberty is under attack from the right these days. It is ''undemocratic,'' we are told, for judges to stand against the state.

title: MAN SHOT DEAD BY PARTY GUEST IN QUEENS YARD
description: A man was killed and two others were injured early yesterday when a man pulled out a pistol at a backyard party in Queens and fired at least six shots, the police said.

title: Chesebrough Disputes P.& G. Lotion Claim
description: Apparently Procter & Gamble and its agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles thought that consumers would see a benefit in the fact that its skin lotion, Wondra, dripped less readily from the overturned palm of a hand than did the ''best selling product,'' which happens to be Vaseline Intensive Care Lotion.

title: Risk of AIDS Is Cited In Blood Transfusions
description: The Connecticut Red Cross has begun a search for recipients of blood from 30 donors believed to have been exposed to the AIDS virus.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. TEXAS RANGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio -WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: War and Peace and a Church's Hymnal
description: To the Editor:

title: SPREAD IN DIVESTMENT MOVE SEEN
description: Gov. George Deukmejian says California's new attitude toward companies doing business in South Africa should influence Congress and his friend, President Reagan.

title: PHILADELPHIA WORKERS VOTE TO END 20-DAY STRIKE
description: Blue-collar municipal employees voted today to end their 20-day strike against the city even though no contract has been achieved.

title: REDS' STREAK ENDS WITH LOSS TO PHILS
description: Juan Samuel had four hits and scored four runs today as the Philadelphia Phillies pounded Cincinnati, 9-3, to end the Reds' five-game winning streak.

title: CONCERT: NADJA SALERNO-SONNENBERG
description: ALTHOUGH the violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg participated in only one of the four selections played by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall, it was her contribution that made the evening memorable.

title: REPORT URGES POLICE TO PURSUE OFFENDERS WHO REPEAT CRIMES
description: Law-enforcement agencies must work ''smarter, not necessarily harder'' by focusing on chronic offenders who average five or more serious crimes a week, according to a study made public today.

title: The Rich Must Lend or Wither
description: Beneath the surface calm, something is wrong in the American economy. Recession has been staved off for nearly four years - a modern record - and prices are remarkably stable. But infusions of credit by the Federal Reserve, the sharp depreciation of the dollar and the collapse in oil prices have failed to give business the anticipated boost. Exports are running far below expectations and much of the spending power created by the Fed has been dissipated in purchases of imports.

title: BRITISH BANK'S NEW INVESTORS
description: When Britain's Standard Chartered P.L.C. announced earlier this month that it had successfully fought off a $1.92 billion takeover bid from Lloyds Bank P.L.C., its top officials were ambivalent rather than triumphant. ''I do have rather mixed feelings about the outcome,'' Michael McWilliam, Standard Chartered's managing director, commented.

title: CANCELING PLANS WITH FRIENDS
description: AN hour before she was scheduled to have lunch with a friend at a restaurant, Barbara Jo Howard, a New York public relations manager for a wine importer, got a call from her canceling the date.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY MAY BE GOING 3-D
description: There may be a new dimension to transit passes - the third.

title: Colleges Can Stop Athletes' Drug Use
description: Surprising as it may seem, the tragic death of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, is not unique, and it raises questions about what universities can do to stop drug use among students, especially student athletes.

title: 18 Are Arrested After Rap Concert
description: Eighteen people were arrested in a series of robberies during and after a concert at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, the police said yesterday.

title: AT BROOKLYN'S 'BILLIE,' BLACK THEATER THRIVES
description: It is curtain time in Bedford-Stuyvesant. As the lights dim in the Billie Holiday Theater, an elderly woman hurries up the aisle with her favorite granddaughter. Two Brooklyn College classmates smooth down their best dresses. A police officer, known to be sweet on the leading lady, peeks in for a look at her first number.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: SANCTIONS DECISIONS DUE
description: In the next few weeks, several Western governments will be considering further sanctions against South Africa.

title: CHERNOBYL ANSWERS: NEW QUESTIONS
description: The Politburoreport issued Saturday on the Chernobyl nuclear disaster seemed a far cry from the terse initial announcement issued 68 hours after an explosion ruptured the fourth reactor. Instead of the simple

title: Andrea L. Loshin Is Wed to Michael Elihu Colby
description: Andrea Lee Loshin, the daughter of Mrs. Jerome Loshin of White Plains and the late Mr. Loshin, was married yesterday to Michael Elihu Colby, a son of Renee Mae Colby of New York and the late Sidney Colby. Rabbi David Kahane performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: The Rehnquist Precedent
description: In his prospective career as Chief Justice of the United States, William H. Rehnquist is likely to have an opportunity to set many precedents, but he is scheduled to participate in at least one even before he takes office. His confirmation hearing July 29 before the Senate Judiciary Committee will be the first ever televised.

title: CHINA ALLOWS VISITS TO REPORTER
description: The Peking bureau chief of The New York Times, detained incommunicado since late last week, was visited for 30 minutes today by a British consular official, who said the detained journalist is fit and ''of good heart.''

title: WORLD JUNIOR MARK SET IN 1,600 RELAY
description: William Reed, a sophomore from Philadelphia's Central High School, turned in a 44.5-second anchor leg to lead the United States to a world junior record of 3 minutes 1.90 seconds for the 1,600-meter relay tonight in Olympic Stadium.

title: Man Shoots 2, One Fatally, in Car
description: A gunman shot a woman and man in the head as they sat in a car in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday, killing the woman and critically wounding the man, the police said.

title: Civic Spirit's Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HUMOR, ON 'FOUR ON THIRTEEN'
description: THE justly famed British flair for flashing wit or good, wordy comedy has given way, as with so many other institutions in Britain, to new ways, to the hearty joke and the pratfall almost of the sort that was once considered the forte of German comedy. Three different manifestations of the new humor materialize tonight from 10 o'clock to midnight on Channel 13's ''Four on Thirteen.''

title: 4,092 Special Interests
description: If you've had an uneasy feeling lately that special-interest groups have again been swarming more numerously over this year's crop of Senate and House candidates, you're right. Political action committees, the groups set up by corporations, unions and associations to give up to $10,000 apiece each election cycle to Congressional candidates, reached a peak of 4,009 at the end of 1984 and then declined slightly last year.

title: ALLEN SETS BACK YANKS ON 2 HITS
description: Bob Tewksbury, who developed a stiff shoulder while throwing in the bullpen Saturday, did not throw yesterday. ''I didn't do anything today,'' the pitcher said. Neither did his teammates, and some of them played in the game the Yankees lost to the Chicago White Sox, 8-0.

title: INDUSTRY TAXES SPLIT CONFEREES
description: When Congressional conferees begin work in earnest this week on piecing together a compromise tax overhaul plan, the most contentious issue they will face is which segments of corporate America should bear a larger tax burden.

title: TEXT OF THE POLITBURO STATEMENT ABOUT CHERNOBYL
description: Following is the official text of the Politburo's statement on the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, as distributed Saturday in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: MAYOTTE HELPS U.S. GAIN IN DAVIS CUP
description: The United States secured a semifinal berth in the Davis Cup tennis tournament when Tim Mayotte defeated Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico, 7-5, 4-6, 0-6, 6-4, 9-7, today.

title: 'ALIVE FROM OFF CENTER' SHOWCASE VIDEO ART
description: VIDEO art has a hard time staying ahead of commercial television - especially video art that uses computer graphics, like the ''Alive From Off Center'' program to be shown tonight at 10:30 on Channel 31 and next Sunday at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 13. Virtually as soon as the computer wizards come up with a new effect, it shows up in commercials, in network logos and in music videos. To dazzle us, video artists need something more than technique - they need startling images or provocative ideas.

title: Working Profile; Scientist and Rule-Maker: Dr. David T. Kingsbury
description: Three weeks ago, a top-level Federal scientist stood in a crowded conference room at the National Science Foundation clutching the 500-page text of the Reagan Administration's new program to oversee the biotechnology industry.

title: Persuasion Plus
description: Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole is so eager to win support in the House for her proposal to sell the Conrail system that she has taken the unusual and seemingly counterproductive step of having her staff draft legislation on behalf of a Democratic member of the House subcommittee in which her bill is stalled.

title: RED SOX ROUTED AS BRADLEY KNOCKS IN 5
description: Scott Bradley drove in five runs with a home run and a single today to help the Seattle Mariners rout the Boston Red Sox, 9-5. As a pinch-hitter in the fourth inning, Bradley hit a three-run home run. He then hit a two-run single during the five-run sixth inning.

title: Market Place; Shrinking Net At Brokerages
description: HAS the securities industry profit cycle swung to the downside?

title: VENEZUELAN RECOVERY POLICY SET
description: The President of Venezuela, Jaime Lusinchi, has announced a 21-point economic program designed to save foreign currency reserves, pull the economy out of a prolonged recession and provide benefits to low-income families.

title: Covering The News On Cancer
description: THE name of the magazine is Cope and it is subtitled Living With Cancer.

title: BancOklahoma's Survival Seen as Assured
description: The BancOklahoma Corporation, shaken by a large second-quarter loss, faces an uphill struggle to raise necessary capital, but it is too important to the Oklahoma banking community to be allowed to fail, banking analysts said yesterday.

title: CITY OPERA: PUCCINI'S 'BOHEME'
description: CELEBRATED for its luxuriant lyric opportunities, Puccini's ''Boheme'' actually works best as a chamber opera - a dramatic process in which individual parts work swiftly and smoothly together, and where the beloved melodic sequences seem almost interruptive delays.

title: U.S. REPLY ON ARMS IS SAID NOT TO LINK DEFENSES TO CUTS
description: President Reagan, in a draft of his response to the latest Soviet arms proposals, has decided against including any explicit overall formula to limit defenses against missile attacks in return for deep cuts in offensive nuclear forces, Administration officials said today.

title: LeMond Surges Into Lead in Alps Stage
description: Greg LeMond took over the yellow jersey of the overall leader of the Tour de France today by finishing third in a grueling series of climbs through the Alps.

title: NICARAGUA CALLS SECURITY OPERATION A SUCCESS
description: The Government is claiming an important victory in the wake of the uneventful celebration Saturday of the seventh anniversary of the Sandinista takeover.

title: TREASURY TO SELL $10 BILLION IN NOTES
description: In addition to its auction today of $15.2 billion in three- and six-month bills, the Treasury will auction on Wednesday $10 billion in two-year notes.

title: School Wilderness Program Is Suspended for Six Months
description: The Oregon Episcopal School has suspended its wilderness education program for at least six months because of the deaths of nine school climbers on Mount Hood last May.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Protests Pennsylvania Klan Rally
description: About 250 people watched as Ku Klux Klan members set fire to a cross at a rally this weekend after a counterprotest that drew 400 people.

title: Washington Watch; Conference on Small Business
description: Operators of small businesses, many of them angry with President Reagan for his efforts to abolish the Small Business Administration, are being wooed by the White House to participate in the National White House Conference on Small Business Aug. 17-21. To date, more than 2,600 people have registered for the conference, which was announced last year, and have paid from $145 to $155 each to participate.

title: Product Introductions
description: Product introductions in June (201) could not keep up with the record pace set in May (263) but were far ahead of the 172 in June last year. These statistics come from the latest issue of the DFS New Product News, which monitors not only the number of entries of supermarket and drugstore products but also the flavors, colors and varieties each comes in. While it shows 201 actual new products last month, the total, including the variations, was 662.

title: Glowing Results
description: If dusk finds you still on the golf course, with too little light to finish your round, there's no need to despair anymore. Just whip out your new Nitelite ball, snap in a lightstick (a tiny version of the ubiquitous novelty item) and hit away. The glow, diffused through the translucent plastic shell, makes the ball visible from more than 100 yards, and, barring a shot into a murky pond, you'll find it resting in a six-inch pool of light.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Weather Records and Forecasts column on July 10 misstated that day's sunset time. It was 8:29 P.M.

title: WHEN BABIES CRY...AND CRY
description: Cassie Schwartz sighs when she remembers how her 1-year-old son, Brian, used to cry as much as he slept during the night.

title: U.S. TOPS SOVIET UNION FOR TITLE, 87-85
description: Kenny Smith, the North Carolina guard, scored 14 of his 23 points in the second half as the United States held off a late threat and beat the Soviet Union, 87-85, tonight to win the world basketball championship.

title: Hostage's Sister Arrives in Damascus
description: The sister of an American journalist held hostage in Lebanon arrived in Damascus Sunday to try to meet President Hafez al-Assad in her mission to free her brother and other hostages, state-run Damascus radio said.

title: THE FACES OF GOODWILL
description: ON the last night of the Goodwill Games, we sat around the press center and ate pungent dried fish with our fingers. The fish was a gift from the Russian telephone operators who had served us so loyally, mostly in our language, for the past two weeks during Ted Turner's summer jamboree.

title: D'ELIA FAVORITE IN OFFSHORE JERSEY RACE
description: John D'Elia decided to go to Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., six years ago to watch one of the country's most popular offshore powerboat races, the Walsh Offshore Grand Prix. It was an event that, as a former race-car driver, he could relate to easily.

title: To Keep Good Teachers Teaching
description: To induce New York City's best teachers to stay on the job, Robert Wagner Jr., the president of the Board of Education, proposes a merit pay program. Despite the skepticism of teachers' unions, the idea deserves exploration.

title: Dairies to Settle Suit Over Fixing of Prices
description: Local governments, school districts and other public and private institutions will receive almost $7.8 million from dairies that illegally overcharged milk customers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds 8 Convictions in Drug Case
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the convictions of eight people in what the Government called the largest cocaine ring ever in the United States.

title: RANGERS' MANAGER LEARNS BY DOING
description: Two hours before his Texas Rangers were to play the Detroit Tigers late last week, Bobby Valentine, the Rangers' manager, sat in the shade of the dugout watching two of his pitchers loosen their arms by playing catch - with a football.

title: COOTER'S JOINS COPA
description: SOON after Tim Teufel, Ron Darling, Bob Ojeda and Rick Aguilera were released on bond Saturday after having spent 11 hours in a Houston holding cell, their Met teammates confused clubhouse humor with jailhouse humor. As if they were prison-cell bars, strips of adhesive tape, some marked in black, hung from the top to the bottom of each of the four players' lockers. On each player's stool at the Astrodome was an empty beer can, a plastic cup labeled ''tequila,'' one cigarette, a book of matches, a bar of soap and a razor.

title: Howard Steven Lyon Weds Ronda Schreiber
description: The marriage of Ronda Elizabeth Schreiber and Howard Steven Lyon, graduates of the University of California at Berkeley, took place in Princeton, N.J., yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fath, uncle and aunt of the bride. Rabbi Mel Glazer officiated.

title: 'GARBAGE LOTTERY' SPURS RECYCLING IN AN ILLINOIS CITY
description: Like many other cities, Rockford wants people to recycle paper and aluminum cans instead of throwing them in the trash. But, perhaps unlike any other city, it offers prizes - $1,000 or more -to those who do.

title: ST. MARTIN'S ESTABLISHES NEW PUBLISHING IMPRINT
description: St. Martin's Press, which publishes about 400 books of general interest a year, has come up with a new way to cope with its growing number of titles: it is establishing a publishing imprint, Charis Books, which will inherit about 100 of the parent company's books and 5 or 6 of its 20 editors.

title: Max Factor, Wells Could Be Breaking Up
description: There could be a break-up in sight for Wells, Rich, Greene and its client Max Factor & Company, which has been spending about $15 million a year on advertising but does its own media placing in-house.

title: THE DILEMMA OF INSIDE TRADING
description: ''The Big Chill,'' the hit movie that captured the spirit of the 1980's, was not a cops and robbers caper. But if you paid attention, you saw a crime in the making.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 4 about the relighting of the Statue of Liberty misstated the method.

title: G.O.P. HOPEFUL MAY BE WILTING AS MICHIGAN CONTEST HEATS UP
description: The atmosphere inside the room at the Kiwanis Club luncheon here was like a sauna, and virtually everyone present had long since shed their jackets and loosened their ties. Not so William Lucas, who sat at the head table with his jacket securely buttoned without seeming to feel the stifling heat.

title: 6 KILLED AS STOLEN POLICE CRUISER CRASHES IN JERSEY
description: Four adults and two children were killed today when a stolen state police cruiser, being pursued by state troopers, ran a red light at high speed and crashed into a second car on a heavily traveled highway here, the state police said.

title: Daughter of Marcos Granted Stay by Burger
description: Chief Justice Warren Burger has stayed a mandate ordering Irene Marcos, daughter of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed Philippine President, to testify before a grand jury or go to jail for contempt of court, a spokesman for the Supreme Court said today.

title: Beth C. Levy Marries Gabriel S. Nechamkin
description: The marriage of Beth Caroline Levy, an associate of the New York law firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, to Gabriel Stephen Nechamkin, director of arbitrage trading at Plaza Securities in New York, took place yesterday at the Merion (Pa.) Tribute House.

title: REPAIRS SET, POLISH SLOOP SAILS FORTH
description: Like an actor stealing an extra curtain call, Operation Sail returned briefly yesterday when a small crowd gathered on Pier 84 to bid farewell to the Stomil, the Polish sloop that arrived in New York four days late for Liberty Weekend.

title: NORMAN WINNER IN BRITISH OPEN
description: Greg Norman of Australia finally won a major golf tournament, running away with the 115th British Open championship today to win by 5 shots on Turnberry's Ailsa Course, the most difficult layout for a major tournament in many years.

title: One Subsidy Too Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Ross Is Married to Donald Robert Shannon
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York yesterday Leslie Ross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Arthur Ross of New York, was married to Donald Robert Shannon, the son of Donald Keith Bombard and Betty Bombard, both of Syracuse. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: TEUFEL AND DARLING APPEAR BEFORE JUDGE
description: Ron Darling and Tim Teufel, who have been charged with assaulting two uniformed police officers at a Houston nightspot early Saturday, prepared to fly off with their Met teammates to Cincinnati tonight after making their first court appearance in the case, a proceeding in which neither player left his seat and the details of the charges against them were not aired.

title: Rachel Ginzberg Becomes a Bride
description: Rachel Ginzberg, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Eli Ginzberg of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Palazzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Palazzo of the Bronx. Rabbi Richard Address performed the ceremony at Douglas Watts Catering in Manhattan.

title: U.S. AIDES KEEPING PLAN FOR A BLACK AS PRETORIA ENVOY
description: Senior Administration officials, after deciding not to go ahead with the naming of Robert J. Brown as the new Ambassador to South Africa, said today that they would try to find another black candidate for the post.

title: Washington Watch; Licensing Truck Drivers
description: THERE appears to be some consensus growing on at least one proposal for the stricter regulation of business, coming in the form of a national truck driver's license.

title: New Zealander Orders Trial for French Agents
description: A district judge in Auckland ordered today that two French agents convicted of bombing a ship operated by the environmentalist group Greenpeace appear in court in September to answer new charges.

title: Bridge: Team of Four From Texas Wins Grand National Final
description: Four players from Texas squeezed out a narrow victory here in the final of the Grand National Team Championship in the early hours this morning.

title: SUIT BY MOTHER OVER ADOPTION TESTS STATE LAW
description: On her baby's second day of life last December, a 22-year-old unwed mother from upstate New York took a drastic step: From her hospital bed, she signed a form giving the infant up for adoption. Adoptive parents soon took the baby home.

title: Debt
description: * Bio-Response Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $20 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2001 and for 1.3 million common shares through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: TEAR GAS USED ON CHURCHGOERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African police disrupted a church service in Cape Town yesterday for relatives of people who are being detained under that nation's emergency decree, and they later fired tear gas at the congregation and arrested at least three worshipers, a participant in the service said.

title: Chairman of LTV Still Hopeful on Steel
description: When Raymond A. Hay was a student at Queens College he led a dance music trio called the Syncopaters and wanted to be a music teacher. But he switched to business and after a successful career at the Xerox Corporation, joined the LTV Corporation, where the music has not been so sweet.

title: Washington Watch; I.C.C. Rail Merger Vote Due
description: A major railroad merger case is scheduled to be ruled on Thursday by the Interstate Commerce Commission. It is expected to have widespread implications for the railroad industry and shippers across the country.

title: AQUINO ASSAILS LACK OF SUPPORT BY BUSINESS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino castigated private enterprise today for what she said was a wait-and-see attitude that had slowed the economic recovery of the Philippines.

title: Market Place; Less Glamour In Technology
description: THE International Business Machine Corporation's bigger-than-expected drop in quarterly profits was one more reminder that much of the magic has rubbed off technology stocks. For years, investors equated technology with earnings growth and, they hoped, with stock market profits. But when the growth stopped - or was temporarily stymied - individual stocks promptly shed their glamour.

title: Frequent Fliers Can Do Without Extra Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: BANCORP HAWAII CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORRIS OUT AS GIANT REGULARS REPORT
description: Today was the day the veterans were supposed to report to the Giants' training camp, and most did. Here is a brief list of some the ins and outs: In: Lawrence Taylor, the all-pro outside linebacker who underwent treatment in the offseason for substance abuse. He was supposed to check in by 1 P.M., and he is usually a last-minute arrival. Instead, he was here before lunch.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toys 'R' Us, Ward
description: In an unusual partnership, Montgomery Ward & Company and Toys ''R'' Us said that they would jointly operate a store in Gaithersburg, Md., starting in October.

title: Meeting Is Planned On Auschwitz Convent
description: Roman Catholic and Jewish spokesmen plan to meet in Switzerland this week in an effort to resolve a dispute over the establishment of a Catholic convent at the Auschwitz death camp in Poland, sources said.

title: DEMOCRATS PESSIMISTIC ON BLOCKING A COURT CHOICE
description: Democratic Senators said today that they might find it impossible to block the appointment of Daniel A. Manion to a Federal appeals court in Chicago.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New British Steel Head Began as Accountant
description: The recent appointment of Martin Llowarch as chief executive of the state-owned British Steel Corporation, the world's third-largest steel company, quickly follows the announcement earlier this month of annual net profits of $58 million.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Western Union Case
description: A Federal appeals court has thrown out a $54 million judgment that a San Francisco man had won from the Western Union Telegraph Company and reversed a verdict that the communications concern had run him out of business.

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After $42.8 million writeoff of goodwill. c-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have paid my taxes, I have represented many major companies in this country very successfully and very effectively.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Basil Rauch Is Dead at 77; Taught History at Barnard
description: Dr. Basil Rauch, professor emeritus of history at Barnard College, died Saturday at Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven. He was 77 years old and lived in Killingworth, Conn.

title: SETTING SOFTWARE PRICES
description: WHY does software cost so much? Some consumers, and even some software makers themselves, say there is no reason, other than greed, for a company to charge hundreds of dollars for a floppy disk, a cardboard binder and a sheaf of documents.

title: Moscow Appoints Minister Of New Atom Power Agency
description: The Soviet Union appointed Nikolai F. Lukonin today to head a new Ministry of Nuclear Power, created to run the nation's atomic power industry after the Chernobyl disaster.

title: Accidents of Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIAS PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY
description: Police and medical officials appeared today before a grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star who died of cocaine intoxication June 19.

title: CAPITOL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF DENVER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A First Showing for 'Star Trek' Pilot
description: ''The Cage,'' the first pilot episode made in 1964 for the television series ''Star Trek,'' will be shown beginning Aug. 7 at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street. The episode, made in black and white, featured Jeffrey Hunter in the role of Captain Pike, commander of the starship Enterprise.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 22, 1986
description: International

title: J.G. SOURWINE, EX-SENATE AIDE, IS DEAD AT 78
description: J. G. Sourwine, chief counsel for many years to a Senate subcommittee that sought to uncover subversion and Communism, died of cancer in the Spark Care Center, a nursing home in Reno, on June 24. He was 78 years old and had lived in Reno since 1976, when he retired from his Senate post.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Burger King's President Quits
description: Jay Darling has resigned as president of the Burger King Corporation, a post he had held since last November.

title: ISRAELI CABINET MEMBER QUITS, AVERTING CRISIS
description: Justice Minister Yitzhak Modai resigned today rather than be dismissed for continuing to criticize Prime Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Trout in Lake Ontario
description: Significant numbers of lake trout have reproduced in Lake Ontario for the first time in 30 years, a team of Federal, New York State and Cornell University researchers has reported. This spring the scientists trapped 75 trout offspring near Henderson Harbor in the eastern part of the lake, the first large number of trout fry to be caught since efforts to restock Lake Ontario with the species began in 1973.

title: GEAR AT HARLEM HOSPITAL HAS LAIN IDLE FOR YEARS
description: The city's municipal hospital system has spent more than $1 million since 1982 to buy and install X-ray equipment at Harlem Hospital that has never been used, according to city records.

title: VULCAN MATERIALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writedowns of $728,000 primarily for tin and steel inventories. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,097,000 and $3,330,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Robb's Rising Star
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia seems to be on almost every Democrat's short list of potential Vice-Presidential candidates, but of late the speculation has escalated and some people are saying why not the top - why not President?

title: Military Will Go On Selling Adult Magazines on Posts
description: Adult magazines such as Playboy and Penthouse will remain available for sale to military personnel despite reservations expressed about such publications by the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2.7 million for the quarter and $5.9 million for the 6 months, and a gain of $3 million on the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 22, 1986
description: International

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 6 months. The latest year's first half figures have been revised because of a change in accounting relating to employee pensions.

title: ON CITY STREET CORNERS, NIGHT OF ANTIDRUG VIGILS
description: Leaders of 60 predominantly black churches, declaring that crack and other drugs represented ''a new form of genocide,'' yesterday set up all-night vigils on several street corners in the city where drug dealing is rampant.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 12 about toxic wastes in affluent areas, based on a report by the Council on Economic Priorities, incorrectly cited a New Jersey community as the site of 25 abandoned toxic dump sites. The community, Short Hills, has none. A corrective article appears today on page B5.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes minority interests of $200,000 and $500,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes minority interests of $400,000 for the quarter and $700,000 for the 6 months.

title: Plea Against Prison Rule Limiting Letters Fails
description: The First Amendment rights of prisoners are not violated by a Virginia Department of Corrections policy that limits inmate correspondence, a divided appeals court ruled today.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
92D STREET Y TO PRESENT RAGS, SWING AND BOP
description: It will be swingtime - and ragtime, and occasionally even boptime - for the next two weeks at the 92d Street Y. Tonight through Thursday, and next Tuesday through Thursday, the Y will present its second annual Jazz in July festival, directed by the pianist Dick Hyman and concentrating on jazz before World War II and a few of its offshoots in pop and classical music - from concert ragtime pieces to a Krazy Kat ballet.

title: SEOUL-U.S. ACCORD SET ON TRADE
description: The South Korean Government has agreed to enact legislation to protect United States patents, copyrights and trademarks and to permit United States insurance companies to compete for the sale of life insurance policies in that country, according to White House officials.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK OF N Y reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $5,010,000 for the quarter and $9,285,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago per share earnings are not available. The bank converted from mutual to stock form on Nov. 27, 1985.

title: Steel on the Ropes
description: LTV's petition for protection under the bankruptcy laws shocked Wall Street, whose experts thought the second-largest steel maker could hold out for a time longer. But Big Steel's problems are deep and chronic and require drastic adjustment. It is hard to think of another industry so battered - or so slow to meet the challenge. Americans can only hope that the LTV move hastens the conversion to a smaller, lower-cost basic steel industry that could prosper without subsidy.

title: Career Switch
description: Glen Braxton, who last year turned down a football scholarship to Oklahoma to sign a contract with the Chicago White Sox, has reversed his field. The 18-year-old outfielder/fullback has left professional baseball and this fall will suit up with Coach Barry Switzer's Sooners.

title: YALE PANEL ON SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT'S SPLIT ON DIVESTMENT
description: A delegation from Yale University that spent eight days in South Africa reported today that it was divided on whether Yale should get rid of its stock in American companies doing business in that country.

title: TRANSWORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4.5 million and $5.7 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for latest quarter declined due to a substantial increase in its effective tax rate to 47 percent from 27 percent a year ago.

title: DETROIT UNION LEADERS SEE PROGRESS ON WAGES
description: After a 17-hour bargaining session, union leaders reported their first progress today on wages, the issue that sent 7,000 municipal workers to the picket lines five days ago.

title: City Plan to Get More Cabs Stuck in Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: VATICAN REPORT THREATENS PRO-CHOICE NUNS
description: The Vatican today formally threatened to take disciplinary action against two American nuns who signed an advertisement during the 1984 presidential campaign supporting the right of Roman Catholics to dissent from the church's opposition to abortion.

title: Paraplegic Man Fathers Child by New Technique
description: A newly developed technique that has enabled a paraplegic man to father a child also holds promise for men who have been unable to have children because of testicular cancer, a doctor said today.

title: Playboy Cuts Rate Base For Circulation 17%
description: Citing a general decline in single-copy sales of magazines, as well as the effects of the recent Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, 33-year-old Playboy magazine announced yesterday that with its November issue it would cut its domestic circulation rate base by 17 percent, to 3.4 million, from 4.1 million. Penthouse, its archrival, is at 3 million and delivering it, according to Kathy Keeton, vice chairman of Penthouse International.

title: BMW AIMS FOR OLDER, AND WEALTHIER, BUYERS
description: BMW, the German luxury auto maker, is trying to make its image more luxurious still.

title: Stock Repurchase Planned by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. said that it plans to begin a stock repurchase program under which up to five million shares of its common stock might be bought in the open market from time to time.

title: VETERAN CLINGS TO HOPE
description: Don Hasselbeck has never been one of the National Football League's great tight ends. For most of his career, he has backed up such outstanding players as Russ Francis of the New England Patriots and Todd Christensen of the Los Angeles Raiders. Last year, he was the backup, roommate, confidant and unofficial coach on the field of Mark Bavaro of the Giants.

title: G.M., Deere Plan Joint Diesel Venture
description: The General Motors Corporation and Deere & Company said today that they intend to form a joint venture to design and produce diesel engines. The new company is expected to have annual worldwide sales of $1.5 billion.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $58,000 for the quarter and $99,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,127,000 and $1,534,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: PAPER SAYS NICARAGUA DETAINED 2 U.S. JOURNALISTS
description: A correspondent for The Washington Times said today that he and an American freelance journalist were detained for nine hours Friday by the Nicaraguan authorities in Managua and then expelled after their notebooks, film and other materials were confiscated.

title: MANVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIOLOGIST SAYS TESTS DON'T BAR MARTIAN LIFE
description: A biologist who for several years has argued that tests of Martian soil 10 years ago did not rule out the presence of life there, yesterday described new experiments that he said strengthened his argument. The soil tests were conducted by two Viking landers on Mars.

title: Jaworski in Accord
description: After agreeing to terms on a new four-year $2 million contract Sunday, Ron Jaworski, the veteran quarterback of the Philadelphia Eagles, was expected to report to the team's training camp at West Chester State University. ''He will come in as a back-up quarterback right now,'' said an Eagles spokesman, Ed Wisneski.

title: PARIBAS FINANCES THE RAIDERS
description: There is a ploy used by corporations when they are worried, even remotely, about becoming the target of an unfriendly takeover. They develop business relationships with as many big commercial banks as possible.

title: HELP FOR CYPRUS: A FOREIGN-AID ODDITY
description: At the order of Congress, reluctant American foreign-aid administrators have for many years been allotting at least $15 million in annual economic assistance to Cyprus, whose standard of living is on a par with that of southern Europe.

description: Trading volume on Wall Street sank to its lowest level in two months yesterday, and stock prices were mostly lower as investors, fearing a repeat of the volatility of the last two Mondays, decided that inactivity was the wisest investment decision.

description: The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh said yesterday that second-quarter profits fell 19.5 percent, to $54.8 million, or $1.87 a share, from $68.1 million, or $2.45 a share, a year earlier. Most of the decline appeared to come from a sharp increase in loss-loan provisions.

description: Jack Nicklaus played his first round of golf in Ireland yesterday when he and Seve Ballesteros staged an exhibition match at the Royal Dublin Golf Club, which sits on an island in the harbor of the nation's capital. Ballesteros, who won the Irish Open twice on this course - in 1983 and 1985 - had enough ''local knowledge'' to win the match, although he needed to sink a 35-foot putt on the 18th hole to win, 70-71, on the par-72 links.

The experience and age of the principals are wrong - architecture is what they are out of and Peter Arnell is only 27 years old, while his partner, Ted Bickford, is 29.

title: KROGER RESTRUCTURING WILL CLOSE 100 STORES
description: In a series of tough measures, the Kroger Company said yesterday that it would close 100 unprofitable supermarkets, possibly dispose of its 900 drugstores and cut headquarters expenses by 25 percent through an early retirement plan for 300 employees.

description: Two major chemical companies, American Cyanamid and Monsanto, yesterday reported strong earnings improvements for the recent quarter.

title: The Editorial Notebook; What Ails Manhattan's West Side
description: Leaders and residents of Manhattan's West Side propose an indefinite moratorium on all further construction until the city shows them a ''master plan'' of the area's future. They seem to believe that the successful development initiated in the late 1950's now threatens unbearable density. As the City Planning Commission observes, they are wrong.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CLAY EATING PROVES WIDESPREAD BUT REASON IS UNCERTAIN
description: The practice of eating dirt, usually fine clays, is so common in so many societies that it must be regarded as a normal human behavior rather than an oddity, according to scientists who are studying it. Yet why hundreds of millions of people and dozens of animal species consume earth remains a mystery, and information about the health effects is contradictory and incomplete.

When Mr. Cunningham stopped and talked informally with them, it was the climax of an extraordinary six-week exploration of American modern dance that began in North Carolina.

description: Recently, we returned to China after a two year absence to find that the encouragement of individual business initiative that the Deng Xiaoping leadership has been talking about for six years was at last clearly visible in the cities. It does not, however, advance such reforms for the Western media and President Reagan to hail the advent of capitalism in China. In fact, such gloating provides a pretext for ideological and bureaucratic opposition by Communist Party hardliners.

title: RED SOX LEAD SLIPS TO FIVE
description: Kurt Young tossed a three-hitter over eight and two-thirds innings and retired 14 batters in a row in one stretch, while Tony Phillips and Dave Kingman hit home runs to lead the Oakland A's to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title: Get Rid Of the 'Monster'
description: There is a genre of cheap horror film in which the monster does not die. Unfazed by bullets that would stop mere mortals, the behemoth charges forward, laying waste to everything. The ugliest, most formidable monsters even get resurrected after the last reel. So it is with Gramm-Rudman-Hollings.

title: 4TH QUAKE IN 2 WEEKS HITS WIDE REGION OF CALIFORNIA
description: A sharp earthquake, the fourth in California in two weeks, shook a wide area of the state today and rattled buildings as far east as Salt Lake City, 700 miles away. There were no injuries, but at least 20 homes were destroyed in California and other extensive damage was reported.

title: Hutton Sues Former Client
description: The E. F. Hutton Group Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit against George Aubin, a Houston entrepreneur, and 20 other individuals and companies that he is said to control. The lawsuit asserts that Mr. Aubin defrauded the brokerage firm of $48 million through a commodities and securities trading scheme. Mr. Aubin has countersued, his lawyer said.

title: Rangers Sign Erixon
description: Jan Erixon, one of the top penalty killers in the National Hockey League, has been re-signed by the Rangers. The 24-year-old Swede will start his fourth season with the Rangers. Last season he appeared in only 31 games because of a fractured left leg and had 2 goals and 17 assists.

title: AARON RENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW FINDS CHALLENGE IDEAS ON EARLIEST AMERICANS
description: NEW discoveries in the Arctic and in South America are rekindling scholarly debate over some of the most intractable problems in American archeology: how and when did humans first enter the New World? What kind of people were they?

title: Colt Chairman Cites Stockholder Gains
description: ''Stockholders have always done very well by us,'' said David I. Margolis, chairman and chief executive of Colt Industries. ''It's been our history.''

title: DRAMA: 'STATE OF BOOGEDY BOOGEDY'
description: NEBUCHADNEZZAR is on trial in ''The Sovereign State of Boogedy Boogedy'' at the New Federal Theater; his judges are Shadrach, Meshach and Abed-Nego and his lawyer is Danielle. But, while Lonnie Carter has cool revelations about justice to unveil, this courtroom is no place of order and decorum. The judges have all dabbled in petty crime; the angel who rescues the three men from the fiery furnace is a fireman of dubious morals; the king, possibly on the principle that the sins of sons will be visited on their fathers, is shackled with a charge he threw Danielle into the lions' den and doomed by the handwriting on the wall that spelled the downfall of Belshazzar in the Bible, and Danielle is reduced to stunned horror by the fate of the false accusers who persuaded the king to fling her to the big cats.

title: SOFTWARE FOR RAINBOW OF CHARTS
description: HOW crucial is color, really, to computing? Besides enhancing games, does it serve any function? Although color monitors are constantly being improved, only models having limited applications and costing thousands of dollars offer the display quality of plain monochrome.

description: West Germany allowed an East German economist suspected of espionage to return home today.

description: Guinea-Bissau executed six men today for plotting to overthrow the Government, two Portuguese news agencies reported.

title: 4 Groups Demand That Regan Resign for Remark on Women
description: Civil rights leaders today demanded that the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, resign because of his suggestion that women might object to economic sanctions that cut off imports of diamonds from South Africa.

title: IT CAN STILL WORK
description: Despite the Supreme Court ruling striking the involvement of the Comptroller General in the Deficit Reduction Act, the law remains the principal statute regulating the outcome of the Federal budget process. The fate of Gramm-Rudman-Hollings, the achievement of fiscal responsibility and the future of a recovery that has brought jobs, hope and opportunity to our people are for better or worse inextricably linked.

title: The Stinger Is No Stinger

He was talking about Stinger antiaircraft weapons and was reiterating a plea often heard these days from the various rebel groups implementing the Reagan Doctrine around the world.

title: REAGAN IS TERMED READY TO DISCUSS ABM PACT CHANGE
description: President Reagan is willing to negotiate on disputed issues in the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty as a way of bridging differences with the Soviet Union over space-based missile defenses, Administration officials said today.

description: The International Trade Commission released figures today, at the opening in Geneva of negotiations on a new textiles trade accord, showing that American imports of cloth and clothing from 33 countries more than doubled between 1976 and 1985, to 8.4 billion square yards from 4 billion.

description: In a move to put pressure on the nation's biggest supermarket chain, Herbert H. Haft, chairman of the Dart Group Corporation, told directors of Safeway Stores yesterday that he was prepared to raise his offer to $3.9 billion in cash.

title: China-India Talks Reopen
description: The seventh round of border talks between China and India opened here today. The two sides are trying to settle disputes over an area of 34,700 square miles in Arunchal Pradesh, in the eastern part of the frontier, and an area of 14,500 square miles in the Aksai Chin area in the western sector.

title: Arco Seeks Buyer For 3 Small Units
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said that it was seeking a buyer for three small agricultural units that were earmarked for divestiture in a restructuring announced last year.

title: Roy Cohn Admitted To Research Hospital
description: Roy M. Cohn, the former New York lawyer who was disbarred by a state appeals court last month, has been admitted to a Maryland hospital that specializes in medical research. Mr. Cohn, who is 59 years old, has said he has liver cancer.

title: Help for Willie Smith
description: Willie Smith, a former University of Miami football star arrested June 30 in Miami on cocaine-possession and weapons charges, can avoid prosecution if he successfully completes a counseling program.

title: Reindictment Sought
description: A deputy United States attorney said today that he would press for a reindictment of a former Continental Illinois Corportion executive on bank and wire fraud charges. Last week a Federal judge dismissed the charges because too much time had elapsed since the indictment of the executive and two other men. The prosecutor, James Ferguson, said the charges would be brought against John Lytle, former vice president of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, who oversaw the bank's purchase of $1 billion in mostly bad energy loans from Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

title: Travel-Agency Cut by A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has one of the nation's largest business travel accounts, has decided to reduce the number of travel agencies it uses to three, from 273 companies.

title: Helen Craig, 74, Dies; Created 'Belinda' Role
description: Helen Craig, an actress who made many film, television and radio appearances and created the role of the deaf-mute in the original Broadway production of ''Johnny Belinda'' in 1940, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Cabrini Medical Center. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.
