description: A Bronx man suspected of using a stolen cab to pick up passengers in Manhattan and rob them at gunpoint was arrested early yesterday after police officers saw him driving the taxi on the Upper East Side.

description: Greg Norman, who won the British Open Sunday for his first major tournament victory, and Jack Nicklaus, with a record 20 major championships, have had a close personal relationship since they met playing in the 1974 Australian Open.

title: PANHANDLE WRITES OFF $460 MILLION
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today that it would take an after-tax charge of $460 million against its second-quarter results after agreeing to settle a dispute with Sonatrach, Algeria's state-owned oil and gas company, over Panhandle's refusal to accept liquid natural gas shipments since December 1983.

description: The State Department said today that it would start using a new device at some embassies overseas to detect explosives.

Memorial Placed on Titanic
description: Scientists left a memorial plaque on the stern of the Titanic today, dedicated to the 1,513 passengers who died April 15, 1912, when the luxury liner sank after striking an iceberg. The researchers, who descended to the ocean floor for their first close look at the severed stern section, had planned to use the robot scout Jason Jr. to explore the wreckage, but decided against it because of the stern's questionable condition.

title: A Big Push for Pentagon Reform
description: ''The defense acquisition system has basic problems that must be corrected.'' So concludes the President's Commission on Defense Management headed by David Packard, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense. Its verdict is no great surprise. But its authoritative voice should propel Congress to alter the way the Pentagon buys weapons and structures its military command.

title: JUST AS THINGS SEEMED TO BE LOOKING UP . . .
description: The United States Postal Service confounded some skeptics the other day when it announced that profits were up and the price for mailing cards, letters and packages was unlikely to rise for at least 18 months.

description: Mexico plans to sign an agreement Tuesday with the International Monetary Fund that could lead to $12 billion in new loans, Mexican Government and international lending authorities said today.

title: AGUILERA FANS NINE TO END MET SLUMP
description: The subject was still unapproachable. The Mets had requested that postgame questions pertain only to baseball, but it only seemed logical to wonder: Did Rick Aguilera pitch tonight with the past on his mind?

title: LeMOND BUILDS OVERALL LEAD
description: Shepherded by Bernard Hinault, his longtime mentor and rival, Greg LeMond solidified his hold today on the overall lead in the Tour de France.

title: ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talking Business with Gallagher of Fisher, Gallagher; Liability Curb On Insurance
description: Soaring prices for many types of insurance coverage, and an absence of coverage in some areas, have prompted both state and Federal legislators to try to fashion new laws governing liability insurance claims. Many insurers have welcomed such efforts. But one group that is less happy with this approach is trial lawyers, many of whom earn a generous living through liability claims.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manville Net Up 23%
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 23 percent, to $25.2 million, or 79 cents a share, from $20.4 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. Manville's sales rose slightly to $490.5 million, from $488.7 million a year ago. ''The improved results stemmed primarily from increased sales volume pretty much across all of our product lines, reduced energy costs and lower litigation and workers' compensation costs,'' David A. Samson, a company spokesman, said.

title: Law Firms to Merge
description: The Miami law firm of Paul & Burt said yesterday that it would merge Aug. 1 with Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, the largest law firm in the United States, with 600 lawyers in eight offices. Dan Paul, a leading First Amendment lawyer whose clients include The New York Times Company and its newspapers in Florida as well as other media companies, will create a new media division for the merged firm, a spokesman said. Franklin G. Burt will continue to specialize in corporate law in the Miami office of the firm.

title: CHINA OFFERS CORRESPONDENT NO SIGN OF QUICK RELEASE
description: The Peking bureau chief of The New York Times spent a sixth day in Government custody today with no sign of a change in his situation.

title: Corrales Suspended
description: Pat Corrales of the Cleveland Indians and an Oakland A's pitcher, Dave Stewart, were suspended for four games by the American League President, Bobby Brown, yesterday for their part in a bench-clearing brawl at Oakland on July 1.

title: Tennessee Official Heard In Suit Over Textbooks
description: Giving some pupils alternative textbooks to ones that violate their religious beliefs would open a ''floodgate'' of demands for different books in every subject, Tennessee's Education Commissioner testified today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was a week when fashion mingled with music and dance. A dinner for Rudolf Nureyev and the stars of the Paris Opera Ballet at Scarlatti attracted Cornelia Guest in a beaded white denim dress by Fabrice, Doris Duke in abstract-print palazzo pants and Judy Peabody in big shoulders by Jacqueline de Ribes. The hosts were Jean Louis and his wife, Maggy Louis, who live in Paris and Santa Barbara, Calif. He dressed the Duchess of Windsor before becoming head designer at Columbia Pictures in the 1940's, where he put Rita Hayworth in strapless black satin for her film ''Gilda.'' During his Hollywood career, his Oscar nominations included those for ''Born Yesterday'' and ''From Here to Eternity.''

title: New Salomon Product Tied to Exchange Rates
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. has introduced a new short-term investment product called a ''Mini-Max,'' which is linked to foreign exchange rates. The new instrument is being offered to investors seeking to benefit from foreign currency fluctuations with a minimum amount of risk.

description: Trading in the credit markets was virtually paralyzed for much of yesterday as participants awaited today's report on the second-quarter gross national product and Congressional testimony on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker.

title: Eye Service for the Elderly
description: Since Jan. 9, a telephone hot line has been spreading slowly, region by region, across the country. The hot line, (800) 222-E-Y-E-S, is for people older than 65 who have eye problems and cannot pay for medical services.

title: I.O.C. Pressured
description: North Korean officials are pressuring the International Olympic Committee for permission to be host to more than two events for the 1988 Summer Games.

description: Hundreds of aftershocks rattled the High Sierra today, one day after a severe earthquake shook the region, and scientists said more big quakes were possible soon in the same area.

title: DANIEL S.C. LIU
description: Daniel S.C. Liu, the first Chinese-American police chief of an American city, died Friday.

title: Gunfire Off Morocco Coast
description: Guerrillas fired machine guns and mortars at a Soviet fishing ship and a Spanish trawler off Morocco, killing one Spaniard and wounding another, a radio report said today. Crew members aboard the Soviet ship returned fire with machine guns, wounding three of the attackers, who were in a small motor-powered boat, the network said. No group has taken responsibility for the attacks, but Polisario Front guerrillas are suspected.

description: France formally apologized today to New Zealand for the Rainbow Warrior incident and transferred $7 million in compensation ordered by the United Nations, Prime Minister David Lange said.

description: President Reagan urged the South African Government today to move toward ''political peace.'' But he reaffirmed his opposition to stringent economic sanctions, saying that to impose them would be a ''historic act of folly.''

title: Son of Sam and Literary Spies
description: Americans are properly incensed when criminals cash in on their notoriety with books and films. New York moved swiftly a decade ago to strip book profits from David Berkowitz, the multiple murderer who called himself ''Son of Sam.'' Two years ago Congress decreed a similar sanction against persons convicted of violent Federal crimes, and it now seeks the same ban for convicted spies. But the Senate's bill carries outrage too far and threatens even legitimate journalism.

title: CREATIVE COMPUTER APPLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $71,000 and $192,100 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $42,400 for the quarter and $53,400 for the 9 months.

title: F.B.I. Charges 170 In Car Insurance Fraud
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has charged 170 people with filing false automobile insurance claims totaling more than $1 million in 12 states and Canada.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT SLOW 1.1% RATE IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The economy grew at an annual rate of only 1.1 percent in the second quarter, the weakest performance since late 1982, when the current expansion began, the Commerce Department said today.

title: U.S. APOLOGIZES TO AIDS RESEARCHER
description: The Reagan Administration has apologized to a Harvard researcher who says the Justice Department misrepresented his views on the transmission of AIDS.

title: L.I. Radio Stations Sold
description: The Radio Company Inc. and the San Diego-based Noble Broadcast Group have agreed to buy the Long Island radio stations WBAB (FM) in Babylon and WGBB (AM) in Freeport for about $13 million.

title: Reuben Thorson, Once Chief Of Paine, Webber Committee
description: Reuben Thorson, a retired chairman of the policy committee of the stock brokerage house of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, died Sunday in Chicago. He was 84 years old and lived in Chicago and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOURNALISM IN MEXICO CAN TURN INTO A RISKY CRAFT
description: One evening in March, Jose Angel Leal Rivera, the assistant editor of the Matamoros daily El Popular, returned home with his wife and a daughter to find three men waiting outside his house. The men pulled Mr. Leal Rivera from his car, beat him and then fled.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What New South Africa Policy?
description: President Reagan's monthlong ''reassessment'' of his attitude toward South Africa ended yesterday without an iota of change or regret.

title: RENT PLAN HEATS MONTCLAIR SUMMER
description: The pace is quick these languid summer days in the township clerk's office as the vacation-bound have been streaming in for absentee ballot applications to preserve their votes in next Tuesday's special referendum.

title: FILM: 'LOVE SONGS,' WITH DENEUVE AND LAMBERT
description: IN the long list of Catherine Deneuve's films, works of high art live beside treacly star turns.

title: 5,000 Barrels of Radon Dirt Forced to Stay in Montclair
description: Five thousand drums of soil contaminated with radon must remain stacked on the lawns of homes in Montclair until the State Supreme Court decides whether they can be transferred to a quarry in Sussex County, a justice of the court ruled today.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Buys Lobbying Stake
description: America's advertising agencies certainly seem determined to affect our lives one way or another.

title: POUGHKEEPSIE SAVINGS BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago periods' per share earnings are not available due to stock conversion on Nov. 20, 1985.

title: Thomson Expands Executive's Duties
description: Ten years ago, International Thomson Organization Ltd. acquired a Los Angeles publishing company, Bowmar/Noble, and with it International Thomson acquired Robert J. Jachino.

title: POP: JORGE BEN OF BRAZIL
description: JORGE BEN made his long-delayed American debut Monday at Sounds of Brazil (204 Varick Street, at Houston Street), with a 90-minute set that turned rock and funk and samba rhythms in kinetic new directions.

title: BELO, A H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Explosions Are Heard In the Afghan Capital
description: Western diplomats here said today that explosions, machine-gun battles and rocket attacks occurred last week in the Afghan capital of Kabul, including an area where the Soviet Embassy is situated.

title: Gettysburg Redux
description: Who says that the House of Representatives cannot be won over by an evocative historical reference?

title: FOOD NOTES
description: OVERHEARD at the International Fancy Food and Confection Show, which ends its four-day run today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center: ''Sprinkle it on top, and out comes a gourmet delight.'' Leonard Brauner, an exhibitor, was referring to grated cheese, but there were dozens of spice blends (with and without salt), seasoned oils, nut toppings and chocolates to which the comment could apply. Herewith, some notes from the show: Almost Infinite Flavors Multiple flavors are the order of the day, from 14 flavors of fettuccine in the Gaston Dupre line to the 6 California Vineyard mustards by Classic American Foods, which now include a spicy Creole mustard bearing the Brennan's label (at Bloomingdale's, $5.49 a jar). Coffee Bean International of Portland, Ore., offers 178 flavors, including 37 decaffeinated. The company, which has begun distribution in New York, has certified organic coffee from Guatemala, so you only have to worry about caffeine, not pesticides. It makes a delicious cup of coffee, but this variety, alas, is not yet available here. Olive Oils

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH WALTZES -Following in the alliterative footsteps of the Mostly Mozart presentations, tonight's Damrosch Park concert by the Goldman Memorial Band is billed as ''Often Offenbach.'' Jacques Offenbach was born in Germany in 1819; as a child he went to Paris, which became his home. In his lifetime he composed nearly 90 operettas, many of them satirizing the manners of the day and the pretensions of grand opera. Offenbach's light and satirical musical style was called opera bouffe.

title: Drug Raid Nets 10 At Brooklyn Hotel
description: Brooklyn narcotics detectives arrested 10 people yesterday afternoon in a raid at the Brooklyn Arms Hotel for the homeless in the borough's Fort Greene section, the police reported. The welfare hotel, once known as the Granada, drew widespread notice earlier this month when four small children died in an apartment fire there.

title: U.S. and Soviet Discuss 1979 Treaty in Geneva
description: American and Soviet arms negotiators opened talks here today on President Reagan's decision not to adhere to the unratified strategic arms agreement of 1979.

title: Hanson to Sell Assets of Unit
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., a London-based conglomerate, said yesterday that it would sell the hotels and restaurants of Imperial Group P.L.C., a subsidiary, to Trusthouse Forte P.L.C. for about $285 million in cash.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY
description: MUCH television music programming falls into one of two categories -slick, surreal videos aimed at establishing a visual identity for a popular song, a la MTV; or celebrations of famous artists as virtual embodiments of high culture in our time, on programs like ''Pavarotti Live in Las Vegas.'' Serious, substantial symphonic concerts are decidedly uncommon; when they make it to the air, they usually combine a charismatic, photogenic leader with well-known repertory. ''Bernstein's Brahms,'' perhaps, but never ''Bernstein's Berio.''

title: DR. CHARLES GREENBERG
description: Dr. Charles Greenberg, a psychiatrist who from 1952 to 1972 was director of the Rome (N.Y.) Developmental Center, a state institution for the retarded, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Nyack, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said there are no comparable year-ago results because the company was not in operation prior to its initial public offering in May 1985.

title: RABBI DAVID EICHHORN
description: Rabbi David Max Eichhorn, the former director of field activities for the National Jewish Welfare Board in New York City, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at Holmes Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Satellite Beach, Fla.

title: Sims to Retire
description: Billy Sims, the 1978 Heisman Trophy winner from Oklahoma and the most successful running back in the history of the Detroit Lions, is expected to announce his retirement today. Sims, who is 30 years old and was the National Football League's rookie of the year in 1980, suffered ligament damage to his right knee on Oct. 21, 1984, in a game against Minnesota.

title: The U.N. Today: July 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: What's Reasonable About the Goetz Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress; From Farm Foes To Farm Friends
description: At times in the tumultuous debate over America's farm policy last year, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader from Kansas, and Senator John Melcher, a Democrat from Montana, engaged in a verbal battle so caustic and so personal that many people who witnessed it wondered how long it would be before the two lawmakers would stand together again in the same room.

title: Sears Net Rises 7.3%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 7.3 percent in the second quarter, helped by a $27.8 million gain from an accounting adjustment for pension expenses. Without the gain, earnings would have fallen 3.2 percent.

title: Pay Dirt, as It Were
description: The report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography has been hailed as a marvel of single-mindedness - a sterling example of what happens when like minds put their heads together. The only possible exception right-thinking citizens could take to such a noble crusade might be a budgetary one. In this age of fiscal restraint - especially for domestic spending - might not a half-million dollar outlay for 1,960 pages appear a bit prodigal?

title: BOYCOTTED CHICAGO STATION HIRING A BLACK ANCHOR
description: The CBS television station in Chicago, which has been under pressure from a minority-group organization to hire minority anchors, reporters and managers, plans to hire Lester Holt, a New York newscaster, as a daily anchorman.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results restated due to restructuring of a division. The share earnings restated for May 1986 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Mets' Hearing Is Tomorrow
description: A hearing was scheduled for tomorrow morning in Houston regarding the assault charges brought against Ron Darling and Tim Teufel of the Mets, but their lawyer said last night that he hoped the judge would reschedule the hearing for the afternoon.

title: Chile Releases 17 Soldiers Held in Burning Incident
description: A judge investigating the case of two teen-agers burned in anti-Government protests has released 17 of 25 soldiers who were detained during the inquiry.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net loss c-Includes pre-tax charges of $9 million for the quarter and $39 milion for the 6 months to cover severance costs.

title: CITY HOSPITAL STAFF SHORTAGE ASSAILED
description: A chronic lack of doctors and nurses and shortages of vital equipment are endangering patients at New York City's municipal hospitals, witnesses told a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: CHINA EXPELS TIMES REPORTER FOR ENTERING RESTRICTED AREA
description: The Peking bureau chief of The New York Times was expelled from China today after being detained for nearly six days on suspicion of espionage.

title: Eyes on Arkansas
description: The opponents in the current Arkansas Senate race will make an unusual joint appearance on Capitol Hill today. Senator Dale Bumpers, the Democratic incumbent seeking a third term, will attend a hearing of the Energy Committee's Water and Power Subcommittee on a proposal he has sponsored to protect utility customers in his home state from rate increases.

title: 100 Arrested in Lab Protest
description: About 100 people opposed to the use of animals in medical experiments were arrested for investigation of trespassing after blocking the entrance to a laboratory at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, the police said today. Some 250 protesters blocked the entrance to the hospital's Halper Research Laboratory on Monday, chanting slogans againt vivisection. Those arrested were released on their own recognizance, the police said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the past decade or so, eating and cooking have both altered the nation's vocabulary. Americans speak with authority about such dishes as vitello tonnato, gazpacho, spaghetti carbonara, fettuccine and ratatouille, as though familiar with these words since birth, although of course it isn't true. We have become one of the most sophisticated nations on earth when it comes to the stove.

title: June Deficit Below May
description: The Federal budget posted a $1.01 billion deficit in June, sharply less than the May imbalance because of a large increase in month-to-month tax collections, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Travels With Shultz
description: Like many another humidity-logged Washingtonian, Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to get out of town in August. In his case, however, the schedule calls for travel to some even warmer jurisdictions for a number of meetings, both ceremonial and working and mainly unrelated, with officials from five countries.

title: Leasing Unit Adds To Boeing Order
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had increased its order to buy new aircraft from the Boeing Company to 46 planes, worth $1.7 billion, from the 32 it had agreed to buy in May 1985.

title: For Fireman's Fund, a Profit
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation said yesterday that net income for the second quarter was $55 million, or 83 cents a share, against a loss of $84 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Too often in the past, we Americans - acting out of anger and frustration and impatience - have turned our backs on flawed regimes, only to see disaster follow.''

title: WHITE HOUSE AID TO TEAMSTERS IN VOTE IS ALLEGED
description: The White House arranged a meeting between top officials of the Army and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which was seeking to oust another union from representing 2,500 civilian workers at Fort Sill, Okla., according to Army documents.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $90,800,000 for both the quarter and 6 months from the sale of depositary units of Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P., and $2.5 million from a quarterly distribution of Freeport- McMoran Gold Co. common shares to Freeport-McMoran Inc. shareholders for the quarter and $9.7 million for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: U.S. IS SAID TO HAVE GIVEN PRETORIA INTELLIGENCE ON REBEL ORGANIZATION
description: The United States, working closely with British intelligence, has provided South Africa with intelligence about the banned and exiled African National Congress, according to current and former Government officials.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICAIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 5
description: b-Net income

title: Oil and Grain Prices Down as Trading Shifts
description: Crude oil in the soon-to-expire August contract fell more than $2 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, ending a five-day rally. Prices for the September and October contracts posted losses of around 80 cents.

title: LITTON UNIT GUILTY PLEA ON DEFRAUDING OF U.S.
description: A military-contracting subsidiary of Litton Industries pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court to 321 counts of fraud for overbilling the Defense Department by $6.3 million.

title: GM HUGHES ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago figures are pro forma, reflecting the acquisition by General Motors Corp. of Hughes Aircraft Co., effective Dec. 31, 1985, and the formation of a new subsidiary that includes Hughes Aircraft and certain operations of GM's Delco Electronics unit.

title: PITTSTON COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McGIVERN APPEALS MURDER CONVICTION AGAIN
description: The state's highest court was asked yesterday to reopen the case of Gary McGivern, a convicted murderer and the focus of heated political debate involving Governor Cuomo and Republican leaders.

title: Issues by Counties In Two States
description: In a $200 million financing, the Santa Clara County Traffic Authority, Santa Clara, Calif., yesterday offered $200 million of limited tax bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: RESTAURANTS DROP NAMES, LITERALLY
description: IN the 1970's and early 1980's, restaurants emblazoned their names on awnings, windows and flags, thinking the bigger the letters and brighter the neon, the better for business. But dazzle is giving way to discretion. In the last two years, a growing number of restaurants have been keeping their names inside and under cover. Anonymity is in.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of American Express Co., elected Alan C. Langley, Ian R. Jardine and L. Alan Bawden executive vice presidents.

title: People
description: * Edward Harrigan, Barbara Hughley, Tina Raver, Paul Rubinstein and Roy Tuck have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Ogilvy & Mather Advertising, New York.

title: New Uses for Japan's Thrift
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Levin Is Married To a Cultural Official
description: Nina Levin, the international rep-sentative in Paris for Europe 1, a French radio station, was married last Thursday to Alain Jalladeau, director of the Festival de 3 Continents, a cultural program in Nantes, France. The ceremony was performed by Elvira Burrows of the City Clerk's office in Nantes.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ASHLAND INCOME HIGHER
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, reported yesterday that because of funds from the sale of assets and write-downs, its earnings rose 41.6 percent.

title: Error With an Emmy
description: This story has two winners and no winners. It has humiliation and human error. It is the stuff of soap operas. But this was real.

title: D'LITES OF AMERICA reports earnings for 12wks to April 1
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary credits of $206,000 for the quarter and $436,000 for the year.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PERES-HASSAN TALKS SEEN IN ISRAEL AS STEP TOWARD ACCEPTANCE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres's visit to King Hassan II of Morocco was seen by Israelis today as helping to establish acceptance of Israel's existence by its Arab neighbors. But there appeared to be no immediate hope that the trip will lead to a breakthrough in Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Morris at Giants Camp
description: Joe Morris, who failed to report with the other veterans Monday because of a contract dispute, showed up today at the Giants' training camp. Although the star running back did not say so, his holdout seemed to have ended.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Ravelle Brickman Public Relations has opened at 275 Seventh Avenue and is specializing in children's products, education and publishing.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The prior year net includes a dividend from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of $187,000. Per share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid May 15.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,738,000 for the quarter and $6,438,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Knight-Ridder Profit Up 4%
description: Knight-Ridder Inc., a publishing and broadcasting concern, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 4 percent from a year earlier on a 9.5 percent revenue gain.

title: SOUTH'S FARM LOSS PUT AT $1 BILLION
description: With each additional day of record-breaking temperatures and little or no rainfall, the cruelest summer in memory is taking a grim toll on the farms and the cities of the Southeast.

title: 3 U.S. AGENCIES URGE VETO OF ART-CLAIM BILL
description: The State Department, the Justice Department and the United States Information Agency have all urged Governor Cuomo to veto a bill intended to make it easier for museums to establish ownership of artworks in their possession.

title: ELECTRONIC SPECIALTY PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago 6-month period includes an after-tax gain of 10 cents a share on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: MAN ADMITS OVERRIDING HBO SIGNAL
description: A 25-year-old man employed part time by a Florida satellite relay service admitted to Federal authorities today that he overrode Home Box Office's satellite signal last April with his ''Captain Midnight'' message.

title: Fidelcor Acquires Merchants Bancorp
description: Fidelcor Inc., in a move to beef up its regional presence in eastern Pennsylvania, acquired Merchants Bancorp Inc. yesterday in a stock swap valued at about $380 million.

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $7.6 million for the quarter and $13.8 million for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $5.7 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: THEATRE: 'FANNY' AT THE GOODSPEED
description: In past seasons, the Goodspeed Opera House has specialized in reviving musicals of the 1920's and 30's, filling the elegant theater with the sounds of Porter, Gershwin and others of their era. With ''Fanny,'' the second in a three-show salute to David Merrick, the Goodspeed takes a time trip to the 1950's, when Broadway shows could be both deeply sentimental and lavishly produced. The revival, directed by Thomas Gruenewald, eliminates the lavishness -without loss - while remaining committed to the sentiment, a feeling that is amply conveyed in both the book and Harold Rome's score.

title: G.N.P. REVISION CITED
description: Wall Street yesterday enjoyed its best gain in more than a month as the slumping Dow Jones industrials recovered a modest 16 points after a report that the nation's economy in the first quarter was not as weak as previously thought.

title: PRESIDENT'S SPEECH: REBUFF TO CONGRESS
description: After a monthlong review of his Administration's South African policy, President Reagan made it clear today that he would rather rebuff Congress than crack down on the Pretoria Government.

title: PRUDENTIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Software Adds 2 Lines
description: In a major shift in strategy, the Software Publishing Corporation today introduced two product lines and a program intended to attract large corporate customers.

title: Levi Strauss In License Shift
description: Levi Strauss & Company said that it had agreed to transfer its Perry Ellis America license for men's and women's sportswear to Manhattan Industries, effective with the spring line. The move is the latest in a series of retreats for the company from non-Levi branded products.

title: Severance Pay Of Ex-Aides Held
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin is holding up the severance pay of two former Koch Administration officials who have been indicted on charges of corrupt activities in office.

title: TRANSIT OFFICER KILLS 81-YEAR-OLD
description: A transit police officer yesterday shot and killed an 81-year-old Brooklyn man who fired at the officer and his partner outside the man's apartment building, the transit police said.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest third quarter results include a pre-tax non-recurring $27.7 million addition to Paine Webber's litigation reserve.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF TALK BY REAGAN ON SOUTH AFRICA AND APARTHEID
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech in Washington yesterday on South Africa, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for 1985 have been restated for the reclassification of freight expenses. The company said results for 1986 reflect the acquisition of American Hospital Supply Corp. in late 1985. The company said the 1986 share earnings for both periods are after preferred dividend requirements of $15 million and $31 million, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: CZECH FANS ROAR FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: The tennis was routine, a typically virtuoso peformance by an international champion that led to an easy first-round victory on a small side court at the Federation Cup matches here. But for Martina Navratilova, playing in her homeland for the first time since she defected to the West in 1975, the match was as special as it was for the thousands of Czechoslovak fans who came to cheer her.

title: ARRAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A CALIFORNIA RANCH'S CASH CROP: SNAILS
description: TWO California ranchers, Tracy Brash and Michael Beyries, like to talk about their 1.25-acre spread and their herd of nearly a million head - not longhorns, but a breed called Helix aspersa, also known as the petit-gris escargot. In other words, snails.

title: The Value of a B.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: S&F Communications To Open Aug. 1
description: Sheldon Hechtman, 48, and Frederick Schwartzfarb, 40, a pair of widely experienced admen, will open S & F Communications at 363 Seventh Avenue on Aug. 1.

title: NEAT AND CHIC
description: 1. Tie Tender -This tie rack will be a happy sight in the boat lover's closet. It looks like a rowing scull, with a crew of oarsmen in red-and-white shirts. The ties are hung on the oars. The scull is made of painted wood and costs $10.95 at Paret & Champagne, 370 Third Avenue, between 26th and 27th Streets. 2.Bibs for Babes If your youngster is typically sloppy at mealtime, he or she can put up a good front with this smart-looking bib. It is gray, with a white pin stripe, and is trimmed with a white collar and cuffs and a red bow tie. It also has two hands, one to hold a fork and the other, a spoon - both sized for children. The bib is a washable mix of cotton and polyester and costs $20 at Tyke-oons, 858 Lexington Avenue, between 64th and 65th Streets. 3.Walking on Water You can walk on water - no kidding - with these inflatable shoes. They are useful when you're cleaning a boat or if you just want to enjoy yourself. The shoes inflate to a length of 56 inches and will support up to 190 pounds. They come with a pair of aluminum balancing poles for propulsion. The set costs $99.50 at Hammacher Schlemmer, 147 East 57th Street. 4.Dressed to Grill For the barbecue chef who has everything - except the latest and most fashionable of haute accessories -Hermes has designed an ensemble for the grill.

title: WANG HAS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: Highlighting the diverse fortunes in the computer industry, four manufacturers of computer systems reported profit results today. Wang Laboratories Inc. edged back toward health and Tandem Computers Inc. was strong as expected. The Amdahl Corporation's earnings fell substantially and Prime Computer Inc. held up fairly well in comparison to an excellent quarter last year.

title: Peace Cruise, Peace Trek
description: Efforts to promote cooperation and understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union have spread into some fairly unlikely enterprises.

title: Charge Cuts Paine's Profits
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday reported generally strong earnings in the quarter that ended June 30. But, because of a one-time charge of $27.7 million, earnings fell 42.9 percent, to $7.14 million, or 25 cents a share, from $12.5 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Yields 6.90-7.75% On Texas Offering
description: A $112 million financing by the Dallas County Utilities Redevelopment Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: CONSTELLATION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS Stake Raised
description: The New York-based Loews Corporation said that it had raised its stake in CBS Inc. from 19.7 percent, to 20.98 percent. Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of Loews and a member of the CBS board, has said previously that Loews might eventually raise its stake in CBS to 25 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it bought 312,600 CBS common shares from June 16 through July 21 for prices ranging from $133.50 to $138.50 a share.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SYRIA BREAKS MOROCCAN TIES
description: King Hassan II of Morocco and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel were reported to have held several hours of talks today at the King's summer palace in Ifrane, but officially, Morocco has still not acknowledged the Israeli leader's presence.

title: FORMER AIDES TO GURU IN OREGON PLEAD GUILTY TO NUMEROUS CRIMES
description: Three former top leaders of an Oregon commune were sentenced to Federal prison terms today on a variety of state and Federal criminal charges ranging from immigration fraud to attempted murder.

title: Flutie Catching On
description: Doug Flutie, who won the 1984 Heisman Trophy and then a rich contract with the Generals for his ability to run and throw, is practicing catching the football. Jim Kelly, twice the United States Football League's leader in passing and total offense, is now a teammate of Flutie, who had only a mediocre season as a rookie and has been catching passes during informal workouts this week in Houston.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from operations of the Foxmoor division of $9,646,036 and a gain of $646,366 on the disposal of the Foxmoor division.

title: TUTU DENOUNCES REAGAN
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu bitterly attacked President Reagan's speech on South Africa today, saying the President ''sits there like the great, big white chief of old.''

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sun Plans Spinoff
description: The Sun Company said it plans to sell its interests in three common-carrier trucking companies as part of its strategy to concentrate on its energy operations. The company said it plans to form a new subsidiary to own and operate the carriers.

title: Expensive View Of the Cowboys
description: A certain luxury box for the Dallas Cowboys' games at Texas Stadium in Irving, Tex., has a few features that can make watching a highly pleasurable experience. Overlooking the 45-yard line, it accommodates a dozen people who can watch the field or one of two color television sets while enjoying air-conditioned temperatures and perhaps making use of the well-stocked bar's beverages and snacks.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRETORIA ANNOUNCES CAPTURE OF ARMS AND REBELS
description: The South African authorities announced the capture today of ''a large number'' of anti-Government guerrillas said to have been responsible for a series of bomb attacks around the Indian Ocean port city of Durban.

title: GENERAL MOTORS ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINE TALK
description: AMERICANS are unquestionably white wine fans. There is a theory that, in reality, they are cold drink fans and simply lean toward white wine, first, because traditionally it is chilled, and only second because it is perceived as lower in calories and less alcoholic.

title: School Appointee Approved
description: The State Board of Regents today gave final approval to the appointment of Irving Hamer, the headmaster of a Baltimore school, to the new position of deputy state commissioner of education for improving the New York City school system. In the $80,000-a-year post, Mr. Hamer, 39 years old, will be responsible for coordinating state and Federal resources for improving the city's public and private schools. The appointment takes effect Aug. 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 23, 1986
description: International

title: ANDUJAR DEFEATS RED SOX, 4-2
description: Joaquin Andujar pitched a six-hitter and Dave Kingman hit a two-run single off Tom Seaver in a three-run first inning today, lifting the Oakland A's to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: OFF THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE AND INTO HISTORY
description: It may mark an act that served little more than to lend credence to the cliche ''a flight of the imagination,'' but today is the 100th anniversary of the day that Steve Brodie supposedly jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge, and lived.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-The company began operations in September 1985 and did not report figures for the year-ago periods.

description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,056,136 for the quarter and $1,920,000 for the 6 months.

title: THE FEDERALIST SOCIETY: The cover of a pamphlet published by the Federalist Society; Judge Scalia's Cheerleaders
description: Probably no organization in Washington is happier with the nomination of Antonin Scalia as a Justice of the Supreme Court than the Federalist Society, a group of conservative lawyers and law students.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I REMEMBER with great clarity the afternoon my mother, an exceedingly gentle soul, hurled the current best seller across the living room with such force that it bounced off the wall opposite. ''It's a dirty book,'' she said, nostrils flaring, as she saw my face, and she stomped off into the kitchen. It was some measure of how rattled she was that she left the book itself, its yellow jacket a bright blot on the carpet, in the same room with a teen-ager whose paperback copy of ''The Group'' fell open automatically to Dottie's deflowering.

title: PAWLING SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Matter of No Fact
description: One of the mysteries is why President Reagan is soft on South Africa. Here is a Government apparently operating under the fatal delusion that Nazi Germany did things right. It now has more people imprisoned without due process of law than the United States Immigration Service and exercises a press censorship that makes the Soviet Union's seem sissified by comparison.

title: WINDUP NEAR IN U.S.F.L. SUIT
description: A jury of five women and one man, who have listened to testimony since May 15 in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League, will hear final arguments today from the opposing attorneys, Frank Rothman for the N.F.L. and Harvey Myerson for the U.S.F.L.

title: MINERALS APLENTY IN POUND OF LOBSTER
description: ALTHOUGH lobster has high levels of sodium and cholesterol, for people who don't have to watch either, lobster has its good nutritional points, aside from its unquestionably delightful flavor. Great benefits derive from the large quantities of valuable minerals - like potassium and phosphorus -in lobster. The succulent flesh also contains traces of selenium and zinc.

description: The 1985 results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of General Bancshares Corp. in March 1986 on a pooling-of-interests basis.

U.S. Accuses Boeing Over Executives' Pay
description: The Justice Department sued the Boeing Company and five of its former executives today, saying the plane manufacturer in effect supplemented the Government pay of the five by giving them $485,000 in severance when they left to take key jobs in the Defense Department.

title: His Trip Canceled, U.N. Chief Begins 'Routine' Heart Tests
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who canceled a trip to Africa this week, is undergoing a series of ''routine tests to evaluate his cardiac status'' and will spend a few days in a hospital, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: IN BRIGHTON BEACH, ANOTHER TIME OF CHANGE
description: A neighborhood can have many lives, wear many faces. On Brooklyn's southern shore along a narrow peninsula with oceanfront streets, Brighton Beach is ready for yet another metamorphosis, perhaps another great change.

title: ERVING CONSIDERS JAZZ OFFER
description: Will Julius Erving finish his career with the Utah Jazz? Will Harold Katz, the Philadelphia 76ers' owner, allow Erving, a 36-year-old free agent, to leave?

title: Winery to Tracy-Locke
description: Tracy-Locke, the Dallas-based BBDO International subsidiary, has picked up a local winery account.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: TEN years ago, when my husband wanted to give me a microwave oven for our anniversary, I asked if he was trying to get rid of me. Last Christmas, however, I bought one myself.

title: Reds Reflecting Rose's Hustle
description: It is unthinkable to imagine another team reflecting the spirit of its manager more than the Cincinnati Reds. They hustle.

title: PIEDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Delay of Game
description: The Giants' rookies and free agents have been in training camp in Pleasantville, N.Y., for a week, and their first four draft choices are still unsigned and absent. Coach Bill Parcells says he feels sorry for them.

title: Preparing It for the Grill
description: BARBECUED lobster can be a delicious twist on the standard steamed or boiled version this time of year.

title: LONG TERM SECURITIES SHOW SHARP PRICE DROP
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after economic growth figures gave the credit markets conflicting signals about the direction of the economy.

title: CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Princeton Settles Suit On Sex Discrimination
description: Princeton University has reached an agreement with a 1980 graduate who sued the university and three all-male student eating clubs on sex-discrimination charges, university officials announced yesterday.

title: MINE KILLS 28 ON SRI LANKA BUS
description: Tamil rebels set off a powerful mine under a bus today, killing 28 people, as the Government and less militant Tamil leaders pursued talks to resolve the island's ethnic conflict.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talk-Show Host and Victim
description: When he was on his way to work at the unconventional hour of 4:45 A.M., Alan B. Colmes was robbed at knifepoint.

title: SYRIA BREAKS TIES WITH MOROCCANS
description: Syria broke diplomatic relations with Morocco today, and other Arab hard-liners denounced the meeting of King Hassan II with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel as a betrayal of their cause.

title: President Resigns Post At MONY Financial
description: Henry S. Romaine has resigned as president and trustee of MONY Financial Services. He is expected to join the American General Corporation in Houston as vice chairman of the board and chief investment officer, according to a source familiar with the appointment.

title: U.S. CLAIMS SUCCESS IN BOLIVIA
description: American military and drug-enforcement officials said today that they believed they had stopped cocaine production in Bolivia for at least six months.

title: Capitals Sign Defector
description: After a series of seven secret meetings in seven different countries over the last two years, the Washington Capitals have announced the defection of Michal Pivonka, a member of the Czechoslovak national hockey team.

title: MUSIC: CLEVELAND QUARTET
description: THIS summer's Mostly Mozart season has reportedly had its ups, but Monday evening's concert by the Cleveland Quartet was a down. This was a roughly played, routinely interpreted run-through of three great scores that deserved far better - as did the audience.

title: Profit Growth: Outlook Dims
description: IN each of the last three years, securities analysts began by making overly generous earnings estimates for companies they follow and then chopped these projections as the year progressed. Indications are that 1986 will repeat this pattern -perhaps even more speedily than in the past, because of some disappointing quarterly reports and a lackluster economy.

title: FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Electronics
description: U.S. Electronics Group Inc., a chain of consumer electronics stores based in Aurora, Colo., said that the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Oakland, Calif., had approved an agreement for the company to operate 50 Pacific Stereo stores on the West Coast, beginning in September. Pacific filed for Chapter 11 protection on May 13. U.S. Electronics Group would acquire Pacific in exchange for about 3.6 million shares of U.S. Electronics' stock and payment of $2.8 million, from 1 percent of the gross sales to be generated by the reorganized Pacific.

title: Think of Immigrants as Mostly Women

title: The Pressures Facing Volcker
description: WHEN Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, goes before Congress today to deliver the central bank's midyear review, he is likely to encounter a tougher grilling than usual on the Fed's forecasts and plans for correcting the economy's perceived weaknesses.

description: The year-ago per share figures were not available. The company went public in August 1985. The per share earnings reflect 50 percent stock dividend paid June 25.

title: JETS' McNEIL HEALTHY, LIGHTER AND FASTER
description: Before they even suit up for the start of training camp today, the Jets are in better shape than they were at the end of last season.

title: A.T.&.T. Chip Out
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced a microchip that will allow faster exchanges of information between different types of computers over phone lines. The chip, called Unite, which attaches to the microprocessor in the terminal as well as to the phone, will allow computers to send digital signals through phone lines. A.T.&T. will put the chip directly onto the commercial market, rather than offering it only on its own personal computers, to enhance its profit value. Paul Johnson, an analyst for L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, estimated that the market for the chip would be ''a couple of hundred million dollars.''

description: A judge on the Federal appeals court in Chicago has described Daniel A. Manion, a nominee for that court, as unfit, Senator Paul Simon said tonight.

description: Per share earnings were not provided since no shares were outstanding prior to June 27, 1986.

IMPEACHMENT OF U.S. JUDGE PASSES HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives impeached a Federal official for the first time in 50 years today, charging a judge from Nevada with tax evasion and bringing ''disrepute'' on the Federal judiciary.

title: BANKERS WARMING TO MEXICO
description: For the first time in months, international bankers around the country seemed receptive yesterday to issuing $6 billion to $7 billion in new loans to Mexico, more than twice the amount contemplated before the price of its oil collapsed.

title: Suspect Is Slain; Vest Saves Officer
description: An armed-robbery suspect was fatally shot and a police officer was hurt in a brief gun battle last night on the West Side, the police said.

title: OFFICIALS OF NORTHEAST STATES WARNED OF FEDERAL AID LOSS
description: Officials from 10 Northeastern states were told today that cuts in Federal aid under the budget-balancing law would be deeper and more difficult to absorb than previously estimated.

title: Maximum Yield 7.67% On Triborough Bonds
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, a subsidiary of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is offering $450 million of general purpose revenue bonds through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: FOUR EJECTED AFTER BRAWL
description: The Mets did not back down in the ninth inning tonight, nor in the 10th or the 14th. They brawled when they were challenged, and they finally beat the Cincinnati Reds on Howard Johnson's three-run homer in the 14th, as the game reached its fifth hour.

title: Convent at Auschwitz Is Subject of Debate
description: A meeting between some of Europe's Roman Catholic and Jewish figures took place today to try to resolve a dispute over the establishment of a Carmelite convent near the Auschwitz death camp in Poland, where millions of Jews were killed by the Nazis. Some Jewish organizations say that the monastery is an insult to the memory of those who died there.

title: HOWSER'S TUMOR FOUND TO BE MALIGNANT
description: Dick Howser, the 50-year-old manager of the Kansas City Royals, underwent brain surgery today for removal of a tumor that was found to be malignant.

title: 8 Congressmen Back Green in Senate Race
description: Eight members of the New York Congressional delegation today endorsed Mark Green for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, saying that his ''record and philosophy are precisely the combination that can defeat'' Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the incumbent Republican, next November.

title: BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, which last week reported a $640 million loss for the quarter, said it is having problems in the planned sale of its Los Angeles office building. The company said it intends to continue its efforts to sell the building, which is also owned by the Atlantic Richfield Company, and expects to receive full value for the property. Separately, BankAmerica said that its management would recommend to the board that the company continue paying preferred stock dividends.

title: IN PRAISE OF THE LOBSTER: FROM POT TO PLATE
description: AT 9 o'clock on a July morning, the fog hangs thickly over the Fox Island Thoroughfare, a narrow body of water separating the islands of North Haven and Vinalhaven in Penobscot Bay in Maine. Peter MacDonald, a North Haven lobster fisherman, is pulling his first traps of the day. He is off to a late start because of heavy rain.

title: NATIONAL PENN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
6 TESTIFY IN BIAS DEATH CASE
description: Six students from the University of Maryland, five of them athletes, appeared today before a grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias, the basketball star who died of cocaine intoxication.

SWEEPING CHANGES FOR JAPAN CABINET
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone announced sweeping changes in his Cabinet and the ruling party hierarchy today after Japan's Parliament re-elected him Prime Minister, formally ratifying his party's landslide election victory earlier this month.

YANKS ROMP, 9-1, AS RASMUSSEN IS HURT
description: Dennis Rasmussen continued to confound opposing hitters and inspire his own last night, but he also gave the Yankees a brief fright when a line drive struck him on the back of the left arm just above his elbow.

title: SIMON IS SAID TO REFUSE TO TESTIFY IN AN INQUIRY
description: The Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon, has declined to testify in an inquiry into political corruption in the Bronx if he is required to waive his constitutional protection against self-incrimination, law enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Floating Point Stuns Wall St.
description: Floating Point Systems Inc., in an announcement that surprised Wall Street and sent its stock tumbling $12.375, to $21.125, said yesterday that its revenues and earnings for the quarter ending July 31 and for the fiscal year would be sharply below earlier projections.

title: SCREEN: 'MEANTIME,' FROM BRITAIN'S CHANNEL 4
description: CHANNEL 4, the British television network, has won a reputation in the last several years for such features as ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and ''Letter to Brezhnev.'' Today, Film Forum begins a weeklong series of seven movies that Channel 4 had a hand in producing and that have not been shown in theaters.

title: Real Estate; 2 Projects Add Glitter In SoHo
description: THE first shops to open in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan tended to be unpolished avant-garde boutiques carved out of the gritty ground floors in the industrial buildings that artists were converting into studios and living spaces.

title: Zale to Sell Unit
description: The Zale Corporation, as part of a major company restructuring announced last March, said it was in an ''advanced stage'' of negotiations to sell its British retail segment to Combined English Stores Group P.L.C. The subsidiary, Zale Jewellers Ltd., operates 111 stores and had sales of $40 million for the year ended March 31.

title: NEW YORK WINES: A QUALIFIED SUCCESS
description: IT is axiomatic in the New York State wine industry that to regain its national reputation for premium quality it must win acceptance in the highly competitive New York City market. In a risky move aimed at proving itself, the industry laid some of its best bottles before a tough 27-judge panel last Sunday - with qualified success, many judges said.

title: INSTANT STARDOM AT PIANO BARS
description: JESSICA GIBSON approached the piano in a hazy barroom the other night, straddled a stool and took the microphone in her right hand. In her left hand was a banana, which she waved as she introduced herself.

description: ''CHILDREN have gotten to be a hot item,'' said Elaine Morgenstein, who was talking about children as targets of consumer research. And she couldn't be more pleased, since that is what she does.

title: ARIZONA BANKING SHOWDOWN
description: In a scene drawn from the Wild West, a battle of New York, California and Arizona banking titans will unfold here beginning Oct. 1. Any bank in the country will then be able to own any local Arizona bank.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Science Watch column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly paraphrased remarks by Dr. Joshua Lederberg on the possibility of life on Mars. Dr. Lederberg, speaking at a conference in Washington, said Viking landings had not found any evidence of life on Mars, but he did not rule out the possibility that such evidence would be found.

title: TENTATIVE PACT IS REACHED IN PHILADELPHIA A DAY AFTER STRIKE ENDS
description: Philadelphia and the union representing blue-collar workers reached tentative agreement on a contract today, one day after the 12,000 workers ended their 20-day strike.

title: WHITNEY '85 BIENNIAL ON CHANNEL 13
description: IF there is an art extravaganza today that evokes the 19th-century French salons, it's the Whitney Biennial, the big painting-sculpture-video show that is mounted every two years by the Whitney Museum. As with the salons, the idea of the biennials is to show what's going on in current art, although there is one significant difference. Where the Paris salons were hotbeds of the arriere-garde, adamant in their insistence on the tried and the traditional, the Whitney Biennial is equally notorious for its rush to embrace the new - or at least the latest and loudest of what's hawked in the smart art districts of Manhattan.

title: A KING OF THE UNEXPECTED: HASSAN II
description: King Hassan II of Morocco, who has been meeting at his summer palace with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, has been a maverick among Arab leaders regarding Israel.

Mr. Weinberg is the third executive to join Hutton from Citicorp in the past week. Last week, it was reported that Mr. Weinberg was negotiating with Hutton, but that he was undecided.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STEVE WINWOOD RETURNS TO MAKE THE JUICES FLOW
description: Every few years, a little more frequently than sunspot cycles, the British keyboardist-singer Steve Winwood releases an album of buoyant pop songs and a single that promptly zips into the top 10. He has done that once again with his current single, ''Higher Love,'' and his new album, ''Back in the High Life'' (Island). He is also planning his first American tour in a decade, which will bring him to Jones Beach on Aug. 31 and to New York's Pier 84 on Sept. 12 and 13. ''I'm a slow worker,'' Mr. Winwood said with a shrug. ''I'm trying to step up production, but I think you've got to do it till it's good, and there's no point in just throwing a record out there. I guess I'm fortunate that I've developed my career so I can afford that luxury.'' Mr. Winwood, who is 38 years old, has been singing and writing hit singles since the mid-1960's, when he was the teen-age belter for the Spencer Davis Group. From 1967 to the mid-1970's, he was with the eclectic band Traffic, and during one of Traffic's breakups, he worked with the guitarist Eric Clapton in the group Blind Faith. After Traffic's dissolution, he started a leisurely solo career, releasing albums in 1977, 1980 and 1982. While making ''Back in the High Life,'' Mr. Winwood also had another studio booked, where he completed a soundtrack for a Granada Television documentary on the cyclist Robert Miller.

title: James Lamberton Dies at 61; A Lawyer and Rights Activist
description: James W. Lamberton, a New York lawyer who was an early civil rights activist, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 61 years old.

title: Mid-America Reports Loss
description: Banks of Mid-America Inc., the largest bank holding company in Oklahoma, said today that it lost $28.9 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a profit of $4.3 million a year ago.

title: MORRIS BRESSLER
description: Morris Bressler, a folk singer known as Moishe who specialized in Yiddish and Russian material, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in West Orange and Roosevelt, N.J.

title: KEAN'S SPEECH ON EDUCATION WELCOMED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey, a Republican, said today that he had accepted an invitation to speak at the National Urban Leauge convention here to ''inject into the national debate some of the ideas and things that are uniquely Republican.''

title: DANCE: 'ALICE' PREMIERE BY NATIONAL OF CANADA
description: JUST as the dance season was preparing to close, one of best new ballets tumbled into the Metropolitan Opera House last night - much like Alice in Wonderland falling down her rabbit hole.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE REPORTS PEOPLE EMPLOYED IN HOME ARE EXPLOITED
description: Clerical workers who work at home are often exploited by employers, according to a Congressional committee report released today. But the committee opposed taking steps to ban such work, as labor unions have urged.

title: BLACK DOCTORS URGED TO NOTE VIOLENT SIGNS
description: The chairman of the psychiatry section of the leading national association of black physicians, reacting to an increase in crimes against blacks, urged black doctors yesterday to screen their black patients routinely for violent or homicidal feelings.

title: FIRST OF MICHIGAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
France Expels South African Second Time on His Return
description: A South African military attache ordered out of France early this year had to be asked to leave a second time after he returned incognito, diplomatic sources said today.

title: REV. BENEDICT J. DUDLEY
description: The Rev. Benedict J. Dudley, a Franciscan friar who was the unofficial Roman Catholic chaplain of the New York Giants football team for more than 40 years, died Saturday at St. Anthony Hospital in Warwick, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MCDONALD'S GAINS
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter net income fell 52.9 percent because of a large one-time gain taken during last year's second quarter.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $2,190,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month net include a reserve of $78,000 for potential settlement of a lawsuit.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10.7 million for the quarter and $15.5 million for the 6 months. The year-earlier periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 23, 1986
description: The Economy The nation's growth slowed sharply in the second quarter to a lackluster 1.1 percent annual rate, the worst performance since late 1982, when the current expansion began, the Commerce Department said. The report was seen as perhaps the strongest evidence so far of the widespread and persistent weakness in the economy. The department also revised upward the first-quarter growth rate for the G.N.P., to 3.8 percent from 2.9 percent, still far short of the Administration's 4 percent target for the year. Administration spokesmen cited the report's bright spots, particularly strong consumer spending, but Democrats used the data to criticize the effect of Reagan policies on jobs, income and productivity. [ Page A1. ] The South's farming losses are estimated at $1 billion, and most of the region's corn crop has been burned by a severe drought. [ A1. ] The Senate Finance Committee approved about $3 billion in Medicare savings as Congress began action on spending cuts and revenue increases in the 1987 budget resolution. [ B8. ] International Bankers are receptive about providing Mexico with up to $7 billion in loans, twice the amount previously being considered. The new stance reflects bankers' growing confidence that Mexico's accord with the International Monetary Fund might work. Some say their only alternative is to risk losses on existing loans. [ D1. ] Mexican officials signed the pact in Washington. [ D14. ] Companies Safeway Stores, putting itself on the auction block, said it had held talks about a leveraged buyout with an unidentified party and rejected a $3.6 billion bid by the Dart Group as inadequate.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEXICO SIGNS $1.6 BILLION I.M.F. PACT
description: Mexico signed an agreement today with the International Monetary Fund under which the debt-ridden country pledged to enact a series of economic reforms in return for $1.6 billion in emergency assistance over the next 18 months.

title: 2 Groups Selling Maryland Issues
description: The Maryland Department of Transportation is selling $111.4 million of double-A rated bonds through two separate underwriting groups.

title: FOR ITS 300TH BIRTHDAY, ALBANY GOES COLONIAL
description: This city of Henry Hudson and Martin Van Buren and Legs Diamond and Nelson A. Rockefeller and William Kennedy turned 300 years old today, its church bells chiming and cannons firing in a celebration of history.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH IN RESPONSE TO REAGAN
description: Following are excerpts from the Democratic response yesterday to President Reagan's speech in Washington on South Africa, as delivered by Representative William H. Gray 3d and recorded by The New York Times:

title: Contra Aid in the House Wasn't 'Me-Tooism' but Bipartisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTOR STANDING TRIAL FOR DEATHS ON FILM SET
description: Just a few miles below the hillside ''Hollywood'' sign that characterizes this city around the world, a trial opened in a Los Angeles courtroom today that promises some of the splashy drama of a guns-and-action Hollywood film.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL - CHICAGO (AL) - Optioned Joel Davis, pitcher, to Buffalo of the American Association. Purchased the contract of Ivan Calderon, outfielder, from Buffalo.

title: SPECIALIZED SCHOOLS FOUND LESS VIOLENT
description: Specialized city high schools that screen students they accept according to academic talent reported markedly fewer incidents of violence over the last school year than other secondary schools, statistics released by the Board of Education show.

The latest 6 months net from discontinued operations is after an after-tax gain of $11,171,000, or 53 cents a share, from the sale of investment in Triton Group. title: CORRECTION
description: The Editorial Notebook yesterday about Manhattan's West Side misstated the number of apartments built between 1980 and 1984. The average was 3,121 for each year.

title: Baxter Travenol Gain
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories said yesterday that its second-quarter net increased 18.6 percent, to $51 million, or 17 cents a share, from $43 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales soared to $1.42 billion, from $512 million. The results reflected the purchase of the American Hospital Supply Corporation in late 1985.

title: Jury Awards $30 Million To Former Scientologist
description: A former member of the Church of Scientology was awarded $30 million today after a trial in which he charged that the church wrecked his business and drove him to a nervous breakdown when he grew disillusioned and resisted its teachings.

title: Democratizing High School Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: LESSON OF COOTER'S
description: Four Mets - Tim Teufel, Ron Darling, Rick Aguilera and Bob Ojeda - became shut-ins last week in Houston. The Met quartet was escorted by cops to a local cooler where they whiled away 11 hours for, in the case of Teufel and Darling, a charge of aggravated assault on a police officer and, with Aguilera and Ojeda, a charge of hindering arrest.

title: BALLARD MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Perfect Weddings
description: A long time ago, when she was 3 or 4 years old, a woman we know decided that hers was the more fortunate sex because it was the one that got to wear the bridal dress. The dress she had in mind - she must have seen it in a book of paper dolls - was long and white and had a train, and the sleeves ended in points. But for those sleeves, in fact, it wasn't all that different from what an American President's daughter wore for her wedding on Cape Cod last week or from what another young bride will probably wear in London today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The appeal by Larry Holmes to overturn his split-decision loss to Michael Spinks in their International Boxing Federation title rematch has been denied by the federation's grievance and appeals committee, according to Holmes's attorney. . . . Terry Metcalf, former running back with the St. Louis Cardinals and the Washington Redskins, has been indicted by an Arlington County grand jury in Virginia on charges of possession of cocaine and disorderly conduct, stemming from an incident last March 26 when he was stopped by the police for speeding. While searching his car, the police said they found one-half of a gram of cocaine.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $65,000.

Edward Townsend, Ex-Official Of First Boston Corporation
description: Edward Townsend, retired senior vice president and director of the First Boston Corporation, the investment-banking concern, died Saturday at his home in Lloyd Neck, L.I. He was 73 years old.
