title: Required Reading; When Diplomats Fail
description: Excerpt from an article, ''U.S. Multilateral Diplomacy at the United Nations,'' by Richard S. Williams, a Chicago lawyer who was formerly American representative at the United Nations offices in Vienna. It appears in the summer issue of The Washington Quarterly:

title: TYSON'S SCHEDULE IS MUDDLED
description: A decision on whether Mike Tyson will become part of the HBO heavyweight unification series is still on hold. In fact, the situation turned more complicated this week when a Tyson-Larry Holmes fight for this fall became a possibility.

title: FRANCE DISMISSES 12 TOP EXECUTIVES
description: In a sweeping managerial shake-up, France's new conservative Government today discharged the presidents and chief executives of 12 of the 25 large state-owned banks, insurance companies and industrial groups that it plans to sell, replacing them with its own choices.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $12,039,000 from settlement of a gas sales contract. c-Net income The latest 6 months' results reflect a substantial charge for inventory writedowns to market values, but does not include income tax benefits.

title: Rostenkowski License Loss
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, who pleaded guilty to drunken driving in Wisconsin last month, will lose his Illinois driver's license for one year. Officials of the Illinois Secretary of State's office said Tuesday that the notice of revocation, filed through a reciprocal agreement with Wisconsin, would be in effect from July 29, 1986, to July 29, 1987. Mr. Rostenkowski may receive a restricted license if he can prove driving is vital to his work.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Convicted Spy Agrees To Reveal Data He Sold
description: Ronald W. Pelton, who was convicted June 5 of spying for the Soviet Union, has agreed to tell intelligence officials about the National Security Agency secrets he sold to Soviet agents, his lawyer and a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: The Seattle Seahawks have signed their top draft choice, John L. Williams, running back from Florida, to a series of four one-year contracts. . . . Earl Campbell, the 1977 Heisman Trophy running back, has signed a contract with the Saints for his third year in New Orleans and ninth in the N.F.L. . . . The Seattle SuperSonics have traded Al Wood, their 6-foot-6-inch swingman, to Dallas for the Mavericks' 6-7 swingman, Dale Ellis. . . . Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the suspended Boston Red Sox pitcher who is undergoing hospital tests after a run-in with Chelsea, Mass., police last week, was arrested yesterday for an unpaid speeding violation that was several years old. The outstanding violation was discovered during a routine computer check after his wife was stopped for another speeding violation with Boyd as a passenger. The State Police said Boyd would appear today in court in Wrentham.

title: 7 ACCUSED IN SALE OF PLANES TO LIBYA
description: Two Libyans and five American businessmen were charged today with selling two civilian transport planes worth almost $60 million to the Libyan Government.

title: CHARLES LEVY
description: Charles Levy, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Charles Levy Circulating Company, died of emphysema Sunday at his home in Chicago.

title: Colson the Author
description: Charles W. Colson, the former aide who once said he ''would walk over my grandmother if necessary'' to insure President Nixon's re-election, is himself now a grandfather and is writing children's books.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLASTIC pipe and tubing are ideal for amateur plumbing jobs because they demand no special skills or tools, and are lighter, longer-lasting and easier to work with than metal.

title: ADMINISTRATION DIVIDED ON VALUE OF ARMS PACTS
description: The Standing Consultative Commission does not sound like the sort of organization that would excite a lot of passion. But names, of course, can be misleading.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Consumers Power Co., Jackson, Mich., said it and Dow Chemical had held preliminary discussions on Dow's possible purchase of electricity from a gas-fired facility Consumers Power hopes to complete on the site of its mothballed Midland nuclear power plant.

title: Impeach and Convict
description: Impeachment is so rare that the public misunderstands the very word and Congress must relearn the process whenever the need arises. Often that has required tormenting judgments. But not in the case of U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne.

title: To Give Homosexuality a Constitutional Imprimatur; Posterity Will Mock
description: To the Editor:

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FORMER AIDE AT LAZARD NAMED IN INSIDER CASE
description: The biggest insider trading case in Wall Street history widened yet another notch yesterday, as another former employee of Lazard Freres & Company received a subpoena as part of the stock trading investigation centered on Dennis B. Levine, the 33-year-old former merger official.

title: SHULTZ SAYS C.I.A. HEAD DENIES PASSING DATA TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Director of Central Intelligence had assured him that the United States had not given South Africa any intelligence on the principal anti-apartheid guerrilla group.

title: Quaker State Leaves Lorimar Unit for Grey
description: The Quaker State Refining Corporation, Oil City, Pa., has exited USAdvertising in favor of Grey Advertising, which already has automotive, tire and car-polish accounts but needs a lube job.

title: Auto Auctions Inc. Raises Its Offer
description: Auto Auctions Inc. said it had increased its offer for all outstanding shares of the Sandgate Corporation to $18.75 a share, or a total of $81.6 million, from $18 a share, or $78.3 million.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $326,000 after tax gain related to pension plans.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL WRESTLES WITH REDISTRICTING
description: The Los Angeles City Council, after Mayor Tom Bradley's veto of its first redistricting plan, has devised a second plan aimed at giving the city's large Hispanic population a chance to elect a second Hispanic person to the Council.

title: VOLKER AGAIN URGES ALLIES TO SPUR GROWTH
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, complained today of ''massive international disequilibrium'' and urged America's trading partners to take steps to expand their economies to head off protectionism and other threats to an increasingly fragile world prosperity.

title: 'WOZA AFRICA!' SPOTLIGHTS BLACK SOUTH AFRICANS
description: The most prolonged exposure New York theatergoers have had to black people's lives in South Africa today, as seen by its black playwrights, will be offered in September at Lincoln Center.

title: In the Achille Lauro Trial, Justice and Palestinians Lost
description: In ''West Side Story,'' Diesel, playing a judge in a street scene fantasy, says of the accused miscreant, Action: ''In the opinion of this court, this child is deprived on account he ain't had a normal home.'' Action, elated and appreciating this sympathetic explanation for his criminality, exults: ''Hey, I'm depraved on account I'm deprived!''

title: Dynamics Net Rises by 3.9%
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, a leading military contractor, said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter increased 3.9 percent, to $103.5 million, or $2.43 a share, from $99.6 million, or $2.35 a share, a year ago. Sales were up 18.9 percent, to $2.33 billion, from $1.96 billion.

title: A'S SET BACK SLUMPING RED SOX AGAIN
description: Carney Lansford twice hit two-run home runs, and Tony Phillips drove in three runs to pace a 16-hit attack today, leading the Oakland A's to their fourth straight victory, a 9-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $616,000 and a gain of $10,558,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Bonn Exchanges a Spy For 2 Western Agents
description: West German officials exchanged a convicted East German spy today for two accused Western agents, Bonn's chief Government spokesman said.

title: POLICE SHOOTING VICTIM FACED GUN CHARGE IN '84
description: The Transit Authority police said yesterday that the 81-year-old man who was shot and killed Tuesday by a transit police officer had been arrested in 1984 on charges that he menaced one of his daughters and one of her friends with an unlicensed gun and a steel pipe.

title: IN DANCE, A BIZARRE SPIRIT OF WAR, POWER AND PAIN
description: AMONG the most fascinating of recent programs by new choreographers were Dance Theater Workshop's ''Fresh Tracks'' at the Bessie Schonberg Theater and the presentation of works by young choreographers and composers at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. By emphasizing a Neo-Expressionist choreographic style, the two programs were as disquieting as they were stimulating.

title: PRETORIA PRAISES REAGAN'S SPEECH
description: The South African Government offered a broad welcome today to President Reagan's statement Tuesday on the nation's crisis and said ''foreign intervention and threats'' would only promote a siege mentality in Pretoria.

title: Accord Set In Seafirst Suit
description: The Seafirst Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with its former accounting firm, Arthur Anderson & Company, for an out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit charging that the accounting firm neglected to point out weaknesses in the Seattle bank's energy loans.

title: U.S. Journalists Expelled In Error, Nicaragua Says
description: The Government said today that its expulsion last week of two American journalists had been a mistake and said they could return when they pleased.

title: Steamy Days For the Falcons
description: The oppressive summer heat wave that has killed 21 people in Georgia since May 30 has the Atlanta Falcons watching their players like hawks and taking such precautions as draining the team's hot tub and filling it to the rim with ice water. Still, conducting two-a-days at the club's training complex in Suwanee is proving occasionally troublesome.

title: For Better-Looking Trash
description: In the belief that even garbage can be beautified, the City Art Commission has leaned on the Sanitation Department to come up with better-looking garbage cans. And it did.

title: Wertheim Gets 4 From Chase
description: In another example of the talent-raiding taking place on Wall Street among interest rate swap specialists, Wertheim & Company said that it had hired a four-member swap team from the Chase Investment Bank.

title: Freddie Mac Bond Redemption
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association, known as Freddie Mac, announced that it was redeeming all the outstanding 8.60 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1995.

title: BIAS'S PARENTS SEEK GRAND JURY SESSION
description: The parents of Len Bias want to appear before the grand jury that is investigating his death, a family lawyer said today.

title: 5 Plead Guilty To U.S. Fraud
description: Five real estate brokers pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Government of more than $9.5 million as part of a plot to obtain Government-backed mortgages.

title: The $65 Million Malpractice Question
description: All New York loves a lottery, and the best game in town takes place in the courtroom. That's what Agnes Mae Whitaker, a victim of medical malpractice, discovered recently. She drew a jury that gave her $65 million - but it's not the kind of luck the rest of us should toast.

U.S. APPROVES A GENETICALLY ALTERED VACCINE
description: Commercial production of the first genetically altered vaccine for humans was approved today by the Food and Drug Administration, opening what Federal officials called a new era for vaccine production.

title: HASSEY'S 'SPRINT' BEATS RANGERS
description: In making up four games on Boston in the week since the All-Star Game break, the Yankees have not traveled as remarkable a distance as the 90 feet that Ron Hassey safely traversed in dashing and sliding from home plate to first base yesterday.

title: VIEW FROM TOP ELUSIVE FOR LYNCH
description: The three flagpoles not far from the corner of North Michigan Avenue and East Delaware Place once provided an early clue in the days when Ed Lynch was a Met visitor at Wrigley Field.

title: VISES AND VERSES
description: The Intuflo Hardware Store, crammed with the normal clutter of tools and screws that one might expect, was also crowded with people Tuesday night. But they were not there for nuts and bolts.

title: Chemist Testifies At Florida Murder Trial
description: A Government chemist testified today that he found particles of zinc on Steven Wayne Benson's clothing the day the tobacco heir's mother and adopted brother were killed by two powerful pipe bombs.

title: INCOMES GAIN 0.1%
description: Americans' personal incomes rose a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in June while consumer spending rose by a more robust six-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Complaint Dismissed
description: A domestic violence complaint filed against Micheal Ray Richardson, the former Net and Knick guard, by his wife will be dismissed under an agreement reached between the two and outlined in court yesterday. The agreement stipulates that Richardson, who was banned from the National Basketball Association in February for violating the league's drug policy a third time, will be allowed to return to his Mahwah, N.J., home, where his wife Leah lives with the couple's two children.

description: b-Net income

description: The per share figures were restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in April.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AT ENTERRA
description: John A. Sergovic resigned yesterday as president, chief executive and a director of the Enterra Corporation, an energy company in Radnor, Pa., that has suffered substantial losses in recent years. Mr. Sergovic, 50 years old, had been with Enterra for 18 years.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
ALL-MALE JAPANESE CAST TO DO 'MEDEA' IN PARK
description: The actor arrived wearing an opulent kimono-like cape made of many strands of obi, the traditional Japanese sash. His face was painted white and he had gold beads dripping from his black-lined eyes. He wore false breasts - exposed - a multicolored veil and an intricate headdress of fuchsia hair. His lips were painted green. ''Call me Mickey,'' he said. The actor was Mikijiro Hira of Japan, who will perform the title role in Euripides' ''Medea'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park in early September. He was on hand at a news conference yesterday at the Essex House with Joseph Papp, who is presenting the play.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: PANEL ADVISING KOCH TO WIDEN HISPANIC ROLE
description: The draft report of a special mayoral commission recommends sweeping revisions in New York City policies to give Hispanic people greater participation in all facets of city government, according to some commission members.

title: CITY WILL BEGIN SCHOOLING PLAN FOR 4-YEAR-OLDS
description: The new president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., yesterday set 1989 as a target date for publicly funded prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds.

title: ALLTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STRAW-HAT CIRCUIT IN TOWN
description: AS inevitable as summer itself, the sophisticated and traditional straw hat is bobbing along Fifth and Madison Avenues these humid days, providing shade from the sun and echoes of a more formal time.

title: PRESSED BY UNION, CITY POSTPONES RECYCLING PLAN
description: New York City's venture into neighborhood newspaper recycling - scheduled to begin today - was abruptly postponed yesterday after the city and the sanitation workers union could not agree on whether one or two workers should be assigned to a new recycling truck.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL ON BONDS FOR CLEANUP OF TOXIC WASTE
description: Estimating that 500 toxic-waste sites in the state posed a threat to health or the environment, Governor Cuomo yesterday signed a bill to issue $1.2 billion in bonds to help pay for their cleanup -part of the largest environmental bond issue in New York's history.

title: JOSLYN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Hunt Is Called Off
description: The Chrysler Corporation has called off the hunt for a major high-technology acquisition to fill the ''empty box'' on its organization chart, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'REFUGEE ROAD' ON 13, ON ASIANS
description: ''REFUGEE ROAD'' is a muddle, and something of an anachronism, too. It is a 1981 documentary, made with a 1960's sensibility, and shown, in all the unpredictability of summertime-doldrums programming, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight. At the same time, it does have points of interest.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pinch-Hitter
description: Frank Layden, coach of the Utah Jazz and self-deprecating humorist, addressing the graduating class at Westminster College in Salt Lake City after receiving an honorary degree there: ''Your president told me they considered Rodney Dangerfield, but Dangerfield was going to charge a fee. 'Don't worry about it,' I told him. 'You'll still get his material.' ''

title: G.M. NET FALLS 15.7% IN QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that second-quarter earnings fell 15.7 percent, to $978 million, or $2.81 a share of common stock, compared with $1.16 billion, or $3.58 a share, in the 1985 period. Most analysts had expected the nation's largest automaker to earn about $3.10 a share.

title: REPUBLICAN ANXIETIES STIRRED BY THE ECONOMY
description: Just when Republicans thought the political waters were safe for a midterm election, indications that the economic recovery is in a stall are beginning to show like shark fins on the horizon.

title: WITCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 50-percent stock distribution on July 15.

title: FURNITURE ON THE MOVE: FIXING CASTERS 4:3>
description: Furniture casters have been around for a long time. Originally the wheels were of hardwood; later on they were leather, and then toward the end of the 18th century brass was the principal material.

title: OPERA: JERRY HADLEY IN MASSENET'S 'WERTHER'
description: THE only plausible way to approach ''Werther'' is to assume that the 20th century never happened. That is exactly what the New York City Opera has done in the evocative new production of Massenet's opera that had its first performance last evening. Since there is almost no way that the psychological, religious and social dilemmas that faced Goethe's sorrowful young hero in the 18th century can be translated into modern terms, this Lotfi Mansouri production invites one to enter a time warp. We are asked to bring historical imagination to bear on a situation that, as expressed in the original novel, set a whole generation of young Germans to contemplating suicide in emulation of the romantically frustrated Werther.

title: ENERGY COSTS ARE CITED
description: Consumer prices increased five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the steepest rise in seven months, chiefly because of a since-ended spurt in the price of gasoline, electricity and natural gas, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Queens Man Held In Fatal Shooting
description: A 20-year-old man was ordered held without bail yesterday on charges stemming from the killing of one man and the wounding of two others at a backyard party in Queens.

title: SUSQUEHANNA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 1 stock split paid in June.

title: Council Chairmen Will Get Raises
description: The City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, who earlier this year increased the stipends paid to most of the Council's committee chairmen, announced yesterday that the two remaining chairmen would also get raises.

title: WALTON PLANNING CHANGES
description: In his last two seasons, Coach Joe Walton has vigorously shaken any complacency the Jets might have enjoyed. Today, with the rookies reporting, he announced, ''We've got to get some new blood on our team.''

title: Plant Closing May Hurt Armco
description: Armco Inc. said the closing of a Minnesota iron ore operation it runs with the LTV Corporation would ''materially'' affect its second-quarter results.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESPITE FOR SOUTH AFRICA: A ROYAL WEDDING
description: At an office here, the secretary said that the boss had been generous: Television sets were provided to view the event and the staff was permitted to bring cucumber sandwiches and champagne to celebrate.

title: Gorospe Takes 19th Leg of Tour
description: Julian Gorospe of Spain won the 19th stage of the Tour de France today despite several late challenges on a hilly course.

title: TOTAL OF OFFICERS HIT IN SHOOTINGS GROWING IN CITY
description: When Officer Richard P. Garcia intervened in a dispute between two men over money late Tuesday night on the Upper West Side, he became the 13th officer to be shot and wounded in the line of duty in the city this year.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS 8/ RISE IN TAX ON CIGARETTES
description: The Senate Finance Committee, defying its chairman and the Reagan Administration, today approved an 8-cent increase in the cigarette tax to make up part of the increase in revenue proposed in the 1987 budget.

title: PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The total expense of higher interest costs because of increased debt, and its recapitalization plan was about $4.6 million after tax in the latest second quarter. The latest results also reflect a writedown of certain oil and gas properties of about $2.1 million, and an after-tax charge of about $1.4 million from the premium paid on the early retirement of debt.

title: SHULTZ, SEEKING SANCTIONS DELAY, SAYS U.S. AND ALLIES MAY ACT SOON
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held out the possibility today that the Reagan Administration might join its allies in imposing sanctions against South Africa in two months if Pretoria does not move by then to open negotiations on ending apartheid.

title: MOROCCO AND ISRAEL DIFFER IN ASSESSING PROGRESS AT MEETING
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel ended a 48-hour visit to Morocco tonight and said he and King Hassan II had agreed in principle to have further contacts to advance the cause of peace.

description: In 1977, Paul Cheng and Simon Edward Heath started a home-building concern, the Pacific Realty Corporation, in Dallas with five employees.

title: REPORT ASSAILS SAFETY OF NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE AT CAROLINA PLANT
description: Highly radioactive and toxic wastes from more than three decades of nuclear bomb production are polluting soil and water at a nuclear fuel plant in South Carolina, according to a private study based on Department of Energy documents. The study also said an earthquake or explosion at the plant could release huge amounts of radiation.

title: HOME & CITY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $825,000 for the quarter and $1,468,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss Home & City converted from mutual to stock form in February and did not report per share earnings for the year-ago second period.

title: New Post for John
description: Tommy John, who has won 262 major-league games and lost 208 with six clubs during his 23-year career, has been named pitching coach at North Carolina and will join the Tar Heels when the Yankees end their season. John, a 43-year old left-hander with a 3-1 record for the Yankees this season, was placed on the 21-day disabled list July 12 with a strained Achilles' tendon.

title: HERS
description: LAST week, in a handsome suburban food market, I saw a fine glowing girl of a mother and a 5-year-old who was her scaled-down replica. It was fun to watch them, so fresh and ironed and smart and lucky.

DUQUESNE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Europe Cites U.S. Barriers
description: Deregulation of the American telecommunications market has not eliminated unfair barriers to foreign suppliers, a report by European government and industry officials said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM EXCHANGE
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange over American policies toward South Africa that occurred today in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee between Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Senator Biden began by referring to the criticism of President Reagan's speech on Tuesday by Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, who said the Reagan policy was ''nauseating.''

title: A Musical-Revue Tour Of City Nursing Homes
description: ''I Can Still Hear and See Them,'' a musical revue of Broadway show tunes, will be performed by the AMAS Repertory Theater throughout the summer at nursing homes and other facilities for the elderly around the city. The production, which is free and open to the public, is part of the company's 16th summer tour.

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CHESAPEAKE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STAGE: OUTDOOR 'ANTONY'
description: Watching ''Antony and Cleopatra'' outdoors at the Mount, Edith Wharton's former home, is, in environmental terms, an evocative experience. The grounds are the stage. A generous performance space has been carved out near the courtyard and the natural setting is treated as scenery - a greensward, towering trees and the acreage beyond. Had ''Macbeth'' been the play, Birnam Wood would have been ready to march on Dunsinane.

title: Safeway Offers Severance Plan
description: Safeway Stores Inc., the subject of a takeover bid from the Dart Group Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it had an executive severance pay plan in the event Dart's bid is successful.

title: U.S. ADVANCES AS TOP STARS WIN
description: Martina Navratilova, the star attraction, and Chris Evert Lloyd each swept their final 10 games against Spanish teen-agers today to put the United States into the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup.

title: PITNEY BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations and the disposal of discontinued operations of $6.5 million for the quarter and $7.1 million for the 6 months. c-After a gain of $1.9 million from discontinued operations and the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: COLORADO NATIONAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension costs.

title: M.C.&K Wins Account Of 13 Honda Dealers
description: In another development that was born out of an account conflict, MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has won the Western Pennsylvania Honda Dealers Association, made up of 13 dealers in the state.

title: To Give Homosexuality a Constitutional Imprimatur; What Was Facetious
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute on Vatican Envoy
description: Speaking of the High Court, a number of major religious denominations will ask it today to review the opinion of lower courts upholding the Government's right to send an ambassador to the Holy See of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: New Australian Agency Is Biggest Independent
description: The word came in from Australia yesterday about an agency acquisition that did not involve either a United States agency or Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: Chilean Army Officer Faces Trial in Burnings
description: A civilian judge indicted an army lieutenant today in the fatal burning of a photographer during protests against military rule, but transferred the case to a military court and released the remaining soldiers in custody.

title: FOLD-OUT CHIC: THE SOFA BED FINDS NEW FOLLOWING
description: ONCE considered a clunky eyesore and disparaged by overnight guests for its lack of comfort, the convertible sofa bed has emerged as one of the most popular pieces of furniture on the market. Privately held companies dominate the industry, making an accurate measurement difficult, but analysts estimate that the market is growing 5 to 10 percent annually, and that as many as 2.8 million sofa beds - representing more than $1 billion in sales - will be sold this year.

title: Data General Narrows Loss
description: The Data General Corporation, a computer systems manufacturer based in Westboro, Mass., said yesterday that its third-quarter loss had narrowed to $2 million, from $8.3 million a year ago. Revenues for the quarter rose 14 percent, to $325.3 million, from $285.5 million in the period a year ago.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hurricane Damages 10 Homes on Hawaii
description: A hurricane smashed homes on Hawaii Island with 20-foot waves today and forced the evacuation of about 200 residents before moving back out to sea.

title: Update on Howser
description: Only hours after doctors told him that his brain tumor was malignant, Dick Howser, the 50-year-old manager of the Kansas City Royals, was reported to be in good spirits.

title: EXXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After special charges of $22 million. The net charge includes a charge of $28 million in connection with foreign exchange on debt, less a credit of $6 million relating to the company's restructuring plan for the quarter, and the 6 months is after special charges of $229 million. The net charge includes a restructuring charge of $249 million, less a credit of $20 million in connection with foreign exchange on debt. c-After special charges of $527 million, or 71 cents a share, provision for the adverse court ruling related to Hawkins Field Pricing and a charge of $12 million relating to the company's restructuring plan, less a credit of $30 million in connection with foreign exchange on debt for the quarter, and the 6 months is after special charges of $478 million. The net charge includes a second quarter provision of $545 million for the adverse court ruling related to Hawkins Field Pricing, less a credit of $43 million in connection with foreign exchange on debt and a credit of $24 million relating to the company's restructuring plan.

title: 7 INDICTED IN SCHEME THAT EVADED GASOLINE TAXES
description: State, Federal and local prosecutors announced the indictment today of seven men in a scheme that authorities said evaded payment of more than $11 million in state excise and sales taxes on gasoline brought into New York.

title: SENATE, ENDING JUDICIAL FIGHT, GIVES MANION FINAL APPROVAL
description: The Senate voted 50 to 49 today to give final approval to Daniel A. Manion's appointment as a Federal appellate judge in Chicago after a divisive debate about the Indiana lawyer's competence and political views.

title: Cannery Row Fire Contained
description: A fire destroyed two warehouses on Cannery Row early today but did not endanger the tourist attractions, such as the Monterey aquarium. The flames were controlled within 90 minutes and there were no reports of injuries.

title: Transit Policeman Arrested On Brooklyn Heroin Charges
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer was arrested in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday morning and charged with possession of four packets of heroin.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a change in accounting methods which contributed $1.9 million, or 15 cents a share. c-Includes gains of $12.2 million, or 90 cents a share, from the sale of certain cellular telephone and sportschannel interests. Year-ago results are restated to reflect retrospective adoption in December 1985 of the equity method of accounting for the company's investment in Cowles Media Co. stock. The company acquired 53 cable TV systems from Capital Cities Communications Inc. in January.

title: UNUSUAL SECURITY BOLTS
description: UNUSUAL security bolts, for Dutch doors or tall French doors, are available at a number of places. Other surface bolts, most often used as an extra latch or bolt on the front door of a house or apartment, in tandem with a stronger lock system, are also widely available. They usually consist of two plates attached to abutting surfaces of the door and doorjamb; the plates are joined together by a pin, hook or chain. Smaller versions of these bolts can be used as an extra lock on a bathroom or bedroom door.

The reserve totaled $570.2 million at June 30.

title: Gunman Frees Hostages In Siege Near Pittsburgh
description: A gunman who wounded two police officers and then held four hostages, including his daughter and another child, for more than 16 hours, surrendered early today to the cheers of relieved neighbors in this Pittsburgh suburb.

title: 2.1% RISE IN ORDERS FOR DURABLE GOODS
description: Orders to United States factories for big-ticket durable goods shot up 2.1 percent in June, the first increase in four months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Greyhound Unit
description: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation's debt rating is under review, Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday.

title: Reagan Urged To Help Steel
description: The chairmen of five steel companies and the president of the steelworkers' union today urged President Reagan in a letter to meet with leaders of the Congressional Steel Caucus to discuss ways to help the industry. A spokesman for the White House said the President was developing his response to the group's letter.

title: Mr. Botha's Poodle
description: After President Reagan's speech, the hope for a negotiated transition to democracy in South Africa is at the vanishing point. The prospect is for years of repression and violence, eroding a great country's future.

description: The USX Corporation, citing a drop in orders and the possibility of an Aug. 1 strike by the United Steelworkers of America, said it would begin to shut facilities near Pittsburgh and at Gary, Ind.

title: URBAN LEAGUE HEARS FROM HOMELESS
description: As its four-day conference ended today, the National Urban League had a sobering reminder of the critical issues it had attempted to address.

title: JAZZ VIOLINIST ON A&E CABLE CHANNEL
description: THE violinist Stephane Grappelli's moon-shaped face, apple cheeks and sly smile make him look like an ageless sprite - and his playing, with its insouciant swing, makes him sound like one. The first part of a 1981 concert in Edinburgh by Mr. Grappelli and his group will be shown tonight at 11:30. on the Arts & Entertainment cable channel, from the British television series ''Rhythm on Two''; a second half-hour completes the concert next Thursday at 11:30 P.M.

title: Financial Corp. Reports Profit
description: Bolstered by heavy sales of loans and mortgage-backed certificates, the Financial Corporation of America today reported net income in the second quarter of $11.6 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with a loss of $17.9 million a year ago.

title: Sudanese Guerrillas Report Battle for Main Southern City
description: Sudanese rebels said today that they had begun a drive on Juba, the main city in the southern Sudan, and urged residents to evacuate children.

title: Iraqi Aircraft Resume Raids On Targets Near Iran's Cities
description: Iraqi warplanes bombed an arms factory just south of Teheran and other targets in Iran including a steel plant, an army camp and two railroad bridges today, a military spokesman said.

title: Jersey Supreme Court Upholds 'Blue Laws'
description: The State Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of so-called blue laws that force merchants to close on Sundays.

title: People
description: * Jan A. Sneed has been appointed senior vice president, director of corporate communications at Geers, Gross Advertising.

title: Edward A. Garmatz, Former Congressman
description: Former Representative Edward A. Garmatz, a Democrat who represented Baltimore for 12 terms and headed the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, died of lung cancer at his home late Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

title: 2d Bond Offering Made by Illinois
description: The State of Illinois yesterday offered $40 million in consumer loan bonds priced at par, to yield 9 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The taxable bonds, which will mature on June 15, 2006, will be used to make loans to private entities for economic development purposes.

title: SAFETY BOARD INQUIRY AT O'HARE PROMPTED BY CONTROLLER ERRORS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has begun an investigation of the air traffic control system at O'Hare International Airport because of an unusually large number of controller errors at the Chicago airport, according to safety board officials.

title: BANKS OF MID-AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter is after a provision for loan losses of $32,350,000, compared to year-ago period of $5,430,000. The latest 6 months result is after a provision for loan losses of $52,272,000, compared with $9,330,000 for year-earlier period.

title: JAZZ: RAGTIME AT THE Y
description: THE opening concert on Tuesday of the second annual Jazz in July series at the 92d Street Y - six midweek evenings this week and next of ''Hot Jazz, Ragtime, Oldtime and Blues'' - was essentially an encore of last year's opening concert. What was a glorious start last year proved to be an equally glorious start this year.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rumors Spur Rise In Pennzoil Stock
description: The Pennzoil Company's stock price rose yesterday after rumors swept through Wall Street that the company was close to settling its multibillion-dollar legal dispute with Texaco Inc. The rumors were denied by sources close to both companies. Pennzoil closed at $56 a share, up $2, in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Disneyland Must Pay $600,000 in Park Murder
description: Disneyland was ordered to pay $600,000 to the family of a teen-ager murdered at the amusement park in 1981 after a jury found that park officials were negligent in treating the injured youth.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: RELIEF FOR SOUTH'S CATTLE, A PRAYER AND...RAIN!
description: At the Farmer's Market south of the city there were more than 50 trucks in line this morning waiting for the 40 tons of hay flown by the Air Force from the Middle West for Georgia livestock starved by the drought.

title: New Concepts In Steelmaking
description: THE LTV Corporation's collapse into bankruptcy proceedings last week reinforced steel's image as an old product of the smokestack era that is steadily losing ground to plastics, synthetic fibers and lighter metals. In reality, steelmaking is in a state of technological ferment that could lead to major changes in the metal's competitiveness.

title: JERSEY TO OFFER $5 MILLION CARD
description: Taking a page from thoroughbred racing's Breeders' Cup, the Meadowlands is staging the richest card in harness-racing history Saturday night, with 12 stakes races that will total $5,093,750 in purses.

title: DeLeon Is Traded
description: Jose DeLeon, the Pittsburgh Pirate right-hander who lost 19 of 21 decisions last season and was with a farm club this season, was traded to the Chicago White Sox yesterday for Bobby Bonilla, an outfielder, and Lee Mazzilli got caught in the squeeze. Last December, the Pirates left Bonilla on the unprotected list in the major-league draft and he was picked up by Chicago.

title: BID FOR AIDS TEST FAILS IN JERSEY RACKETS TRIAL
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a motion by lawyers for reputed organized-crime figures to have the Government's key witness against them tested to determine if he had AIDS.

title: CITY CONTRACTS WITH PRIVATE TEACHING HOSPITALS ARE ASSAILED
description: The head of a physician's union told a City Council hearing yesterday that private teaching hospitals and medical schools that provide medical oversight and services in New York City's municipal hospitals ''are ripping off our municipal hospitals and exploiting the patients who use them.''

title: WHAT MAKES AN AD WORK?
description: People like Mark and Joyce Iseminger of Sioux Falls have a disturbing message for consumer products companies: Some of those hundreds of millions of dollars spent on advertising each year may be buying less than the companies think.

title: Self-Interests in Morocco
description: No matter how narrow their motives, the meeting of King Hassan and Shimon Peres amounts to a step toward reason in the Middle East. The King has long trafficked with Israelis and was always a good candidate for becoming the second Arab leader to openly receive Israel's Prime Minister. That the King now thinks he can afford the gesture and gain at least the tacit support of other Arabs should stiffen Egypt's spine and further isolate extreme factions of the P.L.O.

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were restated for a 100 percent stock distribution in June.

title: MUSIC: MARK LAUBACH, ORGAN
description: MARK LAUBACH, winner of the 1984 Young Artists' Competition sponsored by the American Guild of Organists, played a recital at Riverside Church on Tuesday night. A 25-year-old native of Pennsylvania who studied at the Westminster Choir College and the Eastman School of Music, he is currently the organist of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

title: Richard C. Carroll, 77, Dies; Former Administrator at Yale
description: Richard C. Carroll, former associate dean of Yale College and associate secretary of Yale University, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in New Haven. He was 77 years old. Mr. Carroll, who had been associated with the Yale administration from 1932 to 1974, was largely responsible for formulating the school's undergraduate scholarship policies and its system of self-help employment for students.

title: BOY, 1, IS KILLED AND A 4-YEAR-OLD IS INJURED IN FALLS FROM WINDOWS
description: A 1-year-old boy was killed and a 4-year-old boy was seriously injured in falls from windows of their homes in Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday.

title: CRAXI SAYS NEW ACCORD WILL LET HIM STAY AS PRIME MINISTER
description: Bettino Craxi announced today that political leaders had reached an understanding under which he would stay on as Italy's Prime Minister.

title: DOMESTIC AUTO SALES FELL 7.8% IN JULY 11-20 PERIOD
description: Sales of American-made automobiles in the July 11-20 period were down 7.8 percent, on a daily selling rate basis, the major manufacturers reported here today. There were eight selling days in the period this year and nine last year.

title: Dole's Dodgers Default
description: Senator Bob Dole celebrated his 63d birthday last Tuesday, but whatever the event may have gained for him in the wisdom and stature of age, it may have cost his staff on the playing fields of Capitol Mall.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 30.

title: USAir Net Off 40.2%
description: USAir Group reported second-quarter net income of $29.6 million, or $1 a share, down 40.2 percent from $49.5 million, or $1.64 a share, a year ago. Revenue dipped 4.7 percent, to $458.5 million, from $481 million a year ago. Net income for the earlier quarter was the best for a single quarter in the company's history.

title: SUMMER SOLITUDE: IN QUEST OF QUIET TIMES
description: WHEN I tell my friend who is walking toward her guest house, arms full of Pratesi sheets, that I don't allow summer house guests, she stops and addresses me with incredulity and disapproval. ''But what do you say when a cousin calls from California and asks to come East to spend a few days?'' I shrug. She grows more agitated. ''What about your best friend who happens to be city-bound in August? Not even a weekend? You wouldn't even offer her an overnight?'' ''Nope.'' When I first decided to change our summer life style, my responses were less direct and were as weighted with guilt as Goethe's letters to abandoned friends back in the court of Weimar - those whom he had not invited along when he assumed another name and caught a night mail coach headed for Italy and solitude.

title: WRIGLEY, WM JR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mets' Hearing Is Rescheduled
description: The court hearing in the Ron Darling-Tim Teufel assault case that had been tentatively scheduled for this morning in Houston was rescheduled for 8:30 A.M. tomorrow to give the players time to get to Houston after last night's game in Cincinnati.

title: Panama Editor in Miami After Death Threats
description: The editor of Panama's largest newspaper has taken refuge in Miami because of death threats and Government denunciations after United States press reports on Gen. Manuel Noriega, the Panamanian strongman, a family member told Congress today.

title: COLONIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JERSEY 'WILLING' TO GIVE ADDICTS CLEAN NEEDLES
description: New Jersey health officials want to offer drug addicts clean needles for dirty ones as part of a program to combat the spread of AIDS.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SUMMER IN THE CITY Season in, season out, the streets of New York are always populated. One aspect of this outdoor urban view is the world of culture. Uptown, downtown, East Side and West Side, all play host to entertainers ordinarily seen in nightclubs or on the concert stage. While most indoor events charge an admission, practically all outdoor performances are free.

title: P.L.O. ASKS MEETING ON MOROCCO
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization today appealed through its dominant group, Al Fatah, for a meeting of Arab nations to discuss the Israeli-Moroccan talks.

title: Retiring Pose
description: Marla Collins, who began working as a ball girl at Chicago Cub home games in 1982, says she had planned to make this her last season anyway. Now she's made an early exit, a result of her posing for a nude pictorial in Playboy magazine.

title: The Need for Enemies
description: Somehow, thoughts keep turning to Lebanon as the prime example. It is mostly out of the news these days, partly because it's so dangerous to cover, partly because the Syrians are imposing their Draconian order on West Beirut again.

title: More Charges Brought In Prostitution Case
description: An insurance executive awaiting trial on charges of running a prostitution ring of college students, juveniles and other women pleaded not guilty today to four new felony charges in the case.

title: Anti-Abortion Bill
description: The White House is helping frame a sweeping bill to be introduced by the Presidential aspirant Jack F. Kemp and two other members of the House. Backers expect Mr. Reagan to put his prestige behind the bill.

description: TOP-PERFORMING equity managers at banks used different strategies during the second quarter to handily outperform their competition - and the stock market.

description: The last time Ron Guidry pitched in the minor leagues was in 1976. Tonight - 10 years and 158 major league victories later - he was back in the minors: on rehabilitation assignment pitching for the Eastern League Albany-Colonie Yankees.

title: BRITISH END SCHOOL CANING
description: The schoolroom caning, a formidable fixture that has lingered in modern British life, was struck down Tuesday night by a narrow vote in the House of Commons.

title: COMPUTER CLUBS GROWING AS HOBBYISTS SHARE DATA
description: EACH night before bed, George R. Wilhelmsen, who works at a nuclear power plant in Morris, Ill., settles down in front of his computer terminal and tunes into the nightly meeting of his electronic club, an organization surging in popularity. Linked by telephone wires, hundreds of club members around the globe freely exchange advice, ideas and information on topics of joint interest.

title: 'REMINGTON STEELE' GETS REPRIEVE
description: NBC has reinstated its romantic detective series ''Remington Steele'' just two months after canceling it.

title: TAKING CENTER STAGE, STYLISHLY
description: SOFA BEDS often take center stage in a living room, and are more stylish, varied and comfortable than they have ever been. Styles range from traditional overstuffed Chesterfields and camel-back shapes to modern, although voluptuous, silhouettes. Not only is there a style for just about every conceivable decor, there's an appropriate size for every kind of home, from tiny studio apartments to large houses.

title: The Background; Massenet's Goethe
description: Jules Massenet's ''Werther,'' the 13th of his 29 operas, is based on ''The Sorrows of Young Werther,'' Goethe's novel (1774) about thwarted young love and suicide. First given in Vienna on Feb. 16, 1892, in a German translation, the work waited until Dec. 27 that year for its first French performance, in Geneva.

description: While they commmended the Reagan Administration's new framework for regulating genetic engineering research and the products of biotechnology, Congressmen, scientists, and environmental lawyers said today that there were key weaknesses in the program.

description: YES, there is a design heaven: a place where people tote Robert Venturi umbrellas when it rains and wear Harry Anderson-designed shirts when it shines.

description: One of baseball's tired tenets describes it as a game of inches.

description: A newly renovated home for the City Planning Commission, begun eight years ago with the work expected to take 18 months at a cost of no more than $4 million, is not finished yet and may not be ready until the beginning of next year.

Officials of some unions and companies, not those of the Labor Department, said such action would lead to violations of minimum wage laws and other worker protections.

title: GROUND RULES FOR GUEST ROOMS
description: It isn't a matter of money, although, considering the square-inch cost of housing these days, the very idea of a guest room implies some degree of affluence. Still, as many a guest will testify, money doesn't automatically mean the kind of room that embraces a visitor. There are plenty among the not-so-rich who would rather stay home than spend a weekend of luxurious discomfort in the palatial digs of rich friends.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON MANION POST
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today confirmed the nomination of Daniel Manion to be a Federal appeals court judge. The vote was whether to reconsider last month's 48-to-46 vote in favor of Mr. Manion.

description: The Northern States Power Company announced yesterday that its president and other top officers were leaving the company in the wake of a review of the hiring of a former member of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission.

description: In its first bond sale for the fiscal year 1987, New York City is tentatively offering about $400 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

description: The National Building Museum is celebrating the return of ornament in contemporary architecture with a glowing exhibition that traces the history of the use of terra cotta in urban architecture.

title: Hot Ticket
description: Washington has many characteristics of a small town.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 24, 1986
description: The Economy Consumer prices posted their steepest rise in seven months, climbing 0.5 percent in June, chiefly because of a short-lived spurt in the prices of gasoline, electricity and natural gas, the Labor Department reported. Despite the increase, the Consumer Price Index for urban consumers fell 0.2 percent for the first half of the year, the first decline in 31 years. [ Page D1. ] The index for the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose 0.7 percent in June. [ D4. ] Americans' personal income rose a slight 0.1 percent in June, after a 0.3 percent drop in May, the Commerce Department said. Consumer spending rose by 0.6 percent. [ D4. ] Orders to factories for big-ticket durable goods soared 2.1 percent in June, the first increase in four months. [ D4. ] The Fed's chairman complained that Japan and Western Europe, by not acting to expand their economies, were endangering a fragile world prosperity. In his semiannual report to the Senate Banking Committee, Paul A. Volcker cited ''huge and rising trade deficits and counterpart surpluses abroad.'' [ D1. ] Companies General Motors' net fell 15.7 percent and Chrysler's 18.1 percent in the second quarter. G.M. said its business had been hurt by the cost of extensive marketing and new technology. Chrysler cited slumping truck sales. [ D1. ] Beatrice is considering spinning off its international food group into a separate corporation and offering stock in it to the public. Beatrice, which expects to retain a significant stake in the resulting entity, would become primarily a domestic food company.

title: Yields Dip In Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all moderately lower for the week ended yesterday.

title: Ryder Truck Selects Ogilvy From 5 Firms
description: Ryder Truck Rental Inc., Miami, which has 5,500 dealers in North America and plans to spend $20 million in the coming year to stimulate their business, has selected Ogilvy & Mather, New York, to handle the stimulation.

title: JUNE COSTS UP BY 0.7% LOCALLY
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: REPORTER CHINA EXPELLED DENIES CHARGE
description: The Peking bureau chief of The New York Times, expelled from China after being detained for nearly a week on suspicion of espionage, said here today that he would not have ridden through the Chinese countryside on a motorcycle if he had had any intention of spying.

title: GRACEFUL COUSINS OF A WILDFLOWER: ACHILLEAS
description: ALONG the country lanes and back highways of the Eastern United States now, in high summer, the roadsides glow with bright splashes of color. Some of the plants - the black-eyed Susans and sunflowers and early goldenrods - are native wildflowers, but mingled with them are other plants we are so accustomed to that we forget they are the descendants of plant immigrants from the Old World. The sky-blue chicory, the graceful and stately Queen Anne's lace, the perennial sweet pea that covers banks and ditches with a rosy haze, all were brought here originally by European colonists, from whose gardens they soon escaped into the wild.

description: b-Includes a charge of $11 million for expenses resulting from the consolidation of two manufacturing operations and from a corporate organization restructuring for the quarter, and an extraordinary after tax loss of $3.8 million from redemption of debentures for the 9 months. c-Includes an $8.2 million charge from an inventory writedown and a $6.3 million charge for costs of a work force reduction. d-Net income

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 3 P.M.

title: Officers Stumble Onto Drug Cache
description: Uniformed police officers who went to a Bronx apartment to serve a Family Court warrant yesterday found a wholesale drug-selling operation in progress, the police reported. Two women and a man were arrested on drug possession charges.

title: REAGAN, IN TOUR THROUGH SOUTH, ASSAILS LIBERALS
description: President Reagan, denouncing ''the liberals in Washington,'' said today that this year's Congressional and gubernatorial elections marked a pivotal moment that could ''permanently alter'' the nation's political landscape.

title: STAY EXTENDED IN QUEENS VOTE
description: A temporary stay preventing Alton R. Waldon Jr. from assuming the Queens Congressional seat held by the late Representative Joseph P. Addabbo was extended late yesterday afternoon by a Federal appeals judge in New Haven.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A CASE OF NAKED ROBBERY
description: Donning, if that's the word, one of the more unusual disguises in the annals of crime, a man wearing sneakers, a headband and nothing else attempted to rob a woman on a street in Medford, L.I.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHAPING THE SHADES OF THINGS TO COME
description: IN the 1970's, the back-to-nature movement and the rediscovery of the American West inspired a decade of earth tones in interior design. In the 1980's, flashy colors have come to dominate the home and office. ''Nancy Reagan red,'' turquoise and fuchsia, designers say, are signs of a strong economy and political optimism.

title: Nuclear-Power Plants Would Be Better the Rickover Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Margin of Victory Is Large For Life Master Pairs Title
description: Everything is big at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here. The tournament is expected to be the biggest ever, with about 20,000 tables in all, by the time it ends Sunday. And the winners of the Life Master Pair Championship Tuesday night had one of the biggest margins of victory in the event's 57-year history.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Fall
description: Stronger-than-expected economic data sent bond prices tumbling yesterday for the second day. Credit markets were also discouraged by comments from Paul A. Volcker, Federal Reserve Board chairman, about the limited impact of a cut in the discount rate.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect a change in method of inventory accounting.

title: Wealth, in Black and White
description: Give the Census Bureau credit on two accounts. In an Administration that doesn't much think about such things, the bureau has done a study highlighting dramatic disparity between races. And into a discussion that has long revolved around trends in income, the bureau has introduced a new measure that may be a better indicator of well-being: wealth.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Dynamics Corp.of America, Greenwich, Conn., named Bruno M. Valbona president of its Waring Products division, New Hartford, Conn., replacing Richard Clancey, who died.

title: METS WIN ON MITCHELL HOMER
description: The news that emerged from Dave Johnson's office might have been as significant as the game itself. Before the Mets completed a sweep of their three-game series with the Cincinnati Reds tonight, winning by 3-2 at Riverfront Stadium, it was announced that the slumping George Foster had lost his job in left field, a clear sign that his unproductive tenure in New York may finally be coming to an end.

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: TEXT OF CHINA'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a Chinese statement on the case of John F. Burns, the Peking bureau chief of The New York Times, who was expelled yesterday. The statement was read in Peking by Xu Hui, an official of the State Security Bureau, to A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The Times, and Warren Hoge, the newspaper's foreign editor.

title: The Rural Woman
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: SUMMATIONS PRESENTED IN ANTITRUST TRIAL
description: The jury of five women and one man that has been listening to testimony in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League for 10 weeks in Federal District Court heard the final arguments yesterday from the attorneys representing each side.

title: GIFTS THAT SAY THANK YOU
description: Perfect house guests pitch in to cook meals, wash the dishes and make the beds. They also bring gifts. Here is a sampling of gifts that range in style from traditional to avant-garde.

title: Dow Gains 3.24, Just Short of 1,800
description: Wall Street stock prices rose slightly yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average fell just short of reaching the 1,800 level. Investors' attention was again riveted on the stocks of corporations that reported quarterly earnings.

title: E.F. HUTTON POSTS LOSS
description: Salomon Inc., the huge investment banking and commodities trading group, yesterday reported a 19.3 percent decline in net earnings for the second quarter, to $117 million, from $145 million the year earlier, after being hit with steep losses in bond and oil trading.

title: Xerox Net Drops 44.5%
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter plunged 44.5 percent, primarily because of a $95 million gain from discontinued operations in the 1985 quarter and weak capital spending that has reduced the demand for office equipment.

title: Poetry Prize to Feldman
description: Irving Feldman, an author and teacher, has been awarded the 50th prize for ''distinguished poetic achievement'' by the Academy of American Poets. Mr. Feldman, a professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, is the author of eight collections of poetry, the most recent being ''All of Us Here,'' released last month by Viking-Penguin.

title: AMERADA, TENNECO OFF
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, said yesterday that its net income for the second quarter, helped partly by improved margins for petroleum products and chemicals, rose 50.3 percent.

title: ALEX BROWN & SONS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public Feb. 28, 1986. Year-ago results are presented as if the company had been public in the year-ago periods.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Los Angeles yesterday, on the trial arising from the deaths of three people in the filming of a movie, misstated the result of a previous case involving James Neal, the defense lawyer. When Mr. Neal defended Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana on charges of political corruption the jury was unable to agree on a verdict. The Governor was acquitted at a second trial in which Mr. Neal did not participate.

title: SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.M.C. Expects Losses Until 1988
description: The American Motors Corporation said it expects to lose money this year and next, but predicted that a new line of midsize cars would pull it into the black in 1988. A.M.C., in which the state-owned French car group Renault is controlling shareholder, also said it expects annual profits through 1990 if its new product plan works because of its ability to use credits for past losses.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I plight thee my troth.'' - Prince Andrew.

title: IN A PINCH, PICK SCHATZEDER
description: Partly because of the 24-man roster, 13 National League pitchers have been called on to pinch-hit a total of 28 times in 1986. Twelve of them have combined for just two singles in 18 appearances, but the 13th, Dan Schatzeder of Montreal, is 4 for 10 in the role, and his overall batting average is even better.

title: BRING ON THE GUESTS, THE MORE THE BETTER
description: IN our rented vacation house in northern Maine we have five guest beds available after our own family is installed, and they are rarely empty. This is not due to a rush of guilt on my part after years of freeloading. It is the result of a discovery about vacation time that markedly differs from the pattern adhered to by many New Yorkers, who seem to be satisfied with a period of vegetation, reading, sleeping and shopping.

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a non-recurring net charge of $4 million resulting from a writedown of certain assets and restructuring costs, net of a gain on the sale of certain assets.

title: Jacques Gelman Dies; Art Collector Was 74
description: Jacques Gelman, a prominent collector of 20th-century art and for many years the partner and producer of Cantinflas, the Mexican comedian, died Wednesday at a hospital in Houston where he had gone for a heart operation. He was 74 years old and lived in Mexico City and New York.

title: John Henry Won't Run
description: John Henry, the 11-year-old gelding who is the career earnings leader among race horses, will not run in the Aug. 31 Arlington Million, according to his owner, Sam Rubin. Rubin, who put John Henry back into training last month after a nine-month retirement, has decided not to make the $75,000 supplementary payment due today for the race. Instead, he hopes to race in the Del Mar Handicap Sept. 1.

title: PLEDGE OF TRUTH AND FAITH BY A DUKE AND A DUCHESS
description: At its core, under all the layers of pomp, circumstance and tabloid romanticizing, was the simple and dignified marriage ceremony of the established church in which the Queen's second son today told his bride, ''I plight thee my troth.''

description: b-Includes an investment tax credit of $30,144,000. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: Hughes Tool Takes Write-Off
description: The Hughes Tool Company, the world's biggest maker of oil-well drilling bits, said today that the ''collapse'' in drilling activity caused it to write down assets $495.7 million in the second quarter.

title: CITY-STATE DISCORD ON PEDESTRIAN-VEHICLE INJURIES
description: City and state officials cannot agree whether the number of pedestrians hit by vehicles in New York City rose or fell last year.

title: SENATORS HEAR OF ARMY'S PROBLEMS WITH MUNITIONS THEFTS
description: The Army is unable to control the theft of large amounts of weapons, ammunition and explosives, which end up being sold on the black market, Congressional investigators told a Senate panel today.

title: O'NEILL PROPOSES CONGRESS MOUNT ATTACK ON DRUGS
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill, flanked by 11 chairmen of House committees, today called for a bipartisan House effort to develop a comprehensive drug law and bring it to the floor for a vote by Sept. 10.

title: THE PEOPLE, JOYOUS AND JOSTLING, TAKE HISTORY AND TRADITION IN THEIR STRIDE
description: Out among the crowds, the commoners were hardly commanded to watch, and their fascination with the royal wedding parade seemed as basic as Chaucer: the chance to witness love professed and life moving forward as a continuing tale.

title: US WEST PLAN WEIGHED
description: The Justice Department is considering a proposal by U S West, the Denver-based regional telephone company, that it be authorized to deal in investments such as stocks and bonds. The phone company pledged, in a request for expedited consideration filed a week ago, that it be allowed to set up a subsidiary to enter the securities and commodities brokerage business. U S West pledged not to use telephone company assets to finance the new company nor to allow its telephone business to do any special favors for the new entity.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The wooden soffits on our 50-year-old house need paint, but to avoid maintenance - the land slopes and the soffits are up high - I want to cover them with aluminum soffits, some with perforations. However, the old soffits appear to be moldy or dirty, particularly on one side. Must the wood be cleaned before the aluminum is installed? A.If the stains are mold or mildew, they should be washed off first, or they will spread and could do other damage. Someone will have to climb up to install the aluminum anyway, so the mold can be washed off at that time with a bleach solution. If you are putting aluminum over wood, the aluminum should have openings its entire length, not at intervals. Q.Believe it or not, my wristwatch, which has a quartz movement and a plastic case and strap, became stuck to my bureau several weeks ago. Prying with a knife scratched the finish, and hot water didn't help. The watch is running fine and is causing many laughs. How can I get it off? A.Try cold cream. Lift the plastic as high as you can; spread the cream under it, and let soak an hour two. Pry with a plastic scraper - the kind for removing ice from windshields or for defrosting refrigerators and freezers. Used with care, these won't scratch the wood or finish.

description: The six jurors in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League and its commissioner, Pete Rozelle, began deliberations yesterday, 64 days after they were selected to hear the case in Federal District Court.

description: Nineteen people and a company were indicted today on charges of giving or receiving bribes in exchange for military contracts.

title: Fruehauf Delayed On Going Private
description: The Fruehauf Corporation's managers must wait until late August before taking the company private and in the interim must negotiate with the investor Asher B. Edelman on his attempt to acquire the truck-trailer maker, a Federal judge ruled today. Mr. Edelman has been seeking to buy Fruehauf since March, first through a proxy fight and later through a series of public offers to shareholders.

description: An Indiana businessman's gift of 25,000 pounds of ice arrived this afternoon, making this parched town the coolest spot in the sizzling South.

title: Topics; Leveling Influences; Lunch Loophole
description: Few tax loopholes are so widely criticized, yet so well preserved, as the deductibility of the business lunch. Hopes for eliminating it altogether in the new tax bill were in vain, but tax reformers have scored a small triumph: both the House and Senate bills would cut the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses to 80 percent.

description: The Textron Corporation said that net income in the second quarter jumped 26.1 percent, to $61.3 million, or $1.48 a share, from $48.6 million, or $1.34 a share, a year earlier. Revenues increased 13.7 percent, to $1.13 billion, from $994.8 million.

The Oz-like vista of lower Manhattan at night serves to confirm what so many citizens of the metropolis have always maintained: this, indeed, is the center of the universe.

''I have been given medical clearance to return to baseball and I am eager to rejoin my teammates as soon as possible,'' Boyd said in a statement.

Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: CITY PLANS TO CURTAIL AND CONTROL PERMITS FOR OFFICIAL PARKING
description: In a move to cut traffic congestion in the City Hall area, all parking permits for city employees - estimated to number 15,000 - will be eliminated next Feb. 1, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Nixon Tapes
description: In September the National Archives plans to open to the public 8,500 White House audio- and videotapes made in the Nixon Administration, but officials do not anticipate any objections by the former President or his aides. The tapes are those of the White House Communications Agency and record public appearances and speeches by Mr. Nixon, his Vice President, Spiro T. Agnew, and others, as well as the Watergate proceedings in Congress and television news programs.

No, it says in a careful and welcome new report; transplant surgery is not just rich man's medicine. It is for every American who needs it and meets the medical criteria.

title: 'We're Puttin' on the Ritz,' A Comedy Special on CBS
description: Update a traditional screwball comedy with 80's glitz, throw in a tablespoon of ''Upstairs Downstairs,'' and add a dash of ''Dallas'' in New York and you have ''We're Puttin' on the Ritz,'' the one-hour comedy-adventure special that can be seen tomorrow at 8 P.M. on CBS. Inside every secretary and chauffeur, the show tells us, there is a rich snob struggling to be born. No sooner will the keeper of the townhouse leave than his servants will pretend to be their master.

In a speech in North Carolina the other day, he took to task two fellow Democrats, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia, for organizing groups that he said threaten Democratic unity in the fall elections.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Black Rock Coalition Orchestra, Prospect Park Band Shell, Prospect Park West at 10th Street, Brooklyn (718-768-0699). The electric guitarist Vernon Reid is a prime mover behind the Black Rock Coalition Orchestra, which celebrates the contributions black musicians are making to contemporary rock, of both the commercial and the more futuristic varieties. The compositions of precursors like Sly Stone account for some of the material. But members are reportedly composing more and more original music, and with Mr. Reid, the keyboardist Geri Allen and the vocalist Bernard Fowler in the band, that can't be bad. The concert takes place Sunday at 8 P.M. in the band shell, which is a block from the Brooklyn Seventh Avenue stop on the F train. Admission is free. Art Farmer-Benny Golson Jazztet featuring Curtis Fuller, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near West Fourth Street (242-1785). Three horns, three rhythm - the classic format for playing the music once called hard bop. It was good enough for Art Blakey's mid-60's Jazz Messengers, good enough for the original Art Farmer-Benny Golson Jazztet, and it's still good enough for the Jazztet, which has matured, refined the music but retained its feeling and punch. Mr. Farmer's trumpet and fluegelhorn are warmly thoughtful, Mr. Golson is as persuasive an exponent of the Coleman Hawkins-Ben Webster approach to the tenor saxophone as you'll encounter and Curtis Fuller is twice the trombonist he was in the 60's, which is saying a lot. Mr. Golson's richly evocative tunes and careful arrangements are the finishing touch.

title: HOUSTON SET FOR START OF SPORTS FESTIVAL
description: It is hot, it is humid and the unemployment rate here is nearly 3 points higher than the national average. Yet, for all of its natural and man-made troubles, this sprawling Texas city has used sports to deflect - at least temporarily -the effects of the searing heat and sagging economy.

DEAL WITH THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS?;
YES: BLACKS MAY RUN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has now finally agreed to meet Oliver Tambo, the president of the African National Congress, while President Reagan has warned of the danger of a Communist takeover in South Africa. The question is once again in the forefront: how far is the A.N.C. influenced by Communists and Moscow?

description: The Police Department will double the size of its special anticrack unit by next month to intensify its drive against the spread of the drug, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres continued to say today that his surprise meetings with King Hassan of Morocco were a success, although he acknowledged that there had been no breakthrough in Middle East peace efforts.

description: The U.S. Home Corporation, a home builder with headquarters in Houston, said that its board had unanimously rejected the $367 million buyout proposal made by the Pacific Realty Corporation.

description: John M. Nelson, who has spent his entire career at the Norton Company, a maker of abrasives, engineering materials and petroleum and drilling products, was named the concern's president and chief operating officer yesterday. The post was last held in 1980 by Donald R. Melville, now the chairman and chief executive officer.

description: The last open door to Western Europe, West Berlin, has in recent weeks been swamped by a flow of people from the third world seeking asylum. And this has put new strains on the fragile fabric of East-West understandings underpinning this city's peculiar status.

Knievel Is Fined $200
description: Evel Knievel, charged with soliciting for immoral purposes, pleaded guilty Wednesday to an amended charge of disorderly conduct and was fined $200. The motorcyclist and stunt man had been charged with approaching Cheri Williams, an undercover police officer, on June 26.

description: b-Includes a charge of $1.8 million and $600,000 for the latest and year- ago 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a non-recurring net gain of $3.2 million.

title: Salt Lake City Parade Honors Utah Pioneers
description: Thousands of people lined a parade route here today to begin an annual celebration honoring Utah's settlers.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNION SQUARE TO FLATIRON: A RENAISSANCE IN THE MAKING
description: WHAT was once the mercantile center of the city has, after nearly a century of languishing, flowered again as an attractive neighborhood, a new scene on the eternally changing stage of New York. These are the blocks between Fifth Avenue and Irving Place, from Union Square to 23d Street.

title: 1,000 DOCUMENTS FOR SECRET AIRCRAFT CANNOT BE FOUND, HOUSE PANEL TOLD
description: The Lockheed Corporation cannot find more than a thousand secret documents concerning an Air Force fighter so secret that the Pentagon will not concede it exists, and the company's chairman said today, ''Our internal laxness is inexcusable.''

title: FILM: BY STEPHEN KING,'MAXIMUM OVERDRIVE'
description: WHEN in doubt, Stephen King relies on disembodied forces - a poltergeist, telekinesis, evil spirits and, in ''Maximum Overdrive,'' an all-out revolt of the machines. The glass-breaking, blood-spattering, flame-spurting melee opens today at Movieland Eighth Street and other theaters.
