description: b-Included losses of $1 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 6 months. The latest periods include a $54 million after-tax charge for a special separation program that was partly offset by a $10 million after-tax gain on asset sales. The year-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued operations and a change in accounting for pension costs.

title: Lincoln Was Harsher
description: To the Editor:''The Sandinista Road to Stalinism'' presents a vicious caricature of Nicaraguan reality. Analogy with Lincoln's response to internal dissent during the Civil War offers a more reasoned approach to assessing Nicaraguan events.

title: QUEENS AND KINGS OF THE ROAD
description: When Dormand Melte leaves for work each day, he climbs out of a bed tucked behind the cab of a 16-wheel truck, slips behind its steering wheel, starts its diesel engine and heads for Kansas City, Albuquerque, New York or someplace else. Right beside him is his wife, Alice.

title: FALL FROM WINDOW INJURES A 1-YEAR-OLD AT QUEENS BUILDING
description: A 1-year-old girl fell nearly 20 feet from a window of her family's apartment in Queens yesterday, the third small child to fall from a window in the city in two days. She was not seriously injured.

title: Saluting the Mona Lisa Of Subway Stations
description: The journey lasted minutes but extended back decades - to the days when subway passengers waited under diamond-patterned skylights and herringbone-patterned vaults, under chandeliers and green glazed tiles proclaiming ''City Hall.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on the Washington Talk page on July 2 about the signing of the Declaration of Independence incorrectly described the illustration. (A detail from the illustration also appeared in the News Quiz on July 5.) It was a Currier & Ives engraving of a painting by John Trumbull.

title: FILM: BRAD RIJN STARS IN 'PERFECT STRANGERS'
description: LARRY COHEN is a writer-director-producer of action-thriller-horror movies, which are particularly popular on videocassettes. The titles include ''It's Alive,'' parts one and two, with part three promised; ''Black Caesar'' and ''Hell Up in Harlem,'' which is part two of ''Black Caesar''; ''The Demon''; ''Full Moon High''; ''Housewife''; ''Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover,'' and ''Q - The Winged Serpent.'' Although none of these has made Mr. Cohen a household name, he has won admirers among critics, and this week and next the Public Theater is throwing a mini-Cohen festival, consisting of two productions that until now have not been shown in New York.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB O'HARE AIR TRAFFIC ERRORS
description: Air traffic controllers in the Chicago area have made errors in 15 incidents since Jan. 1, and officials of two Federal agencies are disagreeing over how to avert potential hazards.

title: A GASTRONOMIC GUIDE TO THE SAVVIEST NEW RESTAURANT TURF IN THE CITY
description: It is no exaggeration to say that the neighborhood that includes Union Square and the Flatiron Building is the hottest new restaurant turf in Manhattan. Savvy restaurateurs have followed - or in some cases preceded - publishing companies, public-relations agencies and apartment hunters who have fled higher-priced midtown. Former industrial and commercial spaces are being converted into cavernous dining rooms with soaring ceilings and spiffed-up period design highlights.

title: Surgery for an Expo
description: Andres Galarraga, the rookie first baseman who is on the Montreal Expos' 15-day disabled list, will undergo surgery on his right knee today and will probably not resume playing until Sept. 1. The Expos had hoped the injury could be healed by rest and therapy.

title: IN SEARCH OF COOL IN THE HEAT
description: Tama Janowitz's air-conditioner is faltering. It makes too much noise, she said, and barely keeps her West Village apartment cool. So when the temperature and humidity edge upward, she grabs Lulu and Beep-beep, her two Yorkshire terriers, and heads for a nearby butcher shop where she wanders in and out of the meat locker.

title: ART: A POLITICAL EDGE IN NEIGHBORHOOD SHOW
description: A NEIGHBORHOOD invitational art exhibition is probably not the sort of show to make the general public's mouth water. It promises work by people for whom art is not a vocation. It also has the potential to be self-righteous or self-serving - particularly in those New York City streets where it would be very much in a gallery's interest to be on good terms with the community. In short, it is the sort of exhibition that needs to be organized with intelligence and care.

title: PANHANDLE EASTERN LOSS
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today that it lost $516.1 million in the quarter ended June 30 because of special charges of $528.9 million. The company had earned $125 million, or $2.83 a share in in 1985.

title: What Stipends Might Mean
description: Critics have long held, of course, that big-time college athletes are amateurs in name only. As recipients of scholarships keyed to their participation in football or basketball, they are compensated for playing their sports, the usual definition of a professional. And, although some courts have ruled otherwise, a series of judicial decisions have held that such players are in fact university employees, at least for purposes of qualifying for worker's compensation.

description: B. Rionda Braga, a sugar merchant and former president of the Francisco Sugar Group, an importing concern, died of a heart attack Tuesday while vacationing in London.

At the new Cadillac Bar, a rough-edged Tex-Mex watering hole and restaurant on West 21st Street, a credible version is being rustled up at lunch and dinner.

title:
DEAL WITH THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS?;
NO: IT IS CONTROLLED BY COMMUNISTS
description: Although most Americans hate apartheid and want South Africa's blacks to have a chance to lead decent lives, both the Reagan Administration and its leading critics are acting in ways that are likely to destroy any chance of success the blacks might have - by helping the African National Congress to gain the dominant role in opposition to apartheid. The most useful thing that Americans can do for South African blacks now is to help them make sure that their opposition movement is free from the A.N.C.

description: Policemen shot and killed a man today who had tossed a packet of garbage at Pope John Paul II's summer residence and then rushed police officers with an ax.

Called up Jackie Gutierrez, infielder, and John Stefero, catcher, from Rochester, and Tom Dodd, utility player, from Charlotte of the Southern League.

title: Market Place; Schlumberger Payout Outlook
description: DIVIDEND cuts in one of the nation's most troubled industries - oilfield service and equipment - have become common. The Halliburton Company reduced its cash payments by 44 percent in May. Two days ago, Baker International halved its quarterly dividend - to 11.5 cents a share - while Hughes Tool, citing a ''collapse'' in drilling activity, slashed its quarterly payment to 2 cents from 12 cents.

title: Soetaert a Ranger
description: Phil Esposito, the Rangers' new vice president and general manager, yesterday announced his first acquisition for the club: Doug Soetaert, the veteran goaltender who most recently played for the Montreal Canadiens, the current Stanley Cup champions. The 31-year-old Soetaert, who accepted a three-year contract, was drafted by the Rangers in 1975 as their second selection.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Historic Site to Observe Its 300th Anniversary
description: A birthday party tomorrow and Sunday will mark the 300th anniversary of the founding of Livingston Manor, one of the feudal fiefdoms created in New York before the American Revolution.

title: Goldwyn tries eclectic mix of stories.
description: ''I THINK basically that writing is the key to movies,'' said Samuel Goldwyn Jr. ''I think the public doesn't really go to movies for directors. They basically go to see stories. The architect of the movie is the writer.''

title: HOSPITAL HEARINGS HAVE A FAMILIAR RING
description: The public official's criticism of the public hospital system in New York City was strong and to the point. His investigations, he said, have ''uncovered critical drug shortages in some hospitals, and the purchase of expensive equipment that does not work or go unused.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fred Dean, the four-time Pro Bowl defensive end, has been put on waivers by the San Francisco 49ers. The 34-year-old Dean underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee a year ago and had only three sacks for the season. ... Another defensive end, Dave Lindstrom of the Kansas City Chiefs, announced his retirement after playing in 98 consecutive games and missing only three since joining the Chiefs in 1978. He said he wanted to devote his time to a new Burger King franchise.

description: The police and other emergency services were given some unused radio frequencies by the Federal Communications Commission today, making it possible for one radio to be used to conduct routine business or coordinate rescues and pursuits across jurisdictional boundaries.

title: CLUB ACT CONJURES A 20'S CHANTEUSE
description: IT is New Year's Eve in 1929 when we meet Lily Walker, the character portrayed by Helen Schneider in her one-woman show, ''A Flapper's Folly.'' A nightclub singer in her late 20's, Lily is still smarting from an unhappy love affair with a glamorous but faithless New York bootlegger named Frankie. Nostalgic and a little tipsy, Lily begins to reminisce. In a 90-minute theatrical collage of brief monologues and one-sided conversations, strung together with pop and blues songs, all from the 20's, Lily tells the story of the ill-fated relationship.

title: Science Digest
description: Hearst Magazines said that with the Sept. 19 issue it would cease publication of Science Digest, the monthly magazine founded in 1937 and acquired by Hearst in 1959. Time Inc. which owns Discover, also a science monthly, will purchase certain assets, including the subscription lists of Science Digest and the trademark. Science Digest said it published 84.7 pages of advertising in the first six months of this year, down 46 percent from 156.9 pages a year ago.

title: FROM TIGHTS TO TAPS: BALLET GOES BROADWAY

Mr. Barbee is a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater. But Broadway audiences can see him these days center stage at the Royale Theater in ''Song & Dance,'' where he stars as Joe, the nice guy from Nebraska to whom Bernadette Peters loses her heart.

title: 'FATHER'S DAY,' A NEW COMEDY ON 7
description: ''FATHER'S DAY'' is amiable; it is also pointless. It won't assault you; it won't enchant you, either. It is one of those programs that start with the wisp of an idea, and then lose even the wisp. It means to be up-to-date and new, but its real antecedent is ''The Life of Riley.'' It is another show about a befuddled father.

title: Reliance Offering
description: Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings Inc. said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of about 24.3 million common shares, valued at between $16 and $19 a share, or about $389 million. Upon completion of the offering, which had been expected, Mr. Steinberg, members of his family and certain family trusts will own about 67 percent of Reliance, an insurance and financial-services company. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the First Boston Corporation and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. will co-manage the offering the United States.

title: Power Failure Halts 2 Summerfare Shows
description: A power failure on Wednesday night that affected areas of Purchase, White Plains and Scarsdale, N.Y., also interrupted two performances at the Pepsico Summerfare festival at the State University at Purchase. They were ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and ''Cosi Fan Tutte.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JAZZ AND DOO-WOP Rock and pop are general terms that purport to describe a wide variety of music. This weekend, an organization called ''Celebrate Brooklyn'' (which also covers a lot of ground) will present three different programs of pop and rock at the Prospect Park Band Shell, near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Tonight at 8, the violinist Noel Pointer will perform with his jazz group and the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, under the direction of Tania Leon; the program will be made up of selections from Mr. Pointer's six albums. Tomorrow night at 8, the Harptones and Reparata and the Del-Rons, two ''doo-wop'' groups, will present some of their hit songs from the 1950's and 60's. Finally, Sunday night at 8, the Black Rock Coalition, directed by the guitarist and songwriter Vernon Reid, will present its own distinctive blend of rock, blues and jazz at the band shell. All events are free. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: JWP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Joan Armatrading, Pier 84, 45th Street and 12th Avenue (249-8870). In the 12 years that Joan Armatrading has been making records, the West Indian-born, British singer-songwriter has probably written and recorded more songs that have become cult classics than any other pop composer of her generation. Artistically, Miss Armatrading, now 35 years old, is a fascinating mass of crosscurrents and contradictions. Her music synthesizes folk, reggae and, on her later albums, a harder electronic rock in combinations that are often surprising. Her rich, swooping folk-jazz voice is also interestingly at odds with a stage personality that is modest to the point of shyness. While her first-person dramatic monologues have the quirky complexity of confessional songs, they embrace too many different characters and points of view to be taken as anything but fiction. Expect to hear the whole range of Miss Armatrading's work, including ''Show Some Emotion,'' ''Love and Affection'' and ''Willow.'' Graham Nash opens the show, which is tonight at 7:30. Tickets are $15.

title: Rich Farmers, and the Rest of Us

title: Convicted Spy Agrees To Reveal Data He Sold
description: Ronald W. Pelton, who was convicted June 5 of spying for the Soviet Union, has agreed to tell intelligence officials about the National Security Agency secrets he sold to Soviet agents, his lawyer and a Federal prosecutor said Wednesday.

title: JAZZ: MIKE LIPSKIN, PIANIST
description: MIKE LIPSKIN, a young stride pianist who left New York 10 years ago to settle in San Francisco, is back in town for a short run at Hanratty's, Second Avenue near 92d Street, through tomorrow and an appearance next Tuesday at the 92d Street Y's Jazz in July program, ''Stride Piano and Other Delights.''

title: SCREEN: 'OUT OF BOUNDS,' A THRILLER
description: A BETTER title for ''Out of Bounds'' might be ''Tom Sawyer Goes to L.A.'' And even Anthony Michael Hall, who made nerds seem lovable in John Hughes's ''Sixteen Candles'' and ''The Breakfast Club,'' can't do much to reconcile the opposites here. Richard Tuggle's new film wants to be a realistic thriller, but it merely acts out kids' fantasies of heroism and adventure, with drugs and rock music thrown in for a contemporary twist.

title: MANION REBUTS CRITICS ON DAY AFTER CONFIRMATION
description: A day after the Senate narrowly staved off a challenge to his confirmation as a Federal appellate judge, Daniel A. Manion met with reporters today to address the questions that had been raised about his qualifications.

title: GREATER GROWTH IN '87 IS NOW SEEN BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration is now forecasting substantially more economic growth in 1987 than it expected just five and a half months ago, according to confidential budget documents.

title: SUSPECT IN RAPE IN NEWPORT LINKED TO EAST SIDE ATTACKS
description: A 29-year-old New York man arrested Tuesday on charges that he raped a woman and stole $1 million in cash and jewels from a mansion in Newport, R.I., is also suspected in a series of rapes and burglaries on the Upper East Side since early June, the police said yesterday.

title: DONALD vs. GOLIATH
description: It was close to noon Wednesday in the packed courtroom in the United States Court House in Foley Square, and Frank Rothman, a rather scholarly looking man in spectacles and gray suit and red tie, was concluding his two-and-a-half-hour summation in defense of his client, who is being sued for $1.69 billion in damages and sundry other items.

title: DOC POMUS STILL WRITES, ROCKS AND RAMBLES
description: ''WHENEVER you hear about a tribute show, right away you think the guy is getting ready to go over the hill or something,'' Doc Pomus growled amiably this week, in reference to the concert in his honor that is being presented at the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16-17 tomorrow night. ''But I'm as active as I ever was, writing songs with people like Dr. John and Willie DeVille. And I'm still stumblin' in and out of those late-night joints all the time to hear music.''

title: SCREEN: 'HEARTBURN,' STREEP AND NICHOLSON
description: NORA EPHRON'S novel ''Heartburn'' was stuffed with food jokes, sex jokes, food-sex jokes and Jewish food-sex jokes. It was like a bowl of rice pudding dotted with raisins. If you liked raisins and didn't mind rice pudding, it made an O.K. nosh. In her script for the movie version of the novel, Ms. Ephron has tried to expand to a spread of the sort that confronts one at weddings. Some of the dishes are tasty, but a meal it's not.

description: The Westchester County Medical Center reported today that infant formula in the pediatric division had been tainted with a laxative, but it was discovered last Saturday before any babies received it, according to James Patrick, a spokesman. Hospital workers found the tainted formula in two bottles after their suspicions were aroused when a baby being admitted showed signs of suffering from a laxative, Mr. Patrick said. He said the child, whose condition is not serious, is under the jurisdiction of Child Protective Services, an agency of the county Department of Social Services.

title: SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CITY OPERA: MASSENET'S 'WERTHER'
description: THE only plausible way to approach ''Werther'' is to assume that the 20th century never happened. That is exactly what the New York City Opera has done in the evocative new production of Massenet's opera that had its first performance Wednesday evening. Since there is almost no way that the psychological, religious and social dilemmas that faced Goethe's sorrowful young hero in the 18th century can be translated into modern terms, this Lotfi Mansouri production invites one to enter a time warp. We are asked to bring historical imagination to bear on a situation that, as expressed in the original novel, set a whole generation of young Germans to contemplating suicide in emulation of the romantically frustrated Werther.

title: ANOTHER SUCH VICTORY
description: President Reagan and Attorney General Meese are proud of having won Senate confirmation of Daniel A. Manion's appointment to the important Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals. Here, step by step, is how their ''victory'' was achieved: 1. The Senate Judiciary Committee, which has a Republican majority, rejected Mr. Manion's nomination on a 9-to-9 tie vote, on grounds that he was not qualified. But Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, Republican, and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Democrat, voted to send the nomination to the Senate unapproved. 2. Before the floor vote, the Justice Department notified David Durenberger of Minnesota, Democrat, that his choice for a Federal district judgeship, David Doty, would be nominated after being held up for 10 months. On June 26, Mr. Durenberger, who had opposed the Manion nomination, voted for it. 3. That day, after getting what they thought was a pledge from Slade Gorton of Washington, Republican, to oppose Mr. Manion, Democrats agreed to a plea by Bob Dole, Republican, the Senate majority leader, for a vote. But Mr. Dole said that two Republican supporters of Mr. Manion, Paula Hawkins of Florida and Bob Packwood of Oregon, were out of town. The Democrats agreed to withhold two of their own votes to balance these absentees. 4. Barry Goldwater of Arizona was not on the floor for the vote. Republican leaders, who represented Mr. Goldwater as a Manion supporter, prevailed on Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, Republican, an opponent of the Manion nomination, to withhold her vote to balance Mr. Goldwater's absence. 5. Mr. Packwood later said he had not asked for his vote to be ''paired'' and did not know how he would have voted.

She told reporters that a letter had been sent to Comecon suggesting a meeting of experts in Geneva in late September ''to study ways of establishing links.''

title: ADELYN DOHME BREESKIN, 90, CURATOR AT NATIONAL MUSEUM
description: Adelyn Dohme Breeskin, senior curatorial adviser at the National Museum of American Art in Washington, a leading figure in the museum world and a champion of contemporary art, died of kidney failure yesterday at a hospital near Lake Garda, Italy. She celebrated her 90th birthday in Washington last week, then left for Europe to study Romanesque architecture.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART: FROM JAN GROTH, TAPESTRY AND DRAWING
description: THERE is something really rather peculiar about the art of Jan Groth, the Norwegian draftsman and tapestry designer, whose work can be seen both at the Guggenheim Museum through Sept. 1 and at the Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, through Aug. 8. At a first glance, it is difficult to say why it should be so compelling. In the tapestries, a white line shoots this way and that across a field that reads as the deepest imaginable black. It has an effect of urgency, in every case, and it also has an effect of integrity. We believe that these tapestries are the work of a good artist and a serious man, and we notice that even when they get really big (99 by 169 inches, for instance) they do not look inflated.

description: Depressed oil prices hurt Britain's trade position in June, with the visible deficit showing little improvement at $928 million, according to Government figures published today.

description: b-Net loss

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PUNCH GIVES TYSON AN EDGE
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight from Catskill, N.Y., meets Marvis Frazier of Philadelphia today in Glens Falls, N.Y., in a bout that has many boxing people saying Frazier is overmatched.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FARM LOSS IS PUT AT OVER $2 BILLION IN DROUGHT REGION
description: Livestock and crop losses from the drought that has parched eight Middle-Atlantic and Southern states are estimated at $2 billion or more, twice as much as earlier this week, state agricultural officials said today.

title: TOWN PROTESTS PLAN BY JERSEY TO STORE RADON
description: Minutes after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Thursday to allow radon-contaminated soil to be shipped here, residents gathered to protest.

title: Pentagon Audit Delays Grow
description: When military contractors want to close their books on a project, they have to get in line, sometimes waiting two or more years.

title: THEODORE LAYMON
description: Theodore Laymon, a retired newspaper and radio news editor, died as the result of a blood clot Wednesday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Southold, L.I.

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results include the consolidation of Ingalls Associated Inc., which was purchased in the second quarter.

title: Wheeling Steel Reports Losses
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, the nation's 10th-largest steel concern, said today that its loss for the second quarter widened to $60.3 million, from $50 million last year.

title: Dole Woos the Right
description: Those whose business it is to watch Presidential aspirants have observed that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who has made it clear he is not loath to consider the Republican nomination, has been courting the party's right wing.

title: Judge Wald Moves Up
description: Amid the swirl of attention given to personnel changes on the Supreme Court, another event of judicial significance has escaped much notice: The elevation today of Judge Patricia M. Wald to chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: MASSTOR SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes foreign exchange loss of $83,000 for the quarter and a foreign exchange gain of $76,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes foreign exchange loss of $24,000 for the quarter and a foreign exchange gain of $177,000 for the 6 months. Both periods also included a loss of $946,000 from a writeoff of equipment.

title: CALL FOR AN ARAB MEETING
description: The Secretary General of the Arab League today called for an emergency summit meeting in the aftermath of King Hassan II's talks with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 29. The 1986 share earnings were affected by an accounting change, adding about 1 cent a share in the quarter and 2 cents a share in the 6 months. The company said the year-ago results have been restated to reflect capitalization of software, which increased net income by $208,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and $252,000, or 6 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich Conn., said its London-based subsidiary, Gallaher Ltd., had completed the acquisition of the ordinary and preferred shares of NSS Newsagents P.L.C. for about $120 million.

title: Heritage-Rollins
description: Heritage Communications Inc. of Des Moines, the cable television operator, has agreed to buy 2.7 million shares, or 18.4 percent, of Rollins Communications Inc. from the New York investor Mario J. Gabelli, and a group of companies he controls, for $41 a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Gabelli group said that, under the agreement, Heritage must gain control of Rollins, an Atlanta-based television company, before it will sell the shares. Rollins, based in Atlanta, is a holding company that operates television stations and outdoor advertising.

title:
PATENTS;
Electrical Connector
description: I. Martin Spier, president of Beacon Plastic and Metal Products Inc. in New York, was granted patent No. 4,601,528 this week for a hermetic self-locking electrical connector that he regards as particularly helpful in outdoor and indoor electronic use where moisture causes shorts. The connector is to be made of two plastic materials.

title: How to Curb New York Corruption
description: Many of the seemingly solid proposals to curb New York City corruption are off the mark.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: The company said its primary share earnings comparison for this year was adversely affected by the company's prior year conversion of its $55 million of 9 l/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures and its $40 million of 9 3/4 percent subordinated convertible notes into a total of 3,756,000 common shares.

title: The Growth Rate Held Hostage
description: News that the rate of economic expansion shrank to 1.1 percent in the spring quarter sharpens the dilemma that has long haunted the Reagan Administration. With budget and trade deficits still mounting, and interest rates still hanging too high, what to do now for a sluggish economy?

title: NURSES AND DRUG ABUSE: NEW WAYS TO HELP
description: A growing number of nurses are being identified as drug addicts, and are receiving treatment through volunteer, hospital and state-sponsored programs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday this week misidentified the company that makes illuminated golf balls. It is the Pick Point Sports Company of Mirror Lake, N.H.

title: With the Bags Packed But Nowhere To Go
description: For 62 Peace Corps trainees, what started out early this month as a two-year tour of Zaire ended before it began.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the combined results of Logicon and Chase, Rosen & Wallace.

title: Virginia Player Indicted
description: The president of the University of Virginia has responded to the news that an investigation into local cocaine trafficking had resulted in indictments against a member of the football team and two former football standouts.

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BSD MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SIKHS IN PUNJAB REPORTEDLY SLAY 15 HINDUS SINGLED OUT ON A BUS
description: Sikh extremists halted a bus in a rural area of the Punjab Friday, singled out the Hindu passengers and shot 15 of them to death, news agencies reported.

title: REAGAN SENDS ANSWER TO SOVIET ON ARMS PLAN
description: President Reagan formally responded today to arms control proposals offered by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, with a plan for deployment of a missile defense system, Administration officials said.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: BALLET: NEW DANCERS FOR CANADIANS' 'ALICE'
description: A new cast of principals from the National Ballet of Canada stepped into Glen Tetley's ''Alice'' Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House - with the result that the ballet retained all its heartwarming magic and whimsy.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING HAS LONG RECORD
description: A 38-year-old drifter who called two news organizations on Thursday and said he had killed a Manhattan man has a long record of arrests for threatening to kill three Presidents and has been repeatedly hospitalized for treatment of mental illness, the authorities said yesterday.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the sales decrease is primarily attributed to the closing of its Graham, W.Va., plant in December.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This is part of a $2 billion problem. Explain. 2. Sarah Ferguson will not be called Princess because, less than two hours before her marriage to Prince Andrew, Queen Elizabeth II conferred on the Prince a title traditionally given second sons of the British Royal Family. What title is it and who last used it? 3. July 23 marked the 100th anniversary of Steve Brodie's legendary leap, actual or imaginary. Explain. 4. ''I think the West, for my part, can go to hell.'' Who made this statement, what were the circumstances, and what possibility was subsequently raised for the first time, perhaps in an effort to temper the situation? 5. ''We won by one vote,'' said President Reagan. ''A little lynch mob had organized resistance against his nomination.'' To what was he referring? 6. An incident at a Houston, Tex., night spot, Cooter's Executive Games and Burgers, was of special interest to New Yorkers. Explain. 7. Test market research suggests that, contrary to long-accepted wisdom, increasing the amount of advertising for a product does not necessarily lead to higher sales. True or false? 8. ''We would have liked assistance of a different nature. But instead we got the invasion of Normandy,'' said a Bolivian official. To what was he referring? 9. To appear exclusive, many Manhattan restaurateurs are name-dropping. Explain. 10. By a vote of 406 to 0, the House of Representatives took an action for the first time in 50 years.

title: Adele Nathan, Author Of Books for Children
description: Adele Gutman Nathan, an author of 14 books for children, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Nathan, who lived in New York City, was 86 years old.

title: FILM: WILDER AND RADNER IN 'HAUNTED HONEYMOON'
description: Humor and horror make an uneasy combination. The audience that has been set up to laugh may find it difficult to give out with a heartfelt scream. If the spooky old castle with curtains blowing and candles sputtering and strange types prowling the corridors and sneaking through hidden doors is plainly laid on in the interests of farce, then what's there to scream about?

title: Worker Killed by Elevator
description: An office building elevator plunged six stories Thursday, crushing Terry Brownell, 45 years old, an elevator serviceman, underneath it, and injuring a fellow worker, Douglas Kanuha, 30. Mr. Kanuha was in fair condition today at Denver General Hospital. The men were employees of the Continental Elevator Service Company. The elevator was on the sixth floor of a seven-story building, with Mr. Brownell in the elevator pit and Mr. Kanuha on top of the car, said Fire Capt. Rod Juniel.

title: TENTATIVE PACT REACHED IN DETROIT STRIKE
description: A tentative agreement on a new, three-year contract was reached just before midnight tonight, ending a 10-day strike by 7,000 municipal workers and 5,000 city employees who supported the walkout.

title: Bid for Sandgate
description: The Sandgate Corporation said its investment adviser, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., had determined that the British Car Auction Group P.L.C.'s $18.75-a-share, or $81.6 million, tender offer for Sandgate was financially unfair. Earlier this week British Car had increased the price from $18 a share, or $78.3 million. Sandgate said that the committee it had selected to review the offer had decided to remain neutral on the bid.

title: GRAND JURY TO GET CASE OF TWO METS
description: The case of two Mets accused of aggravated assault on a pair of Houston police officers will be submitted to a grand jury.

title: CHERNOBYL FALLOUT: APOCALYPTIC TALE AND FEAR
description: A prominent Russian writer recently produced a tattered old Bible and with a practiced hand turned to Revelations. ''Listen,'' he said, ''this is incredible: 'And the third angel sounded, and there fell a great star from heaven, burning as it were a lamp, and it fell upon the third part of the rivers, and upon the fountains of waters; and the name of the star is called wormwood: and the third part of the waters became wormwood; and many men died of the waters, because they were made bitter.' ''

title: New York's Stake In the Texaco Case
description: When an appellate court in Houston hears arguments next Thursday in Texaco v. Pennzoil, a basic principle of New York State contract law will be at stake.

title: Polar B'ar Link Sought In Death of Florida Man
description: A 51-year-old man died tonight after contracting meningitis, and the authorities were investigating whether eating a Polar B'ar ice cream bar had caused his illness.

title: Palladium Party For a Senator's Daughter
description: ''In case any of you out there don't know, I'm Maura,'' announced the only daughter of United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to 1,000 friends the other night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on July 18 (and a related article on July 19) about the arrest of a 26-year-old Brooklyn man, Tyrone Graham, in a series of sexual assaults misstated his address. It is 919 Park Place in Crown Heights, not 119 Park Place in Park Slope.

title: DANCE: CLARK CENTER PRESENTS 'DANCING FEET'
description: Toes tapped, heels thudded and legs kicked high at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday nights. It was time for ''Dancing Feet,'' a spirited weeklong celebration of that essential element of dance. Conceived by Louise Roberts, director of Clark Center, ''Dancing Feet'' is part of the center's Summer Dance '86 festival at the Fairbanks and will be seen there through Sunday.

title: Piedmont Airlines
description: Piedmont Airlines said it had ordered six Boeing 767-200 extended-range wide-body aircraft and had secured an option on another six. The value of the order, with delivery expected to begin in May 1987, was not disclosed. The new Boeing is a medium- to long-range wide body that seats 220 passengers.

title: PAYCO AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Day of Abrupt Changes
description: The end to the 10-day-old strike by Detroit's municipal unions came abruptly tonight after Mr. Cheek this afternoon withdrew a contract offer the union had been optimistic about.

title: Don't Regulate Air Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPELLING IT ALL OUT IN GLITTER
description: All that glitters these days may be a T-shirt, the ones in stenciled patterns of gold or silver.

title: One Death Is Reported In French Forest Fires
description: Strong winds fanned forest fires near the French Riviera today, killing at least one person and leaving devastated woodland, burned-out buildings and smoldering cars.

title: GAETTI HELPS TWINS SLOW DOWN YANKS
description: The Minnesota Twins went into last night's game against the Yankees with the worst record in the American League. Their staff earned-run average was 5.10, last in the major leagues. Opposing teams were batting .288 against them.

title: JUROR SAYS TAX INQUIRY LED TO CONVICTION OF NAVAL SPY
description: An Internal Revenue Service investigation of extravagant expenditures by Jerry A. Whiworth, coupled with records of money he received for spying, were the ''absolutely deadly evidence'' that led the jury to convict him of espionage and tax fraud Thursday, the jury foreman said in an interview today..

title: MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSRIAL CO LTD (JAPAN) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: United States dollar amounts are translated at the rate of U.S. $1 equals 167 yen. Share earnings are American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represents 10 shares of common stock.

title: IN WEARY WATERTOWN, AN ARMY OF HOPE AT FT. DRUM
description: At the turn of the century, this was home to prosperous lumberjacks and paper mill barons, and residents boasted of having more millionaires than in any other small city in America.

title: 2 ON TOWN COUNCIL HELD ON JERSEY DRUG CHARGES
description: Two members of the Town Council of this northern New Jersey community were arrested Thursday night on charges of operating a cocaine and marijuana ring with weekly sales of about $16,000, a county prosecutor said today.

title: 15-YEAR-OLD IS ARRESTED IN SHOOTING OF AN OFFICER
description: A 15-year-old youth, believed by police to be a member of a Chinatown gang, was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting a police officer during an exchange of gunfire in a lower Manhattan park early Tuesday, the police said.

title: No Charge in Twins' Deaths
description: The mother of 3-month-old twins who died of heat prostration Sunday after she left them alone in her car under a hot sun was released from jail today after a judge ruled she could not be held any longer. Judge Margaret Anderson of Municipal Court ordered that the mother, Beverly Jean Ernst, 25 years old, be released on her own recognizance because prosecutors had not filed criminal charges against her in the deaths.

title: HENDERSON DAY WALKER
description: Henderson Day (Bo) Walker, a sculptor known for his commemorative bronzes of black political and cultural leaders, died of pneumonia Thursday in Brooklyn.

title: EXPLOSION WOUNDS 24 NEAR CHILEAN PALACE
description: Senator Jesse Helms said today that a United States resident and a companion who were burned and dumped in a ditch in anti-Government protests in Chile this month were ''young Commu- &ist terrorists'' who were seen setting fire to a barricade.

title: NEVADA NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter results from a $1.7 million increase in its loan reserve, establishment of a $1 million reserve for foreclosed real estate and a $2.2 million charge relating to the trust department.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LLOYD UPSET BY No. 64 PLAYER
description: Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver saved the top-ranked United States from elimination today after Italy's Sandra Cecchini, ranked 64th in the world, upset Chris Evert Lloyd in the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. PICKS EDDY TO CHALLENGE DOOD FOR SENATE
description: Connecticut Republicans, facing a three-way contest for governor, opened their state convention tonight with the nomination by acclamation of Roger W. Eddy for the United States Senate.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 SAID TO BE INDICTED IN BIAS CASE
description: Three people, two of them University of Maryland basketball players, were indicted on drug charges today by the grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias, according to law enforcement officials close to the case.

title: Learning How to Read and Write Is True Vocational Training

When Barriers to Jews Fell at Yale and Banks

title: AFTER COURT VICTORY, A CONGRESS-MAN ELECT: ALTON RONALD WALDON JR.
description: Alton R. Waldon Jr. was visiting the Washington office of Representative Charles B. Rangel yesterday morning when he made a telephone call to New York City and got the news he had been hoping for: A three-judge Federal appeals panel had just upheld Mr. Waldon's contested election to fill the Queens Congressional seat held by the late Representative Joseph P. Addabbo.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Du Pont Heir Loses Bid To Control His Assets
description: A 29-year-old heir to the du Pont family fortune who gave or lent thousands of dollars to the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has lost a court fight to regain control of his $1.5 million estate.

title: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
LeMond Is Nearing Victory in Tour
description: Greg LeMond of the United States virtually clinched the Tour de France bicycle race today when he stretched his overall lead to more than three minutes over his teammate and rival, Bernard Hinault.

title: BancTexas Near Sale of Assets
description: The BancTexas Group Inc., moving another step closer to completing the sale of its assets, said that it had signed a definitive agreement with United Bankers Inc. to sell its four Houston-area banks. United Bankers, a bank holding company in Waco, Tex., with $765 million in assets, announced on July 11 that it intended to buy the unprofitable banks.

title: HEAD OF NASA ATTEMPTS TO CALM HOUSTON'S FEARS ON ROLE IN SPACE
description: Asserting that the Johnson Space Center would retain its pre-eminent role in the space program, the Administrator of the space agency made an effort today to calm extraordinary local fears about the center's future.

title: KOHLBERG BID SEEN ON SAFEWAY
description: The Bankers Trust Company, one of the nation's biggest banks, is lining up a multibillion-dollar loan among other banks to finance a client's takeover of Safeway Stores, banking sources dislosed yesterday.

title: Delta's Income Down by 73.6%
description: Delta Air Lines said it had earned $22.2 million, or 55 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down 73.6 percent from the $84.2 million, or $2.11 a share, it earned in the corresponding period in 1985.

title: TV: MOZART BY ZUCKERMAN AND PERLMAN
description: The Huberman Festival was a weeklong celebration of the violin that took place in Israel three years ago, designated to honor the late Bronislaw Huberman, a violinist who was also a founder of what is now the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. The artists who participated included Isaac Stern, Ida Haendel, Shlomo Mintz, Henryk Szeryng, Itzhak Perlman and Pinchas Zukerman - no dearth of talent.

title:
PATENTS;
Automated Office Plan Criticized
description: A REPORT by the General Accounting Office, made public by the House Committee on Government Operations, has recommended that no further funds be expended on a contract for the automation project of the Patent and Trademark Office until further assessments of it are made.

title: Death Toll in Bombing of Bus Is Lowered to 12 in Sri Lanka
description: The Government today lowered to 12 the death toll in a bus bombing that occurred on Thursday, saying the initial count of 31 was overstated because many bodies were dismembered.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Howser's Treatment
description: The Kansas City Royals said yesterday that Manager Dick Howser would undergo about five weeks of radiation treatments for the cancerous tumor found in his brain earlier this week, but the team declined to provide detailed results of pathological tests.

title: Short Polish Sci-Fi Film To Be Shown in Series
description: A short animated film from Poland, about a friendly visitor from outer space, is one of two science fiction films to be screened on Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street. Also featured at the free screening will be the 1956 film ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers.''

title: CASTLE, A.M. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TWO CONCRETE EXECUTIVES ACQUITTED OF FRAUD
description: Two top concrete-industry executives were acquitted by a jury in Manhattan yesterday of charges that they had stolen $23 million from two New York banks.

title: STRIKERS APPROVE PACT WITH CUTS AT WEYERHAEUSER
description: A six-week strike of loggers and sawmill workers against the Weyerhaeuser Company neared an end today with the announcement that a proposed settlement involving cuts in pay and benefits had been approved by the union representing most of the strikers.

title: Cheap Power Should Be Shared
description: Who should reap the multibillion-dollar windfall from the virtually cost-free hydropower produced on Federal waterways? Ideally the electricity would be sold for full market value, thereby encouraging conservation and generating revenue for the U.S. Treasury. But the courts have supported claims to that power by publicly owned municipal utilities. That is why bills passed by both houses of Congress, sharing the spoils with the much larger number of customers served by private licensees, deserve support. The task now is to resolve differences between the two bills before Congress adjourns.

title: WHEN WILL AMERICA MARKET ITS MYSTIQUE?
description: Never has one word so successfully undermined a nation's economy as ''Imported'' has done in America. This word has insinuated its way into the judgment of how Americans buy anything from a jar of mustard to a $50,000 sports car. No Marxist conspiracy could have aspired to more. Meanwhile,the trade deficit zooms ever upward.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $3,500,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and the 9 months includes a loss from discontinued operations of $8,704,770. c-After a loss of $5,502,771 for the quarter and $6,941,405 for the 9 months.

title: Congress's Doctor Replaced
description: The attending physician of the Congress is abruptly being released by the Navy from the job he has held for 13 years, to be replaced by another military doctor.

title: NEW CANDIDATE RAISES QUESTIONS FOR G.O.P. IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: After enduring growing embarrassment as both their candidates for Governor were forced to drop out of the race by disclosures about their background, Massachusetts Republicans this week finally picked a new contender: a wealthy businessman who is a former Democrat.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid on July 14, 1986.

title: BUSH CONSIDERING STOP IN MOROCCO
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking to nurture the recent Israeli-Moroccan initiative, tentatively decided today to have Vice President Bush stop in Morocco during a visit to the Middle East.

title: Gold Broker Is Penalized
description: Charles E. Federbush, one of the two former owners of Volume Investors, a brokerage house whose collapse last year was the source of a controversy in the gold market, signed a consent agreement with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday settling civil charges against him.

title: UNIVERSITY FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RULING BY A COURT KEEPS FETUS ALIVE
description: Caught in a dispute between the husband of a brain-dead woman and the father of her 21-week-old fetus, a hospital won a court order today to keep the woman alive so the fetus would have a chance to survive.

title: UNCOUPLED BETTING STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: The decision by the New Jersey Racing Commission to allow horses from the same stable to compete as separate betting interests in the Million Dollar Babies card at the Meadowlands Saturday night has sparked arguments among harness racing trainers and drivers.

title: Same Old Junk
description: New York City is having one of its periodic drug hysterias. These are characterized by overuse of the word ''epidemic,'' news pictures of people buying narcotics on street corners, TV film of angry citizens declaring that dope dealers are destroying their neighborhoods and demands for police crackdowns.

title: Bliss at Dawn On Brighton Beach
description: The sun rose at 5:45 A.M. yesterday, which is when Violetta Kelner went for a dip in the privacy of her own ocean.

title: SCALIA'S MIDWEST COLLEAGUES CITE HIS LOVE OF DEBATE, POKER AND PIANO
description: On the road leading to his nomination to the Supreme Court, Antonin Scalia spent a decade in the Middle West, six years in Cleveland, where he had his only stint in private practice, and four in Chicago, where he taught at the University of Chicago, a bastion of conservative legal thought.

title: Charter Debt Plan Accord Reached
description: The Charter Company said today that it had reached an agreement with representatives of its creditors and equity security holders on a reorganization plan that would enable it to emerge from Chapter 11 protection of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Wanted: Speechwriters
description: The White House speechwriting team, under some internal criticism for providing President Reagan with indifferent material in recent speeches, remains in a state of flux. Patrick J. Buchanan, director of communications, had hoped to name a new chief speechwriter to succeed the departed Bently T. Elliott by Aug. 1 but now concedes he will not meet that deadline. Meantime, the acting chief speechwriter is Anthony Dolan, brother of John T. Dolan, head of the National Conservative Political Action Committee. Mr. Elliott and Margaret Noonan both left the speechwriting unit amid reports that their efforts had failed to satisfy the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, and his aides.

title: Bond Prices Decline Abruptly
description: Bond prices fell abruptly late yesterday after a Treasury official said that the Government would not postpone its $30 billion August refunding.

title:
PLAYERS;
An Umpire Calls Her Tune
description: When Perry Lee Barber stands on stage cradling an electric guitar replete with its tremolo bar and amp connections, there is something incongruous about her. She is petite and seems almost to disappear behind a wall of lacquered wood and strings. Her voice, though, is clear and strong. She wails a lyric, usually her own, in the manner of the rock singer Grace Slick.

title: Fervent for Fungi
description: CELEBRATING THE WILD MUSHROOM: A Passionate Quest. By Sara Ann Friedman. Illustrations by Diana Jacobs. 265 pages. Dodd, Mead. Hardcover, $18.95; paperback, $10.95. Why would anyone want to look for, let alone eat, fungi? For any number of reasons, according to this entertaining celebration of wild mushrooms by Sara Ann Friedman. They can be delicious, a far sight better than the bland commercial variety. They are fascinating to hunt and study, especially the rare ones like the morel, which many mycophiles consider the Moby Dick of mushrooms. And they are sensual and erotic, not only in their appearance but often, too, in their taste, texture and smell.

description: A jet-powered helicopter carrying law-enforcement officers on their way to destroy a marijuana field crashed and exploded shortly after takeoff Thursday, killing three of the officers aboard and injuring two others, officials said.

title: POLL FINDS REVIVAL OF NUCLEAR FEARS
description: Misgivings about the safety of nuclear power plants, which began to recede shortly after the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island, were revived by the accident in April at the Soviet nuclear plant at Chernobyl, according to the findings of two recent polls.

title: Costly Brawl
description: The brawl between players of the San Francisco Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals Tuesday night has cost the Giants the services of Mike Krukow, a pitcher, for at least two weeks. Krukow's 11 victories in 17 decisions have helped put San Francisco in contention this season. The right-hander suffered thigh and rib injuries while fighting Vince Coleman of the Cardinals and has been placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to Wednesday.

description: Reijo Ruotsalainen, the Rangers' most agile defenseman and second- leading scorer last season, has decided to play hockey in Switzerland next season rather than return for a sixth year with the Rangers.

Satellite System
description: Pairs of orbiting satellites that communicate by radar and do holographic imaging are to operate in a global system patented this week by William H. Grisham of Long Beach, Miss. Patent No. 4,602,257 says the method, which he has dubbed the Sarah, is particularly useful for detecting underground minerals, forest and agricultural growth, moisture collection and other conditions. The patent describes illumination of the earth by synthetic radar from one satellite and reception of reflected signals by the other.

title: Robbed of Justice, Too
description: This is a true story. Nonfiction. I didn't make any of it up. One Sunday night at about 10 as I was coming home from a poetry reading in New York City, my purse was snatched as I put my key in the front door of my Prospect Heights apartment building. Seeing that the thief was unarmed and being unwilling to relinquish my good leather purse that I had bought in Spain and whose contents had been hard-earned, I tugged it back and screamed. The thief tore the handle of the purse and took off with the bag.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I tell physicians: 'You can play this game like OPEC, the oil cartel, for a few more years, but the more physicians raise their prices, the more attractive will be the services of pediatric nurse-practitioners and other paramedics who charge half as much.' '' - Uwe E. Reinhardt, professor of political economy at Princeton University. [ 34:1. ]

title: Dr. John Livingood, 83, Dies; Pioneer in Artificial Isotopes

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOLEFUL No one has yet been publicly credited with having invented tap-dancing (Ted Shawn said it was ''an invention of the devil''), but Charles (Cookie) Cook must have been around at its birth. He started dancing early - around 1929. He has seen his art form hibernate in the 1950's and re-emerge in the 1970's. And it has been reborn with some of its originators still its most eminent practitioners.

title: Reliance Electric
description: The Reliance Electric Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that it is seeking to sell its North American Transformer unit as part of its plan to sell the remaining units acquired in its 1979 purchase of the Federal Pacific Electric Company. North American Transformer, which produces high-voltage, liquid-filled transformers for utility and industrial use, had sales of $36 million in 1985, according to Reliance Electric.

title: ART SCHOOL GOES BACK TO THE HUMAN FIGURE
description: The highly publicized rise of Neo-Expressionism, and more recently of a new hybrid of conceptual and abstract art, are not the only trends that the booming contemporary art scene in New York has produced. A revival of interest in realist figurative art has also occurred with less ballyhoo.

title: U.S.-JAPAN CHIP MAKERS SAY TALKS ARE DERAILED
description: Semiconductor manufacturers based in the United States and Japan said today that trade negotiations between the two countries had been derailed. Manufacturers on both sides of the issue are now pessimistic that any agreement can be reached.

title: Charles Ward, a Dancer, at 33
description: Charles Ward, a leading dancer with American Ballet Theater and a member of the original cast of the Broadway musical ''Dancin,' '' died July 11 at his home in Downey, Calif. Mr. Ward, who was 33 years old, had been suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: CBS REPORTEDLY PLANS TO DROP 'MORINING NEWS' AT YEAR'S END
description: CBS News, after years of failed efforts to develop a successful morning news program, will relinquish the two-hour ''CBS Morning News'' time period at the end of the year, according to network officials.

title: Dow Rises by 18.42 To Top 1,800 Level
description: Helped by an optimistic forecast on the economy from the Reagan Administration, Wall Street staged an impressive rally yesterday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average above the 1,800 level for the first time in two weeks.

title: Carleen Hussung Wed To C. Winston Simone
description: Carleen Francesca Hussung, the daughter of Alleen Hussung and Will Hussung, both of New York, was married yesterday to C. Winston Simone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Simone of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Nassau, the Bahamas. The Rev. Dr. G. Eric Pace, pastor and director of the Universal Science of Mind Center in New York, performed the ceremony at the Players Club in New York.

title: Savings Units: Going Public
description: THE current plan by the Dime Savings Bank of New York, the third-largest thrift institution in the state, to convert from a mutual to a stock form of ownership has focused attention on an increasing conversion trend among thrift units. It has also raised questions among depositors about whether they should take advantage of the opportunity to buy shares in these institutions.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Port Authority Bomb Threat
description: The Police Department's bomb squad was summoned to the Port Authority bus terminal after an anonymous bomb threat was called in during rush hour last evening, but no explosive was found. Two parking levels and one bus level were closed for about 45 minutes, delaying hundreds of commuters at the midtown terminal.

title: BRITISH OFFICIAL ADMITS PESSIMISM ON RESULT OF SOUTHERN AFRICA TRIP
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, expressed pessimism about his South African mission for the first time today, saying it may be left to another person to pave the way for peace.

title: SLAM HELPS CLEMENS WIN 17th
description: Roger Clemens, the top winner in the major leagues, pitched the first two-hitter of his career and Rich Gedman hit a grand slam tonight as the Boston Red Sox broke a four-game losing streak by beating the California Angels 8-1.

title: Bridge; Seeded Squads Incur Upsets In Play at Summer Nationals
description: Dramatic upsets that sidelined the first- and second-seeded squads in the Spingold Knockout Teams marked the play Thursday at the American Contract Bridge League Summer Nationals here.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Better Way to Collect Garbage
description: In Philadelphia, after sanitation workers refused to work for 20 days, garbage is being collected by court order until union members vote on a new contract. In Detroit, after 10 days of strike, citizens are bringing their own garbage to the dumps. If the Philadelphia union rejects a pact, or the Detroit talks falter again, the citizens' noisome difficulties could continue indefinitely. There should be a better way of settling labor disputes affecting vital municipal services, and there is.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Baltimore Orioles have sent Alan Wiggins, Mike Young and Floyd Rayford - three players stuck in batting slumps - to Rochester of the International League and have called up Jackie Gutierrez, John Stefero and Tom Dodd. . . . Richie Adubato, one of Hubie Brown's assistant coaches with the Knicks since 1982, has accepted a job as assistant coach to Dick Motta of the Dallas Mavericks. He will be Motta's only aide, replacing Bob Weiss, who was named head coach of the San Antonio Spurs in May.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months earnings include a charge of $1,712,000 for bond redemptions.

title:
PATENTS;
Growth Hormone Used Against Dwarfism
description: Genentech Inc. of San Francisco, the biotechnology company, received a patent this week on the use of microorganisms to create human growth hormone, which fights dwarfism.

title: FAMED DIRECTOR WAS 76
description: Vincente Minnelli, whose deft intermingling of song, dance and plot made him one of the greatest directors of Hollywood musicals, died in his sleep at his home in Los Angeles last night. He was 76 years old. The director had been hospitalized several times within the last year for emphysema and pneumonia, according to Ron Wise of the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

title: PUROLATOR COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1.3 million to settle a litigation matter involving Purolator's U.S. Courier division and a tax credit of $3,105,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $7,998,000.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Delta's Pilots Reach Tentative 3-Year Pact
description: Delta Air Lines and its pilots have reached tentative agreement on a new three-year contract, the Air Line Pilots Association said Thursday.

title: Bias Suit Against G.M. Is Reported Expanded
description: A lawsuit accusing the General Motors Corporation of discrimination against four black salaried employees has been expanded to cover 14,000 black men and women in management jobs in three states.

title: CAR BOMB HITS A WEST GERMAN COMPANY INVOLVED IN 'STAR WARS'
description: A car bomb exploded today outside the headquarters of a leading West German aerospace concern.

title: CCX NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Aetna Operating Profits Soar 58.5%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest investor-owned insurance company, reported yesterday that its operating earnings in the second quarter of 1986 climbed 58.5 percent, to $158.8 million, or $1.37 a share, from $100.2 million, or 90 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Kellogg's Net Rises by 11%
description: The Kellogg Corporation's second-quarter profit rose by 11 percent above the corresponding period last year on higher sales of the company's breakfast cereals, it said today.

title: LOAN AMERICA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CECO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $13.7 million for unanticipated costs of modifications required by the Army on the Apache helicopter for the quarter and 6 months and also the 6 months is after a pre-tax charge of $47.9 million taken in the first quarter related to Apache helicopter modifications. The year-ago 6 months net included a one-time net gain of about $10 million from the sale of land. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Expense Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEISMANN OPTS FOR WAIVER LIST
description: Joe Theismann was declared unfit to play this season by the Washington Redskins, who then announced today that they would put the veteran quarterback on waivers at his request.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $9.9 million from the purchase of debentures.

title: CUOMO URGES SIMON TO TESTIFY
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that Stanley Simon, the Bronx Borough President, should testify before a grand jury investigating political corruption without invoking constitutional protections against self-incrimination.

title: Players Acquitted
description: Three former University of Minnesota basketball players were found not guilty of charges that they raped an 18-year-old woman, in a verdict read early yesterday in Dane County Circuit Court.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rare Monkey Born in Oregon
description: A rare golden monkey, on loan from China, has given birth to the first golden monkey ever born outside China. The curator of the Washington Park Zoo, Steve McCuster, said that before the birth here Thursday the mother and a male golden monkey also lent by China had been seen mating frequently in their recent three-month stay at the Woodland Park Zoo in Seattle. The monkeys have been at the Portland zoo since May and will be exhibited there until Aug. 11.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $177,000 and $398,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: YORK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago share earnings are not available; the company went public in April.

title: Thais Tighten Security For National Elections
description: Thailand mobilized its police force today to maintain order for parliamentary elections on Sunday, which follow six weeks of campaigning that authorities said left eight people dead.

title: U.S. JURY RECESSES IN FOOTBALL CASE
description: The jury in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League recesssed at 4:30 P.M. yesterday after deliberating for six hours and failing to reach a verdict.

title: CAN DAVID LETTERMAN SURVIVE SUCCESS?
description: It is a long, hot summer in New York for David Letterman. First, there is the problem of the Nielsen ratings - they've never been higher. ''It's like a tap on the shoulder from some ominous unknown force,'' said Mr. Letterman the other night after the 5:30 P.M. taping of NBC's ''Late Night With David Letterman'' in studio 8H in the RCA Building, where Toscanini once conducted. ''It's like a warning that I've got to do better, and keep doing better, or the ratings will go down and I'll be left a lonely broken shell of a human - like I am now.''

title: IN ATTACKS ON OFFICERS, FAMILIES ALSO SUFFER WOUNDS
description: Long after the headlines disappear, the visits from high-level officials end and the cards of sympathy stop arriving, the trauma lingers.

title: Echoes of Gettysburg, Delights of the Basque
description: PIVOTAL BATTLE OF CIVIL WAR IS RECALLED -

title: WHOSE STAGE IS IT ANYWAY?
description: GREAT DIRECTORS AT WORK Stanislavsky, Brecht, Kazan, Brook. By David Richard Jones. 289 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25. GROTOWSKI AND HIS LABORATORY By Zbigniew Osinski. Edited and translated by Lillian Vallee and Robert Findlay. Illustrated. 185 pp. New York: PAJ Publications. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $9.95. LATELY, the most rabid controversy in the theater has been over the role of the modern stage director - often characterized by outraged actors, critics and even spectators as an upstart careerist determined to usurp the traditional function of the playwright. Auteur directors have been raising temperatures for over 100 years; yet discussion of their work has rarely risen above the level of snarls and grumbles. Now two new books approach directors not as egoistic intruders but rather as prime movers of the theatrical occasion, indeed as among the most original artists working in the modern theater.

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title: WISE TIMES TAKES HASKELL IN AN UPSET
description: Wise Times, a small, stretch-running long shot piloted by a 17-year-old rider who had never won a stakes race, rallied through the slop at Monmouth Park today to score an upset victory in the $300,000 Haskell Invitational Handicap for 3-year-olds.

title: TOPICS
description: MOST travel guides suggest that vacationers try to meet the ''real people.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SEVEN SUMMITS. By Dick Bass and Frank Wells with Rick Ridgeway. (Warner, $19.95.) What would motivate two middle-aged businessmen, strangers with little climbing experience, to spend four years attempting to climb the highest mountain on each of the seven continents? Were Frank Wells, president of the Walt Disney Company, and Dick Bass, a ski resort owner, compelled to climb Everest, McKinley, Kilimanjaro and the others by some profound force, a deep need to test themselves? ''Seven Summits'' doesn't say.

title: FAIR AT ABBEY FEATURES ACTRESS
description: WHEN the Abbey of Regina Laudis in Bethlehem throws open the gates for its 34th annual Monastic Fair next weekend, it will offer, along with its traditional home-made goods, craft demonstrations, hay rides and ethnic food booths, a series of special presentations by the Academy Award-winning actress Patricia Neal.

title: Criticizing U.S. on South Africa Needs No Apology; Policy Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Fuel Cost Pass-Along - Question: I am a tenant in a rent-controlled apartment and was recently assessed an additional surcharge for my existing fuel-cost pass-along, which I have been paying for some years. Although the additional surcharge was slight, is it - and the pass-along itself - authorized, considering the rapidly falling price of oil? . . . R. B., Brooklyn Answer: Yes. According to Charles Hogg, of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the formula used to determine the amount of the pass-along and the surcharge includes such variables as what type of heating system - electric, gas or oil - is used as well as the size of the apartment. You can find out if the amount of your surcharge was appropriate by visiting or calling the division's Brooklyn office at 91 Lawrence Street. Noisy Pump Question: We live on the ground floor of a cooperative building. The co-op has just put a new water pump in the basement that is causing the floor in our kitchen to vibrate. The new pump is also noisier than the old pump. Do we have any recourse in getting the co-op to install a quieter pump? . . . D. H., Manhattan Answer: Your first step, whether you are an owner or a renter, is to complain to the building's managing agent. If this route is unavailing, your next course of action would be to bring the problem before the board of directors, which is responsible for the managing agent.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I TAKE a look at Tommy's feet when he visits on weekends. I don't want another Sneaker Crisis to sneak up on us.

title: Desert War Games Start
description: Some 35,000 troops have assembled in the California desert for the opening round of 10 days of war games. The biennial war games, which opened Friday, are designed to assure that marines, soldiers, sailors and pilots will be able to respond quickly and effectively if summoned to a Middle East hot spot, military spokesmen said.

title: BALLET: SUMMER STUDENTS PERFORM 3 NEW WORKS
description: THE School of American Ballet presented three new dances performed by summer-session students Thursday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater.

title: CHANGES IN RESEARCH FUNDS CHALLENGED
description: CONGRESS knew better than to get embroiled in a 20-year-old argument. So when the nation's leading research universities sought its help in blocking a Reagan Administration plan to change the way the Government supports research, Congress declared a 60-day moratorium and told both sides to settle the dispute themselves.

title: COMPOSER AND LIBRETTIST: THE NEW CHEMISTRY
description: ''A songwriting partnership is like a marriage,'' Richard Rodgers wrote. ''Apart from just liking each other, a lyricist and a composer should be able to spend long periods of time together - around the clock if need be - without getting on each other's nerves. Their goals, outlooks and basic philosophies should be similar, so that the song they create is accepted as a spontaneous emotional expression emanating from a single source.''

title: BEHIND 'MEN' STANDS A WOMAN WITH A SENSE OF HUMOR
description: Doris Dorrie went to America when she was 17 and brought back something that she found had died in Germany - a sense of humor. It helped her make one of the most successful films in the cinematic history of postwar Germany -a comedy called ''Men'' (''Manner'') that has been seen by some six million Germans in the last eight months and has drawn critical comparisons with the work of the great Ernst Lubitsch.

title: PUSHING THE WALLS OF DRAMATIC FORM
description: It's no secret to say that drama is a restrictive medium, and that those of us who try to write plays are hedged in on all sides by tough laws of dramaturgy which we break only at our peril. To compound the problem, American playwrights, dependent as we are on the uneasy generosity of private enterprise, would seem to be even further encumbered by economic inhibitions that require us to be downright miserly about the number of characters we use or the settings in which our plays take place.

title: ACROSS THE SOUTH, PRAYERS FOR RAIN
description: ''This isn't a drought,'' Ray Ward, a Georgia dairy farmer, said one day last week. ''It's not even a disaster. It's a catastrophe.''

title: COMPOSER FINDS HIS NICHE IN LIFE
description: ''CONSIDERING how much trouble I gave them, it's nice that they hung my picture up in the lobby.''

title: AN ACTION BORDERING ON THE INCOHERENT
description: THE Federal Trade Commission argues that the proposed mergers of Coca-Cola and Dr Pepper, and of Pepsico and Seven-Up, would limit competition in the soft drink market and make it more difficult for new companies to enter and compete. In opposing the mergers, it suggested that Coke and Pepsi's combined 80 percent share of the market in soft drinks might create monopoly power, thus raising prices and leading to an inefficient allocation of resources.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.* Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SURVIVING THE FLOOD. By Stephen Minot. (Second Chance Press, $18.95.) This wry novel belongs to that category of books whose purpose is to set the historical record straight.

title: Christina Jadach Marries in Michigan
description: Christina L. Jadach, a consultant with Bain & Company, a management consulting concern in Boston, was married yesterday to Francisco Rodriguez, an associate with McKinsey & Company, a management consulting concern in New York. The Rev. Mitchell Kaminski, the bride's uncle, and the Rev. Edward Prus performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak, Mich.

title: THE REAGAN LEGACY
description: I am very much afraid that the Reagan legacy will turn out to be hollow. The President's love of simplification hardly needs repeating, but mention should be made of his sentimentalism.

title: Building Offices Without a Prime Tenant
description: BEFORE New York's office economy grew as burly as it is today, financial institutions often required developers to have anchor tenants in place before they would write a construction loan for a major new office tower.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: AN OBELISK FOR A PIG

title: ROXY, SPINOZA AND OTHER URBAN GREATS
description: METROPOLIS New York as Myth, Marketplace, and Magical Land. By Jerome Charyn. 304 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95. IN ''Metropolis,'' Jerome Charyn has written a love song to cities in general and to New York City in particular. It is also a passionate invocation of his own life and of the earlier immigrant days of Ellis Island. (Someone - I cannot believe it is the author -has given the book the foolish subtitle ''New York as Myth, Marketplace, and Magical Land.'' Just ignore the cheap alliteration.) The best things about this roller coaster-written, hypnotic, ambitious, often brilliant, often utterly wrongheaded and fascinating book are its author's voice and its beautifully lived-in subject. In the invisible place where subjects and authors are mysteriously joined, a fortunate meeting has occurred between a ''Bronx Iroquois'' and the anarchic city he has soaked up through his nerve endings, a pairing that extends here to the borders of poetry, mythology and politics. This last category, in my opinion, takes Mr. Charyn onto tricky ground; he occasionally lurches and retrieves his footing mainly by the sheer energy of his language and poetic drive.

title: F.B.I. REPORTS 5% CRIME INCREASE IN 1985, AFTER THREE YEARS OF DECLINE
description: The number of crimes reported in the United States rose 5 percent last year, the first increase since 1981, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Black Women Writers
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
CONVERTIBLES: A DOUBLE-EDGED ALLURE
description: ON Wall Street, which is often as fashion conscious as Seventh Avenue, convertible securities are in vogue. The combination of falling interest rates and a rousing stock market has made these hybrid securities particularly attractive. Indeed, over the last 12 months, they outperformed all other fixed-income investments.

title: Miss Mansell Wed on L.I.
description: Jessica Lyman Mansell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Mansell of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to William Drew Briner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Briner of Tahoe City, Calif. The Rev. Robert F. Capon performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: Mothball Agent Found In Cracker Jack Package
description: A container of Cracker Jack that sickened a man contained a chemical found in mothballs, but no contamination was found in other containers inspected, including those bought by two women who reported flu-like symptoms after eating the snack, the Allegheny County Health Department said today.

title: BALLOT QUESTIONS MAY TEST DUKAKIS
description: Massachusetts voters will find questions on a wide range of issues in the voting booths in November, including public financing of abortions, mandatory use of seat belts, limits on state taxing authority and hazardous waste cleanup efforts.

title: Jill M. Ghari Married To Robert J. Vellinger
description: The marriage of Jill M. Ghari, an account supervisor at Ogilvy & Mather, to Robert J.
