Vellinger, a civil engineer with the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, took place yesterday at the Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. James Zwernemann performed the ceremony.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Cliff Johnson, the Toronto Blue Jays' designated hitter who has been suffering from a sore wrist, has been put on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to July 23. . . . Yannick Noah, who won the D.C. Tennis Classic last year, has withdrawn from the 1986 event because of a slow-healing ankle injury.

title: Japan Seizing More Drugs
description: The police seized a record amount of illegal drugs in Japan last year, and the number of people arrested for drug abuse exceeded 20,000 for the sixth consecutive year, the Health Ministry reported today.

title: Helping 'The Kids' Get Started
description: THE financial demands of buying the first house are often too great for young people to take on without parental help, normally in the form of a lump sum against part or all of the down payment. But several factors have conspired to create increasing concern over the way this is handled, and the arrangement may require careful structuring.

title: CAST IRON, POTATOES MARRY WELL WITH ITALIAN FLAIR
description: POTATOES cooked in olive oil are delicious with the grilled foods of summer.

title: THERE'S A GOLDEN GLOW 'ROUND THOSE GRAINY RERUNS
description: The current wave of nostalgia for Television Past is either tantalizing or suffocating, depending on your age and point of view. Come this fall, a parade of veteran perfomers who ruled television as far back as the early 1950's will return to the small screen - Lucille Ball and Milton Berle will each star in new situation comedies; Andy Griffith (as Mayberry's Sheriff Andy Taylor) and Raymond Burr (as Perry Mason) are rejuvenating their characters, and most of the original ''Leave It to Beaver'' cast is reappearing in ''Still the Beaver.'' These familiar faces, among them some of the brightest stars created by the medium, are trying to capitalize on the immense popularity of a barrage of grainy black-and-white reruns on syndicated television and cable, as well as dozens of books filled with nostalgia trivia about seemingly every detail of the first four decades of television.

title: A Vaccine Made By Gene-Splicing Wins Approval
description: The manipulation of genes in a laboratory, a kind of experimentation barely heard of a decade ago, has for the first time produced a vaccine approved for human use. The Food and Drug Administration, announcing the licensing of the hepatitis B vaccine last week, said it should be the first of many.

title: CITY'S HOUSING CODE ENFORCEMENT MAY NEED RENOVATION
description: WHAT can be done when a landlord refuses to keep up his property - even after the city or a Housing Court judge orders him to do so?

title: REHNQUIST'S INHERITANCE
description: STORM CENTER The Supreme Court in American Politics. By David M. O'Brien. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95. THIS is no time to deny that the Supreme Court is a political institution. Throughout history the Court, which is three years away from its 200th birthday, has been a vital actor on the political scene even when trying to float majestically above it. Often, as today, the Court is fought, or fought over, by the other two, more overtly partisan branches of Government as they seek to control the direction of the law. Just as often the Court has been engaged in telling Presidents and Congresses how to behave - or deciding to disclaim the right to interfere with elected officials. At all times the Court must interpret not only the Constitution but also a multitude of laws that order the lives of all citizens, a task that demands political wisdom no less than legal learning.

title: Marriage Finances
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Landslide Kills 5
description: A landslide struck this southern Italian town today, burying three houses and several other buildings.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S MIGHT BELIES A REGION'S WEAKNESS
description: WITH the international clamor for sanctions, South Africa's white leaders, in a bellicose mood, seem increasingly to be preparing for a siege. ''If we are forced to go it alone, then so be it,'' President P. W. Botha said recently. ''South Africa will not crawl before anyone to prevent it.''

title: Georgia Democrats Vote To Bar LaRouche Group
description: Georgia's Democratic leadership voted today to change the party's charter to prevent followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. from gaining any influence in the party's political machinery.

title: ANGELS DEFEAT RED SOX
description: Doug DeCinces and Bobby Grich hit home runs in the fourth inning today, and Mike Witt scattered five hits over eight innings as the California Angels beat the Boston Red Sox, 4-1.

title: BIG FARMS TO GET HUGE U.S. SUBSIDIES
description: A single California farming operation will collect $20 million in Federal subsidies this year, one of many multimillion-dollar payments the Government is expected to make in the struggle for the United States to regain its former dominance in farm exports.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
A New Design for Chinatown
description: CHINATOWN: Restaurants, apartments and curio shops jumbled along narrow streets? Not for long. This city's Chinese-American community is about to expand into brand new modular quarters that will make it the most modern Chinatown in the country.

title: OIL PRICES CAST A PALL OVER PRUDHOE BAY
description: NEAR the front door of ARCO Alaska's Prudhoe Bay operations center on the wind-swept tundra of the North Slope is a display showing the spot price of a barrel of crude oil in Texas and the price for the same date a year earlier. On one recent afternoon, the display showed that the price had fallen from $26.10 12 months earlier to $10.30.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: WASTE SITING AGENCY IS FAULTED
description: THE PROPOSAL by the state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission to have a waste-storage facility in New Jersey raises serious questions that go to the heart of forming sound environmental policy.

title: Oliveira at Waterloo
description: The violinist Elmar Oliveira will appear with the Waterloo Symphony Orchestra on Aug. 2 at the Waterloo Music Festival in Stanhope, N.J. Mr. Oliveira replaces Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, who canceled her appearance with the orchestra for personal reasons, according to her manager.

title: WHEN A HOLIDAY ISN'T A HOLIDAY
description: Suzanne Reade must be kidding in ''Teachers and the Criticism of their Vacation.'' A 10-week vacation? Teachers work under 180-day contract. They are, in effect, laid off for those 10 weeks. Just because a town agrees to stretch a teacher's pay over the whole year doesn't change that.

title: 1985 EXPORT BAN ON SOUTH AFRICA MAY BE RENEWED
description: President Reagan plans to renew a year-old ban on the export of some goods to South Africa and may send a special mission to warn the Pretoria Government that unless it speeds political change, stiffer penalties will follow, a ranking Administration official said today.

title: Inmates Said to Put AIDS Serum in Coffee
description: Two prisoners have been charged with conspiracy to commit murder by putting blood serum from an AIDS patient in a correction officer's coffee.

title: 'Ghosts' and Mystery
description: To the Editor:

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
THREE FRENCH PAINTERS TO BE PROFILED
description: Art history combines with social history - and even a bit of film history - in ''Artists and Models,'' a three-part series having its American television premiere on Arts and Entertainment Wednesday evening at 9. In weekly two-hour chapters, the series provides dramatized biographies of three French painters, using their works and their experiences to explore the most turbulent epoch in French history -from the Old Regime with its decadence that led to the Revolution, the rise and fall of Napoleon, and beyond. The series was produced by R. M. Arts, a Munich-based production house, in association with the BBC.

title: THE STRANGERS OF SUMMER
description: They would usually appear in a rowboat, my mother rowing, my father sitting in the back, facing her, his clear view of where the boat was heading allowing him to give directions. The boat would round the near point on Wisconsin's Plum Lake and all of us 10-year-olds on Camp Highland's swimming pier would spot them.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DON COYOTE: The Good Times and the Bad Times of a Much Maligned American Original. By Dayton O. Hyde. (Arbor House, $16.95.)

title: Recent Releases
description: 'Master Harold'. . . and the Boys. Starring Zakes Mokae, Matthew Broderick and John Kani; directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, 1984-Karl-Lorimar Home Video, 90 minutes.

title: DIVERSITY IN NUMBERS
description: There was a time when stamp collectors in this country packed away their albums for summer and dealers departed for European buying trips. Those days are past and nowhere is this clearer than in the flood of new issues from every continent.

title: PAGLIARULO: A WORKAHOLIC IN PINSTRIPES
description: ACCORDING to Joe Altobelli, sometimes the Yankees' coaches have to ''kind of tone him down.'' Roy White told of how ''he comes out for extra hitting and he's done with that and he wants extra hitting on top of the extra hitting. He says, 'This feels good; I want to keep working on it,' and he goes down to the cage. After a while, I try to stop him. There's such a thing as overdoing it.''

title: President, in Radio Address, Assures Nation on Economy
description: President Reagan today chided those who predict economic doom, saying that the economy was showing strength and that growth in a rate slower than expected over the past few months was only temporary.

title: ON WALL STREET, A GREEDY NEW BREED
description: WALL Street fumed after Dennis B. Levine was arrested on insider trading charges in May. Investment bankers were embarrassed that one of their own displayed such greed and outraged that their own integrity was being questioned because of it.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Perth Amboy Rediscovers Its Waterfront
description: DURING the first half of this century, Perth Amboy, an old port city that skirts the Raritan and Arthur Kill Rivers, was a thriving workplace. But over the years, many of the businesses that enlivened the waterfront moved away, leaving a trail of abandoned factories, rusted oil tanks, crumbled piers and a city on the decline.

title: OUT OF DENTISTRY AND INTO CANDY
description: FOR years - practically since he started his dental practice -Jerry H. Lynn knew that dentistry was not enough to make him happy. His practice included many stars of the theater, ballet and television - ''I capped the teeth of just about every important rock singer,'' he recalled recently - and their anecdotes of glitz and glamour made it painfully obvious to Dr. Lynn that ''there was more to life than looking into people's mouths.''

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS SOJOURN OUTSIDE
description: SO your house plants are on vacation, too. They are doing so well under the shade tree in the backyard. Why, only last week you glanced in their direction when you checked out the lawn sprinkler, and they were still there. Maybe you had better look again. Perhaps you have exiled them to Siberia, rather than an outdoor paradise.

title: Kelly G. Palmer Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Warren George Palmer of Ann Arbor, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Germaine Palmer, to W. Garrison Jackson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Garrison Jackson of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Mashpee, Mass. A November wedding is planned. Ms. Palmer, who graduated from Simmons College, is a management associate for Mutual of New York Financial Services.

title: Where Are the 'Stealth' Papers?
description: A month ago, John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads a House investigative subcomittee, charged that Lockheed Corporation was mishandling classified documents. Company spokesmen said that was news to them.

title: ROCK: CACTUS WORLD NEWS
description: THE Irish rock band U2 and the Scottish bands Big Country and Simple Minds brought a new, heroic style to 1980's rock - with martial drumming, ringing guitars, dreamlike lyrics and yearning, breathy, clarion vocals. Now, the heroic approach is getting channeled back into pop by such bands as Cactus World News, which performed Thursday at the Ritz.

title: SIGNUP OF VOTERS ORDERED WIDENED
description: A voter registration campaign that has generated skirmishes in state capitals around the country has won a courtroom victory in Los Angeles, where a judge ruled that workers in county offices should actively solicit the registration of voters.

title: PROGRAM PUTS COMMUNITIES IN COMPETITION FOR STATE AID
description: A NEW economic incentive package awaiting Governor Cuomo's signature could help four troubled Westchester municipalities - Yonkers, Mount Vernon, Peekskill and Ossining -but they will have to compete for access to its benefits, according to the bill's sponsors.

title: TYSON A WINNER OVER FRAZIER IN 0:30
description: Near midnight Friday, Marvis Frazier, in sweat clothes, stepped out the door of the Queensbury Hotel here and went for a run of a mile and a half. Based on what happened in the ring at the Glens Falls Civic Center today, Frazier should have kept going, due west to his hometown of Philadelphia and out of harm's way.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: IN some homes, it's become a piece of sculpture.

title: 2 TROLLEY BUFFS PUT MEMORIES INTO PRINT
description: WHEN Albert W. Mankoff, a personnel training officer for the State of California, was growing up in Newark in the early 1930's, he used to walk with his mother and younger brother from their home on Stuyvesant Avenue to meet the big red trolley that brought his father back from work.

title: OF TEA LEAVES AND INTEREST RATES
description: SELDOM has it been harder to read the United States economy. Analysts say that some some recent measurements looked awful, some appeared strong and others were just plain puzzling. The Government reported last week that the nation's output of goods and services rose at an annual rate of 1.1 percent in the second quarter. At the same time, it raised the growth rate for the January-March quarter to 3.8 percent from the 2.9 percent calculated earlier. The gross national product thus grew at a rate just under 2.5 percent for the first half of 1986 - not quite satisfactory, most economists maintain, but not cause for alarm.

title: CROSS-HUDSON WARFARE OVER AID FOR WATERFRONT JOBS FLARES AGAIN
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York has called the affair a ''scandal'' and said that he hoped it could be resolved privately. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey said that he agreed the two states ''ought not to fight,'' but that frankly he thought New York was ''dead wrong.''

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography
description: It no longer comes as a surprise to discover exhibitions of art ensconced in the midtown lobbies of corporate office buildings, but who would expect to come upon one in an automobile showroom? That's exactly where you will find ''Seven Decades of Style in Photography,'' a 50-print show that inaugurates an exhibition program at the BMW Gallery, 320 Park Avenue at 51st Street. And though you have to run a gantlet of gorgeous cars and motorcycles, both new and vintage, to see the pictures, which are mounted on partitions in a space of their own, the venue is not as bad as it may sound.

title: MINORITIES ARE UNEASY IN YUGOSLAV PROVINCE
description: The Yugoslav Government is keeping a watch on Serbs and Montenegrins in Kosovo Autonomous Province to prevent them from staging protest marches on Belgrade. The two groups charge that the region's Albanian ethnic majority is trying to force them from their ancestral homes.

title: GOODSPEED OPERA OFFERS A MUDDLED 'FANNY'
description: TOE tapping, lighthearted musicals, early 1900's style, have become the hallmark of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam. Witness such frothy fare as ''Going Up'' (Louis A. Hirsch and Otto Harbach, 1917) and ''Tip-Toes'' (George and Ira Gershwin, 1925).

title: A NEW GERMAN MUSEUM OFFERS AN UNEXPECTED MIX
description: Earlier this year, there was inaugurated in Dusseldorf, West Germany, a museum of 20th-century art that is not quite like any other. It has the air of a private collection, in that it is not didactic, does not aim to be comprehensive and goes heavily into some areas and very lightly into others. It lingers, where other museums move briskly along, and someone in there clearly delights in unexpected conjunctions. Where else should we find Modigliani represented on the one hand by his straightforward, linear, low-keyed portrait of the poet Max Jacob and, on the other, by a portrait in which Modigliani makes the painter Diego Rivera look like a great giggling barrel of blubber?

title: Recent Releases
description: Show Me a Story: Tales From Beatrix Potter. Coffee Table Videos, 43 minutes. $24.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: GIFTS FROM LILCO THE Long Island Lighting Company has finally done something right, according to Richard E. Kessel, head of the State Consumer Protection Board. ''I've got to give credit where credit is due,'' said Mr. Kessel, a long-time critic of the utility. ''I like their energy-conservation program.'' Specifically, he added, he likes this summer's gift incentive program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 27, 1986
description: International

title: TOGETHER AT TANGLEWOOD
description: They are calling this week's Friday concert at Tanglewood ''A Brass Spectacular,'' and -even before it takes place - that seems an apt description of the event. After all, it isn't every day that the likes of the Canadian Brass, the Empire Brass and the entire brass contingent of the Boston Symphony Orchestra get together for a performance.

title: CHARACTER ACTORS: BRIGHT PERENNIALS OF BRITISH THEATER
description: At one point this summer, Vanessa Redgrave, Albert Finney, Maggie Smith, Glenda Jackson, Roger Rees and Jane Lapotaire were all appearing in plays in London. The fact that these stars were on stage says something about the health of the English theater - a vitality that continues despite a paucity of interesting new plays and a preponderance of over-produced musicals. After several weeks of theatergoing in London, one begins to think that the English theater is the English actor, and nowhere is there a greater indication of that than in the performance of Bill Fraser in the West End revival of J. B. Priestley's 1938 comedy, ''When We Are Married.'' Mr. Fraser is a paradigm of the art of the English character actor.

title: THE GREMLINS BOWL OVER ALL OF THEM
description: DURING the last game, tension was so high, Marcia Steindler, a team member, recalled, ''You could hear a pin drop.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.60 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 6.17 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 6.04 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 11.02 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 14.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 15.50 Bank of America, San Francisco 18.25

title: No Longfellow Kin in Tomb
description: An historian studying the family of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow said Thursday that he could not find the bodies of the poet's parents, thought for years to be in a tomb at a local cemetery.

title: VOICES TRANSPORT THE EAR TO ANOTHER REALM
description: Pandit Pran Nath, the Indian classical vocalist, sat singing phrases from a raga amid a clutter of electronic equipment at the downtown loft of the composer La Monte Young on a sunny afternoon. Some of the equipment had been set up for recording purposes, but just now Pran Nath was singing to the sustained drone of an electronic tone generator, while Mr. Young tracked his most minute fluctuations in pitch on the screen of an oscilloscope. ''This way,'' Mr. Young said, ''you can see the difference between what we think of in the West as being 'in tune,' and what the greatest Indian musicians can do.''

title: 2 Nuns Face Vatican Discipline
description: The Vatican, having reached settlements with most of the members of religious orders who publicly dissented from Roman Catholic teachings on abortion, turned its attention last week to two nuns who work at a center for the homeless in Charleston, W. Va. The nuns had refused to renounce a statement that abortion ''can sometimes be a moral choice.''

title: WRITING WELL IS THE BEST REVENGE
description: WHEN, in August 1929, the art critic Thomas Earp adversely criticized both D. H. Lawrence's introduction to a catalogue of his paintings, and the paintings themselves, Lawrence wrote and published the following poem: I heard a little chicken chirp: My name is Thomas, Thomas Earp! And I can neither paint nor write I only can set other people right. All people that can write or paint do tremble under my complaint. For I am a chicken, and I can chirp; and my name is Thomas, Thomas Earp. How good a weapon is literature for settling scores with someone by making his person or art an object of ridicule? To what extent can we adequately ac-count for a poem, story or novel by locating its origin in spiteful feeling, a determination on the author's part to celebrate - with humorous zest or steely-eyed contempt - the offenses of another?

title: SIMPLE GIFTS FROM A STRANGER ON THE STOOP
description: SHE was only 9 - a little black-eyed beauty who stepped off the train with a suitcase in her hand and more aplomb than I might hope to muster. Only 9, yet ready to plop herself into my world, a stranger's house, for two weeks of fresh air. Even now, in my 30's, I don't think I could do that.

title: A CHAPTER OF INDUSTRIAL HISTORY CLOSES WITH THE HOMESTEAD STEEL WORKS
description: Red Hrabic, not so red anymore, was one. Ed Buzinka, Bill Evans and Ray MaGuire were others. So was Bob Todd, a large, outgoing man who, the workers joked, registers on the Richter scale when he walks, and who was taking home his locker in the back of his pickup truck.

title: COMING OF AGE IN SUMERIA: GILGAMESH AND OTHER LIVES IN CLAY
description: SAMUEL NOAH KRAMER - one of that tiny group of scholars who over the last century have recovered the literature of the ancient Sumerians, the world's first readers and writers - has himself grown so old that he seems entitled by now to speak his mind and talk a bit about himself.

title: WHO THEY ARE, WHAT THEY DO, THE TESTS THEY FACE
description: EACH WEEKNIGHT, 38 MILLION AMERicans watch one of the network evening news programs - 22 minutes of news and eight minutes of commercials. In this brief envelope of time, three men - Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw and Peter Jennings - present the world to a vast audience in a communication so intimate that it leads strangers to greet them automatically as Dan, Tom and Peter. In their role as anchors of the network evening news, the three have become not only celebrities equal to any in Hollywood, but also the nation's best-known journalists, who have come to symbolize continuity and order in the face of sometimes shattering news events. Like town criers, the anchors offer proof each night that ''the world's still here and there's going to be another day,'' said Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News for 16 years, until 1979. While the world the anchors present is often graphically violent, the anchors themselves are reasoned and calm, and the three shows usually lighten the report with something upbeat or heartwarming. ''They want it to be a reassuring view of the world,'' said Les Brown, editor in chief of Channels magazine, which covers the electronic media.

title: A REVITALIZED CATHEDRAL DRAWS YOUNG ADULTS
description: Only a decade ago, St. James Cathedral was dying.

title: YOUNG WRITERS SHARPENING SKILLS AT WORKSHOP
description: THE quiet of a summer morning is broken only by the singing of birds and a piano softly playing in the distance. Scattered around a spacious, sun-filled room, 13 students are at work on an assignment. They must write a paragraph conveying a character's personality solely through a description of his room.

title: GRIFFEY FAILING IN THE CLUTCH
description: Ken Griffey says he is more relaxed these days, although his sense of relief has been tempered by a sense of urgency over a fading pennant race. He is no longer preoccupied with being traded - the Yankees granted his wish last month, sending him to the Atlanta Braves for Claudell Washington and Paul Zuvella - but he occasionally wonders about his former team and the friends he left behind.

title: HITS AND MISSES
description: When the kings have castled on opposite wings and each player is pressing a mating attack, the outcome is usually determined by a direct hit on the enemy king position. But there are times when the decisive combination derives its force from hindering the opponent.

title: U.S. LEADERS LAUD HARRIMAN
description: President Reagan, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other leading political figures paid tribute yesterday to W. Averell Harriman.

title: More Advice For Jackson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. King Fiancee Of Lee G. Vance
description: Canon and Mrs. Jonathan LeRoy King of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Bayard King, to Lee Gregory Vance, a son of Lee N. Vance of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and the late Mary Elizabeth Vance. A Sept. 13 wedding is planned.

title: Favored Zoning for 'Community Facilities' Restudied
description: WHEN New York City's 1961 zoning resolution was adopted, ''community facilities'' were given a favored status.

title: COUNTY PRESSES EXPANSION FOR CROWDED WOMEN'S JAIL
description: WITH overcrowding at the Women's Correctional Unit of the county's Department of Corrections approaching crisis proportions, county officials have speeded up approval of a team of consultants to develop an expansion plan for the facility.

title: PANEL WILL STUDY WEST SIDE GROWTH
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced the appointment of a panel today to study development of the waterfront on the West Side of Manhattan below 42d Street.

title: Heather Richards Weds John Evans In Greenville, Del.
description: Heather Richards, who plans to enter the New York University Law School in the fall, and John Michael Evans, an investment banker at Salomon Brothers, were married yesterday in Greenville, Del. The Rev. William B. Lane performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: POMP AND CIRCUMSTANCE
description: For parents escorting their children to Europe for the first time perhaps the most eye-boggling sight is that of colorfully uniformed soldiers assigned to protect the lives and homes of their chiefs of state. British regiments guarding Buckingham Palace and other royal residences are probably the most famous, but despite their panoply and bearing they are not the most romantic of these vestiges of a bygone age when warfare was limited to short-range gunfire, sword, knife, discipline and courage. Although war is always brutal even when conducted on a scale that could be comprehended in human terms, the ceremonial guards continue to stir romantic thoughts.

title: THE SUDDEN WILTING OF REAGAN'S ROSY ECONOMY
description: JUST six months ago everything looked so good. Interest rates, oil prices and the dollar were all down, and many economists, expecting better days, applauded the luck and work of Ronald Reagan.

title: PLAYWRIGHT'S HOME IN NEW LONDON A PLACE FOR STUDY
description: FIFTEEN high-school teachers from around the country have come to New London this summer to study the works of Eugene O'Neill, meet actors and playwrights, improve their own writing and teaching and maybe encounter a ghost or two.

title: The Reagan Legacy
description: In ''The Reagan Legacy'' (June 22), Bernard Weinraub has described the crucial way in which President Reagan has influenced American society: Mr. Reagan's speeches give us a compelling vision of this country. In his genius for using stories, both his famous anecdotes and his grand epic of America as a divinely blessed land fulfilling its destiny under his leadership, he has given us a powerful and effective image of a people who are ''back and standing tall''( a description which we seem to accept without serious examination).

title: THE ANDALUSIAN BROTHERS
description: IN THE GREEN MORNING Memories of Federico. By Francisco Garcia Lorca. Translated by Christopher Maurer. Prologue by Mario Hernandez. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $23.50. Paper, $12.95. TOWARD the end of his days as a student of law at the University of Granada, the poet Federico Garcia Lorca stopped showing up for exams. The faculty was hesitant to throw him out, however. He had published a book of poems, and he was cultured and widely read. If not the poet, then the university might gain honor from the young man's degree. So, when he failed to appear for the examination in penal law, the committee sought him out in the courtyards, led him to their chambers, asked his opinion of the death penalty and waved him on. Civil and private law, canon law, public finance - one way or another he passed each one. Then came the last, and again no candidate. Again, allowances were made, a special session arranged. The topic was mercantile law; what exactly, the examiners asked the poet, was a merchant? Garcia Lorca knew that. They gave him his degree.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Office Growth Persists in a Softer Market
description: THE Island's office market has begun to show signs of softness, according to market observers, but developers continue to be confident and are pressing ahead with construction plans.

title: New Office Frontier Growing Along I-684
description: TALL signs reading ''Now Leasing'' are popping up above the greenery along Interstate 684 where it cuts through the rural landscape of eastern Westchester.

title: Leslie Nadel Engaged To Rand Rosenbaum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard W. Nadel of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Allison Nadel, to Rand Kevin Rosenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy I. Rosenbaum of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title:
'KILLER BEES' SEEN AS THREAT IN STATE;
AN APT NAME
description: THE African ''killer bee'' can be just that, for it is known to have killed humans in Brazil and Argentina.

title: WHERE AVANT-GARDE MEETS ROCK-AND-ROLL, MUSIC FLOURISHES
description: The predominant form of ''downtown'' experimental music in New York during this decade has been a fusion of the experimental avant-garde with rock-and-roll. So far, this music has been even less welcomed by the ''uptown'' new-music establishment -those composers with tangible links to the classical vanguard tradition - than were the Minimalists and scientistic experimenters and meditational environmentalists and exoticists of the 1970's. But a scene it is, it's vital, and most of its key practictioners have recently released records.

title: Sidney Charles Kurth Is Married to Evelyn Carton
description: Evelyn Carton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Carton of Lake Forest, Ill., was married there yesterday to Sidney Charles Kurth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Kurth of Billings, Mont. The Rev. John A. Bellingham performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: SENATE CONFEREES VOTE TAX CHANGES TO MEET SHORTFALL
description: In the first concrete step toward agreement on a final tax bill, Senate conferees today approved more than a dozen measures that would raise a total of $26 billion over the next five years. House conferees said the action by the senators was essential to allow further bargaining on the overall legislation.

title: Give Credit To Turner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHITE PROFESSIONALS LEAVE SOUTH AFRICA IN RECORD NUMBERS
description: A well-to-do white woman asked a furniture shipping company here the other day how complicated it would be to send two cars to Australia.

title: Neall M. Burger and Wesley Ostertag Are Married
description: Neall Margaret Burger, a daughter of Otis Kidwell Burger of New York and Colebrook, Conn., and Knox Burger of New York and Woodstock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Wesley Ostertag, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Frank Ostertag of East Orange, N.J. The bridegroom's father, pastor of the Calvary Roseville United Methodist Church in East Orange, performed the ceremony at the Holy Cross Episcopal Monastery in West Park, N.Y.

title: ONE MORNING THE NEIGHBORS PACKED THEIR MEMORIES AND MOVED AWAY
description: STILL in bed at 8 o'clock this morning, I hear the heavy roll of a truck in front of our house. Not the garabage man, I think, too early. Not the oil man, he was here the other day. Without looking, I knew. The movers. Our neighbors move today.

title: Miss Neithammer To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Neithammer Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Presley Neithammer, to James Edward Schwinn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Schwinn of Dayton, Ohio. An October wedding is planned.

title: NO-FAULT, NO FAIR
description: DAYS LIKE THIS A Tale of Divorce. By Phyllis Gillis. 302 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $15.95. PHYLLIS GILLIS had been a good wife, almost a Stepford wife, the kind of woman who fills up her appointment book with her husband's business engagements. At her husband's urging, she had given up a promising career to devote herself more single-mindedly to his. ''He means well,'' she told her feminist friends, and at least his Type A strivings brought in enough income to position them squarely in the exurban tennis-and-cocktail set. Then one night he came home late, silently strode over to the television set Phyllis was watching, pressed the off button, and announced, ''I'm leaving you. . . . I will be moving in the morning.'' This is the beginning of the two years of legal terrorism recounted in ''Days Like This,'' as Ms. Gillis fights to hold on to her home, her son and her depleted supply of self-confidence.

title: THE REAGAN LEGACY
description: Oh, we septuagenarian male chauvinists, but shouldn't all Americans feel fortunate to have a 75-year-old President who looks 35?

title: AT LAST, PROGRESS AT STAMFORD STATION
description: AFTER 20 months of picking their way through rocks and rubble, treading makeshift stairways and using temporary shelters, Stamford commuters are seeing light at the end of the leaky tunnel under their $50 million railroad station.

title: AT U.S. RADIO FOR EAST BLOC, TIME OF FLUX
description: Radio Free Europe broadcasters have not been accustomed to call-in shows or other forms of contact with the listeners who huddle over shortwave radios in Warsaw or Prague, twisting the dial to get around almost incessant jamming.

title: Aftermath of a Sail Around the World
description: AFTER sailing alone nonstop around the world in a 60-foot sloop - a 26,000-mile voyage that took him 150 days - 54-year-old Dodge Morgan of Cape Elizabeth, Me., said, ''I am going to stay ashore for a while.''

title: Gordon Radford Wed To Kristin A. Tennent
description: Kristin Ann Tennent, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Lee Tennent of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday to Gordon Radford, a son of Frederick Radford of Bellevue, Alberta, and the late Amelia McKenzie Radford. The Rev. Almus Thorpe performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COUNTY SWIM MEETS - Rick Carey, who won gold medals at the 1984 Olympics for the 100- and 200-meter backstroke and as part of a relay swim team that set a world record, started his competitive career in the 61-year-old Westchester County Annual Diving and Swimming Championships, to be held this week and next week.

title: TEACHERS' VACATION NOT WHAT IT SEEMS
description: While the effort to entice top college graduates to the teaching profession by advertising the perquisite of ''free'' summer vacations is a laudable one to a degree, it unfortunately distorts and misrepresents the situation for many teachers to the general public [ ''Teachers and the Criticism of Their Vacation,'' Opinion page, July 6 ] .

title: Visions of a Candy Factory Dance in His Head
description: The truth is, for a while, it was hard to find anyone who wanted to be Mayor of this little village on the Pennsylvania border.

title: TINY VILLAGE SEEKS LIMIT ON BUILDERS
description: WHEN the heirs of an estate proposed putting up homes on more than a third of the open fields and woodlands in the village of Dering Harbor on Shelter Island, the community came up with a highly unusual answer: Make it illegal to build in the village unless the builder will occupy the house.

title: P.S.: IT'S NOT JUST WHAT YOU WRITE, BUT HOW YOU WRITE IT
description: ASK ANY corporate leader whether writing is important, and the answer will be a hearty affirmative.

title: A LOOK BACK AT THE IDEA THAT CREATED THE U.S.F.L.
description: WHEN Federal District Court Judge Peter K. Leisure sent the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League to the jury last Thursday, 11 weeks and several million dollars had been spent in search of an answer to the question: Will there continue to be a U.S.F.L.?

title: TV MAKES THE READER
description: FOR most books, the best that television has to offer is a mention on the ''Donahue'' show. For a few fortunate authors of children's books, however, there's something better still. ''Reading Rainbow,'' a weekday public television offering for children aged 5 to 8, was designed to encourage children to keep up their reading skills during summer vacation. But the popular program (now seen year round in many areas) has proved to have another function - encouraging the sale of well-written children's books. And according to publishers whose books have been featured, there really is a pot of gold at the end of the reading rainbow.

title: SENATE IS FORCED TO MODIFY ITS BLACKBALL PRIVILEGE
description: BY STAYING out of a fight over his renomination, Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court has forced the Senate to modify its traditional method of dealing with gubernatorial appointments.

title: PERIOD PIECES SHOULD BE TAKEN AS THEY ARE
description: In opera, just as in that other dramatically improbable sphere that we call the real world, it is sometimes wiser to accept small gifts gladly than to hold out for the multimillion lottery payoff. It occurred to me, for instance, during a recent performance of ''Les Pecheurs de Perles'' at the New York City Opera that Bizet's work is one of a fairly small family of fatally flawed operas that even the most inspired stage direction cannot much improve. With its impossibly muddled libretto and intermittently captivating music, this is the sort of faded period piece that must be taken as is or not at all. Once the listener accepts the intellectually blasphemous idea that any change will only be for the worse, a mood of tolerant resignation may overtake him. Given a moderately well-sung performance, secret flushes of affection may then be felt. Guilty pleasures, as musical intellectuals and other puritans know, are the best kind, after all.

title: GROUP PROMOTING READING BY CHILDREN
description: ''WE have to make an impact on the community so that reading becomes an issue of priority right after hunger and health,'' said Judith Rovenger, children's services librarian for the Westchester Library System.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A HARDWARE STORE THAT HAS WORN WELL -Brewers Hardware and Marine Center was established in 1879 in Mamaroneck, and the fifth generation of the family is supplying household and general hardware and marine supplies in the main store, and a gardening-needs outlet and The Woodworker's Store both downhill toward the Post Road Boat Yard. Now a True Value Hardware Store, Brewers participates in monthly group promotions, with its own specials seasonally on building and plumbing materials, marine paints and rigging assemblies, lifejackets and slickers.

title: MORNING GLORIES LEAD TO A TRAIL OF VINES
description: One summer, an artistic neighbor decided to devote the entire season to painting only morning glories.

title: UNREST IN THE GRASS
description: IN a meadow at Bethpage State Park yesterday, a bunch of guys brandishing sticks over their heads chased each other around on horseback.

title: Mary Hall Is Married
description: Mary Amanda Hall, a daughter of Mortimer W. Hall of Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Diana Lynn, the actress, was married at Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook yesterday to Abbett Post Howland, a son of Mrs. Cornelius DeForest Howland of New York and Millbrook and the late Mr. Howland. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Warren Skipp, was followed by a reception at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: RETIRED WORKERS RETURNING TO PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT
description: WHEN Ruth Fragus, a financial analyst, left General Foods in January last year after almost 20 years in the financial department, she was given a ''wonderful'' retirement party by 75 of her co-workers. Ms. Fragus, who is more than 50 years old, spent the first few months of her retirement catching up on things she had always wanted to do, including remodeling her house in White Plains. Last month, Ms. Fragus was back at General Foods in Rye Brook, working as a temporary employee, in the corporate contributions department, three-and-a-half hours every morning.

title: Nationalism Versus Denationalization
description: THE new rightist French Government's plan to sell 65 state-owned banks and industrial companies to private investors has produced the first serious clash between Premier Jacques Chirac and Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist President, in the four months they have shared power.

title: Robert Woodbury 2d Marries Jessica Miller
description: Jessica Davi Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Arthur Woodbury 2d, a son of Drs. George and Linda Woodbury of Memphis.

title: CONGRESS'S DOCTOR REPLACED
description: The attending physician of Congress is abruptly being released by the Navy from the job he has held for 13 years, to be replaced by another military doctor.

title: REAGAN RESISTS SANCTIONS, BUT...
description: PRESIDENT Reagan urged Congress last week to reject ''punitive sanctions'' against South Africa, but many senators could not have disagreed more. Senator Richard G. Lugar, the influential Republican chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, was weighing new measures aimed at pressuring white South Africans to open negotiations with black leaders on abolishing apartheid.

title: Article 986886 -- No Title
description: The 60-year-old son of an exiled South Vietnamese Ambassador to the United States was held on $100,000 bond today in the slaying of his mother and father, the parents of Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu, who was known as the ''Dragon Lady.''

title:
ART;
SPIRITED SHOWS IN NEW HAVEN
description: PREDOMINANT in a glass case in New Haven's Gallery Jazz is one of Henri Matisse's limited edition books entitled ''Jazz,'' and one looks to this 20th-century masterpiece to set the spirit and tone for the gallery. The collection of cutout shapes embodies caprice, and the gallery is capricious in the best sense.

title: Miss Thomas to Wed A Lawyer in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. David G. Thomas of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Victoria Catherine Thomas to E. Robert Lupone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erzio Lupone of Hamden, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: OPERA: SCHUMAN'S 'MIGHTY CASEY,' SUNG IN THE BASEBALL CAPITAL
description: On its own modest level, the Glimmerglass Opera Theater's production of ''The Mighty Casey,'' by William Schuman, is a near total success, and one of the most engaging and unpretentious evenings of music theater I've attended in a long time.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FIGURES OF ENCHANTMENT. By Zulfikar Ghose. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) This odd, alluring novel explores what Zulfikar Ghose calls ''fantastic reality'' by following the related journeys of two spiritually desperate men in a fictional South American country.

title: Kim Tripp is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James D. Tripp of Huntington and Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Elizabeth Tripp, to David John Fickbohm, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Henry Fickbohm of St. James, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMADEUS: A Mozart Mosaic. By Herbert Kupferberg. (McGraw-Hill, $14.95.) The title and tone of this bio-miscellany seem calculated to cash in on the new attention drawn to Mozart by the Academy Award-winning film, ''Amadeus.''

title: YANKEES FALL TO TWINS, 8-4
description: Each answer was short and each word was hesitant yesterday as a dejected Lou Piniella was forced to talk about his pitching staff that had been battered for a second straight game by the Minnesota Twins.

title: POP: NEIL DIAMOND'S GUITAR-BASED MELODIES
description: ''HISTORY begins,'' announces the poster advertising Neil Diamond's current engagement at Madison Square Garden. Exactly what that statement means is anybody's guess, but it evokes the kind of glitzy showmanship, accompanied by an aura of vague mysticism, that have made Mr. Diamond one of the country's two or three biggest concert attractions among middle-aged suburban audiences.

title: Sept. 14 Wedding Set For Katherine Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel David Smith of Morristown, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Newell Smith, to Alan Clay Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Miller of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: HOW U.S. INTELLIGENCE SHARES SOME SECRETS AMONG FRIENDS
description: AMONG all the furtive dealings of intelligence agencies, few are more secret than the sharing of information with other countries. For while such exchanges are essential to any intelligence service, their public disclosure could hopelessly complicate foreign policy questions.

title: WHAT'S DRIVING MBA'S TO WALL STREET
description: CAPTAINS of industry are upset that they don't make M.B.A.'s the way they used to: Today's models crave the fast buck on Wall Street and shun work in real companies making real products. American industry, they say, is being brought to its knees by a rapidly multiplying horde of paper entrepreneurs. Nonsense. Investment banks did indeed attract thrice as many M.B.A.'s from Harvard this year as did industrial companies - a complete reversal of the ratios that prevailed when I graduated in 1979. But this reflects not the greed of recent graduates but the important point that most M.B.A.'s in corporate finance, securities analysis and venture capital are merely taking over the financial functions that used to be performed by managers in large corporations.

title: A Letter to Bishop Tutu: 'Don't Give Up on Us Yet'
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu

title: A Soccer Benefit
description: Diego Maradona, who led Argentina to the World Cup soccer championship in Mexico last month, will lead the Americas team against the Rest of the World in the Rose Bowl today in the World All-Star soccer game. Maradona's teammate, Jose Luis Brown, who scored a goal in Argentina's 3-2 victory over West Germany in the World Cup final, will also be on the Americas team, as will be five members of the Brazil team.

title: PROTECTING PROGRAMS FROM PIRATES
description: RECENTLY, I reread Christopher Sykes's ''Four Studies in Loyalty,'' a satisfying little book that has been relegated to the scrap heap of history not only by its near antiquity in the eyes of teen-agers like my eldest daughter, the volume having been published as long ago as 1946, but also by its very subject matter.

title: USE OF LOCKING SWITCHES WEIGHED
description: The state police in New Jersey, in the wake of the deaths of six people in a crash involving a stolen police car, are examining the possibility of installing devices capable of locking the ignition or transmission and preventing the quick theft of vehicles.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 27, 1986
description: Fiction

title: THE SUBTLE WORK OF MAKING SUPERTITLES
description: Whether called ''subtitles,''

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE HORSE KNEW THE WAY
description: Michael Wood, who has based IN SEARCH OF THE TROJAN WAR (Facts on File, $22.95) on the BBC television series of the same name, concludes that Mycenae and other Greek kingdoms did in fact destroy the Anatolian city of Troy at Hissarlik at the end of the Bronze Age, between 1375 and 1250 B.C. Although the ancients had no documentary evidence, in the modern sense, the veracity of the story was accepted in the bardic tradition crystallized in Homer's ''Iliad,'' and by Herodotus and Thucydides. A Greek colony was built at Hissarlik, and the ruins of Troy were smothered by classical temples and shrines.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Sports of The Times column in some copies last Sunday on the 1961 Yankees incorrectly stated the game number in which Roger Maris tied Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs in a season, as well as the date and site of the homer. Maris hit his 60th home run in the Yankees' 159th game at Yankee Stadium Sept. 26.

title: IN MELISSA MILLER'S WILD KINGDOM LURKS A WORLD OF WONDER
description: In Melissa Miller's painting ''Leopard Dance,'' three tigers and a leopard are transfixed at the edge of a clearing. Two of the tigers peer out from the overhangs of cliffs. The third, as well as the leopard, is perched on a blue tree. All four animals seem like giant fuses, or like ambulatory orange and black furnaces. The object of their rapture is on its hind paws in the distance. In a pocket of almost white light, a leopard is dancing.

title: LEMOND STILL LEADS AS TOUR NEARS END
description: Greg LeMond of the United States held on to first place after the 22d leg of the Tour de France cycling classic today, and was the overwhelming favorite on the eve of the race's finish on the Champs-Elysees in Paris.

title: 10 PROJECTS ARE HONORED FOR L.I. 'SENSE OF PLACE'
description: TEN projects built or planned for the East End were cited for design excellence at BeauxArch, an annual architectural exposition in the Hamptons that encourages a higher and more responsible sense of design on Long Island.

title: Greene Named Winner Of Piano Competition
description: The pianist Arthur Greene was named winner of this year's William Kapell Piano Competition, sponsored by the University of Maryland. Mr. Greene, who is from Sheffield, Mass., will receive $15,000 and appear in concerts in New York (at Carnegie Hall in January) and in other cities. The pianists Nelson Padgett and David Allen Wehr each received $7,500 in a tie for second prize.

title: Manion Judgeship Won Narrowly And With Muscle
description: Daniel A. Manion, whose critics said he lacked the competence, commitment and experience to be a Federal judge, ultimately did not lack the votes. After months of debate, some last-minute maneuvers and a horse-trade or two, the Senate narrowly approved last week Mr. Manion's appointment to the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

title: Solo Voyagers
description: To the Editor: I am writing in response to the answer given the woman who travels alone and has to pay more for the privilege. This has long irked me, and I was glad to see a Q & A item (Travel, June 29) on the subject.

title: Wedding in Brussels For Sophie Everaert
description: Sophie Everaert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Everaert of Brussels, was married there yesterday to Dr. Christopher Paul Cannon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Cannon of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Jacques 't Serstevens performed the ceremony at the Annunciation Roman Catholic Church.

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor: Resorting to hyperbole to make a point is not an unknown practice among critics, but I believe Harold C. Schonberg [ ''Do Today's Pianists Have the Romantic Touch?,'' July 6 ] goes beyond the acceptable when he describes the reaction of today's pianists to recorded performances of past generations. I know of no pianists who come away from these records ''dazed, stunned and talking to themselves,'' overwhelmed with ''an order of technique they have never before imagined.'' When it comes to the ''order of technique'' alone, old-master recorded performances are matched by modern ones.

title: EX-BLACK PANTHER EXTRADITED TO U.S.
description: A principal actor in the violent past of the Black Panthers - sought for 14 years in connection with the hijacking of an airliner - arrived under guard from Paris at Kennedy International Airport yesterday.

title: Recent Releases
description: Mozart and Haydn:

title: NORTHERN SHOPPERS SCRAMBLE FOR ELUSIVE PARKING SPACES
description: A SIGN in the middle of the village green in bucolic Bedford Village reads: ''Part of a common laid out in 1681 for grazing cattle, horses and swine.'' Surrounding the lone sign are dozens of others, cautioning drivers to park for no more than an hour or restricting parking altogether. Weaving through the tightly packed cars surrounding the green is the town's parking-enforcement officer, chalking this one's tire or placing a ticket on that one's windshield. The green itself has become less of an oasis and more of a traffic circle.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: ON TUESDAY, 6-year-old Danny Carlisle of Dayton, Ohio, is coming to New Jersey to thank the people who helped save his life when he was a baby.

title: TOP CANDIDATE FOR PRETORIA POST FACES CRITICISM ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: The possibility that the Foreign Service's senior black diplomat may soon be named Ambassador to South Africa has revived an eight-year-old debate over his view that human rights should best be advanced through quiet diplomacy and not through public declarations.

title: GAS GONE, BUT BHOPAL STILL ACHES
description: Quresha Bee, a 35-year-old victim of the gas leak from the Union Carbide plant here in 1984, visited a hospital for the first time in June and told a psychiatrist that she had suddenly begun experiencing strange symptoms - bouts of fear combined with breathlessness and chest pain.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:After we were bumped from one of its flights in May, People Express gave us free round-trip tickets to be used anywhere the airline flies within the United States. The tickets are good for one year. Since People may sell part or all of its airline, should I use the tickets now or will the new owners honor the airline's debts? - S. L., Princeton, N.J. Answer:People Express has agreed, in an announcement made July 10, to sell its Frontier Airlines subsidiary to United Airlines. ''People Express is conducting business as usual and will honor all tickets and vouchers,'' said Russell Marchetta, an official of the airline. The sale of the Denver-based Frontier Airlines, he said, will not be completed for at least three and possibly six months, and any voucher will be valid on Frontier's routes until the sale becomes official, as well as on the rest of the domestic People system.

title: Stock Cars Turn To Something New
description: The Winston Cup stock cars will be putting on one of their usual high-speed shows today at Talladega, Ala. But in two weeks the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing will make a stop in upstate New York for a race billed as the Budweiser at the Glen. It is an event that signals a fundamental change in one of the country's most popular forms of auto racing.

title: Art Deco Factory
description: It takes a stretch of the imagination to link Manhattan's Chrysler Building with the two-story factory building that hugs the Long Island Rail Road tracks in Long Island City, Queens.

title: OPPOSITION TO REHNQUIST NOMINATION HARDENS AS 2 NEW WITNESSES EMERGE
description: Liberal opposition to the nomination of Justice William H. Rehnquist to be the 16th Chief Justice of the United States is hardening amid a flurry of renewed allegations to be aired at hearings beginning Tuesday.

title: GOING ALL-OUT AGAINST APARTHEID
description: IN 1975, acting at the request of black leaders in South Africa, the Rev. Leon Sullivan began to devise a code of conduct for American corporations doing business in South Africa. Since he finished thecode in 1977, those Sullivan Principles have helped black South Africans gain workplace rights in numerous businesses and have played a role in the successful effort of black industrial labor unions to win the official recognition.

title: STUDYING TOKYO AS CITY THAT WORKS
description: The memory that Vincent P. Whitfield took home to New York City is of clean garbage trucks, loaded by men in white gloves.

title: A FURNITURE MAKER WATCHES 7th AVENUE
description: ''THE furniture business generally mirrors the economy,'' said Lee A. Corson of Great Neck, ''and it's very sensitive to interest rates. So as interest rates go down and housing starts increase, it bodes well for the furniture industry.''

title: 65-Year-Term for Rapist
description: A paroled killer from New York City who sexually attacked 17 girls and young women in Los Angeles apartment buildings has been sentenced to a maximum of 65 years in prison. Judge Robert Altman of Superior Court imposed a sentence that will require Ronald Melvin, 28 years old, to stay in prison for at least 32 years.

title: For Women, a Central Role in Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas; Texas 'Village' Is Topped Off
description: LAST month, after 17 years of constructing two- and three-story apartment buildings with pools, trees, patios and vast parking lots, the Lincoln Property Company finished the last of the 7,115 rental units in the Village -- 14 adjoining communities comprising the largest garden-apartment complex in the nation.

title: Ear to the Ground In California
description: Since an earthquake caused damage in and around Palm Springs July 8, Californians have been listening more intently to the ruminations of seismologists. But the experts are the first to admit that they do not know when, where or how big the next jolt will be or why this month has been the most seismically active period in California in several years.

title: LOW WATER LEVELS IN SOUTH LIKELY TO LAST MONTHS
description: The effects of what is already the worst drought in the South's history will probably persist through the rest of the year, officials say, and worsening water shortages could close factories and drive even more farmers toward financial ruin.

title: SOVIET BUILDING ATOM SMASHER, WORLD'S BIGGEST
description: Outside this small Russian town, Soviet physicists are busy creating the world's most powerful atom smasher, a sprawling machine expected to give the Soviet Union a dominant role in particle physics over the next decade.

title: TWO MILLION AMERICANS AND COUNTING
description: THE PLAGUE YEARS A Chronicle of AIDS, the Epidemic of Our Times. By David Black. 224 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95. MOBILIZING AGAINST AIDS The Unfinished Story of a Virus. By Eve K. Nichols. 212 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Institute of Medicine/National Academy of Sciences/Harvard University Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $7.95. MANY people read about AIDS thinking of themselves. The AIDS virus is fatal, mutating, sexually transmitted and equally common among men and women in certain countries; its true incubation period is unknown.

title: RABBINICAL COLLEGE IN MORRISTOWN EXPANDS CAMPUS
description: IN THE hills overlooking this county seat stands what is believed to be the largest campus in the world for the study of Hasidic Judaism: the Rabbinical College of America, an affiliate of the Lubavitch Movement.

title: Susan B. Brooks Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of Susan Byrd Brooks to George Hutchison Love 2d has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Ernest A. Brooks 2d of St. Louis.

title: BEATING CANCER DISCRIMINATION
description: A POLICE officer walked briskly to Timothy Calonita's front proch recently and delivered the news that the 24-year-old Mineola resident had awaited for months.

title: A BIT OF FRANCE OFF THE COAST OF CANADA
description: Al Capone slept here when the gangster was running bootleg liquor into the United States during Prohibition. Charles de Gaulle stopped in as President of France. And the French Navy scored its first victory of World War II with an invasion here launched behind the backs of Canada and the United States.

title: SEMIOTICIANS HAVE MORE FUN
description: TRAVELS IN HYPERREALITY Essays. By Umberto Eco. Translated by William Weaver. 307 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95. IN ''Reports From the Global Village'' - falling roughly halfway through the sequence of essays and articles which Umberto Eco has gathered together under the general title ''Travels in Hyperreality'' - the wily and witty Italian philosopher, historian, semiotician and author of the best-selling novel, ''The Name of the Rose,'' offers a surprising proposition: ''All the professors of theory of communications, trained by the texts of twenty years ago (this includes me), should be pensioned off.'' Mr. Eco is only kidding, of course; and the reader who has followed him that far knows it instantly, being already experienced in the rhetorical stances, several kinds of ambiguity and stylistic fun and games Mr. Eco employs to consider almost everything under the sun - holography, wax museums, ''The Return of the Middle Ages,'' Superman and ''Casablanca,'' Federico Fellini and Michelangelo Antonioni, the survival of ancient African religious sects and cults in contemporary Brazil, Jim Jones and his murderous temple, the Red Brigades and terrorism in general, Marshall McLuhan and Charles Manson, Woody Allen and St. Thomas Aquinas, the social and personal implications of snug-fitting blue jeans and the secret meaning of spectator sports.

title: Man Tried to Sell Daughter
description: An Encino man was convicted Friday of attempting to sell his 2-year-old daughter for $90,000 to a couple who wanted to adopt her. Jurors deliberated less than two hours before finding Alan Daniel, 30, guilty of attempting to sell a person.

title: Detroit Strikers Settle With City
description: As proof of his impatience with a 10-day-old strike by 7,000 municipal workers, Mayor Coleman Young of Detroit began taking offers off the bargaining table last week instead of putting them on.

title: West Germans Throng To Anti-Nuclear Concert
description: Tens of thousands of West Germans and Austrians descended on this Bavarian hamlet today for a two-day rock concert to protest nuclear power.

title: BURMA
description: To the Editor: Having spent a month in Southeast Asia in February - including the allotted week in Burma -my wife and I enjoyed the three articles on Burma. Herewith, some observations on this interesting country from our own experience.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
PIPING PLOVER
description: Charadrius melodus Size: Seven inches long.

title: IN ITALY, SUMMER ON ICE
description: Before gelaterias started appearing on every street corner in Rome, and before gelato became a yuppie standard in New York and San Francisco, Romans fought off the long hot summer with libations of crushed ice and fruit juice called grattachecche and granite. A grattachecca is shaved or crushed ice over which a variety of syrups or fruit juices are poured. A granita, on the other hand, is fruit juice or coffee first frozen and then ground into ice.

title: Shown the Door
description: Often the difference between reportage and espionage is in the eye of the jailer. Certainly there were diverging views of what John F. Burns, the Peking bureau chief of The New York Times, was up to last month when he and two companions took a motorcycle trip through central China.

title: 'Lolita' Precursor To Be Published
description: A Vladimir Nabokov story about a man with an obsessive desire for a young girl -written years before the publication of ''Lolita'' - will be published late this year by G. P. Putnam's Sons, the publishing house said today.

title: Janice B. Hinkle, Teacher, Marries
description: The marriage of Janice Byington Hinkle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. Hinkle of New Canaan, Conn., to John Scott Kitchen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kitchen of Indianapolis, took place yesterday in New Canaan. The Rev. Roland H. Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS SOJOURN OUTSIDE
description: SO your house plants are on vacation, too. They are doing so well under the shade tree in the backyard. Why, only last week you glanced in their direction when you checked out the lawn sprinkler, and they were still there. Maybe you had better look again. Perhaps you have exiled them to Siberia, rather than an outdoor paradise.

title: SUFFOLK TAKEOVER OF LILCO CONSIDERED
description: DISSATISFIED with the pace that Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature have set for replacing the Long Island Lighting Company with a public power authority, members of the Suffolk County Legislature are considering a $7.3 billion Lilco takeover effort of their own.

title: Tara Weingarten Engaged To Marry Fellow Reporter
description: Lila Weingarten and Arthur Weingarten, both of Beverly Hills, Calif., announce the engagement of their daughter, Tara May Weingarten, to Robert M. Feinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Selwyn Feinstein of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: The Betrothal of Sandra C. Thornton To Sheldon Whitehouse Announced
description: Sandra Christine Thornton, a daughter of Daphne Sellar Thornton of Newport, R.I., and Henry H. M. Thornton of Ridgefield, Conn., and Sheldon Whitehouse, a son of Charles S. Whitehouse of Marshall, Va., and the late Mary Rand Whitehouse of Washington, plan to be married in September.

title: VINEYARDS BECKON TO WINE LOVERS
description: NOW through harvesting in September, Connecticut's eight vineyard-wineries are a sea of greenery. Starting with bud-breaking in early June, the scene shifts rapidly from the appearance of small green flowers to shoots leafing out, growing an inch a day, eventually becoming heavy with grapes.

title: A United Statesian Celebrates
description: William Safire's article, ''Who Is an 'American?' '' (On Language, June 29), was soothing to a longstanding hang-up of mine: What lies behind our having persuaded the entire world to call our country ''America''? It implies an unbecoming arrogance on the part of one segment of the vast Western Hemisphere.

title: Currie Cabot to Wed Thomas Barron
description: The engagement of Currie Cabot to Thomas Archibald Barron has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Cabot of Cold Spring, N.Y., and La Malbaie, Quebec, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald G. Barron of Colorado Springs.

title: GOODEN FAILS TO HOLD LEAD
description: The game was going to be a crossroads of sorts for Dwight Gooden, a chance to test the minor tinkering he had undergone during two sessions on the sidelines earlier this week. In one respect, the young Met pitcher passed; in another, he did not.

title: Turf Upset At Belmont
description: A late afternoon thunderstorm, so severe that it delayed the running of the seventh race at Belmont yesterday by 20 minutes, produced an improbable result in the Sword Dancer Handicap, which followed. Southern Sultan, the seventh betting choice in the field of eight, drew away through the stretch to score a 10-length upset victory.

title: No Mideast Glimmer
description: It is hard to see how the Israeli-Moroccan summit can have advanced anything constructive in the Middle East. The timing was obviously in connection with internal Israeli politics.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS SOJOURN OUTSIDE
description: SO your house plants are on vacation, too. They are doing so well under the shade tree in the backyard. Why, only last week you glanced in their direction when you checked out the lawn sprinkler, and they were still there. Maybe you had better look again. Perhaps you have exiled them to Siberia, rather than an outdoor paradise.

title: THERE'S A CROWD IN CUOMO'S WAKE
description: LIEUTENANT governors are the downtrodden of politics and government. Custom dictates that they be seen only in the shadow of governors and speak only in their praise. But obscure as the spot may be, it has drawn a field of four Democratic candidates in New York this year, and Governor Cuomo - once a lieutenant governor himself - is making extraordinary efforts to avoid being handed a running mate he does not want.

title: Challenger's Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: METS ADOPT YANKEES' TUMULTUOUS STYLE IN RUNAWAY RACE
description: Any day now, Nelson Doubleday will surely issue a statement blistering George Foster for failing to generate the type of hitting that is incumbent upon a man making $2 million a year.

title: WHAT'S NEW AMONG BLACK ENTREPRENEURS
description: NEARLY a generation ago, President Richard M. Nixon's Administration sought to create a class of highly visible, successful black businessmen to counter charges of indifference to blacks. There were increased budgets and special programs for the Small Business Administration, and ''set-aside'' programs that reserved some subcontracting business for companies controlled by members of racial minority groups.

title: CONGRESS SEEMS A RELUCTANT PROSECUTOR
description: FOR only the 14th time in the nation's history, the House of Representatives has impeached a Federal official. The vote last week, 406 to 0, means that Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas, a convicted tax evader who is serving a two-year prison term, must resign or face a Senate trial.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of transmission errors, the telephone number of American Field Services International, which recruits host families for foreign exchange students, should have been (800) AFS-INFO. Also, the name of another recruiting organization should have been Youth for Understanding.

title: Lisa Bain, Editor, Marries William McD. Schwarz
description: Lisa Bain, a daughter of Rosemary Haward Bain of Port Washington, L.I., and the late David Bain, was married yesterday to William McDonald Schwarz, the son of Lucille Haley Schwarz of Manhasset, L.I., and the late William M. Schwarz. The Rev. Wyndham Anderson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: PRETORIA ARRESTS PUT AT 10,000
description: More than 10,000 people have been detained since the state of emergency was declared in South Africa on June 12, according to the Geneva-based World Council of Churches.

title: Thorns Have Their Uses
description: This is high season for thorns, what with blackberries slashing greedy pickers, cat brier tearing the skin of innocent passers-by and roses jabbing at unwary admirers. ''No rose without its thorn,'' a victim might say, being poetic and also inaccurate.

title: WHERE NO SIGN IS A GOOD SIGN
description: STARR BOGGS, the chef, who opened Starr Boggs, the restaurant, in Westhampton Beach on Memorial Day Weekend, is one of the individuals responsible for the high quality of cooking in Quogue and Westhampton over the last few seasons.

title: Cable TV
description: Two film premieres on cable should make entertaining light antidotes against the hot weather. ''The Coca-Cola Kid'' (1985), with Eric Roberts and Greta Scacchi, is a whimsical diversion sprinkled with surprises about a corporate troubleshooter dispatched to Australia - Friday at 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Bravo.

title: Now Back to the Show
description: Changing channels was not enough for John R. MacDougall, who became upset when Home Box Office began scrambling its signal to keep owners of satellite dish antennas from receiving it free. Mr. MacDougall, a Florida salesman of those very same antennas, protested by interrupting an HBO broadcast in April with his own message. In a televised note signed ''Captain Midnight'' and beamed through the uplink facilities of the teleport company where Mr. MacDougall worked, he said ''No way!'' to HBO's scrambled signals.

title: HONG KONG
description: Hong Kong is often referred to as a global village, but it is really a Cantonese city that trades with, absorbs, borrows, buys and sells the talents of people from all provinces of China, all countries of Asia and most parts of the world.

title: Susan S. Powell Is Wed in Maine
description: Susan Sargent Powell, the daughter of Richard M. Powell of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Patricia McLean Powell, was married yesterday to Steven Michael Rosstad, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olav Rosstad of Clearwater, Fla. Bishop William H. Marmion, retired from the Episcopal Diocese of Southwestern Virginia, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's-by-the-Sea Church in Ogunquit, Me.

title: Nancy Burke Is Married
description: Nancy Burke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burke of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Bryan Jason Tunney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Tunney of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Nathan Adams performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. James Curry, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is an actress and Mr. Tunney a government securities broker for Garban Ltd. in New York.

title: BY RAIL TO THE OTHER SIDE OF JAPAN
description: When the poet Basho visited the sparsely populated low cliffs along the Sea of Japan in the summer of 1689, he described an ''angry sea'' and called the forbidding coastline the ''expression of a troubled mind.''

title: SILVERSMITHING: AN ART NOT LOST
description: ''OUT OF 1,200 booths at the craft fairs in Springfield (Mass.), there was only one piece of holloware.''

title: INDIAN MARKET: A MAZE OF ART
description: Temptations beckon shoppers from all sides in Santa Fe. There are 60 Indian traders and shops, dozens of Indian women with their wares spread out under the portal of the Palace of the Governors and scores of boutiques and gift shops.

title: Long Tackles Steroids
description: Howie Long, the Los Angeles Raiders' all-pro defensive end, says the National Football League is focusing on the wrong drug culprit in its plans to test players for cocaine. The real chemical bane of the league, he says, is steroids, which are used by some athletes as a training aid in building bulk quickly.

title: MALPRACTICE: PUTTING PROGRESS AT RISK
description: CONSIDER: A woman who had an implant inserted into her body 10 years ago develops cancer. She wins a suit for a million dollars against the doctor who inserted the implant. Her lawyer, on being told that there was no scientific evidence that an implant can cause cancer, says, ''To hell with scientific evidence: the jury says it did!''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DEFENDER: The Story of General Dynamics. By Roger Franklin. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) This book is the literary equivalent of a strategic bomber.

title: The Old Ball Game
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNSON LEADS DU MAURIER BY 1 AFTER 74
description: Chris Johnson shot a 2-over-par 74 today but managed to take a one-stroke lead at 209 after three rounds of the $353,000 du Maurier Classic.

title: Miss Rosenthal to Wed S. G. Gellman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Rosenthal of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Pamela Rosenthal, to Stephen Glenn Gellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Gellman of Scarsdale, N.Y. A Sept. 6 wedding is planned.

title: Renegade Cowboy
description: Dextor Clinkscale, the Dallas Cowboys' strong safety and a training camp holdout, sees himself as the Rodney Dangerfield of the National Football League. Like the comedian, Clinkscale says, he gets ''no respect'' - and not very much money either.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: STRANGER IN TWO WORLDS by Jean Harris. Macmillan Publishing Company. 388 pages. $18.95.

title: Violence in India: Sikh Extremists Kill 15 on a Bus
description: Violence broke out again last week between Sikhs and Hindus in India.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 'BRASS SPECTACULAR'

title:
ANTIQUES;
UNRAVELING THE MYSTERIES OF LACE
description: SOME of the history and much of the romance of old lace, as well as tips on care and advice on using antique and heirloom pieces, will be explored at the Heritage Museum here next Sunday in an informal talk entitled ''The Luxury of Lace.''

title: WILSON PACE WON BY CULLIN HANOVER
description: Cullin Hanover, with Buddy Gilmour driving, captured the $1,561,500 Woodrow Wilson Pace at the Meadowlands tonight on the richest card in harness racing, dubbed the Million Dollar Babies.

title: THE PURIFICATION OF FRANCE
description: THE PURGE By Herbert R. Lottman. 332 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95. IN the fateful years between the armistice of June 1940 and liberation in the summer of 1944, French men and women faced an anguished choice. They could take their lead from Charles de Gaulle in London, resist the Germans and create disruptions and diversions until, with outside aid, the occupying army was expelled. Or they could follow the lead of Marshal Philippe Petain and his government in Vichy, which by collaborating promised to shield France from even harsher enemy treatment.

title: THE DEMISE OF A LONG-LIVED IF SLOPPY SPY RING
description: A Federal jury rang down the final curtain last week on an espionage conspiracy that began with a meeting between two Navy buddies in 1974 at a now-defunct San Diego restaurant called Boom Trenchard's Flarepath. After 10 days of deliberation, the jury found a former Navy radioman, Jerry A. Whitworth, guilty on seven counts of espionage and five counts of tax fraud for passing military data to John A. Walker Jr., who sold it to the Soviet Union for nearly a decade.

title: Potomac, the Restaurant
description: By most accounts, Washington has become a restaurant city only in recent years, and its most successful establishments tend to be relatively small and discreet. This pattern may or may not come to an end Wednesday when Warner LeRoy, identified by his own publicity as ''a restaurant impresario,'' opens Potomac, a 900-seat multimillion-dollar multilevel restaurant overlooking the river of the same name.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'CORPORATE ACTION'
description: A newly formed county community-services group tentatively called ''Corporate Action'' will meet Aug. 5 to begin ''planning to do something worthwhile in a social setting,'' according to John Damonti, the corporate-relations manager of MONY Financial Services, and one of the organizers. The meeting will take place in The Pub of Arrowwood of Westchester in Rye Brook at 6 P.M. ''It will be for an introduction - we don't want to set anything too solidly until we meet,'' Mr. Damonti said.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Beauty, like fame, is fleeting.

title: HARNESS RACING: AMERICANA TO BOOM, THEN BUST
