description: EXACTLY 70 years ago this month, the racing stallion Dan Patch, a burnished Illinois harness horse who paced his way to over $3 million in earnings, died in his stall and was mourned nationwide in the manner reserved for heads of state and heroes.

title: CHANGES ARE FEW AS SPAIN SWEARS IN CABINET
description: A new Cabinet with few changes was sworn in here today, reflecting Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's determination to maintain continuity despite high unemployment and a new round of Basque terrorism.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS SOJOURN OUTSIDE
description: SO your house plants are on vacation, too. They are doing so well under the shade tree in the backyard. Why, only last week you glanced in their direction when you checked out the lawn sprinkler, and they were still there. Maybe you had better look again. Perhaps you have exiled them to Siberia, rather than an outdoor paradise.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ONE OF the key points of disagreement between environmentalists and developers in the current debate over wetlands regulation is buffer zones: How much room there should be between development and sometimes-fragile wetlands ecosystems.

title: Green Beans, Red Dawn: Canned Security
description: Once, not many years ago, before it was possible to eat today what was growing outside Florence last night, the American cupboard was a sight to behold. Just think of the colors.

title: P. B. Cawley Wed To Leslie Keating
description: St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Leslie Patricia Keating, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass., to Peter Belden Cawley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Cawley of Bristol, Conn. Msgr. Russell H. Davis performed the ceremony.

title: CHESS RIVALS MAKE MOVES FOR PUBLICITY
description: Anatoly Karpov, vowing to wrest back the world chess championship from Gary Kasparov, began his half of a publicity match with his nemesis by attempting what is known in the art of public relations as the oblique lionizing opening.

title: FROM YOUNG TO THE OLD, BEACHGOERS ARE A VARIED LOT
description: AH, the beach! On a beautiful sunny weekend in Fairfield County, any of our beaches can unearth a potpourri of sound, color and sights. Sunworshippers of all sizes, shapes and ages crowd together on common territory, where the conversations alone can entertain an alert listener.

title: FAR FROM PORTUGAL, A BREED OF WATER DOGS THRIVE
description: CHILDREN who come to swim in the pool at Deyanne F. Miller's New Canaan home have to pass what she calls ''the Charlie Brown lifeguard test.''

title: Which Side Are We On?
description: Like a complacent sleepwalker, oblivious to evil and isolated by a yea-saying staff, Ronald Reagan risks failing the greatest moral test of his Presidency: South Africa.

title: FUND'S GIFT TO A 9-YEAR OLD: A SECOND FAMILY
description: The night of July 4, Kevin Haaz watched the fireworks display over New York Harbor and stayed out until 4 A.M. But there will be no such splurging now.

title: CITY PLANNING 18% INCREASE IN BEDS FOR PSYCHIATRIC PATIENTS
description: Aiming to reduce overcrowding at psychiatric treatment centers, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation plans to increase by about 18 percent the number of beds for psychiatric patients in municipal hospitals, officials said yesterday.

title: POLICE CHASES: QUICK DECISIONS
description: In the early morning hours last Sunday, a patrol car pursuing two suspected car thieves slammed at high speed into a lamppost in Brooklyn and split in half. The two officers were injured, one of them seriously.

title: Dance
description: Summer festivals continue to be festive. This week, Pilar Rioja and the Mandala Folk Dance Ensemble share the bill at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival near Lee, Mass. Ms. Rioja is noted for stylistically varied and emotionally intense solo programs of Spanish court, flamenco and gypsy dances.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ON GOLDEN OSCEOLA
description: SUMMER in the suburbs is not all golf and tennis. Tucked away on a stretch of old road here is a little spot that looks like - well, like someplace else. Maybe New Hampshire. Maybe upstate New York. But not Westchester, at least not the image many hold of Westchester.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Fresh Air Fund misidentified a child in the Friendly Towns Program. He was Peter Lanausse, not Dante Johnson.

title: LLOYD, NAVRATILOVA TAKE CUP MATCHES
description: Bolstered by Chris Evert Lloyd's partial return to form, the United States team swept past West Germany in the Federation Cup today, setting up a test of both tennis and emotional loyalty in the final round against Czechoslovakia.

title: TEXAS' OIL TROUBLES SPUR A BITTER DEBATE ON SERVICES Vs. TAXES
description: For months Texans have heard warnings that the collapse of world oil prices would soon bring a grave fiscal crisis to state government. This week state budget analysts gave Texans a vision of what that means:

title: SANTA FE: A SUMMER SAMPLE
description: The nearest commercial airport to Santa Fe is an hour away in Albuqerque, where one can rent a car or take the Shuttle Jack (505-982-4311), a taxi service. Reservations are necessary, and the cost one way is $15. In August and early September the high desert sun is strong, and there are frequent summer showers. The mornings are chilly, with temperatures in the mid-50's. The afternoons are usually hot (80 degrees or higher).

title: A Suffolk Court Orders Parents to Aid Couple
description: A teen-age married couple, who are expecting their second child in October, must be supported by their own parents, a Family Court hearing examiner in Suffolk County has ruled.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Airports are not generally known for their effective communication to the busy traveler, but the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey hopes to change that for those people who use Newark International, Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lincoln City, Ore.;
For Vacation Or Retirement
description: TWO styles of real estate - one for vacation living, another for retirement - meld together in a little known 55-mile stretch of ocean beauty and hinterland lakes in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Recent Sales
description: Montgomery $164,000 328 Sunset Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9 1/2-year-old ranch; family room with fireplace, *2*oak floors, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $2,490. Oak Ridge $149,000 Longwood Lake Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old bilevel; family room, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,331. Sandwood $152,000 210 Marion Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, *2*formal dining room, 1-car garage, family room; taxes $2,154. Scotch Plains $280,000 27 Allenby Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; cathedral living-room ceiling, *2*patio, dressing area in master bedroom; taxes $5,708. South Orange $305,000 630 Mountain Drive *2*5-bedroom, 4-bath, 20-year-old ranch; living room with *2*fireplace, den, enclosed porch, office, pool; taxes $9,061. West Orange $133,000 127 Mitchell Street *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old Tudor; den, 1-car garage; *2*taxes $2,941. OTHER AREAS Bedford, N.Y. $419,800 185 Middle Patent Road East *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 286-year-old frame Colonial; family room, *2*3 fireplaces, stream, pond, 3.94 acres; taxes $3,941. Branford, Conn. $109,000 6 Harvard Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; walk to beach, *2*large laundry room, 72- by 115-foot lot; taxes $827. East Northport, L.I. $180,000 1 Honey Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, central air-conditioning, in-ground *2*sprinklers, 2-car garage; taxes $3,800.

title: A FRUSTRATING STAKE-OUT IN BOLIVIA
description: A WEEK after the United States Army landed to help attack cocaine traffickers in the Bolivian jungle, the Interior Minister, Fernando Barthelemy, stood before a microphone at the American base here. ''This is not an open war with death,'' he said, addressing the concerns of some of his countrymen. ''There is no chance of U.S. troops getting involved in armed conflicts with Bolivians.''

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 DIE AS HINDUS AND INDIAN POLICE CLASH
description: Four people were killed here today as crowds of Hindus clashed with the police, threw rocks and set fires in New Delhi to protest the killing of 15 Hindu bus passengers in the Punjab on Friday.

title: GETTING STRONGER, GETTING WEAKER?
description: THE SOVIET PARADOX External Expansion, Internal Decline. By Seweryn Bialer. 391 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95. SEWERYN BIALER has done it again. He has rewritten the penetrating, often brilliant analysis of the Soviet regime and its policies that he has produced at intervals over the last decade. This time his stimulating, updated synthesis of his own views and those of others is wider-ranging than before. He gives more space to futurology, the international context, the Soviet policy of the United States, and his own prescriptions for policy. Unlike his book ''Stalin's Successors'' (1980), the new work is aimed more at lay readers than at scholars.

title: AN OFFICIAL ANALYSIS
description: The Epson World Simultaneous Pairs last month was pronounced a success by the participants, who apparently numbered over 60,000 in 83 countries; and a repeat is scheduled for next May. More than a quarter of the players were in the United States, with the next-largest group -about one-tenth - in France, which provided the organization and the winners.

title: Criticizing U.S. on South Africa Needs No Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SCHOLARLY ROUTE TO BOTTLING PEPSI
description: WHEN William Harvey, the soft-spoken 45-year-old president of Hampton University in Virginia, stares at his printouts and spews out words like ''variances'' and ''indices,'' academe's groves seem far, far away. Mr. Harvey does, in fact, have another professional life. Since March, he has been both president of the country's wealthiest black college (endowment: $71 million) and owner of the Pepsi-Cola bottling franchise in lily-white Houghton on Michigan's economically depressed Upper Penninsula.

title: HONING IN ON PICTURE SHARPNESS
description: The brief midsummer lull in the electronics trade provides a welcome chance to reconsider some of the fundamental concepts of video that are often glossed over in the headlong rush of developments. Such concepts should be re-examined periodically, for it is only in terms of these basic principles that we can evaluate the ceaseless stream of innovation.

title: AMERICAN HOSTAGE FREED IN LEBANON AFTER 19 MONTHS
description: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, one of five kidnapped Americans missing in Lebanon, was freed today by a radical Shiite group that said he was being released after nearly 19 months as a captive because his health was worsening.

title: GRADING HOLLYWOOD'S RATINGS SYSTEM
description: Although the report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, issued this month, deals only in passing with mainstream movies, the dispute it has reawakened is likely to draw attention to the way the movie industry is responding to public concern over the sex and violence that keep showing up at everybody's neighborhood theater. So it seems a useful time to assess the movie ratings system that was introduced 17 years ago in an effort to stave off crackdowns by local authorities. It has much to commend it, but it can be improved.

title: 'KILLER BEES' SEEN AS THREAT IN STATE
description: STATE agriculture officials are concerned that, in spite of a planned tightening up of inspections, African ''killer bees'' will appear in New Jersey within two years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the growing use by blind people of tape recordings instead of Braille misidentified the director of the Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, a division of the Library of Congress. He is Dr. F. Kurt Cylke, not Dr. Kurt Silke.

title: Train-Truck Collision Kills 9 in England
description: A passenger train hit a truck at a railroad crossing today near this village in northeast England, killing at least nine people and injuring 42, the police said.

title: THE PENTATHLON IS A PUSHOVER
description: For nearly an hour this morning, Jim Liddy stood behind a podium on an elevated platform, his clean-cut, all-America looks accented by a spotless white Navy uniform.

title: THE REAGAN LEGACY
description: There have been few chief executives since 1945 who have enjoyed the kind of domestic support and confidence presently invested in Mr. Reagan by his fellow countrymen.

title: On Needles and Pins
description: Hundreds of garment workers are coming to Washington this week to clamor for a bill that would limit imports of textiles. About 1,500 members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union have scheduled a rally for noon Wednesday on the Capitol steps, with sympathetic lawmakers from both parties as speakers.

title: Susan E. Cole is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger Thomas Cole of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Cole, to Mark A. Furlong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Furlong of Yarmouth Port, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: GORBACHEV'S DILEMMA
description: THERE IS AN OLD RUSSIAN SKAZKA (FAIRY TALE) IN which a wife must wash her hands into eternity, trying to remove the blood of the husband she murdered. All summer long the yellow water trucks have been flushing radioactive dust from the streets of Kiev and a cluster of towns surrounding the crippled Chernobyl nuclear reactor. By autumn, it is hoped, most of the dust will be gone. Not so the political fallout. That is a far different matter.

title: THE YEAR 2000: AN L.I. AGENDA
description: WHEN I was growing up, the year 2000 seemed a thousand years away. But today the turn of the century is fewer than 14 years away, less than a generation. Indeed, the kindergarten class entering school this fall will be the last high school graduating class of the 20th century, the class of 1999.

title: LEACH GAINS FINAL ON CIRCUIT, AT LAST
description: In 1982, Mike Leach became the first player from the Big 10 Conference in 25 years to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's singles championship. But since joining the men's pro tour at the United States Open later that year, Leach had never won a tournament or even reached a final.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Italians have come to town and they promise ''one big show,'' according to Capt. Douglas Draper, a spokesman for McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown.

title: SUMMER'S BEST
description: One August, several years ago, I was asked to judge a tomato contest. Appreciating the nuances of ripe tomatoes as I do, it struck me that this was an appointment to be taken seriously. The judging was to be held in New Jersey - home of a thousand varieties tended in backyard gardens and farmstand fields, all known generically as ''Jersey tomatoes'' - so competition was bound to be lively.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TOKEN REFUGE: The Story of the Jewish Refugee Shelter at Oswego, 1944-1946. By Sharon R. Lowenstein. (Indiana University, $27.50.) On June 12, 1944, President Franklin D. Roosevelt announced the establishment of the Fort Ontario Emergency Refugee Shelter that was to provide 1,000 refugees - mostly Jews - with a haven from Nazi Europe.

title: Green Beans, Red Dawn: Peace and Quiet
description: Early one recent Saturday morning - 6:30, to be exact - the penetrating staccato of pneumatic drills broke the silence of Manhattan's East 67th Street. Shirtless workmen were tearing up the sidewalk in front of the Soviet Union's United Nations mission.

title: TEACHERS ATTEND ECONOMICS INSTITUTE
description: FORTY-ONE teachers went back to school recently and the talk was of demand and supply curves, the dynamics of a capitalist economy, major economic theorists and the debates concerning current economic policies.

title: AFTER AN ARID 1985, WATER IS PLENTIFUL
description: WITH rainfall at or above normal for several months, water is plentiful throughout the state this summer, unlike last year, when many water customers were being asked to restrict their water use.

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title:
ON LANGUAGE;
STARTING FROM SCRATCH
description: A STUDY COMMISSIONED by a brewery in the early 1980's found that nearly 70 percent of Americans watch, discuss or read about sports every day, and that 44 percent actually take part in some kind of sports activity daily. The same study revealed that only 3.7 percent of those surveyed were ''virtually uninvolved'' in sports. Not surprisingly, sports affect the way we think, the way we look and the way we talk.

title: BRIDGE TEAMS IN ROUND OF 16
description: The biggest bridge tournament ever played wound down here today with 16 teams surviving in the prestigious Spingold Knockout Team Championship.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VIC HOLYFIELD AND THE CLASS OF 1957. By William Heyen. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $4.95.) Most of us develop some feeling of nostalgia for our high school years, especially as those years recede.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $3.95.) Garrison Keillor's comic memoir of the fictional hamlet of Lake Wobegon, Minn. - home of such institutions as the Chatterbox Cafe, Our Lady of Perpetual Responsibility Church and Art's Bait & Night O'Rest Motel - is ''a genuine work of American history,'' Veronica Geng said in The Book Review last year. Lake Wobegon, she said, ''joins Thurber's Columbus as an absurd definition of a very real Midwest.'' Next month Penguin will reissue Mr. Keillor's HAPPY TO BE HERE ($3.95), a collection of short pieces. LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) A cattle drive from south Texas to Montana in the late 1870's provides the backdrop for Larry McMurtry's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, which is peopled with cowboys, buffalo hunters, Indians, pioneers, gamblers and prostitutes.

title: ITEMS FOR A GADGET BAG
description: RECENTLY, I ran into a colleague just back from China. He had a sour expression on his face. ''I had a great trip,'' he said, ''a once-in-a-lifetime experience, but I just got back my first roll of film and the prints all look terrible. I think they're overexposed. There must be something wrong with my camera.''

title: POSTINGS: Murray Hill Rentals; 710 IN 2 TOWERS
description: A square-block site in the East 30's once envisioned as a major postal center for Manhattan is instead being developed as two 30-story rental apartment buildings.

title: HOW A KENTISH GARDEN GROWS
description: Comparing the gardens of English country houses may sometimes seem like comparing the flavors of ice cream - one is as delicious as another, especially this year, when a cold spring delayed some flowering so that by late June two seasons, in effect, had come to a peak in a magnificent display. But there is an important difference: for all their beauty, gardens restored with their owners no longer present soon become sterile, whereas an active overseer breathes life into the undertaking.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEACAUCUS: EXCEPTION TO THE RULE
description: ONE OF the prejudices common among food people is the conviction that good food is unlikely to be found in a very large restaurant, or in one that is part of a chain. However, a visit to the Devon Bar and Grill in Secaucus should convince all but the most stubborn that there are exceptions to every rule.

title: PERSONAL GROWTH THROUGH MURDER
description: ACROSS By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 138 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. BETWEEN 1966 and the early 70's, the Austrian

title: CEMENT-BLOCK STAIRS: A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE
description: WOODEN porch steps or entrance stoops are common on older houses. Unless continuously maintained and repaired, these eventually become an eyesore and a safety hazard because of sagging, rotting and cracking, and they almost always need repainting.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article July 13 about England's potteries incorrectly gave the year of a national garden festival in Stoke-on-Trent. The festival is taking place this year; it began in May and will continue until October.

title: Managers' Woes
description: To The Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A MATTER OF HONOR. By Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) When Adam Scott learns that he has inherited $:500 and a chit for a Russian icon cached in a Geneva bank by Hermann Goring, he flies to Switzerland - the money will barely cover the young Englishman's overdraft, but the icon might be worth something.

title: HELPING YOUNG WITH STRESS
description: WHILE many of his friends were away at camp, or swimming at local beaches, 9-year-old Chris Johansen of Weston spent time this summer learning about meditation, power breathing and trips into the subconscious mind.

title: VIRTUOUS MEN AND PERFECT WEAPONS
description: RED STORM RISING By Tom Clancy. 652 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95. TOM CLANCY'S first novel, the best-selling ''Hunt for Red October,'' was a superior example of the technological thriller, a genre that awards equal billing to human actors and state-of-the-art computers, missiles, devices of detection and deception, spy satellites, nuclear submarines and Mach 2 or Mach 3 fighter planes. Men, and even an occasional woman, prevail when they outwit their opponents with better deployment of exotic tools, not necessarily superior in design to those in the enemy arsenal. Skilled spinners of such au courant tales, among them Mr. Clancy, appeal simultaneously to the universal appetite for individual heroics and the special American affection for high tech.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RED DAWN AT LEXINGTON: ''If They Mean to Have a War, Let It Begin Here!'' By Louis Birnbaum. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.)

title: Spider Lockhart Fondly Recalled
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AMOTHER HOSTAGE SEEN IN VIDEOTAPE
description: David P. Jacobsen, one of the remaining American hostages in Lebanon, has said in a videotape made by his kidnappers that he felt ''like one of Custer's men,'' and added: ''You know the end of their stories. Pray that ours will have a happier ending.''

title: City Plans to Start Schooling A Little Earlier
description: New York could become the first major American city to provide classes for all 4-year-olds. Citing ''dazzling results'' in cutting down on dropouts by giving children - especially those from poorer families -an early start in school, the new president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., last week set 1989 as a target date for extending its prekindergarten program citywide.

title: PIANO SCHOOL TONES UP THE HANDS ON THE KEYS
description: For most pianists, holding the hand in an open position on the keyboard is no great feat. But when Eugene Evans fully extended his right hand on the keys the other day and held it there for 45 seconds, he was visibly excited.

title: BOWS AND BATS MEET AT NORFOLK FESTIVAL
description: IN Norfolk, Beethoven and baseball are being played with almost equal fervor. Through Aug. 9 at the Yale Summer School of Music and Art and its byproduct, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, the Tokyo String Quartet is coaching gifted young professional musicians in the art of string quartet performance. Simultaneously, the quartet is in the midst of a mammoth undertaking: the performance of all 17 Beethoven string quartets.

title: 150 Italians Indicted in Cases Linked to Crime Syndicates
description: A Milan judge has indicted 150 people in a series of killings, kidnappings and illegal arms and drug deals linked to crime syndicates and terrorist groups, the ANSA news agency reported today.

title: Grand Prix Racing Is Feeling Pinch
description: The future of grand prix racing in the United States has come under scrutiny during the last year as entry lists from major regattas show dwindling numbers. But proponents of the high-technology racing contend that the lower turnouts are not necessarily an unhealthy sign.

title: AFTER RETIREMENT, NO NEED TO BE RETIRING
description: SOME men and women cope well with retirement; some retire and discover uncertainty and dread. One's work is not easily shed. Work fills one's days and thoughts; work sustains ambition, that sense of self that sets us aside from others. After many years, one's work becomes the reason for living; it provides continuity, the impetus to continue the long fight for survival. Work is the pragmatic answer to our needs and dreams.

title: SPEAKING UP WHEN A HOTEL LETS YOU DOWN
description: Glenda da Fonseca was enticed. According to a newspaper advertisement of Air France and its tour subsidiary, Jet Vacations, if she flew on the airline she could stay at any of 39 Paris or Riviera hotels for ''just $25 to $180 a night.'' She said in a telephone interview she asked her travel agent to arrange for her to fly to Paris on Air France in April and, not wanting to stint, to stay seven nights in a large room at the Hotel Meurice Inter-Continental, which the French Government rates as four-star deluxe. Ms. da Fonseca, a New York lawyer, said she had paid $930 for the room or $133 a night - including $252 as a single supplement.

title: RADICAL SPEAKER DESIGNS IMPROVE
description: Running counter to hallowed rules is rarely rewarding and often risky.

title: A Concrete Offer By Mayor Koch
description: NOTING that there were two plants in Manhattan that made concrete and that they charged what he called the highest price in the country - $85 a cubic yard, compared with $60 in Brooklyn and Queens and $45 in Philadelphia - Mayor Koch moved to increase competition.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ ON STATEN ISLAND The Preservation Hall Jazz Band has one big fault: If you don't live in New Orleans, you have to go there to hear it.

title: Transplanting A Health Hazard
description: Radon is odorless, colorless and dangerous. The gas may cause about a quarter of the lung cancer in the United States.

title: Karen M. Thurm Engaged To Lawrence Evan Safran
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Thurm of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Michelle Thurm, to Lawrence Evan Safran, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Safran of Berkeley, Calif. A late August wedding is planned.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 27, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Susan DeL. Ball Planning to Wed Thomas B. Lloyd
description: Announcement has been made by Anne DeLong Ball of Palm Beach, Fla., and Peter Ball of Stuart, Fla., and Brooksville, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan DeLong Ball, to Thomas Bedford Lloyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lloyd of Palm Beach and Southport, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: THE WALKER SPY RING
description: Howard Blum's chronicle of the Walker spy ring points to an absence of appropriate punishment for those who barter top secrets for top dollar (''Spy Ring - The Untold Story of the Walker Case,'' June 29). Judging from the sentences handed down - father, John, eligible for parole in 10 years and son, Michael, in 8 years - you might think they stole cars and sold them instead of stealing some of this nation's most crucial military secrets.

title: Challenger's Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: Bears' Dent Signs for 4 Years
description: Richard Dent, the defensive end who rose from a ninth-round draft pick to most valuable player in this year's Super Bowl, signed a new contract agreement today with the Chicago Bears.

title: VINCENTE MINNELLI DIES; MOVIE DIRECTOR WAS 76
description: Vincente Minnelli, whose deft intermingling of song, dance and plot made him one of the greatest directors of Hollywood musicals, died in his sleep at his home in Los Angeles Friday night. He was 76 years old. The director had been hospitalized several times within the last year for emphysema and pneumonia, according to Ron Wise of the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

title: IT'S BEEN A LONG HOT SUMMER FOR MAYOR BARRY
description: Marion S. Barry Jr., the Mayor of Washington, frequently reminds his audiences that the usual political status of the District of Columbia makes his job not only that of a municipal administrator, but also the equivalent of a county exeucutive and the governor of the state.

title: We Can Never Ignore Disturbed, Violent Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: POPS BAND GOES TO THE 'GRASSROOTS'
description: WHEN Dean Karahalis, a trombonist turned conductor, calls pops music ''grassroots,'' he's not referring to the fact that the form traditionally is performed outdoors during the summer before audiences seated on grass.

title: STAYING COOL IN BIG COTTON SWEATERS
description: THE best summer clothes are cool and comfortable yet sensual, the kind that strike a little fire without adding to the heat. Big cotton-knit sweaters, which these days tend to be both long and oversize, are a good example.

title: THE CHALLENGE IN CHILE
description: Having spent a month traveling through Chile earlier this year, I read Ariel Dorfman's article ''The Challenge in Chile'' (June 29) with a mixture of discouragement and hope.

title: THE FOUNDLING OF THE LONG KLOOF
description: FIELA'S CHILD By Dalene Matthee. 350 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. SET in rural South Africa in the 19th century, Dalene Matthee's novel ''Fiela's Child'' deals with a white foundling raised by a black family. One night in 1865 Fiela Komoetie, the family's matriarch, awakes to find a young boy standing at her back door. Nine years later, the boy, now known as Ben, has become an integral part of the Komoetie farm, Wolwekraal. The family explains the difference in his skin color to neighbors by little more than the fact that he is ''his parents' hand-child. Like the hand-lamb the ewe does not want that has to be hand-fed.'' ''If you took a lamb and reared it, who's going to tell you whose sheep it is?'' Fiela Komoetie asks when the question of the real mother is raised.

title: CEMENT-BLOCK STAIRS: A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE
description: WOODEN porch steps or entrance stoops are common on older houses. Unless continuously maintained and repaired, these eventually become an eyesore and a safety hazard because of sagging, rotting and cracking, and they almost always need repainting.

title: What Ails the City's Hospitals?
description: Is New York City's municipal hospital system a ''bureaucratic swamp,'' rife with ''malignant neglect and arrogance'' and getting worse? Or should the system get at least some credit for improvement?

title: FOR CHESTER'S 150th, A HISTORICAL 'FEAST'
description: THEY ARE calling it a ''Musical Feast.'' It celebrates the 150th anniversary of Chester's incorporation as a town, and it involves a fascinating set of historic compositions by musicians who lived, worked or published their collections in the Connecticut Valley before 1825.

title: Videomeat
description: Members of Congress are continuously bombarded with newsletters, and the Washington-based American Meat Institute has just started a new one, Meat Matters.

title: 'SHEBA' REVIVED WITH A TWIST
description: IT is always a treat to see a William Inge play. His works -such as ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs,'' ''Bus Stop,'' ''Picnic'' and ''Come Back, Little Sheba'' - depict the emotional struggles of people in small-town Midwest America in the 1950's with poignant accuracy.

title: Data Bank: July 27, 1986
REFUGE UNDER A HEALING SKY
description: The adobe wall that surrounds our house has been made of bricks of mud dug from the earth. I designed the wall. Our oldest son built it brick by brick. But neither he nor I knew how to put on the final coat of mud and stucco. So I hired an old Indian man from the nearby Pueblo of San Juan to finish the wall. When the work was done I asked him what he thought of his job. He eyed the wall, stepped back several steps and squinted at it critically.

title: THE ALLURE (SWAT) OF GARDEN (SCRATCH) PARTIES (ITCH)
description: IT is an absolute though unverified truth that the closer you get to the South Shore, the greater is the mosquito, green fly and gnat population. This truth is based on attendance at countless garden parties on both shores and middle island, and on the scars remaining from the bites of giant insects.

title:
ART;
FOOD AND THE ARTIST: A LOAF OF BREAD, A JUG OF WATERCOLORS
description: ARTISTS are attracted to food not only because they, like all of us, enjoy eating, but also because it has provided them with subject matter since time immemorial.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Business is great, but G.M. and Chrysler are enjoying it less.'' - Donald Healy, auto analyst at Drexel Burnham

title: FIRST GIANT VICTORY FOR CARLTON
description: Steve Carlton combined with two relievers on a four-hitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9-0.

title: Pamela Joyce Baldwin Weds David Rothwell
description: At St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield, Conn., yesterday Pamela Joyce Baldwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman J. Baldwin Jr. of Avon and Goshen, Conn., was married to David Chapman Rothwell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter S. Rothwell of Trenton, Mich.

title: People Express
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
A GRIM PROGNOSIS AT A.T.&T.;
description: Investors have heard scant good news lately from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and some of Wall Street's bears have quietly sold the venerable stock short. Still, the stock has held its own, last week trading around $24, little changed despite disappointing second-quarter earnings, which sagged to 37 cents a share, from 41 cents a year earlier.

title: Democrats and Dixie
description: The Democratic national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., has cautioned members of the party's 1988 convention site selection committee not to let their enthusiasm for rebuilding Democratic strength in the South outweigh loyalty to the party's traditional power bases in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: SOME DISMAY ON THE ROAD TO MOROCCO
description: WHEN Prime Minister Shimon Peres slipped off in the night last Monday to visit King Hassan II of Morocco, the very fact of his journey created a kind of euphoria here, as Mr. Peres clearly intended it to.

title: ASSESSING THE BENEFITS OF AN H.M.O.
description: LAST year was a tough one medically for the Anderson family. Six-year-old Billy was burned over a third of his body in a freak accident. The youngster spent 10 days in intensive care at a hospital, underwent multiple skin grafts and then spent months in physical therapy treatments. However, the Andersons (their name has been changed to protect their privacy) counted themselves lucky in one respect: they did not have to worry about Billy's medical bills. The family belonged to a Health Maintenance Organization, which provides full health care benefits for a prepaid fee as long as the patient uses H.M.O. doctors and hospitals.

title: Siobhan O'Duffy To Wed Fellow Lawyer on Sept. 27
description: Siobhan Therese O'Duffy and Pressly McAuley Millen 3d, 1985 graduates of the Duke University School of Law and associates of New York law firms, plan to be married Sept. 27.

title: Susan Grubstein To Marry in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Marilyn Merians Grubstein of Brooklyn and Dunewood, Fire Island, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Susan Merians Grubstein, to Cary Kendle Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Davis of San Francisco and Pittsburgh. An October wedding is planned.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'OBERTO,' IN THE PARK
description: GIUSEPPE VERDI was only 26 when he wrote ''Oberto,'' the first of his many operas. It is, in many ways, a crude work, with a silly libretto and many imperfections, but it is shot through with genius and is recognizably Verdi's from the first slashing phrase. On Thursday night at the Central Park band shell, New York Grand Opera, under the direction of Vincent La Selva, gave ''Oberto'' a rare staged performance. Despite the inherent difficulties in presenting music outdoors - where amplification is necessary and melodies fly away on the breezes - and despite costumes and sets that called to mind a high school Arbor Day pageant, Verdi's power came through.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIME/STEPS. By Charlotte Vale Allen. (Atheneum, $19.95.) What can you say about a novel written by someone who changed her name to one inspired by a Bette Davis tear-jerker? (Charlotte Vale is the name of the Cinderellalike heroine in ''Now, Voyager.'')

title: NOW, JAPAN INC. WEARS A HARD HAT
description: UNDER the hot Arizona sun, a team of Japanese engineers watched carefully as a huge, white-and-red ''mole'' was lowered into a hole 30 feet wide and 65 feet deep. The Japanese-made machine was positioned to dig three huge drainage tunnels for the last leg of I-10, the interstate highway that will link Los Angeles with Florida.

title: THE PEERAGE, BRITAIN'S ULTIMATE EXECUTIVE PERK
description: SOON after the honor was announced to Ralph Halpern, one of England's highest-paid and hardest-driving business executives, that the Queen was dubbing him ''Sir Ralph,'' he sent a note of congratulations to all 30,000 workers in his own empire of specialty clothing shops, telling them they shared the honor.

title: SCHOOL 'TAKEOVER PLAN' CRITICIZED
description: A BOLD plan that would permit the state to take over troubled school districts is drawing sharp criticism from the New Jersey School Boards Association, an organization that represents all of the state's 603 operating school boards.

title: Criticizing U.S. on South Africa Needs No Apology; Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE PRIVATE LANDSCAPE,' LAST IN A RUTGERS-NEWARK SERIES
description: EXHIBITIONS at the Robeson Center Gallery at Rutgers-Newark this season have been devoted to landscapes. These shows have included ''The Political Landscape'' and ''The Metaphysical Landscape,'' both of which connoted a kind of elusiveness.

title: DEEP IN THE HEART OF ARTICHOKE CITY
description: For the automobile vacationer, odd byways have a strange way of being remembered as well as some of the grander sights that are a trip's primary destinations. Sometimes these roadside punctuation marks that break up the monotony of the highway are fondly recalled because of an unexpected, fun quality while others can stick like a poorly digested hamburger. In the former category, one might put the unpretentious town of Castroville, Calif., which lies on Highway 1, the Pacific Coast Highway, 100 miles south of San Francisco. It is a spot that many visitors to Northern California, traveling this wonderful road, are likely to stumble upon, intentionally or otherwise.

title: VERBATIM: Crime Prevention?
description: 'We screen for cardiac problems, and we can screen for violent feelings as a preventive measure.' - Dr. Deborah Prothrow-Stith, a Boston internist, urging black physicians at a New York meeting to examine patients for homicidal tendencies in an effort to reduce violence among blacks.

title: Karen E. Ogren, A Teacher, Wed To Phillip Seder
description: At the Congregational Church of Greens Farms in Westport, Conn., yesterday Karen Elizabeth Ogren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hanson Ogren of Westport, was married to Phillip Andrew Seder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Grantham Seder of Hong Kong and Eugene, Ore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William B. Bryant, assisted by the Rev. Ronald Scott Beebe, brother-in-law of the bride.

title: Bad Step for Nixon
description: It must have seemed a pretty clever idea at the time.

title: PLEASE PASS THE FETTUCCINE ATOMICO
description: Q CLEARANCE By Peter Benchley. 340 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95. AWHITE HOUSE speechwriter, Timothy Burnham - wearer of plaid boxer shorts, gobbler of multivitamins, disciple of Samuel Johnson -reluctantly vaults from the contented obscurity of siring 400-word toasts and forgettable proclamations to become the President's confidant. His abrupt transit was not sought, nor is it smooth. Within days Burnham gains Q clearance - access to nuclear secrets - loses his politically pious wife, becomes amorously entwined with a honey-haired Soviet spy and defuses a Cuban crisis of sorts by cutting a deal with a transsexual in-law. Not your average bureaucrat's 8 to 4:30 tour, but then Burnham is not your average bureaucrat. He is profane, well-read, insubordinate, creative when pressed and certainly funnier than most foot soldiers in the long gray flannel line. At the top he becomes predictably pixilated with power, though, happily, he does not dull out before his equally predictable fall.

title: TAINTED WELLS RAISE BIG ISUES ON WATER
description: INCREASING concern for a safe water supply in the small community of Napeague in the Town of East Hampton has led to a conflict between government agencies that could have an impact on water management programs throughout Long Island.

title: FEATURING THE MUSIC OF PUERTO RICO
description: ''T he classical music world is tremendously Eurocentric,'' Eva de la O, the director of Musica de Camara, said. ''We have a musical tradition in North and South America that has been all but ignored.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
YONKERS JOBS
description: BUOYED by a strong regional economy, the unemployment rate in Yonkers has steadily declined to a point where city officials say there are increasingly fewer jobs paying only the minimum wage.

title: HEALTH-NEEDS SURVEY TAKEN IN YONKERS
description: ONCE inside the old five-story brick apartment house in a dilapidated neighborhood in southwest Yonkers, Gene Argentina and Franklin Paul split up. Mr. Paul agreed to knock on all the doors on the first two floors while his partner canvassed the upper floors.

title: NUREYEV'S PRODUCTIONS SHOWCASE THE DANCERS
description: Dancers, not ballets, have always come first at the Paris Opera Ballet. One need only recall the two most famous ballets created at the Opera to prove the point. ''La Sylphide'' was composed in 1832 for Marie Taglioni. ''Giselle'' was created in 1841 for Carlotta Grisi. The pattern can be traced in the illuminating exhibition, ''Three Centuries of the Paris Opera Ballet,'' organized by Jean-Luc Maeso and which is now on view through Sept. 27 at the Library and Museum of Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: THE REAGAN LEGACY
description: Bernard Weinraub's comparison of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan calls to mind the similarity in style of the two men. David A Stockman, former Director of the Office of Management and Budget, observed, in his book ''The Triumph of Politics,'' that ''Reagan's body of knowledge is primarily impressionistic: he registers anecdotes rather than concepts.'' Henry L. Stimson, President Roosevelt's Secretary of War, recorded in his diary on Dec. 18, 1940 that Roosevelt's ''mind does not follow easily a consecutive chain of thought but he is full of stories and incidents and hops about in his discussion from suggestion to suggestion and it is very much like chasing a vagrant beam of sunshine around a vacant room.'' DAVID J. DANELSKI Dean of Faculty and Vice President for Academic Affairs Occidental College Los Angeles

title: HOLOCAUST CENTER IS BLOCKED
description: A HOLOCAUST research center in Woodmere has been denied permission by the Hempstead Town Board of Zoning Appeals to open its doors in a residential neighborhood.

title: THEATER CONCLUDES BRAVE NEW SEASON
description: A FINE madness permeates Richard Dresser's ''Better Days.'' This is the second and last of two new fully staged plays in a brave new season of new works, including three staged readings, being presented by the Levin Theater Company at Douglass College.

title: A PLAYER'S DREAM ENDS: STRIKE TWO AND HE'S OUT
description: SURELY, now, I should be able to let go of the dream.

title: JAZZ: REMEMBERING BIX
description: THE art of re-creating jazz ensembles of the past, a complex procedure that requires projecting the nuances of individual instrumental styles within the nuances of an ensemble style, has advanced to such a point that the 92d Street Y's ''Jazz in July'' festival was able to offer on Thursday evening remarkably spirited, perceptive and full-blooded presentations of the work of two major jazz figures of the 1920's - the cornetist Bix Beiderbecke and the pianist and composer Jelly Roll Morton.

title: A New Deal For Mexico
description: With a foreign debt of $98 billion and an economy depressed by declining oil prices, Mexico has signed an agreement with the International Monetary Fund that could lead to $12 billion in new loans.

title: Carson, Oldest Giant, Feels Revitalized
description: When you are 32 years old and starting your 11th season in the National Football League and the humidity is high and the temperature higher, training camp is not exactly a dream vacation. Harry Carson, the Giants' defensive captain and resident philosopher, said that under the circumstances he was reasonably happy.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: EDWARD E. BARR, chairman of the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology, has announced grants to Rutgers University in New Brunswick, the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken and the New Jersey Technological Consortium in Pomona, Atlantic County, to develop plans for establishing ''incubators'' for small advanced-technology businesses.

title: 'THE GREAT MOUSE DETECTIVE' GIVES CLUES TO THE FUTURE OF DISNEY ANIMATION
description: On July 2, Walt Disney Pictures premiered ''The Great Mouse Detective,'' its 26th animated feature in 49 years, its seventh in the nearly 20 years since Walt Disney died and the first made since the new management of Walt Disney Productions took over. This movie - finished during a period of major upheaval at Walt Disney Productions -throws some light on the problems of an art form that must struggle to survive inside a big corporate business.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Cape Scores Gain In Park Battle

title: The City's Thorny Review Process
description: WHEN a group led by William Zeckendorf Jr. was selected earlier this month as developer of the $384 million South Ferry Plaza office project, the Koch administration predicted that it would take 18 months before construction could begin.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I never thought I'd say this, but we are all praying for hurricanes -nice, friendly hurricanes that will bring us a lot of rainfall this fall.'' -Ann Nolte of the South Carolina Water Resources Commission. [ 1:3. ] <

title: Recent Releases
description: Falco: Rock Me Falco. A&M Video, 20 minutes. $19.95.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TRAVELING CARILLON One of only a few traveling carillons in the world will visit Connecticut this week on a nationwide tour. Mounted on a heavy duty Volvo truck, the 16-foot long, 9-foot high, 18,700-pound instrument has 52 bronze bells, designed and struck in the Nauen Foundry in Tonsberg, Norway. The method by which it was attached to the truck and is able to travel was designed by the Olympic Carillon Engineering Company of Seattle.

title: MOVING INCH BY INCH ON ARMS CONTROL
description: AFTER six and a half years, the Reagan Administration and the Russians are finally engaged in what officials and diplomats here say is the beginning of a serious bargaining process on arms control. And, despite substantial differences, there were strong signals last week of both sides' willingness to compromise.

title: HOSPITALS START BUSINESSES IN SEARCH FOR PROFITS
description: CONNECTICUT hospitals are starting more and more businesses, among them a catering service and a ''wellness'' cruise to the Carribean, and they say competition among institutions is increasing.

title: Spain Blames the Usual Suspects
description: Terrorists believed to be Basque separatists were busy in Spain last week.

title: Swimmer, 13, Youngest To Take Gold Medal
description: Allison Higson, a Canadian swimmer, became the youngest gold medal winner in the history of the Commonwealth Games today when she won the women's 200-meter breast-stroke in 2 minutes 31.20 seconds.

title: Tax Reform Corrects Inequities, but Doesn't Help the Poor Much
description: To the Editor:

title: WINDING DOWN FOR SUMMERFARE
description: SUMMERFARE at the State University of New York campus at Purchase may be the largest of our county festivals in terms of artistic scope, as well as the sheer number of events, but it is also one of the shortest. Barely two weeks after the gala opening, therefore, it is already time to consider the final concerts.

title: 2 NUNS AT EYE OF DISPUTE ON ABORTION
description: In a hot and busy old house here each day, two Roman Catholic nuns, Barbara Ferraro and Patricia Hussey, tell people who are poor and abused that they must stand up for their rights and fight when unjustly treated.

title: Another View On Legal Needles
description: Supplying drug addicts with clean needles might help combat the spread of AIDS, but is it worth the risk of encouraging addiction? New York State and City officials think not. But last week, New Jersey's deputy health commissioner said he hoped the Legislature would allow that state to try the idea.

title: Dr. Katerina Tsirilakis Becomes Bride
description: Dr. Katerina Tsirilakis, a daughter of Kalliope Tsirilakis of Sitia, Crete, and the late John Tsirilakis, was married yesterday to Dr. Arthur Reese Abright 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abright Jr. of Dallas. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Mexican Plan - Last week, in an unprecedented move, the International Monetary Fund agreed to lend more money to debt-ridden Mexico if the price of oil - Mexico's primary export - should drop below $9 a barrel. The agency implied that it expects the world's commercial banks to follow suit with similar new lending.

title: GRILLED MACHO
description: ALL RIGHT, HERE IT is straight from the shoulder: I hate to cook out.

title: A SALMON'S HOMECOMING IN VERMONT
description: TWO hundred years ago, the Atlantic salmon had grown so abundant in the Connecticut River that New Englanders often used the fish as currency. ''They got tired of eating it,'' said Dr. Henry Broke, a professor of fishery biology at the University of Massachusetts. ''It was just too common.''

title: 300 Yachts Start Race To Mackinac Island
description: The annual Chicago to Mackinac Island yacht race started at noon today under sunny skies and with a weather forecast for Lake Michigan that called for winds 5- to-15 knots through Sunday.

title: Ellen M. Karcher Married To Dr. John L. Hochberg
description: Ellen Margaret Karcher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Karcher of Sayreville, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. John Louis Hochberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hochberg of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal officiated at the Somerset (N.J.) Hilton.

title: SELF-RULE SOUGHT IN NEW CALEDONIA
description: A group of South Pacific governments, seeking to end French colonial rule in New Caledonia, hope to take their campaign to the United Nations, according to Vanuatu's Prime Minister.

title: DELAYS PLAGUE STATE WASTE CLEANUP
description: Eight years ago this summer, 239 families were ordered to leave Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., in an evacuation that made toxic waste a national concern. A year later, the evacuation prompted New York State to initiate a program to clean up its hazardous waste sites.

title: A PLEASANT SPOT FOR SNACKING
description: EVERY college town needs a restaurant like Caulkins, a two-year inhabitant of an artfully converted Cadillac showroom in Middletown. With a trendy menu (you will find blackened fish Cajun-style, carpaccio and baked Brie), an attractive, plant-filled decor and informal atmosphere, a sophisticated beer menu and small but well-chosen and fairly priced wine list, it fits right into the groves of academe.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. SETS 3-WAY GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: A divided Republican State Convention today endorsed former State Senator Richard C. Bozzuto for governor, but gave enough votes to two challengers to set up a three-way gubernatorial primary election on Sept. 9.

title: TIMELESS MEMORIES ON A QUIET COUNTRY LANE
description: WE turn off at Peconic, leaving the busy divided highway with its tourist traffic, bicycles and farm trucks, and drive onto a road that evokes carefree childhood memories.

title: ON THE FARMINGTON, NEW TUBING RULES
description: WITH new state rules on drinking, inner-tube riding on the Farmington River appears to be attracting a new class of practitioners.

title: The Lives of Averell Harriman
description: Averell Harriman could have devoted his life to his beloved polo and in other ways squandered the millions he inherited from his railroad-baron father. But if some Americans were born richer, none have been less idle.

title: FOR ONE BALTIMORE FAMILY, A YEAR OF POLITICAL MUSICAL CHAIRS
description: When Whitney Young Jr., then head of the Urban League, talked about the civil rights movement, he often said, ''When historians look back, they will pay a lot of attention to a man most Americans never heard of: Clarence Mitchell Jr.''

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title: William G. Flynn Married To Margaret Gilmour Diaz
description: Margaret Gilmour Diaz and William Gerard Flynn were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., by the Rev. David S. Hoag. Mrs. Flynn, a daughter of Manuel Diaz of Muttontown, L.I., and Mrs. Alfred Nesbitt Wohlwend of Pelham Manor, graduated from the Masters School and Simmons College.

title: AMERICA'S AVAILABLE ASSETS
description: If it is French, it is creativity that counts. If Italian, it is the luxurious fabric and its application that are admired. If English, it is the eccentricity that is appreciated. But if it is American, the most accurate label is availability.

title: EX-GOV. AVERELL HARRIMAN, ADVISER TO 4 PRESIDENTS, DIES
description: W. Averell Harriman, the durable Democrat who was Governor of New York from 1955 to 1959 and served four Presidents in key diplomatic roles, died early yesterday at Birchgrove, his home in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 94 years old. Mr. Harriman, who had been in failing health for about a month, died of kidney failure complicated by pneumonia, according to a family spokesman, Robert M. Shrum, Mr. Harriman, a patrician heir to a railroad fortune, first went to the Soviet Union as a businessman in 1926, and in subsequent decades he played a major part in the development of Soviet-American relations. As Ambassador in Moscow during World War II, he had a rough-and-tumble relationship with Stalin, going on to carry out crucial negotiations with Communist governments in later years.

title: AT BOTTOM OF LADDER, A 'SPECIAL' PROSPECT DREAMS
description: WHEN Curtis Pride was 14, he made a list of 40 goals for himself. One of them was to play professional baseball.

title: Rents and Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: SANTA FE SUFFERS A STUNNING REFUSAL
description: The big railroad merger of Santa Fe and Southern Pacific was rejected by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a surprise vote that apparently left Santa Fe without a plan of action. The commission said the $2.6 billion merger, agreed upon in 1983, could reduce competition. Santa Fe now must divest itself of one or both railroads or come up with a new plan. It could also appeal, but analysts said that was unlikely. The rejection, which was made against recommendations by I.C.C. staffers, broke a 20-year Washington tradition of routinely approving big railroad mergers. When looked at in the context of regulatory scotching of big deals in soft drinks and close scrutiny of airline deals, the I.C.C. rejection threw into question the success of President Reagan's policy to allow big business to operate freely.

title:
DINING OUT;
DANISH FARE STARS AT FRENCH SPOT
description: RECENTLY opened on the spot once occupied by Kaffee Bazar, Le Gueridon is full of unusual accomplishment as well as promise, yet is still young and unpolished. It lacks the high-styled ambience of other multistarred restaurants offering dishes in the French tradition, and the somewhat stiff tariff at dinner warrants plusher surroundings; nonetheless, the ingredients are conspicuously fresh and renditions vital. But what gives Le Gueridon an edge, what sets it apart from others in its category is that it brings to county luncheon tables a delight of Scandinavian cuisine, those esculent open-face sandwiches that the Danes with loving understatement call smorrebrod. And if dinner is somewhat pricy, lunch can be a bargain.

title: WHAT THE DUTCH BROUGHT TO AMERICA
description: Some excellent examples of portraits, painted furniture and silver made for Dutch colonists in pre-Revolutionary America have been assembled along with scores of lesser works in ''Dutch Arts and Culture in Colonial America,'' on view at the Albany Institute of History and Art, through Oct. 12.

title: FREED PRIEST CALLS HOME WITH MESSAGES OF HOPE
description: The Rev. Lawrence M. Jenco, freed yesterday after being held for almost 19 months in Lebanon, called his family in Joliet, Ill., from Damascus and gave them messages of hope for the families of the other American hostages.

title: WHY CAN'T GENTLEMAN BE 2 WORDS INSTEAD OF 1?
description: I HAVE never been able to figure out why the word ''gentleman'' is not two words, since no gentleman worthy of the name has ever not also been a truly gentle man.

title: RACKETS TRIAL OF 11 TO FOCUS ON 'ASIAN CRIME SYNDICATE'
description: A group described by the Federal authorities as ''an Asian organized crime syndicate'' will be the focus of a major racketeering trial beginning Monday in Manhattan.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF CHANGE
description: THE LAST THREE CENTURIES HAVE seen dazzling revolutions in scientific theory and dazzling advances in the translation of theory into technology.

title: Rape of Blind Woman To Go to a Grand Jury
description: Prosecutors intend to present evidence to a grand jury this week that a 26-year-old man accused in a series of sexual assaults in Brooklyn raped a legally blind woman in her Upper East Side apartment in Manhattan on July 14, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's Office said yesterday.

title: SANTA FE'S NEW CUISINE
description: Next to muted earth tones, wide open spaces, sunlight and crystal skies, Santa Fe is admired for its artists and art galleries and for its opera season, which continues this year until Aug. 23. Soon it may be almost as well known for its new Southwestern cooking and the variety of its lodgings. Changes in the worlds of food and innkeeping are beginning to happen in Santa Fe.

title: WHEN THE GIANTS WERE SUPER
description: THIRTY years later, Charlie Conerly puts the 1956 Giants in perspective.

title: METS' BIG WEEK: TRIUMPH, DEFEAT, EMBARRASSMENT
description: THE METS have marched through Chicago and St. Louis and across the border to Montreal, and their journeys have been largely uneventful. Their days and nights have been marked by victories and by postgame beers consumed in clubhouses in celebration. They have encountered few disturbances along their trail.

title: THE MANY FACETS OF FOLK MUSIC AT NEWPORT FESTIVAL IN WASHINGTON
description: ''FOLK music is honest music,'' the guitarist and songwriter Christine Lavin said. ''It's music from the hearts, about the lives of real people - whether they live on the streets of New York City or in the mountains of Colorado.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: The elderly and the disabled in New Jersey will continue to receive, throughout the fiscal year that began July 1, the support provided by three specially tailored transit services. The programs -two financed by the Federal Government and one by the state - are designed to help the elderly and the disabled gain easy access to mass-transportation services.

title: THE WALKER SPY RING
description: Howard Blum quotes unnamed Government officials as calling the Walker spy ring ''the most damaging case of espionage in United States history.''

title: YOUTHS QUESTION EFFECTIVENESS OF WEST HARTFORD TOBACCO BAN
description: AFTER watching tobacco use among teen-agers increase in West Hartford, a town councilman became determined to do something to prevent other young people from taking up the habit.

title: WHEN A CAR AND DEER COLLIDE, EMOTIONS AND COSTS DO, TOO
description: AS we passed the spot on the road where the car and deer had collided, I called out, ''Twooooo-Six, Twooo-Six.'' Of course the animal did not materialize.

title: VOTES FOR THE MODERN PIANIST
description: To the Editor:

title: PAKISTAN'S ESTABLISHMENT WON'T EASILY BE BUDGED
description: IN their sleek new Parliament building, Pakistan's lawmakers seem to be engaged in the business of civilian government. Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo calls their deliberations a symbol of the ''democratic process,'' while the opposition says it is all a sham in which President President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq and the army rule behind the scenes.

title: THE THREE WHO ASPIRE TO CHALLENGE O'NEILL
description: RICHARD C. BOZZUTO

title: HOWARD BEACH
description: ON Liberty Weekend, while the eyes of the nation focused on New York Harbor, the streets of Howard Beach, about 10 miles away, teemed with its residents. Red, white and blue pennants, hung by the local development association, crisscrossed the commercial district, while American flags flew along residential streets.

title: SHOPPER'S COMPLAINT: WHAT'S THE HURRY?
description: THE prominent sign above the ''Express'' checkout counter said that this counter was handling six items or less.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON THE BOARDWALK The Long Beach Boardwalk actually dates to 1905, but since time and the elements made it necessary to tear down and rebuild it in 1936, this is the 50th anniversary of the landmark. Naturally, it's cause for celebration, and that's what the local folks will do today starting at 11 A.M. on the Boardwalk at Washington Boulevard. There'll be a 1936 bathing suit contest, 1930's cars and 1930's music, and all the nostalgia you can stand. Everything's free.MUMMERS THE WORD

title: Yarborough Captures Race of Champions
description: Cale Yarborough held off Harry Gant to win the third round of the Budweiser International Race of Champions today at Alabama International Motor Speedway.

title: I.R.A. Attack in Ulster Kills 3 Policemen
description: Two Irish Republican Army gunmen dressed in butchers' smocks fired point-blank into an unmarked police car on a crowded street today, killing three plainclothes officers, the police said.

title: BETRAYED BY BLIND FAITH
description: GOD DIES BY THE NILE By Nawal el-Saadawi. Translated by Sherif Hetata. 138 pp. Totowa, N.J.: Zed Books/Biblio Distribution Center. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. NAWAL EL-SAADAWI, the Egyptian physician, civil servant, feminist, political detainee (under Sadat) and novelist, writes in a tradition that ascribes to fiction the duty of social inquest and takes for granted the intersection of literature and politics. Born, like her characters in this book, in a village by the Nile, she bears down on social issues with directness and passion, transforming the systematic brutalization of peasants and of women into powerful allegory.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Steve Engel, pitcher, to Houston to complete deal for Jerry Mumphrey, outfielder.

title: Music
description: The free parks concerts by the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera represent one of the true pleasures of our summer life. Sometimes these events are star-studded, and sometimes they seem more dutiful than anything else.

title: Suzanne Telsey Becomes a Bride
description: Suzanne Lisa Telsey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daubert Telsey of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last night to Steven Carl Bennett, a son of Rollie Garnet Bennett of Minneapolis and the late Norman Nelson Bennett. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Harriman: A Tribute
description: Averell Harriman lived long enough to fight the central political battles of the age and still retain the respect and admiration of both his colleagues and his critics.

title: You Can Go Home Again
description: After something more than an extended road trip, Martina Navratilova returned to her native Czechoslovakia last week to enjoy her first home-court advantage in more than a decade.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Reasons to Pity A Full-Time Angler
description: AFEW weeks ago I went shark-fishing out of Montauk on a friend's boat and had a fine time. One reason I had a fine time was that I didn't catch a shark.

title: Quiet Enclaves Amid City Clamor
description: BY New York standards, it was a novel idea: the creation of oases of quietude where people could escape the hustle and jangle of the city in the summer.

title:
DRAWING THE LINE ON MERGERS;
COKE AND PEPSI WERE GOING TOO FAR
description: AFTER six years of generally going along with corporate America's merger decisions, the Federal Trade Commission recently challenged two huge proposed mergers in the soft drink industry. And just last week the Interstate Commerce Commission, with Justice Department backing, rejected the proposed merger of the Southern Pacific Railroad and the Santa Fe Railway. By challenging the growth ambitions of these companies, the F.T.C. and the I.C.C. returned the public spotlight to antitrust enforcement - especially merger enforcement - during the Reagan years.

title: Museum's Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: SEABROOK FEELS THE CHERNOBYL SYNDROME
description: TO the American nuclear industry, problems with emergency planning must seem contagious.

title: UNION VOTE BEING PLANNED ON TENTATIVE PACT IN DETROIT
description: Union officials began planning today for a membership vote on a tentative three-year contract worked out late Friday night to end a 10-day strike by Detroit's municipal unions.

title: T. G. Carbone to Wed Randall Harris Swatek
description: Randall Harris Swatek and Thomas Gregory Carbone plan to be married Sept. 6, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Morris Swatek of Atlanta, have announced. Mr. Carbone is a son of Joseph Carbone of Gassetts, Vt., and Jean Carbone of Quogue, L.I.

title: RIDING A GERMAN BUS TO WEALTH
description: DANNY LAWSON'S road to becoming a big-time assembler of bus fleets has been strewn with all sorts of business mines - scarce capital, sluggish demand and poor product quality. In fact, little went right for the Houston-based Lawson National Distributing Company until it teamed up two years ago with M.A.N., a giant West German manufacturer of buses and trucks.

title: INSANITY VERDICT INCITES A DISPUTE IN ALLENTOWN
description: A police sergeant who was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the fatal shooting of his girlfriend is battling to recover his pension and back pay, setting off a bitter dispute with city officials.

title: POSTINGS: Mt. Laurel Plan Dropped; Bedminster Shift
description: At first, the 63-acre site at the corner of Route 206 and Lamington Road in Bedminster, N.J., was to be a development of 400 town houses.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WARRIOR'S GIFT. By Mack Faith. (University of Iowa, $14.95.) Mack Faith's first novel, the winner of a 1985 Associated Writing Programs Award, is narrated by Louis, an unschooled but prescient 16-year-old.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
DANCE TROUPE GAINS TOEHOLD
description: WHEN Ali Pourfarrokh finally made the big decision to establish his own company - and what choreographer doesn't dream of ''doing it my way?'' he said - he decided to do it on Long Island.

title: Lendl Praised For Benefit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MOVING OUT OF THE PENTAGON'S SPHERE
description: THE mood at Joshua Smith's Maxima Corporation in Rockville, Md., oscillates between euphoric and just upbeat.

title: BURMA
description: To the Editor: Burma is one of my favorite places and I have visited there seven times since 1974. I have also read everything about Burma I can find. For these reasons, may I take the liberty of adding some points to the articles.

title: TOPICS
description: IT IS a sweet time of year, weatherwise, except that the predatory ones will be upon us. I mean bees - mean, mean bees.

title: THE RITE OF RENEWAL
description: LOU PINIELLA IS 42. I AM 43. FOR the first time in my life, I am older than the manager of the Yankees.

title: Benjamin Robert Murray Evett Wed To Antonia Prescott in New Canaan
description: The marriage of Antonia Courthope Prescott and Benjamin Robert Murray Evett, 1986 graduates of Harvard College, took place yesterday in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: POSTINGS: 38 in North Salem; A Cluster Project in Horse Country
description: Clustered zoning, a concept aimed at preserving open space, usually means a density equivalent to a house every quarter acre or so.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 36 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEATLH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: L.I.R.R. PRIORITIES ARE CRITICIZED BY BACKERS OF ELECTRIFICATION
description: DEPENDING on where you live, the Long Island Rail Road's plan to fully electrify its rail system and offer smoother and more reliable service is either on track or at a dead end.

title: Katryn Gabrielson Weds
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday Katryn Ann Gabrielson and Paul Mark Boots, 1984 graduates of the Vermont Law School, were married by the Rev. Owen Christianson, a brother-in-law of the bridegroom. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Gabrielson of Morristown, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boots of Dorchester, Iowa. The bride graduated from Vassar College. Mr. Boots is an alumnus of Luther College.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BREWERS, at Milwaukee, 8:35 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: CUOMO IS RAISING DOUBTS ON DEBATE
description: The Cuomo campaign is sending out word that Governor Cuomo might not debate his Republican challenger, Andrew P. O'Rourke, unless Mr. O'Rourke discloses more fully his personal finances and a list of his law firms' clients.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN T.W.A. TALKS
description: COUNTY officials expressed confidence last week in the progress of negotiations to move Carl C. Icahn's corporate holdings from New York City to North Castle. The investor, who lives in Bedford, is considering a newly constructed building on the King's Mead property in North Castle as the site to consolidate several of his companies, most notably the headquarters of Trans World Airlines.

title: VF AND BLUE BELL AGREE TO $378 MILLION MERGER
description: The VF Corporation, the nation's largest publicly held apparel company, yesterday acquired Blue Bell Holdings, the second-largest maker of jeans and casual wear, for about $378 million in cash and stock.

title: Dr. Cathy Friedman Is Married to Thomas Feyer
description: Dr. Cathy Jayne Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Friedman of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas Robert Feyer, the son of Emery R. Feyer of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Edith Feyer. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: A HONG KONG YOUTH'S PATH TO A JAIL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: For Trini Sham, the 15-year-old accused of shooting a police officer in a Manhattan park last week, the path to jail led from the streets of Hong Kong to the alleys of New York's Chinatown, where shadowy gangs absorb many young Asian men.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BREWERS, at Milwaukee, 8:35 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) BOSTON RED SOX VS.

title: MOYNIHAN CITES STATE LAG IN U.S. FUNDS
description: New Yorkers paid $27.5 billion more in Federal taxes than they received in Federal aid and programs over the last decade, and they will probably continue in coming years to receive less than they contribute, according to a report to be issued Monday by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: REAGAN WOULD BAR CIVIL USE OF RACKETS LAW
description: The Reagan Administration, asserting that a provision of the Federal Government's major antirackeetering statute is being abused by private lawsuits, has proposed a major amendment to the law.

title: Advertising; Grey Unit Gets ABC Business
description: GREY Entertainment and Media, the show business subsidiary of Grey Advertising, will now be handling the advertising promotion of all of the ABC-TV Network's non-sports and non-news programming, with total billings of at least $25 million.

title: Americas Squad Wins Star Soccer
description: Diego Maradona of Argentina scored in the 88th minute to even the score at 2-2, then made the decisive penalty kick in a shootout today to send the Americas past the Rest of the World in the FIFA-Unicef World All-Star Game.

title: LARGEST CIVILIAN PARTY LEADS THAI VOTE COUNT
description: Thailand's oldest and largest civilian political party, the Democrats, emerged from parliamentary elections Sunday with a commanding lead, but not a majority, according to the Government-owned radio.

title: PRO-MARCOS CROWD IN MANILA BEATS MAN TO DEATH
description: The police repeatedly fired tear gas in a Manila park today to disperse about 500 demonstrators supporting former President Ferdinand E. Marcos. The demonstrators beat one man to death, the police said.

title: 'WORDS TO RHYME WITH,' LEXICON FOR THE OBSESSED
description: In the past few days my head has been full of manias and phobias. This is largely on account of someone called Rudy Ondrijka, but I would never have known about Mr. Ondrijka if it hadn't been for Willard Espy. And Mr. Espy, at least, needs no introduction, or shouldn't. His books on language are learned, ingenious, entertaining and quirky. He is a masterly explorer of verbal byways and with his latest work - ''Words to Rhyme With,'' published earlier this year by Facts on File - he has plunged readers even deeper into his debt.

title: GILBERT AVENGES DEFEAT BY LEACH
description: When Mike Leach last played in the final of a men's singles tournament, he beat Brad Gilbert to capture the 1982 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paramilitary Group Drops Border Patrols
description: A paramilitary group, Civilian Materiel Assistance, ended its convention today with the vow to fight Communism but not to form a patrol along the Mexican border to keep out aliens and drugs.

title: LTV PROBLEMS STIR CONCERNS ON SURVIVAL OF STEEL INDUSTRY
description: The nation's steel crisis has taken on a new sense of urgency since the LTV Corporation, the second-largest steelmaker, filed for bankruptcy reorganization earlier this month.

title: Gartner Founder Profits From I.B.M. Expertise
description: I.B.M.-watching pays. For Gideon I. Gartner, it recently paid $2 million.

title: TO ORDEALS IN GRENADA, ADD A TRIAL
description: In a small, bare courtroom, high on a windswept pinnacle overlooking the picture-postcard harbor dotted with sailing yachts, steamers loading bananas and cruise ships unloading tourists, 17 men and a woman are being tried here on charges of committing one of the most spectacular murders the Caribbean has ever witnessed.

title: Whose House?
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has not directly addressed the question of whom he would like as a successor when he retires at the end of his current term.

title: IN PARIS, AN AMERICAN WINS TOUR DE FRANCE
description: Greg LeMond won the big one today: the Tour de France. The Tour is the world's most important bicycle race, and LeMond became the first American - the first non-European - to win it since it was first held in 1903.

title: ESTIMATES ON PROFITS SLASHED
description: With the Commerce Department reporting last week that second-quarter economic growth was at its lowest level in four years, the outlook for corporate profits has taken a sharp turn downward. While some sectors of the economy are showing improvements in profits, analysts have slashed their estimates for many of the country's largest companies.

title: JAZZ: CHRIS FLORY AT GARVIN'S
description: THREE musicians who are usually associated with the tenor saxophonist Scott Hamilton - the guitarist Chris Flory, the bassist Phil Flanigan and the drummer Chuck Riggs - are playing Tuesdays through Thursdays at a new jazz room, Garvin's Cafe Lido, 15 Waverly Place, between Greene and Mercer streets.

title: Alexander Troy Wed To Dale Alyn Winokur
description: Dale Alyn Winokur and Alexander Troy, summa cum laude graduates of Yale College and lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Eugene Katz performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Richard M. Winokur of Weston, Conn., and Joan Heller Winokur of Norwalk, Conn., and Leo Troy of West Orange, N.J., and Sandra Gottlieb Troy of Montclair, N.J.

title: Financially Responsible Health Care Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE NATIONAL VILLAGE, NEIGHBOR HELPS NEIGHBOR
description: Farmers sent freshly baled hay from all over Indiana, corporations lent their trucks and heavy equipment, and scores of volunteers here loaded 79 boxcars today on a train bound for South Carolina's drought-stricken farms.

title: Traders Look to August Refunding
description: Some of the supply uncertainty that plagued the credit markets last week should be alleviated this week with the Treasury Department's announcement on Wednesday of the terms for its August refunding.

title: TWO VICTORIES FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: When Martina Navratilova hit a perfect cross-court volley today to clinch the Federation Cup for the United States, a group of gray-haired, gray-suited Czechoslovak men sat motionless amid a sea of applauding, cheering spectators. Then they abruptly rose and hurried out of Stvanice Stadium.

title: KING HASSAN QUITS ARAB LEAGUE POST OVER PERES TALKS
description: In an unexpected development, King Hassan II of Morocco announced today that he was resigning as Arab League conference chairman after strenuous criticism from some Arab countries of his meeting last week with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

title: The Softball Platform
description: Officials of the Institute for Policy Studies, a resolutely left-wing research group, say representatives of the Heritage Foundation, an aggressively conservative organization, have refused in the past, on ideological grounds, to share a platform with institute spokesmen.
