Heritage officials maintain that they do not appear at events sponsored by the institute but have joined its representatives on panels and in debates on neutral ground.

title: MUSIC: MOZART CONCERTO BY ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: ALICIA DE LARROCHA plays so many New York concerts, and plays Mozart concertos on so many of them, that in between times it is possible to take her and her Mozart for granted. And occasionally (depending on the listener's mood and perhaps on Miss de Larrocha's as well) it may take a few pages or even a whole movement before one remembers why she isn't run-of-the-mill. The A major yet again, No. 23, at Mostly Mozart Saturday night; one could almost listen on automatic pilot, and she doesn't exactly insist that one do otherwise. But it would be a shame.

title: IMMIGRATION ENFORCEMENT IS ASSAILED
description: Last month, Immigration and Naturalization Service agents raided two Long Island factories, arresting 47 workers as illegal aliens. All but three of them were from El Salvador.

title: School Reportedly Broke Gift Rule
description: Texas A&M coaches gave basketball players thousands of dollars in cash, airline tickets and amenities between 1982 and 1985, the Dallas Times Herald reported today.

title: CANADIANS WIN FOUR GOLD MEDALS
description: Graeme Fell and Ben Johnson led a surprising Canadian team to four gold medals in track and field at the Commonwealth Games today.

title: C. W. Buchheister, 85; Ex-Audubon President
description: Carl William Buchheister, a naturalist and former president of the National Audubon Society, died after a brief illness Friday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 85 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: JERSEY CRIME UP 5% LAST YEAR
description: New Jersey's overall crime rate rose more than 5 percent last year - the first increase since 1980 - according to F.B.I. figures.

title: DETAILS, DETAILS
description: And now, the new hit show of the season, ''Stump Your Congressman!''

title: Police Search for Tiger In Pennsylvania Woods
description: Police armed with searchlights and tranquilizer guns combed a densely wooded area of northeast Pennsylvania tonight following reports that a 450-pound tiger was on the loose.

title: KOCH AND A STATE AIDE IN DISPUTE
description: Mayor Koch and the state's top drug-abuse official traded charges yesterday over who was to blame for a shortage of drug-treatment centers in New York City. Each called the other ''a fraud.'

title: PAINTER JOINS SEATTLE ART LOVERS IN LOOKING BACK ON HIS CAREER
description: In the first four days of the Jacob Lawrence retrospective, more than 8,000 people moved through the Seattle Art Museum. There were 3,700 for the preview showing alone.

title: RYAN FINDS OLD STYLE STILL FITS IN NEW JOB
description: IN the first week of the first training camp Buddy Ryan has known as a head coach in the National Football League, the Philadelphia Eagles were enduring up-downs, a drill that helps make the summertime preparation for a season not unlike the act of hitting one's head against a wall. Neither feels good until you stop.

title: VONDRASEK TAKES JUDO CHAMPIONSHIP
description: Moments before her oldest sister, Kathleen, and youngest sister, Darlene, were scheduled to meet in a preliminary judo match this morning, Teresa Vondrasek recalled the first time she and Kathleen had fought.

title: Tropical Depression Fades
description: The third tropical depression to be observed since the opening of the hurricane season on June 1 dissipated today after meteorologists reported it was moving slowly north of Bermuda.

title: BRITISH HUMOR SAMPLER ON CHANNEL 13 SERIES
description: BRITISH comedy - slapstick, suave and conceptual - can be sampled tonight at 10 on Channel 13. The station's showcase of productions from England's independent Channel 4 brings a 45-minute episode of ''Mighty Moments From World History: Boadicea'' followed by two half-hour segments of ''Comic Strip,'' proving there's more to British television humor than ''Monty Python'' reruns. Unlike much American comedy, the imported shows don't assume a short attention span; they take the kind of premises that ''Saturday Night Live'' would use for sketches and let them stretch out.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citizen Watch Company of America has named Laurence R. Grunstein president.

title: Knicks' Jackson Injures Shoulder
description: Michael Jackson, the Knicks' second-round draft pick from Georgetown, suffered a dislocated left shoulder today in the team's final workout at a minicamp for rookies and free agents at Rider College. The guard will be X-rayed Monday and is expected to miss the first week of the Knicks' summer league.

title: Y.&R.'s Houston Unit Sold to Operating Chief
description: Young & Rubicam has sold its Houston subsidiary, Rives Smith Baldwin Carlberg + Y&R, to W. Charles Carlberg, who has been general manager and chief operating officer. The agency, which dates back to 1948, bills around $14 million.

title: KRISTIE PHILLIPS, 14, SETS SIGHTS ON GYMNASTICS GOLD
description: THE pictures catch the eye just inside the door of the house that Bela built. On the wall facing the doorway of Bela Karolyi's Gymnastics on a quiet road at the northern edge of the city, Mary Lou Retton wears red, white and blue. Mary Lou smiles. Mary Lou waves. Mary Lou hangs out the window of an automobile at her triumphant post-Olympic West Virginia homecoming.

title: ASTROS DEFEAT PHILLIES
description: Nolan Ryan and Aurelio Lopez combined for a two-hitter as the Houston Astros defeated the Philadelphia Phillies today, 3-2.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 28, 1986
description: International Morocco's king is giving up his role as Arab summit chairman. King Hassan II announced he would step down after some Arab countries strongly criticized his meeting last week with Prime Ministr Shimon Peres of Israel. In a letter to Chedli Klibi, Secretary General of the Arab League, King Hassan said he was turning over to him responsibility for organizing the next Arab summit meeting, in order to enhance prospects that a full meeting might be held soon. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: Stores Halt Sales Of a Mouthwash
description: Scope mouthwash was removed from the shelves of a supermarket chain in four states today after an anonymous caller to a mental health crisis hot line claimed to have tainted the product with cyanide.

title: 'INTRAPRENEURSHIP' RAISING DOUBTS
description: When debt-laden Levi Strauss & Company abandoned its tiny, money-losing Fashion Portfolio sportswear venture earlier this year, it did not attract much attention.

title: FORGERY AND THEFT CHARGES STRESSED AT TRIAL OF EX-CITY HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: The prosecution in the trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, intensified its efforts last week to show that Mr. McLaughlin stole hundreds of thousands of dollars from a wealthy heiress and lied about his assets on tax returns and disclosure forms.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 28, 1986
description: Companies

title: Man in the News; THE WINDING ROAD TO THE TOP: GREGORY JAMES LeMOND
description: When he was growing up in Nevada, Greg LeMond was a skier - first downhill, then freestyle.

title: U.S. VOWS IT WON'T MAKE CONCESSIONS OVER HOSTAGES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would not alter its policy and make concessions to free the remaining American hostages in Lebanon, despite the release of the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco and a videotaped plea by another hostage.

title: Queen's Aide Assails Newspaper on a Report
description: A top aide of Queen Elizabeth today publicly attacked The Sunday Times, which reported a rift between the Queen and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: END OF ROAD FOR STURDY '8's'
description: The flags will not be lowered to half-staff and no retirement parties are scheduled, but the United States Treasury is about to lose an old friend.

title: ARMY TO PRESENT AIR DEFENSE PLAN COSTING $8 BILLION
description: A year after the Defense Department canceled the Sergeant York air defense gun as a failure, the Army is seeking approval to spend $8 billion to $22 billion on weapons to protect front-line divisions from air attack.

title: HOPES SET ON A FEW FILM HITS
description: With summer more than half over, the movie industry is feeling a mixture of regret and relief.

title: LIMITS PROPOSED ON ENDING WORKER PENSION FUNDS
description: A special Reagan Administration advisory council has recommended major changes in Federal laws to discourage companies from terminating employee pension plans.

title: Feminist Leader Gets Death Threat
description: A 30-year-old woman was held in the Camden County Jail today on charges that she threatened to kill the president of the National Organization for Women and assaulted women attending a state conference of the group.

title: Drug-Free Yukon
description: To the Editor:

title: A Monumental Sculpture May Be Getting New Home
description: Theodore W. Kheel has been a mediator in some bitter labor disputes. When it comes to comparing those with debates over art, he acknowledges, ''You ain't seen nothing yet.''

title: IN A SURGE OF VISITORS, SARATOGA'S PAST RETURNS
description: A smartly dressed gentleman leaned toward the tourist information booth here and quietly told the receptionist, as if in confidence, ''I've never been to New York before.''

title: Life Begins At 56
description: HE is today's most singular story in golf, if not in all of sports. For most of the other pros over 50, the Senior PGA Tour has represented a ''mulligan'' in life, a second chance to earn big money. But for Charles Owens, it's his first chance.

title: CANE PACE IS WON BY BARBERRY SPUR
description: Barberry Spur, with Bill O'Donnell driving, captured the Cane Pace, the first leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers, in record-tying time tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Bridge: Health Problem Has Impact In Knockout Play in Toronto
description: A health problem had some impact on a key match when the quarter-final stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon.

title: James McCarthy Dies; Aided Troubled Youths
description: James E. McCarthy, a social worker who rose to prominence by providing street-corner counseling for members of some of the city's toughest gangs, died of a respiratory illness at the New York University Medical Center Thursday. He was 70 years old and lived in Washington.

title: MEXICO'S NEW BID TO STEM CAPITAL FLIGHT
description: Beginning this week, investors here will be able to put their money into a new type of Government savings instrument whose value in Mexican pesos is tied to the value of the dollar.

title: Democracy in Guatemala Will Take Time
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JOBS: BREAKING THE ICE
description: THE woman sat at her new desk doing her new job at an international trading company in Washington and waited for someone, an executive or perhaps an associate, to invite her to lunch.

title: NETWORK UNION PROPOSAL WORRIES TV JOURNALISTS
description: Some television journalists have expressed concern that a proposal by ABC, CBS and NBC in current union negotiations could seriously affect the quality of broadcast journalism. The proposal would allow the networks to assign correspondents to do some of the work now done by technicians.

title: Self-Evident Truths
description: ''When a government does not have the consent of the governed, you can't expect people to forswear the only strength they have - the strength of their right arms. To think so is against American theology anyway!''

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS KILLING 2 REBELS IN GUNFIGHT
description: South African security forces said today that they had shot and killed two armed black insurgents, one of whom was described by the officially controlled news organizations as the country's leading terrorist.

title: DESPITE DECISIVE STEPS, AUSTRALIA IS STUMBLING
description: Since the Labor Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke took office here in 1983, it has moved decisively to impose measures that have left its conservative, business-backed opponents in its dust by deregulating banks, floating the overvalued Australian dollar and reining in the powerful unions with income restraints.

title: Chile Primate Appeals To Top Court on Youths
description: Chile's Roman Catholic Primate, Cardinal Juan Francisco Fresno, urged the Supreme Court today to take over the case of two youths burned in anti-Government protests, saying the explanations provided by an investigating judge were insufficient.

title: A Pronunciation Guide: It's Not Tess or Tessie
description: Easy does it.

title: T. A. Manasseh Marries Miss Schecter
description: The marriage of Suzanne Elena Schecter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Schecter of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Timothy Alex Manasseh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Manasseh of Combe, England, took place yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Justice George F. Roberts of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: CURBS PROPOSED BY MORGENTHAU ON DRUG MONEY
description: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau called yesterday for a state law that could be used to prosecute any bank officers, travel agents or other intermediaries who launder cash for drug dealers.

title: Help for AIDS Patients Goes Beyond Group's Name
description: Despite its name and despite stereotypes, the Gay Men's Health Crisis finds itself helping a growing number of AIDS patients who are neither homosexual nor male; who are not white, do not speak English, do not live in the middle of Manhattan.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. PINS HOPE ON A 3-WAY RACE
description: With Connecticut's political conventions concluded, the Republicans say they are counting on a three-way gubernatorial primary fight to stir interest in their effort to win the governor's office this fall for only the second time in 32 years.

title: Financially Responsible Health Care Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Judging Justice Rehnquist
description: If confirmed by the Senate, William Hubbs Rehnquist will become the Chief Justice of the United States, only the 16th in American history, and the leading edge of President Reagan's effort to redefine the judiciary's role in American life. The hearings that begin tomorrow in the Judiciary Committee mean much.

title: A Crossroads on Nuclear Testing
description: For 30 years, the difficulty of verifying a test ban on nuclear weapons was seen as a major obstacle to arms control. Then, earlier this month, the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group in the United States, put seismometers in place in the Soviet Union, demonstrating to all the world that it is entirely possible to monitor Soviet testing. As long as the Russians accept in-country seismic monitoring - and they gladly did in this case - existing technology can detect any nuclear explosions big enough to have military significance, and even some smaller ones.

title: DANCE,'VILLANELLA' SOLO WITH VERONICA TENNANT
description: DAVID ALLAN'S ''Villanella'' was commissioned in 1984 by its star, Veronica Tennant. It is easy to see why. The solo, performed for the first time in New York by the National Ballet of Canada on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, displays her considerable authority as a performer.

title: 7,000 Detroit Strikers To Vote on Pact Today
description: Bargainers for the city and 7,000 striking municipal employees pressed ahead today reviewing a long tentative agreement, forcing a delay in ratification.

title: Brokerage Bullish On Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Wertheim & Company, the brokerage house, has released a rather positive recommendation on Saatchi & Saatchi, the London-based, publicly held advertising holding company that has quickly became the world's largest.

title: IT'S GATOR TO THE RESCUE
description: It was the stuff of fairy tales, the kind of scenario that Mother Goose and her gaggle of scribes would have been happy to hatch.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: S. J. PERELMAN: A Life. By Dorothy Herrmann. Illustrated. 337 pages. Putnam. $18.95.

title: HISTORIC WEEK FOR PRO FOOTBALL?
description: The opposing attorneys in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League, who agreed on precious little during 10 weeks of arguments, are in relative agreement on one point: The jury of five women and one man, which has been deliberating since last Thursday and will continue at 9:30 A.M. today after a day off, will reach a verdict this week.

title: SAFEWAY AGREES TO BUYOUT BID
description: The nation's biggest supermarket chain, Safeway Stores, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell the company to a group of investors headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the top management of Safeway for $4.25 billion.

title: Calligraphy of the Ages
description: In China and Japan, the experts say, calligraphy enjoys a prestige superior to all the other arts. In the Islamic world, where religious tenets long prohibited pictorial representation, calligraphy has become a major decorative art for everything from books to towering mosques.

title: Ad Assault on Abuse Of Drugs Gets Support
description: The planned advertising assault against drug abuse that the American Association of Advertising Agencies announced as a solo effort in May is now going to be getting the organized support of the rest of the industry.

title: ON ISLAND IN PHILIPPINES, FEAR AND BURNED HOMES
description: For months, Communist rebels had moved freely through the isolated hamlets around this mountainside village, challenging the military to dislodge them, and now the soldiers had come, scattering artillery fire and setting fire to the thatched roofs of the farmers' homes.

title: 10 Dead in British Rail Crash
description: The death toll in Britain's worst rail accident in two years rose to 10 today when an 11-year-old boy died in a hospital. He had been traveling in a truck hit Saturday by a train in this village in northeast England. Six people were killed immediately, three died later in a hospital and 52 were injured.

title: Actors Authorize Strike
description: Members of Hollywood's two actors unions overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike, officials said today. Ballots returned by 30,493 members of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists showed 87 percent voted to authorize a strike, said a SAG spokesman. A strike would postpone the television season scheduled to begin this fall, halt motion picture production and cost the entertainment industry millions of dollars, industry officials have said.

title: Next Impeachment?
description: As soon as the Senate either acquits or convicts Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Nevada of impeachment charges brought against him by the House, probably sometime in the fall, Congress will consider impeaching one of his colleagues, Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. of Mississippi, according to Hill sources.

title: PRIEST IS SILENT ON THE HOSTAGES STILL IN LEBANON
description: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, an American priest freed after nearly 19 months as a hostage in Lebanon, arrived here today clutching an American flag and remaining silent about the conditions under which other Americans are still being held.

title: BUSH, IN JERUSALEM, VISITS HOLOCAUST SHRINE
description: Vice President Bush penetrated the silence inside a darkened memorial to Jewish Holocaust victims here today with a question that he really did not want answered.

title: What About Mr. Reagan's Own Judicial Activism?
description: The Reagan Administration has gotten good political mileage from assailing the Federal courts for entering into social and political controversies. Its campaign to reshape the Federal judiciary serves the avowed purpose of seating judges who will not be ''activists'' but will exercise ''restraint.'' Yet the positions that the Administration has been urging on the courts ever since it took office show that when it comes to furthering the Reagan social and political agenda, it is itself rather eager for activism.

title: The Quiz
description: The news staff of WJZ-TV in Baltimore put five questions on current events to the 17 Maryland candidates for the United States Senate.

title: BABBLING MAN SHOOTS 3 PEOPLE ON A STREET IN WASHINGTON HEIGHTS
description: A 28-year-old man who the police said appeared to be under the influence of drugs approached another man on a street in Washington Heights in Manhattan yesterday, yelled at him, and for no apparent reason pulled out a 15-shot pistol and began firing. He wounded the man and two passers-by, one an 8-year-old girl.

title: BREAKING TRADITION IN ROME: WOMEN JOIN GYMS
description: The image of the Italian woman as being content solely to cook, clean and raise a family may need some revamping. Today, many women in Rome are venturing outside the home, and they are landing in some untraditional places.

title: G.M. Offers $500 Rebate
description: As an alternative to cut-rate financing, the General Motors Corporation said today that it had added a $500 rebate on its so-called A cars.

title: Wilander Upset
description: Emilio Sanchez of Spain jolted Mats Wilander today, defeating the world's No. 2 ranked player, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, to win the Swedish Open.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A PRIMARY, HOT DOGS, AND PRIDE
description: Officially, with the Missouri primary still ahead, the general election campaign for the Senate has not yet begun. But Harriett Woods and Kit Bond, the two leading candidates, couldn't wait to get at each other in a battle of television commercials.

title: 74 Former Ursuline Sisters Hold a Reunion in Louisville
description: Seventy-four former Ursuline nuns, many of them now married with children, gathered over the weekend at the Ursulines' community for a reunion prompted by a television program.

title: ITALIAN WOMAN IS FIRST
description: The women's Tour de France bicycle race ended today on the Champs-Elysees in Paris, possibly for the last time.

title: Stanley F. Clay Weds Sheryl Stone, a Nurse
description: Sheryl Joy Stone, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Stone of Pittsford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stanley F. Clay, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Clay of Alachua, Fla. Rabbi Judah Miller performed the ceremony at Temple B'rith Kodesh in Rochester.

title: IMMIGRANTS' HURDLES REFLECT FEW CHANGES, SCHOLAR FINDS
description: The problems confronting the current wave of immigrants in New York City are more similar to those of earlier immigrants than is commonly recognized, according to one of the nation's leading sociologists, Nathan Glazer.

title: Baldrige Visits Japan
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige arrived Saturday in Japan for a four-day visit during which he will meet Japanese Government and business leaders, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. On Monday Mr. Baldrige will meet Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, Foreign Minister Tadashi Kuranari and Minister of International Trade and Industry Hajime Tamura, the spokesman said. Secretary Baldrige will address the Japan Industrial Policy Research Institute on Tuesday.

title: Chess: 3d Kasparov-Karpov Match May Settle Many Questions
description: It usually takes one match to win the world chess championship, but Gary Kasparov needed two and now needs another to certify the result. The 23-year-old citizen of the Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan begins his third title match with his countryman, Anatoly Karpov, 35, the former champion, today in London.

title: Radio Transmitter Hit by Lightning
description: A lightning bolt hit a WABC-AM radio transmitter in Lodi, N.J., during weekend thunderstorms, shutting off station programs twice over two days, company officials said yesterday.

title: Veterans Need Access To Courts for Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillin Is Youngest Stock-Car Winner
description: Bobby Hillin Jr. became the youngest winner in the history of Nascar racing today in the Talladega 500 at Alabama International Motor Speedway.

title: Virginia Diamond Wed To Richard Bensinger
description: Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester in Chappaqua, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Virginia Rae Diamond, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Thomas Diamond of Chappaqua, to Richard Arthur Bensinger, a son of Mrs. John Marshall Bensinger of Louisville, Ky., and the late Mr. Bensinger. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

title: HCM Reunites Winning Team
description: The award-winning copywriter-art director team that was knocking them dead with their Volvo advertising in the late 1970's has been reunited at the HCM agency.

title: CRENSHAW HAS FIRST VICTORY SINCE '84
description: Ben Crenshaw, who had not won a tournament since the 1984 Masters, shot a 68 today to win the $500,000 Buick Open by a stroke over J. C. Snead and Doug Tewell.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's great to be back, but don't forget three brothers are still there.'' -The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, freed as a hostage in Lebanon. [ A1:4. ]

title: TERESE BERGANZA CONCERT
description: ZARZUELA may be likened to an idiomatically Spanish strain of opera, an alternation of singing and dancing with spoken dialogue interspersed. In the past two decades, several artists of Hispanic origin - notably Placido Domingo, Montserrat Caballe and Teresa Berganza - have inaugurated a small, sporadic revival.

title: PANEL OF REGENTS TO FILL STATE POST
description: The New York State Board of Regents has created a six-member search committee to find a successor to the State Education Commissioner, Gordon M. Ambach.

title: BANK CRISIS LOOMING IN PERSIAN GULF STATES
description: Plunging oil prices have already dealt one punishing blow to the economies of the Gulf oil states. Now, an upsurge of Islamic fervor among local judges and indebted businessmen is posing a threat to the region's banking system as well.

title: Proposed Components Of Omnicom Set Vote
description: Thursday, Aug. 28, is the big day as far as the proposed Omnicom components are concerned. At a meeting of shareholders of publicly held BBDO International and Doyle Dane Bernbach, along with those of privately held Needham Harper Worldwide, the makeup of the world's second-largest advertising company will be decided upon.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Bronx Death Termed Suicide
description: The body of an unidentified man, believed to be in his 20's, was found hanged in a stairwell of a Bronx parochial school yesterday in an apparent suicide, the police reported. A spokesman, Sgt. Ronald Severin, said the body was discovered at 2:50 P.M. on a first-floor landing, hanging from a rope tied to a second-floor railing, at Monsignor Scanlon High School at 915 Hutchinson River Parkway.

title: Anti-Apartheid Move
description: Despite Reagan Administration resistance to formal sanctions against South Africa, Congress continues to express its distaste for the situation in a variety of pending bills.

title: Kean Blames Port Authority For Delay of Ferryboat Plans
description: Governor Kean criticized the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday for not moving quickly enough to approve a plan to provide ferryboat service between New Jersey and New York.

title: SANDINISTA MAKES HIS CASE ON A BROOKLYN CHURCH VISIT
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, taking his case against the United States to a Brooklyn church, condemned the Reagan Administration yesterday for choosing to ignore a ruling of the International Court of Justice against American support for anti-Sandinista rebels.

title: AGUILERA STOPS BRAVES
description: The road trip was finally over. It had taken the Mets through three cities in 11 days, from the controlled climate of the Astrodome in Houston to the weary and oppressive humidity of Atlanta. And now, they were returning home.

title: POP: JOAN ARMATRADING AND GRAHAM NASH
description: JOAN ARMATRADING is one of pop music's most gifted practitioners of the dramatic monologue, a form that doesn't lend itself readily to the conventional strictures of pop songwriting. Yet in her 12-year recording career, the West Indian-born English singer, songwriter and guitarist has succeeded in writing dozens of pungent first-person lyrics that examine the terrain of romantic love from a remarkable variety of perspectives.

title: U.S. TO RESTORE HAITIANS TO LIST OF HIGH-RISK AIDS GROUPS
description: With clusters of AIDS showing up in Florida that do not match the pattern elsewhere in the nation, the Federal Centers for Disease Control is preparing to put Haitians back into a special risk classification.

title: ADMINISTRATION GOES TO JUSTICES ON RULE FOR WEIGHING DISABILITY
description: The Reagan Administration is asking the Supreme Court to uphold the standard that officials use in ruling that hundreds of thousands of applicants each year are ineligible for Social Security disability benefits.

title: Cancer Treatment Set for Howser
description: Dick Howser was in satisfactory condition and ''doing fine'' today at the hospital where he will begin radiation treatments this week for a malignant brain tumor, officials said. The Kansas City Royals' manager will begin radiation therapy at the beginning of the week, according to a team statement. The 50-year-old manager of the 1985 champions will receive treatment five times a week for about five weeks.

title: Market Place; Car Part Shift Aids Suppliers
description: THE Value Line Investment Survey expects domestic automobile production to decline in 1986 and 1987. On the surface, this would seem unfavorable for suppliers of original equipment parts to the car manufacturers.

title: ALBANY IS STALLED ON AID TO AGED FOR DRUG COSTS
description: After months of negotiation, Governor Cuomo and legislators have not reached agreement on a plan to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly, and for the first time the Governor is saying that it is possible no plan will be voted this year.

title: Israeli Cabinet Selects New Justice Minister
description: The Israeli Cabinet appointed a new Justice Minister today, six days after Prime Minister Shimon Peres forced Yitzhak Modai to resign from the post.

title: Gasoline Prices At 7-Year Low
description: The average price of gasoline at self-service stations has dropped to 81 cents, its lowest level since 1979, according to a survey of 15,000 gas stations in 50 states. According to the survey by

title: GUIDRY IS STRONG IN RETURN OUTING
description: Ron Guidry brought a feeling of hope and relief to the beleaguered Yankee pitching staff yesterday.

title: SLOW PACE SEEN FOR REVAMPING SECURITY POLICIES
description: Senior officials in Congress and the Reagan Administration say it will take years to fully repair the weaknesses in security policies brought to light by the recent series of damaging espionage cases.

title: DIVORCED PARENTS AND THE NEGLECTED CHILD
description: The persistent high divorce rate is leading to a widespread problem of child neglect, according to a number of new studies on the long-term impact of divorce upon children. Much of that neglect appears to be coming from the emotional and economic stress faced by divorced parents rather than lack of concern for their children.

title: WATER CALLED FACTOR IN SHAPING MARS
description: Intensive study of 55,000 images recorded over a four-year period by two Viking spacecraft in orbit around Mars has persuaded some geologists that volcanic activity and fluid erosion have shaped the planet's surface to a far greater extent than previously believed. Scientists now believe there is enough water hidden in the crust of Mars to theoretically flood the entire planet to an average depth of at least 1,000 feet.

title: D'Amato Faults a Key Ruling Made by N.R.C. on Shoreham
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that he would take legal action to try to overturn a Nuclear Regulatory Commission decision that could allow testing of the evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: Ultimate Golf Club
description: Having trouble remembering what your husband looks like because he spends more time on the golf course than at home? Or is it your boss or a co-worker or a dimly remembered friend who's the obsessive golfer in, or rather out of, your life?

title: Beyond the Test Pattern
description: Television coverage of the Senate, conducted experimentally for the last two months, appears to have a future.

title: Due Regard for Old Broadway
description: The threat to Times Square's nighttime excitement no longer comes from just dirt and crime. Equally ominous are the well-advanced private plans for five major office and residential towers at the intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue.

title: South Korean Dissidents Detained Before Meeting
description: Riot police detained scores of dissidents today who tried to attend a prayer meeting to protest the reported sexual abuse of a Government opponent while she was in police custody.

title: BELMONT MEET LEFT MUCH UNDECIDED
description: Belmont Park closes today after a 69-day summer meeting that produced a few exhilarating performances but left the leadership of most divisions wide open.

title: Alliance Gives Family New Hammermill Try
description: Better known for putting up commercial buildings in New Jersey, the family of H. Bert Mack now seems to have fulfilled a dream that its members have had since at least last year. Mr. Mack and his four sons, who operate the Mack Construction Company of Rochelle Park, N.J., are becoming players in the high-pressure world of corporate takeovers.

title: A Powerful Blast Hits Beirut Neighborhood
description: A powerful explosion ripped through a densely populated residential district in East Beirut today, and the police said there were many casualties.

title: Army Drops the Idea Of Re-enlisting Mules
description: Mules are ''wonderful animals, but there are problems in bringing them back into the Army,'' Maj. Phil Soucy said in explaining the decision against returning the beasts of burden to active duty.

title: JAZZY 'CLUB DATE' ON 31
description: JAZZ musicians with Eastern European roots can be seen tonight on Channel 31 in ''Club Date,'' two half-hour jazz programs presented back-to-back at 9 o'clock. The Hungarian guitarist Gabor Szabo plays pop-jazz with a diluted flamenco element; the pianist Larry Vuckovich leads a superior quartet that adds hints of Mr. Vuckovich's Yugoslavian heritage to aggressive hard-bop.

title: OPEC MEETS AGAIN ON OUTPUT
description: OPEC delegates began gathering here today for another emergency meeting amid growing concern that failure to agree on the crucial issue of individual production quotas would further depress oil prices.

title: JETS' SIGN NO. 2 PICK
description: Doug Williams, the Jets' No. 2 draft pick out of Texas A&M, signed his contract, took his physical and worked out with the team yesterday, ending his brief holdout and bringing the number of players in camp to an even 100.

title: Catching Up
description: * Gary Sheffield, who followed in the footsteps of his uncle, Dwight Gooden, as a first-round pick in the amateur draft last month, is looking a bit more like a pro after a slow start with the Helena (Mont.) Gold Sox of the Pioneer Rookie League.

title: A Woman of Strength
description: When the University of Arizona's football players gathered last fall for their first meeting with the new strength coach, there was a bit of disrespectful muttering, at least until the coach stared them down and told them straight out: ''My job is to make you as strong as I am.''

title: Costly to Economize on Pregnant Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hold Down Airline Carry-Ons
description: Anyone who wonders what inspires nitpicking Federal regulations need only watch an airliner loading passengers and their carry-on baggage. The flying public knows few limits to its willingness to impose on airlines and fellow passengers.

title: Kenn Duncan Is Dead; A Dance Photographer
description: Kenn Duncan, a prominent dance photographer, died Saturday in New York Hospital of toxoplasmosis. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Washington Watch; Effects of I.C.C. Merger Move
description: THE Interstate Commerce Commission's sobering punch to merger mania in rejecting the proposed merger of the Southern Pacific Railroad into the Santa Fe Railway is being viewed as having far-reaching implications for several other big merger plans subject to Government review.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Madness of Farm Subsidies
description: It's no secret that government policies set in Washington (and Brussels and Tokyo) favor domestic farmers at the expense of consumers and taxpayers. Prodded by frustrated aid officials, poor countries, too, are beginning to acknowledge that their controls on farmers harm efficiency. But the devastating effect of government meddling in agriculture, as dryly assayed in a new report by the World Bank, still has the power to shock.

title: Phone Rate Restructuring Plan
description: At meetings scheduled to begin today in San Diego with officials of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, the four principal telephone trade groups plan to present a broad strategy for further restructuring of telephone rates. It is called the Unity 1-A agreement.

title: CURFEW ENFORCED IN INDIAN CAPITAL
description: A curfew remained in effect in sections of New Delhi today as the army and paramilitary police officers patrolled here and in Punjab and Haryana states to prevent any recurrence of violence between Sikhs and Hindus.

title: Economists Wary of Tax Bill
description: As Congressional negotiators work their way toward compromise on the tax bill, some economists are becoming increasingly concerned that the legislation, whatever its final details, could cause enough short-term disruption of consumer spending and business investment patterns to further batter an already weak economy.

title: 2 U.S. Nuns Ordered To Leave the Sudan
description: Two American nuns who were held briefly by rebels in a war zone last week were declared persona non grata by the Government and ordered to leave the country, the official Sudanese news agency said today.

title: SHARP INCREASE IN INMATES AT CITY JAILS
description: The number of inmates in city jails has risen sharply in the last few weeks to the highest level in at least six years, causing overcrowding in the system, city correction officials said yesterday.

title: GIRL, 14, CONQUERS TANGLEWOOD WITH 3 VIOLINS
description: Prodigious talent for a performing musician has three components: technical skill, artistic mastery and, rarest of all, that strange combination of pluck and luck that allows the artist to triumph in sudden crises.

title: RED SOX LEAD CUT; SUTTON TOPS SEAVER
description: Don Sutton pitched six scoreless innings to defeat Tom Seaver in a rare meeting of 300-game winners today as the California Angels, getting a home run from Bobby Grich, beat the slump-ridden Boston Red Sox, 3-0.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 28, 1986:

title: New Hutton Unit Head
description: E. F. Hutton & Company said Friday that it had named John N. Desrosier, a 36-year-old senior vice president at the brokerage house, to head its mergers and acquisition department. Mr. Desrosier, who joined the department in 1984, succeeds Daniel Good, who left Hutton for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. earlier this month.

title: 7 TENNESSEE FAMILIES AND SCHOOLS NEARING END OF BATTLE OVER BOOKS
description: Seven fundamentalist Christian families, who are seeking reading material in their children's schools that they do not consider offensive, have been described in court as an oppressed minority similar to black Americans before the era of civil rights.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Natural Turf
description: When he was a boy, Dave Sanders would go hiking in a marshy area near his home in Addison, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He thought of it as his private little refuge because so few people realized that such a place existed amid the metropolitan sprawl.

title: BELGIAN GUN MAKER STRUGGLES FOR PROFIT
description: Earlier this year, the bullet-riddled corpse of Juan Mendez was found alongside a freeway leading to the headquarters of Fabrique Nationale Herstal S.A., the Belgian arms manufacturer. The mysterious assassination of Mr. Mendez, who was Fabrique Nationale's sales manager for Latin America, sparked a headline-grabbing scandal fueled by rumors of black-market arms sales in Central America.

title: Boston Banker Gets Bowery Presidency
description: Neal F. Finnegan, a 48-year-old Bostonian who has worked in banking for 32 years, has been selected as the president and chief operating officer of The Bowery Savings Bank, effective next Monday.

title: Jury Selection In Trial of Officer
description: Jury selection is to begin Monday in the trial of a Transit Authority police officer accused of fatally shooting his wife, a New York City police officer, last Oct. 29.

title: THE SPEECH THAT LAUNCHED A THOUSAND CRITICS
description: A senior White House official remarked the other afternoon: ''Initially, I was cool to the idea of a speech. At the end I was just as cool.'' Several hours later, another official said, ''A lot of people here were mystified by that speech.''

title: Giants Put Minton On Disabled List
description: The San Francisco Giants placed Greg Minton on the 21-day disabled list today and recalled another pitcher, Kelly Downs, from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Spying Case Outlined Against Military Clerk
description: A clerk at an Air Force base for spy planes tried to sell military secrets to an Federal agent posing as a Soviet spy, prosecutors said Friday in an opening statement at his court-martial on espionage charges.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Could you list the pitchers who have thrown more than one no-hitter in their careers?

title: PASTOR, EXPELLED BY PRETORIA, URGES SANCTIONS
description: An American Lutheran minister, expelled from South Africa, has returned to the United States to tell of official acts of repression and to transmit a plea from South African church people, black and white, for strong economic sanctions.

title: HOUSATONIC BASS
description: THE Housatonic River drains the western Connecticut and Massachusetts hills. With the dam at Falls Village, Conn., to control the flow, the river maintains a good level during the warm, dry summer months.

title: DROUGHT MAY SAVE SWANP
description: The Southern drought is parching this national wildlife refuge but may actually save it in the long run, the authorities said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CORPORATE NOTES Midday, outdoors and in the financial district the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council is as busy this summer as a stock market ticker. The nonprofit council is in league with such bottom-line scrutinizers as Olympia & York, the real-estate giant, Continental Insurance and the Chase Manhattan Bank. These partnerships are responsible for free concerts for downtown workers and residents, who can see and hear a variety of artists - usually musicians and dancers - in various locations on different days of the week.

title: JIM BRAXTON
description: Jim Braxton, the former Buffalo Bills fullback, died today of cancer at Roswell Park Memorial Institute here. He was 37 years old.

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lightning Kills Guardsman
description: A National Guardsman was killed and 10 others were injured by lightning while standing under a tree at this Army base Saturday, officials said. Nine of the injured were treated and released and one guardsman was admitted to the base hospital. Killed was Donnie Paul McKinney, a 20-year-old resident of Marion, an Army spokesman said.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $16.4 million for the quarter and $20.4 million for the 6 months.

title: U.S. SEIZES 13 IN LOUISIANA IN PLOT TO INVADE SURINAME
description: Federal agents arrested 13 men in Louisiana today on charges that they were preparing to overthrow the leftist Government of Suriname, a small country on the eastern coast of South America.

title: DATATRAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Who's Hot
description: The records of the major league teams since the All-Star Game two weeks ago in Houston and the changes in their games behind the division leaders:

title: BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESORS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income represents net assets. The 1985 share earnings results is before a capital gain distributiion of $1.19 a share and income dividend fo 35 cents a share paid in March 1986.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the narrowing of its loss in the latest quarter was due to reduced costs at the company's operations, improved results at Asarco's Assocaited companies and income of $4 million from the liquidation of excess metal inventory valued on a LIFO basis. The company's equity in earnings of its associated companies, located principally in Australia, Mexico and Peru, improved to $3.7 million in the latest quarter from a loss of $6 million in the year-ago quarter. The equity results include foreign currency translation losses of $500,000 in the latest quarter and $2.4 million in the 1985 second quarter.

title: DUDEK IS GETTING ATTENTION NOW
description: Joe Dudek went into April's National Football League college draft with a confidence born from his spectacular success as a small-college running back. Playing at the Division III level for Plymouth State College in New Hampshire, he set N.C.A.A. all-division career records With 79 touchdowns, 474 points and a rushing average of 7.1 yards. Those impressive numbers earned him ninth place in the Heisman Trophy balloting even though he had played at a college with a male enrollment of only 1,500.

title: NAPA VALLEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: July 29, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Nicaragua at 10:30 A.M.

title: Giving Back a Medal
description: In protest over United States military involvement in Central America, an American war hero plans today to return the Medal of Honor he was awarded for carrying 20 men, dead and alive, out of a combat zone in Vietnam.

title: BROADCAST CONCERN HAS PROFIT
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that it earned $67 million in the second quarter, compared with the $41.2 million that Capital Cities alone earned during the 1985 period.

title: Wait for 1990
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUFFOLK ADOPTS PLAN OF ITS OWN TO ACQUIRE LILCO
description: A plan to create a local public power authority to buy a controlling interest in the Long Island Lighting Company was approved today by the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ORGAN FINALE Another New York boast: The three largest organs in the United States may be right around here - at the United States Military Academy in West Point, St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue and Riverside Church. Riverside has a five-manual Aeolian-Skinner with 216 ranks, which it uses for church services as well as many concerts. The summer recital series with concerts each Tuesday evening is about to run its course, and today the penultimate performance will be presented by David Higgs, associate organist of the church. It is his farewell performance. He leaves after three years for a position in San Francisco.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $10.1 million, or 29 cents a share, extraordinary gain on the refinancing of a portion of Northwest Pipeline Corp.'s long term debt. Latest-quarter results were reduced by a non-cash charge of 23 cents a share as a result of the company's $8.6 million writedown on the carrying value of its Bancoklahoma Corp. stock.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bowery Savings Bank announced that John D. Griffiths had joined the bank as executive vice president and treasurer.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss, which is after special charges incurred during the quarter, reduced earnings from operations to $38.1 million, compared to $287.4 million in the prior quarter. The company said the latest 6-month period reflects after tax special charges of $210.7 million associated principally with reductions in work force, writedowns and writeoffs of inventories and equipment, and the purchase and redemption of certain debt issues.

title: Philip Morris
description: Philip Morris Companies Inc. is issuing in the Euromarket $100 million of 7 5/8 percent bonds due in 1990, through underwriters led by the Union Bank of Switzerland (Securities) Ltd. Noncallable for the life of the issue, the bonds are offered at 101 3/8, to yield 7.22 percent.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE OF IOWA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The figures were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: HOME SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a prepayment penalty to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of $103,623. c-Net loss and after a Federal Home Loan Bank Board dividend of $74,480.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASKETBALL CHARLESTON (CBA) - Named Gerald as Oliver coach and Geary Deniston as public-relations director. FOOTBALL

title: Jersey Is Planning Book-Entry Issue
description: The State of New Jersey plans to sell its first book-entry issue next month when it accepts bids on $130 million of general obligation bonds.

title: Market Place; Which Way Will Gold Go?
description: IN January, when the price of gold rose to $360 an ounce, some followers of the precious metal predicted it would reach $400 within months if investors became sufficiently worried about the stability of the banking system.

title: BREAST MILK TIED TO JAUNDICE
description: AN analysis of 22 studies of newborn infants with jaundice has found that breast-feeding is a common cause in the first week of life. However the author Dr. A. Patrick Schneider 2d of the University of Iowa, said that his finding should not deter mothers from breast-feeding their infants.

title: What Do Military Bands Do With $154 Million?
description: To the Editor:

title: NWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN ADMINISTRATION SCOFFS AT MOSCOW MOVE
description: The Reagan Administration scoffed today at Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement that six Soviet regiments would be withdrawn from Afghanistan.

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 31 IN A BEIRUT SUBURB
description: A huge bomb planted in a car devastated a three-block area in a Christian suburb of Beirut today, killing 31 people and wounding 120 others.

title: Howser Released
description: Dick Howser was released from a hospital yesterday and will begin radiation treatment this week for a malignant brain tumor.

title: Pennsylvania Police End Hunt For Elusive Tiger
description: An expert on big cats says the elusive feline that prompted a two-day search in the mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania was more likely a native puma than a runaway tiger.

title: Safeway Stock Rises Sharply
description: Safeway Stores shares rose $4.625 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $66.50, after reaching $67.125 during the session.

title: Hammermill's Takeover Study
description: The Hammermill Paper Company's directors will study a $52-a-share tender offer for all of its outstanding common shares made by a group led by Paul Bilzerian, a California investor, the company said. W. Craig McClelland, president and chief executive, of the paper manufacturer, said in a statement Sunday that Hammermill would consult with outside legal and financial advisers and would advise shareholders of its conclusion and recommendations before Aug. 7.

title: Prudential Gets a Briton To Head a London Unit
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., seeking to become a stronger player in merchant banking in London, has hired a Briton, John MacArthur, to lead the initiative.

title: In New York City, the Pedestrians Are a Hazard to the Bicyclists
description: To the Editor:

title: VIVIGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BREZENOFF TESTIFIES AT TRIAL OF EX-HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff took the stand in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday at the bribery and theft trial of John J. McLaughlin, his successor as president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Dozens Punished by Peking In Drive on Abuses of Power
description: Two Chinese Communist Party members in Peking have been sentenced to jail terms, eight have been stripped of their party membership and 40 others have been reprimanded in a campaign against abuse of power by Government officials, the official English-language newspaper China Daily reported today.

title: Carol Teitel, 62, Dies; Veteran Stage Actress
description: Carol Teitel, an actress who made many stage appearances both on and Off Broadway, died Sunday at the Cooper Hospital in Camden, N.J., of complications following an automobile accident on April 23 in Pensacola, Fla. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Landlord Goes to Jail For Violations of Code
description: J. Leonard Spodek, the landlord with thousands of building-code violations charged at 40 of his properties in Manhattan and Brooklyn, went to jail yesterday to serve civil and criminal sentences for some of the violations.

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results for the latest periods include provisions for the cost of personnel reductions of $1.4 million for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 6 months.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pakistan Resents Interference in Its Internal Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUGHT TIGHT RULES AS F.C.C. CHAIRMAN
description: Frederick W. Ford, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission who was given the task of polishing the agency's image after the television game show and payola scandals of the late 1950's, died of cancer Saturday at Hinsdale Hospital in Illinois. He was 76 years old.

title: BUTLER, JOHN O CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
REGNQUIST CALLED RIGHTS 'EXTREMIST
description: Major civil rights and women's groups declared their opposition today to the proposed elevation of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court to Chief Justice of the United States.

title: Clement Haynsworth's Invaluable Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REID MAKES HIS MARKS
description: J.R. Reid, the power forward from Virginia Beach, Va., who will be going to the University of North Carolina this fall, said that in a matter of a few months in his freshman year in high school he went from being a gangly, 6-foot-3-inch, 175-pounder to a jumping jack of 6 feet 7 inches and 200 pounds.

title: DEVRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEAD OF BENDEL'S MAY RESIGN
description: Sources in the retail industry say Geraldine Stutz will resign soon as president of Henri Bendel. Ms. Stutz, who in her 29-year tenure has molded the store into the epitome of big-city chic, is expected to announce that she will leave in September.

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRAZY EDDIE SETS NETWORK
description: Crazy Eddie, which prides itself on offering ''insane'' prices, wants to bring its brand of discount retailing into homes from coast to coast.

title: POLITICS IS THE KEY TOPIC AT CUOMO-HART FORUM
description: Mario M. Cuomo and Gary Hart came face to face here today, ostensibly for a forum on economic development. But in the end, it was the Presidency - not the economy - that was the topic of the day.

title: SEARCH FOR THE ORIGIN OF LIFE ENTERS A DYNAMIC NEW PHASE
description: Secrets gleaned from rocks on land and vents on the ocean floor, from probes far into space and deep inside living cells are producing what researchers call an exciting and dynamic new phase in the search for the origin of life.

title: FORMER INDIAN HEALTH OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Amolak Ram Mehta, a retired deputy director general of health services for the Government of India, died Saturday in New Delhi. He was 91 years old.

title: A Letter to Ortega
description: President Ortega, As chairman of the board of directors of La Prensa, I was not greatly astonished to hear your recent statement that I deserve to be sentenced to 30 years in jail after being tried by the people's anti-Somocista tribunals.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss There were no share earnings in the latest 6 months after preferred dividends. Midway Air said 1985 results did not include revenue and expenses incurred in connection with the Midway Express Service conducted under contract by Air Florida Inc.

title: Cocoa Crop Delay Seen
description: A premature end to the rainy season is likely to delay next season's cocoa crop in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest producer, trade sources said today. The sources said it was too early to determine the full impact on next season's harvest.

title: LaRouche Backers Lose Illinois Court Round
description: Two supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. who won Democratic Party primary races are not automatically entitled to party support, a judge ruled today.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results include an after-tax writeoff of $1.6 million.

title: Exxon to Pay $143 Million
description: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to a proposed settlement of $143 million for regulatory violations, the Department of Energy said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL TOTALIZATOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $55,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today in Vladivostok, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass. His remarks have been grouped by subject matter. Afghanistan

title: CPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Davis's Clout in 8th Defeats Braves, 4-2
description: Glenn Davis, who entered the game in an 0-for-19 slump, belted a three-run home run in the eighth inning tonight and singled in the other run to lead the Houston Astros to a 4-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: BLAST HITS THE WALL IN BERLIN
description: A bomb blew a hole in the Berlin wall on the Allied side of the border with East Berlin today, shattering nearby windows.

title: Topics; New Sports for Americans; The Invisible Senate
description: The Senate votes today on whether to continue to appear gavel-to-gavel on television's C-SPAN. Approval is expected, and certainly warranted, but few New Yorkers would know it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERE LIES. An Autobiography. By Eric Ambler. Illustrated. 234 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS NEW COURT RULING
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said yesterday that Nicaragua had filed suit against Honduras and Costa Rica at the International Court of Justice, seeking a ruling that would prohibit military actions by Nicaraguan rebel forces operating from those countries.

title: THE PAIN OF THE STEELWORKER
description: Battered by imports and slack demand, many of the nation's largest steel companies looked to labor three years ago to cut costs and help them become more competitive. After painful negotiations, the United Steelworkers of America reluctantly agreed to as much as $1.8 billion in concessions.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NOVA, AN ALBERTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $58.9 million accounting loss relating to dilution of the company's ownership in Husky Oil Ltd. for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: FLU VIRUS CHANGE COULD CUT VACCINE'S EFFECT, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Changes reported in one of the world's major flu viruses could reduce the effectiveness of flu vaccine being manufactured for use this fall and winter, according to a Federal health official.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $22,080,000 and $41,642,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $14,852,000 and $20,820,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Two Airlines' Profits Fall
description: NWA Inc., parent of Northwest Airlines, and Republic Airlines Inc., which plan to merge, both reported sharply lower second-quarter earnings today, which they attributed partly to fare discounts.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,189,000 for the quarter and $1.5 million for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: Payment Halt By Cuba Cited
description: Cuba has suspended payments on its short-term commercial debt to Western nations because of an acute shortage of foreign capital, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Coach's Criticism
description: Coach Marty Schottenheimer of the Cleveland Browns criticized his predecessor, Sam Rutigliano, yesterday, saying his predecessor's remarks about the death of Don Rogers ''are out of date because he hasn't been here in two years and has no idea what's going on.''

title: Heritage-Rollins
description: Heritage Communications Inc., a Des Moines cable television operator, said yesterday that it would begin a $41-a-share offer for the 5.2 million shares of Rollins Communications Inc. that it does not control. The offer for the additional stake in Rollins, an Atlanta holding company that operates television stations and outdoor advertising, has been expected since Heritage acquired 43.5 percent of the company from the Rollins family in June. Heritage owns about 6.7 million shares, or 46 percent.

title: The Last Prisoners in Lebanon
description: There is this much to celebrate in the release of the Rev. Lawrence Jenco after 19 months of captivity in Lebanon: He is alive, if in uncertain health; his joy is an elixir, and he brings news about three remaining American hostages. He also carries a videotaped plea from one of them, David Jacobsen, who says - or was made to say - that unless Washington negotiates, the other hostages will be murdered.

title: Advertising; Financial Cable
description: Business Television Network, a service of the Samuel Broadcasting Corporation, which is a subsidiary of Western-World Television, will beam its first hourlong financial news program via satellite to Europe on Aug. 4. Special cable systems in hotels, as well as other cable channels and systems will carry same-day Wall Street closings on stocks, bonds, precious metals and commodity exchanges in English. Advertisers can get a 30-second spot for $3,000, and during the first three months, a low charter rate will be available.

title: Citrus Trade Accord Gains
description: The United States has accepted a key European Community condition in a trade dispute over American citrus fruit exports, apparently clearing the way for a full settlement of the long-running disagreement, community diplomats said today.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The pro forma share earnings for 1985 were calculated based on the assumption that the shares of common stock outstanding at Dec. 31, 1985 were outstanding at the beginning of 1985.

title: GULF AND WESTERN SEEKING THEATERS
description: Gulf and Western Industries, the parent of Paramount Pictures, is increasing its stake in the movie exhibition business.

title: Window Guard Fails And Fall Kills Boy, 5
description: A 5-year-old boy was killed in a fall from his sixth-floor Bronx apartment last night when a window guard he was leaning against gave way, the police said.

title: Rumors Lift Hutton Stock
description: Speculation about a possible takeover pushed the price of E. F. Hutton & Company's stock sharply higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the company declined to comment on the rumors.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month results include the operations of McGraw-Edison Co. for two months.

title: Georgia Fight Heats Up
description: Increasing rancor is developing in the Democratic primary in Georgia's Fifth Congressional District, where two old friends and comrades-in-arms in the civil rights movement - State Senator Julian Bond and City Councilman John Lewis of Atlanta -are seeking to represent the district in Washington.

title: BUSH ABANDONS PLANS TO VISIT MOROCCO DURING MIDEAST TRIP
description: Vice President Bush abandoned plans today to visit Morocco after receiving no encouragement from King Hassan II for the trip, Bush aides said.

title: ESTATE OF ARTIST'S WIDOW BRINGS A COURT DISPUTE
description: Papers alleging that the late Mathilde Beckmann, widow of the painter Max Beckmann, was coerced into transferring her estate to two women who acted as her caretakers have been filed in United States District Court and in Surrogate's Court here. The transfer conveyed Max Beckmann paintings and other property worth millions to the caretakers, and left Mrs. Beckmann's sister, previously her principal heir, with $5,000.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: RULING PAVES THE WAY FOR HIRING CITY'S FIRST FEMALE TRASH HAULERS
description: A state judge yesterday rejected union arguments that the City Sanitation Department's most recent entrance test, which was passed by nearly all 45,054 applicants, was too easy. The ruling paves the way for the department to hire its first women.

title: U.S. BONDS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday in extremely light trading that reflected the continued absence of retail investors, many of whom expect next week's $30 billion quarterly Treasury refunding to augment the supply of Government debt sharply and thus produce much higher yields.

title: CAPITAL WIRE & CABLE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chief of Operations Appointed at Apple
description: Delbert W. Yocam took time out from water-skiing yesterday to be promoted to executive vice president and chief operating officer of Apple Computer Inc. Mr. Yocam, who joined Apple in 1979, was taking a six-week sabbatical with his family at Lake Tahoe when he moved up from being executive vice president and group executive of product operations.

title: ON 13, SANDINISTAS VS. MISKITOS
description: ''NICARAGUA WAS OUR HOME'' accuses the Nicaraguan Government of a calculated brutalization of the Miskito Indians, and rebuts the notion that the Sandinistas, idealistic revolutionaries, pursue peace and justice for all people. The documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, suggests, in fact, that they are thugs.

title: INTELLICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,079,000 for the quarter and $1.7 million for the year. c-Net loss The latest fourth quarter and year include a $3,185,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of a 60 percent interest in Intelligenetics Inc.

title: SOUTH'S DROUGHT IS RAISING PRICES OF MANY FOODS
description: Consumers in the Northeast and the Middle West are feeling the effects of the great Southern drought as the prices of poultry, eggs and many vegetables and fruits have reached the highest levels in months.

title: University of Iowa Sets Rule to Bar Harassment
description: The University of Iowa announced a policy today that forbids faculty members to have romantic relationships with students, as part of an effort to rule out sexual harassment.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bama's Burden
description: Coach Ray Perkins of the University of Alabama, looking forward to a 1986 football schedule that includes Ohio State, Notre Dame, Penn State, Florida, Tennessee, Louisiana State and Auburn: ''Somebody told me I must not like my job very much to arrange such a schedule.''

title: TEST'S PRINT ERROR CAUSES LOSS OF MILITARY BENEFITS
description: The mistaken use of tiny type on a standard test administered to military recruits caused some to lose thousands of dollars in cash and tuition benefits as well as job opportunities, the Pentagon said today.

title: UNPRETENTIOUS PRODIGY PUZZLED BY ALL THE FUSS
description: Two days after her triumphant appearance at Tanglewood, the 14-year-old Japanese violinist Midori returned to her home in New York. Everything had changed. Now there were interviews to give, phone calls to return, photographers and news cameramen flocking outside the door, waiting for a glimpse of the young prodigy.

title: REPUBLIC AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,020,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After tax credits of $17,980,000 for the quarter and $20,827,000 for the 6 months.

title: France's Deficit Down
description: France's oil import bill fell by 44.4 percent in the first six months this year over the corresponding period in 1985 and is likely to have a continuing beneficial effect on the trade balance, Government officials said today. Customs figures showed the net value of imports in the first six months declined to $6 billion, from $10.8 billion last year. France's trade deficit in June fell to $180 million, from $300 million in May, bringing the seasonally adjusted trade deficit for the first half of the year to just over $1 billion, compared with more than $2 billion a year ago.

title: Bank Responds To Suit by Hunts
description: The Bank of America, one of 23 banks sued last month by the Hunt brothers, filed its answer and counterclaim in Federal Bankruptcy Court here today.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: KNICK SHARES KING'S STRUGGLE
description: Bernard King was a college all-American, a top draft choice, one of the most heralded small forwards in the game, an all-star with a salary of $874,000 a year and the National Basketball Association scoring champion in the 1984-85 season.

title: HERRICK K. LIDSTONE
description: Herrick Kenley Lidstone, former senior partner of the law firm Battle, Fowler, Lidstone, Jaffin, Pierce & Kheel of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Slater, Colo., in the Little Snake River Valley. He was 65 and also lived in Broomfield, Colo., and Chamela Jalisco, Mexico.

title: ASSESSING BRAND X
description: DOZENS of companies are making copies of the I.B.M.

title: NIEKRO GONE EARLY IN DEFEAT
description: Joe Niekro, dejected, stood off to the side of the mound with his arms folded. Manager Lou Piniella worked the dirt on the other side, kicking it casually, his head down. For a team in the thick of the race, the Yankees have had many of these small, uneasy moments, and for one fundamental reason: Their pitching continues to hold them back.

title: PITFALLS IN USING RESEARCH
description: DISASTER in the classroom often results when school administrators translate educational research into standardized teaching programs. This warning is issued by Miles Myers, president of the California Federation of Teachers and former administrative director of the National Writing Project at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Net income c-Net income and includes a loss from discontiunued operations of $13.7 million.

title: ANGELA PLACE
description: Angela Place, an official for many years of New York and national horticultural and preservation organizations, died Saturday at her home in Canaan, Conn. She was 90 years old.

title: Strike by Hindus Shuts Stores in New Delhi
description: Stores throughout the capital were closed today in a one-day strike called by Hindu leaders to protest the killing of 14 Hindus on a bus in the Punjab on Friday.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Packers Waive Zorn
description: Jim Zorn was waived yesterday by the Green Bay Packers, who reached tentative agreement with another quarterback, Lynn Dickey. Dickey, who became a free agent at the end of last season, was expected to report to Green Bay late yesterday or early today.

title: IN VOTES SO FAR, CONGRESS APPEARS FAR FROM MEETING DEFICIT TARGET
description: Congress, preoccupied with finding a way to repair the mechanism for automatic spending cuts in the budget-balancing law, is falling behind in its effort to cut the 1987 Federal deficit on its own.

title: If Verrazano Had Sailed Up the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: DILUCIA LOSES SPOT ON BALLOT IN THE PRIMARY
description: The State Board of Elections yesterday ruled Gilbert DiLucia off the Sept. 9 Democratic primary ballot for lieutenant governor on the ground that he had not filed enough valid signatures.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., said Occidental Chemical Corp. had purchased Cyanamid's North American dicalcium phosphate business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ella Fitzgerald Resting In Intensive Care Unit
description: Ella Fitzgerald was resting comfortably and in good spirits today in the intensive care unit at the Niagara Falls Memorial Medical Center, where she was being treated for congestive heart failure, hospital officials said.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A LIGHTER 'NICKLEBY' IS COMING TO BROADWAY
description: ''Scene nine,'' says the voice over the loudspeaker, urgently. ''Smike and Nicholas to Portsmouth.''

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 22
Israel Charges Guards Faked Bomb Threat
description: A bomb discovered at the United States Consulate in East Jerusalem on Friday had been put there by local security guards so that they could pretend to find it, the Israeli police said today.

title: EXCERPTS OF CONVERSATION ON SHUTTLE
description: Following are excerpts from the final conversations of the Challenger crew members, as recorded on board the Challenger and released yesterday.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest-quarter results include the operations of Peoples Natural Gas, acquired in December.

title: Theismann to CBS
description: Joe Theismann has been hired as a CBS color commentator. The former Washington Redskin quarterback suffered a broken right leg last Nov. 18 while being sacked by Lawrence Taylor of the Giants. He is supposed to be paired with Jack Buck, a seasoned commentator.

title: Competition Is Music To Some Ears
description: For years, J. William Middendorf 2d has been making Beethoven roll over. And occasionally he puts John Philip Sousa at parade rest.
