description: b-Net loss

title: FOOTBALL TRIAL JURY GETS MORE MATERIAL
description: The jury in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League deliberated through the late afternoon yesterday, took a dinner break, deliberated some more and recessed at 9 P.M. without reaching a verdict.

title: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $511,000 and $834,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: From Settlement Houses, 100 Years of Service
description: Jana Gray stepped, a little nervously, up to the stage of the bandshell in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center yesterday, wearing a green sponge-rubber crown, green robe and holding aloft a paper torch.

title: 'WE JUST HAVE TO GO ON'
description: Outside the barn, in green and gold, the words ''W. R. Haughton Stable'' encircled the small silhouette of a driver and a horse in a sulky. And now, wearing his green and gold driver's suit after a morning of working horses here at the Meadowlands race track, Tom Haughton looked into the stall where Speedy Tomali was standing.

title: QUEEN'S AIDE ENTERS PRESS FRAY, CRYING SHAME
description: The Queen does not write letters to newspapers, but the most prominently displayed letter in The Times of London today was dispatched from the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh, where she is now staying.

title: A Door Tipped Open
description: A series of disclosures from the Administration has described the belated letter President Reagan sent to Moscow last week as a ''positive response'' to Soviet arms control proposals. If so, it's because a door that seemed to be closed and sealed may now be tipped open.

title: ADAPTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $705,000 for the latest quarter and $244,000 for the year-ago period.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the 1986 results include the operations of a sheet and towel unit that Fieldcrest acquired from Cannon Mills Inc. in January 1986. The company recently changed its name from Fieldcrest Mills Inc.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for- 1 stock split in May.

title: TIMKEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: YORK FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $132,000 relating to an adjustment of a tax-credit benefit. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $563,00 which includes a special dividend of Home Loan Mortgage Corp. for participating preferred stock of $386,000 and a tax-credit benefit of $177,000. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Topics; New Sports for Americans; Champion du Monde
description: The Tour de France is the world's premier bike race, one of the most grueling of all athletic contests and long a passion of Europeans. Now, thanks to a young man named Greg LeMond, it also belongs to America.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $1,516,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $6 million on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter, and includes for the 6-month period, income of $7,173,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $1,940,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5,213,000 and $10,485,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WESTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $5 million from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $14 million and $20.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Latest-quarter results include a pre-tax charge of $1.7 million, and for the latest 6 months, results include a pre-tax gain of $33.2 million. Results for the year-ago quarter include a pre-tax gain of $8.5 million on the disposition of property and equipment, and for the year-ago 6 months, results include $12.4 million on the disposition of property and equipment.

title: FATHER JENCO FINALLY CATCHES HIS CAB
description: For his first six months as a hostage in Lebanon, the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco was kept chained by his ankle to the wall of the room where he was held in solitary confinement. When his captors asked him if he wanted anything, he would invariably reply, ''A taxicab.''

title: U.S. Now Monitoring All Fuel-Injected Cars
description: The head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that it was monitoring all cars equipped with electronic fuel injection to watch for sudden acceleration problems.

title: RED SOX WIN, 3-1, FROM WHITE SOX
description: Don Baylor's two-run home run and a bases-empty homer by Dwight Evans led the Boston Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight, extending Chicago's losing streak to eight games.

title: UNITED SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Another Chance
description: His real name was John Garcia, but last summer when he stepped into a boxing ring against Meldrick Taylor in Norfolk, Va., it was as Roberto Juan Medina.

title: DATAFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARIS COUTURE: BEADS, FEATHERS AND FURS
description: Flamboyance rather than understatement was the rule as the couture houses here began showing their fall and winter made-to-order collections over the weekend. The drama goes far beyond the elaborately beaded evening dress, which can cost as much as $35,000 and is one of the couture specialties. It involves feathers, furs, intricate inlaid effects and appliques as well as shapes that are tighter, fuller or simply more exaggerated than in the more mundane ready-to-wear collections. The results can be so rich they are cloying, and a simple black princess dress is welcomed to clear the palate.

title: JERSEY PUTS OFF SHIPPING OF SOIL
description: The shipment of 5,000 drums of radon-contaminated soil from Montclair, N.J., to Vernon Township, N.J., will be delayed until the end of August, New Jersey officials announced yesterday. The transfer, which was to have begun within a week, will be delayed to permit a panel to study the plan for storing the soil.

title: Advertising; Fisher Name Change
description: At a party last night, Fisher & Company, specialists in theatrical advertising, was to announce a name change to Fisher/LeDonne/Wilner, as its partners, Peter LeDonne, 41 years old, and John Wilner, 31, join Joseph Fisher, 39, with their names in lights.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q & A
description: Q.

title: CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The cause of death of the Challenger astronauts cannot be positively determined; the forces to which the crew were exposed during orbiter breakup were probably not sufficient to cause death or injury, and the crew possibly, but not certainly, lost consciousness in the seconds following orbiter breakup due to in-flight loss of crew module pressure.'' - Dr. Joseph P. Kerwin of NASA. [ C9:1. ]

title: Hanover Rating May Be Lowered
description: The debt rating on about $10 billion of outstanding securities issued by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Overseas Capital Corporation is under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: IN JERSEY, A SOCIAL VISION OF '10 CARRIES ON IN '86
description: On one side, cars hiss down the six lanes of Interstate 78. On the other, $250,000 houses rise, each crammed onto a treeless lot. And in the grove of oaks and pines between sits a colony called Free Acres, a social experiment that has somehow survived into the 1980's.

title: DIGITAL'S PROFITS MORE THAN DOUBLE
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the world's second-largest computer company, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $238.6 million, or $1.81 a share, from $100.4 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier.

description: A four-year nonpartisan project evaluating the domestic record of the Reagan Administration has produced a final volume suggesting that part of its legacy may be a faltering economy, growing divisions on religious issues and confusion in both political parties.

description: A $480 million issue of Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission ''multi-mode'' revenue bonds, series B through J, was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: 'CUNNINGHAM,' ON BRAVO NETWORK
description: ''MERCE CUNNINGHAM,'' an hourlong program broadcast tonight at 10 o'clock on the Bravo cable network, is a lovely and revealing program about that master experimentalist and the world in which he creates his dances. The program, which is followed by Mr. Cunningham's ''Channels/Inserts,'' doesn't provide a historical frame or context for his innovative and extremely influential work. Instead, we plunge right in as if the choreographer needed no introduction.

title: Marshals Catch Fugitive After Rookie's Tracking
description: One of the Marshal Service's 15 most wanted fugitives, with a long history of escapes, was captured Sunday after being tracked by a rookie marshal, the authorities reported.

title: MORGAN'S NET RISES
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. reported yesterday that it avoided some of the bond trading losses that afflicted other major securities firms in the second quarter, with its net income rising 59.1 percent, to $45.5 million, or $1.82 a share, from $28.6 million, or $1.44 a share, in the corresponding 1985 quarter.

title: CUOMO VETOES ART-OWNERSHIP BILL
description: Gov. Cuomo today vetoed a bill that he said might have made New York ''a haven for cultural property stolen abroad.''

description: Joseph R. Pisani, a former State Senator from New Rochelle, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for evading taxes on $27,000 of his income in 1979.

description: Debt

description: Why risk the lives of seven astronauts to park a satellite in space when an unmanned rocket could do the chore more reliably?

description: ''No children'' is a sign of the past for housing in New York City.

title: Congress; Morals, Politics, South Africa
description: A year ago, President Reagan managed to head off a Congressional drive to adopt sanctions against South Africa by initiating some modest actions on his own, primarily the banning of the importation of Krugerrands, the South African gold coins.

description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

description: What ails the American economy? Why, in the face of strongly growing spending by consumers and the Federal Government, has the economy faltered, and why have American workers been unable to increase their output of goods and services?

title: TITANIC'S EXPLORERS RETURN HOME TO CHEERS
description: After making 11 dives to the wreck of the Titanic and discovering destruction they say rules out raising the giant ship, researchers on board the Atlantis II returned to their home port here today after 22 days at sea. They were greeted by hundreds of well-wishers and salutes from ships horns.

Sex Life of Deer Mice
description: The reproductive behavior of deer mice can be drastically altered by natural selection in as short a period as two generations, a remarkable rate, according to biologists at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: DRAW OPENS CHESS MATCH
description: The world champion of chess, Gary Kasparov, overcame the disadvantage of playing second and gained a draw today against Anatoly Karpov in the opening game of their third battle for the world title.

title: WILLIAM H. O'BRIEN
description: William H. O'Brien, a former instructor and administrator at Long Island University, died of cancer Saturday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in East Moriches, L.I.

description: b-Net income

title: Business and the Law; Lawyers Await Japanese Rules
description: FOR more than 30 years, the Japanese have made it clear that United States lawyers are among the most unwelcome exports this country produces. But this spring, the barriers came down: Japan, finally, passed a law allowing foreign lawyers to practice there.

title: Citicorp Acquires Lynch, Jones Firm
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking concern, said yesterday that it had bought Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a small Wall Street brokerage firm that specializes in institutional research products.

title: Swimmer Loses Arm To Alabama Alligator
description: An 11 1/2-foot alligator that had been fed by fishermen attacked a man who went swimming in a lake Saturday to cool off. It tore off the man's right arm before he was able to escape.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''HEY, turkey, where's your T?'' someone shouted Thursday night at Doubles. That's the private club below the lobby of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Fifth Avenue where the upper brackets play, but, usually, only if they're dressed up.

title: CINCINNATI MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Is Investigating A High-Tech Diversion
description: The Reagan Administration is investigating a purported attempt to divert a shipment of militarily sensitive high-technology equipment to the Soviet bloc, officials said today.

title: Bridge: Unexpected Teams Make It To the Knockout Semifinals
description: Some unexpected teams battled this afternoon in the semifinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship, and all the favorites were on the sidelines. For the surviving teams, the average seeding number was 17.25, believed to be the highest in the event's history.

title: SUBWAY DELAYS EXPECTED TO LAST UNTIL EARLY '88
description: Repair work on the Manhattan Bridge, which has forced more than 200,000 subway riders a day to take alternate routes, will continue for 18 months longer than planned because extensive corrosion has been discovered, transportation officials said yesterday.

title: PUBLIC VOICES FAITH IN MILITARY
description: A survey sponsored by a Presidential commission has found a high degree of American confidence in the nation's armed forces, with about half the people believing that they should come under less civilian control.

title: HOLE IN OZONE OVER SOUTH POLE WORRIES SCIENTISTS
description: ATMOSPHERIC scientists are struggling to explain one of the strangest mysteries ever to confront them: a widening and potentially dangerous hole in the ozone layer over the South Pole.

title: Advertising; Ad Pages Up in June
description: In June magazine members of the Publishers Information Bureau carried 12,699 ad pages, a 2 percent gain from the 12,447 in the month in 1985. Estimated revenues were $430.7 million, a 4 percent gain.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (KALAAZOO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METS GET 4 IN FIRST INNING, ROUT CUBS BEHIND OJEDA
description: Even if there were occasional bouts of complacency, it would be easy to forgive the Mets. But they have not faltered once. In a season full of accomplishment, they have not so much as paused to consider the possibility of a lapse.

title: CRUDE OIL EDGES UP; WHEAT AND CATTLE RISE
description: Crude oil futures prices edged slightly higher today as OPEC began its meetings in Geneva amid disagreement among members about the organization's production quotas.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 100-percent stock dividend paid May 1986.

title: 36.14 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,773.90
description: The Monday ''jinx'' continued yesterday on Wall Street, where stock prices sagged badly under the weight of rising interest rates, a weak economy and a misalignment in the level of stock index futures.

title: INDICTMENT CITED OVER CONTRACTS FOR MINORITIES
description: A Queens construction company with millions of dollars in city contracts has been indicted on state charges of evading rules that required it to give a piece of its city road repair work to companies owned by minorities or women, officials familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Mandela on Communism
description: When the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group visited Nelson Mandela in prison this year, the members of the delegation were struck by ''the consistency of his views,'' and said that he told them his ''principles were unchanged from those to which he subscribed . . . in 1955.'' The following is adapted from his statement from the dock in the Pretoria Supreme Court, where he was convicted of sabotage in 1964.

title: STAGE: 'HOMECOMING,' FROM IRELAND
description: In bar plays - in the words of Harry Hope in ''The Iceman Cometh'' - there is often ''no life in the booze.'' The road to anesthesia by alchohol is paved with veritas, as characters, against their will, begin to see themselves as others see them. This certainly is the case in Tom Murphy's ''Conversations on a Homecoming,'' an Irish play of the genre, presented last weekend at the Pepsico Summerfare festival at the State University of New York here.

title: Election Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union would withdraw six regiments from Afghanistan by the end of the year, and asked that the move be matched by a reduction of Western aid to the guerrillas.

description: OPEC today opened emergency discussions of ways to reverse the slide in oil prices, but denunciations of Saudi Arabia by the Iranian delegate reflected the deep divisions within the group.

title: FREUD'S LONDON REFUGE: LONG A SHRINE, IT OPENS AS A MUSEUM
description: Speaking to his disciples two days after Nazi storm troopers marched into Vienna in 1938, Sigmund Freud drew a parallel. ''After the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem by Titus,'' he said, ''Rabbi Jochanan ben Sakkai asked for permission to open a school at Jabneh for the study of Torah. We are going to do the same.''

title: BIG IN JAPAN: AMERICAN HOMES
description: The Nakamura family's dream house stands high on a hill in this old port city. It could just as easily be found in Valley Stream, L.I., or Morristown, N.J.

title: DETROIT WORKERS REJECT PACT BY 3 TO 1
description: Striking municipal workers rejected a tentative contract today, their union said, prolonging a walkout already in its 13th day.

title: From 53d Street, A Map of 'Gems'
description: Flip it open, and buildings seem to jump out in three-dimensional perspective. That is the new three-foot, four-color map that the 53d Street Association has begun distributing free to people who want to know more about their byway.

title: Coast Guard Seizes Boat After 9 Distress Calls
description: The sailing vessel C-Lyon tested the Coast Guard's patience too often and Coast Guard officials said today that they seized the vessel and its pilot for an investigation.

title: ROME'S SUMMER CIRCUS: LIONS FEED ON THE MAYOR
description: Some 1,900 years ago the poet Juvenal declared this city was going downhill because its once noble citizens wanted bread and circuses more than anything else. Lots of water has gone under the Tiber bridges since then, but the Romans still expect their rulers to provide lots of entertainment, especially on warm, starry nights.

title: PRODUCERS CUT COSTS OF ACTION SHOWS
description: As the action-adventure television show ''Airwolf'' goes into its third full season, it is subject to certain imperatives that promise to make production itself something of an adventure. For one thing, the show, which is about the exploits of a futuristic attack helicopter, will have to be shot virtually without the helicopter. The chopper is too expensive. ''Airwolf'' is now being produced on a severe austerity budget, part of an effort by MCA Universal, the studio that produced the series for CBS, to recover its roughly $12 million loss on the series's first 58 episodes broadcast before the network canceled the show last spring. Universal now hopes to produce enough new episodes of the program as cheaply as possible to sell the series in syndication to independent television stations.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $514 million for the quarter and $535 million for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago quarter results are after a charge of $1.5 billion. The company said the second quarter results also include a favorable adjustment of about $12 million after tax from the adoption of new pension accounting as defined by the FASB.

title: Careers; Computer Science in Transition
description: DEMAND for new graduates with a bachelor's degree in computer science continues to be strong, according to Thomas L. Tarantelli, assistant director of career planning and placement at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. But there are some twists in job openings and in the type of work that computer science majors want.

title: QMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
GIANTS LOOKING TO ROBINSON
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants is pleased with several parts of his team. He says he has many good offensive linemen. He feels comfortable with his outside linebackers. Wide receiver is something else. ''I'm very concerned about that position,'' said Parcells. ''I think it could be the difference for us, good or bad.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 29, 1986
description: International Moscow will trim its Afghan force by the end of the year, according to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Soviet leader, in announcing plans for the withdrawal of six regiments, or about 6 percent of the Soviet force, also said in a speech in the Pacific coast city of Vladivostok that the Kremlin was seeking closer relations with China. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: 8 BLACKS REPORTED SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA VIOLENCE
description: The South African authorities reported today that eight more blacks had died in the nation's violence, and the Government continued to crackdown on the nation's black high schools.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INCALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Iceland, Voicing Anger, Halts All Whaling
description: Iceland suspended the island's whale catch today to avoid what it said were United States plans to impose a crippling boycott on Icelandic fish products, the country's main source of income.

title: CRUISING ON THE SHORES OF LAKE MICHIGAN, DUNE-BUGGY STYLE
description: ''Hello, folks. My name is Bob. I'll be your driver for most of the ride. For how many of you is it the first time out on the dunes? Good. Well, it's my second time; they decided to give me another chance.''

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter's net includes costs totaling $17 million for production shutdowns and writedowns of inventories and fixed assets, as well as a gain of $11 million from the sale of part of Inco's investment in Biogen N.V., reducing its stake to about 12 percent from 17 percent. The results include gains from sales of securities and retirement of long- term debt and currency translation adjustments of $10.8 million in the latest 6 months and $23 million for the year-ago period. All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: CHALLENGER CREW KNEW OF PROBLEM, DATA NOW SUGGEST
description: The Challenger crew members were probably aware that the space shuttle was in trouble in the final seconds before it disintegrated and may well have survived the initial breakup, according to evidence made public today.

title: FATHER BAKER'S BOYS ARE ONCE MORE A FAMILY
description: By the time Bill Beck was 8 and his brother Charles 6, both their parents were dead. It was 1921. They remember being put on a train in New Jersey with large tags around their necks that said only ''Father Baker's.'' And they got here.

title: LIFE CARE COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: UNOCAL NET TUMBLES BY 71.3%
description: The Unocal Corporation and the Atlantic Richfield Company today reported mixed results for the second quarter, and analysts said that third-quarter results are likely to slip further for both companies in the face of depressed crude oil prices.

title: DSC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a charge of $13,718,000 for the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting of revenue recognition.

title: William D. Patterson Is Dead; Was Publisher of Magazine
description: William D. Patterson, a former publisher of Saturday Review, died July 26 of a heart attack while driving his car near Greensboro, Vt. Mr. Patterson, who lived in Brooklyn, was 76.

title: AN ELECTRONIC WILL: NOT A LAWYER
description: THE promise of personal computing has always been that it would make life easier and more fun. Yet, on the whole, it seems rather to have made our days more complicated and more frustrating. This fact alone explains why the home computer failed to find a wide market. Although the machine will ultimately become the entertainment center of the hearth, the much touted domiciliary computer of the early 80's turned out to be no more than a faddish game machine, a commuter's extension of the computer at the office or a mere bookend propping up expensive software, promising in appearance but rarely utilized after the first exploratory employment, wearing alluring titles such as Managing Your Money, The Scarsdale Diet or The MicroCookbook.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS REAGAN PLANS NEW CAMPAIGN AGAINST DRUG USE
description: President Reagan plans to announce a broad new campaign in the next few weeks to combat the use of narcotics, White House officials said today.

title: STATE COLLEGES SEEKING SHARE OF PHILANTHROPIC PIE
description: After years of watching from the sidelines while private colleges and universities dominated the field, the country's public universities are moving aggressively into large-scale fund-raising.

title: Boyd Hearing Delayed
description: A hearing to determine if the Boston Red Sox pitcher, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, should face criminal charges stemming from a shoving incident with the police has been postponed until October.

title: Northrop Teams With McDonnell
description: The Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said they had formed a team to compete for contracts to develop the Air Force's next-generation fighter aircraft, the Advanced Tactical Fighter.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JURY IN CANCER DEATH SUIT SAYS FACTORY POLLUTED WELLS
description: Eight families who say that chemicals in their city's water system have caused six leukemia deaths and numerous illnesses won the first round of a major lawsuit today when a Federal jury found that W. R. Grace and Company ''substantially contributed to the contamination'' of two wells.

title: Peru Hardens Debt Stance
description: President Alan Garcia hardened Peru's stance on its foreign debt today, limiting repayments on private sector foreign debt and extending for a year a strict ceiling on public sector debt repayments.

title: CHESS TITLE MATCH OPENS WITH DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union opened his defense of the world chess championship today with a draw against his countryman, Anatoly Karpov.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $34.4 million for the quarter and $31.6 million for the 6 months; a tax credit of $18 million and a charge of $27.2 million representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change, both for the quarter and 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $3.5 million and $20.5 million for quarter and 6 months, respectively. title: CONFEREES REMAIN SPLIT ON TAXES ON BUSINESSES
description: House and Senate conferees remained stymied on tax revision legislation today, with representatives pressing for higher taxes on business and senators resisting.

title: Tool Orders Down 14.5%
description: Orders for machine tools fell 14.5 percent in June from the period a year earlier, ending a sluggish first half in which total orders were down 11.2 percent from a year ago, according to the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: BIAS CASE SUSPECT YIELDS TO THE POLICE
description: Brian Tribble, the man Maryland authorities suspect supplied the cocaine that killed Len Bias, surrendered to the Prince George's County police yesterday and was held on a bond of $250,000, the police said.

title: A Wave of Bombings Shakes Peru's Capital
description: Leftist rebels set off bombs at 17 sites in Lima, including luxury hotels, banks, stores and a restaurant, the police and news reports said today. Newspapers said two waiters were injured in one attack.

title: Approval Urged For Frontier Sale
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division urged approval of the proposed $146 million acquisition of Frontier Airlines by United Airlines, although it conceded that the merger might reduce competition. Justice officials urged the Transportation Department to approve the merger because of Frontier's weak financial condition.

INFLATION RATE SHOWS IN REGION
description: The rate of inflation in the New York-northeastern New Jersey region was the lowest in 22 years in the first half of 1986, reflecting record declines in energy costs, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Boeing's Net Rises by 24.3%
description: Bouyed by increased sales and orders, the Boeing Company today reported second-quarter earnings of $169 million, or $1.09 a share, up 24.3 percent from $136 million, or 93 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

title: Can Mandela Be South Africa's de Gaulle?
description: I'm a South African white businessman with a vested interest in the survival of the free-enterprise system. And I'm terrified that a head-on clash of wills between obstinate and repressive Afrikaner nationalism and increasingly violent black nationalism will plunge this magnificently endowed country into bloodshed.

description: b-Net loss

title: Eastern Air Planning Cuts
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. has warned employees that it is drawing up plans to cut $100 million in expenses in preparation for its acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation. Glen Parsons, Eastern spokesman, said today that layoffs were ''certainly a possibility.''

title: Lineman Signed
description: Sean Farrell, a cornerstone of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' offensive line, has agreed to a one-year contract, the club has announced. Terms were not disclosed.

title: J. C. Penney Deal
description: The J. C. Penney Company is expected to announce that it will begin offering financial products of the Security Pacific Corporation, the Los Angeles-based banking organization, through its existing J. C. Penney Financial Centers. Sources familiar with the transaction said that loans, lines of credit and investments such as mutual funds would be offered in 17 Penney stores in northern California.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $824,000, or 10 cents a share, from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: Chrysler, U.A.W. Contract at Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers have agreed to a contract adopting Japanese-style management practices at the aging Jefferson Avenue assembly plant here, a top union official said. The two sides jointly announced the agreement after a 17-hour bargaining session. U. A. W. vice president Marc Stepp said the tentative pact would incorporate the team concept, under which there would be more worker responsibility in factory operations and a reduction in the number of supervisors from the current ratio of one manager for every 18 workers.

title: Armstrong Set To Restructure
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company, the nation's sixth-largest tire maker, announced a restructuring plan today that involves the closing of at least one tire manufacturing plant and acquiring a fourth business segment.

title: Niagara Mohawk
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation is offering $150 million of 8 7/8 percent first-mortgage bonds with a final maturity in 1994 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds are offered at a price of 99.75, to yield 8.919 percent, or 1.6 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable for the life, the bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by S. & P.

title: SENATE VOTES 78-21 TO RETAIN TELEVISION COVERAGE OF PROCEEDINGS
description: After a three-month experiment, the Senate entered the television age for keeps today, voting 78 to 21 to permit gavel-to-gavel television coverage of its proceedings on a permanent basis.

title: YANKS TRADE HASSEY AND OBTAIN KITTLE
description: The pitching has been the Yankees' glaring shortcoming, but they have had other problems preventing them from mounting a full-scale charge at the Red Sox. They have needed another right-handed hitter and a regular shortstop.

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: New Vatican Envoy
description: President Reagan is preparing to name Frank J. Shakespeare Jr., a broadcasting executive and former director of the United States Information Agency, as Ambassador to the Vatican, according to diplomatic sources.

title: KARPOV KEPT UNSETTLED BY KASPAROV OPENING
description: One of the major objectives when playing Black in a world championship chess match is to keep the opponent from getting settled in a secure formation from which he can press for a victory. This objective was fulfilled without a hitch Monday by the 23-year-old champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, in the first game of his title defense in London with his countryman, Anatoly Karpov.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28

title: House Vote Fails to Overrule Trade Benefits for Rumania
description: The House of Representatives today defeated a move to overrule an extension of trade benefits to Rumania.

title: U.S. Planes in NATO Games
description: The United States will send six Air Force units to England next week to take part in an annual NATO exercise involving tactical fighter aircraft, the Pentagon said today. Units from Canada, Belgium, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, West Germany and Britain will also take part in the exercise, which will be held from Aug. 4 to 8.

title: LA PETITE ACADEMY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unbumped by Bush
description: Wolf Blitzer, Washington bureau chief of The Jerusalem Post, is going to Jordan with Vice President Bush after all. On Monday the journalist said he had been barred from the Jordan segment of the Vice President's Middle Eastern trip by a Bush aide, despite the fact that he was a United States citizen with an American passport and a visa to Jordan signed by the Jordanian Ambassador himself.

title: Mayflower Study
description: The Mayflower Group Inc., operator of one the nation's largest moving van companies, said that its directors were continuing to study the possibility of selling all or parts of the company, or taking the concern private in a leveraged buyout. Mayflower has been considering various options since Laidlaw Transportation Ltd. dropped its $29.25-a-share tender offer in June. Mayflower's stock closed up $1.625, at $23.125, in trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

description: THE sharp drop in the bond and stock markets at the start of this week was set off by worries that the United States Government's borrowing needs in the near future would drive up interest rates. And anxieties over the weakness of the American economy drove the dollar down.

title: Cineplex Theater Deal Seen
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation, a Toronto-based theatrical chain, has agreed to acquire the RKO Century Warner Company, sources familiar with the talks said yesterday. RKO Century is a chain that owns 100 movie screens in the metropolitan area plus 40 in the five boroughs.

title: BRITISH CARTOONIST AND WRITER
description: Sir Osbert Lancaster, the doyen of English cartoonists, a gifted stage designer and a perceptive and provocative writer on art, architecture and social history, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 77 years old.

title: Latin-Caribbean Carnival Is Scheduled
description: Street sounds will give way to the samba at a daylong carnival Aug. 10 sponsored by the Caribbean Cultural Center. A parade of performers in native costumes will kick off the day at 1 P.M., beginning at 10th Avenue and 58th Street.

description: Both year-ago periods have been restated to reflect pooling of interest accounting in regard to Maytag's merger on May 30 with Magic Chef Inc.

description: Voters in Montclair, N.J., yesterday defeated a proposal that would have led to creating a board to arbitrate rent disputes between landlords and tenants, the Township Clerk's office said last night.

description: The Hunt brothers today escalated their legal attack against their lenders, charging their 23 banks with attempting to create a monopoly in the offshore drilling rig business.

description: Immunologists at Georgetown University Hospital next month will begin human clinical trials of a treatment for AIDS aimed at revitalizing the immune system of those afflicted, a research company says.

Extensive Surgery
description: Doctors worked on the pelvic fractures of Jacques Laffite for nearly six hours yesterday, then they worked on his right leg for three hours and his left leg for two more hours before deciding that the Grand Prix race-car driver will need another two hours of surgery later to mend a fracture of his left heel. They said Laffite, who suffered multiple fractures in a crash at the British Grand Prix on July 13, was in satisfactory condition.

title: BIRTHS RISE FOR UNWED WOMEN
description: Childbearing by unmarried women in 1984 accounted for more than one baby in five, the highest level since the Government began collecting data on the subject in 1940, according to a report from the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: U.S.-Japan Chip Talks
description: Semiconductor trade negotiations between the United States and Japan continued amid growing skepticism today that any agreement would be reached. Failing an agreement by midnight Wednesday, the Commerce Department could brand Japan an unfair trader and reimpose anti-dumping tariffs on erasable programmable read-only memory chips, which are known as Eprom's. Negotiators failed to meet a deadline set for last Saturday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''HI, it's me, I'm back,'' said Mayor Koch. The Mayor was back on the radio, chatting and answering telephone calls as he has once a month since early this year on ''The Roy Fox Show'' on WMCA-AM. The program is news-and-issues-oriented; when the Mayor turns up, as he did the other evening, it becomes a kind of town hall meeting. Lillian of Borough Park called to thank the Mayor for a wonderful Statue of Liberty weekend. Anne of New Rochelle called to complain about litter-strewn parkways. Then 12-year-old Charlie Redell called.

title: Congressional Sources
description: Members of Congress go out of their way to obtain television coverage of their activities, but they don't seem to rely on radio or television sources a good deal as authorities in floor debates. In the first five months of 1986, according to a study by a Washington public relations agency, Jean Rainey Associ-ates, senators and representatives cited newspapers, magazines and other print sources 1,504 times in floor speeches, as against 37 mentions of radio and television sources.

title: Boy George Fined
description: Boy George, the British rock singer noted for his pancake makeup, lipstick and flowing gowns, pleaded guilty today to possessing heroin and was fined the equivalent of $370.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, the chess board diagram with an article yesterday about the first game of the rematch between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov misplaced two black pieces. The correct final position appears today, with an analysis of the game, on page C20.

title: STEELS PENSION-FUNDING WOES
description: For decades, steelmakers bought labor peace with generous salaries and attractive pension benefits. Now, as business is faltering and more workers are retiring, those pension obligations are coming back to haunt them.

title: A STORE FOR THE GOURMET COOK
description: Thirty years ago, when Charles E. Williams stocked his Sonoma, Calif., hardware store with the specialized utensils of haute cuisine, the world did not beat a path to his door. But that was before gourmet cooking became a yuppie hobby and great chefs attained a status previously reserved for rock stars or movie idols.

title: Eastern Lowering A First-Class Fare
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said that it would offer a new ''First-Class Super Saver'' round-trip fare for as little as $75 above its lowest weekend coach discount rate. The new fares are available to all of Eastern's United States destinations, including Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

SOURCES OF CALCIUM
description: GETTING enough calcium can be a problem, especially for women, whose need for calcium is great throughout most of their adult lives. For people who are lactose-intolerant, or as a welcome alternative to milk and milk products, many green, leafy vegetables are good sources of calcium -kale, collards, bok choy and turnip and mustard greens among them. Other leafy vegetables, particularly spinach and beet greens, though high in calcium, are not good dietary sources of the mineral: oxalic acid in these vegetables combines with the calcium to prevent its absorption by the body.

Mr. Modai stepped down after making personal criticisms of Prime Minister Shimon Peres. He said that to avoid a Cabinet crisis he had chosen to resign rather than be dismissed.

title: DARLING WINS 11th
description: Their offense and their defense have had a stabilizing presence this season, but last night both betrayed the Mets. They split a double-header with the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium, and the difference was this: Ron Darling survived a lack of support; Rick Anderson and Doug Sisk did not.

title: STILL COOKING ITALIAN AND LOVING IT AT 94
description: THE man in the apron held two chefs' knives parallel and firmly together in one hand and clasped them with total self-assurance, neatly, tightly. He gathered together a handful of parsley on a chopping surface and chopped away, staccato, with a show of agility that would have been impressive in a chef a quarter his age. Gus Severi is 94 years old. Next year will mark the 80th anniversary of his arrival in this country.

title: U.S. Ends Its Inquiry Into Grand Prix Race
description: The United States Attorney in Brooklyn has closed his investigation into possible illegalities in the unsuccessful effort to bring Grand Prix racing to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, an official of the office said yesterday.

description: MANUFACTURERS of machine tools have been beset by declining orders, excess capacity, foreign competition and shrinking profits - not to mention the uncertainty as to how their fortunes will fare under the new tax bill.

description: The Atlanta Braves may be last in the National League West, but Cliff Speck is happy to be wearing their uniform. For the 29-year-old pitcher, who was the Mets' No. 1 pick in the 1974 free-agent draft, his arrival with the Braves represents something he has pursued for more than a dozen years - pitching in the major leagues.

description: Law enforcement agencies have given up pressing for the deportation of most aliens arrested for selling drugs in New York City because, officials say, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is unable or unwilling to investigate the cases.

title: LOUIS H. PFOHL
description: Louis H. Pfohl, a real-estate developer and the founder and chairman of Plaxall Inc., a plastics-packaging manufacturer in Long Island City, Queens, died Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WARTIME WRITINGS 1939-1944. By Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Translated by Norah Purcell. 256 Pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. IN the middle of war, Antoine de Saint-Exupery turned his mind to peace. He envisioned a time when the guns, including those on his P-38 Lightning, would be silent and the real challenge would begin for France and other democratic nations. War was only a momentary blip on his mental radar screen.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS IN FOOTBALL SUIT
description: 1980 Nov. 10 - David Dixon, a New Orleans entrepreneur, circulates to advertising agencies and prospective owners a prospectus in which he puts forth a new idea in professional sports - football played in the spring - and says it could appeal to the public and to the television networks. 1982 March 16 - ABC and the National Football League sign a five-year, $681.5 million contract for prime-time games, one Super Bowl game, five Pro Bowl games and five Hall of Fame exhibition games. March 17 - CBS and the N.F.L. sign a five-year, $713 million contract for a package of games, five National Conference championship games and two Super Bowl games. March 22 - NBC and the N.F.L. sign a five-year, $638 million contract for a package of weekend games, five American Conference championship games and two Super Bowls.

title: IC Sells Track
description: IC Industries said that its Illinois Central Gulf Railroad subsidiary had agreed to sell 631 miles of track to the Chicago, Missouri & Western Railway Company for $81 million. Chicago, Missouri & Western Railway is a subsidiary of the Venango River Corporation, which owns the Chicago South Shore & South Bend Railroad. IC, a diversified consumer and commercial products company, said the rail line runs south from Joliet, Ill., to Springfield, Ill., with additional lines from St. Louis to Kansas City, Mo.

description: ''AFTER THE SEXUAL REVOLUTION'' says something has happened in American life, not always to good effect: the relationship between men and women has been altered. Overall, however, the three-hour ABC News report is cheerful about this, declaring that the pluses outnumber the minuses. The report, on Channel 7 at 8 o'clock tonight, is still a very long three hours.

description: PERFORMERS who come to cabaret from the world of soap opera tend to bring with them a television-bred charm that is the antithesis of the kind of intimacy traditionally associated with cabaret singing. Candice Earley, a star of ''All My Children,'' is typical.

description: THE piano and violin sonatas are not among Mozart's most individuated works.

title: Make Smokers Pay the Price
description: When the Federal excise tax on cigarettes was raised to 16 cents in 1983, cigarette consumption went down 5 percent. The added expense evidently deterred teen-agers from taking up the habit.

title: Nobility, and Knowledge, in Space
description: Dead astronauts are always heroes, in part because they are heroes and in part because heroic stature nurtures the image of NASA's manned space program. ''Nothing is here for tears . . . no weakness, no contempt, dispraise or blame, nothing but well and fair, and what may quiet us in a death so noble.'' Those words of Milton in effect comprise the epitaph that NASA always writes, regardless of whether it fits the truth, and regardless of whether knowledge of the truth could help prevent further accidents.

title: Treasury Securities Rebound
description: Prices of Treasury securities bounced back yesterday after steep declines on Monday. They were bolstered partly by encouraging comments from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board about inflation and interest rates.

After the game, it was announced that Kittle had been traded to the Yankees in a deal that sent Ron Hassey to Chicago.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the questions I am most often asked about shellfish is whether an ''iodine'' taste in shrimp is an indication of their being spoiled. The answer is no. Shrimp generally have a higher iodine flavor than most other crustaceans, including lobsters and crabs. They get their taste from what they eat and the waters from which they are harvested. Although the public has few ways to determine the precise origin of the shrimp in the shell, those taken from the sweet, free-flowing river waters are less likely to taste of iodine than those taken from salt-water sources.

title: EVOLUTION OF PSYCHOBILLY ON NEW CRAMPS ALBUM
description: ''PSYCHOBILLY - THE CRAMPS,'' read the fliers announcing the first performance by a new band 10 years ago at CBGB on the Bowery. The Cramps had coined the word ''psychobilly'' to refer to their equal affection for the wildest rockabilly music of the 50's and early 60's and the Grade-Z horror and science fiction films of the same period. None of the musicians wanted to play bass, so a singer, two guitarists, and a drummer constituted the group at its first performances. For all their trash-culture nostalgia, the Cramps were in most respects ahead of the times. Today, ''psychobilly bands'' abound, in the United States and especially in Britain, where bands with guitars but no bass are now fairly common.

title: BIG 'MORAL VICTORY' CLAIMED BY TRUMP
description: Donald J. Trump, the real-estate developer who owns the New Jersey Generals, called it a moral victory. But most others in professional football pointed to the resounding monetary defeat suffered by the United States Football League yesteray when it was awarded only nominal damages in its antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: Counting Interest
description: Shopping around for the best rate on a certificate of deposit? Maybe you should be looking in Chicago. Or Pittsburgh. Or Louisville. Or Providence. These are some of the cities where local banks have found a way to cash in on fan excitement over a local team's success, and the trend is spreading.

title: Russians and Americans On Midwest Peace Tour
description: The stern-wheeler Delta Queen carried 47 citizens of the Soviet Union into Dubuque today, one stop on a peace cruise down the Mississippi River.

title: NORTHEAST GOVERNORS SEE PROSPERITY AND PERIL

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. AGREES TO SOVIET PLAN FOR MEETINGS
description: President Reagan said today that the United States had agreed to a Soviet ''work plan'' that would lead to a summit meeting later in this year and that both nations had moved beyond ''misunderstanding and suspicion.''

title: JURY ASSIGNS JUST $1 IN DAMAGES
description: The United States Football League suffered what both sides considered a resounding defeat in United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday when a jury found that the National Football League had violated antitrust law but awarded the U.S.F.L. only $1 in damages.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bear Mauls 2 More Scouts
description: Officials at a Boy Scout ranch are tightening security after five bear attacks in two weeks, including weekend incidents in which two boys were mauled. In the latest incidents, 14-year-old Kevin Unruh of Salina, Kan., and Joey McKinney, 13, of Danville, Ark., were attacked by a black bear early Sunday while camping seven miles from the headquarters of the Philmont Scout Ranch, a 215-square-mile Boy Scout camp that draws scouts from around the country. Officials killed the bear.

title: THE SCREEN: 'NOTHING IN COMMON'
description: AS the advertising whiz kid David Basner in ''Nothing in Common,'' Tom Hanks comes on fast, striding into his Chicago agency with a crack for everybody, about anything. He's the office smart aleck, a touch obnoxious but irresistible. Even as he fires off a funny line, you can see him registering the response and then reflecting on his reaction. He's simultaneously outer-directed and self-absorbed. His eyes are shrewd yet shaky.

Comparison of this figure with that for the July 14 concert (where the musical portion of the program was, if anything, marginally less attractive) suggests that attendance might be quintupled by the promise of fireworks.

title: Whale Chase Draws Fine

Barbara Leavitt, a spokesman for Exploration Holiday Services of Seattle, said today that the company had not decided whether to appeal the fine levied by the National Marine Fisheries Service. She said the company had no intention of harassing whales.
